description: Now that Rick Pitino has been delivered safe and sound to Nirvana-in-the-Bluegrass for a few years, can we finally turn our attention to baseball?

title: KEY RATES
Another Setback for Bush Savings Rescue
description: The Bush Administration's rescue bill for the nation's troubled savings and loan industry suffered another setback today in Congress as the House Government Operations Committee voted along partisan lines to include in the Federal budget most of the costs of the plan.

title: How Congress Can Help Change China
description: To the Editor:

title: Estonians Meet Gorbachev and Report He Is Open to Their Plans
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev privately reassured the Estonian deputies to the new national congress today that their insurgent call for independent self-management of their economy fitted in with his reform plans, one of the deputies said.

title: Review/Art; Painting Without Canvasses: Roy Lichtenstein as Sculptor
description: Roy Lichtenstein's brightly painted bronze sculptures may not represent the artist at his best but they could hardly look snappier than they do lined up in the airy, ample space that is 65 Thompson Street, a new gallery under the joint direction of Leo Castelli and Larry Gagosian.

title: Restaurants
description: With all the hand-wringing and gloomy talk about the restaurant business these days, one is hard-pressed to explain the packed house at three-month-old Jane's Bar and Grill. To be sure, the setting is exceptionally attractive, but that is hardly a guarantee; on paper the menu is unremarkable, an amalgam of American, Italian and French fare, and the location, on East 60th Street, is already chockablock with restaurants. Add to this an owner who has no restaurant experience and you have . . . a success?

title: Productivity Slips as Labor Costs Increase
description: The productivity of American workers slipped in the first quarter, while unit labor costs rose 6.6 percent on an annual basis, the Labor Department said today. Analysts cited the report as proof both of a slowing economy and stubborn inflation.

title: Funny Way to Lead an Army
description: Now that President Bush has become an instant hero among American foreign policy strategists, Heaven protect us, he may be able to devote more of his mind and time to a rather larger group of constituents.

title: Seeing Disaster, Groups Ask Ban on Ivory Imports
description: Two leading international conservation groups called today for an immediate worldwide ban on imports of ivory to prevent a threatened catastrophe for African elephants.

title: What the Band Played at NATO's Birth
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Art; In 40 Ways, the Big Picture Of Helen Frankenthaler
description: ''A Paintings Retrospective'' is the title of Helen Frankenthaler's exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art. Like the show itself, it is well chosen. We are warned from the outset that the confrontation is to be on the high, clear, level ground on which Ms. Frankenthaler has always excelled.

title: Critics' Choices for an Arts-Filled Weekend; Pop and Folk
description: Fans of folk music in the broadest senses, stylistically and geographically, can hear a world of local styles this weekend in Manhattan.

title: Pitino Feels at Home in Kentucky
description: Accompanied by his wife, Joanne, and modest applause, he walked into a conference room brimming with 15 television camera crews, a sportscaster powdering his nose with makeup, a number of newspaper reporters and the 22 members of the University of Kentucky Athletics Association Board of Directors, as well as other university dignitaries.

title: An Open-and-Shut Showcase
description: Well, it doesn't look like a stadium, at least not the conventional kind. From one angle or another, it seems to resemble an airplane hangar or a merchandise mart or a place in which Crazy Eddie might hold a giant warehouse sale.

title: Review/Theater; 'Crackers': 3 Good Ole Boys Doing Bad Ole Business
description: Back in that innocent time when drugs were ''reefers'' rather than a national tragedy, Tom Lehrer wrote a hilarious ballad singing the praises of that pillar of American folklore, ''The Old Dope Peddler.'' Mr. Lehrer's song was a put-on, of course, but William S. Leavengood, who expresses much the same sentiments in a new play titled ''Florida Crackers,'' doesn't appear to be joking. ''Florida Crackers,'' the wan finale to a robust Circle Repertory Company season, is a nostalgia piece about the old dope peddlers of 1979. It takes us back to the days when the good ole boys of St. Petersburg could still run soft drugs for big laughs and small bucks.

title: Bush in Europe: Looking to Germans
description: That long-running romance, the ''special relationship'' between the United States and Britain, is not ending just yet, even though Ronald Reagan, whose own special relationship with Margaret Thatcher brought a period of unusual warmth between the two nations, has left office.

title: School Officials Seek to Quell Coverup Rumor
description: School authorities refused tonight to say when they first learned of allegations that a mentally impaired girl had been sexually assaulted March 1 by five members of the high school football team.

title: Reviews/Theater; Hollywood Blacklist in the Next Generation
description: The blacklist resulting from the investigations of the House Committee on Un-American Activities led to a fearful and personally harrowing time in our political history. But with the exception of the film ''The Front'' (starring Woody Allen) and a few other examples, the subject has been left principally to authors of nonfiction and creators of documentary dramas. In ''The Value of Names,'' Jeffrey Sweet has attempted to rectify that oversight. The play opened last night at the Vineyard Theater, inaugurating that company's new home on East 15th Street.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly PREPARATORY COMMITTEE FOR SPECIAL SESSION ON ECONOMIC ISSUES - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. WORKING GROUP ON THE DRAFTING OF AN INTERNATIONAL CONVENTION ON THE PROTECTION OF MIGRANT WORKERS - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Pact Would Affect Only Old Arms, Officials Say
description: Senior Pentagon officials said today that the United States would take steps to insure that only old American equipment is destroyed under the conventional-weapons proposals made in Europe by President Bush.

title: Queens College
description: The president of Queens College, Shirley Strum Kenny, told graduates at the college's 65th commencement yesterday, ''It will be your burden to continue the tradition of our commitment to civil liberties, the determination to right wrongs, to insure equality of opportunity for all Americans.''

title: Critics' Choices for an Arts-Filled Weekend;  Theater
description: For those who have already seen or cannot get tickets to ''The Heidi Chronicles'' and ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway,'' the presumed victors in Broadway's Tony Awards ceremony on Sunday night, there is still plenty of lively, not to mention enjoyable, theater to be found in New York this weekend.

title: Cornell, Penn and Wisconsin Qualify for Final
description: The varsity eights from Cornell, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin won their heats this morning to qualify for Saturday's championship race at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's annual regatta.

title: Shostakovich Quartets
description: The Manhattan String Quartet will play all 15 of Shostakovich's string quartets in chronological order in four concerts this weekend at the Paramount Center for the Arts, 1008 Brown Street, in Peekskill, N.Y. The series begins tomorrow afternoon at 3 o'clock. The other performances are tomorrow evening at 7:30, and Sunday at 3 and 7:30 P.M. Tickets are $10 for the full series. Information and directions: (914) 739-2333.

title: Ford Promotes Edsel Ford 2d
description: Edsel Ford 2d, great-grandson of the Ford Motor Company's founder, was named executive director today of the auto maker's marketing staff, effective next month.

title: SENATORS REASSESS FURTHER MEDICARE
description: Prodded by a storm of protests from older Americans who must pay the bill, the Senate Finance Committee began today to re-examine the new program that provides extended Medicare coverage for catastrophic illness.

title: Critics' Choices for an Arts-Filled Weekend;  Cabaret and Comedy
description: If cabaret is an endangered species of entertainment, there are still new clubs popping up around Manhattan. When Rainbow and Stars opened in January on the 65th floor of the RCA Building, it became the crown jewel of the city's intimate cabarets. The luxuriously appointed room has perfect acoustics and offers a spectacular view north over Central Park. Its current resident is Lorna Luft, who is making her first New York appearance in eight years.

title: War Tribute: It's All Over but the Unveiling
description: In Washington nothing quite tops a fight over a monument that is to take note of a war. The squabble over the design of the Vietnam Memorial comes first to mind. Despite the fact that the black stone slash in the Mall is just about the most popular visitor's site in town, it still draws periodic outbursts that it is too pacifically abstract or not heroic enough.

title: Bilzerian Testifies About Swapping Fraudulent Invoices
description: Paul A. Bilzerian, under cross-examination after a request for a mistrial was denied, testified at his securities fraud trial yesterday that he had exchanged numerous fraudulent invoices with Jefferies & Company, the West Coast brokerage.

title: Construction Stays Weak; Rates Cited
description: High interest rates continued to hamper private construction in April, although total construction spending rose a weak one-tenth of 1 percent because of an upturn in work on public projects.

title: A Few Stay Hot on Long Island So More Can Stay Cool
description: On this summer's hottest days, the Dominic Bratta family here plans to go without air-conditioning for 40 minutes every hour.

title: When Bulls Meet Pistons, The Defenses Never Rest
description: Scoring 100 points in the Eastern Conference final is proving to be difficult for the Chicago Bulls and the Detroit Pistons.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Y.&R. Europe Finds One Is Enough
description: SOMEDAY it may be said that advertising's battle for Europe was won on the playing fields of New Haven. It was there, in 1956, that Joseph E. DeDeo, a Princeton sophomore, met Alexander Kroll, a sophomore at Yale, in a contest for the Ivy League football championship. Mr. Kroll, a sizable center, spent much of the afternoon trampling over Mr. DeDeo, a linebacker, as the Elis defeated the Tigers. It was the last time the two men worked at cross-purposes.

title: Yugoslav Police Quell Protest
description: The police fired tear gas on several hundred ethnic Albanian students in the Yugoslav province of Kosovo as nationalist protesters took over a university campus for the second evening, the authorities said today. Witnesses said 300 to 400 students occupied the campus Wednesday at Pristina University, shouting Albanian nationalist slogans and jeering at the police.

title: Charles E. McDonnell Jr., Stockbroker, 41
description: Charles E. McDonnell Jr., a stockbroker and president of McDonnell & Company (Bermuda Ltd.), died of cancer yesterday at his home in Paget, Bermuda. He was 41 years old and had lived in Bermuda since 1972.

title: Corrections
description: A Company Briefs listing in some editions of Business Day on May 17 gave an incorrect location for Charan Industries, which said it intended to sell a sporting goods subsidiary, Cooper Canada. Charan, a Canadian company, is based in Montreal and is not affiliated with Charan Industries of Garden City, L.I.

title: Critics' Choices for an Arts-Filled Weekend; Film
description: High-spirited adventure and big-budget special effects are the symptoms of summer movies, especially in this season that promises enough sequels - from ''Ghostbusters II'' to ''Friday the 13th - Part VIII'' - to provoke fear of mathematics. But New York City also offers a wealth of quirky films, something for everyone's specialized taste. This is a good time to catch some off-beat works, before Captain Kirk and the Karate Kid take over the town.

title: Market Place; Pledge Comes Due At Western Union
description: CAN a company really guarantee the value of its own securities? The Western Union Corporation is finding that it is hard to live up to such a promise. At best, the cost will be severe dilution for the company's shareholders. At worst, the company could run out of cash.

title: Arms Won't Defeat the Khmer Rouge
description: LEAD: The U.S. has apparently decided to provide military aid to the non-Communist forces in Cambodia. One rationale is to give Prince Norodom Sihanouk's troops and others greater ability to counter the Khmer Rouge.

title: Father Returns With Ill Boy; Judge Frees Jailed Mother
description: A Brooklyn woman was released from jail yesterday after her husband returned to New York City with their 4-year-old son, whom he had taken from the hospital where he was to be treated for leukemia.

title: Review/Art; Pieced-Together History: Hannelore Baron's Collages
description: Tucked away in the small gallery near the top of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum are 19 collages and assemblages by Hannelore Baron. They are a useful foil to the main show - the retrospective of Arnulf Rainer, the contemporary Austrian artist whose effusive performances on paper and canvas struggle with confinement and oblivion in a furious, almost exhibitionistic way. In Baron's delicate, muted work, an entire way of life seems wrapped in a single thread. Her show is welcome.

title: Labatt in Italy
description: The Labatt Brewing Company of Canada, which recently entered the British beer market, has now moved into Italy with the purchase today of a 70 percent stake in Birra Moretti S.p.A. Sid Oland, president of Labatt Brewing, would not say how much his company, Canada's largest brewer, had paid for the controlling stake in Moretti, but industry analysts put the cost as high as $80 million (American). Mr. Oland said that the remaining 30 percent of Moretti, based in Udine, would be held by the Moretti family and that the company would continue to be managed by Luigi Menazzi Moretti, its president.

title: N. A. Kenworthy, 87, Consulting Engineer
description: Nelson A. Kenworthy, a consulting engineer who supervised construction projects, died Tuesday at the Ashbrook Nursing Home in Scotch Plains, N.J., after suffering a stroke. He was 87 years old and lived in Colonia, N.J.

title: Stuart E. Jacobson, Author, 34
description: Stuart E. Jacobson, a writer of books on gift-giving, died Saturday at his home in Dallas. He was 34 years old.

title: After First Round at Cliburn, Judges Narrow Field to 12
description: The missing voice at this year's Van Cliburn International Piano Competition made itself heard for the first time in the early hours of this morning from the stage of the Landreth Auditorium at Texas Christian University here. Speaking at 12:45 A.M., John Giordano announced the first decisions of the 14-member jury of which he is chairman - the 12 competitors who will go on to the semifinal round of the quadrennial event.

title: K.G.B. Chief Says New Legislature Should Ride Herd on His Agency
description: The chief of the K.G.B. said today that the newly elected Soviet legislature should have full authority over the state security agency, including power to approve the appointment of the K.G.B. chairman.

title: Reviews/Theater; A Comic Actor Tries His Hand as the Melancholic Prince
description: Locked somewhere in the heart of any actor worth his greasepaint is the ambition to play Hamlet. The chance to undertake the role, however, is mercifully not given to every actor in his lifetime. And, as Winston Churchill said in another context, even when such an opportunity presents itself, it should not necessarily be taken.

title: Audrey Mars Is Dead; Civic Worker Was 79
description: Audrey Mars, a civic leader and longtime volunteer in cancer organizations, died yesterday from complications of cancer at her home in Washington. She was 79 years old.

title: Tony Lama Agrees To Be Acquired
description: The Tony Lama Company, the maker of western boots in El Paso, agreed to be acquired by Equus Investments II L.P., a leveraged buyout fund, and two senior Tony Lama executives in a transaction worth about $50 million. Under the agreement, which is subject to a number of considerations, Tony Lama's common shareholders would receive $13.65 a share in cash.

title: TV Weekend; A Coming-of-Age Film and Martin Short
description: Two pay-cable presentations are among the more prominent offerings this weekend. One, a movie called ''Looking for Miracles,'' is on the Disney Channel at 7 o'clock tomorrow evening. That's a problem for many New Yorkers because Manhattan Cable TV does not carry the Disney Channel, the winner in a Consumer Reports poll asking which cable service generates the most subscriber satisfaction.

title: Economic Scene; The U.S. Charges Against Japan
description: THOUGH President Bush put Japan, Brazil and India on the ''hit list'' of countries charged with unfair trade practices, and named a score of other countries to the ''watch list,'' everyone knows, including the Japanese, that it is overwhelmingly the American grievance against Japan that lies at the root of his decision to start using the so-called Super 301 section of the 1988 United States trade law.

title: Ladd-Maytag Pact
description: Ladd Furniture Inc. said it had agreed to buy the furniture manufacturing businesses of the Maytag Corporation for $213 million, consisting of $202.5 million in cash and the assumption of about $10.9 million of debt. Maytag acquired the companies in January when it bought the Chicago Pacific Corporation. It said at the time that it would keep Chicago Pacific's Hoover Company unit and sell the furniture companies. The businesses that Ladd is acquiring are Brown Jordan, Gunlocke, Kittinger, McGuire, Pennsylvania House and Charter Group. The transaction is expected to close in about 30 days.

title: Miss Rounick Is the Bride Of a Builder
description: Tiffany Elizabeth Rounick, the daughter of Mrs. A. Alfred Taubman of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and Herbert Rounick Sr. of New York, was married yesterday to Louis Myerberg Dubin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Newton Dubin of Bethesda, Md. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi David M. Posner at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

title: JOHN PAUL BEGINS SCANDINAVIAN TOUR
description: Pope John Paul II arrived here today on the first visit by a Pope to Scandinavia, bringing a message of ecumenism to a Protestant stronghold where Roman Catholicism has long struggled to survive.

title: O.E.C.D. Opposes Unilateral Trade Steps
description: A week after the United States named Japan, India and Brazil as unfair traders, the world's industrial nations said today that they rejected unilateral measures that undermine the world trade system.

title: A Revamping At Affiliated
description: Affiliated Publications Inc., parent of the Globe Newspaper Company and Billboard Publications Inc., Wednesday announced a restructuring that would separate those companies from Affiliated's ownership interests in McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., a cellular-phone company. In February, the API Print

title: Simplified Gene Transplant Method Reported
description: A remarkably simple way of transplanting genes by using sperm as the vehicle has been discovered by Italian scientists in a research development that other specialists have described as surprising, even astounding.

title: Death Is as Capricious as Life for Farm Leader
description: As the farm crisis of the 1980's deepened, Dixon Terry rallied farmers who were beaten and weary, calling on them to turn their plowshares into political swords.

title: Few Cheer the New Japanese Leader
description: Sousuke Uno accepted his appointment as president of the governing Liberal Democratic Party today. As he prepared to become Japan's 18th postwar Prime Minister he warned that the country ''has to save the bright and growing side of Japan from being overshadowed by the darkness'' of political corruption.

title: WELFARE NOMINEE YIELDS TO ATTACK
description: An Oklahoma official, under attack in the Senate because of an old state hospital policy that denied surgical care to poor babies born with spina bifida, withdrew today from consideration as administrator of the agency that oversees the Federal welfare program.

title: Pakistan, India and The Bomb
description: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto arrives on Tuesday for a five-day visit at a critical time in U.S.-Pakistani relations. Her efforts to reassert democratic civilian control over political and foreign policy questions, including the war in Afghanistan, deserve the strongest U.S. support. Yet foreign aid programs are jeopardized by Pakistan's determination to develop nuclear weapons.

title: Review/Film; Seamy Side of Irish Life, in 'The Courier'
description: ''The Courier'' is a small, ambitious, uneven Irish film that identifies the gritty scene where the underworld and the working class meet. In the dismal streets and narrow houses of Dublin, Mark (Padraig O'Loingsigh) works as a motorcycle messenger. He's now clean of drugs, though his former best friend, Danny, is deeply and desperately involved in the drug world and has made an enemy of Val (Gabriel Byrne), a vicious dealer.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 22% Rise in Donations For Public Service Ads
description: Contributions of broadcast time and print space for public service advertising increased a record 22 percent in 1988, the Advertising Council reported yesterday. The council and the Media-Advertising Partnership for a Drug-Free America, two affiliated organizations that say they account for roughly one-third of all public service advertising in the United States, recorded $1.2 billion worth of donated time and space last year.

title: Newcomer Sworn as Salvador's Leader
description: In the first transfer of power from one elected civilian to another in El Salvador's history, a political neophyte was sworn in today as President amid rising concern that right-wing extremists have played a dominant role in shaping his administration.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday listing winners of the New York City school board elections omitted a name for District 29 in Queens and included an erroneous name. The winner was Denise Richardson; Denis H. Stuart did not win.

title: Dining Out Guide: New Jersey
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the New Jersey Weekly section of The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. The Brass Rail Very Good (March 12, 1989), 135 Washington Street, Hoboken (201-659-7074) - The restaurant, behind etched-glass doors that mute the sounds of the pub downstairs, has the luxurious style of a French dining salon. This is accomplished with extravagant bouquets, red velvet banquettes and painted cherubs on the ceiling. A new menu for summer is in the works; for now one can still order the recommended lobster bisque and seafood salad served with a raspberry vinaigrette. Entrees of note include medallions of veal with chanterelles and shelled lobster in puff pastry in a rich shellfish sauce. Petal-thin cookies, layered with cream and strawberries, make a delicious mille-feuille dessert. Appetizers are $7.50 to $17.50, entrees $18.50 to $24.50. Dinner from 6 to 10 P.M. Monday to Thursday, until 11 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Hamilton's Grill Very Good (Jan. 1, 1989), 8 1/2 Coryell Street, Lambertville (609-397-4343) -A charming courtyard is the scene of this year-old restaurant near the Delaware River in Hunterdon County. An open grill and adobe oven dominate the front room, while the back dining area presents a conversation piece with its large, gilt-framed ceiling mirror surrounded by a celestial mural. Most of the salads and shellfish appetizers can be recommended. Crisp-crusted pizzas include one with shrimp, pesto and cheese. Seafood is a strong suit at Hamilton's, and flash-grilled and lightly charred salmon fillet is a standout. Other good choices are the roast chicken, grilled lobster and, for dessert, the lime tart. There is no liquor license, but patrons may bring their own wine or beer. Appetizers are $4 to $60 (for 3.3 ounces of caviar), entrees $6.95 to $30. Open 6 to 10 P.M. Tuesday to Sunday and 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. for Sunday brunch. Margaux Very Good (Jan. 22, 1989), Route 34 South, Colts Neck (201-431-7594) - A provincial French style lends atmosphere to this casual restaurant in an area known for its scenic horse farms. A wood-burning grill is used to cook several dishes on the summer menu. One is an appetizer called grilled shrimp cocktail; marinated goat cheese with olives, and a salad of dandelion greens and radishes in a walnut vinaigrette are other seasonal starters. Entrees include grilled chicken breast (marinated in tequila and lime); soft-shell crabs with smoked salmon and bacon butter, and ''London broil'' of American lamb. Appetizers are $3.50 to $9, entrees $13.50 to $22.50. Lunch: 11:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 5 to 10 P.M. Monday to Thursday, 5 to 11 P.M. Friday and Saturday, 5 to 9 P.M. Sunday. Patrice Very Good (Oct. 23, 1988), 555 Passaic Avenue, West Caldwell (201-808-0555) - Contemporary eclectic cuisine is served in a serene dining room designed in tones of pale green and sandstone. Hand-painted marbled columns and service pieces and graceful architecural details belie the location upstairs in a shopping center. A small terrace has been opened for outdoor dining. Appetizers on the new menu include calamari and scallops with eggplant and red-pepper coulis and crab cakes with red-pepper mayonnaise. Among the entrees are grilled tuna given a Japanese twist with ponzu, wasabi and pickled ginger; black sea bass with tangerine and basil sauce, and grilled loin of lamb with mint pesto. The pastry chef creates, among other desserts, a peach shortcake. Appetizers are $4 to $12, entrees $15 to $26. Lunch: 11:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 5:30 to 9:30 P.M. Monday to Friday, until 10 P.M. Saturday.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Thomas Stephen Foley; A Politician Outside the Mold
description: In the last three decades, the House Speakership has passed smoothly from Sam Rayburn to John W. McCormack to Carl Albert to Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. to Jim Wright. The Austin-Boston axis, it was called, one from the oil patch, the next from Massachusetts. They were, whatever their origins, politicians cut from the same bolt.

title: Critics' Choices for an Arts-Filled Weekend;  Dance
description: Variety and then some is par for the course at the height of the spring dance season.

title: 5 Are Indicted Over Illegal Exports to Soviet Union
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn has indicted five men on charges of conspiring to export highly sophisticated underwater mapping and surveillance equipment to the Soviet Union.

title: Hiccup for a Computer Superstar
description: After seven and a half years of record growth, Sun Microsystems Inc. said today that earnings for the fourth quarter, ending June 30, will be significantly below the results for the period a year ago. Depending on revenues, Sun said, it could even report a slight loss.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Plantathon, a plant and crafts sale, the northbound lanes of Broadway between 72d and 79th Streets will be closed tomorrow from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M.

title: Agassi And Chang Breeze In Paris
description: In a showcase day for young Americans, Andre Agassi and Michael Chang advanced to the third round of the French Open tennis championships today with easy victories on the Center Court of Roland Garros Stadium.

title: G.E. to Move Division
description: The General Electric Company announced today that it is shifting some of its electronics manufacturing to a more modern plant in Shreveport, La., a move that will affect 700 workers. Company officials said they planned to move the regulator and inductive products division beginning in January. A company spokesman, Bruce Farren, said 200 of the 700 workers who will be laid off in the next few years as a result of the move are eligible for retirement. Others will be offered transfers or retrained for different jobs. G.E. employs about 5,600 people in Pittsfield, mostly in its ordnance plants.

title: Review/Ballet; Old-Fashioned Tudor Work With the Impact of the New
description: Antony Tudor, one of the 20th century's greatest choreographers, was especially attuned to the cruelties and inequities of life. Such concerns were once deemed outside ballet's province, but it was Tudor's achievement to treat them with expressive power and through an entirely innovative use of the classical dance idiom.

title: Koch Heckled at Event for Gay Pride Month
description: As hundreds of protesters shouted ''Dump Koch,'' Mayor Edward I. Koch proclaimed the month of June as Lesbian and Gay Pride and History Month at a ceremony last night in Sheridan Square in Greenwich Village.

title: Icahn Sells His Texaco Holdings
description: Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire chairman of Trans World Airlines, yesterday sold his entire stake in Texaco Inc., the oil company, for slightly more than $2 billion in cash.

title: Allen Will Harris, Consultant, 72
description: Allen Will Harris, a retired management consultant, died of liver disease last Friday at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday ATTENTION FILM BUFFS

title: Same Old Shameless S & L Game
description: The chairman of a healthy California savings and loan association calls his industry's lobbying to weaken the S & L bailout bill ''disgraceful'' - as bad as if Exxon, after the Valdez oil spill, had called for the ''liberal use of whisky by tanker captains.'' Charles Munger of Pasadena's Mutual Savings and Loan Association vented his thoughts in an angry letter canceling Mutual's membership in the U.S. League of Savings Institutions. The league, unfazed, lobbies on.

title: Political Sway of the Military Is Subtly Spreading in China
description: While China's political leaders have removed themselves from sight to engage in a bitter struggle for power, there are signs that the military may be accumulating a larger role in the Chinese political process.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Affiliated Publications Inc., Boston, a publishing and broadcasting company, promoted Arthur F. Kingsbury to executive vice president and William B. Huff to chief financial officer.

title: Argentina in Chaos as Food Prices Rise Daily
description: ''Weimar Germany never had an I.B.M. computer,'' Adrian Rodriguez Boero said today, explaining with a wry smile how he manages to keep his supermarket ahead of Argentina's annual inflation rate of 12,000 percent.

title: Review/Film; The Woman He Adores, It Turns Out, Is a Vampire
description: In ''Vampire's Kiss,'' Nicolas Cage plays a literary agent named Peter Loew, a young man who keeps a photo of Kafka behind his desk and seems to suffer from garden-variety fear of commitment. When he finds the woman of his dreams, she turns out to be a creature who bites his neck passionately with her long fangs at night, and is sure to be out of his hair by dawn. Though his true love is an imaginary vampire (played by Jennifer Beals), those nights full of heavy breathing and bleeding convince Peter that he is a vampire, too.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 The K.G.B. should be controlled, said Vladimir Kryuchkov, the head of the Soviet secret police. He also said the new Soviet legislature should have power to approve the K.G.B.'s chairman. Page A1

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Chris Rea

title: Consumers Win a Victory on Auto Insurance; Policy Scarcity Coming
description: To the Editor:

title: Eastern Unions Get Extension
description: The three primary unions of Eastern Airlines yesterday won an additional day to put together a viable offer to buy the airline, but their chances of meeting the deadline appeared doubtful.

title: Big Travel Agency Moving To a System of Fixed Fees
description: In a move that could sharply alter the way large travel agencies earn their money, a leading corporate travel agency has begun an aggressive campaign to set fixed fees for its services rather than relying exclusively on a commission system.

title: About Real Estate; Auction Set for Condos On Connecticut Shore
description: Fifty-one new waterfront units at Four Beaches, one of the more dramatic condominium projects to be constructed along the Connecticut shoreline in the last few years, will be auctioned off at the Marriott Hotel in Trumbull, Conn., on June 25.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: New Bond Reacts To Credit Ratings
description: Bear, Stearns & Company introduced a new form of corporate bond on Wednesday that could help to alleviate institutional investors' concerns about the downgrading of bonds following leveraged buyouts.

title: Plant and Crafts Fair
description: The Federation of West Side Block Associations will present the 18th annual Plantathon and Crafts Fair, tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. on Broadway between 72d and 79th Streets. A plant-it-yourself table for children, a plant doctor, more than 10,000 plants and flowers from Florida and antiques and crafts dealers will be among the attractions. Admission is free. Information: 799-9782.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Trio Con Brio Ray Brown Trio, Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). One cannot identify Ray Brown simply as ''a bassist.'' He is one of the most celebrated bassists in jazz, having been the anchor of the original Dizzy Gillespie big band in the 1940's; an original member of the Modern Jazz Quartet, when it consisted of four members of the Gillespie band, and a longtime member of the Oscar Peterson Trio. But in more recent years, he has also managed other musicians and restarted some careers, including that of the pianist Gene Harris (who led the group called the Three Sounds in the 1960's and is now the pianist in the Brown trio), and Jeff Hamilton, a former drummer with Woody Herman and now the third member of the Brown trio. Featured with the group this weekend is Ernie Andrews, the veteran West Coast singing star who came out of the Central Avenue music milieu of Los Angeles in the 1950's to work with the big bands of Louis Bellson, Benny Carter, Ernie Wilkins and Gerald Wilson. The trio and Ernie Andrews get hot tonight and tomorrow at 9, 11:30 P.M. and 1:30 A.M., and at 9 and 11:30 P.M. on Sunday. There is a $15 cover charge and a $5 minimum at the tables or a $10 admission at the bar. Edwards Quartet

title: A Man's Death Divides A Tense Harlem Street
description: The commander of the 30th Precinct, Capt. Richard Martin, strolled Edgecombe Avenue on the Upper West Side of Manhattan yesterday, patting children on the head and waving to elderly neighbors fanning themselves on the stoops. He wore a white shirt and a tight smile.

title: Warsaw Journal; In an Unpredictable Land, the Pariah as Candidate
description: The indictment in Jacek Kuron's trial for anti-Government activity in 1983 describes him this way: ''Not working, no estate, no decorations, nonassociated.'' Despite such meager qualifications, Mr. Kuron has been a favorite target of official repression over the years.

title: Books of The Times; The 50-Year Life of a Musical Eccentric
description: When his first recording of Bach's ''Goldberg Variations'' was released in 1956, the 23-year-old Glenn Gould became an immediate international star. In taking what had been regarded as a cerebral set of academic exercises and revealing the passion and beauty lurking beneath its glittering surface, he had also revealed himself as one of the world's most gifted and distinctive pianists - a pianist blessed with precision and intelligence, breathtaking speed and a rare ability to isolate contrapuntal lines and weave them back together again in a glorious pattern of sound.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: G.O.P. House Leader Asks End to Inquiry Disclosures
description: The House Republican leader, Robert H. Michel, today called for an end to disclosures of criminal investigations against House members and urged Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to consider the appointment of an independent prosecutor to investigate the disclosures.

title: Suspect in 5 Killings in 1971 Caught With Aid of TV Show
description: An 18-year search for one of the nation's most wanted fugitives - a New Jersey man who vanished when his mother, wife and three children were found shot to death in 1971 - ended in Virginia yesterday after his case was featured on a national television program.

title: Lawrence Keville Larson, Executive, 90
description: Lawrence Keville Larson, a retired lumber company official, died May 25 at his home in Chapman, Ala. He was 90 years old and had been ill for several months.

title: Now for the Hard Part
description: President Bush has scored an unmistakable triumph in Europe, calming potential crisis within NATO and dramatizing his leadership with a strong proposal for conventional arms reductions. Good for him and good for us, but . . .

title: Mets Get Relief at a Crucial Point
description: It was the worst trip to the West Coast for the Mets in the six years of the reign of Davey Johnson, three victories and six losses, and the last time they did it, George Bamberger resigned as the manager. But nobody was resigning this time, and the Mets even came home yesterday after one night of success that somehow seemed to relieve the sense of crisis swamping the team in California.

title: Review/Opera; Words and Music by Jean Jacques Himself
description: As part of its celebration of the bicentennial of the French Revolution, the French Institute/Alliance Francaise is presenting Concert Royal and the New York Baroque Dance Company in performances of ''Le Devin du Village,'' a one-act opera by Jean Jacques Rousseau. The production opened on Tuesday evening at Florence Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street, and will be repeated there next Wednesday through Saturday.

title: New Partner in the Firm: the Marketing Director
description: Last month, Cathy L. Petryshyn, marketing director at Benesch, Friedlander, Coplan & Aronoff, held a seminar for the Cleveland firm's 165 lawyers on how to sell their legal services. But aware that lawyers cringe at the thought of giving their clients a sales pitch, she took care to avoid using the word ''sell.''

title: Court Allows Inquiries Into Pasts of Workers
description: New York City schools can guard against corruption scandals by conducting background checks on certain employees and requiring them to give detailed financial statements, a state appeals court ruled today.

title: Norval F. Myers, 87, Retired Oil Executive
description: Norval F. Myers, a retired oil-company executive, died on May 21 at the Crestview Convalescent Center in Portland, Ore. He was 87 years old and lived in Lake Oswego, Ore.

title: Gibraltar Payment On Bonds Delayed
description: The Gibraltar Financial Corporation, parent company of Gibraltar Savings and Loan of Beverly Hills, Calif., said it would not make a $1.02 million interest payment due today to bondholders. If the payment, due to holders of $22 million worth of 9 1/4 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2008, is not made by July 1, the company will default on the notes and it said it might also default on another $99.5 million in senior subordinated debentures.

title: Critics' Choices for an Arts-Filled Weekend;  Galleries
description: To see the most ambitious shows in New York City at this moment requires straying from the museums and wandering into SoHo where, as it happens, two important traveling exhibitions have stopped on Wooster Street.

title: Review/Recital; Soviet Emigre at the Piano
description: Gabor Fuchs, a Soviet emigre pianist, brought a fine sense of drama, if not always a great deal of color, to most of the music he played in his Wednesday evening recital at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Angry Skirmish Over Charter Brings Apology
description: In a steamy Masonic hall in Brooklyn yesterday, the head of the commission that is drafting a new government for New York City and a borough president whose job he wants to change traded such harsh words that another member of the panel chastened the chairman and the borough chief apologized.

title: Critics' Choices for an Arts-Filled Weekend;  Museums
description: A museum can be all things to all people. It can show great works of art, one by one, in isolation. It can bring a complete world before us, with paintings, prints, drawings and a learned, unhurrying commentary. It can offer us what has long been well known and loved but not often so well set out. And it can provide an artist of our own day with a privileged space in which the work can be looked over in august surroundings.

title: If There's a Law, There's a Newsletter
description: In the nation's capital, no interest is too narrow to be deserving of its own newsletter. There's a newsletter called Sludge. There's one called Gas Daily. There's Brazil Watch, Fiber Optic News, Space Commerce Bulletin, Octane Week, Navy News and Undersea Technology, Blood Bank Week, Nuclear Waste News and even The Newsletter on Newsletters.

title: Top Retail Executive Moves to Interpacific
description: Jane Evans, who held several top retailing jobs before moving to investment banking, has returned to the business as head of a company with specialty stores throughout the Pacific region.

title: Review/Film; Pursuing a Stolen Lance That Is Holy To the Sioux
description: With a little more wit and a little less blood, ''Renegades'' could have been ''Lethal Weapon Jr.'' It is a fast, violent, implausible film about mismatched partners, and though it doesn't exactly break the bounds of its trashy genre, it's not at all bad for what it is.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Saatchi Names U.S. Executives
description: Saatchi & Saatchi announced a round of appointments in its executive suite yesterday, led by the expected promotion of Edward L. Wax to president and chief executive of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Inc. Mr. Wax in effect replaces Gary Susnjara, who resigned last week to pursue other personal and business interests. Mr. Wax, chairman of

title: New York State Revenue Bonds
description: The New York State Medical Care Facilities Finance Agency yesterday tentatively priced about $266 million of hospital and nursing home mortgage revenue bonds for Montefiore Medical Center. The bonds are insured by the Federal Housing Administration.

title: Pace of Sales At Big Stores Is Slowing
description: The nation's large retailers reported yesterday that sales last month were better than in May 1988, but sales at several of the biggest chains barely kept up with inflation and in some cases rose less than the prices of their goods.

title: California Drops Charges Against Lukas and 4 Others
description: Accusations against D. Wayne Lukas, Laz Barrera and three other thoroughbred trainers charging cocaine was present in horses they train were dismissed today.

title: At the Movies
description: A Volcano

title: Lark Quartet
description: The Lark String Quartet will perform Libby Larson's ''Alauda,'' Peter Schickele's String Quartet No. 2 and Jon Deak's ''Fundevogel'' as part of the Queens Symphony Orchestra's ''From the Left Bank'' series on Sunday afternoon at 3 o'clock at P.S. 1, 46-01 21st Street, Long Island City, Queens. Tickets are $7. Information: (718) 275-5000.

title: Consumers Win a Victory on Auto Insurance
description: To the Editor:

title: Phoenix Journal; For Some, Grand Prix Is Seen as a Grand Pain
description: Maxine Apple doesn't know a Formula One from an Indy car. But that doesn't keep her from having a strong opinion about auto racing: she thinks it's bad news that this desert city will for the first time be host to one of the 16 races on the international Formula One Grand Prix circuit.

title: Tyson and Givens: Divorce Is Official
description: Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, and the actress Robin Givens were officially divorced yesterday.

title: Alexis Lichine, 76, an Author and Expert on Wine
description: Alexis Lichine, an internationally known wine expert and author of landmark reference books in the field, died of cancer yesterday at Chateau Prieure-Lichine, his home in Bordeaux, France. He was 76 years old and had been ill for about six months.

title: PRESIDENT ASSURES THATCHER ON TIES
description: President Bush reassured Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today that the close ties between the United States and Britain would continue despite Mr. Bush's view that West Germany is now the key to the future of the East-West relationship in Europe.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Precision Tune Inc., to J. Walter Thompson, Detroit, with a budget of $5 million.

title: Diner's Journal
description: De l'Alsace a Brandywine

title: Chief Says Democrats Won't 'Smear' G.O.P.
description: The Democratic national chairman said yesterday that the Republican Party had turned the issue of ethics into a partisan weapon but that the Democrats would not retaliate in kind.

title: State Dept. Condemns West Bank ID Badges
description: The State Department said today that an Israeli settlement in the West Bank that has begun requiring Palestinian workers to wear special identification badges was acting in an ''offensive'' manner ''incompatible with democratic values.''

title: Treasury Bonds Are Unchanged
description: Treasury bond prices were essentially unchanged yesterday as traders and investors marked time awaiting this morning's scheduled release of the employment data for May.

title: Details of Mosaics Purchase Emerge in Indiana Trial
description: A summary of a sealed deposition created a sensation today in a trial in Federal District Court to decide the ownership of four sixth-century mosaics from a church in Cyprus. The summary, read aloud by a lawyer for the Government and Church of Cyprus, who say the mosaics were stolen and are seeking their return, revealed previously unknown details of the financial arrangements in their purchase.

title: Critics' Choices for an Arts-Filled Weekend;  Classical Music
description: Although the calendar year is gradually filling up with music, early June has traditionally remained a dead spot, a lull between the late spring frenzy and summer festivals. Thus it is surprising to find a number of notable events in classical and ethnic music this weekend.

title: Donald Ballman, 79, a Chemical Executive
description: Donald K. Ballman, retired senior vice president of the Dow Chemical Company, Midland, Mich., died in his sleep Wednesday at his daughter's home in Hinsdale, Ill. He was 79 years old and lived in La Jolla, Calif.

title: Search Ended for 14 Missing
description: American military officials today called off the search for 13 marines and one sailor missing since the helicopter they were aboard crashed into the sea near Okinawa late Tuesday. All are presumed dead. Seven marines and a sailor were rescued after the CH-46 Sea Knight, based at Kaneohe Bay in Hawaii, crashed after taking off from a Navy amphibious ship in a training exercise.

title: Ching Ho Cheng Dead; Mixed-Media Artist, 42
description: Ching Ho Cheng, an artist, died May 25 at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Longhorn Is Honored
description: Scott Bryant, a versatile junior player for the University of Texas, was selected as the college player of the year by the American Baseball Coaches Association yesterday as the Longhorns prepared for the College World Series, which begins today in Omaha. Bryant, who hit 18 home runs and led the nation with 108 runs batted in and 31 doubles, was an outfielder, a designated hitter, a first baseman and pitcher for Texas. He batted .388, striking out only 21 times in 242 times at bat. As a pitcher he had a 1-0 record in three games.

title: Gormley Pins Hopes In Primary On Issues
description: Walking in shirtsleeves through the midday sun, State Senator William L. Gormley of Atlantic County was far from his southern New Jersey base today. But he was not out of his element.

title: Cosmos Spirit Infuses 2 At Tournament Debut
description: Tab Ramos and John Harkes grew up watching the Cosmos at Giants Stadium and dreaming of playing for the country's most glamorous soccer team.

title: China Said to Offer $25 Million For Tyson-Foreman in Beijing
description: The Chinese Government has agreed to pay $25 million to stage a boxing match between the heavyweight champion, Mike Tyson, and the former champion George Foreman, Tyson's manager and the fight's promoter said yesterday.

title: Gilda, I Can't Forget You
description: LEAD: There are two green hair ribbons hanging over my desk.

title: INSIDE
description: Student Loan Crackdown The Education Secretary established tough penalties for colleges and trade schools with large numbers of former students who default on federally backed loans. Page A10. Welfare Nominee Yields The choice to run the Federal welfare system withdrew because of a dispute on his role in an Oklahoma policy that denied surgical care to poor spina bifida babies. Page D14. The Hottest Race in Poland A Solidarity champion is pitted against a distinguished lawyer with strong Catholic backing in the contest for a Warsaw-area seat in the new Polish Parliament. Page A4. Record Trade on Big Board Carl C. Icahn sold his 42-million-share Texaco stake for $2 billion, prompting a flurry of activity in his other large holding, USX. Page D1. Harsh Words Over Charter The chairman of the Charter Revision Commission and one of the borough presidents whose job he wants to change squared off in a steamy Masonic hall in Brooklyn. Page B1.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Black & Decker Corp., Towson, Md., said it plans to sell Dynapert, a maker of automatic assembly machinery for the electronics industry, and its Mallory and Arcotronics capacitors businesses. The units were all acquired in its purchase of Emhart Corp.

title: Our Towns; In War of Odors, Can 'Fresh' Ever Conquer Putrid?
description: Ah, springtime in Shelton. Barbecues. Softball games. Cottonwood blooms blowing in the breeze. And, in the Pine Rock section of town, the stench of rotting garbage wafting through the air. ''It's decomposing material - not garbage!'' said Bill La Rovera, manager of the 41-acre Shelton landfill, where the odor originates. ''What you're smelling is wood.''

title: 1,000 Children Dancing
description: Jacques d'Amboise and the National Dance Institute will present 1,000 schoolchildren in ''Meilleurs Amis - Best of Friends,'' a celebration of the bicentennial of the French Revolution and of the signing of the American Bill of Rights, Sunday at 7:30 P.M. at the Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden. Eli Wallach will narrate and Judy Collins will sing. Tickets are $25 and $15. A performance on Monday at 8 P.M. will be a benefit for the institute: $500 tickets include dinner before the show and a party at Macy's Cellar afterward; $300 tickets include just the Macy's party; and tickets at $100, $50 and $25 are for the show alone. Information and reservations: 563-4943.

title: Hudson River Houses
description: A tour of Hudson River houses will take place tomorrow from 9:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. in Coxsackie and Athens in Greene County, along Route 385, which runs parallel to the river. Picnic lunches will be offered for sale along the route. Admission: $7.50. Information: (518) 731-6822. To get to the starting point: take the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway to Exit 21B in Coxsackie, then Route 9W and Route 385, following the signs to the Second Reformed Church on Washington Street.

title: Ford Cash Rebates
description: The Ford Motor Company raised cash rebates on several cars and trucks and extended the other discounts that it had introduced in late March. Rebates on the Ford Tempo and the Bronco II increased $250, to $750, and those on the Thunderbird and Mercury Cougar rose $150, to $750. But the alternative of low-rate car loans, starting at annual interest rates of 2.9 percent for two-year contracts, will be available on fewer vehicles and a few truck models carry lower rebates.

title: Ms. Gerber Is the Bride Of J. P. Klein
description: Michele Gerber, the daughter of Lillian Gerber of New York and Pierre Gerber of Tempe, Ariz., was married yesterday to Jeffrey P. Klein, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Klein of New York. The ceremony was performed by Judge Milton Pollack of Federal District Court in Manhattan at the Klein family home in New York.

title: Storytelling in the Park
description: Ten guests will read from a collection of ''Stories to Save the Planet'' tomorrow at 11 A.M. to open the 33d season of storytelling for children at the Hans Christian Andersen statue in Central Park. Stories by Andersen and folk tales from Brazil, Turkey and China will form the programs of future Saturday-morning events in the series, which runs through Sept. 30. The statue is on the west side of the model-boat pond, near East 72d Street and Fifth Avenue. All programs are one hour, except tomorrow's, which will end at 1 P.M. Admission is free. Information: 360-1333.

title: Consumers Win a Victory on Auto Insurance; Reduce the Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Gains 10.48, to 2,490.63; Icahn Sale Spurs Trading
description: LEAD: The stock market moved higher yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 10.48 points to close at 2,490.63.

title: Several Names Emerge as the Chancellor Hunt Opens
description: Although the search for a new schools chancellor for New York City has yet to begin in earnest, more than a dozen people fit the preliminary qualifications sought by the Board of Education, say educators, board officials, union leaders and others.

title: Review/Pop; A Neville Brother Alone
description: In a tremulous falsetto, with phrases that ripple and float, Aaron Neville sings of perfect romance and intricate pain. He's a member of the Neville Brothers band, for whom he delivers change-of-pace ballads and fills out harmonies, but on Tuesday night at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights, accompanied by Asa Miller on piano, he revealed his cabaret-singer side, sitting on a stool and glancing at a music stand as he sang.

title: Auctions
description: Bird Books

title: Huge Slab Falls off F.D.R. Drive, Killing a Motorist
description: A 500-pound slab of concrete fell from beneath the northbound lanes of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive near 21st Street last night, crashed through a car windshield and fatally injured the driver, the police said.

title: The Air Around the President
description: George Bush's campaign promise to pay more attention to the environment was welcome news after eight years of indifference from Ronald Reagan. He now faces a marvelous opportunity to match rhetoric with substance: the urgent need to revise the Clean Air Act of 1970, landmark legislation grown flaccid with age.

title: Quayle to Central America
description: Vice President Dan Quayle will visit Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador and Costa Rica from June 11 through 14 to meet with leaders in the region, his office announced today. The trip will be used to underscore support for El Salvador after the inauguration today of President Alfredo Cristiani, Mr. Quayle's office said. The Vice President met with Mr. Cristiani in February, when he was the presidential candidate of the Arena party.

title: C. L. R. James, Historian, Critic And Pan-Africanist, Is Dead at 88
description: C. L. R. James, the Trinidadian-born historian, literary critic and philosopher who was a leader of the pan-African movement, died suddenly of a chest infection Wednesday at his home in London. He was 88 years old.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 467 money market mutual funds increased by $599.30 million, to $312.68 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 141 institutional funds increased by $17.60 million, to $79.43 billion. The assets of the 231 general-purpose funds rose $414.20 million, to $101.66 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds increased by $167.50 million, to $131.60 billion, the institute said.

title: Wright Now Feels Whirlwind's Lash
description: One day after he announced that he was giving up the job he cherished, House Speaker Jim Wright was still struggling to make sense of it all, still struggling to understand his year in the whirlwind.

title: BEIJING TIGHTENS PRESS RESTRICTION
description: The Government announced tough new restrictions on foreign reporters today that, if enforced, would in effect bar correspondents from writing any articles about the nation's democracy movement.

title: Lampoon Stake
description: Jack H. Docktor, a Miami investor, has acquired a 5.2 percent stake in National Lampoon Inc., the New York-based publisher of the monthly humor magazine. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Docktor said he had acquired the National Lampoon shares for investment purposes. He said he had bought 81,500 shares in the open market for an average price of $3.72. National Lampoon closed today at $4.375, unchanged, in over-the-counter trading.

title: New Jersey's G.O.P. Rivals Compare Promises of Thrift
description: With the primary just a few days off, the Republican candidates for governor have turned their attention away from noble visions of the future to answer questions on how much the future is going to cost.

title: The Giuliani Lesson: Wall Street Practice and Politics Can Be a Poor Mix for a Lasting Mortar
description: On paper it seemed like a perfect match. White & Case gave Rudolph W. Giuliani an establishment image, a generous income and a long leash for his extracurricular political activities. And whether he became mayor or not, Mr. Giuliani would be a classic ''rainmaker'' for staid old White & Case, bringing it new clients, new visibility and new panache.

title: LaPoint's Shoulder Troubles Yankees
description: They have not yet begun to panic, but the Yankees tonight expressed their first public concern about Dave LaPoint, who has stiffness in his left shoulder and has been unable to pitch effectively in each of his last three starts.

title: Shift in Testimony
description: Dave Steen, who competes in the decathlon, backed down yesterday on an allegation that Ben Johnson's doctor had given him a bottle containing the steroid that cost the sprinter an Olympic gold medal.

title: Wright's Plan to Resign Causes Sorrow in Texas
description: House Speaker Jim Wright's intention to resign his Congressional seat prompted widespread sorrow and some anger among many of his fellow Texans today as they pondered the loss of a powerful favorite son.

title: Fresco by Michelangelo May Lose Its Loincloths
description: Art restorers will probably strip the painted loincloths from many figures in the Michelangelo masterpiece ''The Last Judgment,'' it was reported today.

title: Man Who Let Son Die Is in Hospital for Drugs
description: A man who held off hospital staff members at gunpoint last month while removing his comatose 15-month-old son from a life-support system was hozspitalized today apparently for a drug overdose, the police said.

title: McGuigan Retiring
description: Barry McGuigan, the former World Boxing Association featherweight champion from Belfast, Northern Ireland, announced his retirement from the ring on Wednesday night in Manchester, England, after suffering a fourth-round loss to Jim McDonnell, a superfeatherweight from London. McDonnell opened a cut over McGuigan's right eye in the second round and Micky Vann, the referee, stopped the fight at 1 minute 43 seconds of the fourth round.

title: POWER OF SPEAKER ALREADY STARTING TO PASS TO FOLEY
description: The power of the Speaker's gavel began to pass today from Jim Wright of Texas to Thomas S. Foley of Washington, who quickly sent a message of calm and reassurance to his battered House colleagues on both sides of the aisle and appealed for their support.

title: Quaker State Acquisition
description: The Quaker State Corporation has completed its acquisition of McQuik's Oilube Inc. The acquisition was made Wednesday through an exchange of less than 3 percent of Quaker State's outstanding shares for all shares of McQuik's. McQuik's operates 71 fast car lubrication facilities in Indiana, Ohio, Florida, Kentucky, Maine, Michigan, South Carolina and Tennessee.

title: Three Youths Arrested In New Jersey Shooting
description: Three youths were charged today with attempted murder in connection with a shooting Tuesday that wounded a high school custodian and a student, the Essex County Prosecutor said.

title: On Stage
description: Musical From 'Shirley' Author

title: Ruth Tefferteller, 71, Settlement-House Aide
description: Ruth S. Tefferteller, a social worker and former associate director of the Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side, died of cancer on May 15 at her home in Marblehead, Mass. She was 71 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have never been driven by a desire to become Speaker. I'm not a fatalist. But I am one who thinks circumstance, happenstance, accident has a lot to do with what happens in a political career.'' - Representative Thomas S. Foley. [ A1:5. ]

title: U.S. Sets Tough Penalties For Student Loan Defaults
description: Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos today established tough penalties against colleges and trade schools with large proportions of former students who default on federally backed loans.

title: MAI Basic Lowers Bid For Prime Computer
description: MAI Basic Four Inc., the minicomputer producer, yesterday cut its takeover offer for Prime Computer Inc., another minicomputer company, to an estimated $18 a share in cash and securities, or $1.2 billion.

title: Credit Cards Back Citibank Security
description: Citibank is selling $845 million of credit card participation certificates through National Credit Card Trust, with the First Boston Corporation as lead underwriter for the financing.

title: Choice of Federal Court Is Valuable Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Lou Centlivre announced his retirement as executive vice president of Foote, Cone & Belding, Chicago.

title: Voters Deserve a Choice on New York City Charter Proposals
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Shaking Up a Boys' School With Poetry
description: The time is 1959 and the place is the Welton Academy in Vermont. Welton is one of those expensive, tradition-bound boys' preparatory schools somewhat more beloved in, and more significant to, English literature than American.

title: Last-Minute Arms Policy Worries Bush's Critics
description: President Bush's arms control initiatives at the NATO summit meeting appear to have deflated much of the criticism that his Administration was not being responsive enough to the ''new thinking'' of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Happy Birthday, Martha! Ice Cream for All
description: A birthday party for Martha Washington will be held 2:30 to 4 P.M. Sunday at Washington's headquarters in Newburgh, N.Y., in Orange County, on the banks of the Hudson River.

title: Big Board Planning 'Basket' Trades
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it planned to join the list of exchanges trading a ''basket'' product that will enable investors to buy or sell, in a single execution, a large portfolio of stocks.

title: A $1.1 Billion Lilco Offering
description: The Long Island Lighting Company said today that it intends to offer $1.1 billion of debentures and use the proceeds to reimburse its treasury for construction expenses, to redeem outstanding bonds and to provide working capital.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: JUSTICE
description: A carefully scripted little ceremony at the Supreme Court this week lasted barely a minute. But for that moment, it opened a window on the select, tightly knit world of lawyers whose professional lives revolve around the nation's highest court.

title: U.S. Said to Receive 5 Offers for 20 Former Mcorp Banks
description: Federal bank regulators received at least five bids for the third-largest banking network in Texas before the regulators' deadline late Wednesday, analysts and banking officials said today.

title: Sugar Complaint Is Backed
description: An international panel has backed a contention by Australia that the United States violated trading rules by limiting its sugar imports, the Office of the United States Trade Representative said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; WPP Buys Coley
description: It is not Ogilvy & Mather and the price is not $864 million, but yesterday Coley Porter Bell, a British corporate identity consulting firm, became the latest link in the WPP Group's growing chain. The London-based conglomerate acquired Coley in a deal valued at up to $19.6 million. Coley, which had revenues of $5.3 million last year, will become part of a holding company for WPP's continental European subsidiaries.

title: Post for Shirley Temple Black
description: Shirley Temple Black, the onetime child film star who fashioned a diplomatic career, is returning to public service as United States Ambassador to Czechoslovakia, the White House said today. Mrs. Black, who is 61 years old, has long been active in Republican politics. She served previously as a member of the United States delegation to the United Nations in 1969-70 and was Ambassador to Ghana from 1974 through 1976.

title: Henley Group Recapitalizing Unit
description: The Henley Group Inc. said it would recapitalize a subsidiary, the PA Holdings Corporation, shifting about $400 million from short-term to long-term debt. Henley, which has headquarters in La Jolla, Calif., and Hampton, N.H., said it would invest $100 million in cash and $75 million in notes in PA Holdings, a manufacturer of military and commercial aircraft equipment.

title: Top Discus Thrower Thwarted by Time
description: Tony Washington, a Syracuse junior, is favored to win the national collegiate title Friday night in the discus throw. It may be now or never because, he said, a professor told him he might not graduate if he continued in track and field next year.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums Schedule ''UGLY AND THE BEAST: OR BEAUTY IS AS BEAUTY DOES,'' a play with original music, presented by the Appleseed Players, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Home for Contemporary Theater and Art, 44 Walker Street. Admission: children, $5; adults, $8. Reservations: 431-7434. ''FAMILY TREASURES: TOYS AND THEIR TALES,'' an exhibition of toys from the permanent collection of the Museum of the City of New York that reflect a distinct pattern of New York City's social history, with dolls from France, modest family toys, treasure boxes of trinkets, keepsakes and extravagant playthings, at the museum, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. Museum hours: 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesdays though Saturdays and 1 to 5 P.M. Sundays and holidays. Suggested contributions: children, $1; students and the elderly, $1.50; adults, $3; families, $5. Information: 534-1034. ''A YEAR WITH CHILDREN: 20TH-ANNIVERSARY EXHIBITION,'' a show of paintings, sculpture, photographs, prints and mixed-media constructions by schoolchildren who participated in Learning Through Art, the Guggenheim Museum Children's Program, on view through June 11, at the Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street. The museum is open 11 A.M. to 7:45 P.M. Tuesdays and 11 A.M. to 4:45 P.M. Wednesdays through Sundays. Admission: children, under 7, free; students and the elderly, $2.50; others, $4.50; Tuesday evenings, 5 to 7:45, free. Information: 360-3555. CHILDREN'S DAY'S FAIR, with a theme of ''The World According to Puppets,'' with the Manteo Family Sicilian Marionette Theater, other performers, games, food, rides, music and crafts, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Sunday, at the Museum of the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences, 75 Stuyvesant Place, St. George. Admission: free. Information: (718) 727-1135. ''THE SEAPORT EXPERIENCE,'' a film spectacle about the South Street Seaport, with 104 projectors and special audio effects, 10:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. Mondays through Thursdays and 10:30 A.M. to 6:30 P.M. Fridays through Sundays, at the Trans-Lux Seaport Theater, 210 Front Street. Children, $3.25; adults, $4.75. Information: 608-7888.

title: Postal Union In Sears Fight
description: A union representing 365,000 postal workers says its members will slice up any Sears, Roebuck and Company credit cards they hold and boycott the retail giant unless it removes mini-post offices from 11 of its stores. The American Postal Workers Union said Thursday that it was also considering asking for a nationwide labor boycott of Sears if it ignored the demand.

title: Airline-Merger Caution Abroad
description: The European Community favors deregulation of air transportation, but it will strictly control airline mergers, an European Community official said today.

title: Brookens' Pinch Hit Wins It In 10th
description: The night was not looking good. A lead had been lost, then regained, and now, in the 10th inning, Dave Righetti stood on the mound at County Stadium with the bases loaded and with a small disaster facing him.

title: New Study Is Easing Fears On AIDS and Mental Illness
description: Fears that large numbers of people infected with the AIDS virus might suffer mental deterioration long before they develop the disease have been eased by new studies, researchers said here today.

title: Bilzerian's Credibility Attacked at Fraud Trial
description: The credibility of Paul A. Bilzerian was attacked yesterday at his securities fraud trial as the Government confronted him with what it said were false or misleading statements he made under oath on other occasions.

title: Alfred W. Jones, 88, Sociologist And Investment Fund Innovator
description: Alfred Winslow Jones, an investor who founded one of the first hedge funds on Wall Street, died in his sleep yesterday morning at his home in Redding, Conn. He was 88 years old and had been in declining health in recent weeks. He also had an apartment in Manhattan.

title: NEW GROUP FIGHTS EPISCOPAL CHANGES
description: Traditionalist Episcopalians who oppose their church's approval of women as priests and bishops today founded a new national association that could become an independent denomination if they felt their views were not respected.

title: Firefighters to Perform 'Guys and Dolls' Benefit
description: A troupe of about 35 New York City firefighters and their friends and families will perform Frank Loesser's musical ''Guys and Dolls'' at 8 o'clock tonight and on June 9 and 10 at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, 899 10th Avenue, at 58th Street.

title: Bakkers Get $1.2 Million Bill
description: The evangelist Jim Bakker and his wife, Tammy, have received a $1.2 million tax bill from the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Pension Fund Risks Cited
description: More than $1.6 trillion in pension funds are potentially at risk because of poor regulations and inept enforcement of Federal laws, the Labor Department's Inspector General said today.

title: For Post-Wedding Smiles
description: Looking for a wedding photographer? It's wise to do more than ask about price and look at sample albums or videotapes.

title: Tenneco Pays $5 Million in Gas 'Flaring'
description: Tenneco Inc., a natural gas pipeline holding company, paid the Department of the Interior $5 million today as part of a civil settlement of charges that it burned off gas from Federal leases without the necessary Government approvals.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JUNE 3, 1989
description: The Economy

title: Review/Film; The Ferocious Hulk Hogan And Other Tough Guys
description: In ''No Holds Barred,'' Hulk Hogan's first feature film, the blond, mustachioed wrestling idol plays a professional gladiator who is so ferocious he can reduce a gymnasium to rubble in five minutes flat and so sensitive that he spontaneously bursts into tears after his little brother is beaten up.

title: As Inmates Pour In, Cuomo Plans 3,000 Beds in Prison Gymnasiums
description: To cope with an influx of almost 3,000 inmates over the summer, New York State will begin housing prisoners in gymnasiums starting next week, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today.

title: Youths With Brutal Pasts, in a Prison 'Without Cruelty'
description: One youth fired a round of bullets into the heads of two men to prove he was a hardened drug dealer. When another youth fatally beat an elderly man, he did so to impress two friends. And a third claims ''a misunderstanding'' provoked him to kill another teen-ager on his way to school one day.

title: Jane S. Kaufman Wed to Attorney
description: Jane Steele Kaufman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur L. Steele of Palm Beach, Fla., and Kenneth L. Fishman, a son of the late Dr. and Mrs. William Fishman of Chestnut Hill, Mass., were married yesterday by Judge Walter M. Schackman in his chambers at State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Correction
description: A brief article on May 17 about the Fox Broadcasting schedule misstated the air time for a new half-hour television series, ''Open House,'' which is to have its premiere in September. It is Sundays at 9:30 P.M., not 8:30.

title: Pistons Earn a Rematch With Lakers in Final
description: All season, the Detroit Pistons have hoped for a rematch against the Los Angeles Lakers for the National Basketball Association championship. Tonight, the Pistons got their wish.

title: The Getty Fills a Role, for Itself and the Public
description: When the hammer fell Wednesday afternoon at Christie's on the auction of Jacopo Pontormo's portrait of a young man, George Goldner of the Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., exchanged high fives with a colleague sitting next to him. It was not, perhaps, a typical gesture for someone who has just spent $35.2 million for a painting, but the amiable and savvy Mr. Goldner is in no way typical.

title: Gibraltar To Sell Off Portfolio
description: The Government-appointed managers of Gibraltar Savings, a California financial institution seized by Federal regulators two months ago, said today that they planned to sell or restructure a large portion of Gibraltar's $4.7 billion mortgage-backed securities portfolio, probably at a substantial loss.

title: A Short-Term Solution Eases the Job of Caring
description: Thelma and John Silano care for Mrs. Silano's mother in their Livingston, N.J. home. But last Saturday they flew to Spain and Portugal for a vacation without any worries. That's because Mrs. Silano's mother, Helen Coppola, is spending three weeks at the Northfield Manor nursing home in nearby West Orange while the couple is overseas.

title: Movies Should Install Listening Devices
description: To the Editor:

title: Suit Seeks to Save Churches
description: Members of Roman Catholic churches that have been closed or are to be closed as part of a reorganization plan have sued the Archdiocese of Detroit. The lawsuit, filed Thursday in Wayne County Circuit Court, seeks an order allowing 16 of the 30 churches to remain open beyond the June 30 deadline so they can appeal to the Vatican.

title: Owner of Tavern on the Green Sues Union Over Long Strike
description: The owner of Tavern on the Green filed a $110 million lawsuit yesterday against the union that has been picketing the restaurant in Central Park for more than a month.

title: Knee Surgery for Weiss
description: Walt Weiss, the Oakland Athletics shortstop who was the American League rookie of the year in 1988, underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday to repair torn cartilage in his right knee. He is expected to be out for six weeks.

title: Frogs' Eyes Inspire Motion Detection System
description: A motion detection system inspired by frogs' eyes has been designed by researchers at the Xerox Corporation's research center in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: BEIJING RESIDENTS BLOCK ARMY MOVE NEAR CITY CENTER
description: Tens of thousands of Beijing students and workers surged onto the streets early this morning to turn back more than 2,000 troops who were marching toward Tiananmen Square.

title: Booksellers Convention Gains in Foreign Flavor
description: The internationalization of book publishing is more apparent than ever at the annual four-day convention of the American Booksellers Association, which opens here Saturday.

title: Strong Stock Market Digests Large Sale of Texaco Shares
description: The aftereffects of Carl C. Icahn's sale of the huge stake he held in Texaco Inc. rippled through the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: Man Is Stabbed in Hasidic Feud Leaving Home of Brooklyn Editor
description: A man was abducted, beaten and stabbed in Brooklyn early Wednesday by a group of Hasidim who apparently mistook him for the editor of a newspaper that has written about internal disputes in a Hasidic sect, the police said yesterday.

title: Sowell Is Rapidly Approaching the Top Sprinter Ranks
description: With Florence Griffith Joyner retired, the next great American female sprinter may turn out to be Dawn Sowell.

title: Suspect Fights With Guards
description: The man accused of fatally stabbing four people on Memorial Day was transferred to a psychiatric center after fighting over a bed sheet with Union County Jail guards, the authorities said today. Rolando Marcelo, 24 years old, assaulted five corrections officers Thursday, said County Police Capt. William White. He was transferred to the hospital in Ewing Township.

title: Has Thatcherism Really Worked?
description: For much of her term in office, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher seemed to make good on her promise to transform the British economy by taming inflation and curbing industrial unrest. But recently, a surge in inflation and a burst of wage disputes and strikes have led many economic analysts to wonder whether Thatcherism really did cure the old ills of the British economy after all.

title: 12 Bodies Found in Sri Lanka
description: The charred bodies of 12 suspected rebels were found overnight in different parts of Sri Lanka, the police and residents said today. No group claimed responsibility for the killings.

title: Alfonsin Under Pressure to Quit
description: Calls for President Raul Alfonsin to step down increased today, with leading politicians saying it was the only way to prevent a resurgence of the bloody rioting that broke out in Argentina this week.

title: ESOP Payout Set by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would distribute $924 million, the assets of its employee stock ownership plan, to 544,000 hourly and salaried employees.

title: Troubled Goods Getters
