description: In the old days being a newspaperman made you feel good. The pay wasn't much but you were out there on the front lines of a mean world comforting the afflicted and afflicting the comfortable.

title: Suicide Theory Pursued in Iowa Blast
description: Government officials said tonight that Navy investigators were focusing on a theory that 47 sailors killed aboard the battleship Iowa last month died in an explosion caused by a sailor intent on suicide.

title: Eastern Unions Are Given New Extension to Draft Bid
description: The three major unions at Eastern Airlines said yesterday that they were willing to commit an additonal $175 million to $200 million in money and wage concessions to help offset any losses under a buyout plan led by Joseph Ritchie, a leading commodities trader from Chicago.

title: Jules Blankfein, 89, A Hospital Founder
description: Dr. Jules Blankfein, a physician and a founder of Physicians Hospital in Jackson Heights, Queens, died of pneumonia yesterday at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 89 years old and lived at the Glengariff Health Care Center in Glen Cove.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A spring breeze penetrates iron walls. That is a motto that has always supported me.'' - Prime Minister Sousuke Uno of Japan. [ 6:6. ]

title: Richard K. Doan, Writer, 78
description: Richard K. Doan, a writer on radio and television affairs, died of natural causes Wednesday at his home in Yarmouth Port, Mass. He was 78 years old.

title: Hoffman as Shylock: London Critics Cool
description: British critics took a pound of flesh out of Dustin Hoffman today, as he expected, for having the audacity to play Shylock in a commercial production of Shakespeare's ''Merchant of Venice'' that opened Thursday night.

title: U.S. Holds Off Benfica, 2-1, in Marlboro Cup
description: After the devastating loss of a point in its World Cup qualifying game against Trinidad and Tobago three weeks ago, the United States national team received a dose of confidence tonight in defeating Benfica of Lisbon, 2-1, in the Marlboro Cup soccer tournament at Giants Stadium.

title: May Unemployment Rates Down In New York and New Jersey
description: The unemployment rates in New York State and New Jersey declined last month, primarily because fewer people were seeking jobs, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

title: 2 Sentenced In Pentagon Bribery Case
description: A military consultant, William L. Parkin, and the former Navy engineer he bribed were given 26-month prison terms today for a scheme to help two companies get Pentagon contracts.

title: Elbow Surgery for Rice
description: Jim Rice, Boston's veteran designated hitter, will undergo elbow surgery early next week and be out for four to six weeks. Dr. Arthur Pappas, the Red Sox orthopedist, said yesterday that Rice had a bone chip in the back of his right elbow. Rice has been in an extended slump and is hitting only .238. He will be replaced on the roster by Carlos Quintana, who was summoned from the Red Sox team in nearby Pawtucket, R.I.

title: Disney, Murdoch Settle Lawsuit
description: The Walt Disney Company and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation said today that they had settled a lawsuit filed last month in which a News Corporation subsidiary had accused Disney of sabotaging a satellite broadcasting venture between the companies in Britain and Ireland. Under the terms of the settlement, Sky Television, Mr. Murdoch's European pay-television company, will assume all the financial obligations of the joint venture. The venture had planned to broadcast the Disney Channel and a movie channel via satellite to viewers in Britain and Ireland.

title: KEY RATES
Teaching Sleazy Lessons
description: Chancellor Richard Green's death has left New York City's battered school system with a leadership gap and an unfinished agenda for reform. The No. 1 item on that agenda for the next chancellor must be to do something about the astonishing absence of professional accountability at the Board of Education.

title: Reorganization Of UNR Approved
description: A United States bankruptcy judge approved a reorganization of UNR Industries, which transfers most of the ownership of the company to people who filed asbestos-related claims against the manufacturer. The reorganization plan was overwhelmingly approved this spring by shareholders, most claimants and creditors. A group of nearly 50 claimants had filed objections to the plan with the bankruptcy court, but Judge David H. Coar dismissed these objections Thursday in approving the plan, which will bar future lawsuits.

title: Drop Seen In Auto Sales
description: Lee A. Iacocca, chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, says that the United States auto industry is beginning a mild downturn, but he predicts car makers will be able to take the decline in stride without significant damage to profits.

title: Social Security Chief Gave 2 Views on Staff Cuts
description: Two weeks before the Social Security Commissioner told Congress that personnel cuts proposed by the White House would have no impact on her agency's services, she said in an internal memorandum that the services would in fact ''deteriorate all over the country'' if the cuts were carried out.

title: Details of Profits in Mosaics Trial
description: The man who first interested Peg L. Goldberg, a local art dealer, in buying four sixth-century mosaics that the Cyprus Government and Greek Orthodox Church want back, testified in Federal District Court today about what he did with the $650,000 he received for his part in the sale.

title: David McAlpin 3d, A Longtime Patron Of Photography, 92
description: David H. McAlpin 3d, a philanthropist and investment banker, died Thursday at his home in Princeton, N.J., after a long illness. He was 92 years old.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium, said Air France, the state-owned airline, had ordered one Airbus A320 and four A310-A300's. Terms were not disclosed.

title: HDTV Subsidies Won't Revive U.S. Electronics; Why Take Second Best?
description: To the Editor:

title: Wife Killer Dies While He Waits For Prison Term
description: Joseph Pikul, the former Wall Street securities analyst who was awaiting sentencing for the murder of his wife, died early today after a one-week stay in a Goshen, N.Y., hospital.

title: At Manhunt's End, a Very Average Man
description: The fugitive who called himself Robert P. Clark put his past behind him in New Jersey 18 years ago, authorities say, and began a second life remarkably like the first - as a quiet, churchgoing accountant who impressed neighbors, pastors and acquaintances as respectable and altogether average.

title: Blundering Ahead in Cambodia
description: The Bush Administration seems determined to supply lethal aid to the non-Communist resistance in Cambodia. Prince Sihanouk, ostensibly the main recipient, says he doesn't need the aid. Congress shows no willingness to vote for it. Yet with a determination worthy of a better cause, the Administration has evidently decided to make the aid covert to avoid Congressional scrutiny. Thus the means are as objectionable as the ends.

title: HDTV Subsidies Won't Revive U.S. Electronics; On to Telecomputers
description: To the Editor:

title: An Olfactory Approach to Success
description: You don't have to be a bloodhound to sense there is something in the air in this city of 100,000 that straddles the New Jersey Turnpike. The only thing is, that something has never been mistaken for the sweet smell of success.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14.

title: District of Columbia Drops a Curfew Plan
description: The District of Columbia has abandoned plans for a curfew on teen-agers to help reduce narcotics sales and drug-related violence.

title: Nuclear Waste Dump Faces Another Potential Problem
description: Nine months after the Department of Energy postponed the opening of the nation's first underground repository for nuclear waste, cracks in the ceilings and floors of two large waste storage rooms have been reported.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-6 Chinese troops were turned back from their march toward Tiananmen Square by tens of thousands of students and workers surging onto the streets. The confrontation may present a new challenge to the Government. Page 1 A portrait of a 20-year-old young man as Beijing student leader 4 Deputies assailed Andrei Sakharov in the new Soviet congress, accusing him of slandering his homeland and its military with some of his sharp criticism of the Soviet war in Afghanistan. 1 Soviet paper discloses how soldiers killed strikers in 1962 6 A Polish director who used politics as a theme on the screen and stage has become an actor in real politics. Andrzej Wajda is a Solidarity candidate for the Polish Senate in elections to be held tomorrow. 1 Man in the news: Sousuke Uno, Japan's new Prime Minister, is descibed by friends as a tough negotiator. But officials have referred to himas a ''temporary relief pitcher'' who would follow others. 1 Political dissent in Singapore has been undercut in the last year by legal and constitutional amendments weakening the principle of judicial review. 3 A new rage among Israeli settlers in the occupied territories is being directed both at the Palestinians and Israel's own army, raising official concern about potential repercussions on relations between Jews. 3 Calls for Argentina's leader to resign increased, with leading politicians saying it is the only way to prevent a resurgence of the rioting that broke out in the nation this week. 6 Has Thatcherism worked? 35 Land threatens French island 4 National 8-10, 28 Job growth slackened last month, the Government reported in the most conclusive evidence so far of an economic slowdown. The unemployment rate nevertheless fell slightly. 1 Unemployment rate drops in New York and New Jersey 10 Stock and bond markets soared as interest rates fell in reaction to the employment report. With analysts predicting low inflation, the Dow Jones jumped 27.20 points, to close at 2,517.83, a post-crash high. 38, 39 Dollar falls after job report 35 Sales of a chemical used on apples have been halted, the Uniroyal Chemical Company said. It said it wants to calm consumer fears stirred by a finding that the chemical causes cancer in laboratory animals. 1 More black judges in Mississippi are expected to win office under a Federal court ruling that said the state's judicial elections were discriminatory. The ruling could affect many of the 37 other states. 1 The evaluation of judicial nominees by the American Bar Association will resume, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh announced. The practice was halted shortly after President Bush took office. 9 Republicans will stay on the attack on House ethics issues, said the House minority whip, Newt Gingrich. He said the G.O.P. will produce a ''reform package'' to show it as committed to cleaning up Congress. 9 Oliver North, the public speaker, is a worldly, opinionated incarnation of Oliver North never seen by Congress nor jury. But it has been seen by more than 100 rapt audiences around the nation in the last year. 8 A possible suicide on a battleship, the Iowa, is becoming the focus of Navy investigators. The theory is that a despondent sailor whose job had been to load gunpowder set off the blast to commit suicide. 8 Mental deterioration in AIDS victims rarely occurs in the years before the AIDS virus hits the immune system, researchers said. The finding eased fears set off be earlier reports. 10 Cracks in a nuclear waste repository have been reported in the ceilings and floors of two large waste storage rooms, nine months after the Government postponed the repository's opening. 8 A group of dissident Episcopalians who oppose their church's approval of women as priests and bishops have founded an association that could become independent if the group feels its views are not respected. 8 Effects of Social Security staff cuts were described in different ways earlier this spring by the Social Security Commissioner. She said in an internal memo that the cuts would ''deteriorate'' services, but told Congress they would have no effect. 28 Bakkers get a $1.2 million bill from the I.R.S. 9 Regional 29-32 Inmates will be housed in gyms in New York State prisons starting next week, Governor Cuomo said. The move is intended to cope with an expected influx of almost 3,000 inmates over the summer. 1 The institutions for violent youths convicted of crimes in New York State, Goshen Secure Center and four other centers, are coming under scrutiny as the deterrent value of the juvenile offender law is being debated. 29 A fugitive charged with shooting his wife, mother and three children to death at their Westfield, N.J., home in 1971 lived a normal life centered on work, home and church until the F.B.I. arrested him Thursday. 29 A man was stabbed by Hasidim in Brooklyn on Wednesday. They apparently mistook him for the editor of a newspaper that has written about internal disputes in a Hasidic sect, the police said. 31 Joseph Pikul, who was convicted of wife's murder, dies 32 Officer shot in Brooklyn dies 31 13-year-old shot to death; police suspect link to drugs 31 Tavern on the Green filed a lawsuit against the union that has been picketing the restaurant in Central Park for more than a month, accusing the strikers of stealing information about coming banquets. 31 F.D.R. drive called safe as structural tests continue 30 Jim Courter was confidant of victory in the Republican primary Tuesday for Governor of New Jersey. As he campaigned through Ocean and Hudson Counties, the race was entering its heated final stage. 29 Oyster and clam beds will be closed or restricted starting Sept. 1 in 12 Connecticut towns, while 14 other towns - neighbors to those on the closed list - will be unaffected. The reason is a regulatory snafu. 29

title: A Laser Device to Speed Long-Distance Data
description: Scientists at Spectra-Physics Inc., a laser manufacturer in San Jose, Calif., won patent approval this week for a fiber-optic device that they said could eventually increase the speed of long-distance communication by 500 to 1,000 times.

title: Subsidiary Sale Set by Honeywell
description: Honeywell Inc. said it would sell its Colorado Springs semiconductor unit to the Atmel Corporation, a privately held company based in San Jose, Calif. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Honeywell announced in November that it was looking for a buyer for the unit, which manufactures custom and semi-custom integrated circuits primarily for computer producers.

title: How to Get America Moving Again
description: The United States, Europe and Japan are locked in competition for the high-tech industries of the future. But in one American industry after another, the response to the challenge of the Japanese export drive has been weak and ineffective, eroding the base for future prosperity.

title: Growing Anger Voiced Over Arts Budget Cuts
description: In a concerted protest against new budget cuts by the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, New York City's municipally supported cultural institutions have painted a bleak -almost desperate - picture of a future with fewer performances, in dirtier and more dangerous settings, with large museums having to close whole galleries and smaller museums having to close some days of the week.

title: A Portrait of a Young Man as a Beijing Student Leader
description: Four months ago a scrawny, scraggly-haired student gave speeches about human rights that baffled his classmates, who wondered how anyone could harbor such a passion for what was then a remote concept like democracy.

title: Gingrich Seeks to Seize 'Reform' Label
description: Despite the pleas of Democratic leaders for a bipartisan effort on ethics, the second-ranking House Republican asserted today that his party would try to lead the charge with its own proposals and its own claim to be ''the reform party.''

title: Taiwan Shipyard Booms
description: Taiwan's largest shipbuilder, the China Shipbuilding Corporation, cashing in on strikes in South Korean shipyards, said its orders in May had set a record for the state-owned company. A spokesman said China Shipbuilding had signed a contract with Teh-Hu Cargo-Ocean Management of Hong Kong to build a 149,000-ton bulk carrier. This brought the company's total orders to 19 ships of almost 1.96 million tons at the end of May. The orders compare with the previous records of 15 ships and 1.74 million tons in February and 21 vessels totaling 1.43 million in May last year, the spokesman added.

title: Yugoslav Inflation Rises
description: Yugoslavia's Federal Bureau of Statistics said today that the annual inflation rate soared to 601.6 percent in May, compared with 490.1 percent in April. In May 1988, the inflation rate was 149 percent. The Government predicted this week that inflation would reach 945 percent for the whole of 1989. But some Yugoslav and Western economists say it may exceed 1,000 percent.

title: Sound as a $3 Bill
description: Standing in line at the supermarket checkout counter, I am struck by the wonderful headlines in the tabloids displayed.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Plantathon, a plant and crafts sale, the northbound lanes of Broadway between 72d and 79th Streets will be closed today from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M.

title: 3Com Reports Slower Growth
description: The 3Com Corporation, a large manufacturer of computer networks, said today that its fourth-quarter revenues and earnings would be below analysts' estimates, but that it still expected a record year.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Keeping Pets Healthy
description: Summer's outdoor activities are fraught with potential problems for dogs and cats. Here are some common problems and what to do about them to keep pets healthy through the hot, humid months. Heartworm: An often fatal dog disease spread by mosquitoes and detected by a blood test. A veterinarian should begin injections immediately. A diethylcarbamazine tablet, administered daily, or the recently approved ivermectin, administered monthly, will prevent heartworm. Ticks: Dogs and cats should be checked daily. To remove ticks, wear gloves, grasp the tick with tweezers and pull it out gently. Disinfect area and flush ticks down the toilet.

title: Your Money; Brokerages Offer Personal Advisers
description: Increasing numbers of individual investors are turning to personal asset managers, independent professionals who control their clients' accounts. These investors, attracted by the financial markets' potential for high returns but chary of the markets' risks, are willing to pay for expertise, and brokerage firms have found a growth business in matching investors and managers.

title: SOVIET PAPER LISTS SECRET '62 KILLINGS
description: An official newspaper published an article today disclosing the 27-year-old secret of how soldiers in a southern city killed a score of strikers in a blaze of gunfire and then secretly buried them.

title: SLACK JOB GROWTH SEEN AS EVIDENCE OF SLOW ECONOMY
description: In the strongest evidence so far that the nation's economic growth has slackened, the Labor Department reported today that jobs rose only 101,000 in May, about half as much as expected, while employment in factories fell for the second consecutive month.

title: V.A. Loan Rate Reduced to 10%
description: The Veterans Affairs Department announced today that it would cut its maximum interest rate for federally backed V.A. home mortgages by one-half percentage point, to 10 percent, effective Monday.

title: A Steroid Treatment For Sickle Cell Anemia
description: William J. Harrington, a professor at the University of Miami School of Medicine, this week patented a treatment for sickle cell anemia based on danazol, a steroid drug made from male hormones that is best known for increasing muscle strength.

title: Korea's Struggles With a Big Friend
description: White Badge A Novel of Korea. By Ahn Junghyo 337 pages. Soho Press. $19.95.

title: Singapore Plugs Loopholes of Dissent
description: Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew has been the elected head of Government since self-rule was granted by the British in 1959, and he has presided over a 12-fold increase in per capita gross domestic product while creating an administration known for its capability and integrity.

title: Foster Making Return
description: Last year, three weeks before the United States Olympic Trials, Greg Foster broke his left arm and failed to make the Olympic team, though he tried. Five months ago, playing pickup basketball, he broke the arm again.

title: A Police Officer Who Was Shot In Flatbush Dies
description: A New York City police officer who was shot in Brooklyn early Tuesday while investigating a dispute between two former companions died yesterday at Kings County Hospital, the police reported.

title: New York's Cabarets Don't Deserve Reputation for Violence
description: To the Editor:

title: Power Is Reduced for 156,000 in Brooklyn
description: Nearly half the feeder cables that provide electricity to about 70,000 homes in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn failed late last night, prompting Consolidated Edison officials to reduce power to 156,000 homes and appeal to people to voluntarily cut back on their power use.

title: Earl of Oxford Preferred to Stratford Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Phil Jackson Deserves A Shot
description: How did Phil Jackson keep 10 lengthy and grumpy basketball players, stuffed in a van and making a long ride in the wintry night from Albany to Toronto, not only from killing each other, but from killing the coach? Who happened to be Phil Jackson. And from killing the driver? Who also happened to be Phil Jackson.

title: Apple Chemical Being Removed In U.S. Market
description: Saying it wanted to calm consumer fears, the Uniroyal Chemical Company announced today that it was halting domestic sales of a chemical used on apples that has been found by the Government to cause cancer in laboratory animals.

title: Vietnamese Refugees Protest in Hong Kong
description: Government officials kept 1,000 newly arrived Vietnamese refugees aboard their boats today to keep them away from 5,300 refugees who are on a hunger strike, saying they would rather die than go back to Vietnam, officials said.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Insurance
description: Summer means vacation time, and insurance policies are hardly the first thing that come to mind when people make plans. Almost everyone has adequate coverage for their primary residence and for automobiles. But what about the car you are renting to tour Maine? Or the rental cottage?

title: Can Tides Stay Faithful to a Marvel?
description: After the long slumber of winter and the mist-wrapped tranquillity of spring, the pilgrimage season has resumed to the spired abbey whose graceful profile still draws gasps of awe when first glimpsed on the Normandy coast.

title: Davis Hits for Cycle, First Red Since 1959
description: Eric Davis became the first member of the Cincinnati Reds to hit for the cycle in 30 years tonight as the Reds beat the San Diego Padres, 9-4.

title: Horse Fair At Belmont
description: HorseFair, a celebration of various horse breeds that attracted nearly 250,000 visitors last year, opens this morning for eight days at Belmont Park in Elmont, L.I.

title: Life Imitates Art as a Director Mounts Polish Political Stage
description: Andrzej Wajda, the director who so often brought the political tensions of Poland to screen and stage and in that way intensified some of them, has become an actor in real politics. He is a Solidarity candidate for the Polish Senate.

title: Severe Thunder Squall Kills 1 And Fells 2 Church Steeples
description: A severe thunder squall injured seven people and killed one, demolished two church steeples and ripped several roofs from buildings as it tore through northern Massachusetts today, the police said.

title: DOW SURGES BY 27.20 TO A POST-CRASH HIGH
description: LEAD: Buoyed by an employment report that Wall Street believed indicated lower inflation and a further drop in interest rates, the stock market soared to new post-crash highs yesterday in heavy trading.

title: Review/Pop; Quintet's Soft Brand of Eclecticism
description: When the guitarist Howard Alden and the trombonist Dan Barrett formed a quintet three years ago, they used the soft and subtle qualities of the John Kirby sextet and Red Norvo's trios as a foundation on which to build their group. Their objective, Mr. Alden said, was ''to play quietly, to play in tune and to swing.''

title: Rail Unit Workers Are Seeking CNW
description: Employees of the Chicago and North Western rail system have submitted an offer to buy the parent CNW Corporation, challenging the $658 million hostile bid from the Japonica Partners investment group. Terms of the buyout proposal will not be made public, the Railway Labor Executives' Association said. The proposal calls for one-third of the recapitalized company to be held by employees, with two-thirds retained by shareholders.

title: Sakharov Draws Wrath in Stormy Soviet Congress
description: In a furious outpouring of patriotism and resentment, the new Soviet congress turned on Andrei D. Sakharov today and accused him of slandering his homeland and its military with some of his sharp criticism of the Soviet war in Afghanistan.

title: Oak Industries Fights Vote Move
description: Oak Industries announced that it would oppose efforts by its largest shareholder, MIM Ltd., a British investment firm, to vote its shares in favor of a dissident group waging a proxy battle for control of the San Diego-based electronic communication equipment manufacturer. On Thursday, MIM Ltd. filed suit in Delaware state court seeking to affirm its right to vote its 24.9 percent stake in favor of a dissident group at Oak Industries' annual meeting scheduled for Tuesday.

title: Brooklyn Boy, 13, Found Shot to Death
description: A 13-year-old boy who had stopped attending school and had apparently been unable to avoid the drug wars that plague his neighborhood was found dead yesterday in a vacant apartment in the East New York section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Sousuke Uno; Tokyo's Politician of Both Pen and Sword
description: Aspirants for Prime Minister in Japan usually spend a lifetime cultivating friendships, doing favors, collecting funds and discreetly shoving their rivals out of the way. Yet it was precisely his lack of experience in these matters that today thrust Sousuke Uno into the job.

title: INSIDE
description: A Turn in Navy's Inquiry

title: Judge Held in Tax Case Is Suspended With Pay
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice from the Bronx indicted on tax evasion and drug distribution charges was suspended with pay today by the state's highest court.

title: Banks Cool To Mexico's Debt Offer
description: The Mexican Government presented its committee of commercial bankers with a new plan to reduce and restructure $54.5 billion in debt, but the offer did not satisfy the banks, officials involved in the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Umbrella Survival
description: A New Yorker who returned to live here after a long absence found that umbrellas have changed it into a different city. At least it seemed that way this rainy spring when umbrellas added another level to the streets, creating a many-colored layer - red, black, yellow, pink, striped, checked and blotched -that bobbed, weaved and ducked in a kind of soggy syncopation.

title: Koor Industries
description: Koor Industries, Israel's largest industrial conglomerate, reached agreement today with foreign and domestic creditors on repaying its huge debts. After the agreement, an Israeli court dismissed an application to liquidate the concern, brought eight months ago by the Bankers Trust Company of New York. Koor said the pact would pave the way for a program to sell off loss-making operations and improve efficiency.

title: Bridge; Sam Stayman celebrates his 80th birthday by making a contract of seven hearts.
description: The Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, the most highly prized event in the New York tournament calendar, continued last night at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street in Manhattan. At the midpoint of the semifinal stage the scores by captain were: Henry Bethe over Adam Wildavsky by 33 imps; Glenn Eisenstein over Sam Stayman by 1. All are from Manhattan.

title: G.O.P. Race Nears Finish, And Courter Is Confident
description: Despite a splash of headlines declaring other candidates on the rise, Representative Jim Courter campaigned through Ocean and Hudson Counties today projecting a calm confidence that he will win the Republican nomination for governor of New Jersey in the primary election Tuesday.

title: Melissa A. Brown And Sean Moore Wed in Bermuda
description: In Devonshire Parish, Bermuda, Melissa Ann Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren Archibald Hoadley Brown of Smith's Parish, Bermuda, and Boston, was married yesterday to Sean McCrary Moore, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Moore of Montrose, Colo. Canon Thomas N. Nisbett performed the Anglican ceremony at the Old Devonshire Church.

title: Swimming Warning Issued On L.I. After a Sewage Spill
description: Health officials warned against swimming along a 10-mile stretch of Long Island shore today after 15,000 gallons of sludge and effluent spilled into the bay waters of the southern shore.

title: Allen H. Seed Jr., 87; Led Anti-Litter Group
description: Allen H. Seed Jr., retired executive director of Keep America Beautiful, a national anti-litter organization, died apparently of natural causes in his sleep Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

title: Amgen Faces Challenges on Anemia Drug
description: Although Amgen Inc. won a major victory Thursday, when the Food and Drug Administration gave it exclusive permission to market the drug epoetin alfa, under the name Epogen, the company still faces two serious challenges to its patent position.

title: Letter: On Trade; Sugar Quota Our Exception, Their Rule
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Official in West Virginia Indicted on Extortion Counts
description: A former president of the State Senate has been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges that he extorted $15,000 from hotel officials who were lobbying for a law that would have allowed casino gambling in West Virginia.

title: A.B.A. to Resume Rating of Judicial Nominees
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today that he planned to resume the Justice Department's longstanding practice of having the American Bar Association evaluate judicial nominees.

title: The Hot Dollar Buys Trouble
description: LEAD: The dollar's recent surge means trouble ahead for the U.S. economy.

title: Water-Saving Toilets
description: To the Editor:

title: To His Audiences, North Is Still the Inspiring Freedom Fighter
description: ''Some have called me a hero, but I have never thought of myself as such,''

title: Panel Supports Gross On Misconduct Charges
description: A New York State medical panel has concluded that misconduct charges should be dropped against Dr. Elliot M. Gross, the former Chief Medical Examiner in New York City, the panel's chairman said today.

title: National Effect Seen in Ruling On Black Judicial Candidates
description: A Federal court ruling that judges were elected in Mississippi in a discriminatory manner is changing the racial makeup of the judiciary here. And because it is grounded in the Voting Rights Act, the ruling may affect many of the 37 other states that elect trial judges.

title: Germany's Jobless Rate
description: The number of unemployed people in West Germany, Europe's largest economy, fell below two million people in May for the first time in seven years, the Labor Minister, Dr. Norbert Blum, said today. Dr. Blum said that less than 1.95 million people were without work last month. The monthly unemployment figure is to be released officially on Tuesday.

title: Review/Dance; A Gala Spanning Two Worlds
description: A historic event in the dance world, the gala benefit held jointly by the Martha Graham Dance Company and American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday night, went beyond the now common truce between ballet and modern dance.

title: Vander Meer Remains The Pitcher of Record
description: Johnny Vander Meer threw consecutive no-hitters 51 years ago. His feat still hasn't been beaten.

title: Giants Obtain DeOssie
description: The Giants yesterday sent an undisclosed draft choice to the Dallas Cowboys in return for the reserve linebacker Steve DeOssie.

title: About New York; For Park Joggers, A Camaraderie Joins Wariness
description: Central Park was bathed in sunlight. A mounted policeman greeted a hot-dog vendor. In the distance, classical music could be heard. Joggers chugged round and round the Reservoir. A gray squirrel looked up, then stared as if witnessing something astonishing.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Mail-Order Houses Selling a Tax Revolt
description: Mail-order houses are including a new product in their catalogues this year: form letters or post cards to send to members of Congress, urging them to kill legislation that would raise the cost of most mail-order goods by up to 8 percent, a total of about $3 billion a year.

title: HDTV Subsidies Won't Revive U.S. Electronics
description: To the Editor:

title: Hollywood Park Suitor
description: Thomas W. Gamel, a Denver businessman, said today that he was considering seeking control of Hollywood Park Realty Enterprises Inc., the owner and operator of the Hollywood Park horse-racing track in Irvine, Calif.

title: Interest Rates Plunge on Jobs Data
description: Interest rates plunged yesterday as Treasury bond prices soared on the report of a much lower-than-expected rise in the number of nonfarm jobs created in May. Corporate bond prices followed suit, with top-grade long-term issues rising 1.5 points, or $15 per each $1,000 of face value.

title: Frederic Prokosch Is Dead at 81; Novelist and Portrayer of Literati
description: Frederic Prokosch, an American novelist and poet who wrote a score of books and also did translations from the Greek, French and German, died yesterday at his home in Plan de Grasse in the Alpes Maritimes in France, where he had lived for many years. He was 81 years old and was hospitalized a week ago as a result of a heart attack.

title: Magadan Jolts Pirates With Two-Run Homer in the 11th
description: Dave Magadan had reported to the ballpark early, had the batting cage put up, the tarps taken off. He wanted to hit, and he demanded that curveballs and fastballs be thrown at him. Magadan stood and stroked ball after ball into the outfield, content with what became a large collection of imaginary singles and doubles.

title: John McCauley, Hockey Official, 44
description: John McCauley, the director of officiating of the National Hockey League, died today from complications following surgery. He was 44 years old. Mr. McCauley joined the N.H.L. in 1970 and refereed for 10 seasons. He retired after an eye injury and was named the assistant director of officiating in May 1981. Five years later, he was named director of officiating.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Graf Rolls On: The rains came at noon yesterday in Paris, and Steffi Graf had just enough time to finish off Nicole Jagerman of the Netherlands, 6-1, 6-2, before play was suspended at the French Open. When play resumed about 6 P.M., Ronald Agenor of Haiti upset Tim Mayotte of the United States, 3-6, 7-5, 5-7, 7-5, 6-2, in a match that was suspended at dusk Thursday at 3-3 in the fourth game. Boris Becker advanced with a 7-5, 6-1, 6-2, rain-interrupted triumph over Jeremy Bates of Britain. Jay Berger of the United States got through to the final 16 with a 6-4, 6-4, 6-2 victory over Jaime Yzaga of Peru. Helen Kelesi of Canada beat Gretchen Magers of the United States, 6-4, 2-6, 6-3. COLLEGE BASEBALL Florida State 4, North Carolina 2: Top-seeded Florida State won the opening game of the College World Series in Omaha last night. The victory advanced the Seminoles (53-16) to the winners' bracket tomorrow night. North Carolina (41-17-1) will play an elimination-round game tomorrow afternoon.(AP) GOLF Blake Moves Ahead: Jay Don Blake matched the course record with a seven-under-par 64 yesterday and took a one-shot lead over Don Pooley after two rounds of the Kemper Open in Potomac, Md. Blake finished his second straight bogey-free round with three birdies in the final four holes on the 6,917-yard T.P.C. at Avenel course. His 36-hole total of 132 put him 10 strokes under par.(AP) King and Turner Lead: Betsy King and Sherri Turner shot three-under-par 69's yesterday to share the second-round lead at the L.P.G.A.'s Rochester International tournament in Pittsford, N.Y. Both were at five-under-par 139 after 36 holes. The first-round leader, Patty Sheehan, shot a 73 and dropped back into a tie for second place with Ayako Okamoto at 141.(AP) Player in Front: Gary Player shot a five-under-par-67 yesterday and a one-stroke lead in the Doug Sanders Classic in Houston. Al Geiberger and Bruce Devlin were tied for second at 68.(AP) ROWING Three More Advance: The heavyweight eights from Navy, Northeastern and U.C.L.A. won qualifying heats yesterday at the Intercollegiate Rowing Assocation regatta on Onondaga Lake at Syracuse. Those victors in the repechage, or second-chance, heats will join Cornell, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin, winners Thursday, in the championships today. CYCLING Colombian Wins in Italy: Luis Herrera of Colombia took the grueling 13th stage of the Tour of Italy yesterday, arriving alone in Tre Cime di Lavaredo in the Dolomite mountains. Erik Breukink of the Netherlands, who placed third in the stage, retained the pink jersey as the overall leader.(AP)

title: Frank B. Hall to Pay $48 Million to Settle Dispute
description: New York State and Frank B. Hall & Company said yesterday that they had reached a $48 million agreement to settle an insurance lawsuit that encouraged state regulators to push for more stringent rules on the industry.

title: Atalanta-Sosnoff Buys Airline Stake
description: An investment group led by the Atalanta-Sosnoff Capital Corporation, a New York money management concern controlled by Martin T. Sosnoff, has bought the equivalent of an 8.46 percent stake in America West Airlines Inc. for $17.7 million. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Sosnoff said the America West shares were for investment purposes only.

title: Red Tape, Not Red Tide, Shutting Shellfish Beds
description: Medical waste on beaches and bacteria in the water scared a lot of people away from Long Island Sound seafood last summer. This year's plague is paperwork.

title: Marvin Mitchelson Wins Suit Involving Accusation of Rape
description: A Superior Court jury has returned a verdict in favor of the well-known divorce lawyer Marvin Mitchelson in a $7 million civil suit filed by a woman who accused him of raping her.

title: Steep Drop For Dollar On Job Data
description: The dollar plummeted yesterday in a surprisingly sharp reaction to the weaker-than-expected employment report for May. It fell almost 4 pfennigs against the West German mark and 2 Japanese yen.

title: Group Purchases 7.1% Of Aristech Chemical
description: A group of investors led by Jon M. Huntsman, the owner of the largest private chemical company in the United States, said yesterday that it had acquired 7.1 percent of the shares of the Aristech Chemical Corporation and had approached the company's management about possibly selling one or more subsidiaries.

title: F.D.R. Drive Is Called Safe As Structural Tests Continue
description: Workers tested a quarter-mile stretch of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive near 21st Street in Manhattan yesterday, searching for signs of dangerous structural damage after a concrete slab fell from the underside of the elevated highway Thursday night and killed a driver below.

title: Jewish Settlers' Anger Turning Violent
description: When his 5-year-old son was hit in the head with a rock a little over a year ago, Rafi Ben-Hur said, there was grief and anger in this Jewish settlement close to Jerusalem, but no mass retribution against the nearby Arab village where the rock was thrown.

title: MacLeod Won't Take Job as Coach of Knicks
description: The Knicks yesterday lost the coach they really wanted.

title: Variety and Specials in a Cozy Setting
description: A RESTAURANT with a purple neon sign proclaiming ''Wine and Roses'' has a laid back 1960's sound to it. But nothing could be further from the truth at this small place on Main Street in Old Saybrook, which seems to be a model of efficiency. In limited space with elbow-to-elbow tables and diners waiting to be seated, a no-nonsense staff manages to serve successions of courses with no undue delays.

title: Scott Seaton and Diana Ford Married
description: At Holy Trinity Church in Guildford, England, Diana Frances Ford, a daughter of Sir John Ford of Guildford and the late Emaline Lady Ford, was married yesterday to Scott Ward Seaton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Seaton of Pepper Pike, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth Stevenson, an Anglican minister, and the Rev. Donald Seaton, an Episcopal minister who is an uncle of the bridegroom, officiated.

title: 30 Artists Show Off Their Scrappy and Their Junky
description: AT the moment, visitors to the Whitney Museum in Stamford are finding its main gallery dominated by what is manifestly a heap of old wood. Yet, the way the beams, lashed together with chains, stand their ground in the pristine, almost airtight setting of this museum proclaims them to be a work of art, and by no less a sculptor than Mark di Suvero. Besides, where else but in an art museum would so ambiguous a pile be given house room?

title: ISRAEL: MIRED IN THE WEST BANK
description: Thomas Friedman writes that the Jews in Israel are ''paralyzed by a deep fatalism seeping up from the depths of Jewish history.''

title: Linking Culture And Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Wotan Is On Top of the Heap
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Bush's Leap Toward Leadership
description: Before President Bush departed for Europe just over a week ago, he was widely and justly criticized for the lack of courage, vision and content in his policy for NATO and East-West relations. Now he has returned as a conquering hero, a world statesman. How did he accomplish this meta-morphosis?

title: Finding the Time to Listen
description: ''MOM, you never listen!'' shouted Kristin, our oldest daughter. We were sitting around the dinner table - my husband and I, plus our three daughters and our French exchange student. I was grateful to have us all together - shared dinner hours are rare these days.

title: Philadelphia Is Developing a Lost Waterfront
description: After 30 years of false starts, the city has chosen a developer for a riverfront section to rival the great waterfronts of cities like Baltimore, New York and Boston.

title: Mike Schmidt and the Good Now Days
description: He was batting .203 with six homers, but when his glove also betrayed him, Mike Schmidt knew it was time. With two on and two out in a 3-3 game in San Francisco a week ago, the Phillies' third baseman booted a grounder for what would have been the third out, a grounder he would have once handled routinely. When the next hitter, Will Clark, smashed a grand-slam homer, the Phillies were on their way to an 8-5 loss. And at age 39, Mike Schmidt decided that he won't be playing baseball anymore. It's baseball's loss, not his. Too many baseball fans yearn for the good old days, as if nobody playing now could possibly be as good as the old-timers. But too many baseball fans don't always appreciate the good now days. Over nearly two decades, Mike Schmidt was the third baseman of the good now days. While accumulating three National League most valuable player awards, he hit 548 homers and was voted 10 Gold Gloves. No other third baseman ever did what he did with both his bat and his glove. Not Brooks Robinson, not Eddie Mathews, not Pie Traynor.

title: A Foreign Push for U.S. Patents
description: Hardly a day goes by without somebody voicing concern about America's deteriorating ability to compete in world markets. Japan and other Pacific Rim countries now dominate the manufacture of videocassette recorders, cameras and many other consumer electronics goods. Japanese companies make about one-quarter of the cars sold in the United States.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Unwinding the Regulatory Red Tape
description: LEAD: A DWINDLING supply of available land, increasing environmental constraints and regulatory delays have made development in New Jersey complicated and risky and have driven up the cost of doing business, many developers say.

title: Elisabeth Bittner Wed
description: The wedding of Elisabeth Anne Bittner, an associate at the First Boston Corporation, and Chansoo Joung, an associate at Goldman, Sachs & Company, both in New York, took place yesterday in Woodstock, Vt. The Rev. Norman Brower officiated at the First Congregational Church. The bride, who will keep her name, is a daughter of Dr. N. Douglas Bittner of Peapack, N.J., and Dorothy P. Bittner of Basking Ridge, N.J. She graduated from Yale University. She and her husband, a graduate of Dartmouth College, received M.B.A. degrees from Dartmouth in 1987. Mr. Joung is the son of Julia S. Brown of Evanston, Ill., and Chan Soo Joung of Chicago.

title: Where to Turn for Help
description: THERE is ample opportunity in the county to learn about AIDS prevention and to obtain a confidential test that would determine if one has the human immunodeficiency virus that causes AIDS, according to health officials.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: Of all the bells and whistles that have been added to single-lens-reflex cameras in the past five years, none has arrived more quitely than built-in electronic flash. On auto-focusing cameras like the Canon 750, Nikon 4004S and Pentax SF 10, the flash sits snuggly within the pentaprisms, which are slightly wider than on conventional SLRs.

title: Kiwis, Koalas, And Proper Names
description: I RECENTLY learned just how callous and ignorant educated Americans may be about national and religious symbolism of others. And how arrogant they can be in justifying themselves.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The latex paint on the wood trim in my entrance hall has started to blister and peel. This paint was applied a number of years ago over the original oil paint put on 39 years ago. I believe there are two coats of latex. Where the paint has peeled, the original oil paint, which was a different color, is intact. Can you suggest a cause for this peeling and a way to prevent it in the future?

title: WASP'S IN FLIGHT
description: CRASHING THE GATES The De-WASPing of America's Power Elite. By Robert C. Christopher. 304 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95 Readers of a certain age will recall the inevitable moment in films dealing with World War II and the Korean War when the crusty platoon sergeant reeled off the roll-call, which inevitably went something like this: ''Carducci; Ginsberg; Gzymzywicz; Jones, Frank; Jones, Washington Jefferson; Van Rensselaer'' and so on. It is an image that Robert C. Christopher, a former editor at Time and Newsweek and now the administrator of the Pulitzer Prizes, deploys in ''Crashing the Gates,'' a comprehensive survey of the changing stratification of power in American culture and society.

title: Conventional Camcorders March On
description: The advanced camcorders discussed in this column on May 21 may well turn out to be the future standard; but, as newcomers on the block, they have so far gained only scant acceptance. Only a small percentage of current sales involve models with the new image-recording methods of Hi8 and Super-VHS.

title: New Tack Proposed on Auto Insurance
description: LEAD: IN mid-April, Citizens Auto Revolt, a coalition of two citizen advocacy groups, announced a campaign to let New Jersey voters vent their frustration over soaring automobile insurance premiums. The coalition proposed a nonbinding referendum asking voters in November to approve a 20 percent rollback of current automobile insurance rates.

title: 20,000 Israelis Protest Assaults on Arabs
description: About 20,000 Israelis, many of them from left-wing parties and peace movements, demonstrated tonight in central Tel Aviv against what some termed lawlessness and violence by Jews in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Freehold $183,226 21 Stokes Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 43-year-old colonial; enclosed porch, den, full basement; taxes $2,325. Mahwah $157,900 23 Island Road 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; pool, eat-in-kitchen, w/w carpeting; taxes $1,135. Neptune Township $119,900 4 Dianne Drive 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old split level; den, patio, fenced yard; taxes $2,631. Point Pleasant $189,900 118 New York Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 23-year-old ranch; dining room, porch, 1-car garage; taxes $1,859. Roseland $208,000 27 Second Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 47-year-old Cape Cod; full basement, eat-in-kitchen, recently remodeled; taxes $2,020. Teaneck $208,500 146 Lindbergh Boulevard 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 50-year-old Tudor; fireplace, new kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,116. OTHER AREAS Goldens Bridge, N.Y. $417,500 Apache Circle 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old contemporary; family room w/fireplace, 2-car garage, 1.13 acres; taxes $7,500. Brookfield, Conn. $166,000 41 Woodview Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; mint condition, family neighborhood, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,342. Commack, L.I. $164,000 2 Barley Place 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 29-year-old split level; den, dining room, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: After the advent of Jose Raul Capablanca, the brilliant Cuban who held the world championship from his defeat of Emanuel Lasker in Havana in 1921 to his defeat by Alexander Alekhine in Buenos Aires in 1927, the old quantitative idea of mobilizing the pieces was scorned as primitive. No longer could anyone just ''get 'em out as fast as you can'' and worry later about what to do with them in the middle game. Yet every once in a while, quantitative development seems to work. Capablanca had turned what had been considered elementary by strong players into an immensely sophisticated process involving the strategy of the whole game. His idea of qualitative development often required a slowing of the entrance of the minor pieces into the battle in favor of a delicate, positional queen move. Sometimes it was necessary to break off development for a preventive pawn move. His underlying thought was that the pieces should not just come out, but come out with some strategic aim. The eventual goal was harmonious cooperation in an attack.

title: Muffling the Interstates by Walling In Their Noise
description: LEAD: AN Interstate highway, with its traffic noise and the glare of vehicles' headlights, does not mix well with a residential neighborhood. Connecticut is increasingly fencing the two apart, under a long-term project to put high wooden walls between superhighways and dwellings. The response has been largely, though not universally, favorable.

title: Child's Garden of Vs.
description: How do you pronounce the >v. in >Roe v. Wade?

title: Rohatyn Warns of City Crisis Worse Than in 70's
description: Offering a gloomily unsettling vision of New York City's future, Felix G. Rohatyn said Friday that he believed the fiscal crisis of the late 1970's might seem ''benign'' compared to what the city is likely to endure in the next five years.

title: An Off-Season Swing in the Caribbean
description: During July and August in the French West Indies, it seems as if the only items not on sale are the pina colada and the rum punch. The summer months in the Caribbean are only a part of a prolonged off-season. The official low season stretches from mid-April, post-Eastertime, to mid-December, pre-Christmastime. On just about all of the islands, these eight months are celebrated by bargain rates and special vacation packages. Hotels and resorts cut their room prices, often by nearly 50 percent. Airlines seek to fill seats by lowering fares. Windsurfing concessions lower their rates, about $8 an hour instead of $12, and jewelry and souvenir shops offer reductions. Now, some island associations are trying to convince restaurants to join in the markdowns.

title: Vacancies Halt New York Thruway Authority
description: The New York State Thruway Authority, in the midst of a $1.7 billion reconstruction program, is unable to take any significant actions because of a political dispute over filling two vacancies on its three-member board.

title: Blame Walker, Knick Fans
description: Kenny Walker, the former Kentucky basketball star, was one of Rick Pitino's confidants during the past few weeks as Pitino considered an offer to become the Wildcats' coach.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bayport $158,000 273 Oakwood Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,300. Commack $164,000 2 Barley Place 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 29- year-old split level; den, dining room, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. Massapequa $178,000 97 Joludow Drive 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 28- year-old Cape Cod; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. Roslyn Heights $217,000 29 McGregor Avenue 3-bedroom, 1- bath, 52-year-old Cape Cod; family room, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $1,600. Sayville $242,000 23 Sunset Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old ranch; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, dining room; taxes $4,200. Westbury $230,000 190 Rhododendron Drive 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; fireplace, finished basement, 2- car garage; taxes $5,500. OTHER AREAS Goldens Bridge, N.Y. $417,500 Apache Circle 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old contemporary; family room w/fireplace, 2-car garage, 1.13 acres; taxes $7,500. Brookfield, Conn. $166,000 41 Woodview Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; mint condition, family neighborhood, 0.5 acre; taxes, $1342. Mahwah, N.J. $157,900 23 Island Road 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; pool, eat-in-kitchen, w/w carpeting; taxes $1,135.

title: Completely and Believably Someone Else
description: Meryl Streep, unlike most film actresses, doesn't bend her personality gently in the direction of a role. She invents her characters from scratch, creating an entirely different physical vocabulary for each part. One comes away from her performances with the sense of people who are much more than well-observed types. Each is a complex, quirky little universe.

title: Stranger Off a Train
description: SOME TIME AGO, ignoring signs of a marriage in trouble, my small family and I took a train trip to San Antonio with a friend. It was a way to incorporate many things into one vacation, many different needs and opposing ideas of what constitutes a good time. Once on a train, there comes a kind of safety, in the way a caged bird feels safety, I suppose. Trains are like islands in that way. If you've ever lived on an island, you know the curious security that comes of being isolated with others. Whatever their ilk or mettle, they are stuck with you and you with them for the duration.

title: AWOL Discharge Is Sought
description: A sailor who went absent without leave during the Vietnam War 20 years ago comes from ''a different era'' and should not be court-martialed, his lawyer said Friday at a hearing.

title: And the Music Goes On . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Ici Se Habla Euro-English
description: Europe is entering its Berlitz era of movie making. Language in the form of demotic speech is at the barricades.

title: Soviet Doctor Says Sloppy Care Spread AIDS Virus to 73 in 2 Cities
description: A top Soviet health official today described in detail the extraordinary story of how the AIDS virus spread through one hospital's pediatric unit and then leaped to a hospital in another city.

title: Charges Against Bronx Judge Stun the Community That Esteemed Him
description: The sadness of the situation was obvious: Here was William T. Martin, New York State's youngest Supreme Court justice - a man who appeared to be committed to his community, a hard-working judge with a bright future - standing before the bar, accused of perjury, tax evasion and distributing drugs. How had it come to this? If people within the limestone monolith that is the Bronx courthouse had any answer, they were not forthcoming last week. Several insiders said there had been rumors of a Federal investigation even before Justice Martin was nominated for the judgeship in September 1987. But none would speak about it on the record.

title: WHOSE SAINT IS HE, ANYWAY?
description: THE POLITICS OF LITERARY REPUTATION The Making and Claiming of ''St. George'' Orwell. By John Rodden. Illustrated. 478 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $27.50.

title: Correction
description: An article on May 14 about the Clean Air Act misstated the amount being spent, largely by private interests, to control air pollution in the United States. It is $35 billion a year, not $35 million.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: William and Mary; Rules Are Shifted To Ease the Filing Of Rape Reports
description: Responding to reports of date rape and pressure from women's rights groups here to do something about it, the administration of the College of William and Mary last week changed its procedures to make it easier for the victim to press charges. The changes also provide stiff penalties, including permanent dismissal for offenders.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The latex paint on the wood trim in my entrance hall has started to blister and peel. This paint was applied a number of years ago over the original oil paint put on 39 years ago. I believe there are two coats of latex. Where the paint has peeled, the original oil paint, which was a different color, is intact. Can you suggest a cause for this peeling and a way to prevent it in the future?

title: Review/Dance; Martins's Folk-Inspired 'Songs of the Auvergne'
description: Peter Martins choreographed a strange ballet in 1986, inspired by a well-known group of folk songs that a modern French composer, Marie-Joseph Canteloube, had collected in his native province and orchestrated.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: A WORLD OF IDEAS: Conversations With Thoughtful Men and Women About American Life Today and the Ideas Shaping Our Future. By Bill Moyers. Edited by Betty Sue Flowers. (Doubleday, Cloth, $29.95; Paper, $19.95.) Forty-one interviews, well-edited transcripts from the recent public television series of the same name, compose ''A World of Ideas.

title: Yugoslav Teen-Ager Tops Garrison
description: Remember when little Chrissie Evert shook up conventional tennis with her two-fisted backhand, then an unconventional shot?

title: Salvadoran Rebels Reject New Offer for Talks
description: Leftist rebels today spurned the new president's proposal for a dialogue, dismissing it as a call to capitulate.

title: Scientists Share Data At Speed Of Light
description: IN the hills above Berkeley, Calif., a physicist, Peter Trower, sat at his computer terminal recently and watched an experiment that was being conducted half a world away, in a research center next to a nuclear reactor in Pavia, Italy.

title: Clean Hands in Tom Foley's House
description: To help the House bind its wounds. To guide it back to a public-policy focus. To address ethical problems. These are the announced priorities of the new Speaker, Representative Tom Foley of Washington, in the wake of last week's leadership upheavals, and he lists them in that order.

title: Baseball Anecdotes
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
Warhol Legacy for the East End
description: LEAD: IT seems appropriate that Andy Warhol's work is the first that visitors see in Guild Hall's current silk-screen exhibition, for the art he left behind offers one of the strongest arguments for that image-making technique.

title: England's Merry Morris Men
description: THE dancers assemble at midmorning by the ancient parish church of Thaxted, a village in Essex. Inheritors of one of England's finest and oldest folk traditions - Morris dancing or, simply, the Morris - the men are clad in spotless white pants and shirts, sturdy black shoes and red vests. Their shins are covered with pads, sometimes called ruggles, that are lined with small silver bells. On their heads they wear straw Panama hats, adorned with streaming ribbons and brightly hued spring blossoms. One of an estimated 500 such groups in Britain, they have gathered to perform for the village.

title: Nurse Held in Painkiller Theft
description: A hospital nurse has been charged with stealing narcotic painkillers meant for patients who were injected instead with an ineffective saline solution. The nurse, Thomas L. Knight, 38 years old, was charged May 19 with misdemeanor theft and released on $500 bond, the police said Friday. Mr. Knight, who worked at Washington County Hospital from April 1988 until his arrest, denies the charges.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: Today is an obscure anniversary. A recent find in a dealer's box at a stamp show in Cleveland turned up an obscure commemoration thereof, written in an obscure language.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. in Afghan Shift

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Paris Hotels Booked Solid For Summer

title: An Anxious Philips
description: Cornelis Van Der Klugt's goal in life is to insure that Philips N.V., Europe's largest electronics company, avoids the fate of the many American companies that dropped out of the consumer electronics business because they could not stand the heat of Japanese competition.

title: Sarah Keohane Becomes a Bride In Massachusetts
description: Sarah Elizabeth Keohane, the daughter of Robert Owen Keohane of Wellesley, Mass., and Ann Wright Keohane of Franklin, N.C., was married yesterday in Wellesley to Mark Neville Williamson, the son of Margaret Williamson of Norwich, England. The Rev. J. John Keggi performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: Fiery Finale for an Art Deco Palace Hollywood Dreams Were Made On
description: Preservationists here are wringing their hands over the destruction of the Pan Pacific Auditorium, a rare icon of a glamorous, idealized age when Hollywood was wholesome, the air was clean and a huge brown derby actually sat on top of the Brown Derby.

title: Ratepayers' Rebellion Is Not Far Off
description: ''Shoreham: Pressures and Prospects'' [ May 14 ] was fair and objective. However, the existing litigation to have the Cuomo-Lilco agreement declared invalid and the recent introduction by Governor Cuomo of legislation to try to legalize the Long Island Power Authority's taking title to Shoreham should be added to the pressures and prospects.

title: Sprint Past Wisconsin Gives Penn I.R.A. Title
description: A closing burst by the Pennsylvania crew caught Wisconsin in the last four strokes of the varsity race today at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's regatta here on Onondaga Lake.

title: The Allure of Milan and London
description: IT WOULD BE ALL TOO EASY TO DISMISS LONDON and Milan as second cities - once-celebrated fashion capitals whose offerings these days pale in the blaze of French creativity. Easy, and shortsighted too, since each remains a mecca to fashion watchers, who look at London for trendy ideas and Milan for the sort of refined innovation that ultimately finds its way into fashion's mainstream.

title: Bryan O. Colley And Miss Gates Exchange Vows
description: Sarah Livingstone Gates, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Sanford Gates of Lake Forest, Ill., was married yesterday to Bryan Omer Colley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Omer Colley of North Salem, N.Y., and Southampton, Bermuda. The Rev. J. Clark Grew performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Church of the Holy Spirit in Lake Forest, assisted by the Episcopal Bishop of Chicago, Frank Tracey Griswold 3d.

title: Signs of Intelligent Life in the Theater Bill Irwin and friends in ''Largely New York'' (Joan Marcus); Joan Allen and Boyd Gaines in ''The Heidi Chronicles'' (Peter Cunningham)
description: Since every New York tHEATER SEASON IS the worst in history, why should the one just concluded have been any different?

title: South African Economy Grows Political
description: A chance remark recently by Deputy Finance Minister Georg Marais created a furor here that had nothing to do with race, the central issue of white politics. Mr. Marais assured Parliament that white South Africans were on average no worse off economically than they had been 20 years ago.

title: NONFICTION
description: WOMEN OF THERESIENSTADT: Voices From a Concentration Camp. Edited by Ruth Schwertfeger. (Berg/St. Martin's, $22.) It has been said that ''If Auschwitz was hell, Theresienstadt was the anteroom.'' While deprivation, disease and death were commonplace (during one period 150 people died each day), the camp, located in Czechoslovakia, was used as a showplace to persuade international organizations that the Jews were being well cared for. To perpetuate this facade prisoners were allowed, at times even encouraged, to participate in cultural activities. After brutal days of physical labor there were poetry readings, lectures on literature and philosophy, and even opera productions in the barracks. For many people art became a strategy of survival. In 1944, for example, there was a poetry competition and of the then 37,000 inmates, 3,000 submitted poems. And that was only in German. Ruth Schwertfeger, an assistant professor of German at the University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee, has translated and edited the poetry and memoirs of Theresienstadt's women. Their writing on children, loss, death and hope are powerful documents - certainly nothing that the Nazis planned for when they sponsored poetry contests. The worst fear of life in Theresienstadt was transport to the east, which meant Auschwitz. Ilse Blumenthal-Weiss wrote of the farewell from her husband, ''And now without you I go towards you / And bear your death across a wide world.'' In her poem ''Resonance,'' another survivor, Gerty Spies, writes eloquently of living with her memories: ''The chains lie now / At my feet and I am free / But now I know / How heavy freedom weighs on me.''

title: Sunday Dinner Together
description: WHEN I tell my peers - grandparents, that is - of how our children and their families come to our house on Sundays for an old fashioned middle-of-the-day Sunday dinner, they look at me in disbelief.

title: Dressing for Soft Summer Nights
description: After a day on the boat or the beach comes dinner on the patio, at the country club or at the newest bistro. After that, perhaps dancing under the stars. What do you wear?

title: Question Of the Week; Should Contracts Be Honored Or Ignored?
description: Should contracts be honored or ignored? What a sad and revealing question it is. We witness the decay of the human pride and decency of truth, loyalty, honesty, fair play and trust. We wonder at the loss of faith in the democratic system. We hope that our children will grow to be good citizens, whatever that means anymore, and yet we can even ask if a contract (''a binding agreement between two or more persons or parties'' Merriam Websters definition 1) should be honored.

title: How World War III Was Averted
description: It may have been Stengelian poetic license, but Casey used to say that every baseball game contains something you never saw before. This capacity for surprise is precisely why baseball is . . . . Aw, but you've heard me say that before.

title: Nancy Corey Weds D. J. Ives
description: Nancy Ann Corey and David John Ives were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin in Chappaqua, N.Y., by the Rev. William Harper. Mrs. Ives, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall T. Corey of Armonk, N.Y., is a commercial insurance broker with Alexander & Alexander in New York. Mr. Ives, the son of Betty P. Berry of Franklin, Tenn., and the late Col. Albert R. Ives, U.S.A. retired, is the owner of Victory Systems Associates, computer consultants in New York.

title:
FOCUS: Hollywood;
A 'Town' of Comebacks Is Making One
description: LEAD: IN an effort to recapture some of the feeling of its heyday as the dream capital of the world, Hollywood is taking its first concrete steps toward a commercial renewal. But developers say that, like any great star's comeback, this one could take almost as long as the original climb to glory.

title: DATA BANK: June 4, 1989
CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: 'GOING TO DEMOCRACY'
description: CHINA IN SEARCH OF ITS FUTURE Years of Great Reform, 1982-87. By John Woodruff. Illustrated. 218 pages. Seattle: University of Washington Press.

title: A One-Two Punch at Education
description: Public education in New York City is reeling from two blows in one month. The first, the death of Schools Chancellor Richard Green, was stunningly unexpected. The second was regrettably predictable: the outcome of the recent school board elections. Only 6 percent of eligible voters went to the polls, the lowest turnout in a history of low turnouts. Then it took fully three weeks to determine who won, and even then, some of the winners were those charged with mismanagement and improprieties.

title: ROAD STILL CLOSED BELOW F.D.R. DRIVE
description: Traffic is expected to be normal for the rush hour tomorrow on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive - but not below it, in the area where a concrete slab fell and killed a driver Thursday night, city Transportation Department officials said yesterday.

title: The Question in New Jersey's Campaign: Can the Voters Learn to Like James Florio?
description: WITH voters going to the polls Tuesday to nominate two candidates for governor of New Jersey, the most important issues in the race may turn out to be the personalities of the people who are running.

title: Pamela Copeland Biddle, a Student, Is Wed to Joel E. Fishman, an Editor
description: Pamela Copeland Biddle, a daughter of Mrs. Robert W. Duemling of Washington and James Biddle of Andalusia, Pa., was married yesterday to Joel E. Fishman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Fishman of North Woodmere, L.I. Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman and the Rev. Gregory Straub, an Episcopal minister, officiated at the home of the bride's father.

title: ISRAEL: MIRED IN THE WEST BANK
description: Thomas L. Friedman's call for bold moves by Israeli politicians exposes his American cultural impatience, which is out of sync with the Middle East (''Israel: Mired in the West Bank: The Politicians;'' ''The Soldiers,'' by Joel Brinkley, May 7). The Arab world has not yet accepted the United Nations resolutions of 1947 to establish the State of Israel. Egypt took a bold step in establishing relations with Israel. The ensuing minor dispute over a tiny piece of land (Taba) of no social, economic or military value has taken a decade to resolve.

title: For Congress, Money Is the Root of Evil and Re-election
description: WHILE Speaker Jim Wright was in the well of the House of Representatives last week announcing his resignation, the Congressmen on the back benches were reflecting on the ethics of the system in which they live and work. Many, possibly most, concluded that aspects of it, if not absolutely corrupt, are inherently questionable.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months.

title: Political Price Rises for Mayor Of Los Angeles
description: Adversity is engulfing the proud Mayor of Los Angeles, Tom Bradley, who rose from rural poverty to lead the nation's second largest city. His is the story of a man puzzled and angered that the admiration he had long enjoyed has turned into criticism, skepticism and even criminal investigation.

title: Brooke Buckley Becomes a Bride In Pennsylvania
description: Ann Brooke Buckley and Thomas Anderson Ashforth were married yesterday at the Cathedral Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, Pa., by the Rev. John R. Coble, an Episcopal priest. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Donald George Leahan of Newtown Square, Pa., and Walter White Buckley Jr. of Bethlehem. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Ashforth Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Peru, Vt.

title: Half-Court Game Needs Attention
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Why H.U.D. Has Been So Inviting To So Many
description: FOR the Department of Housing and Urban Development, scandal is all too familiar.

title: Canada's St. Andrews by the Sea
description: By 6:40 the sun's been up for two hours in St. Andrews, New Brunswick, yet still its strange, boreal light looms low on the horizon. The surrounding hills, covered with coniferous forest and checkered with tawny fields, roll to a granite shoreline gouged 10,000 years ago by receding glaciers. On the water, a few wisps of morning sea smoke drift in raggedly from Fundy Bay; they'll soon burn off as daylight stirs the crisp night air. Vaguely, this June morning, one can make out the glint of white lobster boats heading out from nearby island villages to tend their traps. Nearer to shore, other boats are bobbing silently around the herring weirs - Indian fishing mazes spun from cedar poles and kelp-tattered netting. St. Andrews, about three hours north of Bar Harbor and minutes past Maine's easternmost coastal border, lies at the heart of the Maritimes, deep in a baffle of islands and coves known as the Fundy Tidal Region.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
NOVELIST WITH CAMERA
description: LEAD: Emile Zola took up photography late in life. His major fiction had been written by the time he began taking most of the thousands of pictures from which his grandson Francois Emile-Zola and the French art director Massin have made their selection for ZOLA: Photographer (Seaver/Holt, $29.95). A few pictures - one of a pair of fisherfolk, barely distinguishable as to sex, bent over their nets in the muddy waters of the port of Le Havre, another of a team of shabbily dressed men sweeping manure from an alley in the Parc Monceau with a policeman looking on - are suggestive of what

title: Savory Street Food of Istanbul
description: CLOSE your eyes and try to call forth the sounds of Turkey. Surely you hear the muezzin's ancient call to prayer from atop the minarets. Were you there, you might also hear a sound just as ancient, the the street hawker's call to food. Pushcarts are a way of life in Turkey, and nowhere is this truer than in Istanbul. The city's streets are teeming with vendors pushing food carts through the narrow, winding streets, hawking everything from melon seeds to crepelike pastries called borek. Most street food here is surprisingly fresh, tasty and attractively displayed.

title: Miss Huber Wed To W. R. Gaffey
description: The wedding of Catherine Hurley Huber, a daughter of Hans Anthony Huber of Rumson, N.J., and Mrs. Robert C. Stanley Jr. of Middletown, N.J., to William Robert Gaffey, a son of Mrs. Howard Gaffey of Atlantic Highlands, N.J., and the late Mr. Gaffey, took place yesterday. The Rev. Foster Wilson performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of Rumson.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: FESTIVAL OF BOATS

title: Hollywood's Indy Envy
description: Keeping up with the Joneses has taken on new meaning in Hollywood. In this case it is a trilogy of adventure movies about Indiana Jones, the intrepid archeologist, that has other movie makers envious. Last weekend, the latest tale, ''Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade,'' became the first movie to sell $10 million worth of tickets on a single day, grossing a record $46.9 million in its first six days. The previous record? ''Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom,'' which grossed $42.2 million in 1984.

title: State Dept. Backs Off From View That Contra Aid Plan Was Killed
description: A State Department official has backed away from his testimony that the Reagan Administration scrapped a 1985 plan to link aid to Honduras to that country's help for the contras, a Congressman says.

title: Lapses Found in Handling of Iran-Contra Material
description: Inquiries by the House and Senate Intelligence Committees have found some lapses in the Reagan Administration's handling of documents related to the Iran-contra affair. But investigators have found no evidence to date that the White House deliberately withheld material dating from the 1987 inquiry, Congressional officials said.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: MAIN STREET IN WESTPORT;
In Transformed Downtown, a Conflict Over Success and Community
description: LEAD: AS he took patio furniture to the sidewalk outside his store one recent afternoon, Steven Blasbalg, the owner of Westport Hardware, said he was holding what would likely be his last preseason furniture sale. Mr. Blasbalg said he plans to close the store by October, when his lease expires. Rents for store on Main Street, he said, ''are chasing all the individually owned stores out of Westport.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: A PLACE AT THE TABLE. By Edith Konecky. (Random House, $16.95.) Rachel Levin is pushing 60 and fighting cancer. A divorced mother of two and a moderately successful New York writer, she is also smart, funny, generous and, above all else, clear-eyed. She has given up what illusions she once had and now sees herself and the people in her life with honesty, compassion and affection.

title: Margaret Quinn, Physician, Weds
description: Dr. Margaret Mary Quinn and Daumant Robert Kusma were married yesterday at St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J. Msgr. John E. Grimes performed the ceremony, assisted by Bishop Edward U. Kmiec, the Auxiliary Bishop of Trenton, and the Rev. Walter J. Burghardt.

title: Yankees Miss Their Opportunities and Get Shut Out Again
description: It is like a waiting game. Dallas Green believes the Yankees will eventually awake, as if from a seasonlong spell, and begin to hit and score runs and win games and contend. But night after night, they disappoint their manager.

title: Pioneering Programs In Hospice Care
description: When reading the article on the hospice movement in New Jersey (''Efforts Are Under Way to Expand Hospice Care,'' April 30), I was surprised to find no mention of the pioneering Riverside Hospice in Boonton, N.J.

title: Laura C. Scott Weds Raymond J. Auch
description: Laura Cumming Scott, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Scott Jr. of Little Silver, N.J., was married yesterday to Raymond Joseph Auch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Auch of Berkeley Heights, N.J. The Rev. Robert T. Griner performed the ceremony at St. George's Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J.

title: An Ideal Capsule For Bad Weather
description: I have seen the rain.

title: BUT SOME BOOKS ARE STILL BAD
description: CONTINGENCIES OF VALUE Alternative Perspectives for Critical Theory. By Barbara Herrnstein Smith. 229 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $22.50.

title: PRESIDENT ASSAILS SHOOTINGS IN CHINA
