description: President Bush said today that he deeply deplored the shooting of protesters by Chinese troops.

title: From Scotland by Way of India: Richly Colorful Paisley Shawls
description: WHEN I first made the acquaintance of Paisley shawls some 30 years ago, I thought they were made to drape over pianos. The glowing, gemlike colors - black and turquoise, mustard and plum, ruby and white - and intricate, tapering forms of my first shawl, with its black center and fringed borders, would have been a fitting addition to a Victorian parlor. But in fact the development of the Paisley shawl closely followed the lines of 19th-century fashion, and when fashion no longer allowed itself to be covered by an all-enveloping, untailored expanse of cloth, the Paisley shawl faded into the obscurity of closets and trunks, revived in the last 10 years by ardent collectors of Victoriana.

title: 3 Pianists and a Baritone in Recitals
description: Deborah Bradley

title: To Sci-Fi Writers Hollywood Is Mostly Alien
description: When William Shatner pressured Paramount Pictures into letting him direct the new $32 million production ''Star Trek V: The Final Frontier,'' opening Friday (by threatening not to appear in it otherwise), he knew its performance would be measured against the benchmark set by his shipmate Leonard Nimoy, who directed the highly successful 1986 release ''Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home.''

title: Hong Kong Adds Spice To Protests
description: Days ago, just before dawn, more than 100 nightclub hostesses, still wearing the bright, provocative clothes of their trade, staged a demonstration in front of the New China News Agency, the de facto Chinese consulate here. They arrived in sleek sedans and taxis, and marched in front of the office building, carrying banners and calling for democracy.

title: Miss Anderson Plans to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Peter Anderson of Ambler, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Pirrall Anderson, to Joseph Anthony Califano 3d, a son of Mr. Califano Jr. and Trudy Kendrew, both of Washington.

title: When Listomania Strikes
description: THE reason you are reading this is that I had it down on my list of things to do and had to cross it off. Just had to. I was beginning to feel feverish, my hands were trembling, I couldn't concentrate on the simplest tasks. What was the problem? Well, you see, I am a listomaniac.

title: Margot H. Ladd And Sean Brady Exchange Vows
description: The First Congregational Church in Madison, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Margot Heminway Ladd, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Delano W. Ladd Jr. of Greenwich and Madison, to Sean P. Brady, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Brady of Hingham, Mass. The Rev. Winthrop E. Stone officiated.

title: 18th-Century Desk Sold For Record $12.1 Million
description: An elaborately carved 18th-century American desk was bought yesterday by a New York antiques dealer for $12.1 million, the highest price ever paid at auction for an object other than a painting.

title: Family Ties
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary Ellmann, Literary Critic, Dies at 68
description: Mary Ellmann, a writer, died of a cerebral hemorrhage yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital in Oxford, England, where she lived. She was 68 years old.

title: Correction
description: A caption on the music page of the Arts and Leisure section today gives an incorrect date for a concert of 20th-century works at Alice Tully Hall. It will be on Friday, not tonight.

title: Dishing About Divas and Other Opera Chat
description: Terrence McNally has other and more substantive claims to distinction, but he is proud to say that he knew Callas when. Not knew her personally - he didn't - but he was a fan, or let us say a thoughtful admirer of her singing, in the early 1950's when he was a high school student in Corpus Christi, Tex., and Maria Callas was an emerging presence on long-playing opera records, not yet an international gossip-page celebrity or a fad or a cult figure.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: MARY PATRICIA KNAGGS;
Ready for Golf Classic, Despite Weather
description: LEAD: FIRST there was a drought and with it came regulations about watering; then it rained cats and dogs, which brought puddles and floods; and then it rained even more. It was enough to frazzle any golf-course superintendent.

title: In East, Orioles Gain Catbird Seat and Hope It's Permanent
description: Assessing what passes for a race in the American League East, General Manager Harry Dalton of the Milwaukee Brewers said the other day: ''Everybody says they're waiting for someone to get hot and pull away. That's what Baltimore is doing. They've won 12 of 15.''

title:
GARDENING;
Dusting and Spraying: A Must for Roses
description: LEAD: EVERYONE enjoys the beauty of roses, but not everyone is willing to put forth the effort to grow them.

title: Correction
description: Because of a transcription error, a report on the Evening Hours page last Sunday about celebrations of the arts referred incorrectly to a guest at a birthday party for Leo Lerman. The guest was Betty Comden, not Eddie Condon. Mr. Condon, the jazz guitarist, died in 1973.

title: In 'Great Books,' Children Learn Questions as Well as Answers
description: LEAD: IT is 9:45 on a Thursday morning at the Assumption School here. Fifteen third graders are settling into a somewhat ragged circle. Barbara Waters, one of the two adults in the circle, asks, ''Does anyone have an interpretive question today?'' Six hands wave in the air. Another Junior Great Books discussion has begun.

title: Inches of Error, and Dream Tunnel Deferred
description: Chicago and the state of Illinois started work on a tunnel from opposite ends. The result is a tunnel, but the two ends do not precisely meet.

title: Article 389089 -- No Title
description: First, Stephen L. Smith will go to prison, convicted of defrauding investors in his oil and gas exploration company of about $20 million.

title: On Foot in Big Sur Country
description: Dizzy from the afternoon heat, forest silences and two hours of trudging up a steep wilderness trail, my wife and I wondered at first whether we were lost or had merely underestimated the time it would take us to get up the mountain. We had left the coastal highway, with its views of the Pacific Ocean, several miles back.

title: V.M.I's 'Brother Rats' May Get Some Sisters
description: For 150 years the Virginia Military Institute has maintained a tradition of molding the citizen-soldier. On campus, V.M.I. cadets wear military dress and members of the guard wear the same formal uniform worn for 100 years: blue-gray coatee, white ducks (black in winter) and shako hats. Cadets attend Saturday classes, observe reveille before 7 A.M. and taps at 11 P.M. Women are not admitted to the school and are not permitted to visit the barracks.

title: 'Daisy' Blossoms Once More in Atlanta
description: Framed by Dogwoods, Magnolia trees and live oak, the red brick house on Lullwater Road radiates Southern gentility. It fits in perfectly with the other stately domiciles in this verdant section of Atlanta called Druid Hills. But inside, in a residence whose accouterments include a creaky Easy Spindrier machine, a remarkable scene is under way. Dressed in a 40's pinstripe suit and gray overcoat, Dan Aykroyd stands next to Jessica Tandy, who looks snug in a quilted bathrobe. In front of them in a brown suit, complete with natty bow tie, a gray-haired Morgan Freeman holds a can of Mi-Boy salmon that he has just lifted out of a Piggly Wiggly bag. ''Oh, Miz Daisy. Yestiddy when you out visitin', I ate a can of yo' salmon,'' he says with a flawless Southern accent.

title: Solomon Senior, 85; Led Workmen's Board
description: Solomon E. Senior, a former chairman of the New York State Workmen's Compensation Board, died Thursday of complications following a stroke at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 85 years old.

title: Spain Lands Sabonis
description: He's been one of the world's most sought after basketball players. Now, after a series of false starts, Arvidas Sabonis is finally being given a chance to make it as a real professional, but not, as it turns out, with the Portland Trail Blazers, the National Basketball Association team that has been trying to sign him since 1986. Instead, the towering Lithuanian center, who led the Soviet Union to the gold medal in basketball at the 1988 Olympics, announced in Spain that he had signed a one-year contract to play for the Forum Vilatelico of Valladolid in the Spanish league.

title: Students Ponder Whether Pets Think
description: WHEN your dog cocks his head and looks at you, what is on his mind? He may need to go out, or want to be fed but perhaps something more lies behind those big brown eyes.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: PARADISE REGAINED: Memoirs of a Rebel. By C. L. Sulzberger. (Praeger, Cloth, $32.95; Paper, $12.95.) Who would have guessed that Milovan Djilas and C. L. Sulzberger would become lifelong friends? The first time they met, just after the end of World War II, the then Minister of Propaganda for Marshal Tito's newly formed Yugoslav Communist regime angrily turned his back when introduced to The New York Times's foreign correspondent, unhappy with Mr.

title: Keeping Fit
description: To the Editor: I was heartened to read your article (Travel, March 5) about potentially fatal blood clots that can form while on an airplane. Such an article could have saved my client's life.

title: A GRANDDAUGHTER'S FEAR
description: I want to thank Natalie Angier. Her article gave me insight into my own relationships.

title: Modern Dance Imbued With Mountain Spirit
description: THE modern dancer Yung Yung Tsuai has introduced us to her ancestral China and now she will bring us a view of a culture within our own country.

title: 3 TV Shows That Captured a Decade
description: Suddenly, it's the end of three eras: ''Moonlighting'' is television history, and ''Family Ties'' and ''Miami Vice'' have aired their (respectively, tearful and explosive) all- time finales.

title: Are Golf Purses Out of Bounds?
description: Tom Watson, who has won more money playing the PGA Tour than any other golfer, said tournament purses are becoming so big they are ''obscene.'' Tom Kite, who is currently third on the career earnings list behind Watson and Jack Nicklaus, and could easily become No. 1 before the year ends, said the purses are so big that tour pros have to pinch themselves every day to make sure they aren't dreaming.

title: Anne Churchill Weds
description: Anne Churchill, a saleswoman for the Halstead Property Company, and John P. Coffey, an associate in the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, both in New York, were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Evanston, Ill. The Rev. David Handley performed the ceremony assisted by the Rev. John Collins, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Reseed if the abundant rainfall has made the soil soggy and rotted out lettuce, radish, bean and other crops. Last call to plant seed of lima beans, pole beans and other crops that need warm soil to germinate. Plant another block of sweet corn seed. Last call to transplant to the garden vegetable seedlings. Last call to plant window boxes, terrace planters, patio tubs and urns. Keep Going

title: Stephanie Resanovich Weds Francis J. Kovar
description: Stephanie Ann Resanovich and Francis James Kovar, an assistant actuary and a programming supervisor, respectively, at the Fort Lee, N.J., employee benefits consulting firm of Kwasha Lipton, were married yesterday. The Rev. John Branson performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Chatham, N.J. The Rev. William Winston, a Roman Catholic priest, assisted.

title: A NEW CROP OF CONSULTANTS GROWS UP IN ELDER-CARE
description: The spreading efforts by companies to help employees care for elderly relatives is giving rise to a new industry. A handful of entrepreneurs have cropped up over the last two years to assist them.

title: Anne Romanelli Married on L.I. To J. P. Schmitz
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Patrick in Huntington, L.I., Anne Elizabeth Romanelli, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. P. Romanelli of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Joseph Patrick Schmitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Schmitz of Lloyd Harbor. Msgr. James B. Richter performed the ceremony.

title: Going Into Overtime
description: The way Gene Klein sees his litigation with Al Davis, ''the score is tied 1-1 and we go into overtime.'' By that, Klein meant he would appeal an intermediate court's decision overturning a ruling by a lower court, which had awarded him $2 million of Davis's money.

title: Mitchell Belts No. 18 as Giants Beat Braves, 4-0
description: Kevin Mitchell hit his 18th home run of the season today, a two-run shot, as the San Francisco Giants beat the Atlanta Braves, 4-0. The Giants' victory was their seventh in eight games.

title:
DINING OUT;
Restaurant's Heart Belongs to Sushi
description: LEAD: CELEBRATING its sixth year, Azuma Sushi remains the only one of the area's Japanese restaurants that offers sushi exclusively. True to tradition, this sushi house serves no desserts, pickles (except as a component in sushi) or salads, or appetizers such as skewered chicken (yakitori), tempura or noodles.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LEAD: THE FIFTH CHILD, by Doris Lessing. (Vintage, $6.95.) The perfect couple with the perfect family in the perfect house give birth to a monster. ''If [Doris] Lessing is a better writer than the teen-age Mary Shelley, she is fully the equal of the mature Orwell,'' Carolyn Kizer said in The Book Review last year.

title:
GARDENING;
Dusting and Spraying: A Must for Roses
description: LEAD: EVERYONE enjoys the beauty of roses, but not everyone is willing to put forth the effort to grow them.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: HERE COMES THE CAT! tr,br1By Frank Asch and Vladimir Vagin. Unpaged. New York: Scholastic. $11.95. (Ages 7 to 11)

title: Ms. Liebesman Has a Wedding
description: At the Hotel duPont in Wilmington, Del., Deborah Karen Liebesman, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Maurice Liebesman of Wilmington, and Gerald Joseph Siano, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry J. Siano of Washington's Crossing, Pa., were married last evening. Rabbi Shimon Berris and the Rev. Charles Kane, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''This is a caveat emptor situation. We're already seeing some real cheesy merchandise.'' Roger B. McNamee, co-manager of T. Rowe Price New Horizons Fund on the surge of new public offerings of small companies.

title: The Path to a Tony Nomination
description: SIGNORA MARIA MERELLI is the wife of the world-famous tenor, Tito Merelli, otherwise known as Il Stupendo. As played by Tovah Feldshuh in the Broadway farce, ''Lend Me a Tenor'' at the Royale Theater, she could well be called La Stupenda, in spite of her diminutive size.

title: Daniel J. Halloran, 52, Housing Dept. Official
description: Daniel J. Halloran, a deputy assistant commissioner in the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development, died Friday of prostate cancer at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 52 years old and lived in Flushing, Queens.

title: Beyond the Glue of Fear
description: Overlooked in the to-do at President Bush's last-minute feat of rescuing NATO from diplomatic donnybrook is a new plan to keep the alliance together well into the next century.

title: TALKING: Curb Appeal; Sewing Up A Sale at First Sight
description: BROKERS have long recognized that a buyer's decision to select one home over another often depends as much on emotions as on practical considerations. The term used by professionals is ''curb appeal.''

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Wolf at the End of the World

title: Dr. Cafferty Wed To an Executive
description: Dr. Maureen Sarah Cafferty, an assistant attending physician at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in New York, and Donald McAllister Jr. were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Gertrude in Bayville, L.I. The Rev. Joseph F. McCloskey, a cousin of the bridegroom, officiated.

title: PSYCHO KILLER
description: SOUL/MATE By Rosamond Smith. 248 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/ E. P. Dutton. $17.95.

title: Seattle Roadway Is Opening
description: A seven-mile stretch of Interstate 90, the most expensive segment of freeway ever built, will open here Sunday.

title: ISRAEL: MIRED IN THE WEST BANK
description: Mr. Friedman blames Israel's leadership for not picking up the telephone to call for peace with its neighbors. However, Israel's leadership has been talking and meeting with Jordan's King Hussein for over 20 years, trying to hammer out some compromise solution. But Hussein's primary goal is survival, and he has disappointed both the Israelis and the Americans many times. Assad of Syria makes no bones about wanting Israel's destruction and the creation of a Greater Syria - to include Palestine (Israel), Jordan and Lebanon. Clearly, the telephone line is dead. FRED EHRMAN Chairman, Israel Commission Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America New York, N.Y.

title: With 2 Democrats Toppled, Washington Debates Republican Role in Affair
description: In an extraordinary week in which two top Democrats fell and another was questioned about finances, a submerged but spirited debate has developed on Capitol Hill about the Republican Party's role in crippling the Democratic leadership in the House.

title: 'Why Hartford?'
description: LEAD: IN the past 20 months, I've been away from my Los Angeles home for 6 of them, living not in New York or on a film location, but in downtown Hartford in order to work at the Hartford Stage Company in productions of ''Hamlet'' and ''Peer Gynt.'' And perhaps the question most frequently asked of me in that time has been ''Why Hartford?

title:
ART;
Surprises in a Collection That Had a Late Start
description: LEAD: JOHN C. WHITEHEAD, who served as Deputy Secretary of State in the Reagan Administration and who is currently active with the International Rescue Committee, became an art collector rather late in the game. In 1978 he bought a Modigliani drawing at an auction because he got caught up in the spirit of the proceedings.

title: Q and A
description: Madeira

title: A Report on Babies Wtih AIDS Confirms Fears in County
description: NEW statistics on the spread of AIDS among child-bearing women in the county, released in May by the State Health Department, have many long-term implications and confirm fears that the disease has a strong foothold in Westchester, experts say.

title: Dana Baum, Tutor to Handicapped, Wed to Peter Hopper, an Industrialist
description: Dana Ellen Baum, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore B. Baum of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Peter Bogert Hopper, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David T. Hopper of Wilmot Flat, N.H. Cantor Raymond Smolover performed the ceremony.

title: Hicksville Questions Zoning 'Sucess'
description: TWO main branches of the Long Island Rail Road course through Hicksville, splitting the east-west route into northern and southern halves. Similarly, the northern part of Hicksville and the southern part, below the elevated train station, seem to be going in different directions.

title: Baseball Anecdotes
description: To the Editor:

title: Reunion Aboard 2 Maxi-Boats
description: There will be a reunion this week for key players in the America's Cup series sailed two years ago in Australia. Dennis Conner and Peter Gilmour, opposing 12-Meter skippers in 1987, are among the top sailors planning to compete in an international maxi-boat regatta beginning Friday in Newport, R.I.

title: IN TAIWAN, SYMPATHY AND ALOOFNESS
description: A few days ago when high school students formed a human chain from the northern to the southern tips of this island to show their solidarity with protesting students in Beijing, it seemed like the sort of gesture one might expect from Taiwan, whose Government still likes to see itself as a ''free'' alternative to Communist rule on the mainland.

title: WHAT'S FARTHER THAN ALL THE WAY?
description: THE WAR ZONE By Alexander Stuart. 210 pp. New York: Doubleday. $16.95.

title: China's Next Long March
description: LEAD: After seven weeks of incomparable restraint, shadow boxing and psychological warfare, the tinderbox at Tiananmen Square has exploded. The authorities could have avoided striking the match that now threatens, like a prairie fire, to engulf all of China. Instead of addressing the future of China, they invoked the ghosts of its past.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE SHOPLIFTER'S APPRENTICE. By Ellen Lesser. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Women poised on the brink of self-discoveries dominate this slim collection of well-observed and evocative stories. From the Miami journalist visiting her old school friend's Vermont farmhouse to the East Village proofreader forming an uneasy bond with the tenant of a neighborhood group home to the transplanted Middle Westerner in midtown Manhattan whose solitary routine is disturbed by the noisy lovemaking of the couple upstairs, these characters often see themselves reflected in the lives of others.

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: ELEANOR BAUM;
Training Engineers That Defy Stereotypes
description: LEAD: DISPELLING stereotypes about engineers and encouraging women and minority students to study engineering are two priorities of Eleanor Baum, dean of the Nerken School of Engineering at Cooper Union in Lower Manhattan.

title: POSTINGS: At Home in the Hamptons; Motel Room Sales
description: Those who would like to summer in the Hamptons but are shocked by the cost of a season's rental might consider buying a motel room and using it as your vacation base. Conversions of motels started in the Westhampton Beach and Montauk areas, and in January two motels in the Village of Southampton were bought and converted by a development company, DM Associates of Huntington, L.I.

title: THE DEADLY GAME
description: I am a graduate of the University of Liverpool, currently studying for my doctorate in the United States. I was born and raised in Liverpool and have attended soccer matches there for the last 19 years. In no way do I condone the actions of this violent minority of soccer fans. However, I can speak for thousands of English soccer fans who want only to go to the stadium on Saturday afternoon, see a good game and, naturally, hope that their team wins. The Liverpool crowd is vociferous, and, yes, the Anfield roar is an intimidating sound. However, they also have the reputation for being one of the most sporting crowds in England, and if an opposing team plays well, it is appreciated by the Liverpool fans. V. B. UNNITHAN Springfield, Mass.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Michigan; Pleas for Money Win Automobiles In Student Contest
description: While the real-life pleas of Jennifer Foster and Philip Boyer for money from parents back home may go unheeded, their imaginative entries to a contest sponsored by a greeting-cards company have resulted in a payoff that ought to hold them for a while: 1989 Nissan Pulsars, worth $14,500, for each.

title: Pope Takes Message to Arctic Circle
description: With fewer than 1,000 Catholics scattered across the mountains and fjords of the world's northernmost diocese, it was something of a triumph for Pope John Paul II when twice that number welcomed him this weekend on his first trip inside the Arctic Circle.

title: STREETSCAPES: Alan Garage-Franklin Hotel; Unusual Combination for Conflict
description: ALTHOUGH the block between 86th and 87th Streets, from Lexington to Third Avenues, has mostly unexceptional buildings, some big names in real estate - Norman Segal, Mark Perlbinder, Edward S. Gordon and William Zeckendorf - are involved in carving it up for development. Mr. Zeckendorf took title in April to the sprawling Loews 86th Street theater.

title: Distributor to Stop Selling Pistol-Shaped Juice Package
description: A distributor has agreed to discontinue sales of a pistol-shaped juice package from which children drink by putting the barrel in their mouths.

title: TENDING A SICK PARENT? DIAL THE CORPORATE HOT LINE FOR HELP
description: After his mother was diagnosed last fall as having Alzheimer's disease, Jim West faced the arduous task of lining up long-term care for her. But by January, on his mother's 75th birthday, Mr. West had admitted her into a retirement home in her native Charleston, S.C., without missing a day of work in Boca Raton, Fla.

title: CRIME
description: Things are just not right in the sleek new library at Midwestern University. Undergraduates are industriously at work vandalizing periodicals and plagiarizing term papers. An erudite thief is making off with first editions from the stacks. And in the south tower, someone has just murdered a student working late in study carrel 1501.

title: Garden Flowers Can Be Watered
description: I read with interest the article about the loss of business suffered by the county's plant nurseries. [ ''A Spring of Drought Restrictions Shrivels Business at Nurseries,'' May 14 ] . While the article was informative, it did contain a factual error that should be brought to the attention of your readers.

title:
INVESTING;
The Pendulum Swings for H.M.O.'s
description: LEAD: Since the beginning of the year, share prices of health maintenance organizations have soared, in response to strong profit increases at several H.M.O.'s. While many analysts do not expect the big run-up to continue - some share prices have more than doubled - some still recommend a few top companies.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: GHOST WAVES. By James McManus. (Grove, $18.95.) ''The past is the present, isn't it?'' asked Eugene O'Neill in ''Long Day's Journey Into Night'' - then answered, ''It's the future, too.'' That is certainly the case in James McManus's third novel, ''Ghost Waves,'' where time runs amok and the difference between reality and illusion is sometimes impossible for the reader (or the characters) to ascertain.

title: The Way up From Poverty Begins in the Home; Poor Isn't Underclass
description: To the Editor:

title: A Call for Steps that Ease Traffic and Aid the Environment
description: WE must find a solution to traffic congestion that is both cost effective and friendly to the environment. There are no simple solutions since increasing taxes for new highways is politically unpopular and many proposed routes for new roads go through fragile wetlands and water supplies.

title: INSURING WHAT MEDICARE DOESN'T
description: One of the newest elder-care benefits provided by employers is long-term-care insurance. In fact, these policies, which cover nursing-home and custodial-care expenses and medical exams, are also among the newest products offered by insurers.

title: Affordable Housing: Another View
description: It was with a sense of incredulity that I read the two Opinion page articles on ''affordable housing'' on May 7 (''Affordable Housing: State Has Ideas,'' by Anthony M. Villane Jr., and ''But the Federal Government Has to Do Its Share,'' by John Atlas). The errors of logic and outright nonsense were too numerous to counter, but I shall cover a few points.

title: Montclair Journal; Remote Parking Areas Keep College Fears Alive
description: ABOUT 7 P.M. on Dec. 11, 1985, a 19-year-old student at Montclair State College was walking to her car, which was in a remote campus parking area. A man driving a van stopped and asked for directions. The directions she gave him, the man said, were unclear; he asked her to get into the van to guide him. She did.

title: Light of Day and New Paint Refresh First Coca-Cola Sign
description: The salesman and artist who painted the first Coca-Cola wall sign was no Rembrandt, but 95 years later his work is getting as much attention as some masterpieces.

title: Alix Cochrane Is Married
description: At St. David's Episcopal Church in Baltimore, Alexandra Wyndham Cochrane, the daughter of Mrs. John H. Cochrane of Baltimore and the late Mr. Cochrane, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Kinsey Rodman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. James P. Rodman of Alliance, Ohio, and Cape May, N.J. The Rev. David E. Crossley performed the ceremony.

title: Elizabeth Friday Becomes Bride Of Brian Spears
description: At St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., Elizabeth Herron Friday, the daughter of Elizabeth Hansen Friday of Stamford, Conn., and John E. Friday Jr. of Lyme, Conn., was married yesterday to Brian Edward Spears, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Spears of Greenwich. The Rev. Sydney Woodd-Cahusac, an Episcopal priest, and Msgr. William Genuario, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Anne G. Friday was matron of honor for her sister-in-law. Mr. Spears Jr. was his brother's best man.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Soft, Shapely Belted Suits
description: Several well-known designers of women's suits are tightening their belts lately. Until now, most suits didn't have any belts to tighten. But this year they are an integral (not to mention interesting) part of the suit wardrobe, providing a softer shapeliness. And there's a new flourish - the half-belt that ties at the side.

title:
ART;
Glorious Pre-1900 Vuillard Sampling
description: LEAD: IN his essay for the catalogue accompanying ''The Intimate Eye of Edouard Vuillard,'' at the Katonah Gallery, William Kelly Simpson allows that the artist's journals stress his commitment to art and experimentation before 1900 and that after that the emphasis is on his ''social life.''

title: Student Critically Ill After Meningitis Attack
description: A college student home on summer vacation was in critical condition today with meningococcal meningitis, health officials said.

title: Glass Art By Czechs On Display
description: NINE limp champagne bottles seem to huddle together like weary old ladies with their heads bent down or twisted sideways; some residue of glue from the labels might be their tattered shawls. Nearby stands a life-size glass head of Barbra Streisand with a golden canary in her throat.

title: DATA UPDATE: June 4, 1989
STALIN'S DEAD. CAN LENIN BE NEXT? LET HISTORY JUDGE
description: LEAD: The Origins and Consequences of Stalinism. Revised and Expanded Edition. By Roy Medvedev. Translated by George Shriver. 903 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $57.50.

title: Pakistan Bus Crash Kills 15
description: A speeding bus full of wedding celebrants overturned on a curve near this southern Pakistani city, killing 15 people and injuring 25, officials said today.

title: 'Heaven Can Wait' Has Its Fatal Flaws
description: AND then there's the one about Joe Pendleton, the saxophone-playing pugilist, who dies prematurely (by 60 years) and, it turns out, erroneously. Somewhere outside heaven, the mistake is discovered. Having already been cremated, the boxer is escorted back to earth in search of another body.

title: Syrian Gunners Strike Again At Beirut's Christian District
description: Syrian gunners blasted the Christian sectors in and around Beirut today with 400 howitzer shells, and 5 artillery rounds crashed into Muslim West Beirut in another violation of a cease-fire called three weeks ago.

title: Musical 'Follies': Showgirls' Reunion
description: ''FOLLIES,'' Stephen Sondheim's sophisticated musical about memories and the futility of reliving the past, is currently at Theater Three in Port Jefferson through June 24. Theater Three frequently presents large-scale musicals. Generally, these shows are of better quality than this unaffecting production.

title: DANGEROUS TRAFFIC
description: IN A RECENT AFTERNOON when the entire New York region is in aerial gridlock because of fog and rain, the tension is almost palpable at the New York Terminal Radar Approach Control, or Tracon, facility in Westbury, L.I. - widely regarded as the most complex air-traffic control room in the world.

title: Fairfield Takes Note of Its Social History with Quilts
description: LEAD: QUILTS, passed down through generations, represent not only the nostalgia of a warm bed, but also a socialized art form.

title: Law on Disabled
description: To the Editor:

title: Tommy's Dear John
description: For Tommy John, the fortunes of baseball this season have been as fickle as one of his sinkers. The left-handed pitcher had not been expected to make the New York Yankee roster. But there he was as the season began, pitching and winning the opening game against Minnesota, hailed as a geriatric marvel. But after that, his record fell to 2-7, and there were no victories in May. Last week, seven days after his 46th birthday, the winner of 288 games in 26 seasons was told that his arm was no longer needed. But Mr. John, the first big-league player in baseball's modern history to compete in so many seasons, wasn't about to retire, as the Yankees had hoped. Maybe, he said, another club will want him. ''If I retire, it will be later on,'' he said. ''I'll keep working out and throwing. You never know.''

title: Harnessing the Power of Suggestion
description: Marshall Fisher, a co-founder of the Century 21 real estate company, retired to Hawaii 12 years ago to pursue an ambitious goal: he wanted to understand the process of creativity. Mr. Fisher placed an advertisement in a Honolulu newspaper offering work for ''creative people,'' and since then he has hired scores of inventive people to sit around and brainstorm. His goal is to discover how the mind makes creative associations among the thoughts, concepts, images and facts that are stored in the brain.

title: Lee Ann Stackhouse Weds Russel H. Patterson 3d
description: St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Washington was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Lee Ann Stackhouse, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Stackhouse of High Point, N.C., and Russel Hugo Patterson 3d, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Patterson Jr. of New York. The Rev. James Adams performed the ceremony.

title: Silver Splendor In Philadelphia
description: A wildly Rococo cream pot - the quirkiest and most lavishly embellished vessel on view in the newly refurbished American Wing of the Philadelphia Museum of Art - is Beatrice Garvan's favorite piece of American silver.

title: Waterfront Caberet, Dancing And Jazz
description: Baltimore's Fishmarket, the latest adjunct to the city's Inner Harbor complex, is a glossy supermarket of entertainment. Six clubs offer cabaret shows, jazz ensembles and dancing to big bands or rock groups. There are two restaurants, for a light snack or a full meal.

title: No Favor Goes Unrepaid
description: When party favors failed to materialize at the end of a benefit dinner given by the Landmarks Conservancy this spring, the guests didn't grumble. Some simply helped themselves to the centerpieces on the tables at the Four Seasons restaurant.

title: Lee Reynolds Begelman, 65, a TV Producer
description: Lee Reynolds Begelman, a television and theater producer, died of cancer Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: THE DEADLY GAME
description: Lesley Hazleton's reference to the ''family atmosphere'' of major-league baseball in the United States was curiously naive.

title: Spa Helps Cancer Victims Enhance Their Looks
description: LEAD: A BEAUTY spa in Stamford is helping women with cancer deal with hair loss and other physical side effects caused by chemotherapy.

title: MAJOR MOVES IN PARIS
description: THE LONGEST SHADOW ON FRENCH FASHION is now Italian. Last month, the house of Dior, that symbol of French style, revealed it had chosen the Milanese designer Gianfranco Ferre to carry its creative banner. And just a few weeks earlier, Romeo Gigli, another Italian, showing his fall ready-to-wear collection in Paris, received an ovation the likes of which have rarely been witnessed.

title: After a Home Is Sold, It's Just a House
description: WE are dismantling the family home, one memory at a time. We are removing our furniture, photographs and housewares that are the expressions of three generations. The house once belonged to my grandparents but they are no longer alive. It was my uncle's house next, but he, too, died. Now it is no one's and everyone's - a part of my uncle's estate.

title: Watch His Lips, But It's Not Bush
description: ONE night about 15 years ago, Fred and Lois, a husband-and-wife singing team, were performing at Andrews Air Force base near Washington.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Down the Bridal Path (At $300 a Minute)
description: LEAD: MARRIAGES may be made in heaven, but weddings are made by parents. They eagerly spend $30,000 for a five-hour festivity for one reason: they can't believe they lived long enough to see this day.

title: POSTINGS: Diamonds Downtown; Condos Atop a Jewelry Exchange
description: While most New Yorkers associate jewelry sales with the Diamond District around West 47th Street in midtown Manhattan, many old-line jewelers originally set up shop on the Lower East Side a century ago. Canal Street just west of the Manhattan Bridge, and the neighorhood immediately north of it, still has dozens of jewelry stores and pawn shops with their distinctive clusters of three golden balls hanging outside.

title: ISRAEL: MIRED IN THE WEST BANK
description: We could have used an author as eloquent as Joel Brinkley to defend us when I was serving with the Marines in Vietnam. In 1966-67, most of the children who were shot or killed were armed to the teeth and not merely throwing stones. GEORGE WATSON Montauk Point, L.I.

title: 'War: Ends and Means'
description: To the Editor:

title: Ms. Pancotti Is a Bride
description: At St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church in Westbury, L.I., Carolyn Ann Pancotti, the daughter of Mrs. Robert G. Pancotti of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and the late Mr. Pancotti, was married yesterday to Michael Bradley Ray, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Bradley Ray of Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. Robert G. Fulton officiated.

title: State-Run Success
description: To the Editor:

title: Looming Threat Of Incinerators
description: The tax storm brewing now (''In Suffolk, Tax Revolt Gathers Steam,'' May 14) pales compared to a tax cyclone forming on the horizon. Fueling this oncoming turbulence is the huge fiscal waste of burning trash.

title: Late Bloomer Not Overlooked
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Flatbush
description: THE rich past of Flatbush - originally Vlackebos, or ''wooded plain'' in Dutch - is reflected in one of its many landmarks, the Flatbush Dutch Reformed Church: The present building, at the corner of Church and Flatbush Avenues, was completed in 1793, but the original church was commissioned by Peter Stuyvesant and completed in 1662.

title: The Dollar Defies Those Who Would Rein It In
description: WHILE the Group of Seven - the United States and six of its Western trading partners -would like to be able to stabilize or adjust their currencies in relation to one another with deliberate, deft actions, the fact is that currencies, like stocks and bonds, change value on the basis of rumor, speculation and other influences of the market that not even governments can control.

title: Janice G. Hyman Married
description: Janice Gail Hyman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abe Hyman of Brooklyn, was married last evening at the Kingsway Jewish Center in Brooklyn to Dr. Stephen Harris Wolpo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliott L. Wolpo, also of Brooklyn. Rabbi Israel Wagner and Cantor Moishe Hecht officiated. The bride, a graduate of New York University, is a coordinator of press relations at the American Jewish Committee in New York. The bridegroom, a dentist in Huntington, Conn., graduated from N.Y.U. and its dental school.

title: Bruce T. Simonds, 93; Led Yale Music School
description: Prof. Bruce T. Simonds, a pianist and a former dean of the Yale University School of Music, died of kidney failure Friday at his home in Hamden, Conn. He was 93 years old. Professor Simonds taught at Yale from 1921 to 1973, when he retired. He was dean of both the school, which was for graduate students, and the department of music, which was begun in 1941 to provide courses for undergraduates, from 1941 to 1954.

title: Lawmaking in States Evolves Into Full-Time Job
description: The ''citizen'' legislator, who spends one season in the state capital and returns home to tend to a business in the next, is becoming a rare breed.

title: Indians in Canada Cross Border to Fight Utility
description: The Cree Indians of northern Quebec are looking across the border for help in their effort to stop a huge hydroelectric project that would flood their hunting lands.

title: Verdict in Estranged Wife's Killing Draws Protests
description: The conviction of a former police officer for manslaughter rather than murder in the slaying of his estranged wife, a district judge, is drawing protests here.

title: Cheruiyot Wins Tough 1,500 in N.C.A.A.
description: A spectacular spill knocked the best American out of the feature race tonight as the National Collegiate Athletic Association outdoor track and field championships ended.

title: Wave of Future: A Choice of Schools
description: The American tradition of the neighborhood school may be going the way of the McGuffey's Reader and the one-room schoolhouse.

title: Taking No Chances
description: The pitcher's complaint was just a bit of tightness in his left shoulder, but when the shoulder belongs to a gold-medal rookie on a roll you don't want to take any chances. So Jim Abbott, who has won his last three starts for the California Angels, has been removed from the rotation for today's game against the Kansas City Royals. According to a club spokesman, the action was a ''precaution'' to avoid aggravating the tendinitis that appeared during Abbott's last start, a 3-2 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers last Tuesday.(AP)

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; On Two Grand Estates, History and Horticulture
description: Here, where many great estates have vanished, at least two old mansions seem to be growing richer in luster and charm.

title: Alex Donner - Band Leader
description: It was his appearance in a college production of ''H.M.S. Pinafore'' that changed the course of Alex Donner's career. Today, the conductor-singer of the Alex Donner Orchestra (and head of seven other orchestras with the same name), is making big waves.

title: GETTING THE ELECTRONICS JUST RIGHT
description: Carl E. Reichardt, the chairman and chief executive of Wells Fargo & Company, doesn't have a personal computer in his office. And he is quite happy to use secretaries, phones and meetings to communicate with underlings.

title: Making a Splash
description: WHO, OTHER THAN ESTHER WILLIAMS and her chorus, would have any use for waterproof makeup? Tearful brides and Miss America contestants may paint themselves with Scotchgard-like makeup, but the stuff seems lost on the rest of the population.

title: Miss King Plans To Wed Dentist
description: Dr. and Mrs. Abraham A. King of Binghamton, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter Georgia King to Dr. Todd Lerner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Lerner of Brooklyn. A November wedding is planned.

title: 'O POOR COOK!': THE ANNOTATING M.F.K. FISHER
description: I have known her for years already, this amazing, outrageous, not-as-sweet-as-she looks, unpredictable, brilliant, erratic, exasperating woman who calls herself M. F. K. Fisher. So I should not have been surprised at anything, especially at surprise itself, because that is what she is so good at. But I was not prepared for her unexpected invitation to look over her fascinating collection of cookbooks and ''take whatever you want.''

title: Miss Norris Weds James E. Chappell
description: At the Williamsburg (Va.) Presbyterian Church, Kimberly Anne Norris, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul L. Norris of Burke, Va., was married yesterday to James Edward Chappell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Chappell of Holmdel, N.J., by the Rev. J. Shepherd Russell Jr. The bride, a graduate of the College of William and Mary, as is her husband, is to begin studies there next month for a master's degree in education. Her father is a branch manager in Columbia, Md., for the Polychrome Corporation, a manufacturer of printing equipment in Yonkers.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Fairfield, Conn.$535,000 1338 Pequot Avenue 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 68-year-old colonial; new furnace, 2-car garage with 2-room apartment, 0.75 acre; taxes $5,658. Brookfield, Conn.$166,000 41 Woodview Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; mint condition, family neighborhood, 0.5 acre; taxes $1,342. Trumbull, Conn. $295,000 20 Riverbend Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 11-year-old colonial; renovated kitchen, finished basement w/ workshop, 0.75 acre; taxes $3,252. Goldens Bridge, N.Y.$417,500 Apache Circle 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old contemporary; family room with fireplace, 2-car garage, 1.13 acres; taxes $7,500. Mount Kisco, N.Y.$284,500 10 Kathleen Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 37-year-old ranch; fireplace, 1-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $4,672. Pound Ridge, N.Y.$1.4 million Eastwoods Road 3-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 2-year-old Normandy; library, sun room, Jacuzzi, fireplace, 3 terraces, pool, 3.4 acres; taxes $11,216. OTHER AREAS Freehold, N.J.$183,226 21 Stokes Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 43-year-old colonial; enclosed porch, den, full basement; taxes $2,325. Mahwah, N.J.$157,900 23 Island Road 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; pool, eat-in-kitchen, w/w carpeting; taxes $1,135. Sayville, L.I.$242,000 23 Sunset Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old ranch; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, dining room; taxes $4,200.

title: In West Bank, the Corruption of Education Is Deemed Criminal
description: To the Editor:

title: Thousands Gather to Protest Seabrook Atomic Power Unit
description: Thousands of people gathered here today to protest the Seabrook atomic power plant, where low-power testing is under way after being long delayed by disputes over whether the area could ever be safely evacuated in a nuclear emergency.

title: For Its Importers, Soviet 'Peave Bread' Proves Divisive
description: A 4,670-MILE bread route, from Moscow to New York, is bringing thousands of loaves of Russian rye to eager customers in the New York City area each week and creating a strain between the two entrepreneurs responsible for the imports - former colleagues and still neighbors in Harrison.

title: With All This Great Concrete, Why Sit Quietly on the Sand?
description: Josh Greenberg's roommate has a share in a beach house on Long Island. His brother has a girlfriend whose parents have a place on the Jersey Shore. ''It's lousy being stuck in the city on weekends,'' said Mr. Greenberg, who was drinking cappuccino in an outdoor cafe in Greenwich Village and fantasizing about a Fresh Air program for urban 27-year-old word processors like himself.

title: The House That Didn't Want to Be Sold
description: IN the summer of 1980, we decided to sell our house in Manhasset, in which we had lived for 20 years. We were looking for a different life style, a change of pace.

title: In Taiwan, Sympathies Lean Toward Home
description: A few days ago when high school students formed a human chain from the northern to the southern tips of this island to show their solidarity with protesting students in Beijing, it seemed like the sort of gesture one might expect from Taiwan, whose Government still likes to see itself as a ''free'' alternative to Communist rule on the mainland.

title: Exhausted Afghanistan Hunts for Glimmer of Hope
description: His voice, once a resonant bass, has sunk to an indistinct monotone. President Najibullah, leader of the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul, seems to have become a chastened man, a change from the imposing, implacable figure of the earlier 1980's when as the secret police chief here he was known to his supporters as ''The Ox.''

title: POSTINGS: Lower and Upper East Side; Tenement Tours
description: The words ''Lower East Side'' conjure up for many people images of squalid tenements bulging with large immigrant families. How close to or far from the truth those images are can be determined next Thursday when the Lower East Side Tenement Museum conducts a two-and-a-half-hour tour of not only its own building, at 97 Orchard Street, between Broome and Delancey Streets, but also of a representative tenement at the York Avenue Estate.

title: U.S. WEIGHS SHIFT ON AFGHAN POLICY
description: Amid growing doubts that the Afghan guerrillas can topple the Kabul Government, the Bush Administration is edging toward a new policy that emphasizes the possibility of a political solution to the conflict.

title: SOCIAL EVENTS
description: Gastronomic Benefit

title: Radcliffe's Choice
description: The 16-month search for a new president of Radcliffe College raised questions among students, faculty and alumnae about whether the college had lost its allure and whether it should still be considered a college separate from Harvard University. Several candidates withdrew their names from consideration, although the college said their reasons were personal. Founded 110 years ago as a women's annex to Harvard, the college is known today primarily as a research center on women's issues for graduate and postgraduate students. Last week, Linda S. Wilson, a University of Michigan vice president for research, was named Radcliffe's seventh president, succeeding Matina S. Horner, who has led the college since 1972. The selection reflected the college's continuing interest in expanding its research role. Part of the appeal of the job, Ms. Wilson said, was the ''public policy forum'' that Radcliffe offered in women's issues.

title: Outdoors; Angling for History or Dollars
description: Most anglers - although some would be loath to admit it -have at one time or another wondered what it would be like to catch a world-record fish.

title: Nasty Reviews
description: To the Editor:

title:
FOOD;
VEGETATING
description: LEAD: In many cuisines, vegetables are afterthoughts. But when Italian cooks take to sauteeing or baking their vegetables, their results are full of imagination and flavor. Baby eggplants are baked with garlic and glistened with oil. Sauteed red and yellow peppers are soaked in a marinade of balsamic vinegar.

title: Rolling Stone Keith Richards at 45
description: KEITH RICHARDS'S FACE shows an odd mixture of relief and satisfaction as he reviews his latest chart success. The 45-year-old rock star is interred in the back seat of a limousine, and New York City's rush hour is advancing his reputation for excessive lateness. The triumph under discussion is not another Rolling Stones record, but a doctor's appointment - ''My first in nine years,'' Richards exults - required by contract for all band members before commencing a tour. ''The bugger stuck electrodes all over my body, hooked up more monitors to me than the Stones use on stage, and told me I was - normal!'' The irony in his tone is palpable. ''I mean, can you imagine anyone telling Keith Richards he was normal?''

title: O.A.S. Draws Latin Fire for Stand on Panama
description: The decision of Latin American countries to cooperate with Washington's efforts to seek ''a regional solution'' to the crisis in Panama through the Organization of American States has generated widespread criticism and skepticism in the hemisphere. The displeasure has been greatest in Mexico, where foreign policy has historically been based on standing up to the United States.

title: CRACKDOWN IN BEIJING: Reporter's Notebook; 'Please, Tell the World,' Students Beg
description: The violence against students and workers in Tiananmen Square was most obvious today, because for the most part they were the ones getting killed. But they, too, were violent against the police and army troops, although less effectively so.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The latex paint on the wood trim in my entrance hall has started to blister and peel. This paint was applied a number of years ago over the original oil paint put on 39 years ago. I believe there are two coats of latex. Where the paint has peeled, the original oil paint, which was a different color, is intact. Can you suggest a cause for this peeling and a way to prevent it in the future?

title: Rev. S. C. Holton Weds Miss Bacon
description: Charlotte Gibney Bacon and the Rev. Stephen Cathcart Holton were married yesterday at All Saints Episcopal Church in New York, where the bridegroom is the curate. The Rev. R. DeWitt Mallary Jr., the rector, and the Rev. Charles S. Gilman Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Susan Friedman Engaged
description: Susan Hilary Friedman and David Samuel Cohen, who will both receive J.D. degrees Tuesday from Yale University, plan to be married in August. Their engagement was announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Friedman of New York. Mr. Cohen is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jordan J. Cohen of Old Field, L.I.

title: Kathryn Del Gaudio Weds Stephen Daly
description: Kathryn Camille Del Gaudio, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Del Gaudio of Greenwich, Conn., and Delray Beach, Fla., was married yesterday at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale, N.Y., to Stephen John Daly, a son of Claudette Daly of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and Daniel Daly of Elmsford, N.Y. The Rev. Robert F. Grippo performed the ceremony.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; Two Simple Variations Of a Ratatouille Dish
description: Many people like to spend part of the weekend cooking for the week ahead, preparing vast quantities of stews and casseroles, freezing some and refrigerating the rest for use at the beginning of the week.

title:
WORKS IN PROGRESS;
Projecting Her Voice
description: LEAD: WITH ALL THE KEYBOARDS piled up, slide projectors clicking and screens erratically lit, it's hard to imagine that what's going on in Laurie Anderson's studio (above) in lower Manhattan is a miniature of anything. But the actual set for her new performance piece is being constructed ''someplace in Pennsylvania,'' she says.

title: NEVER READY FOR LOVE
description: POLARIS AND OTHER STORIES By Fay Weldon. 237 pp. New York: Penguin. Paper, $6.95. LEADER OF THE BAND By Fay Weldon. 196 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: Q and A
description: Joining Apartments

title: In the Streets, Anguish, Fury and Tears
description: As the crackle of automatic weapons filled the air today on the Avenue of Eternal Peace, tens of thousands of Beijing residents, even elderly men and women, rushed out to see what they could do to turn back the troops.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
A Formal Rose Garden to Visit
description: LEAD: To delight the eye with masses of bloom in an immaculately kept setting is the primary goal of curators of the Rudolf W. van der Goot Rose Garden at Colonial Park in Somerset, N.J. Sweeps of reds, pinks and yellows, punctuated by soaring climbers, are pleasingly arrayed along neat walkways.

title: What Is Too Old?
description: THE WOMAN IS 99, she has fainted several times. So she is brought by her family to a hospital, where an electrocardiogram shows that her heart is pausing too long between beats. Her problem would normally be solved by the relatively simple insertion of a pacemaker. But in this case, the intern who examines the patient believes that if he calls the cardiologist about a pacemaker for a 99-year-old, his call won't even be returned.

title:
DINING OUT;
Traditional American Fare at an Old Inn
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH Atlantic City is only about 20 miles down the road, the Inn at Sugar Hill in Mays Landing is light-years away from the glitzy casino scene. The quaint restaurant and inn perched on the bank of Great Egg Harbor River is long on charm, if not quite on gastronomic polish.

title: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, 89, the Unwavering Iranian Spiritual Leader
description: The life of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini was so shadowy, so overlain with myth and rumor, that there was lingering disagreement or uncertainty about his ancestry, his true name and his date of birth.

title: Circus Acts Signal Festival's New Mix
description: LEAD: IF scheduling can make or break a festival, then Alan Inkles, director of the International Theater Festival, which begins its fourth season at SUNY/Stony Brook on Tuesday, believes he has come up with an unbeatable formula.

title: In West Bank, the Corruption of Education Is Deemed Criminal; Jews Against British
description: To the Editor:

title: Sanctions Do the Job, But Apartheid's Critics Are Not All for Them
description: ARCHBISHOP DESMOND M. TUTU sounded less than enthusiastic last week about his known support of economic sanctions as a weapon against apartheid. Addressing a church gathering in Durban, the Anglican archbishop, one of the Government's most visible critics, reiterated an earlier confession that he was ''not wedded'' to sanctions. ''If we can bring about the end of apartheid without sanctions, I would be the first to say Hallelujah,'' he said.

title: For Children, Bluegrass and a Chrous of Ducks
description: LEAD: PHIL ROSENTHAL spent almost the entire day holding a microphone to a team of puzzled ducks. Quacking is not standard sound in the children's records Mr. Rosenthal produces, but in this instance he was veering from his usual bluegrass repertory into a storytelling genre that required duck talk.

title: Trade Is the Real Road to Peace
description: By calling for the integration of the Soviet Union into the community of nations and for cuts in troops and conventional arms, President Bush has taken the United States off the sidelines and actively into the arena of redefining East-West relations. The United States should now move quickly to establish a United States-Soviet trade policy that supports these objectives. Increased trade between our two nations is one of the surest ways to achieve them.

title: New Jersey Democratic Rivals Disagree on Taxes
description: Despite an almost 2-to-1 registration advantage, New Jersey Democrats have not strongly backed their party's candidates in recent gubernatorial and Presidential races. Party leaders hope the winner of Tuesday's primary for governor can turn that around.

title: From 'Fort Apache' to a Treehouse
description: Kenneth Johnson grew up a block away from a South Bronx landmark - the besieged 41st Precinct station house on Simpson Street, inspiration for the 1981 film ''Fort Apache, the Bronx.''

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Munich
description: LEAD: Would Munich still be Munich without Muncheners? That's not just an academic question. Natives are a dwindling breed in the city, amounting to only one-fourth of its 1.2 million inhabitants. The remaining three-fourths are 200,000 Turks, Yugoslavs, Italians, Greeks, Americans, Spaniards, Frenchmen, Britons, Japanese and other non-Germans, along with 700,000 Germans from the north who, by

title: Learning the Art of the House Call
description: LEAD: IN an effort to improve patient care, particularly for the elderly, a new generation of family physicians on Long Island is learning the nearly extinct art of making house calls.

title: Gunpowder Plant Explodes In New Jersey, Injuring 12
description: An explosion tore through a gunpowder manufacturing plant here early this morning, injuring 12 workers, leveling three buildings and shattering windows up to two miles away.

title: CBS Says Its Correspondent Is Seized by Chinese Soldiers
description: CBS News reported last night that two of its employees in Beijing, including its correspondent, Richard Roth, were seized by Chinese soldiers yesterday and were being held at an unknown location last night.

title: Sale by Icahn Sets a Record
description: Carl C. Icahn sold his Texaco stake for $2 billion. The 42-million-share trade was the biggest ever transacted on the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. Icahn's shares were sold for about $49 each; his average cost was estimated at $36.50 each, and his profit was put at $700 million, including dividends. The block was believed to have been bought by several big Wall Street houses, which are reselling to big financial institutions like insurance companies. Mr. Icahn began buying Texaco shares in late 1987, and in May 1988 made a $60-a-share takeover bid. The oil giant resisted, and eventually worked out an uneasy truce with Mr. Icahn. Last week, Mr. Icahn said he sold his 17.3 percent stake because ''it's time to move on.'' There was much speculation that he would move on USX, the oil and steel company in which he already holds a large stake. *

title: Robbers' Target: Expensive Rings
description: LEAD: DIAMONDS may be a girl's best friend, but they apparently are a friend, too, of two thieves. According to the Nassau County Police Department, the pair has robbed 26 women in several affluent western Nassau communities over the last 16 months.

title: Marie-Louise Diedrick, Inn Owner, Weds John Witcher in Connecticut
description: At St. Michael's Episcopal Church in Litchfield, Conn., Marie-Louise Diedrick, a daughter of Adele d'Assern Taylor of Caldwell, Idaho, and Arthur Hill Diedrick Jr. of New York and Litchfield, was married yesterday to John Mark Witcher, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Rex Witcher of Colorado Springs. The Rev. Allen W. Farabee performed the ceremony.

title: Keeping Fit
description: To the Editor: My wife and I have taken many long international flights and just returned from Hawaii where my wife had to stand frequently to handle a back problem that had occurred recently.

title: Why Rock Hasn't Rescued Broadway
description: Ever since 1967, when ''Hair'' first opened at the Public Theater, many have assumed that somehow our ailing musical-theater tradition would be salvaged by rock-oriented musicians. In the most optimistic scenario, it was hoped that such leading singer-songwriters of the 60's and 70's as Paul Simon, Randy Newman and James Taylor would graduate from records into the theater and overhaul Broadway, bringing their audiences with them.

title: Jennifer Bingham Marries
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, Jennifer L. Bingham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel D. Bingham of New York and Argyle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Graham Pelham Agee, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Pelham Agee of Basking Ridge, N.J., and Pawley's Island, S.C. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley officiated. The bride, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is a financial associate for the New York investment-banking division of the Seltzer Organization, a Philadelphia real-estate development company. Mr. Agee is a municipal bond trader for Quick & Reilly in New York.

title: When Choreographers Get the Urge to Go Afield
description: There are times when theaters are not enough - times when dancers feel inspired to perform in rotundas or atriums, in front of civic monuments or on park lawns or city streets. Such locations challenge the imagination.

title: Mariners Get Only One Hit Off Ryan
description: Nolan Ryan pitched his 11th career one-hitter and struck out 11 as the Texas Rangers beat the Seattle Mariners, 6-1, tonight.

title: Revitalizing a Fading Tradition: Living Over the Store
description: Their Ossining home is a showplace, furnished with period antiques, Oriental rugs, and memorabilia from frequent trips abroad. But friends searching for the home of Voni and Charles Yerkes have a hard time finding the front door, sandwiched as it is between T/T Auto Parts and Main Street Hardware.

title: Who Dares to Enter The Political Woods?
description: WASHINGTON

title: Paul and Benjamin Steinitz - Gallery Owners
description: When they came to New York from Paris a few years ago and decided to open an art gallery, Paul and Benjamin Steinitz settled on the meat-packing district of Greenwich Village.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: AFTER THE WAR. By Frederic Raphael. (Viking, $19.95.) The British screenwriter and playwright Frederic Raphael's latest novel, ''After the War,'' actually begins in the grim days of World War II, with the narrator, a young boy named Michael, sequestered in a makeshift prep school, far from the bombs then falling on London.

title: Car Stereo In High Gear
description: Leisure has shrunk rather than grown, as machines relentlessly forced their own pace upon the general scheme of things, rarely leaving time enough for listening to music at home. Instead, music nowadays hits the road, becoming literally the better part of commuters' daily travels. It's Haydn on the highway, Monteverdi by the mile.

title: Professor Backs Natural Gas for Autos
description: THE day may well come when motorists pulling into a service station in this country will say, ''Gas it up,'' and mean real gas, not gasoline. If that happens, Dr. Enoch J. Durbin, a 66-year-old professor of engineering at Princeton University, will not be surprised.

title: Poland Flirts With Pluralism Today
description: Solidarity, born in 1980 as an independent trade union, is being reborn on Sunday as an all-but-official opposition party in the first openly contested election in Eastern Europe in more than four decades.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: My Stepmother Is an Alien 1988. RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video. 1 hour, 48 minutes. $89.95. Closed captioned. PG-13. Kim Basinger, in a role that is ''as winningly played as [ it ] is annoyingly written,'' is Celeste, an alien sent to Earth to sweet-talk a scientist (Dan Aykroyd) out of secrets that will save her planet. This entails sleeping with and cooking for the fellow, which seems hardly worth the effort with Mr. Aykroyd, ''who isn't the least bit funny . . . in this role, nor remotely suited to play a romantic lead.'' Miss Basinger ''ought to be more than enough to make the film interesting. But, unfortunately, she's not alone.'' (Janet Maslin) The Prisoner 1955. RCA/Columbia. 1:31. $69.95. Not rated. Charged with treason, Alec Guinness, as a character based on Hungary's Jozsef Cardinal Mindszenty, is psychically pulled apart by a skillful state interrogator (Jack Hawkins) in a film that, in the words of a reviewer in 1955, says much ''about the character and dignity - or lack of dignity - of men who live under the rule of political tyrants.'' Mr. Guinness, in a role of ''tremendous intellectual complexity,'' performs with ''such clarity and feeling that it strikes the very marrow of your bones.'' Random Harvest 1942. MGM/UA. 2:08. $29.95. CC. Not rated. With Greer Garson and Ronald Coleman, directed by Mervin LeRoy from James Hilton's novel, this is, wrote one critic, ''a towering picture, filled entirely with emotional lights and shades.'' An amnesiac (Mr. Coleman) tries to remember his wife (Miss Garson). ''What we see here is a story shaped entirely by chance . . .love lost and then recaptured after an uncommon lot of emotional strain . . . directed in slow tempo with an eye to poignant moods.'' All of that added up to seven Oscar nominations. Pat and Mike 1952. MGM/UA Home Video. 1:35. $29.95. CC. Not rated. Katharine Hepburn is an athlete and Spencer Tracy her manager in George Cukor's frolic about an amateur who turns pro. A reviewer wrote that Miss Hepburn can handle a racquet or golf club ''as adroitly as she can sling an epigram'' in a ''likable fable about a highly coordinated dame who takes over an authoritative guy, with slight overtones of honor triumphing over shadiness and greed.'' Butterfield 8 1960. MGM/UA. 1:49. $29.95. Not rated. Elizabeth Taylor won the Academy award as a pricey call girl in Daniel Mann's film derived from the novel by John O'Hara. ''I was the slut of all time,'' Gloria Wandorous (Miss Taylor) tells her mother (Mildred Dunnock) at one point. Maybe, but, wrote one critic, she ''looks like a million dollars, in mink or negligee.'' Laurence Harvey plays a man always out of reach, and a character named Steve turns out to be Eddie Fisher. The Postman Always Rings Twice 1946. MGM/UA. 1:52. $29.95. Laser Disk (Image Entertainment), $34.95. CC. Not rated. Cora Smith (Lana Turner) and Frank Chambers (John Garfield) take time out from passion long enough to kill her husband (Cecil Kellaway), only to discover that you ''can't monkey with murder.'' The film retains the realistic style and terse dialogue of James M. Cain's novel. ''The buildup of incident and character has the rhythm of a throttled-down machine,'' wrote a reviewer, and ''the moments of cold, deliberate violence suddenly burst with accelerated force.'' I'll Cry Tomorrow 1956. MGM/UA. 1:59. $29.95. Not rated. This is the autobiographical story of Lillian Roth's 16-year ''bout with booze, told straight, without water or sugar.'' As Ms. Roth, Susan Hayward was nominated for an Oscar. ''The dramatic punch of such an intensely intimate story depends almost wholly upon the utter candor of its re-creation,'' wrote a reviewer. ''The strong part [ of the film ] is that in which Miss Hayward indicates the actual agonies of Miss Roth.''

title: Strawberries Are Here and It's Time for Desserts
description: THE local strawberry season has started. These rich, ripe berries, whether purchased from a farmstand or gathered from a farm that allows pickers, are highly perishable and should be used within a day.

title: Bush's Arms Plan Sets the Alliance On a Bolder Course
description: IN the great debate on the destiny of Europe, President Bush last week shifted the United States out of the camp of prudence and vigilance and into the camp of optimism and movement. In so doing, he acknowledged the strategic importance within the Atlantic alliance of West Germany, which has seemingly resolved to take Mikhail S. Gorbachev's innovations as harbingers of a lasting peace that could profoundly alter the division of Europe.

title: Deaths of 19 Prostitutes Pose a Mystery in Miami
description: The circumstances suggest foul play. The bodies of all 19 women were found in the same section of the city in outside areas like fields, or they were behind buildings. Yet medical examiners said they had found no wounds on the bodies, no bruises, no scratches, no needle marks. Nothing.

title: Pistons Raise Sights
description: When the Detroit Pistons won the Eastern Conference championship Friday night in Chicago, they celebrated in a subdued manner. There was no champagne. There were few embraces. Whatever satisfaction they felt was tempered because their ultimate goal was not yet accomplished. For the Pistons, winning the National Basketball Association championship is the only accomplishment that will make this season special.

title: THE DEADLY GAME
description: Though Lesley Hazleton makes British soccer graphic in all its dispiriting ugliness, it is remarkable that she does so with only a passing reference (''bellies filled with strong English ale'') to an important - and closely related - factor: alcohol consumption.

title: Danger: Underage Drinking
description: THIS summer, about 50,000 New Jersey college students will come home for vacations. Some will take temporary jobs, many will work on projects, others will travel. But almost all undergraduates will, at some time, gather with their friends at parties and reunions.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MUSIC IN THE MANORS Since a little history never hurt anyone, including music lovers, today's the day for fanciers of both to get together at either Sagtikos Manor in West Bay Shore or the Joseph Lloyd Manor House in Lloyd Harbor. Each site is pre-Revolutionary and belonged to a prominent Long Islander: Sagtikos, circa the 1600's with additions in 1758, to the powerful Thompson-Gardiner clan, who really entertained George Washington in April 1790, and the Lloyd Manor, circa 1767, to a a wealthy merchant who owned Jupiter Hammon, the first black poet to be published in the United States.

title: 'We Don't Have Time'
description: The intifada has gone on for 18 months now, far longer than anyone thought possible. The Palestinians of the West Bank and Gaza have decisively asserted their national identity and their will to be free of the occupation.

title: 17 Artists to Participate In a Chamber Festival
description: ''IF you were there last year,'' said Ruth Glasser Sommers, the cellist who founded the Dobbs Ferry Chamber Festival, ''you experienced the joy of chamber music exuberantly performed. If you missed it, now is your chance.''

title: Gingrich, Pursuer of Democrats, Now Finds Himself the Pursued
description: Representative Newt Gingrich's role in bringing down House Speaker Jim Wright seems to have set him up for a Wright-style roasting that could determine his future as the leader of the young and aggressive backbenchers bidding for control of their party in the House.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: SANTA BARBARA, CALIF.;
Downtown Mall Clears Hurdles
description: LEAD: SANTA BARBARA'S first downtown shopping mall is under construction after nearly 20 years of false starts. The plans have been reviewed by nine civic committees, including two groups that scrutinize every architectural detail in this resort community 120 miles northwest of Los Angeles.

title: Rambo Dancer Wins a Photo Finish
description: The late Red Smith particularly enjoyed writing about the names that people give horses, so it was altogether appropriate that the $120,600 Red Smith Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday ended with a tight finish and an ironic twist involving the names of the horses involved.

title: Japan Begins Broadcasts of High-Definition TV
description: Japan began the world's first daily broadcasts of high-definition television programs today, leaping ahead in a politicized race with the United States and Europe for command of the next generation of television technology.

title: Hartford Stage is Playing to Success
description: FOUR seasons ago, the Hartford Stage Company was going through its worst of times. Its debt exceeded $400,000, subscriptions had fallen to an all-time low of 8,900 and confidence in the risk-oriented repertory favored by the artistic director, Mark Lamos, was wobbly. Now, in a turnaround that for dramatic surprise may rival a cunningly crafted play, the company, in its 25th year, is enjoying its best of times.

title: Teresa H. Clarke Is Married to Walter K. Booker
description: Teresa Hillary Clarke, the daughter of Audrey M. Clarke of Los Angeles, was married yesterday at All Saints by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Santa Barbara, Calif., to Walter Kettel Booker, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Booker of Columbia, S.C. The Rev. G. Stewart Barns performed the ceremony.

title: Marcia A. Ferdon Weds Consultant
description: Marcia Anne Ferdon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Ferdon of Alpine, N.J., and Hamilton, Bermuda, was married yesterday to David Read Crampton at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Closter, N.J., by the Rev. Daniel O'Neill. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Neal Crampton of Westport, Conn., and East Orleans, Mass.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Sometimes, especially at a private party, you wonder why they're there? Are they friends of the host? Were they brought by someone? Why, within minutes after their arrival, are they alone? Why are they not part of the crowd swirling around them?

title: Rabbi Disputes Report of His Views
description: Herbert Hadad's article ''A Leader of P.L.O. Is to Speak'' [ May 14 ] misquotes my words and severely distorts my attempt to build bridges of understanding between Arabs and Jews. In its distortion of my statement, The Times inflames passions on a topic already too hot for reasonable dialogue. The article's manipulation of facts and quotations makes it more difficult for the moderates of both sides to establish the middle ground of understanding on which peace might be established.

title: ISRAEL: MIRED IN THE WEST BANK
description: If, as the Israeli philosopher David Hartman insists, the memories of the Holocaust and the unrelenting hostilities of neighboring states account for a kind of national political angst, one must remember that the actions of others have exacerbated this condition.

title: Ann Lourie Is Married
description: Ann Bradford Lourie, the daughter of Mrs. Robert P. Stout of Bronxville, N.Y., and Donold K. Lourie of Siasconset, Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to Douglas Cushman Merrill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Merrill of Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. Edward B. Anderson, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the Union Chapel in Siasconset.

title: Abigail Aldridge Marries Writer
description: Abigail Nancy Aldridge, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Aldridge of Westpoint, Me., was married in New York yesterday to Steven Lawrence Kroll, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Julius Kroll of New York. The Rev. Donald S. Harrington, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Radio City Suite at Rockefeller Center.

title: Health Care Isn't A Free Ride
description: THE health system in the United States is undergoing a major upheaval. Health care rendered in a traditional way is vanishing without much explanation. In place of a system that provides necessary care to those in need, we have a system of increased rationing and rapidly limited resources.

title: Summer, a Time to Study the Arts
description: FOR students with an art orientation, summer vacation provides opportunities for study with working professionals in residential or daytime settings. Aspiring artists, dancers, musicians, actors and writers can select from a range of programs that serve a wide geographical area and offer a variety of options for training and performance.

title: Lockerbie Holds Party Commemorating Crash
description: Hundreds of people ate hot dogs and listened to music today at a party thrown for the village where Pan Am Flight 103 fell to earth, but relatives of some crash victims said the good time was in bad taste.

title: Taiwan's Chief Acknowledges Communist Control of China
description: President Lee Teng-hui said today that if Taiwan wanted to regain international recognition it must admit that the Communists rule mainland China.

title: Dr. J. I. Greenfeld Wed to Ms. Levy
description: Elizabeth Andrea Levy, the daughter of Cynthia Levy of New York and Dr. Roger N. Levy of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married last evening to Dr. Jonathan Ian Greenfeld, a son of Dr. Albert R. Greenfeld and Dr. Sandra Greenfeld of Westlake Village, Calif. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

title: Challenge Issued To Local Educators
description: LEAD: IN an impassioned plea to his former colleagues, the State Education Commissioner, Thomas Sobol, challenged 160 of the Westchester area's top school officials to make a long-term commitment to ''genuine fundamental reforms.''

title:
THE WORLD;
Deeper Fractures In Central America
description: LEAD: WHEN President-elect Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador visited Oscar Arias Sanchez last month, the Costa Rican leader asked him to invite Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua to the inauguration.

title: Lehman's 10th Season
description: The singer Harry Belafonte will open the 10th-anniversary season of the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts, on Sept. 23. Other programs will feature Mel Torme and Maureen McGovern, the New York Pops and Skitch Henderson, Judy Collins and James Galway, and the Royal Winnepeg Ballet.
