The center is at Lehman College of the City University of New York, Bedford Park Boulevard and Goulden Avenue in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx. Information and tickets: 960-8833 or 307-7171.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: The seams of coal in the Appalachians changed the country and gave rise to a peculiar and somewhat seedy form of token known as company scrip or flickers.

title: Long Island Journal
description: Pick Your Own Stalk ''I DIDN'T think they would be so obvious,'' said Ruth Henze as she surveyed the field of vegetables. ''I thought maybe they'd be hidden in bushes. They could have grown on trees for all I know. But just popping out of the dirt like this, well it looks Mount St. Helen's landscape.

title: TROOPS ATTACK AND CRUSH BEIJING PROTEST; THOUSANDS FIGHT BACK, SCORES ARE KILLED
description: Tens of thousands of Chinese troops retook the center of the capital early this morning from pro-democracy protesters, killing scores of students and workers and wounding hundreds more as they fired submachine guns at crowds of people who tried to resist.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: PAINTING EXCHANGE An exchange of paintings between two American Impressionist museums, one in Connecticut and the other on Long Island, is the basis for ''En Plein Air: The Art Colonies at East Hampton and Old Lyme, 1880-1930.'' The Connecticut exhibition runs Saturday to July 30, the East Hampton show from June 18 to July 30. Financed in part by the National Endowment for the Arts, this is the first such exchange of the regional collections.

title: Wendy Crandall Is Wed
description: Wendy Jane Crandall, the circulation manager of Bon Appetit magazine, and Glenn Ronald Weber, an assistant vice president of Johnson & Higgins, insurance brokers, both in New York, were married yesterday at the George Washington Manor in Roslyn, L.I. The Rev. Lois Hines, a Methodist minister, officiated.

title: But First This Message From Buick
description: Will viewers eschew the fast-forward control and watch product commercials on videos of top feature films? Earlier this year, a commercial for Schweppes on ''A Fish Called Wanda,'' performed by one of the film's stars, John Cleese, had high audience acceptance. But, wonder studios and advertisers, will there be consumer backlash over further encroachments into generally commercial-free territory?

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: GRASS clutched at the bottom of the gate, but I was adamant and the weathered latticework finally opened wide enough to let me slip through. I didn't trouble to close it. I didn't think it would stand the strain.

title: Andrea Robinson - Cosmetics Executive
description: Few people would guess Andrea Robinson's profession by her appearance. A cosmetics executive would surely be more flagrantly painted, varnished and coiffed. But Mrs. Robinson, 46 years old, is transforming Revlon's Ultima II line in her own image.

title: Robes That Wear Well With a Host
description: Summer houseguests can make points with a clever gift, a willing hand at the kitchen sink - and a crisp and neatly wrapped appearance first thing in the morning. In most houses, a bath towel just won't do and a negligee is distinctly de trop.

title: Super 301's Big Bite Flouts the Rules
description: In her confirmation hearings, Carla A. Hills, the United States Trade Representative, used the imagery of a crowbar to underline her intention to pry open foreign markets. After her testimony, capital insiders rushed to reassure the world that Ms. Hills needed to talk rough on Capitol Hill but that she will hang tough against Section 301 of the 1988 Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act, which is known as Super 301.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The latex paint on the wood trim in my entrance hall has started to blister and peel. This paint was applied a number of years ago over the original oil paint put on 39 years ago. I believe there are two coats of latex. Where the paint has peeled, the original oil paint, which was a different color, is intact. Can you suggest a cause for this peeling and a way to prevent it in the future?

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Property Acquisition; Why Investors in Manhattan Take Long-Term Leases
description: AS property sales dwindle in Manhattan because of the tax repercussions, more investors are settling for a second-rate option - deals that give them control of office buildings for up to 49 years.

title: Picking a Place to Move for Retirement
description: Many people intend to move when they retire, looking for a more attractive life style, perhaps, or to be closer to family.

title: High Schools Lure Seniors Into Having Safe and Sober Fun
description: FOR several years it was the custom of parents and teachers at Weston High School to give a graduation party for the departing seniors. The intention was to keep the students away from parties where there would be alcohol and drugs.

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Michael Moffatt;
Undergraduate Life the 2d Time Around
description: LEAD: WHEN Michael Moffatt was an undergraduate at Dartmouth College, one of his first papers was an anthropological analysis of the college's Freshman Week. Years later, as an associate professor of anthropology at Rutgers University here, Mr. Moffatt set out to analyze college culture once again. But this time to learn about the students' lives, he decided to pose as a student.

title: Patricia J. Netter Is Married on L.I.
description: Patricia Jane Netter, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Netter of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to William McAlpin Shiland Jr., a son of the late Harriet Manice Shiland of Old Westbury, L.I., and the late Mr. Shiland of Locust Valley, L.I., and New York. The Rev. Robert F. Capon officiated at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton.

title: ABC Revives 'Hooperman' for Summer
description: ABC has announced that ''Hooperman,'' a weekly series that starred John Ritter as a police detective in San Francisco, will return to the network's prime-time schedule for the summer, beginning on June 14. The half-hour show will be broadcast on Wednesdays at 9 P.M. The network will present five new episodes of the series, which is produced by Steven Bochco and Terry Louise Fisher, as well as repeats. ABC dropped ''Hooperman'' in March and did not renew it for the fall.

title: 30 ARtists Show Off Their 'Junk'
description: AT the moment, visitors to the Whitney Museum's branch here are finding its main gallery dominated by what is manifestly a heap of old wood. Yet, the way the beams, lashed together with chains, stand their ground in the pristine, almost airtight setting of this museum proclaims them to be a work of art, and by no less a sculptor than Mark di Suvero. Besides, where else but in an art museum would so ambiguous a pile be given house room?

title: An Essay in English Gothic
description: STAMFORD is foremost among the towns of Lincolnshire, one of the county's and of England's most memorable places. It is situated just off the A1, the Great North Road joining London and Scotland, in a narrow isthmus between the old counties of Rutland and Northamptonshire. Few places can match it for the wealth and variety of its buildings, but what makes a visit to Stamford so special is the unspoiled charm of the townscape as a whole, with its mix of Gothic spires and Georgian houses, all set off by gentle hills, meadows and the River Welland.

title: POSTINGS: Free at Federal Hall; Window Exhibit
description: For the person who has a yen to look back through a time warp at what has gone before in window design, an exhibition and workshop on Thursday, June 15, at Federal Hall, 26 Wall Street, may be just the thing. The New York Landmarks Conservancy and the National Park Service have gotten together to sponsor ''Windows Through Time, an Exhibit of Historic American Windows and Workshop on Window Rehabilitation and Replacement.''

title: A Doctor's Office Without Appointments
description: ON a recent Sunday morning, a weekend gardener stabbed himself in the leg when he tripped over a rake. Instead of driving him to the emergency room at the local hospital, his wife took him to Metro-Med, a walk-in medical office on Central Avenue in Yonkers, where he immediately received a tetanus shot and two stitches in his leg. Less than an hour later, he was back in his garden, relaxing in a lawn chair.

title: Central American Nations Urged to Take Lead on Refugees
description: The United States and other Western countries have approved a plan by five Central American nations for resettling the roughly two million people driven from their homes in the region by more than a decade of strife and civil war.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Contracts Be Honored Or Ignored?
description: One of the components leading to the probable decline and fall of the American Empire is dishonesty. Once upon a time, man/woman needed only a handshake to seal a pact or make a bargain, and both sides honored their commitment. When a handshake no longer sufficed, the written word, with legal signatures and official seals, took its place. Now, it seems that even a contract no longer guarantees honor on the part of both signers. EILEEN W. COHN Douglaston, Queens

title: Question Of the Week; Should Contracts Be Honored Or Ignored?
description: In this day that allows select baseball players to file for arbitration, why bother with contracts?

title: A June 18 Bridal For Joanne Ross
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Ross have announced June 18 wedding plans for their daughter, Joanne Ross, and Benjamin Simon, a son of Marion Simon of Homestead, Pa., and the late Rudolph Simon.

title: As the Thrift Bailout Plan Gets Backed Up, The Meter Keeps Running for Congress
description: PRESIDENT BUSH imbued Congress with a sense of emergency in February when he asked that his bailout plan for the savings and loan industry be passed within 45 days.

title: Pioneering Programs in Hospice Care
description: We certainly favor the concept of hospice as an alternative method of care and as a cost-effective one for families who choose this method.

title: How Bush Finally Got Foreign Policy Pizazz
description: THE making of President Bush's dazzling initiatives at the NATO summit last week began inauspiciously. After a four-month review of American foreign policy, it all came down to a long weekend at President Bush's Kennebunkport home. By all accounts the President was angry. His mountain of papers, the product of his bureaucracy's much ballyhooed effort to set the framework for his Administration's foreign and defense policies, had produced a mouse. So over the weekend of May 19th Mr. Bush and his Cabinet advisers put together their own arms control initiatives.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: DETROIT;
Introducing Loft Living
description: LEAD: AFTER several failed attempts by developers in the last decade, the Stearns Building, a vacant turn-of-the-century structure on the Detroit riverfront two miles from downtown, is finally being converted to residential use.

title: Ms. Sorokin Wed To R. W. Kessler
description: Emily Sorokin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Sorokin of West Hartford, Conn., and Robert W. Kessler, a son of Dr. Edwin Kessler of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Mrs. Kessler, were married last evening. Rabbi Steven J. Mason officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Libya Said to Halt Arms Deliveries to Lebanon
description: Libya has abruptly stopped supplying money and arms to hard-line Lebanese groups and Palestinian guerrilla factions in Lebanon after more than a decade, leaders here and Arab diplomats say.

title: Arlene Ford Married to C. P. Reynolds
description: Arlene Jennifer Ford, an associate in the New York law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges, and Christopher Paul Reynolds, an associate in the firm of Hughes Hubbard & Reed, also in New York, were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. C. Hall Powers performed the ceremony. Mrs. Reynolds, a daughter of Clifton L. Ford of Hollis, Queens, and the late Barbara Carr of Kingston, Jamaica, graduated from St. John's University. She and her husband received law degrees from Harvard University. Her father is a real-estate developer in New York.

title: The Longing For an Empty Nest
description: MY family and I have not been using our kitchen door - the one that is convenient to the driveway and garage - for the past week. We are being considerate of a purple finch that is nesting just outside. But I'm beginning to feel more than consideration for the bird; I am identifying with her.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE WIDOW OF DESIRE. By Justin Scott. (Bantam, $17.95.) Justin Scott's 10th novel can be described in one word: confusing. Television may be the medium best suited to such a convoluted tale: with a few visual reference points, it might actually be possible to distinguish all the nasty men with long names.

title:
ART;
The Mind's Eye as Creator
description: LEAD: I BELIEVE it was Marcel Duchamp who said that a work of art is finished not by the artist, but by the viewer. This completion is, of course, psychic rather than physical, since it is accomplished through perception and interpretation instead of creation.

title: And Now, The No-Frills David Bowie
description: David Bowie's 1987 Stadium extravaganza, the Glass Spider Tour, was overstuffed with dancers, props, videoprojections and fancy lighting effects. But for one stretch the trappings disappeared while Mr. Bowie and his band simply knocked out rockers like ''Rebel Rebel.'' Now Mr. Bowie has realized it was the best part of the show.

title: M. P. Starn Wed To Ms. Pasternak
description: Anne Robin Pasternak, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Pasternak of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday to Michael Paul Starn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Robert Starn of Absecon, N.J. Charles H. Felson, a justice of the peace, officiated at the Wadsworth Athenaeum in Hartford.

title: SILENT SHOES'S LAST RIDE
description: BILL SHOEMAKER IS LOOKING for an opening.

title: Gary S. Barancik Weds Tia Wolfson
description: The marriage of Tia Sue Wolfson, a daughter of Dr. Sanford Wolfson and Dr. Devora Wolfson of Wayne, N.J., to Gary Scott Barancik, the son of Lynn Barancik and Bill Barancik, both of Los Angeles, took place yesterday at the Harvard Club in New York. Judge Marie M. Lambert of Surrogate's Court in New York officiated.

title: TOWARD A CONTINENTAL HODGPODGE
description: EUROPE, EUROPE Forays Into a Continent. By Hans Magnus Enzensberger. Translated by Martin Chalmers. 325 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $18.95.

title: In Apartment Market, the Tone Is Flat
description: WHEN Anita Lobel began trying to sell a Greenwich Village apartment in January 1988, she joined thousands of New Yorkers facing a difficult reality in the market for cooperatives and condominiums, a reality that has taken time to sink in.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q & A: DR. THOMAS LANE;
''Modern Life Styles May Play a Role''
description: LEAD: SINCE it was identified by medical researchers last year, chronic fatigue syndrome has become a subject of controversy.

title: FROM JOHN SAYLES, A FLAWED HERO FOR THE 90'S
description: The pilot is one of television's more slippery creations. Depending on varying combinations of ratings, reviews and audience research, it can lead directly to a regular weekly series, which in turn means big money and at least temporary fame for most concerned.

title: Jacqueline Lourie Parker Is Married
description: Jacqueline Lourie Parker and Stanton John Freeman were married last evening at the couple's home in New York by Rabbi Richard S. Chapin.

title: Transactions
description: FRIDAY Baseball

title: Finding a Bit of Peace on the Vineyard
description: The long bumpy road to the Long Point Wildlife Refuge on the south shore of Martha's Vineyard - an unmarked dirt track that turns off the Edgartown-West Tisbury Road into a sand pit - inflicts equal punishment on the car and the driver's nerves. As the scrub oak wood closes in and the dirt tracks fork randomly, the feeling of being hopelessly lost sinks into the pit of the stomach. Yes, one wanted to get away from the crowds of tourists at Edgartown and Oak Bluffs, but not this far.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Augusta, Me.; Farm Buffer Zone Faulted
description: THE Maine Association of Realtors and a host of property owners are working to change a state law passed last year that bars development within 150 feet of a registered farm. They say the law favors the farmer at the expense of the individual landowner because the 150-foot buffer zone is on the abutter's, not the farmer's, land.

title: A Museum Exhibits a Splendid Lack of Glitz
description: In an age in which museums are increasingly grand, elaborate and pretentious, it is refreshing to see one that is grand, elaborate and reasonable. The Chrysler Museum, which until 1971 was known as the Norfolk Museum of Arts and Sciences, has just completed a $13.5 million expansion and reconstruction that stands out by its refusal to stand out: the building's new wings have been designed not to make an aggressive ''statement'' but to join the disparate parts of the museum into a coherent whole.

title: Good Times In Behalf Of 2 Good Causes
description: A touch of Harlem came to Roseland on West 52d Street Wednesday night. About 750 guests turned out to support the only tuition-free, private school in Harlem, the Children's Storefront. The crowd included 175 parents, students and teachers from the school. ''We've outgrown the church basement in Harlem where we used to give this party,'' said Eleanor Meglio, one of the evening's organizers.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: POIGNANT POEMS ''I used to be locked up in a room without the key. My mother would go to work, came in late, was never there. The guy with whom she lived would come home and hell would start.'' Those are the opening lines of a poem by Nilsa Curet, one of ''The Women of the Regent Hotel.''

title: NO HOPE FOR JOSEPH, OR ANYBODY
description: HIS DAUGHTER By Yoram Kaniuk. Translated by Seymour Simckes. 293 pp. New York: George Braziller. $17.50.

title:
GARDENING;
Dusting and Spraying: A Must for Roses
description: LEAD: EVERYONE enjoys the beauty of roses, but not everyone is willing to put forth the effort to grow them.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: SHATTEMUC YACHT CLUB;
Sailing the Hudson's Tricky Waters
description: LEAD: THE Hudson River may be scenic and historic and all right for the occasional canoe, but real sailors stick to the Sound and the open sea, right?

title: The Elvis Revue And the Art Of the Deal Photos of Johnny Seaton in ''Elvis: A Rockin' Remembrance'' (pg. 21); Terry Mike Jeffrey, Johnny Seaton and Julian Whitaker, the three ''Elvi'' who play the King at various ages in the show (pg. 33)
description: THE MOST UNUSUAL THING about the multimedia, multimillion-dollar musical, ''Elvis: A Rockin' Remembrance,'' opening Tuesday at the Beacon Theater, may be that it got to the stage in the first place.

title: PAPERBCK BEST SELLERS: June 4, 1989
description: $ Weeks ThisOn Week List Fiction 1 2 DEFY NOT THE HEART, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $4.50.) The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Lakers 'Arrived At the Right Time'
description: The weather was gorgeous, the scenery was picturesque, and adoring Los Angeles Lakers fans were waiting outside. But inside, behind closed doors, the Lakers were enduring another grueling practice, supervised by Pat Riley, their relentless coach and taskmaster.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Did Pitino Make the Right Move?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Feb. 12, with an article about Salvador Dali's bequest of his works to the Spanish state rather than to his native region of Catalonia, misidentified the sculptor whose work Dali's coffin was passing.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; For Tiny Columbia, a Huge Development
description: A PROPOSAL for a 1,000-acre mixed-use project in the tiny Tolland County town of Columbia took local officials by surprise because of its size, but the official reaction has favored of the development.

title: To France Via the Golden Gate Bridge
description: The news from the fine Arts Museums in San Francisco is that under their new director, Harry S. Parker 3d, who was formerly director of the Fine Art Museum in Dallas, both the California Palace of the Legion of Honor in Lincoln Park and the M.H. de Young Memorial Museum in Golden Gate Park have changed their character in ways that have aroused quite a stir in the city.

title: June 3, 1979: Shoreham's Rainy Day
description: JUNE is a many-splendored month, but no June day in the memory of Shoreham opponents was more splendid than June 3, 1979. It was a watershed event for Long Island, that demonstration against the Shoreham nuclear plant 10 years ago.

title: Correction
description: The Personal Finance column last week about central asset accounts referred incorrectly to features of the Active Assets Account offered by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. The account is indeed linked to an automated teller machine network - the Plus, which has 30,000 locations. It does provide automated bill-paying for fixed monthly payments like mortgages. And its daily ''sweeps'' into a money market fund apply to uninvested cash of more than $1, not to invested cash.

title: Child Killed and 36 Are Hurt In Bus Accident in Colorado
description: A school bus returning from a field trip plunged off a mountain road near this central Colorado town Friday, killing one student and injuring 36 others.

title: An Accountant's Debt
description: It was crime-busting with a sculptor's bust. Eighteen years ago, John E. List, a churchgoing accountant in Westfield, N.J., vanished after his mother, wife and three children were found shot to death in their home. The search for the fugitive was futile until the case was featured on May 21 on a television program, ''America's Most Wanted,'' with a bust, shown here, depicting what the fugitive might look like now, with wrinkles and a receding hairline. Last week, on a tip from a viewer, F.B.I. agents arrested another churchgoing accountant in Richmond, Va. He had a new name, Robert P. Clark, and a new wife, but he still had Mr. List's fingerprints and telltale scar behind his ear. The arrest of the suspect, now 63 years old, delighted James F. Moran, Westfield's former police chief who had doggedly followed leads even after his retirement in 1986. ''How can a guy murder five people and walk away?'' Mr. Moran said.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: LENOX, MASS.;
A Second Spa For Berkshires
description: LEAD: ANOTHER estate property in this resort area of Berkshire County has become a health resort. It is the second in the western Massachusetts county, with a third scheduled to open later this year.

title: Wales
description: To the Editor: Having just returned from a hiking trip in Wales I'd like to suggest an alternative to the do-it-yourself walking tours of Wales described by Pamela J. Petro (''Footloose on the Byways of Wales'' Travel, April 23). I recommend that readers consider an experience far easier to arrange, offered by High Trek Snowdonia, which provides weeklong guided walking trips in the Snowdonia area. The very reasonable fee includes all specialized clothing and gear, six days of guided walks, hearty food for all meals, and accommodation in cozy bed and breakfast hotels each night, except for one night in a tent and one night in a mountain hut. We had a flexible itinerary suited to the participants' desires and level of fitness, excellent leadership, a small group (no more than six people), and of course terrific scenery and very unpredictable weather (including blizzards as well as sunbathing by mountain lakes!). High Trek Snowdonia can be contacted at Tal y Waen, Deiniolen, Gwynedd LL55 3NA, Wales; telephone Llanberis (0286 871232). PEGGY F. HULL Durham, N.C.

title: Review/Dance; Peaceful Coexistence in Martins Work
description: The New York City Ballet blended disparate dance styles Wednesday night at the New York State Theater by offering Peter Martins's ''Barber Violin Concerto.'' Created last year for the company's American Music Festival, it was performed in this revival by the same cast that danced its premiere. The casting suggested what this inventive ballet is about.

title: On Tiananmen Square, Echoes of Chicago in '68
description: If they are not pushed too far, there are astounding parallels between the Chinese students demonstrating for democracy in Tiananmen Square in recent weeks and the American students demonstrating for an end to the Vietnam War at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago in 1968, before most of those Chinese students were even born.

title: Syphilis Rise in Connecticut Is Blamed on Cocaine Abuse
description: The number of syphilis cases in Connecticut is growing, largely because of drugs and prostitution, state officials said.

title: CONSUMER RATES
PEOPLE OF THE PURPLE SEA
description: THE PHOENICIANS Edited by Sabatino Moscati. Illustrated. 764 pp. New York: Abbeville Press. $125.

title: CHINA ERUPTS . . . THE REASONS WHY
description: EMPERORS AND EUNUCHS, WARLORDS and revolutionaries - all have presided over Beijing's Tiananmen Square. Last month was the turn of the hunger strikers.

title: Correction
description: An article on the theater page of the Arts and Leisure section today about the Manhattan Theater Club's production of ''Lisbon Traviata'' gives an incorrect opening date in some copies. The show opens on Tuesday, not Thursday.

title: 'Regurgitating The TV News'
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Approves School Choice Program in Boston
description: Boston can go ahead with a plan allowing students more choice about where they go to public school, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: The Battle to Turn Around Lomas
description: Once the nation's largest mortgage banker, the Lomas Financial Corporation thought a year ago that it had outrun the disaster in Texas real estate and the competitive upheaval in mortgage lending.

title: Foundation
description: To the Editor:

title: The Polish Vote
description: The Solidarity labor union takes a step toward becoming a broad political movement today as Poles vote in the first openly contested elections in the Soviet bloc.

title: The High Price Of Winning
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Chicago Rival Will Look Down on Sears Tower
description: The city of big shoulders and bigger egos already has the tallest building in the world, the Sears Tower - and now that is not enough.

title: For Argentina, Inflation and Rage Rise in Tandem
description: AFTER mobs looted six of Salvador Zito's butcher shops last week, he decided to give away meat in his seventh store. Within minutes, hundreds of women formed a line that stretched for two blocks. ''It's very simple,'' the butcher said of the looting of supermarkets that swept Argentina last week. ''People here are very hungry.''

title: Any Way You Slice It, Graf Is the Best
description: What everyone is saying about Steffi Graf, they say about the dominant player in every generation. She is like Chris Evert when she was a youngster, she is like Martina Navratilova when she started to win, she is like Maureen Connolly in the '50s and Suzanne Lenglen in the '20s.

title: Learning the Three Indispensable Human Skills
description: CLEAR PICTURES First Loves, First Guides. By Reynolds Price. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95.

title: In a Wheelchair but in the Mainstream
description: WHEN David Clark graduates from Amity Regional High School in Woodbridge on June 23, his thoughts will likely be 3,000 miles away. In April, David, who was born with cerebral palsy, was accepted to the University of California in Berkeley. The idea of living in the city of his dreams makes most other events pale in comparison.

title:
GARDENING;
Dusting and Spraying: A Must for Roses
description: LEAD: EVERYONE enjoys the beauty of roses, but not everyone is willing to put forth the effort to grow them.

title:
INVESTING;
Profits as an Objet d'Art
description: LEAD: With prices of art skyrocketing, investors have been searching for ways to take advantage of the booming markets. Some analysts suggest the stocks of art retailers.

title: The Way Up From Poverty Begins in the Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets' Bats Begin to Resound
description: Every couple of minutes, the jets appeared in the sky above Shea Stadium's upper deck in left field and out beyond the scoreboard in right, rumbling off into the night. This, of course, was hardly remarkable. That they couldn't be either heard or felt was.

title: 'Skip-Stop' Subway Plan Annoys No. 1 Riders
description: A plan to speed service on the IRT No. 1 subway line by dividing it into two separate lines north of 116th Street has civic leaders up in arms and riders grumbling.

title: Deciding How Diligent Art Collectors Have to Be
description: ''HOW many Americans, including heartland Hoosiers, know that arcane detail?'' asked Joe C. Emerson, a lawyer representing Peg L. Goldberg, a local art dealer who is being sued here in Federal District Court.

title: On L.I., Skin Cancer Threat Appears to Be on the Increase
description: LEAD: DESPITE a widespread educational campaign aimed at its prevention, skin cancer in the United States is believed to be on the rise. This is also true for Long Island, where the disease is more prevalent than in many other parts of the country.

title: Calling Strike, Urdu Scribes Sheathe Pens
description: Several dozen calligraphers went on strike last week along India's newspaper row, reminding the Asian publishing world that there is still one language that has eluded the typesetter: Urdu.

title: Why a Dark Horse Triumphed in Louisville
description: A few weeks ago, the proprietors of the Grawemeyer Award in Louisville, Ky., announced that their winner was a composer named Chinary Ung. So what? you might wonder: there are lots of competitions, even composers' competitions. But this one was unusual in several respects.

title: Standing Ovations
description: Making his first appearance at Veterans Stadium in Philadelphia since announcing his retirement, Mike Schmidt received a two-minute standing ovation last night from a crowd of 37,000.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Waiting for a Turnaround in the Market
description: LEAD: FOLLOWING generally slow sales early in the spring, the Long Island housing market received a much needed boost late last month when more than 3,500 people showed up for the opening of sales at a 359-unit homeowners association in Holbrook called the Colony.

title: Severe Thunder Squall Kills 1 And Fells 2 Church Steeples
description: A severe thunder squall injured seven people and killed one, demolished two church steeples and ripped several roofs from buildings as it tore through northern Massachusetts today, the police said.

title: Residential Resales

Goldy) Wakefield $235,000 2202 Strang Avenue 3-family, detached, aluminum-frame house; 2 bedrooms, porch, fireplace in first-floor unit; 3 bedrooms, porch, fireplace in second floor unit, 1 bedroom on top floor; 1 bath, large kitchen in each; basement, 1-car garage, 50- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,476 (Broker: J.A.V. Realty) BROOKLYN Brooklyn Heights $570,000 62 Joralemon Street 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1,780-sq. ft. duplex co-op; in a prewar former Y.M.C.A. building; dining area, private roof deck, Manhattan skyline view; maintenance $940, 62% tax-deductible (Broker: Marilyn A. Donahue) Prospect Heights $190,000 10 Plaza Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,300-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining alcove, terrace, common roof deck; maintenance $606, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Joseph Berman Realty) QUEENS Bayside $100,000 202-15 42d Avenue 1-bedroom, 1-bath, postwar co-op; dining area, large kitchen, hardwood floors; maintenance $258, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Century 21/Weber & Rose) Elmhurst $58,000 40-18 Hampton Street (Hampton House) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 600-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining foyer, large kitchen; maintenance $398, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Kraham Realty) STATEN ISLAND Huguenot $213,000 558 Stafford Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, detached high-ranch; dining room, large kitchen, finished basement, 1-car garage; 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,680 (Broker: Schlott Realtors) Willowbrook $283,000 682 Colefield Avenue 2-family, detached colonial; 3 bedrooms, 1 1/2 baths, dining room, large kitchen in each unit; 50- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,250 (Broker: Kingsley Real Estate)

title: THE DEADLY GAME
description: In your article, the reader is haunted by the specter of a berserk, bloodthirsty mob. The collective violence of these thugs is, according to Ms. Hazleton, ''a reaction to the prim properness of Margaret Thatcher's determinedly middle-class regime . . .'' - a left-of-center analysis that, in one stroke, attacks Mrs. Thatcher and apologizes for the work of the hooligans.

title: A GRANDDAUGHTER'S FEAR
description: I wonder how many nerves Natalie Angier's article ''A Granddaughter's Fears'' touched (Hers, May 7). It certainly jolted me back several years. Although she had no major physical problems, my mother, a beautiful woman, became depressed as she aged. Having outlived her friends, her social life gone, she lost her zest for life. My family and I visited her daily; however, I always felt guilty that I wasn't doing enough. A wonderfully wise minister friend said to me: ''Do what you can for your mother, but remember, it is not in your power to make her happy. That has to come from within herself.'' I can't tell you of the release those words gave me. I did what I could for her with love, but I didn't chastise myself for not doing enough. OLIVE REICH Brooklyn

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: WORKERS ON THE WATERFRONT: Seamen, Longshoremen, and Unionism in the 1930s. By Bruce Nelson. (University of Illinois, $29.95.) Herman Melville lamented that seamen were ''deemed almost the refuse and offscourings of the earth,'' and in the 1930's Fortune magazine found little changed for this ''homeless, rootless, and eternally unmoneyed'' group.

title: Margaret O'Brien Weds
description: Margaret Ann O'Brien and Brian Grady McDonnell were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York by the Rev. Michael McHugh. Mrs. McDonnell is a daughter of Karen Frandi of Jackson Heights, Queens, and Thomas O'Brien of New York. Mr. O'Brien is the general manager of the Gramercy Park Hotel. Mr. McDonnell is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter McDonnell of Wantagh, L.I. The bridegroom's father is a sheet-metal worker.

title: U.S. Discovers Creative Talent It Can Count On
description: In beating Benfica of Portugal Friday night to reach the championship game in the Marlboro Cup tournament Sunday, the national team of the United States discovered three players who can contribute in its critical World Cup qualifying game against Guatemala in two weeks.

title: TOO SAD TO TIE HIS SHOES
description: LEAD: THE PLAY AND OTHER STORIES By Stephen Dixon. 160 pp. Minneapolis: Coffee House Press. Paper, $9.95.

title: Something Old Is Now Something New
description: FOR more than a decade, La Viola in Cedarhurst has been more than just a restaurant for residents of the Five Towns. It was there that they celebrated rites of passage: birthdays, anniversaries, homecomings and communions. A few years ago, the restaurant was sold and later closed.

title: College Athletics: Winning Games, Losing Perspective
description: IN 1883 the Harvard Committee on Athletics, declaring that football was ''no longer governed by a manly spirit of fair play'' and had become dominated by ''a spirit of sharpers and roughs,'' ordered the Harvard Football Club to disband. The club refused. Harvard and Yale had already made arrangements to play at the Polo Grounds in New York City, the committee was told. Furthermore, Harvard was spending $13,000 to redesign its football field and Yale planned to acquire property near its campus and build a new field of its own. Both colleges were relying on gate receipts from their game to meet the costs of their new fields.

title: Off Montauk: Thar She Blows!
description: A brief report with an article on June 4 about whales off Montauk, L.I., misstated the schedule of service on the Long Island Rail Road between Montauk and Pennsylvania Station in New York. The departure and arrival times given applied to service on Saturday and Sunday, not Monday to Friday.

title: NONFICTION
description: OUT OF THE BLUE. By Orel Hershiser with Jerry B. Jenkins. (Wolgemuth & Hyatt, $17.95.) In 1988, Orel Hershiser had a dream season. Though there is no such thing as a two-man baseball team, the Los Angeles Dodgers came close with Kirk Gibson's bat and Mr. Hershiser's incredible arm - he won 23 games and pitched 59 consecutive scoreless innings, breaking Don Drysdale's record of 58Z. As a result, an only slightly better than mediocre Dodgers team managed to wrest the National League crown from the Mets, then proceeded to swipe the World Series rings right off the fingers of the favored Oakland A's. With the help of the sports biographer Jerry B. Jenkins, Mr. Hershiser has produced one of those quickie books that hit the shelves just months after the season ends. Usually these books, dictated in the heat of the moment, are superficial rehashes of the season meant primarily for die-hard hometown fans. Alas, for the most part, this is the case with ''Out of the Blue.'' In the first half of the book Mr. Hershiser, a modest man who insists ''I'm proof that great things can happen to ordinary people if they work hard and never give up,'' gives the reader a fascinating look at what it takes to become a major-league pitcher - and it takes a lot more than those of us who have never stepped to the mound can imagine - as well as a brief notion of what makes Orel Hershiser, a deeply religious Christian, tick. However, the second half is little more than a lackluster synopsis of the season, sadly lacking in insight. If you are a Mets or A's fan, this is somewhat akin to listening to your dentist give a postoperative blow-by-blow description of your root canal.

title: 300 YEARS OF THE 'TROUBLES'
description: MODERN IRELAND 1600-1972. By R. F. Foster. Maps. 688 pp. New York: Allen Lane/The Penguin Press. $35.

title: A Rare Spear Point Is Secret for 5 Years
description: IN a discovery kept secret until now, a rare 10,000-year-old stone spear point was unearthed in a vacant lot in downtown White Plains five years ago. The two-inch-long fluted point from the Paleo-Indian period is an example of the oldest dated style of spear point found in North America, experts who have authenticated it agree.

title: From France With Love
description: ''HELLO,'' he said earnestly.

title: Hungary
description: To the Editor: I appreciated your article on Hungarian china by Anne Marshall Zwack (Travel, April 16). Let me add, however, one minor point. While Herend china is available in the United States in major department stores, as the article stated, Zsolnay products are imported by M & M Associates Ltd., 8128 North Lawndale Avenue, Skokie, Ill. 60076; 312-675-7177. FRIGYES HORCHLER Commercial Attache, Hungarian Embassy Chicago

title: Sudanese Rebel Seeks Credibility in U.S. Visit
description: The leader of the Sudanese rebel group arrives in the United States on Sunday for a visit intended to endow him with a political respectability that has eluded him despite his military victories.

title: Olympic Cover-Up?
description: Did the head of the International Olympic Committee want to suppress the laboratory finding that Ben Johnson had steroids in his system when he set a world record in winning the 100-meter dash at the 1988 Summer Olympics? Johnson's doctor, Jamie Astaphan, testified at a Canadian inquiry last week that he had been told just that. He said he had been told that the I.O.C. president, Juan Antonio Samaranch, would have intervened to prevent the test results from being made public if the laboratory had not leaked the results.

title: A Drastic Way to Get A Guilt-Free Weekend
description: ''JOYCE, you can go anywhere you want,'' the oral surgeon said as the nurse inserted the needle into my arm. ''You've got great veins, Joyce. Do you work in a garden?'' I could hear his words, but couldn't respond. ''Joyce, do you work out with weights? You've got great arms. Joyce? Joyce?'' Those were the last words I heard before he went to work.

title: Israeli Fisherman Wounded By Egyptian Patrol at Aqaba
description: An Egyptian patrol boat shot at an Israeli fishing boat, seriously wounding its skipper when he ignored orders to halt and entered Egyptian waters in the Gulf of Aqaba, Israel radio reported.

title: Moscow's View
description: To the Editor:

title: The Beijing Spring: From Heady Defiance to Repression
description: Demonstrations by students and workers demanding greater democracy and an end to Government corruption went on for more than six weeks in Beijing's central Tiananmen Square before the authorities resorted to armed force to suppress them. Here are the high points of the sustained protest, which has come to be regarded as a turning point for China:

title: At the Soviet Congress, Watching Big Brother Squirm
description: EVEN for a country growing accustomed to high-voltage rhetoric, the past week provided a jolt. The debut of the Congress of People's Deputies - part morality play, part parliamentary improvisation, part exorcism - has gripped the public like no other event in the short history of glasnost. Shopkeepers huddle around television sets, pedestrians hold transistor radios to their ears, waiting to hear what can possibly be next after the unmasking of the K.G.B., the ridicule of top Communist Party officials, the reopening of the wound of Afghanistan, the outpouring of ethnic recriminations.

title:
FOCUS: Town of Comebacks, a Comeback for a Town;
Redevelopment Starts in Core Of Hollywood
description: LEAD: In an effort to recapture some of the feeling of its heyday as the dream capital of the world, Hollywood is taking its first concrete steps toward a commercial renewal. But developers say that, like any great star's comeback, this one could take almost as long as the original climb to glory.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Lenox, Mass.;
A Second Spa For Berkshires
description: LEAD: ANOTHER estate property in this resort area of Bershire County has become a health resort. It is the second in the western Massachusetts county, with a third scheduled to open later this year.

title: Molly Ashby Wed To Gerald Lodge
description: Molly Frances Ashby, the daughter of Mrs. Donald Roberts Ashby of San Diego and the late Lieut. Comdr. Ashby, U.S.N., was married yesterday to Gerald Michael Lodge, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald A. Lodge of Franklin Lakes, N.J. The Rev. Stanislaus Moseley performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: Tax Ruling May Shift Burden In Nassau
description: IN declaring Nassau County's system of tax assessment unconstitutional late last month, State Supreme Court Justice Leo F. McGinity struck down a program, unique in New York State, that has long been criticized as outdated and inequitable.

title: Missed Out On Something?
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music; Reich's Trains, Friendly or Menacing
description: Steve Reich presided over a Composers' Showcase retrospective of his works at Alice Tully Hall on Friday evening, playing percussion in one piece and supervising the sound mixes in the others from a mixing console perched in the balcony.

title: Prospects; Unemployment's Tiny Fall
description: The unemployment statistics for May, which were released Friday, showed the rate dropped by one-tenth of one percentage point to 5.1 percent. But while unemployment dropped, the number of new jobs created in May was 101,000, less than half of April's total. During May, 18,000 jobs in manufacturing were lost along with 14,000 in construction. Four experts discuss the significance of these statistics. Allen Sinai Chief economist, the Boston Company Economic Advisers Inc.

title: Finland
description: To the Editor: In ''A Land of a Thousand Lakes'' (Travel, April 16) reference was made to the university town of Kuopio, Finland, with its Puyo Tower topped by a revolving restaurant. When my wife and I were traversing Finland from the extreme north to Helsinki on the south, we stopped off at Kuopio. At the base of the Puyo Tower an English-speaking ticket agent told us we could get an excellent meal and view in the revolving restaurant on the top of the tower.

title: Classic's Founding Family Honored
description: LEAD: IN anticipation of the Westchester Classic, which begins tomorrow, Eunice (Lory) Jennings Gambrill of Rye Brook was recalling the event's founder, her father, the late William Mitchell Jennings, and her mother, Elizabeth Hite Jennings, who still lives on the family estate in Greenwich.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Cycling New Leader in Italy: Flavio Giupponi of Italy outsprinted Laurent Fignon of France yesterday to win the 14th stage of the Italian cycling tour in Corvara, but Fignon claimed the pink jersey as the overall leader. Fignon finished 5 seconds behind Giupponi, who held off the French rider on a final uphill climb of nearly a mile. Fignon inherited the first-place jersey from Erik Breukink of the Netherlands, who dropped to eighth place over all after falling apart on a 2.5-mile uphill stretch near the end. Third place in yesterday's leg went to Andrew Hampsten of the United States.(AP) Boxing Chitlada Regains Title: Sot Chitlada of Thailand regained the World Boxing Council flyweight title yesterday with a 12-round split-decision victory over Kim Yong Kang of South Korea in Trang, Thailand. Although clearly the more aggressive boxer, Kim failed to connect during many exchanges with Chitlada and could not put him away. Juan Guerra of Mexico, one of the judges, scored it 117-113 for Chitlada, while David Moretti of the United States scored it 116-112 for Chitlada, who had lost the title to Kim last November. Harold Lederman of the United States gave Kim the edge, 115-113.(AP) Track and Field American Record Set: Judi St. Hilaire set an American record for the women's 5-kilometer yesterday with her time of 15 minutes 25.3 seconds, and only missed the world record by 6 seconds in the 11th Annual Freihofer's Run for Women in Albany. St. Hilaire, 29, of Hingham, Mass., took the lead at the start of the race and held it throughout, beating former record-holder and a 1988 Olympian, Patti Sue Plumer, of Stanford, Cal. The previous record before yesterday was nearly 6 seconds slower. Plumer took second at 15:41.75. The Freihofer's race was also the national 5,000-meter championship for The Athletics Congress, and carried a total purse of $15,500.(AP) Vaulter Clears 19 Feet: Kory Tarpenning, a hometown favorite at Eugene, Ore., cleared 19 feet 1/4 inch in the pole vault, but foreign athletes provided most of the excitement yesterday at the Prefontaine Classic. Ana Quirot of Cuba shattered the field and meet records in the women's 400 in the fastest time in the event this year. Lynn Williams of Canada beat Ingrid Kristiansen of Norway and recorded the fastest women's 3,000-meter time of 1989. Wolfgang Schmidt continued his stirring comeback with a victory in the discus at 222 feet 7 inches, two years after being allowed to leave East Germany.(AP> Lynch Upset by Neptune: Charlene Neptune upset Nnenna Lynch twice yesterday and Mike Williams posted a meet record in the Public Schools Athletic League boys and girls outdoor championships at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island. Neptune, an 18-year-old junior at Clara Barton, ran away from Lynch, a Hunter College High School senior, in the 3,000 meters to win in 9 minutes 42.7 seconds, the fastest time in the country this year. The two runners returned to the track 90 minutes later and Neptune used a finishing kick in the final 150 meters to edge Lynch by 5 meters in 4:33.4. Williams, a 17-year-old junior at Wingate, ran the boys 400 meters in 46.9 seconds, almost a second under the meet mark. Golf Sheehan Takes Lead: Patty Sheehan had a double-eagle on the par-5, 459-yard 17th hole, highlighting a 6-under-par 66 that moved her into the lead after yesterday's third round of the Rochester International a Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament in Pittsford, N.Y. Sheehan's 3-wood on No. 17, her second shot, traveled 219 yards, bounced just in front of the green and rolled into the hole for the first double-eagle on the L.P.G.A. tour in two years. Sheehan, who led after Thursday's first round with a 68, had a three-day total of 9-under 207, one shot ahead of Sherri Turner. Turner, who was tied for the lead going into yesterday's round, had her second successive 69 for a three-day total of 208. She led for most of the third round until Sheehan's double-eagle.(AP) Byrum Is Surprise Leader: Tom Byrum, seeking his first victory in four years on the PGA Tour, shot a 6-under-par 65 yesterday to take a two-shot lead over Tommy Armour 3d after three rounds of the Kemper Open in Potomac, Md. Byrum, who had missed the cut in 9 of his 16 previous tournaments this year, took the lead with a birdie on No. 12. He parred the next five holes before sinking a 37-foot birdie putt on No. 18 to finish at 13-under-par 200 after 54 holes. He had seven birdies and a bogey. Armour, who has won less than $250,000 in his three years on the Tour, matched the course record with a 64 to close at 202.(AP) Geiberger in Front: Al Geiberger rolled in a 12-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole yesterday to tie Gary Player for the lead after two rounds of the $300,000 Doug Sanders Classic at Houston, a seniors event. Player, the first-round leader, shot a 2-under-par 70, including birdies on the 16th and 17th holes, while Geiberger shot a bogey-free 69. They were tied at 7-under 137 after 36 holes.(AP) BASEBALL Texas 7, Long Beach State 1: Craig Newkirk drove in three runs to back the six-hit pitching of Kirk Dressendorfer and lead Texas to a 7-1 victory over Long Beach State yesterday in the first round of the College World Series at Omaha. Scott Bryant, the National Collegiate Athletic Association leader in runs batted in with a school-record 109, had three hits and knocked in two runs while David Lowery had three hits and an r.b.i. for the second-seeded Longhorns (52-17). Texas advances to tomorrow night's winners' bracket game, while the 49ers will play in the loser's bracket Tuesday night. Dressendorfer (17-2) limited the 49ers to six singles en route to his 15th complete game of the season. (AP)

title: Economic Riots Are Spreading in Nigeria
description: A strike in Nigeria over the Government's economic austerity program spread overnight to Port Harcourt, a city of a quarter-million people in the southeastern region, and at least three people were reported killed and several hundred arrested in new clashes.

title: For Its Own Good, Japan Needs a Shove
description: Designating Japan an unfair trader under the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988 has advantages for the United States. It probably will hold advantages for Japan, too. In four working stays in Japan, I was told repeatedly by informed and influential Japanese that the present economic relationship between Japan and the United States is not sustainable; that Japan is, for historical reasons, unable to alter its posture on its own, and that change will come about only through outside pressure.

title: Let's Not Do as the French Do on Nuclear Power
description: To the Editor:

title: ALL THAT MATTERED WAS THE P.M. NEWS
description: UNHOLY ALLIANCES Working the Tawana Brawley Story. By Mike Taibbi and Anna Sims-Phillips. Illustrated. 375 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $18.95.

title: Soviet Emigre Mob Outgrows Brooklyn, and Fear Spreads
description: A criminal underworld of Soviet emigres, some of them skilled in white-collar crime and hardened by Soviet prison and labor camps, is reaching beyond its base in Brooklyn, using extortion and violence in its own neighborhoods and engaging in multimillion-dollar racketeering schemes on an international scale.

title: How Five Dozen Tiny Governments Fight for Power
description: ANY doubts that New York City's community boards feel overlooked and fundamentally powerless were erased two weeks ago, when Mayor Edward I. Koch went to the Rockaways in Queens to talk with a local board about plans for a huge new middle-income housing complex.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Hartwick; Recycling Efforts Help Environment And Save Money
description: ''I feel guilty at home throwing things out after living in a recycling community,'' said Nancy Locklin, a junior at Hartwick College. Like all the students at this city's two colleges, Ms. Locklin, from Bellingham, Mass., had participated this year in a citywide recycling program.

title: New Integration Plan for Louisiana Colleges
description: A special official appointed to draft an integration plan for higher education in Louisiana has recommended that no universities be closed or merged and that they be governed by a unified board.

title: ISRAEL: MIRED IN THE WEST BANK
description: Thomas Friedman's article on Israel is just the kind of incisive and illuminating article one expects from this Pulitzer Prize-winning writer. He always comes up with new insights that clarify the tortured situation of Israel and its neighbors.

title: Review/Dance; A Different 'Don Quixote'
description: American Ballet Theater presented its first ''Don Quixote'' of the season on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. It was an evening of almost incessant leaping and twirling, with lots of waving capes and flashing fans.

title: U.S.O.C. Ratifies Mutual Testing
description: The executive board of the United States Olympic Committee ratified the basic structure of a mutual drug-testing agreement with the Soviet Union today. The approval represents a major step toward the start of a program in which officials of one country could test athletes of the other on short notice at any time.

title: TALKING TWO MOTHER TONGUES
description: LEAD: MEATLESS DAYS By Sara Suleri. 186 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $17.95.

title: Miss Moss Bride Of A. P. Homola
description: Susan Sylvester Moss, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Moss of Garrison, N.Y., and Andrew Paul Homola, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Homola of New York, were married yesterday at Our Lady of Loretto Roman Catholic Church in Cold Spring, N.Y. The Rev. James J. Tubridy and the Rev. Emmanuel Sullivan performed the ceremony.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-21

title: Amid Green Fields, the Shadow of War
description: WE had not planned to stop last summer at an infantry museum in Bodmin, Cornwall. But our car developed brake trouble, and only a factory-authorized dealer in Bodmin could install new linings. Faced with two empty hours on the outskirts of town, we strolled by a heavy stone fortress with a modest sign announcing that it housed the Duke of Cornwall's Light Infantry Regimental Museum.

title: As Lyme Disease Gains, So Does the Response
description: THE reported incidence of tick-borne Lyme disease is up more than sixfold in Westchester this spring and medical experts are scrambling for research dollars in the hope of finding answers to what they are calling a suburban epidemic.

title: Celebrity Doesn't Always Equal Quality
description: Current recordings featuring five women of song - sopranos and mezzos, celebrated and relatively unsung - bear out the fact that the celebrity of an artist and the quality of the final product are not necessarily in direct proportion.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Contracts Be Honored Or Ignored?
description: In the same issue in which you ask, ''Should Contracts Be Honored Or Ignored?'' a front-page article deals with congressmen violating their public trust; an article inside the paper tells of some 40 youths casting aside all civilized bounds and rampaging through Greenwich Village, and the editorial column, most extraordinarily, is devoted to but one subject: the breakdown brought on by the crack epidemic, which threatens ''life itself, at all levels of American society.''

title: Of Fashion Museums And Spy Novels And Grand Parties
description: Sonny Mehta, who wasn't quite impartial, said it was ''the publishing event of the year.'' Mr. Mehta, the president and editor in chief of Alfred A. Knopf, was describing John le Carre's ''Russia House,'' which hit bookstores last week with a bang. So he gave a party Tuesday night for Mr. le Carre that began at the Metropolitan Club and continued at the Plaza Hotel, where Robert Bernstein, the chairman of Random House, which owns Knopf, gave a dinner for 60. Guests included Lauren Bacall, Arthur Schlesinger Jr., Norman Mailer, E. L. Doctorow and Gay and Nan Talese.

title: A Man Is Critically Injured In Staten Island Explosion
description: A 20-year-old man was critically injured in an explosion that blew out the rear wall of a Staten Island house yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: DESPAIR GROSSES OUT
description: EXTRAVAGANZA By Gordon Lish. 190 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: LEARNING BY HEART: AIDS and Schoolchildren in America's Communities. By David L. Kirp. (Rutgers University, $22.95.) Jamie, Marcus and Ryan are schoolchildren who should have no more to worry about than tomorrow's homework. Instead they can be thought of as the smallest soldiers in a battle to stay alive and to go to school for as long as they are able.

title: Correction
description: The Sunday Outing article on May 21 referred incorrectly to the model for West Egg in ''The Great Gatsby,'' by F. Scott Fitzgerald. It is believed to be Great Neck, L.I., not Port Washington.

title: More Help for Workers Who Care for Their Parents
description: The labor contract agreed upon last week by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is further indication that family-care benefits have come of age. Under the accord, A.T.&T. will give employees unpaid leave to care for ailing relatives. By next year, it will establish a resource and referral service to help workers find nursing or custodial care for their sick parents.

title: Correction
description: The Practical Traveler column on May 14 about hotel telephone charges omitted part of the address for Consumer Action. The address is Suite 223, 116 New Montgomery Street, San Francisco, Calif. 94105.

title: FICTION
description: SAME BLOOD. By Mermer Blakeslee. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) The Catskill Mountains are full of myth and mystery in this striking first novel, which takes us beyond the region's resorts, ski slopes and second homes and into the life of Margaret Becker. A single mother who ''just about always cleaned houses for a livin','' Margaret tells her story in the unvarnished vernacular of the farmers and laborers who make up her world. These are people rubbed raw by poverty, but they seem burnished, not dulled, by it. As she struggles to make a life after the death of her 3-year-old son, Margaret can't help connecting - at times, quite mystically - with the stark landscape and with the women and children who become her adopted family. Men are not at the center of this clan. It is the women, by turns stoic and sensual, who heal, nourish and, when necessary, banish the ghosts of past griefs. Margaret's own preternatural power is that she can ''switch over,'' can enter the blood and brain of other creatures and see events through their eyes. That is the author's power, too. The themes in ''Same Blood'' may be familiar, but in Mermer Blakeslee's capable hands, the story - of loss and renewal - is fresh.

title: Who Pays?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bargains in College Dorms and Youth Hostels
description: IF you are a backpacking type, all the time or occasionally, and cost is more compelling than even such basic amenities as a private bathroom, there are at least two cheaper ways to travel than using minimum-service motels. These are staying either in hostels or in college dormitory rooms that come open in the summer, where time-warp prices such as $9 and $20 a night are easy to find.

title: Review/Opera; Seeking A Phantom Dick Tracy
description: Opera and comic strips are not incompatible art forms. Both exaggerate and simplify. Neither shies from points emphatically made. Each has the alarming and yet uplifting tendency to grind the subtleties of human intercourse into magnificent overstatement -with all the attendant pows, bams and whams.

title: LATIN AMERICA FROM THE BLECHERS
description: EL BEISBOL Travels Through the Pan-American Pastime. By John Krich. 272 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $18.95.

title: The Day That Began The Battle For Right
description: SOME days are significant because of what occurred around us on that day. Other days owe their significance to what happened to us personally on a certain date. And then there are days when the outside world and our personal experience merge to create a milestone in time and place.

title: Review/Theater; Social Awareness In a Jungle
description: Emilio Carballido's passion for torrents of words and his taste for exposing the underside of life might make ''Conversation Among the Ruins'' an appropriate title not only for his latest play but also for his collected works. ''Conversation,'' however, lacks much of the humor that has given bite to the Mexican playwright's other scripts, and the language becomes a murky flood that sinks his story.

title: Too Many Run For the Roses
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Review/Music; Italian Wind Quintet in U.S. Debut
description: The Quintetto a Fiati Italiano - or Italian Wind Quintet, as it might more comprehensibly have been translated - is a group of leading Italian instrumentalists who got together five years ago. This week they've made their first American appearances with three evening concerts in the New York area: Tuesday at Weill Recital Hall, Wednesday in Fort Lee, N.J., and Thursday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Art and the Rabble
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors on the Trail of Curious Symptoms
description: WHY did the dentist forget Christmas and wear funny hats? How did Harry the boater's skin turn blue? What was ''the kosher connection'' to Sarah's terrible condition?

title: BEST SELLERS: June 4, 1989
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 4 WHILE MY PRETTY ONE SLEEPS, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The murder of a gossip writer creates a storm in New York's high-fashion world. 2 3 6 THE NEGOTIATOR, by Frederick Forsyth. (Bantam, $19.95.) An American expatriate tries to thwart terrorists' attempts to prevent the signing of a disarmament pact. 3 4 5 THE TEMPLE OF MY FAMILIAR, by Alice Walker. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) The relations of the species, races and sexes through the past 5,000 centuries. 4 6 9 THE JOY LUCK CLUB, by Amy Tan. (Putnam, $18.95.) The tensions and bonds shared by Chinese- American women and their immigrant mothers. 5 9 3 PLAYMATES, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $17.95.) Magic, chivalry and high adventure in a fantasy kingdom called Elenia. 14 * 1 RED PHOENIX, by Larry Bond. (Warner, $19.95.) Three American servicemen and the roles they play in a second Korean War. 15 1 CAPITAL CRIMES, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam, $19.95.) Scott Berg. (Knopf, $24.95.) The life of the pioneering motion picture producer. 12 15 7 OUT OF THE BLUE, by Orel Hershiser with Jerry B. Jenkins. (Wolgemuth & Hyatt, $17.95.) Americans' mathematical illiteracy and its consequences for our culture. 14 14 19 BLIND FAITH, by Joe McGinniss. (Putnam, $21.95.) The family tragedy that came to light after the 1984 murder of a Toms River, N.J., woman. 15 7 WORDSTRUCK, by Robert MacNeil. (Viking, $18.95.) A ''guide for inner transformation'' through meditation. 3 3 19 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.)
