The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE GOOD TIMES, by Russell Baker. (Morrow, $19.95.) The sequel to ''Growing Up'' is an often hilarious and always intelligent salute to the American 1940's, 50's and early 60's, a reporter's autobiography ending with his conversion to a Times columnist. IN TRANSIT: Twenty Stories, by Mavis Gallant. (Random House, $17.95.) The themes of these tales by the expatriate Canadian master of classical prose include travel, noise and the jumpiness induced in people removed from their habitual patterns. THE LONG ROAD TO FREEDOM: Russia and Glasnost, by Walter Laqueur. (Scribners, $21.95.) Thoughtful and pessimistic, Mr. Laqueur argues that Western political ideas won't take root in Russia; what we have already seen is what they're going to get. THE GROTESQUE, by Patrick McGrath. (Poseidon, $17.95.) An outrageous, original and energetic first novel that incorporates murder mystery, satire, Gothic, black comedy and gargoyles. BARBARIAN SENTIMENTS: How the American Century Ends, by William Pfaff. (Hill & Wang, $19.95.) An insightful portrait of that intractable world that isn't America and is learning how to get by without us, by a seasoned and sage reporter on foreign affairs. WE FIND OURSELVES IN MOONTOWN, by Jay Gummerman. (Knopf, $16.95.) A first collection of stories, presenting people whose lives are desperate, blasted by solitude or craziness or television or dope, but tempered by a tenacity of spirit that sometimes prevents the final descent of despair. THE MOST BEAUTIFUL HOUSE IN THE WORLD, by Witold Rybczynski. (Viking, $18.95.) The extraordinary interior conversation, exploring the connections between architecture and everything else, of an architect who built his own house.

title: Nancy Reagan Says Memoirs Will Deal With Controversies
description: Nancy Reagan said today that her memoirs would deal with the main controversies of her eight years in the White House.

title: Suzanne Sunshine Engaged
description: The engagement of Suzanne Pauline Sunshine and William Robert Mendel has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Louise Mintz Sunshine of New York and Morristown, N.J., and Dr. Abraham Sunshine of New York. Mr. Mendel is a son of Jane Wyker of Rye Brook, N.Y., and Werner Mendel of Neversink, N.Y., and New York. A January wedding is planned.

title: Reinventing Hollywood at Disney World
description: IF there is a modern P. T. Barnum, surely it is Disney - first the man, now the corporate giant. Part hucksterism, part substance, part Americana, part razzle-dazzle, Disney's proliferating enterprises combine exhibitions, education and entertainment on a grand scale: Come see the colossal and the magical. Come have fun and learn at the same time.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Wilmingtons.; Expansion Casts Pall on Malls
description: SHOPPING centers are growing rapidly in New Castle County, the northern and most densely populated of Delaware's three counties, amid fears that overbuilding will blight neighborhoods and undermine older centers.

title: West Praises the East for Strides Toward Freedom
description: At a 35-nation East-West conference on human rights that opened here this week, Western diplomats praised the Soviet Union and East European countries for making important strides in granting basic freedoms.

title: NOTES FORM THE UNDERPAID
description: FYODOR DOSTOEVSKY: COMPLETE LETTERS Volume Two, 1860-1867. Edited and translated by David A. Lowe. Illustrated. 321 pp. Ann Arbor, Mich.: Ardis. $35.

title: A GRANDDAUGHTER'S FEAR
description: Ms. Angier dismisses the option of a nursing home for her grandmother as being ''too awful.'' Too awful for whom? I have often seen elderly people improve mentally, emotionally and physically when they gain the security, socialization and medical supervision provided at a nursing home or a residential facility. Not infrequently, it is the family that has difficulty with such a move, because of the ''awful'' guilt or because they have watched the latest evening news expose of a few ''awful'' nursing homes. KWI BYUN BULOW, M.D. San Diego

title: Who's Learning What in School?
description: To the Editor:

title: Picking Fame's Fruits
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPLAINING MEN IS SOMEONE ELSE'S JOB
description: LEAD: SAYING GOODBYE A Memoir for Two Fathers. By M. R. Montgomery. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Cathy Franklin Weds W. M. Eckstein
description: Cathy Felicia Franklin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William D. Franklin of New York, and Warren Matthew Eckstein, the son of Harriett M. Eckstein of Lexington, Mass., and the late Prof. Otto Eckstein, were married last evening at the Stanhope Hotel in New York by Rabbi Ronald Sobel.

title: Music Mountain to Open 60th Season
description: MUSIC MOUNTAIN, the oldest summer concert series in the country, will open its 60th season in Falls Village on Saturday with some changes, most notably the resignation of the Manhattan String Quartet as resident ensemble.

title: Sealing an Asphalt Driveway For Protection From Elements
description: ASPHALT driveways benefit from a coating of sealer every two or three years to protect them from water, weather and chemicals.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I couldn't keep my eyes open because of the dense tear gas.

title: Turning Tick Bites Into Dollars
description: In mid-May, Eclipse Laboratories Inc. of Boca Raton, Fla., mounted a lavish public relations and advertising campaign for Tick Garde, a ''new'' insect repellent. In its news release, Eclipse said that ''laboratory testing on Tick Garde has shown it to be the only effective measure to help prevent Lyme Disease,'' and that the product has special ingredients to prevent ticks from becoming immune to the spray.

title: Two Views of a View Bring a Lawsuit
description: HAVING a water view is regarded by some perspicacious New Yorkers as the height of chic urban living. When buyers of such costly apartments have their river views blocked by new buildings, it often leads to bitterness - and lawsuits.

title: Schmidt Departs With Grace, Style
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on May 21 with an article about a new firefighting policy in Yellowstone National Park misidentified the park area shown. It was Roaring Mountain, not Roaring Brook.

title: Joan Dixon Wetmore Becomes Bride Of Walter W. Yahn in Millbrook, N.Y.
description: At the Grace Episcopal Church in Millbrook, N.Y., Joan Dixon Wetmore, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Thomson Wetmore Jr. of Amenia, N.Y., and Walter Wallace Yahn, the son of Nedra Guyette of Farmington, Me., and the late Wallace Yahn, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Kenneth Swanson. The Right Rev. Stuart Wetmore, the retired Suffragan Bishop of New York, assisted. Mrs. Yahn, a graduate of the Westover School and the University of Southern Maine in Portland, is an assistant sales manager at the Cascade Mountain Winery in Amenia. Her father is the owner and the wine maker.

title: KENYAN PRESIDENT FREES 4 DETAINEES
description: In a surprise move, the Government of Kenya has released four of seven political detainees whose cases have drawn widespread international criticism from human rights groups and lawyers' organizations.

title: Toasting the 'Carriage Trade'
description: LEAD: ''THIS is what happens when you don't make your car payments,'' Rita Trapani said, as she hoisted herself into the carriage. Her husband, Jerry, snapped the reins smartly, and Duke and Petey took off for a gentle scamper around the fenced-in acreage at the Trapani home in Islip.

title: Seville
description: To the Editor: Several months ago I traveled with my daughter to Spain. When we arrived in Seville we drove first to the cathedral and walked around it. By the time we returned to our car, our locked car was opened and all our luggage stolen. This act ruined what should have been a happy vacation.

title: Cholesterol Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: Hextall's Action Shows Cowardice
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; Choices in Manhattan Both Elegant and Rustic
description: This is a listing of Manhattan restaurants that have been reviewed by Bryan Miller in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. Cavaliere

title: THE DEADLY GAME
description: Lesley Hazleton's article ''British Soccer - The Deadly Game'' (May 7), is right on the mark. But I wonder how far the problem extends.

title: Ancient Romans Were Wary of Lead
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAEL: MIRED IN THE WEST BANK
description: Does it never occur to Joel Brinkley that the Israeli soldiers he is tagging along with might behave somewhat differently in the presence of an American reporter than they would unaccompanied? This naivete makes for some heavily ironic moments, as when the paratroopers take the trouble to knock (albeit, ''heavily'') on the door of a Palestinian house and politely preface their orders to the occupant with ''Do me a favor.'' Mr. Brinkley reports that the Palestinian responded with a ''sycophantic smile.'' In fact, he was probably smiling in amusement at the outrageously demure behavior of the soldiers. M. A. KHALIDI New York, N.Y.

title: Two on the Aisle In Russia: Glasnost And Greasepaint
description: From mid-March to mid-April I was in the Soviet Union, seeing and talking about theater as part of the American Soviet Theater Initiative, an informal cultural exchange program. I went to four cities, saw nearly 20 productions (some of them recommended, others of my own choice) and talked to critics, directors, students, professors, editors and writers. I went with high expectations stemming from the reputed new energy and openness that glasnost has brought about in the theater, as elsewhere. My diary shows that those expectations were only partly fulfilled. There is energy and openness on the Soviet stage these days, but with few exceptions I found little imaginative vigor. Moscow

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: A welcome effort to encourage bridge activity by young players has come from two directions - above and below. The American Contract Bridge League has recently applied itself vigorously in this area, and one result was a special effort in Memphis, Tenn. on May 19-21.

title: Second Body Found in River
description: A second body pulled Saturday from the Great Miami River may account for all of the victims killed when a bridge collapsed May 26 under the force of flood-fed currents. Frank Weikel, a spokesman for the Hamilton County Sheriff's Department, said the authorities had accounted for all other people reported missing after the temporary span gave way. Officials believe the only victims were a mother and daughter. The mother's body was found Tuesday.

title: Colorado Prime Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
For Poles in U.S., Jubilation As Absentee Ballots Are Cast
description: Poles in the United States who took part in the Polish elections cast their absentee ballots overwhelmingly in favor of the Solidarity slate. They rejected all those who were running with Communist endorsement.

title: Kampala Journal; When the Trouble Is Men, Women Help Women
description: By noon on most days, a small corner office in downtown Kampala is crowded with women, many in traditional Buganda floor-length dresses, one or two in the Western style that reflects their professional status.

title: American Eagle Petroleums Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said in the latest and year-ago first quarters there were no earnings for common shares after preferred-share dividends. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cinram Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 5, 1989: MONDAY Cincinnati Bell Inc Harnischeger Inds TUESDAY McDermott Intl Inc Premier Indl Corp Pacific Enterprises Witco Corp WEDNESDAY Alaska Air Group Inc Louisville Gas & Elec Co Browning Ferris Inds Mercantile Stores Inc Corroon & Black Corp Natl Convenience Stores General Dynamics Corp Pennwalt Corp Handleman Co Del Starrett LS Co Helmerich & Payne Inc USF&G Corp Illinois Pwr Co THURSDAY Centel Corp Trinity Inds Graco Inc Universal Foods Corp Nerco Inc Vestaur Sec Inc Times Mirror Co FRIDAY Abbott Labs Lowes Cos General Cinema Corp

title: The Fall and Rise of Fred Silverman
description: The television industry is littered with top executives who made their mark and then disappeared from the industry. But Fred Silverman, who controlled the programming destinies of each of the three networks in the course of two decades, is no longer among them.

title: Astros Win It In 13th
description: The pitcher Mike Scott hit a sacrifice fly in the 13th inning to give Houston a 7-6 victory over Los Angeles today, sending the Astros to their 10th straight victory only hours after they beat the Dodgers in 22 innings.

title: Correction
description: A map last Monday misidentified the area of the Tongass National Forest, which encompasses most of the 500-mile Alaskan Panhandle. The story was about the debate over Government-sponsored logging in the region.

title: Bernard Shiffman, 71, Social-Work Leader
description: Bernard M. Shiffman, a former executive director of the Community Council of Greater New York, died of cardiac arrest on Thursday while attending a meeting at the United Nations, where he was the representative of the American Association of Retired Persons. He was 71 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Leiner, P Nutritional Prodcts Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The results included Vita-Fresh Vitamin Co., acquired in February 1988 and Freshlabs Inc., which was acquired in October 1988. The operations of these companies are included from the first of the month in which they were purchased.

title: First Toronto Mining Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company changed its name from First Toronto Capital Corp. following the merger with Pacvest Capital Inc. earlier this year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Need for Money Tempers Ethics Drive in Congress
description: Shortly after witnessing Speaker Jim Wright announce that he was ending his 34-year Congressional career amid allegations about his financial dealings, a more junior Congressman headed from the House chamber to the nearby Democratic Club to conduct some business.

title: France Tests Bomb in Pacific
description: France exploded a 20-kiloton nuclear bomb at an underground site in French Polynesia today, New Zealand Government scientists said. The explosion, the third conducted by France this year, probably occurred on the Pacific atoll of Mururoa, the Department of Scientific and Industrial Research said.

title: Review/Opera; 'Rheingold' Evocative of a Director, if Not Wagner
description: To judge from the ''Rheingold'' with which the Deutsche Oper Berlin began its traversal of ''Der Ring des Nibelungen'' at the Kennedy Center here on Friday evening, the staging of Wagner's ''festival drama'' will hew closely to tradition. Before modernist ideologues begin to snort, however, let it be clear that the tradition is of relatively recent origin. The West German company's general director, Gotz Friedrich, borrows heavily and often amusingly from the anti-illusionist theatrical concepts of Bertolt Brecht and, more lately, Patrice Chereau.

title: Hach Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Dik Browne, 71, Cartoonist, Dies
description: Dik Browne, the cartoonist whose ''Hagar the Horrible'' strip about a bumbling Viking chieftain is published by more than 1,800 newspapers in 58 countries, including 100 papers in Scandinavia, died of cancer yesterday in Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Sarasota, Fla., where he lived. He was 71 years old.

title: Crown Books Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Williams College
description: Williams College marked its 200th commencement yesterday, conferring degrees on 508 undergraduate and 40 graduate students at its Williamstown, Mass., campus.

title: Rate Action by Fed Expected Soon
description: The buying frenzy that capped last week's bond trading was spurred by the perception that the latest employment figures provided convincing evidence that economic growth had slowed and that the Federal Reserve would soon address this situation by reducing interest rates.

title: Nutmeg Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Included a gain of $113,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. Latest quarter results included a $63,400 credit from the cumulative effect of an accounting change on prior periods net of income taxes.

title: BSI Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Britain's Boot Camp Detention Hasn't Worked; Put Them in the Stocks
description: To the Editor:

title: Fund-Raiser Attacks the Practices He Thrived On
description: For more than a decade Jim Calaway was known in Washington as a Texas oilman with a gold-plated address book because he could raise millions of dollars for Democratic candidates.

title: Finally, It's the Finals
description: MANY years ago, the 1989 National Basketball Association playoffs began.

title: Sea Containers Bid Blocked
description: A Federal District Court in Washington issued an order Friday temporarily prohibiting Stena Holding A.B., a Swedish ferry operator, and Tiphook P.L.C., a British container-rental company, from continuing their joint tender offer for Sea Containers Ltd., a Bermuda company with interests in containers and British ferries.

title: Cuomo Recalls Good Times at St. John's
description: Recalling his days as an undergraduate and law student at St. John's University, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo gave a short speech heavy on humor and light on controversy yesterday at the Catholic school's 119th commencement on its Jamaica, Queens, campus.

title: Group Tennis Is Gaining Favor
description: EXCEPT for the Davis Cup and intercollegiate competition, tennis has had virtually no reputation as a team sport. But at the recreational level that may be changing. Today, many clubs and recreation departments are offering different team formats to get players involved and, more important, keep them involved in the game.

title: Short-Term Chancellor, Long-Term Goals
description: For a time last month, Bernard Mecklowitz considered resigning from the New York City school system, which had employed him for 35 years.

title: Britain's Boot Camp Detention Hasn't Worked; User's Moral Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: Crackdown in Beijing; For Students in U.S., Grief and Fury
description: Chinese students in the United States reacted with outrage today to the army's killing of pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing, saying in a letter to President Bush that the Communist Party had turned into an ''evil fascist dictatorship.''

title: Israeli Soldier and 3 Arabs Die in Clash
description: An Israeli Army sergeant was shot to death and three Palestinian guerrillas were killed early today in a gunfight on the Lebanese border that halted the fourth attempt in eight days by guerrillas to infiltrate northern Israel, the army said.

title: Dumars Undaunted By 'Ultimate' Test
description: The question made Joe Dumars hesitate, something he rarely does while playing basketball for the Detroit Pistons. Who is tougher to defend, Magic Johnson or Michael Jordan?

title: Contra Resupply Not Discussed at Bush's May 1, 1986, Meeting
description: To the Editor:

title: Xplor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Elainie Ray King Wed To Steve Gagne on L.I.
description: Elainie Ray King, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan King of Kings Point, L.I., was married yesterday to Steve Gagne, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Gagne. Sol Wachtler, Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Outdoors: Eel Flicking and Other Tricks of the Bait Trade
description: ALTHOUGH it doesn't appeal to some anglers, bait, dead or alive, often catches more fish than lures. Using the real thing rather than an approximation of it makes sense, of course, but bait, if it isn't needed, is a bother, particularly when it is some species of fish that has to be kept alive. There are times, however, when, if one is to be successful, using live bait cannot be avoided.

title: U.S. Says 1939 German-Soviet Treaties Are Real
description: Federal archivists said today that there could be no doubt about the authenticity of the 1939 German-Soviet treaties assigning the Baltic republics to the Soviet Union, even though the original documents have never been found and the German versions were apparently destroyed by the Nazis in World War II.

title: Growing Worries for Panama's Entrepreneurs
description: By all outward appearances, there are only two sides in Panama's 18-month power struggle: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and his political opposition. In fact, there is a third, rapidly growing camp: entrepreneurs who are disgusted with both.

title: Bowl Game Plan to Be Evaluated
description: The College Football Association ended its annual meeting today without acting on a proposed 16-team playoff. It did, however, vote to form a committee that would study the post-season bowl-game structure.

title: Listening In As the News Is Prepared
description: On Wednesday evening, television viewers in the San Francisco Bay area peeked inside what appeared to be the front-page meeting for the next morning's San Francisco Chronicle. As they listened, editors hashed over whether corporations should establish a ''mommy track'' for women who are executives. Less than 12 hours later, the story was splashed across the paper's front page.

title: Tonys for 'Heidi' And for 'Robbins'
description: ''The Heidi Chronicles'' won the Tony Award for best play last night, and ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' won for best musical and in five other categories, including leading actor in a musical.

title: Boat Hitler Built Is Sunk in Ceremony
description: Never mind that the rumors are exaggerated and that the Ostwind was not really Hitler's personal yacht. He ordered her built and was aboard her a few times. And that was enough for the 100 Holocaust survivors.

title: Don't Dismiss Open Skies
description: President Bush's call for a new, enlarged ''open skies'' arrangement displays imagination. The value of this initiative was recognized by the endorsement it received at the NATO summit meeting.

title: Publishers Are Uneasy At Booksellers Meeting
description: Booksellers at this year's gathering of the American Booksellers Association, which ends its four-day convention Tuesday night, seem optimistic about the state of the industry. But the major publishers appear less enthusiastic than usual.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday New-Car Sales May Tuesday None Wednesday Consumer Credit April Thursday Business Investment 1st Qtr. Friday P roducer Prices May

title: Cape Town Writer on Race Slain
description: Richard Rive, a novelist, critic and editor whose works depicted the plight of South Africans of mixed race under apartheid, was found slain today in his house near Cape Town.

title: Hempstead Harbor Closes Its Beaches After Sewage Spill
description: The beaches at Hempstead Harbor on Long Island's North Shore were closed this weekend after a pump station in Roslyn malfunctioned, sending thousands of gallons of raw sewage spewing into a parking lot and cascading into the water.

title: Unitog Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Article 550689 -- No Title
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues this week includes today's regular auction of new three-month and six-month bills. Late Friday the three-month bill discount rate stood at 8.36 percent, while the six-month bill rate was 8.13 percent.

title: Interest Rates Fall, Easing Recession Fears
description: Interest rates have begun to decline across much of the economy, reducing the probability of the recession some economists have been predicting but also perhaps fanning the fires of inflation.

title: U.S. Awarded $86 Million In a Savings Unit Lawsuit
description: A Federal judge in New Orleans has awarded the Federal Home Loan Bank Board an $86 million judgment against former officers of the defunct Alliance Federal Savings and Loan Association of Kenner, La.

title: Soviet Violinist Wins Belgian Contest
description: A 17-year-old Soviet musician won the Queen Elisabeth international violin contest today and will receive $7,000 and a lucrative contract for concerts throughout Europe.

title: Miss Sand, Law Student, Takes Vows
description: Elisabeth Natalie Sand, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jay P. Sand of Wayne, N.J., and Eric Peter Straus, the son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Peter Straus of New York and Washington, were married yesterday in Manhattan. Rabbi Mark Golub performed the ceremony in the Penthouse of the Parker Meridien Hotel.

title: Karen Braunstein, Cantor, Wed to Paul Offenkrantz
description: Karen Braunstein, the cantor of Temple Avodah in Oceanside, L.I., and Paul Offenkrantz, the cantor of Temple Emanuel in New Hyde Park, L.I., were married yesterday at Temple Avodah. Cantor Israel Goldstein, director of the School of Sacred Music at Hebrew Union College, where the couple received master's degrees, performed the ceremony. Also officiating were Rabbis Robert Benjamin and Philmore Berger.

title: Guerrillas Are Said to Kill 14 In Raids on 2 Afghan Cities
description: At least 14 people have been killed and 13 wounded in rocket attacks by Muslim guerrillas on two Afghan cities, a spokesman for the Soviet-backed Government said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: AUTO RACING Prost Wins Grand Prix: Alain Prost of France took advantage of his teammate Ayrton Senna's mechanical problems yesterday and ran away with the first Phoenix Grand Prix. Prost's 36th career victory, adding to his Formula One career record, also moved him past Senna into first place in the season point standing, 29-27. It was the 34-year-old Prost's first victory of the season and the fourth for his McLaren-Honda team.

title: SL Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The 1988 per share figures have been adjusted for 6 percent stock dividend distributed in November 1988.

title: Review/Theater; Shaw's Mockery of Victorian Society
description: When ''Arms and the Man'' opened in London in 1894, a wildly cheering audience demanded that the author take a bow. As Shaw stepped onstage, one man in the balcony shouted a loud, long ''Boo!'' Shaw looked up at the gallery and said, ''My dear fellow, I couldn't agree with you more, but what are we against so many?''

title: U.S. Tops Peru, 3-0, in Final
description: Despite the absence of several key players and its coach, the national soccer team of the United States captured the Marlboro Cup tournament at Giants Stadium tonight with a 3-0 victory over the national team of Peru.

title: 500 on 2 Trains Reported Killed By Soviet Gas Pipeline Explosion
description: A powerful gas pipeline explosion demolished part of the trans-Siberian railway late Saturday night, engulfing two passenger trains in flames and leaving hundreds dead, according to the Tass press agency and local officials reached by telephone.

title: Biocraft Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest quarter included research and development expenses of $2.7 million, compared with $1.2 million for year-ago period.

title: Beirut Truce Shattered by Artillery Attacks
description: Major artillery exchanges broke out today as Lebanon's warring factions continued to violate a 25-day-old Arab-brokered cease-fire. The fighting was renewed as Muslim areas mourned the death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran.

title: Hong Kong Stock Market Plunges 589 Points, or 22%
description: Hong Kong's volatile stock market plunged nearly 600 points in early trading today as investors reacted to the weekend violence in China.

title: The West Condemns the Crackdown
description: Western nations and Chinese around the world condemned the military crackdown and bloodshed in Beijing yesterday with anguished protests, pleas for restraint and calls for economic and political sanctions against China.

title: Crackdown in Beijing; Ungoverning China
description: Whoever wins the power struggle now under way in the Communist Party will find the challenge of ruling China incomparably greater after this weekend.

title: Soviet Nationalist Violence Spreads to Uzbek Republic
description: Nationalist violence spread to another Soviet republic this weekend as armed rioters battled the police, burned cars and destroyed buildings in eastern Uzbekistan, the Tass press agency reported tonight.

title: A Sentimental Journey for the Negro Leagues
description: Through all those years, the thread of the professional existence these men had shared was the time they spent on buses, hurrying from one stop to another in the old Negro leagues of baseball.

title: Ann Slocum Wed To T. H. Edmonds

title: Study Finds Alarming AIDS Rate in Homeless Shelter
description: The first study of AIDS among the homeless in New York City has found the infection in 105 of 169 men tested at a municipal shelter on Wards Island, a rate of 62 percent.

title: Hevesi Runs for Comptroller
description: Pledging that it is time for a ''change and a fresh start,'' Alan G. Hevesi, the Democratic Assemblyman from Queens, formally announced his candidacy yesterday for New York City Comptroller.

title: Merril Bernstein, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Merril Ruth Bernstein, an associate at the New York law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton, and Michael Robert Lissack, a managing director at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, were married yesterday in New York. Rabbi Lawrence W. Raphael performed the ceremony at the Mondrian Restaurant.

title: Jersey Races For Governor Nearing End
description: The candidates for governor scurried about New Jersey yesterday, shaking hands wherever they could find them, with each candidate hoping to combine enough longtime supporters with new-found followers to win the primary election tomorrow.

title: Mallard Coach Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Oriole Saga Strange but True
description: A week ago, Sylvia Tettleton revealed the secret behind the power-hitting success of her husband, Mickey. Between innings at Memorial Stadium, she announced on cable television that Tettleton was eating Fruit Loops, and that she had advised Sharon Sheets to feed her husband, Larry, the same.

title: Campaign Matters; Alumnus Brings Message of Hope And Politics
description: ''Who's Ron?'' Faith-Alegra Coleman ebulliently demanded of the small entourage making its way down a corridor of Hunter College Elementary School in Manhattan. ''I am,'' Ronald H. Brown volunteered. Faith-Alegra, a third grader, was beside herself with excitement over finally meeting a distinguished alumnus who has come to symbolize both the aspirations of many of Faith-Alegra's fellow students, particularly those who, like Mr. Brown, are black, and the fragile notion that politics isn't all bad.

title: Tax Watch; Planning Needed On Home Gains
description: ONE of the benefits of selling a home and buying another is that capital gains on the first house or apartment are generally not taxed if the proceeds are reinvested in the new residence within two years.

title: 171 Dead In Sri Lankan Torrents As the Monsoon Strands 100,000
description: Floods and landslides caused by torrential rains killed 171 people and destroyed entire hamlets in the hills of central Sri Lanka, officials said today.

title: Review/Music; A Premiere by Mingus, Big, Boisterous and Jazzy
description: Charles Mingus, one of the greatest composers in jazz, left his magnum opus to be discovered after his death in 1979. ''Epitaph,'' a 500-page score that runs more than two hours, was heard for the first time Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall at a concert that ranks with the most memorable jazz events of the decade. The concert was recorded and videotaped.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES USX is coming under pressure to consider a restructuring that could split the giant steel and energy company, industry analysts say, because it might otherwise face a hostile takeover bid from Carl C. Icahn. The financier, who owns 11.4 percent of USX, sold his stake in Texaco last week for more than $2 billion. [ Page D1. ] Nintendo and Atari introduced video games that they hope will sweep the nation: portable, handheld games. [ D6. ] THE ECONOMY Interest rates have begun to decline, reducing the probability of the recession that some economists have been predicting but also perhaps fanning the fires of inflation. [ D1. ] Federal savings regulators have won an $86 million judgment against former officers of Alliance Federal Savings and Loan of Kenner, La., which failed. [ D5. ] MEDIA BUSINESS Whittle Communications has decided to offer its commercially sponsored news programs to high schools across the country, a communications industry executive said. The decision comes in spite of potential competition from two cable channels. [ D1. ] Fred Silverman is quietly making a successful comeback as an independent producer after his difficulties at NBC almost pushed him out of television. [ D1. ] The networks are producing more of their own shows and hope to break into the syndication market. Bill Carter: Television. [ D14. ] CBS affiliates are happier with the network's management and prospects this year than they were in 1988. [ D15. ] Gardner Communications has created an ad campaign for The San Francisco Chronicle that demonstrates how video technology can bring radio advertising's low cost, quick turnaround and topicality to television. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D15. ] Booksellers seem optimistic about their industry at their convention, but publishers appear less enthusiastic than usual. [ D14. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Prices plunged on Hong Kong's volatile stock market, with the Hang Seng index off 589 points, or 22 percent, as traders reacted to the weekend violence in China. [ D1. ] Mexico's domestic debt has risen to more than $50 billion, from less than $23 billion two years ago, and it constitutes a heavier drain on the nation's financial resources than all the obligations owed to foreign banks and governments. [ D16. ] There may appear to be only two sides in Panama: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and his political opposition. But in fact, there is a third, rapidly growing camp: entrepreneurs who are disgusted with both. [ D16. ] OPEC's meeting seems to be at an impasse as Saudi Arabia and Kuwait clash over production quotas. [ D2. ] The world's finance ministers agree that international coordination on their economic policies has stumbled. But at last week's meeting of the O.E.C.D., they disagreed over what those policies should be. News Analysis. [ D2. ] MARKETS The buying frenzy among bond traders was spurred by evidence in the employment figures that economic growth had slowed and that the Federal Reserve would reduce interest rates. [ D5. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Homeowners are normally able to avoid taxes on the sale of a primary residence if they buy a new one within two years. But without careful planning, they could create a situation that would make them liable for a big tax. Jan M. Rosen: Tax Watch. [ D2. ] The New York Stock Exchange plans to offer baskets of stocks, which will make program trading easier and possibly take some action away from the Chicago futures exchanges. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: Lyme Disease Battlers Trying a Mouse and Tick Census
description: Tramping through the woods, carrying a white flannel flag and two cartons of tin traps, Phyllis Erlandson and Tom Galotti would not have been mistaken for Jane Goodall and Marlin Perkins. In fact, Ms. Erlandson, a Stamford public health specialist, seemed a bit squeamish as she stalked the day's quarry: field mice and deer ticks.

The latest quarter and year losses from continuing operations reflected the writeoff of $2,060,000 from the revaluation of 20 restaurants acquired in 1988.

title: Some Optimism Amid Grim Predictions as 87-Nation AIDS Meeting Opens
description: With 11,000 participants from 87 countries, the world's largest meeting on the AIDS epidemic opened here today with some optimism despite predictions that the 1990's will be even worse than the 1980's and that a vaccine is nowhere in sight.

title: Grieving in Teheran: 'We Have Been Orphaned'
description: Hundreds of thousands of grief-stricken Iranians jammed Teheran's streets today in mourning for Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, beating their heads and chests in the traditional Shiite Muslim show of grief, official reports from Teheran said.

title: DDB Needham Buys Shop in San Francisco
description: DDB Needham bolstered its entertainment advertising services on Friday, acquiring a small San Francisco agency with a roster of leading motion picture clients. The agency, Jack Wodell Associates, will become part of DDB Needham's entertainment division, which handles regional advertising for 23 film production companies in San Francisco, San Diego, Sacramento and Denver. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Barber Wachenfeld of Wallingford, Pa., and Mr. Jessen is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Claus Jessen of Copenhagen.

description: To see one of his sculptures leading a full life of its own in the open air was one of Henry Moore's greatest pleasures. title: Two Old Men, Many Young Lives; The Ayatollah Wrote His Annals in Blood
description: A decade ago, in a matter of weeks, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini made himself into an icon recognized worldwide. The round black turban, the harsh eyes, the long white beard: to outsiders, they came to personify the merciless zeal of the American hostage crisis, and one terrorist episode after another. And to Shiite Moslems, often patronized and reviled, the icon personified strength and spiritual probity. Indeed, the Ayatollah, who died Saturday at the age of 89, owed much of his vast authority in Iran, and Islam, to the aura of sanctity that pervaded his person.

title: U.S. Judges Earn Considerably More Than Salary
description: Almost all Federal judges have outside income, a majority have six-figure investment portfolios and many make more money off the bench than on it, according to their Government financial reports.

title: Delta Adds 10 Routes
description: Delta Air Lines Inc. announced it was opening 10 new routes, including four daily nonstop flights from its hub at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. Henry Conley, Delta district manager at Dallas-Fort Worth, said the airline would offer nonstop flights from there to Miami; Huntsville, Ala.; Wichita, Kan., and Sacramento, Calif. Delta also announced these new daily nonstop routes: Cincinnati and Frankfurt, West Germany; Atlanta and Milwaukee; Cincinnati and Milwaukee; Orlando, Fla., and Nassau, the Bahamas; Huntsville and Memphis, and San Juan, P.R., and Los Angeles.

Henry Bethe and Brian Glubok of Manhattan, Bill Root of Boca Raton, Fla., Tom Smith of Greenwich, Conn., and Chuck Lamprey of White Plains, who between them had won 20 Reisinger titles, had added Edgar Kaplan of Manhattan, an eight-time winner.

title: Review/Television; The Pop World Wrestles With 'Our Common Future'
description: The oddest, most incoherent global television broadcast since the 1989 Academy Awards took place on Saturday afternoon. ''Our Common Future,'' a five-hour program relayed to about 100 countries, was intended to create awareness of environmental problems and to urge global cooperation. For five hours, broadcast live from Avery Fisher Hall with material from the Soviet Union, England, Australia, Poland, Norway and Brazil, the program mixed musical performances with pro-environmental statements, a format akin to Live Aid, with which it shared a producer (Hal Uplinger) and director (Tony Verna).

title: Question Box
description: Triple Crown Dead Heat Q. Suppose that in the Belmont Stakes next Saturday, Sunday Silence, who beat Easy Goer by 2 1/2 lengths in the Kentucky Derby and by a nose in the Preakness, finishes in a dead heat with Easy Goer. Having not beaten the entire field of Belmont horses, would Sunday Silence still be considered a Triple Crown winner? A. Absolutely, and he'd earn the Triple Crown bonus money to boot. The situation would resemble the one in baseball in 1967, when Carl Yastrzemski of the Boston Red Sox won the Triple Crown after leading the American League in batting (.326) and runs batted in (121), and finishing in a dead heat with Harmon Killebrew of Minnesota in home runs (44). There's no asterisk in the record books for Yaz's feat.

title:

NWA Bidder, Only 40, Is a Seasoned Expert

description: LEAD: As the nation struggles suffers with ever-worsening air pollution and Washington struggles to revise the Clean Air Act, attention is focusing at last on ''clean fuels'' - the gaseous fuels (natural gas and propane), the alcohols (methanol, ethanol and ethers) and electricity.

title: Iran Quickly Appoints Successor to Khomeini
description: The Iranian president, Ali Khamenei, was quickly chosen today as his country's supreme religious leader to replace Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who died Saturday night.

Decline of Interest Rates The decline in interest rates throughout the economy reduces the probability of a recession but could push up inflation. Page D1. AIDS in Shelters Though flawed, a study of AIDS in homeless men generates considerable alarm. Page B1.

title: Greek Church Is Completed After 18 Years
description: LEAD: Its mighty dome asserting itself against a sun-streaked sky, a 100-foot-high Greek Orthodox church in Flushing was finally completed yesterday, ending an 18-year campaign to adorn its bare-walled interior with icons and relics.

title: A Trap for Speed Traps
description: For Bobby Unser, the three-time winner of the Indy 500, the mere thought of driving less than 70 miles an hour at Indianapolis is enough to send a shudder down his spine.

title: Mets Top Pirates On Carreon Homer
description: It's small wonder patience has been Mark Carreon's problem at the plate. You watch enough pitches from the bench and you wind up inclined not to look at too many more when you finally get a bat in your hands.

title: Corrections
description: A column on the Washington Talk page Thursday incorrectly reported the number of United States Senators elected in 1936. Including special elections, 36 of the 96 members of the Senate were elected in that year.

title: Civil War Era
description: Undemocratic regimes everywhere are facing the prospect of civil war.

title: Emily K. Zaslow Weds Jeremiah M. Hourihan
description: Emily Karen Zaslow and Jeremiah Mahoney Hourihan, 1986 graduates of Wesleyan University, were married yesterday at the Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Stephen L. Zaslow. Rabbi David Benedict officiated. Mrs. Hourihan is a senior artist for the Gannett Company in White Plains, where her husband is a supervisor for the Chubb Group of Insurance Companies. Her father is the director of the Long Island Psychoanalytic Institute in the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Hourihan of Willimantic, Conn.

title: Saudis and Kuwait At Odds on Oil Output
description: A meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries here seemed to be at an impasse as Saudi Arabia, which is determined to preserve its nearly 25 percent share of OPEC production, clashed with Kuwait over its insistence on a larger production quota. The formal full ministerial session opens Monday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Arthur Andersen & Co., Chicago, the accounting firm, named David M. Walker, a former United States Assistant Secretary of Labor, director of its compensation and benefits practice.

title: Gulf and Western Switch
description: Gulf and Western Inc. will change its corporate name today to Paramount Communications Inc. to reflect its concentration on entertainment and publishing. The company's main assets now include Paramount Pictures, Paramount Television and Simon & Schuster/Prentice Hall. Paramount Communications will have the stock symbol PCI on the New York Stock Exchange. The address of its headquarters building in Manhattan has been changed from 1 Gulf and Western Plaza to 15 Columbus Circle.

title: TransTechnology Corp reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included a loss of $1,243,000 from a subsidiary held for sale. c-Included a loss of $953,000 from a subsidiary held for sale and a gain of $1,010,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. Prior-year results are restated to reflect the subsidiary held for sale. Latest and prior year losses from the subsidiary held for sale are net of tax benefits of $1,536,000 and $637,000, respectively.

title: S.E.C. Charges Father and Son
description: A father and son have been charged with insider trading in a scheme that is said to have cleared $328,844 in stock-trading profits before the American Stores Company took over Lucky Stores Inc. last year.

description: General Assembly WORKING GROUP ON DRAFTING OF INTERNATIONAL CONVENTION ON PROTECTION OF MIGRANT WORKERS - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - 3 P.M. description: Jim Courier, an 18-year-old Floridian in his first French Open, predicted with conviction last week that his third-round match with fifth-seeded Andre Agassi would be exciting.

description: WHEN the three networks announced their fall prime-time schedules last month, the news in Hollywood had much less to do with who was starring in the new shows than with who was making them.

description: A California company has introduced new cycling shorts that incorporate reflective film as part of the fabric pattern.

Bock of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Samuel S. Bock. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel performed the ceremony.

A Pain in the Wrist Proves to Be Instructive
description: NINE months ago, while working out on my bicycle in the predawn darkness, I took a shortcut through a parking lot and was thrown to the pavement when I hit a bump hidden in the shadows. I instinctively extended my left arm to break the fall and landed heavily on the hand and wrist.

title: Genetic Tomatoes Test
description: The Monsanto Company said Thursday that it had begun a research field trial of tomato plants genetically engineered to resist caterpillar pests, like tomato fruitworm and tomato hornworm. The field test follows trials on insect-resistant tomatoes in Mexico, Florida and Illinois earlier this year.

description: Ask Bonnie Blair if she was ever afraid of falling off the speed-cycling track and she laughs.

description: Share earnings represented American Depositary Receipt (ADR) and each ADR represents 10 shares of British Telecom ordinary stock. Results are in U.S. dollars; U.S. dollars have been translated at an exchange rate of $1.69 to the pound, the rate prevailing on March 31, 1989, the last date of the reporting period. The company said figures for the three months to March 31, 1988 have been restated to include the full year effect of employee profit sharing arrangements thereby putting the prior year figures on to a comparative basis.

title: Two Old Men, Many Young Lives; Deng Xiaoping Defiles His Legacy With Blood
description: Mao Zedong taught Chinese Communists that political power grows out of the barrel of a gun. Deng Xiaoping believes it. Now 84 years old, and said to be hospitalized with cancer, he is neither too old nor too ill to order the army massacre of hundreds of unarmed, idealistic Chinese students in Beijing's central square. Tiananmen, it is called: the Gate of Heavenly Peace. America's conscience cries out.

description: In a Friday prayer sermon at Teheran University last month, the President of Iran, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, said the Government needed to be more centralized.

description: China's leadership faces a much more difficult task in governing. Page A10.

description: PROGRAM trading has a bad name on the corner of Broad and Wall streets, where the New York Stock Exchange is situated. So who would have thought the exchange would come up with a product aimed at both making such trading easier and, possibly, taking away a lot of the action from the Chicago futures exchanges?

title: Tiny Nauru, a Colony No Longer, Sues Australia for Neglect
description: The tiny Republic of Nauru in the central Pacific has begun a suit at the International Court of Justice here charging Australia with exploitation and neglect in removal of Nauruan phosphates earlier in the century.

title: Pok Ta Pok Wins Roseben
description: Pok Ta Pok, a tough sprinter who simply refuses to be passed, dueled with True and Blue every step of the way and held on by a head to win the $84,600 Roseben Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: U.S. Backed on Debt Plan
description: Leading industrial nations on Friday gave broad backing to a United States plan to reduce the third world's $1.3 trillion debt, but they warned commercial bank lenders not to expect taxpayers to bail them out.

title: Wide Quake in California
description: A moderate earthquake centered in the Mojave Desert was felt over a wide area of Southern California this afternoon, the United States Geological Survey said. There were no immediate reports of damage from the quake, which measured 4.5, indicating possible damage, on the Richter scale of ground motion. The epicenter was miles south-southeast of Barstow, Calif., said a survey spokesman, Don Finley.

title: Circus Circus Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a gain of $9,235,000 from an accounting change.

title: Despite Polls, Cardinale Is Optimistic
description: State Senator Gerald Cardinale appeared to have won many hearts at a center for the elderly here today. He told 70 people that if elected governor, he would freeze property taxes for people who turned 65 years old if they had lived in the same house for the previous five years.

title: McFarland Energy reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
La Conner Journal; What Attracts Tourists Repels Some Residents
description: Before there were theme parks and multiplex theaters in America there were small towns like La Conner, living museums where life moved along like a river in midsummer, slow around the bend.

title: Stephanie Kretchmer Has a Wedding
description: Stephanie Lisa Kretchmer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Kretchmer of New York and Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday at her parents' Katonah home to John Kolsin Crossman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Crossman of Armonk, N.Y. Rabbi Balfour Brickner officiated.

title: France Bans Imports of Ivory
description: France is banning imports of ivory to help save African elephants, the Government announced today. Brice Lalonde, the Environment Minister, said the import prohibition will take effect Monday. Experts estimate that the African elephant population has dwindled to half a million under pressure from poachers who kill elephants for their tusks.

title: TV Notes
description: Musical Anchors

title: Stamp for Bastille Day Reverses the Tricolor
description: The United States Postal Service, it seems to some collectors, cannot tell its right from its left. Others find a streak of puritanism or suggestions of racism - and all this on just one stamp.

title: Brendle's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Best Products reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: The company said results for the latest quarter are not comparable to those of a year-ago, since its acquisition was recorded under the rules of purchase accounting. In the year-ago quarter, the company reported a loss of $8,433,000, on sales of $377,871,000. The company was acquired in a leveraged transaction on Nov. 8, 1988.

title: ARMY TIGHTENS CONTROL OF CITY BUT ANGRY RESISTANCE GOES ON
description: Army units tightened their hold on the center of the Chinese capital on Sunday, moving in large convoys on some of the main thoroughfares and firing indiscriminately at crowds as outraged citizens continued to attack and burn army vehicles.

title: Throwing Dollars at Crop Insurance
description: Fraud. Waste. Disuse. The Federal crop insurance program works badly. So Congress appointed a commission, which has now published an interim report. As the recommendations show, the commission is stacked. Taxpayers, beware.

title: Heads of Units Named By American Express
description: The departure of Louis V. Gerstner Jr. from the American Express Company in April continues to bring executive changes there.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,389,000.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: U.S.O.C. Supports Utah Site
description: Anchorage's campaign to win the Winter Olympics for the United States ended today when the executive board of the United States Olympic Committee voted to make Salt Lake City its bid city for the Games in 1998, and failing then, in 2002.

title: Heico Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included direct expenses for recent proxy contest of $380,000 ($242,000 after reduction for income taxes) which reduced net income per share by 8 cents a share. Year-ago shares outstanding are restated for 3-for-2 stock split.

description: b-Included a gain of $2 million. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Injunction On MCorp
description: A Federal judge today issued a preliminary injunction to keep MCorp's bankruptcy case in the courts and out of regulators' control.

title: Bridge
description: Many players eager to improve their game wish now and then for a word of advice - spoken, rather than written in a book. Others are interested in tournament schedules and results, along with the deals played in them.

title: Lakers and Pistons Set to Stretch Long Season
description: On June 21, 1988, at the Forum in Inglewood, Calif., the longest season in National Basketball Association history ended after 106 games with the Los Angeles Lakers defeating the Detroit Pistons, 108-105, in the seventh game of the N.B.A. Finals to become the first team in 19 years to repeat as champions.

title: Bosket Loses Federal Court Ruling Over Being Shackled to Cell Door
description: Willie Bosket, the murderer who is considered New York State's most violent prisoner, lost a challenge yesterday over how the prison authorities chain and shackle him.

title: Salomon Offering $300 Million Issue
description: Salomon Inc. is offering $300 million of floating-rate notes, due in 1994, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. as sole manager.

title: SUPERCONDUCTORS SHOWING A FLAW THAT DIMS HOPE
description: Recent discoveries have dimmed hopes that a new class of superconductors will ever find wide use, despite predictions two years ago that they could bring vast economic benefits.

title: Dep Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said net income for the three and 9 months ended April 1989 included $318,000 relating to a change in accounting for income taxes pursuant to adoption of SFAS 96. The lower 9 months earnings resulted from a $471,000 after-tax loss from the company's United Kingdom operations; the sales of new, high- growth, lower-margin products accompanied by higer advertising and promotional spending; and a provision for loss on disposition of the company's fine-fragrance assets of $260,000.

title: Gas Blast and Uzbek Rioting Preoccupy Soviets
description: The Soviet Union today suspended organization of a new legislature for a day of national mourning while the authorities contended with two crises: a gas explosion that left hundreds dead or missing in the Ural Mountains, and an outbreak of violence that brought thousands of troops into eastern Uzbekistan.

title: Review/Ballet; With Kisses and Roses, Patricia McBride's Goodbye
description: In 1965, George Balanchine created a very special solo for Patricia McBride. He had perceptively chosen the young dancer to be the sweet and sparkling Colombine in his commedia dell'arte ballet, ''Harlequinade.''

title: Paper in Hong Kong Says Li Is Wounded
description: A Hong Kong newspaper reported today that the Chinese Prime Minister, Li Peng, had been shot by a police officer in Beijing and that he survived the assassination attempt.

title: European Backing for Films Set by U.S. Talent Agency
description: International Creative Management Inc. today announced an innovative deal through which movie projects it recommends will be financed and distributed primarily by a European company instead of a traditional studio in the United States.

title: AN ISRAELI MAYOR IS UNDER SCRUTINY
description: Attorney General Yosef Harish has ordered the police to investigate whether the Mayor of a Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank incited racism by issuing badges stamped ''foreign worker'' to Palestinian laborers.

title: For Japanese Living in New York city, (Influence Grows)
description: Kiyoko Tucker braces herself when she walks into Hermes, or Chanel, or Tiffany's.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday listing sources and recipients of campaign contributions in Federal elections last year categorized Senator Herb Kohl, Democrat of Wisconsin, incorrectly.

title: Police Mourn Officer Slain In Brooklyn
description: As bagpipes played a solemn funeral farewell outside a small Brooklyn church yesterday, 4,000 uniformed police officers and several hundred civilians honored the second officer killed this year in the line of duty.

title: A. C. Elkins Wed To Ellen Lazrus
description: Ellen Beth Lazrus, a daughter of Naomi K. Lazrus of New York and the late Jay Kay Lazrus, and Andrew Cary Elkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hubert E. Elkins of Port Washington, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., were married last evening at the George Washington Manor in Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated.

title: Dollar Regains Lost Ground Amid Uncertainty Abroad
description: The dollar rose sharply against most major currencies yesterday, regaining the ground lost in its hectic slide Friday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Wine Talk column in The Living Section on Wednesday referred incorrectly to the British comedian Terry-Thomas. He is not ''the late.''

title: Solomon Senior, 85; Led Workmen's Board
description: Solomon E. Senior, a former chairman of the New York State Workmen's Compensation Board, died Thursday of complications following a stroke at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 85 years old.

title: TSI Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Music; Upbeat Fusion Of Styles From Kenny G.
description: Every decade at least one pop-jazz horn player attains the kind of commercial success usually reserved for pop singers. Herb Alpert in the 60's, Chuck Mangione in the 70's and Kenny G. in the late 80's have all reached mass audiences that ordinarily give only half an ear to instrumental soloists. The musical common denominator of the three is a buoyant, upbeat sensibility and an insistent melodicism.

title: Interphase Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Executives Are Shifted At D.M.B.&B. Office
description: The St. Louis office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles announced a major executive realignment yesterday, shifting several executive and senior vice presidents.

title: Health Chief Urges Listing People With the AIDS Virus
description: The New York City Health Commissioner, Dr. Stephen C. Joseph, said here today that he believed that all people who are found to be infected with the AIDS virus should be confidentially reported to the city health authorities. Health workers would then trace the people with whom they have had sex or shared needles.

title: Rose Glasser Kaplan; Social Worker Was 88
description: Rose Glasser Kaplan, a social worker and a founder of the East River Group of Hadassah on Manhattan's Lower East Side, died of a heart attack last Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 88 years old.

title: Nobel Insurance Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Sea Mammals Feast On Oregon's Salmon
description: Hungry seals and sea lions are dining on salmon off Oregon, and fish experts say Oregon residents are picking up the check.

title: Swedes Scuttle Cruise for Young Delinquents
description: It seemed like a good idea at the time, Ragnar Jotestam explained, referring to a Swedish decision last month to send a group of juvenile delinquents on a faraway sailing trip to try to teach them the values of community and cooperation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the investigation of the explosion aboard the battleship Iowa characterized a Navy statement incorrectly in some copies. The statement did not mention Petty Officer 3d Class Kendall L. Truitt by name. The article also referred incorrectly to the Navy's four battleships.

title: Owens-Illinois Debt Snag
description: Owens-Illinois Inc. said today that it does not expect its cash flow to enable it to make on-time principal payments on the $2.8 billion of debt incurred in the $3.64 billion leveraged buyout by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company in 1987.

title: State Executions Help Teach That Life Is Cheap; Expression of Outrage
description: To the Editor:

title: Kandahar Journal; New Problem for Guerrillas: No Russians to Fight
description: ''Before, here were Russians, there were Russians, everywhere Russians, so people were busy with the fighting,'' said Tahir Khan, a young guerrilla commander helping to direct the siege of the ancient royal city of Kandahar. ''No question, everybody was against the Russians. But now people are confused.''

title: INSIDE
description: Vodka Market Bucks Trend When most of the liquor business has been stagnant, the vibrant $450 million premium vodka market has lured several new entrants. Page D1. Lendl Suffers Upset Seventeen-year-old Michael Chang suffered from cramps, but defeated top-seeded Ivan Lendl at the French Tennis Open. Page A25.

title: Rymer Foods reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Included income of $3,000 and $318,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and gains of $30,000 and $1,094,000 from the early retirement of debt for the same periods, respectively. c-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $6,000 for the quarter and income of $605,000 from discontinued operations for the 6 months.

title: KEY RATES
Fresh Flowers, Long Ago
description: At this time of the year, with all their efforts coming literally into flower, gardeners tend to settle into their own little habitats - proud of their peonies, self-congratulatory about their roses and close to the deadly gardening sin of smugness.

title: Pilots' Fatigue Seen As a Possible Factor In 2 Stealth Crashes
description: Pilot fatigue and disorientation may have been a factor in fatal crashes of two Stealth jet fighters in California and Nevada, according to heavily censored Air Force accident reports.

title: Edward McShane, 85, Mathematician, Dies
description: Edward J. McShane, a mathematician who taught at the University of Virginia for 39 years until his retirement in 1974, died of congestive heart failure Thursday at the University of Virginia Hospital in Charlottesville. He was 85 years old and lived in Charlottesville.

title: Coffee Pact Threatened
description: Producers of high-quality arabica coffee beans took a tough line today as crucial talks opened on the future of a 74-nation coffee agreement to support prices.

title: Team Visits Fusion Lab But Divides on Claims
description: THE first Federal team of scientists to inspect the Utah laboratory that claims to have achieved low-temperature fusion came away divided. Some members said they were favorably impressed while others said they were deeply skeptical that a new source of energy had been discovered whose importance would rival the discovery of fire.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING Italian Tour Snowed Out: Snow and below-freezing temperatures forced cancellation yesterday of the much-feared 16th stage of the Italian cycling tour, a 93.1-mile ride through four mountain passes. A landslide in the Valtellina Valley prevented use of an alternative course. Organizers indicated the tour would be resumed today. (AP) COLLEGE BASEBALL L.S.U. Defeats Long Beach: Tookie Johnson's three-run double in a six-run third inning powered Louisiana State to an 8-5 victory over Long Beach State in a College World Series elimination game yesterday in Omaha. Kyle Abbott (15-3) was the losing pitcher after being picked ninth yesterday in the major league amateur player draft. In the elimination game today, L.S.U. will face Miami, which lost to Texas, 12-2, last night.(AP)

title: Notes Are Priced By Sallie Mae
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association yesterday priced $450 million of floating-rate notes, due Dec. 14, at par for offering through the agency and its regular selling group.

title: Review/Film; Japanese Fanatic's Wish: Jail Cell at Home
description: ''The Emperor's Naked Army Marches On,'' was shown as part of the 1988 New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 15, 1988. The film opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Piedmont Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Student's Body Is Honored With Tears of Horror and Cries for Revenge
description: For the dozen student pallbearers who walked solemnly into the university hall, it was a grim scene: The body of a friend lay wrapped in a red cloth and nestled in a bed of ice on a table.

title: State Executions Help Teach That Life Is Cheap; Deep Ambivalence
description: To the Editor:

title: High Court Helps Assure Drexel Pact
description: Rejecting an appeal by Michael R. Milken and his brother, the Supreme Court yesterday cleared the way for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to reach a final settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission on a wide array of securities-law infractions.

title: S-K-I Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Employees Taken Out Of Beijing
description: Several big United States corporations, including I.B.M., Xerox and Dow Chemical, pulled their non-Chinese employees out of Beijing yesterday or closed offices as a result of the weekend violence.

title: Stunning Vote Casts Poles Into Uncharted Waters
description: As the breadth and depth of Solidarity's overwhelming victory over the Communists in Poland's freest election in more than four decades emerged today, both the Communist leadership and Solidarity faced questions never confronted before in a Communist-ruled Eastern European country.

title: Let City Charter Vote Follow Mayoral Election
description: To the Editor:

title: Shift at Merrill Lynch
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that Courtney F. Jones would leave his positions as chief financial officer and executive vice president to become a managing director in the investment banking division. Mr. Jones, 49 years old, will continue as chief financial officer until a successor is named, Merrill said. In his new post, he will have senior responsibilities for providing strategic advice to leading clients, the company said.

title: Eastern Unions Set Back As Bid for Takeover Fails
description: The long search by the unions at Eastern Airlines to find a buyer for the airline and wrest its control away from Frank Lorenzo suffered a major setback yesterday when a Chicago commodities trader failed to put together a takeover deal.

title: Explosive Fabricators Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Squaring the Circle: New Light on Old Riddle
description: MATHEMATICIANS still cannot square the circle using only a compass and straightedge, a problem first posed by the ancient Greeks and later proved to have no solution.

title: POLITICAL CHANGE PROMISED IN JAPAN
description: Japan's new Prime Minister, Sousuke Uno, vowed today to clean up the corruption that has engulfed his country's political system for the last year. He said he would ''go to the very roots of this affliction so that no similar disgrace ever occurs again.''

title: Weapon Scientist Says Harassment Is Renewed
description: A FEDERAL scientist who asserted that high Government officials were misled about the feasibility of a proposed antimissile laser and successfully fought what he asserted were reprisals for his outspokenness says he is now being harassed with a security investigation.

title: Buyout Firm Joining American Medical Bid
description: A New York leveraged buyout firm said today that it had joined the group offering $1.8 billion for American Medical International Inc., the Beverly Hills-based hospital and health-care company.

title: Florida Wants to Put the Brakes on Water Scooters
description: A new kind of traffic is worrying the authorities who patrol Florida waterways: water scooters, some of them piloted by children hardly old enough to ride a bicycle.

title: Support for Borough Presidents at Bronx Hearing
description: Dozens of members of Bronx civic groups, community boards and social service agencies told the Charter Revision Commission yesterday that it had failed to give enough weight to New York's borough presidents in its proposed government.

title: Orioles Make Pitcher No. 1 Selection in Draft
description: Ben McDonald, 14-3 for Louisiana State this year after starting the season with 44Z scoreless innings, was chosen by the Baltimore Orioles yesterday as the first pick in baseball's amateur draft.

title: PRESIDENT SPURNS OTHER SANCTIONS
description: President Bush today ordered a suspension of American military sales to China in response to what he called the ''violent and bloody'' crackdown against demonstrators in Beijing.

title: Appointment at Kidder
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company, a unit of the General Electric Company, yesterday announced the appointment of B. J. Megargel, 35 years old, as the head of mergers and acquisitions. Mr. Megargel has been the head of international mergers and acquisitions for Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. He will report to Scott C. Newquist, the newly appointed head of investment banking for Kidder.

title: Precious Metal Prices Slip As Rush to Dollar Continues
description: Precious metal prices eased yesterday under pressure from a soaring dollar. Although many Asians, particularly those in Hong Kong, are growing fearful of the recent violence in Beijing, many prefer to convert their assets into dollars rather than gold, as has traditionally been the case in uncertain times.

title: New Research Overturns A Milestone Of Infancy
description: FOR years it was considered a mark of healthy development for infants at around nine months of age to show distress at the presence of a stranger. Indeed, the dogma that ''stranger anxiety'' is a major milestone in an infant's emotional growth is still espoused in most books of advice for parents, and in many textbooks on child psychology.

title: Bodies of 4 Who Were Killed In Vietnam War Are Identified
description: An Army laboratory has identified the remains of four Air Force officers missing in the Vietnam War, the Defense Department said today.

title: SkyWest reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Westchester Field Set
description: Among the golfers who announced over the weekend they would play in this week's $1 million Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N.Y., were Tom Kite, the PGA Tour's leading money-winner, and Curtis Strange, the defending United States Open champion.

title: Leader Manufacturing Inc reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-After a charge of $76,431. c-After a special charge of $431,152. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Tandem to Enter Software Ventures
description: Tandem Computers Inc. entered development agreements with three leading producers of database software. Tandem, which specializes in computers for on-line transaction processing like airline reservation systems and automatic teller machines, has relied primarily on its own proprietary software.

title: Briton Sees a Revival In Design in the U.S.
description: Michael Peters, who heads a fast-growing design company in Britain, has come to New York as the president and chief executive of the concern's North American subsidiary.

title: Sun-Times Fills Posts At Company and Paper
description: The Sun-Times Company, the publisher of The Chicago Sun-Times, said yesterday that it had named Sam S. McKeel president and chief executive and said he would concentrate on building the holding company into a major media enterprise.

title: Powerful Cosmic Rays
description: Physicists in Utah have reported the highest energy radiation yet detected from a specific source in the sky. It is in the range of ''exaelectron volts,'' a recently invented category to cover energies of one billion billion electron volts. It is also expressed as 10 followed by 18 zeros.

title: Championship Series Turns Old Friends Into Foes
description: When Magic Johnson strolls to midcourt before Tuesday night's game, he will exchange kisses with Isiah Thomas and Mark Aguirre. Then Johnson will ignore his two closest friends and do everything he can to lead Los Angeles to another championship.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 China troops took defensive positions that suggested that they feared attack from other military units. There were reports that some clashes had already occurred. Page A1

title: Vodka Import Boom: New Entries Rush In
description: Inspired by the strong sales of Absolut vodka at a time when most of the liquor business has been stagnant, several major companies have plunged into the $450 million premium vodka market.

title: Final Tirade Heard as Throngs Mourn Khomeini
description: The body of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the soul of Iran's Islamic fundamentalist revolution, lay surrounded by hundreds of thousands of weeping, chanting mourners today. Even in death, he managed one last denunciation of his enemies.

title: Indian Deeds Didn't Give Land Title to Colonists
description: To the Editor:

title: 31 Riders Hurt as Cement Pours on Subway
description: Thirty-one subway riders were injured during last evening's rush hour when freshly poured cement struck the roofs of an express train on Manhattan's East Side and disrupted service on the Lexington IRT.

title: Giuliani Plans Earlier Leave From His Firm
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani has decided to take a leave of absence from his law firm to avoid further controversy in his campaign for mayor, top Giuliani aides said yesterday.

title: Blue Jays Open the SkyDome but Lose
description: The Blue Jays lost their debut in the SkyDome tonight as Glenn Braggs hit a two-run homer, leading Milwaukee past Toronto, 5-3.

title: Abiomed Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Strike by Oil Workers
description: More than 1,000 British North Sea oil workers, who have been staging sporadic job actions to protest their pay and working conditions, struck today for 24 hours at several offshore fields. The Amalgamated Engineering Union said the men, mostly construction workers employed by subcontractors, stopped working in the Brent, Forties and Thistle fields. Oil company spokesmen said production was not affected by the wildcat strike. The strikes, which began last month, have focused on working conditions, which the contract workers contend are inferior to those of regular oil company employees.

title: Sudan Rebel to Meet With Officials on Truce
description: A Sudanese rebel leader said today that he would meet Saturday with members of the Sudanese Government, including the Deputy Prime Minister, to discuss terms of a cease-fire in the six-year-old civil war.

title: Civil War For Army?
description: American military specialists say a serious rift has developed within the Chinese armed forces as a result of the Beijing Government's crackdown on the students over the weekend.

title: FPS Computing reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Designcraft Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The shares have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend distributed in September 1987.

title: Hopes for Superconductivity Begin to Fade
description: AN unexpected electromagnetic phenomenon threatens to block the most dramatic potential applications of high-temperature superconductors, researchers say.

title: Despite Threats to Actress, Prison to Release Attacker
description: An actress is terrified that a crazed fan who nearly butchered her seven years ago will try to finish the job after he is released from prison next week.

title: Jack Belden, Journalist, 79
description: Jack Belden, a foreign correspondent who reported from China before and after World War II and from Africa and Europe during the war, died Saturday of lung cancer in Paris, where he had lived for the last 20 years. He was 79 years old.

title: Powell Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Quality Survey Has Buick Smiling
description: The General Motors Corporation's Buick division captured two high positions in an independent study on the quality of new cars, adding to the growing evidence that American car makers are moving to reduce defects and problems that have plagued their products.

title: Blue Jays Utilize a Strength Within
description: Reflecting on a 25-year career that has led to a place in baseball history, Cito Gaston had at least one regret.

title: SHOOTING OF CIVILIANS GOES ON; BUSH BARS ARMS SALES TO CHINA
description: Chinese troops took up what seemed to be defensive positions here on Monday that suggested they feared attack from other army units, and there were reports that clashes between units had already occurred on the outskirts of the capital.

title: Ethiopian Parliament Backs Talks With Rebels in Eritrea
description: The Ethiopian Parliament today endorsed unconditional peace talks with the rebels in Eritrea in an effort to end the country's civil war.

title: Kurt A. Solmssen, 84, A Drug Executive, Dies
description: Kurt A. Solmssen, a former vice president of Smith, Kline & French Laboratories, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Philadelphia. He was 84 years old.

title: Beating the Heat in Shorts, Skirts, Tights
