description: Legs are coming out into the open. Designers were predicting the move when they introduced their fall collections a few months ago, but with the arrival of warm weather, New Yorkers have jumped the gun.

title: Corrections
description: A listing on the statistics page of SportsMonday this week about the National Basketball Association Finals included some incorrect sites. The first two games - tonight and Thursday - are in Detroit; the third, fourth and, if necessary, fifth games, June 11, 13 and 15, are in Los Angeles; the final two games, June 18 and 20 if necessary, are in Detroit.

title: Market Place; Phone Companies Fear Takeovers
description: ONE by one, the seven regional Bell telephone companies are taking the kinds of defensive measures normally associated with the big industrial corporations: they are adopting ''poison pills'' and employee stock ownership plans.

title: Talking Business - with Camacho Gaos, Mexican official; Mexico's Effort To Lure Investors
description: Even though Mexico has one of the world's most open economies, foreign investment has dropped substantially, to $3.15 billion last year from $3.87 billion the year before.

title: In Paris, Chang Topples Lendl in Five Sets
description: Michael Chang said a prayer to make the cramps go away and then summoned all the courage of his 17 years to defeat top-seeded Ivan Lendl today in a spellbinding match at the French Open, 4-6, 4-6, 6-3, 6-3, 6-3.

title: 3 Pianists at Juilliard Win Scholarships
description: Three pianists at the Juilliard School have been awarded full scholarships as winners of the school's Gina Bachauer International Scholarship Competition.

title: Mets Take A Turn for The Worse
description: Just when they seemed to be getting the act together, the Mets were bushwhacked by the Chicago Cubs tonight and were handed their worst defeat in four years: a 15-3 mauling that began when David Cone was knocked out after two innings in the fastest exit of his career.

title: DEFENDANT DENIES HE KILLED PALME
description: The man charged with murdering Prime Minister Olof Palme more than three years ago pleaded not guilty today at the beginning of his trial.

title: Manville Sets Warrant Price
description: The Manville Corporation said today that it had set a $9.40 exercise price for its warrants, issued as part of the company's emergence from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: In Blood, a New China Is Born
description: Room number 735 in the old Beijing Hotel has a beautiful view up Changan (Long Peace) Boulevard, leading into Tiananmen (Gate of Heavenly Peace) Square a block or two distant. It is a front row seat from which to witness the birth of a new era in China and the death of Deng Xiaoping's dream of an era of enlightenment.

title: New Conner Syndicate
description: The next America's Cup competition will not be held until 1992, and the location is, at the moment, uncertain, but Dennis Conner is already making plans. Last March, Justice Carmen Ciparick of the New York State Supreme Court awarded the cup to New Zealand after Conner had seemingly defended it successfully the previous September as the skipper of a catamaran against a monohull sailed by Michael Fay of New Zealand.

title: Next Big Oil Spill Could Be in Great Lakes
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Court Opinions About Job Rights
description: Following are excerpts from the majority opinion of Justice Byron R. White and the minority opinion of Justice John Paul Stevens in the Supreme Court's 5-to-4 decision today on the elements of proof in employment discrimination cases. FROM THE OPINION By Justice White

title: Communists Conceding A Victory for Solidarity And Call for a Coalition
description: The Communist Party acknowledged tonight that the Solidarity movement had achieved a ''decisive majority'' of the popular votes in the Polish parliamentary elections, and it challenged the victors to join in a coalition government.

title: Darkness In China
description: In breaking off military sales to the Chinese, and in his measured statements of condemnation, President Bush has done about as much as he could in the wake of the awful events in Tiananmen Square.

title: Harry A. Jackson, Oil Executive, Dies at 89
description: Harry Andrew Jackson, an oil company executive, died in his sleep yesterday at his home in Winchester, Va. He was 89 years old. Mr. Jackson was a graduate of the University of California at Berkeley. He was a former vice president of Seaside Oil Company in Santa Barbara, Calif., and of Tidewater Associated Oil Company (later known as Getty Oil) at its New York headquarters. In the mid-1950's he was a founder of American Petrofina Inc., the New York-based branch of Petrofina of Belgium. He was its president until 1968, when he retired. He was also a trustee of Fordham University and a director of the Wilmington Trust Company and the Seaboard Surety Company.

title: Aviator, 11, Starts Flight To U.S.S.R.
description: An 11-year-old boy who is the youngest pilot to fly across the United States took off today on a 19,000-mile good will flight, to the Soviet Union and around the world.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Joel Goldstein has been named creative director of Bozell Direct.

title: Literary Journal Is Planned in 4 Languages
description: After two years of preparation, four prominent European publications plan to start a literary and cultural review this fall whose contents and design will be identical in its English, German, French and Italian editions. A participating editor described it as ''an attempt at a multinational operation that deals in ideas rather than in fast food or consumer products.''

title: Quotas Stall OPEC Talks
description: OPEC talks bogged down today as members tried to decide how to share larger oil quotas among 13 competing members without setting production levels so high that prices would tumble.

title: New Technique Eases Fertilization
description: COUPLES having difficulty conceiving may eventually benefit from a new technique that makes it easier for sperm to fertilize an egg.

title: Hornbeck Offshore Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Excerpts From Bush's News Session
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's White House news conference yesterday, as transcribed by the Federal News Service: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Latshaw Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits for Bionaire Inc. of $15,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $40,000, or 7 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: 'New Town': Oasis or Mirage In Rockaways?
description: Theophillis Houston stood on the boardwalk on the Rockaway peninsula in Queens and gazed inland at the section of Arverne around Beach 68th Street. As beachgoers talked and laughed on the sand at the edge of the Atlantic, Mr. Houston, a longtime Arverne resident, tried to envision the ''new town'' that New York City officials say will rise on the vast, largely barren stretch.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. AD HOC COMMITTEE ON FOURTH DEVELOPMENT DECADE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council

title: G.E. Agrees to Sell Electronics Plant
description: The General Electric Company said it would sell an electronics components plant here to a small Pennsylvania-based manufacturer for a Tennessee plastics plant and $110 million. GE said the sale of its Instrument Products Operation to Ametek Inc. would not affect 1,110 workers at the plant. The workers would keep their jobs, and Ametek has agreed to recognize the plant's three unions, a G.E. spokesman, Robert Risch, said.

title: Groups Postpone China Trips
description: Groups planning to visit China, ranging from a high school chorus in the Bronx to a group of specialists on the American Presidency, have postponed their trips as a result of the violent crackdown in Beijing.

title: Cyanamid to Buy Praxis Biologics
description: Praxis Biologics Inc. agreed to be acquired by the American Cyanamid Company for Cyanamid common stock valued at $14 a share for each Praxis share, making the deal worth around $190 million. The company said the exchange ratio will be based on the trading price of Cyanamid stock for a period before the shareholder meeting called to consider the merger and will be no less than 0.2268 share and no more than 0.2772 share. The agreement is subject to approval by the Cyanamid board.

title: NWA Asks Its Suitors for Stronger Bids
description: Dissatisfied with the takeover proposals it has received so far, NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, told bidders today to think matters over and submit new bids.

title: Evolving Black Hole
description: Also in the Cygnus constellation, astronomers have detected an exploded star they believe may be evolving into a black hole. The star, designated V404 Cygni, is only the fourth star that astronomers have detected that seems likely to become a black hole.

title: Starrex Mining Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company noted that it began gold production in April 1988, and the year-ago first quarter's results are made up primarily of investment income. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Exalted Warriors, Humble Roots
description: AN anthropologist has concluded that the exalted samurai, the legendary warriors who were idealized as the epitome of everything Japanese, were actually descended from the lowly Ainu, an ethnic group that is considered primitive by most Japanese and is often the target of their discrimination.

title: State Executions Help Teach That Life Is Cheap
description: To the Editor:

title: Primary Today In New Jersey
description: Polls will be open today from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M. Voters will choose candidates in the race for governor and for seats in the State Assembly. In the gubernatorial primary, there are three Democratic candidated and eight Republicans: Democrats James J. Florio Alan J. Karcher Barbara Boggs Sigmund Republicans Gerald R. Cardinale Jim Courter W. Cary Edwards William L. Gormley Chuck Hardwick Thomas Blomquist James A. Kolyer 3d Lois G. Rand

title: Short Screens and Other Word-Processing Woes
description: THE playwright Larry Kramer, like many writers, is frustrated by the limitations of current computer-based word-processing systems. ''I can't for the life of me understand why all screens are so short,'' he lamented.

title: Near Desert Resorts, A Threatened Lizard Gets Its Own Refuge
description: THE Coachella Valley fringe-toed lizard is unusual in more than its name. It is now the only lizard in the world with $25 million worth of real estate.

title: Court Strengthens Copyright Status Of Freelance Artists on Commission
description: In an important legal victory for freelance artists and writers, the Supreme Court ruled today that such artists retain the right to copyright what they create as long as they were not in a conventional employment relationship with the organization that commissioned their work.

title: Washington Talk: Districtspeak; From Those Who Would Be Understood
description: A ruling issued by the Merit Systems Protection Board, June 1, 1989:

title: DIVORCE GRANTED FOR NURSING CARE
description: A judge today issued a divorce decree for a Methodist minister who said he wanted to end his marriage to his paralyzed wife of 32 years so she could afford nursing care.

title: Beijing and Moscow
description: How strange this is:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Drexel Sold 'Junk Bonds' For Chiat
description: YES, the controversial Drexel Burnham Lambert did sell some infamous high-yield ''junk bonds'' for Chiat/Day last summer. Why? So Jay Chiat could buy back the agency from employees.

title: Vehicle Sales in Late May Fell 3.6% Despite Incentives
description: Sales of American-made cars and light trucks dropped by 3.6 percent in late May despite continuing incentives aimed at rekindling buyer interest.

title: State Executions Help Teach That Life Is Cheap; Cure for Recidivism
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't want to see a total break in this relationship and I will not encourage a total break. When you see these kids struggling for democracy and freedom, this would be a bad time for the United States to withdraw.'' - President Bush. [ A1:5. ]

title: Our Towns; Naturalist Dies But His Legacy Still Blooms
description: The woods will miss Dan Smiley. So will his research assistants, Anna Forster and Paul Huth. Before the memorial service for their boss Friday, the two took a walk along North Lookout, a ridgetop path Mr. Smiley loved most at dawn, when bird song filled the valley. Miss Forster listened. ''Hermit thrush,'' she said. She knew what Mr. Smiley would have said: ''Make a note, Anna!''

title: Sanders Sees How It's Done
description: Yankee management has been telling Deion Sanders that he can be a major league outfielder, and his new teammates demonstrated last night that there are plenty of openings for him.

title: Review/Television; What Are Commercials Selling to Children?
description: About 20 years ago, the new Action for Children's Television, started by mothers in the Boston area, prompted a national crusade when it attacked commercials in children's programming as being exploitative and a disservice to society. For the past couple of weeks, I have been dipping into the children's schedule and watching endlessly repeated sales pitches for sugary cereals, sweet drinks, fruit-flavored candies and blond blue-eyed dolls with ''fabulous hair'' and ''the hottest clothes.''

title: Hanson Coup: Smith Corona Offer
description: When Hanson P.L.C. bought the SCM Corporation for $930 million in 1986, many analysts and executives thought the acquisitive British industrial conglomerate had overpaid. But every few months since then, it seems, Hanson has announced a stunning new deal for SCM assets to show the skeptics how wrong they were.

title: A Package For Those Aspiring To Surgery
description: THEY may have gone too far this time, the people at Software Toolworks. Life and Death is a medical simulation in which you play the part of an inexperienced resident at Toolworks General, examining patients, reading charts, interpreting X-rays and, ultimately, performing surgery.

title: Freelance Workers Gain on Copyrights
description: In an important legal victory for freelance artists and writers, the Supreme Court ruled that such artists ordinarily retain the right to copyright what they create. The Court held that the right applies as long as the artists were not in a conventional employment relationship with the organization that commissioned their work. Article, page A24.

title: Books of The Times; Food and Sex as Substitutes for a Father's Love
description: Sweet Desserts By Lucy Ellmann 145 pages. Viking. $17.95.

title: House Leadership Candidates Are Among Top Fund-Raisers
description: Candidates vying to lead the House of Representatives into a new era of Congressional ethics and campaign financing are themselves among the lawmakers whose incomes and political funds have benefited most from the current system.

title: One Man Can Make a Difference: This One Jousted Briefly With Goliath
description: It all started with a man in a white shirt who walked into the street and raised his right hand no higher than a New Yorker hailing a taxi.

title: Chess
description: A predilection that two of the greatest attacking players of all time, the present world champion, Gary Kasparov, and Bobby Fischer, a former world champion, have in common is the provocative defense.

title: In 1800's, U.S. Excelled As an Unfair Trader
description: To the Editor:

title: Prime Rate Cut 1/2 Point, To 11%
description: In a move that reflected the general decline in interest rates, the nation's leading banks yesterday lowered their prime lending rate half a percentage point, to 11 percent.

title: Review/Opera; A Berlin 'Walkure' With Guns as Well as Spears
description: Have no fear: stage directors have not yet run out of ways to make one smile at Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen.'' The second installment of the Deutsche Oper Berlin's production, ''Die Walkure,'' continued to gratify in that useful respect at its first American performance on Sunday evening at the Kennedy Center Opera House. The four-year-old staging by Gotz Friedrich, the West German company's general director, gave evidence at times of having large goals in mind but seemed to aim most consistently at the funny bone.

title: Voicemail International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bohemia Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $191,000 and $2,163,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss Year-ago quarter and year losses reflected a provision of $24,125,000 for losses on timber contracts and related assets.

title: Bell, W & Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Careers; Helping Older Workers Get Jobs
description: COMPANIES today look more favorably at hiring workers aged 60 and older than they did a decade ago, says James E. Challenger of Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc., a Chicago-based outplacement firm.

title: Prices Inch Up in Volatile Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched higher at the close of a topsy-turvy session yesterday, as waves of profit taking during the afternoon wiped out big gains earlier in the session.

title: A Showplace for a Showman
description: Visitors to the $7.5 million three-years-in-the-making Barnum Museum will definitely not be greeted by a banner that proclaims ''Welcome, Suckers'' when it opens to the public on Saturday.

title: RCM Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Review/Opera; An Early-Music 'Idomeneo': It Might as Well Be 1781
description: Every scene has its stars, and more of the stars of the early-music scene are English than any other nationality. This year's Boston Early Music Festival has had its many ups and occasional downs, but it began and, for all practical purposes, has ended with genuine events - Andrew Parrott's speculatively reconstructed ''Monteverdi Mass'' on May 29 and 30, and Roger Norrington's concert performances of Mozart's ''Idomeneo'' on Friday night (which this writer heard) and tonight.

title: An Army With Its Own Grievances
description: American experts on the Chinese Army say its morale has been badly affected over the last year by the same problems of inflation and corruption that have created widespread dissatisfaction among the public with the Communist Governnment.

title: Bundesbank Is Cautious On Further Rate Moves
description: For the last several months, the world's financial markets have anxiously tried to guess whether the Bundesbank, West Germany's powerful and highly independent central bank, would raise interest rates in a bid to bolster the mark against the dollar.

title: Beijing Chiefs, Probably for the First Time, Are Actively Opposed by Large Numbers
description: Mao used to say that 95 percent of the people were with the Communist Party and only 5 percent against it. Nobody ever took polls in China, much less allowed votes, but it is probably safe to say that the Great Helmsman, who died in 1976, was close to being right.

title: A.&P. Waldbaum Fine
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company has agreed to pay a $3 million fine to settle a complaint that it did not notify regulators of its 1986 takeover of Waldbaum grocery stores, the Justice Department said today. A.&P. and Tengelmann Warenhandelgesellschaft, its West German parent, agreed to pay the fine without admitting any wrongdoing. A.&P. was charged with violating the pre-merger notification requirements of the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act when it brought control of Waldbaum Inc.

title: Yankees Lose, but Don't Ask!
description: The comedy couldn't have become blacker, so the crowd of 24,711 was left with nothing to root for except that the clouds overhead might get darker. The top of the third inning had degenerated into the nadir of the season for the Yankees, and so out came the umbrellas.

title: Meeting About Rose
description: Ronald Peters, identified by his lawyer as the principal bookmaker for Pete Rose, will be cross-examined Saturday by lawyers for the Cincinnati Reds' manager.

title: Court, Ruling 5 to 4, Eases Burden On Employers in Some Bias Suits
description: In a major civil rights ruling, a sharply divided Supreme Court today made it substantially easier for employers to defend hiring and promotion practices that have an unfavorable impact on women and members of racial minorities.

title: Enclean Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the year-ago quarter and 9 months.

title: Smith Retires, Will Coach Goalies
description: Billy Smith, at the age of 38 the National Hockey League's eldest statesman, announced his retirement today after 17 combative seasons with the Islanders. Smith had one year remaining on his contract but elected to accept a three-year pact as the club's goaltending coach rather than spend his final season sitting on the bench.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; WPP Group Acquires
description: Through its subsidiaries, J. Walter Thompson and Hill & Knowlton, the WPP Group yesterday acquired two Austrian marketing companies. J. Walter Thompson bought Ernst Haupt-Stummer, Austria's second-oldest full-service advertising agency after Thompson's own Austrian branch. The agency will be merged with Thompson. Hill & Knowlton acquired Pubrel Public Relations Gesellschaft, a leading Austrian public relations firm. Terms of both deals were undisclosed.

title: Rig Count Rises by 35
description: The number of United States rigs drilling for oil and gas rose by 35 last week, to 784, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago there were 898 rigs active. The offshore rig count was steady at 101, while the number of rigs in shallow inland waters rose by 3, to 23, Baker Hughes said.

title: Clashing Views on Purchaser of Mosaics
description: Two opposing views of Peg L. Goldberg, the purchaser of four sixth-century Byzantine mosaics whose ownership is in dispute, emerged today. Ms. Goldberg, an Indianapolis art dealer, took the stand here in Federal District Court in the fifth day of a trial in which the Government and the Greek Orthodox Church of Cyprus are seeking the return of the antiquities.

title: Already a Victory for New Jersey
description: New Jerseyans endured one of the nastiest political campaigns in the nation last fall, when the Democrat, Frank Lautenberg, and the Republican, Pete Dawkins, slung mud at each other in a contest for the U.S. Senate.

title: 2 Riders' Similarities Stop Astride a Saddle
description: They both are named Pat, they both ride horses for a living and both are former cocaine abusers who say they have now found sobriety through religion. When either wins a big race, he makes a point of raising his eyes and arms skyward in thanks as soon as he reaches the winner's circle.

title: Mega Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Longshore Shape, a Hiring Ritual, Ends
description: This morning, most likely for the last time, men with broad backs and rough hands went down to the water's edge here and in Manhattan and Brooklyn looking for work on the piers and berths of New York Harbor.

title: Gandalf Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 6
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Fewer Viewers For Networks
description: Here is one way to understand the declining viewership of network television: A decade ago, NBC finished last among the three major networks, according to the A.C. Nielsen Company, with a 27 percent share of the viewing audience. In 1988, with a 26 percent share, NBC was a resounding first.

title: Forceful, Not Frantic, About China
description: China is still reeling from the shock of last weekend's murderous army assault on the demonstrating students at Tiananmen. And now come reports of large troop movements, possibly pointing to battles between the military allies of different political factions.

title: George Schermer, Rights Expert, Dies at 78
description: George Schermer, a former human rights official and an expert on race relations, died of congestive heart failure Saturday at his home in Washington. He was 78 years old.

title: Summit County Journal; Taking Time Out From Themselves
description: The blue of the sky seemed more a force than a color, a palpable energy hovering over the aging snow of the highlands and the Rocky Mountain meadows coming into the full green of late spring. The driver of the Resort Express van looked from the Rockies to the road, shifted gears and sighed.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Pantorama Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company changed its fiscal year-end to Jan. 31 from July 31. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Iran-Contra Deceptions By Ex-Agent Charged
description: A former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency who faces trial in the Iran-Contra affair misled the Tower Commission and agency investigators in 19 instances, Government prosecutors charge.

title: Q&A
description: Goosebumps Q.I understand why you get goosebumps when you feel cold, because each bump is where a hair is standing on end the way fur would. But why do you feel cold and even shiver when something else, like chalk screeching on a blackboard, gives you goosebumps? A.Just as an animal's fur stands on end when cold, it stands on end as a response to threatening noises or sights. This bristling is thought to occur to make the animal look larger, and therefore more formidible, to an opponent, said Dr. Henry Edinger, an associate professor of physiology at the New Jersey Medical School in Newark. Bristling fur as a respone to cold keeps the animal warmer by increasing the amount of air between hairs, which traps body heat.

title: Hasbro Adopts 'Poison Pill'
description: Hasbro Inc., the toy manufacturer, said today that it had adopted an anti-takeover measure.

title: Errors Prompt Proposals to Improve 'Peer Review' at Science Journals
description: DISCLOSURES about fraudulent and erroneous scientific papers have focused new attention on the publication process and have prompted an array of proposals to make scientific journals more accountable.

title: U.N. Chief Sees the Outline Of a Cyprus Accord in Talks
description: Talks between the leaders of the two Cypriot communities have progressed to the point where ''the contours of an overall agreement are discernible,'' Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar said today.

title: Diagnostic/Retrieval Sysems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The MIG Surrender at Trabzon
description: Turkey is a member of the NATO alliance and last year received more than $500 million in U.S. military and economic aid. Yet its Government refused to let American officials inspect a Soviet MIG-29 fighter plane that a defecting pilot flew across the Black Sea to a Turkish airport near Trabzon. An invaluable opportunity has been lost to examine an advanced fighter that is the mainstay of the Soviet air defense system.

title: Bankers Cool to Appeal By Brady on Debt Plan
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady appealed today to leading commercial bankers to embrace the principles of his plan for reducing the debt burden of less developed countries.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times last Tuesday about effects of pesticide misuse in the third world misstated a finding of a survey of farm workers in Brazil. It found that 28 percent of 5,000 workers - not 28 workers -said they had suffered pesticide poisonings.

title: CONCERNS RAISED ON SCHOOL QUALITY
description: President Bush announced tonight that he would appoint a President's education policy advisory committee to help him carry out a ''national crusade for excellence in education.''

title: A Disney Office Crown?
description: A special set of Mickey Mouse ears will crown the top of the Walt Disney Company's new headquarters here, The Los Angeles Business Journal reported today. The chairman and chief executive of Disney, Michael D. Eisner, and its president, Frank G. Wells, each will have an office in one of the two domes built on top of the 336,100-square-foot building, the paper said, quoting unidentified sources. Disney officials refused to comment about the structure, which is scheduled to be completed in six months.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Domecq Importers Inc., a wine and spirits importer, to Tromson Monroe Advertising, with a budget of $3 million.

title: Program in Michigan to Pay Insurance for AIDS Victims
description: Michigan is starting a program to keep AIDS victims off the Medicaid rolls by paying their private insurance premiums.

title: Argentine Hints of Early Inauguration
description: As an edgy peace settled over Argentina after the worst riots in a decade, politicians said today that President-elect Carlos Saul Menem would probably seek an early transfer of power.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Celgene Corp., Warren, N.J., a chemical biotechnology company, named Thomas B. Lewis senior vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Enzon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Stewart & Stevenson Servces Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
NCH Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
By Design; Small Equals Chic
description: All it takes is a second for the fashionable ''eye'' to switch. For instance, big bold accessories have been looking just fine - up to now. But suddenly, the smaller the better.

title: Life Inmates Can Wed, Judge in Syracuse Rules
description: A New York State law that prohibited inmates from entering into marriages while serving life sentences has been struck down as ''arbitrary and irrational'' by a Federal judge.

title: Stocks Plummet Amid Concern on China
description: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday, pulled down by a late wave of selling. The Dow Jones industrial average, off 19 points about an hour before closing, ended 37.13 points lower. The drop of 1.5 percent, to 2,480.70, was the biggest decline since the indicator fell 48.57, or 2.1 percent, to 2,292.14, on March 17.

title: Historic Desegregation Case Still Open in Topeka
description: A Federal appeals court has refused to close the landmark Brown vs. Board of Education desegregation case, saying that the Topeka, Kan., school board has failed to carry out fully the United States Supreme Court's 1954 mandate.

title: Pepper Buried in Florida In Affectionate Farewell
description: Lillian Jenkins never met Claude Pepper. He was not even her Congressman. But Saturday evening, as mourners filed through the First Baptist Church in Miami to view his body, Mrs. Jenkins was among them, holding the hands of her daughters, Shuntel, 5 years old, and Takesia, 11, dressed in their Sunday best, blue ribbons in their hair.

title: Thomas A. Wilson, Administrator, 60
description: Thomas A. Wilson, administrator of the Federal milk-marketing program in the New York-New Jersey area, died last Wednesday at the Hoboken (N.J.) Medical Center after a heart attack. He was 60 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Andrews Group Inc. said its Four Star Holdings Corp. unit had accepted almost 4.8 million, or about 97.6 percent, of New World Entertainment Ltd.'s common shares under its $8.95-a-share offer for New World.

title: Schools Watch Court on Liability Issue
description: In a case being watched closely by school districts across the state, New York's highest court is considering how far schools must go in trying to protect student athletes from injury.

title: Patterns
description: Bright Note: Short Skirts

title: Dime Savings of New York Gets Lower Moody's Rating
description: The long-term deposit rating of the Dime Savings Bank of New York has been lowered by Moody's Investors Service as a result of a rise in delinquent residential property loans.

title: Proposal to Reduce Flow of Boat People Is Delayed
description: Western and Southeast Asian countries have agreed to put off action on a proposal that is expected to lead to more restrictive treatment of Vietnamese boat people.

title: Using Optics to Concentrate and Exploit Sunlight
description: AN optical system that concentrates sunlight at least 56,000-fold has been developed by scientists at the University of Chicago.

title: Tonys? Six. Profits? None Soon.
description: When ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' won the Tony Award for best musical on Sunday night, it greatly increased its chances of earning back its investors' money.

title: Colonial Oil & Gas Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Saatchi & Saatchi will sell Gamma International S.A., a French computer software company, to Le Groupe Andre for $12.4 million. Saatchi had acquired Gamma through its purchase of the Hay Group in 1984.

title: Pope Says Religious Freedom Is Progressing
description: Pope John Paul II said today that while some Roman Catholic communities are still forced to live an underground existence, progress is being made toward guaranteeing religious freedom throughout Europe.

title: Washington Talk; 3 Missions With Nothing but a Cause Fight for Independence From Soviets
description: Fifty years ago, Stalin swallowed the republics of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. But as the independent nations vanished, they left behind foreign diplomatic missions that are experiencing a renaissance today as pressure for a break from Moscow grows in the homelands.

title: Rexene Proposes $7-a-Share Payout
description: The Rexene Corporation, a maker of chemicals and a plastic products company, said its board had decided on a restructuring plan with a one-time dividend of $7 a share and an increase in the company's regular quarterly dividend to 25 cents a share from 15 cents. The plan also calls for raising $425 million by the sale of high-yield debt through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Washington Talk; Congress
description: The Jim Wright affair is often talked about as an exercise in partisan warfare, with Republicans bagging a Democratic Speaker and Democrats plotting revenge.

title: Neo-Nazi Gets Life Sentence For Beating Black to Death
description: A neo-Nazi member of a local skinhead gang was sentenced to life in prison today for beating a man to death with a baseball bat because he was black.

title: Booksellers Still Feel Khomeini's Influence
description: Even in death, the Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini has been a noticeable influence at the convention of the American Booksellers Association. Everyone who enters the convention hall must pass through a metal detector and submit to a baggage check. And before and during the exhibit, security guards and bomb-sniffing dogs patrol the aisles.

title: A Playwright's Path to His Play
description: ''What I hope to accomplish with my writing,'' says Philip Kan Gotanda, ''is to allow people to enter into the world of what it means to be Asian-American. So that the next time you walk down the street and see an Asian-American, you can no longer look at that face and reduce it to a stereotype. You'll be forced on some level to deal with this person as a complex human being, and a human being who is also unique because he or she is an Asian-American in this country.''

title: The Last, Swish, Certainty
description: They're still playing basketball.

title: 2 Foreigners Named Sony Board Members
description: Michael P. Schulhof, a 46-year-old businessman-scientist, is one of two non-Japanese who have been nominated to the board of the Sony Corporation.

title: Mitsubishi Motors
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation said it would introduce a new luxury car in the United States in 1991. The auto maker said it would not set up separate dealerships to sell the luxury model, unlike Honda, Nissan and Toyota. Mitsubishi said the car would would be priced between $20,000 and $30,000.

title: Article 193689 -- No Title
description: In a bid that reflects both the soaring values of cellular telephone properties and the increasing consolidation in that industry, McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said late yesterday that it would begin a cash tender offer valued at $6.5 billion, or $120 a share, for the Lin Broadcasting Corporation. McCaw already owns 9.8 percent of Lin.

title: Dow Advances by 15.62 in Volatile Trading
description: After a volatile session, the stock market closed higher yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average regained part of the ground it lost Monday.

title: Bridge
description: The first stage of the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team Championship, in which the best squads from the New York metropolitan region struggle for almost a year, ended two weeks ago.

title: China's Future: Four Scenarios
description: Words are inadequate to encompass China's tragedy. But even while trying to comprehend what is happening, it is useful to look at what might be ahead.

title: Review/Theater; Agony and Ecstasy of an Opera Addiction
description: In ''The Lisbon Traviata,'' Terrence McNally has written the theatrical equivalent of an operatic double bill - an opera bouffe followed by a tragic denouement. The first act, in the play's newly revised version, is a savagely amusing and empathetic study of two men whose lives have been lost in opera. The second act is discordant, as it was in the play's earlier showcase production in 1985.

title: New Look at Eastern Bid Reported
description: Although the Texas Air Corporation has rejected a takeover deal in which a Chicago commodities trader would acquire Eastern Airlines, the acquisition effort appeared yesterday to still be alive.

title: Sharing Recognition
description: Susan Butcher got a silver platter yesterday in honor of her athletic achievements. But her teammates won't mind her stealing the spotlight.

title: Mitchell Hits 3 Out As Giants Split 2
description: Kevin Mitchell led off the ninth inning with his second bases-empty home run of the game to give San Francisco and its pitcher, Rick Reuschel, a 3-2 victory over Cincinnati and a split of a doubleheader tonight.

title: University Control Of Schools Backed
description: The Massachusetts Senate has approved a plan by Boston University to take over the troubled Chelsea schools for 10 years.

title: Euroflag Aircraft
description: The four partners in Airbus Industrie and a fifth aerospace company plan to develop a new generation of military transport aircraft for the late 1990's. Aerospatiale of France said they would form a new industrial alliance called European Future Large Aircraft Group, or Euroflag. In addition to Aerospatiale, the Airbus partners are are British Aerospace P.L.C., Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm G.m.b.H. of West Germany and Casa of Spain. Joining them in Euroflag is Aeritalia of Italy.

title: Loyal to Kean and to Reagan, Courter Embraces 2 Camps
description: In a state where conservatives do well in the Republican primary and moderates usually win the general election, Representative Jim Courter can run in each contest without missing a beat.

title: King-Duva Rivalry Now a Family Feud
description: Boxing may soon have its version of ''Family Feud,'' the television game show in which rival families compete for prizes.

title: Critic's Notebook; Feeling the Weight of Judgment
description: On paper, the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition is a drama in three acts: the preliminary and semifinal rounds that are now virtually over and a final round of concertos with orchestra to begin on Thursday. Yet it might be more accurate to divide this event in two - into its days of innocence and days of judgment.

title: Bank Yields Fall Further In Week
description: Yields for certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts slipped further in the week that ended yesterday, a day after large banks lowered their prime lending rate to 11 percent.

title: Capitol Police Investigating Columnist for Smuggling Gun
description: The Capitol Police are investigating an incident in which the syndicated columnist Jack Anderson smuggled a pistol and a bullet into the Capitol to demonstrate security lapses.

title: Bonn Calls Quarter Growth Strongest of Decade
description: West Germany posted its strongest quarterly economic growth of this decade, according to data released today.

title: Bonn Bans African Ivory
description: The West German Government today joined France in banning ivory imports from Africa in an effort to save African elephants from extinction. The ban invoked by the Environment Ministry took effect immediately, a ministry statement said. France imposed a similar ban over the weekend, and the West German ministry said it expected other European Community countries to follow suit soon.

title: Bush Order May Affect Grumman
description: President Bush's order to suspend American military sales to China has created fears of new layoffs at the largest employer on Long Island, the Grumman Corporation.

title: Review/Television; 4 Perspectives on America as Myth
description: Public television's ''American Playhouse'' takes an unusual spin tonight at 9 on Channel 13 with ''Imagining America,'' an hourlong anthology that is intended to be a pilot for a possible series. It's not just that the material comes from independent film makers, who normally have a tough time finding outlets in television. These are short films, most running somewhere between 10 and 15 minutes. That market is even more limited. Music videos and occasional news essays, the kind of thing Jon Alpert might do for NBC News, monopolize the field.

title: Solidarity and Warsaw Search For a Way to Govern Poland
description: Solidarity and the Communist Government appear to be moving toward greater cooperation in the face of the opposition's success in outpolling the Communists in Sunday's national elections.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Placed Gerald Perry, first baseman, on the 15-day disabled list. Called up Jeff Wetherby, first baseman, from Richmond of the International League. CINCINNATI (NL) - Recalled Scott Scudder, pitcher, from Nashville of the American Association. Placed Herm Winningham, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Placed Luis Aquino, pitcher, on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to May 31. Called up Rick Luecken, pitcher, from Omaha of American Association. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Optioned Ramon Martinez, pitcher, to Albuquerque of the Pacific Coast League. Recalled Tracy Woodson, infielder, from Albuquerque. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Activated Steve Ontiveros, pitcher, from the 21-disabled list. Sent Mike Maddux, pitcher, to Scranton-Wilkes Barre of the International League. TORONTO (AL) - Sent Jeff Musselman, pitcher, to Syracuse of the International League on a 20-day rehabilitation assignment. Activated Manny Lee, infielder, from the 15-day disabled list. Assigned the contract of Alexis Infante, infielder, to Syracuse. COLLEGES BETHEL, KAN. - Named Glenn Snyder men's head basketball coach. BROCKPORT STATE - Named Rick Ross hockey coach. CLARKSON - Announced the resignation of Brian Chafin, men's soccer and women's basketball coach, effective July 1. DARTMOUTH - Named Roy Coates men's swim coach and Mary Hulbert women's squash coach. DUQUESNE - Named Joe DeSantis men's assistant basketball coach. KENTUCKY - Named Herb Sendek men's assistant basketball coach. TEXAS A&M - Named Bert Hill strength and conditioning coach. FOOTBALL NEW ORLEANS (NFC) - Signed Florian Kempf, place-kicker. TAMPA BAY (NFC) - Declared Dan Turk, offensive guard, a free agent by withdrawing a contract offer.

title: New TV Thriller: Root Development
description: As television cameras continue to shrink, the scientific possibilities continue to grow. At the Department of Agriculture, for example, scientists are using miniature cameras to watch plants grow.

title: Legions of Soldiers Encircling Beijing: Loyalty to Whom?
description: Administration officials estimate that elements of 10 People's Liberation Army units, totaling 100,000 to 150,000 troops, have been deployed in and around Beijing.

title: In Much of World, Racial Distinctions Prevail
description: To the Editor:

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: VARIATIONS on pasta with spring vegetables are endless. The ubiquitous pasta primavera has seen so many twists and turns over the years that it has virtually lost its original identity.

title: Japan Sets $1.4 Million Bail For Scandal's Central Figure
description: The Tokyo District Court today set bail of $1.4 million for the former chairman of the Recruit Company at the center of Japan's biggest postwar political scandal.

title: Cooperation, Not Coalition, in Poland
description: Credit Poland's Communist authorities with an honest count in Sunday's election. The results have transformed the Solidarity union into the Eastern bloc's first elected parliamentary opposition party. Now Communists and Solidarity will need to learn how to work together, even as they continue to challenge each other. How well they manage could determine the pace of change elsewhere in Eastern Europe.

title: The Americanization of Bao Bing, a Cool, Fruity Asian Treat
description: By SUSAN MERNITd wonders of Oriental cuisine, bao bing, a simple fruit dessert, has long stood out as one of the most ubiquitous in Asia. Yet it is almost unknown in the West.

title: Topics of The Times; Bus Busters
description: A six-month undercover investigation has uncovered evidence of pervasive corruption in New York City's school bus inspection system.

title: Bad News for Morris
description: Jack Morris (2-7), not long ago the ace of the Detroit Tigers' pitching staff, went on the 21-day disabled list two weeks ago because of a chip in his right elbow. After an examination on Monday by Dr. David Collon, Morris learned he would be out for at least another seven weeks.

title: Buyer of Mosaics Is Backed By Two Witnesses at Trial
description: Lawyers for Peg L. Goldberg, the Indianapolis art dealer whose purchase of four sixth-century Byzantine mosaics is being contested in Federal District Court by the Government of Cyprus and the Greek Orthodox Church there, today introduced the testimony of two expert witnesses who characterized her actions as wholly within the law.

title: Prime Computer
description: Prime Computer Inc. dropped its appeal to to enjoin MAI Basic Four Inc.'s unsolicited takeover bid. Prime said it dropped its action in the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit because MAI's 50-cent-a-share reduction of its offer had made the appeal irrelevant. Prime said MAI's offer of $19.50 cash ''does not reflect the intrinsic value of the company.'' Prime postponed its annual meeting to July 26 from June 14 to explore alternatives.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES Paramount Communications bid for Time Inc., offering $175 a share, or $10.7 billion. The offer is expected to set off a nasty battle involving some of the nation's most visible media and entertainment companies. [ Page A1. ] Martin S. Davis, the head of Paramount Communications, said a year ago, ''I don't like unfriendly takeovers, and I won't participate in them.'' [ D5. ] McCaw announced a $6.5 billion cash tender offer for Lin Broadcasting, in a deal that would merge two of the nation's largest cellular telephone companies. The proposal reflects the trend toward consolidation in the industry. [ D1. ] RJR Nabisco announced the sale of five European food businesses to BSN, France's largest food company, for $2.5 billion, as part of its plan to reduce debt. [ D1. ] CNW said it would become a private company in a leveraged buyout it valued at $1.6 billion. [ D1. ] G.M. announced plans to unify under one division the design and engineering of its small domestic cars. [ D1. ] A Chicago commodities trader's offer for Eastern Airlines appears to still be alive. [ D25. ] Five suppliers of Crazy Eddie asked a Federal judge to order the liquidation of the troubled electronics retailer. [ D4. ] MCI won its biggest contract ever, a five-year, $150 million deal to provide Merrill Lynch with a worldwide network. [ D4. ] MARKETS The Federal Reserve signaled an easing on credit, allowing the Fed funds rate to fall for the first time in 15 months. [ D1. ] Yields slipped further for C.D.'s and bank money market accounts in the week ended yesterday. [ D15. ] After a volatile session, the Dow Jones industrial average regained part of the ground it lost Monday, ending 15.62 points higher. [ D8. ] The demand for precious metals increased in the wake of the turmoil in China, driving up the price of gold and silver. [ D16. ] The dollar sagged in the face of gold's steep rally. [ D16. ] INTERNATIONAL More U.S. companies rushed to pull personnel out of Beijing as the Bush Administration urged all Americans to leave. [ D7. ] President Bush's suspension of military sales to China created fears of new layoffs at Grumman. [ D7. ] West Germany posted its strongest quarterly growth of the decade, according to data released yesterday. [ D28. ] THE ECONOMY Bowing to pressure from colleagues, Senator Bentsen said the Finance Committee would begin work next week on overhauling the provision of the tax law that prohibits discriminatory treatment of low-wage workers. [ D2. ] Whether air fares have risen abnormally at airports dominated by one or two airlines is a matter of dispute by a Congressional agency and an industry group. [ B5. ] TECHNOLOGY Automated message handlers can function as librarians and mail sorters, routing or filing documents according to their contents and even extracting information. [ D1. ] Scientists are using miniature cameras to watch plants grow, in a study of root development. [ D6. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Doctors are feeling the pressure for tighter controls of medical costs. Economic Scene. [ D2. ] The Japanese stock market placed a value of about $510 million on Levi's Japanese subsidiary. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D8. ] Marketers were warned that they are missing an opportunity in the Pacific. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D24. ]

title: Paramount, Pressing Warner, Bids $10.7 Billion for Time Inc.
description: In a move expected to set off a nasty battle involving some of the nation's most visible media and entertainment companies, Paramount Communications Inc. - known until Monday as Gulf and Western Inc. - offered last night to pay $175 a share, or $10.7 billion in cash, for Time Inc.

title: For Orioles, The Future Is Truly Now
description: So much for five-year plans. Let's not hear any more talk about rebuilding through the draft or how a team is just one player away from being a contender. The Baltimore Orioles are spoiling it for all those coaches, managers and general managers in sports whose job security is based on convincing their owners that success cannot be delivered overnight like express mail.

title: Rice, Barrett Surgery
description: Jim Rice and Marty Barrett of the Boston Red Sox underwent surgery yesterday for injuries that will sideline them for up to six weeks.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I believe the standard of public conduct is higher and the performance of that standard is better in this House today than in any other time in the history of our nation.'' - House Speaker Thomas S. Foley. [ A22:4. ]

title: INSIDE
description: U.S.-Soviet Military Accord Washington and Moscow will sign a military agreement to prevent accidental encounters from turning into major confrontations. Page A6. Reagan's Judicial Legacy The Supreme Court, in two recent rights rulings, shows that it is the body that President Reagan wanted it to be. News analysis, page A16. U.S.-Pakistani Meeting President Bush and Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto agreed to continue aid to the Afghan rebels. Page A3. RJR Nabisco is selling five European businesses to BSN, France's largest food company. Page D1.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-14

title: Britain Stands by Its Pledge To Cede Hong Kong to China
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told Parliament today that despite ''utter revulsion and outrage at the indiscriminate firing on people'' in Beijing, Britain would abide by its commitment to hand over the colony of Hong Kong to China in 1997.

title: Needle Exchange Programs Hint a Cut in AIDS Virus Transmission
description: Needle and syringe exchange programs for intravenous drug users in three cities have reduced needle-sharing and the risk of transmitting the AIDS virus without an increase in drug use, new studies show.

title: Los Angeles Acts to Cut Construction Traffic
description: Trucks, traffic and construction are both the boon and the bane of Los Angeles, and today the city announced an unusual plan to get construction workers' cars and trucks off the streets during rush hours.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Maxwell Halts China Daily
description: The British publisher Robert Maxwell yesterday suspended the European publication of China Daily, the official English-language newspaper, because of the Chinese Government's crackdown in Beijing.

title: Florio's Strategy: Blend of Ideals and Caution
description: The Democratic nominee for Governor, James J. Florio, is a complex amalgam of political images: a tough amateur boxer, a thoughtful environmentalist, an idealistic political reformer and the leading political figure in a county known for corruption and patronage.

title: DOCUMENTS GIVEN TO ARABS IN GAZA
description: The Israeli Army began distributing computer-coded identity cards in the Gaza Strip today, enabling the authorities to penalize those considered troublemakers by preventing them from working or traveling in Israel.

title: Food Notes
description: Taste of the Caribbean

title: Future Seen By the Pacific, Not in Europe
description: MARKETERS transfixed by the creation of a unified European market in 1992 are missing an even bigger opportunity if they do not look to the nations bordering the Pacific, a top Australian advertising executive said yesterday.

title: The Pop Life
description: Buster in Films?

title: Class of '89 Takes the Torch
description: It's time for graduation speeches once again, and I have once again agreed to give one. I say ''once again'' as if I'd given dozens over the years. In truth, this will be only my third in 22 years; the first was given in 1967, on the day I graduated from the Westlake School for Girls in Los Angeles. I gave what is remembered in family lore as a speech of such stunning seriousness and overwrought 60's idealism, delivered at such breathtaking speed as to be all but incomprehensible. Do these family members still laugh about it? Indeed they do. Even I do, sometimes. I gave another graduation speech at Westlake seven years later. If the country's tone had darkened by then, what with Vietnam and Nixon, my own had lightened up a bit, by virtue simply of age. I was no longer an adolescent. But my speech was still sober and exhortatory, the standard graduation fare.

title: 5 RJR Units Sold for $2.5 Billion
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. today announced the sale of five of its European food businesses to BSN, France's largest food company, for $2.5 billion.

title: William J. Grede Is Dead at 92; Joined in Founding Birch Society
description: William J. Grede, an industrialist who joined in the founding of the John Birch Society, died in his sleep Monday at the Congregational Nursing Home in Brookfield, Wis. He was 92 years old.

title: The Charter: Wait, Weight or Improve?
description: It's halftime in New York City's bumpy pursuit of a new government. In the three months since the Supreme Court probably doomed the Board of Estimate, a Charter Revision Commission has held hearings, solicited expert advice, tolerated the special interests and struggled to draft a proposal.

title: Mets Pull Triple Play But Cubs Pull Away
description: The Mets wrote a footnote to their history today when they made a triple play against the Chicago Cubs. But it was a little like drinking champagne on the Titanic because the Cubs otherwise smacked them around for the second straight game, knocked out Bob Ojeda in the fifth inning and tumbled the Mets, 8-4.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THE Third Avenue buts was headed uptown. Just north of the Bowery two chatty women boarded. They took the last vacant seats, facing each other across the wide aisle, and continued their conversation, which was heard by, among others, Jean Libman Block. ''Did I tell you he used a new kind of finish on the floors?'' ''What kind?'' ''It's supposed to last forever.'' Scornfully: ''Forever? That's ridiculous.'' ''He said it would last forever.'' ''Nothing lasts forever.'' Peevishly: ''That's what he said.'' ''I tell you, nothing lasts forever.'' New voice: ''There's something that does.'' All heads turned to the rear of the bus where the interloper went on to insist, ''One thing lasts forever.'' ''Exactly what?'' demanded the skeptic. ''Death. That's what lasts forever.''

title: Senate Panel to Begin Overhaul of Tax Clause
description: Bowing to pressure from Senate colleagues, Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, said today that the panel would begin work next week on overhauling the provision of the 1986 tax law that prohibits discriminatory treatment of low-wage workers in employer-paid health plans.

title: Investors Acquire 14.3% Sorg Stake
description: Richard N. Hokin and J. Kermit Birchfield Jr., two investors who control the Chas. P. Young Company, said they had bought a 14.3 percent stake in Sorg Inc. from Young and a partnership. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Hokin and Mr. Birchfield said they intended to renew discussions with Sorg ''about the advisability and possibility of a business combination or joint venture between Young and Sorg.''

title: In Brooklyn, College Ends A Lean Year With Relief
description: At Brooklyn College this was the year of the budget crunch: Because of cuts in state financing, there were fewer courses, larger classes, no faculty and staff hirings, and a reduction in the number of part-time college jobs that are important to students who need the income.

title: Resignation at Salomon
description: After only three months as head of merchant banking at Salomon Brothers, Lee H. Kimmell resigned yesterday. He will remain as a consultant to the firm until Aug. 1.

title: John H. Bryan, Food Executive, 80
description: John H. Bryan, co-founder of the Bryan Packing Company, now Bryan Foods, died Monday at Clay County Medical Center here. He was 80 years old and lived in West Point.

title: Bonds for Dormitory Unit
description: The New York State Dormitory Authority yesterday tentatively priced about $699 million worth of tax-exempt revenue and special obligation bonds for state university educational centers through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company.

title: Don't Meddle In Iran
description: LEAD: In his final years, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini brought down Jimmy Carter in the hostage crisis and humiliated Ronald Reagan in the Iran-contra scandal. Now, his legacy threatens a third Administration, if it should succumb to the temptation of trying to exert influence over a post-Khomeini Iran.

title: Shanghai, at a Standstill, Waits Apprehensively
description: This is a city waiting. The buses have stopped running. Barricades have been erected across main thoroughfares. The police are nowhere in sight. For the moment, the authorities seem to have abandoned Shanghai to its people.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Review/Television; The Inherent Bias, Good or Bad, of the Mindless Eye
description: No, the shoots of democracy that the world has seen springing up and being crushed in China during the last few astonishing weeks were not planted by television, but the presence of the cameras in Tiananmen Square nourished them and may keep them alive despite the army's guns. Whatever the outcome in Beijing, the picture of a lone figure stopping a line of advancing tanks will remain an affirmation of the individual's steadfastness before the might of the state.

title: Mary Morrison Kennedy, Hotel Executive, 87
description: Mary Morrison Kennedy, a former vice president of architecture and decoration for the Sheraton Corporation of America, died Sunday at her home in Boston. She was 87 years old.

title: It's a One-Horse Town for Trainer
description: As the morning sky over Belmont Park was changing from deep purple to gray dawn yesterday, Charlie Whittingham arrived for work as late as he ever does: it was already 5:15 A.M.

title: A Female First for Jaycees
description: The founding chapter of the Jaycees, a longtime male-only organization, is being headed by a woman for the first time in its 74-year history. Camille Oehler, a 26-year-old field representative with the American Cancer Society, was elected president of the 125-member chapter here last month.

title: Topics of The Times; Postal Immortal
description: Unlike most people whose names adorn Federal buildings, Walter Edward Grady never served in Congress or the Cabinet. Neither was he rich or famous. Yet a new post office on Staten Island in New York City is about to be named in his honor, and for good reason.

title: Japan, China's Main Foreign Benefactor, Puts Billions in Aid in Doubt
description: Responding to reports of growing turmoil in China, Japan ruled out immediate sanctions on Tuesday but took steps that cast doubt on the future of billions of dollars in aid projects widely deemed crucial to China's economic growth.

title: Paramount Chairman's Advice: 'Do Something'
description: One year into his job as chairman and chief executive of Gulf and Western Inc., Martin S. Davis told a reporter, ''I don't like unfriendly takeovers, and I won't participate in them.''

title: China's Upheaval: The Repercussions
description: American companies rush to remove personnel from China.

title: Drug Needle Exchange Is Gaining but Still Under Fire
description: After operating for seven months, New York City's program to give intravenous drug addicts new hypodermic needles to help stem the spread of AIDS has finally begun to attract more participants but remains under attack.

title: Pennsylvania Schools Chief Quits Amid Criticism
description: Pennsylvania's top education official has resigned amid criticism of his leadership and of the state's plans to reallocate spending for special education programs.

title: Legislature to Set Child-Support Rules
description: In a move that is expected to dramatically increase the size of child-support payments in New York, the State Legislature is preparing to enact guidelines that would fix support payments as a percentage of the parents' income.

title: From the Security Apparatus, An Obscure Leader Emerges
description: Qiao Shi, the Communist Party leader whose major role was reaffirmed by the Beijing radio early today, has had a long career in the shadowy Chinese security apparatus and is believed to be close to old-guard conservatives.

title: Violence of Old Men vs. the Idealism of Youth; Chinese Personalities
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite a Strong Base, Dinkins Struggles
description: David N. Dinkins was already an hour late, but nearly all of the 50 Queens voters who had shown up early for his 9:15 P.M. speech to the Jesse L. Jackson Independent Democratic Club were waiting patiently in a sultry and dimly lighted Elks Club hall in Far Rockaway.

title: Criminal Investigation Is Begun at Arms Plant
description: The Justice Department today announced a broad criminal investigation into possible violations of Federal environmental laws at the Rocky Flats Plant in Colorado, which processes plutonium for nuclear warheads.

title: Airlines Discriminate Against the Blind
description: To the Editor:

title: Carefree Days of Turning Garbage Into Real Estate Are Over
description: To the Editor:

title: Kenya Frees Three Detainees Being Held Without Charge
description: Kenya is releasing the last three political prisoners detained without charge, the state radio said today.

title: Dana Converse Backus, A Retired Lawyer, 82
description: Dana Converse Backus, a retired lawyer, died of Alzheimer's disease Sunday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan and Sands Point, L.I.

title: G.M. Plans To Realign Operations
description: In a primary reorganization, the General Motors Corporation announced plans today to unify under one division the responsibility for the design and engineering of its small domestic cars.

title: Americans Donated $104 Billion in '88
description: Americans gave $104.3 billion to charities in 1988, the first time donations topped $100 billion, but fund-raising officials said the figure would have been much higher if it had not been for changes in the tax law.

title: The Night After: LaPoint, Yankees Rebound
description: The two of them stood on the grass in front of the visitors' dugout the other day in Milwaukee and worked on mechanics. When Billy Connors spoke, Dave LaPoint listened attentively, not knowing whether the discussion would reap benefits or offer little help.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Travel Related Services Co., a financial services company and unit of American Express Co., appointed Warner J. Canto Jr. senior vice president of worldwide event marketing.

title: Real Estate; High-Tech Offices Rise In Jersey City
description: FROM the outside, the 14-story building nearing completion on Newport Drive and Washington Boulevard in Jersey City differs little from the other commercial structures that have sprouted on the west bank of the Hudson River in recent years.

title: Economic Scene; Doctors Pressed To Curb Costs
description: DOCTORS are feeling the pressure for tighter controls of medical costs as Congress and the Administration try to halt double-digit increases. Medical organizations have been thrown on the defensive, struggling to preserve the professional autonomy of 500,000 physicians.

title: Citicorp Paper
description: Interest rates were down sharply yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. The bank holding company said it had sold $50 million in 91-day paper at an average rate of 9.018 percent, down from 9.2937 percent. It also sold $50 million in 182-day paper at an avergae rate of 8.7150 percent, down from 9.0261 percent.

title: Los Angeles Journal; Quest for Gritty Reality Unfolds Amid the Tinsel
description: When Los Angeles newspapers wrote about one of the city's newest social groups, a club called Disgruntled Ex-New Yorkers, even the hate mail struck the Easterners as excessively mellow.

title: 2 van Gogh Shows Insured for Billions
description: Two exhibitions of works by Vincent van Gogh to mark the centenary of his death next year are to be insured for $2.73 billion, probably a record, a Dutch bank said Monday.

title: Pistons Overpower Lakers in Playoff Opener
description: The Detroit Pistons' backcourt came to the forefront tonight.

title: Audubon's 'Birds' Brings $3.96 Million
description: A copy of John James Audubon's five-volume ''Birds of America'' was sold last night at Sotheby's for $3.96 million, the highest price paid at auction for an illustrated printed book. The buyer, who bid over the telephone, was not identified.

title: U.S., Trying to Protect Elephants, Declares Ban on All Ivory Imports
description: The United States has banned imports of ivory to help avert further slaughter of African elephants.

title: OPEC Accord Called Near
description: A meeting here of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries remains deadlocked in its fifth day, with sentiment among delegates going against Kuwait, which has insisted on a special increase in its oil production quota.

title: Wine Talk
description: SO Lichine is gone, dead at 76 last Thursday at his home in Bordeaux, Chateau Prieure-Lichine. We had come in the end to think of him as a kind of Monument Historique, dominating the wine scene the way the Eiffel Tower dominates Paris. Like the tower, Alexis Lichine was once controversial, even hated, but, like the tower, he lived to become a symbol of what is best about France.

title: Crazy Eddie Suppliers Ask for a Liquidation
description: Five suppliers of Crazy Eddie Inc. asked a Federal bankruptcy judge in Manhattan yesterday to order the liquidation of the troubled electronics retailer, which they accused of ignoring $860,000 in past-due debts.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies in Science Times yesterday about a mathematical theory on squaring the circle incorrectly described the number 10#50.

title: Review/Music; A Night of Flamenco Guitar, With Sabicas and Friends
description: The stage of Carnegie Hall was pelted with long-stemmed red roses on Saturday evening as Sabicas, the legendary flamenco guitarist, entered from the wings.

title: Books of The Times; A Europe Modeled on Italy, Foibles, Swindles and All
description: Europe, Europe By Hans Magnus Enzensberger Translated by Martin Chalmers. Pantheon. 325 pages. $18.95.

title: Foreigners Scramble to Leave Beijing
description: As gunfire continues to echo in the capital, thousands of foreigners are preparing to leave and the United States Embassy here is urging all Americans to get out of the country.

title: Washington Talk; The House, the Press and Bad Feelings
description: Representative Jack Brooks of Texas says reporters have ''engaged in a feeding frenzy.'' Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin accuses them of ''a mean-mindedness and reckless disregard for balance and fair play in their skewering of the Congress.''

title: Llamas Are Trekking in U.S.
description: Llamas made news last April when a herd of 268 was taken from Chile to Barbuda, a small island off Antigua, where about 100 of the llamas died of heat stroke. They were reportedly being held in quarantine until they could be imported into the United States.

title: In Refrigerator's Depths, Mystery Lurks
description: IF your refrigerator is like most, the oldest thing in it has been there for at least two years - and it is still edible. Without looking, do you know what it is? Most people haven't a clue. Of a dozen people questioned, only Julia Child knew right away; everyone else had to check.

title: From Poland, Much More Than Sausage and Sauerkraut
description: DANUTA DOBRZYCKI is clear about one of her missions in life, a mission she expressed with characteristic exuberance. ''I want to change the image of the Polish kitchen,'' she said while she slivered bright green leaves of sour sorrel for a favorite early-summer soup. Polish food, she said, has had a bad reputation in this country for far too long. ''It is not just sausage and sauerkraut,'' she said.

title: Note to Readers
description: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the growing volume of submissions, however, we regret that we can no longer return articles unless they are accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope.

title: Job Ruling Makes It Clear: Court Has Shifted Right
description: The Supreme Court's 5-to-4 decision in a major employment discrimination case on Monday has dispelled much of any remaining doubt about whether former President Ronald Reagan accomplished his goal of moving the Court in a more conservative direction on civil rights.

title: For Beijing, A Shortfall In Soy Sauce
description: Slowly, Beijing residents are peering out of their windows into the winding alleyways where they live to talk about the events of the last few days. But the more they look, the more they see that life is not normal, and it is not clear when it will return that way.

title: Lois Bringing Humor To New York Politics
description: When many companies were marketing condoms by citing the threat of AIDS, George Lois used the Phantom of the Opera in a drugstore. Where most newspapers try to attract readers with ads focusing on their reporters or the scope of their coverage, Mr. Lois used Willard Scott, the weatherman, singing.

title: Suddenly, Pork Rinds Are Classy Crunch
description: RENDERED from smoked, fried hog skin, pork rinds have suffered a dismal image over the years, never quite garnering the following of other, arguably more respectable junk foods, like pretzels or potato chips.

title: Foley Is Elected House Speaker, But Partisan Warfare Continues
description: Thomas S. Foley of Washington was elected Speaker of a battered House of Representatives today, but his appeal for an end to partisan warfare was met with new attacks from the Republicans.

title: Atlanta in Accord on Plans for a Domed Stadium
description: After weeks of tense political maneuvering that threatened the future of a proposed $210 million domed stadium, the Atlanta City Council approved the project Monday, virtually guaranteeing it will be built.

title: Mediterranean Gold: An Olive Oil Invasion
description: OLIVE oil imports, once a mere trickle, are now surging into the mainstream. Health and fashion have put the Mediterranean diet on the American table, and with it, a bottle of olive oil.

title: Lessons
description: When the 200 chief executives of large corporations who make up the Business Roundtable convene for their annual meeting, the speeches usually focus on a series of topics like personal liability, trade deficits and tax policy. ''Dullest horse meat'' is the way Andrew C. Sigler of Champion International described the fare.

title: U.N. RELIEF AIDE HOPEFUL ON SUDAN
description: A relief operation appears likely to avert tens of thousands of deaths from famine in the southern Sudan, a United Nations official said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASEBALL L.S.U. and Wichita State Stay Alive: Ben McDonald, the top choice Monday in the major league baseball draft, got the final two outs for a save last night as Louisiana State stayed alive in the College World Series by eliminating Miami, 6-3, at Omaha. Last Saturday, McDonald, a 6-foot-7-inch right-hander who was picked by the Baltimore Orioles, was the starter and loser in a 5-2 victory by Miami. In an earlier game, Eric Wedge hit a three-run homer and Greg Brummett won for a second time in this double-elimination tournament as Wichita State ousted Arkansas, 8-4. The fourth-seeded Shockers (65-16) will face unbeaten and top-seeded Florida State (54-16) tonight. The Seminoles downed Wichita State, 4-2, Sunday. Sixth-seeded L.S.U. (54-16) will meet unbeaten and second-seeded Texas (53-17) tomorrow night.(AP) CYCLING Anderson Wins 17th Stage: Phil Anderson of Australia won the 17th stage of the Tour of Italy race yesterday, edging four pursuers by a few seconds at the finish line in Meda. Laurent Fignon of France, who finished in the pack 15 seconds behind the winner, retained the pink jersey of the overall leader with only five stages to go. The 31-year-old Anderson fled the pack along with Rolf Jaermann of Switzerland and the Italians Moreno Argentin, Maurizio Fondriest and Gianni Bugno nine miles from Meda.

title: Broadcasts Show Widespread Unrest
description: Chinese radio broadcasts monitored by the United States Government report turmoil and unrest in many provinces as students and other citizens protest the Government's crackdown on demonstrators in Beijing.

title: New Zealand Bank's Loss
description: In the biggest corporate loss in the nation's history, the Bank of New Zealand said today that it had lost 648.80 million New Zealand dollars, or $374.4 million, for the year that ended in March.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Washington Talk page on Monday about Washington social life misidentified the publisher of USA Today. She is Cathleen Black.

title: Wine-Auction Bills Considered in Albany
description: THE New York Legislature is considering bills that would permit public auctions and retail sales of privately collected vintage wines.

title: Marines Halt Flying, Citing Crashes
description: The Marine Corps today ordered each of its airplane and helicopter units to stop flying for two days of review and training in safety procedures in the next two weeks because 45 marines have died in seven crashes this year.

title: U.S. and Soviets to Sign Pact To Cut Accidental War Risk
description: The American and Soviet military establishments will sign an agreement next Monday to prevent accidental encounters from turning into major confrontations, Administration officials said today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Security Council Meets at 3:30 P.M. on situation in occupied territories. General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. AD HOC COMMITTEE ON FOURTH DEVELOPMENT DECADE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM GOVERNING COUNCIL - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Erno Balogh, Pianist And Author, 92, Dies
description: Erno Balogh, a pianist, composer and author, died Friday at a retirement home in Mitchellville, Md., where he lived. He was 92 years old.

title: Pyramid Selloff
description: Shares of the Pyramid Technology Corporation plummeted today after the Mountain View, Calif., company said it might report a loss for the quarter ending June 30. Pyramid's shares fell $3.50, to $9.75, in over-the-counter trading, where its drop of 26.4 percent was the second worst of the day.

title: KEY RATES
Topics of The Times; Two Women, Thirtysomething
description: At one table in a busy midtown restaurant, a youngish woman in a black blazer talked eagerly over lunch with two friends from the office. She hadn't seen them in a while; she had been away having a baby. ''Ooh!'' they exclaimed when she opened a box and held up a tiny white sailor suit.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Arkla Inc., Shreveport, La., a natural gas company, said it would acquire Louisiana Intrastate Gas Corp. and related properties from a group headed by Wasserstein, Perella L.P. for $50 million and the assumption of existing debt.

title: 59th St. Bridge Market to Shrink a Bit
description: Neighborhood opponents of the enormous marketplace planned for the vaults under the Queensboro Bridge have agreed to set aside their lawsuit in return for the developer's agreement to try to build a much smaller project - one with less space for shops and restaurants and more space for the public.

title: Arizona's Governor Vetoes Spending Plan
description: Gov. Rose Mofford of Arizona, a Democrat, has vetoed a $3.2 billion budget from the Republican-controlled Legislature and demanded that Democrats get a greater say.

title: It's Big East Vs. A.C.C.
description: The Big East and the Atlantic Coast Conferences announced today that they would play their first interconference challenge series of eight basketball games at arenas in Hartford, Greensboro, N.C., and at Byrne Meadowlands Arena in New Jersey.

title: Charter Panel Postpones Vote on Final Proposals
