description: Responding to criticism of its proposals and to demands for more time to review them, the commission drafting a new charter for New York City agreed yesterday to hold extra public hearings and to delay a vote on its final recommendations until late July.

title: Manhattan Loses Jobs; Harm to Region Is Feared
description: The number of jobs in business in Manhattan dropped last year, in sharp contrast with the past several years and with continued job growth in other boroughs, particularly Queens.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: What is the source of student power? What, in the latest dramatic example, gave China's students the power to temporarily paralyze the Government and perhaps, despite the bloody rout by military firepower, change their country's course?

title: Old Crime Held Town In Thrall
description: In this quiet, relatively wealthy town, the arrest last week of a man said to be John Emil List was the biggest news, some residents say, since he disappeared almost 18 years ago.

title: Medellin Journal; In 'Machine-Gun City,' Life's Not Worth a Song
description: In a triumph of life-giving science, surgeons here recently announced that they had completed their eighth successful transplant of a human heart. The patient, a young man who received the heart of a woman, was reported in excellent condition at the Santa Maria clinic, in Medellin's gleaming, high-rise downtown.

title: Eating Well
description: The Eating Well column in The Living Section on Wednesday referred incorrectly to fees charged by California Certified Organic Farmers to certify produce as organic. The program charges one-half of 1 percent of gross sales annually and a one-time application fee of $150.

title: Violence of Old Men vs. the Idealism of Youth; What Tocqueville Said
description: To the Editor:

title: J. H. Merrick, 90, Lawyer and Executive
description: J. Harold Merrick, a lawyer and former corporate executive, died of congestive heart failure Monday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: Johnson Has Talks On Ranger Post
description: Bob Johnson, who is reported to be the top candidate to become the next general manager and perhaps coach of the Rangers, met with Madison Square Garden officials yesterday, sources reported.

title: Mark J. Appleman, 72, Wall Street Consultant
description: Mark J. Appleman, a consultant, died of heart failure Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72 years old.

title: Disaster Pay Planned for City
description: A railroad and a fuel-shipping company have announced plans to reimburse residents of a neighborhood stricken by twin disasters last month.

title: Market Place; Japanese Relish Levi Unit's Stock
description: BY American standards of valuation, Japanese investors are giving money away when they buy stocks. Yesterday, Levi Strauss Associates Inc., the jeans maker, took in some of that money. In the process, Levi emphasized how radically the valuations of stocks differ in the two countries.

title: Juveniles Find Education Behind Prison Walls
description: Nineteen-year-old Marcus Wright had to be sent to jail for cocaine possession before he began receiving a decent education.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Politics
description: Categories like liberal and conservative are about as helpful to understanding the divisions here over what American policy should be toward the upheaval in China as genealogies of the Ming Dynasty are toward understanding the turmoil of today.

title: After 15 Months, Fed Signals Easier Rates
description: Reacting to signs of a slowing economy and a surging dollar, the Federal Reserve Board yesterday signaled that it was easing its grip on credit conditions, allowing the Federal funds rate to fall for the first time in 15 months.

title: 4 Gold Medals Won by Fallon
description: Fallon McElligott continued its winning ways at the One Show last night, garnering four gold medals for print advertisements, including a public service ad for the Episcopal Church, a perennial Fallon winner, and an ad for Porsche cars that proclaims, ''Compromise is for politicians.''

title: 3 Who Put Together The Time-Warner Deal
description: With his bid last night for Time Inc., Martin S. Davis, chairman of Paramount Communications, is taking on a powerful triumvirate. These three men agreed to merge the companies they head, Time and Warner Communications, and Mr. Davis's bid threatens to break up that deal. Steven J. Ross

title: Craig Colgate Jr., 76, Retired Book Publisher
description: Craig Colgate Jr., the retired founder and publisher of Columbia Books Inc., died Friday at his home in Bethesda, Md., after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Edberg and Becker Gain Semifinals
description: Stefan Edberg of Sweden relied on his proven serve-and-volley game today even though the rain made the slow clay courts even slower, and he beat Alberto Mancini to reach the semifinals of the French Open.

title: Companies Speeding Beijing Exodus
description: More United States companies rushed to pull personnel out of Beijing yesterday as the Bush Administration urged all Americans to leave the embattled city.

title: Saudi Oil Find Reported
description: Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, has made a new oil find in the Khurais region southeast of the capital of Riyadh, oil industry executives said today. Officials at Saudi Aramco, reached by telephone from Bahrain, confirmed the report but refused to give details about its potential.

title: To the Spelling Victor Belong the Spoliators
description: In January, Scott Isaacs started studying 104 words a day, the number he could fit on a piece of computer paper. It paid off.

title: Wells-Gardner Finds Possible Heir Apparent
description: At Wells-Gardner, a small and well-established electronics company, Albert S. Wells Jr., the chairman and chief executive, has been having difficulty finding someone to take over when he retires.

title: Amid Frenzy, Iranians Bury The Ayatollah
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the revolutionary cleric who dominated Iran for a decade, was buried today after hours of frenzied mourning that at one point saw his body torn from its coffin and carried off by a hysterical crowd.

title: Regina-Electrolux
description: The Regina Company, the vacuum-cleaner maker, said it had signed a definitive agreement to be acquired by the Electrolux Corporation, an appliance maker. Electrolux said the total price for Regina, which is in Chapter 11 bankruptcy, is expected to be $65 million to $70 million.

title: Comparing Princeton '64 With '92
description: One oft-repeated defense when Junior or Jane is denied admission to Dad or Mom's alma mater is that if Dad or Mom were applying today, they probably wouldn't qualify either.

title: 57 REPORTED DEAD IN UZBEK VIOLENCE
description: At least 57 people were killed over the weekend in clashes in the Soviet republic of Uzbekistan, Soviet officials said today.

title: Bush and Bhutto Agree on Afghan Aid
description: President Bush and Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan agreed today that the United States would continue aiding the Afghan guerrilla movement while searching for a political settlement to end the conflict in Afghanistan.

title: For Ruling Mexico Party, a Stiff Test
description: A governor's race is in full swing here in the state of Baja California Norte, and in a sharp break with Mexican political tradition no one dares to predict the winner.

title: State Dept. Making Plans for Airlift of Americans
description: The State Department began making arrangements today for a charter airlift of Americans from Beijing should commercial flights be halted, while defense planners drew up contingency plans for a possible military evacuation.

title: Iran-Contra Deceptions Laid to Former Agent
description: A former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency who faces trial in the Iran-contra affair misled the Presidential investigative commission and agency investigators in 19 instances, Government prosecutors charge.

title: Book Notes
description: Timely Wright Portrait

title: 2 STUDIES CONFLICT ON AIRLINE FARES
description: A Congressional agency and an industry group have reached divergent conclusions in separate studies on the contentious issue of whether air fares rise abnormally at airports dominated by one or two airlines.

title: Computers That Read and Analyze
description: In the Chase Manhattan Bank's corporate finance department, a computer system is being installed to ''read'' wire service news reports, determine what each is about and alert people who may be interested in a particular item.

title: Moscow Steady Ahead
description: Despite the staggering news pouring in, the Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, Viktor Karpov, reflects a remarkable equanimity and steadiness in Moscow's view of the changing scene. Here to prepare for Mikhail Gorbachev's visit next month, he discussed negotiations on arms cuts, the aftermath of Poland's elections, turmoil in China and the future of Germany in an interview that showed no signs of policy diverted by events.

title: Rexene Is Blocked On Revamping
description: The Rexene Corporation said the plaintiffs in an employee class-action lawsuit against the chemical company had obtained a court order preventing it from pursuing a restructuring until after a hearing on June 15. A judge in Houston granted the temporary restraining order preventing the Rexene board from paying dividends under the plan or selling certain assets.

title: Turmoil in China; Eager Not to Offend, Soviet Congress Criticizes Outside Pressure on China
description: The Soviet Congress of People's Deputies today condemned outside efforts to bring pressure on China, saying that the upheavals in that country were purely an internal matter.

title: Fourth Man Is Convicted In Byrne Case
description: The last member of a four-man team accused of executing a rookie police officer in Queens was found guilty of murder yesterday just hours after two others already convicted in the killing were sentenced to 25 years to life in prison, the maximum possible term.

title: Whalers Retain Francis
description: Emile Francis, who served as both president and general manager of the Hartford Whalers from May 1983 until Ed Johnston was hired to succeed him as general manager early last month, will stay on with the Whalers as president, the club announced yesterday.

title: Soviet Response: A Fine Line
description: The Soviet Union condemned foreign sanctions against China, but urged Beijing to continue economic and political change. Page A10.

title: Amnesty for Namibians Reported
description: South Africa has agreed to grant full amnesty to about 40,000 Namibian exiles due to return home next month, the top United Nations official in the territory said today.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: AS summer approaches, we are welcomed with harvests of the best and freshest of vegetables. Dormant herbs reassert themselves in fragrant splendor. This is good news for the cook who uses a microwave oven, which quickly cooks these foods to perfection, preserving color, flavor and vitamins.

title: Agencies Watching Activities in China
description: Moody's and Standard & Poor's said yesterday that they were watching the current turmoil in China.

title: TW Services Gets New Bids
description: TW Services Inc. said today that it had received an unspecified number of bids for all or a part of the restaurant operator.

title: Group Celebrates a Decade Of Distributing Black Films
description: The Black Film Maker Foundation is celebrating a decade of putting the work of black film makers before American, European and African audiences.

title: Dozens of Atomic Warheads Lost In Sea by Superpowers, Study Says
description: Accidents involving American and Soviet ships, bombers and rockets have left at least 50 warheads and nine nuclear reactors scattered on the ocean floors since 1956, according to a comprehensive study of naval accidents that was released today.

title: 'Pill' Is Time's Best Defense
description: Time Inc.'s primary armor against the attack by Paramount Communications Inc. may well be its ''poison pill'' defense, intended to make the company so expensive that no one could afford it.

title: ARTILLERY FIRING IN SUBURBS ADDS TO TENSIONS IN BEIJING; MYSTERY ON LEADERS GROWS
description: Artillery fire reverberated through the capital Tuesday, and there were continued reports of clashes among rival military units.

title: CNW Accepts Buyout Bid From Blackstone Group
description: Capping a three-month attempt to avoid a hostile bidder, the CNW Corporation said today that it would become a private company in a leveraged buyout it valued at $1.6 billion.

title: A Macy Executive Is Elected To Head Columbia Trustees
description: Gertrude G. Michelson, a senior vice president of R.H. Macy & Company, was elected chairwoman of the Columbia University board of trustees on Monday, the university has announced.

title: Confusion Over Lien
description: North Sails of Milford, Conn., placed a lien Monday on Stars & Stripes, the 60-foot catamaran that defended the America's Cup in San Diego last September. The sailmaking firm has since withdrawn the lien, claiming that an agreement has been made with the boat's owners.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Science Watch in Science Times yesterday about a star that may be evolving into a black hole misstated the diameter of the sun. It is 864,000 miles, not 250,000 miles.

title: Europe Unemployment
description: The unemployment rate in the European Community fell to 9.3 percent in April, down one-tenth of a percentage point from the previous month, the European Community statistics agency said today.

title: Violence of Old Men vs. the Idealism of Youth
description: To the Editor:

title: Courter and Florio Win Primaries In New Jersey Race for Governor
description: Representative Jim Courter won a hard-fought race against three challengers to gain the Republican nomination for governor of New Jersey yesterday, as another Congressman, Representative James J. Florio, swept to an easy Democratic victory.

title: Paul Devlin, 86, Retired Investment Banker
description: Paul Devlin, a Wall Street investment banker for almost half a century, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Golf, Fla. He was 86 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y., for many years.

title: Friar Aide to Kentucky
description: Herb Sendek, an assistant basketball coach at Providence College since 1986, has been named assistant coach at the University of Kentucky.

title: About New York; The Line of Duty: Special Officers Help Their Own
description: ''Happy Birthday, Joe,'' read the cake's inscription. But Joe had been crossed out with different-colored frosting. The name ''Richie'' had been added.

title: Manischewitz Gets Takeover Bids
description: The B. Manischewitz Company, one of the best-known makers of kosher food and wine, said it had received two takeover offers higher than the $40 million bid by Levine, Tessler, Leichtman & Company. The 101-year-old Jersey City company signed a merger agreement on March 14 with Levine, Tessler, a Los Angeles investment firm. Manischewitz would have to pay a $1.7 million fee if the deal failed to go through.

title: Cardinals Get the Votes
description: Fans of the St. Louis Cardinals have been backing their heroes on the National League All-Star ballot, with four Cardinals, led by the shortstop Ozzie Smith, ahead in the early voting. Smith had 190,499 votes to lead all players in the balloting. The Mets' Darryl Strawberry was second with 136,121. Other Cardinals leading at their positions are the third baseman Terry Pendleton and the outfielders Vince Coleman and Tom Brunansky. (AP)

title: Ad Set in China Is Withdrawn
description: The escalating turmoil in China has prompted Kentucky Fried Chicken, one of the nation's largest advertisers, to drop a television advertisement filmed partly in Beijing. And the American Express

title: An Architect's Touch In Castles Made of Sand
description: A cold wind was blowing and an intermittent rain fell from the sort of dark gray sky that too often typifies San Francisco summers. But that did not deter members of the 15 architectural firms that gathered just after dawn on Sunday at the shore of Aquatic Park to build sand castles and sand sculptures.

title: The Case for Tracing AIDS Partners
description: The good news about AIDS is that useful treatments are at last becoming available. No cure is in sight, but it now seems that the drug pentamidine can avert the pneumonia that often kills those infected. That raises a vexed issue, which has sparked debate at the current AIDS conference in Montreal. How can those who don't know they are infected be reached with news of the new treatments?

title: Q&A
description: A Crack in a Ceiling

title: Educational Development reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
Firefighters Jeer an Angry Koch at Ceremony
description: Hundreds of New York City firefighters loudly booed Mayor Edward I. Koch and top leaders of the Fire Department yesterday at a ceremony to present medals to members of the department.

title: Turmoil in China; U.S. to Withhold U.N. Funds Over China Population Plan
description: The United States will withhold its annual contribution to the United Nations Population Fund because the fund subsidizes abortions in China, a State Department official said today.

title: Time's Staff Is Glum; Stock Price Is Salve
description: Walter Isaacson, a senior writer at Time magazine, sat at his computer terminal yesterday with a split image on his screen, tracking events in China on one side and following the financial news wires on the other for information about the $10.7 billion offer from Paramount Communications Inc. for Time Inc.

title: Brooklyn Teacher Arrested On Drug Charges in Inquiry
description: A Brooklyn high school teacher who came under investigation after he was reported to have ''nodded off'' in class was arrested on Tuesday by undercover officers who saw him buying drugs in Coney Island, the authorities said yesterday.

title: Irving Journal; Long March to Texas, And to Unemployment
description: It was with great fanfare that the Caltex Petroleum Company moved its headquarters from Manhattan's Madison Avenue to this Dallas suburb seven years ago. The company's 600 employees moved too, with generous help from Caltex, which helped with the selling of homes and the changing of children's schools. There were even company-subsidized driving courses so employees might cope in this land with no subways.

title: Review/Guitar; Flamenco Amid the Classic
description: Time was when flamenco guitarists and classic guitarists kept their distance from each other's repertories, and when flamenco players devoted themselves to virtuosic improvisations on traditional dance patterns, reinventing the literature with every performance.

title: National HMO reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
WASHINGTON TALK: Exact Words; Concerning the Advantages of Incumbency
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford, a onetime House Republican leader, in a speech at the National Press Club on June 5, 1989:

title: New Evidence of Mismanagement Found in Internal H.U.D. Report
description: Mismanagement and potential political abuses at the Department of Housing and Urban Development extend far beyond a Federal low-income housing program now under scrutiny by Congress and the Justice Department, an internal report shows.

title: Now Hear This: Navy Won't Invade Duluth
description: The Navy has canceled plans for a mock amphibious assault on a Duluth beach this summer because of protests by peace groups and others, who had threatened to meet the landing force on the beach with an army of protesters.

title: Curbs Voted For Hospitals In Connecticut
description: The General Assembly approved today an overhaul of Connecticut's hospital regulation system and gave the State Correction Department an emergency authorization to suspend competitive bidding for one year to allow urgently needed prison expansion.

title: New Candor Transfixes a Soviet City
description: Sergei Oinus looked up from the theoretical world of Lenin that he was feverishly inscribing in his final examination essay. He waxed less enthusiastic about the latest in realpolitik from Moscow.

title: Panama Transition Called Impossible Now
description: The Organization of American States has given a team of mediators six weeks to work out a democratic transition in Panama, but a top Panamanian official said no solution was possible as long as his country was ''permanently threatened'' by the United States.

title: Paramount's Appeal Is Similar to Warner's
description: Paramount and Warner, the two entertainment giants that would like to join forces with Time Inc., have more similarities than differences, many people in the entertainment industry say, adding that each would combine equally well with Time.

title: Staten Island Would Be Better Off Without Rest of New York City; Raise the Ferry Fare
description: To the Editor:

title:
Favorite Stocks chart;
Dow Jumps 16 on Takeover Action
description: LEAD: A takeover-rocked stock market moved higher yesterday, amid evidence that interest rates were declining and that the Federal Reserve had apparently decided to loosen its credit policy.

title: New Jersey's Gasoline Rule
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today gave New Jersey permission to put into effect new rules on the formulation of gasoline, in an effort to cut smog.

title: Frank McGrath, 89, Ex-Uniroyal Executive
description: Frank J. McGrath, a retired senior financial vice president and treasurer of Uniroyal Inc., died of spinal cancer on Tuesday at White Plains Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Novell Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
New Pennsylvania Bonds Have Top Yield of 6.85%
description: Pennsylvania priced $263 million of general obligation bonds yesterday through competitive bidding.

title: Bhutto Urges U.S. to Start Seeking Political Solution for Afghanistan
description: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan is urging the United States to try to persuade the Soviets to accept the departure of President Najibullah of Afghanistan, Pakistani officials said today.

title: Bertram Lichtenstein, Manufacturer, 70
description: Bertram Lichtenstein, a clothing manufacturer, died of cancer yesterday at Montefiore Medical Center. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Handleman Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Goodyear to Sell South African Operations
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, one of the largest American companies in South Africa, announced today that it was leaving the country after 42 years and selling its assets to a South African company.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-19

title: TURMOIL IN CHINA: Reporter's Notebook; Civil Warfare as a Spectator Sport
description: When the cacophony of submachine-gun fire broke out for a solid five minutes two blocks away from him, the old vendor turned his back, pushed his cart toward a small crowd, and went on selling his wares.

title: No U.S.-Pakistan Split Over Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Is Peace Bullish?
description: The insight that has illuminated my strategic landscape for the past few years - and has enabled faithful readers of this space to be first on their block to understand the desperation behind the Gorbachev peace offensive - has been ''Charlie & Harry's Thesis.''

title: Times to Get Fashion Award
description: The Fashion Institute of Technology has chosen The New York Times to receive its fifth annual industry award, which will be presented to Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher, at a fund-raising dinner next Wednesday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Marvin Feldman, president of the institute, will present the award.

title: Ethics Panel Says Cuomo 'Blurs' Roles
description: A state ethics commission yesterday criticized Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for ''blurring'' the distinction between his roles as Governor and fund-raising candidate.

title: Accord on Risk of Accidental U.S.-Soviet Conflict
description: American and Soviet military leaders plan to sign an agreement in Moscow on Monday to reduce the risk of inadvertent military confrontations throughout the world, American officials said today.

title: Andrew Jitkoff Dies; Financial Planner, 46
description: Andrew Jitkoff, an estate and financial planner, died of a heart attack Tuesday on an airplane en route to Tulsa, Okla. He was 46 years old and lived in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Edison Brothers Stores Inc reports earnings for 13wks April 29
description: Last year's first quarter ended April 23, 1988 and consisted of 16 weeks.

title: Belmont's Nagging Question; Why Will 8 Colts Challenge Sunday Silence and Easy Goer?
description: When Affirmed and Alydar hooked up for a dramatic Belmont Stakes showdown in 1978, only three other colts bothered to run against them. When Majestic Prince and Arts and Letters concluded their 1969 Triple Crown rivalry, only four others went into the starting gate.

title: House Passes FSX Curbs
description: The House today passed and sent to President Bush legislation aimed at imposing more restrictions on the $6 billion FSX fighter deal with Japan.

title: Gen. Wlodzimierz Oliwa, Polish Official, 64
description: Gen. Wlodzimierz Oliwa, Deputy Defense Minister, died Monday, the official news agency reported today. No cause of death was given. He was 64 years old.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. AD HOC COMMITTEE ON FOURTH DEVELOPMENT DECADE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council POPULATION AWARD CEREMONY - 5 P.M.

title: Justice Department to Oppose Eastern's Plan to Sell Gates
description: The Justice Department said today that the antitrust division would oppose the plan of Eastern Airlines to sell its assets in Philadelphia to USAir Group Inc. for $85 million.

title: Logicon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mentek Corp reports earnings for
description: b-Net loss

title: New York Won't Fight Ruling
description: New York will not appeal a Federal judge's ruling that overturned a state law prohibiting marriage by prison inmates serving life terms, Nancy Connell, a spokeswoman for State Attorney General Robert Abrams said today. Judge Neal McCurn of Federal District Court in Syracuse ruled last month that the New York law was arbitrary and irrational.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING

title: Child-Care Tax Defeated in California City
description: Voters here have soundly defeated a measure that would have made Fremont the first city in the nation to tax residents and businesses to pay for child care for all who seek it.

title: MENTAL DISORDERS MEASURED IN YOUNG
description: At least 7.5 million children, or 12 percent of the nation's population under 18, suffer from a mental disorder or emotional disturbance and few are getting treatment, the Institute of Medicine said today.

title: Goodman Nominated For U.S. Arts Council
description: President Bush has nominated State Senator Roy M. Goodman, Republican of Manhattan, for membership on the National Council on the Arts, the White House announced yesterday. The nomination must be approved by the United States Senate.

title: Explosive Fabricators reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
An Emblem Is Renewed
description: LEAD: If the rain ever stops so the restorers can get back to work, this small north Georgia town will soon boast a piece of historic Americana: the first wall sign advertising Coca-Cola, lovingly restored to its original 1894 condition.

title: Immunotherapeutics Inc reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: The company said the greater loss incurred in its fiscal year ended Jan. 31, was the result of the higer expenses connected to the company's increased research and development activities, including the hiring of additional staff and leasing additional space.

title: Software Patents Promote, Not Stifle, Creativity; Vital to Small Companies
description: To the Editor:

title: Northwest Teleproductions reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cunningham to Appear At Jean Erdman Benefit
description: Merce Cunningham is to be a featured guest in the opening night benefit performance by the Jean Erdman Theater of Dance, tonight at 8 at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, 221 East 71st Street.

title: Harnischfeger Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included tax benefits of $4,325,000 for the quarter and $7,625,000 for the 6 months. c-Included tax benefits of $2,975,000 and $5,025,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Iran Reports 11,000 Injured In Grieving for the Ayatollah
description: About 11,000 people were injured and many died in three days of grieving for Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Government said today.

title: Tunisia Choice on Mine
description: The Tunisian Government's Office of Mines said today that it had selected the West German company Metallgesellschaft A.G. to be its partner in developing a zinc mine in the northwestern part of the country. The mine, to be about 85 miles southwest of Tunis, has reserves of six million metric tons of ore containing 12 percent zinc and 3 percent lead, said Mohsen Zrelli, the head of the office.

title: Art, Wealth and Filial Duty Ensnarl Dispute Over de Kooning's Assets
description: A legal drama is quietly unfolding in a Long Island courthouse that will decide the fate of a vast and immensely valuable collection of Abstract Expressionist art assembled by one of the century's most prominent painters, Willem de Kooning.

title: LDI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a non-recurring gain of $1,450,000 from an accounting change.

title: MAI Basic-Prime
description: MAI Basic Four Inc. said it had filed a suit to force Prime Computer Inc. to hold its annual meeting on June 14, as previously scheduled. Prime said Tuesday that it would postpone its shareholders' meeting until July 26 to consider possible third party buyout offers or other alternatives for the company. Prime, based in Natick, Mass., has been trying to avoid a takeover attempt by MAI Basic Four, which has offered to pay $19.50 a share for the computer maker. MAI Basic said its financing and planning for its offer are based on a June 14 meeting date.

title: Trump Takes Control of The Shuttle
description: Donald J. Trump took control of the Eastern shuttle at 12:01 A.M. today and he immediately began to put his stamp on it.

title: Topics of The Times; False Flailing at Mr. Quayle
description: Dan Quayle has made so many quotable bloopers in his brief time as Vice President that he gets tagged even for things he didn't say. For instance, consider this howler: ''I was recently on a tour of Latin America, and the only regret I have was that I didn't study Latin harder in school so I could converse with those people.''

title: Reviews/Dance; From Africa, Festive Rites And a Fire-Eating Sorcerer
description: Chuck Davis extended greetings in several languages at the start of Dance Africa on Sunday afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. All were languages spoken in Africa, and his multi-lingual welcome, he explained, was a way of establishing ''a spirit of unity and peace.'' Mr. Davis is the artistic director of this festival, which is celebrating its 12th anniversary, and the program he assembled suggested the diversity of African culture.

title: Scientific Measurement reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Turmoil in China; ASIAN DIPLOMATS EXPRESS CONCERN
description: While expressing confidence that the unrest in China has passed its ''critical point,'' Thailand's Foreign Minister has expressed concern that the upheaval could delay a settlement of the war in Cambodia.

title: On Madison, Shops Fly the Tricolor
description: SEVENTEEN boutiques on 57th Street and up Madison Avenue as far as 75th Street were open after hours Tuesday for a mile-long cocktail party. Five thousand of their customers were invited by the Comite Colbert, an association of 70 French manufacturers of luxury goods.

title: A Place to Shelter Dreams
description: As a young architect, Witold Rybczynski, author of the recently published book ''The Most Beautiful House in the World,'' recalls terrorizing his first clients (as with many young architects, the first clients were none other than his mom and dad).

title: After Charisma in Iran
description: Television has rarely shown more astonishing sights than the crowds in Teheran literally ripping the shroud from Ayatollah Khomeini. It was a scene from the Age of Belief: mourners flagellating themselves and crushing one another as they grabbed at a helicopter bearing aloft the Imam's coffin. What may also have fed the crowd's awesome grief was awareness that the Ayatollah's authority was unique, that this was the last act of a drama expiring with its dominating character.

title: Review/Music; Robert Wilson Stages 'De Materie,' a New Opera
description: Every few years, Robert Wilson gathers himself together and undertakes some gigantic summary of his theatrical art - ''The Life and Times of Josef Stalin'' in 1973, ''Einstein on the Beach'' in 1976 and ''The Civil Wars'' of 1984.

title: Larry McMurtry To Head PEN Center
description: Larry McMurtry, the author of ''Lonesome Dove'' and 13 other novels, was elected president of the PEN American Center. The election, by the membership of the 2,300-member writers' organization, was announced last night at the organization's annual meeting in Manhattan.

title: Calendar: Festivals on Sea and Land
description: West Side Waterfront, Pier 45, Hudson River at 10th Street; 212-349-6460.

title: Parent & Child
description: J. DAVID HAWKINS remembers seeing a miniature milk bottle in a restaurant when he was 8 years old. He wanted it so much that he simply stole it from the table. He has been involved with crime and consorting with thieves ever since.

title: Turmoil in China; U.S. Says 200,000 Troops Are Near Chinese Capital
description: An Administration official estimated today that up to 200,000 troops of the Chinese People's Liberation Army are now in or around Beijing and that troop movement into the vicinity of the capital ''has apparently not yet ended.''

title: No Headline
description: There are grizzly bears in one corner of Thomas S. Foley's home district and huge grain silos in the other. In between the Selkirk Mountains and Walla Walla wheat farms is this city of Roman Catholic neighborhoods and generational loyalties as predictable as anything in the East.

title: Albany Weighs Expanding 'Shock' Jails
description: It has been a year and a half since the first prisoners in New York State's shock incarceration program got off the bus at a prison camp in Beaver Dams in Schuyler County dressed in state-issued fatigues, hair cropped to a quarter inch and prepared for six months of paramilitary drills and drug therapy.

title: Talking Deals; How Nintendo Can Help A.T.&T.
description: THERE is no signed contract yet, or even a handshake on a deal, but the American subsidiary of the Nintendo Company, the Japanese manufacturer of electronic games, and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company are in the midst of discussions that could lead to the creation of another interactive communications network in the United States.

title: Trust Certificates From Union Pacific
description: A $105.3 million issue of Union Pacific Railroad Company equipment trust certificates due 1999 is being offered through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets Inc.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a bid by Paramount Communications Inc. for Time Inc. gave an incorrect age in some editions for Martin S. Davis, chairman of Paramount. He is 61. A profile of Mr. Davis in Business Day referred incorrectly to the departure of David N. Judelson as president of Gulf and Western in 1983.

title: Paragon Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Staten Island Would Be Better Off Without Rest of New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: Phillips-Van Heusen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago quarter earnings exceeded by preferred dividend requirements.

title: Mail Boxes Etc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Chesnokov and Chang Reach Semifinals 971>
description: LEAD: Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, the world's 27th-ranked player, defeated Mats Wilander at the French Open today, beating the defending champion in a one-sided match, 6-4, 6-0, 7-5, to reach the semifinals.

title: Turmoil in China; Hong Kong Cancels Mourning Rallies
description: Plans for a series of rallies to mourn the victims of the Chinese crackdown were canceled here today after a violent confrontation between the police and a group described as provocateurs from the mainland.

title: Paramount Bid Lifts Time by $44
description: Time Inc. stock soared $44 yesterday, to a record $170 a share, as top executives of the communications giant met with advisers to consider how to fight off a $10.7 billion hostile takeover bid from Paramount Communications Inc.

title: Park Victim Goes to Connecticut
description: The 28-year-old investment banker who was beaten and raped in Central Park nearly two months ago was taken by ambulance yesterday to Gaylord Hospital, a medical rehabilitation center in Wallingford, Conn.

title: Arms Costs, Now and Then
description: The United States military budget of $299 billion for fiscal 1989, the current budget year, roughly equals, in constant dollars, military spending during the height of the Korean and Vietnam wars.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a trial over ownership of mosaics omitted attribution for a claim about the church in Cyprus from which they were taken. It was the buyer of the mosaics who said in court that the church was destroyed in 1974 fighting between Greek Cypriots and the Turkish Cypriots who occupied northern Cyprus. That is disputed by the Government and the Greek Orthodox Church of Cyprus, which seek the return of the mosaics.

title: Software Patents Promote, Not Stifle, Creativity
description: To the Editor:

title: Primary Victors In New Jersey Attack Quickly
description: The two Congressmen who won the Democratic and Republican nominations for governor Tuesday met with reporters today to sketch the differences between them and to outline what looks like a tough and potentially bitter contest for the state's highest office.

title: Transmation Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Books of The Times; An Emotional Roadblock in the Heart of 'Lust'
description: Lust and Other Stories By Susan Minot 147 pages. Houghton Mifflin/Seymour Lawrence. $16.95.

title: Volt Information Sciences reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: b-Included a loss of $1,113,000 and $1,403,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and an extraordinary gain of $170,000 for the quarter from the repurchase of the company's 12 3/8 subordinated debentures for both periods. c-Included a loss of $737,000 and $1,435,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6 months also included income of $5,355,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. d-Net income

title: Soviet Troops Unable to Halt Uzbekistan Clashes
description: Despite the presence of 12,000 troops, the killing continued today in the towns of eastern Uzbekistan, a ranking official of the Soviet Internal Affairs Ministry said.

title: Closing Arguments Made in Bilzerian Trial
description: Closing arguments were presented yesterday at the securities fraud trial of Paul A. Bilzerian, chairman of the Singer Company, with the Government painting Mr. Bilzerian as a man who pushed his way to the top by breaking the law and defense laywers asserting that he was a victim of overaggressive prosecution.

title: Close to Home; By Mary Cantwell
description: ''CAN you imagine what it's like to have a newspaper that gives you nothing but the local news?'' a woman who lives at what she considers the end of the earth asked me recently. Yes, I can imagine it, because whenever I visit my family I have the pleasure of reading one that does just that.

title: Anti-Bias Bill Is Killed in Albany
description: For the third year in a row, the Republicans who control the State Senate have rejected a bill that would increase the penalities for people convicted of committing ''bias related'' crimes.

title: Soviet Premier Says Cutbacks Could Reach 33% for Military
description: The Soviet Prime Minister said today that the Government intended to continue steadily cutting the military budget until at least 1995, slashing annual spending by up to one-third.

title: New OPEC Limits Meet Resistance
description: A contentious six-day meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended in disarray today after Kuwait refused to abide by the group's decision to raise only slightly the nation's production ceiling.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Shabuoth, the Feast of Weeks, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City tomorrow and Saturday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Mets Helped by Revamped Lineup
description: It was time, Davey Johnson reasoned, to do something illogical. Maybe something crazy. Something to energize the logical lineup that had been bashed for two days by the Chicago Cubs and outscored by 23 runs to 7 in old Wrigley Field.

title: Saudis Confirm A Big Oil Find
description: Saudi Aramco, Saudi Arabia's oil-producing company, today confirmed a large oil find that it said could yield 8,000 barrels a day of crude oil.

title: HEALTH: Obstetrics; Testing for Infections That Can Harm the Fetus
description: Until very recently, a pregnant woman who was possibly infected with certain viruses or parasites had to make an almost impossible choice.

title: Attacks on U.S. Homosexuals Held Alarmingly Widespread
description: Violence against gay men and lesbians continues to be ''alarmingly widespread,'' a national organization said yesterday in a report outlining more than 7,200 incidents of violence and verbal harassment against homosexuals around the country last year.

title: Fast Resolution Sought On New Schools Chief
description: The head of the committee searching for a new schools chancellor for New York City said yesterday that he hoped to give the Board of Education a list of one or more candidates by early fall.

title: Review/Recital; On Piano, With Energy
description: Hui-mei Lin, a pianist trained at the Hartt and Juilliard Schools of Music, played Mozart, Schubert, Ginastera, Jeremy Goldsmith and Ruth Schonthal with lively spirit Sunday afternoon in Weill Recital Hall.

title: D'Amato, His Village and Favoritism in Housing
description: Officials in this middle-class village rigged the distribution of federally subsidized houses in the early 1980's, selecting politically connected villagers and keeping out blacks, according to an audit by the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: From Anita O'Day, Hints of Many Hurdles
description: ''I'm not a singer; I'm a song stylist,'' Anita O'Day insisted. ''When I started out, I had no chops, just a lot of guts. It was Martha Raye who showed me what I wanted to do in life. I saw her in an early movie in which she sang and ad libbed. She was what they call a natural.''

title: 168 Aboard Airliner Killed in Crash in Suriname
description: A Suriname Airways jetliner en route from the Netherlands with 182 people aboard crashed today in a jungle area near the Paramaribo international airport, killing 168 people, the airline said.

title: Buick Seeks to Sponsor A 3d PGA Tour Event
description: Buick, which will take over the sponsorship of the PGA Tour's Westchester Classic next year and also conducts the midsummer Buick Open in Flint, Mich., is planning to gain sponsorship of a third event on the PGA Tour by 1992.

title: Money Fund Yields Down
description: Yields offered by money market mutual funds were down for the week that ended yesterday, reflecting a general easing of interest rates.

title: Fluor Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Currents; Would Greenstreet, Lorre And Bogie Approve?
description: NEW designs from the West Coast are changing the look of the old-fashioned ceiling fan.

title: Review/Music; 'Babes in Arms,' With Score but No Show
description: With its frivolous story about how the teen-age children of unemployed vaudevillians put on a revue in order to avoid going to a work farm, Rodgers and Hart's ''Babes in Arms'' is hardly the most dramatic or sophisticated 1930's musical. But with a score that includes five Rodgers and Hart gems - ''Where or When,'' ''I Wish I Were in Love Again,'' ''My Funny Valentine,'' ''Johnny One Note'' and ''The Lady Is a Tramp'' - the show still stands as one of the most musically enticing in Broadway history.

title: Irises to Be Cherished for More Than Flowers
description: WHEN I was a boy, my life as a gardener began the day I fell in love with bearded irises, so I wouldn't dream of disparaging these highly colorful plants of late spring. On a bright morning, they look like little thunderheads in almost every color of the spectrum except true red.

title: Sears to Open Departments
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said Tuesday that it would open 164 Brand Central home electronics and appliance departments within existing stores by July.

title: Gretzky Is M.V.P. For Ninth Time
description: Wayne Gretzky of the Los Angeles Kings was named the National Hockey League's most valuable player last night, winning the Hart Trophy for a record ninth time. Brian Leetch of the Rangers won the Calder Trophy as the rookie of the year.

title: National Security Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Scarborough Picked For a New Program
description: Chuck Scarborough, an evening news anchor at Channel 4, will be a co-anchor with Maria Shriver and Mary Alice Williams of ''Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow,'' a prime-time news program that NBC News hopes to put on the schedule in January. The program, NBC News's latest venture into prime-time, is scheduled to have a three-week tryout in August.

title: Paramount Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included earnings of $70.9 million and $128.4 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included earnings of $53.1 million and $102.1 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Revenue figures are exclusive of financial services. On April 9, 1989, the company announced its intention to sell Associates First Capital Corp., its consumer/commercial finance business. Accordingly, the results of these operations have been classified as discontinued operations for all periods presented. Paramount Communications was formerly Gulf & Western.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Smitty Carried A Big Stick
description: Now that Billy Smith has retired, it can be revealed that the stick-swinging goaltender was not some mad-dog chopper, as people in Philadelphia and Edmonton believed, but rather a nonviolent devotee of Eastern ritual.

title: Longtime Criminal Guilty of 3 Murders
description: A 63-year-old career criminal was convicted yesterday of executing three people in a liquor-store holdup, a crime for which another man with a long record had been jailed for a year and a half.

title: Creditors Act Against Utility
description: Three creditor banks have filed a petition to force the financially troubled Colorado-Ute Electric Association into involuntary Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization, a unusual situation for a utility. The Manufacturers Hanover

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''It went too far. It was wrong.

title: Advantage Cos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $57,000 loss from discontinued operations. c-Net income and included $81,000 income from discontinued operations and a $138,000 tax credit.

title: Mets Sign Draftee
description: Tom Engle, a pitcher for Lancaster (Ohio) Fairfield Union High School, who was the second selection of the Mets in Monday's free agent draft, has signed a contract with the team. Engle, a right-hander who was drafted in the third round, pitched six no-hitters as a senior. He is expected to report to the Mets' farm club in Kingsport, Tenn., on Monday. (AP)

title: Turmoil in China; After Decades of Restraint, Japan Criticizes China
description: Japan today ended four decades of unwillingness to criticize the Chinese Government publicly, declaring that the shooting of civilians on Beijing's streets ''could not be tolerated.''

title: Public Relations to Play Key Role in Negotiations
description: The man who gives you Donald Trump in the newspapers and on television as often as he can will play a role in the coming negotiations between the owners and the players for a new labor agreement. In fact, he is already playing a role.

title: Canon Agreement Expected for Next
description: Next Inc., the Palo Alto, Calif., computer company headed by Steven P. Jobs, the co-founder of Apple Computer Inc., will distribute its computer work station in Japan through Canon Inc., industry officials said. The agreement, which would mark Next's first move to sell outside the United States, had been rumored since earlier this week, when Next scheduled a press tour of its Fremont, Calif. manufacturing operation for next Monday.

title: Murdoch in Magazine Deal
description: News America Publishing Inc., a subsidiary of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, said yesterday that it planned to acquire Soap Opera Digest magazine from the Network Publishing Corporation.

title: The Return of a Native: The Front Porch
description: THE porch was the apron of the house - the outdoors domesticated, the indoors given a breath of fresh air. Tack a porch onto a wooden facade and you bridged private and public space and allied welcome and retreat. The porch cosseted babies in arms and lovers on swings, Andy Hardy on its stoop and grandparents in the rocking chair. The porch was the ultimate transitional space, connecting the individual home and the communal street.

title: Inside a Loft, A Cozy Cottage Nestles
description: IT took Judy Pfaff, a New York-based artist, 13 years to get around to concentrating on putting her house together. But last year, when she finally did, she built her dream house, or at least a small version of it.

title: Bridge
description: The biggest sporting event in the world, in terms of official participation, is the Epson Worldwide Bridge Contest. The fourth Epson, scheduled for tomorrow evening, is expected to break the records set last year, when 84,352 contestants in 94 countries took part.

title: Merry-Go-Round Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: Per share figures reflected a 5 percent stock dividend paid in May.

title: Citibank Sued By Warner
description: In an attempt to upset Paramount Communications Inc.'s competing deal for Time Inc., Warner Communications Inc. sued Citibank, Paramount's lead bank, in New York State Supreme Court yesterday.

title: Arab Suspected of Aiding Israelis Is Hacked to Death in West Bank
description: A 30-year-old Palestinian was beaten and hacked to death today, his body left hanging by chains from a telephone pole in the West Bank city of Hebron. Residents said he was killed by Arabs who suspected him of collaborating with Israeli security forces.

title: Nuggets Chief in Doubt
description: Pete Babcock, the president of the Denver Nuggets, said yesterday he did not know if the National Basketball Association would penalize him for revealing which player the Nuggets will expose in the expansion draft to be held after the end of the league's championship series.

title: Dollar Up in Seesaw Trading Despite Fed Move on Rates
description: The dollar inched up yesterday in seesaw trading, even though the Federal Reserve Board signaled on Tuesday that it was easing interest rates.

title: Review/Rock; Elvis Presley as He Was, Sort Of
description: ''Elvis: A Rocking Remembrance'' has been touring the United States, purportedly headed for Broadway; it has landed in New York City 30 blocks north of Times Square. It's not a rock concert, not a staged biography and not a Broadway musical. The show, scheduled to run through June at the Beacon Theater (2124 Broadway, at 74th Street), is just what you'd expect when the ''media designer'' and director-and-lighting designer of ''Beatlemania'' got the rights to Elvis Presley's music: a high-tech nostalgia trip carried by dozens of well-loved songs.

title: Rentrak Corp reports earnings for
description: Fiscal 1989 loss included a gain of $891,366 from the sale of discontinued operations and a loss of $202,964 from discontinued operations.

title: Stake in Amdura
description: A group that includes Cilluffo Associates L.P. raised its holdings in the Amdura Corporation to 16.4 percent of the heavy equipment manufacturer's common stock outstanding. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the group said it had bought 68,900 additional common shares for between $13.25 and $13.375 a share. Amdura shares rose 62.5 cents today, to $14, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Lin Shares Soar $26; Higher Bid Anticipated
description: Shares in the Lin Broadcasting Corporation soared $26 today, to $129.50, with more than 3.2 million shares trading as investors bet that someone would top the $120-a-share, $6.5 billion bid announced yesterday by McCaw Cellular Communications Inc.

title: General Cinema Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,840,000 and $10,796,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $855,139,000 from the sale of the company's soft drink bottling business for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $14,899,000 for the quarter and $23,226,000 for the 6 months, and a gain of $4,855,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations for both the quarter and 6 months. Results have been restated to reflect the soft drink bottling business as a discontinued operation.

title: Is Poland Ready For Open Politics?
description: The Poles used to divide their country into two simple categories:

title: Super Food Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 6
Arnold Fein, Ex-New York Judge And Reform Democrat, Dies at 79
description: Arnold L. Fein, a retired associate justice of the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court and a former leader in the reform movement of the Democratic Party in Manhattan, died of cardiopulmonary arrest and complications of pneumonia Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Matthew Gormley, 86, A Former Brick Maker
description: Matthew J. Gormley, a former brick manufacturer, died May 25 at his son's home in Garnerville, N.Y. He was 86 years old and lived in Haverstraw, N.Y.

title: Director Held Time Stock
description: Paramount Communications Inc. disclosed today that one of its directors, James A. Pattison, a Canadian businessman, had made a profit of $21,848 in transactions involving Time Inc. common stock in April.

title: New, Faster Chip Created by Bipolar
description: A small Oregon semiconductor company introduced an extremely fast version of the Sparc microprocessor designed by Sun Microsystems Inc. The new chip, made by Bipolar Integrated Technology of Beaverton, Ore., can run at up to 65 million instructions a second, at least three times faster than versions of the Sparc microprocessor now on the market.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amax Gold Inc., Golden, Colo., a mineral exploration company, appointed Marvin K. Kaiser chief financial officer.

title: The Slime-Slinger
description: America has had its peddlers of political hate, its Father Coughlin and its Joe McCarthy. But I do not know that we have ever had a major party chairman who raises viciousness and cowardice to as professional a level as does Lee Atwater of the Republican National Committee.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Battle for Time Inc.

title: Programming & Systems reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
Prices of U.S. Issues Rise Again
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose again yesterday, aided by falling oil prices, a strong dollar and increased demand from foreign and domestic investors.

title: Cherne Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and after a $1,025,000 gain from the settlement of a patent- infringement lawsuit.

title: Douglas Ensminger, 79, a Sociologist, Dies
description: Douglas Ensminger, a sociologist who directed programs for the Ford Foundation in Nepal, India and Pakistan for nearly two decades, died of acute respiratory distress syndrome on May 25 at the University of Missouri Hospital in Columbia, Mo. He was 79 years old and lived in Columbia.

title: Poland Grim As It Awaits Next Chapter
description: As in most of Poland, there was little jubilation today under the granite arcades of the dreary former cafe where Solidarity posts the latest unofficial returns testifying to its success in Sunday's national elections. The mood is conditioned by the memory of the union's brief heyday at the start of the decade.

title: Bianchi Is on Search
description: Al Bianchi was in Chicago yesterday, along with other general managers and pro scouts from every National Basketball Association team, to evaluate the talent at the opening of the four-day pre-draft camp at the University of Illinois at Chicago Circle. It is the final camp before the June 27 draft and it lacked the big-name college players who are expected to be first-round choices.

title: TW Agrees To Buyout By Coniston
description: LEAD: A battle for the parent company of more than 1,600 Denny's and Hardee's restaurants ended yesterday when TW Services Inc. agreed to be acquired by Coniston Partners L.P. for $34 a share, or $1.7 billion.

title: Strike Grounds Qantas
description: The Australian airline Qantas canceled all flights today because of an engineers' strike. The international carrier said in a statement that it was trying to transfer the 10,000 passengers affected to other airlines but that it would not be possible to accommodate all of them. Five hundred engineers who check maintenance work on planes and certify them for flying began the stoppage on Monday in a pay dispute.

title: IFL Investment Foundation Canada Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Rostenkowski May Reverse Stand And Back Capital-Gains Tax Cut
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that he might reverse himself and consider a reduction in the capital-gains tax rate. President Bush contends that such a step would enhance economic growth and bring in more revenues without raising taxes.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Theme: The Older Feel Younger
description: ''WHEN I look in the mirror, I see a 45-year-old Jerry Hotchkiss,'' said 58-year-old Gerald G. Hotchkiss, publisher of New Choices for the Best Years, formerly named 50 Plus.

title: No U.S.-Pakistan Split Over Afghanistan; Don't Make Informers
description: To the Editor:

title: Henry Hansburg, 79, Psychologist, Is Dead
description: Henry G. Hansburg, a psychologist and author, died of lymphoma Friday at Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 79 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Lakers Trying to Regroup After First Loss in Playoffs
description: Pat Riley's eyes looked tired from a short night's sleep. Byron Scott was limping and carrying an electronic stimulator attached to his partially torn left hamstring. And for the first time since April, the Los Angeles Lakers had to explain why they had lost a game.

title: Any Way You Slice It, Big Pie for Sunday Silence
description: If you had a nickel for every time Sunday Silence has been inaccurately described as eligible for a $5 million Triple Crown bonus, you would be almost as rich as he will be if he wins the Belmont Stakes on Saturday.

title: Cecil Collins, Painter, 81
description: Cecil Collins, an English artist who painted in the mystical, romantic tradition of William Blake, died Sunday. He was 81 years old.

title: OPEC Plan to Raise Output Sends Oil Prices Plunging
description: Oil prices tumbled yesterday after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced it would raise its output by a million barrels a day, to 19.5 million, through the end of the year.

title: Topics of The Times; 123456789
description: A poker straight is a hand of five consecutive numbers. Yesterday, the clock and calendar brought a date straight. The day started as a four-digit run, 6/7/89. Then people realized what would arrive at 23 minutes and 45 seconds after 1: a moment that could accurately be rendered as 1:23:45/6/7/89.

title: Reviews/Music; Songs by Janis Siegel
description: Janis Siegel of Manhattan Transfer is about as eclectic in her musical tastes as a pop singer can get. In exploring several decades of pop, jazz and rhythm-and-blues songs both with the group and on three solo albums, she has shown an especially sharp eye for sophisticated high-quality pop-jazz songs by writers like Dave Frishberg.

title: Age-60 Rule for Pilots Is, Alas, Best We Have
description: To the Editor:

title: Borough Chief And Critics Split On the Charter
description: The commission revising the New York City Charter once again heard two distinctly different views yesterday of the value of borough presidents.

title: Wilfred American Educational reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Magnetech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company said it completed its initial public offering last month and also said that for the period from its inception on Nov. 12, 1987 to March 31, 1988, it had a net loss of $14,661 on sales of $93,271.

title: Voters, in a First, Shut Down Nuclear Reactor
description: Residents of Sacramento, Calif., voted Tuesday to shut down their utility's only nuclear power plant, the first time voters have decided to close a working reactor.

title: In Honor of the Rose, A Host of Celebrations
description: This weekend offers flower lovers, and especially rose fanciers, an opportunity to enjoy the scents and sights of thousands of plants.

title: The Capital
description: The Queen Mother went to Bayeux on Tuesday to celebrate the 45th anniversary of Operation Overlord, the Allied invasion of Normandy, which marked the beginning of the end of World War II.

title: Personal Health
description: What are little boys made of? My own sons have survived for 19 years on a relatively boring diet that few adults would consider ideal. Nonetheless, they seem to have thrived on it. Their narrow array of foods featured pasta with tomato sauce and Parmesan cheese and ready-to-eat cereals sweetened with raisins and moistened with skim milk, with an occasional dose of broccoli, carrots, peanut butter, chicken legs, sardines, fish fillets and cheese, all washed down with fruit juices and chocolate milk.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Business People column of Business Day on Monday about changes at the American Express Company misidentified the new president and chief executive of American Express International. He is G. Richard Thoman. The article also misstated the responsibilities of Edwin M. Cooperman. He is president of Travel Related Services North America and a member of a new Office of the Presidents of the American Express Travel Related Services Company. The office is headed by Aldo Papone and includes Mr. Thoman and Jonathan S. Linen, president of the TRS direct marketing and traveler's checks operations, along with Mr. Cooperman.

title: Currents; Cloudland Revisited: The Palaces
description: JOHN EBERSON (1875-1954), a Chicago architect, was the prolific designer of scores of the movie palaces that sprang up in the 20's in American cities from Springfield, Mass., to Gary, Ind., to San Antonio.

title: At the Soviet Inferno: 'Such Suffering'
description: Tatyana Prokhorov stumbled up to a twisted, burned-out train wagon that lay on its side in a ravine here, her entire body heaving with sobs.

title: Cold Year Ends for Valenzuela In Atlanta
description: Fernando Valenzuela won for the first time in nearly a year, ending his eight-game losing streak tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers beat the Atlanta Braves, 5-4.

title: Morrison Knudsen Stake Cut by Heil
description: Edward F. Heil, an Illinois businessman, has lowered his stake in the Morrison Knudsen Corporation to 2.6 percent from 6.3 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Heil, the president of the American Environmental Construction Company, gave no reason for the sale.

title: CPI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $2,246,000 and $384,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: Marcos Undergoes Surgery; His Condition Is Still Critical
description: Surgery has eased abdominal pain and a persistent fever plaguing Ferdinand E. Marcos, but the ousted Philippine President remained in very critical condition on Wednesday, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Home Improvement
description: A ceiling fan, also called a paddle fan, can contribute greatly to comfort and energy efficiency year round. In summer, although a fan will not reduce the air temperature, it produces air currents that cool the skin. Even in an air-conditioned room, the air will feel cooler with a fan. This allows you to set the thermostat controlling the air-conditioner higher and save on energy costs.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Coach Leatherware Co., to Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners, with an undisclosed budget.

title: Rostenkowski Seeking ESOP-Loan Benefit Cut
description: Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, introduced legislation yesterday to repeal the preferential tax treatment for loans granted to employee stock ownership plans.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: KFW International Finance Inc., a Delaware-based American subsidiary of Kreditanstalt fur Wiederaufbau of West Germany, is offering $200 million of 8.85 percent guaranteed notes due 1999 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Pope Sees a 'New and Better Era' on the Way
description: In a hopeful assessment of the current state of the world, Pope John Paul II said today that growing awareness of worldwide interdependence was creating the conditions for birth of ''a new and better era.''

title: Savings-Unit Withdrawals Are Smaller
description: Depositors withdrew billions of dollars from the nation's savings and loan associations in April, the Government reported today, but at a considerably slower rate than earlier this year.

title: Trash Haulers Face Racketeering Charge
description: In an effort to drive organized crime from the trash hauling industry, Federal officials yesterday charged 112 defendants, including reputed members of the Gambino and Lucchese organized-crime groups, a Long Island carting trade association and 44 Long Island carting companies with racketeering.

title: Datavision reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
JDS Investments reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: The company said in both the latest and prior years ended Feb. 28, preferred-share dividend payments exceeded net income. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Victims Seem to Accept News of Genetic Defect
description: Men and women who have the genetic defect that leads to Huntington's disease react surprisingly well to the grim news that they will almost certainly develop the brain disorder, new research has found.

title: Defendant in the Palme Case Testifies He Is an Alcoholic
description: The man on trial for the 1986 murder of Olof Palme said today that he had admired the Swedish Prime Minister so much that he once stole a picture of him and wrote a poem in a condolence book after his assassination.

title: Mexico Aid Package Spurs Talk With Banks
description: A $5.5 billion aid package will be provided to Mexico by the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund and Japanese banks.

title: 2 Sentenced In Fraud Case
description: A Federal judge today imposed sentences in halfway houses on two vice presidents of Teledyne Electronics who were convicted in the Pentagon corruption investigation. He said the trial had revealed practices that let consultants ''live a parasitic life.'' In passing sentence on

title: Reviews/Music; Via Muzak and Shea, a Pianist Like Neither
description: In the nine years since Jane Jarvis gave up an unlikely pairing of two careers - 18 years with Muzak producing piped-in music programs for supermarkets and elevators and 16 of those same years as organist for the New York Mets at Shea Stadium -she has not only established herself in a new career as a jazz pianist but has also built a special relationship with the two bassists who usually work with her in New York, Milt Hinton and Major Holley.

title: Arms Plant Accused of Environmental Violations
description: The Colorado Department of Health today accused the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant of 25 environmental violations, one day after Federal agents seized records at the plant and began a criminal investigation of similar allegations.

title: 12 Winners to Receive Governor's Arts Awards
description: Twelve winners of this year's New York State Governor's Arts Awards will receive sculptures tonight at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with Governor Mario M. Cuomo and his wife, Matilda Cuomo, as hosts.

title: PRESIDENT REBUKES KEY ELECTION AIDE FOR FOLEY ATTACK
description: President Bush today rebuked one of the primary architects of his 1988 election triumph as the White House sought to blunt outrage in both parties over a Republican National Committee attack on the new House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley.

title: Stick to the High Road in New Jersey
description: Voters in New Jersey decided Tuesday to let Jim do it. They nominated Representatives James Courter, a Republican, and James Florio, a Democrat, to run for governor in November to succeed the popular two-term incumbent, Thomas Kean.

title: Oppenheimer Capital reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Fiscal 1988 figures are not comparable because the limited partnership began operations on July 9, 1987.

title: Turmoil in China; Service at the U.N. Pays Tribute to Victims
description: About 300 Chinese employees of the United Nations held an emotional memorial gathering today to pay tribute to the hundreds of demonstrators killed in Beijing in recent days.

title: Attack on H.U.D. Widens
description: Mismanagement at the department extends beyond a low-income houseing program now under investigation, a report says. Page B9.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Dravo Corp., Pittsburgh, a natural resources company, said it had sold its Round Rock division to Texas Lime Co., a unit of Rangaire Corp. Terms were not disclosed.

title: FOREBODING GRASPS BEIJING; ARMY UNITS CRISSCROSS CITY; FOREIGNERS HURRY TO LEAVE
description: As reports of clashes between military units on the outskirts of Beijing continued, a major convoy of tanks and trucks returned to the capital early today, dashing hopes that the unit responsible for large-scale killing might be withdrawing.

title: New Slogan Says Dinkins Is Strong (Not Too Strong)
description: Never mind what you've heard about David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President and a Democratic candidate for mayor.

title: Telos Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting change of $800,000. c-Included $89,000 income from discontinued operations. The company also said it has restated its results for the third quarter ended Dec. 31. It said earnings were revised to $346,000, or 9 cents, compared to the previously reported $681,000, or 18 cents. Revenue was restated as $28,003,000, compared to $28,561,000 as previously reported. The company said that restatement was due to the reversal of certain sales inadvertently accrued in its field engineering division in that quarter.

title: Planners Act to Save Low-Density Areas
description: The New York City Planning Commission unanimously approved broad new zoning rules yesterday that are meant to preserve the character of lower-density neighborhoods in Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx and on Staten Island.

title: War Memory Stirring Hope In Old Britons
description: Tom Freer listened to the declaration of war, the bombs exploding in a city under siege and the mellow, 1940's harmony in ''On a Slow Boat to China.'' Mr. Freer then began dusting off some memories.

title: What Colleges Really Teach
description: LEAD: In heated discussions about what students do and don't learn in school, people mistakenly restrict their attention to the curriculum. This emphasis is far too narrow. Much of what is learned has less to do with the intellectual training touted by academia than with the unadvertised skills (often snobbishly undervalued by professors) that are learned during that training.

title: Bonneville Pacific Corp reports earnings for Year to April 30
Japonica Reduces CNW Stake to 3%
description: Japonica Partners L.P. said it had lowered its stake in the CNW Corporation to 3 percent from 8.8 percent at an estimated profit of $15.7 million. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Japonica said it had sold 943,500 CNW shares on Tuesday for $47.50 a share.

title: Royal Gold reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Iowa Starts New Tour
description: Seven weeks after an explosion in a gun turret killed 47 crewmen, the battleship Iowa left the Norfolk Naval Station today for a six-month tour in the Mediterranean Sea. The damaged No. 2 turret has been cleaned and painted, but the 16-inch guns in that turret and the ship's other two turrets will not be fired until the Navy completes its investigation of the explosion, said Lieut. Comdr. Brad Goforth.

title: KEY RATES
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a ban on ivory imports by the United States omitted the full name and affiliation of a conservationist who praised the action.

title: Consumer Borrowing Pace Eases
description: Americans took out $2.73 billion more in consumer debt than they retired in April, a sharp slowing of the borrowing pace of earlier months, the Government reported today.

title: Market Place; In the Time Inc. Game, Warner Head Has Aces
description: Steven J. Ross, his own dreams of taking control of Time Inc. perhaps shattered, now holds the trump card in deciding who will be able to buy Time, and on what terms.

title: CAMBRIDGE MOVES ON ANIMAL RIGHTS
description: The Cambridge City Council has voted to appoint a commissioner to supervise all experiments conducted on animals at laboratories in the city.

title: Random House to Buy British Book Publisher
description: In a move that will nearly triple the size of its holdings in Britain, Random House announced yesterday that it would acquire Century Hutchinson Ltd., a prominent London-based publisher of fiction and nonfiction. The acquisition will also expand Random House's presence in Australia and New Zealand.

title: INSIDE
description: Elderly Win Insurance Vote

title: 1992 Lures U.S. Lobbyists to Brussels
description: There are many similarities between Washington and Brussels. They have about the same population, similarly hospitable living conditions - and, now, the same lobbyists.

title: Honco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Isco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Arpil 28
Short Brothers Is Up for Sale
description: The British Government said today that it would sell Short Brothers Ltd., the ailing Belfast aircraft and missile maker, to Bombardier Inc., the Canadian aerospace company, for $:30 million, about $47 million.

title: First Team Sports reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
For Air Industry, a Divided Outlook
description: As more than 100,000 aerospace executives converge in Paris for the opening on Thursday of their annual air show, the industry finds itself split.

title: Review/Dance; 1,000 Schoolchildren Storm the Bastille
description: The Bastille was stormed Monday night when the National Dance Institute presented ''Meilleurs Amis'' (''Best of Friends'') at the Felt Forum. It was the 13th annual event of the institute, which was founded by Jacques d'Amboise, a former principal dancer of the New York City Ballet, to provide dance classes for schoolchildren from New York City and New Jersey.

title: Ernest W. Saward, 74, A Health Plan Expert
description: Dr. Ernest W. Saward, who was instrumental in establishing prepaid health insurance plans in Portland, Ore., Denver, Cleveland and Rochester, died Tuesday at his home in San Jose, Calif. He was 74 years old.

title: President to Be on TV In News Conference
description: President Bush will hold his first prime-time televised news conference Thursday and will probably break with tradition by answering questions for more than half an hour, his spokesman said today.

title: Barneys to Open California Store
description: Barneys New York will open its first store outside Manhattan with a 100,000 square-foot store in Beverly Hills, Calif., one block west of Rodeo Drive, the Pressman family, owners of Barneys, said. The apparel and gift specialty store will open in 1993 and have projected first-year sales of about $40 million, the family said.

title: Bowne & Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
2 Soviet Defectors to Alaska Are Given Asylum
description: They were audacious, the two Soviet students who faked a letter from a Moscow publication to join a friendship mission to Alaska and then defect in April. Now they have been granted political asylum in the United States.

title: In Brazil, Family Fights To Destroy Its Mansion
description: FOR decades, the neoclassical mansion on Avenida Paulista here symbolized the grandeur of the Matarazzos, an enterprising family of industrialists of Italian heritage. Designed by one of Mussolini's architects and situated on Brazil's best business address, the landmark displayed the family crest to generations of passing ''paulistanos,'' Sao Paulo natives. Recently, though, the Matarazzos have taken a less sentimental view of the family inheritance, the most coveted property on the avenue. With hopes of selling this, the most expensive urban land in the nation, they have tried to demolish their grand birthright with bulldozers, pickaxes and dynamite.

title: Drink Games Said to Pose Stroke Risk
description: Young adults have suffered strokes from simple tasks like brushing teeth or tossing back a drink that can cause seemingly minor traumas to one of the four main arteries supplying blood to the brain, doctors report.

title: 2 Major Appointments Made by R. P. Scherer
