description: The R. P. Scherer Corporation, a maker of drug capsules, has named John Cashman as acting chairman and Aleksandar Erdeljan as acting president.

title: AMR Joins Perot Project
description: American Airlines said today that it would spend $400 million to build maintenance and engineering operations at a new airport and industrial park being developed by the family of H. Ross Perot, the Texas entrepreneur.

title: Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Cliburn Finalists: Virtuosos of Toughness
description: It has been said that the purpose of music competitions is to identify performers first, musicians second. Decisions made early this morning by the 14 jurors of the Van Cliburn International Competition tend to confirm the thought. The list of finalists reads as follows: Aleksandr Shtarkman, Eliso Bolkvadze and Aleksei Sultanov of the Soviet Union, Ying Tian, a Chinese now living in Boston, Jose Cocarelli of Brazil and Benedetto Lupo of Italy.

title: Egypt and Libya Begin a Reconciliation
description: Egypt has embarked on an unexpectedly rapid reconciliation with Libya, a move mistrusted by some Egyptians who recall a decade of enmity and hostile propaganda between Cairo and the regime of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Denpasar Journal; A Funeral Without Tears (the Tourists Love It!)
description: By all accounts, Anak Agung Ayr Putu Rai, who died at 71, had a good life, but the liberation of her soul for its passage from this existence into the next one, accomplished at a cremation before a jostling crowd of 1,000 people, was still quite a send-off.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * S. Murray Gaylord has been appointed executive vice president and director of account services at the New York office of TBWA.

title: U.S. Gives Japan a Date To Settle a Trade Issue
description: The United States has given Japan until July 10 to resolve a dispute over limits on American access to its $9 billion-a-year telecommunications market, if it is to avoid retaliation.

title: Where to Find It; Vintage Phones Made New Again
description: THERE, sitting among telephones shaped like petulant pink lips and brook trout and football helmets are the oldies: those heavy, black rotary-dial phones out of 1940's movies. All are for sale at the Phone Boutique in Manhattan. And for people who have just bought an antique phone at a flea market or found one in the attic, the shop specializes in fixing the dinosaurs of the communications age.

title: Flow International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $40,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $5,493,000 for the year. c-Net loss Sales represents combined sales. The company acquired Admac Inc. in February and changed its name from Flow Systems Inc. to Flow International Corp.

title: 'Prime Time' Is Running Out of Time
description: His feet are barely wet, but by the time the weekend passes, it is likely that Prime Time will be out of time. Deion Sanders will have tasted the big leagues and the big city and will be on his way back to the minors, probably Columbus. The memories won't all be good, but he'll keep them close by.

title: McDermott International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $4,182,000 and $29,322,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also included a gain from an accounting change of $52,580,000. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $260,000 for the quarter, a loss from discontinued operations of $34,698,000 for the year, and an extraordinary credit of $4,276,000 for both periods.

title: Wiltex Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
METRO DATELINES;
description: An 11-year-old boy who was paralyzed from the neck down when he fell from a sculpture at a city playground was awarded more than $33 million yesterday by a Manhattan jury.

title: Comair Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Budd Officer Named Chairman and Chief
description: LEAD: The Budd Company, an auto-parts concern based in Troy, Mich., yesterday named Siegfried Buschmann as its chairman and chief executive, succeeding James H. McNeal Jr., who plans to retire at age 62.

title: Panel Opposes Drug to End Lactation
description: A Food and Drug Administration advisory group has recommended that the agency withdraw approval for the use of drugs and hormones to suppress painful breast engorgement in non-nursing mothers after childbirth.

title: CML Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Hallwood Group reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income The company said its latest third- qiarter results reflect the write-off of its $11.5 million investment in Alliance Bancorporation. The company also said the quarter included revenue of $6.7 million from its new subsidiary, Brookwood Cos., acquired in mid-March.

title: Students in Shanghai Wage War of Buses With Officials
description: First there are several disabled buses blocking the road to traffic and then, at the entrance to Fudan University, whose students put up the barricade, there are the signs of rebellion.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Tuesday showing sites of major developments in Beijing misidentified one of two military groups reported to have clashed at an airfield south of the city. The clash was said to involve units of the 27th Army, not the 17th. A military analysis article on Tuesday misidentified the home base of the 27th Army. It is normally based at Shijiazhuang, southwest of Beijing, not in Inner Mongolia.

title: Currents; A Perfect Setting For Parked Cars
description: ''HE wanted a garage, not the Baths of Caracalla or a temple or some postmodern thing,'' said Stanley Tigerman.

title: Currents; For Artists Of All Ages
description: PARENTS whose children bring artwork home from school no longer have to tape the masterpieces to walls and refrigerators. Berdie Stein's My Frame is a snap-together set with white backing, a clear plastic cover and four primary-hued side pieces that frame a 9-by-12-inch opening. ''I created it for children, but adults are also having fun with it,'' Ms. Stein said. The kit is $15 at Penny Whistle Toy stores.

title: 21 Aboard Jumbo Jet Injured By Turbulence Over Kansas
description: Turbulent weather buffeted a United Airlines jumbo jet Tuesday, tossing babies in the air and bouncing luggage and a food cart off the ceiling of the plane.

title: Rebels in El Salvador Mount Big Attacks in Several Areas
description: Government troops and leftist guerrillas battled in several provinces early today in the first major military actions since El Salvador's new President took office a week ago.

title: Senate Calls for Revisions In New Tax for Health Care
description: Bowing to intense pressure from the elderly, the Senate today directed its Finance Committee to consider revamping the new Medicare program covering the catastrophic costs of severe illnesses - in particular the tax that pays for it.

title: An Authenticated Edition of Anne Frank's Diary
description: After years of detective work, the Dutch Government has for the first time proved the authenticity of Anne Frank's diary down to the last detail. An authoritative edition of the book, which has moved millions of readers around the world, will be published in the United States by Doubleday on Monday.

title: Vote Is Set on Nominee To Post in South Korea
description: Leaders of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee have set June 20 as the date for a vote on the nomination of Donald P. Gregg to be Ambassador to South Korea, Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky said today.

title: Fluorocarbon Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 6
description: b-Included a $1,049,000 gain from the sale of an asset. Latest quarter included results for Dixon Industries, CHR Industries and Bunnell Plastics, acquired in February.

title: Actuary to Draw New York City's Top Salary
description: Which official draws the highest salary from New York City? Of course, it's not the Mayor. (That would be too easy.) He pulls down a relatively paltry $130,000. Nor is it the Schools Chancellor, who makes $150,000 a year.

title: Ethics, in the British Mode
description: LEAD: British political history is littered with the shattered careers of those who have behaved unethically. Yet the approach of the House of Commons to ''ethics'' is very different to that now prevailing in Congress. It may not be better, but it is certainly less self-righteous, more practical and more in accordance with human nature.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 30 about the ages of victims and offenders in sex crimes misidentified Dr. Judith Becker and her hospital affiliation.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amalgamated Bank of New York, a commercial bank affiliated with the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, appointed John J. O'Connor and Edward H. Gitelson senior vice presidents.

title: Priest Puts Up Bail to Free Youth, 14, in Jogger Attack
description: The second of six youths indicted in the rape and attempted murder of a 28-year-old woman who was jogging in Central Park has been released on $25,000 cash bail put up by the Rev. Louis Gigante, a Roman Catholic priest in the South Bronx, the youth's lawyer said yesterday.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''ONCE UPON A MIRACLE,'' an original old-fashioned melodrama with music, performed by the Children's Company of Bronx Creative Arts for Youth, 7 P.M. tonight and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, (final performance: June 18), in the Gillet Auditorium, Lehman College, Gate 6 on Goulden Avenue, off Bedford Park Boulevard East, the Bronx. Free, but donations accepted. Information: 733-3176. ''THE NAUGHTY BOY,'' a story by Hans Christian Andersen as told by Diane Wolkstein, 11 A.M. tomorrow at the Andersen Statue in Central Park at 72d Street and Fifth Avenue. Free. SPRING STREET FAIR, sponsored by the Children's House of Park Slope, the fair will include games, a clown, a jug band, face painting and a buffet luncheon, noon to 4:30 P.M. tomorrow at 421 Seventh Street, Brooklyn. Admission: free. Information: (718) 499-5667. STREET FAIR, with crafts booths, a band, a magician, games, new and used books, snack booths and ethnic food, and clothes, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. tomorrow, (rain date: Sunday) sponsored by P.S. 87 Parents Association, West 77th Street, between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues. Admission: free. Information: 595-9054. PEGGY ROCKEFELLER ROSE GARDEN OPENING, the new garden, which was dedicated last September, was designed in 1915 by Beatrix Jones Farrand and has been restored at the 250-acre New York Botanical Garden; it has 83 flower beds. After a ceremony at 11:30 A.M. tomorrow, the area will be open until 5 P.M.; at 3 P.M. the North Shore High School Madrigal Group will present a concert; from noon to 5 P.M. Sunday, 15 antique cars will be on display in front of the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory. Admission to the garden, which is in the Bronx, is by contribution. Information: 220-8616.

title: The Reporters of Beijing
description: ''Every journalist who is not too stupid or too full of himself to notice what is going on knows that what he does is morally indefensible. He is a kind of confidence man, preying on people's vanity, ignorance, or loneliness, gaining their trust and betraying them without remorse.'' - The New Yorker, March 13, 1989

title: ARMY SEEMS TO TIGHTEN GRIP; BUSH BARS NORMAL TIES NOW; BEIJING IS WARNED
description: President Bush said tonight that the United States could not have normal relations with China until the authorities in Beijing ''recognize the validity'' of the pro-democracy student movement.

title:
THE LAW;
Law School Admission Exam Is Revised
description: LEAD: For the first time in seven years, the Law School Admission Test will have a new format, but the jury is still out on the significance of the changes.

title: Stocks Up As Dow Gains 4.59
description: Stock prices rose narrowly yesterday, as takeover-related issues again stole the spotlight.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Comrades, thanks for your hard work. We hope you will continue with your fine efforts to safeguard security in the capital.'' - Prime Minister Li Peng, addressing soldiers who attacked civilians in Beijing. [ A1:6. ]

title: Market Place; Is Paramount Ripe For a Takeover?
description: WHILE Paramount Communications Inc. concentrates on trying to acquire Time Inc., Wall Street is looking hard at whether Paramount itself could become a takeover target.

title: 3 Get Prison Terms In Wells Fargo Heist
description: Three Puerto Rican nationalists were sentenced to the maximum prison terms today for their part in the $7.1 million Wells Fargo robbery in 1983 as a Federal judge rejected claims that they were prosecuted for their political views.

title: Grievance Filed For an Ex-Brave
description: The Major League Baseball Players Association has filed a grievance on behalf of Albert Hall, a former outfielder for the Atlanta Braves, who was released this spring after voluntarily taking treatment for alcohol abuse.

title: Graf and Sanchez Advnace to Paris Final
description: Steffi Graf needed three sets, but Arantxa Sanchez breezed to victory today as both women advanced to the final of the French Open.

title: Hong Kong Deserves a British Roar
description: Is there no roar left in the old British lion? After the bloodletting in China, Prime Minister Thatcher's equivocation over Hong Kong seems spineless, even shameful. Adding insult, Foreign Secretary Geoffrey Howe now declares that Britain ''could not easily contemplate'' admitting 3.5 million Chinese holders of British passports because that might double the ethnic minority population.

title: Review/Art; A Look at Romare Bearden's Long Life Journey
description: By the time Romare Bearden died last year, he had received the National Medal of Arts, he had been given several traveling museum shows and he had acquired countless admirers and friends. Yet within the New York art establishment, he remained an outsider. Major New York museums bought and occasionally showed his work, but his magical narrative epics remained peripheral to their concerns.

title: Turmoil in China; 'We Can Do It,' Envoy Says of Evacuation
description: The United States Ambassador promised today that his embassy would get all Americans who want to leave out of the Chinese capital.

title: Washington Talk: Guest List; Embassy Planning a Party Fit for a Queen
description: It will be gridlock on Massachusetts Avenue Friday afternoon as a stream of limousines and 1,000 guests make their way to the British Embassy residence and its three acres of lush gardens to celebrate the birthday of Queen Elizabeth II.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Top Effie Prize To Chiat/Day
description: Chiat/Day and its mischievous ad campaign for the Nynex Corporation won a second Grand Effie last night at the 21st annual Effie Awards.

title: Afghanistan Won't Be a U.S. or Soviet Puppet; Those Darling Mullahs
description: To the Editor:

title: Kentucky High Court Says State Must Redesign Its School System
description: The Kentucky Supreme Court ruled today that the state's school system was unconstitutional because of wide disparities in spending between rich and poor districts. The court ordered the Legislature to develop a procedure to make local tax rates uniform.

title: Salk Says Tests of Vaccine Show Halt of AIDS Infection in Chimps
description: Dr. Jonas Salk, the inventor of a vaccine that helped control polio, said at an international meeting here today that a vaccine he has developed might eventually help prevent people already infected with the AIDS virus from developing the deadly disease.

title: Company News; Hospital Chain May Get Bid
description: American Medical International Inc. said today that it had received a letter from an adviser to labor organizations who said he might try to acquire the company for an employee stock ownership plan for $27 a share, or $2.05 billion.

title: U.S. Businesses Plan Rise Of 6.5% in Capital Spending
description: American businesses plan a strong 6.5 percent increase in plant and equipment spending this year, the Government said today. Economists said the capital investments would help economic expansion while tending to limit inflation.

title: World Bank Is Planning $1.5 Billion Debt Offering
description: Seeking to become an issuer like the United States Treasury, the World Bank said yesterday that in coming months it plans to offer $1.5 billion worth of new debt that will be simultaneously underwritten and distributed abroad and in the United States.

title: Flea Markets: An Urban Obsession . . .
description: EARLY Saturday and Sunday mornings, a lineup of dilapidated trucks, battered vans and vintage station wagons can be seen outside scores of Manhattan's empty parking lots and vacated schoolyards, with veterans of Manhattan's flea markets unloading everything from Victorian garden benches and 30-year-old copies of Life magazine to stone-washed blue jeans and 1930's clip-on earrings.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Who Wants New Prisons? In New York, All of Upstate
description: When Roger E. Poland, the Town Supervisor here, heard that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was proposing six new state prisons, he knew he had to have one.

title: Company News; Rolls-Royce Move
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C., the British aerospace manufacturer, said it had formed a partnership to finance the purchase of commercial aircraft and other products, a market whose volume could total $300 billion by the end of the century. The venture, Partners Finance Ltd., will be based in London and capitalized at $200 million. Rolls-Royce will own 40 percent of the partnership, with the Chrysler Capital Corporation, a unit of the Chrysler Corporation, and the Mitsubishi Trust and Banking Corporation and National Westminster Bank P.L.C. each holding 20 percent.

title: Cecil Collins, Painter, 81
description: Cecil Collins, an English artist who painted in the mystical, romantic tradition of William Blake, died Sunday. He was 81 years old.

title: Washington Talk; New Lobby Is Helping Wildlife Of Africa
description: Only three days after conservation groups called for an immediate end to the international ivory trade to save the African elephant, President Bush obliged, announcing a ban on all ivory imports.

title: Suffolk County Agrees to Buy Robins Island and Preserve It
description: Suffolk County agreed today to buy Robins Island, a pristine 445-acre wooded isle in the Great Peconic Bay, and preserve it as a nature sanctuary and study area.

title: Still a Teen-Ager, but Not a 'Little Kid'
description: Twelve months ago, when he was a 16-year-old rookie trying to make a dent in professional tennis, Michael Chang walked onto the center court of Roland Garros Stadium to play a third-round match against John McEnroe.

title: FAIRS AND FESTIVALS
description: Tomorrow STREET FAIR, West Fourth Street, between Washington Square Park and Broadway; Village Visiting Neighbors. Crafts, raffle. Rain date is Sunday. Information: 260-6200. TIBETAN FAIR, 221 East 27th Street, sponsored by the New York Tibetan Association. Tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Information: 213-5010. STREET FAIR, Public School 87, West 77th Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues. Crafts, clothing, games. Tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Rain date is Sunday. Information: 595-9054. STREET FAIR, East 78th Street between York Avenue and the East River; City and Suburban Tenants' Association. Tomorrow, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Crafts, clothing, records, books, food. Rain date is Sunday. Information: 628-8751. CRAFTS FAIR, Queens County Farm Museum, 73-50 Little Neck Parkway, Floral Park. Tomorrow, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Crafts, entertainment, food. Information: (718) 347-3276. Sunday IRVING PLACE FESTIVAL,#14th to 20th Streets between Third Avenue and Park Avenue. Jewelry, food, crafts. Sunday, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Rain date is June 18. Information: 684-4077. SPRING FESTIVAL, Union Square West, from 14th to 17th Streets; sponsored by NOW-New York City. Sunday, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Crafts, food, entertainment. Rain date is June 18. Information: 764-6330.

title: Company News; Investor Offers To Buy Di Giorgio
description: The Di Giorgio Corporation, a food and building materials company based here, has received a takeover offer from the New Jersey investor Arthur M. Goldberg for $30 a share in cash. Di Giorgio, a $1 billion company whose best-known food brand is White Rose, said Mr. Goldberg had met with its chairman and chief executive, Peter F. Scott, on Wednesday and then sent a letter outlining his offer. Kent P. Ainsworth, Di Giorgio's chief financial officer, said the board would discuss the offer at its next meeting.

title: Company News; AMR Eagle Places Order for 25 Planes
description: AMR Eagle Inc., American Airlines' regional partner, said it had reached an agreement with British Aerospace Inc. to buy 25 new turboprop aircraft. A spokesman for the British company, a unit of British Aerospace P.L.C. in London, said the accord, which included options for 25 more planes between 1992 and 1994, could be worth a total of $500 million. AMR Eagle said the planes, which each seat 19 people, would be used on routes serving its hubs in Nashville and Raleigh-Durham, N.C., beginning this summer.

title: Company News; Penney Is Selling An Insurance Unit
description: The J. C. Penney Company will pull out of the property and casualty insurance business by selling its J. C. Penney Casualty Insurance Company unit in Westerville, Ohio, to the Metropolitan Property and Casualty Insurance Company for an undisclosed price. Penney will keep its life insurance subsidiary, a spokesman, J. Duncan Muir, said from the retailer's Dallas headquarters.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Eastern's Rush for New Pilots
description: To replace striking pilots, Eastern Airlines has begun training 500 new ones, and 51 of them have met federally mandated competency requirements and are already carrying passengers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Taps Cut From Ad
description: Responding to complaints from customers, the maker of Black Flag has decided to delete a rendition of taps from a television commercial for the insecticide. A spokeswoman for the American Home Products Corporation, which makes the product, said several people had objected to the use of the military bugle call in a commercial promoting an insect spray. ''There were people who were offended by it,'' said the spokeswoman, Carol Emerling. ''We're sorry that it didn't occur to us in checking the ad.'' The Black Flag account has been handled by Kornhauser & Calene, which was recently acquired by Partners & Shevack.

title: Urban Park Rangers Reach 10-Year Mark
description: It doesn't take long for an institution to reach the age of venerability in fast-moving New York, so it gives pause for celebration to learn that the Urban Park Rangers have made it, this month, to the age of 10.

title: INQUIRY IS ORDERED ON H.U.D. FUND USE IN D'AMATO'S TOWN
description: Federal Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp yesterday ordered a new investigation into a federally subsidized housing program in Island Park, L.I., and placed on leave his department's New York administrator, who is also a member of Island Park's village board.

title: Groups Offer Poor a Place to Turn for Abortion Aid
description: The mother was frantic. Her only daughter, 15 years old, desperately wanted an abortion. But by the time the girl had sought help she was four months' pregnant and the fee for the second-trimester operation was $600. The mother, a welfare recipient, had almost no money to give her.

title: Richard P. Graves, 82, Real Estate Executive
description: Richard Perrin Graves, a retired real estate executive who was a former official of the League of California Cities, died Tuesday at his home in Pebble Beach, Calif., after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Review/Film; A 'Boheme' On Screen: Synching In Close-Up
description: As has been demonstrated by Ingmar Bergman's adaptation of ''The Magic Flute'' and Franco Zeffirelli's adaptation of ''La Traviata,'' filmed opera need not be lugubrious. Mr. Bergman and Mr. Zeffirelli each found cinematic equivalents to, or substitutes for, those things that make the so-called live performance a singular experience.

title: Head of Panel Releases Data on Toxic Risks
description: The chairman of a House committee distributed Federal data today identifying 205 industrial plants as increasing cancer risks through the release of airborne toxic chemicals. The Environmental Protection Agency quickly disputed his interpretations.

title: Money Fund Assets Rise
description: The assets of the nation's 467 money market mutual funds increased by $1.78 billion, to $314.48 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 141 institutional funds increased by $390 million, to $79.85 billion. The assets of the 231 general-purpose funds were down by $50.70 million, to $101.59 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.44 billion, to $133.04 billion, the institute said.

title: Crazed Inmate May Not Go Free
description: The crazed fan who knifed the actress Theresa Saldana in 1982 and was about to be paroled was charged today with making death threats against her from prison. The move could prevent him from ever getting released.

title: Rose Defense Cancels Interview With a Witness
description: Lawyers for Pete Rose have called off an interview with Ronald Peters, who is believed to have provided the baseball commissioner's office with some of the more damaging evidence in its investigation of Rose.

title: Once Again, Ellis Island Will Open Its Arms in Welcome
description: Decades of rubble have been cleared and restoration is nearly complete on the grandiose brick and limestone Main Building at Ellis Island and its Great Hall, through which millions of immigrants passed.

title: Plans for Tyson Bout Head Into Final Round
description: Although an official announcement has been held up by contract negotiations, an agreement has been reached between Don King, the promoter, and Trump Plaza Hotel in Atlantic City that paves the way for Mike Tyson to defend his heavyweight championship against Carl (the Truth) Williams on July 21. It would be Tyson's sixth fight and fourth title defense at Trump Plaza.

title: Bankruptcies and S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission voted unanimously today to study whether it should expand its role in bankruptcy proceedings, a decision that could lead to a reversal of a five-year-old policy limiting the commission's activity in bankruptcy cases to those containing significant legal issues.

title: Pistons Take 2-0 Lead in N.B.A. Final Series
description: An injury to Magic Johnson tonight, plus the fourth-quarter defense of the Detroit Pistons, were too much for the Los Angeles Lakers to overcome.

title: Donn Beach, Restaurateur, 81
description: Donn Beach, a restaurateur credited with creating many popular bar drinks, died of liver cancer here Wednesday. He was 81 years old.

title: Tuxedos and Curiosity As Trump Shuttle Flies
description: On its first day of operation, Donald J. Trump's new airline appeared ready to challenge the supremacy that the Pan Am shuttle has enjoyed in recent months in the lucrative Northeastern corridor. Drawn by a combination of curiosity and convenience, thousands of people decided yesterday to use the Trump Shuttle.

title: Tests Are Ordered For Davis at Bellevue
description: A State Supreme Court justice has ordered Larry Davis returned to the Bellevue Hospital Center for tests after his lawyers submitted a doctor's affidavit that his life was in danger because of repeated beatings by prison guards.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday AT PEACE WITH NATURE

title: Yeltsin, Gorbachev's Wily Goad, Hints of Some Future Ambitions
description: Each evening after the Congress of People's Deputies adjourns from another day of parliamentary combat, the wavy white hair of Boris N. Yeltsin looms above a reverent crowd in the lobby of the Kremlin Palace of Congresses.

title: Review/Art; Majolica at Met: A Form for All Purposes
description: By way of a summer offering, the Metropolitan Museum reminds us that in Italy during the High Renaissance a ubiquitous, all-purpose art arrived at apotheosis. Majolica was its name, and through Oct. 1 an exhibition devoted to it fills much of the main floor of the Lehman Wing. Robert Lehman left the museum more than 150 pieces of majolica, and as the museum already had some 275 pieces of its own, there was plenty to choose from.

title: Unlikely Ticket Agency
description: The Michigan Department of the Treasury got $700 for two tickets it auctioned for tonight's National Basketball Association Finals game between the Detroit Pistons and the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Where to Find the Flea Markets and Antiques Shows
description: Following is a list of some of the continuing flea markets and antiques shows held in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. Manhattan 1. ANTIQUE FLEA AND FARMERS MARKET, Public School 183, East 67th Street near York Avenue. Saturdays, 6 A.M. to 6 P.M., year-round. Indoors and outdoors. 2. INTERMEDIATE SCHOOL 44, Columbus Avenue between 76th and 77th Streets. Sundays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., year-round. Indoors and outdoors. 3. GREENWICH VILLAGE FLEA MARKET, Public School 41, Greenwich Avenue at Charles Street. Saturdays, noon to 7 P.M., year-round. Outdoors. 4. ANNEX ANTIQUES FAIR AND FLEA MARKET, Avenue of the Americas from 24th to 26th Street. Saturdays and Sundays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., year- round. Admission to the annex is $1.00. 5. CANAL WEST FLEA MARKET, Canal Street at West Broadway. Saturdays and Sundays, 7 A.M. to 6 P.M., year-round. 6. TOWER MARKET, Broadway between West Fourth and Great Jones Streets. Saturdays and Sundays, 10 A.M. to 7 P.M. Outdoors. Connecticut 7. ANSONIA: New England Antiques and Flea Market, Warsaw Park, Route 243. Sundays, 8 A.M. to 4 P.M., through July 30 (except weekend after next, when market will be held on Saturday, June 24), and Aug. 20 through October. Outdoors; 70 to 100 dealers. Information: (203) 426-0656. 8. BROOKFIELD: Brookfield Antiques/Collectibles Flea Market, Nick's Motel, Route 7, north of Exit 7 of Interstate 84. Saturdays and Sundays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., year-round. Indoors; 8 dealers. Information: (203) 775-3744 or (203) 775-2450. 9. CANTON: Cob-Web Flea Market, junction of Routes 44, 202 and 179. Sundays, 9 A.M. to 4 P.M., May through late fall. Outdoors; about 50 dealers. Information: (203) 693-2658. 10. JEWETT CITY: College Mart Flea Market, Wedgewood Drive near Exits 84 and 85 of Interstate 395. Sundays, 9 A.M. to 4 P.M., year-round. Indoors and outdoors; 120 dealers. Information: (203) 642-6248 or (203) 376-3935. 11. MANSFIELD: Eastern Connecticut Flea Market, junction of Routes 31 and 32. Sundays, 9 A.M. to 3 P.M., April through November. Outdoors; parking, 50 cents; 200 dealers. Information: (203) 456-2578. 12. NAUGATUCK: Naugatuck Flea Market, Route 63. Sundays, 6 A.M. to 5 P.M., April through November. Outdoors; 125 dealers. Information: (203) 729-1791. 13. NEW HAVEN: Flea Market, Ella T. Grasso Boulevard, between Route 1 and Interstate 95. Sundays, 6 A.M. to 3 P.M., year-round. Outdoors; 95 to 125 dealers. Information: (203) 624-9963. 14. NEW MILFORD: Elephant's Trunk Flea Market, Route 7, north of exit 7 of Interstate 84. Sundays, 7 A.M. to 5 P.M., April through November. Outdoors; 150 to 175 dealers. (203) 355-1448. 15. OLD MYSTIC: Old Mystic Antique Flea Market, Route 27 at Exit 90 of Interstate 95. Sundays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., year-round. Outdoors; 22 dealers. Information: (203) 536-2223. 16. TORRINGTON: Wright's Barn and Flea Market, Route 4 between Torrington and Goshen. Saturdays and Sundays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., year-round. Indoors; 30 to 40 dealers. Information: (203) 482-0095. 17. WALLINGFORD: The Trading Post. Tollgate Shopping Plaza, Route 150, near Exit 65 of the Wilbur Cross Parkway. Saturdays and Sundays, 8 A.M. to 4 P.M., year-round. Indoors; 35 dealers. Information: (203) 272-4958. 18. WOODBURY: Tique Market, Route 6, near Exit 15 of Interstate 84. Saturdays, 9 A.M. to 4 P.M., April through November. Outdoors; about 130 dealers. Information: (203) 758-1571. Upstate New York 19. AMSTERDAM PARK: Rainbow Barn, Route 5-S. Saturdays and Sundays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., April to January. Indoors; 30 to 35 dealers. Information: (518) 842-0172. 20. CLIFTON PARK: Yesterday Antique Mall, Route 9 at Sitterly Road. Daily, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., year-round. Indoors; 18 dealers. Free admission. Information: (518) 371-9488. 21. PATTERSON: Patterson Flea Market, Route 22, north of Brewster. Sundays, 6 A.M. to 5 P.M., April through October. Outdoors; 60 dealers. Information: (914) 878-6660. 22. YONKERS: Yonkers Raceway Market, Yonkers Raceway, exit 2 of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway. Sundays, 9 A.M. to 4 P.M., mid-March to late May and June 18 to mid-December. Outdoors; several hundred dealers. Admission: $2.50 per car. Information: (914) 968-4200. Queens and Long Island 23. ELMONT: Belmont Park Flea Market, Belmont Racetrack, near exits 26A-B-C-D of the Cross Island Parkway. Saturdays and Sundays, 7:30 A.M. to 4 P.M., March to May and mid-October to December. Admission: $1.50 per car; 50 cents for walk-ins. Outdoors; 1,300 dealers. Information: (516) 775-8774. 24. SOUTH OZONE PARK: Aqueduct Flea Market, Aqueduct Racetrack, near the Lefferts Boulevard exit of the Belt Parkway. Tuesdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 7:30 A.M. to 4 P.M., May to mid-October. Admission: $1.50 per car on weekends; $1 on Tuesdays; 50 cents for walk-ins. Outdoors; 1,300 dealers. Information: (516) 775-8774. 25. SMITHTOWN: Tri-County Flea Market, 291 Main Street. Wednesdays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays, noon to 9 P.M., Sundays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., year-round. Indoors; 400 dealers. Information: (516) 360-9110. 26. WESTBURY: Plain and Fancy Shows, Roosevelt Raceway. Sundays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., year- round; Wednesdays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., April to December. Admission: $2 per carload on Sundays; $1.50 on Wednesdays. Outdoors; 2,000 dealers on Sundays; 1,800 on Wednesdays. (516) 222-1530. New Jersey 27. COLLINGWOOD PARK: Collingwood Auction and Flea Market, Highways 33 and 34, near Exits 100A and 100B of the Garden State Parkway. Fridays, noon to 9:30 P.M.; Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 9:30 P.M.; Sundays, 10 A.M. to 6:30 P.M. Year-round. Indoors and outdoors; 650 dealers. Information: (201) 938-7941. 28. COLUMBUS: Columbus Farmers Market, Route 206, south of Exit 7 of the New Jersey Turnpike. Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, dawn to 1 P.M. (outdoors); Thursdays and Saturdays, 9 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Fridays, 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Sundays, 9 A.M. to 6 P.M., year-round. Indoors, 62 vendors; outdoors, several hundred. Information: (609) 267-0051 or 609-267-0400. 29. ENGLISHTOWN: Englishtown Auctions, Old Bridge Road, near Route 18 and Exit 9 of the New Jersey Turnpike. Saturdays, 7 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M., year-round except February. Outdoors and indoors; 1,300 dealers. Information: (201) 446-9644. 30. LAMBERTVILLE: Lambertville Antique Market, Route 29. Wednesdays and Thursdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Fridays, 1 to 8 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 6 A.M. to 4 P.M., year-round. Indoors and outdoors; 135 dealers. (609) 397-0456. 31. LAMBERTVILLE: Golden Nugget Antique Flea Market, Route 29. Saturdays and Sundays, 6:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. Information: (609) 397-0811. 32. NEW BRUNSWICK: U.S. No. 1 Flea Market, Route 1, near Exit 9 of the New Jersey Turnpike. Fridays, noon to 9:30 P.M.; Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Sundays, 10 A.M. to 7:30 P.M., year-round. Indoors; 500 dealers. Free admission Fridays and Saturdays; $1 on Sundays. Information: (201) 846-0902. 33. NEW EGYPT: New Egypt Auction and Farmers Market, Route 537 west of Great Adventure amusement park. Wednesdays and Sundays, 7 A.M. to mid-afternoon, year-round. Indoors and outdoors; 50 to 100 dealers. Information: (609) 758-2082. 34. RANCOCAS WOODS: William Spencer's Antique and Craft Shows, Creek Road, near Exit 43 on Interstate 295. Second Sunday of each month, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. for antique shows;, fourth Saturday of each month for craft shows, March through December. Outdoors; 200 dealers at each show. Information: (609) 235-1830. 35. SOMERVILLE: Packard's Farmer's and Flea Market, 135 Route 206. Wednesdays and Fridays, noon to 9 P.M.; Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., year- round. Indoors and outdoors; 100 dealers. (201) 725-1045 or (201) 369-3100.

title: Astros' Biggio Arrested
description: Craig Biggio, a catcher for the Houston Astros, was arrested on a in Houston early yesterday and charged with driving while intoxicated. Biggio, 23 years old, a former star at Seton Hall University, was stopped at 2:15 A.M. after a patrolman said he saw him traveling at 50 miles an hour in a 35 m.p.h. zone.

title: At the Movies
description: Bisset in 'Wild Orchid'

title: One Killed as Tanks Collide
description: Two National Guard M-1 tanks collided at Fort Harrison today, killing one driver and seriously injuring the other, officials said. Sheriff Chuck O'Reilly said one of the 60-ton Abrams battle tanks ended up on top of the other.

title: Watch That Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: Borough Hall Is Reopened In Brooklyn
description: After a six-year renovation, Brooklyn's historic Borough Hall reopened to the public yesterday in a ceremony almost as ornate as the restored civic symbol of New York City's largest borough.

title: Law Firms Moving Rapidly Into New Businesses
description: When Michael Smith left his job as Deputy United States Trade Representative last fall to become affiliated with a law firm, a gap in his background was in one way more notable than his Foreign Service accomplishments: Mr. Smith is not a lawyer.

title: Triborough Bridge Authority Bonds
description: The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority is tentatively offering $232.4 million of general purpose revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 6.89 percent for an issue due 2015.

title: Sharks! Seals! An Aquarium Seeks Notice
description: Two baffling billboards rise above Interstate 95 on the stretch from here to Bridgeport. They read: ''Sharks in Norwalk Harbor.'' Nothing else. Just . . . ''Sharks in Norwalk Harbor.''

title: Megamall, a New Fix for Future Shopping Addicts
description: The world may not need another mall, but it is getting one anyhow. It is getting no ordinary shopping center, but one that will disputably be the biggest in the world - 10 times the size of the malls most people usually cart their shopping bags through.

title: Zinka Milanov Memorial
description: A memorial service for Zinka Milanov, a soprano at the Metropolitan Opera for nearly 30 years, is to be at 6 P.M. Monday at the Yugoslav Press and Cultural Center, 767 Third Avenue, at 48th Street. Miss Milanov died May 30 after a stroke at the age of 83.

title: Fuhr Calling It Quits?
description: Grant Fuhr, a goaltender, announced yesterday that he intended to end his National Hockey League career after eight seasons with the Edmonton Oilers.

title: Tutu Elected to Harvard Post
description: Harvard University officials announced today that Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu, the leader of the South African Anglican Church and the recipient of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, has been elected to the university's Board of Overseers.

title: Company News; Burlington Resources Sale
description: The Pennzoil Company and Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. said today that Pennzoil had sold 11.7 million shares of Burlington Resources Inc. to Shearson for $45.25 each, or about $530 million.

title: Andrew Lee, Insurer, Dies at 70
description: Andrew P. Lee, an insurance executive and a member of a founding family of Manhattan's Chinatown, died of complications from pneumonia Wednesday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 70 years old and had lived for 30 years in Great Neck, L.I., before moving to Manhattan five years ago.

title: Review/Opera; 2 Siblings Fighting The Nazis
description: It is always a little embarrassing to see willing actors struggling to find intensity in arid, inert material. They have to do it, because honest dramatic work is impossible if belief cannot somehow be found or forced. If the actors are superb, and have enough in their own experience to draw on, some sleight-of-hand can be achieved. But at St. Bart's Playhouse on Saturday evening in ''The White Rose,'' an opera by Udo Zimmerman, no such magic was worked.

title: Vote on Unionizing Planned Next Month at Nissan Plant
description: Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corporation U.S.A. and the United Automobile Workers agreed Tuesday to hold an election at which workers at the company's American plant will decide whether to join the union.

title: Chinese at Grumman Plant Lose Jobs Under New Policy
description: Forty Chinese nationals were ordered dismissed from Grumman's Long Island plant under President Bush's suspension of military dealings with China, a Grumman spokesman said today.

title: Helping Men Beat Back The Urge to Violence
description: Across Northern California several weeks ago, television viewers struggled to make sense of Ramon Salcido's peculiar grin as he confessed to a bloody rampage that left his wife, daughters, mother-in-law and sisters-in-law dead.

title: Turmoil in CHina; Evacuated Americans Recount Some Near Misses
description: The nightmare began while Michael and Matthew Krug were watching a video movie in their Beijing apartment Wednesday morning. Suddenly army tanks and trucks rumbled outside the window, followed by random shots and then a rattling sound of bullets.

title: Thomson McKinnon Said to Be in Sale Talks
description: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. is in the final stages of negotiations to buy Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc., and a deal is expected to be announced by the end of the month, people with direct knowledge of the talks said yesterday.

title: Dr. Paul Milvy, 57, Environment Expert Who Was Professor
description: Dr. Paul Milvy, an educator, environmental scientist and biophysicist, died of a brain hemorrhage last Friday at his home in Washington. He was 57 years old.

title: Voice of America Beams TV Signals to China
description: Responding to the unrest in China, the Voice of America has begun sending television signals to China, the first time that the agency has taken that step, the director of the agency said today.

title: Company News; Spurned NWA Bid Confirmed by MEI
description: A company owned by the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs and Carl Pohlad, the Minnesota Twins owner, confirmed that it had bid for NWA Inc., the parent company of Northwest Airlines. A special NWA board committee rejected the bid by an investor group that included MEI Diversified Inc., the company's president, Donald E. Benson, said.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: O'Hara Returns

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Shabuoth, the Feast of Weeks, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City today and tomorrow. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: 'Daddy, Did You Make The Cut?'
description: On the PGA Tour, the 36-hole cut is golf's guillotine. Make the cut, play the final 36 holes of the tournament and you're assured a check. Miss the cut and pay your motel bill Friday night.

title: Sieckmann Leads in Soggy Westchester
description: The PGA Tour has encountered such consistently poor weather this year that some competitors are joking that the tour is besieged with requests to hold tournaments anywhere there is a drought. They say a visit by the PGA Tour is certain to guarantee rain.

title: Allegheny Offers Role To a Former Suitor
description: James D. Milligan may figure in the future of Allegheny International Inc. after all.

title: Dropout Fighting Law On Denial of Licenses
description: A 17-year-old expectant father who lost his driver's license for dropping out of school is planning the first court challenge to the state's new law aimed at reducing the number of dropouts.

title: Review/Film; The Fifth 'Star Trek,' With Old, New and Evil
description: ''Star Trek'' has always been a simple life form that seems to propagate itself, the amoeba of the movie world. Each new episode must be different but the same, offering a moderate twist on the crisp money-making formula no one dares to abandon. With its built-in audience of insatiable fans - mostly aging baby-boomers who now prefer the more businesslike name Trekkers to the too-cute Trekkies - of both television and film incarnations, ''Star Trek'' has remained successful by stealing only from itself.

title: Carter and Dunleavy Hint at Knicks' Job
description: Fred Carter and Mike Dunleavy are the latest names to surface in the search to fill the Knick coaching job. Their names came up yesterday in Chicago, where general managers, assistant coaches and scouts have congregated at the National Basketball Association's four-day predraft camp to watch some of the lesser college talent perform.

title: In 3 States, the Strawberries Are Ripe for the Picking
description: A week later than usual because of a wet, cool May, the strawberry-picking season opens this weekend in nearby New York, New Jersey and Connecticut farms and will continue through June.

title: Agent in Motorcade Is Convicted in Beating
description: A Secret Service agent was found guilty yesterday of using excessive force but acquitted of making a false arrest in the beating and arrest of a Manhattan lawyer during a Presidential campaign motorcade in New York City a year ago.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Washington Talk page on May 23 about Bush Administration appointees awaiting confirmation, and an article on May 24 about Italians' criticism of the nominee for Ambassador to Rome, misstated the background of the nominee, Peter Secchia. He is a Republican national committeeman from Michigan; he is not a former state party chairman.

title: Yankees Waste 3-Run Lead, Then Prevail in the 11th, 8-7
description: The game reached the ninth inning, and it was going to end right there. Dave Righetti was going to walk from the bullpen to the mound; he was going to retire three batters quickly and easily, and the Yankees were going to slip away to their clubhouse and rejoice.

title: Robert Wishart, 84, Pension-Plan Actuary
description: Robert A. Wishart, a retired pension-plan actuary and former chairman of Buck Consultants Inc., died of heart failure on May 28 in Delray Beach, Fla., where he lived in retirement. He was 84 years old and had lived for many years in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Cubs' Squeeze in 10th Defuses Mets' Rally
description: It may not have been the final ''battle for first place,'' but it counted and the Mets lost it, three games to one. They were beaten by the Chicago Cubs tonight on a squeeze bunt in the 10th inning and fell three and a half games back in the National League East.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a Republican attack on House Speaker Thomas S. Foley rendered a passage incorrectly in some copies when quoting Mark Goodin, who resigned as director of communications for the Republican National Committee. Discussing a memo he wrote about Mr. Foley's voting record, Mr. Goodin said there had been no intent ''to damage anyone's reputation.''

title: Turmoil in China; BBC Crew Beaten in Beijing
description: A British Broadcasting Corporation reporter and his two-member film crew were beaten and interrogated by the Chinese police in Beijing, a BBC spokesman said. ''They were kicked and punched and forced to kneel by the roadside with loaded and cocked pistols pressed to their heads,'' the spokesman said of the incident, which happened Wednesday night. The reporter, Brian Barron, told BBC radio: ''It was really fairly dreadful for a couple of minutes there. We are sitting in on the life or death of modern China. It's on the very brink.''

title: Judiciary Committee Asks for Lucas Records
description: The Senate committee reviewing the nomination of William Lucas to head the Justice Department's civil rights division has asked him to provide about 200,000 pages of documents, a spokesman for the department said today.

title: TV Weekend; The Bretts Are Back! See Them Pose, Strut and Gasp
description: Created a few years ago by Rosemary Anne Sisson and Frank Marshall for Central Independent Television of Britain, ''The Bretts'' returns to ''Masterpiece Theater'' Sunday evening at 9 on Channel 13. The theatrical family is made up of six frightful egos: Charles and Lydia Brett (Norman Rodway and Barbara Murray) and their four very determined children.

title: U.S. Asks P.L.O. to Endorse Elections
description: The United States formally asked the Palestine Liberation Organization today to allow Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip to take part in Israeli-sponsored elections.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Security Council Meets at 3:30 P.M. on extension of mandate of peacekeeping force in Cyprus General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. AD HOC COMMITTEE ON FOURTH DEVELOPMENT DECADE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Welch Chorale
description: The Welch Chorale of St. Philip Neri is to sing works of Mozart, Puccini, Gounod, W. C. Handy, William Finn and Brian Hunter at 2 P.M. Sunday at the Woolworth Chapel at Woodlawn Cemetery, Webster Avenue and 233d Street in the Bronx. Admission is free. Information: 920-0500.

title: Turmoil in China; 2 STUDYING IN U.S. DISAPPEAR IN CHINA
description: Two Chinese graduate students in the United States, one traveling with her infant son, disappeared this week while visiting China to lend support to pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing.

title: Chrysler Missouri Plant
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it was nearing completion of a $124 million modernization of a plant at Fenton, Mo., outside St. Louis, where it will produce new versions of the Dodge Daytona and Chrysler Lebaron.

title: Pirates Score 10 in First but Lose to Phillies
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates, who opened the game tonight with their biggest inning in 47 years, became the second team to squander a 10-run lead this week, losing to the Philadelphia Phillies, 15-11.

title: Father of TV, a Scot, Never Saw Idaho
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Cuts Its Beijing Staff
description: The United Nations has evacuated some of its Beijing staff to Hong Kong, but those regarded as essential to its China operations will remain in that country, a spokesman said today.

title: Divorce Data Stir Doubt on 'Trial Marriage'
description: Researchers who expected the widespread practice of ''trial marriage'' to usher in an era of increased marital stability have been surprised by new studies showing that those Americans who lived together before marriage separate and divorce in significantly greater numbers than couples who go directly to the altar.

title: Pull the Plug on TV Marti
description: LEAD: The proposal to create TV Marti, modeled after the Government-sponsored radio station that broadcasts into Cuba, appears deceptively simple: Get a few million dollars from Congress, recruit a staff (mostly from among conservative Cuban exiles), float a transmitting balloon above Key West and start broadcasting.

title: Books of The Times; In Occupied Prague, a Life Of Diminishing Rewards
description: Life With a Star By Jiri Weil Preface by Philip Roth. Translated by Ruzena Kovarikova with Roslyn Schloss. 208 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.95.

title: Wall St. Black Sheep
description: To the Editor:

title: Questions at Georgia
description: Jan Kemp said yesterday that she had several questions on a report by a University of Georgia faculty committee investigating charges she made against tutors provided by the Athletic Association to students in the school's developmental studies program.

title: Review/Art; 30 Hispanic Artists At Brooklyn Museum
description: ''Hispanic Art in the United States: 30 Contemporary Painters and Sculptors,'' which opens today at the Brooklyn Museum, is the wrong exhibition at the right time. One begins walking through it full of expectations about artists who are finally receiving their due recognition. One leaves full of doubts - doubts not about the quality of painting and sculpture, which is generally high, but about the premise of the show's curators, John Beardsley and Jane Livingston of the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington.

title: Finance/New Issues; China Debt Rating Is Under Review
description: Moody's Investors Service said yesterday that it is considering reducing the bond ratings of both the People's Republic of China and Hong Kong.

title: Warsaw Accepts Solidarity Sweep And Humiliating Losses by Party
description: As Government and Solidarity negotiators sat down tonight to map out potential fields of political collaboration, the Government announced the official returns showing the extent of Solidarity's success in Sunday's national elections.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Turmoil in China; Seeing Shadows Where Once There Were Leaders, Facts and Informants
description: Writing about China's leadership these days must be a bit like covering the afterlife: Even if one is convinced it exists, confirming the details can be tough.

title: Review/Film; Naughtiness For Rich And Poor In 'Struggle'
description: It all depends on whether you want a film that is great and awesome or one that is small and irresistible. If ''Potemkin'' is what you're after, you may want to pass up Paul Bartel's ''Scenes From the Class Struggle in Beverly Hills,'' which is somewhat less rousing but a lot more cheerful. It opens today at the 68th Street Playhouse and other theaters.

title: Pretoria's Emergency Decree Is Extended for Fourth Year
description: The South African Government said today it was renewing emergency regulations for the fourth consecutive year.

title: Campaign Trail; Cuomo Is Reaching Out To Former Opponents
description: Will you love us in December 1990 as you do in June 1989?

title: Whittle Expands Its Plans For Broadcasts to Schools
description: Whittle Communications announced plans yesterday to begin an expanded national version of Channel One, its commercially sponsored daily news program for broadcast to high school classrooms.

title: Auctions
description: Haggadah in Geneva

title: S.E.C. Hears Arguments In Lawyer Case
description: In an unusual proceeding, the five members of the Securities and Exchange Commission today sat in their judicial capacity to hear arguments in the case of George C. Kern Jr., a senior partner at the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Overseas Chief At Waste Management
description: LEAD: Waste Management Inc., the nation's largest handler of solid and hazardous wastes, has named Edwin G. Falkman president of its international subsidiary.

title: Third World Debt Declines
description: Debts of the undeveloped world to commercial banks dropped by a net total of $12.4 billion last year, partly because banks were trading the debt for local assets, according to new figures from the International Monetary Fund.

title: Pop/Jazz; Radio City's 10 Years As a venue For Rock
description: It's a sign of the times that Radio City Music Hall, the Art Deco dream palace where Manhattan and Middle America have traditionally rubbed shoulders, should now be one of the city's most important pop- and rock-concert venues. Now that rock-and-roll has grown up, it is as much a part of mainstream popular culture as the family-oriented movies that for decades drew thousands of people to Radio City each week. This year, the hall is celebrating its 10th anniversary as a pop-concert site, and can look back at a decade of well over 700 musical events.

title: Restaurants
description: Umeda is a peaceful little haven near Gramercy Park where the clamor of the city gives way to bucolic strains of the flute, where gentle Japanese women always have a reassuring smile, and where the food is as pure and clean as a Pacific dawn. This is as close as you can get to a health spa without breaking into a sweat.

title: Bush Says He Doesn't Favor Mandatory Reporting of AIDS
description: President Bush tonight rejected the idea of mandatory reporting of AIDS cases, saying ''there is a certain right to privacy that we should respect.''

title: Review/Dance; Purcell's 'Dido and Aeneas' As Mark Morris Sees It
description: Mark Morris's version of ''Dido and Aeneas'' is a danced opera. The hourlong production is spare in its staging but florid in its sentiments, focusing completely upon the choreographer's performance in two women's roles. It is also suprisingly good.

title: Senate Clears Personnel Chief
description: The Senate has approved Constance B. Newman as director of the Office of Personnel Management. The approval came by voice vote Wednesday. Ms. Newman, 53 years old, got her start in Government work as a clerk-typist in the Interior Department and rose to become an Assistant Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Turmoil in China; Yale Plans a Benefit Concert To Help Wounded Protesters
description: More than 40 musicians, including Yale music students, faculty and alumni, will put on a nine-hour concert on Friday to raise money for medical supplies and other aid for those wounded in the demonstrations in Beijing.

title: To Our Readers
description: Because of problems with the computers that receive and transmit financial market data at The Associated Press, the New York Stock Exchange Bond Trading table does not include bonds traded between noon and 3:45 P.M.

title: U.S. Fights Europe TV-Show Quota
description: The United States has registered ''very sharp and strong'' objections to the European Community's proposed quotas on American television programming, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today.

title: Economic Scene; Turmoil in East Seen Aiding West
description: THE tumultuous events of these times - the Chinese Government's efforts to stamp out the students' and workers' pro-democracy movement and the moves of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to reform the Soviet economic and political system - have greatly strengthened the prospects for the United States and the other capitalist democracies for a long time to come.

title: At the Bar
description: ''There are two things wrong with most legal writing,'' Fred Rodell of Yale Law School wrote more than 50 years ago in an article entitled ''Goodbye to Law Reviews.'' ''One is its style. The other is its content.''

title: Company News; Gibraltar Financial Sues U.S. on Unit
description: The Gibraltar Financial Corporation said it had filed an action against Federal regulators to recover $11 million owed to it by a subsidiary, Gibraltar Savings of Beverly Hills, Calif. The regulators, who are operating Gibraltar Savings under a conservatorship, prevented the parent company from receiving the money in May.

title: Corrections
description: The Eating Well column in The Living Section on Wednesday referred incorrectly to fees charged by California Certified Organic Farmers to certify produce as organic. The program charges one-half of 1 percent of gross sales annually and a one-time application fee of $150.

title: Turmoil in China; On the Surface, Beijing Starts to Appear Normal
description: A bitter memory lingers on a narrow street where soldiers opened fire on scores of citizens last Sunday, but even here on South Pond Street, life today seemed to be gradually returning to normal.

title: A DRUG CHEMICAL IS HELD TO BE SAFE
description: Contrary to earlier reports, a chemical used in many cold and allergy medications and diet pills does not significantly increase blood pressure, a new study has found.

title: Chinese Upheaval Shakes Italy's Communists
description: The explosive events in China have sent shivers through Italy's faltering Communist Party, the largest in the West, and have emboldened Socialists who hope to emerge soon as the country's dominant left-wing group.

title: Company News; Burger King Asks For Coke Proposal
description: The Burger King Corporation is reviewing its soft-drink contract with Pepsico Inc. and has asked the Coca-Cola Company for a proposal, a spokeswoman said. ''It's part of a normal vendor review,'' said Cori Zywotow, a spokeswoman for Burger King, the nation's second-largest fast-food chain, after the McDonald's Corporation.

title: Battle Lines Tangled In Fight for Time Inc.
description: Not since the multibillion-dollar takeover of RJR Nabisco, which showered almost $1 billion in fees upon bankers and lawyers, has Wall Street seen a potential payday like that offered by the battle for Time Inc.

title: New Bill Seeks to Track Hazardous Matter
description: Two Congressmen introduced legislation today that would create a nationwide system to track the transport of hazardous materials and provide information that could prevent chemical explosions.

title: Lesson of Lattimore
description: Owen Lattimore died the other day, an almost forgotten man.

title: Radical Plan to Balance Soviet Budget
description: Warning that the Soviet Union faces economic collapse within the next few years, a prominent economist proposed an unorthodox plan today for balancing the budget, including cutting aid to Cuba and Nicaragua, selling land to farmers and slashing imports of American grain.

title: Cohoes Stores in Bankruptcy
description: Cohoes Specialty Stores Ltd., a retail chain that discounts designer and brand-name clothing, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection yesterday, saying it had liabilities of more than $30 million and assets of $15 million to $16 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Selling The Public On Issues
description: MOST people would consider selling insurance a comedown from directing a Presidential campaign, but John Sasso has stepped from one to the other with his ego intact.

title: Film Planned On Brazilian Ecologist
description: A Brazilian film company has won the rights to the life story of the slain Brazilian ecologist Francisco (Chico) Mendes.

title: Kuwait, Softening Stance, Says It May Curb Oil Output
description: In a conciliatory gesture to the other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, Kuwait said today that it might curb its oil production. But it still refused to accept its OPEC quota of 1.093 million barrels a day.

title: Summary; Business Digest
description: The Battle for Time Inc.

title: First Chicago
description: The First Chicago Corporation is offering $200 million of 9 percent subordinated notes due in 1999 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc. Underwriters said the notes are priced at 99.05, to yield 9.15 percent, or about 90 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. They are noncallable through maturity and rated A-3 by Moody's Investors Service and A- by Standard & Poor's.

title: INSIDE
description: Apartheid Foe Poisoned An anti-apartheid campaigner who collapsed with a mysterious illness was apparently poisoned, his doctor said. Church leaders called on white South Africans to condemn such violence ''done in their name.'' Page A6. Progress on AIDS Vaccine Based on preliminary experiments, Dr. Jonas Salk said a vaccine he developed might help prevent people infected with the AIDS virus from developing the disease. Page A8. Before Arrest, a Quiet Life The man arrested last week on charges of killing five family members in 1971 apparently spent 17 years hiding behind a cloak of ordinariness and a penchant for privacy. Page B1. A New Look to Law Pressed by sharp competition in the legal marketplace, law firms are rapidly expanding into other kinds of businesses. The Law, page B5.

title: New York Sues Paint Makers Over Lead
description: New York City is suing five major paint manufacturers and their trade association, seeking more than $50 million for the cost of reducing health hazards created by lead paint.

title: Review/Opera; In Hamburg, Attention for the Neglected Schreker
description: Rarely in music history has a reputation risen so high and fallen so low as that of Franz Schreker. In the 1920's the Austrian-born Schreker (1878-1934) was the toast of central European opera, widely regarded as the leading opera composer of the day, or at the very least Richard Strauss's only competition. As the director of the Berlin Conservatory, he enjoyed not only prestige but also leverage to insure the production of his scores.

title: Turmoil in China; 2 TV Networks Are Sending Top Anchors to China
description: Top anchors from NBC News and ABC News will report from Beijing next week. The move provoked excitement at those networks yesterday and skepticism from their competitors, who questioned the value of sending the anchors at a time when television reports are being increasingly restricted by the Chinese Government.

title: Bilzerian Fraud Case Goes to Jury
description: Jury deliberations began yesterday in the securities fraud trial of Paul A. Bilzerian, chairman of the Singer Company, in a case that could result in the first jury verdict since the Wall Street scandals began.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Vucciria

title: Dining Out Guide: Long Island
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Long Island Weekly section of The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Chez Noelle Excellent (Oct. 9, 1988), 34 Willowdale Avenue, Port Washington (516-883-3191) - A street of lumberyards and auto-body shops in a modest corner of Port Washington yields one of the Island's best restaurants. Chez Noelle has a classic decor with white linen tablecloths, candlelight and a handsome Art Deco service bar. Dishes are carefully cooked and sauced, and the presentation is Japanese inspired. Appetizers include langoustine mousse and frog-leg ravioli with watercress sauce. Among the entrees are rack of lamb Provencal (prepared with garlic, herbs and fresh tomatoes); poached salmon with basil sauce, or breast of free-range chicken. Appetizers are $4 to $7.50, entrees $15 to $25. Dinner 6 to 9:30 P.M. on Sunday and Tuesday to Thursday, 6 to 11 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Closed Monday. La Estancia Very Good (Jan. 22, 1989), 481 Hempstead Turnpike, a half-mile east of Belmont Race Track, Elmont (516-328-8481) - Serious eating means steak to many Argentines, and this authentic restaurant specializes in beef at reasonable prices. The name means ranch, and the appropriately horsy decor includes stylized drawings of gauchos and photographs of Thoroughbreds, jockeys and trainers from the nearby race track. Pastas, made with a light hand by the owner's wife, are all recommended, as are the charcoal-grilled chicken and chicken scarpariello. The best of the beef dishes is Milanese con papas fritos, a robust relative of chicken-fried steak. Also good are filet mignon and sliced steak. Homemade peppery Argentine steak sauce adds spark to all grilled meats. Entrees are $5.50 to $15. Hours: 11:30 A.M. to 10 P.M. Monday to Thursday, until 11 P.M. Friday; 1 to 11 P.M. Saturday, until 10 P.M. Sunday. La Ginestra Very Good (May 14, 1989), 4 School Street, Glen Cove (516-671-3184) -Despite red roses, crisp white tablecloths and waiters in tuxedos, the atmosphere at La Ginestra is that of a Sicilian country inn. Hearty red sauces of southern Italy are here in abundance, but so are light meals featuring vegetables and meats from the wood-fired grill. Baby eggplant, sliced and lightly charred, is paired with fresh chopped tomato for a good starter. Another delightful choice is the antipasto vario. Among the entrees, the best include orecchiette a la Ginestra, or tiny pasta shells tossed with broccoli, sausage and olive oil; pollo romano, and calamari marinara. Appetizers are $5.95 to $8.95, entrees $12.95 to $19.95. Dinner 5:30 to 10 P.M. Tuesday to Thursday, until 11 P.M. Friday and Saturday; 4 to 9 P.M. Sunday. Lotus East Excellent (Jan. 8, 1989), 416 North Country Road (Route 25A), St. James (516-862-6030) - Lotus East is Chinese modern, short on ornate lighting fixtures and gold dragons and decorated in subtle grays, rose and burgundy. Traditional starters of shrimp toast and spring rolls are greaseless and tasty. Familiar dishes are deftly prepared: beef and broccoli, tangerine beef and chicken lo mein are first rate. Other recommended dishes include scallion three-taste; stir-fried salty and crispy shrimp, and Chinese eggplant. Lunch is $4.75 to $6.75, dinner $6.75 to $28 (Peking duck). Hours: 11:30 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. Monday to Thursday, until midnight Friday and Saturday; noon to 10:30 P.M. Sunday. Michael Anthony's Creative Cuisine Very Good (May 7, 1989), 470 Montauk Highway (Route 80), East Moriches (516-878-9667) - The young chef and owner is a creative cook and conceives some delicate contemporary dishes with a French identity. His simply appointed storefront restaurant, lighted by carriage lights, has an all-white design punctuated with colorful fresh flowers. For starters, there are crunchy deep-fried artichokes, or escargots in a leek vinaigrette. Steak au poivre and veal cordon bleu are good renditions of classics. Seafood entrees include catfish with basil beurre blanc and sun-dried tomatoes, and swordfish with horseradish-mustard glaze. Appetizers are $4.95 to $6.95, entrees $13.50 to $16.95. Dinner 5 to 10 P.M. Wednesday to Sunday. Closed Monday and Tuesday.

title: Nova Ensemble
description: The Nova Chamber Ensemble is to give the New York premiere of Boris Liatoshynsky's Piano Trio (Op. 7) at 7:30 P.M. tomorrow at the Ukrainian Institute of America, 2 East 79th Street. The program also includes Beethoven's String Quartet No. 12 in E flat (Op. 127) and the Frank Martin Piano Quintet. The performers are to include Laura Seaton and Deborah Wong, violinists; Tina Pelikan, violist; Erik Friedlander, cellist, and Laryssa Krupa, pianist. Tickets are $10. Information: 288-8660.

title: Questions for Senator D'Amato
description: Senator Alfonse D'Amato says his hands are clean and his conscience clear in the latest scandal bubbling up from the cesspool in the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development. Besides protesting his innocence, he ought to be encouraging the H.U.D. Secretary, Jack Kemp, and the Justice Department to pursue answers.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a military analysis article on Wednesday about the Chinese Army described the relationship between a military official and China's President incorrectly in some copies. The official, Yang Baibing, head of the army's general political department, is a brother of President Yang Shangkun. Gen. Yang Jianhua, a nephew of the President, commands the 27th Army.

title: Judges Hear Appeal on Cup
description: A panel of five judges yesterday heard arguments on the future of the America's Cup, including the possibility of resailing the 1988 series.

title: Company News; Lin Tender Offer Begun by McCaw
description: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. has begun its cash tender offer for the outstanding shares of the Lin Broadcasting Corporation. McCaw said the offer of $120 a share, or about $6.5 billion, was contingent upon Lin's not proceeding with its plan to spin off its seven television stations as a new company. The offer also requires Lin to remove its ''poison pill'' anti-takeover measure that stipulates that if any party buys more than 15 percent of its common stock, all other shareholders can buy shares at half price.

title: Parliament Chief Is Making a Bid For Iran's Helm
description: The Speaker of Parliament positioned himself today to bid for Iran's leadership after the death of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini.

title: Afghanistan Won't Be a U.S. or Soviet Puppet
description: To the Editor:

title: Appeals Court Voids School Injury Award
description: Ruling that schools must provide only ''reasonable care'' to protect student athletes from injury, New York State's highest court today overturned an $878,000 jury award to a former New York City high school student.

title: Time Inc's Board Plots A Defense
description: The directors of Time Inc. met yesterday for a marathon strategy session amid speculation on Wall Street that the media giant may approve plans to make a takeover bid for Warner Communications Inc. as an 11th-hour stand to fight off Paramount Communications Inc.

title: Washington Talk; Pentagon
description: For the generals and the military planners of the Pentagon, that old warrior's maxim, ''know thine enemy,'' is less and less their rod and staff.

title: Lester Granet, Accountant, 76
description: Lester Granet, a founder in 1934 of the accounting firm of Granet & Granet, of Livingston, N.J., died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital in Newark. He was 76 years old and lived in Verona, N.J.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Bush Pushing Efforts to Pull Down Noriega
description: President Bush said tonight that the Organization of American States should continue in its efforts to persuade Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to surrender power in Panama.

title:
ABOUT REAL ESTATE;
Condos Top 6th Building To Rise at Lincoln Center
description: LEAD: Thirty years after a groundbreaking ceremony at Columbus Avenue and West 64th Street marked the start of Lincoln Center, a sixth building is being added to the performing arts complex. And the new building is serving as the base for a 45-story residential condominium at the corner of West 66th Street and Amsterdam

title: Turmoil in China; Shanghai Issues an Appeal for Calm, and a Warning to Go With It
description: The Mayor of this city appealed in a televised address for an end to the ''chaos'' that he said has prevailed here for several days, warning that anyone causing disturbances or interfering with efforts to restore Shanghai's transportation system would be ''dealt with by the police in accordance with law.''

title: Grain Output Rise Seen
description: World grain production in the 1989-90 season may be larger than forecast, with early signs of an 11.4 percent increase from the drought-affected yield last season, the International Wheat Council said on Wednesday.

title: Poisoning of African Church Leader Charged
description: A South African church leader who collapsed with a mysterious illness and nearly died while visiting the United States had apparently been poisoned by a toxic compound like nerve gas or an insecticide, his doctor said yesterday.

title: Time Inc.'s Lesson: No Company Is Safe
description: In Wall Street jargon, companies being sought in a takeover attempt are ''in play,'' but a more accurate term might be ''at war.''

title: On Stage
description: Two Musicals Headed This Way

title: President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Issues
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times: QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS PRESIDENT BUSH: Welcome to the East Room, please be seated and we shall proceed. Helen? U.S. Outrage on China

title: Vught Journal; Remember the Moluccans? Is This a Last Stand?
description: In a former Nazi concentration camp set in picturesque woodland, the talk is of broken promises and a distant homeland.

title: Study Says U.S. Count On AIDS May Be Low
description: A University of Chicago study suggests that Federal officials may be significantly underestimating the number of Americans who have AIDS and that there are more whites and fewer blacks with the disease than previously believed.

title: KEY RATES
Husband Files Suit Over Abortion Delay
description: A man whose battle to obtain an abortion for his comatose wife reached the nation's highest court filed a $10 million lawsuit yesterday against a hospital and the anti-abortion advocates who opposed him.

title: Yoshiro Araki, Banker, 67
description: Yoshiro Araki, chairman of the Fuji Bank and Trust Company, died of pneumonia on Saturday at the Keio Hospital in Tokyo. He was 67 years old and lived in Yokohama.

title: At Chicago Center, New Clients, Ols Ills
description: The bundled-up children who tumble into the Hull House Sheridan day care center each day are named Francisco, Alejandro, Mariela and Ariana. Their parents, mostly of Mexican and Puerto Rican descent, are factory and hotel employees who drop off the children on their way to work.

title: Bush Resists Pressure to Soften Antimissile Policy
description: Bush Administration officials said today that they did not expect the United States to make basic changes in its negotiating position on antimissile systems despite arguments by the American military that Washington should soften its stand.

title: Why Torpedo Tax Reform?
description: Question: How can Congress deliver on its agreement with the Bush Administration to generate an extra $5.3 billion in new revenues for the next fiscal year? The answer would appear simple but painful: Raise taxes. But the House Ways and Means Committee chairman, Dan Rostenkowski, is flirting with a more imaginative idea: Cut the capital gains tax, temporarily.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, the Personal Health column yesterday omitted a phrase in some editions.

title: News Business Manager Is Named by The Times
description: Penny Muse Abernathy, a corporate planning manager at The New York Times Company, has been named business manager of The Times's 1,000-member news department. Her appointment was announced yesterday by Max Frankel, the paper's executive editor.

title: President Supports Atwater In Furor Over Foley Memo
description: President Bush today renewed his support for Lee Atwater, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, amid Democratic calls for Mr. Atwater's resignation.

title: Prosaic Life of Suspect in '71 New Jersey Murders
description: The man who says he is Robert P. Clark apparently spent 17 years hiding behind little more than a cloak of ordinariness and a penchant for privacy before his arrest on murder charges a week ago, friends and acquaintances said.

title: Treasury Securities Inch Higher
description: Prices of Treasury securities inched modestly higher in slow, cautious trading yesterday, as dealers awaited today's release of an important inflation report.

title: Teacher Pleads Not Guilty
description: A 36-year-old high school teacher from Brooklyn, arrested on charges of buying drugs on Tuesday on a Coney Island street, was arraigned early yesterday before Judge Angelo F. Tona of Criminal Court and released on his own recognizance. The teacher, Salvatore Cafiero, entered a plea of not guilty to a charge of criminal possession of a controlled substance in the seventh degree, a misdemeanor. If found guilty, he could be sentenced to up to a year in jail and fined at the judge's discretion.

title: Study Finds Flaws in U.S. Effort To Stop Airborne Drug Smuggling
description: Intensified Federal efforts to curb the smuggling of cocaine and marijuana into the United States on private planes have been largely ineffective, says a General Accounting Office report to be made public Friday.

title: Soviet Game Canceled
