description: The football game between Southern California and Illinois, scheduled for Sept. 2 in Moscow, was canceled yesterday. The game became a victim of contractual problems between the host country and Raycom, the television network that had hoped to televise the first American college football game to be played in the Soviet Union.

title: Lomas to Sell Credit Card Bank Operation
description: The Lomas Financial Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its credit card bank subsidiary for $500 million in cash and preferred stock to an investor group led by Merrill Lynch Capital Partners. The price is the highest ever paid for a credit card business.

title: ...And a Country Passion
description: VIRTUALLY every weekend for the last 60 years, the people of Englishtown, N.J., have gathered at the edge of the village to partake in one of the area's most venerable rites of commerce - the sprawling free-form marketplace known as Englishtown Auctions. Although the local cow fields are rapidly giving way to condominiums, this semi-rural, semi-suburban patch of central New Jersey remains the setting for one of the largest and oldest flea markets in America.

title: Police Seek Parolee In Attacks on Girls
description: A man who was convicted of sex attacks is responsible for five recent similar attacks on teen-age girls in Brooklyn, the police said yesterday.

title: The Big Two Will Go Head to Head at the Start
description: Sunday Silence and Easy Goer figure to be close together at the finish of the Belmont Stakes tomorrow, and yesterday the luck of the draw put them right next to each other at the start.

title: Review/Opera; 'Siegfried' From Berlin In the Underground 'Ring'
description: It is ''Siegfried'' time in the Deutsche Oper Berlin's production of the ''Ring'' and the Off Valhalla Players are still trapped in their underground theater, the Tunnel of Time, acting out Gotz Friedrich's version of Wagner's cycle. That the tunnel strikingly resembles the Washington Metro is not strange: the capital's vaulted and vaunted subway system was the German director's inspiration for this 1985 Berlin staging, in town for a two-cycle visit. What is strange, however, is almost everything else about this ''Ring'' so far, an archetypal example of the modern ''director's opera.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aircoa Hotel Partners L.P., Denver, announced the execution of a purchase and sale agreement by Kona Operating Partnership L.P. for the sale of its Kona Village Resort in Hawaii. The price is $55 million.

title: School Board Election Is a Voter's Nightmare
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Piano; Hearing More Than Beethoven Set Down
description: Mordecai Shehori did his colleagues a benign disservice Tuesday evening by reminding a full house at Weill Recital Hall, through his contrary example, how dully most other pianists play Beethoven. Far too many act as though their job is simply to get across what the composer has set down; Mr. Shehori constantly reminded us how many more shades and textures and rhythmic subtleties there are in fine piano playing than in even the most meticulous notation.

title: Hecla Mining's Notes Yield 8%
description: The Hecla Mining Company is offering $175 million of zero-coupon liquid yield option notes due 2004 through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, the sole manager of the financing.

title: Eastern Air Gives Proposal to Pilots
description: Eastern Airlines presented its striking pilots union a contract proposal today that seeks temporary pay and vacation reductions similar to those implemented last week for nonunion workers.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Mal Waldron Quintet

title: Airbus Discloses Orders for New Jetliner
description: Airbus Industrie announced today that it had received orders for the first 18 of its A321-100, a stretched Airbus model announced three weeks ago.

title: Gtech to Study Merger Offers
description: The Gtech Corporation, a major supplier of lottery networks, which has long been rumored as a takeover target, said a special management committee would evaluate merger and takeover offers. Gtech acknowledged that ''certain parties have expressed interest in possibly acquiring'' the company, but said no offers had been received.

title: SHANGHAI PROTESTERS RALLY
description: Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, appeared on television this evening with nine other top officials, apparently resolving the question of who is running the country.

title: Let Prayer Resound At Gate of Auschwitz
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 More for Tettleton as Orioles Win
description: Mickey Tettleton hit two homers and took over the American League home run lead with 16, powering the Baltimore Orioles past the Milwaukee Brewers tonight, 7-1. Baltimore, which had just lost two games in succession for the first time this season, has won 8 of 10 and 13 of 16.

title: U.S. and Soviet Veterans Share Pain of War
description: Two Soviet veterans of Afghanistan and two American veterans of Vietnam met in a Manhattan office on Thursday to talk about some of the things they have in common: the wars they did not win, the comrades they loved and lost, the loneliness of coming home to people who do not always understand what war does to the soldiers who fight it, and the utter futility of fighting for causes that have been abandoned by their Governments.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 50.

title: Together, We Can Make Hospitals Work
description: To the Editor:

title: Dow Drops 3.49 Amid Conflicting Signals
description: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, as investors tried to sort out conflicting signals about the economy.

title: WATT DETAILS ROLE FOR $400,000 FEES
description: Former Interior Secretary James G. Watt told Congress today that he had received more than $400,000 as a private consultant in Federal low-income housing projects even though he had no background in housing issues and had never inspected any of the projects he was promoting.

title: Death Penalty Takes Spotlight In Lauder Ads
description: In a new television advertisement, Ronald S. Lauder, a Republican candidate for mayor, denounces his main opponent in the party's primary, Rudolph W. Giuliani, for a position on the death penalty, even though that position is similar to one Mr. Lauder took in a book analyzing violent crime.

LEAD: President Bush made the right choice when he pledged continued U.S. military support to Jonas Savimbi, leader of the Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or Unita. Congressional oversight committees, which are reportedly considering a request for more aid for Unita, should follow his lead.

title: Plane Lease Pact
description: The International Lease Finance Corporation, a jet leasing company based in Beverly Hills, Calif., said it had leased $1 billion worth of Boeing, Airbus and McDonnell Douglas airplanes to nine airlines. The 20 jets, including one Boeing 747-400 and several Boeing 737's and 757's, will be delivered beginning in early 1990 to Cathay Pacific Airways, Air Portugal, Air Inter and several other airlines.

title: Soviet Congress Ends With One Last Spat
description: The National Congress of People's Deputies ended its marathon 13-day debut tonight with Andrei D. Sakharov raging at the restless assembly that they had failed in their main task, to wrest control from the Communist Party elite.

title: Rates Hit 2-Year Low in Bond Rally
description: Interest rates plunged to two-year lows yesterday, as the prices of long-term Treasury bonds surged.

title: Retrial of 1979 Murder Case Begins, Minus a Confession
description: The retrial of a defendant in the 10-year-old murder case of John Pius began here today with opening statements and three witnesses, but without the prosecution's major piece of evidence from the original trial: a confession.

title: Suit by Rexene Employees Is Settled for $140 Million
description: As many as 1,800 employees of the Rexene Corporation will share $140 million under a settlement of their suit against the Dallas-based chemical maker, the parties said yesterday.

title: Turoff Sentenced in Taxi Medallion Scheme
description: Jay L. Turoff, the former head of New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission, was sentenced to three months' house arrest and fined $1,000 for taking part in a scheme to misappropriate 23 taxi medallions and more than $500,000 in taxi revenues.

title: French Agency Drops Bid for Boase
description: The French advertising agency Boulet Dru Dupuy Petit dropped its bid for the Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership of Britain yesterday, clearing the way for the Omnicom Group to complete a friendly takeover.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Medical International Inc., Beverly Hills, Calif., a hospital operator, said all parties interested in acquiring the company would be asked to submit their proposals by June 29.

title: Test May Show Status Of AIDS, Scientist Says
description: The fifth international meeting on AIDS closed here today, with a discoverer of the AIDS virus reporting preliminary results of a test that might help monitor progress of the infection in a patient.

title: Review/Opera
description: The P.S. 161 Opera Workshop performance of ''Carmen'' yesterday did not go entirely without a hitch. The prelude to Act III, for instance, had to be interrupted. ''Where are our mountains?'' the conductor called out. ''Has anyone seen our mountains?''

title: Anne K. Hilker, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Anne Katherine Hilker and Robert D. Sack, associates at the New York law firm of Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher, were married yesterday at the Sherman House hotel in San Francisco. The bridegroom's father, Rabbi Eugene J. Sack of Mountain View, Calif., performed the ceremony.

title: End Seen to LVMH Battle
description: A battle for control of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the French luxury goods company, appeared near an end today after the head of the Vuitton luggage division hinted he would step down soon.

title: In Shanghai, Protesters Turn Defiant
description: Tens of thousands of students and others held a protest rally and marched through the streets of this city today in a demonstration of continued defiance of the Communist leadership.

title: China Names a Culprit Behind Student Unrest
description: The television news this evening named as the real villain in the recent bloodshed someone whom most people had not even conceived of as a possible culprit.

title: Judge Orders Tests on Davis's Paralysis Claim
description: As Larry Davis lay on a gurney a few feet away, a Manhattan judge ruled last night that the 23-year-old inmate must be returned to Bellevue Hospital Center for new tests to determine whether he has been partly paralyzed by beatings by correction officers or is faking his condition.

title: New Alliance Presses States on Insurance
description: A concerted effort is being made by consumer groups and insurance agents to persuade state governments to approve minimum standards for financing, structuring and staffing the departments that regulate the insurance business.

title: Annie Laurie Auersperg Is Married
description: Annie Laurie Auersperg, a daughter of Martha (Sunny) Crawford von Bulow of New York and Prince Alfred Auersperg of Salzburg, Austria, was married yesterday to Ralph Isham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Heyward Isham of New York and Sagaponack, L.I. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Six Are Killed by Car Bomb During Rush Hour in Beirut
description: A car packed with 150 pounds of explosives blew up in the Muslim sector of the capital today at the peak of the morning rush hour, killing six people and wounding four others, the police said.

title: Uzbek Violence Continues As Gunfire Wounds Scores
description: Ethnic violence is continuing in Uzbekistan, the Government reported today, with scores of people wounded by gunfire and troops hard pressed to rout mobs of Uzbek marauders hunting down the republic's minority Meskhetians.

title: Storehouse Spurns Bid by Edelman
description: Storehouse P.L.C. rejected a proposal by the American takeover specialist Asher B. Edelman to acquire the British retailer for $:760 million, or about $1.2 billion. Mr. Edelman said he was prepared to offer 185 pence, or $2.89, a share for Storehouse, subject to several conditions including approval by Storehouse's board of directors.

title: K Mart Coupons
description: The K Mart Corporation, the nation's second-largest retailer after Sears, Roebuck & Company, said yesterday that it would hold a one-day double-couponing promotion in all its 2,200 stores today to increase store traffic and help its profits. For the day, the chain will discount an item by twice the stated value of each manufacturer's coupon presented by a customer.

title: Mets Let Go of Leach and Game
description: The Mets traded Terry Leach to the Kansas City Royals today for a minor league player, and cleared the way for the long-awaited arrival of David West, their prime pitching prospect, who joined the team tonight as its No. 6 starter and No. 2 left-hander in the bullpen.

title: Civil Suit Filed Against Marcoses
description: With Ferdinand E. Marcos reportedly in grave condition in a Honolulu hospital, Federal prosecutors in New York yesterday moved to guarantee claims against his fortune in the event of his death.

title: Agency Proposes Shift in Information Policy
description: The Office of Management and Budget yesterday released proposed guidelines on dissemination of public information that point to a significant reversal in the Federal Government's policy of favoring the private sector for publishing Government data.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 11.

title: Check-Up For Trees
description: It's time to get a tree-care professional to check your large shade trees. First, do some checking yourself, so that you will know what to show the expert.

title: Bellevue Gets Warning On Psychiatric Ward
description: Bellevue Hospital Center was warned by a national monitoring commission yesterday that its prison psychiatric ward may lose its accreditation within six months unless improvements are made.

title: Arrest in a Theft From New York City
description: A $39,000-a-year accountant working for New York City used a loophole in the city's computerized accounting system to divert $1 million to his own bank account and lived the high life in Florida, city officials charged yesterday.

title: I Forgive Goethe, Tolstoy and, Above All, Mozart
description: LEAD: Whenever I stage an operatic masterwork, I come out of the experience enriched by new knowledge. Of such master works, ''Le Nozze di Figaro'' seems to be the one that amazes me the most. It quickly revealed to me how inaccurate the common image of Mozart is, now made popular by the play and film ''Amadeus.

title: 19 Children Hurt on Thruway
description: A school bus filled with students from Buffalo rammed a second loaded bus today during a heavy downpour on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, sending 19 children to hospitals, the authorities said. Children's Hospital in Buffalo was treating 15 children, ages 9 to 11, said a spokeswoman. At Mercy Hospital in Kenmore, four children were being treated for bruises, sprains and possibly a few broken bones, a spokeswoman said. All of the students were from Buffalo Public School No. 6. The accident happened about 3 P.M.

title: Kabul Reaction to Bush Mixed
description: The Soviet-backed Government in Kabul has welcomed President Bush's affirmation that the United States will seek a political settlement of the war in Afghanistan. But it rejected any suggestion that President Najibullah should step down as a condition for peace talks.

title: City Ballet Appoints Executive Director
description: The New York City Ballet has announced the appointment of William P. Wingate as executive director of the company, effective July 1. He succeeds Charles V. Raymond, who resigned last year.

title: Acclaimed Restaurant Is Changing Hands
description: One of America's most acclaimed restaurants, Le Francais in Wheeling, Ill., is changing hands.

title: The 'Canary' Who Seeks The Belmont
description: It started to get away when Arthur B. Hancock 3d was 13, returning to the family home, which is not exactly like any other family home in America, but is, in fact, Claiborne Farm.

title: Poor Parent Charge Dropped For Mother of Gang Member
description: A judge dismissed charges Friday against a mother accused of failing in her parental duties by allowing her son to run with a gang. It was the first case brought under a new California law aimed at the parents of gang members.

title: STEALTH BOMBER IS GIVEN GO-AHEAD
description: The Secretary of the Air Force, Donald B. Rice, said today that the Bush Administration planned to go ahead with the Stealth bomber program despite its cost and Congressional opposition.

title: Kremlin Dismayed, Aide Says
description: The Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that the Kremlin was surprised by China's crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators and that the Soviet authorities were ''extremely dismayed'' at Beijing's actions.

title: A 17-DAY FESTIVAL OF WORKS BY BALCK ARTISTS
description: Clowns and a storyteller; musicians, actors and dancers; art galleries and a fashion museum are all part of the three-borough, 17-day Audelco Black Arts Festival that is being held outdoors and indoors, in cabarets, churches and theaters through June 25.

title: Your Money; Popularity Grows For Incentive Pay
description: The millions of Americans who hope for a salary increase might well expand their horizons. Incentives and perquisites are the most rapidly growing areas of executive compensation, and they are starting to filter down to middle management, said Avery E. Neumark, a partner in Ernst & Whinney.

title: New Charges Against Inmate Are 'a Stopgap,' Actress Says
description: Theresa Saldana, the actress whose life has been threatened from prison by the man convicted of knifing her seven years ago, said Thursday that she was pleased that her attacker was facing new charges. But she said she still feared that he would be freed from Soledad Prison someday.

title: A Wet Track Could Dampen Bid for Crown
description: Rain continued to soak Belmont Park yesterday on the eve of the 121st Belmont Stakes, raising the possibility that Sunday Silence's bid today for racing's Triple Crown could be settled as much by the track condition as by the colt's ability.

title: 'Born Yesterday' Closing
description: ''Born Yesterday,'' a revival of the 1946 comedy by Garson Kanin, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the 46th Street Theater. The play, directed by Josephine R. Abady and co-starring Edward Asner and Madeline Kahn, will have run for 153 regular performances and 13 previews.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Playground Safety
description: It's important to inspect and maintain outdoor playground equipment, and now is a good time to do it. Playground experts recommend that for safety, pressure-treated wood, which is prepared with chromated copper arsenate, be sealed with water-repellent sealer, and that for durability, all wood be sealed. Many brands of sealer are available at hardware stores and home centers. $ Playground Equipment Care Wooden swings, slides, climbers Smooth sharp edges and remove splinters; treat with water-repellent wood sealer; recess protruding bolt ends or replace with capped nuts. Metal swings, slides, climbers Tighten loose hardware twice monthly; smooth sharp edges with emery cloth or file; replace conventional nuts with capped nuts; lubricate moving parts and remove rust. Swing attachments Test ropes or chain monthly with adult weight; smooth sharp edges of chain links; close any open hooks; make sure anchors remain secure. Sandbox Remove debris; dampen sand to prevent blowing; cover when not in use; replace old sand. Ground cover Keep playground area covered with 3- to 6-inch-thick layer of shredded wood chips or bark. Under swings, slides and climbing equipment, increase depth of cover to 9 inches.

title: After These Messages
description: We had a fierce struggle with the fax installer. He couldn't believe we didn't want a fax in the office. ''You are joking,'' he said, starting on a fax installation despite our warning. Apparently everybody wants a fax. It is the hottest-selling toy since Cabbage Patch dolls.

title: Chang to Meet Edberg in Final of French Open
description: Seventeen-year-old Michael Chang of Placentia, Calif., turned in another display of gutsy tennis here today, winning a 4-hour-5-minute match with Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, 6-1, 5-7, 7-6, 7-5, to become the youngest male player to reach the final of the French Open or any other Grand Slam tournament.

title: Court Records Say That Schiff Was Informant
description: Irwin Schiff, a mob-connected businessman who was shot to death in a Manhattan restaurant in 1987, gave Federal authorities information about corruption in New York City, including details of bribe-taking by former Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes, according to court records in Newark.

title: The Reagan Doctrine in Southwest Africa - More U.S. Aid for Savimbi?  It Will Heat Up The Civil War
description: Despite great progress toward peace in southwestern Africa, the Bush Administration is reportedly seeking a substantial increase in covert military aid to Unita insurgents in Angola. Congress should resist. The Administration has contended that militarily strengthening Unita, or the Union for the Total Independence of Angola, would advance a process of ''national reconciliation.''

title: Bush Before the Press: A Tack That Is 'Natural'
description: President Bush dispensed with the dramatic stride down the red-carpeted hallway, and he did not make it a point to call on reporters wearing his favorite color (blue). He had the lectern moved away from the doorway in the middle of the East Room to a less conspicuous spot on the south side, where he could sidle in and just begin taking questions.

title: Dollar High Against Yen And Mark
description: The dollar rose sharply yesterday, again surpassing 2 West German marks and topping 146 yen, its highest level since October 1987.

title: About New York; A Visit by Artists From the Top Of the World
description: All things considered, Judas Ullulaq said, he'd rather be hunting polar bears. Angus Cockney, who recently walked across shifting ice to the North Pole, allowed as how it was nice to be on firm ground. Barnabus Arnsungaq, famed for carving stone musk oxen, thought trees a tremendous treat.

title: It's a Long Way Away, But the Work Is Grand
description: In one of the more obscure outposts for one of the world's most traveled peoples, 60 Irish workers are living near the brooding woodlands beyond Moscow on two floors of a dim airport hotel.

title: Reversal in the South Seas
description: Sometimes the difference between violent action films and pure exploitation is very easy to see. ''Lady Terminator'' may sound like a female counterpart of the Arnold Schwarzenegger film ''The Terminator.'' In fact, it is a vile reversal of those nauseating movies whose point is to show naked women being hacked to pieces. Here, a woman cursed by the spirit of a vengeful South Sea beauty mutilates men, when she isn't shooting randomly into crowds of innocent people or slicing out her own eyeball.

title: Dexter Nukes Wins Classic
description: Dexter Nukes took the lead at the top of the stretch tonight and scored a convincing 1 1/2-length victory over Britt's Best in the final of the $500,000 New Jersey Classic.

title: Patents; A Method to Detect Alzheimer's Disease
description: J. Leslie Glick, a cellular physicist and biotechnology entrepreneur, has patented a method of detecting Alzheimer's disease and other forms of dementia before the symptoms become apparent.

title: Environmental Rules Are Killing Gas Stations
description: To the Editor:

title: Fatal Pipeline Back in Service
description: Despite last-minute legal efforts by angry residents, fuel started flowing again today through the pipeline that exploded here last month, destroying part of a neighborhood just 13 days after a runaway train disaster.

title: Bush Names Envoy to Vatican
description: President Bush has chosen Thomas Melady, former president of a Catholic university, to be the new American Ambassador to the Vatican, the White House announced today.

title: Klima in Court Again
description: Petr Klima of the Detroit Red Wings waived a preliminary examination yesterday in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., on drunken-driving and other charges stemming from a his most recent run-in with the law.

title: Legacy of an Urban Priest
description: Tomorrow at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the Episcopal Diocese of New York will bid farewell to its Bishop of 17 years, the Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr. He will end his career as he began it over 40 years ago as a young seminarian in Chelsea: an urban priest.

title: CORPORATE RAIDER GUILTY ON 9 COUNTS IN WALL ST. FRAUD
description: Paul A. Bilzerian, the corporate raider and chairman of the Singer Company, was convicted yesterday of nine counts of securities fraud, conspiracy and making false statements to the Government.

title: Lyn Murray, 79, Dies; Composed Film Scores
description: Lyn Murray, a composer and arranger for radio, television, theater and film for more than 50 years, died of cancer May 20 in Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 79 years old and lived in Pacific Palisades, Calif.

title: Graffiti Come Out of Subway Into Light of Day
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the front page of Weekend yesterday with an article about flea markets in New York misidentified the market shown at the top. It was the Annex Antiques Fair and Flea Market on the Avenue of the Americas at 24th Street, not a 67th Street market.

title: Hiker, Legs Broken, Survives Through Grit and Rainwater
description: A hiker who suffered a fall that left her with two broken legs and injured wrists crawled on her elbows for two days and drank water from rain and hail before being rescued Wednesday.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of Shabuoth, the Feast of Weeks, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended today in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Executive Wed To Dee Durham
description: Dee Durham, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Davis Godfrey Durham of Wilmington, Del., and David Hammond Goodman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome D. Goodman of Saddle River, N.J., were married yesterday in a Quaker ceremony at Center Meeting, a meetinghouse in Centerville, Del.

title: Bush to Ask Sharp Cutback In Key Source of Acid Rain
description: President Bush will urge a 10-million-ton annual reduction in sulfur dioxide emissions by public utilities, the chief source of acid rain, as part of a major alteration of the Clean Air Act, senior Administration officials say.

title: Nevelson Estate Is the Focus of a Battle
description: One year after Louise Nevelson's death at the age of 88, the sculptor's estate is the focus of a struggle that pits her only child and legal heir, Myron (Mike) Nevelson, against her longtime assistant, Diana MacKown.

title: Patents; Blood Sample Gives Doctors 'Report Card'
description: Alex M. Saunders, a pathologist in San Carlos, Calif., has invented a chemical ''report card,'' made from a single sample of blood, that could help physicians determine how carefully their patients have followed instructions.

title: Another Republican Smear?
description: The grace of Thomas Foley permits President Bush to avoid more persistent questions on the scurrilous intimations circulated by the Republican National Committee about the new Democratic Speaker of the House. ''I think that Speaker Foley, a most honorable man who obviously was done a terrible ill service to by this, is correct when he says let's get it behind us,'' Mr. Bush told reporters at his news conference Thursday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BASEBALL Wichita State in Finals: Todd Dreifort drove in three runs, including the go-ahead run with a sixth-inning double, and Mike Wentworth scored three runs with a homer as Wichita State earned a berth in the College World Series championship game with a 12-9 victory yesterday over Florida State. Wichita State's opponent in Omaha today is Texas, which beat Louisiana State, 12-7, in the other semifinal Thursday.(AP) CYCLING Frenchman Increases Lead: Laurent Fignon of France outsprinted his top rivals in La Spezia to win the 20th stage of the Tour of Italy yesterday, increasing his overall lead. Two stages remain in the race.(AP) GOLF Rizzo Wins Second Round: Patti Rizzo posted a second round of 14 points for a total of 28 to win $4,000 in the $400,000 Pat Bradley International tournament yesterday in High Point, N.C. Myra Blackwelder won $2,000 for 26 points. Under the modified Stableford scoring, birdies are worth 3 points, pars score nothing and bogeys cost a point. After falling to 16 points with a bogey at her ninth hole, Rizzo sank an 8-foot putt for birdie at 10, and followed with an 18-footer for 22 points.(AP) Player Leads Seniors: Heavy rain and strong wind knocked out power and blew down trees at the Senior Tournament Players Championship yesterday in Ponte Vedra, Fla. But that didn't stop Gary Player. The three-time Masters champion shot a six-under-par 66 on the 6,646-yard course at Sawgrass Valley for a one-stroke lead over Butch Baird.(AP) HORSE RACING Long Shots in Nassau: Forever Silver and Baltic Fox, the two longest shots in the field, led their five rivals on a fruitless chase through the slop to finish first and second in the $118,600 Nassau County Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park. Forever Silver, who paid $19.40 for $2 to win, scored by four lengths. Baltic Fox, a 14-1 shot, was second by three lengths over Brian's Time. Forever Silver, a 4-year-old Silver Buck colt trained by Stanley (Skippy) Shapoff, ran the mile and an eighth under Jacinto Vasquez in 1:46 4/5.

title: Johnson's Leg Injury Hurts Lakers
description: The Los Angeles Lakers are battered. In their last two games, they have been beaten. Will a return to their home court change things? If not, the Detroit Pistons will soon be the National Basketball Association champions.

title: Lots of Worse Things to Be Alarmed About Than the Lottery
description: To the Editor:

title: Matilda Cuomo in Settlement
description: A bitter dispute between Matilda Cuomo, the wife of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, and some of her family over her father's $13 million estate has been settled, a lawyer for the Governor's wife said yesterday. The lawyer, Peter Johnson Jr., said the settlement was reached during a conference Tuesday at Nassau County Surrogate's Court attended by Mrs. Cuomo, her mother and the other family members involved. Terms of the settlement were not announced.

title: Together, We Can Make Hospitals Work Residency's a Sweatshop
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rocky Period Lies Ahead For Washington and Beijing
description: With the hard-liners having emerged in control for the time being in Beijing, the Bush Administration has begun to wrestle with how to relate to a China that is no longer advancing toward more openness but rather toward increased repression.

title: McDonnell Receives Orders for 24 Planes
description: The world's leading aircraft makers continued to announce significant new orders for civil airliners today as the industry's leading manufacturers and buyers did business at the Paris Air Show.

title: Virginia's Gubernatorial Contest Is Viewed as Tight as It Heats Up
description: Never before in the long history of Virginia politics has there been a gubernatorial contest quite like the 1989 race.

title: Sather Is Sanguine At Fuhr's Retirement
description: Grant Fuhr's splendid play was an essential part of four Stanley Cup championships in the last six years for the Edmonton Oilers. But Coach Glen Sather did not seem overly concerned by the goaltender's sudden announcement late Thursday that he plans to retire from hockey at the age of 26 with five years remaining on a contract that pays him $400,000 to $600,000 a year.

title: Bridge; Remorseful fates compensate for a player's disappointment.
description: One would like to think that the fates are even-handed: If they administer a heavy blow, they compensate with generosity. This certainly was the recent experience of Rene Ducheyne of The Hague.

title: Producer Prices Up 0.9% in May
description: Prices at the producer level jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent in May after two months of reassuringly modest inflation, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Woman Suing Detroit Mayor Is Investigated
description: Undercover police officers investigated a woman's relationships with other men after she filed a paternity suit against Mayor Coleman A. Young, a newspaper reported today.

title: Antonio Macedo, 82; Led Portugal Socialists
description: Antonio Macedo, a former leader of the Portuguese Socialist Party, died today. He was 82 years old. Mr. Macedo retired from politics in 1987 but remained the honorary president of the party.

title: Brooklyn Bridge Show
description: The Anchorage at the Brooklyn Bridge, the site of a continuous array of arts installations, is itself the subject of a new exhibition on the light and sound potential of space. The exhibition, sponsored by Creative Time Inc., will will open at the Anchorage, Cadman Place West and Front Street, Brooklyn Heights, on June 22 at 8 P.M. with a video performance piece by Jessie Jane Lewis and will run through Aug. 13. Viewing hours for the installations are Thursday through Sunday, noon to 6 P.M. Free admission. Information: 619-1955.

title: Koch Campaign a Shadow of '81 and '85
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch was asked a few days ago about yet another political club that had refused to endorse him, this time a Greenwich Village club that had been founded by his supporters and lobbied by his aides.

title: Code Stolen For Macintosh
description: Apple Computer Inc. said today that the copyrighted source code for its Macintosh computers had been stolen and illegally distributed through the mail by unknown thieves.

title: Odds Favor Ex-Mayor In Jersey City's Runoff
description: Sound trucks ply the streets, and reports of roving vandals tearing down campaign posters are relayed to campaign headquarters. Another city election is at hand.

title: Weapon Plant Dumped Chemicals Into Drinking Water, F.B.I. Says
description: Employees at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant in Colorado twice discharged toxic chemicals into creeks leading to drinking water supplies in the Denver area last November, according to a Justice Department affidavit made public today.

title: Court Refuses to Block Move by Time Inc.
description: The Delaware Chancery Court denied a motion by Paramount Communications Inc. late yesterday for a temporary restraining order to prevent Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. from swapping stock in each other to protect their proposed $18 billion merger.

title: A Flat Sentence Falls Flat
description: Seven years ago in Los Angeles, a deranged man named Arthur Jackson viciously stabbed a young actress, Theresa Saldana. He was convicted and sentenced to prison for 12 years. While confined, he continued his murderous obsession with Ms. Saldana. Yet for a time this week, prison officials were worried that they would have to release him, leaving Ms. Saldana terrified and the public incredulous.

title: Bush Election Finance Plan Would Sharply Curb PAC's
description: President Bush plans to propose major changes in the way campaigns are financed, including a ban on most contributions to individual candidates by political action committees, White House officials said today.

title: DON'T JOIN REGIME, WALESA IS URGING
description: Declaring that Solidarity seeks ''not to rule, only to exercise control, and to broaden democracy and freedom,'' Lech Walesa said today that he would urge the union's newly elected legislators not to join a Communist-led government.

title: Books of The Times; Hillerman Adds Tribal Rites of Washington to the Navajos'
description: Talking God By Tony Hillerman 239 pages. Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: U.S. Vetoes a U.N. Resolution Condemning Israel
description: The United States today vetoed a resolution before the Security Council condemning Israel's policies in the occupied territories.

title: MOYNIHAN JEERED AT CHINA PROTEST
description: A day of protests that began with some 12,000 people parading their sorrow and anger through the rain-drenched streets of Chinatown to mourn students slain in China ended yesterday with a United Nations rally at which Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan was booed off the stage.

title: Canseco Arranging Plea
description: Michael Stepanian, a lawyer for Jose Canseco, said Thursday the Oakland Athletics slugger would plead no contest to the gun-related charges brought against him in April. A loaded handgun was found in Canseco's car at the University of California Medical Center in San Francisco, which Canseco was visiting for examination of a wrist injury.

title: Klein to Sell His Horses
description: Eugene V. Klein, a three-time Eclipse Award winner as North America's leading thoroughbred owner, has decided to get out of horse racing, he said today.

title: Mobile Phones, as Prices Drop, Aren't Just for Work Anymore
description: Portable phones that can be used just about anywhere, while still very expensive to operate, are shrinking in price, size and weight. One model fits in a shirt pocket. And at least one communications expert says he thinks they will eventually become as common as the wristwatch.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JUNE 10, 1989
description: Economy

title: Rainout Gives Injured Yanks Day to Rest
description: It rained again on the Yankees yesterday, but that's becoming old news. It always rains on the Yankees.

title: Korea's Boom Slows Just a Bit
description: A rash of labor disputes, currency pressures and other uncertainties are shaking South Korea's economy this year. But that means economic growth has slipped from a spectacular rate to one that is merely extraordinary.

title: Immigrant Achieves Top Rank In Class
description: When the Gomes family came to New York City eight years ago from a village in Bangladesh, they hoped America would provide the three daughters with possibilities that did not exist at home.

title: U.S. Acts to Repay Interned Non-Japanese Too
description: The Justice Department, already planning to give $20,000 apiece to 60,000 Japanese-Americans as reparation for their World War II internment, says it wants to compensate members of their families who are not of Japanese heritage.

title: Black Clergy Set to Preach About AIDS
description: Ten of New York City's leading black clergymen are preaching this weekend about the growing threat of AIDS to minorities.

title: After 17-Month Inquiry, Senate Panel Says U.S. Has Failed Indians
description: After investigating for 17 months, collecting a million pages of documents and holding 20 days of public hearings, a Senate panel is preparing a report detailing what its chairman calls the Government's failed responsibility to Indians.

title: Many U.S. Travelers Are Canceling Trips to China Through August
description: Louis Weinberg, a professor of electrical engineering and mathematics at City College, had been planning for some time for the International Conference on Circuits and Systems that had been scheduled for Nanjing on July 6 and 7.

title: Second Round Called In Westchester for Rain
description: Wade Cagle, tournament supervisor for the PGA Tour, ordered a suspension of the second round of the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic today in another of many interruptions by rain on this year's circuit.

title: To Clear New York's Indoor Air
description: After 13 years of public debate, more than a fewlegislative wrangles and a court-rebuked effort from the State Public Health Council, it looks as if New York State may finally get a law to regulate public smoking - and help millions of its citizens breathe easier. If so, special credit will be due to Assemblyman Alexander Grannis, who has labored for such a law for 13 years; Gov. Mario Cuomo, and Senator Michael Tully, chairman of the Senate Health Committee.

title: The Tale of a Young Victim Reflects A Land of Newly Shattered Families
description: His father still cries every day, perhaps because he feels partly to blame. His mother and four sisters cry too, for he was the youngest child, the only son, and the family's hope.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Yoshiro Araki, a Japanese banker, described his position incorrectly. He was chairman of the Fuji Bank Ltd., the parent company of the Fuji Bank and Trust Company.

title: Daewoo Warns on Strike
description: South Korea's giant Daewoo business group threatened this week to shut down its debt-ridden shipyard subsidiary if workers went on strike. The Government in March disclosed an aid package involving loans of 400 billion won ($600 million), saying it would not allow the yard to collapse, taking 13,000 jobs with it. But shipyard workers voted on Wednesday to strike despite a Government warning that they would have to forgo pay demands if the yard, with debts of $1.8 billion, received the rescue plan.

title: KEY RATES
Patents; A Design to Start A Fusion Reaction
description: Although the excitement over claims of achieving ''cold fusion'' has now subsided into skepticism and disappointment, research continues on older approaches to harnessing the power that fuels the sun.

title: First Ohio Study
description: First Ohio Bankshares, based in Toledo, said yesterday that its board of directors had begun to review strategic options, including the sale of the company, continued independence, affiliation with another bank or the purchase of other banks. Stock of the banking company, whose major subsidiary is the First National Bank of Toledo, rose $3 a share yesterday, to $31.25, in over-the-counter trading. First Ohio, with assets of $992.8 million, earned $7.6 million in 1988, including $2.4 million that resulted from a change in accounting practices. In 1987, the company earned $8 million.

title: British Take New Look at Hong Kong Policy
description: The British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, will visit Hong Kong in early July to assess problems in the British colony after the crackdown in Beijing, the Foreign Office said today.

title: Patents; A Broader Use for AZT
description: The Burroughs Wellcome Company, the United States subsidiary of Wellcome Foundation Ltd. of Britain, received a patent this week on the use of the drug AZT as a treatment for people who are HIV positive but have not yet developed AIDS-related symptoms. Wellcome is the sole manufacturer of AZT, under the name Retrovir, and had previously received a patent on its use as a treatment for people who were already ill. The Food and Drug Administration has approved AZT as a treatment for patients with severe infections of the AIDS virus, but the drug is still being investigated for broader use and in combination with other drugs.

title: Two Families Cross Color Lines to the Real World
description: When they shopped for houses, the Harris family and the Sprague family each had a question that is not so unusual among home buyers: What color are the neighbors?

title: Roe Wants to Transfer
description: Matt Roe, a starting guard at Syracuse, has asked for and received permission from the university's athletic department to contact other schools about transferring, Syracuse officials said yesterday.

title: Relaxed Reagan Finds Plenty to Do in 'Retired' Life
description: Ronald Reagan will bypass Washington this weekend when he travels from here to Britain and France for his first overseas visit since leaving the White House, and perhaps that is fitting.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My credibility was used to get a result. If I were a Democrat, I would say that Jim Watt engaged in influence-peddling.'' - Former Interior Secretary James G. Watt, on his dealings with Federal housing projects. [ 1:1. ]

title: 4 A.M. Start for Trading Is Foreseen by N.A.S.D.
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers is making plans to allow trading in more than 200 securities to start at 4 A.M., Eastern time, officials of the organization said yesterday.

title: Review/Ballet; A Tribute Full of Surprises for Jerome Robbins
description: The New York City Ballet's annual spring gala on Thursday night was billed as ''A Salute to Jerome Robbins in his 70th Birthday Year.'' But what do you give a birthday boy whose recent presents already include a gaggle of coveted Tony Awards for his Broadway show?

title: INSIDE
description: Producer Prices Jump; Special Factors Are Blamed

title: China Assails Top Dissident
description: China's television news said Fang Lizhi, the dissident who took refuge in the United States Embassy, is the real villain in the bloodshed. Page 5.

title: Vietnam-I.M.F. Talks
description: Vietnam hopes to complete an economic reform package with the International Monetary Fund next month that should unlock new funds for the the country, a senior banking official, Nguyen Cong Hai, said Thursday. He said an agreement would involve the settling of Vietnam's arrears with the bank of $135 million and I.M.F. approval for radical measures to reduce inflation, eliminate subsidies and promote exports.

title: Donald Katz, 81, Dies; Oil Engineering Expert
description: Donald L. Katz, a retired educator, chemical engineer and internationally known expert on oil engineering, died May 29 at his home in Ann Arbor, Mich., after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: The Call Goes Out From New Jersey: Newarks of the World Unite!
description: Two years ago, officials of Newark, Calif., considered changing their town's name to avoid being mistaken for the ''old rusty industrial city in New Jersey.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-7 Deng Xiaoping appeared on TV with a group of nine other top officials, apparently resolving the question of who runs China. He expressed no remorse for the killing of hundreds, perhaps thousands, of civilians. Page 1 China names a culprit 5 Shanghai protesters defiant 7 Tale of a young victim in Beijing reflects a broken land 7 Rockier U.S.-China relations are emerging as the Bush Administration grapples with the question of how to relate with the hard-liners who have taken control in Beijing. 5 Chinese students at U.S. universities are ignoring the library and lab in favor of a task they consider most crucial: relaying information to keep the democracy movement alive. 6 Moynihan is booed off stage at Chinese protest at the U.N. 6 Travelers cancel China trips 6 A top Salvadoran was assassinated as he left his house. No one immediately took responsibility for slaying the official, the top civilian adviser to the new President. 1 The Soviet congress ended its session of 13 days with Andrei Sakharov saying the assembly had failed in their main task, to wrest control from the Communist Party elite. 1 Ethnic riots in Uzbekistan continue, Moscow reported. Gunfire has wounded scores of people, and troops are hard pressed to rout the mobs of Uzbek marauders hunting down the Meskhetian minority. 3 Lech Walesa plans to urge legislators backed by Solidarity not to join the Polish Government. He said the trade union seeks ''not to rule, but only to exercise control, and to broaden democracy and freedom.'' 3 A U.N. resolution assailing Israel for its policies in the occupied territories was vetoed by the United States in the Security Council. 3 Japan's leader has become ensnared by allegations of a sexual relationship four years ago with a former geisha who now charges him with ''immoral'' behavior. 4 Federal prosecutors file civil suit against Marcoses 3 The fifth world AIDS meeting closed with a discoverer of the AIDS virus reporting preliminary results of a new test that might help monitor the infection in a person. 32 National 8-11, 28 Toxic chemicals were discharged twice from the Rocky Flats Plant, in Colorado, into two creeks leading to metropolitan drinking water supplies in Denver, according a Justice Department affidavit. 1 A takeover artist, Paul Bilzerian, was convicted of nine counts of securities fraud, conspiracy and making false statements to the Government, in the first verdict of the Government's Wall Street inquiry. 1 James Watt said he got larger fees as a private consultant than had previously been reported and he acknowledged that his lobbying activities were not limited to the Department of Housing and Urban Development. 1 Changes in campaign finance rules, including a ban on most contributions to candidates by political action committees, are being planned in a Bush proposal, officials said. 1 A cut in sulfur dioxide emissions by public utilities, the chief source of acid rain, will be urged by President Bush as part of an amending of the Clean Air Act, officials say. 10 Development of the Stealth bomber would move forward despite its cost and strong Congressional opposition, the new Secretary of the Air Force, Donald Rice, said. 10 O.M.B. proposes reversal in data policy favoring private sector 28 The Bush news-conference style has turned out to be determindly different - in where the lectern stands and how the questions are answered -from the style of his predecessor, Ronald Reagan. 11 In Ronald Reagan's first trip abroad, the former President will travel to Britain and France this weekend. Friends say he has slipped comfortably into California life. 8 Prices at the producer level jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Government reported. Although the rise was much bigger than expected, analysts cited special factors. 35 Rates fall; bonds rally 38 Virginians will nominate a black, Lieut. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, today to be the Democratic candidate for governor. If elected, he would be the first black governor in any state. 8 To promote integration in Ohio cities, the state has distributed millions in low-interest loans to whites who buy houses in black areas and to blacks who buy houses in white areas. 8 Failed responsibility to the Indians is the subject of a report being prepared by a Senate panel. 10 U.S. would compensate non-Japanese war internees 8 Regional 29-32 Ten sermons about blacks and AIDS will be delivered this weekend in New York City, breaking what the clergymen say is silence about the disease's threat to minorities. 29 Soviet and American veterans of wars in Afghanistan and Vietnam met Thursday to talk about some things they have in common, like coming home from a futile war. 29 The first Bangladeshi to graduate at the top of her class in New York City, Magdalene Gomes, will leave Washington Irving High School as part of a diverse student group. 29 Mayor Koch's small campaign group for what seems like a daunting bid for a fourth term is far from the juggernaut that helped him amass huge victory margins in 1981 and 1985. 29 Lauder spotlights death penalty 31 Charged with diverting $1 million to his own bank account by using a loophole in a New York City computerized accounting system, a $39,000-a-year accountant was arrested at a motel in Coral Gables, Fla. 31 The mayoral election in Jersey City, to be held on Tuesday, pits Gerald McCann, a former Mayor, against Glen Cunningham, the first black to have a chance to become mayor. 30 13 Newarks celebrate name 30 The retrial of a murder suspect, Thomas Ryan, began in Riverhead, L.I., with opening statements and three witnesses, but without the prosecution's critical piece of evidence: a confession. 31 A judge orders more medical tests for Larry Davis 31

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about plans to publish a European literary and cultural review in four languages misstated the frequency of publication of The Times Literary Supplement. It is weekly, not monthly.

title: Ex-Geisha Accuses Uno Of a Dangerous Liaison
description: Less than a week after taking office with a promise to clean up Government corruption, Prime Minister Sousuke Uno has become ensnared by allegations of a sexual relationship four years ago with a former geisha who now charges him with ''immoral'' behavior.

title: Bibb Falk, Ballplayer, Dies at 90
description: Bibb Falk, who replaced Shoeless Joe Jackson after that Chicago White Sox outfielder was banished from baseball in 1920 for his part in fixing the 1919 World Series, died Thursday night after a long illness. He was 90 years old.

title: Chinese Students Keep Pressure On in the U.S.
description: Wang Qing's phone bill last month was $120, about six times what it used to be. He has been calling his wife's parents in China almost daily since student protesters began their occupation of Tiananmen Square, describing shootings, troop movements and political struggles barely mentioned in the Chinese press.

title: Tane Matsukata Dies; Japanese Educator, 71
description: Tane Matsukata, founder of the Nishimachi International School in Tokyo, died of heart failure on Thursday at Toho Medical University Hospital in Tokyo. She was 71 years old.

title: The Best Way to Noriega Is Through the Canal
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyer Says 4 Held in Park Rape Are Suspects in Earlier Stabbing
description: At least four of the six youths indicted in the rape and attempted murder of a jogger in Central Park are suspects in a gang attack a week earlier at First Avenue and 101st Street in which a street vendor was stabbed in the chest and beaten, a defense lawyer for one of the youths said last night.

title: Review/Theater; The Irrepressible Merman: Affectionate Remembrance
description: ''Hollywood shoots too many movies and not enough blondes,'' Ethel Merman once quipped when commenting on the movie ''There's No Business Like Show Business,'' in which she received top billing but Marilyn Monroe won all the attention. The crack is one of many brassy Merman one-liners that pepper ''Call Me Ethel!'', the tribute to the star at the American Jewish Theater in which Rita McKenzie re-creates Merman's voice and body language with an uncanny accuracy.

title: U.S. Says Nicaragua Ships Arms to Noriega
description: The United States today accused Nicaragua of shipping weapons to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader and said such a move was ''deeply offensive to all who support democracy in Latin America.''

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With TV in the Great Outdoors
description: Reruns or no, summer is hard on TV lovers who also love the great outdoors. Programming your VCR to tape while you're out can help, but what about baseball games, the news and anything else you would rather watch while it is being broadcast?

title: Chrysler Reducing Auto Incentives
description: The Chrysler Corporation said it will reduce the extent of its auto incentives on Saturday, superseding the program that it introduced at the beginning of April. Chrysler is removing from its program the Chrysler LeBaron convertible, the Plymouth Laser, the Dodge Caravan and diesel pickups, the Plymouth Voyager and the Jeep Wrangler. It reduced cash rebates on six models by from $250 to $1,000 in the case of the Eagle Medallion, which now carries a $1,000 discount.

title: Salvador Official Is Assassinated; Guerrillas Are Held Responsible
description: The top civilian adviser to the new Salvadoran President was assassinated today as he left his ranch-style house on the edge of the city's most exclusive neighborhood.

title: Southdown to Sell Its Pelto Oil Unit
description: Southdown Inc., a cement and concrete maker based in Houston, has put its wholly owned oil and gas subsidiary, the Pelto Oil Company, up for sale. The company said it would use proceeds from the sale to retire debt incurred in its purchase of Moore McCormick Resources for $670 million in May 1988.

title: 2 Savings Units Seized
description: Federal regulators took over two more savings institutions Thursday, bringing the total under Government control to 221. The two institutions are the Civic Savings Bank in Portsmouth, Ohio, with $101 million in assets, and Horizon Financial in Southampton, Pa., with $2.5 billion in assets.

title: Soviet Pilot Granted Asylum
description: A Soviet pilot who defected to Turkey in a jet fighter May 20 was flown to the United States today after Washington granted him asylum, the Turkish Foreign Ministry said. An Istanbul daily reported today that the pilot, Capt. Aleksandr Zuyev, defected because he said he feared that rapid change in the Soviet Union would lead to civil war.

title: Sunday Silence's Hoof Whacks Whittingham
description: The rain at Belmont this week does not seem to have dampened Sunday Silence's enthusiasm as he approaches his Triple Crown moment. In fact, the blackish son of Halo was so lively yesterday that he nearly knocked down his 76-year-old trainer.

title: A New Life for the Old
description: MY friend Susan is beginning a new life. About a month ago, she moved from a hospital into a nursing home. Susan, who is 86 years old and legally blind, spent the better part of three months in the hospital undergoing hip surgery, combating pneumonia, breathing with the help of oxygen and fighting off numerous heart and lung problems associated with aging. Yes, she had smoked all her life, but she does so no longer.

title: A Noteworthy Collection
description: This selection of paperbacks is from the New & Noteworthy column since the 1988 Christmas issue. BY SILENCE BETRAYED: Sexual Abuse of Children in America, by John Crewdson. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A journalist shows that when it comes to sexual abuse children have more to fear from their families and friends than from violent interlopers. THE BOOK AND THE BROTHERHOOD, by Iris Murdoch. (Penguin, $8.95.) A novel about lapsed revolutionaries from Oxford who decide to bankroll a friend who is writing a utopian tract. WHO WROTE THE BIBLE? by Richard Elliott Friedman. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) A scholarly hunt for Moses' ghostwriters that reads like a detective story. SAILING, by Susan Kenney. (Penguin, $7.95.) When a cancer patient's wife gives him a sailboat, he gets a grip on his life. THE RISE AND FALL OF THE GREAT POWERS: Economic Change and Military Conflict From 1500 to 2000, by Paul Kennedy. (Vintage, $12.95.) How mighty empires hasten their own demise by spending too much money on the military. JULIA PARADISE, by Rod Jones. (Penguin, $6.95.) The tale of a Shanghai psychoanalyst who cures a missionary's wife of tormenting fantasies by making love to her. SECRETS OF THE TEMPLE: How the Federal Reserve Runs the Country, by William Greider. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $12.95.) A book that demystifies the Federal Reserve Board. HER OWN TERMS, by Judith Grossman. (Ivy, $3.95.) A refugee from dreary south London finds that the Oxford literary world can be just as oppressive to women. THE PAPER: The Life and Death of The New York Herald Tribune, by Richard Kluger with the assistance of Phyllis Kluger. (Vintage, $16.95.) The history of the newspaper that gave Tom Wolfe his start. THE RABBI OF LUD, by Stanley Elkin. (Scribners, $8.95.) A fictional New Jersey rabbi presides over a congregation of the dead. CLOAK & GOWN: Scholars in the Secret War, 1939-1961, by Robin W. Winks. (Quill/Morrow, $14.95.) How Yale University has provided the Government with very well educated spies. LIFE, A USER'S MANUAL, by Georges Perec. Translated by David Bellos. (Godine, $14.95.) Complex word games and characters that include a millionaire who makes jigsaws that he himself must solve. DANGEROUS DOSSIERS: Exposing the Secret War Against America's Greatest Authors, by Herbert Mitgang. (Ballantine, $4.95.) The Federal Bureau of Investigation's secret files on Sinclair Lewis, William Faulkner and other literary suspects. ANTHILLS OF THE SAVANNAH, by Chinua Achebe. (Anchor/Doubleday, $7.95.) A Nigerian novelist's tale of three friends who try to run a country. UNDER THE EYE OF THE CLOCK: The Life Story of Christopher Nolan, by Christopher Nolan. (Delta, $7.95.) A paralyzed poet tells how he learned to flex the muscles of his mind. CAPOTE: A Biography, by Gerald Clarke. (Ballantine, $12.95.) A mesmerizing account of Truman Capote's lifelong masquerade ball. WHO KILLED CBS? The Undoing of America's Number One News Network, by Peter J. Boyer. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) A horror story about the decline of Edward R. Murrow's old aerie. EMPEROR OF THE AIR, by Ethan Canin. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $7.95.) In one of these short stories, a high school astronomy teacher's campaign to save an old elm tree threatens to erupt into a neighborhood war. HEROES OF THEIR OWN LIVES. The Politics and History of Family Violence: Boston 1880-1960, by Linda Gordon. (Penguin, $8.95.) A history of one society's attitudes toward child abuse, incest and wife beating. LIVES OF THE TWINS, by Rosamond Smith. (Avon, $3.95.) Joyce Carol Oates's pseudonymous novel about a woman who has a secret affair with her therapist's estranged identical twin. FAMILY MEMORIES: An Autobiographical Journey, by Rebecca West. Edited by Faith Evans. (Penguin, $7.95.) Surprisingly absorbing recollections about the writer's relatives. SOMEONE WAS HERE: Profiles in the AIDS Epidemic, by George Whitmore. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) Three true stories about victims of the AIDS virus by a man who has since died of the disease. SPENCE + LILA, by Bobbie Ann Mason. (Perennial/ Harper & Row, $6.95.) In a novel by the author of ''In Country,'' a farmer helps his wife survive breast cancer. THE TENANTS OF TIME, by Thomas Flanagan. (Warner, $5.95.) A historical novel about three Irishmen. THE PREDATORS' BALL: The Inside Story of Drexel Burnham and the Rise of the Junk Bond Raiders, by Connie Bruck. (Penguin, $8.95.) The rise and fall of Drexel Burnham Lambert and its West Coast Wunderkind, Michael Milken. THE ARK SAKURA, by Kobo Abe. Translated by Juliet Winters Carpenter. (Vintage International, $8.95.) Inside a hollowed-out mountain, a Japanese beggar assembles a group of outcasts intent on surviving nuclear war. THE YELLOW WIND, by David Grossman. Translated by Haim Watzman. (Delta, $8.95.) A young Israeli novelist spends a season among the West Bank Palestinians. WHATEVER HAPPENED TO GLOOMY GUS OF THE CHICAGO BEARS? by Robert Coover. (Collier/Macmillan, $7.95.) A novel about an ambitious young Quaker named Richard Nixon who becomes a football star. DUSK: And Other Stories, by James Salter. (North Point, $7.95.) Laconic stories about exiles and drifters. QUINN'S BOOK, by William Kennedy. (Penguin, $8.95.) A young newspaperman tries to win the heart of Maud Fallon, the beautiful enigma he saved from drowning when she was 12 years old.

title: Productivity Is More (or Less) Than a Hard Day's Work
description: ''Productivity's Little Secret: Hard Work,'' a Business Forum article appearing on May 14 by Dan Subotnik, prompted an unusually large response from readers. Some of their comments follow. To the Editor:

title: Test On Skills Is Warped
description: TO protect citizens from themselves, the state sometimes produces a well-intentioned program that eventually becomes so warped from its original intent that it causes grave dangers. The New Jersey High School Proficiency Test is such a program. Some background: People were (and are) appalled by the limited skills in reading, writing and mathematics of public high school graduates, especially those of poor and urban high schools. Since local districts either could not or would not handle the problem, the state stepped in.

title: Journalists Given Ford Prizes
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford has presented the second annual Gerald R. Ford Prizes for military affairs and Presidential reporting to Richard Halloran, military correspondent of The New York Times, and David Hoffman, a White House correspondent for The Washington Post. The prizes, $5,000 each from the Gerald R. Ford Foundation in Grand Rapids, Mich., were awarded Monday. Mr. Halloran has reported for The Times since 1969. Mr. Hoffman has covered the White House for The Post since 1982.

title: Review/Theater; Illusion vs. Reality, in 'The Tablets'
description: Armand Schwerner's sly and sophisticated sequence of poems called ''The Tablets,'' published in the 1960's and 70's, make up a wonderful, riddling text on illusion and reality, on communication and misunderstanding and the limits of speech. These imaginative puzzles are dramatic gestures even when they only lie silent on the page. It is surprising it took so long for someone to give them theatrical voice.

title:
MUSIC;
Opera Festival Puts Accent on Enjoyment
description: LEAD: THE June Opera Festival of New Jersey was founded with the philosophy that opera ought to be accessible, enjoyable and understandable. The festival's directors, Michael Pratt and Nagle Jackson, have expanded on the theme of ensemble opera, in repertory, in the manner of the Glyndebourne Festival in

title: Reviews/Dance; Preserving Work by Predecessors
description: In solos, dancers can step before the world to make strong statements or express deep emotions. Therefore it is no surprise that modern dance -an art of rugged choreographic individualism - possesses a rich solo repertory.

title: Jerome Warshaw, 60, Executive at Brokerage
description: Jerome M. Warshaw, a first vice president of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., died of a heart attack Monday outside his home in Brooklyn Heights. He was 60 years old.

title: Long Island Journal
description: The Cloud Commute SHELDON GOLUB of Melville says that sometimes he gets a little ''woozy'' commuting. But then, doesn't everybody? Mr. Golub's ill feelings have nothing to do with sitting in bumper-to-bumper traffic or being stuck in the tunnel at Penn Station. His wooziness comes from air pockets and turbulence, for his daily commute is to Massachusetts by private plane.

title: Where's the Rest of It?
description: To the Editor:

title:
RECORDINGS;
The Dancing Man Who Also Sang Up a Storm
description: LEAD: Fred Astaire once dismissed his singing as being roughly in the same class as Bing Crosby's dancing. ''I consider this high praise because I think Fred sings very well indeed,'' Crosby responded. ''He has a remarkable ear for intonation, a great sense of rhythm, and, what is most important, he has great style - delivery, phrasing, but most of all presence.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Martinu: Cello Sonatas Steven Isserlis, cello; Peter Evans, piano. Hyperion CDA66296; CD and cassette. A surprising number of Martinu's countless works are just as appealingly fresh and cosmopolitan as are his three cello sonatas. The sonatas all contain irresistible airy melodies and swaying syncopations that make you want to wiggle in your seat, and that subtle and sometimes cocky sense of layered counterpoint that characterizes Martinu at his best. These are wonderful pieces, instantly accessible but just unusual enough to retain a sense of mystery. Steven Isserlis plays with an ingratiating lyricism, if not as much color as the music can take, and Peter Evan partners him fluently. The sound, too, is warm and inviting. -Mark Swed Barber: 'School for Scandal' Overture, Adagio for Strings, Three Essays for Orchestra and 'Medea's Dance of Vengeance' St. Louis Symphony Orchestra conducted by Leonard Slatkin. EMI 49463; CD and cassette. This collection adds luster to the record of service to American music compiled by Mr. Slatkin and his Missourians. Lyricism and introspection predominate in the six selections, which have established themselves as American classics. The pieces have a 1930's and 1940's flavor in their plain-spoken, passionate honesty. The performances are superbly disciplined yet fiery in pursuit of Barber's melancholy vision. -Andrew L. Pincus Barber: Cello Concerto; Britten: Cello Symphony Yo-Yo Ma and the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra conducted by David Zinman. CBS Masterworks MK 44900; CD and cassette. This disk explores several less central branches of the cello repertory, with brilliant results. Barber's concerto is, comparatively, one of his more astringent scores. It is good company for Britten's alternately brooding and triumphantly extrovert masterpiece. Britten's accompaniment raises the orchestra to nearly equal status with the cello soloist, perhaps the reason for calling his work a symphony. In both works, the orchestral support offered by the Baltimoreans is exemplary. Add Yo-Yo Ma's masterful playing, and this release of two important but not often heard 20th-century works is irresistible. -Paul Turok Raff: Symphony No. 5 ('Lenore'), Opus 177 The Berlin Radio Symphony Orchestra conducted by Matthias Bamert. Koch Schwann CD 311 013 H1; CD only. Joachim Raff (1822-1882) was a popular and prolific composer: among his 214 opus numbers are 6 operas and 11 symphonies. His Fifth Symphony was inspired by a German poem about a maiden whose lover, killed in war, returns as a specter; they both perish in a wild night-ride. Raff's music is structurally naive, but it does capture some of the imagery of the story, in sound reminiscent of Mendelssohn and Schumann, with suggestions of the Mahler to come. This performance, conducted by the former associate conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra, is caring and sensitive. The recorded sound is lean. - Martin Bookspan Donizetti: 'La Fille du Regiment' June Anderson, soprano; Alfredo Kraus, tenor; Bruno Campanella, conductor. EMI/Angel CDMB 7 63128; two CD's only. This is a reasonably trim and spirited run-through of Donizetti's delightful score, taken from live performances in 1986 and having at times some of the advantages that come from recording in the theater rather than in the studio. While one would probably not regret an evening spent hearing these artists at the opera, there is not much that I would especially like to hear again on the record. The conducting can turn soggy in slow passages. June Anderson has a lovely voice, but sounds tired and lacks spirit, charm and style. Alfredo Kraus has preserved his voice admirably; still, I would sooner go back to the 1975 performance (in Italian, which he sings better than the French used here) issued on Legato (SRO 513-2). For sheer vocal eclat, the new set offers little competition to the Sutherland-Pavarotti classic on London. -Will Crutchfield POP/JAZZ Jackson Browne: 'World In Motion' Elektra 60830; all three formats. Mr. Browne has been groping for his political voice for almost a decade, and on ''World in Motion,'' his most compelling album since ''The Pretender,'' his leftist rhetoric and romantic folk-rock finally blend. Mr. Browne's oratorical lyrics, his hymnlike melodies, his clear, passionate singing and a production that enriches the California folk-rock sound of the 70's with expressive, pointillistic electronics combine to evoke a high-minded vision of human possibility shaded by deep alarm. Mr. Browne's finest new songs - the bluesy ''World in Motion'' and the majestic ''Anything Can Happen'' - effect a smooth fusion of the personal and the rhetorical sides of his sensibility. -Stephen Holden The Jacksons: '2300 Jackson Street' Epic 40911; all three formats. ''We're all united/ And standing strong'' goes the title song of the Jacksons' first album as a family group in five years. The lush, official-sounding state-of-the-family message is the album's only cut in which Michael participates (as a harmony voice, along with assorted Jackson relations), and the address of the title becomes a chanted leitmotif throughout the album. With various cuts supervised by such hot producers as Teddy Riley, Michael Omartian and the team of L. A and Babyface, ''2300 Jackson Street'' sounds opulent. But beneath the gloss, the songs are formulaic. -S. H. Pere Ubu: 'Cloudland' Fontana/Polygram 838273; all three formats. Longtime Pere Ubu fans should ease into ''Cloudland'' by starting with side two, the slightly unbuttoned half of the Cleveland band's most conventional album. Perhaps to prove a point, Pere Ubu has made an album of mostly straightforward rock, with clean-cut melodies, foreground vocals, neat guitar hooks and hardly any of the band's old gleeful noise. David Thomas's lyrics (now fully audible) still dispense skewed insights about everything from parking lots to the music of ice-cream trucks, and Pere Ubu can certainly knock out post-1960's garage-rock - even a gimmicky would-be single. But those who prized Pere Ubu's old anarchic genius may wonder, as one song asks, ''What are we doing here?'' -Jon Pareles Frank Allison and Odd Sox: 'Monkey Business' Relapse 802; LP and cassette only. Relapse Records, Box 611, Plymouth, Mich. 48170. A low-budget production - recorded in Frank Allison's kitchen and onstage in Ann Arbor, Mich. - perfectly suits Mr. Allison's scrappy, hard-nosed, good-humored songs about living on the fringe of an insatiable consumer economy. His car eats cash, a girlfriend is a compulsive buyer, a broke couple can't believe they own ''So Much Junk,'' and when the singer attends ''Bart's Reunion Party,'' ''they're all doing better than me.'' The tunes are steeped in guitar-driven 1960's rock - early Beatles, Rolling Stones, Creedence Clearwater Revival - but the attitude is from the 1980's, at street level. >-J. P. Wayne Shorter, Eddie Gomez, Jack DeJohnette, Dave Liebman, Richie Beirach: 'Tribute to John Coltrane' Columbia 45136; all three formats. Despite the billing, on ''Tribute to John Coltrane'' the saxophonist Wayne Shorter only sat in with the saxophonist David Liebman's group on three of the album's five Coltrane compositions, recorded live in Japan - but when he does, the music levitates. In quick bursts and streaks, in brilliant sprints, in urgent outbursts and songful curves, Mr. Shorter's soprano saxophone solos break free and fly in ways his studio albums rarely capture. Mr. Liebman has hardened the Coltrane influence into a steady torrent of four-note groups, but Mr. Shorter's unfettered solos are cries of passion and exaltation. -J. P.

title: THE SAMURAI OF SUMMER
description: LEAD: YOU GOTTA HAVE WA By Robert Whiting. Illustrated. 339 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $17.95.

title: The Satellite Dish: Hi, Neighbor!'
description: HOW glad I was when the yuppies bought the house across the street.

title: In Chicago, Speaker Calls For Pluralism
description: The University of Chicago ended its 96th academic year with four convocation ceremonies yesterday and on Friday.

title: RETAILERS TAKE ON NEW STRATEGIES - AND CHRYSLER IN COURT
description: Thanks to the boom in the car audio business, retailers have continued to chart record aggregate sales despite their plummeting market share. But many are concerned about the growing inroads of auto makers. Last year, only 7 percent of American cars sold lacked sound systems, compared with about 17 percent in 1978. Similarly, 70 percent of all foreign cars now come with stereos, up from about 40 percent in the late 1970's.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
508 Dwellings for a West Orange Quarry
description: LEAD: A $120 million, 508-unit condominium residential community is rising in West Orange on a 44-acre rocky tract framed by a ridge climbing to 140 feet. Until six years ago, the site just off Eagle Rock Avenue had been part of a quarry.

title: GUIDE
description: CHARITY HORSE SHOW The 60th annual Ox Ridge Charity Horse Show at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club, 512 Middlesex Road in Darien, will be held Tuesday through next Sunday, featuring more than 100 classes of jumping competitions and a number of special events.

title: Ripples Awaited From Auction Splash
description: The auction last weekend of an 18th-century American desk-bookcase for the staggering price of $12.1 million at Christie's in New York represents a watershed in the field of antiques and the decorative arts. The sale figure - the highest sum paid at auction for anything other than a painting - quadrupled the record for furniture and decorations. The purchaser, according to trade sources, was the Texas financier Robert M. Bass.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: The humble 3-cent Jefferson, that squarish purple profile that seemed ubiquitous - indeed, was ubiquitous - throughout the 1940's and 50's, has come back into its own as a stamp that collectors collect.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house is heated with baseboard heating and has been troubled by gurgling and banging noises. The plumber put in a relief valve near the boiler to eliminate the gurgling noises, but said the other noises were due to expansion of the pipes and vanes. I think there is air in the pipes. Bleeder valves are in each heating zone, but I don't know how to eliminate the trapped air, nor whether this will cure the problem.

title: Question Of the Week; Did Pitino Make The Right Move?
description: Thanks to Rick Pitino (and the Knick players) for bringing the thrill of competitive basketball back to New York. Pitino is totally justified in taking the Kentucky job because of the lack of support he has received from Knick management. Also, it would be hypocritical to hold sports figures to standards we do not apply to ourselves. We all make career choices based on job security, financial considerations, whatever makes us happy, and what is best for our families. Rick Pitino is no different. DAVID R. GUZMAN Morris Heights, N.Y.

title: A Feast of Tofu In Tokyo and Kyoto
description: THE tofu restaurant Sasanoyuki is justly proud of its 300-year history in the same location in northeastern Tokyo. Its rather poetic name was given early in the restaurant's history, by a member of the imperial family who had been living at a temple nearby. As the story is told, he compared the restaurant's soybean curd to ''snow on bamboo leaves'' (in Japanese, sasanoyuki). To this day, the restaurant continues to serve only its own freshly made tofu.

title: DID THE PENALTY FIT THE CRIME?
description: There are some who will feel Paul Scatena is a noble whistle blower. The fact that he is a graduate student (although not one who worked with Dr. Frazier) may reinforce this view, because many of us know that leading professors routinely run graduate programs as feudal fiefdoms. As a third-year law student at Yale Law School, I have witnessed several instances in which professors have appropriated the intellectual property of students. The more conscientious may acknowledge these students in a footnote, but rarely give co-authorship.

title: MY MOTHER, THE WRITER: MASTER OF A THOUSAND DISGUISES
description: Several years ago, my mother began giving me unusual birthday presents. Wrapped in conventional gift paper, they pose as innocent surprises, but since she and I are both writers, every one of them is capable of sending me off on a venture of literary sleuthing. She always gives me two or three.

title: DID THE PENALTY FIT THE CRIME?
description: Nothing in the record indicates that Shervert Frazier intentionally purloined Ronald Melzack's work.

title: An Appropriate Reaction From Whittingham: Silence
