description: Charlie Whittingham, his binoculars glued to his eyes as Sunday Silence and Easy Goer dueled their way through the final turn, uttered not a sound as his opponent accelerated and left his horse behind with a quarter-mile to go in the Belmont Stakes.

title: ANYWHERE, WITH THE BEST OF COMPANY
description: The ideal summer vacation requires that a traveling companion be selected as carefully as a fine wine or a spouse. The Book Review asked several writers what character (or characters) in fiction or history they would most like to travel with, and why. Their responses follow: Roy Blount Jr. Author of ''Now, Where Were We?''

title: From City Streets To the Ballet Stage
description: LEAD: WHEN the glittering chandeliers rise slowly to the ceiling, the houselights dim and the curtains part, Daniel Sanchez is there on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera house at Lincoln Center, helping to weave the magic that casts its spell over American Ballet Theater audiences.

title: Changing, Unchanging Nantucket
description: On and off for more than two decades, I have been vacationing on Nantucket, lured by its beaches, moorlands, magnificent mansions, cobblestone streets, history as a famed whaling port and insularity. Above all, I have been enchanted by Nantucket's constancy - the sense that time has stood still for more than a century on the ''Far Away Island'' (the English translation of the Indian name Nantucket), 30 miles out in the Atlantic.

title: The Ins and Outs of Life In a Tall Neighborhood
description: ONE cold and rainy day I sent my 4-year-old son, Eddie, out to play, dressed only in his sweatpants, Mickey Mouse T-shirt and bedroom slippers. In our case, though, ''out to play'' means his scampering over to the apartment next door and saying, ''Can I play with Evan for a while?'' As simply as that, my son had an hour with a friend, and I had an hour with a sleeping baby and a good book.

title: A Greek Divorce
description: Having forced his American born wife to give up her feminist political role, Greek Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has officially given up his wife. A court in Athens granted him a divorce last week from the former Margaret Chant, after 38 years of marriage. Earlier this year, political allies of Mr. Papandreou pressured Mrs. Papandreou to step down from her prominent role in the Greek feminist movement, saying it would hurt her husband's chances for re-election this month. After the divorce, there was widespread speculation that the 70-year-old would marry his companion of recent months, Dimitra Liani, a 35-year-old former airline stewardess with whom he began living last October. Newspapers said the wedding could take place as soon as today.

title: Filling a Twin Operatic Bill From Out of Left Field
description: Glimmerglass Opera, with its pastoral, lakeside setting near Cooperstown, N.Y., has been called an American Glyndebourne, though its general director, Paul Kellogg, objects to the label, saying, ''I hope we have enough personality of our own.'' Various elements make the 15-year-old opera company unusual among regional opera troupes. It recently opened its own intimate (900-seat) theater, and its repertory, never conventional, will have a new twist this year, when Glimmerglass presents its first commission, which is also its first world premiere. The double novelty is a one-act opera, ''A Question of Taste,'' by William Schuman, which will share an evening with Mr. Schuman's other opera, ''The Mighty Casey.'' The twin bill will be performed June 24, in the first of five performances.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: If automatic focusing were truly a panacea, then all of the pictures I get back from the nearby minilab would be in perfect focus. Unfortunately, this is never the case - not for me and, I suspect, not for 99 percent of snapshooters everywhere.

title: A U.S. Angel With Millions Helps Walesa
description: When the going really gets rough, Poles often dream of a rich aunt from Buffalo.

title: Quiet Examples Of Courage
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: DID THE PENALTY FIT THE CRIME?
description: As someone whose academic career was destroyed by undisclosed objections from unidentified sources, I was not surprised by the harshness of Dr. Frazier's experience. Particularly before tenure, academic review is characterized more by star-chamber secrecy than by constitutional due process. The criminally accused have far more legal protection in our society. ROSE ROSENGARD SUBOTNIK Huntington Station, L.I.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Hudson Museum Names New Chief
description: AFTER a five-month nationwide search, the Hudson River Museum's board of trustees has chosen one of its own to lead the 70-year-old institution into a new decade. Barbara J. Bloemink, the museum's 36-year-old chief curator, is the first woman to head the administratively troubled museum, which has had five directors in the last 10 years.

title: Anthony Mohl, Investment Banker, Marries Alix de Nicolay in France
description: Alix de Nicolay, a daughter of Count and Countess Aymard-Claude de Nicolay of Paris and Savigny-Les-Beaune, France, was married yesterday to Anthony Steven Mohl, a son of Mrs. Antoine de Laire de Verdonnet of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and the late Steven Mohl. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed by l'Abbe Jacques Guillaume at the Church of St. Cassien in Savigny-Les-Beaune.

title: Hudson River Revival Returns
description: CLEARWATER'S Great Hudson River Revival had some shaky organizational moments last year in the festival's first season at Westchester Community College in Valhalla, but there were also some significant improvements.

title:
COOKBOOKS;
TWO FOR THE FAST LANE
description: LEAD: It's a fact of American life that slaving over a hot stove day in and day out is becoming almost as rare as cooking over a wood fire -leaving a vacuum that has attracted such creatures of the fast lane as frozen dinners, carry-out and the microwave oven. Speaking eloquently to this situation are two new cookbooks: 20-MINUTE MENUS (Simon & Schuster, $19.95) by Marian Burros, the New York Times food editor; and CUISINE RAPIDE (Times Books, $22.50) by Pierre Franey and Bryan Miller, respectively The Times's 60-Minute Gourmet columnist and restaurant critic.

title: DID THE PENALTY FIT THE CRIME?
description: What I found upsetting was not so much Professor Frazier's plagiarism as Paul Scatena's eagerness to nail a big gun. Anyone who would put off his doctorate to spend, for three months, ''the equivalent of a month of eight-hour days'' investigating might have his motivations considered suspect.

title: Steven Ross's Days Of Deal-Making
description: The traditional chores of a corporate chairman always bored Steven J. Ross. Dealing with the banalities of day-to-day administration, pitching the company to securities analysts and fraternizing with fellow chairmen were not for him. His love and forte has been dreaming and deal-making.

title: AMAZING SPACE
description: Something as utilitarian as a superbly organized closet or as frivolous as the elaborate trimming on a pair of curtains can make a space memorable. So can a sleek kitchen designed and placed as artfully as a giant sculpture or a master bathroom whose architectural shell is as elaborately crafted and furnished as an 18th-century drawing room.

title: THE WOUNDS OF TWO WARS
description: IT IS NOT YET A MONUMENT, MERELY an irregular four-foot stone square set on a base with a plaque on it. It sits in the middle of a field in Friendship Park, stark and solitary on this windswept Moscow morning.

title: Tick-Borne Lyme Disease Is on the Rise Among Dogs
description: VETERINARIANS on Long Island report a sharp increase in the number of dogs with Lyme disease.

title: GADGETS GALORE, FROM JUKE BOXES TO NOISE SILENCERS
description: Consumers today are building sound systems for their cars that rival those in their homes. The success of auto cassette decks has led to an avalanche of new audio products for cars. Some audiophiles are spending $10,000 or more to assemble exotic auto sound systems.

title: A Piano Giant Is Rescued From Ghostdom
description: When piano buffs get together to talk about the great ones, the names of Hofmann, Rachmaninoff, Lhevinne, Cortot and Friedman invariably come up. Seldom is the ghost of Leopold Godowsky (1870-1938) invoked. For that there might be several reasons. There never was, until a short time ago, any transfer of the Godowsky 78-r.p.m. records to LP. Another is that even considering the generally low quality of acoustic recordings (the electrical process did not begin until 1925), Godowsky's playing was dismally recorded.

title: Prospects; A Discrimination Decision
description: Last Monday, the Supreme Court ruled on an employment discrimination case, Wards Cove Packing v. Atonio. The 5-to-4 decision shifted the burden of proof of discrimination in hiring onto the plaintiff - the job seeker. Previously, it was up to the defendant, the employer, to prove it had not engaged in discriminatory hiring practices. This ruling adhered to an earlier decision, Griggs v. Duke Power Co., which allowed companies to utilize standardized tests for hiring. Four experts give their views on these rulings. Eva Clayton President, Technical Resources Ltd., a management consulting firm.

title: Reviews/Dance; Words and Dance in Pearl Primus Tribute
description: Dr. Pearl Primus may be small and soft-voiced, but she is a formidable woman who has played an important role in establishing West Indian and African dance as a viable and influential element in American cultural life. Last Sunday afternoon, 46 years after her first solo recital, Dr. Primus took over the stage of Aaron Davis Hall at City College as the honoree in the Caribbean Cultural Center's ''Osun Festival,'' its Third Annual Tribute to African Diaspora Women.

title: In Bolivia, U.S. Pumps Money Into the Cocaine War, but Victory Is Elusive
description: For the last three years, the United States has been waging a war against cocaine here, deploying troops and narcotics agents and spending millions of dollars.

title: Migration by Blacks From the South Turns Around
description: This century's northward migration of blacks to a land of plentiful jobs and racial freedom has begun to reverse as a growing number of blacks return to their Southern roots.

title: A Spiritual Emergency
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCUBINES CONFIDENTIAL
description: HAREM The World Behind the Veil. By Alev Lytle Croutier. Illustrated. 224 pp. New York: Abbeville Press. $35.

title: Beyond Dumps: What to Do With the Grass?
description: On his way to work, Roy Mayo took five plastic bags bulging with grass clippings and stuffed them in the trunk of his Buick.

title:
MUSIC;
FILLING A TWIN OPERATIC BILL FROM OUT OF LEFT FIELD . . . AND AN OPERA FROM OUTER SPACE
description: LEAD: At first glance, the career of Anthony Davis might seem to have taken a surprising turn. Fresh from the harsh reality of his 1986 opera ''X (The Life and Times of Malcolm X),'' the composer has shifted his attention to the escapist fantasy of science fiction. Instead of dealing with issues of racism, oppression and political assassination, Mr.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Dartmouth; Making Wishes Into Sweet Reality For Ill Youngsters
description: Ryan LeFevre, a giggly, affectionate, sandy-haired 4-year-old, loves to eat ice cream and romp outside with his two older brothers. But Ryan has spent most of his life in hospitals. He has histiocytosis-X, a life-threatening disease in which the body produces abnormal amounts of histiocytes, cells involved in the immune system.

title: Whatever Happened To Music?
description: A decade or so from now, when the world has awakened from the bad dream known as the 20th century, students of musical history will need to resolve many apparent paradoxes. Here is one: why did the production of exciting and durable compositions begin to fall off sharply after World War I and go into a dramatic nose dive after World War II, just when recordings, radio and other technologies were making music available to greater numbers of listeners than ever before? And here is another: why have there been so few lasting additions to the concert and opera repertories in a time when commissions, grants and academic tenure have given thousands of contemporary composers the professional status and security that might be expected to promote artistic fecundity?

title: Off Broadway Plays Sprout in Summer Theater
description: An adaptation of the stories of Breece D'J Pancake, theatrical workshops involving both Jews and Palestinians and the dark-comedic debut of a playwright still in his 20's are among this season's offerings at three of the more innovative summer theaters in the United States - challenging fare seemingly worthy of Off Broadway.

title: Laying Down Rules for Workers
description: My first boss, at the skeet range, explained the company's policies quite succinctly. ''Show up on time, work hard and don't do anything stupid, like getting shot,'' he said. ''Payday is Friday and you get Christmas off.'' He did not need a computer program to draft an employee handbook.

title: Nadine Aubort Weds Violinist
description: Nadine Eliane Aubort, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marc Aubort of New York and Montreux, Switzerland, was married yesterday in Weston, Conn., to Peter Haig Oundjian, a son of Joan Oundjian of Naples, Fla., and Haig Oundjian of London. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Susan DeSimone, a minister of the United Church of Christ, at the Norfield Congregational Church.

title: Yara Sterling Wed To J. E. Montminy
description: Yara Athena Sterling, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter C. Sterling Jr. of King George, Va., was married yesterday in Orange, Conn., to Joseph Edward Montminy, a son of Joan Frobig of Standish, Me., and the late Ralph C. Montminy. The Rev. William Kehayes performed the ceremony at the Greek Orthodox Church of St. Barbara.

title: Turning a Charitable Gift Into a Pension
description: A variety of tax law changes affecting retirement plans in recent years have combined to put the spotlight on what had been a relatively obscure investment vehicle, the charitable remainder unitrust.

title: Environmental Groups Gain in Wake of Spill
description: Public support for environmental organizations has apparently increased since March, when the largest oil spill in American history fouled the waters of Prince William Sound in Alaska.

title: Review/Piano; Beth Levin's Beethoven
description: Beth Levin, a pianist with a bold interpretive personality and a powerful technique, brought fire and originality to works by Beethoven, Chopin and Mussorgsky on Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Johnson to Take the Stand
description: Thirty-nine witnesses have appeared over the last 10 weeks, and the weight of testimony by those close to Ben Johnson seems to suggest that the sprinter not only took performance-enhancing drugs for years, but knew what drugs he was taking, what benefits they brought him and what side effects he risked.

title: To Fresh Air Children, Waves Are More Fun Than Sprinklers
description: When school lets out for the summer, Mattie Rice's children and grandchildren have all day to play in their Harlem neighborhood.

title: Maribeth Hickey Marries
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Pius X in Middletown, Conn., Mary Elizabeth Hickey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Paul Hickey of Middletown, and John Thomas Hartman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman W. Hartman of Montauk, L.I., were married yesterday. Msgr. Thomas J. Hartman, a brother of the bridegroom, officiated. The bride, who is known as Maribeth, is a nursing-care clinician at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York. She graduated from the Boston College School of Nursing. Mr. Hartman, a graduate of Cornell University, is studying for an M.B.A. degree at Harvard University.

title: Much Ado About Rockefeller Center
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Paperback Milestone
description: To the Editor:

title: Reporter's Notebook; A Catholic Crusader in Luther's Lands
description: When Pope John Paul II headed back to Rome today at the end of the 42d foreign trip of his pontificate, he had made a total of 38 addresses and spoken in 10 languages during a 10-day tour of 5 Nordic countries.

title: Eda Ergul to Wed Jeffrey Peterson
description: July wedding plans for Eda Ergul and Jeffrey Randolph Peterson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Peterson of Greenwich, Conn., have been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Necdet F. Ergul of Greenwich.

title: Traffic Alert
description: The Puerto Rican Day Parade will start at 11 A.M. today at 44th Street and Fifth Avenue and head north to 86th Street.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Softening Rents; Sluggish Market Favors Tenants Renewing a Lease
description: COMPANIES that signed leases for Manhattan office space early in this decade have reason to be cheerful as they approach the end of 10-year agreements.

title: Ms. Lierle Wed in Scotland
description: Susan Buchanan Lierle, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Burton Lierle of Ann Arbor, Mich., and Delray Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to G. William Birrell, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Andrew Birrell of Greenwich, Conn., and Figure Eight Island, near Wilmington, N.C. The Episcopal ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Halliday at the ruins of the cathedral in St. Andrews, Scotland. Ann O'Reilly and Lucy Kohlmeier were bridesmaids, and the bridegroom's father was the best man.

title: RED-HOT PASTORALE
description: SUMMER PEOPLE By Marge Piercy. 380 pp. New York: Summit Books. $19.95.

title: COOKBOOKS
description: A few years ago, while I was collaborating on a cookbook with the chef and columnist Pierre Franey, I was certain that the great popularity of recipe books would crest any minute and then dissipate. After all, who could be cooking all these dishes? How long would it take before people realized there are only so many ways to prepare a stew, grill fish, bake a cake? So with an urgency fueled by fear, I hurried.

title: Easy Goer Finally Beats Sunday Silence
description: Easy Goer finally lived up to his spectacular promise of early spring yesterday when he roared past Sunday Silence on the turn for home and won the 121st Belmont Stakes by eight lengths. In doing so, he prevented Sunday Silence from becoming racing's 12th Triple Crown winner.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Ohio; A Funny Thing Happened to Me On My Final Exam
description: Lois Bennett stood in front of an anxious crowd with nothing but her comedy. She had better be funny - one of her final grades partly depended on it.

title: Chinese in Manhattan Urge U.S. Sanctions
description: A postcard campaign was begun in Manhattan's Chinatown yesterday to urge President Bush to bring sanctions against China for the army crackdown.

title: Sprint Picks Up Steam, at Last
description: A year ago, things could not have been worse for the U S Sprint Communications Company, the nation's third-largest long-distance carrier.

title: Question Of the Week; Did Pitino Make The Right Move?
description: Rick Pitino took Boston University to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament in 1983 for the first time in 24 years. He took Providence College to the Final Four in 1987 but came up short of winning the crown. This season he led the Knicks to the second round of the playoffs, still short of the National Basketball Association finals.

title: SOVIETS AIRLIFT UZBEK REFUGEES
description: Facing continuing problems with ethnic violence in Uzbekistan, the Government has resorted to an airlift of besieged Meskhetians to refugee camps in the Moscow region, Soviet newspapers reported today.

title: A TEXAS POWER PLAY
description: ROGER STAUBACH, THE LEGENDARY quarterback of the Dallas Cowboys, was standing beside Richard E. Rainwater, the legendary Texas deal maker. Rainwater had just purchased a 20 percent interest in Staubach's real estate firm. Now, at an early morning meeting last November, he was being introduced to the staff of the Staubach Company.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: ON the occasion of the coming Independence Day holiday, let us take a look at those losers of the Revolutionary War, the Tories. We tend to think of the Tories as aristocratic dandies with lace ruffles, clutching their silk hankies in terror at the sight of the rebels. But they were nothing of the sort.

title: Art and the Holocaust: Trivializing Memory
description: Wittgenstein said it: whereof one cannot speak, one must not speak. The unspeakable draws its force and its mystery from its own silence. A 19th-century Hasidic teacher put it his own way: the cry unuttered is the loudest.

title: Community Program Succeeds in Drug Fight
description: A comprehensive community program that encourages teen-agers to avoid cigarettes, alcohol and marijuana is far more successful than programs that rely only on the schools, a new study has found.

title: A Piano Man Thanks Billy Joel
description: JOEL SILBERMAN's career as a piano man has come full circle and his life has been reaffirmed, thanks to Billy Joel, who doesn't know it.

title: As Foley Steps In, The House Needs Serious Repairs
description: THE House of Representatives is like a small town after a tornado these days.

title: Fryar Hurt
description: It was one of those sounds an athlete would rather not hear, especially when it comes from his own foot after he took an obvious misstep while running laps.

title: Keeping The Home Fires Burning (While The Masters Are Away)
description: It was a great old house like those of the 1930's movies, in which ''Long Island'' meant luxury without saying anything else. It overlooked the Sound, but that winter day when Ann Pearson and her daughter, Mandy, moved in, there wasn't much of a view. A big snowstorm had blown up, borne on strong winds. ''Spooky,'' Mandy said, looking out a window at the storm. ''But we're warm and safe in here,'' Ms. Pearson said. She drew the window down, tightly, she thought; there was a device on the sill that, if the window was loosened would set off the burglar alarm, a squalling outdoor horn, on the other end of the house.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: BRIDGEPORT;
All Hoax and Hokum Aside, Things Are Looking Up
description: LEAD: THERE is something of Phineas T. Barnum in Bridgeport Center, the new headquarters of People's Bank. Whether he would have liked the building or not, the showman and Mayor would have been delighted in the attention it has attracted.

title: Palestinian Rift in Lebanon Growing More Deadly
description: Two members of a militant Palestinian group have been killed in Lebanon in a growing power struggle among rival guerrilla factions.

title: Woman Gives Up Career to Help AIDS Patients
description: SOME people do not understand why Maureen Cassidy of Fairfield gave up a career as a cosmetics executive, and her paycheck, to work with AIDS patients.

title: JACK KEMP FACES REALITY
description: I admire Jack Kemp's belief in the power of positive inspiration to overcome problems, but I wonder why only the homeless are asked to rely on faith (''Jack Kemp Faces Reality,'' by James Traub, May 7).

title: Father's Day Gifts With a Twist on Tradition
description: Next Sunday is Father's Day, and somehow even creative people find their imaginations grinding to a halt when it comes to buying a gift. Unless there is a hobby like golf or stamp collecting to give direction to the quest, a child or wife can feel totally at sea. Hence the decision to buy something ''safe'' like a striped tie or a plain white shirt. Well, there are ties and shirts that are a bit more imaginative and still tasteful.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: New Flights To Wales

title: W. W. Saltonstall Weds Miss Cashel
description: Alison Kerry Cashel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Cashel of Boston and Fishers Island, N.Y., and William Watson Saltonstall, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Gurdon Saltonstall Jr. of Marion, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. Edward Wisneski officiated at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church on Fishers Island.

title: Miss O'Callaghan Becomes a Bride
description: Karen Lynne O'Callaghan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. O'Callaghan Jr. of Katonah, N.Y., and Frederick Geller Horan Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Horan Sr. of Short Hills, N.J., were married yesterday. The Rev. John S. O'Callaghan, a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the bride, officiated at the Church of St. Mary in Katonah.

title: Recitals by 3 Pianists and a Violinist
description: Laura Klugherz

title: Horseback Therapy for the Handicapped
description: LEAD: ALBERT CARUCCI is large for a 13-year-old. And he looks every bit the serious equestrian as he sits astride a big bay horse, wearing knee-high riding boots and a velvet helmet.

title: SHE SAID NO TO JACKIE O.
description: FABULOUS NOBODIES By Lee Tulloch. 272 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $17.95.

title: THE LATEST LEGAL FRONTIER: VIETNAM
description: TWO MONTHS AGO, OWEN D. Nee Jr., a partner in the New York law firm Coudert Brothers, found himself in a hotel conference room in Bangkok, Thailand. Along with 400 business executives and investment bankers from the capitalist centers of the world, he had come there to hear delegates from Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam explain recent economic and political changes in their nations, aimed at attracting foreign investment.

title: Earthquakes in the Communist World
description: In China, what began only weeks ago as new hope for democracy now seems to be trailing off into old repression. A Poland that imposed martial law in 1981 has just completed a free election that legitimized opposition. The new Soviet Congress does not recognize the idea of loyal opposition, but daily listens to critical voices. Other tremors shake Communism, from Hungary to Vietnam.

title: Caroline M. Rudd, Graduate Student, Weds Nicolas Woolworth Combemale
description: Caroline Meade Rudd, a daughter of Julia Meade Rudd and O. Worsham Rudd, both of New York, and Nicolas Woolworth Combemale, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard F. Combemale of New York and Winthrop, Me., were married yesterday at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York. The Rev. J. Seymour Flinn performed the ceremony.

title: Sellers Hope Auction of Condos Aids Market
description: AS the state's first condominium auction nears, condominium owners, real estate agents and developers say they are waiting to see if the auction begins a trend to reduce an oversupply of units.

title: The Creative Uses of Disability, The Restorative Functions of Art
description: In the history of art, many of the greatest creators have been repositories of enormous talent and profound disability. One thinks of Milton, who wrote the whole of ''Paradise Lost'' after he had lost all useful vision; of van Gogh, who produced some of the finest art of our times while institutionalized at Arles, or of Beethoven, who composed his greatest symphonies while he was deaf.

title: BAD TIMES ON THE BAYOU
description: LEAD: INTERSTATE HIGHWAY 10 FROM New Orleans to Baton Rouge is an engineering marvel, 79 miles and four lanes of concrete and steel, some of it on pilings, cleaving mile after mile through lush, misty swampland, connecting Louisiana's biggest city to its capital.

title: Deborah Harmon Weds a Physician In the Caribbean
description: Deborah Lynn Harmon and Dr. Robert Allen Seder were married yesterday evening by Rabbi Stephen Shaeffer at the Malliouhana Hotel on Anguilla, the West Indies. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Harmon of Weston, Conn. Dr. Seder's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Hirschel Seder of Highland Park, Ill.

And Bear in Mind (Editor's choices of other recent books of particular interest) MY SECRET HISTORY, by Paul Theroux, (Putnam, $21.95) Mr. Theroux's somewhat authobiographical novel, picaresque and rambling, is propelled by an impulse of 1930's screwball comedy; like those movies, if concerns the permanence of marriage and favors mature love as the antidote to youthful selfishness.

title:
THEATER;
Excavating in the Name of the Rose
description: LEAD: The property developers who, in the name of Thatcherian commercial thrust, are digging up London in order to disfigure it, are inadvertently making Londoners aware of their remote past. When the bulldozers move in to clear the foundation for a new office block, they uncover the remains of a Roman palace, a Mithraic temple, an Elizabethan playhouse.

title:
FILM;
Seriously, It's Comics: From Superman to Today
description: LEAD: ''Look! Monsters in Mr. Pinkster's backyard! I'm not kidding!''

title: Miss Waiculonis Has a Wedding
description: At the Harbor House in Nantucket, Mass., Christine Anne Waiculonis was married yesterday to Richard Jeffrey Roll. Cantor Raymond Smolover and the Rev. Edward Anderson, a Unitarian minister, officiated.

title: Guatemalan's Choice of Successor Stirs Fight
description: When he was elected to office in 1985 after years of military rule, President Vinicio Cerezo embodied this country's new hopes for democracy.

title: Rural Towns Fight Plans for A Dump
description: THE criteria for a site for a low-level radioactive dump narrow the choice to largely rural areas, and many elected officials feel that is one more burden for small towns.

title: Lyme Disease Spreads to Horses on the Island
description: LEAD: MICHAEL WICKS and Margery Dallas rode their horses together in a South Haven park last October. About a week later, both removed pin-sized ticks from their 8- and 18-year-old geldings.

title: Seeking Sophistication in Hotel Dining
description: THE Chardonnay Restaurant at the Long Island Marriott in Uniondale has the appearance of a first-class hotel dining room. It boasts snowy white tablecloths, sparkling crystal, impressive china, crisp professional service, a jungle of plants, soothing piano music and soaring ceilings outlined in starry lights.

title: 'Citizen Welles'
description: To the Editor:

title: Pampered and Polished, Tips to Toes
description: LEAD: MURIEL ROTHBERG had never had a manicure until her daughter treated her to a set of ''fake nails'' a few years ago. Now, she said, as she waved 10 glossy red fingertips at the Les Nails salon here: ''I've had tips, wraps, all sorts of stuff. I'm having lots of fun with it.''

title: Wedding Attire for the Smallest Guests
description: A family wedding may be a youngster's first encounter with ''serious'' clothes.

title: Sewage Runoff in L.I. Sound Closes Westchester Beaches
description: Sewage runoff caused by heavy rains forced the closing today of all Long Island Sound beaches between Yonkers and Port Chester, the Westchester County Health Department announced.

title: Distance Learning Brings Schools Closer
description: LEAD: DARLENE SOLANO, a senior, was attending a child-development class at Freeport High School when the teacher, Ellen Palazzo, asked her a question.

title: Art, Dissent and Legislative Wrath
description: IN March, amid daily protests by veterans and other patriotic-minded citizens, the School of the Art Institute of Chicago exhibited an American flag spread on the floor. The student work invited people to ''confront their feelings'' about symbols and patriotism and to step on the flag if they chose. It created a furor then, and it is creating one now.

title: Cuomo Seeks to Limit Youths' Work
description: Seventeen-year-old Brian French, a junior at the high school in this Albany suburb, worked 38 hours at the Burger King here last week, including several days on the 4-11 P.M. shift. That is too long and too late, say Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and several New York State legislators.

title: The Passing Playlets of City Politics
description: For a campaign that hasn't caught fire yet, New York's mayoral race has already been a long one. Long on speculation, that is. Every few weeks the spin doctors and kibbitzers settle on a new version of who's ahead. It's speculation with a New York accent - an arrogant certainty that each passing theory is permanent insight.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: George Washington; Executives Praise Car Commercials Made by Students
description: A woman sitting in her car glances in the rear-view mirror and sees a truck catching up with her car. As the truck nears, the theme from ''Jaws'' is heard in the background, and suddenly the truck's horn begins to blare.

title: The Bloodstram Express
description: IT IS A FILM SET UNLIKE MOST, A rubberized and plasticized vision of the human body's insides. And according to Dave Carson, the film's special-effects director, it differs from most of the sets built by the company he works for, George Lucas's Industrial Light and Magic. ''We're used to working with miniatures and foot-long spaceships,'' says Carson, who is a veteran of such I.L.M. projects as ''Return of the Jedi'' and ''Star Trek III.'' (Above, an I.L.M. employee works, subcutaneously, on a finger: ''The balloony things are fat cells,'' Carson says.) The finished film will not be opening in neighborhood theaters; rather, it's to be part of Body Wars, the featured attraction at the Wonders of Life pavilion that opens in October at Walt Disney World's Epcot Center in Florida. Coupling a flight-simulator motion base with I.L.M.'s wild special effects graphics, Body Wars (which, like Star Tours, a similar attraction already operating at Disneyland in California, was conceived by Walt Disney Imagineering, the Disney subsidiary responsible for its theme parks), is designed to give spectators the sense that they are traveling through the human body in a special craft. The fantastic voyage, with room for 40 people, is six minutes long. It's scripted - the plot has something to do with the voyage craft running amok through the heart and lungs - and includes contact with imaginary scientists like the one shown at right, examining a splinter.

title:
INVESTING;
Acquirers of Savings Banks
description: LEAD: Banks that buy other banks can get stung if investors react negatively to the deals and sell off their stocks. But three commercial banks that could benefit from the unusual strategy of buying savings banks are: the Constellation Bancorporation of Elizabeth, N.J.; the First Empire State Corporation of Buffalo, and the North Fork Bancorporation of Mattituck, L

title: Report to Board Revives Plan to Buy Old Putnam Railbed
description: ALTHOUGH joggers and hikers may not get the ''linear park'' once envisioned, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke recommended last week that Westchester buy as much of a 16-mile stretch of the old Putnam Railroad's right of way as it can.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The caption for a photograph accompanying an article in the issue of April 2 incorrectly identified the forum in which John Reed, chairman of Citicorp, was speaking. It was a meeting of the New York Academy of Sciences at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: DID THE PENALTY FIT THE CRIME?
description: Morton Hunt poses a new ethical standard for the Gray 90's by asking how an unknown researcher can dethrone the nation's No. 1 heavy-hitter in administrative psychiatry (''Did the Penalty Fit the Crime? May 14).

title: Correction
description: A report on May 21 about the wedding of Michele Brodsky referred incorrectly to her father, Sheldon Brodsky. He played for the Los Angeles Dodgers' Atlanta farm team in 1961.

title: In a Condition of Perfect Attention
description: To the Editor:

title: Trying to Beat the Odds
description: LEAD: TWENTY-TWO years ago, Linda Geller and her husband, Richard, of Laurel Hollow started Tri-Tech Planning Consultants, a construction management company, out of their basement.

title: FOCUS: Key West, Fla.; Development Laps at Beachcomber Image
description: THIS most southerly point of the continental United States, with its longstanding reputation as a raffish tropical getaway, may be in for some ''changes in attitude,'' as the rock singer Jimmy Buffet - who is to Key West what Bruce Springsteen is to Asbury Park - puts it.

title: Scout Unit Carves Path for Wayward Lives
description: LEAD: BOY SCOUT Troop 388 in Irvington is not a typical suburban Boy Scout troop. The 10 members of the troop are all residents of Abbott House, which provides foster care for children who are homeless, neglected or abused.

title: INSIDE
description: Policy Clash on Nicaragua

title: THERE'S A KILLER IN HER BED
description: LEAD: THE HOUSE OF STAIRS By Barbara Vine. 277 pp. New York: Harmony Books. $18.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house is heated with baseboard heating and has been troubled by gurgling and banging noises. The plumber put in a relief valve near the boiler to eliminate the gurgling noises, but said the other noises were due to expansion of the pipes and vanes. I think there is air in the pipes. Bleeder valves are in each heating zone, but I don't know how to eliminate the trapped air, nor whether this will cure the problem.

title: Road Not Taken Gets Spruced Up
description: Digging ditches, moving boulders or cutting trees is not everyone's idea of a fun holiday, but increasing numbers of people are doing just that on weekends and even on vacations. Throughout the Northeast, there are networks of hiking and cross-country trails that constantly need maintenance, and volunteers are constantly needed to do this work.

title: TONGUE-TIED LOVERS
description: LEAD: LUST & OTHER STORIES By Susan Minot. 147 pp. Boston: Seymour Lawrence/Houghton Mifflin Company. $16.95.

title: Diane Siebert Weds
description: Diane Patricia Siebert, an account executive at the Equity Group, a financial public relations firm in New York, and Christopher Paul Reed, a freelance illustrator, were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Metuchen, N.J. The Rev. Lark Zunich officiated. Mrs. Reed is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. D. Peter Siebert of Edison, N.J. Mr. Reed is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy S. Reed of Miami.

title: A ROARING MARKET IN CAPTIVE CALLERS
description: AFTER TAKING A LOOK AT A CHARGE ON HIS telephone bill last September, Joe M. Regenstein, a professor of food science at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., sat down and fired off angry letters to the Federal Communications Commission and the New York Telephone Company, among others. In March of 1988, Regenstein's wife, Carrie, a computer systems coordinator at Cornell, had made a 29-minute phone call from a motel in Princeton, N.J., to their home in Ithaca. Like most Americans, when she picked up the telephone and punched the ''O'' button for operator assistance, she had assumed she would be dealing with A.T.&T., which would have charged $5.51 for the call. Instead, the Regensteins found enclosed in their New York Telephone bill a charge of $10.70 from National Telephone Services, a company based in Rockville, Md.

title: Death of a Pretense
description: Communism as a political idea, a movement claiming a hold on the minds of men and women, has played a powerful part in world history for more than 70 years. That period came to an end last week.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Mashpee, Mass.;
English Theme For Community
description: LEAD: A LONDON-BASED development company is finishing the first phase of Stratford Pond, 68-acre English theme community that includes cobblestoned streets, ornamental post boxes imported from Britain and a village green.

title: Old Plant Is Linked To Health Threats
description: WHEN Frank Pena, a former Li Tungsten employee, heard about the recent discovery of 16,000 tons of radioactive material at the company's abandoned site in Glen Cove, he was disturbed.

title: A Refreshing Look At a Status Symbol
description: Bartok's Concerto for Orchestra is one of the handful of 20th-century works to have entered the standard repertory. For orchestras, it represents what the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto represents for violinists: a work that simply must be mastered, if only as a status symbol. No wonder, then, that Bartok's concerto has received dozens of recordings since its first performance on Dec. 1, 1944, by Serge Koussevitsky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra. What is wonderful is that every so often a new recording comes along that takes a refreshing look at this familiar music. Of two recent recordings, by Charles Dutoit and the Montreal Symphony Orchestra (London 421 443-2; CD only) and by Andre Previn and the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra (Telarc CD-80174; CD only), it is Previn's that makes the stronger impression.

title:
INVESTING;
The Allure of Regional Bank Stocks
description: LEAD: After years of being in disfavor with investors, bank stocks are providing some of the hottest returns on Wall Street.

title: Review/Pop; Bonnie Raitt Sings of Equality in Love
description: With her album ''Nick of Time'' rapidly rising toward the Top 20, Bonnie Raitt has suddenly found new acclaim for her long-established virtues: her clear voice, her bluesy phrasing, and songs carefully chosen to treat love as a complex but equal partnership. Her songs do not portray women as weak, romantic dreamers or ever-willing objects. Her sold-out concert Thursday at the Ritz was a confident reaffirmation that during her years in rock's commercial middle ground between obscurity and mass popularity, she was on the right track. All she needed was a set of consistently excellent songs.

title: Benefit Events Support Drive Against AIDS
description: LEAD: THE scourge of AIDS burst into the lives of Jonathan and Deanna Annis of Bellport when they tried to reach a family friend who was about to become a doctor.

title: Productivity Is More (or Less) Than a Hard Day's Work
description: ''Productivity's Little Secret: Hard Work,'' a Business Forum article appearing on May 14 by Dan Subotnik, prompted an unusually large response from readers. Some of their comments follow. To the Editor:

title: JACK KEMP FACES REALITY
description: There was a touch of sad irony in your article. As one read about Jack Kemp's efforts to deal with the startling increase in homelessness and the nation's drastic shortage of housing, the eye could not help but wander to the facing page and there linger over the listings of magnificent mansions and huge apartments (one of 11 pages of luxury homes and estates).

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
Moving, Even to an Enchanting House, Is Still an Upheaval
description: LEAD: ''WELL, do I take the job in Manhattan, or what?'' she asked.

title: Teacher Is Wed To Melissa Mari
description: Melissa Mari, the daughter of Daniel Mari and Elizabeth Cater, both of New York, was married yesterday to Norman Havercroft Jr., the son of Chloe Havercroft of Hidden Valley, Calif., and the late Mr. Havercroft, at the Woodside Priory School in Portola Valley, Calif. The Rev. Ronald Chlasta, pastor of the Peninsula Covenant Community Center in Portola Valley, officiated.

title: Revolution Builds an Impasse
description: The problem for totalitarian leaders now is how to get out of the dead end they constructed.

title: Why Piniella's Still a Yankee
description: To the Editor:

title: THEY WATCH WHAT WE WATCH
description: I applauded the determination of ABC's Al Schneider to do what he felt was correct in allowing full frontal nudity in the concentration-camp scene in ''War and Remembrance'': ''I finally justified it by saying that this was not nudity, this was death.''

title: Wendy Cushing - Tasseler
description: Wendy Cushing's handmade tassels are on view in the state apartments at Kensington Palace, the throne room at St. James's Palace and on the navy silk curtains in her new shop in the Soho district. Her clients include the interior decorators John Stefanidis, David Hicks and Colefax & Fowler, as well as the National Trust and English Heritage, Britain's leading preservation groups.

title: Amsale Aberra - Wedding-Dress Designer
description: Clients usually arrive at her salon tense and agitated, but Amsale Aberra, known professionally by her first name, is understanding.

title: Review/Opera; New Staging of Monteverdi 'Poppea'
description: ''Personen-Regie'' is a German term for a stage director's work with actors, as opposed to any grander conceptual conceits. Peter Sellars, for instance, is often brilliant at such subtleties, even if they are usually obscured in his detractors' eyes by his gags and updatings. Harry Kupfer's ''Ring des Nibelungen'' at Bayreuth last summer was often distinguished by the intelligence of its character relations although subverted by its sillier cosmic aspirations.

title: Shipboard Music Becomes Shipshape
description: When the king of England wanted a little water music, he loaded Georg Friedrich Handel on a barge, along with a bunch of other musicians, and shipped out on the Thames. Considering the enduring score composed for the occasion, it was worth the effort, but nowadays the pleasures of music afloat are more easily obtained. Pioneer Electronics and Sony have recently come up with sound gear specifically designed for boats.

title: 'Fra Angelico of Satanism' Shines at Harvard
description: The display of Aubrey Beardsley's works at Harvard University's Arthur M. Sackler Museum through July 9 is the sort of casually splendid show that only an institution with a first-rate collection can mount. It happened almost by chance. A traveling exhibition destined for the Sackler fell through, leaving a gap in the museum's schedule and providing Miriam Stewart, a curatorial associate in the drawings department, with the opportunity to cobble together what Harvard possesses in Beardsley drawings.

title: Special Education: Promise, Not Privilege
description: Jane Goldblatt's letter (''Special Education Isn't Sacrosanct,'' May 14) gives new meaning to the words ''misguided'' and ''cynical.'' In describing funds spent on special education students, she writes, ''I don't think it is in the interest of any country to create a privileged group of children.''

title: A 'Teamwork Effort' as 17 Blind Golfers Face a Tough Course
description: LEAD: STEP onto the golf course. Consider the distance to the first hole, the contours of the land, the direction of the wind and a dozen other details. Now close your eyes and swing.

title: Shanghai Reports Dissidents' Arrest
description: The state-controlled local radio and television stations reported today that nine labor dissidents and an undisclosed number of other people had been arrested for their roles in the protests that have swept this city in recent weeks.

title: Round Ball in a World of Jagged Edges
description: MY children and I were at Action Park, water game headquarters in New Jersey. The kids were busy on the rides, splashing and screaming, thrashing and laughing. It was a very hot, perfect day.

title: From Mary McFadden, Two Decades of Fashion
description: ''I really think it would be possible to wear them all today,'' said Mary McFadden, surveying the two rows of dresses she had assembled to represent her 18 years as a fashion designer.

title: Sammy Davis Jr. and Eddie Cantor
description: To the Editor:

title: Money From H.U.D. Foreclosures Stolen by Contractors, U.S. Says
description: Federal investigators say they have uncovered a nationwide pattern of embezzlement by contractors working for the Department of Housing and Urban Development, who they say have taken millions of dollars the Government should have received from the sale of homes obtained through foreclosure.

title: DID THE PENALTY FIT THE CRIME?
description: In a description of Dr. Frazier's recollections of a meeting of the Faculty Conduct Committee at which he was interviewed regarding the questions that had been raised about some of his writings, Morton Hunt writes: ''Frazier recalls Russell ended the session by stating that he hoped Frazier understood how serious all this was and that it would be impossible for him to continue in his leadership roles.''

title: Too Much Art Is a Curse
description: To the Editor:

title: PASTIMES: Gardening; A Basic Glossary for Newcomers
description: Gardeners speak a peculiar language. They pinch their plants, deadhead them and prick them. When all is said and done, they cover everything with mulch. Those who have been in this game for some time, use this language freely. But those who are new, often wonder what they are talking about.

title: Where the Swiss Take a Break
description: HIDDEN away in remote valleys and odd corners of the Swiss Alps is a special type of mountain inn called a Berghotel (or sometimes Berghaus, Berggasthaus, or even Bergrestaurant) or an auberge de montagne. These Alpine guesthouses are a national institution, beloved by the Swiss; they often afford an American visitor a chance to catch an intimate glimpse, almost a family view, of the Swiss at their most relaxed and joyful.

title: L.I. Hospital Faces State Charges Of Surgery by Unlicensed Doctor
description: New York health officials have charged a Long Island hospital with allowing an unlicensed physician to perform surgery and with several other violations in the case of a patient who died after surgery.

title: H.U.D. Agent Details Diverting Millions
description: Marilyn Louise Harrell says she was always a sucker for a sad story.

title: Legally Defenseless
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan last week indefinitely postponed the tax evasion trial of Harry B. Helmsley, ruling that Mr. Helmsley's deteriorating mental condition had left him legally defenseless. Judge John M. Walker Jr. said that the reports of several doctors, one of them court-appointed, showed that the 80-year-old real estate and hotel tycoon had suffered ''substantial brain damage'' from a series of small strokes and was unable to contribute to his defense. ''To try the defendant would deprive him of his basic rights,'' Judge Walker said, adding that it was unlikely that he would ever be tried. Mr. Helmsley and his wife, Leona, were indicted last year on charges that they evaded income taxes by disguising $4 million in renovations to their Connecticut mansion as business expenses. Mrs. Helmsley's trial is to proceeed as scheduled on June 26.

title: CHINESE ARREST 400 IN BEIJING AMID FEARS OF A WIDE PURGE; ROUNDUPS ON IN OTHER CITIES
description: In the first indication of what many fear will be a growing wave of arrests in the capital, the Government said today that it had arrested more than 400 participants in the democracy movement, including leaders of unofficial student and labor organizations.

title: Philadelphia Council Challenges City Law Barring Nepotism
description: The Philadelphia City Council has gone to court in an effort to overturn a largely ignored municipal law governing the right to hire family members for city jobs.

title: A Chant for the 50th Reunion
description: A major event at the college reunions now being celebrated on American campuses is the memorial service. In many, probably all, a speaker for the class recalls by name members who have died since the previous reunion, while those in the pews silently read a printed list of names and dates of all who have died since the distant fall day when each class first assembled.

title: Edwin Pugsley, 66, Metallurgical Engineer
description: Edwin Pugsley, a metallurgical engineer, died of a heart attack Thursday at Middlesex Hospital in Middletown, Conn. He was 66 years old and lived in Guilford, Conn.

title: Street Smarts
description: James G. Watt may not know a lot about the housing industry, but he does know the street value of a former Cabinet member's influence with housing officials. Appearing last week before a House panel investigating accusations of influence-peddling at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, the former Interior Secretary was asked what he had done to earn a $300,000 consulting fee from the developer of a 300-unit H.U.D.-financed housing project. Mr. Watt said he had made eight phone calls and had one meeting with Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the former Secretary of H.U.D. The project was approved. ''The street knowledge is that if you can get these,'' he said, ''the fee is $1,000 to $2,000 a unit.'' Mr. Watt, who is not charged with any wrongdoing, conceded, ''It seemed like a lot of money to me.''

title: Atlanta Places Its Bets On a New Underground
description: Throughout the 1970's, Underground Atlanta was a raucous monument to the city's coming of age, a gas-lighted hodgepodge of downtown shops and bars where Emory University fraternity boys wooed their dates over Flaming Hurricane cocktails and the segregationist former Gov. Lester Maddox peddled autographed pick handles and ''Wake Up America'' alarm clocks.

title: Miss Jones Wed To Brett T. Hall
description: At the Central Presbyterian Church in Summit, N.J., Elizabeth Goodwin Jones, a daughter of Mary Philbrick Jones of Summit and Carlisle Jones of New York and Lawrenceville, N.J., was married yesterday to Brett Tyler Hall, a son of Mrs. Charles Raymond Hall of Murray Hill, N.J., and the late Mr. Hall. The Rev. Riley Jensen performed the ceremony.

title: Review of Limit on Gas Is Ordered
description: A Federal appeals court ordered the Labor Department on Friday to reconsider the way it assesses the risk of cancer from exposure to formaldehyde and its decision not to guarantee full wages to workers disabled by the gas.

title: POSTINGS: 'Preservation Manual'; A How-to Booklet
description: A publishing party will be held Thursday by the writers and editors of a booklet on how to preserve a house, street lamps, a patch of marsh - just about any part of the environment worth preserving. The party will start at 6 P.M. at the Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue at 51st Street, and the public is invited. The guest of honor will be David Todd, chairman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission, and the $5 booklet will be available free.

title: Productivity Is More (or Less) Than a Hard Day's Work
description: ''Productivity's Little Secret: Hard Work,'' a Business Forum article appearing on May 14 by Dan Subotnik, prompted an unusually large response from readers. Some of their comments follow.

title: Bennington College
description: Bennington College conferred degrees on 107 undergraduate and 4 graduate students at its 54th commencement yesterday.

title: Not Just Another Charlie Bluhdorn J. Richard Munro, Time Inc.'s chairman. (NYT/Sara Krulwich)
description: The letter that Martin S. Davis, chairman of Paramount Communications Inc., received on Thursday from Time Inc.'s chairman, J. Richard Munro, was nothing short of scathing.

title:
LIFE STYLE;
The Wild Blue Yonder As a Weekend Retreat
description: LEAD: Learning to fly is one way to spend Sunday, and in the metropolitan region there are plenty of places to do it. A drive of an hour or so will get you out of most parts of New York City and to an airport. If you are not sure you want to earn your wings with the whole course, for a fee most flying schools will take you up for a preliminary lesson.

title: At Ballet Theater, the Excellence Is Blurred
description: American Ballet Theater's loose ends, tidied up in last year's triumphal season, have begun to unravel during the company's current engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York House FSX Jet: Vote on a measure to impose restrictions on the Administration's proposal to jointly develop and produce with Japan the new $6 billion FSX jet fighter. The restrictions would require that a production agreement prohibit the transfer of ''critical'' engine technologies and bar Japan from selling or transferring to third countries major FSX subcomponents. Houghton (R) A KEY Y Yea; N Nay; (A) Absent or did not vote; (P) Present. There were no votes in the Senate.

title: FEWER INCUMBENTS ON SCHOOL BOARDS
description: When New York City's recently elected community school board members take office on July 1, there will be a few more minority members, a few more women and far fewer incumbents than on the current boards.

title: Pirates Edge Mets With Homer in 9th
description: The Mets staged another horror tale in two acts tonight, and both acts involved the further erosion of their prime asset: pitching.

title: In Dordogne, Paddling A Short Course
description: AMONG the various means of exploring the Dordogne region of southwest France - by car, motor scooter, bike, on foot - one of the most agreeable is by canoe.

title: Artists' Gardens or Art Work?
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH they concede it could happen, the artists Joe Novak and Ty Stroudsburg do not expect to sell any paintings today, when their studios will be open for benefit tours.

title: Assessing Risk
description: To the Editor: Your article, ''Assessing the Risks of Visiting Israel'' (Travel, May 7) reminded me of a recent conversation that I had with an Israeli army officer, who had visited New York.

title: Miss Chung Wed To John Rutledge
description: Barbara Lai Fa Chung, a daughter of Albert Tin Sun Chung of Kailua, Hawaii, and the late Eleanor Liu Chung, was married yesterday to John Loomis Rutledge, the son of Philip Casteen Rutledge of Easton, Pa., and Vero Beach, Fla., and the late Dorothy Loomis Rutledge. The Rev. Ernest L. Bengston Jr. officiated at the Congregational Church in Norfolk, Conn.

title: Bush Pressing Congress to Permit C.I.A. Role in Nicaragua Election
description: In a policy conflict with the Democratic-controlled Congress, the Bush Administration is trying to preserve its power to conduct secret intelligence operations aimed at influencing the Nicaraguan elections next February.

title: Success, Starting From a Shoestring
description: AFTER years of working for others, Joachim Fiebich, an engineer by profession, wanted his own business. Because he lacked the capital to acquire or start up a manufacturing operation, he instead began a house-washing service. His intention was to develop it into a franchise, but the endeavor was not profitable.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in the same issue, about cost consultants in the advertising industry, misstated the role of Ruth A. Gutman. A freelance producer, she was retained by Ogilvy & Mather to shoot a revised television commercial for a Prince Matchabelli fragrance.

title: SOCIAL EVENTS
description: Party for Teen-Agers

title: Concern Grows on Teen-Age Dating Abuse
description: LEAD: ''MY boyfriend hits me once in a while. I know if we get married it will stop, because he'll have to mature.''

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Jersey City
description: LEAD: AFTER a long decline, the fortunes of Jersey City have been rising in recent years as it has changed from a gritty old manufacturing center into a residential magnet for young urbanites.

title: A Family Show On and Off the Air
description: ROD ROSS, the host on WPKN-FM, switched on a cut from Paul Simon's ''Graceland'' album, slipped off his headset and waited. It was 1:10 P.M., 10 minutes past the time that ''Ruthie's Roundup of the Arts'' was scheduled to go on the air. And its host, Ruth Lampland Ross, was nowhere in sight.

title: Gypsy Moths Back For New Invasion
description: NORTHERN Westchester communities are already seeing the effects of a new cycle of gypsy moths, which in their caterpillar stage feed on tree leaves. An infestation can defoliate and possibly even kill the trees.

title: Seth Kaplan Wed To Barbara Lewis
description: Barbara Gail Lewis, a first vice president at the Ruder-Finn public relations agency in New York, and Seth Adam Kaplan, a partner at the New York law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz, were married last evening by Rabbi Amiel Wohl at the East River Yacht Club in New York.

title: An Actress Learns From a Setback
description: LEAD: FOR a young actress who had just been dismissed from a soap-opera role, Elizabeth Dennehy was surprisingly calm.

title: A Kiss Is Not Just a Kiss
description: LEAD: I like kissing women. It ranks up there with eating, sleeping and sock hockey as one of the necessary pleasures of life. And now social conventions require me to kiss more women than I ever have before. I should be happy, no?

title: Liberate Track and Field From Steroids
description: Track and field has a problem. The problem is drugs, not the so-called recreational type like cocaine and marijuana, but the body-building drugs like anabolic steroids.

title: A Message For Jackson
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A MOVABLE SLUMBER PARTY
description: THE BRIDESMAIDS Grace Kelly, Princess of Monaco, and Six Intimate Friends. By Judith Balaban Quine. Illustrated. 498 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $21.95.

title: Kerry O'Dwyer Weds L. D. Marrano 3d
description: Kerry Teresa O'Dwyer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William P. O'Dwyer of Loudonville, N.Y., and Leon D. Marrano 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon D. Marrano Jr. of Rye, N.Y., were married yesterday at the St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church in Loudonville. The Rev. Thomas C. Brown officiated.

title: Harriet G. Buchheister, A Conservationist, 84
description: Harriet G. Buchheister, a wildlife conservationist, died of a respiratory ailment on Thursday at Carol Woods Health Center in Chapel Hill, N.C. She was 84 years old and had been a longtime resident of Manhattan and Bethesda, Md.

title: LAYABOUTS AND LOVERS
description: ELEPHANT'S NEST IN A RHUBARB TREE & OTHER STORIES By H. E. Bates. 206 pp. New York: New Directions. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: How the Northeast Asserted Itself on Smog
description: AS summer falls like a hazy curtain across the Northeast, officials in eight states are predicting that the air this year will be a little less visible than it would otherwise be because of a regional effort to cut the ingredients of smog.

title: Nothing to Sink Your Teeth Into
description: FIRST OF ALL, let me say that my visit to Procter & Gamble was an enormous thrill for me, apart from the sucrose polyester I got to taste. For one thing, I had always wanted to dine in the Procter & Gamble kitchen, and I wasn't disappointed. It was neat, and I mean that literally. It gave every appearance of having been recently scrubbed down, no doubt with Bounty paper towels and Mr. Clean. After all, if Procter & Gamble doesn't have a clean kitchen, who does? Even more exciting, however, was the reaction I elicited from the company. It was the first time in my life that I have ever made a multinational corporation nervous, and the experience was a bracing one that I recommend highly to every American. It's better than voting.

title: Two Democrats Begin Ad Campaigns
description: The comptroller who wants to be mayor and the professor who wants to be comptroller have begun separate $250,000, three-week newspaper and television campaigns.

title: Learning to Love the Colorado River
description: I DON'T like to be too cold. I don't like to be too hot. I don't like to be too high. I don't like to be too low. I don't like to be frightened and I don't like to sleep in a bag. For all these reasons, and many others yet unmentioned, I had absolutely no hope that I would enjoy a six-day whitewater rafting trip down the Colorado River in the Grand Canyon. I did it for love.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house is heated with baseboard heating and has been troubled by gurgling and banging noises. The plumber put in a relief valve near the boiler to eliminate the gurgling noises, but said the other noises were due to expansion of the pipes and vanes. I think there is air in the pipes. Bleeder valves are in each heating zone, but I don't know how to eliminate the trapped air, nor whether this will cure the problem.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Armonk, N.Y. $440,000 1 Upland Lane 6-bedroom, 3-bath, 27-year-old split-level; family room w/fireplace, den, 2-car garage, 2.8 acres; taxes $6,059. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $367,500 110 Macy Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old ranch; fireplace, den, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage, 0.5 acre; taxes $6,150. Mamaroneck, N.Y. $317,000 100 West Garden Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 63-year-old stucco colonial; fireplace, sun room, family room, 1-car garage; taxes $4,708. Avon, Conn. $156,000 294 Arch Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; large country kitchen, fireplace in living room, 0.33 acre; taxes $1,630. Wethersfield, Conn. $215,000 235 Broad Street 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 125-year-old Victorian; fully renovated, c/a, 0.25 acre; taxes $1,888. Danbury, Conn. $182,000 68 Highland Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 100-year-old colonial; large bay windows in formal dining room, walk-up attic, 0.33 acre; taxes $2,000. OTHER AREAS Dix Hills, L.I. $189,000 59 Lauren Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split level; family room, c/a, new roof; taxes $3,600. Hicksville, L.I. $150,000 200 Ninth Street 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 44-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, finished basement; taxes $2,100. Leonardo, N.J. $148,800 22 Belleview Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; Florida room, eat-in-kitchen, fenced yard; taxes $1,859.

title: A Hall of Fame Opens for Boxing
description: Not a single punch was thrown, but the opening today of the International Boxing Hall of Fame ranks among the sport's greatest victories, said several of the ring's legends.

title: Search for Perfect Guest Begins at Kitchen Door
description: She considers herself, Margot Rogoff said, ''the perfect house guest.'' So just what, in this final summer of the 1980's, constitutes a perfect house guest? In the case of Mrs. Rogoff, a director of public relations at Revlon, it is the quite comprehensive list of will-dos and won't-dos she presents her hosts before accepting their invitations.

title: DISTANT AS A CHEROKEE CHILDHOOD
description: HOMELANDAnd Other Stories. By Barbara Kingsolver. 244 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: UNLIKELY, BUT BOISE MEANS BIG BUSINESS
description: THIRTY YEARS AGO, WHEN YOU TOOK the train to Boise, Idaho, you debarked at the Spanish mission-style station, complete with campanile, after crossing seemingly endless leagues of gray sagebrush and black-rock desert. Boise was a mildly improbable place even then, the only city in the nation more than 300 miles from another city, a densely treed oasis (population: 34,000) dwarfed by the timbered blue immensity of the Northern Rockies. In those days, downtown was dominated by the sandstone dome of the state Capitol; the narrow streets were lined with the well-tended dwellings of a solid middle class. And through the middle of it all ran the trout-rich Boise River.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; What's Wrong With The Mets?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: THE LAWYER OF CHOICE: H. Rodgin Cohen; He's the Counselor Banks Call in a Crisis
description: Talk with a banker about hostile takeovers and more than likely the first lawyer to be mentioned will be H. Rodgin Cohen, partner at the New York law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell.

title: The Statue of Liberty in Tiananmen Sq.; Sun Yat-sen's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
When Fruit Trees Bear No Fruit
description: LEAD: REMEMBER those mouth-watering pictures in the catalogues that entice gardeners to plant fruit trees in their backyards? Or, how about the visions of bushels of holly with bright red berries? Although plants may grow and bloom each spring, sometimes there is no fruit.

title: Taste of the Cuisine of Northern India
description: EACH year brings new restaurants purveying the fiery creations of ethnic areas - the Chinese provinces of Sichuan and Hunan; Mexico; Vietnam, and, most recently, Thailand. Yet, the number of Indian restaurants in the state remains small. Now, aficionados of Indian cuisines have Kismet, a new restaurant that calls its extensive repertory ''frontier cuisine.''

title: BRAWLEY ADVISERS BATTLE INQUIRIES
description: Eight months after a New York State grand jury found that Tawana Brawley fabricated her tale of abduction and rape at the hands of a group of white men, the young woman's lawyers, C. Vernon Mason and Alton H. Maddox Jr., are facing mounting legal difficulties stemming from charges that they knowingly made false statements about the case.

title: Dr. D. K. Grayson, Internist, Marries Pamela B. Weiler
description: At Temple Emanu-El in New York, Pamela Brooke Weiler, the daughter of Eileen C. Weiler of New York and Sun Valley, Idaho, and the late Henry Weiler, was married last evening to Dr. Douglas Keane Grayson, the son of Dr. Isabel T. Whitehill-Grayson and Dr. Bernard N. Grayson of Brooklyn. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony.

title: POSTINGS: Victory in Woodside; Status Quo
description: Residents of the Boulevard Gardens development in Woodside, Queens, claimed victory - at least temporarily - last week in their efforts to prevent a sponsor from adding to the number of apartments in each of their 10 buildings. The complex covers a square block between 31st and 30th Avenues, and Hobart and 57th Streets.

title:
ART;
Drawing: A Term Rich in Meanings
description: LEAD: IN art, it is easy to fall into the habit of relying on standard terms and ready definitions for things that, on reflection, are far more complex than such mental shorthand makes them seem.

title: Why the U.S. Is Urged To Think Again About Afghanistan
description: PRESSURE is building on the Bush Administration to undertake a fundamental reappraisal of American policy toward Afghanistan. The pressure has come mainly from Congress, but also from Pakistan, Washington's staunch ally in the 10-year campaign to get Soviet troops out of Afghanistan, and it appears to have resulted in a shift of tone, at least.

title: Banner-Towing Plane Crashes
description: A 35-year-old pilot escaped serious injuries when her small plane, taking off to tow an advertising banner over the South Jersey beaches, crashed into the median divider of the Garden State Parkway in Lower Township yesterday afternoon, the State Police said. Trooper Patrick Sullivan of the Bass River Barracks said Marnie Fehrle of Cape May Court House had just picked up her banner in a field at 12:45 P.M. and was gaining speed when her single-engine Piper Cub suddenly banked and crashed into the trees of the median.

title: GETTING SERIOUS ABOUT SERIOUS
description: GREAT WARRIORS HAVE ALWAYS tried to pick their time and place for a battle,'' says William H. Davidow, a venture capitalist in Menlo Park, Calif. ''If they were businessmen today, Patton, Napoleon, Caesar and Alexander the Great all would have chosen to stand their ground on service.''

title: Let's Go Back to the Idea of Citizen-Politicians
description: To the Editor:

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Middlebury, Vt.;
Housing Plans Put on Hold
description: LEAD: A DEVELOPER who owns 300 woodland acres about three miles from the center of this Vermont town is seeking approval to build its first planned development.

title: For Whom the Mud Dries
description: We are again reminded why only 11 horses have won the Triple Crown. It is not as easy as one might think, even for a good horse like Sunday Silence.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Denver
description: Denver's great charm is its geography. Situated among the folds of the South Platte River Valley, at the western extreme of the Great Plains, the city commands the flanks of the Rocky Mountains.

title: Criticism Stalls Reshuffling Set By Thornburgh
description: A Justice Department plan to reorganize the 14 strike forces that prosecute organized crime has been slowed by criticism in Congress and will probably face scrutiny in Senate hearings this summer, Congressional and law-enforcement officials say.

title: BRIGHT LIGHTS IN THE BIG CITY
description: DAYLIGHT SAVINGS TIME really wipes you out,'' says Ernest E. Maurer, president of Bright Light Company of Philadelphia. In the summer, Maurer puts in a long night's labor. He cannot turn on his 3,000-pound searchlights - available for events from birthday parties to opening nights at about $100 an hour - until 8:30 P.M. In winter, the lights go on as early as 5:30.

title: Solidarity Breezes In, And Is Given A Burden
description: IN April, after Solidarity returned to legality from seven years of repression, Lech Walesa was asked if he might run for president under Poland's new political arrangements. Maybe in four years, he said, adding, ''maybe I'll even run for king.''

title: Ann S. Watson Becomes a Bride
description: Ann Standish Watson, the daughter of David M. Watson of Prince Frederick, Md., and Mrs. Frank A. Allen 3d of New York and Nonquitt, Mass., was married yesterday to Joseph Carlton Lipham, a son of Wilma K. Rowe of Atlanta and the late Glynn E. Lipham, at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in South Dartmouth, Mass. The Rev. Benjamin Lee Lentz performed the ceremony.

title: The Statue of Liberty in Tiananmen Sq.
description: To the Editor:

title: Senior Golf Pros To Tee Off
description: LEAD: LONG ISLAND'S biggest golf event of the year, a tournament for senior professionals, tees off tomorrow at the par-72, 6,595-yard Meadow Brook Club in Jericho, and its organizers have made some changes designed to rekindle the excitement of its first two counterparts.

title: 'BE TERRIBLE'
description: ISH KABIBBLE The Autobiography of Merwyn Bogue. With Gladys Bogue Reilly. Illustrated. 209 pp. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. $24.95.

title: New Radio Group Gains Recognition
description: AMATEUR and citizens' band radio operators from across the state met here recently to recognize the formation of a new group that they hope will transcend familiar rivalries, all to help people in distress.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
The Assessment Mess at Grievance Time
description: LEAD: IN 1984, when Fred and Sandra Chasalow bought a new house in Glen Cove for $240,000, the builder estimated that taxes on the 2,700-square-foot dwelling, on a half acre, would be $4,000 to $4,500. But the house was assessed at $16,250, which represented a valuation of $538,000 under a state formula calculating that houses in

title: Diarams of the Pan Am's and NWA's 1988 route system (pg. 1); chart of comparative strengths and assests of NWA and Pan Am (pg. 14); Pan Am's Bold Bid to Survive
description: When Thomas G. Plaskett became chairman of the Pan Am Corporation last year, a large map depicting what remained of the airline's once vast worldwide route system adorned the hall outside his office. But Mr. Plaskett soon had the map removed. ''I couldn't bear to look at it every day,'' he said.

title: Inside the Club
description: THE BOOK-OF-THE-MONTH CLUB. THE NAME itself - upright and stately - connotes quiet afternoons on a hammock or evenings curled up by the fire with a good book. But these are strange times in the publishing industry, and days of turmoil at the venerable old club.

title: DID THE PENALTY FIT THE CRIME?
description: I was a teaching fellow at Harvard during the late 1960's; at that time, plagiarism was a plague there. Students felt they had a right to get through any way they could to avoid the draft, and many teachers looked the other way, out of sympathy to the anti-Vietnam movement. The result was that the university's attitude toward scholarship itself changed; what had previously been grounds for expulsion became, by the early 1970's, merely an academic peccadillo.

title: KILLING OFF THE FANS
description: SPORT IZ An Irreverent Look at Big Business in Pro Sports. By Dale Hofmann and Martin J. Greenberg. 222 pp. Champaign, Ill.: Leisure Press. $18.95.

title: Dorothy Schneeberger, Lawyer, Weds
description: Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church in St. Louis was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Dorothy Donovan Schneeberger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. F. C. Schneeberger 3d of St. Louis, to Charles Hamilton Davison Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Davison of Greenwich, Conn.

title: THE IMPORTANCE OF BEING OPRAH
description: LEAD: LOOKING AT PICTURES OF HERSELF AS A YOUNG GIRL - ''A nappy-haired little colored girl'' - Oprah Winfrey sees herself on a porch swing, ''scared to death of my grandfather. I feared him. Always a dark presence. I remember him always throwing things at me or trying to shoo me away with his cane. I lived in absolute terror.

title: CAVE DWELLING
description: A recent news item told of a California priest, now deceased, who lived simply and frugally - according to the dictates of his vows - but who kept an air-conditioned home for his prized dogs.

title: Johnson's Status Is Uncertain But Laker Fans Trust Magic
description: One of the many makeshift signs displayed at the Palace in Auburn Hills, Mich., during the first two games of the National Basketball Association Finals this week read: ''We don't believe in Magic.''

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Dream House

title: GROWING UP IS HARD TO PUT IN FOCUS
description: Seven high-school boys at a stern prep school sneak off to a midnight-dark cave to read Whitman and Thoreau. Their wholesome, Huckleberry Finn rebellion in Peter Weir's new film, ''Dead Poets Society,'' carries the faintest echo of Mr. Weir's ''Picnic at Hanging Rock,'' his 1975 film about three students and a teacher who vanish during a girls' school outing to the craggy Australian countryside on Valentine's Day of 1900. ''Hanging Rock'' perfectly captures its period, with striking images of girls in white frocks clambering up hills and over rocks. Yet its ominous atmosphere and aura of Victorian repression also evokes the never-changing, subterranean sexual awakening of adolescence.

title: Joking and Crying In Shadow of AIDS
description: LEAD: THE setting is a small windowless basement room with a hodgepodge of worn and mismatched sofas and upholstered chairs. But the mood is one of caring, optimism, hope and reaching out to one another.

title: Correction
description: The Databank table on page 14 in some copies of Sunday Business today misstates the current prime rate.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; Flavors of Italy and Inventive Pancakes
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Connecticut, Long Island and Westchester Sunday regional sections of The New York Times. Ratings at the end of each item - satisfactory, good, very good, excellent and extraordinary - are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Bentley's

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: CIVIL WAR RAID

title: Deng Reappears With a Chilling Lesson About Power in China
description: AFTER weeks of extraordinary pro-democracy demonstrations and then a savage military assault in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, a coalition of conservative Communist Party elders led by Deng Xiaoping emerged triumphant last week. Their victory revealed that despite a decade of stunning economic progress, politics in China remains heavily traditional. Palace intrigue, control of the army and a web of personal relationships count far more than law or modern political institutions or international opinion.

title: Ellen Auster Wed To Stephen Weiss
