description: Ellen R. Auster and Stephen E. Weiss, both business-school professors, were married yesterday at the Gasho restaurant in Hawthorne, N.Y. The bridegroom's father, the Rev. William Weiss, a retired Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: For Quayles, 'Kinder, Gentler' Rafting
description: Vice President Dan Quayle and his family took a whitewater rafting trip down North America's oldest river today after the Army Corps of Engineers lowered the water level for a smoother ride.

title: A Joint Venture With Japanese
description: ONE of the country's largest and most active real estate developers, John W. Galbreath & Company of Columbus, Ohio, is working with two Japanese concerns as equity partners to develop a $95 million corporate office complex in this city's central business district.

title: Susan Donaldson Marries a Doctor
description: At St. Bernard's Episcopal Church in Bernardsville, N.J., Susan Ann Donaldson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Donaldson Jr. of Millington, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. James Michael Haering by the Rev. Dr. Richard Ottoway. The bridegroom, who is known as Michael, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Haering of Bethlehem, Pa.

title: Managua May Free 39 Somoza Men
description: In the heart of the maximum security prison here there is a small, unyielding colony from another Nicaragua.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: GREAT HUDSON REVIVAL Clearwater's Great Hudson River Revival, to be held on the campus of Westchester Community College in Valhalla from 11 A.M. to dusk Saturday and next Sunday, celebrates the 20th anniversary of the sloop's launching in South Bristol, Me., and the 12th year that the revival festivities have taken place.

title: The Angry Decade Of the Ayatollah
description: AS Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's body was carried by helicopter - ''the horse of death,'' a sobbing television announcer called it - to his gravesite, a screaming, hysterical crowd surged forward, pulling out the coffin, which broke open, spilling the imam's corpse in its white shroud. In a mad scene, as soldiers fought to get the body back, mourners in black wrestled to kiss and caress the dead ayatollah's face.

title: KOCH AGAINST KOCH
description: A FEW MINUTES BEFORE 9 P.M. ON HIS 4,121ST DAY AS MAYOR OF New York, Edward Irving Koch fielded the final question from a diverse crowd of Brooklynites assembled in a school auditorium in Coney Island for his 132d ''town hall'' meeting.

title: The Antheneum Displays The Show it Sent to France
description: IN addition to being the oldest art museum in the country, the Wadsworth Atheneum has proved itself able to supply the wherewithal for a show representing the United States at the French bicentennial celebrations. Titled ''200 Years of American Painting,'' the exhibit was displayed at Galeries Lafayette, the Paris department store, and has now returned to Hartford.

title: Kathleen Mathews Marries in Atlanta
description: Kathleen Watts Mathews, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Mathews Jr. of Atlanta, was married there yesterday at the Episcopal Cathedral of St. Philip to Christopher DeWitt Hohlstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William K. Hohlstein of Atlanta. The Rev. Roger Ard officiated.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Cycling Italian Captures 21st Stage: Gianni Bugno of Italy won the 21st and next-to-last stage of the Tour of Italy yesterday, but Laurent Fignon of France retained the overall lead, moving closer to his first triumph in the race. Fignon, again withstanding the pursuit of his closest rivals in a tough mountainous leg from La Spezia to Prato, placed third yesterday, 46 seconds behind the winner but in the same time as a group of seven cyclists including his top challengers, Flavio Giupponi of Italy and Andrew Hampsten of the United States. Claude Criquielion of Belgium outsprinted Fignon for second place, while Giupponi and Hampsten finished fourth and fifth, respectively. The winner covered the 216-kilometer distance in 6 hours 26 minutes 50 seconds. The 22-day marathon ends today in Florence, following a 53.8-kilometer individual against-the-clock race. (AP) First Canadian Wins Milk Race: Brian Walton became the first Canadian and only the second North American to win cycling's Milk Race by finishing in the middle of the pack to protect his 25-second margin in yesterday's final stage in Birmingham, England. The Vancouver racer, in his first year as a professional, had taken the lead from Keith Reynolds of England in Friday's next-to-last stage of the 13-day race. Mark Walsham of England won yesterday's 12th stage, a 68-mile race from Leicester to Birmingham, while Walton and Reynolds finished in the middle of a pack of 85 riders that all matched Walsham's time of 2 hours 48 minutes 50 seconds. Walton, 23 years old, completed the 1,150-mile race around Britain in 43 hours 34 minutes 41 seconds.(AP) Tennis Quick Victory for McEnroe: John McEnroe needed just 50 minutes to defeat fellow American Paul Annacone, 6-3, 6-2, yesterday in the semifinals of the Beckenham Tournament, a grass-court warm-up for Wimbledon. Brod Dyke of Australia moved into the final by defeating Byron Talbot, of South Africa, 6-3, 3-6, 6-3. In the women's semifinals, second-seeded Anne Minter of Australia overwhelmed Julie Salmon of Endland, 6-2, 6-3, and third-seeded Rose Fairbank defeated Ronni Reis, 6-3, 6-4, in an all-American match.(AP) Golf Moody Sets Course Mark: Orville Moody pulled away from the field with a course-record 64 yesterday, taking a six-shot lead after three rounds of the Senior Tournament Players Championship in Ponte Vedra, Fla. The 1969 United States Open winner had eight birdies and no bogeys on the par-72, 6,646-yard T.P.C. at Sawgrass Valley Course to finish with a 54-hole total of 16-under-par 200, also a record for the $700,000 Senior PGA Tour event. Charles Coody had a 66 and Lou Graham had a 67. But that was only good enough to tie them with the second-round leader, Gary Player, for second place at 206. Player birdied the last two holes for a 72. Al Geiberger, Butch Baird and Miller Barber were next at 209. Moody's 64 broke the previous course record of 65 set by Don January in the third round of the 1988 Senior T.P.C. Arnold Palmer and Chi Chi Rodriguez held the previous 54-hole record of 10-under-par 206.(AP) Massey Survives Challenge: Debbie Massey's 13 points held up through a challenge from the local favorite, Nina Foust, yesterday and she held on for a 1-point victory in the third round of the $400,000 Pat Bradley International in High Point, N.C. Massey, playing in the first threesome to tee off, won $6,000 for the best score in the field of 72 at Willow Creek Golf Club. Foust, 70th on the L.P.G.A. money list, won $3,000. The top 36 scorers advanced to today's final round. Road Racing Ryan Wins 5-Mile Run: Martin Ryan of New York won the New York Road Runners Club Alamo Alumni five-mile run yesterday in 25 minutes 27 seconds in Central Park, beating Bill Rodgers and Frank Shorter. Lance Mason, also of New York, was 85 yards back in second place in 25:43. Rodgers, 41, of Boston, won the Masters Division in 26:35. The four-time winner of the Boston and New York City marathons was seventh over all. Shorter, the 1972 Olympic marathon champion, was third among the Masters in 27:19 and 12th over all. Mary Lou Dinardo of New York and Rollins College won the women's race in 29:43.(AP) Soccer Sockers 6, Blast 5: Branko Segota scored a pair of goals and San Diego held off a last-quarter, four-goal rally to defeat Baltimore last night in Baltimore and win its fifth Major Indoor Soccer League championship. San Diego beat Baltimore four games to three in the championship series, but the Blast put a scare into the Sockers last night, scoring four times in 7 minutes 27 seconds in the final quarter after replacing the starting goalkeeper Scott Manning with David Byrne. Domenic Mobilio led the Blast comeback, scoring three consecutive goals. The San Diego goalkeeper, Victor Noguiera, who finished with 21 saves in the final, was voted the most valuable player of the series.(AP)

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about support within South Africa for economic sanctions omitted the position taken in 1985 by the Congress of South African Trade Unions. The congress said it supported foreign companies' divestiture of South African holdings. In recent months the congress has not issued similar public calls for foreign companies to leave.

title: Japan's Washout on Wall Street
description: A good indication of how Japan's major securities firms are faring on Wall Street was provided recently by Takuro Isoda, the chairman of Daiwa Securities America Inc. Mr. Isoda spent nearly half of a two-hour interview intently discussing investment deals he was trying to arrange with American Indian tribes.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Recent rainfall has spurred growth of grass, shrubs, trees and flowering plants. Prune back this exuberance on hedges, especially yew, hemlocks, spruces; thin trees where needed; mow again and keep the blades set to cut high, no lower than two inches; pinch back petunias, snapdragons, marigolds, geraniums, lantanas and other flowering plants that may need discipline. Over the Ground Although many gardeners seek them, there truly are no miracle plants, those that never require care. This characteristic is often claimed by aggressive promoters, but it just isn't so. Any plant needs some attention. And those who plant plants, soon learn that they must provide at least a modicum of care.

title: Federal Court Turns All Secord Charges Into a Single Case
description: A Federal district judge Friday consolidated into a single case two sets of criminal charges against Richard V. Secord, a figure in the Iran-contra affair.

title: WHERE THE ACE IS KING
description: ON SATURDAY AFTERNOONS, THE BACK ROOM of Reuben's, a Manhattan delicatessen, rings with the hubbub of hocus-pocus. Seated in clusters around the Formica tables, munching on frankfurters and sipping coffee, amateur magicians from all over the city take turns performing their latest tricks for an audience of their peers. Coins disappear. Selected cards emerge from much-shuffled decks.

title: Less Is More
description: To the Editor:

title: Arthur Miller's Vision of Love Becomes a Movie
description: Under the grimy steel beams of the old Norwich thermos factory, an outsized plaster statue of a Civil War major in drooping mustaches stands before a semicircle of welded motorcycle frames, twisted to resemble worshipers bent in supplication. Tattooed pinup girls, clipped from motorcycle magazines, paper the walls. Greasy tools and flophouse couches fill out the corners.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 'DELIGHTFUL DANCE' A little tradition can go a long way. For example, take dance and those who do it on Long Island.

title: GROWING UP IS HARD TO PUT IN FOCUS
description: ABC's ''Wonder Years'' is the kind of small, beautifully crafted weekly series that is so good it prompts immediate speculation on how long it can be held together.

title: ACCIDENTS DECLINE
description: Despite a dramatic increase in the number of people riding bicycles in Manhattan, accidents involving bicycles and pedestrians have decreased for the third consecutive year, a recent study by the New York City Department of Transportation shows.

title: Clubs Dip Into Minor Leagues in Search for Good Starters
description: They are the Rookie Reinforcements, and with names like Mike Schwabe, Clint Zavaras, Greg Hibbard and Kevin Appier they are too new to have made the impact of an Orel Hershiser or a Dwight Gooden.

title: The Look of Connecticut Through One Man's Lens
description: ONE rainy day, William Hubbell, a photographer, trudged up Mount Tom in Litchfield, downhearted because of the weather. Just as he reached the summit, the rain stopped, and a spreading rainbow illuminated the farm below. That photograph became Mr. Hubbell's favorite in his new book, ''Connecticut,'' because, he said, ''it represents my faith that the state of Connecticut would give me the images I needed.''

title: Law Student Wed To Nancy Goldin
description: Nancy Jean Goldin, a daughter of Dr. Lila Greenwald and Dr. Victor Goldin of New York, and William Bradford Middlekauff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alton R. Middlekauff of Cincinnati, were married in Providence, R.I. yesterday in the Manning Chapel at Brown University. The Rev. Edward Horstmann, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

title: Military Satellite Fired Into Orbit on Sixth Try
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 10 (AP) -

title: Mela Lew, Lawyer, Weds Harold Leach Jr. in Boston
description: The Emmanuel Church of Boston was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Mela Lew and Harold Hunter Leach Jr., both lawyers. The Rev. Hongki Kim, a Methodist minister, officiated.

title: Biological Pesticides Win Converts as Fear of Chemicals Grows
description: Biological pesticides are coming into wider use this spring, a reflection of the pressure on farmers to make American agriculture safer and less polluting.

title: Religious Symbols at the Altar Of Artistic Invention
description: CENTURIES ago, ''The Altar Image'' might have been thought heretical, even blasphemous. The current attraction at the Hostos Community College Art Gallery in the Bronx, it consists of work by six artists who use the forms and symbols of traditional religions to address gods that are mostly of their own invention. But with art itself now a kind of religion, the chances of visitors noticing this, much less objecting to it, are slim.

title: Reagan Optimistic on China
description: Former President Ronald Reagan says he thinks the democracy movement in China will in time prevail. In an interview to be broadcast on the CBS News program ''Sunday Morning,'' Mr. Reagan said he was optimistic because ''what we're seeing now is what a lot of us have known for many years: that Communism couldn't really be a successful system.''

title: Carleton College
description: Michael Armacost, the United States Ambassador to Japan, addressed the 115th commencement of Carleton College yesterday in Northfield, Minn.

title: No Shortage of Science Teachers in the Rockies; As Bad in the East
description: To the Editor:

title: Costs of Medical Malpractice Drop After an 11-Year Climb
description: After steadily rising for 11 years, the torrent of medical malpractice lawsuits that has added at least $12 billion annually to the nation's health spending has begun to ease, insurers and physicians say.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Lafayette; Preservationists Defeated As Bulldozer Settles Debate
description: Preservationists and some students and alumni at Lafayette College believed that the campus's Delta Upsilon fraternity house was destined to become a landmark. College trustees and the administration thought it was destined to become rubble, making way for the new student center they want.

title: Political Memo; Attack Shows G.O.P. Strategy Shift
description: The uproar this week over a Republican National Committee memorandum attacking House Speaker Thomas S. Foley underscored an important shift in Republican politics under President Bush: putting control in the national committee headquarters, not the White House.

title: ''When You're Stuck, You're Stuck''
description: ELKE P. MARTIN is the editor of the newsletter of the Connecticut Motor Club, an affiliate of the American Automobile Association, which has 275,000 members in Fairfield, New Haven and Litchfield counties. In a recent newsletter sent to the group's members, Ms. Martin warned of traffic delays because of road and bridge construction and said that ''the sounds of summer may be the honking of car horns.''

title: Ah, the Freedom of the Freelancer
description: AFTER 15 years or so of steady 9-to-5 employment, I decided to quit my job and work at home as a full-time freelancer.

title: Interest Rates Are Heading Down
description: Interest rates headed down, with banks lowering the prime rate by half a percentage point, to 11 percent. The prime, which is a benchmark banks use to set rates on borrowing by individuals and smaller businesses, had been rising steadily for more than a year. In May 1988, the prime was 8.5 percent. The rising rates had been a response to Federal Reserve efforts to squeeze out inflationary pressures, but the Fed, too, was showing signs of easing last week. The Federal funds rate edged down for the first time in 15 months. The rate is what banks charge each other for overnight loans and is the interest rate most directly under the influence of the Fed. The rate had been near 10 percent but the Fed did not interfere last week when it slipped to near 9.5 percent. *

title:
GARDENING;
When Fruit Trees Bear No Fruit
description: LEAD: REMEMBER those mouth-watering pictures in the catalogues that entice gardeners to plant fruit trees in their backyards? Or, how about the visions of bushels of holly with bright red berries? Although plants may grow and bloom each spring, sometimes there is no fruit.

title: SEATS OF POWER
description: CONSIDER THE BOSS'S CHAIR. A MUTE OBJECT, YOU might think, a mere agglomeration of steel springs and upholstery - just a place to sit. In fact, the chair chosen by top executives is a great deal more than that. It is a totem, a symbol of power, and it projects an intriguing, if subliminal, message.

title: In Hong Kong, Black Signs to Denote Horror
description: Rachel Wong, a school teacher here, said this week that when she stepped into her high school classroom, ''many of the students just began to cry.''

title: CAMPUS LIFE: St. Olaf; 23 Years Later, A Script Provides That Last Credit
description: In the fall, Barry Morrow will submit to the St. Olaf College faculty his original screenplay for ''Rain Man,'' for which he won an Academy Award this year. The manuscript, being submitted as an independent study project, will enable him to fulfill the one course he needs to complete the bachelor's program he started in 1966.

title: Beside the Alpine Lake of Annecy
description: WHEN he first saw the remote waters of the Lake of Annecy high in the Savoy alps of what is now southeastern France, the l8th-century philosopher and writer Jean Jacques Rousseau exclaimed: ''Now I have been happy. Now I have lived.'' Some license must be allowed, of course, for Rousseau was a romantic and also in love with a woman from the lakeside town of Annecy who wanted him to exchange the dour Calvinism of his native Geneva for easier-going Roman Catholicism. He agreed, deciding that ''a religion preached by such a missionary can only lead to paradise.''

title: Capricious Regulation Is the Market's Foe
description: Decades of ideological wrangling over the role of government has led us to choose between regulation and deregulation, as if we were deciding whether to handcuff American business or uncuff it. The cuffs were removed in the late 1970's and 1980's. Now the cuffs may go back on. But if the 1990's turn into the decade of re-regulation, we will be right back where we started - with commands emanating from Washington, shackling American business and constraining innovation.

title: TOO RICH TO BUM AROUND
description: MY LIFE WITH THE PROS By Bud Collins. Illustrated. 368 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $19.95.

title: East Meets West, With Sousa, Sails and Greasepaint
description: SOUSA'S ''Stars and Stripes Forever'' is not commonly heard at concerts in Leningrad nor do Russian actors often have a chance to join in a chorus from ''Guys and Dolls.'' And collegiate sailors from Moscow do not usually race yachtsmen from Yale. But these events are under way and illustrate the increasing ways that American and Soviet citizens are being encouraged to learn about one another.

title: London
description: To the Editor: I read with delight Claire Frankel's article on Neal's Yard (''A London Enclave of Whole Foods,'' Travel, April 30), a place I have recommended frequently. But I looked in vain for a mention of the Seven Dials Restaurant, adjacent to Neal's Yard.

title: Wichita State Captures Title
description: Wichita State won its first N.C.A.A. baseball title today as Greg Brummett tied a record with his third College World Series victory and Pat Meares hit a two-run homer in a 5-3 victory over Texas. Wichita State lost to Miami in its only other title game, in 1982. It was the eighth title game for Texas, which has won four times.

title:
GARDENING;
When Fruit Trees Bear No Fruit
description: LEAD: REMEMBER those mouth-watering pictures in the catalogues that entice gardeners to plant fruit trees in their backyards? Or, how about the visions of bushels of holly with bright red berries? Although plants may grow and bloom each spring, sometimes there is no fruit.

title: ; A Guide Dog Relinquishes The Leash
description: THE rain penetrated the ground with a dreary, cold intensity. He was retiring. It was his last day at work and he seemed to sense that something was happening.

title: Productivity Is More (or Less) Than a Hard Day's Work
description: ''Productivity's Little Secret: Hard Work,'' a Business Forum article appearing on May 14 by Dan Subotnik, prompted an unusually large response from readers. Some of their comments follow.

title: Lauren E. Miller Becomes the Wife Of John Koslosky
description: Lauren Elizabeth Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Robinson Miller 3d of Asharoken, L.I., and John Troy Koslosky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Koslosky of Denver, were married yesterday at the Old First Presbyterian Church in Huntington, L.I. The Rev. Michael Lindvall performed the ceremony.

title: Courter vs. Florio: A Contest of Candidates' Visions and Records
description: TWO veteran Congressmen who have long harbored desires to be Governor of New Jersey will test each other in the November election campaign already under way to pick a successor to Thomas H. Kean.

title: W. B. Reynolds Wed to Louise Wales
description: Louise Carrie Wales, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gwynne Huntington Wales of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to William Bennet Reynolds, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcus T. Reynolds of New York. The Rev. John Rogers performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn.

title: For the Elephants' Sake, A Quick Ban on Ivory
description: ''THE ivory trade has been shut down,'' said Curtis Bohlen, senior vice president of the World Wildlife Fund. ''The African elephant is now in far less danger of extinction than it was only a week ago.''

title: Correction
description: A chart last week showing the percent of American patents issued to residents of foreign countries gave an incorrect date. It averaged 25 percent from 1963 to 1974, not in 1974 alone.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house is heated with baseboard heating and has been troubled by gurgling and banging noises. The plumber put in a relief valve near the boiler to eliminate the gurgling noises, but said the other noises were due to expansion of the pipes and vanes. I think there is air in the pipes. Bleeder valves are in each heating zone, but I don't know how to eliminate the trapped air, nor whether this will cure the problem.

title: Special Today: Summer Reading
description: Book Review/Section 7

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the New Jersey gubernatorial campaign misidentified a consulting firm and referred erroneously to its connection with a housing project in Seabrook, N.J. The firm was Ailes Communications Inc. An employee of the firm had helped gain state government approval for the project before joining Ailes Communications, but the firm was not involved.

title: Candlewood Entices A Broadway Actor
description: FIND an accomplished performer with impressive credentials in musical theater and give him the leading role in one traditional favorite and the directorial reins of another. That would seem a sure wayfor a summer playhouse to shore up its professional identity, and the Candlewood Playhouse in New Fairfield aims to do just that.

title: Review/Theater; Sharing Life's Pains, In Kalcheim's 'Friends'
description: In Lee Kalcheim's play ''Friends,'' two men in their late 40's who have been close since their days as Yale undergraduates reunite in a Vermont cabin to share their midlife crises.

title: U.S., Pakistan And Atom Arms
description: Despite Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's assurances that her country does not intend to produce a nuclear bomb, the Bush Administration believes that Pakistan is pressing ahead with some aspects of a weapons program, Administration officials report. Article, page 5.

title: Honoring The Hall
description: On a day when there was a full slate of major league games in New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco and Chicago, many of baseball's leading lights gathered yesterday in a remote but hardly obscure village in upstate New York to honor a footnote to the national pastime.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: Judging by the cast of characters, it might have been the final of a national championship. But in truth it was a regional event, the final of the prestigious Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, played eight days ago at the Cavendish Club in Manhattan.

title: Fish Rain From the Sky In a Twice-Annual Rite
description: Mike Collins, a helicopter pilot with the State Department of Environmental Conservation, was flying a few feet above the upper Hudson one day a few years ago, dropping thousands of young trout, when he rounded a bend and found a raft full of people below him.

title: A Day Out of Padua
description: THE vast plain that surrounds Venice by land is unobstructed but for a cluster of cone-shaped, green-clad mounds that rise on the outskirts of Padua - the Euganean Hills. The hills are volcanic in origin, and their eastern valleys are dotted with hot springs known since ancient times for the therapeutic qualities of their waters and mud.

title: Radical Line in Moscow: Bring on the Consultants
description: Andrei A. Stroyev commands construction gangs with the authority of a man who, literally, is in charge of the restructuring of Moscow.

title: Japanese Students for Marymount
description: LEAD: A GROUP of Japanese college freshmen who will not even begin their studies until September already know where they will be spending their junior and senior year - at Marymount College in Tarrytown.

title: A Lottery in Newtown Offers a Trip to Court
description: NEWTOWN recently held a lottery that no one wanted to win. The ''prize'' involved the threat of being taken to court for allegedly failing to comply with the town's building code.

title: Sanchez Surprises Graf to Win the French Open
description: The stop here on the road to a second straight Grand Slam in tennis seemed to be a routine one for Steffi Graf. Her most serious challengers were either skipping the French Open or were eliminated in earlier rounds.

title: BOOKS FOR VACATION READING
description: This list has been selected from books reviewed since the Christmas issue of December 1988. It only suggests high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alphabetically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from The Book Review. Autobiography and Biography

title: THE MOTHER TONGUE
description: When my daughter was 2 years old and attending a ''playgroup,'' her teacher told me she had ''leadership charisma'' (On Language: ''The Mother Tongue,'' by Patricia Volk, May 14). I called my mother immediately who said to me, ''In my day, it was called being bossy.'' FRANCINE MARTIN STERN New York, N.Y.

title: Mrs. Bramwell Weds Henry Gardiner
description: Katharine Hone Emmet Bramwell and Henry Gardiner were married yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Everett A. Gassett, an Episcopal minister, at the Congregational Church in Keene Valley, N.Y. The bride is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Herman LeRoy Emmet of Stony Brook, L.I. Her husband is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Henry Halsey Gardiner of Quogue, L.I.

title:
Morris Township Journal;
An Increase in Deer Prompts Discord
description: LEAD: FARMS and residences in Morris County are becoming fair game for an increased deer population seeking food and causing property damage in the process. The apparent solution - herd control - is creating a split between hunters and animal-rights advocates.

title: David Paltiel and Stuart Warner Wed
description: Stuart Garland Warner, a daughter of Mrs. Theodore L. Cross of Princeton, N.J., and Lawrence A. Warner of Louisville, Ky., was married yesterday at the home of her mother and stepfather to Aaron David Paltiel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel M. Paltiel of Montreal. Judge Boyce F. Martin Jr. of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, officiated.

title: 'Jerry's Girls': Tasty Sampling
description: JERRY HERMAN'S ''Jerry's Girls'' is a retrospective of this theatrical composer's career.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: REORGANIZING THE FACTORY;
Work Teams Muffle Labor's Voice
description: LEAD: The United Auto Workers convention, which opens next week in Anaheim, Calif., will mark the most fundamental debate in recent years about labor strategy. The debate is between those advocating non-adversarial labor-management relations and those advocating an adversarial approach. The former position is backed by Owen Bieber, president of the U.A.W., and the latter by the New Directions movement, led by Jerry Tucker and Donny Douglas.

title: Firefighter Exam Postponed After 5 Collapse
description: For the third time in a year, New York City has been forced to postpone the grueling examination for prospective firefighters because of the collapse of five men from kidney failure during testing two weeks ago.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Developers Offer Services in a Slow Market
description: LEAD: WITH office vacancy rates in Westchester County relatively high at 18.6 percent, some developers are seeking to attract tenants with services and amenities such as day-care and health facilities, shuttles to trains and buses - and even corporate jets and helicopters.

title: Making Peace With the Mop
description: I HAVE gone to great lengths over the years to avoid what has turned out to be inescapable - housework.

title: Review/Dance; Dreams and Commentary In Sally Silvers Program
description: Sally Silvers presented a typically provocative evening of dance on June 3 at Performance Space 122. Miss Silvers' costume designs bring extra humor, color and a lot of chic to the enterprise. She has a keen sense of her dancers and most of her dances offer revelations about them. But her dances - and the improvisational scores they are set to - are full of small knots and fascinating tangles.

title: Preparing for a Global 'Green' Era
description: LEAD: President Bush's grudging embrace of the need for a global treaty on greenhouse warming marks the end of the first phase of the greenhouse debate. In that phase, the science of climate change was the focus and whether action was needed was the underlying question. With the United States in the discomforting role of nonleader, and with its greenhouse policy still unformed, a second phase has begun.

title: Question Of the Week; Did Pitino Make The Right Move?
description: For a man of Rick Pitino's status, a collegiate coaching job would have come along any time. And the job would not be with a team that is under three years of probation. However, the chance of coaching the Knicks to an N.B.A. championship only comes around once (if that often). Pitino sounds as if he may already be regretting the move as he talks of leaving the Knick job incomplete and assuring fans that the new coach will get that title. It's very subtle, but in a way it's very obvious. MICHAEL BERK Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Prospects Rise for Housing Legislation
description: AFTER years of simmering below the country's political consciousness, the problems of the homeless poor and of the growing proportion of young working Americans who cannot afford to buy a home are pushing the Federal government back into the housing business.

title: Michele DeCarlo, Ph.D. Candidate, Is Married to Thomas Lowry Blum
description: In the Chapel of St. Thomas of Villanova at Villanova (Pa.) University, Michele Joan DeCarlo, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. DeCarlo of Rosemont, Pa., was married yesterday to Thomas Lowry Blum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Blum of New York and Rensselaerville, N.Y. The Revs. Anthony M. Genovese and Vincent McHenry, Roman Catholic priests, officiated.

title: AN OUTSIDE DIRECTOR MAKES HERSELF HEARD
description: LEAD: AT THE AGE OF 11, I LEFT MY PARENTS' sheep station in the Australian outback, where I had been raised in an almost exclusively male world, for a fashionable girls' school in Sydney. The transition was sudden and traumatic.

title: Frail Wildflower Threatened
description: THE Sandplain Gerardia, a frail wildflower believed to be the rarest form of life on Long Island, is raising difficult questions for Federal aviation authorities.

title: Field of Reality
description: The farmer who owns the infield of Iowa's best-known baseball field, the one used in the movie ''Field of Dreams,'' said he was beginning to regret his decision to keep the place groomed. The outfield, meanwhile, is back to corn. ''The way I'm beginning to look at it is, maybe keeping it was a mistake,'' said Don Lansing of Dyersville, Iowa. Lansing and Al and Rita Ameskamp own portions of the northeast Iowa corn field used in last summer's filming of the movie in which a nearly bankrupt farmer, portrayed by Kevin Costner, hears a mysterious voice and is persuaded to carve a baseball field out of his corn acreage.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; From Summer's Fruit, Simply Sweet Desserts
description: The stores are beginning to fill up with the fruits that make serving dessert so simple in the summer. There are blueberries, strawberries, raspberries, nectarines, peaches, plums and cherries, especially those stunning white or cream-colored Queen Anne cherries that make the Bings seem tame.

title: THE SOUTH HAD ALL THE LAUGHTER
description: LEAD: SWEET SUMMER Growing Up With & Without My Dad. By Bebe Moore Campbell. 272 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $18.95.

title: Politics as Usual Over the Dutch Environment
description: When the coalition Government collapsed last month over the financing of a national environmental plan, the Dutch were finally back to politics as usual.

title: An Incentive Program For Hospital Nurses
description: The May 14 article ''Hospitals Find New Ways to Keep Nurses'' unfortunately omitted a significant program instituted at St. Peter's Medical Center in February that is sparking interest all over the country.

title: Nightfall Latest Hurdle at Westchester Classic
description: There was just about enough light left for Wayne Grady and Dick Mast to see the 18th hole for their final putts of this long day at Westchester Country Club. And each of them managed to get down for par to tie J. C. Snead for the lead going into Sunday's final round of the $1 million Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic.

title: Midnight Writers Defacing the L.I.E.
description: AS the saying goes, Rome was not built in a day, but I doubt that Caesar tolerated destruction while under construction. So why can't one of the greatest cities in the world at the latter part of the 20th century keep the Long Island Expressway free of graffiti?

title: Chairmen Are Named For Carnegie Centennial
description: Sanford I. Weill and James D. Wolfensohn have been named co-chairmen of the Carnegie Hall Centennial, which is to take place throughout the 1990-91 season. Special concerts, festivals, lectures, tributes, exhibitions and a commissioning project are all planned for the celebration.

title: THE IDEAL SUMMER BOOKS: HUGE, SCARY, WATERPROOF
description: I came to love summer reading back in the 1950's, when I spent my summers at a camp located in Dutchess County right near a New York State mental hospital. We campers had four major activity options: sports, nature, crafts and reading. I ruled out sports, which consisted primarily of swimming in a lake filled with a murky, dark-green waterlike substance. You couldn't see what was in there, but you knew it was hostile.

title: More Music
description: To the Editor: I would like to note two additional musical festivals that are, in the words of the author, Vernon Kidd, ''of more than local interest'' (''Who's Performing Where,'' Travel, April 30).

title: Charles D. Morrissey, 63, a Civil Engineer
description: Charles D. Morrissey, a civil engineer, died of a heart attack Tuesday in Nairn, Scotland. He was 63 years old and lived in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y.

title: Faked Out By Zethel
description: UNTIL I SAW LAST season's National Collegiate Athletic Association championship game between the University of Tennessee and Auburn, I hadn't watched a game of women's basketball for decades. I wasn't surprised that both teams played skillfully. But I was surprised that none of the players was red-haired. In a game 30 years ago, I had been painfully conditioned to make the connection between hair color and basketball excellence.

title: A Celebration of Beauty in the Wild
description: MARGARET McCARRICK stepped gingerly over a soggy bog in Willington. Mrs. McCarrick's feet were wet this day but her eyes were sharp and her mission was clear: she was at the bog to spot wildflowers, from graceful water arums to insect-devouring pitcher plants.

title: Access Law
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
Metaphysical Wood Panels
description: LEAD: ENIGMATICALLY even for her, Emily Dickinson once wrote that ''hope is the thing with feathers.'' A feathered creature is the main element in a group of small paintings on wood panels from 1987 and 1988 by Cicely Cottingham at the Gallery Jupiter. Ms. Cottingham's feathered creature may not embody hope, but it operates in a metaphysical realm.

title: STREETSCAPES: Wanaque Apartments; An Elegant Tenement Revisited
description: THE five-story, 1887 Wanaque Apartments at 359 West 47th Street, now under renovation by the nonprofit Fountain House as a residence for psychiatric patients, holds many surprises.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: JACKSONVILLE, FLA.;
Utility Moving Headquarters
description: LEAD: HOPES for a business revival in a part of downtown that had declined in recent years have been given new impetus with the decision of the Jacksonville Electric Authority to move its headquarters there.

title: Self-Regulating Investment Planners Asked
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission asked Congress on Friday to allow the booming investment advisory business to regulate itself, subject to the commission's overseeing.

title: A Beer Connecticut Can Call Its Own
description: LEAD: FROM out of a bar, a brewery was born.

title: THEY WATCH WHAT WE WATCH
description: Writers, even Hollywood writers, lead solitary enough lives to lack much sense of our own context, which made Stephen Farber's article ''They Watch What We Watch'' (May 7) all the more interesting.

title: ART BOOKS
description: Over the last year or two, and not before we needed them, several new kinds of art books have come into view. Though the work of disciplined minds, none of them is the kind of book in which one professional addresses a handful of others. Some of them are powered by detective work on a broad social base. Others home in like hornets on the notion that the more we know about what an artist believed - remote as it may be from the accepted wisdom of today - the more likely we are to understand his work. * VERMEER AND HIS MILIEU: A Web of Social History. By John Michael Montias. 407 pp. Princeton University, $49.50. Vermeer the artist is everyone's favorite. Vermeer the man, on the other hand, is famously inaccessible. No one knows what he looked like. Not a letter, not a diary entry, not an eyewitness account of no matter how noncommittal a kind has come down to us. For all we know, Vermeer (1632-75) had no close friends. He went nowhere (except perhaps in the horse-towed barges that linked one Dutch town to another). Unlikely as it may seem that in such a life there were no epiphanies, no inconvenient emotions, no place for pity or terror, no formative or re-formative experiences, Vermeer in human terms is a beloved blank.

title: Katharine duPont Sanger Marries Lewis Rutherfurd
description: Katharine duPont Sanger and Lewis Polk Rutherfurd were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church on Fishers Island, N.Y., by the Rev. John C. Harper, an Episcopal priest, assisted by the Rev. J. Clifford Curtin, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Kindergarten Teacher Is Held in Crack Raid
description: A kindergarten teacher and three other people were arrested on charges of possession of crack early today, when the Suffolk County police raided a motel in Huntington Station.

title: SO MUCH GENIUS! SO LITTLE MONEY!
description: HOLLYWOOD By Charles Bukowski. 239 pp. Santa Rosa, Calif.: Black Sparrow Press. Cloth, $20. Paper, $11.

title: Rap Groups Are Getting a Glitzy Edge
description: When rap first impinged on the consciousness of mainstream America, back in the mid-1970's, its visual appeal seemed more attitude than showmanship. The voice of the urban streets, the rhyming, cadenced poetry of rap was proclaimed by young men (mostly) who wanted to look as if they had just stepped off those streets.

title: FOCUS: Development Laps at Key West Beachcomber Image; A Resort Hotel, Condos and Yacht Club in Works
description: This most southerly point of the continental United States, with its longstanding reputation as a raffish tropical getaway, may be in for some ''changes in attitude,'' as the rock singer Jimmy Buffet - who is to Key West what Bruce Springsteen is to Asbury Park - puts it.

title: Sharon Scott Wed To Fellow Lawyer
description: Sharon Yvonne Scott, an assistant district attorney in Queens, and Joseph Clifford Brooking, a lawyer with the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance in Manhattan, were married yesterday at the Huntington Town House in Huntington Station, L.I. The Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, officiated.

title: 'HAVE I GOT A MUNI FOR YOU!'
description: IT IS AN EARLY SPRING MORNING AND James A. Lebenthal, an irrepressible master salesman, is at it again. On Tuesdays and Fridays, between 6:30 and 9 A.M., his ''drive-time'' commercial for municipal bonds is played on the radio. For 60 seconds, Lebenthal talks about the wisdom of investing in bonds and makes a pitch for his ''Bond of the Day.'' This morning, he recommends a new issue of The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey bonds, and when the commercial ends, the telephones at Lebenthal & Company in downtown Manhattan begin to ring. When they finally stop, around noon, Lebenthal has sold about $1 million worth of the bonds.

title: HOW JAPAN'S SUNTORY COMPANY GIVES ITS REGARDS TO BROADWAY
description: After Emanuel Azenberg stepped to the microphone last Sunday to accept a Tony award as one of the co-producers with the Shubert Organization of the best musical, ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway,'' he uttered the usual thanks to others involved in the popular production. Then he gave an unusual thank you. ''And domo arigato,'' said Mr. Azenberg, ''to the Suntory group,'' another of the producers. That brief expression of thanks in Japanese underlined Suntory's unusual new financial arrangement with America's Broadway. The 90-year-old Japanese brewer and distiller has become a financial partner with the Shubert Organization in its Broadway productions for the next five years.

title: CHINA TRADE
description: The Chinese have been the most intrepid of adventurers. They sailed to Hawaii, they crossed the Formosa Strait and the China Sea, as well as the Strait of Malacca to the Malay Peninsula and beyond to Indonesia. They came to the United States to work in the California gold mines and to build the transcontinental railroad.

title: Todd R. Clark Wed To Lisa F. Fairburn
description: At the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., Lisa Farnsworth Fairburn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Hadden Fairburn of Greenwich, and Todd Rhoads Clark, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis William Clark Jr. of Harvard, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. Ralph E. Ahlberg, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated. Mrs. Clark is a graduate of Manhattanville College. Her father retired as the chairman and chief executive officer of Cherami Pet Foods in Larchmont, N.Y. The bride is a great-granddaughter of William A. Fairburn, who was a president of the Diamond Match Company; in 1911, he invented the safety match that uses nonpoisonous sesquisulfide of phosphorous as an igniter.

title: PERSPECTIVES: The Article 7A Program; Strengthening the Court's Appointees
description: THE building is old and in dreadful condition. The tenants are getting no services and little or no heat or hot water. They appeal to the owner in vain. They withhold rent.

title: Keeping Watch On Young Eagles
description: ONE morning in March, in the heart of a freezing maple swamp, Larry Niles lived for 40 minutes at the end of a rope 80 feet in the air.

title: IN THE AUTO SOUND RACE, DETROIT SPEEDS AHEAD
description: Auto makers were never too enterprising in selling car stereo equipment. Even when retail suppliers were earning high profits from selling newfangled cassette tape decks in the late 1970's, car makers still clung to eight-track players, the Edsel of auto sound.

title: Review/Dance; A Regnier Potpourri
description: There was enjoyable rock music and good dancing but very little depth to the dances by Patrice Regnier that were presented by the Rush Dance Company at the Kitchen on Tuesday night.

title: U.S. SEES PAKISTAN MOVING ON A-ARMS
description: Despite Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's assurances this week that Pakistan does not intend to produce a nuclear bomb, the Bush Administration believes Pakistan is pressing ahead with some aspects of a weapons program, according to Administration officials.

title: Bangladeshi Insurgents Say India Is Supporting Them
description: For more than a decade, India has secretly provided arms and money to tribal insurgents fighting for an autonomous state in Bangladesh, rebels given sanctuary in this border area say.

title: A 'Show Boat' as It's Meant to Be
description: DON'T call the Paper Mill Playhouse's ''Show Boat'' a revival. It isn't likely that the theater is actually bringing back anything you've seen before, no matter how many productions of the 1927 Jerome Kern-Oscar Hammerstein 2d classic are stored in your memory bank.

title: L.L. BEAN, THIS IS A STICKUP
description: I'LL TAKE IT By Paul Rudnick. 292 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: TWELVE WHO GOT AWAY
description: While many characters in fiction are escaping, or trying to escape, from one situation or another, there are novels and stories in which the escape is more dramatic or climactic. The examples in this quiz are both physical and metaphorical escapes, drawn from best-selling books of the 19th and 20th centuries. Match each of the following escapes with its source, one of the 12 works listed alphabetically by author at far right.

title: TALKING: Resort Deals; Buying Condos to Rent Out
description: MANY people looking for a vacation home are tempted to buy a condominium or co-op that is part of a hotel or motel resort complex. Under such an arrangement the unit - whether suite, apartment or just a room - is bought outright and an auxiliary contractual agreement immediately puts it in the hands of the on-site management operating the resort. It is then available for renting out when the owner is not there, with the rental income helping to cover the monthly overhead.

title: High Time for A Culture Czar
description: To the Editor:

title: Elizabeth Hettich Wed to Ned Geeslin
description: Elizabeth Matthias Hettich, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Hettich of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Longboat Key, Fla., was married yesterday at her parents' home in Mamaroneck to Edward Geeslin 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Campbell Geeslin of White Plains and Fairlee, Vt. The Rev. Shannon Bernard, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony. Elizabeth Louise Kelleher was the maid of honor, and Jeffrey Charles Girion was the best man.

title: Honoring Three Who Exemplify Philanthropy
description: Three of New York's best-known philanthropists were honored at two parties on Monday. At the Metropolitan Museum of Art, 250 people gathered to pay tribute to Brooke Astor at a dinner-dance. The hosts were Ann Getty and Carl Spielvogel, the benefit's co-chairmen. A gold and diamond button, a copy of the museum admissions button, was presented to Mrs. Astor by Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, chairman of the museum and publisher of The New York Times. The button grants Mrs. Astor lifelong free entrance to the museum. ''A marvelous feather for my cap,'' she said.

title: A Few More Notes About Recordings
description: Roberta Hershenson's article about recording in Westchester [ ''Noise Drives Recording Musicians Into Quiet Westchester,'' May 21 ] prompts this note. It's a pity she was not aware of the series of recordings ESS.A.Y has made at SUNY Purchase with Philharmonia Virtuosi, a Westchester-based orchestra, when she prepared her article.

title: Connecticut's Precarious Tax Solution
description: IN the 1930's, when state legislatures began enacting the first comprehensive taxes, economists adopted a homely model called ''the three-legged stool'' to describe the system that seemed to work best. One leg was a property tax, the second was a sales tax and the third was an income tax. Without any one of the legs, so the theory went, a tax system would be unstable over the long haul because the other taxes would have to be too high. Eventually, 35 states conformed.

title: Role Change In New Jersey
description: LAST week's gubernatorial primary in New Jersey began what may be the final chapter in the ever-twisting tale of three politicians: Representative James J. Florio, who to no one's surprise won the Democratic race; Gov. Thomas H. Kean, who narrowly beat him eight years ago, and Representative Jim Courter, the 1989 Republican candidate who engineered Mr. Kean's victory in 1981.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Washington;
3 Mixed Projects On One Block
description: LEAD: THE $120 million Chevy Chase Pavilion, a seven-story building now under construction in the Friendship Heights neighborhood on the northern edge of Washington, will add 200,000 square feet of office space to a section of the city noted for its tight cluster of retailers such as Gucci, Neiman-Marcus and Sak's Fifth Avenue.

title:
GARDENING;
When Fruit Trees Bear No Fruit
description: LEAD: REMEMBER those mouth-watering pictures in the catalogues that entice gardeners to plant fruit trees in their backyards? Or, how about the visions of bushels of holly with bright red berries? Although plants may grow and bloom each spring, sometimes there is no fruit.

title: Alvar Aalto
description: To the Editor: Any article on the great Finnish architect Alvar Aalto is always welcome since there is little written about him in this country. Unfortunately, there are several inaccuracies in the Travel article of April 16.

title: UNDEAD AND UNSTOPPABLE
description: THE MUMMY Or Ramses the Damned. By Anne Rice. 436 pp. New York: Ballantine Books. Paper, $11.95.

title: A Paled Graduation
description: My eldest chld is graduting from high school and is on his way to college. All at once, transitions are overlapping. I have not yet touched his high school diploma, but I have dealt with a glossy pamphlet describing orientation for incoming college freshmen.

title: A Jab at Hearns
description: The president of the World Boxing Council yesterday accused Tommy Hearns of trying to smear the super-middleweight champion, Sugar Ray Leonard, by accusing him of using steroids.

title: Grace Vance Has Wedding
description: Grace Roberts Vance, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cyrus Roberts Vance of New York, was married yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Peapack, N.J., to William Clayton Jordan, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William H. Jordan of Los Angeles.

title: Aid Groups Seek Ways to Handle Tide of Refugees From Indochina
description: An international conference to ratify plans to cope with the flow of refugees from Indochina begins on Tuesday in Geneva. But diplomats and United Nations officials say the plans are sketchy, do not deal with the crisis in Hong Kong and avoid an inevitable long-term issue: the forcible repatriation of Vietnamese boat people who flee for economic reasons.

title: Caroline Danish Becomes Bride Of R. J. Thies 2d
description: The marriage of Caroline Anne Danish, a daughter of Mrs. Arthur T. Hadley and Roy Danish, both of New York, to Raymond John Thies 2d, a son of Dorothy M. Thies of San Diego and Raymond J. Thies of Center Point, Tex., took place yesterday at the Century Association in New York. The Rev. David Jenkins, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Beware, Husbands, Of the Retirement Trap
description: I read with identifiable pain Denise Boyce's article (''Beware: Retiree Within,'' May 21, Opinion) of the woes of ''Mrs. Housewife'' and her retiree husband. She spouted every cliche except, ''I married him for better or worse but not for lunch.''

title: Richard Day Wed To Miss Stimpson
description: Courtney Sutton Stimpson was married yesterday to Richard Briggs Day at St. John's Episcopal Church in Salisbury, Conn., by the Rev. Charles A. Bevan Jr. Mrs. Day, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Stimpson of Dedham, Mass., and Lakeville, Conn., is a vice president at the D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles advertising agency in New York. She graduated cum laude from Harvard University. Her father is a real-estate developer and consultant in Boston.

title: Shoreham Deal: Expensive and Foolish
description: One can only hope that all those who have favored the state-Lilco deal got a good look at an ad run the other day by Prudential-Bache Securities.

title: Image Problem
description: Not every National Football League player has the renown, the name recognition or the commercial appeal of Eric Dickerson, the Indianapolis Colts' acclaimed running back. Not only is Dickerson the highest-paid Colt, he can also command top dollar for licensing his name and likeness.

title: Anne Frank Remembered
description: ANNE FRANK would have been 60 years old tomorrow. As a 3-year-old neighbor and friend, I attended her 5th birthday party in 1934 at the apartment building Merwedeplein-37 in Amsterdam. Each guest at the party gave a gift and in turn received one. I was given a child-sized tin tea service that was as unbreakable as my memories of first friendship and life at Merwedeplein-37.

title: U.S. Rocket Expert Pleads Guilty in Egyptian Smuggling Case
description: An American rocket expert accused of trying to smuggle sophisticated weapons technology to Egypt has pleaded guilty and agreed to cooperate with investigators in an international inquiry.

title: Tigers Battle Wind and Blue Jays in 11-3 Victory
description: With the Skydome roof in the open position, the most formidable challenge for both the Toronto Blue Jays and the Detroit Tigers this afternoon was a strong wind that one player ranked worse than the famous gusts at Candlestick Park in San Francisco.

title: Crowded Jails: A Judge's Story
description: In your lead article of May 14, ''Drug Arrests Crowd County Jails,'' your reporter correctly reports the appalling overcrowded conditions in the Suffolk County correctional facilities in Riverhead and Yaphank and the frustration of the sheriff in dealing with these conditions. He further reports that both Nassau and Suffolk Counties have turned to the local courts for assistance in reducing overcrowding.

title: PLAY ME A STORY: IT'S TAPE TIME
description: Dario (D. J.) Schaeffer, a 9-year-old from Belmont, Mass., has been listening to books on tape since he was a toddler.

title: DID THE PENALTY FIT THE CRIME?
description: I am angered that Morton Hunt said almost nothing about what the crime was; the reader gets only a few general remarks plus Dr. Frazier's claim that these were unintentional mistakes. The papers I sent to Harvard speak for themselves: both the quantity and type of errors tell the tale.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: June 11, 1989
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 GATES OF PARADISE, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.50.) An orphaned young woman's quest for her lost half brother leads to sinister surprises. 2 2 TILL WE MEET AGAIN, by Judith Krantz. (Bantam, $5.95.) The exploits of a woman and her two daughters from pre-World War I Paris to present-day Los Angeles. 3 3 THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS, by Thomas Harris. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) An F.B.I. man and woman on the trail of a serial killer on the loose. 4 3 DEFY NOT THE HEART, by Johanna Lindsey. (Avon, $4.50.) These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and suermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Thailand
description: To the Editor: Your article ''Thai Tourism Shows Strains'' (Travel Advisory, April 2), may have deterred some prospective travelers who want to visit Thailand. The real situation is brighter.

title: New Signs To Warn of Interstate Delays
description: LEAD: COMPUTERIZED signs that will advise motorists of traffic delays on Interstate 95 in Darien and Fairfield are to be installed by the end of the summer, according to State Department of Transportation.

title:
DINING OUT;
An Atmosphere of Romance in Armonk
description: LEAD: RAPHAEL'S, open for just about two months, is an appealing dining spot that seems to have already attracted an enthusiastic following. Reservations are essential, particularly on weekends when the house fills. And there is much to enjoy, such as the dining room, spanking new with a suggestion of romance in the lighting and in the privacy well-spaced tables afford.

title: 18-Year-Old Texas Mother Is a Valedictorian
description: An 18-year-old mother who is seven months pregnant with another child finished first in her class at Jack Yates Senior High School and gave the valedictory address here today.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Games of Chance In Summer Fashion
description: Now, just in time for summer, the season for fun, a couple of innovative designers have put their cards on their clothes. Or, in the case of Franco Moschino, on the back of a blazer for women. For whatever reason, he has chosen the ace of hearts (and his name) both of which are embroidered on the jacket, which is selling for $1,600.

title: European Community Bans Imports of Ivory
description: The European Community has decided to ban ivory imports from Africa and to support international efforts to protect the elephants from extinction.

title: Dismaying Moan Ends Belmont Gala
description: Nothing empties a race track before the last race faster than a beaten odds-on choice in the eighth.

title: Lydia Field Emmet, a Teacher, Weds Richard Winkeller in Santa Barbara
description: Lydia Field Emmet, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Barton Hepburn Emmet of Santa Barbara, Calif., was married there yesterday to Richard Winkeller, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Winkeller of Newtonville, Mass. The Rev. Anthony F. Perrino, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Music Academy of the West.

title: As the Temperature Rises, Simplicity May Be in Order
description: SOMETIMES the best meals are the simplest. As the weather warms up, I find myself less inclined to make complicated recipes. Instead, I'd rather use a few very fresh ingredients to add flavor: herbs from the garden, good extra-virgin olive oil, lemon juice and plenty of pepper.

title: EAT, DRINK AND BE SEXY
description: KIKI'S PARIS Artists and Lovers 1900-1930. By Billy Kluver and Julie Martin. Illustrated. 264 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $39.95.

title: Charting Traditions Of Nontraditional Photography
description: The National Museum of American Art in Washington has proved that there is more than one way to celebrate the 150th anniversary of the invention of photography. While some museums have mounted historical surveys and others have zeroed in on the medium's earliest achievements, the National Museum has focused on photography's burgeoning present, a time of runaway growth and influence.

title: Reginald Thomas Is Wed To Sharon L. Shervington
description: Sharon Lyn Shervington, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norris G. Shervington of New York, was married yesterday to Reginald Thomas, a son of Leora Thomas of Detroit and the late Ralph B. Thomas Jr. Dr. Robert Berson, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society of Northern Westchester, officiated at the Union Theological Seminary in New York.

title: Health Care Leaders Disappointed by Cuomo Talk
description: Hospital administrators and labor leaders met privately with Governor Mario M. Cuomo last week to discuss New York's statewide hospital crisis, but many came away disappointed.

title: In Peru's Lush Rain Forest
description: ONCE over the snowy peaks of the Andes, all that can be seen on the flight to Puerto Maldonado, in the Amazon's southern headwaters, is an enormous dark green sea of forest. The only breaks are small clearings, increasingly frequent near the city, and rivers, gleaming silver in the tropical sun. Puerto Maldonado is the capital city of Madre de Dios, a Peruvian department that contains the largest area of pristine rain forest in the entire Amazon basin.

title: Reds Shut Out Dodgers Again, 5-0
description: Tom Browning wasn't perfect this time, but the Cincinnati Reds didn't complain.

title: Drug Fight Stresses Educational Approach
description: FRUSTRATED in their attempts to slow the flow of narcotics into Long Island, officials are trying to reduce demand for drugs through education programs.

title: Relations With U.S. Seem Badly Hurt By Crushing of Democracy Protests
description: After a decade in which China and the United States grew increasingly close, economically and diplomatically, there are signs that the warmth of their relationship may be becoming another casualty of the troops who fired on demonstrators at Tiananmen Square. Already, China and the

title: Mark A. Whitney Wed To Mary Anne Garrity
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., Mary Anne Garrity, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Garrity of Rye, and Mark A. Whitney, a son of Mrs. Richard Whitney of Exeter, N.H., and the late Mr. Whitney, were married yesterday. Msgr. Joseph A. DeAndrea performed the ceremony.

title: As Airline Competition Drops, The U.S. Takes New Interest
description: NO one in Washington suggests returning to the days of airline regulation, when routes and fares were tightly controlled and competition was limited. But the Bush Administration, along with Congress, contends that some restrictions are now needed to protect what it sees as the benefits of years of deregulation.

title: PERILS OF THE PAPER CLIP TRADE
description: FOUR YEARS AGO, THOMAS G. STEMBERG found himself in Langhorne, Pa., interviewing for a job as chairman of a wholesale club called Makro - one of those giant discount warehouses that sell everything from peanut butter to television sets. While touring the store, the then-36-year-old Stemberg noticed that the office-products department was one of Makro's busiest, though it stocked only a handful of different items. Stemberg had a brainstorm.

title: New Ethnic Violence Is Shaking India's Northeast
description: A new wave of violence in the northeastern state of Assam by tribespeople using homemade bombs, guns, and bows and arrows has caused widespread destruction and displaced hundreds of people.

title: A Rising American Impulse To Leave the Land Alone
description: ''A wilderness, in contrast with those areas where man and his own works dominate the landscape, is hereby recognized as an area where the earth and the community of life are untrammeled by man, where man himself is a visitor who does not remain.'' - From the Wilderness Act of 1964.

title: ARGENTINA PLANS TO HASTEN SEATING OF NEW PRESIDENT
description: Carlos Saul Menem, the President-elect, would assume office four months early under a political deal nearing completion here. The arrangement seeks to end Argentina's political impasse following Mr. Menem's election last month and rioting caused by rapidly rising prices.

title: Harvard Routs Yale in Four-Mile Race
description: One of Harvard's better crews routed Yale today in the schools' annual four-mile race, the oldest intercollegiate sports event of all.

title: Steinbrenner's Master Plan?
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: New Taxes Renew Complaints Of a Burden on Firfield County
description: FAIRFIELD COUNTY, particularly the towns in the corridor of afflunce known as the Gold Coast, will pay a disproportionate share of the new state taxes passed by the General Assembly, according to tax experts and legislators of both political parties.

title: Courtney Becker Becomes the Bride Of Peter Seabury Adam in Connecticut
description: At St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn., Lisa Courtney Becker, a daughter of Mrs. John Ewing Becker of New Canaan and Naples, Fla., and the late Mr. Becker, was married yesterday to Peter Seabury Adam, a son of Sydney C. Adam of New Canaan and the late Peter J. C. Adam. The Rev. Margaret H. Minnick performed the ceremony.

title: Productivity Is More (or Less) Than a Hard Day's Work
description: ''Productivity's Little Secret: Hard Work,'' a Business Forum article appearing on May 14 by Dan Subotnik, prompted an unusually large response from readers. Some of their comments follow. To the Editor:

title: Dr. Pamela Freda Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Pamela Ury Freda, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Vincent Freda of Alpine, N.J., and Peconic, L.I., was married yesterday to William Anthony Torsiglieri, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Torsiglieri of Chatham, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Donahue officiated at Trinity Lutheran Church in Tenafly, N.J., assisted by the Rev. Joseph Murphy, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Efforts Aim at Tightening Port Security
description: ALONG with the half-million cars that were unloaded last year at Port Newark and Port Elizabeth to help make them the largest shipping center in the nation were some unwanted goods. Most of the cocaine and marijuana confiscated entering the New York metropolitan region came through the ports, according to United States Customs Service officials.

title: Reading and Writing Are Bigger Than Ever
description: FOR more than a dozen years, until the mid-1970's, the annual convention of the American Booksellers Association was held in the garage of the Shoreham Hotel in Washington. But so many books are now being published, and so many publishers are clamoring to exhibit their wares to booksellers, that even the four exhibit halls of the Washington Convention Center are no longer big enough to hold them.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: The Capitol in Washington is the site for several numismatic events this summer.

title: 2 Get 3 Gold Medals At New York Meet
description: Two high school athletes, Jim Stafford and Sandra Burke, won three gold medals apiece today at the New York State Interscholastic Outdoor Track and Field Championships here. In other highlights, Brad Sumner and Zilla Higgs won two gold medals each and Cheri Goddard ran the fastest girl's 3,000 meters in the country this season.

title: Preparing Outdoor Furniture
description: WHEN summer comes, lawn, patio and picnic furniture often needs cleaning or repairing before it can be used. Getting these items ready may consist only of spraying them with a garden hose or dusting with a whisk broom or soft brush; however, with a bit more care, outdoor items can be maintained for years in like-new condition.

title: Harvard Student Found Guilty
description: A onetime altar boy who escaped from a poor Hispanic neighborhood to become a Harvard University student was convicted of committing six armed robberies during vacations.

title: TRAVEL BOOKS
description: On a recent trip to China, I found myself in one of the most un-Chinese spots on the planet. The arcades of the Lido Holiday Inn function much like an airtight space station floating in the dusty, funless void of Beijing. Outside, the winter winds howled off the Gobi Desert, but all was cozy in the pizzeria - crammed between the German sausage shop, a disco for ''overseas Chinese only'' and the city's only bowling lanes - as yesterday's pigtailed Maoists served the masses thick pies dripping with that indigestible heathen delight called mozzarella. At the next table, a ruddy Norwegian fumbled happily with Great Wall tour pamphlets. This peripatetic retiree was bursting to tell anyone that he'd just reached the halfway point on the journey of a lifetime: around the world in 30-something days. Still ahead were two each in Tokyo, Sydney, Fiji, Lima, Rio de Janeiro, Chicago, New York. An hour on Copacabana Beach, a half-hour at the Empire State Building. When it comes to modern tourism, surprise is synonymous with disappointment. In this one field of truth-seeking, we seem driven to arrive exactly where millions have stood before us, to replicate each postcard image with our own eyes. Travel, as we are coming to know it, is not an act of broad-mindedness but of literal-mindedness, an expression not of mutual understanding but of mutual suspicion.

title: Does U.S. Nuclear Aid to France Even Now Comply With Law?
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: LEAD: THE ROAD TO NIZHNEKAMSK runs 600 miles east from Moscow - a deeply rutted, two-lane blacktop that cuts across the vast, bleak flatlands of the Tatar republic. Suddenly a forest of refinery towers emerges in the distance. The air turns sulfurous. Then, Nizhnekamsk - a city of 191,000 people with tall, drab apartment buildings, billboards extolling the

title: The Script's Already Written
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Let's hope it never happens, that we'll never be in a position where we have to trim whatever standard of living we now enjoy (or perhaps endure). But unless one is particularly affluent, there are times when, in order to do one thing, something else has to go.

title: DID THE PENALTY FIT THE CRIME?
description: During the 1970's, I was a student at McGill University and an occasional research assistant to Ronald Melzack. Never was there the slightest indication that Dr. Melzack's contributions to pain research were falsely attributed to Dr. Frazier or that Frazier was recognized for research on pain. Although words, even paragraphs, were used without attribution, ideas were not stolen.
