title: Dr. Ebert Wed To Neil Fogarty
description: Dr. Blair Hilary Ebert, a veterinarian in Amityville, L.I., and Neil J. Fogarty, a lawyer for Hudson County Legal Services in Jersey City, were married yesterday at the Under Mountain Inn in Salisbury, Conn., by Rosina Rossire, a justice of the peace.

title: Neighbors Skirmish at the County Line
description: THE apparent settlement of a simmering border dispute between Westchester and Putnam Counties, over proposed landfill sites adjacent to two northern Westchester towns, began to falter last week under skirmishing by both sides.

title: Despite Tests, Turin Shroud Is Still Revered
description: It is eight months since radiocarbon tests showed it to be inauthentic, but the Shroud of Turin retains its allure for believers who venerate it as the burial cloth of Jesus.

title: No Shortage of Science Teachers in the Rockies; Scholarship Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Hamilton Hodge - Handbag Designer
description: Hamilton Hodge was not born yet when the De Vecchi handbag company was founded in Italy 45 years ago, but he has put it on the fashion map. The first De Vecchi collection designed by him appeared in March and was a success. Customers liked his woven bags in fan and basket shapes, his soft ottoman pouches and woven faille evening bags on long shoulder straps.

title: Louis Weingarden, a Composer, Dies at 45
description: Louis Weingarden, a composer, died of complications from AIDS on Thursday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 45 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Solo Voyagers
description: To the Editor: I would like to emphatically second Ellen Cole's response (Travel, April 30) to Betsy Wade's ''Getting Around Fees on Singles'' (Practical Traveler, Travel, March 12). As a traveler paying single supplements I think of writing a book ''Air Shafts I Have Known: Memoirs of a Single Traveler.'' It is certainly adding insult to injury being forced to pay more for less in the room department.

title: When the Kids Must Fly Solo
description: EVERY year Americans send more children on air trips by themselves. The figure rises as divorce, remarriage and job transfers combine and as parents settle far from grandparents. The Government does not keep a count, nor do all airlines, but, as an indication, Continental estimates that it will carry 175,000 unaccompanied minors this summer. It is the busy season, with trips to camp, summer school or divorced parents added to the brew.

title: Miss Goodman Becomes Bride Of Glyn Vincent
description: Anastasia Cole Goodman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edmund N. Goodman of Sands Point, L.I., was married yesterday to Glyn Douglas Vincent at the home of the bride's parents by the Rev. Dr. David P. Osborn of the North Shore Unitarian-Universalist Society.

title: Corrections
description: A report in Travel Advisory on May 28 misstated the telephone number of the Cartier Foundation for Contemporary Art in Jouy-en-Josas, France. It is 39.56.46.46.

title: 1989 Maple Syrup Yield Rises But Value Falls in New York
description: Despite early predictions of a short crop, New York's maple syrup farmers processed more this year than last year, the State Agricultural Statistics Service reported.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: It's a cause for attention when a brilliant connoisseur of the closed game opts for open or semiopen games. But don't be surprised if the transition shows evidence of being half-hearted.

title: Garden Party, And a Party For a Garden
description: The rain came for the third year in a row, but it didn't dampen the Museum of Modern Art's Party in the Garden dinner-dance Wednesday. The festivities were moved indoors. No one seemed to mind, and the museum raised $250,000. This year, 1,800 guests drifted among three floors, riding up and down the escalators like shoppers in a department store. There were occasional breaks in the drizzle. ''We're stepping out for a romantic stroll,'' Bob King said as he and his wife, Jodie, caught a flash of moonlight in the garden.

title: Q and A
description: Vermont

title: Child Care Centers at Stony Brook
description: In the article ''On Site Day Care Puts Companies to Test'' [ April 16 ] , you featured on-site child care centers at all local colleges, universities and state agencies except the centers at Stony Brook University.

title: A Day of Vindication For Winner's Trainer
description: Shug McGaughey always thought this would be a coronation, with Easy Goer thundering down the stretch, lengthening his lead, reminding onlookers of the way Secretariat overwhelmed the field to win the Triple Crown 16 years ago. But Easy Goer's Triple Crown aspirations ended at the Kentucky Derby five weeks ago, so yesterday's convincing victory in the Belmont Stakes was a run for respectability for a horse, a trainer and a jockey.

title: Loan Enforcers Focus on Trade Schools
description: FRUSTRATED by the growing number of people who walk away from the Government-guaranteed loans that helped finance their education, the Bush Administration is concentrating its latest crackdown not on the students or the lenders but on the final recipient of much of the money: profit-making trade schools.

title: But Not A Drop to Drink? The Water Scam
description: THE con man preps his target carefully, adding appropriate ingredients of fear, doubt and anxiety, a hefty dose of misinformation, a liter of distortion and a dash of lies.

title: Cancer Comes Home
description: WELCOME TO MY home and hospital,'' says Richard Wahlenmeier. This is Wahlenmeier's joke, but it's accurate. In his New York living room there are two couches, three shelves, a coffee table, wall-to-wall carpeting and, on the wood parquet by the front door, a metal pole supporting a computerized infusion pump and a bag of thick fluid. Pump, bag and pole make up an intravenous rig recognizable to anyone who has ever visited a hospital.

title: Women Making Mark As Business Owners
description: LEAD: THE number of women choosing to be their own bosses on Long Island is increasing. Although female-owned businesses still are the minority, their presence is being felt in a variety of industries, from gift-giving services to computer software to construction.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-21

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: AMY D. ELIEZER;
Joined in a Struggle With Extra Pounds
description: LEAD: WRITE a diet book and there's a chance you'll become a best-selling author. Manage a health club and you'll probably have plenty of members.

title: POSTINGS: Bungalows in Poughkeepsie; The Look of the Past, but Not the Prices
description: In an attempt to recreate the climate of the 1920's, a real estate developer in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., is building bungalows that mimic those that were erected in that area of the Hudson Valley 60 or so years ago. The catch is that they cost almost 20 times as much.

title: Double Jeopardy
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Vote? Some Britons Hardly Know
description: Sir Jack Stewart-Clark has represented East Sussex in the European Parliament for 10 years. Today he went out on the streets of this prosperous town in the rolling English countryside of The Weald to ask people to give him their vote again in the European elections next Thursday.

title: Keeping the Home Fires Burnng (While the Masters Are Away)
description: IT was a great old house like those of the 1930's movies, in which ''Long Island'' meant luxury without saying anything else. It overlooked the Sound, but that winter day when Ann Pearson and her daughter, Mandy, moved in, there wasn't much of a view. A big snowstorm had blown up, borne on strong winds. ''Spooky,'' Mandy said, looking out a window at the storm. ''But we're warm and safe in here,'' Ms. Pearson said. She drew the window down, tightly, she thought; there was a device on the sill that, if the window was loosened would set off the burglar alarm, a squalling outdoor horn, on the other end of the house.

title: TRIBAL FINANCE, JAPANESE STYLE
description: THE SETTING WAS THE board room of Daiwa Securities America in Manhattan, overlooking the Statue of Liberty. ''We have invited you here today so we can do business,'' Takuro Isoda, Daiwa chairman, told leaders of 24 native American governments, including the Navajo, Blackfeet and Chickasaw Nations and the Seminole Tribe of Florida.

title: A Wistful Ode to a Museum That Once Was
description: A month and a day ago, on May 10, the Museum of Modern Art marked half a century in its home at 11 West 53d Street. The museum has observed the date in part by unveiling a handsome and discreet renovation of its sculpture garden, also 50 years old, by the architects Philip Johnson and John Burgee and the landscape architect Robert Zion. Otherwise, the anniversary passed quietly, without the hoopla that has surrounded many other milestones in this institution's life. Perhaps that is just as well, since while the great structure of 1939 designed by Philip Goodwin and Edward Durell Stone still technically exists, it is a very different building in 1989: its interior has been completely rebuilt, and only the upper stories of its facade remain more or less as they were 50 years ago. And even the facade has been overshadowed and obscured by the large additions to the museum by Philip Johnson and Cesar Pelli, additions that make the Goodwin and Stone building no longer a free-standing structure in itself but merely a single element in a much larger architectural composition.

title: Sports of The Times; The Dreaded Damaged Hamstring
description: Before the Detroit Pistons and the Los Angeles Lakers resume the National Basketball Association finals today, Commissioner David Stern should proclaim, ''May the better hamstrings emerge triumphant.'' As well as untorn and unpulled.

title: Question Of the Week; Did Pitino Make The Right Move?
description: In Lexington, Ky., Rick Pitino found what he wanted: a return to the college game in a high-profile job he could keep for a long time. It will only take a few years to turn things around there in what is still one of the plum coaching positions in the country. Pitino knows he probably won't get this kind of opportunity again, thus making his move a sound investment in the future. Besides, coming to Kentucky at a time when he won't be expected to win right away is an advantage that shouldn't be overlooked. ERICH SCHRAMM Highland Park, N.J.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Hostile takeovers are a little like wars: Once they start, it's impossible to tell where they may end.'' Richard Munro, chairman of Time Inc., writing to Martin S. Davis, chairman of Paramount.

title: IT WASN'T ALL DAFFODILS
description: WILLIAM WORDSWORTH A Life. By Stephen Gill. Illustrated. 525 pp. New York: Clarendon Press/Oxford University Press. $29.95.

title: Corrections
description: A correction in this space on May 21, about a listing on April 30 for the Sintra Music Festival in Portugal, referred incorrectly to Ivo Pogorelich. He is a pianist.

title: Question Of the Week; Did Pitino Make The Right Move?
description: I believe Rick Pitino acted too hastily. He could have waited another year; the Knicks are going to be sensational in 1990, and Kentucky may not be. Like chess and checkers, moves must be planned. LOUIS KATZ New York

title: Churches Set Concert To Restore 1827 Organ
description: AN organ in the Second Congregational Church in Middle Haddam that dates to 1827 is one of the oldest surviving instruments in the country made by the Boston organ maker Thomas Appleton. It is also the only one in the state, although a rare 1830 Appleton now in the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City was originally installed in South Congregational Church in Hartford. The Middle Haddam organ has been silent for more than 40 years, and today at 3 P.M. the Recorder Choir of the Hartford church will play a benefit recital at the Middle Haddam church to raise funds to restore the organ.

title: Correction
description: The May 28 article about money for the arts, referred to above, incorrectly described Jim Jeffords of Vermont. He is a United States Senator.

title: EVERYBODY'S GETTING A PIECE OF THE ACTION
description: STOCK OPTIONS HAVE LONG played a supporting role in executive compensation schemes, but these days they're getting top billing -not only for those in the highest corporate echelons but for middle managers as well.

title: U.S. WILL OVERHAUL WEATHER SERVICE
description: After more than a decade of planning, the United States is about to overhaul its weather forecasting service with $1 billion in the newest technology and a reorganization of its network of forecasting offices.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: WASHINGTON;
3 Mixed Projects On One Block
description: LEAD: THE $120 million Chevy Chase Pavilion, a seven-story building now under construction in the Friendship Heights neighborhood on the northern edge of Washington, will add 200,000 square feet of office space to a section of the city noted for its tight cluster of retailers such as Gucci, Neiman-Marcus and Sak's Fifth Avenue.

title: Better Sound, Bigger Sales and Bitter Rivalry
description: Since the 1950's, music and cars have been inseparable parts of the national iconography. But the image of a convertible with a tinny AM radio straining to project the Top 40 above the roar of the engine and the rush of air has faded.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title: Kashmir's Heritage: Art of Papier-Mache
description: IN India, where the traveler on a shopping expedition can wallow in brass and silver and gold, brilliant silks and bold cotton hand looms, embroideries, appliques, fine leather, pottery and wood, some people never get around to the exquisite papier-mache boxes of Kashmir. That's a pity. Kashmiri papier-mache work - not only in boxes, but also in bowls, trays, lamp bases and other objects - reflects in its finely drawn and gilded decoration the Persian heritage of this Muslim frontier of India. Courtly scenes and lavish flowers are favorite themes, recalling the splendor of Mogul life and the richness of Mogul gardens.

title: DATA BANK: June 11, 1989
A Referee Savors Life in the Fast Lane
description: LEAD: RICHARD O. MANN lives life in the fast lane. Though he claims ''I can't get out of my own way,'' he deals in speed and strength, in purity of movement and form, in fractions of seconds and inches.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: JANE FREMON;
Offering an Alternative in Education
description: LEAD: IN the tradition of many pioneering women and men before her, Jane Fremon, 36 years old, began a new school just two years ago in Princeton, an area known for its good schools. Now, as director of the Princeton Friends School, her dream has become reality.

title: Yankees Are Buried by 19 Red Sox Hits
description: The Yankees took their best shot at Roger Clemens yesterday, but the wicked grounder that Deion Sanders hit in the first inning wasn't enough to knock the Red Sox ace out of the game.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Bible says, 'Thou shalt not steal,' and that's what I did.'' - Marilyn L. Harrell, accused of using Federal housing money to buy homes and cars for needy people. [ 30:2. ]

title: How Do Museums Speak the Unspeakable?
description: Last year the United States Holocaust Memorial Council in Washington issued a list of institutions and organizations that were related to the Holocaust. On the roster were 19 museums, 48 resource centers, 34 archival facilities, 12 Holocaust memorials and 26 research institutes. In the United States and abroad, edifices, museums, memorials, monuments and sculptures are being erected with near feverish intensity. Glossy pamphlets promise, in the words of one, that ''the museum will seek nothing less than to change the lives of all who enter.''

title:
DINING OUT;
Imaginative Regional Italian Cuisine
description: LEAD: THE idea of a housing development with a shopping center as an integral part of the complex is not new. Neither is the idea of a restaurant ensconced therein. But only in rare instances is there a restaurant in such a location that is worth traveling to if one lives outside the area.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: GLEN ISLAND CASINO;
At the Prom, Everyone's King and Queen for a Night
description: LEAD: THE phone rang at Glen Island Casino and Susan Berzon, an employee, picked it up. A few minutes later, she found John Mosca, the dapper general manager of the casino, and said in mock-complaining tones: ''These proms are going to be the end of me. It's another mother calling.''

title: Transformation To Pitcher
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SURPRISE FROM ROSE'S CANTINA
description: The Belmont Stakes was the last of four stakes races on a rich card at Belmont Park yesterday, and one of the supporting features provided one of the biggest upsets of the season.

title: AND STILL THEY GO A-HUNTING
description: LEAD: A CENTURY AGO, WHEN John W. Noble, Benjamin Harrison's Secretary of the Interior, sought to praise his President, he called him a ''sportsman.'' Harrison's experiences as a hunter, Noble said, accounted in large measure for his success as a lawyer and politician. In those days, the only true sports were perceived to be hunting and angling.

title: Miss Doubleday, Carl Timpson 3d Are Wed on L.I.
description: Florence McKim Doubleday, a daughter of Mrs. Paul Chase of Mill Neck, L.I., and Nelson Doubleday of Locust Valley, L.I., and Hobe Sound, Fla., was married yesterday to Carl W. Timpson 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Timpson Jr. of Locust Valley and Prouts Neck, Me. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph Roff at St. Rocco's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Cove, L.I.

title: Scientist Questioning Security Investigation
description: A man who is said to have played an important role in a security investigation of a weapons scientist has denied that he accused the scientist of mishandling secret Government documents.

title: DATA UPDATE: June 11, 1989
For Bonn and Moscow, Affinity and Suspicion
description: IF the public opinion polls are right, Mikhail S. Gorbachev will be met by a nation more taken by him than even his own when he arrives here this week on his first official visit to West Germany. Less noted, but perhaps as significant, is that Mr. Gorbachev has not rushed to visit Bonn, which trails far behind other important Western capitals on his traveling list.

title: Dispute Grows Over Cleanup of Florida Dump
description: Ten feet from a row of modest houses here, a wire fence with a ''no trespassing'' notice indicates the boundary of an inactive landfill. Two faded signs, reading ''All Materials/Effective Nov. 1, 1978/$1.65 Cubic Yard,'' are a clue to how the site became the focus of a bitter decade-long environmental dispute.

title: No Shortage of Science Teachers in the Rockies
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Fear the Team - Join It
description: In order to survive, today's industries need rapid, continuous improvement. This can be accomplished only by a totally involved and motivated work force. The workers of today and tomorrow are knowledge workers. Their greatest contribution is their creativity and their ability for self-direction. Their greatest need is for security and the opportunity for self-development. The work team represents a flexible and effective way to meet these objectives.

title: Michelle Steffens Weds
description: Michelle Steffens, the daughter of Mrs. Jack Mariucci of Marlboro, N.J., and Daniel Williams, the son of Donald Williams and Gillian Sterling, both of New York, were married yesterday at the Allaire Church in Allaire, N.J., by the Rev. Elium E. Gault, a Unitarian minister. The bride is the director of broadcast production at Drossman Lehmann Marino, an advertising agency in New York. The bridegroom is an editor at National Video Industries, videotape editors in New York. Both are graduates of the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University.

title: Special Today: The Business World
description: Magazine, Part 2/Section 6

title: Festival Promises Summer Extravaganza
description: LEAD: RUTGERS SUMMERFEST, now a well-established part of the central New Jersey summer arts season, will present a major festival in New Brunswick, with 55 performances in 57 days.

title:
TV VIEW;
Public-Access TV Is Heard in the Land
description: LEAD: Many New Yorkers confuse their adventurous public-access cable television with the garish sights and sounds that surround those channels. As viewers zap through the spectrum, they are likely to be stunned most any night by a full-breasted male or female stripper on Channel J, the commercially leased channel, or assailed by a full-throated Mayor or Comptroller haranguing the citizenry on Channel

title: Rethinking Reclama
description: The caller must have set off all the recording machines in the Central Intelligence Agency by dialing my number at the Washington Bureau of The New York Times.

title: Q and A
description: Selling the Parents' Home

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
First Encounters Of the New Home
description: LEAD: WHO wants to meet new neighbors, especialy when you're the one who's new on the block? I readily confess to ducking behind trees and dashing from car to house to avoid those first awkward moments. Call me coward. I'm the new man next door.

title: POSTINGS: On Great South Bay; 36 With Slips
description: Playing off the wildlife in and around the South Shore of Long Island, three real estate developers in Woodbury, L.I., have given the name Heron Pointe to their new project of 36 single-family houses near Bellport in the Town of Brookhaven. A distinctive feature of each of the homes is its own slip in a nearby communal marina that will be able to accommodate a boat as long as 45 feet. The marina is on a 123.7-foot wide private canal that opens onto Great South Bay across from the Davis Park ferry landing on Fire Island.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-13 China sought to arrest a dissident, Fang Lizhi, and continued to arrest others while official news organizations stepped up their criticism of the United States. Page A1

title: Too Easy to Blame Addiction for Homelessness; They're Our Neighbors
description: To the Editor:

title: Senior Egyptian Official Is in Israel for Talks
description: For the first time since the start of the Palestinian uprising, a senior Egyptian official came to Israel today, pledging his Government's continued friendship despite seeming differences over Israeli peace plans for the occupied territories.

title: Albert Spaggiari, 57, Mastermind Of Notorious Riviera Bank Heist
description: Albert Spaggiari, a photographer who confessed to being the mastermind of an elaborate 1976 bank robbery on the Riviera that captivated all of France and gained international notoriety as ''the heist of the century,'' died Friday in an undisclosed location. He was 57 years old and had reportedly suffered from lung cancer.

title: Minntech Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary tax benefits of $121,000 for the quarter and $198,000 for the year. c-Net loss The share earnings do not reflect the 5-for-4 common stock split payable on June 28, 1989.

title: Party Tilting At Windmills Of Apartheid
description: A new political party unable to choose a single leader would hardly seem ready to sell itself to the voters, but the Democratic Party is running against the grain of conventional wisdom in white South African politics.

title: National League; Smith Has 5 Hits As Cards Top Cubs
description: Ozzie Smith had the first five-hit game of his career and St. Louis rallied for eight runs in the seventh inning today as the Cardinals beat the Chicago Cubs, 10-7, for their fifth straight victory.

title: Pieter Lieftinck, Ex-Dutch Official, 86
description: Pieter Lieftinck, a former Dutch Finance Minister and top official of the International Monetary Fund, died of heart failure at his home on Saturday, a relative said. He was 86 years old.

title: Books of The Times; Curing Facial Agony With Microscope and Mallet
description: Working in a Very Small Place By Mark L. Shelton 315 pages. W. W. Norton & Company.

title: Democracy Movement: Over, for the Time Being
description: The bloodstains are scarcely visible on the pavement now, the once ubiquitous posters calling for greater freedom are now only tattered shreds, and no one dares protest as the prisons open up for those who sought change.

title: At China's Ministry of Truth, History Is Quickly Rewritten
description: In the week since the bloody crackdown on the democracy movement in Beijing, the Chinese propaganda machinery has been put into full swing, seeking to transform the event into a heroic operation that saved the country from ''a counterrevolutionary plot.''

title: Bill to Change Anti-Bias Law Is Proposed
description: The Koch administration, in an attempt to make New York City's Human Rights Commission more effective, will propose what officials describe as the most comprehensive changes in the city's antidiscrimination law since it was enacted three decades ago.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Boulet Gains On Boase Stake
description: Boulet Dru Dupuy Petit, the French advertising agency, will take more than memories away from its unsuccessful four-month effort to acquire Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership. Its capital gain upon selling Boase's stock will exceed $2 million, said Nicholas V. Baum, managing director for international operations.

title: Too Easy to Blame Addiction for Homelessness; Alcoholics Anonymous
description: To the Editor:

title: Slaying at Hearns Residence
description: Henry Hearns, a younger brother of Thomas Hearns, was held in the fatal shooting of a female friend at a home owned by the boxer, station WDIV-TV in Detroit reported today.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Liquid Refreshment for the Outer You
description: LEAD: IN recent years, water exercise, also known as aquaerobics, has become a fitness alternative to swimming. Long the staple of ''water cures'' at elegant spas, water exercise is now an increasingly popular training regimen for millions of poolgoers and beachgoers.

title: Seabrook Reinstalls 3 Valves That Delayed Reactor Tests
description: Three valves that had held up low-power testing of the Seabrook nuclear power plant have been reinstalled and the reactor temperature was back up to operating level, a spokesman said today.

title: Question Box
description: Golfing Millionaires Q. How many golfers have exceeded a million dollars in career earnings on the PGA Tour? In an alphabetical listing, which of those golfers would be the money leader for each letter based on the first letter of his last name? A. Going into this weekend's tournament, the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic, 105 golfers had reached the $1 million milestone and six letters of the alphabet did not have a million-dollar name attached to them - D, Q, U, V, X, and Y. In fact, Q and X don't even carry a golf name, for no member of the PGA Tour ever has had a last name that began with those letters.

title: Subaru of America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Memorabilia Up for Bid
description: When it comes to helping the children of Harlem, Gene Kitt is not one to shrink from stretching a point.

title: Woman Killed by Stray Bullet
description: A 29-year-old Brooklyn woman was killed by a stray bullet early yesterday as she sat in a parked car near her home in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section, the police said. Lydia Pemberton, the mother of a 9-year-old girl, was struck by a single bullet at 12:55 A.M. as gunfire erupted in front of 728 Monroe Street, a known drug location. Ms. Pemberton, of 700 Monroe Street, was pronounced dead at the scene. The police said that she had no involvement with drugs. There were no arrests.

title: White House
description: President Bush, talking about Iran in his news conference last week, used a schoolyard saying: Sticks and stones may break your bones, but names can never hurt you.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
MTV Contests: the Odder the Better
description: LEAD: CBS and NBC last month announced innovative plans to promote new shows through contests sponsored by major advertisers. But before there was talk of cash and prizes from CBS and K Mart or from NBC and Sears, there was MTV, Nabisco and a dusty stretch of West Texas.

title: Arab-Led Peace Effort in Lebanon Falters
description: Three Arab foreign ministers seeking an end to Lebanon's 14-year civil war have failed in their first effort to stabilize a shaky cease-fire.

title: Executive Aids Union In Cluett, Peabody Bid
description: A business owner who gets along well with organized labor, Spencer Hays, is teaming with the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union in a multimillion-dollar attempt to buy Cluett, Peabody & Company, the apparel maker.

title: So the Sick Can Speak
description: Once, dying was simply a matter of being no longer able to draw a breath. Today, it usually involves decisions. When should chemotherapy be discontinued? Radiation ceased? The respirator withdrawn? Ideally, patients should make those choices. Often, they are in no shape to do so. That's why in 1987, New York State's Task Force on Life and the Law proposed that patients be given the right to designate an ''agent'' to make life-and-death decisions should they be unable to do so.

title: Review/Television; Remembering Anne Frank, Holocaust's Witness
description: As an expression of monumental evil, the Holocaust is so incomprehensible and repugnant that its full impact can perhaps be absorbed only in isolated images and symbols. No matter how earnest, most ambitious dramatizations of Hitler's Germany tend to trivialize not only issues but experiences. Yet a diary kept by a 14-year-old girl hiding in an Amsterdam attic managed to capture the essence of the monstrousness. A vibrant, innocent adolescent wrote about everyday pleasures and growing fears, about life and death. And the world still listens. Had she lived Anne Frank would have been 60 years old today.

title: Charles Cola Jr., 54; Voted for Court Plan On Yonkers Council
description: Charles A. Cola Jr., a member of the Yonkers City Council during a bitter battle over housing desegregation last August, died early yesterday at St. John's Riverside Hospital in Yonkers. He was 54 years old. Mr. Cola, who was born in Yonkers, was hospitalized several times this year. The cause of his death was not disclosed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Natwest on Big Screen
description: To find tellers, National Westminster Bank U.S.A. has gone to the movies. Since June 2 the company has been running a recruitment ad before every feature film in 11 theaters in Westchester County. The inspiration came from Davis & Dorand, a New York agency that specializes in recruitment advertising.

title: What Seat Belts on School Buses Teach
description: To the Editor:

title: Coyly, the Court Turns 180 Degrees
description: With alarming disrespect for law and its own precedents, the Supreme Court has overturned one of the most significant rulings of the Court. Not of that activist, liberal Warren Court, but the Court that was headed by Richard Nixon's Chief Justice, Warren Burger. The new 5-to-4 majority, coyly pretending it was doing no such thing, has scrapped a 1971 ruling delivered by the former Chief Justice for a unanimous Court on a fundamental matter of civil rights law.

title: In New Ethics Climate, a Concern On How the Fund-Raisers Operate
description: As members of Congress solicit more and more money from political action committees, PAC's are responding by seizing on new techniques to increase receipts, from putting pressure on potential donors to offering them free trips or cars.

title: Walter Jakes, Manufacturer, 74
description: Walter Jakes, a founder, owner and for many years the chief executive officer of the Santa Fe Manufacturing Corporation, a maker of precision metal parts in the Bronx, and later a computer programmer, died of a blood ailment Friday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 74 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: ON YOUR OWN: Fitness; Elderly Enjoying Benefits of Exercise
description: HELEN GLASHOW is working out on a treadmill, panting faintly, her brow furrowed in concentration. A red digital readout on the treadmill control panel registers 2.5 miles per hour. She will keep this up for 30 minutes or so, a routine she usually follows four times a week.

title: PERU'S GUERRILLAS BECOME A THREAT TO THE CAPITAL
description: Starting from a small nucleus in the Andes, a Communist guerrilla movement has steadily grown in strength in the 1980's to now threaten Peru's coastal cities.

title: Cement Blocks From Ceiling Injure 5 at a Wedding Party
description: Five people were hurt today when cement blocks fell through the ceiling of a Long Island catering hall where a wedding celebration was taking place.

title: Too Easy to Blame Addiction for Homelessness
description: To the Editor:

title: Jersey Copes With Planning Mandate
description: The process through which this suburb and New Jersey's 566 other municipalities are matching their visions of the future against the state's new master plan for development is far behind schedule, planning officials say.

title: Supreme Equipment & Sysems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and after extraordinary tax benefits of $12,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $161,000, or 15 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: Wausau Paper Mills Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Francis B. Mooney, Naval Aviator, 72
description: Francis B. Mooney, a career naval aviator who later taught mathematics in public schools on Long Island, died of lung cancer Wednesday at his home in Southold, L.I. He was 72 years old.

title: Review/Comedy; A Duo Ponders the Creation And Other Improvisations
description: In John Monteith and Suzanne Rand's comic version of the Creation, God is a precocious tyke who boasts to his mother of having created a world in six days. Explaining how He invented people, He tells her that He made two of them, one in His own image, the other of ''spare parts.'' ''I told them they couldn't touch each other,'' God says with a chortle. ''I thought that would get them started.''

description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 11, 1989: MONDAY Amer Stores Co New First Inst Bancorp TUESDAY Chesapeake Corp Cons Nat Gas Co Fltwd Ent Inc Fluor Corp Okla Gas & Elec Co Toro Co Tri Contl Corp Wyle Labs WEDNESDAY Caterpillar Inc Gen Re Corp Heinz H J Co Nicor Inc So N E Telecomm Wallace Comp Svcs Inc THURSDAY Air Pro & Chem Inc Ennis Bus Frms Inc Millipore Corp Nat Fuel Gas Co N J SCEcorp Transamerica Corp Triton Energy Corp FRIDAY Desoto Inc Illinois Tool Wks Inc Southeast Bk Corp

title:
Market Place;
Winner in Efforts To Cut Acid Rain
description: LEAD: WHEN Wall Street's mind is on multibillion-dollar takeover battles, investors often ignore a hot stock like CRS Sirrine, which could be one of the big winners from efforts to reduce acid rain.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Beaman Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Fodder for a Ravenous Inflation
description: Like many Argentine industrial managers last week, Emilio Fischer paced his wood-paneled office overlooking the Rio de la Plata and fretted about Argentina's projected annual inflation rate of 12,000 percent.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Lomas Financial's Chief Optimistic on Recovery
description: LEAD: Jess Hay, the Dallas lawyer who built the Lomas Financial Corporation into one of the largest mortgage banking companies in the country, may be down, but he's still in business, unlike many of his peers in Texas.

title: 2 Sweeps In Playoffs
description: Neither St. Raymond's of the Bronx nor Monsignor Farrell of Staten Island had any problem with the double-elimination format of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association baseball playoffs yesterday. The Ravens beat Monsignor McClancy of Queens, 2-1 and 2-0, at Fordham, and Farrell swept Cardinal Hayes of the Bronx, 5-3 and 8-5, at St. John's.

title: Thanks to Trevino, This Is One Tough Course
description: THERE is a common trait that runs through the egos of club members who feel theirs is the best course imaginable. They cannot stand it when a superb golfer comes along and shoots a record score on their hallowed links. So they solve the problem by change. Those changes are not always for the better, though they may serve the purpose of making the course tougher. But in golf, despite common beliefs, tougher courses are not necessarily better courses.

title: At Electronics Show, Newest and the Oddest
description: Richard Brutti, president of Impulse USA, smiled and gestured proudly to a table covered with the products he will bring to market this summer. They appeared to be shoes: high-topped sneakers, deck shoes, beach thongs.

title: Moscow's View: The Bush Proposal On European Arms
description: LEAD: After the Brussels jubilee session of the NATO council in late May, many commentators adopted the following thesis: President Bush has taken the initiative in disarmament from Mikhail Gorbachev.

title: Dinosaurs Downtown
description: Traveling back to the dinosaur era will be possible through Nov. 1 at the World Financial Center in Battery Park City, in an exhibition called ''Dinosaurs Alive.'' Nineteen large-scale anatomically correct models inhabit a specially designed prehistoric setting, which visitors may see on Mondays and Tuesdays 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. and Wednesdays through Sundays 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. The entrance is at 225 Liberty Street. Admission is $6 for adults and $4 for children ages 2 to 12. Part of the proceeds are to go to the Children's Health Fund of New York.

title: Open Mind Wins by a Head
description: Open Mind finally found a worthy adversary yesterday at Belmont Park and had to run the race of her life to wear down Gorgeous in the deep stretch and win the $227,200 Mother Goose Stakes by only a head.

title: Lagos Journal; Bill Cosby's in Ebony, Yes, but Is Nigeria's Chief?
description: One of the most sought-after publications in Nigeria is the May issue of an American magazine, Ebony.

title: On Falcon Detail, Heights and Heroics
description: Balanced on an 18-inch beam 200 feet above Long Island Sound on the Throgs Neck Bridge, Kathleen O'Brien struggled in a steady rain to move four peregrine falcon chicks from their nest inside a chord of a truss to a safer location, a nesting box 30 feet away.

title: Radiologist Weds Nancy E. Goldberg
description: Nancy Elizabeth Goldberg, a pediatric nurse practitioner at the Harvard Community Health Plan in Watertown, Mass., and Dr. Mark Alan Goldberg, a chief resident in radiology at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, were married yesterday at Temple Emanuel in Newton, Mass. Rabbi Abraham Morhaim officiated, assisted by Cantor Samuel Pessaroff.

title: 5 Die in Fire Linked to Pan
description: An electric pan loaded with grease caught fire and spread into a blaze that left five people dead and a 2-month-old child critically injured in an apartment building Friday. The police believe a resident's failure to shut off the frying pan caused the fire, Sgt. Leonard Sykes said.

title: Sandinista Opponent Goes Home After 7-Year Exile
description: After seven years in exile, a leading member of the anti-Sandinista rebel directorate returned here today to an enthusiastic opposition welcome to take an active role in national elections scheduled for February 1990.

title: Julie A. Novick Marries a Rabbi
description: Julie Alisa Novick was married yesterday to Rabbi Michael Lee Feshbach at Temple Shaaray Tefila in Bedford, N.Y. Rabbis Carol Glass and Eugene Lipman performed the ceremony.

title: Dr. Gayle Masri Weds a Physicist
description: Dr. Gayle Debra Masri, a physician, and Dr. Barry Elias Fridling, a physicist, were married yesterday at the Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y., by Rabbi Mark Winer.

title: Time Inc. and Warner Prepare a Counterattack
description: Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. are expected to call separate board meetings tomorrow or Wednesday to approve a counterattack on the $10.7 billion hostile takeover offer from Paramount Communications Inc. for Time, people close to both companies said yesterday.

title: Vestaur Securities reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The net income figures represented net investment income. The net asset value at May 31 totaled $88,944,000, or $13.91 a share, compared with $86,011,000, or $13.45 a share, for year-ago period.

description: b-Net loss

title: Ms. Album Wed To Scott D. Heller
description: At the Philmont Country Club in Huntingdon Valley, Pa., Fredlyn Album, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Manuel M. Album of Jenkintown, Pa., was married yesterday to Scott David Heller, a son of Joan Heller of Springfield, N.J., and Seymour Heller of West Orange, N.J. Rabbi David H. Wice officiated.

title: Toby Jane Pilsner Becomes a Bride
description: Toby Jane Pilsner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Pilsner of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Dr. Joseph Elliot Saul, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Saul of Boca Raton, Fla., were married yesterday by Rabbi Morton Green at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Cecilia Gardner, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Cecilia Lynn Gardner, a lawyer for the Bank of New York, and Daniel Lee Feldman, a Democratic Assemblyman from the Sheepshead Bay area of Brooklyn, were married yesterday at the Prospect Park Picnic House in Brooklyn. Rabbi Allan Ciner, a cousin of the bride, officiated.

title: U.S. Companies Consider Options for Business in China
description: Amid the uncertainty created by the unrest in China, American companies with operations there are being urged to consider a variety of options.

title: Movies Are Adding To Prices and Places
description: There's good news and bad news for moviegoers this week.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hal Riney Awarded MONY Financial Job
description: Hal Riney & Partners/New York landed a major financial account on Friday, winning the business of MONY Financial Services. The account is worth $5 million to $7 million, according to James Travis, the agency's president. He said the first television ads for the company will break in September during a CBS program that will be sponsored entirely by MONY Financial Services.

title: 'Call Waiting,' on Hold
description: For some people, ''call waiting'' phone service is a godsend. When they are talking, it signals that someone else is calling; the listener can put call A on hold while checking out call B. It's cheaper than two phones or hiring a secretary, and it's a real help in emergencies. But the person on call A may feel angry at being interrupted.

title: Jose Lopez Rega, 72, A Backstage Power In the Peron Regime
description: Jose Lopez Rega, the power behind the scenes in the last years of the Peron Government, died of a heart attack on Friday in a Buenos Aires prison hospital. He was 72 years old.

title: Dartmouth College
description: Despite videocassette recorders, 30-channel television, vacations and career changes, ''a substantial part of what lies ahead of you is going to be boredom,'' the poet Joseph Brodsky told graduates yesterday at the 219th commencement of Dartmouth College.

title: BEI Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income c-Included an extraordinary gain of $39,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

description: * Donnelley Directory, to Earle Palmer Brown Cos., Bethesda, Md., for its mid-Atlantic Yellow Pages, with a budget of $10 million.

description: To the Editor:

title: George W. Beadle, 85, Geneticist And Nobel Prize Winner, Is Dead
description: George W. Beadle, a geneticist who won a Nobel Prize in 1958 for discoveries that contributed one of the basic concepts of modern genetics, died of Alzheimer's disease Friday at the Mount San Antonio Gardens retirement community in Pomona, Calif. He was 85 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on Saturday about American relations with China misidentified a news organization that interviewed Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. It was ABC News, not CBS News.

title: Susan Gladstone, Marketing Director, Becomes the Bride of David De Long
description: Susan Harris Gladstone, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Gladstone of Larchmont, N.Y., and David William De Long, the son of Caruth N. De Long of Yarmouth Port, Mass., and William H. De Long of West Falmouth, Mass., were married yesterday at the mansion of the Stouffer Westchester Hotel in White Plains. Cantor Bernard Fitch and the bridegroom's brother-in-law, the Rev. Patrick Goodman, a minister at the Grace Fellowship Church in Towson, Md., officiated.

title: A Frustrated Warner Head Sees His Dream Threatened
description: Steven J. Ross, the chairman of Warner Communications Inc., is clearly furious.

title: Casual Male Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Net income and included a $33,395 tax credit.

title: Packaging Plus Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Opera; 'Gotterdammerung,' Wagner's Big Booby Trap
description: The whole of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen'' is strewn with land mines for directors and performers, but the finale of the cycle, ''Gotterdammerung,'' is one great booby trap. It was not a total surprise, therefore, that the Deutsche Oper Berlin's performance at the Kennedy Center Opera House on Saturday evening blew itself to bits, not entirely owing to technological missteps. When the Brunnhilde, Ute Vinzing, seized the torch in the Immolation scene, intending to light Siegfried's funeral pyre, the flame unaccountably went out. She quickly grabbed another torch: same result. And another: again the flame went out. A standby torch was rushed in from the wings, but Brunnhilde by this time was fed up. Waving a flameless baton toward the hero's bier, she rushed to her death, no doubt glad to end it all. It was a neatly symbolic end to a frustrating ''Ring'' that consistently aroused more interest than it satisfied.

title: Captors Are Said to Transfer 6 Lebanon Hostages to Iran
description: The Observer reported today that six Western hostages in Lebanon, five Americans and one Briton, have been moved to Iran to insure their safety.

title: Seagram Co Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The latest first quarter included dividend income from E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. of $57,478,000, compared with $46,530,000 for year-ago period. The latest quarter also included equity in unremitted Du Pont earnings of $108,113,000, compared with $85,020,000 for year-ago period. The company said the year-ago first quarter did not include any Martell results and incorporated Tropicana for only three weeks. Sales represented sales and other income.

title: Warner Computer Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After income of $500,000 from an accounting change.

title: Carl Karcher Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 22
Publishing; A Secret of Many Successes: The Independent Bookstore
description: ''THE Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat'' has the kind of title that often does well in bookstore chains, but the chains balked at buying a book about strange neurological disabilities. ''The Joy Luck Club'' is well written, but like most first novels the chains considered it too risky to order many copies. And the chain stores were equally wary of new books on the inadequacies of liberal arts education (''The Closing of the American Mind''), mathematical illiteracy (''Innumeracy'') and a theoretical account of science (''A Brief History of Time'').

title: Glen Ridge Worries It Was Too Forgiving to Athletes
description: In this stately suburb, where five teen-agers stand accused of committing a sexual assault on a slightly retarded schoolmate, residents have been going over and over the case, looking for a way to explain it.

title: Kasler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
ONE OF FOUR HOMES HIT BY CRIME IN '88
description: One in four United States households was the target of a violent crime or theft in 1988, the same proportion as the previous three years, the Justice Department reported today.

title: China Seeks Arrest of Its Top Dissident
description: The Government issued a warrant today for the arrest of Fang Lizhi, China's best-known dissident, as official press organizations stepped up criticism of the United States.

title: Copyright Ruling Opens a Costly Can of Worms
description: A Supreme Court decision last week that expanded the rights of freelance photographers, writers and artists to the ownership of their work has set the stage for a wholesale reassessment of the ownership of billions of dollars in reproduction rights, copyright experts say. Among the works affected are computer programs, fiction and nonfiction writing, advertising copy, drawings and photographs.

title: Chiron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results for 1989 included a $4,909,000 charge for the purchase of certain rights to develop and market superoxide dismutase from the company's joint venture partner, Pharmacia AB.

title: Sports of The Times; David Rivers Takes the Last Shot
description: HIS statistics, as you looked at the Lakers' sheet after the third game of the National Basketball Association finals against the Pistons, were less than spectacular: 11 minutes played, 6 points scored, 3 fouls committed.

description: To the Editor:

title: Beth Mitchneck Has a Wedding
description: Beth Ann Mitchneck, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin F. Mitchneck of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Paul Edward Draper Carter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Carter of Huntington, L.I., were married yesterday. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman and the Rev. Diana Mahida, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Terrace Restaurant in New York.

title: Don't Pick a New Schools Chancellor by Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Roosevelt Home Marks Royal Hot-Dog History
description: Fifty years ago today the British King and Queen came here on a diplomatic visit and made gastronomic history. They ate their first hot dogs.

title: Student Tells the Tiananmen Story: And Then, 'Machine Guns Erupted'
description: When the Chinese Army began its crackdown in Beijing early on June 4, student demonstrators in Tiananmen Square were the focal point. A Hong Kong newspaper, Wen Wei Po, later published what it described as a firsthand account of the assault, given by a 20-year-old student at Qinghua University, whose identity the paper withheld. A translation was published by The San Francisco Examiner yesterday and is reprinted here with The Examiner's permission.

title: 'Wireless' Challengers Nipping at Cable Operators
description: Cable television franchises nationwide are facing increasing competition from a growing number of cable companies that transmit programming over the air rather than through wires. The ''wireless'' cable concerns have signed up 300,000 subscribers in areas that are waiting to be wired with coaxial cable.

title: Calling Collect? A Computer Is at Your Service
description: Human telephone operators are rapidly disappearing, hastened on their way by new equipment that can both recognize and mimic the human voice.

title: Blacks Pause To Consider AIDS Peril
description: Everyone at Christ Church in the Bronx, from little Eugena Creighton in the children's choir to the 101-year-old woman known as Mother Brightman, seemed to have something to say yesterday about AIDS.

title: Aide to New Argentine Chief Wants Military Trials to End
description: Argentina's future minister of defense has called an end to trials of Argentine military officers for human rights violations committed during the ''dirty war'' against leftist guerrillas.

title: Good News for Elephants
description: The destruction of the African elephant is one of the 20th century's grimmer monuments to human stupidity and greed. In just the last 10 years, the number of these mysterious, majestic creatures has dwindled from 1.3 million to little more than 600,000 - a kill rate that would sweep the African elephant from the face of the earth in 20 years. And to what end? Mainly, the manufacture of signature stamps, popular in Japan and other Asian countries, jewelry and ornamental carvings.

title: With a 'Remember Me?' Man Shoots 3 in Subway
description: A teen-ager seeking revenge on a group of youths he believed had robbed him of his gold jewelry the night before opened fire on them with a pistol Saturday night in a Brooklyn subway station, the transit police said.

title: 'Machine Guns Erupted'
description: An account of the Chinese Army's assault on Tiananmen Square, said to have been given by a 20-year-old student who was there. Page A9.

title: Ethel Bass Is Married
description: Ethel Bass, a producer for the ABC-TV program ''20-20,'' and Barry E. Weintraub, the president of the mechanical contracting company William Weintraub & Sons in the Bronx, were married yesterday by Rabbi Mordecai Waxman at Temple Israel in Great Neck, L.I. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Bass of Brooklyn. Mr. Weintraub is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Weintraub of Douglaston, Queens.

title: Jack McMahon, 60; Career N.B.A. Figure
description: Jack McMahon, who spent 37 years in the National Basketball Association as player, coach and administrator, died in his sleep today. He was 60 years old.

description: b-Included income of $713,000 from an accounting change.

description: George W. Beadle, who won a Nobel Prize for discoveries that contributed a basic concept of modern genetics by demonstrating how genes control the chemistry of the cell, died at the age of 85. Page D13.

title: Inflation Ruining Argentine Economy
description: As politicians worked to speed the transfer of power to President-elect Carlos Saul Menem, Argentines reeled this weekend from new figures indicating that hyperinflation is pushing this nation of 32 million people into a depression.

title: New Fall in Long-Term Rates Seen
description: Long-term interest rates, already down to levels not seen since April 1987, could fall further in coming weeks because of strong foreign and domestic demand for bonds, money market economists said.

title: Virginia Democrats Pick Governor Nominee
description: Lieut. Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, the highest-ranking elected black official in the country, has been chosen by Virginia's Democrats to be their nominee for Governor.

title: Dona Guimaraes Memorial
description: A memorial service for Dona Guimaraes, editor of the Home Design and Entertaining sections of The New York Times Magazine, will be held Thursday at 7 P.M. at St. George's Episcopal Church, at 206 East 16th Street on Stuyvesant Square. Ms. Guimaraes, 63 years old, died of lung cancer on May 8.

title: Police Seek Youth Who Fled
description: A search continued today for a youth who might have drowned in a rain-swollen creek after a high-speed chase. The State Police in Kingston said the incident began about 2 A.M. Saturday when the police were pursuing a car carrying five youths. The car had engine trouble and two youths fled on foot, Trooper Steve Hummell said. One was caught, but the other apparently tried to cross Esopus Creek here. Heavy rains have brought the creek to near flood levels and have made the current treacherous, Trooper Hummell said.

title: INSIDE
description: Moral Majority to Dissolve Proclaiming ''our mission is accomplished,'' the Rev. Jerry Falwell announced that Moral Majority would close its doors. Page A14. Time Inc. Bid Assailed Warner's chairman, Steven Ross, criticized Paramount's $10.7 billion bid for Time. He still prefers a merger of Time and Warner, which are planning countermoves. Page D1. Cliburn Competition Winner Aleksei Sultanov, a 19-year-old Soviet pianist, won first prize in the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition in Fort Worth. Page C13. title: Thor Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Reviews/Music; Two of Motown's Finest Update Their Own Sound
description: As hip-hop music overtakes gospel-oriented pop as the dominant mode of commercial black music, the generation of pop and soul songwriters and performers who grew up with Motown face a quandary. Short of totally revamping their style, how are they to continue to keep the faith of the past and still make music that sounds fresh and up-to-date?

title: Rain Helps New Corn; It's Too Late for Cattle
description: The rain has finally come to the plains, watering fragile fields of tender young plants across most of the Corn Belt and bringing green grass back to dried-up pastures.

title: UZBEKISTAN RIOTS REPORTED QUELLED
description: Troops have regained control of towns and cities in the Soviet Central Asian republic of Uzbekistan after a week of ethnic violence that killed about 100 people, newspapers reported today.

title: Pall Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Included a reduction of $6,458,000 due to the settlement of a patent infringement lawsuit. c-Included a gain equaled to 18 cents a share from the sale of its air dryer operation for both periods and charges equaled to 6 cents a share for the quarter and 9 cents a share for the 9 months, for a special inventory take- back. The year-ago quarter and 9-month nets were also restated to reflect the acquisition of RAI Research Corp. on Sept. 30, 1988, accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Insurer Offers Peru Proposal On Oil Claim
description: Overseas investors and the United States Government are closely following the efforts of an American insurance company to receive payment on a $162 million claim against the Government of Peru.

title: Ross Wetzsteon and Laura Ross Exchange Vows
description: Laura Ross, the advertising manager of Viking Penguin Inc. in New York, and Ross Wetzsteon, a senior editor of The Village Voice in New York, were married yesterday at their home in Accord, N.Y. Judge Arthur Sampsen, justice of the town of Olive, N.Y., officiated.

title: Results Plus
description: Golf Hood Wins for First Time: Robin Hood, a second-year player, won her first tournament on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, shooting six birdies yesterday on the Willow Creek course in High Point, N.C., en route to 16 points and the championship in the $400,000 Pat Bradley International. Hood, a three-time Indiana amateur champion who had won just $8,246 in 13 tournaments this year, earned $62,500 for her triumph. She is the fourth L.P.G.A. golfer to win her first career tournament this season.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I feel that I have performed the task to which I was called in 1979. The religious right is solidly in place and, like the galvanizing of the black church as a political force a generation ago, the religious conservatives in America are now in for the duration.'' - The Rev. Jerry Falwell. [ A14:3. ]

title: In Alaska's Schools, 19 Lone Graduates
description: Graduation processions barely lasted one refrain of ''Pomp and Circumstance'' at 19 Alaska high schools.

title: How Rohatyn Made Me A Socialite
description: This is the tale of how an inky, free-lance journalist in North Little Rock, Ark., climbed New York's social ladder for only a quarter, with the help of social doyen Felix Rohatyn, with whom I am now on a first-name basis.

title: Pamela Rollins Marries A. E. Camacho
description: Pamela Lucy Rollins and Alejandro Enrique Camacho, both lawyers in New York, were married yesterday at their home in Southampton, L.I., by Rabbi David Greenberg.

title: Big Gains By Stocks In Nasdaq
description: The broad-based Nasdaq composite index has quietly moved within a whisker of its record high, showing the extent of this spring's surprising stock market rally.

title: Klansman Abusive of Officer Is Told to Study Scout Oath
description: A leader of the Ku Klux Klan has been found guilty of orally abusing a police officer and has been ordered by a judge to memorize the Boy Scout oath and laws.

title: Time's Outside Directors Seen as Having Key Role
description: If past takeover battles are any indication, the eight outside directors of Time Inc. will play a pivotal role in shaping the outcome of the battle with Paramount Communications Inc.

title: Dr. Evelyn Attia Weds a Physician
description: Dr. Evelyn Attia, a resident in psychiatry at the New York State Psychiatric Institute at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, was married at the Park Avenue Synagogue yesterday to Dr. Marcel Laufer, an attending physician at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. Rabbi David H. Lincoln officiated.

title: Cobb Resources reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said $1,076,000 of the year-to-date loss is attributable to its London mine, of which $745,000 is non- cash fixed asset cost recovery through depreciation and depletion. It said the balance of the loss is due to a combination of decreased production and lower prices of oil and gas than in prior periods.

title: Central Bankers Assail U.S. for Budget Deficit
description: In unusually harsh language, the world's central bankers said today that the United States' failure to make further progress in reducing its budget deficit was ''deplorable.''

title: Bridge
description: It seems likely that the winners of the fourth Epson Worldwide Bridge Contest, played around the world on Friday, are two men from Nova Scotia, Canada. Karl Hicks of Dominion and Ron Macdonald of New Waterford scored an astonishing 78.17 percent, easily the highest score reported in North America. Scores from the rest of the world are not yet available, but it will be surprising if anyone can match that effort.

title: Sunday Papers Facing New Rival for Ads
description: A chain of free weekly newspapers ringing St. Louis has announced a venture intended to compete with The St. Louis Post-Dispatch for the colorful circulars and classified advertising that have come to be a lucrative part of Sunday papers.

title: Three Strong Leaders
description: America has a new house guest. He is the astrophysicist Fang

title: F. S. Lane Weds Madeleine Adler
description: Madeleine Wing Adler, the vice president for academic affairs at Framingham (Mass.) State College, and Frederick S. Lane, the director of the master's program in public administration for business executives at Baruch College in New York, were married yesterday by Rabbi Robert S. Goldstein at the home of John Carafoli in Sagamore Beach, Mass.

title: Barbro Heinz Has Wedding
description: Barbro Engstrom Heinz, an interior designer, was married yesterday to Julius Rudel, the opera and symphony conductor. Judge Judith S. Kaye of the New York State Court of Appeals officiated in the bridegroom's Manhattan home.

title: Spain's Long Wait Ended by Sanchez
description: Soon after she won the match that vaulted her into a showdown with Steffi Graf in the final of the French Open, Arantxa Sanchez received a telephone call from Spain. It was from Lili de Alvarez, who lost the 1928 Wimbledon final to Helen Wills. She was calling because Sanchez had just become the first Spaniard since then to reach the women's final of a Grand Slam tennis tournament.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * C3 Inc., Herndon, Va., a computer systems company, named John P. Riceman and Samuel R. Strickland senior vice presidents.

title: Moral Majority to Dissolve; Says Mission Accomplished
description: Proclaiming that ''our mission is accomplished,'' the Rev. Jerry Falwell announced today that Moral Majority would close its doors this summer.

title: Paige A. Gilbert Becomes a Bride
description: Paige Alison Gilbert, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gilbert of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Daniel Jon Goldfarb, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alvin F. Goldfarb of Bryn Mawr, Pa., were married yesterday at the Chieftans in Greenwich, Conn., by Rabbi Peter Weintraub.

title: Norman Believes Best Is Yet to Come
description: THOSE who feel Greg Norman is not one of the world's half-dozen best golfers should listen to the Australian's assessment of his near future.

title: Europe Adopts Car Pollution Rules
description: Under growing pressure from environmentalists, the European Community on Friday adopted the pollution standards used in the United States for small cars sold in its 12 member countries.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Newspaper Ads Up
description: Newspaper advertising increased 3.5 percent in the first quarter of 1989 from the comparable period last year, the Newspaper Advertising Bureau reported on Thursday. Of the $7.31 billion spent, retail advertising accounted for $3.61 billion, representing a 4.8 percent rise over last year's first quarter. Classified and national advertising increased 2.4 percent and 1.7 percent, respectively.

title: 2 at Chinese Consulate in San Francisco Seek Asylum in U.S.
description: Two young officials of the Chinese consulate here have announced that they are seeking political asylum because they can no longer support the actions of their Government or lie about the shootings of demonstrators in Tiananmen Square.

title: Shaer Shoe reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Bonn Is Eager as Gorbachev Visit Begins Today
description: Bonn festooned its main thoroughfare with huge Soviet and West German banners today as the nation prepared for the long-awaited coming of Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Irwin Toy Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Premier Choix: TVEC Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest results included the operating results of Super Ecran and Canal Famille; the prior year did not include Canal Famille. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Vintage Group Inc reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: Reviews/Ballet; Cynthia Gregory in 'Swan Lake'
description: Cynthia Gregory and Serge Lavoie, a guest from the National Ballet of Canada, were seen Saturday night for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera House in the leading roles of American Ballet Theater's ''Swan Lake.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Three Leave Doyle Graf In Protest
description: Three top executives of Doyle Graf Raj walked out on Friday to form an independent advertising agency, accusing Doyle Graf's chief executive of trying to find a buyer for the small New York agency despite an earlier agreement to sell it to them.

title: Yanks Take 2 From Red Sox
description: The Don Mattingly windup doll is back, working as effectively as ever. Dallas Green, who this year got to play with it as the manager for the first time, has belatedly discovered what he was doing wrong: He wasn't winding it up early enough.

title: Business and Scholarship: A New Ethical Quandary
description: Scientists, administrators and lawmakers are increasingly worried that the lure of money threatens to compromise the quality and conduct of scientific and medical research.

title: Security Tag Systems Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income and after a gain of $70,149 from an accounting change.

title: Shrinking Live Gates
description: When Sugar Ray Leonard and Thomas Hearns meet in their rematch tonight, millions of people will be watching, resulting in gross receipts of about $80 million, according to the promoter, Bob Arum. But only a small portion of that audience -about 15,000 - will watch the fight live in an outdoor stadium at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, Nev., and the ''live gate'' will be an infinitesimal part of the gross receipts.

title: Angolans Reported Escaping Into Namibia
description: Hundreds of Angolans are fleeing into neighboring Namibia to escape fighting between right-wing Angolan rebels and Government troops, a Namibian spokesman said today.

title: Honoring One Whose Words Survived
description: Anne Frank, who would have been 60 years old today, died in the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp a few months before the end of World War II. Her celebrated diary was published two years later in the Netherlands, and then translated into many languages. To observe the anniversary, a number of events have been scheduled.

title: 45 Minutes of Terror in Bar Ends With Arrest of Off-Duty Officer
description: LEAD: An off-duty transit police detective, brandishing a pistol in one hand and a drink in the other, terrorized patrons in a topless bar for 45 minutes in Brooklyn Heights Saturday night, before shooting and critically wounding a stranger from point-blank range, the police said.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday Retail Sales ... May Current Account ... 1st Qtr. Wednesday Business Inventories ... April Thursday Balance of Trade ... April Industrial Production ... May Capacity Utilization ... May Friday Consumer Price Index ... May Housing Starts ... May

title: Ultimap International Corp reports earnings for 10mo Jan 31
description: Comparable year-ago figures were not available because the company changed to a Jan. 31 fiscal year from a March 31 year when it was consolidated with Ultimap Corp. last June.

title: Frenchman Wins The Tour of Italy
description: Laurent Fignon took a long leap back toward the top of professional bicycling today as he won the Tour of Italy.

title: Malibu Keeping Sheen as Honorary Mayor
description: The actor Martin Sheen may remain honorary mayor of Malibu despite the impromptu welcome he gave the homeless, the Chamber of Commerce has decided.

title: Thornburgh Waging A Personal War On Disclosures
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh detests unapproved disclosures of news.

title: Outdoors: Unpredictable Clay Targets
description: LEAD: BUFFALO BILL, said the poet e. e. cummings, could ''break onetwothreefourfive pigeonsjustlikethat.'' But he might have had a hard time in the Sporting Clays competition at the North American Game Fair, which concluded yesterday at the Mashomack Preserve Club in northern Dutchess County.

title: Three Killed in a L.I. Collision
description: Three people were killed and two others were injured when a drunken driver making a left turn collided with an oncoming car, the Suffolk County police said today. They said that Anthony Madonna, 37 years old, of Huntington Station, turned into the path of a car driven by Denise Vetrano, 20, of Seaford, at about 11:15 p.m. Saturday. Mr. Madonna, who was charged with driving while intoxicated, died at 3:45 a.m. today. Two passengers in his car were also killed: 34-year-old Ronald Fossing and 38-year-old Bruce Gundersen, both of Huntington Station. Ms. Vetrano and a passenger in her car were injured.

title: Ojeda's 6-Hitter Sets Back Pirates
description: After losing three straight games in the last inning, the Mets finally got their act together today. And in one of their rarer performances of a mystifying season, they combined pitching with hitting on the same day in the same stadium, scored five runs inside two innings, coasted behind the six-hit pitching of Bob Ojeda and subdued the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-1.

title: Custody Battle in Utah's Top Court Shines Rare Spotlight on Polygamy
description: The main route into this thumbnail-size town is barely marked - just a tiny street sign on a red dirt road, easy to miss without detailed directions. There is no reason to increase the size of the sign. The people of Hildale would rather not be found.

title: Review/Theater; Stratford Offers Majesty, Mirth, Farce and Gore
description: When John Neville began his reign as artistic director of the Stratford Festival, he vowed to restore the company to a position of artistic and financial stability. Through a combination of theatrical acumen and pragmatism - seasoned with a dash of audacity - the director has gone a long way toward accomplishing that goal.

title: Ms. Bhutto Makes Her Case
description: Pakistan's Prime Minister, Benazir Bhutto, has rightly won U.S. backing for a new Afghanistan policy that combines aid to the guerrillas with negotiations. She has also gained, and merits, the benefit of the doubt on her assurances that Pakistan does not intend to develop nuclear weapons. Hard questions remain, but not about her poise and persuasiveness.

title: Hurricane Phone Service
description: The Hurricane Hot Line will resume this year when a storm threatens, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said today. The hot line is a telephone service providing information on the progress of named tropical storms and hurricanes. The number is 1-900-410-NOAA. Calls cost 50 cents for the first minute and 45 cents for each additional minute.

title: Peter Miller Wed To Valerie Marcus
description: Valerie Marcus, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Marcus of New York, and Peter Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Myron Miller of Lexington, Mass., were married yesterday at the home of Barbara Kopple in Lake Mohegan, N.Y., by Rabbi Helene Ferris.

title: Alterio Resources Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said in both the latest and year-ago first quarters, net income equalled less than one cent a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Reviews/Music; Rhetoric and Reflections From Jackson Browne
description: Midway in his concert at Radio City Music Hall on Saturday evening, Jackson Browne commented that some reviewers had complained that the song he was about to sing, ''Lives in the Balance,'' was too much of a speech. That was all right by him, he said, because its message - the United States supported repressive right-wing governments in Central America - was so urgent. Mr. Browne followed ''Lives in the Balance'' with ''The Word Justice,'' another even more pointed ''speech'' on the same general topic, from his latest album, ''World in Motion.''

title: Chang, 17, Captures French Open
description: Michael Chang wrote the final chapter to his amazing story at the 1989 French Open today, beating Stefan Edberg for the championship, 6-1, 3-6, 4-6, 6-4, 6-2, in yet another steady come-from-behind effort.

title: Spain Is Transformed Into Builder's Paradise
description: As 1992 draws closer, Spain's urban and rural landscapes have turned into a builder's paradise.

title: A Life Vest for Infants
description: Mustang Manufacturing, a firm in Bellingham, Wash., has developed a life vest designed to cradle an infant on the surface of the water.

title: Bunny Benenson Wed to Physician
description: Dr. Bunny Susan Benenson, a pediatrics resident at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx, and Dr. Andrew Jonathan Roth, a psychiatry resident at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York, were married in Weston, Conn., yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. William Osler Benenson and Dr. Esther Siev Benenson. Rabbi Jon Haddon officiated. The bride, who will retain her name, graduated from Wesleyan University, cum laude, and from Cornell Medical College. Her father retired as an assistant medical examiner for the city of New York. Her mother is the executive director of the Flushing (Queens) Manor Nursing Home and Flushing Manor Care Center.

title: American League; Brewers Set Back Slumping Orioles
description: Rob Deer, a pinch-hitter, doubled home the go-ahead run in the ninth inning today as the Milwaukee Brewers beat Baltimore, 3-1, sending the Orioles to their fourth loss in five games.

title: Marketing: Boxing's New Knockout
description: IT'S no accident that the fight promoter Bob Arum has taken to speaking of ''sound bites'' - television jargon for footage that is catchy enough to make it onto the home screen. When Arum signed Sugar Ray Leonard and Thomas Hearns to fight tonight at Caesars Palace, he feared that the press's reaction to the bout might hurt him at the box office. So he chose to circumnavigate the print medium and make television his primary means of reaching the ticket-buying public.

title: F.B.I. Opening Door to Wide Use Of Genetic Tests in Solving Crimes
description: Quietly, without fanfare in recent weeks, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has introduced into everyday American criminology a revolutionary new laboratory identification process, DNA profiling, that is considered the most important breakthrough in forensic science since fingerprinting.

title: What's in a Name?
description: Many radio stations use call letters applicable to the station's format, such as WFAN, the all-sports station in New York. So it would seem likely that the stations KURV, WBAT, WRUN, WIFF and WRBI took those call letters because they broadcast major league baseball games.

title: Tax-Exempt Issues Abundant This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues this week is confined to the bill market and today's regular auction of new three-month and six-month securities.

title: Take Me UP to the Cubs! (The Roof: $600 a Game)
description: Wrigley Field has been called the cathedral of American ball parks, and not just because the faithful go there to pray for miracles.

title: Reviews/Ballet; Cynthia Harvey as Odette In Baryshnikov's Version
description: American Ballet Theater's new ''Swan Lake'' returned to the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday night in a performance that clearly revealed the production's good and bad aspects.

title: American Claims Evaluation Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Reviews/Music; Softly, but With Contrasts
description: Rowena Arietta, a pianist from the Philippines who has studied at the Moscow Conservatory and the Manhattan School of Music, made her New York debut at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening. She is one of those players who produce a small sound that does not always project as it might, yet whose readings are so thoughtfully conceived and gracefully executed that the listener is drawn into them.

title: Venice Journal; Dying Sculptor Races Against Time and Vandals
description: The architectural centerpiece of the Venice High School campus is a giant iron cage inside which can be glimpsed an old man clambering laboriously over a temporary scaffold.

title: In D'Amato's Town, Pride and Questions
description: Here on D'Amato Drive, around the corner from a sign saying, ''Entering Island Park, N.Y., U.S.A., Home of Al D'Amato, U.S. Senator,'' homeowners respond with hollow laughs when asked if they used connections to qualify for their federally subsidized houses.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about how former President Ronald Reagan is living in retirement misidentified a literary agent who is handling two projects for Mr. Reagan. He is Morton Janklow.

title: Easy Goer's Other Victory
description: To those whose interest in horse racing is piqued only by the prospect of a Triple Crown every few years, Easy Goer's eight-length trouncing of Sunday Silence in the 121st Belmont Stakes Saturday may have been disappointing and baffling. Sunday Silence had beaten Easy Goer by 2 1/2 lengths in the Kentucky Derby and by a nose in the Preakness. Why didn't he beat him again?

title: 'Gorky Park' Is Alive And Well in Moscow
