title: Lauder Drops an Ad Naming Slain Officers
description: Ronald S. Lauder, a Republican candidate for mayor, yesterday agreed to withdraw a campaign commercial listing the names of police officers killed in the line of duty after the father of a slain officer objected.

title: Harold's Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a $119,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Decline
description: Prices of Treasury securities tumbled yesterday, with the longer maturities bearing the brunt of the decline. Dealers attributed the initial heavy selling to a weaker dollar in overseas currency markets and profit taking by Japanese financial houses.

title: Edberg Upset by a Teen-Ager Again
description: Stefan Edberg was upset today in the first round of the Queen's Club tournament by 18-year-old Nicolas Pereira of Venezuela. The defeat came just 48 hours after the Swede had battled through a five-set French Open final before losing to Michael Chang.

title: Dow Slides 15.30; Program Trading Cited
description: Program trading continued to dominate the stock market yesterday, pulling prices down as both bond prices and the dollar weakened. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 15.30 points, to 2,503.54.

title: Analogic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included $6,558,000 from the sale of Analog's 25 percent interest in a joint venture, Medical Electronic Laboratories Inc. Year-ago third quarter revenue included $10,232,724 from the sale of the joint venture interest and about $5.6 million attributable to the operational results of the venture for which no such revenue was reported during the latest third quarter.

title: Quayle Meets Leader of Salvadoran Rightist Party
description: Vice President Dan Quayle met today with Roberto d'Aubuisson and other leaders of the governing right-wing Arena party and emphasized the need for respect for human rights at a time of growing political violence in El Salvador.

title: Ex-Mayor Wins In Jersey City's Runoff Election
description: Former Mayor Gerald McCann won a runoff election tonight for the job he lost four years ago, defeating Glenn D. Cunningham, the City Council President.

title: Bonn Declaration: 'Heal the Wounds'
description: Bolstered by a chorus of ''Gorby! Gorby!'' from thousands of admiring Bonn residents, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev joined Chancellor Helmut Kohl today in signing a declaration defining what both said was a new stage in Soviet-West German relations.

title: Robbins & Myers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Three D Departments reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Toy Boat and Baby Strollers Are Recalled
description: A toy boat and three types of baby strollers are being recalled because of the danger of choking children, the Consumer Product Safety Commission has announced. The Federal agency also issued a warning about a crib toy.

title: International Container Sysems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
More Florida Oranges
description: As Florida's citrus industry heads into the last month of the 1988-89 harvest, government forecasters have reported that about two million more boxes of oranges were harvested last month than they originally calculated. The joint Federal and state forecast projected on Monday that the harvest, which ends July 1, will total 146.3 million boxes of oranges and 55.35 million boxes of grapefruit. The grapefruit estimate was reduced by 500,000 boxes from the estimate a month earlier.

title: Poll Says Two-Thirds Back Bush on Beijing
description: Two-thirds of Americans approve of the way President Bush is dealing with recent events in China, and majorities concur with several of the Administration's recent policies toward China, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Argentine Accepts Early Transition
description: In a reversal, President-elect Carlos Saul Menem said today that he will take office June 30, the day President Raul Alfonsin said he will resign.

title: From Summer Bounty, Fresh Salmon Patties
description: HERE is a menu to take advantage of the season's bounty: Tomato salad with red onion and basil Salmon and green beans Pojarski with cucumber hot sauce Parsley potatoes Ice cream or sherbet Chardonnay.

title: Soviets Find Organized Crime Gaining Hold
description: The Soviet Government reported a deepening of its problems with organized crime today, in part because easier travel abroad has encouraged Soviet gangs to seek international ties.

title: Luby's Cafeterias Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
A Cure for Compassion Fatigue
description: Thousands of Indochinese continue to flee their homelands, often in the face of death on the high seas, as they have for more than a decade. In recent years they have encountered an increasingly chilly reception, all coming to a head in an international conference now under way in Geneva. There the British Foreign Secretary, Sir Geoffrey Howe, reflecting the views of many participants, categorized the boat people as economic emigrants rather than refugees and demanded their forcible return to Vietnam.

title: Imelda Marcos Sings Love Songs
description: Imelda Marcos has released her first record album, on which she sings her husband's favorite love songs. Her producer says a music video is to follow.

title: The Nomads Of New York Foster Care: Overnighters
description: The children who arrive here in the middle of the night often have nothing with them but the clothes they wear.

title: Diversified Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included income of $112,000 from discontinued operations for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After a loss of $26,000 for the quarter and income of $2,455,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations.

title: Arms Chiefs in Congress Urge New U.S. Position on Missiles
description: The chairmen of the Senate and House Armed Services Committees urged the Bush Administration today to change the United States position on mobile missiles when the strategic arms talks resume next week.

title: In Mideast, Don't Bet on Elections to Bring Peace; Baker Is Steadfast
description: To the Editor:

title: Retail Sales Up by Only 0.1% in May
description: Sluggish automobile and department store purchases slowed the pace of retail sales in May to an increase of one-tenth of 1 percent, the Government reported today. Analysts said they did not expect much improvement soon.

title: Citibank Loan-Loss Plan
description: Citibank announced yesterday that it would shield its shareholders' profits from losses on loans to Argentina, by deducting the losses from reserves and not replenishing the reserves.

title: One Ethiopean Rebel Army Agrees to Peace Talks
description: Tigrean rebels fighting the Ethiopian authorities announced today that they had accepted an offer of unconditional peace talks from the Government of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam. The Tigre People's Liberation Front, which this year seized control of virtually all of the northern province of Tigre in its 14-year war against the Government, said it was prepared to start talks within a month.

title: Corcoran, to Foil Dispute, Drops Mapplethorpe Show
description: The Corcoran Gallery of Art has canceled a planned retrospective of the work of the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe, anticipating that its content would trigger a political storm on Capitol Hill.

title: Foreign Golfers Seek Tournament Relief
description: Seve Ballesteros walked out of a meeting today with Deane Beman, commissioner of the PGA Tour, and claimed Beman had refused to consider proposals to allow foreign members of the Tour to play fewer than the minimum of 15 tournaments a year.

title: Mestre Journal; Life With Glamorous Venice Isn't All Romance
description: This, some would argue, is the real Venice.

title: Abdul-Jabbar Winds Up 20 Years to Warm Goodbye
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the 7-foot-2-inch center who added ''sky hook'' to the pro basketball lexicon, ended his 20-year career tonight as the Detroit Pistons swept four games from the Los Angeles Lakers to win the National Basketball Association championship.

title: Gorbachev Urges Greater Trade And Much Closer Ties With Bonn
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called today for much closer economic cooperation between the Soviet Union and West Germany and declared the current level of trade between the two countries ''ridiculously low.''

title: About New York; Adrift 50 Years, Holocaust Victim Finds Family
description: This is the story of a baby who lost her mother to the Holocaust a half century ago, grew up in Britain as a Baptist thinking she had no family of her own and journeyed here last month at the age of 53 to find herself part of a large and loving Jewish family.

title: Dairy Mart Convenience Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Net income The latest quarter results included a nonrecurring pretax charge of $800,000 for corporate restructuring related to consolidation of certain administrative functions. Year-ago quarter results included a nonrecurring pretax credit of $2,904,000 related to the signing of a wholesale grocery contract and the sale of midwest warehouse assets. Sales represented sales, including franchises.

title: Perks Clinch Tyson-Williams
description: There finally will be a news conference tomorrow in New York to announce Mike Tyson's next title defense, against Carl Williams, on July 21 at the Convention Center, adjoining Trump Plaza, in Atlantic City.

title: Charles Rutherford, 97, Canadian War Hero
description: Charles Rutherford, a Canadian who was the last surviving holder of the Victoria Cross in World War I, died Sunday at the Rideau Veterans Home in Ottawa. He was 97 years old. Mr. Rutherford won the medal on Aug. 26, 1918, when the Canadian platoon he was commanding captured a French village, giving observers a view of the defenses of the German Hindenberg Line.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
ITT Appoints Chief For Automotive Unit
description: LEAD: The ITT Corporation yesterday appointed Hubertus von Gruenberg as president and chief executive of ITT Automotive Inc., as well as corporate senior vice president.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Executive Quits Ogilvy Over Job
description: OGILVY & MATHER WORLDWIDE announced yesterday that Norman C. Berry, creative director of its troubled New York office, as well as worldwide creative director, had resigned from the agency.

title: Tackling Proposition 42
description: John Chaney, the Temple basketball coach, said yesterday that he was thinking of organizing a summit meeting of coaches and university presidents to devise a strategy for fighting Proposition 42, the N.C.A.A. rule that links financial aid for athletes to academic performance.

title: Abraham Chasanow, 78, an Aide Vindicated in Navy Security Case
description: Abraham Chasanow, a retired Navy Department official who was suspended as a security risk in July 1953 and restored to his position 13 months later, died of an aneurysm Sunday at the Atlantic City Medical Center. He was 78 years old and had homes in Silver Spring, Md., and Miami.

title: U.S.-Financed Research Data Are Being Sold, Weiss Says
description: Universities are increasingly giving advance word on the results of federally financed research to foreign and domestic companies willing to pay for the privilege, the chairman of a House subcommittee said today.

title: Anson McArthur, 65, Penn Station Architect
description: Anson James McArthur, a New York architect who oversaw the development of the Madison Square Garden-Pennsylvania Station complex, died of lung cancer Sunday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 65 years old.

title: Italy President Asks Premier To Form a New Government
description: President Francesco Cossiga today invited the caretaker Prime Minister, Ciriaco De Mita, to try to form a new Government, but no progress toward ending Italy's latest political crisis is expected until after Sunday's elections for the European Parliament.

title: Home Loan Banks Reduce Offering to $2.29 Billion
description: An improved environment for savings institutions caused by the recent decline in rates is apparently reducing the borrowing needs of the Federal Home Loan Banks.

title: Books of The Times; Warhol on Warhol, as Dictated by Warhol
description: The Andy Warhol Diaries Edited by Pat Hackett 807 pages. Warner Books. $29.95.

title: Costco Wholesale Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 7
description: b-Included a $1,160,000 gain on the retirement of subordinated debentures and a $1,696,000 tax credit. Year-ago quarter and 9 months net was reduced by $2,700,000 by a charge to cover closing costs of the company's three midwest warehouses.

title: Bush, in Driver's Seat, Sets Clean Air Course
description: Although he noted that it could be dangerous for him to get behind the wheel because he seldom drives anymore, President Bush took a couple of laps around the track today in a Chevrolet Corsica fueled by ethanol and Nebraska corn.

title: Emil Verban, 73; All-Star Infielder
description: Emil Verban, a second baseman noted primarily for his fielding with four National League teams from 1944 to 1950, died last Thursday in Quincy, Ill., after suffering a stroke. He was 73 years old.

title: DOZENS OF ARABS SEIZED BY ISRAELIS
description: The Israeli Army announced the arrests today of dozens of Palestinians accused of firebomb attacks against fellow Arabs and military targets in the last 16 months. Shortly after the announcement, the army demolished four West Bank houses and sealed seven others.

title: State Workers Due a Say in Pension Fund
description: To the Editor:

title: Movie Merchandise: The Rush Is On
description: While ''Batman,'' ''Ghostbusters II'' and ''Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade'' fight for mastery at the box office this summer, toy Batmobiles, Ecto-plazm and bullwhips will compete for display space on store shelves around the world.

title: Bangor Journal; In Touch With Nature, In Touch With Tragedy
description: On any list of what Mainers feel passionate about, high up would certainly be hunting, fishing and black flies. These days, there is a lot to get worked up about on all three counts. Heartbreak Goes On

title: A Computer-Age Dog Tag
description: Animal lovers who have relied on dog tags or tattoos to identify their pets can now turn to a more high-tech solution: the microchip implant. Pet owners can have a veterinarian implant the chip in their dog or cat for about $40.

title: The Pentagon
description: What to do about the nation's land-based missile forces? And whose missile is it anyway?

title: Bonneville Pacific reports earnings for Year to April 30
Coach at Ohio State Accepts Maryland Post
description: Gary Williams, leaving Ohio State after three seasons to return to his alma mater, was named basketball coach yesterday at Maryland, taking over a program that is being investigated by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for possible recruiting violations.

title: Klima's Off-Ice Woes Growing at Fast Rate
description: Almost four years ago, Petr Klima was running from his past and from Czechoslovakia to his future and his freedom in the United States.

title: Shearson Fills Key Positions
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., a unit of the American Express Company, yesterday announced a series of appointments in its merchant banking division, including that of James A. Stern to head the unit.

title: Fran Allison, 81, the Human Side Of 'Kukla, Fran and Ollie' Show
description: Fran Allison, the warm-voiced human component of the popular television show ''Kukla, Fran and Ollie,'' died of bone marrow failure at the Sherman Oaks (Calif.) Community Hospital yesterday. She was 81 years old and lived in Van Nuys, Calif.

title: Najibullah Refuses To Depart as a Step To Afghan Accord
description: President Najibullah today rejected demands for the removal of his Soviet-backed Government as a first step toward a political settlement of the war in Afghanistan.

title: Choice of New President Criticized at Northeastern
description: Northeastern University announced Monday that John A. Curry, executive vice president of the university, would be the new president, a choice that drew strong objections from some faculty members.

title: Real Estate; Ramada's Times Sq. Hotel Plans
description: MANY New Yorkers accustomed to the social quagmire around Times Square consider it the last place to look for a room in a quality hotel. Yet executives of hotel chains, as well as real estate developers and consultants to the hospitality industry, see a golden future for hotels in the area.

title: Glenn McQuillen, Outfielder, 74
description: Glenn (Red) McQuillen, a light-hitting reserve outfielder for the St. Louis Browns of the American League from 1938 to 1947, died last Thursday at his home in Gardenville, Md., a suburb of Baltimore. He was 74 years old.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Off to the Country

title: Drop Steeper In Week for Bank Yields
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts continued to fall for the week ended yesterday, and the declines were steeper than in the previous week.

title: High Wattage Payday
description: James Watt, having quit as Secretary of the Interior under Ronald Reagan, made eight phone calls, spent 30 minutes talking to an old colleague and called it work. The pay for this toil was $300,000.

title: Two Simple Tax Incentives Could Give Wall St. a Shot in the Arm
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Television; U.S. Diplomats Delicately Discuss the U.N.
description: Tonight, the hawks lie down with the doves. ''The First Annual Report on the United Nations,'' on Channel 13 at 9, brings together six former chief American delegates to the United Nations to address the question, ''What's in it for the United States?'' The question, it turns out, is the most provocative thing about the hour.

title: Two Issues Set By Londontown
description: The Londontown Holdings Corporation and its Londontown Corporation yesterday announced the offering of two new issues through Kidder, Peabody & Company as sole underwriter.

title: Hearns Shows He Can Take A Punch
description: As the Sugar Ray Leonard-Thomas Hearns fight ended Monday night, Prentiss Byrd, the long-time corner man of Hearns, rushed into the ring and raised his fighter aloft.

title: Review/Dance; Role Debut In a Ballet By Robbins
description: Damian Woetzel is rapidly becoming one of the New York City Ballet's most accomplished performers. There was certainly nothing wrong with Mr. Woetzel's dancing on Saturday night at the New York State Theater in a role debut in Jerome Robbins's ''Other Dances,'' set to Chopin piano music played here by Jerry Zimmerman. And the full, quietly elegaic quality Mr. Woetzel brought to the ballet was just right.

title: Deep Ocean: The Safest Dump
description: LEAD: Is the ocean as Congress views it - a thin, fragile veil of water, brim full of good food for future generations, but wantonly poisoned by man?

title: Pistons Get Support
description: The Pistons were playing on the road, but more than 21,000 screaming fans at the Palace provided Detroit with a homecourt advantage tonight. They counted down the final seconds while watching the game on a large-screen television at the Pistons' home arena.

title: Time Rises $5 Above Bid Price
description: The stock of Time Inc. jumped to $180 a share yesterday, $5 higher than its Monday close and $5 above a takeover bid by Paramount Communications Inc.

title: Book Notes
description: Books on Time

title: Never Too Late for White Men
description: Americans of all races and persuasions have a right to a fair system for settling even the most vexing civil rights battles. For the second time in two weeks the Supreme Court has dashed those reasonable expectations, tearing down a legal structure that was fair, workable and working.

title: Investor May Sell First Illinois Shares
description: Daniel J. Terra, a businessman who controls 28.7 percent of the First Illinois Corporation, said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that he might sell ''some or all'' of his holdings in the bank holding company. First Illinois, based in Evanston, Ill., said it ''knows of no plans by Mr. Terra to sell any substantial portion of his holdings.''

title: House Feels Pressure As Bailout Vote Nears
description: With the House scheduled to begin voting on Wednesday on the Bush Administration's bailout plan for the savings industry, some members of Congress say they worry that a majority of their colleagues are about to repeat a mistake they made two years ago.

title: Mary Hayford, 85, 'Little Old Lady' in Iowa
description: Mary Regina Hayford, the ''Little Old Lady from Dubuque'' who helped turn a New York snub into a symbol of pride, died Monday. She was 85 years old.

title: Howard Simons, Dies at Age 60, An Ex-Editor at Washington Post
description: Howard Simons, a former managing editor of The Washington Post, died yesterday of pancreatic cancer in a hospice of Methodist Hospital in Jacksonville, Fla. He was 60 years old and lived in Jacksonville Beach.

title: Lessons
description: Following the fortunes of women's colleges is like listening to that old teen-age chant, ''One Hundred Bottles of Beer on the Wall.'' So far we're down to 94. Number 95 was Colby-Sawyer College in New Hampshire, which recently announced that it would start welcoming men in September 1990. ''Most young women today want to be educated in an environment with young men,'' explained Peggy Stock, the president. ''If you're selling something people don't want, you'd better change your product line.''

title: Fraud Inquiries Said to Falter
description: A third of all investigatons of fraud at big financial institutions are not being pursued because the Justice Department lacks resources, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said today.

title: Bettors Get Money Back
description: Bettors lined up today to get back the millions of dollars they wagered on Sugar Ray Leonard and Thomas Hearns. But the bookmakers shed no tears because the fight had ended in a draw. Enough was bet on other fight propositions that the legal sports books still came out ahead.

title: INSIDE
description: Bias Rulings Set Off Worries Over Race Many lawmakers critical of recent Supreme Court decisions on discrimination say they will press for legislation to circumvent the rulings. In Alabama, the firefighters at the center of the latest ruling say they want to stress more than race. Page A18. Rebuilding Amid 'Democide' As Democrats in the House try to put their leadership back together, the ethics issue lingers. Page B6. Time Inc. Stock Rises $5 Rumors swirled on Wall Street about which company might make the next bid for Time Inc. Page D1. Pact on Smoking Limits Key New York State legislators reached agreement on a broad array of smoking restrictions in public places, including restaurants, theaters and offices. Page B1. Agreement in Argentina With Argentina's economy reeling from rampant inflation, Carlos Saul Menem, the President-elect, has agreed to take office on June 30, more than five months early. Page A3. School Chiefs Challenged The job of superintendent, particularly for those who are members of minority groups, has become more complex than ever. Page B8. Insane or Overdosing? Prompted by the cocaine-overdose death of a man in police custody, doctors are seeking changes in the way people who seem emotionally disturbed are handled. Page B1.

title: Head of Ethics Unit Says Wife Got No Favoritism on Business
description: Representative Julian C. Dixon said today that his wife had received no special treatment as an investor in a Los Angeles airport gift shop concession whose shareholders include several people with political ties to Mayor Tom Bradley.

title: Big Loss Continued In Savings Industry In Early Part of '89
description: Losses at the nation's savings and loan associations totaled $3.4 billion in the first quarter of the year, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: Pansophic Systems reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Vicorp Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 14
Richard Quine, 68, Actor Who Directed 'Murder Your Wife'
description: Richard Quine, a film actor who went on to become a successful director, died of a gunshot wound on Saturday at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center. The police said the death appeared to be a suicide. Mr. Quine was 68 years old.

title: Mexican Museum Artifacts Recovered
description: Federal officials have recovered most of a cache of gold, jade and stone artifacts stolen from the National Museum of Anthropology three and a half years ago and arrested one of two men accused of staging the robbery.

title: Corrections
description: The Patterns column on the Fashion page yesterday misidentified the president of Adrienne Vittadini. He is Richard Catalano.

title: Mediq in Filing By Chief on Talks
description: Bernard J. Korman, the president and chief executive of Mediq Inc., disclosed that he was in talks with descendants of the company's founder about a possible reorganization or recapitalization of the health-care company. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Korman said the alternatives included the possible sale of most or all of Mediq's assets.

title: Mr. Bush Clears the Air
description: For years, the fight against dirty air has missed a crucial element: a President who thinks the nation deserves clean air. George Bush's proposals to overhaul the antiquated Clean Air Act of 1970 aren't perfect. But they represent a major departure from years of official indifference. They will force industry to think creatively about new technologies. And they challenge Congress to end more than a decade of legislative paralysis.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; New Agency Gets Moussy
description: With an old client in tow, Ken Heidelberg left Geer, DuBois two weeks ago to open his own advertising agency. As a senior vice president and management supervisor at Geer, DuBois, Mr. Heidelberg had handled the account of Moussy, a nonalcoholic beer made by a Swiss company, Sibra Beverages International Ltd. Now, Moussy is the first account at Heidelberg & Associates, the agency Mr. Heidelberg started with seven employees from Clark, Thompson, a New York design firm.

title: CVN Cos reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $600,000 and $2,412,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a loss of $6,900,000 from disposal of discontinued operations for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income d-After a loss from discontinued operations of $417,000 for the quarter and a loss of $258,000 for the 9 months.

title: A Violent Type of Pleasure
description: In the fifth round of their savage battle here Monday night Sugar Ray Leonard was knocking Tommy Hearns from pillar to post, bouncing him from one part of the ring ropes to another. It was a ferocious two-fisted assault and Hearns seemed about to drop when the bell clanged.

title: Marching for Freedom
description: To The Living Section:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For the United States, which is more appropriate: a nonaligned Afghanistan - free, independent, demilitarized and professing democracy - or a fanatic, extremist and fundamentalist regime? Hasn't the United States already tasted the bitterness of fundamentalism? Is it anxious to taste another bitter pepper?'' - President Najibullah of Afghanistan. [ A7:1. ]

title: A Dialogue of Dissidents of 2 Worlds
description: Their pain and despair obvious, a group of young Chinese studying in the New York area spent yesterday afternoon earnestly questioning three dissidents from Eastern Europe. They asked how the dissidents and their colleagues had managed to bring on the erosion of Communist totalitarianism in their countries and to survive deadening terror, the kind that came when troops fired on students in central Beijing.

title: ABC Says Crew Was Detained
description: The police in Shanghai detained a crew from ABC News as it tried to photograph a family watching China's evening television news, a correspondent for the network said today. Mark Litke, the correspondent, said the three-member crew and its Government-assigned interpreter were held for about two and a half hours, adding that the Chinese family was not arrested and no videotape was confiscated.

title: Ronald Bishop, Plane Designer, 86
description: Ronald Bishop, who designed Britain's wooden Mosquito bomber in World War II and the Comet jetliner shortly after the war, died Sunday, his family announced. He was 86 years old. No cause of death was given.

title: Company Urges Regents to Allow Newscasts
description: The Tennessee company that is trying to introduce sponsored newscasts in classrooms has begun lobbying to persuade New York officials not to ban the programs.

title: Ennis Business Forms reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Effort to Verify Fusion Experiment Collapses
description: The Los Alamos National Laboratory said yesterday that months of foot-dragging by the University of Utah had resulted in the collapse of plans for a collaboration between the two institutions on low-temperature or ''cold'' nuclear fusion.

title: Controlling Risks, Not Just Arms
description: With talks on strategic arms set to resume next week, Soviet and American military chiefs have just signed an agreement to help reduce the risk of war by accident and miscalculation. That could do as much to preserve peace as would deep cuts in nuclear arms.

title: Man Is Suspected in 6 Attacks on Riders of A Train
description: The transit police said yesterday that one man may be responsible for at least six unprovoked attacks against rush-hour subway riders on the A line in Queens, Brooklyn and Manhattan since last October.

title: Jim Jensen Returning To Channel 2
description: Jim Jensen, a former Channel 2 news anchor, will conduct interviews with some of the mayoral candidates for the station's Sunday morning ''Newsmakers'' program, the station announced yesterday.

title: Greening of Democrats: An 80's Mix of Idealism And Shrewd Politics
description: Once they were known as ''Atari Democrats,'' young moderates who saw investment and high technology as the contemporary answer to the New Deal. Today, they are the Democrats' Greens, politicians who see issues like clean air, clean water and global warming as the key to future victories for their party.

title: Wreckage of Hawaii Tour Plane Is Spotted
description: A rescue helicopter searching a remote valley early today spotted the wreckage of a sightseeing plane that vanished Sunday with 11 people aboard, the authorities said. There were no signs of survivors.

title: Shopsmith Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Both year-ago periods' results included a tax credit of $100,000.

title: Pactel Infosystems' Assets to Be Sold
description: The Computerland Corporation, the largest franchiser of computer retail stores, said several franchisees would acquire most of the assets of Pactel Infosystems, the computer resale operation of the Pacific Telesis Group, the San Francisco-based telephone operating company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: London Insurer's Pawnshop Stake
description: The Prudential Corporation P.L.C., a London-based insurer, has acquired 6.3 percent of Cash America Investments Inc., the nation's only publicly held pawnshop operator. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Prudential, which is not affiliated with the Prudential Insurance Company of America, said it had acquired the stake on behalf of several investment funds that are managed by its investment affiliate.

title: Harlem Residents Call for Local Power in Charter
description: Residents of Harlem told the panel revising the New York City Charter last night that it should give more authority to community boards and create new municipal bodies, including an all-civilian police review board, to empower black, Hispanic and Asian New Yorkers.

title: Pico Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After income of $519,527 from an accounting change.

title: Economic Scene; Dangers Found In Auto Credit
description: AT one stage in the California real estate frenzy a few years ago, lenders who had placed unrealistically high values on property suffered steep losses when inflation suddenly cooled and values dropped.

title: 'Annie 2' Headed This Way
description: Arf!

title: Board Rules Liberal Primary Is Not Open to Independents
description: The New York City Board of Elections yesterday rejected a move by Liberal Party leaders to open the party's mayoral primary to some 400,000 voters not enrolled in any political party. Only 24,000 are enrolled in the Liberal Party.

title: Warwick Neck, R.I.
description: SUMMER in Rhode Island is the time for clambakes or mammoth shore dinners served in open-air halls. Of these, Rocky Point, about 10 miles south of Providence in Warwick Neck, R.I., bills itself as the largest in the world.

title: Pistons, in a Sweep, Capture First Title
description: The Detroit Pistons won their first National Basketball Association championship last night, completing a four-games-to-none sweep of the Los Angeles Lakers with a 105-97 victory in Inglewood, Calif. The Pistons have been in the N.B.A. for 41 years.

title: The Struggles of Minority-Group School Chiefs
description: The decision by New York City's Board of Education to favor black and Hispanic candidates in its search for a new chief of the nation's largest school system underscores the rise of black and Hispanic educators in big cities since the 1960's.

title: Bridge
description: In preparation for the 1989 World Team Championships in Perth, Australia, in September, the process of selecting zonal teams has picked up its pace. The American trials were played in mid-May, followed by the Far East Championships in Djakarta, Indonesia. The Middle Eastern Championships ended yesterday in Cairo, and the European Championships will begin July 1.

title: Gold Tooth Clears Suspect And Implicates Another
description: A 34-year-old Bronx custodian has been cleared of possessing $21,000 in stolen bonds, and his estranged wife's former boyfriend, who bears a striking resemblance to the custodian has instead been charged with the crime, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Hurt by Excess Inventory, Ashton-Tate Expects Loss
description: Facing large excess inventories of its data base management programs among United States software distributors, the Ashton-Tate Corporation said today that it expected to report a loss for the second quarter on reduced revenues.

title: Sonic Guilty of Assault
description: Dale Ellis of the Seattle SuperSonics was fined $346 in Bellevue, Wash., after being found guilty of assaulting his wife, Monique, and resisting arrest during an incident at their home in January. Steve Hayne, the attorney for Ellis, said the assault was an isolated incident and that Ellis and his wife remain together in a new home in Bellevue.(AP)

title: Ex-Officer Held in Girls' Sex Assault
description: A former New York City police officer, described by the authorities as a suspect in his first wife's death, was arraigned in the Bronx yesterday on charges that he raped and sexually abused his adolescent stepdaughters.

title: Hungarians Open Election Talks
description: The ruling Communist Party and leaders of the opposition began negotiations today on multiparty elections that could lead to Hungary's first coalition government in more than 40 years.

title: Dart Group reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After extraordinary losses from the reacquisition of debentures of $223,000 for the latest quarter and $108,000 for the year-ago period; the year-ago period also included an extraordinary gain of $2,826,000 from a tax loss carryforward.

title: Review/Dance; Turning the Didactic Into a Human Romp
description: ''Fanfare'' is Jerome Robbins's most festive ballet, a mixture of entertainment and didacticism rolled into one. Its return to the New York City Ballet this season gives even old-fashioned music appreciation a good name.

title: Market Place; Why Less Is More At Western Union
description: EXECUTIVES who run companies are supposed to have a stake in making sure the common stock does well. But Bennett S. LeBow, the man who controls the Western Union Corporation, has set things up so that at least for the next several years he will profit if the common stock falls.

title: Review/Recital; A Determined Approach To the Piano
description: There were some needlessly blustery moments in Thomas Labe's Monday evening piano recital at Merkin Concert Hall and lengthy stretches in which the pianist seemed too intent on magnifying the music's rhetorical gestures. But there were also moments of great beauty between thunderous outbursts, and if Mr. Labe's interpretations were sometimes overdrawn, one had to admire the determination and consistency with which he pursued them and the technical command he put at their service.

title: Ford to Expand Research Center
description: Citing the need to find ways of meeting new environmental regulations, the Ford Motor Company said it would spend $97 million to expand its laboratories in Dearborn, Mich., southwest of here. A new building containing 125,000 square feet of floor space will be erected within four years next to the existing plant and will accommodate Ford laboratories for physics, chemistry and metallurgy research. Renovation of the original building, built in 1957, will be completed a year later.

title: Jewelmasters Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-After a gain of $106,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: World Bank Aids Mexico
description: The World Bank announced today that it had approved a $1.5 billion package of loans to Mexico, with as much as $375 million of the money set aside to support the Bush Administration's debt-reduction plan.

title: Ambrit Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and included a pretax gain of $7,075,000 from settlement of a lawsuit and an after-tax loss of $299,000 from discontinued operations. The company said the loss in the latest quarter was primarily to its Isaly division incurring an operating loss of $782,000.

title: McCormick & Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a gain on sale and income from discontinued real estate operations of $80,338,000. c-After a one-time gain of $245,000 on the sale and income from discontinued real estate operations. d-After an extraordinary gain of $765,000 from the sale and income from discontinued real estate operations, and income of $6.4 million from an accounting change.

title: California Offers $200 Million Issue
description: California is offering $200 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the Bank of America's Bank Investment Securities division.

title: Five to Get U.S. Grants for Advanced TV
description: The Pentagon said yesterday that the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency had selected five companies to receive grants to develop high-definition television technology for both consumer and military applications.

title: Milder West Point Honor Code Is Urged
description: A special commission appointed by the Army called today for changes in the United States Military Academy's historic honor code to improve its effectiveness and cadets' compliance.

title: Prudential Securities to Buy Thomson
description: The Prudential Securities Group, parent of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., plans to acquire Thomson McKinnon Inc., which operates the nation's ninth-largest retail brokerage, the firms announced yesterday.

title: Homeless Man in Box Crushed to Death by Truck
description: A homeless man, described by his friends as an artist who roamed the streets with his dog, was crushed to death early yesterday when a truck ran over a box he was sleeping in beside a Bay Shore, L.I., loading dock.

title: Tipping a Thief
description: To The Living Section:

title: Ford Motor Credit Is Offering Notes
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company is offering $200 million of notes due in 1999 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: Los Angeles is offering $160 million of tax-exempt waste-water system revenue bonds with a maximum yield of about 6.878 percent for an issue due in 2019 through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: Review/Film; Comic Books as Sociology and Popular Art
description: Just as you might suspect, the men behind Spider-Man, Captain America and other comic book heroes resemble Clark Kent in real life. They are calm, reasonable, respectable-looking people whose fantasies and superhuman powers are released in the Zap! Pow! Gasp! of their work. In ''Comic Book Confidential,'' Ron Mann's deft race through 50 years of American comic books, these artists and writers recall the origins of their work and read snippets of their stories. The documentary opens today at Film Forum 1 for a two-week run.

title: House Votes More Spending For Washington Police Force
description: The House voted today to spend $127 million to hire 700 additional officers for the District of Columbia police force, which has been fighting a record number of drug-related murders in the past year.

title: Ex-H.U.D. Aide Refuses to Testify To House, Citing 5th Amendment
description: A former top official of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, citing her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination, declined to answer questions from a Congressional subcommittee today about charges of political abuse in a Federal low-income housing program.

title: Racketeer Charges Filed in California Against U.S. Judge
description: Federal District Judge Robert P. Aguilar was indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on racketeering charges.

title: Central Co-operative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income The bank attributed the fourth quarter loss and the year's earnings decline to an increase in its provision for possible loan losses to $975,000 in the latest year from $178,000 in the prior year. It also cited $282,000 in non- recurring after-tax merger costs resulting from the offer from Somerset Bankshares to acquire Central Co- operative.

title: The Pop Life
description: Gabriel's World Music

title: Thermwood Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company is listed on the Boston and Pacific stock exchanges.

title: Oh, the Horror of It! Celebrity Son Tells All
description: BOB and Chris Elliott - father and son, celebrated wits, seasoned performers - were asked about the meaning of Father's Day. ''Father's Day?'' Bob pondered, frowning a bit. ''Well, it means we'll have to entertain him, I suppose,'' he said, eyeing his son.

title: Getty Petroleum Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Teledyne Up On Spinoff Talk
description: Teledyne Inc.'s stock price jumped today after the company announced late on Monday that it was considering a plan to spin off its insurance and finance units to shareholders. Teledyne's stock rose $9.875 each, to $370, on the New York Stock Exchange The announcement also set off speculation on Wall Street that the restructuring plan might lead to the sale of the company's 28 percent stake in Litton Industries. Litton's stock price rose $4.125 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at $84. Some analysts said a sale by

title: Bio-Vascular Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Stratton Mountain, Vt., to Pagano Schenck & Kay, Providence, R.I., with a budget of $3 million to $4 million.

title: Drug Deaths After Arrests Draw Scrutiny
description: Citing the recent death in police custody of a Queens man, medical experts are urging changes in the way police officers handle emotionally disturbed people, who often prove to be cocaine abusers in need of immediate medical attention.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: HIDING THE KIDS IN THE BUSHES

title: Robin Howard, an English Patron Of Modern Dance, Is Dead at 65
description: Robin Howard, who helped establish modern dance in England as the founder of the London Contemporary Dance Theater, died on Sunday night at the University College Hospital in London, where he was admitted last week after a heart attack. He was 65 years old.

title: A New Generation Of Rieslings Is Uncorked
description: WEST GERMAN wine makers, heady from creating a riesling revolu tion at home, are gearing up to export that revolu tion to the United States.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank Leumi Trust Co. of New York, a subsidiary of Bank Leumi le-Israel Group, Tel Aviv, named Zalman Segal vice chairman and chief executive.

title: Campeau Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and included the sale of the Brooks Brothers division of Allied. Year-ago figures have been restated. The increased revenues and operating profits for the latest quarter principally reflect the company's May 1988 acquisition of Federated Department Stores Inc. The loss in the latest first quarter also reflected an increase in financing and other costs related to the company's acquisition of Federated. Revenue included Federated and its former Ralphs Grocery Co. division, now a wholly owned Campeau subsidiary. All results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Western Publishing Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 20
A Treaty That Could Do Harm
description: LEAD: After a six-month suspension, the strategic arms reduction talks will resume Monday amid high expectations generated by a series of dramatic moves in arms control. But without modifications in the U.S. negotiating position, certain provisions of the Start agreement could violate the Hippocratic Oath of arms control: a treaty should do no harm.

title: Chancellor Turns a Campus Around
description: While tornadoes are fairly common in the Middle West, few people here were prepared for the whirlwind that accompanied Marguerite Ross Barnett when she arrived from New York to become chancellor of the University of Missouri-St. Louis.

title: To Start, a Few to Consider
description: IN the accompanying list of recommended mealtime rieslings and other white German wines, the vintage date is followed by the the winery, the vineyard (where relevant), the grape, category of wine, region of origin, importer (this is in parentheses; the importer is in New York City, unless otherwise indicated) and price.

title: Harvey Group reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Included a $164,000 tax credit.

title: Penril Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains from the early extinguishment of debt of $36,000 for the quarter and $566,000 for the 9 months. c-After an extraordinary gain of $261,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: Schneider Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 13
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: No. 1 Pick Starts Talks
description: Ben McDonald, the Louisiana State University pitcher who was the first player taken in the major league baseball draft, began contract talks yesterday with the Baltimore Orioles. He is being represented in negotiations by his father, Larry McDonald.

title: New York Sells Note Offering
description: New York State yesterday sold $460 million of tax- and revenue-anticipation notes with a maturity of Feb. 15, 1990, through competitive bidding.

title: Duke Player to Transfer
description: Phil Henderson, a starting guard on the Duke basketball team that reached the Final Four in the N.C.A.A. last season, announced he was transfering from the school. He did not indicate what school he was going to.

title: BUSH REJECTS RISE IN MINIMUM WAGE TO $4.55 AN HOUR
description: President Bush vetoed legislation today that would raise the minimum wage to $4.55 an hour, setting the stage for a partisan political battle and test of wills with the Democratic majority in Congress.

title: U.S. Suggests Way Out Of Dispute on Dissidents
description: In an effort to resolve the dispute over two Chinese dissidents who have taken refuge in the United States Embassy in Beijing, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has suggested that the couple be allowed to go to a third country for asylum, Admnistration officials said today.

title: Review/Music; New Work by Lukas Foss for Anne Frank
description: The Cathedral of St. John the Divine was the site of a memorial celebration Monday night entitled ''Remembering Anne Frank.'' She died at the Bergen-Belsen concentration camp at the age of 16, and would have been 60 years old on Monday. There was music, including a short new piece by Lukas Foss, who presided over the musical performances.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about plans for a funeral for Imre Nagy, the Hungarian leader executed in 1958, misidentified a foundation through which an American financier is subsidizing activities in Hungary. It is the Soros Foundation - Hungary, not the Quantum Fund.

title: Transnational Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After tax credits of $35,000 for the latest first quarter and $84,000 for year-ago period.

title: Hall Runs Yankees Out of Game
description: Mel Hall stood sheepishly near the center of the Yankee clubhouse tonight and smiled. He had erred, and it came at the worst of times, a moment that may have meant the difference between victory and defeat.

title: Bush Administration Official Voices Dismay Over Dollar
description: The Bush Administration is unhappy with the rise of the dollar but thinks that the increase is temporary and is disinclined to try very hard to stop it, a Treasury official said today.

title: Johnson Admits Lying About Drugs and Asks for Reinstatement
description: Holding back tears, Ben Johnson today accepted full responsibility for failing his drug test at the Seoul Olympics last fall and vowed to join the campaign against drugs in sports if he were given the chance to run again for Canada.

title: Chock Full O'Nuts Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $107,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $671,000, or 9 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Net loss The latest periods included unrealized gains on marketable equity securities of $249,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,560,000, or 12 cents a share, for the 9 months. Year-ago quarter included an unrealized gain of $372,000, or 5 cents a share, and the 9 months included an unrealized loss of $2,974,000, both on marketable equity securities.

title: Fidelity National Financial Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a gain of $1.2 million from the favorable settlement of a claim. c-Net loss

title: In Mideast, Don't Bet on Elections to Bring Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Bush Clean-Air Plan Assessed
description: Many companies reacted with concern and confusion to the sweeping clean-air proposals outlined by President Bush on Monday. Page D1.

title: Reagan Gets A Red Carpet From British
description: Former President Ronald Reagan returned to Britain this week as a private citizen but was welcomed almost as visiting nobility.

title: Lawsuit Seeks Drug Treatment on Demand
description: A lawsuit that would force New York State and New York City officials to provide drug treatment for all city residents who seek it was filed yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan by the Coalition for the Homeless.

title: 8 Arrested in Drug Smuggling
description: Federal agents arrested eight people yesterday after seizing up to 8,000 pounds of marijuana that was being smuggled into the country inside cans labeled as pickled jalapena peppers. ''I guess you could say that we picked pot packed in pickled peppers,'' said Joan Baran, a spokeswoman for the United States Customs Service. The drugs were shipped to Newark from Costa Rica aboard a Panamanian freighter and had a wholesale value of up to $6.4 million, the authorities said. There were no peppers in the six-pound cans.

title: Viewers Doubled For Stanley Cup
description: This year's National Hockey League Stanley Cup telecasts were distributed internationally to countries that represent more than 300 million television viewing households, an increase of 100 percent from the 1987-88 season, according to John A. Ziegler Jr., the president of the N.H.L.

title: A Comic Triumph as a Tragic Callas Worshiper
description: He cuts a preposterous figure in an antique silk dressing gown as he swoops about in black velvet slippers and swoons into a peach satin chaise longue. He is alternately petulant and passionate as he dishes ''La Traviata'' trivia, and positively fiery as he wraps himself in a shawl to impersonate the opera singer Maria Callas. But if he makes theater audiences laugh uproariously, he also moves them to rapt silence as he says poignantly, ''Opera doesn't reject me; the real world does.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Lawmakers Aiming at Reversing Bias Rulings
description: Members of Congress said today that they are planning legislation aimed at reversing a string of recent Supreme Court decisions that they believe undercut enforcement of anti-discrimination laws.

title: Moderates Appear on Beijing TV, Easing Fears of Wholesale Purge
description: Several high-level Chinese officials resurfaced in public tonight on the national television news program, amid signs that the purge in the nation's Communist Party leadership might not be so sweeping as had been feared.

title: Poland Bars 8 Key Communists From Runoff Vote
description: Eight members of the Commmunist Party Politburo, shaken by defeat in the national elections earlier this month, have been barred from runoff balloting on Sunday, the Government said today.

title: Train Hits Truck in Nevada, Killing at Least 2 Transients
description: A Southern Pacific freight train hit a tractor-trailer truck and derailed, killing two transients riding illegally on the train and injuring seven other people, the authorities said.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis On Gateway Talks
description: The American leveraged buyout company Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company said that talks with a third party on a possible bid for the Gateway Corporation P.L.C., a British food retailer, had broken down. In a statement issued at the request of Britain's Takeover Panel, Kohlberg, Kravis said it had ''terminated its discussions with an unaffiliated third party'' that had indicated an interest in a joint Gateway acquisition. It did not say whether either party would bid alone.

title: Jewish Groups Seek Cut in Soviet Trade Bars
description: Officials of American Jewish organizations recommended today that trade restrictions against the Soviet Union be eased in response to recent increases in Soviet Jewish emigration.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17 Britain demanded that boat people from Vietnam who have found temporary asylum elsewhere in Southeast Asia be forcibly returned to Vietnam, beginning by October. Page A1

title: VETERANS' DEATHS REVIEWED IN STUDY
description: Forty-four veterans hospitals had ''significantly elevated'' rates of death among patients, and more than 5 percent of those who died were found to have received inappropriate care, according to a report issued today by the Department of Veterans Affairs.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * Discrimination against AIDS victims is the target of a pro bono campaign developed by Anda, Bokuniewicz & Scotti for the AIDS unit of New York City's Human Rights Commission. The campaign will be introduced in mid-August in the New York City subway systems and in magazines.

title: U.S. Says Toxic Chemicals Are Imperiling Aquatic Life
description: Hundreds of the nation's lakes, rivers, estuaries and coastal areas are contaminated by toxic chemicals and metals at levels that make them dangerous for aquatic life, the Environmental Protection Agency reported today.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Miami
description: LEAD: JOHN MONTAGU, the 4th Earl of Sandwich, is said to have invented the snack that bears his name because he hated to leave the gaming tables to eat. But had the 18th-century Englishman been served the sandwich prepared here by five brothers, emigres from Cuba, he would have been hard pressed to eat and play cards at the same time.

title: BRITAIN DEMANDS RETURN TO VIETNAM OF BOAT PEOPLE
description: Britain demanded today that most Vietnamese boat people who have found temporary asylum elsewhere in Southeast Asia be forcibly returned to Vietnam, beginning no later than October.

title: Two Simple Tax Incentives Could Give Wall St. a Shot in the Arm; Beyond the Dollar
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Soviet Asian Republic, Cause of the Strife Is Elusive
description: Fayzi Shakhismail watched Sunday as his niece, Aziza, hastily packed her family's belongings, then left her village in a borrowed car with her husband and two children.

title: EATING WELL
description: MOST of us appear to get whatever limited nutritional information we have on a piecemeal basis: a smattering from the newspaper, a word or two from a magazine, bits and pieces from commercials. Soem of us even learn a few facts in school. What we're left with, however, are often gaping holes in our knowledge as well as conflicting advice.

title: Incinerator Ban Is Adopted
description: A bill to eliminate the remaining 2,200 apartment-house incinerators in New York City was passed unanimously yesterday by the City Council. If signed by Mayor Edward I. Koch, as expected, the legislation would require apartment-house owners to switch their garbage disposal to compactors or trash bins within four years.

title: Sears Testing Upgraded Card
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company is conducting a limited test of an upgraded version of its Discover card, which will carry a $40 annual fee and be called Private Issue.

title: Smoking Limits In Public Places Set in Albany
description: Ending years of dispute, New York legislators said today that they had reached an agreement on smoking restrictions.

title: KEY RATES
3 Princeton Principals Lose Ruling
description: A Federal judge refused yesterday to dismiss racketeering charges against three principals in a defunct New Jersey investment partnership. They were reported to have engaged in bogus stock transactions to create illegal tax losses.

title: Hard-liners Seem to Control Politics, But the Economy Is Another Matter
description: While China's leaders tighten their grip over the political situation, they now face the even more complicated task of controlling the economy after their military crackdown shook the confidence of Chinese and foreigners alike.

title: Mets Run Afoul of the Cubs Again
description: He flew through the air with the greatest of ease, and Lenny Dykstra wasn't even on a flying trapeze. That was in the third inning when the Mets' center fielder made a remarkable catch of Shawon Dunston's line drive to left-center field.

title: Dr. Joseph Stokes 3d, 64, Leader In Field of Cardiovascular Disease
description: Dr. Joseph Stokes 3d, a leader in preventive medicine and cardiovascular diseases, died of cancer Monday at University Hospital in Boston. He was 64 years old and lived in Arlington, Mass.

title: Battered Democrats Seek to Regroup
description: Even in a year when the unpredictable has become the norm in the House, the race for majority whip is confounding the Democrats as they prepare to caucus Wednesday morning to reconstruct their leadership.

title: Reading a German Label
description: THE labels on all fine German rieslings include names that denote varying levels of ripeness, or sugar content, of grapes at harvest.

title: The Entree That Wouldn't Die
description: WEN people speak today of the rubber-chicken circuit, they are no longer talking about banquet meals that feature chicken a la king, that unspeakable mixture of flour-laden sauce with bits of canned mushrooms, canned pimento and overcooked chicken. Today the chicken is usually wearing a cordon bleu or Kiev dress.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I RECENTLY prepared a quick lunch that the French call poussin grille a la diable - grilled baby chicken coated with mustard, bread crumbs and fresh herbs.

title: Strawberry Takes Lead
description: The Mets' Darryl Strawberry was the top vote-getter among outfielders for the National League All-Star Game in the balloting announced yesterday.

title: New Market for Trading 'Pollution Rights'
description: The Bush Administration's ambitious plan to harness market forces on behalf of clean air will lead to a trading system in which ''pollution rights'' would be bought and sold like securities, with brokers matching the parties, Government and environmental sources said today.

title: Time, Warner Say Franchises Could Snag Paramount Bid
description: Warner Communications Inc. and Time Inc. are asserting that Paramount Communications Inc.'s proposed takeover of Time is likely to stumble over the need to persuade hundreds of municipalities to approve the transfer of cable franchises now held by Time Inc.

title: U.S. Says It Has Hard Evidence of Salmon Pirating by Foreigners
description: The Coast Guard has taken custody of a Taiwanese fishing vessel in the middle of the North Pacific after collecting what American officials say is the first hard evidence of large-scale pirating of West Coast salmon by foreign boats.

title: Current-Account Trade Gap Widens by 7%
description: The current-account deficit, the broadest measure of United States trade, worsened dramatically in the first three months of the year to $30.69 billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American General Corp., Houston, an insurer, reached a three-year accord to repurchase 10.6 million shares from the American Financial Corp., Cincinnati.

title: Nazi Ship Bismarck Is Found in 'Good Shape'
description: The powerful Nazi warship Bismarck, sunk by the British in a crucial fight for control of the North Atlantic, has been discovered ''upright in good shape'' at the bottom of the ocean, its finders said today.

title: Langston and Expos Shut Out Cards
description: Mark Langston pitched a four-hitter for his first National League shutout tonight and Montreal beat St. Louis, 2-0, for the Expos' fourth straight victory.

title: Marcade Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-After tax credits of $1,113,000 for the latest first quarter and $1,022,000 for year-ago period. The year-ago quarter included a $1,255,000 non-recurring gain on the sale of a warehouse lease.

title: Jane C. Spock, 82; Worked on Baby Book
description: Jane Cheney Spock, a civil liberties advocate and writing assistant to Dr. Benjamin M. Spock, her former husband, died at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center Saturday after suffering a stroke. She was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Concern Over Bush Clean-Air Plan
description: The sweeping clean-air proposals outlined by President Bush on Monday drew expressions of concern and confusion yesterday from many companies directly affected by the plan.

title: Ruling on Firefighters Is Debated in Alabama
description: Charles Brush, a lieutenant in the Birmingham Fire Department and president of the city firefighters' union, paused over a midday meal of spaghetti and meatballs at Fire Station 10 to discuss white firefighters' frustrations over the department's affirmative action program.

title: Rural Growers, City Customers
description: IT is daybreak on eastern Long Island. The air is thick with fog. The fields are muddy.

title: Hospital Corporation Sells Units to Cut Debt
description: The Hospital Corporation of America has sold two more divisions, bringing to five the number of units spun off by the health-care company since it began a restructuring three years ago.

title: Pronouncing the Names
description: CHAI LING, student leader: chai (rhymes with high) ling DENG XIAOPING, senior leader: dung sheeow-ping (sheeow rhymes with meow) DING GUANGEN, Politburo alternate member: ding guahn-guhn FANG LIZHI, dissident: fahng lee-jur (rhymes with burr) FENG CONGDE, student leader: fung tsong-duh HAN XU, Ambassador to the United States: hahn shoo HU QILI, Politburo member: hoo chee-lee HU YAOBANG, former Communist Party leader: hoo yow-bahng (yow rhymes with now) LI CHANGCHUN, Governor of Liaoning Province: lee chahng-chwoon LI PENG, Prime Minister: lee pung LI SHUXIAN, dissident: lee shu-shyen LIU GANG, student leader: leeoh gahng QIAO SHI, Politburo member: cheeow sure (cheeow rhymes with meow) QIN JIWEI, Defense Minister: chin jee-way SONG PING, Politburo member: soong ping TIAN JIYUN, Politburo member: teeyen jee-yuhn WANG DAN, student leader: wong dahn WEN JIABAO, party official: wen jeeyah-bow (rhymes with now) WU XUEQIAN, Politburo member: woo shooeh-chyen WUER KAIXI, student leader: woo-are kai-shee (kai rhymes with high) YAN MINGFU, party official: yan ming-foo YANG RUDAI, Politburo member: yahng rew-die YANG SHANGKUN, President: yahng shahng-kwuhn ZHAO ZIYANG, Communist Party General Secretary: jow dzuh-yahng ZHU HOUZE, union leader: joo hoe-dzuh

title: Advice for Restaurateurs
description: To The Living Section:

title: WINE TALK
description: IT had to happen. For several years now, California wines made in the style of the wines of the Rhone Valley of southeastern France have been growing in popularity in this country. Now it seems that the California versions are generating new interest in the originals.

title: Morton Rogers, 62, Welfare Group Official
description: Morton S. Rogers, executive director of Louise Wise Services, a welfare organization for children and families, died Friday at his home in Mount Vernon, N.Y. He was 62 years old.

title: Importuning Red Flags
description: Big red hammer-and-sickle flags waved over the flourishing German capital today. But they signified the opposite of the old dreams of Lenin, Trotsky and Stalin, and the capital is Bonn, not Berlin.

title: Pistons Earn First Title by Sweeping Lakers
description: The Detroit Pistons, who began in Fort Wayne, Ind., and moved to Detroit and its outskirts, always seeking fans and acceptance while changing coaches 16 times, defeated the Los Angeles, 105-97, tonight to win their first National Basketball Association championship in the history of the franchise.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Chiat/Day Resigns
description: Chiat/Day, Los Angeles, said yesterday that it had resigned the account of the Sunbeam Appliance Company after 18 months, saying it would be better served by a local agency. When Chiat/Day won the business in December 1987, the account was projected to be worth between $10 and $20 million, the bulk of which was for promoting an innovative oven. Sunbeam later abandoned the oven before it went into production, citing design problems. Its advertising budget with Chiat/Day then dwindled to $1.5 million, largely devoted to sales promotion.

title: Westerbeke Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Net income

title: Court Backs Prime On July Meeting
description: Prime Computer Inc. said a Delaware Chancery Court judge had ruled that it could proceed with plans to hold its annual meeting on July 26. MAI Basic Four Inc., which has made a hostile bid for Prime, had sued to have the meeting held on Wednesday, as scheduled earlier.

title: Improving Batteries: Big Hurdles
description: The consumer's appetite for portable electricity has leaped ahead of the ability of batteries to store it. With products like hand-held tape players and laptop computers creating new demand for better battery performance, engineers are trying to make improvements but are facing major hurdles.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Los Angeles
description: LEAD: IN the land of ghosts, Charlie Chaplin must be smiling to see La Brea Bakery occupying the ersatz Italian palazzo he built as a commercial building in the 1920's.

title: BAPTISTS RE-ELECT A CONSERVATIVE
description: Delegates to the Southern Baptist Convention today re-elected a president whose victory was a clear sign of the conservative hold on the denomination.

title: Dataram Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Former Law Official Is G.O.P. Candidate To Govern Virginia
description: In one of the most acrimonious and hard fought political contests in this state in many years, Virginia Republicans narrowly nominated former State Attorney General J. Marshall Coleman today to be their candidate for Governor.

title: Award Golden Apples To Wildflower Tenders
description: To the Editor:

title: Sales of U.S. Vehicles Rose 1.1% in Early June
description: Sales of domestic cars and light trucks rose 1.1 percent in early June, but demand remained too weak to reduce inventories significantly, analysts said today.

title: Dispute Stalls Koch Proposal For Homeless AIDS Patients
description: A Koch administration plan to provide humane housing for homeless people with AIDS-related illnesses has been held up by a dispute with the state over where best to house them.

title: A New Site, A New Serra Work, A New Dispute
description: Another sculpture by Richard Serra, the creator of the ill-fated ''Tilted Arc'' on the Federal Plaza in lower Manhattan, is causing a stir -this time in New Haven at his alma mater, Yale University.

title: Direct Action Marketing Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $5,029.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I tried to get my daughter to play with G.I. Joe and my son to play with dolls. It didn't work. My daughter's favorite toy is Barbie. I am aghast.'' - David Zaslow. [ C10:3. ]

title: Meeting the Challenge of Demilitarizing Our Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Is Chase Medical Deadlock Ending?
description: FIVE months after the authorities discovered a bold attempt to corner the stock of Chase Medical Group, it appears the deadlock over the stock is about to be broken. Trading could resume in the near future.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-19 In the capital of Sichuan Province, Chengdu, foreigners and the few Chinese willing to talk to reporters these days say events closely resembled those in Beijing. Page A1 China expelled two U.S. journalists, including one from the Voice of America. The Government accused the two reporters of violating martial-law regulations in Beijing. A16 China's expulsion was protested by the Bush Administration, saying the move would not keep ''the truth about what is going on in China from being heard.'' A16 On evening television news in China, the Government has reverted to the kind of indoctrination that was familiar during the Mao years. A16 A key murder case in Mexico, the 1984 shooting of the country's best-known journalist, appears to have been cracked with the arrest of a former security official who headed the initial investigation. A1 After years of terror, Uganda has emerged as a major hope of the World Bank and the United States. The three-year-old regime has achieved an unprecedented measure of political stability. A1 Vietnam and Britain were at odds over the forced repatriation of boat people now in Hong Kong as an international conference on Indochinese refugees ended. A19 In Stuttgart, Mikhail Gorbachev was welcomed with enthusiasm that appeared to confirm a West German perception of him as an extraordinary statesman. A10 Currency devaluations in Nicaragua have sent consumers reeling and provoked new doubts about the Government's ability to control the economy in a crucial election year. A3 News analysis: Dan Quayle is emerging as a defender of the Nicaraguan ''freedom fighters,'' pressing the U.S. policy adopted in a bipartisan compromise with Congress. A3 In the Olof Palme murder trial, key prosecution witnesses have given testimony far more favorable to the defendant than expected. A7 National A20-29, B8-11 The new Democratic majority leader in the House will be Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri. William H. Gray 3d of Pennsylvania was elected majority whip. A1 The largest unmanned U.S. rocket to climb into space, and the first one big enough to rival the space shuttle, was launched in Florida, marking the debut of a multibillion-dollar fleet of Titan 4's. A1 The discovery of radioactive metals at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant, produced only by splitting atoms, has raised tantalizing new questions about the plant's troubled history. A1 A ''frequent shopper'' program at supermarkets would award rebates to regular buyers of certain name-brand goods. Pathmark, Giant Food and Vons will begin testing. A1 A vote on the Pentagon's package for buying weapons was called for by the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, Les Aspin, provoking a frenzy of lobbying and political maneuvering. B11 The victor in Virginia's primary for the Republican nominee for governor, former state Attorney General J. Marshall Coleman, plunged into the campaign. A20 A fire at the Jackson Laboratory, one of the world's leading suppliers of re- search mice, has caused major disruptions for medical scientists in the United States, Canada and other countries. A20 House Democrats failed to override the President's veto of a bill to increase the minimum wage. But the Democrats vowed to seek compromise legislation. A21 Labs that do DNA ''fingerprinting'' analyses to be used as evidence in criminal cases need a set of national reliability standards, experts in the new field say. A26 Washington Talk B10 Personal and political finances are difficult to juggle for Representative Edward F. Feighan. Like many of his colleagues, Mr. Feighan finds himself in an economic and political vise. Politics: Measuring Moral Majority's impact on U.S. Regional B1-7 Political clubs are threatened as their members age and dwindle. Many clubs that once were centers of their communities have been forced to retreat to seedy storefronts. B1 Rent rules will be extended for New York City for two years, legislative leaders agreed, leaving unresolved a series of demands from tenants and landlords. B1 Enfield's spread is about to change on July 1, when Connecticut imposes the largest one-time tax increase in its history. The spread refers to the difference between tax rates there and in Massachusetts. B1 A stormy dispute over the Tongass, the huge rain forest along western Canada, has involved Representative Robert J. Mrazek of Long Island in a peculiar mixture of bicoastal grudges and alliances. B1 A youngster's anti-crack T-shirts are part of her one-child program. Her parents hope to have the shirts distributed across the country by civic leaders and organizations. B5 On a tour of buildings being revived, 25 prominent New Yorkers joined Abraham Biderman, New York City's Housing Commissioner, while he inspected refurbished buildings in the South Bronx. B2 A travel agency was penalized more than $75,000 for violating United States trade embargoes against Vietnam and Cambodia by offering tours to those countries. B3 Subway riders are more fearful and cautious in New York City following a rash of violence in the last week. Subway crime was up 19 percent in the first three months of this year from the period a year ago. B3 Metro-North ties crumble B2

title: Recognition Gets New Prospect Bid
description: Prospect Group Inc., a New York buyout firm, today offered $11 a share for control of Recognition Equipment Inc., a Texas company whose top executives have been indicted in a scandal involving Federal contracts. The bid is Prospect's second in six months. The previous offer of $12.75 a share was rejected as ''highly conditional.''

title: Commtron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Turmoil in China; Beijing Ousts 2 American Correspondents
description: China today ordered the expulsion within 72 hours of two Beijing-based American journalists, including one from the Voice of America.

title: University Patents reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said the decline in revenue reflected the sale of the contact lens product line of its subsidiary, University Optical Products Co., on Jan. 31.

title: Sizzler Restaurants Internaional Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Actually, Commuters Pay Less Tax
description: Suburbanites who commute to New York City from New Jersey and Connecticut are fuming at a law that took effect this year, raising the income tax some of them owe New York State. It's much ado about little. Fourteen other states have similar laws, and the legal principle passed muster in the U.S. Supreme Court 70 years ago.

title: Britain and Vietnam Still at Odds on Refugees
description: As an international conference on Indochinese refugees ended, Vietnam and Britain failed today to resolve a dispute over the forced repatriation of boat people from Hong Kong.

title: Interpublic Raises Stake In Lowe Howard-Spink
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies said yesterday that it would swap its ownership of Lowe Marshalk for an increased stake in Lowe Howard-Spink & Bell P.L.C., the London-based advertising company that now owns 30 percent of Lowe Marshalk.

title: Wife of Ethics Panel Head Says Her Investment Was Aboveboard
description: Betty Dixon, the wife of the House ethics committee chairman, defended her investment in a Los Angeles airport gift shop concession today, citing her previous retailing experience and saying the business proved profitable because of big-spending Japanese tourists.

title: Mays, J W Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss and included tax credits of $25,000 for the quarter and $449,000 for the 9 months. The latest quarter results included a tax credit of $5,135,000 and an after- tax gain of $10,838,298 from the sale of property, partially offset by an after- tax loss from continuing real estate operations of $579,432, a loss from discontinued retail operations of $243,919 and a loss from the disposal of the retail segment of $286,680. The latest 9 months results included the $5,135,000 tax credit, and a $10,680,597 gain from the sale of property, partially offset by an after-tax loss from continuing real estate operations of $144,027, a loss from discontinued retail operations of $1,832,743 and a loss from the disposal of the retail segment of $3,112,709.

title: AEP Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Latest quarter and 6 months' figures included results of Design Poly Bag Corp., which was acquired on March 31 and accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: Burt Approved for Arms Post Despite Objections by Helms
description: Richard R. Burt, formerly the United States Ambassador to West Germany, was confirmed by the Senate today as negotiator for strategic arms reduction talks with the Soviet Union resuming Monday in Geneva.

title: Barry Wright Agrees to Be Sold
