description: The Barry Wright Corporation agreed to be acquired by Applied Power Inc. for $12.40 a share, ending a hostile takeover battle in a deal valuing the company at about $145 million. Applied Power, an electric products company based in Butler, Wis., had previously offered $10 a share for Barry Wright, which makes office filing systems and vibration control devices for heavy machinery.

title: Cooper Cos reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $2,674,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-After extraordinary gains of $1,434,000 for the quarter and $4,580,000 for the 6 months, and the 6 months also included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,628,000. Year-ago quarter loss from operations included income of $98,000 from discontinued operations. Year-ago quarter and 6 months results are restated to reflect Cooper Surgical as a discontinued operation. Latest second quarter and 6 months losses both included the reversal of a provision for costs associated with restructuring operations of $3.9 million, a provision for the net loss resulting from the reduced sales price on the planned divestiture of Cooper Technicon of $7.3 million for the quarter and $3.5 million for the 6 months, both of which had not been anticipated in the 1988 fiscal fourth quarter, a net loss on sales of businesses of $4.9 million for the quarter and a net gain of $8.7 million for the 6 months, an extraordinary loss of $2.7 million related primarily to early debt extinguishment for both the quarter and 6 months and dividend requirements on preferred stock of $3 million for the quarter and $5.9 million for the 6 months. Year-ago second quarter loss included a net gain on sales of businesses of $3.8 million and the 6 months included a net loss of $5.2 million, extraordinary gains of $1.4 million and $4.6 million for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, both related to tax credits and dividend requirements on preferred stock of $2.7 million for the quarter and $5.3 million for the 6 months.

title: Mitsui Bank To Buy Stake
description: The Security Pacific Corporation announced on Tuesday that it would sell 5 percent of its consumer and commercial finance subsidiary for $100 million to Mitsui Bank Ltd., Japan's seventh-largest bank.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Computerization may displace the supermarket coupon. Several large chains, including Pathmark, Vons and Giant Food, will begin testing a program that will track purchases and offer rebates to regular buyers of certain brand-name goods. [ Page A1. ] John A. Mulheren Jr. was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan on 42 counts of securities fraud and other charges, stemming from his business relationship with Ivan F. Boesky. Mr. Mul heren was once one of Wall Street's leading arbitragers. [ D1. ] Girls are playing with frilly dolls, boys with armed action figures that stand ready for battle. Toy manufacturers say the notion of breaking down sex barriers in toys has failed. [ C1. ] Lawmakers in Texas have approved a stiff tax on burning fuel oil at industrial plants. [ D1. ] President Bush appealed to Democratic leaders for help in setting tough capital standards for savings institutions. The Democrats said they would do so. [ D1. ] Sales of domestic cars and light trucks rose 1.1 percent in early June, but demand remained too weak to reduce inventories significantly, analysts said. [ D2. ] Business sales rose 1.7 percent in April, the steepest gain since March 1988. It far outpaced a 0.6 percent jump in inventories. [ D16. ] COMPANIES In the battle for Time Inc., Wall Street action shifted to the two companies that want the media giant. Paramount's stock rose $1.75, to $59.50, and Warner's was up 75 cents, to $55. They were the second- and third-most-active stocks on the Big Board. [ D1. ] Mcorp said it lost $449 million in the fourth quarter of 1988, raising its total loss for last year to $977.9 million. [ D5. ] A Federal bankruptcy judge allowed Eastern Airlines to sell 15 planes and 6 engines for $277.5 million, in a continuing process to lessen the airline's losses and build up its cash. [ D4. ] The television stations affiliated with Fox Broadcasting announced that they would commission and present original programming for children, beginning in the fall of 1990. [ D19. ] A Delaware judge refused to block the merger agreement between Conagra and Holly Farms, clearing the way for Holly shareholders to vote on the pact. [ D4. ] Goldman Financial offered to acquire Gleason, a manufacturer of gear-making equipment, for $20 a share, or $120 million. [ D4. ] MARKETS Stock prices moved listlessly and finished mixed on moderate volume. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.18 point, to 2,503.36, but advances on the New York Stock Exchange edged declines, 745 to 725. [ D8. ] The Treasury bond market rose as prices followed the gains in the dollar. The advance erased most of Tuesday's declines. [ D14. ] Yields offered by money market mutual funds were off for the week ended yesterday. [ D7. ] Speculators gave the dollar's rally a push in anticipation of the Government's report today on the trade deficit. [ D18. ] The weather forecast sent buyers swarming back to the grain markets. [ D18. ] INTERNATIONAL Korea is likely to open its beef market, the United States trade representative said yesterday. [ D17. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Anheuser-Busch has offered to build an 18,000-seat arena in St. Louis and to buy the city's hockey team. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] The deadlock over Chase Medical appears to be near an end, and trading could resume soon. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D8. ] Saatchi & Saatchi reported significant declines in profits and said it was planning to sell its consulting division or to take it public. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D20. ]

title: Low-Level Atomic Testing Begun At Seabrook After Long Dispute
description: Operators at the Seabrook nuclear power plant started an atomic chain reaction in the plant's 100 tons of uranium fuel at 5:23 P.M. Tuesday, the start of low-power testing after years of dispute.

title: House Panel Backs Changes in Compensating Medicare Physicians
description: A House subcommittee today approved fundamental changes in the way physicians are compensated for treating Medicare and Medicaid patients. The action came as the panel polished its recommendations for reducing Medicare's projected growth by $2.4 billion.

title: VETO OF WAGE BILL WITHSTANDS VOTE
description: In a vote they acknowledged was largely symbolic, House Democrats today failed to override President Bush's veto of a bill raising the minimum wage. But the Democrats vowed to press for a compromise the President would sign.

title: Brandeis University Bonds Have Maximum Yield of 7%
description: The Massachusetts Industrial Finance Agency is tentatively offering $89.5 million of revenue bonds for Brandeis University with a maximum yield of 7 percent for an issue due 2019 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. For bonds with shorter maturities, yields on the serial bonds range from 6.30 percent in 1991 to 6.40 percent in 1994, 6.60 percent in 1999 and 6.70 percent in 2002. A bond due 2009 is priced to yield 6.95 percent.

title: Ourasi to Return
description: Ourasi, the 9-year-old trotter from France who has amassed more than $3 million in his career, will pay his second visit to the United States this year to race in the $250,000 Statue of Liberty International Trot on July 1 at the Meadowlands. Joe DeFrank, the race secretary at the Meadowlands, said he had received a written commitment from Frederic Sauque, the owner of Ourasi, who is expected to be retired next February. In his first trip to the United States, Ourasi was defeated at the wire by Sugarcane Hanover in the March of Dimes Trot at Garden State Park last November.

title: Quayle Abroad: Cheers for the Right
description: Vice President Dan Quayle is emerging as an eager defender of Nicaraguan ''freedom fighters,'' pressing the limits of the policy toward Managua that was adopted by the Bush Administration in a bipartisan compromise with Congress.

title: Sales Climb Outpaces Increase in Inventories
description: Business sales rose 1.7 percent in April, their steepest gain since March 1988, and far outpaced a jump of six-tenths of 1 percent in inventories.

title: Mulheren Indicted on 42 Counts
description: John A. Mulheren Jr., once one of Wall Street's top arbitragers, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Manhattan on 42 counts of securities fraud and other charges stemming from his business relationship with Ivan F. Boesky.

title: Homage to Japan's Influence on American Pottery
description: AMERICAN pottery owes a great deal to Japanese ceramics, and a major exhibition that pays tribute to this connection is at the Everson Museum of Art in Syracuse.

title: A Designer's Whimsical Essays in 'Tex-Baroque'
description: HILTON McCONNICO has never been to Texas or Arizona. But, he said, he wanted ''to bring the cactus into its own.''

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The NCNB Corporation yesterday priced $300 million of 9 1/2 percent subordinated capital note obligations due in 2004 through underwriters led by Stephens Inc.

title: CHIRAC ASKS PARIS TO FREE TERRORIST
description: Former Prime Minister Jacques Chirac has revived a debate over the price France paid for the release of its citizens held hostage in Lebanon, declaring that the bicentennial of the French Revolution is an occasion to consider an amnesty for a pro-Iranian terrorist jailed for life.

title: Ex-K.G.B. Chief Says Andropov Supported Purges
description: A former chief of the K.G.B. has accused Yuri V. Andropov, a onetime mentor of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, of aiding Stalin's purges and ignoring corruption under Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: Advance Circuits reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
PROSECUTION LAGS IN THE PALME CASE
description: The prosecution case against a 42-year-old Swede accused of killing Prime Minister Olof Palme in 1986 is faring poorly in the trial that began last week.

title: Xytronyx Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
McRae Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
300 Rebels Reported Killed In Clash With Uganda Army
description: The Ugandan Army has killed more than 300 rebels in one of the biggest battles it has fought since President Yoweri Museveni took power in 1986, military sources said today.

title: Hunt Manufacturing Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: The share earnings reflected a 3-for- 2 stock split paid in April.

title: A New Generation Takes Command at Lykes Brothers
description: Lykes Brothers Inc., which operates Florida's largest agribusiness and has banking, shipping, real estate and energy interests, has a new chairman and chief executive, Thompson L. Rankin, a descendant of the founder.

title: Senate Backs Gas Decontrol
description: The Senate approved legislation today to remove price controls on natural gas, a move supporters said would help to insure adequate supplies of the fuel used by 48 million American households, even if consumers must pay more.

title: Stocks Mixed, as Dow Dips 0.18, to 2,503.36
description: Stock prices moved listlessly yesterday, finishing mixed on moderate volume. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.18 point, to 2,503.36, but advances on the New York Stock Exchange edged declines, 745 to 725.

title: Canada to Permit Mock U.S. Bombing Runs
description: After four years of controversy and debate, Canada gave permission today for the United States Air Force to fly low-level bomber training runs over portions of the Canadian Northwest.

title: Mack Announcement Is Speeded by a Leak
description: When ITT Automotive Inc. announced a new president and chief executive on Tuesday, it said that the current executive, Ralph E. Reins, was leaving to pursue other interests.

title: Tikal Journal; With Bible in Hand, Evangelics Come Marching In
description: Most of those who make the trip here have eyes only for the ancient Maya temples towering above the jungle. But even in this remote corner of the country, the miserable Indian villages show traces of a vital new religious force at work in Guatemala that is arousing controversy in a much divided land.

title: Mexico Arrests Investigator In Political Journalist's Murder
description: Mexico's most politically charged murder case, the 1984 shooting of the country's best-known journalist, appears to have been cracked with the arrest of a former security official who headed the initial investigation.

title: Eaton Vance Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included charges of $1,242,476 and $1,136,680 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, both from net realized and unrealized losses on gold mining securities. c-Included charges of $14,339 for the quarter and $354,627 for the 6 months both from net realized and unrealized losses on gold mining securities.

title: Holly Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The share earnings reflected a 2-for- 1 stock split in July 1988.

title: 2 Film Series
description: ''American Movie Makers,'' a series highlighting two aspects of film making - the development of sound and the career of the director Vincente Minnelli - is to begin Nov. 17 at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street.

title: Albany Agrees To Extend Rent Control
description: With New York City's rent rules scheduled to expire on Thursday, state legislators agreed today to extend them for two years, leaving unresolved a sweeping series of competing demands from tenants and landlords to revise some rules.

title: NO HEART AID SEEN IN MILD CIGARETTES
description: Smoking cigarettes with less nicotine and carbon monoxide than regular cigarettes does not reduce the risk of heart attack, a new study has found.

title: European TV Plan Rejected
description: A plan by the European Community for ''television without frontiers'' fell apart today after six of the 12 member countries refused to accept it at a meeting in Luxembourg.

title: Hitler's Sunken Yacht Is In the Wrong Place
description: When Holocaust survivors cheered the sinking of Hitler's yacht off Miami Beach earlier this month, they thought they saw the last of the battered wreck. But now it appears the 85-foot yacht Ostwind will rise again.

title: North Hills Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Xeta Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income The revenue reported for the three and six-month periods ended April 30, 1989 included $1,095,000 and $1,997,000, respectively, in operator services revenues earned from the company's zero-plus long distance service, Hobic-Plus.

title: 2 U.S. Reporters Expelled
description: China ordered the expulsion of two Beijing-based American journalists, including one from the Voice of America. Page A16.

title: Pistons' Crown May Lose a Jewel
description: The Pistons, the newly crowned National Basketball Association champions, flew back to Detroit this morning, after a night of celebration, to join more celebrations in the streets of Detroit.

title: Big Fella Goes Back A Few Years
description: Nice touch in the Forum. The Big Fella came off for the last time with 19 seconds left, and the spotlights flashed on the championship banners, and the fans stood and cheered.

title: Detroit Hopes Pistons Help To Improve the City's Image
description: Nearly 2,000 fans waited in rain at nearby Willow Run Airport today to welcome home the champion Detroit Pistons, whose triumph as the ''bad boys'' of professional basketball is making this working-class city feel positively good about itself.

title: Fund Yields Remain Off
description: Yields offered by money market mutual funds were off for the week that ended yesterday, despite attempts by money managers to squeeze optimum returns from money market portfolios because interest rates were still moving lower.

title: Stamp Out Junk-Frank
description: ''Official Business: United States Senate Public Document,'' it says on the cover. Because the ''postal customer'' on the outside of the document is me, and I am a good citizen of Maryland, I open it.

title: Legal Curb On Sewing Draws Ire
description: A woman who runs a $1.7 million-a-year gift business here says the state's enforcement of a law banning industrial sewing at home is unfair and has cost nearly 100 women their jobs.

title: Capital Flees an Edgy Hong Kong
description: The signs of fear are everywhere in Hong Kong, economists, bankers and brokers say, from the Chinese women crowding into little shops to buy small bars of gold, to the thousands of residents patiently lining up in the hot June sun for immigration forms from the Canadian, Australian or American consulates.

title: Ryan Completes Victory Tour
description: Nolan Ryan became the sixth pitcher in major league history to defeat all 26 teams as the Texas Rangers beat the California Angels, 5-1, tonight in the first game of a double-header.

title: AIDS Outlay Nears That on Other Fatal Ailments
description: Federal spending on AIDS research, prevention and education this year will reach levels comparable to expenditures for other major fatal illnesses, like cancer and heart disease, according to a new study.

title: Georgetown Surprise: Penthouse On a Cliff
description: Patricia and Arthur Cotton Moore's penthouse apartment, incongruously set in historic Georgetown, evokes a style rarely seen in this city. Mr. Moore, a well-known architect who cuts a debonair figure, describes it as ''industrial baroque.''

title: Expansion Is Considered
description: The National League moved one step closer to expansion today when Bill White, the league president, unveiled a three-man expansion committee to a meeting of major league baseball owners.

title: A Veto That Can Help the Poor
description: President Bush's veto Tuesday of the minimum wage bill did more than stop an increase to $4.55 an hour. He impelled Congress toward a stunning public policy triumph. Mr. Bush welcomes Congress to join in a grand compromise: Expand tax credits for poor families in exchange for a small increase in minimum wages. Exactly right.

title: Court Lets Posner Vote DWG Shares
description: The DWG Corporation said the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio, in Cleveland, issued an order that vacated and dissolved the temporary restraining order issued on May 18 that enjoined Victor Posner from voting his almost 9.3 million shares of DWG common stock. Mr. Posner acquired the 46.5 percent stake last month upon conversion of all of the convertible securities of DWG owned by him and certain entities he controlled.

title: Survival Technology reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Trees and Power Lines Felled As Severe Storm Hits Capital
description: The worst thunderstorm in the local power company's records hit the Washington area today, felling hundreds of trees and cutting power to thousands of homes.

title: Zilog Team Seeks Company
description: Zilog Inc. said that its management and employees had teamed with the Warburg, Pincus Capital Company L.P., a venture capital fund, to purchase the company from the Exxon Corporation. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but it is an all-cash transaction with Exxon selling all of its ownership.

title: SafeCard Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a gain of $1,950,000 from a litigation settlement.

title: Sikorsky Contract
description: The Sikorsky Aircraft Division of the United Technologies Corporation has been awarded a $1.2 billion contract for work on UH-60 Blackhawk military helicopters, the Army said. The contract includes $6.5 million in modifications that will help protect the medium-lift Army helicoptersfrom electromagnetic interference, the announcement said. The Army announced earlier that control surfaces of some Blackhawks have suffered problems when the aircraft flew near sources of high electronic emissions like power lines.

title: Bounty Debated for Capture of Drug Lords
description: The Bush Administration is debating a plan to offer $5 million rewards for information leading to the arrest of the most-wanted accused drug kingpins, officials said today.

title: Coins Are Struck to Mark Congress's 200th
description: The Capitol plaza was temporarily transformed into a mint today as white-gloved officials manned giant presses to strike gold and silver coins commemorating the 200th anniversary of Congress.

title: Importance of R & D in U.S. Building Contracts
description: To the Editor:

title: W. Richard Weagly, Music Director, 80
description: W. Richard Weagly, a director of music at the Riverside Church for 21 years, died of coronary disease on June 4 at his home in San Marcos, Calif. He was 80 years old.

title: Giving the Official Spin: 6 Scenes on Chinese TV
description: Every evening in the last week, the official television news, viewed by millions of Chinese, seems to have reverted to the kind of indoctrination techniques familiar in the Mao era.

title: Two New Leaders With a Willingness to Listen and a Willingness to Deal: Richard A. Gephardt
description: Only 48 years old and in his 13th year in Congress, Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, who was elected majority leader today, has risen farther, faster in the House of Representatives than anyone else in the last 50 years.

title: House Votes More Officers For Washington Police Force
description: The House has approved hiring 700 more officers for the District of Columbia police force at a cost of $127 million, which has been fighting a record number of drug-related murders in the past year.

title: Core Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Accolade for Reagan: Honorary Knighthood
description: Queen Elizabeth II conferred an honorary knighthood on former President Ronald Reagan today, the highest honor Britain can give a foreigner.

title: Lawmaker's Headache: 3 Balance Sheets In Public/Private Lives
description: Like all members of Congress, Representative Edward F. Feighan is constantly juggling three separate balance sheets that overlap his public and private life: his personal finances, the allowance he receives from the taxpayers for running his Washington and district offices, and his campaign finances.

title: Gooden And Mets Triumph In Rain
description: Dwight Gooden's season of mixed results continued last night.

title: Japan's Savings At $5 Trillion
description: Japanese personal savings rose to $5.04 trillion at the end of the 1988 fiscal year, up 11.4 percent over the previous year, the Bank of Japan said in a report today.

title: Lowrance Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Borden Begins $150 Million Offer
description: Borden Inc., a food manufacturer and industrial and consumer products company, is offering $150 million of 9 1/4 percent sinking-fund debentures due 2019 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Hawaii Official Opposes Plan
description: Hawaii's Attorney General, Warren Price 3d, sent a letter yesterday to Dennis R. Patrick, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, opposing a proposal by Paramount Communications Inc. to put any Time Inc. stock that it receives under its takeover offer in a voting trust while seeking Government approval to transfer to itself Time's cable franchise ownership licenses.

title: Meeting the Challenge of Demilitarizing Our Economy; Surprise for Gorbachev
description: To the Editor:

title: Ultimate Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a $2,000,000 credit from the cumulatie effect of an accounting change. c-Net income The company said the loss for the year is attributable to one-time charges of $20.1 million associated with its previously reportd restructuring.

title: New Visions Entertainment Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of net operation loss carryforward of $2,170,000.

title: Dovetail Joints Offer Grace and Strength
description: LEAD: The dovetail, one of the most useful and strongest joints used in cabinetmaking, provides unusual strength and rigidity. But it also adds a touch of decoration when exposed.

title: Review/Television; A Summer Cycle of Horror Shows on HBO
description: In case you haven't heard the shrieks of delight as profits are tallied, the country is in the midst of a horror boom. From Stephen King's mystical-supernatural exercises to the Grand Guignol antics of comic books, anything promising a shudder and perhaps a giggle is being packaged for the mass movie and television markets.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday about a custody battle involving a polygamist reversed the identities of the lawyers in the case. Steven E. Snow was at the left, Tim Anderson at the right.

title: Miss Parsons Has Wedding
description: Laila Helen Parsons, a daughter of Sir Anthony and Lady Parsons of Ashburton, Devon, England, was married yesterday to Robert Wisnovsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. Wisnovsky of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Ivor Halliwell performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Anglican Church in Buckland-in-the-Moor, Devon.

title: Biggest Unmanned U.S. Rocket, Rival of Shuttle, Soars Into Space
description: A Titan 4 thundered off a Florida launching pad yesterday on its maiden flight, becoming the nation's largest unmanned rocket to climb into space and the first one big enough to rival the space shuttle in cargo capacity.

title: Samuel F. Thomas, Neurologist, 75
description: Dr. Samuel F. Thomas, a former chief of neurology at St. Luke's Hospital, died of an aneurysm on May 31 at Latter-Day Saints Hospital in Salt Lake City. He was 75 years old and lived in Salt Lake City.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: If you are one of the millions of Americans who will be traveling abroad, or even nationally, this summer, you will be more likely to have an enjoyable vacation if you prepare now for possible illnesses or ailments.

title: Navy Sub Sinks a Tug; A Crewman Is Missing
description: A nuclear-powered submarine sailing underwater hit a tug cable today, sinking the tug and apparently drowning a tug crew member, naval officials said.

title: Braniff Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Last year's operating results only included those of Florida Express for the period after the acquisition of Florida Express by Braniff on April 19, 1988. The operations of Florida Express are now merged with Braniff's operations.

title: Campeau Units' Losses
description: The Campeau Corporation said Tuesday that its two retailing subsidiaries, Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation, had pretax losses of $90.3 million and $51.4 million, respectively, although sales at both stores rose in the first quarter ended April 29.

title: Brooklyn 9-Year-Old Starts A One-Child War on Crack
description: Moved by the crack addiction of a favorite uncle, a 9-year-old from Brooklyn decided that she had to do something to persuade people to stop smoking the cocaine derivative.

title: Toys: Girls Still Apply Makeup, Boys Fight Wars
description: IN families across the country, it's toys as usual: girls are playing with frilly dolls that have man-luring manes and awesome wardrobes, and boys are playing with armed action figures that stand ready to battle for control of the universe.

title: A Plan for New York Schools
description: It may be some time before a new chancellor is appointed to lead the New York City school system. While the late Richard Green's successor should be free to develop his or her own program, steps can to be taken now to improve the schools and help the new chancellor succeed.

title: New Rail Ties Are Crumbling On Metro-North
description: A three-mile stretch of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad in the Bronx may have to be replaced because some of the 8,000 concrete ties installed there beginning four years ago have begun to crack and crumble, the president of the system said yesterday.

title: Approval Urged for Entire Pentagon Buying Plan
description: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, deluged with requests to restore programs cut from the military budget, touched off a frenzy of lobbying and political maneuvering today by proposing that the Pentagon's entire spending package for the purchase of weapons and equipment be approved without changes.

title: Suitors For Time In Spotlight
description: In the takeover battle for Time Inc., the Wall Street action shifted yesterday to the two companies that want it.

title: Edwin Clark Davis, Lawyer, 84
description: Edwin Clark Davis, a retired vice president and general counsel of Borden Inc., died June 6 at a nursing home in Keller, Tex. He was 84 years old and lived in Grapevine, Tex.

title: City Ballet Announces Promotions of 16
description: The New York City Ballet announced 16 promotions yesterday, including the advancement to principal dancer of Helene Alexopoulos, Peter Boal, Gen Horiuchi, Melinda Roy and Damian Woetzel. Robert Hill, formerly a soloist with American Ballet Theater, has joined City Ballet as a principal dancer.

title: Braves Settle Suit
description: Robin Monsky, the Atlanta Braves' former director of media information, who had accused the club and its former manager, Chuck Tanner, of sex discrimination, has dropped state and Federal law suits against the two defendants after receiving what she described yesterday as ''a substantial'' financial settlement.

title: Corrections
description: The News Summary in some editions yesterday erroneously listed an article about a bill on tax increases for New York City and Nassau County homeowners. In fact the article was printed on Tuesday.

title: Seven Die in House Fire
description: A house fire Monday night killed seven people, the authorities reported. Sgt. Glen Brown of the sheriff's department said the house was engulfed in flames when firefighters arrived, and after the blaze was controlled, the bodies of two women, a man, a girl and two boys were found in the ruins. An 8-year-old girl who escaped from the house died later at a hospital. A 9-year-old boy escaped uninjured. The cause of the fire was unknown.

title: In a High-Tech Germany, High Praise for 'Gorbi!'
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev took his perestroika campaign today to this capital of West German high technology, and once again enthusiastic crowds lined his routes and chanted his name.

title: Judy's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Groundwater Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Royalpar Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
9th Death in Delhi Rail Blast
description: A witness to the explosion at a city train station on Monday died today, raising the death toll in the blast to nine. The newest fatality, Kalyan Singh, was a station porter who other witnesses say was handling the luggage that apparently contained a home-made bomb. Police officials had been hoping that Mr. Singh could describe or identify the person who had given him the box or bag. No group has taken responsibility for the explosion.

title: Mystery Arises at Arms Plant With Finding of Radioactivity
description: A discovery of man-made radioactive elements produced only by splitting atoms has raised tantalizing new questions about the troubled history of the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant near here.

title: Head of Stock Trading Resigns at First Boston
description: Luis S. Mendez, a managing director and the head of stock sales and trading at the First Boston Corporation, resigned yesterday to pursue other interests. Replacing him is Curt R. Welling, a managing director and head of capital markets.

title: Judge Blocks A Bell Service
description: A Federal judge ruled Tuesday that three regional Bell telephone companies could not enter the information services market by offering customers electronic yellow pages and directories.

title: Turmoil in China; Far From Beijing's Spotlight, A City Bears Scars of Clashes
description: Filling nearly a full square block of this city in the Chinese hinterlands is the burned-out rubble of collapsed roofs and melted shutters, of shattered glass and the mangled remains of bicycles and carts. All of it is testimony to the fact that the violence that gripped Beijing a week and a half ago was echoed in at least one major provincial city.

title: Latest Rules for Dogs in New York Parks Are Unreasonable
description: To the Editor:

title: Dog Federation Adds 2 Breeds and 7 Members
description: The annual general assembly of the Federation Cynologique Internationale, the world governing body of dogs, ended here today with the acceptance of two new breeds and seven more countries.

title: HOUSE DEMOCRATS CHOOSE GEPHARDT AND GRAY TO LEAD
description: House Democrats completed the rebuilding of their leadership today, electing Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri as their majority leader and William H. Gray 3d of Pennsylvania as whip.

title: Uganda After Its Years of Terror: A New Political Stability Emerges
description: As this long-terrorized country has been transformed into a society with large pockets of safety and even vibrancy, it has become a major hope in Africa of the World Bank and the United States.

title: Standards Urged for Genetic 'Fingerprinting'
description: Laboratories that perform genetic analysis for identification purposes in criminal cases urgently need a set of national reliability and performance standards, experts in the new field say.

title: Taiwan to Buy U.S. Products
description: Taiwan will send five missions to the United States between August and early next year to buy American products totaling $1.5 billion to help narrow the trade gap between the countries, officials said this week.

title: Korea May Soon Ease Beef Curbs, U.S. Says
description: ''In a matter of weeks'' South Korea is likely to open its beef market, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today. She described that pending move as a major liberalizaton of trade.

title: Saatchi, Net Down, Plans To Shed Unit
description: REPORTING a significant decline in profits for the first half of the year, Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. also said yesterday that it planned to sell its consulting division or to take it public as a separate company.

title: Vote Seen as a Test for the New Virginia
description: Fresh from a come-from-behind victory in Tuesday's Republican gubernatorial primary, former State Attorney General J. Marshall Coleman plunged enthusiastically today into the campaign for the fall election, saying it would provide a reading on where Virginia is headed politically, economically and racially in the next century.

title: Scott Ross Dies at 38; Played Scarlatti Works
description: Scott Ross, a harpsichordist who specialized in the music of Rameau, Couperin and Scarlatti, died Tuesday at his home in Assas, France. He was 38 years old. Mr. Ross had been suffering from AIDS, according to his record company, Erato, in Paris.

title: Bergen Brunswig Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $510,000 for the quarter and $124,000 for the 9 months, and the 9 months also included a $1,999,000 gain on the disposition of discontinued operations.

title: Steroid Data Cited and Disputed
description: The International Olympic Committee's medical commission may have data suggesting that Ben Johnson was not the only male track and field athlete who used anabolic steroids in training for the Seoul Olympics, even if he was the only one who failed his drug test.

title: L.I. Assured on Power Supply
description: The electricity supply on Long Island is expected to be ''tight'' but adequate this summer, a state report released today said. The supply should increase markedly when three combustion turbines are completed in July and August, said the report from the state Public Service Commission and state Energy Office. If all goes well, the Long Island Lighting Company will have an 18 percent power reserve, the report said.

title: City Investigating Yankee and Met Tickets
description: The New York City Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday that it had subpoenaed records relating to the sale of Yankee and Met tickets. The department acted after a preliminary investigation indicated that box office personnel and representatives of two ticket agencies were misleading the public about the availability of tickets.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: SOCCER Australia 2, U.S. 2: Pangallo scored one goal and set up another in a three-minute span late in the second half yesterday to give Australia a tie against the United States in the Under-16 World Cup tournament in Aberdeen, Scotland. Because Brazil beat East Germany, 2-1, in the first game, the United States had to win by four goals to move past Brazil and into the quarterfinals.(AP) TENNIS Shriver Beaten: Pam Shriver, who has cast doubt in recent weeks on her future in the game, was beaten, 7-6, 7-5, yesterday by a fellow American, Ann Henricksson, in a tournament at Edgabaston, England. Zina Garrison defeated Kathy Rinaldi, 6-1, 5-7, 6-1, to reach the quarterfinals. In doubles play, Billie Jean King and Martina Navratilova, teaming for the first time in nine years, won a postponed first-round match over Maria Lindstrom of Sweden and Heather Ludloff of the United States before losing to Anne Minter and Julie Richardson of Australia.(AP) Wilander Advances: Mats Wilander of Sweden moved into the third round of the Queens Club grass championships in London yesterday with a 7-6, 2-6, 6-3 victory over David Wheaton of the United States. Tim Mayotte lost to Tim Wilkison, a fellow American, 6-3, 7-6. Kevin Curren was beaten by Pete Sampras of the United States, 6-3, 6-3. Ivan Lendl defeated Mark Kratzmann of Australia, 6-2, 6-3. Nicolas Pereira, an 18-year-old from Venezuela who defeated Stefan Edberg in the first round, lost to Chris Bailey of Britain, 6-3, 7-6.(AP) McEnroe Breezes: John McEnroe eased his way to a 6-3, 6-1 first-round victory over Ross Matheson of Scotland yesterday in the Scottish grass championships at Edinburgh. Vitas Gerulaitis of the United States beat David Felgate of Britain, 6-7, 7-6, 6-4.(AP) YACHT RACING Australian Boat Wins on Tie Breaker: Sovereign, sailed by Peter Gilmour of Australia, won the Maxi-Boat Series yesterday in Newport, R.I. The five-race series resulted in a tie between Sovereign and Emeraude, sailed by Dennis Conner of San Diego. A provision in the scoring based on where the boats finished in each race broke the tie.

title: Reviews/Dance; Mystical Originality of Angela Caponigro
description: The program of dances presented by the Angela Caponigro Dance Ensemble on Friday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio was one of the oddest and most joyous of the year. Ms. Caponigro is a mystic whose training includes longtime work in Kundalini yoga, a physical discipline based in part on breathing techniques. And her dances, often governed by the firm central axis of the spine, have a compelling plainness and simplicity to them. But Ms. Caponigro also has a strong, wildly imaginative sense of theater that is most readily discernible in spare but exotic costumes that are frequently a matter of headpieces of gilded, fantastic plumage.

title: Two New Leaders With a Willingness to Listen and a Willingness to Deal: William H. Gray 3d
description: Like many other black politicians, Representative William H. Gray 3d has his roots in the ministry, as pastor of the Bright Hope Baptist Church in Philadelphia, where his father and grandfather preached before him.

title:
CURRENTS;
A New Bunk Bed That's Cozy and Safe
description: LEAD: WILLIAM McDONOUGH, a New York architect, was renovating a Upper West Side town house for Joanna and Sasha Muniak when the couple asked him to design a bunk bed for their son, Alexei, shown above with his sister, Olivia.

title: New Data on Divorce Filing
description: When an American marriage ends in divorce, the wife is nearly twice as likely as the husband to initiate the process, according to a report from the National Center for Health Statistics. Women filed 61.5 percent of the divorce petitions acted on in 1986, and men filed 32.6 percent. The remaining petitions were filed jointly.

title: Article 246489 -- No Title
description: A Houston lawyer has been fined $15,000 in Federal Court for killing a whooping crane, one of only 200 in the world, during a hunting trip near Corpus Christi in January. The lawyer, Mario Max Yzaguirre, pleaded guilty to violating the Endangered Species Act, an Assistant United States Attorney, Jeff Babcock, said Monday. Mr. Yzaguirre said he thought the bird was a snow goose. He could have been sentenced to a year in prison and fined $100,000, and the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department said it might still seek $11,000 in civil damages.

title: A Currency Crisis Shakes Nicaragua
description: Five months after the Sandinista Government imposed strong austerity measures, a drastic set of currency devaluations has sent Nicaraguan consumers reeling and provoked new doubts about the Government's ability to control the economy.

title: Kewaunee Scientific Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a loss of $106,000 from an accounting change.

title: In This Computer Age, Who Needs Coupons?
description: As it apparently must for all things, computerization is coming to challenge the humble supermarket coupon. This fall, several of the nation's largest supermarket chains, including Pathmark, Vons and Giant Food, will begin testing a program that will track purchases on computers and offer rebates to regular buyers of certain brand-name goods.

title: Reviews/Dance; New 'Swan Lake' and 'Quixote' Principals
description: Martine van Hamel and Kevin McKenzie are the latest pair of principals to make their debut in American Ballet Theater's new production of ''Swan Lake.'' And Cynthia Harvey, who had been on leave with the Royal Ballet in Britain, was seen for the first time this season on Tuesday night in ''Don Quixote.''

title: Holly-Conagra Merger Is Cleared by Judge
description: A Delaware judge yesterday refused to block the merger agreement between Conagra and Holly Farms Inc., clearing the way for Holly shareholders to vote on the pact.

title: Chagas' Disease Claimed an Eminent Victim
description: To the Editor:

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: THEY crowd the elevators on Friday mornings, the people with the shrouded tennis rackets and the carryalls and the prematurely sneakered feet. They are going to what they always call ''the country'' for the weekend, and if they have any luck they will be leaving the office by three.

title: Rain Becomes a Major Threat On Eve of United States Open
description: Heavy rains came to Oak Hill Country Club again today shortly after P. J. Boatwright, executive director for competitions of the United States Golf Association, said, ''One good shower and we're out of business.''

title: Coleman Undergoes Surgery on Left Foot
description: Derrick Coleman, the 6-foot-10-inch center for Syracuse, underwent foot surgery last Friday and will be on crutches for the next several months, according to athletic officials at the school. Dr. Bruce Baker, the team physician, performed the surgery. which involved repairing two injured toes on Coleman's left foot. Coleman, who was among the top five rebounders and shot blockers in the country last season, had suffered repeated jamming of the two toes in the recent season and chose the surgery to correct the problem. ''It's not major at all,'' said Bernie Fine, the assistant coach. ''It's certainly not career threatening.''(AP)

title: Bridge
description: Two Polish players won the fourth Epson Worldwide Bridge Contest played Friday.

title:
CURRENTS;
New Restaurant's Look Is Refinery (Not Refined)
description: LEAD: LAST week a touch of heavy industry came to Battery Park City in a new restaurant, Pipeline, designed by Sam Lopata. The look is early oil refinery, geared to residents and employees of the financial district bored with corporate offices and trading rooms.

title: Hydro-Quebec
description: Hyrdo-Quebec, a large Canadian utility, is offering $250 million of debentures due 2029 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The debentures feature a noncallable provision, which is not often seen in a 40-year debt issue. Underwriters gave the debentures an 8 5/8 percent coupon and priced them at par, to yield about 45 basis points more than the Treasury's 30-year bond. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The financing is rated A-3 by Moody's and AA- by S.&P.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Citicorp appointed Philip D. Sherman global business manager of its institutional investment management business.

title: Prices of Treasury Bonds Climb
description: The Treasury bond market rose yesterday as prices followed the gains in the dollar. The advance erased most of the previous day's declines.

title: EAC Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $1,210,000.

title: Foodarama Supermarkets Inc reports earnings for 13wks to April 29
description: The company said operating losses coupled with close-down costs of four Pennsylvania stores discontinued in the first quarter of 1989 totaled $950,000 before income taxes, accounting for the lower earnings in the latest 6 months.

title: Crime Reports Scare Subway Riders
description: LEAD: One woman started carrying a pocketknife this week. Another uses her umbrella as a weapon. A man says he stopped wearing his favorite gold bracelet and chain.

title: Review/Music; Bach and Mozart Programs
description: An ensemble of musicians from the Bach and Mozart Festival of Tokyo came to Weill Recital Hall last week for a pair of programs, a Bach evening and a Mozart afternoon. The latter, given on Saturday, brought mostly familiar pieces in performances that, while reasonably accomplished and professional sounding, were rather ordinary, and suggested that international touring may not be the most important service the group could render.

title: Bronx Housing Impresses Rockefeller and Builders
description: Abraham Biderman, New York City's Commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, had just completed a 20-minute inspection yesterday of a half-dozen abandoned apartment buildings being brought back to life in the South Bronx. He bounded up the steps of the bus, grabbed a microphone dangling from the wall and said, ''O.K., anybody want an apartment?''

title: Staodynamics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
description: b-Net loss

title: GAME GOES AWRY, AND SUITS FOLLOW
description: Winners in a Kraft promotion contest that went awry have filed at least two lawsuits against the company, contending that it is trying to withhold their prizes, which include skateboards, bicycles and a $17,000 van.

title: U.S. Will Require Back Seat Harnesses In 1990 Model Cars
description: The Government has issued a rule requiring that virtually all new cars sold in the United States have lap and shoulder safety belts for two passengers in the rear seat.

title: WORLD RESEARCH DISRUPTED BY FIRE
description: A fire last month at the Jackson Laboratory, one of the world's leading suppliers of research mice, has caused major disruptions for medical scientists in the United States, Canada and other countries.

title: Books of The Times; A Revealing Portrait of a Master at Concealing
description: The Life of Graham Greene Volume I: 1904-1939 By Norman Sherry Illustrated. 783 pages. Viking. $29.95.

title: Telco Systems reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Mcorp Discloses Loss Of $977.9 Million in '88
description: Mcorp, the troubled Texas banking company, said today that it had lost $449 million in the fourth quarter of 1988, raising its total loss for last year to $977.9 million.

title: Review/Theater; Fearful Visions, a Fat Farm And an Aging Artist Offstage
description: Neal Bell takes the title and central image of his one-act play, ''The Open Boat,'' from Stephen Crane. As Crane wrote about the shipwreck in his short story of the same name, ''Many a man ought to have a bathtub larger than the boat which rode upon the sea.'' Mr. Bell plays upon the idea of a tub as boat and vice versa, with, in this macabre case, both becoming vessels of death.

title: KEY RATES
Tiny Green Patches Of a Polish Spring
description: In Poland, a land where vegetables are in chronically short supply and people line up when cucumbers hit the market, the hothouses ringing the capital burst with explosions of dahlias and roses, profusions of tulips and hyacinths.

title: Tri-R Systems Corp reports earnings for
description: b-Net income

title: Dollar Continues Its Rally And Tops 150 Yen in Tokyo
description: The dollar moved sharply higher against the yen in Tokyo today, opening above 150 yen for the first time in 22 months.

title: S. S. Stern, 99; Designed Ritz Crackers Box
description: Sydney S. Stern, designer of the original Ritz Crackers, Shredded Wheat and Animal Crackers boxes, died of heart failure June 5 at the Palms of Pasadena Hospital in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 99 years old and lived in St. Petersburg.

title: Artists Protest Corcoran Cancellation
description: Some 5,000 members of the Corcoran Gallery of Art received invitations in the mail this week to a June 30 reception for the exhibition ''Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment.''

title: Calendar: Island Cruise And a Woodland Walk
description: Buildings by Boat, Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street; 212-860-6871.

title: Savings Bill Appeal Made By President
description: In a last-minute push for tough capital standards in his rescue plan for the savings and loan industry, President Bush appealed to the House and Senate leadership today for help.

title: Sun City Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Net loss

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Review/Pop; In the Spirit of the Old-Time Piano Masters
description: Neville Dickie, a big, burly Englishman whose piano repertory focuses on stride, ragtime and boogie-woogie, has the physical outlines of such masters of those traditionalist styles as the stride pianist James P. Johnson and the boogie-woogie master Pete Johnson. He also has the fingers and the sensitivity to evoke the spirit of their playing.

title: Atwater 'Doing a Great Job,' Bush Tells G.O.P. Gathering
description: President Bush tonight defended his beleaguered former campaign manager and Republican Party chief, Lee Atwater, saying he was ''doing a great job.''

title: Hunts' Plan Leaves Millions Intact
description: Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt, one-time billionaires, would retain millions of dollars of assets under liquidation plans they filed today in Federal bankruptcy court.

title: Ex-Congressman's Bid for Mistrial Is Denied
description: A Federal judge refused to declare a mistrial in the perjury trial of former Representative Pat Swindall today, ruling that a question the prosecutor asked a witness had not unfairly influenced the jury Defense attorneys asked for the mistrial after the prosecutor, Craig Gillen, asked Bobby Lee Cook, a lawyer who is a defense witness, what motivates defendants to take the stand.

title: Fox TV Affiliates Will Join in a 'Kid's Network'
description: The television stations affiliated with the Fox Broadcasting Network announced yesterday that they would commission and present original programming aimed at children, beginning in the fall of 1990.

title: Alaskan Timber Dispute Echoes on L.I.
description: Few places in the United States are more removed from the Alaska panhandle - in both miles and mood - than Long Island. But that has not stopped one of the Island's Representatives in Congress, Robert J. Mrazek, from jumping into the middle of a stormy dispute over the future of the Tongass, the huge rain forest that covers much of the American fringe along western Canada.

title: American Franchise Group reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: The company said its Business Cards Tomorrow subsidiary contributed revenue of $8,161,742, up 28 percent over fiscal 1988, and had earnings of $735,532, up 111 percent over fiscal 1988. The company also said its earnings were substantially reduced by the showing of its other subsidiary, Print Shack, which lost $383,215 on revenue of $1,216,696 from the time of acquisition in August 1988. This loss was due primarily to a one time writeoff of $451,000 in bad accounts receivable which existed at the time of acquisition.

title: Hilton Hotels
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said it plans to hire a financial adviser to help it evaluate ways to ''optimize shareholder value.'' Hilton, the hotel and gaming concern based in Beverly Hills, Calif., has been the focus of intense takeover speculation since last month when Barron Hilton, the company's chairman, suggested he would consider selling the company if an offer were made. Hilton said it was not taking the action, which came at a regularly scheduled meeting of the board of directors, in response to any specific inquiries or contacts with outsiders. In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Hilton shares closed at $95.125 today, up $3.125.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly PARTIES TO ANTI-APARTHEID CONVENTION - 11 A.M. COUNCIL FOR NAMIBIA - 3 P.M. COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title:
CURRENTS;
When Pools Have Style, Who Needs the Beach?
description: LEAD: THE beach is sandy, the ocean can be dirty and the sun might damage your skin. No wonder some city people are heading indoors and underground to health clubs.

title: The Death Penalty Is Not an Answer to Grief
description: To the Editor:

title: Travel Agency Is Fined for Tours to Vietnam and Cambodia
description: A Connecticut travel agency was penalized more than $75,000 yesterday for violating United States trade embargoes against Vietnam and Cambodia by offering tours to those countries.

title: Latest Rules for Dogs in New York Parks Are Unreasonable; A Park Is Not a Home
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film; Soviet Director Has Fun With Folklore
description: ''Ashik Kerib'' was shown as part of the 1988 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Walter Goodman's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 29, 1988. The film, in Russian with English subtitles, opens today at Anthology Film Archives, 32-34 Second Avenue, at Second Street.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: ''THIS isn't how I expected my family to turn out at all,'' said Mary, who asked that her last name not be used.

title: Japan Trade Surplus Is Cut
description: Japan's trade surplus with the United States narrowed by 19 percent last month, to $2.76 billion, from a revised $3.4 billion a year earlier, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Qintex Entertainment reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $118,000 and $1,454,000 for the quarter and 9-month period, respectively. The comparable year-ago figures are not applicable. The company was formed by the merger of Hal Roach Studios Inc. and Robert Halmi Inc. in April of last year, and commenced its first full fiscal year Aug. 1.

title: Baldor Boehm Is Closing a Plant
description: The Baldor Boehm Company said it would close its Connecticut plant at the end of the year in a move that would eliminate about 180 jobs in the state. The company said operations at the Connecticut factory, which makes electric motors for industrial use, would be moved to a plant in Clarksville, Ark.

title: Restricting Oil Use, Texas Expects Gas Sales to Rise
description: In this state where oil money has long been politically powerful, lawmakers have approved what would seem to be a remarkable move for Texas: a stiff tax on burning fuel oil at industrial plants.

title: The Care and Feeding of the Composer at Yaddo
description: ''This is the time of year when I ask myself why I'm living in New York City,'' said Richard Danielpour, a 33-year-old composer whose works were performed by the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center and Music Today this past season and who is at work on his Third Symphony and a piano concerto. ''I'm exhausted from the season just ending, and I'm looking at several large commissions that have to be completed during the summer. It's an unusually busy time for me.''

title: Bally to Build Plant
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation, which owns gaming properties in Nevada and New Jersey, announced plans this week to build an equipment plant in Las Vegas for an estimated $10 million. The plant, which will manufacture gaming machines and lottery terminals, is scheduled to be completed by mid-1990. It will initially provide jobs for up to 300 people. Bally makes leisure and recreation products. The Chicago-based company also operates casino hotels in Nevada and Atlantic City.

title: Letting Woodwork Shine Through
description: WHEN molding, paneling, mantels or other interior woodwork need to be stripped of paint, a homeowner has two choices: do it yourself or call a professional.

title: S.E.C. Bars Bogus Bidder
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today barred a Cincinnati financial adviser from the securities business for reportedly masterminding a false bid for the Dayton Hudson Corporation in the summer of 1987.

title: Is Eurocom Seeking to Buy WCRS?
description: British and American advertising circles are rife with rumors that Eurocom, the French agency that is part owner of HDM, is on the verge of engineering the acquisition of all or part of the WCRS Group, the British parent of Della Femina, McNamee WCRS in the United States.

title: Max & Erma's Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to May 14
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $111,000 for the quarter and $218,000 for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary credits of $67,000 for the quarter and $115,000 for the 6 months.

title: AVOID IRAQI ARMS, LEBANESE WARNED
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has warned Lebanese Christian leaders against using new Iraqi-supplied weapons against his country, threatening unlimited retaliation, according to a report published here today.

title: Time of the Assassins
description: Abraham Chasanow died the other day, and attention should be paid. He was not a famous person; he disliked the limelight. But when he was victimized at a time of fear and injustice in this country, he fought back. He made a difference.

title: WTD Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30

CURRENTS;
Looking in Windows That Aren't Really There
description: LEAD: ''EVERYONE is a voyeur,'' said Patricia Sapinsley, an architect whose window installation at Grand Central Terminal encourages commuters to peek. The project is part of ''Grand Windows,'' a show sponsored by the Architectural League of New York. The show, which runs through the summer, makes use of spaces left vacant while the ground floor of the terminal is renovated.

title: Judge Lets Eastern Sell 15 Planes
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge in Manhattan allowed Eastern Airlines yesterday to sell 15 planes and 6 engines for $277.5 million in a continuing process to reduce the airline's losses and build up cash for a possible rebuilding.

title: Q & A
description: Asbestos in Basement

title: Political Clubs: Power Is Only a Memory
description: Across New York City in this election season, Democratic clubs are savoring a taste of the power they once had.

title: Nervously, Border Town Awaits Taxes
description: There is a lot of number-crunching going on here. At the Enfield Square Mall, Charles J. McKeen is refiguring his utility bills. At the Lego toy factory, they're measuring floor space. And everyone is looking north and thinking about the spread.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: KNOTS are tools, really. They perform the same tasks as clamps. Special knots, like special tools, are often just the thing to have; there is nothing like using the right tool for the job. Here are several uncommon knots that will probably be more useful than the square knots, bowlines and sheepshanks learned in scouting or summer camp.

title: Exxon Spill Captain Is Heckled Aboard Plane
description: Joseph J. Hazelwood, the former Exxon skipper whose tanker ran aground and caused the biggest oil spill in United States history, was heckled Tuesday night on an airline flight by passengers, who called him ''a real jerk'' and other names.

title: U.S. May Ease Hungary Trade
description: Officials of the Bush Administration said this week that they expected to grant full trade status to Hungary within a few months and were working on other trade benefits to encourage economic reforms and a move toward democracy. William Bodde Jr., Deputy

title: SRI LANKA PULLOUT REJECTED BY INDIA
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi today categorically rejected a Sri Lankan Government request that New Delhi withdraw its 45,000 soldiers from the island by the end of July.

title:
CURRENTS;
In London, 3 Floors Of Design
description: LEAD: THE glass storefront of the new Collier Campbell Shop in London is hardly imposing. But once beyond it, visitors find a dramatic three-level atrium that looks like a 1980's version of the Burlington Arcade on Piccadilly.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Who Runs Japan? The System.
description: Who really holds power in Japan? If it's the people, how can the ever-ruling Liberal Democratic Party continue in office even though its popularity recently dropped to 3.9 percent? If it's the party that holds power, why has it been unable to change an industrial and trade policy that leads Japan toward direct collision with its largest trading partner?

title: INSIDE
description: Frenzy Over Military Budget Les Aspin called for a single vote on the Pentagon purchasing package, starting a lobbying flurry. Page B11. Indictment on Wall Street John Mulheren Jr. was indicted on 42 counts stemming from his relationship with Ivan Boesky. Page D1. Stereotypes in the Toy Box The sexual revolution has not changed toys; it's still dolls for girls and action figures for boys. Page C1.

title: Deng's Ploy, Bush's Test
description: Deng Xiaoping and Li Peng have begun searching for ways to divert attention from the carnage they wrought in Tiananmen Square on June 3. They have singled out the brilliant astrophysicist Fang Lizhi, China's best known dissident.

title: Rapids Rivals Shooting for Championship
description: Because their sport, white-water slalom racing in canoes, is so obscure, Jon Lugbill and Davey Hearn are two of this planet's best but least-known athletes.

title: Stock Offering By Weirton Steel
description: The Weirton Steel Corporation, one of the nation's largest employee-owned companies, went public today by offering four million shares of its common stock for trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The first offering of Weirton Steel stock opened at $14.50 a share. The stock ended the day at $15.125, up 62.5 cents, and was the 10th-most-active issue with more than 1.2 million shares trading. Proceeds from Weirton Steel's stock offering will be used to help finance a $650 million modernization project.

title: Gleason Gets Merger Offer
description: Goldman Financial Group Inc., a privately owned industrial concern, offered yesterday to acquire the Gleason Corporation, a leading manufacturer of gear equipment, for $20 a share, or a total of about $120 million.

title: A Fogbound Fly Ball Rescues Yanks in 9th
description: The ball rose gently into the summer night like a shooting star. The players watched and the fans watched, and for a small moment, everything seemed frozen. Then the ball simply disappeared into the thick fog.

title: Children's Garden Still Grows in Brooklyn
description: SUSAN D. KRONICK is a 37-year-old senior vice president at Bloomingdale's in Manhattan. Christopher Boyd is an 11-year-old fifth-grade student at Public School 193 in the Midwood section of Brooklyn. They have never met, but they have something in common: both have been gardeners at the Children's Garden of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Cenvill Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said increased sales of improved land to builders at the Polo Club and a total $1.7 million gain on the sale of unimproved land were included in the latest 6 months.

title: Senator Hints at Change In Vote on Death Penalty
description: Prospects for overriding Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's veto of the death penalty appeared to dim this week when a State Senator whose vote is crucial to the effort said he might switch his position and vote against it.

title: A Legendary Dance Studio That's Still Kicking
description: The sketchily handwritten sign reads simply ''Fazil's.'' Two dark and narrow flights up, the stairway opens out into a small room with a desk and chairs. The sound of castanets and a tinkling tango floats out from the battered rehearsal studios that surround the front desk. Yellowing photographs of dancers and club performers from another time crowd the walls around the small desk.

title: Turmoil in China; Pronouncing the Names
description: DENG XIAOPING, senior leader: dung sheeow-ping (sheeow rhymes with meow) FANG LIZHI, dissident: fahng lee-jur (rhymes with burr) HAN XU, Ambassador to the United States: hahn shoo HU QILI, Politburo member: hoo chee-lee LI PENG, Prime Minister: lee pung XIONG YAN, student leader -shyoong yen YANG RUDAI, Politburo member: yahng rew-die ZHAO ZIYANG, Communist Party General Secretary: jow (rhymes with how) dzuh-yahng ZHOU FENGSUO, student leader - joe fung-swoh

title: The Minskoff Studio Closing Over Rent
description: Dance and theater studios have become an endangered species in New York City because of rising rents and real estate development. The latest studio closing will be that of the Minskoff Rehearsal Studio complex, a 14,000-square-foot space with eight studios in the Astor Plaza building on Broadway, between West 44th and 45th Streets. The closing, on June 30, will result from a new lease raising the rent by about 150 percent.

title: Joseph Cardinal Malula, 71, Dies
description: Joseph Cardinal Malula, a leading Roman Catholic prelate in Africa who fought for church rights in Zaire, died today in Louvain, Belgium, after a long illness. He was 71 years old. Cardinal Malula, born in what was then the Belgian Congo, was appointed Archbishop of Kinshasa, the capital, in 1964. Five years later, Pope Paul VI elevated him to cardinal.

title: Talking Deals; Busch Proposes A Hockey Trade
description: THE Anheuser-Busch Companies has offered St. Louis an unusual deal. In return for the right to demolish 10 turn-of-the-century landmark warehouses adjacent to Busch Stadium, Anheuser-Busch would build an 18,000-seat arena for the St. Louis Blues hockey team, buy the team and promise to keep it in St. Louis.

title: Rangers' Top Job: Johnson May Score on Breakaway
description: The Rangers, operating for almost a month with a virtual vacuum in their front office, have moved considerably closer to hiring Bob Johnson as the team's next general manager, perhaps even before the National Hockey League draft Saturday in Minneapolis.

title: Open Space Replaces 'Arc'
description: A ''new art form - open space,'' will replace Richard Serra's sculpture ''Tilted Arc'' on Federal Plaza in lower Manhattan, in the words of William J. Diamond, the regional administrator of the Federal General Services Administration.

title: Virco Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a gain of $557,000 from cumulative effect of an accounting change for the latest period and income of $63,000 from discontinued operations for the year-ago period.

title: Clark Mired in Slump
description: Ten strikeouts in 11 times at bat over three games has left the Padres' Jack Clark disgusted with himself. ''I need to look in the mirror personally because I'm not enjoying baseball,'' Clark said Tuesday night after the Padres lost to Cincinnati, 9-6, at San Diego.

title: 202 Data Systems reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
'People's Court' Finds Itself Before the Dock
description: A man who lost his case on ''The People's Court'' is suing Judge Wapner.

title: Old Dominion Systems reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: WASHINGTON TALK: POLITICS
description: The name of the organization itself was almost enough to provoke arguments: it was hard to be neutral about Moral Majority, and among political people, almost nobody was.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Avery Inc., a chemical company, said its board had approved the sale of its Uniroyal Chemical Co., a specialty chemical business, to a management-led group for $800 million.

title: Ex-Officer Known as 'Batman' Is Charged in Fraud
description: Without so much as a POW! BAM! or a ZOOM!, Federal law-enforcement authorities yesterday announced the arrest of a former New York City police officer who gained fame as the Batman half of a celebrated anticrime team known as Batman and Robin.

title: Review/Comedy; Phyllis Diller's New Targets
description: With her hard hacking laugh and a barrage of caustic one-liners that portray physical imperfections as natural catastrophes, Phyllis Diller may be the ultimate exponent of smiling comic self-deprecation.

title: Campaign Matters; Lauder Likes TV But at Rikers Jail It's an 'Outrage'
description: Running for office is a voyage of discovery for the multitude of candidates who would be mayor in New York, as they tour the dark and dismal corners of the city in search of an issue or two to smite the incumbent.

title: Commodities-Orix
description: The Commodities Corporation, one of the world's largest money managers in the futures market, announced it would sell 30 percent of the company to the Orix Corporation, a global financial services firm based in Tokyo. Orix will also retain the right to acquire an additional 10 percent of the Commodities Corporation under the deal. The initial purchase will cost $80 million, plus a contingent amount based on the company's future earnings, Commodities said.

title: Gilroy Journal; Officials Swallow Pride On What Students Eat
description: Here amid the garlic fields and the almond groves, betwixt cherry orchards and lush vineyards, school administrators are learning what parents have known for decades: You can surround teen-agers with nutritious food, but you can't make them eat it.

title: Gotti's Son Is Arrested In Fight at Restaurant
description: Three men, including the son of John Gotti, the reputed organized-crime boss, were charged with assaulting three people in a fight that began in a restaurant, the police said today.

title: Ethics of a Subsidy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Moment of Truth: Can Lotus Do It Again?
description: It's white-knuckle time for the Lotus Development Corporation.

title: Peter Hill, Hijacking Hostage, Is Dead at 61
description: Peter W. Hill, a tour guide who was among the 39 people held hostage in Lebanon after their Trans World Airways jumbo jet was hijacked by Shiite Moslem terrorists in 1985, died Monday in Plantation, Fla. He was 61 years old and suffered from cancer.

title: At Least 60 Doctors Arrested In Zimbabwe Hospital Strike
description: The police arrested at least 60 doctors today during a three-day nationwide strike at state-run hospitals for higher pay.

title: Turmoil in China; U.S. CHIDES CHINA OVER 2 EXPULSIONS
description: The Bush Administration protested to the Chinese Government today over its expulsion of two American journalists, saying the move would not keep ''the truth about what is going on in China from being heard.''

title: Wildcat Coal Strike Continues Despite Order
description: Thousands of West Virginia coal miners continued a wildcat strike today, some in defiance of a Federal judge, and the walkout spread to Virginia.

title: Great American Management & Investment Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and the year-ago 9 months' share earnings was less than 1 cent a share.

title: Williams in L'eggs Race
description: Lynn Williams of Canada, the 1984 Olympic bronze medalist in the 3,000 meters, and Marty Cooksey, who won a gold medal in the 10,000 meters at the 1987 Pan American Games, have entered the L'eggs Mini Marathon to be held Saturday in Central Park. More than 9,000 women are expected to compete in this year's event.

title: Making City Planning a Game
description: A NEW computer game, Sim City, allows the player to build a city from the ground up and then manage it.

title: Mariners' Big Trade Isn't Looking So Awful
description: The Seattle Mariners won't finish high enough this season for Woody Woodward to be named executive of the year, but he should at least be designated Houdini of the year among major league general managers.

title: Topps Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
Judge Denies North's Motions for Acquittal
description: Oliver L. North's motion to set aside his three Iran-contra convictions was denied today by the trial judge, clearing the way for the former White House aide's sentencing next week.

title: Costain Buying Pyro Energy
description: A United States subsidiary of the Costain Group P.L.C. of London is buying the Pyro Energy Corporation, an Indiana coal-mining company, in a cash transaction valued at $193 million, the companies said. Costain Holdings Inc., based in Chicago, will pay $12 a share for all of Pyro's common stock, which closed at $11.75 today, up $1.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Eagle-Picher Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said the Chi-Vit division and the Bearings division, which were sold during the first quarter of 1989, contributed $18.6 million to sales and $2.5 million to operating income in the second quarter of 1988. The company also said net income was aided by a substantial reduction in the effective tax rate arising from the recognition of the benefit of the book loss carryforward related to the company's 1988 provision for asbestos litigation.

title: Baseball Final Is Rescheduled
description: The game between Lincoln and Fort Hamilton for the baseball championship of the Public Schools Athletic League will be played next Monday at 5 P.M. at Yankee Stadium. The teams had originally been scheduled to play last Monday afternoon, but wet grounds made the field unplayable.

title: Museum Cancels China Film
description: The American Museum of Natural History in New York has dropped its scheduled showing of a documentary film about Qin Shihuang, the Chinese Emperor who built the Great Wall 2,000 years ago, because of the recent violence in China.

title: As Alternative Fuel, Methanol Is Not Yet a Cure-All
description: To the Editor:

title: Better Investor Information On Municipal Bonds Sought
description: The Public Securities Association is exploring ways to provide more information to investors on prices in the $760 billion municipal bond market.

title: Abandon Rent Controls, and Turn New York Into Yuppie City
description: To the Editor:

title: Recent Findings on Light Could Be a Boon to Sleep
description: The human body clock, which regulates sleep and other activities, can be reset simply and quickly by exposure to light, new research has found.

title: Teachers' Union Backs Dinkins's Mayoral Bid
description: The United Federation of Teachers, endorsing its first mayoral candidate since 1977, threw its support yesterday behind Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Hubert Graf Forms Agency
description: An important player in the recent tumult at Doyle Graf Raj has moved on to a new agency. Hubert Graf, who resigned as chairman two weeks ago after three colleagues announced a plan to buy the agency from its owner, said yesterday that he had opened a new agency with offices in New York and Dusseldorf, West Germany.

title: Trade Floor Shifts Seen
description: The trading floor for securities may eventually be replaced by a computer and screen, David S. Ruder, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today.

title: 4 Boeing Orders Put at $400 Million
description: The Boeing Company said it had received orders for four of its aircraft from Lufthansa German Airlines and Maersk Air of Denmark in deals valued at a total of around $400 million.

title: Soweto Students Recall '76 Uprising
description: In the gravel schoolyard at Lamula Jubilee High School, several hundred students congregated outside one of their classrooms, which like all the others had no glass in the windows, no chairs inside, no working light fixtures and only a few desks haphazardly scattered around.

title: Cuba Arrests Top General on Corruption Charges
description: Cuba has arrested a top army general on corruption charges. American officials and other experts on Cuba said today that the action strongly suggested dissension at the highest levels of the Cuban armed forces.

title: Long Island Facing Inquiries on H.U.D.
description: The Nassau County prosecutor and H.U.D. officials are investigating possible criminal misuse of funds in a program for storefront rehabilitation in Hempstead.

title: Excerpts From Opinions on Scope of Rights Act
description: Following are excerpts from the majority and dissenting opinions in Patterson v. McLean Credit Union, in which the Supreme Court today interpreted the scope of the Civil Rights Act of 1866. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote the majority opinion. Opinions dissenting in part were filed by Justices William J. Brennan Jr. and John Paul Stevens. FROM THE OPINION By Justice Kennedy

title: 'Stampede' Of Selling Hits Dollar
description: In a wave of what some traders called panic selling, the dollar plunged yesterday, closing below 2 marks and 146 yen. The selling continued in Tokyo early today. The dollar fell 6 pfennigs against the mark and 6 yen from its highs yesterday in New York. The dollar had jumped sharply in Asia and Europe before the selloff in New York, demonstrating how volatile the foreign exchange market has become.

title: 'Gullible Enough To Believe'
description: Not long after Jack Nicklaus arrived here for the United States Open, he noticed himself swinging a golf club on a television screen in the locker room at the Oak Hill Country Club. ''What's that?'' he asked. ''It's a tape,'' a teen-age locker-room attendant said, ''of the old P.G.A. Tournament they had here.''

title: Review/Music; From Polyphony to Chordal Mass
description: The Florilegium Chamber Choir, conducted by Jo Ann Rice, gave premieres of three works on its Tuesday evening program at Merkin Concert Hall, all couched in a conservative, easily accessible language, but each in a distinct style.

title: Use of Grants From H.U.D. Is Investigated in Hempstead
description: The Nassau County District Attorney and the Department of Housing and Urban Development's Office of Inspector General are each investigating possible criminal misuse of H.U.D. funds in the Town of Hempstead.

title: Our Towns; Mutant Algae: Has the River Been Fertilized?
