description: William P. T. Hill, martini in hand, cut the throttle on his Mako 20 as it swept up the Mystic River. ''There it is - there's some mung,'' he said, turning the boat's bow toward a small cove. ''That's nothing compared to what it was a few weeks ago. It was much, much thicker, much, much greener.''

title: A Plea to the High Court for a Clarification
description: From a Supreme Court brief filed earlier this month by the Solicitor General's office, asking the Court to grant review in a case called W. S. Kirkpatrick & Co. v. Environmental Tectonics Corp. The case presents the question of whether Federal courts can examine whether a foreign country's action was improperly motivated by a bribe.

title: Auctions
description: Leonardo Designs

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Gerber Plan For Infant Formula
description: THE Gerber Products Company, the nation's leading baby food manufacturer, said yesterday that it would re-enter the $1.6 billion infant-formula market in September in a joint venture with the Bristol-Myers Company.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * James Vail has been named senior vice president and group media director of Ally & Gargano.

title: In Hungary, a Prophet Honored
description: A resonant rite occurs in Hungary today when the remains of Imre Nagy and other Communist reformers are moved from a potter's field to the dignity of marked graves. The commemoration is unofficial, but work is expected to cease in Budapest as church bells peal in a ceremony on national television. Thus Hungary will rebury a hero who was reviled and hanged as a traitor on June 16, 1958.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 In a trial of Chinese demonstrators, three young men were sentenced to death for their role in a protest in Shanghai, signalingan even harsher policy than expected. Page A1

title: From Apple to Sun, And Now Back Again
description: In an unusual case of musical chairs in Silicon Valley, Joseph A. Graziano, chief financial officer at Sun Microsystems Inc., has left to take the same job at its rival, Apple Computer Inc.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Study Predicts Oil Price Rise
description: Oil prices are likely to remain below $20 a barrel for a few years, but growing worldwide energy consumption will push them to about $24 a barrel by the mid-1990's, according to a report issued yesterday by Conoco Inc.

title: Jefferies' Hit in 12th Lifts Mets Over Cubs
description: The Mets pulled one of the neatest tricks of an otherwise murky season and an absolutely murky evening last night in Shea Stadium: They waited 91 minutes through two rain delays, rallied for one run in the eighth inning and two more with two out in the ninth to tie the Chicago Cubs, and then rallied one more time in the 12th to beat them, 4-3.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the use of genetic analysis for identification misstated experts' views on its value. They say many criminal cases may be reopened because of questionable test results in the Bronx and elsewhere.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the return of an opposition figure to Nicaragua misidentified him. He is Alfredo Cesar.

title: Thornburgh Orders Inquiries Into All Local H.U.D. Offices
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh ordered Federal prosecutors around the country today to investigate all local offices of the Department of Housing and Urban Development for possible fraud and embezzlement.

title: Restaurants
description: Returning to Le Perigord after an absence of several years is like tuning in a late movie you had nearly forgotten and enjoying it so much you sit up until 3 A.M. They don't make loopy Cary Grant romances anymore, nor do they make luxury French restaurants that are as sincere and uncalculating as this one.

title: Which Party, Which Hampton
description: You can always - well, almost always - determine which Hampton is which by the parties and party invitations. East Hampton-Bridgehampton guests are neatly dressed, laid-back, sand-in-the-loafers types. Guests at Southampton soirees are apt to sport blazers and neckties and pad about the premises in velvet slippers (insignia, no sand).

title: Park Victim Is Making Big Gains, Doctors Say
description: The jogger who was raped and beaten in Central Park this spring has made significant gains in her rehabilitation and may be ready to leave the Gaylord Hospital here - and perhaps even live independently - in two to four months, her doctors said today.

title: CONGRESS HOPEFUL QUITS OVER REMARK
description: Just two days after opening his race for the seat left vacant by the death of Representative Claude Pepper, the leading Democratic candidate withdrew today, saying that comments by the Republican national chairman had made it impossible for him to run without appearing to attack the large Cuban-American population here.

title: Fuss Over Fishing License May Do In the Irish Leader
description: If Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey fails to win the majority he sought in today's general election - the latest polls indicate he will fall short when the votes are counted on Friday - the fishing license may be what does him in.

title: An Illegal Landfill Is Gone, But Whiffs of Anger Linger
description: More than two years have passed since a putrid smell began wafting here. ''Rotten eggs,'' Katherine Derbyshire, a waitress at the coffee shop, remembers. ''It was out of this world.''

title: Findings Point to Previously Unseen Space Bodies
description: New telescopic observations have produced substantial evidence for the existence of theorized celestial objects called brown dwarfs that are intermediate between a planet and a star.

title: Pact May Improve Cable TV Service
description: After 15 years of waiting, the unwired blocks of Harlem and the Lower East Side would get cable television and, after four rings, cable customers in Manhattan would get their telephone calls answered, under an agreement approved yesterday by the New York City Board of Estimate.

title: Public Beaches, Private Access
description: Although many miles of sandy, lifeguard-attended beaches in the Hamptons are open to everyone, beach parking is not.

title: Car Makers and Dealers at Odds
description: Auto makers and car dealers are headed for a showdown. After dismal spring sales, showrooms nationwide are bulging with unsold vehicles. But the big auto makers, fearful of losing market share, are sticking for the most part to robust production schedules for 1990 models, which will start rolling off assembly lines this summer.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Le Madri is an insouciantly chic new Italian restaurant created by Pino Luongo, an original partner in Il Cantinori on East 10th Street and the owner of Sapore di Mare in Wainscott, L.I. It is financed by the owners of Barneys New York, the nearby department store. Since opening this month it has received more press than a linen suit in August, and reservations have been tight. The name (The Mothers) derives from Mr. Luongo's irresistible notion of importing revolving trios of Italian mamas to his kitchen to stir up authentic regional fare.

title: Court Upholds Use of Rights Law But Limits How It Can Be Applied
description: A unanimous Supreme Court refused today to overturn a major civil rights precedent that gave minorities the right to use a Reconstruction-era law to sue for private acts of racial discrimination.

title: Chief Financial Officer Named at RJR Nabisco
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. added a chief financial officer to its new management team yesterday. He is Karl Von der Heyden, who comes from the H. J. Heinz Company in Pittsburgh, where he held a similar post.

title: F.D.A. Approves Drug That Fights Leading Killer of AIDS Patients
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved a drug that helps prevent a type of pneumonia that is the leading cause of death among AIDS patients.

title: Playing Shylock as He Should Be Played
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Circus
description: A two-day festival of free music, dance and poetry readings is planned this weekend in Tompkins Square Park, Avenue A at Seventh Street. The festival, called the Art Circus, is sponsored by the Tompkins Square Arts Festival. Among the music ensembles set to appear are the Spirit Ensemble, the Valerie Naranjo Marimba Ensemble and the Soldier String Quartet. The Mark Dendy Dancers, the Maya Milenovic Dancers and Pink Inc. will perform, and some 50 poets will read from their works, among them Pedro Pietri, Miguel Algarin, Ira Unger, Taylor Mead and Shelley Miller. Hours are tomorrow and Sunday 1 to 7 P.M. Rain date: next weekend.

title: INSIDE
description: Discoveries in Space Astronomers have found substantial evidence of the existence of brown dwarfs, peviously unseen celestial objects that could resolve mysteries about the cosmos. Page D16. Paris Rewards Poland France has offered a package of debt relief to Poland, including $100 million in new bank loans. It is the first Western aid since 1981. Page A3. Complaints Audited Auditors studying a sampling of corruption allegations made to the New York City Board of Education last year found that half showed no evidence of being investigated. Page B1. Plan for New York Schools The Koch administration has proposed an innovative plan to raise an additional $450 million over the next five years for schools. Page B1.

title: Congress Begins Work on Programs for Poor Children
description: Congress moved on two fronts today to focus on the needs of children, an issue that moved to center stage in the Presidential and Congressional campaigns last year.

title: Suffer, Little Children
description: All the babies are dying. This is the AIDS ward for babies, and they are all dying.

title: Review/Film; Citywide Bad Temper: Better Call In Ghostbusters!
description: It is the not wildly improbable premise of ''Ghostbusters II'' that Manhattan, in the words of one of the title characters, ''is about to blow, like a frog on a hot plate.''

title: 3 Heads of Waste Companies Are Seized in Dumping on S.I.
description: Three owners of waste-disposal companies were arrested yesterday on charges that they illegally dumped medical waste, asbestos and other hazardous materials in a landfill on Staten Island and then concealed the debris by mixing and covering it with dirt and granite and other ''clean'' waste.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly SPECIAL COMMITTEE AGAINST APARTHEID - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. DAY OF SOLIDARITY COMMITTEE ON PEACEFUL USES OF OUTER SPACE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM GOVERNING COUNCIL - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: All About Hal Prince
description: Harold Prince will discuss his career as a producer and director with the theater critic Edwin Wilson on Thursday at 6 P.M. in the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center. The talk is part of an exhibition at the library entitled ''Audacious Stages: The Musical Theater of Harold Prince,'' on view through Sept. 2, which that surveys Mr. Prince's career from ''The Pajama Game'' in 1954 to ''Don Giovanni,'' which opens next month at the New York City Opera. Tickets are free, first come first served. Information: 870-1670.

title: Underground Atlanta Opens Despite Jeers
description: Hecklers and a last-minute lawsuit failed today to stop the opening of Underground Atlanta, a $142 million complex of shops, restaurants and clubs intended to lure people back to downtown Atlanta.

title:
THE LAW;
Lawyers Find New Ways to Sue Other Lawyers
description: LEAD: Lawyers, creators of new ways to sue doctors, accountants and other professionals, have now devised two novel ways to pursue one another.

title: Who'll Stop the Rain?
description: Acid rain is reported by scientific observers to have turned the top of Camel's Hump, this state's highest mountain, into a ''moonscape.'' On a recent fishing trip to heavily forested Quebec, even an unscientific observer saw enough blighted trees to raise the hackles on his neck.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think we have come out of a period of cold war, even if there are still some chills and drafts.

title: Saints Cut Clark; Grievance Filed
description: Bruce Clark, a former Pro Bowl defensive end, was waived today by the New Orleans Saints, then filed a grievance with the National Football League Players Association protesting his release.

title: Awaiting Ralph In East Hampton
description: In East Hampton, this is the year of the horse. Or to be more precise, the polo pony.

title: 4 ISRAELI SOLDIERS JAILED IN SLAYING
description: A military court in southern Israel handed down sentences of six to nine months today against four Israeli soldiers convicted last month of brutality toward a detained Palestinian who died in army custody.

title: Paramount Is Willing To Negotiate Time Bid
description: Martin S. Davis, the chairman and chief executive of Paramount Communications Inc., said yesterday that he was ready to be persuaded to increase his offer for Time Inc.

title:
Market Place;
Investor Focus: 'Witching Hour'
description: LEAD: WALL STREET is bracing for a wild session today, which marks another ''triple witching hour,'' when many important stock index futures, index options and individual stock options expire.

title: 3 CHINESE WORKERS SENTENCED TO DIE FOR PROTEST ROLE
description: In the first trial of Chinese pro-democracy demonstrators since the military crackdown 11 days ago, the Government today sentenced three young men to death for their role in a violent protest in Shanghai.

title: Heber Ladner, Mississippi Official, 86
description: Heber Ladner, who in 32 years as Mississippi's Secretary of State was a central figure in suits by blacks to revise election and school laws, died of heart disease Wednesday at Mississippi Baptist Medical Center. He was 86 years old.

title: KEY RATES
Reviews/Art; Bruce Show as a Bicentennial Tribute to France
description: As effectively as many a more elaborate exhibition, this show is a tribute to France in the bicentennial year of the French Revolution. Everything in it was made in France, not long before 1914, and the show as a whole speaks for a country still unravaged. The soft, feathery movement of the brush in Patrick Henry Bruce's summer landscape of around 1909 dips down deep into space and comes up with a little town snoozing in the sun. Having done that, the same unhurrying movement pulls the deep blue purple-speckled water almost vertically toward us. As when Cezanne painted the bay at L'Estaque, the horizon line thus formed is just an inch or two short of the top of the canvas.

title: Leftist Gains Expected As Europe Vote Opens
description: Socialist and environmentalist parties were expected to register gains as voting started today for the European Parliament, an institution that remains little known to most Western Europeans even though it has considerably increased its legislative clout.

title: Koop, Parting, Reviews A Contentious Tenure
description: Dr. C. Everett Koop offered his valedictory today after eight years as Surgeon General of the United States, describing how he transformed an ''emasculated'' public office with little official authority into a bully pulpit for health.

title: B.P. Plans to Sell Its Coal Division
description: The British Petroleum Company, one of the world's largest energy companies, said it would sell its coal mining division to concentrate on its core business of oil and chemicals. The sale of the Cleveland-based BP Coal could yield from $450 million to $600 million, stock analysts said. The sale fits in with B.P.'s restructuring and with the general industry trend toward jettisoning non-oil businesses acquired during the cash-rich days of the late 1970's.

title: Broad Retreat Sends Dow Down 28.36
description: Stock prices retreated broadly and steeply yesterday in moderately higher volume.

title: Pentagon Offers Plan to Help Smooth Arms Talks
description: The Joint Chiefs of Staff have suggested a new approach for counting air-launched cruise missiles that could help close the gap between Washington and Moscow on the issue, Administration officials said today.

title: Victor French, 54, Actor on TV
description: Victor French, an actor and director who played leading roles in the television series ''Highway to Heaven,'' ''Little House on the Prairie'' and ''Gunsmoke,'' died of lung cancer on Thursday at Sherman Oaks Community Hospital. He was 54 years old.

title: U.S. Computer Group Forms
description: Executives of several American computer manufacturers met in Washington yesterday to discuss the formation of a new policy group intended to enhance the industry's competitiveness.

title: British Soldier Shot to Death In Ulster in Error, Police Say
description: A 21-year-old British soldier was shot to death today, apparently by a fellow soldier who was firing at a motorist who tried to run one of the soldiers down, the police said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Hoechst Celanese Corp., Somerville, N.J., a chemical manufacturer, named Herbert Buergermeister vice president of engineering and manufacturing technology.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: THE BUDGET
description: Representative Dan Rostenkowski is the champion horse-trader in Congress.

title: Janis Ian Making a Musical Comeback Once More
description: Janis Ian still remembers the moment in 1973 when the opening lines of her signature song, ''At Seventeen,'' were delivered to her.

title: Reviews/Art; Taking a Look or Two Back in the Hamptons
description: It being the middle of June, the annual migration of the New York art world to the eastern end of Long Island has not yet begun in earnest. There's still a certain freshness to the charmingly redundant greeting ''Are you out here?'' as people try to figure out if you own, rent or are merely visiting for the weekend. And the frenzied socializing of August is weeks away.

title: Intruder Fatally Stabs a Woman In Sex Attack on Upper East Side
description: A pregnant woman was fatally stabbed in her Upper East Side apartment Wednesday afternoon, and the police said her attacker may have been responsible for a similar stabbing on Sunday.

title: McCaw Files Financing Plan
description: In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. disclosed today that it had received commitments for about $4.5 billion in financing for its cash tender offer to acquire the Lin Broadcasting Corporation.

title: Koch Edges Out Rivals in Campaign Gifts
description: Shut off from big contributors by the new city campaign-finance law, Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday reported campaign contributions just slightly higher than several opponents and considerably less than he had raised at this time in the last mayoral election.

title: Books of The Times; From a Rebel to a Pen of Bolshevism
description: Gorky By Henri Troyat Translated by Lowell Bair. Illustrated. 216 pages. Crown Publishers. $19.95.

title: E. L. Palmieri, Federal Judge, Is Dead at 82
description: Edmund L. Palmieri, who served as a Federal District Court judge for 35 years, died of cancer of the pancreas and liver yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title: U.S. and Japan Report a Stalemate on Trade-Talk Format
description: Senior Japanese and American economic officials said today that they had ended two days of ''intensive'' discussions but were unable to agree on a format for new trade negotiations sought by President Bush.

title: Karachi Journal; City of Street Waifs and a Combat-Ready Campus
description: Rani was barely 11 when she ran away to Karachi, hundreds of miles from her Punjabi home, along with her 15-year-old sister, Paras, and their cousin Azira, who was 10. Beaten by her stepfather, Rani said she got on a train, dodging conductors, because her mother had left home that way, and she wanted to find her.

title: Suffolk Checks for Fraud in U.S. Housing Program
description: The Suffolk County District Attorney is investigating allegations of fraud in a Department of Housing and Urban Development program in the Town of Brookhaven, L.I.

title: A GORBACHEV HINT FOR BERLIN WALL
description: Wrapping up a triumphant visit to West Germany, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that the Berlin wall was not necessarily permanent, but would be taken down only when conditions that created it fell away.

title: On Stage
description: 90 Minutes of Stoppard

title: Review/Film; Two Star-Crossed Lovers Cross Paths (and Swords)
description: ''I was 13 when I met Kay. She was 5.'' Thus starts one of the rambling, intensely boring monologues that help to make ''Ice House,'' which is really a two-character, one-set love story, seem longer and more verbose than ''Strange Interlude.''

title: Zayre Completes Its Revamping
description: The Zayre Corporation, one of the nation's leading discount retailers, completed a complex restructuring that included the spinoff and repurchase of subsidiaries and a special cash dividend. Under the previously announced plan, Zayre merged with its 83 percent owned subsidiary, the TJX Companies. consisting of the clothing chain T.J. Maxx, Hit or Miss apparel shops and Chadwick's of Boston, a catalogue operator. Zayre plans to change its name to the TJX Companies at its annual meeting next Tuesday.

title: Beijing Memo; Foreigners Once Again Find The Chinese Wary of Contact
description: Some years ago foreign speakers of Chinese complained that when they came to live in this country their language skills evaporated because they so rarely found any Chinese daring enough to talk to them.

title: Stars Pull Out in Houston
description: Jackie Joyner-Kersee and Butch Reynolds led a group of stars in withdrawing from the USA/Mobil outdoor championships today.

title: Sears Acts To Stimulate Its Sales
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company has introduced a $6 million, one-month give-away promotion, hoping to sustain interest in the new pricing policy it began three months ago, when it cut prices on 50,000 items.

title: Dunkin' Donuts Hostile Target
description: Two Canadian companies, the Unicorp Canada Corporation and Cara Operations Ltd., began a hostile $305.3 million tender offer today for Dunkin' Donuts Inc. The $43-a-share offer replaces a $298.2 million bid rejected by Dunkin' Donuts last month. Richard Hart, Dunkin'

title: About Real Estate; Lower-Cost Condos Set for Greenwich
description: For only $110,000 a unit, a pilot group of seven families will soon be buying new two-bedroom duplex condominiums in Greenwich, Conn., where the median price for a house in 1988 was $562,000, according to its Multiple Listing Service.

title: Newspaper Stock Issue
description: Central Newspapers Inc., which owns newspapers in Indiana and Arizona, said Wednesday that it planned to make its first public stock offering. The company said it would register some of its class A, or nonvoting, common stock for sale. Central Newspapers publishes eight papers in Indiana and Arizona, including The Arizona Republic, The Phoenix Gazette, The Indianapolis Star and The Indianapolis News. Newspaper executives said the amount of stock to be sold and the sale price had not been determined.

title: Tribute to a Guitarist
description: Jose Salazar, a guitarist and composer, is to perform the world premiere of his ''Homenaje a Pujol'' at Weill Recital Hall tonight at 8. The work is a tribute to the Spanish guitarist Emilio Pujol, who was one of Mr. Salazar's teachers. Mr. Pujol, who died in 1980, had been a student of the turn-of-the-century guitarist Francisco Tarrega and was considered by many guitarists to be the last link with the pre-Segovia guitar tradition in Spain. Music by Tarrega and Pujol is also on the program, as are transcriptions of works by Bach, Beethoven and Albeniz and flamenco works by Sabicas. Tickets are $8 to $10. Information: 247-7800.

title: Houshold to sell Its Thermos Unit
description: Household International Inc. announced today it was selling the Thermos Company to Nippon Sanso K.K., a large manufacturer of industrial gas that is diversifying into consumer products, for $134 million.

title: Shearson To Sell Unit
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell the Lehman Management Company, one of its investment management subsidiaries, to a management-led group for $100 million.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 467 money market mutual funds increased by $2.8 billion, to $317.26 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 141 institutional funds increased by $1.09 billion, to $80.91 billion. The assets of the 231 general-purpose funds were up by $562.60 million, to $102.15 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.15 billion, to $134.19 billion, the institute said.

title: Possible Heir for the Top Job Appointed by Ohio Mattress
description: The Ohio Mattress Company, one of the world's largest makers of bedding, said yesterday that Malcolm Candlish, former chief executive of the Samsonite Corporation, had been named president and chief operating officer.

title: Staff Changes At Miniscribe
description: The Miniscribe Corporation, a troubled maker of hard disk drives, said today that several officers had resigned and that other officers and employees had been dismissed.

title: Stanley Gray, 61, Dies; Ex-Retailing Executive
description: Stanley F. Gray, former president of the retail-store division of Warnaco Inc., died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 61 years old.

title: Honor Tracy, Travel Writer, Is Dead at 75
description: Honor Tracy, a travel writer, columnist and novelist who satirized Irish and English society, died Tuesday in a nursing home in Oxford, England. She was 75 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the Consumer Electronics Show in Chicago misidentified the headquarters city of Rabbit Systems Inc. It is Santa Monica, Calif., not New York.

title: Did Czech Star Defect?
description: Robert Holik, an 18-year-old left wing with the Czechoslovakia national hockey team, may have defected to the United States with the hope of joining the Minnesota North Stars of the N.H.L., according to a report yesterday in The Toronto Star. The paper quoted an unidentified N.H.L. executive who is attending the league meetings in Minneapolis as saying: ''The question of the day is: Where is Robert Holik? If he's in North America, as is rumored, it could throw the draft upside down.'' The entry draft will conclude the league meetings tomorrow.

title: Economic Scene; Greenspan's View On a Soft Landing
description: IS the United States economy, with Alan Greenspan of the Federal Reserve at the controls, coming in for a soft landing?

title: Yount Out With Injury
description: Robin Yount will be lost to the Milwaukee Brewers indefinitely because of a knee injury he suffered Wednesday night, the team said yesterday. In the game against the Toronto Blue Jays, Yount crashed into the center-field wall in the fourth inning while attempting to catch a ball hit by Manny Lee that went for a triple. Although he remained in the game for two more innings, Yount left suffering from a bruised left knee and kneecap, the club said. He later had fluid removed from the knee.

title: Ways to Get There: Plain and Fancy
description: Driving to the Hamptons on a summer weekend can be recommended only to the patient, the stubborn or those with a lot to transport, since a trip that takes about two hours from Manhattan on weekdays at nonrush hours can all too easily turn into a grueling, stamina-testing half-day ordeal. Indeed, the Long Island Expressway and Route 27, the two-lane road from Hampton Bays to Montauk, are choked with eastbound traffic on Friday afternoons and westbound on Sunday nights and Monday mornings.

title: Burstyn to Replace Collins in 'Valentine'
description: Ellen Burstyn has been signed to replace Pauline Collins in ''Shirley Valentine,'' the play's producers announced yesterday.

title: Reclaim Housing From the Drug Lords
description: Recent reports about Edenwald Houses, a Bronx public housing project, provide a frightening illustration of cocaine's power to destroy life even for those who don't touch it. They also provide a powerful argument for Mayor Edward Koch's proposal to strengthen the undermanned housing police.

title: Problems in Engines Result in Grounding Of Boeing Jetliners
description: Most of the world's 46 Boeing 737-400 jetliners have been grounded in recent days after an engine type that has become increasingly suspect failed twice in the last week.

title: Pop/Jazz; Music and Comedy After Dark
description: Nightlife? After a day at the beach, the golf course, the antiques circuit, the garden or the sailboat, who can stay awake past 9 o'clock? Besides, aren't crowds, noise and smoke-filled rooms what city-dwellers go to the country to escape? From Southampton east, many people's idea of a big night out is a trip to the ice-cream parlor. But for those who get a second wind after the fish has been grilled and the pie devoured, there is life after sunset in the Hamptons. A New Danceteria

title: H.U.D. Aide Under Scrutiny Quits as Island Park Trustee
description: Geraldine McGann, a high-ranking official with the Department of Housing and Urban Development who is under investigation, resigned from the Island Park Village Board tonight, citing a new H.U.D. conflict-of-interest policy.

title: Belgian Doctor Freed By Lebanon Captors
description: A Belgian doctor held hostage in Lebanon for 13 months was freed by his kidnappers today.

title: Federal Official Sees Bid to Save Shoreham Plant
description: Asserting that the Shoreham nuclear power plant has become a symbol of the country's commitment to nuclear energy, a top Federal energy official told Long Island business leaders today that the Bush Administration would do everything in its power to prevent the plant from being dismantled.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Old Quintet, New Voices

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''CHANTICLEER,'' a one-act comic opera by Seymour Barab, presented by the Enchanted Forest Opera, 1 and 3 P.M. tomorrow, at Studio Theater 603, sixth floor, 311 West 43d Street. Admission: children, $4; the elderly, $5 and others, $6; group rates available. Reservations: 594-5113. CHILDREN'S CLAY WORKSHOP, a program to teach children children how to make clay objects and how marbles, buttons, pipes and bowls were once made out of clay, in conjunction of ''Dig In,'' an exhibition, 3 P.M. Sunday, (repeat program June 25), at the South Street Seaport Museum's Children's Center, 265 John Street. Free, with museum admission of $2 for children, $5 for adults. Reservations recommended: 669-9489. ''CINDERELLA,'' a musical version of the story, told with rod and marionette puppets, by the Papageno Puppet Theater with Susan Delery Whedon, who is to sing accompanied by recorded music during the performance, 1 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, at the West 72d Street Studio, 131 West 72d Street. For young children. Admission: $4. Reservations: 874-3297. ''ONCE UPON A MIRACLE,'' an original old-fashioned melodrama with music, performed by the Children's Company of Bronx Creative Arts for Youth, 1 P.M. Sunday, in the Gillet Auditorium, Lehman College, Gate 6 on Goulden Avenue, off Bedford Park Boulevard East, the Bronx. Free. Information: 733-3176. ''PINOCCHIO,'' a play by the Puppetworks,noon on Saturdays, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at 287 Third Avenue, at Carroll Street, in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn. Children, $4; adults, $5. Reservations required: (718) 834-1828.

title: Rates Advance as Dollar Plunges
description: Interest rates rebounded yesterday as prices of Treasury notes and bonds plunged, along with the dollar.

title: Searle to Settle Copper-7 IUD Suits
description: G. D. Searle & Company said it had agreed to settle all claims of women who said they had been victims of its Copper-7 contraceptive device represented by the Minneapolis law firm of Robins, Kaplan, Miller & Ciresi. The number of lawsuits and the amount of the settlement were not immediately disclosed. A company spokeswoman said there were still about 350 lawsuits pending.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday CIVIL-RIGHTS SACRIFICES

title: Did Heavens Finally Fall on Deng? Some See His Defeat in China Events
description: Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, used to reassure nervous foreign leaders that they need not worry about China after his passing because he had installed his own successors, several veteran analysts here recalled today.

title: King Makes It Official
description: Don King, the promoter, formally announced yesterday that Mike Tyson would defend his heavyweight title against Carl (the Truth) Williams on July 21 in Atlantic City.

title: Dr. Richard Day, 84, Ex-Pediatrics Professor
description: Dr. Richard L. Day, retired professor of pediatrics at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in Manhattan, died yesterday at his home in Westbrook, Conn. He was 84 years old.

title: Review/Ballet; Revealing New Facets Of Established Talents
description: Many of the New York City Ballet's best dancers, over the decades, owed their first success to the fact that Jerome Robbins cast them in his new works.

title: Siemens in Deal With Matsushita
description: Siemens A.G., the West German electronics giant, agreed to set up a joint component company with the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company of Japan, a move considered significant to its expansion strategy. The new venture will be part of a cooperation accord for the production and sales of passive components beginning on Oct. 1, the chief executives of the two companies said.

title: Livingston Prizes Given To 3 Young Journalists
description: Winners of the eighth annual Livingston Awards for Young Journalists were announced yesterday at the New York Public Library.

title: Charter Chairman Widens Proposals
description: The chairman of the New York City Charter Revision Commission proposed major changes yesterday in its recommendations to assure that disputed city building projects could be reviewed by the City Council and to give new weight to the views of communities and borough presidents.

title: Knicks' Green Is Taken First In N.B.A.'s Expansion Draft
description: Yesterday was a costly day for the Knicks, and several other National Basketball Association teams as well.

title: Penalties By N.A.S.D.
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers has penalized managers at the investment firm Buchanan & Company for wrongdoing in the underwriting and sale of $250 million in tax-free bonds that later defaulted.

title: Inspector General on the Firing Line
description: After more than 26 years of quietly seeking out wrongdoing in Federal housing programs, Paul A. Adams wanted to retire last January as Inspector General of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. But he stayed on to finish a major inquiry that has rocked the agency and propelled the laconic civil servant himself onto the firing line.

title: Drug Report on Cooper
description: Bert Cooper failed a drug test a few hours before he entered the ring to fight George Foreman on June 1 in Phoenix, The Arizona Republic reported yesterday, citing a source close to the Arizona Boxing Commission. The bout ended after two rounds when Cooper refused to leave his corner. Because the boxer showed no sign of injury, the boxing commission withheld payment of his $17,500 share of the purse.

title: Nature's Capricious Harvest Fells Trees Long Cherished
description: This suburb just north of the District of Columbia line is serious about its trees.

title: Dining Out Guide: To Stay or To Go
description: Not since the legendary Henri Soule unpacked his pots and pans at the Hedges Inn in East Hampton more than 30 years ago have the Hamptons attracted as many New York chefs and restaurateurs. The result? Summer dining is better than ever.

title: Tokyo Stocks Drop Again After Thursday's Sharp Fall
description: Prices fell again this morning on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, which on Thursday suffered its worst one-day loss in a year.

title: McCullers Is Unable To Put Orioles Away
description: The hit that won the game for the Baltimore Orioles tonight was little more than a soft single that floated over second base, then landed easily in the grass in shallow center field. But it sounded something like a sonic boom to the Yankees, who let one get away.

title: Cowboy Boots Under The Robe
description: Beneath the thunder of Yosemite Falls, amid the splendor of Half Dome and Sentinel Rock, presides one of the nation's most unusual Federal judges.

title: Gorbachev Expresses Regret on China Strife
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev expressed regret today over the violent culmination of the mass student protests in China. But he also defended Moscow's ''balanced'' response, asserting that the information was still vague and that the priority was to safeguard the fledgling Chinese program of change.

title: France to Give Poland New Bank Loans
description: President Francois Mitterrand has announced a package of debt relief for Poland that aides said included the first Western bank loans since sanctions were imposed in response to martial law in 1981.

title: Familiar Faces at Fore As U.S. Open Begins
description: Softened by heavy rains early this week and today's occasional showers without any wind, the Oak Hill East Course was as defenseless against the attack of superb golfers as any United States Open course has ever been. And the golfers attacked in droves, like wolves after a wounded fawn.

title: Abandon Rent Controls, and Turn New York Into Yuppie City; Benefits of Conversion
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; WCRS Reports Talks With Eurocom Agency
description: A senior WCRS Group official refused to say yesterday whether the British marketing company was the target of a takeover bid by Eurocom, but said it was holding discussions with the French agency ''to look at various ways to accelerate the joint goals we set 18 months ago.''

title: Factory Operating Rate Eased Slightly in May
description: The operating rate for the nation's factories eased last month, and economists said the slower pace should help to cool inflationary pressures.

title: The Hamptons: Luxury, Calm And Voluptuousness by the Sea
description: IN a free-association test, given the clue ''Hamptons,'' most people would probably answer ''beach.'' A likely second would be ''traffic.'' But there is a whole world at the eastern tip of Long Island that is neither wide, sprawling beach nor the justly hated Long Island Expressway, a world set in one of the most beautiful, if fragile, natural landscapes in the Eastern United States.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Anheuser-Busch Cos., St. Louis, the giant brewer, accepted 12.5 million shares, of 13,491,300 shares tendered, at $44 a share under its Dutch auction tender offer.

title: Embarking on the Road to Barcelona
description: Mike Conley and Dawn Sowell are at opposite ends of the track striding toward the same goal here at the USA/Mobil outdoor championships.

title: Milken Quits Drexel and Will Open a Firm
description: Michael R. Milken resigned as head of the high-yield ''junk bond'' division of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. yesterday and said he was forming his own financial consulting firm.

title: The Court, Still Haggling Over Rights
description: Last year the Supreme Court rattled the foundations of modern civil rights law when it decided to re-examine one of its strongest rulings for racial justice. That 1976 decision held that Congress had the intent and the power in 1866 to outlaw private acts of discrimination in fields like housing, private schools and jobs. Now the Court, having re-examined, holds that the 1976 decision, in a case called Runyon v. McCrary, has proved workable, clear and harmonious ''with the prevailing sense of justice in this country.''

title: Review/Art; Franz West, With Whom Neatness Doesn't Count
description: Like all contemporary Austrian artists, it seems, Franz West is messy. His jagged and lumpy papier-mache sculptures, his welded scrap-metal chairs strewn with newspapers and his bumpy, plaster-smeared screens have a transient, throwaway quality to them. Chris Dercon, a curator of ''Possibility/Franz West,'' at the P.S. 1 Museum, describes these works as ''homeopathic art.'' This show, organized with Alanna Heiss, the director of P.S. 1, was, he says, intended to suggest alternatives to ''American art, which right now is much too hygienic.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING Zanoli Wins Jersey Race: After racing for four hours through the central New Jersey countryside, Michael Zanoli of the Netherlands won a mass sprint yesterday to capture the first CoreStates New Jersey National Bank Cycling Classic in Freehold. Zanoli, 21 years old, representing the Coors Light/ADR team, was timed in 4 hours 1 minute 57 seconds for the 110-mile event, an average speed of 27 miles an hour. Zanoli, a former world junior champion and a 1988 Olympian, won $1,500. Graeme Miller of New Zealand placed second in the field of 140 men and Roberto Pellonci of Italy was third. Bruyneel Takes 2d Stage: Johan Bruyneel of Belgium, won the second stage in the Tour of Switzerland yesterday, a 123-mile ride to Lausanne featuring two Alpine passes. Beat Breu, a 31-year-old Swiss who won the tour in 1981, captured the overall leader's yellow jersey from Eric Vanderaerden of Belgium in the section from Bern, the Swiss capital, to Lausanne. Bruyneel finished in 5 hours 1 minute 13 seconds, outsprinting Stephan Joho of Switzerland by 7 seconds at the finish.(AP) GOLF Three Share Lead in English Open: Sam Torrance of Scotland, reeled off five successive birdies at the scene of his greatest triumph to take a share of the first-round lead in the $400,000 English Open yesterday in Sutton Coldfield. Tied with Torrance at six-under-par 66 were Craig Parry of Australia and Steen Tinning of Denmark. One shot behind was Jeff Hawkes of South Africa. Mark Mouland of Wales, Jose Davila of Spain and Keith Waters of England were tied at four-under 68.(AP)

title: At the Movies
description: Up on Chestnut Hill

title: Lehman Wingding in Lehman Wing
description: One of the country's great clans gathered last night in the Lehman wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, although the reunion, the family's first, might have been held at Lehman College or the Children's Zoo in Central Park or many other spots around New York City where plaques bear the Lehman name.

title: Classic Cardozo ruling in a negligence case of the 20's is still reverberating in an 80's appeal
description: In his aphoristic, involuted opinions, Judge Benjamin N. Cardozo depicted the same bygone New York, of trolleys and els, ''Broad-way'' and Coney Island, that John Sloan captured on canvas and Rodgers and Hart set to song.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Monteith and Rand

title: Surgeon Married To Debra H. Klein
description: Debra Helen Klein, the daughter of MaryAnn Klein of New York and Ira Klein of Yardley, Pa., was married last evening at the East River Yacht Club in New York to Dr. Todd Kenneth Rosengart, a son of Barbara Bard of Old Westbury, L.I., and North Miami Beach, Fla., and the late Dr. Martin Rosengart. Rabbi Daniel Mehlman officiated.

title: BUSH SAVINGS PLAN IS PASSED BY HOUSE
description: After handing President Bush a decisive victory on an important provision of his savings and loan bailout proposal, the House late tonight passed the entire rescue plan on a vote of 320 to 97.

title: Posner Restricted In DWG Share Use
description: Despite the lifting of a temporary restraining order that enjoined Victor Posner from voting his almost 9.3 million shares of common stock in the DWG Corporation, the Florida-based investor is still restricted in his ability to use his shares, according to Granada Investments Inc., which brought the litigation. Under the order of the United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio, Mr. Posner may not vote, sell or pledge his 46.5 percent stake in DWG without providing 10 days' notice to Granada. The court also said it would set a hearing in mid-July on a preliminary injunction.

title: Integrated Resources to Default
description: Integrated Resources Inc., which built its fortunes on tax shelters and tried to expand into a financial services giant, said yesterday that it would default on its bonds and commercial paper. About $1.5 billion in such debt is outstanding.

title: Review/Pop; Diana Ross Flirts With a Willing Audience
description: As Diana Ross swept down an aisle of Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday evening to tumultuous adulation, one was reminded that no pop diva wallows in the role of folk goddess more delightedly than this singer, who will celebrate her 25th anniversary of stardom next month.

title: Lavery a City Ballet Aide
description: The New York City Ballet has announced that Sean Lavery, a principal dancer with the company, has been named assistant to the directors, and will aid Peter Martins, who is the company's co-director with Jerome Robbins.

title: Argentine Transition July 8
description: President Raul Alfonsin will hand over power to President-elect Carlos Saul Menem on July 8, it was announced today. Mr. Alfonsin's term was to expire Dec. 10, but he said Monday he would resign sooner to give Mr. Menem's government a chance to deal with the country's deepening economic crisis.

title: Pepperell Job Rise
description: West Point-Pepperell will put plants in Alabama, Georgia and Texas on seven-day workweeks in an expansion that is expected to create 330 new jobs. The textile company also plans to buy $40 million in new equipment for its bed products group, Pepperell's parent company, Chicago-based Farley Inc., announced.

title: As Alternative Fuel, Methanol Is Not Yet a Cure-All; Federal Incentives
description: To the Editor:

title: The Republicans Can't Back Off Now
description: LEAD: A memo containing an unfair and nasty inference was the top political story in Washington last week. The memo, written by a Republican Party official, intimated that Tom Foley, the new Speaker of the House, was homosexual. Democrats then seized upon it as a vehicle for attacking Republican tactics.

title: Wheelabrator In Merger Move
description: Wheelabrator Technologies Inc., whose operations generate electricity by burning trash, said it would merge with Wheelabrator Group Inc. to create a $1.3 billion energy and recycling company. The combined company will be named Wheelabrator Technologies Inc., according to a news release issued by Wheelabrator Group, which is Wheelabrator Technology's largest shareholder. The transaction is subject to approval of shareholders in both companies.

title: Yitzhak Yaakov Weiss; Israeli Rabbi Was 88
description: Rabbi Yitzhak Yaakov Weiss, the spiritual leader of the rigorously Orthodox Ashkenazim in Jerusalem, died on Wednesday. He was 88 years old.

title: Review/Rock; Bowie and Band, Without Disguises
description: For most of his career, David Bowie has surrounded himself and his songs in theatrical trappings, adopting images from space alien to rock idol and letting ironies pile up. Now, at least for the moment, he has recast himself as a rocker, just a singer with a guitar-driven band called Tin Machine.

title: Nominee Denies an Iran-Contra Link
description: Facing intense questioning from the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, President Bush's nominee as Ambassador to South Korea declared today that he had told the truth about his role in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Council in Palm Beach Drops Plans for Bridge Surveillance
description: The Town Council has decided against putting surveillance cameras on the bridges into this island community after the Police Chief questioned whether they would help fight crime.

title: Let Schools Choose 'Channel One'
description: Focusing a nationwide debate, New York's Board of Regents today considers whether to allow Whittle Communications's ''Channel One,'' a commercially sponsored video news program, to be shown in public schools. Though the idea of commercial sponsorship troubles some educators, many schools are likely to find the Whittle deal attractive. State officials would be wise not to stand in their way.

title: Chase Planning An Italy Fund
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation and Gemina S.p.A., an Italian investment company, yesterday announced an agreement to create a $50 million to $100 million fund to make equity investments in leveraged buyouts and other opportunities in Italy.

title: In Spirit of Glasnost, a Half-Toast to Perestroika
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Trade Gap Narrows Sharply; 2d Straight Month of Improvement
description: A decline in imports of cars and other manufactured goods, combined with a new record in exports, produced a sharply lower trade deficit in April, the Government reported today.

title: Technology Export Arrest
description: The Commerce Department said on Wednesday that a Taiwanese national had been charged with trying to export illegally an American computer system whose export is restricted for national security reasons.

title: Sator Is Dismissed As Coach of Sabres
description: Ted Sator, who coached the Buffalo Sabres to two third-place finishes but was unable to get the team past the first round of the playoffs, was dismissed yesterday.

title: Three U.S. Soldiers Are Killed In Copter Crash in Panama
description: An American military helicopter crashed today near the Panama Canal, killing three American soldiers, a United States Embassy spokesman said.

title: Mitchell B. Stock, 97, Connecticut Executive
description: Mitchell B. Stock, a retired owner of a sewage disposal company, died Tuesday at Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital. He was 97 years old and lived in Fairfield, Conn.

title: Article 648989 -- No Title
description: The Koch administration has proposed an innovative plan to raise an additional $450 million over the next five years for New York City's deteriorated school system by revising the use of surplus funds from the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: A Secret Shop That Everyone Knows
description: ''It still amuses me that a lot of people think of my shop as their secret little place,'' said Eliza Werner of Sage Street Antiques, an off-the-beaten track (if only geographically) shop in Sag Harbor. ''They say they won't tell anybody about it.'' They don't have to. Locals and weekenders, who include art directors, models, photographers and assorted trend-setters and celebrities, have made the shop their premier stop in the Hamptons. ''Peter Jennings, Anne Jackson, Paul Davis, Martha Stewart and Mary Emmerling are some of the ones I can think of right now,'' Ms. Werner said this week.

title: Alfred G. Katzin, U.N. Ex-Official, 83
description: Col. Alfred G. Katzin, a former Under Secretary General of the United Nations, died on May 15 at his home in Weybridge, England, after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

Hyde, Republican of Illinois, to relax the capital requirements called for by President Bush's savings and loan bailout proposal. A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the Hyde measure. Voting ''yes'' were 38 Democrats and 56 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 212 Democrats and 114 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. ''Present'' denotes those present during the vote who did not vote ''yes'' or ''no.'' There is one vacancy in the 435-member House. title: Hospital Bonds For Philadelphia
description: The Hospitals and Higher Education Facilities Authority of Philadelphia is selling $128.8 million of tax-exempt hospital revenue bonds for the Albert Einstein Medical Center, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: In Spirit of Glasnost, a Half-Toast to Perestroika; U.S. Left Supportive
description: To the Editor:

title: School Pursuit Of Corruption Is Put in Doubt
description: A sampling of corruption allegations made to the New York City Board of Education last year found that half the cases showed no evidence of being investigated, state auditors said today.

title: Coleco Agrees to Sell Its Assets to Hasbro
description: Coleco Industries, the troubled toy maker, has agreed to sell most of its assets to a rival, Hasbro Industries, for $85 million in cash, the companies announced today.

title: Davis Extending Offer for NWA
description: Marvin Davis, the oil billionaire, has extended his $2.7 billion tender offer for all outstanding shares of NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, until next Tuesday. The $90-a-share offer had been scheduled to expire Wednesday.

title: Kraft Now Offers Cash to Irate Contestants
description: Kraft Inc. offered cash compensation today to hundreds of disgruntled sweepstakes contestants who held coupons saying they had won vans and other big prizes.

title: Review/Film; Life of 'Milk and Honey' Is Anything but Sweet
description: When a young woman named Jo leaves her village in Jamaica for a richer life in Canada, she does more than trade crumbling red tile roofs and glorious hillsides for the slushy streets of Toronto. She entrusts her 7-year-old son to her mother and begins working as a live-in nanny for a brisk businesslike couple. In no time she faces her first disillusionment: with her employers deducting room, board and air fare, her weekly take-home pay of $70 will not bring her son to their new home any time soon.

title: Joseph Josephson And Miss Taylor Exchange Vows
description: At Temple Emanuel-El in New York, Martha Scott Taylor, a daughter of Marion M. Taylor of Summit, N.J., and Arthur R. Taylor of Salisbury, Conn., was married yesterday to Joseph Theodor Josephson, the son of Ingrid B. Josephson and Marvin Josephson, both of New York. Rabbi David M. Posner officiated. The bride graduated summa cum laude from Princeton University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received an M.B.A. degree at Columbia University. She is an associate at McKinsey & Company, management consultants in New York. Her mother is the senior editor of The Journal of Cash Management in Fairfield, N.J. Her father, a former president of CBS Inc., is the chairman of Arthur Taylor & Company, an investment concern in New York, and the dean of the business faculty at Fordham University.

title: A Fallen King Revisits His Realm
description: ''I am a rich man,'' Earl Manigault said. ''Just look at my arms. All of my money is in my veins.''

title: A Reflective Riggs Finds Finesse Yielding to Power
description: It has been 50 years since Bobby Riggs swept through Wimbledon, winning the singles, doubles and mixed doubles. He looks at the new crop of tennis stars, and at the recent upsets in the French Open, and marvels at the power being displayed on the courts.

title: Timetable for Expansion
description: The National League will announce a timetable for adding two teams within three months after the owners reach agreement with the players' union on a new contract, Commissioner Bart Giamatti said today.

title: Alcoholism Battled at the Gutter Level
description: Under pressure from community groups in this city's seedy Tenderloin district, the world's largest winery has agreed to suspend sales of the cheap, fortified wines that are the beverage of choice of curbside alcoholics.

title: INCUMBENTS TURN TO PERSONAL PAC'S
description: Members of Congress are increasingly seeking to build good will among colleagues and constituents by establishing their own political action committees and using free mailing privileges, two studies released here today show.

title: Mrs. Papandreou, Divorce at Hand, Tells of Public Ordeal
description: On Friday, Margaret Papandreou says, she will sign a legal document that will end her 38-year marriage to Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou of Greece.

title: Dodgers Win in 11th Inning to Sweep Series With Astros
description: A single by Mariano Duncan drove in Franklin Stubbs in the 11th inning and gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 2-1 victory over the Houston Astros tonight. The Dodgers' victory was their fifth in a row and gave them a three-game sweep of the Astros.

title: Tyson May Raise Holly Farms Bid
description: Tyson Foods Inc. may raise its bid to acquire Holly Farms Inc. after a judge denied its latest effort to block the merger of Holly Farms and Conagra Inc., a Tyson spokesman said. A Delaware Chancery Court Wednesday denied Tyson's request to block Conagra Inc.'s $1.3 billion stock offer for Holly Farms. The action clears the way for shareholders of Conagra and Holly to vote on the merger proposal.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; State Immunity Is Upheld in Suits on Constitutional Violations
description: Dividing narrowly in three cases involving the immunity of states from lawsuits, the Supreme Court ruled today that state governments may not be sued for damages growing out of constitutional violations committed by state agencies or their officials.

title: TV Weekend; 'First Born': Scrambling the Species
description: The three-part British drama ''First Born,'' beginning tomorrow night at 10 on the Arts & Entertainment cable network, opens with Dr. Edward Forester cooing gently to the child developing in his wife's womb. ''She can hear us, you know,'' the doctor insists. ''Our voices, your heartbeat and your bowel sounds.'' But this child, who indeed turns out to be a daughter, is not the firstborn of the title. That distinction belongs to a hybrid, the first of a new species developed in Forester's institute lab. The good doctor, it seems, is a genetic researcher for Britain's Ministry of Defense.

title: Where the Clothes Are Correct and Everybody Is Somebody
description: I never heard of the Hamptons when I was a kid growing up over the store in Brooklyn. In fact, I never heard about the Hamptons until 1976 when my beau, now my husband, invited me to a friend's ''cottage'' on Gin Lane in Southampton. I was not prepared.

title: Reyna Lander McGowen, Lawyer, 57
description: Reyna Lander McGowen, a lawyer with the Legal Aid Society, died of cancer Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 57 years old.

title: Las Vegas Journal; Different Salvation Seen By Baptists and Bettors
description: Mike Henry was standing in a crowd on the gaming floor of Caesars Palace Wednesday waiting for a woman dressed as Cleopatra to announce the winner of 7,236 quarters. He clutched his ticket and shot her a hopeful glance.

title: Don't Raze the Berlin Wall
description: LEAD: Should the Berlin Wall be demolished? Mikhail Gorbachev's willingness to address the issue in his visit to West Germany is likely to raise hopes that the wall could soon come down. But we should heed the Soviet leader's words at a Bonn news conference yesterday. ''The wall was raised in a concrete situation and was not dictated only by evil intentions,'' he said.

title: Lendl and Wilander Notch Victories
description: Ivan Lendl and Mats Wilander, with 13 Grand Slam tournament titles between them but not a single Wimbledon championship, continued their preparation for the world's foremost grass-court event today by reaching the quarterfinals of the Queen's Club championship.

title: Johnson's Testimony Disputed
description: Yet another witness appearing before a Canadian Government commission testified today that Ben Johnson was well aware of the steroids he was taking and their potential adverse side effects.

title: New York's Tax Revenue Rises
description: State tax collections, which have risen and fallen over the last two years as wildly and inexplicably as the commodities market, surged upward recently, leaving the state with more than $300 million in extra revenues.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Spanish Children's Parade, Third Avenue between 87th Street and 122d Street will be closed tomorrow from noon to 3 P.M.

title: Pistons and Fans Share Joyous Exchange
description: Decades of frustration ended with a great outpouring of joy today as thousands of fans rocked the Palace, celebrating the Detroit Pistons' first National Basketball Association championship.

title: Mothers to Be Told if Babies Have AIDS Virus
description: In response to increasing evidence that early treatment can prolong the lives of people with AIDS, the State Health Department announced today that it would permit women whose babies have been anonymously screened to learn the results of the tests.

title: Children's Opera
description: Enchanted Forest Opera is to present a children't program that includes Seymour Barab's ''Chanticleer,'' a one-act comic opera about a hen, a rooster and a fox, and ''A Visit With Cinderalla's Fairy Godmother and Her Storybook Friends'' tomorrow afternoon at 1 P.M. and 3 P.M. at Studio Theater 603, 311 West 43d Street. Tickets are $4 to $6. Information: 595-5113.

title: Bush Is Expected to Name Reagan Aide as F.C.C. Chief
description: The White House is expected to name Alfred C. Sikes, the Reagan Administration's chief policy adviser on communications matters, as the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Review/Theater; Elegant Jamesian Battle Of Father vs. Daughter
description: Despite Henry James's own reservations about the complexity of his short novel ''Washington Square,'' it has proven to be one of the author's most durable works. That popularity has been further enhanced by Ruth and Augustus Goetz's engrossing adaptation (on stage and as a film). The Goetz version, ''The Heiress,'' manages the difficult feat of dramatizing James without overdramatizing James - as is clearly demonstrated in Kenneth Frankel's production at the Long Wharf Theater.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The neat part for me was that I was on the 12th tee, less than 100 yards from the 6th green, when Mark got his hole-in-one.

title: Thomas A. Nochese; Union Leader, 76
description: Thomas Anthony Nochese, president of District Council 9 of the International Brotherhood of Painters and Allied Trades, died Wednesday, apparently of heart failure, at Cabrini Medical Center in Manhattan, a union spokesman said. An autopsy is being performed.

title: Late Rally Erases Big Bond Losses
description: A late rally swept through the Treasury securities market yesterday, erasing large price declines that had been posted in early trading and leaving the market essentially unchanged on the day. Dealers said long-term bond prices fell as much three-quarters of a point soon after the opening, as the dollar appeared to be facing another day of heavy selling.

title: Deng Is Said to Link Force to Safety of Party
description: Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, is reported to have asserted in a speech last week that the Communists had to crack down on pro-democracy demonstrators to prevent their own demise.

title: At Least 22 on Delta Jetliner Are Injured by Air Turbulence
description: A Delta Air Lines jet hit a pocket of turbulence on a flight from Seattle today, injuring at least 22 passengers, who were taken to hospitals when the plane landed here. Several others were treated at the airport.

title: Saving Campers From Lyme Disease
description: Many youngsters heading for camp this year will pack insect repellents and long pants to protect them from Lyme disease, the widespread tick-borne illness that reaches its zenith in summer.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Dunkin' Donuts Studying an Offer Dunkin' Donuts Inc., a doughnut chain with 1,700 outlets, said it was studying a $43-a-share cash tender offer from a company formed by two Canadian companies and said it would advise stockholders by June 29 whether to accept the offer. ''We request that you defer making a decision whether to accept or reject the tender offer until you hear the company's position on the offer,'' Dunkin' Donuts told shareholders. The tender offer, which is to expire on July 13, was made on behalf of a partnership formed by Cara Operations Ltd. and the Kingsbridge Capital Group, the merchant banking arm of the Unicorp Canada Corporation.

title: Grounding of Historic Planes Is Urged
description: When an A-20 Havoc, an extremely rare World War II bomber, was destroyed in a crash at an air show in Harlingen, Tex., last October, its loss sparked warnings from aviation historians and others that a part of American history was slipping away.

title: Halliburton Deal
description: The Halliburton Company, the giant oil-services company, said it had signed a letter of intent to buy C. F. Braun Inc. from the Santa Fe International Corporation for undisclosed terms. Braun is a petroleum and chemical engineering concern based in Alhambra, Calif., with about 1,600 employees worldwide. Halliburton said the acquisition would enable it to offer a range of engineering services from project conceptualization to construction and maintenance.

title: INSIDE
description: Consumer Prices Up 0.6%

title: ARCO Suspends An Alaska Project
description: ARCO Alaska Inc. said it had suspended a 25-well drilling and production test program on Alaska's North Slope because of reductions in state tax incentives. The suspension of the test program will delay full production from the West Sak oilfield.

title: Investors Seeking Talks at La-Z-Boy
description: A group of investors led by Prescott Investors Inc. of Greenwich, Conn., said it would seek to discuss way to increase the stock price of the La-Z-Boy Chair Company with its management and shareholders. Prescott holds a 5.6 percent stake in La-Z-Boy. The management controls more than 40 percent of the stock.

title: British Inflation Rate Up
description: Britain's annual inflation rate rose to 8.3 percent last month, almost double what it was a year ago and its highest level in seven years, according to official figures released today. The figure was in line with forecasts by independent economists.

title: Purcell's 'Fairy Queen' And Baroque Ensemble
description: A concert version of Purcell's ''Fairy Queen'' will be performed Thursday by the Central City Chorus, accompanied by an orchestra of original Baroque instruments, at 7:30 P.M. at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 64th Street.

title: Dollar Posts Modest Drop; New Fall Seen Before Rally
description: The dollar fell again yesterday, but not nearly as sharply as on Thursday, when a selling stampede overran the market.

title: 42d Street Landlords: Greed Inc.
description: LEAD: A dispute between the New York City chapter of the American Institute of Architects and the self-styled Committee to Reclaim Times Square publicly has revealed what we have long known: Although some otherwise well-meaning people may be involved, the committee is financed and dominated by a small group of well-heeled property owners and operators who have maintained a stranglehold on 42d St.

title: Above All, the Novice Skydiver Needs Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Wet and Wild: Mets Waste 8-0 Lead but Win
description: Are you ready for this? The Mets scored eight runs in the top of the first inning tonight, but still had to rally twice to beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 15-11.

title: U.S. SHIFTS STAND ON THE MONITORING OF AN ARMS TREATY
description: The Bush Administration will seek to negotiate and carry out some measures to monitor Soviet strategic forces before completing a new strategic arms treaty, a senior Defense Department official said today.

title: Honeywell's Cuts
description: Honeywell Inc. said it would cut its corporate staff by 300. Seventy-five of the jobs will be lost to attrition, while the rest of the cuts will be made with layoffs and some early retirements, the military contractor and building-controls maker said. About 200 cuts will be made at the company's Minneapolis headquarters. Honeywell has about 178,000 employees worldwide. Honeywell's stock jumped $1.375 a share today, to $75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: KEY RATES
More Chinese Diplomats Seek Refuge
description: A small but growing number of Chinese diplomats are reported to have sought refuge in the United States and several other countries as a result of the crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in their homeland.

title: Robins Plan Is Approved
description: A Federal court today approved the bankruptcy reorganization of the A. H. Robins Company, including a fund of $2.5 billion for women who demonstrate that they were injured by the company's Dalkon Shield birth control device. The United States Court of

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the anniversary of the 1976 riots in Soweto, South Africa, carried an erroneous figure in some copies for Government spending on education. In the latest financial year, $1.4 billion was spent on the one million white students and $1.05 billion on the five million black students.

title: Ray McAnally, Stage and Film Actor, Dies at 63
description: Ray McAnally, a veteran character actor on stage, in films and on television, died Thursday at his cottage in County Wicklow, Ireland. He was 63 years old.

title: 3 Palestinians Killed in Protests in the Gaza Strip
description: Israeli soldiers shot and killed a stone-throwing Palestinian protester outside a mosque in the occupied Gaza Strip today and killed two more when his funeral turned into a protest march, Palestinian witnesses and hospital officials said.

title: Review/Dance; Gatherings and Partings in Works by Rick Merrill
description: Rick Merrill's dances were sometimes as pretty as pictures. That was both what was attractive and what was disturbing about the three new works that Rick Merrill and Company presented Thursday night at the Washington Square United Methodist Church. Choreographic phrases that were pleasant to behold had surprisingly little impact.

title: Patents; Replacement Of Quigg Expected
description: The Secretary of Commerce, Robert A. Mosbacher, is said to have recommended that Harry F. Manbeck, head of the General Electric Company's patent department, replace Donald J. Quigg as Commissioner of Patents and Trademarks.

title: U.S. Drops Part of Its Case Against Iran-Contra Figures
description: The independent prosecutor in the Iran-contra case said today he would drop theft, fraud and conspiracy charges against two remaining defendants, including John M. Poindexter, President Ronald Reagan's national security adviser.

title: In a Corner of France, Long Live the Old Regime
description: Baron Armel de Wismes, who puts on a black tie of mourning on the anniversary of Louis XVI's execution, is not enthused about the festivities marking the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution.

title: Battle Over Anti-Drug Money Holds Up Funds for Veterans
description: A battle over more money for anti-drug programs this year is delaying approval of emergency financing for health care services to veterans.

title: Sowell and Burrell Blaze in 100 Meters
description: Nearly everyone likes the 100-meter dash because it starts fast and ends faster, with the winning margin often a quick foot or a leaning chest. Few were disappointed with the race here tonight as Dawn Sowell and Leroy Burrell blazed past their respective fields in near-record-setting pace in the USA/ Mobil outdoor track and field championships at Robertson Stadium.

title: Patents; Exchanging Digital Data On Fiber-Optic Network
description: Steven Saneski, an engineer at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's Bell Laboratories, received patent approval this week for an inexpensive circuit that makes it easier to exchange digital information over fiber-optic networks.

title: Britain Supports Proposal To Save Rose Theater Site
description: The Government gave its support Thursday to developers' plans to build an office building on giant stilts above the ruins of the 16th-century Rose Theater, where Shakespeare is believed to have acted.

title: It's Not Just Books Facing Cuts at Queens Library
description: When Afshan Rehman Hussaini arrived in Flushing, Queens, from Karachi, Pakistan, in 1984 to join her husband, an employee of Pakistani Airlines, Urdu was her main language.

title: Goldin Offers Plan to Fight Air and Waterway Pollution
description: Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for mayor, offered a four-point plan yesterday to fight air and water pollution in New York City.

title: Cuba Seizes 6 More Officers Amid Signs of Big Shakeup
description: Amid signs of a political purge, Cuba announced today that it had arrested six more military officers, and it asserted that an army general arrested earlier this week had been involved in international drug trafficking.

title: Corrado Agusta, Italian Industrialist, 66
description: Corrado Agusta, former chairman of Agusta S.p.A., one of Europe's leading helicopter manufacturers, died on Wednesday in Switzerland. He was 66 years old.

title: New York State Shouldn't Kill People
description: New York State is about to make a life or death decision. As early as next week, the Legislature could consider an override of my veto of capital punishment legislation.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; REFINANCING A HOME
description: Recent drops in interest rates have injected life into the mortgage market, including a wave of refinancing. Because adjustable rates respond slowly to interest-rate fluctuations, some homeowners could save up to $30,000 in interest payments over the life of a typical 30-year $100,000 mortgage by switching to a fixed rate. Two years ago, an adjustable rate made sense because interest rates were higher and adjustable rates offered the least-costly path to owning a home. But the buyer who borrowed $100,000 two years ago at 7.89 percent, a typical introductory rate then, might do better by converting to a fixed rate. The table shows the savings on a $100,000 mortgage at 9.98 percent, the current national fixed-rate average, as opposed to the current average adjustable rate of 11.15 percent. Payments Fixed ARM Savings Monthly $863 $949 $86 Over 5 years 51,788 56,965 5,177 Over 30 years 310,727 341,791 31,064 (Source: Bank Rate Monitor, North Palm Beach, Fla. 33408)

title: Troyanos Cancellation
description: Tatiana Troyanos has canceled the first four of her eight scheduled performances in Pier Francesco Cavalli's Baroque opera ''La Calisto'' at the Santa Fe (N.M.) Opera. She will be replaced in the role of Diana on July 1, 5, 7 and 14 by the mezzo-soprano Katherine Ciesinski. Miss Troyanos is to sing in the performances of Aug. 5, 10, 16 and 25. Information: (505) 982-3851.

title: URANIUM VERDICT FAVORS PLAINTIFFS
description: A jury impaneled by a Federal district judge in a nonbinding trial has recommended a $136 million award to people living around a Federal uranium processing plant.

title: HEAVY 'WITCHING' TRADING GOES RELATIVELY SMOOTHLY
description: Yesterday's huge stock trading volume of 107.9 million shares in the first half-hour, which was tied to ''triple witching hour,'' went relatively smoothly, traders say, because it had been so widely anticipated.

title: Schools to Get $4.3 Billion For Repairs
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch and the Board of Education, resolving a five-month dispute, agreed yesterday on a five-year plan that will provide at least $4.3 billion to renovate many of New York City's dilapidated school buildings and build several new ones.

title: Kodak to Merge Four Operations
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it would consolidate its consumer photography products and photofinishing operations, cutting costs and hundreds of jobs. Four operations will be merged in the newly created Consumer Imagery division.

title: Met's Zeus Is Home Free As Whitney Finds Another
description: The skirmish is over between the Metropolitan and the Whitney museums over a statue of Zeus owned by the Metropolitan. The statue, stripped of the baseball bat and television monitor an artist bestowed on it with the Whitney's blessing, has been returned to its lender, and replaced by a Zeus borrowed from a Texas businessman.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: A STUDENT LEADER TURNS HIMSELF IN
description: The Government today reported a new series of arrests around the nation of those involved in the democracy movement, and another student leader turned himself in to the authorities.

title: Theater Auction
description: Clothing worn by the performers Madeline Kahn and Edward Asner and a songbook signed by the folk singer Pete Seeger are among the items to be auctioned at 4 P.M. tomorrow at the Henry Street Settlement, 466 Grand Street. Proceeds from the auction are to benefit the Working Theater company, which is presenting a series of one-act plays at the Settlement. The auctioneers are to include Mr. Asner, F. Murray Abraham and the comedian Irwin Corey. Information: 967-5464.

title: Duke Shoulda Been Here
description: In Washington our hotel was surrounded by limousines. A grandfatherly man wearing an ambassador suit took the luggage.

title: Pronouncing the Names
description: DENG BUFANG, Deng Xiaoping's son: dung boo-fahng

title: Row Houses Reviving Debate on Albany's Past
description: A block of crumbling brick buildings sandwiched between the Greyhound bus station and the gleaming Knickerbocker Arena rising here has led this history-conscious city to suspend the advance of construction cranes and once again debate the cost of preserving the past.

title: 'Human Beings Can Be Awful Cruel to One Another'
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Theater; For a Surly Husband, Infidelity Eases the Marital Strains
description: Beneath its fanciful title, Wendy MacLeod's ''Apocalyptic Butterflies'' is earthbound. In this domestic comedy-drama (presented at Intar by the New Arts Theater), Ms. MacLeod is preoccupied with the marital strife of a young couple, cutely named Hank and Muriel Tater, who live in a small Maine town with their as yet unnamed infant daughter. During the brief play, the Taters bicker to such a degree that one may question what brought them together in the first place.

title: Soviets a Hit at Paris Air Show
description: Under a glaring sun, the people in the crowd arched their necks upward to watch the roaring Soviet fighter plane swoop down, roll and then climb straight up like a rocket. More than one person joked that the pilot of the sky-blue Sukhoi Su-27 was the Soviet Union's best salesman at the Paris Air Show.

title: Mapplethorpe Backers Picket the Corcoran and Plan New Shows
description: Chanting slogans and waving photographs and signs, a hundred or more artists and advocates of gay rights demonstrated today at the Corcoran Gallery of Art to protest the cancellation of an exhibition of Robert Mapplethorpe's work.

title: Your Money; For Some Bonds, It's Time to Sell
description: Investors who bought long-term municipal bonds or unit investment trusts made up of such bonds in the high-interest-rate climate of the early to mid-1980's invested wisely.
