As rates have generally dropped in recent years, the prices of those securities have risen, and credit market experts say investors should now consider whether to sell those holdings.

title: Patents; Trademark Exposition
description: Parents and children can meet famous figures on June 24 and 25, when the Patent and Trademark Office holds its annual Trademark Exposition at the Commerce Department in Washington. Celebrities will include the Fruit of the Loom characters (two grapes, an apple and a leaf); Geoffrey the Giraffe from Toys ''R'' Us, and the Michelin tire man.

title: Panel Urges Delay of Plutonium Refinery
description: A special House panel has recommended delaying construction set to begin next year on a $1.2 billion-dollar plutonium refinery in Idaho. But the Energy Department says it has no plans to alter its schedule for the project.

title: Jersey Panel Allows Trump to Purchase Another Large Hotel
description: The Casino Control Commission decided today that the developer Donald Trump wields unequaled economic power in Atlantic City, but not so much that he should not be allowed to add 500 more hotel rooms by acquiring the failing Atlantis Casino Hotel.

title: 'Starmites' to Close
description: ''Starmites,'' a musical about a young woman who magically visits the world of her favorite comic-book characters, will close after the matinee on Sunday at Stage Right of the Criterion Center, 1514 Broadway, at 45th Street. The play, directed by Larry Carpenter, with music and lyrics by Barry Keating and book by Stuart Ross and Mr. Keating, will have run for 60 regular performances and 35 previews.

title: Reviews/Music; Triple-Threat Entertainer: Singer, Harpist and Pianist
description: Paul Balfour may be the only cabaret entertainer in the country who sings and plays the harp and piano all at the same time.

title: Peeters Now a Flyer
description: A former teammate of Kerr, Pete Peeters, became a teammate again yesterday when he signed a contract as a goaltender with the Flyers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 23 about the Encyclopedia of Southern Culture misidentified its printer. R. R. Donnelley & Sons is the printer; the University of North Carolina Press is the publisher.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-6 Ways to monitor Soviet compliance with projected weapons cuts will be negotiated by the Bush Administration before it completes a new strategic arms treaty, a senior Defense Department official said. Page 1 Hungary gave Imre Nagy a funeral, followed by a hero's burial, 31 years after the former Prime Minister was hanged and his body thrown into a prison grave. 1 Beijing may remain uneasy for a long time, small reminders seem to indicate, despite a surface calm that has settled over the capital 12 days after soldiers machine-gunned civilians on the streets. 1 The future of U.S.-Chinese exchanges that have brought tens of thousands of Chinese students and teachers to the United States has been thrown into doubt. 1 Deng is said to link force to safety of Party 4 Solidarity has requested $10 billion in relief from non-Communist industrialized nations for Poland's economy over three years. The union hopes the proposals will go before the economic summit meeting in Paris next month. 6 Japan announced ivory import limits as it joined an international drive to save the African elephant from extinction. Japan is the world's biggest consumers of ivory. 6 Cuba has arrested additional officers, it said, amid signs of a political purge. It asserted that an army general arrested earlier this week had been involved in drug trafficking. 3 Ireland's leader didn't win a majority of the Irish Parliament, returns indicated. He may end up worse off than before the vote he called to strengthen his government. 3 The Soviets are the hit of the air show in Paris, with a marketing offensive and the exhibition of the largest squadron of Soviet aircraft ever seen at a Western show. 31 Papandreou loses support in Crete, once a solid base 3 National 7-8, 24 Samuel Pierce was concerned while he was housing secretary that inquiries into allegations of influence peddling were moving too quickly, an inspector general who said had not been influenced told Congress. 1 Time rejected Paramount's bid and proposed instead to buy Warner Communications. Executives hope a merged company would be too big for Paramount to swallow. 1 Analysts call Time bid fair 31 Prices rose six-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Government said, confirming evidence that inflation remains persistent in the economy but is probably not worsening. 31 Some charges in the Iran-contra case against John Poindexter and another defendant will be dropped to avoid protracted struggles over Government secrets, the independent prosecutor in the case said. 7 The House ethics chairman's wife, Betty Dixon, was part of a company that obtained a lucrative contract for the duty-free shop concession at Los Angeles International Airport. 7 An era of windblown contamination is slowly coming to an end across the West as radioactive sand from uranium production is buried beneath tons of dirt and desert stones. 8 Bonuses to the plutonium operator at the troubled Rocky Flats plant are to be blocked by the Energy Department, it said, pending a Federal investigation of legal violations. 8 Jury favors plaintiffs in nonbinding trial of uranium plant 8 Panel urges delay of plutonium refinery 8 A debate over flying old planes has erupted because hundreds of rare planes have been lost in crashes in the last 25 years. The problem centers on questions of private ownership and historic preservation. 7 Lee Atwater won a vote of confidence from the Republican National Committee and an endorsement from Senator Dole, with whom he has been at odds in the past. 7 To limit soaring health costs, the Bush Administration and Congress moved to curb rising fees by doctors of Medicare patients. 24 Battle over anti-drug money holds up funds for veterans 7 Midway Airlines plans a new hub in Philadelphia, after agreeing to buy Eastern's gates and landing rights there. 31 Regional 25-28 Commercial television was banned from public schools by the New York State Board of Regents. That dealt a severe blow to the company that hopes to market a daily news broadcast to 6.5 million teen-age students. 1 A plan to provide at least $4.3 billion to renovate many of New York City's dilapidated school buildings and build several new ones was agreed upon by Mayor Koch and the Board of Education. 25 Proposed budget cuts could limit the Queens Public Library 27 Director of economic development in New York State, Vincent Tese, has used his background as a commodities trader to make deals with businessmen while consolidating power in the Cuomo administration. 25 The region's condominium glut has hit Connecticut particularly hard, turning a soft market into mush. The state is now studying a plan to allow it to buy financially troubled complexes. 25 Changes in plans for a new charter for New York City, proposed Thursday by the chairman of the Charter Revision Commission, appear to have pleased many critics. 27 The cost of preserving Albany's past is being debated anew because of plans to destroy a set of dilapidated row houses that is thought to be the oldest in the city. 26 A Trump expansion in Atlantic City was approved by the Casino Control Commission, which allowed Donald Trump to buy 500 more hotel rooms with the acquisition of the failing Atlantis Casino Hotel. 26 The sun came out, and so did complaints about the rain 25 Police officials learn about Satanism 26

title: 'Brilliant Pebbles'? No, Loose Marbles
description: With ''brilliant pebbles,'' proponents of the Strategic Defense Initiative may finally have gone off the deep end.

title: Sentence Reduced
description: Ronald Peters, who has been described as Pete Rose's bookmaker, yesterday earned a major reduction of his sentence on tax-evasion and drug charges because he cooperated with Federal investigators.

title: The Shame of the Sudan
description: Peace is an idea whose time is overdue in the Sudan, a huge, starving land bled by six years of civil war. In February the military told Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi to make peace or resign. The seeming results are peace talks and an agreement to let food supplies through war zones. But much of this is a mirage, part of a public relations battle by both sides.

title: U.S. Suspends Bonuses to Operator of Rocky Flats Plutonium Plant
description: The Department of Energy said today that it was blocking the payment of contract bonuses to the operator of the troubled Rocky Flats plutonium plant, pending the outcome of a Federal investigation of violations of pollution laws.

title: Asian Art Exhibition
description: Asian art from the Mr. and Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d Collection, will be on view beginning Thursday at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street. The exhibition, which runs through Sept. 3, traces more than 1,100 years in the history of Chinese ceramics and 200 years of Japanese ceramics. It is part of the society's permanent collection. There will also be a display of Hindu and Buddhist sculpture. Hours are 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Tuesday through Saturday, noon to 2 P.M. Sunday. Admission is $2 ($1 for students and the elderly). Information: 288-6400.

title: Wildcat Coal Strike Being Linked to Union
description: More than 20,000 coal miners in six states stayed off the job today in an expanding wildcat strike that a union official said is being directed by the president of the United Mine Workers, Richard Trumka.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in some copies on Thursday about coins commemorating the 200th anniversary of Congress misstated the prices. Including a surcharge for the Capitol Preservation Fund, they range from $6 for an uncirculated half-dollar to $215 for a proof-quality gold coin.

title: French Withdraw Assistance
description: The French charity Doctors Without Borders canceled an aid mission to China today after the Chinese authorities said there were no injured to treat. A spokesman, Dr. Antoine Crouan, said the authorities refused 24 tons of supplies sent from France, and the consignment was at the Beijing airport.

title: Apple's Stock Falls $3; Estimates of Profit Cut
description: Shares in Apple Computer Inc. fell $3 today, to $44.50, in heavy trading as analysts reduced their earnings estimates for the quarter ending June 30.

title: Reviews/Dance; A Korean-Born Choreographer's Serenity
description: Serenity and a gently charged lyricism were the hallmarks of two premieres choreographed by Young Soon Kim and presented by her White Wave Rising company on Wednesday at St. Clement's Church (423 West 46th Street), where the group performs in two programs through next Saturday.

title: IRISH LEADER FAILS TO WIN A MAJORITY
description: Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey apparently lost his gamble today to win a majority of the 166 seats in the Irish Parliament, leaving himself worse off than before the election he called to strengthen his minority Government.

title: The Costs of Alcohol, and Tragedy
description: Just a few years ago, the nation was claiming victory over drunken driving. Alcohol-related highway fatalities stopped growing as states raised the legal drinking age and public awareness rose. But now progress has stalled; that prompts the departing Surgeon General, C. Everett Koop, to call for stern new measures, including a promising proposal for sharply higher alcohol taxes.

title: Bridge; In the beginning, choosing a national team was a simpler matter than today.
description: A recent furor over the selection of the United States women's team for the 1989 world championships serves as a reminder that such matters were not always viewed with such seriousness. For the first world championships, in Budapest in 1937, Ely Culbertson took his own team, two men and two women - and three extra women as an afterthought.

title: G.O.P. and Dole Give Strong Backing to Atwater
description: Lee Atwater, the chairman of the Republican National Committee, won a vote of confidence from the committee today and an endorsement from Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, with whom he has been at odds in the past.

title: Officers Study Voodoo To Identify Cult Crime
description: It was not your routine day of police training: devil worship, necrophilia, animal sacrifice and voodoo. ''There's some weird stuff going on out there,'' muttered one police officer, a bit pallid, during a break.

title: Kerr Awarded Trophy
description: Tim Kerr, the Philadelphia Flyers' power-play specialist whose shoulder problems limited him to eight games in the 1987-88 season, came back to score 48 goals this past season. That earned him the Bill Masterton Memorial Trophy yesterday, the award presented annually by the Professional Hockey Writers Association for perseverance, sportsmanship and dedication to hockey.

title: Kurt Stone, 77, Editor And Scholar of Music
description: Kurt Stone, a musicologist who edited the works of many prominent American composers and who was an expert on 20th-century musical notation, died Thursday of heart and liver failure at his home in Wilmington, N.C. He was 77 years old. Mr. Stone, who was born in Hamburg, Germany, studied at the university there and at the Royal Danish Conservatory in Copenhagen. He moved to New York in 1938, and worked for several music publishers, including G. Schirmer and Alexander Broude.

title: Holmes Tuttle, 83; In 'Kitchen Cabinet' That Aided Reagan
description: Holmes P. Tuttle, a California automobile dealer who was a longtime adviser to former President Ronald Reagan, died yesterday at Cottage Hospital in Montecito, Calif. He was 83 years old and lived in Santa Barbara.

title: In H.U.D.'s Backyard, a Cesspool
description: Secretary Jack Kemp calls the mess he inherited at the Department of Housing and Urban Development ''a swamp.'' And Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has now moved to help drain it by ordering a Justice Department investigation of every local H.U.D. office.

title: Solidarity Plan Seeks $10 Billion in Aid for Poland'sEconomy
description: The Solidarity union has circulated sweeping proposals to the leading non-Communist industrialized nations calling for $10 billion in relief for Poland's economy over three years.

title: Flood of Newsprint Erodes Success Of Recycling
description: Americans bought 13.2 million tons of newspapers last year, then put 4.7 million tons of them out on the curb to be recycled and advance the cause of conservation. But public officials say a growing glut of used newsprint, brought on by an increase in recycling programs, has thrown many of the programs into disarray and dashed some hopes for keeping recycling costs down.

title: Try Breathing Their Air
description: To the Editor:

title: STRANGE MAKES BID FOR ANOTHER OPEN TITLE
description: Curtis Strange made a strong move today to break a 38-year-old precedent and succeed himself as United States Open champion, while four touring pros with little or no chance to win this Open - Doug Weaver, Mark Wiebe, Jerry Pate and Nick Price - made golfing history: each had a hole-in-one on the par-3 sixth hole at Oak Hill Country Club's East Course, outside of Rochester.

title: CHINA'S DUAL VIEW OF WESTERN TIES
description: Near the end of the evening news programs here for the last few days, some people identified as ''foreign investors'' have been shown at meetings with Chinese partners. The investors express their confidence that after the army's ''calming'' of the recent ''counterrevolutionary disturbance'' in Beijing, business can proceed more or less as usual.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Choosing Sunglasses
description: Sunglasses, a year-round necessity for many, make vision outdoors more comfortable by reducing light and glare and, like a sunscreen, warding off harm from ultraviolet light.

title: Xerox Reductions
description: The Xerox Corporation said 680 employees nationwide had agreed to leave the company voluntarily, including 170 in the Rochester area, where Xerox has its largest manufacturing work force. The employees will receive from one month's to one year's compensation for leaving, depending on age and length of service. While the voluntary reductions will not guarantee against future layoffs, Xerox had originally predicted that only 250 to 350 would take advantage of the program, a spokesman said.

title: H.U.D. CHIEF FEARED SPEED OF INQUIRY, HOUSE PANEL HEARS
description: The inspector general of the Department of Housing and Urban Development told Congress today that Samuel R. Pierce Jr. was ''quite concerned'' while he was Secretary that investigators were moving too quickly last year in pursuing allegations of influence peddling at senior levels of the agency.

title: To Lure People Into Nursing, You've Got to Accentuate the Positive
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Condos Hit Hard by Soft Sales
description: It was an ordinary weekend at the Fox Meadows condominiums. Young mothers pushed strollers up and down the street. Young fathers washed cars and tinkered in garages. Singles sunned themselves around the swimming pool.

title: A Knighthood Is Bestowed On Rex Harrison
description: Buckingham Palace was to announce today that Rex Harrison had been granted a knighthood in the annual honors list marking the official birthday of Queen Elizabeth II. He was made a Knight Bachelor, which is the most common type of knighthood.

title: Books of The Times; Still Poor, 50 Years After Agee Portrait
description: And Their Children After Them By Dale Maharidge And Michael Williamson Foreword by Carl Mydans. Illustrated. 262 pages. Pantheon Books. $24.95.

title: New Move to Halt Cheap Wine
description: The maker of Richard's Wild Irish Rose announced today that it was joining E. & J. Gallo in withdrawing brands of cheap high-alcohol wine from the city's seedy Tenderloin district.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Lendl In; Wilander Out: Ivan Lendl, in his first stiff test on grass as he tunes up for Wimbledon, reached the semifinals of the Queen's Club grass-court tennis championships in London yesterday with a 6-4, 4-6, 6-3 victory over Michael Stich of West Germany, who is ranked 107th. Mats Wilander was upset by Paul Annacone of Bridgehampton, L.I., 6-2, 6-4. (AP) Navratilova Wins: Martina Navratilova eased into the semifinals of a Virginia Slims event yesterday in Edgbaston, England, by beating a 19-year-old Australian qualifier, Kristine Radford, 6-4, 6-2. Navratilova will face Elna Reinach of South Africa, who defeated Betsy Nagelsen of the United States, 1-6, 6-3, 7-5. In the other semifinal, second-seeded Zina Garrison will meet the defending champion, Claudia Kohde-Kilsch.(AP) McEnroe Gets Even: John McEnroe evened the score from a two-year-old defeat yesterday when he overwhelmed Horacio de la Pena of Argentina, 6-3, 6-3, to gain the semifinals of a grass-court tournament in Edinburgh. McEnroe lost to the Argentine in the first round of the French Open in 1987, a loss he called ''the sort of low point of my entire career.'' McEnroe will face a fellow American, Aaron Krickstein, who advanced to the semifinals when fourth-seeded Brad Gilbert withdrew during the second set because of a stomach muscle injury, leading by 7-5, 2-4. In women's semifinal action, top-seeded Mary Joe Fernandez defeated Ann Grossman 6-1, 6-1. She will play the defending champion, second-seeded Gigi Fernandez, who beat the unranked Suzie Mair of Scotland, 6-1, 3-6, 6-1.(AP) GOLF Berteotti Six-Under at Keystone: Missie Berteotti, a nonwinner in four years on the L.P.G.A. Tour, shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday to take the first-round lead at the Lady Keystone Open in Hershey, Pa. Berteotti had seven birdies and one bogey on the soggy West Course of the Hershey Country Club. Laura Davies of England shot a 67 and was second, and Ok Hee Ku of South Korea and Jackie Bertsch were third at 68. Betsy King, Sherrin Smyers, Pat Bradley, Marci Bozarth and Miki Cheng were tied at 69.(AP)

title: Four! A Hole-in-One Record at the Open
description: Near the sixth hole at Oak Hill Country Club, not far from the blue forget-me-nots in the muddy creek in front of the green, a historical marker reads, ''Denonville with army of 3,000 French and Indians crossed these grounds twice in July, 1687.'' Now another historical marker should be placed there.

title: Dow Advances 11.38 in 'Witching' Session
description: LEAD: Heavy trading related to the ''triple witching hour'' pushed the Dow Jones industrial average up 11.38 points yesterday, to a close of 2,486.38.

title: Lord & Taylor's New Jersey Plans
description: Lord & Taylor, which plans to take over four store sites of Hahne & Company in New Jersey, said it would also establish units in two other Hahne stores, in Eatontown and Trenton. Hahne is being phased out by the May Department Stores Company, which also operates Lord & Taylor.

title: In the Surface Calm of Beijing, What's 'Normal' Isn't Quite
description: Twelve days after soldiers machine-gunned civilians on the streets, the Government seems to have willed the capital back to normal life, with buses and bicycles rolling down streets and markets filled with the latest harvest of watermelons.

title: E.P.A. Officer Recommends Permitting Sludge-Dumping
description: The staff of the Environmental Protection Agency recommended issuing permits to nine New York City-area municipalities that dump treated sewage sludge in the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Loyal Crete Wavers on Papandreou
description: When the sheep farmers on the rocky slopes of Crete were asked to vote for Andreas Papandreou, they did so, almost in a bloc, two elections in a row. They liked the man who talked about helping ordinary Greeks like them. His party workers had visited the farmers in villages that men of power in Athens had always ignored.

title: In Savings Bill, a Populist Message
description: In the final hours of deliberations on the Bush bailout bill for the savings and loan industry late Thursday, the House approved a series of amendments certain to be distasteful to the financial community.

title: China's Strife Brings Uncertainty To Exchange Programs With U.S.
description: The future of student- and teacher-exchange programs that have brought tens of thousands of Chinese to the United States and sent smaller numbers of Americans to China has been thrown into doubt by the events in China.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Spanish Children's Parade, Third Avenue between 87th Street and 122d Street will be closed today from noon to 3 P.M. Because of the Broadway

title: Interest in Allegheny Cited
description: Steinhardt Partners, a New York money management firm, is interested in bidding for the bankrupt Allegheny International Inc., the maker of Sunbeam and Oster appliances, a Steinhardt lawyer said today.

title: Costs Show 0.5% Rise in New York Region
description: Consumer prices in the New York metropolitan area rose five-tenths of 1 percent in May, the regional bureau of the Labor Department reported yesterday.

title: Milton Pikarsky, 65, Transportation Figure
description: Milton Pikarsky, director of the City University's Institute for Transportation Systems at City College and a former transportation official in Chicago, died, apparently of a heart attack, Wednesday at the Mayflower Hotel in Washington, where he was attending a meeting of the American Society of Civil Engineers. He was 65 years old and lived in Yonkers.

title: Sentence Suspended
description: Rod Scurry, a former relief pitcher with the Pittsburgh Pirates, the Yankees and the Seattle Mariners, was given a one-year suspended sentence on a cocaine possession charge in Reno on Thursday after he agreed to undergo drug counseling. District Judge Jerry Whitehead also ordered Scurry to submit to periodic checks for drug use during an 18-month probationary period.

title: Expos Capture Lead In East
description: Bryn Smith helped Montreal move into first place in the National League East tonight as Hubie Brooks and Andres Galarraga each had three hits and two runs batted in, leading the Expos past the Chicago Cubs, 8-5.

title: 'Metropolis' Screening To Open Film Festival
description: A free outdoor screening of Fritz Lang's 1927 film ''Metropolis,'' in Riverside Park, 110th Street at Riverside Drive, opens a silent film series sponsored by the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The screening will be on July 6 at 8:30 P.M. Like others in the series, it will feature a live musical accompaniment by Lee Erwin, an organist. Viewers should bring their own seating.

title: Review/Ballet; Dance in Classic Mode To a Modernist Score
description: Michael Torke, the young composer with whom Peter Martins has collaborated successfully in the past, is no minimalist. But his new score for Mr. Martins's latest ballet makes Philip Glass sound like Mozart.

title: White House Backs Move to Curb Medicare Fees
description: The Bush Administration and Congress took aim at soaring health costs today in related moves to curb rising fees by doctors who treat Medicare patients.

title: New Question on Wife of House Ethics Chief
description: At least two other companies offered higher participation by women and members of minorities in the duty-free shop concession at Los Angeles International Airport than the company selected for the contract, a joint venture that includes Betty J. Dixon, wife of the House ethics committee chairman.

title: Cindy Rosen Braun Wed To Scott William Battreall
description: Cindy Rosen Braun, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Monroe D. Rosen of New York, and Scott William Battreall, a son of Margaret Hancock and Ronald C. Battreall, both of San Antonio, were married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in New York by Rabbi Richard S. Chapin.

title: Corrections
description: A map yesterday showing the area of storm damage in the District of Columbia misplaced Walter Reed Army Medical Center. It is within the district's boundaries, slightly south of the point shown.

title: 2 More Bidders Enter NWA Contest
description: The long struggle for control of NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, which has been an especially confusing takeover battle because of the large numbers of players involved, became even more complex today when two more players jumped into the fray.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY JUNE 17, 1989
description: Companies

title: Construction Of Housing Down 2.1%
description: Housing construction fell by 2.1 percent in May, to the lowest level since the last recession in 1982, the Government reported today, but many analysts said declining interest rates should turn the industry around in coming months.

title: Anita O'Day Extended
description: An engagement by the singer Anita O'Day has been extended through July 8 at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street. Performing with Miss O'Day is the Gene Krupa Band. Shows are Tuesday through Saturday at 9:15 and 11:15 P.M. Information: 758-2272.

title: Hungarian Who Led '56 Revolt Is Buried as a Hero
description: Thirty-one years after he was hanged and his body thrown into a prison grave, Imre Nagy, who led the 1956 uprising against Soviet domination, was given a solemn funeral today on Budapest's largest square, followed by a hero's burial.

title: Dudley, Former Sabre, Is Named Head Coach
description: The Buffalo Sabres, who dismissed Ted Sator as head coach on Thursday, wasted little time filling the void. Yesterday, they named Rick Dudley, a former Sabre left wing with minor league coaching experience, to replace him.

title: Mortgage Rates Drop
description: Interest rates on fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.04 percent this week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. That rate was down from a rate of 10.2 percent last week. The average initial rate on one-year adjustable-rate mortgages was 8.95 percent this week, down from 9.09 percent the week before, according to the corporation, which is known as Freddie Mac.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Artra Group Inc., Northfield, Ill., a scientific instruments company, said it would sell the Welch Vacuum Pump division of its Sargent-Welch Scientific unit to an investor group led by certain senior officers of the division. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Consumer Prices Up 0.6% in May
description: Consumer prices climbed by six-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Labor Department said today, confirming evidence that inflation remains persistent in the economy but does not seem to be worsening.

title: About New York; Bridges Are Built Out of Dreams (And Resources)
description: Today is the official commemoration of the golden anniversary of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge, a couple of months after the fact due to an admirable preference for warmer weather. The hoopla will include speeches by Mayor Edward I. Koch and other politicians, horse-drawn trolley rides, fireworks and performances by Retumba Con Pie, a women's Afro-Caribbean dance and percussion ensemble.

title: Talk of Mergers In Accounting
description: On the weekend before the United States partners of Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young are scheduled to vote on a merger that would create the world's largest accounting firm, other top-tier firms appear to be exploring possible mergers of their own.

title: Jonathan Lieberson, 40, Author
description: Jonathan Lieberson, an author, editor and teacher of philosophy, died Friday at the home of his mother in Kent, Conn. He was 40 years old.

title: Radioactivity Cleanup Proves Slow and Costly
description: An era of windblown contamination is slowly coming to an end across the West as huge piles of radioactive sand from uranium production are buried beneath tons of dirt and desert stones.

title: New York Bans Sponsored TV From Its Schools
description: The New York State Board of Regents voted unanimously today to prohibit commercially sponsored television programs in the state's public schools, dealing a severe blow to the company that hopes to beam a daily news broadcast for teen-agers into the nation's classrooms.

title: 'Human Beings Can Be Awful Cruel to One Another'; When Rape Makes News
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking Back at 1956: Passion, and Then Pain
description: For Tibor Kalmar, the end of the 1956 uprising brought the beginning of state-ordered and unnecessary electric shock treatment. Then came the heart attack, endless unemployment and a bramble bush of poverty. But today, having come this far on faith, Mr. Kalmar knew the balm of forgiveness.

title: For One Brief Shining Moment . . . the Sun!
description: The sun shone down benevolently on the people yesterday afternoon. This happened at 12:46, and the people, almost as one, drew in their umbrellas, peeled off their jackets, snapped on their shades and peered from the sidewalks below with confused, even amazed faces. But the people were not fooled.

title: Integrated Talks With Its Creditors
description: Integrated Resources Inc., the troubled financial-services company, said it was continuing to talk with its creditors in an effort to restructure its short-term debt. Earlier this week, the company was unable to roll over its commercial paper and its credit lines were cut off by its banks.

title: A Mob Leader In New England Is Believed Slain
description: The body of a man said to be a major organized-crime figure in New England was found yesterday on a riverbank near Wethersfield, Conn.

title: Warner Gets Good Price, Analysts Say
description: Steven J. Ross, the chairman of Warner Communications, who had not wanted to sell his company, at least seems to have negotiated a good price for it, analysts said. Yesterday he accepted a $70-a-share bid from Time Inc. that values Warner at about $14 billion.

title: For the Self-Reliant Pet
description: Call it pet liberation.

title: Reviews/Music; Canticum Novum Singers Offer Handel's 'Samson'
description: The Canticum Novum Singers seem never to be far from one of New York City's concert stages. Besides its own series at Merkin Concert Hall, the group is regularly heard in larger productions that require a chamber chorus. Most years, the choir's director, Harold Rosenbaum, also hires an orchestra and soloists, and mounts an ambitious production of his own to close the group's season.

title: Strong Pitching Gives Yankees 2 Over Texas
description: If he was the anchor, as Manager Dallas Green called him in the spring, Andy Hawkins was not giving the Yankees stability. He was, in some ways, pulling them down.

title: Solidarity Presents Relief Plan to West
description: After its electoral victory in Poland, the Solidarity union has circulated sweeping proposals to non-Communist industrialized nations calling for $10 billion in relief for the Polish economy over three years.

title: Critics of First Charter Plan Praise Proposed Revisions
description: Many of those who have been most critical of the initial proposals of the New York City Charter Revision Commission said yesterday that they were pleased with changes proposed Thursday by the panel's chairman.

title: Transactions
description: THURSDAY Baseball

title: How Many Yews Grow In Novum Eboracum?
description: To the Editor:

title: Eastern to Sell Operations In Philadelphia to Midway
description: Midway Airlines, one of the few start-up carriers to survive the competitive pressures of deregulation, bolstered its position yesterday by agreeing to pay $206.5 million for Eastern Airlines' Philadelphia gates, landing rights and Canadian routes.

title: Deal Maker Brings His Craft to Albany
description: When Vincent Tese, New York State's Director of Economic Development, ended his career as a commodities trader to turn to government service in 1983, his life did not change very much.

title: Reviews/Dance; Variations on Human Personality
description: In ''The Four Temperaments,'' George Balanchine took a new look at an old theme. His allegorical ballet is based on the notion, which prevailed from the time of the ancient Greeks through the Renaissance, that there are four basic types of personality, and his fine choreography does much to make that theory seem eternally valid.

title: Ben Johnson Confesses
description: A watching world was stunned last September when Canada's gold medal sprinter, Ben Johnson, tested positive for drugs at the Seoul Olympics. He insisted then that he had ''never ever knowingly'' used a banned substance, but now he has confessed that that was a lie. He had been taking pills and injections for seven years.

title: N.F.L. List Narrows
description: The National Football League search committee for a new commissioner met at the league offices on Park Avenue yesterday to narrow its list of candidates from 11, but did not reveal how few are on the list.

title: Judy Johnson, a Star 3d Baseman In the Negro Leagues, Dies at 89
description: Judy Johnson, who never received a chance to play in the major leagues but became the sixth black player elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame from the Negro leagues, died at his home in Wilmington, Del., on Wednesday. He was 89 years old and suffered a stroke last year.

title: JAPAN TO CURTAIL ITS IVORY IMPORTS
description: Joining an international drive to save the African elephant from extinction, Japan announced today that it would sharply limit imports of ivory and ivory products and work to change buying practices that make the Japanese the biggest consumers of ivory in the world.

title: James Henderson, 77, Adviser to MacArthur
description: James McInnes Henderson, a longtime Federal official who helped reshape the Japanese economy after World War II, died of pancreatic cancer on June 7 at the Tremont Health Care Center in Dallas. He was 77 years old.

title: Time Inc., Rejecting Bid by Paramount, Will Pursue Warner
description: Time Inc. took a new approach yesterday to its goal of joining with Warner Communications Inc. and offered to buy the company for $14 billion.

title: Judge Approves Sale of LTV Unit
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge has approved the sale of the LTV Corporation's steel bar division to workers for about $220 million, the company said. The sale of the Ohio-based division to a new employee stock ownership plan must still be ratified by employees, who are members of the United Steelworkers of America, LTV said.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the United States trade deficit for April referred incorrectly in some editions to the history of improvement in recent months. April's was the second monthly improvement in a row, not the third.

title: Red-Green Tide in Germany
description: The ''Red-Green'' coalition will soon complete its first 100 days in power here. It is being watched closely because the experiment can determine who wins the next elections in Bonn.

title: Language
description: To the Editor: In reference to Margaret Logan's ''When Berlitz Is Not Enough'' (Travel, May 7), I have two solutions that have worked for me:

title: Jay Feinberg: Jewelry Designer
description: Jay Feinberg designs large-scale flashy costume jewelry for the extroverted woman. A silver-plated 40-inch-long chain is studded with 4,000 glittering Austrian crystals. Two-inch-wide wood bangles are hand-painted to look like leopard or zebra. ''The jewelry is strong and loud,'' said the 28-year-old designer, who is based in Manhattan. ''You want somebody to see it.''

title: Carnegie's Legacy Continues To Bear Interest
description: POSSIBLY the most literate statements on laissez-faire capitalism and charitable giving during America's Gilded Age appeared 100 years ago in the June and December 1889 issues of ''North American Review.'' The author, who is buried in North Tarrytown's Sleepy Hollow Cemetery, was the largest single producer of steel in the world and the man who made philanthropy Big Business in America: Andrew Carnegie.

title: Wasn't Speaker Foley Who Was Smeared
description: To the Editor:

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Bayside
description: WHEN moviemaking was in its heyday in Queens, W. C. Fields, Gloria Swanson, Norma Talmadge and other stars built sprawling mansions in the North Shore community of Bayside and commuted to their studios in Astoria.

title: Antoin Petras, 67, Designer of Tennis Shirts
description: Antoin (Tonda) Petras, the fashion designer believed responsible for introducing the colored tennis shirt, died of kidney and liver complications yesterday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Manhattan and Newtown, Conn.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Wexford, Pa.;
Pittsburgh Link Spurs Building
description: LEAD: THE prospective completion of a limited-access highway linking this village 13.5 miles north of Pittsburgh with the city's downtown is giving new impetus to a 15-year surge in residential construction here. Commuting will take 20 minutes when the Interstate 279 link opens this fall.

title: A Student Is Wed To Miss McGrath
description: Elizabeth-Anne McGrath, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. McGrath of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to William C. Finneran 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Finneran Jr. of Yonkers. Msgr. James P. Connolly officiated at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Bulk Grocery Clubs Grow in Popularity
description: LEAD: THE word is spreading from Montauk to Manhattan. ''Have you been to the club?'' people are asking across bridge tables, in lunchrooms, even just in passing.

title: Miss Petrie Weds W. D. DeVoll Jr.
description: Elizabeth Scott Petrie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Joseph Petrie of Great Neck, L.I., was married there yesterday to Willys David DeVoll Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. DeVoll of Westport, Conn. The Revs. Edward Johnston and Gary Maier officated at All Saints Episcopal Church.

title: Glittering Italian on the South Shore
description: THERE'S a spectacular new superstar in Long Island's culinary heaven. The six-month-old Gaetano Restaurant in Patchogue is the beloved baby of two talented young owners. One is a master chef, the other a knowing host who guides a seamless service staff.

title: Anna Borst Marries
description: Anna Benson Borst, the daughter of Frances S. Borst of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Alan W. Borst of Columbus, Ohio, was married yesterday to Michael Jacob Henry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Henry of Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. George Pennington, a Unitarian minister, officiated at Wainwright House in Rye, N.Y. The bride and bridegroom are graduates of Oberlin College and Mr. Henry received a J.D. degree from Yale University. Mrs. Henry is an artist and photographer. Mr. Henry is to become a clerk for Judge William W. Schwarzer of the United States District Court in San Francisco in August.

title: Batman Prowls a Gotham Drawn From the Absurd
description: Suppose Manhattan were a smaller island than it is, and pressure to build consequently more intense. Suppose there had been no planning regulations in force for the last 100 years or so. Suppose corrupt politicians, lackeys of the crime bosses, had been at the civic helm all along. Then New York might look, feel, at times almost smell the way it does in Warner Brothers' ambitious remake of ''Batman,'' opening on Friday: a stygian Babylon of emaciated alleys and big, bruising towers, all murk, sleaze and psychopathic architecture.

title: WHO'S TO JUDGE?
description: I do not know whether Elizabeth Morgan is telling the truth when she says that her former husband sexually abused their daughter (''Who's to Judge?'' by Marianne Szegedy-Maszak, May 21). Nor do I know whether the allegation is a delusion (i.e., a genuinely held belief that has no basis in reality). It may even be that what was originally a lie has now become a delusion.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; Warm Fresh Scallops With Sauteed Onions
description: Scallops and onions make a delightful warm-weather treat. You don't need Vidalia, Maui or other sweet onions if you have the patience to cook ordinary red onions very slowly with a bit of sugar. Combine them with scallops, which are naturally sweet, make a side dish of potatoes, add a salad or green vegetable and Sunday lunch or dinner is served. Scallops on a Bed Of Red Onions 1 1/2 pounds red onions 1 tablespoon olive oil 1/3 cup water 2 teaspoons sugar 2 teaspoons lemon juice Freshly ground black pepper to taste 1 pound bay or calico scallops 1 clove garlic, chopped, or 1/2 teaspoon minced garlic in oil 2 tablespoons dry vermouth.

title: The Eyes and the Color of Life
description: ''OH, I knew something was terribly wrong,'' I murmured to the ophthalmalogist who had just told me that I had a cataract in the left eye. He assured me that some cataracts developed slowly, taking years in fact, and that if an operation was needed, there were new techniques, among them lens transplants, that were extremely successful.

title: Julie Andre Wed To Barton Lund
description: Julie Marie Andre, a daughter of Mrs. Howard P. Johnson of Montclair, N.J., and the late William C. Andre, was married yesterday at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in Montclair to Barton Alexander Lund, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Marquard H. Lund of Montclair. Msgr. James J. Finnerty performed the ceremony.

title: The Old West Preserved on Canvas
description: BRAVADO and eccentricity have long been the stuff of American legends, and the cowboy artist Charles M. Russell, who captured the Old West at a peak moment, was no exception. His brand of homespun philosophy, humor and talent made him a personage in Great Falls, Mont., where he lived and worked for more than 40 years. The Russell mystique grew with his death in 1926, and the city, not about to let a legend slip away, took steps to hold onto its own Hemingwayesque character. The C. M. Russell Museum, a complex made up of the artist's home, studio and a gallery of his work, was the result.

title:
ART;
The Star at This Gallery Is the Baseball Card
description: LEAD: GETTING children to attend the latest exhibition at the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson is hardly a problem. The difficult part is getting them to leave.

title: Miss Herbert Weds J. H. Von Heill, Fellow Banker, in Florida Ceremony
description: The marriage of Penelope Elisabeth Herbert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raford W. Herbert of Jupiter, Fla., to James Hanto Von Heill, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard S. Von Heill of Garden City, L.I., took place yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd in Tequesta, Fla. The Rev. Jonathan B. Coffey officiated.

title: Bunning's Perfect Gift
description: It was Father's Day, and accustomed as he was to toiling on Sundays, as the father of seven children, the 32-year-old man might have asked for a day off, especially since his work took him away from home that weekend.

title: What's So Funny About Japan?
description: JUZO ITAMI WOULD CUT A swath anywhere, but in Tokyo he stands out more distinctly than the Tokyo Tower, the replica, constructed in 1958, of Gustav Eiffel's prototype. At 1,098 feet, the Tokyo Tower is 43 feet taller than the Paris landmark, though it looks shorter. It seems to be standing in a gulley. Not Itami.

title: Margaret Bessey Becomes a Bride
description: At Christ United Methodist Church in New York, Margaret M. Bessey, a daughter of Mrs. Robert E. Bessey of New York and the late Mr. Bessey, was married yesterday to Edward J. Brown, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Brown of Fort Wayne, Ind. The Rev. Philip A. C. Clarke performed the ceremony.

title: French Fete a New Rochelle Revolutionary, Thomas Paine
description: TWO centuries ago, the writings of Thomas Paine helped inspire revolutions in two countries and stirred fears of one in a third, England. This month the French honored the New Rochelle resident for his role in their revolution 200 years ago.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Bayport $158,000 273 Oakwood Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,900. Commack $187,500 36 Harvard Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 31-year-old split level; c/a, basement, 1-car garage, above-ground pool; taxes $3,200. East Northport $220,000 64 Colonial Street 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old colonial; dining room, family room, basement, half acre, 1-car garage; taxes $5,000. New Suffolk $260,000 1090 First Street 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 30-year-old bayfront contemporary; great room, 7 skylights, 1-car garage; taxes $1,900. Rocky Point $169,000 1 Hilltop Court 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 23-year-old ranch; 2 fireplaces, half acre, deeded beach rights; taxes $3,900. Smithtown $208,000 6 Merrivale Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 27-year-old high ranch; pool, Florida room; taxes $4,300. OTHER AREAS Chester, Conn. $175,000 33 Spring Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 24-year-old contemporary; wraparound deck, views of pond, half acre; taxes $1,147. Waccabuc, N.Y. $450,000 Makepeace Hill 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 13-year-old contemporary; family room, eat-in kitchen, deck, 2-car garage, 2 acres; taxes $6,040. Avon, N.J. $315,000 46 Sylvania Avenue 7-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, century-old Victorian; eat-in-kitchen, h/w floors, 3-car garage; taxes $2,884.

title: Correction
description: An article on May 28 about the impact of foreign ownership on American industry misstated the origins of the relationship between Switzerland's Holderbank and the Dundee Cement Company and the year in which that relationship began. Dundee started its operations in 1959 as a subsidiary of Holderbank.

title: Laura G. Hacker Becomes a Bride
description: Laura Gay Hacker, the daughter of Joan L. Hacker of Wyckoff, N.J., and George L. Hacker of London, was married yesterday to Randy George Durbin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Durbin of Regina, Saskatchewan, at the Apple Ridge Country Club in Mahwah, N.J., by the Rev. John P. Smith 3d, a Presbyterian minister.

title: What Will the People of China Do Next?; Journalistic Tradition
description: To the Editor:

title: China Sentences 8 More to Death; Sharply Attacks U.S. 'Interference'
description: In another sign of the Government's determination to deal harshly with leaders of pro-democracy demonstrations, the authorities today sentenced eight young people to death for their role in a violent protest in the capital.

title: Full Repairs for the Broken House
description: LEAD: When I came to Washington, more than 30 years ago, I heard about old Representative Clare (No Pockets) Hoffman of Michigan, who had his pockets sewn shut. Some say this practice kept him from putting his hands in his pockets while speaking. Others said it was to prevent anyone from slipping an envelope full of cash into his pockets, reputedly a common practice at the time.

title: Pride and Resentment Rising Among Israeli Arabs
description: A framed photo of President Chaim Herzog hangs high on the wall, just over the Arab Mayor's right shoulder. The Israeli state seal is to the left.

title: Struggles of Would-Be Film Makers
description: Hollywood studios often spend more than $20 million to produce a film these days. But Gary Handel, a 29-year-old New York City cab driver, recently spent only $3,000 to produce a 10-minute film that has been broadcast nationally on cable television. And Maxi Cohen, 30, of Manhattan, who until recently made ends meet working in the New York City morgue, was commissioned to produce a short comedy for ''Saturday Night Live'' on NBC.

title: Cynthia Donahue Weds a Student, Andrew Richards
description: Cynthia Louise Donahue, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Mark Donahue of Westwood and Edgartown, Mass., and Andrew Hamilton Richards, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Francis Richards of Far Hills, N.J., were married yesterday by the Rev. Michael Crimmins, a Roman Catholic priest, at St. Elizabeth's Church in Edgartown.

title: TRACKING SHOPPERS WITH PERSONAL BAR CODES
description: Electronic scanners have become one of the first lines of defense for supermarkets in fighting labor shortages and beating back long check-out lines. About half of all supermarkets now have scanners. And last year, 62 percent of all grocery purchases were rung up on these devices, up from just 21 percent in 1981.

title: Be Adventurous, Executives Tell The Class of 1989
description: LEAD: They say that everything has its cycle. So, too, with advice.

title: Coping With a Bogus Credit Card Charge
description: WHEN it comes to handling money overseas, Murphy's Law - if it can go wrong, it will - has wrinkles in its wrinkles. Take the problem that befell Lawrence and Barbara Eisenberg of New York. On vacation last August, they spent two weeks in Greece. Mr. Eisenberg estimates that they used their Chase Manhattan Bank Visa card in two restaurants, three or four shops and one hotel. In September, they received a bill from Visa that included a charge for $1,100 that they had not incurred, from an organization called Marine Facilities. The charge, dated several days after the Eisenbergs left Greece, was for a fur jacket.

title: Housing Chief's Fund Favored New York
description: Almost a third, or $12 million, of the nearly $38 million in a discretionary fund at the disposal of the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development went to projects in New York State between 1981 and 1988. And all but a small fraction of that went to causes championed by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York.

title: NOTHING IS NATURAL
description: LEAD: LAST CALL By Harry Mulisch. Translated by Adrienne Dixon. 288 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: French Horse Is Withdrawn
description: Ourasi, the French horse considered by many to be the world's best trotter, has been pulled out of the the Statue of Liberty International Trot at the Meadowlands because of an injury suffered in a race this week.

title: Dr. Gail Riess Is Married
description: Dr. Gail Michele Riess, an intern in internal medicine, and Dr. Leonard Bruce Saltz, a fellow in hematology and oncology, both at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, were married last evening at the Helmsley Palace by Rabbi Jack Stern. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Riess of Warren, N.J. Dr. Saltz is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Saltz of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Philadelphia
description: To the Editor: Although I am not a Philadelphian, I feel impelled to say that ''What's Doing in Philadelphia'' (Travel, April 2) omitted both in the content of the article as well as the map, the famous Rodin Museum. It is believed to have the largest collection of sculpture by Rodin outside of Paris. CY KRAMER North Brunswick, N.J.

title: 7 Palestinians: Journalists or Revolutionaries?
description: As legal procedures in an Israeli military court unfold against seven Palestinians accused of leading or aiding the uprising in the occupied territories, a defense lawyer said there was ''hardly any chance'' that they would be acquitted despite repeated denials of the charges.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CASEY ON THE LOOSE. By Frank Deford. (Viking, $15.95.) Frank Deford, a former senior staff writer for Sports Illustrated and a television sports analyst, is also a novelist, mystery writer, biographer and the author of several nonfiction books. Now he has written the essential what-if book of baseball, ''Casey on the Loose.

title: Irish Leader Looks to a Minority Government
description: Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey, conceding failure in his attempt to secure a majority in elections on Thursday, said today that he would do his best to form another minority government when the new Parliament meets later this month.

title: 'No Fault' Divorce Is Considered By New York State Lawmakers
description: New Yorkers for the first time would be able to get ''no fault'' divorces under a measure being considered by the Legislature.

title: The Great Houses of North Wales
description: IN 1283, after King Edward I conquered the remote regions of Snowdonia in North Wales, thus terminating the rule of Welsh princes, his military architects built a string of majestic castles to fortify his gains. Even as romantic shells with castellated towers, these ruins of medieval castles have always exerted a powerful force on the imagination and on the history of Welsh domestic architecture. Important country houses that evolved later in the same northern territory incorporate structural motifs derived from these solid ancestors.

title: Kathleen Comella Is Wed in Chicago
description: Mary Kathleen Comella, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles M. Comella of Dover, Ohio, was married yesterday to Robert Cornelius Sullivan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Sullivan of Manhasset, L.I. The Rev. John J. Sanaghan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Bond Chapel at the University of Chicago.

title: TURNING OFF THE ENLIGHTENMENT
description: LEAD: THE NEW REALITIES In Government and Politics/In Economics and Business/In Society and World View. By Peter F. Drucker. 276 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: ARTFUL SURVIVOR
description: As an abstract painter, I was inspired by Deborah Solomon's article on Helen Frankenthaler (''Artful Survivor,'' May 14). I admire Ms. Frankenthaler for remaining true to her vision in an art world that has been preoccupied by a series of cynical, short-lived trends for much of the last two decades. She reminds us that beauty will always be the rarest and most highly valued component of art. ALLAN ROSENFIELD Los Angeles

title: Marguerite Mann Becomes a Bride
description: Marguerite Mary Mann, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Mann of Myrtle Beach, S.C., and David Andrew Viklund, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Viklund of Plandome Manor and Quogue, L.I., were married yesterday at the Cathedral of the Incarnation, an Episcopal church in Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Robert J. Broesler, an Episcopal minister, and the Rev. Dr. C. Thomas Spitz, a Lutheran minister, officiated.

title: Q and A
description: For the Disabled

title: INSIDE THE BELTWAY WITH CHEE AND LEAPHORN
description: TALKING GOD By Tony Hillerman. 239 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: Everett Melosh, 62, TV Lighting Director
description: Everett Melosh, who won four Emmy awards as a lighting director for ABC-TV, died on Thursday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J., after a heart attack. He was 62 years old and lived in Woodcliff Lake, N.J.

title: Disney's Shrunken Kids Have a Mission
description: An absent-minded professor in a placid suburb invents an incredible shrinking machine that accidentally turns his own children and his next door neighbors into creatures one-quarter of an inch tall. In their miniaturized state, the four tots must do battle with a bumblebee, an ant and a scorpion the size of dinosaurs.

title: Needed: Competition For Commuter Rail Lines
description: COMMUTER rail fares have gone up again, this time by three times the inflationary rate since last year's increase. N. J. Transit argues that without major additional taxpayer subsidy - to a level exceeding $700,000 a day - there is no alternative to higher fares and reduced service.

title: Families in Legal Fight Over Cemetery Plot
description: TWO Windham families are embroiled in a legal dispute on who has the right to a cemetery plot that the town sold to both families.

title: Kemp Sees Criminality in H.U.D. Program
description: Jack F. Kemp, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, says he believes there was criminal wrongdoing in a Federal low-income housing program under scrutiny for political abuse.

title:
FILM;
'Napoleon' Campaigns In the Battle for Preservation
description: LEAD: When the restored version of ''Napoleon,'' Abel Gance's four-hour, three-screen, color-tinted silent film of 1927, had its premiere at Radio City Music Hall in 1981, the director was ailing in Paris and could not attend. But at the end of the second night's show, the producers reached Mr. Gance by telephone.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE NIGHT THE BEAR ATE GOOMBAW. By Patrick F. McManus. (Holt, $15.95.) A book of essays or stories should be even in tone and pace to avoid the impression of limping. Unfortunately, ''The Night the Bear Ate Goombaw,'' Patrick F. McManus's latest book, limps. Some of his essay/stories are funny, others are not.

title: CONGRESS STYMIES BUSH PLAN TO ARM CAMBODIAN REBELS
description: Bush Administration officials acknowledged today that they could not win Congressional approval for their proposal to arm non-Communist guerrillas in Cambodia through a secretly financed operation run by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Auto Insurance Plans Gaining Wider Support
description: LEAD: PROPOSALS by the Democrats and the Republicans in the State Assembly to allow voters to decide directly whether and how automobile insurance rates should be reduced gained broader support as they were released by the Assembly Insurance Committee this month.

title: Jeff S. Adler Wed To Susan Pepper
description: At the Faculty House of Columbia University, Susan Ruth Pepper, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Pepper of Brookline, Mass., and Jeff Scott Adler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Adler of Woodside, Queens, were married last evening by Rabbi Debra Cantor.

title: Question Of the Week; What's Wrong With The Mets?
description: Like any sport, baseball should be practiced and played faithfully, with dedication. Players should learn to perfect and improve their skills so that during a crisis, things won't fall apart. Proper attitude and attention to the game's fundamentals go a long way and usually result in pennants.

title: Jennifer L. Stafford Married
description: Jennifer Lee Stafford, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Stafford of Essex Fells, N.J., was married yesterday to John Glen Farrow, a son of Dorothy Kilkenny of Woodland Hills, Calif., and Glenn W. Farrow of Thousand Oaks, Calif., at the First Presbyterian Church in Caldwell, N.J. The Rev. Dr. David Worth officiated.

title: Lunch on the Connecticut River
description: THERE is so much wringing of hands each summer over where to eat at the water's edge that perhaps a new solution is called for: eat on the water instead, on a cruise boat that serves lunch and dinner.

title: Cyclists Vying for Title
description: Nearly 100 cyclists from the United States and other countries will compete here Sunday in the fifth CoreStates United States professional cycling championships, a 156-mile race through the streets of Philadelphia. The highest placed American finisher will earn the title of United States professional national road champion. Greg LeMond, who in 1986 became the first American to win the Tour de France, will be riding on the Coors team with the former Olympic gold medalist Alexi Grewal. Roberto Gaggioli of the Eurocar/Galli team is the defending champion.

title: Sports of The Times; Free the 'Major' Foreign Golfers
description: For more than a century, the Statue of Liberty has pleaded, ''Give me your tired, your poor, your huddled masses yearning to breathe free.'' But not, Deane Beman of the PGA Tour has decreed, your tired but wealthy golfers, your foreign touring pros yearning to putt free.

title: POSTINGS: Raggedy Ann's Birthplace;
description: The birthplace of Raggedy Ann - an 80-year-old house and its surrounding 11 acres - is being developed into four expensive homes along the Silvermine River in Wilton, Conn. The wood-frame Colonial house has been renovated and expanded into a five-bedroom, five-bathroom mansion on two acres, with an asking price of $2.25 million.

title: In Takeover Wars, Everyone Wins
description: The shareholders of Time Inc. have already realized considerable gains from the mere prospect of a takeover by Paramount Communications Inc. The price of their Time stock has jumped by more than 50 points. But will the acquisition of Time by Paramount - or by another corporate suitor for that matter - result in losses to the other parties with a stake in the deal: the consumers, employees and the tax collector?

title:
ART;
Sculpture With a Provocative Edge
description: LEAD: ONE of the most important things about Louise Bourgeois's work from the 60's is that it looks like the 80's. This is a strong impression conveyed by the current installation of her sculpture at the Dia Art Foundation in Bridgehampton.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Avon $315,000 46 Sylvania Avenue 7-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, century-old Victorian; eat-in-kitchen, 3-car garage; taxes $2,884. Bricktown $115,000 51 Bridge Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 28-year-old colonial; fireplace, fenced yard, 1-car garage; taxes $1,318. Manasquan $207,500 64 Clark Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 38-year-old Cape Cod; enclosed porch, family room, h/w floors; taxes $1,771. Neptune $160,000 409 Prospect Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 41-year-old Cape Cod; den, deck, finished basement; taxes $3,100. South Belmar $132,500 404 17th Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old ranch; c/a, sun porch, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $1,814. Florham Park $186,000 11 Elmwood Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 22-year-old split level; full basement, eat-in-kitchen, new roof; taxes $1,682. OTHER AREAS Chester, Conn. $175,000 33 Spring Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 24-year-old contemporary; wraparound deck, views of pond, half acre; taxes $1,147. Waccabuc, N.Y. $450,000 Makepeace Hill 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 13-year-old contemporary; family room, eat-in kitchen, deck, 2-car garage, 2 acres; taxes $6,040. Bayport, L.I. $158,000 273 Oakwood Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,900.

title: Exhibit Celebrates Centuries-Old Love Of French Chic
description: LEAD: AMERICAN attitudes toward Europe changed in the 19th century. Eighteenth-century austerity with suspicions of Old World luxury and decadence gave way to 19th-century admiration and emulation - particularly of France.

title: Pronouncing The Names
description: BO YIBO, party elder: bwaw (rhymes with saw) ee-bwaw

title: Kite Charges to a 1-Stroke Lead in Open
description: Tom Kite used his new cross-handed putting grip and some late scrambling saves after running four birdies in a six-hole stretch today to pass Curtis Strange, the defending champion, and gain a one-shot lead going into Sunday's final round of the 89th United States Open.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: PORTLAND, ORE.;
Economy Spurs Building Plans
description: LEAD: WHILE apartment construction nationwide is on the wane, developers in Portland are engaged in a spurt of multifamily building prompted by rising rents, a reviving economy and a vacancy rate that fell below 3 percent in late 1988.

title: Liane Chamberlin to Wed T. H. French
description: Mr. and Mrs. John S. Chamberlin of Princeton, N.J., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Liane Helen Chamberlin and Timothy Hutchins French, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alden French Jr. of Annisquam, Mass.

title: A Verdi Soprano Treads Carefully In Career Moves
description: ''I was pretty scared. After all, he had been one of my heroes for a long time.'' The soprano Susan Dunn is recalling the first time she sang for Luciano Pavarotti, in the autumn of 1980. ''I suppose he heard potential, because he asked me to come and sing in his competition in the spring. My feet didn't touch the ground for a week!''

title: Jetliner Crashes off Runway In East Berlin and 17 Perish
description: An East German jetliner carrying 113 people veered into a field and caught fire today while trying to take off from East Berlin, killing at least 17 people, and injuring 39, the East German press agency reported.

title: Someone Who Knows Tha Even Graveyards Need Friends
description: A GRAVEYARD holds no terrors for Pat Miller. There are few places she would rather be.

title: Paying a Penalty for a Golden Parachute
description: Five years after Congress imposed a 20 percent excise tax on ''excessive'' golden parachutes, the Internal Revenue Service has finally issued proposed regulations explaining just how and when the tax should be applied.

title: Palestinian Killed in Gaza
description: A 20-year-old Palestinian died today after being shot in the neck by soldiers firing at stone-throwing Arabs in the occupied Gaza Strip, officials at a United Nations clinic said. An Israeli military spokesman said the report was being investigated. Palestinians identified the dead man as Ahram Sadat al-Hanuni of the town of Khan Yunis.

title: At Williamstown, a Search for a Vision THEATER; At Williamstown, a Search for a Vision
description: On an icy afternoon last January, several hundred of the country's best-known actors and directors gathered in the candle-lit darkness of the Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York. They were assembled to honor the memory of the fiery Greek director Nikos Psacharopoulos, who had died unexpectedly a few weeks before. Though the long service was filled with poignant reminiscences, tearful speeches and humorous anecdotes, no accolade brought more laughter or rang truer than the comments of the actor Richard Thomas: ''Right now Nikos is having a hard time casting his heavenly project of 'The Three Sisters,' because he's promised the same roles to all the divine actresses up there.''

title: Kander-Ebb Musicals Revisited
description: WHEN one could count on a modicum of new musicals a season, the scores and the shows of John Kander and Fred Ebb were often underrated. Such modest musicals as ''Flora, the Red Menace'' (1965, three months), ''The Happy Time'' (1966, nine months) and ''70, Girls, 70'' (1971, four weeks) had more than a fair share of melodic moments, fondly remembered.

title: Gorbachev Aide Warns of Rightist Reaction Ahead
description: An economist chosen to be one of the chief advisers in President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Government has warned that ''society will be destabilized'' and a rightward political swing will prove inevitable if the economy does not improve within the next two years.

title:
DINING OUT;
Eclectic Fare in a Former Firehouse
description: LEAD: THE engaging little Park Avenue Cafe in Rutherford came under new ownership last August, but the casual diner might not even have noticed much of a change. Imaginative, eclectic fare still issues from the kitchen, and a neighborhoody atmosphere is still the order at the restaurant, which is a few blocks off Route 3 just west of the

title: Amelia Hamill, Teacher, Weds
description: Amelia Richardson Hamill, the daughter of Mrs. Philip A. Litchfield of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and the late James L. Hamill 3d, was married yesterday to Timothy Balch Hopkins, a son of Elizabeth B. Hopkins of Westport, Conn., and the late Dwight D. Hopkins of Buffalo. The Rev. Dr. William E. Foley performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Susanne Schulte, Ph.D. Candidate, Becomes a Bride
description: Susanne J. Schulte, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry F. Schulte of Manlius, N.Y., was married yesterday to Bradford M. Firkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce J. Firkins of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Mark C. Ioset officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in Cazenovia, N.Y.

title: Miss Head Weds Matthew J. Smith
description: At the Madison (N.J.) Presbyterian Church, Leslie Ann Head, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn O. Head of Madison, was married yesterday to Matthew James Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Smith of Cedar Knolls, N.J. The Rev. Dr. William Bearden, the church's minister, officiated, assisted by the Rev. Charles J. Miller, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: 'The Living City'
description: To the Editor:

title: Schools and Asbestos: Law Posing Problems
description: SCHOOL districts across New Jersey may find it difficult to comply with Federal asbestos-management guidelines because of a shortage of experienced inspectors, management planners and contractors who remove asbestos, school and industry officials say.

title: Driver's Education For Paramedics
description: LEAD: IT happened so quickly that Glen Ostlund had no time to think. When a car pulled out in front of the ambulance he was driving, his reflexes took over to avoid a collision.

title: Chinese and Jewish Intermarriage
description: I am of Chinese descent and my husband is a nice Jewish boy from Rockaway Park. We seem to be part of an intermarriage boom, specifically between women of other religions and races married to Jewish men. Certainly the Chinese race and its heritage have been around just as long if not longer than the Jews. There is wealth of tradition from both sides that enriches our life together.

title: Dr. Denise Shapiro Weds
description: Dr. Denise Marie Shapiro and Dr. Martin Craig Nager, periodontists who practice, respectively, in Providence and Warwick, R.I., were married yesterday at Astors' Beechwood in Newport, R.I., by Rabbi Robert Miller. The bride, who will keep her name, is the daughter of Dr. Lewis Shapiro of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Mrs. Robert Mentzinger of Huntington, L.I. Dr. Nager is a son of David Nager of Weston, Mass., and Ellie Nager of Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: Dad's Helping Hand for an Apprentice
description: THE very thought of my reading any handyman's helper column is laughable. I know it. My wife and children know it. Anyone who has known me understands that. Whatever skills I may have, mechanical ones are not among them.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Let's Celebrate Dadhood, for a Change
description: LEAD: MOST men don't want to be fathers; they want to be Dads (as in, ''Hey, Dad, want to come out and shoot a few baskets?'') You can't blame them. For one thing, fathers have had a rotten press. Years ago fatherhood was invoked as a threat somewhat akin to the Black Plague. (''That's it - we're sending for your father.

title: A Meal That Takes Imagination, Not All Day
description: PLAYING culinary ''Beat the Clock'' has become part of the contemporary life style. Meeting the challenge of serveing presentable meals of honest, healthy food, without spending all day at it, takes imagination and timing.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Political Sunrises and Sunsets, and Thorns That Sting
description: Representative Tony Coelho stood on the lawn of the Capitol early Thursday morning, wired for one of a long string of interviews scheduled for this, his final day in Congress.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: DADDY BOY. By Carey Cameron. (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, $15.95.) No, ''Daddy Boy'' isn't about a kinky love affair. Instead, this first novel by Carey Cameron is a restrained, modestly engaging account of growing up rich and spoiled in Hollywood in the early 1960's. Ten-year-old Robin, the narrator, is the youngest of four children.

title: POSTINGS: Shopping in Piscataway; Plugging a Gap
description: Piscataway Township, a community of 45,000 people in New Jersey's Middlesex County about one hour's drive west of Manhattan, has in recent years been the site of an enormous commercial real estate boom. A dozen major corporations have moved offices into the area and collectively taken more than 5 million square feet of commercial space.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Last call to catch up and finish planting; seed vegetables in rows or set out plants; transplant annuals, perennials, shrubs to flower or shrub borders. Control insects when seen; stomping them under foot is always a good measure. Slugs are rampant; control with diatomaceous earth dust or sprinkle ashes or sand beneath favorite plants to prevent their crawling under them to feed. Spray again for control of black vine weevils. Move 'Em Out

title: PURSUED BY THEY
description: LEAD: LIFE WITH A STAR By Jiri Weil. Translated by Ruzena Kovarikova with Roslyn Schloss. Preface by Philip Roth. 208 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $22.95.

title: WHO'S TO JUDGE?
description: Hilary's case is indeed complex, but one thing is clear: there exists reasonable suspicion of her having been sexually abused by her father. To require unsupervised visitation in light of such suspicion is nothing less than a perversion of power and judgment, particularly when a less-detrimental alternative, in the form of supervised visits, may be taken. EMANUEL E. GARCIA, M.D. Philadelphia

title: Mob Leader's Slaying May Signal Power Struggle
description: The murder of the man reported to be the most important mobster in Connecticut and the attempted murder of another reputed mob leader hours later in Massachusetts may be the first salvos in a power struggle in the Patriarca crime family of New England, law-enforcement authorities said yesterday.

title: HIS MOTHER AND HER MURDERER
description: A DEATH IN ZAMORA By Ramon Sender Barayon. Illustrated. 196 pp. Albuquerque: University of New Mexico Press. $19.95.

title: Shelby Wyckoff And A. G. Binger Exchange Vows
description: Shelby Lawrence Wyckoff, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clinton Randolph Wyckoff 3d of Buffalo, was married yesterday to Andrew Garrison Binger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Garrison Binger of Plainfield, N.H., and Little Compton, R.I. The Rev. Ralph E. Merrill officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church on Fishers Island, N.Y.

title: T. C. Savage Wed To Daisy Douglas
description: Edith Wayne Douglas and Thomas Charles Savage were married yesterday at the Lawrenceville, N.J., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Douglas 3d. The Rev. Daphne Hawkes, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Grave Scandal for Greece
description: Threatening to bring down the Government of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou is the gravest political and financial scandal to sweep Greece in the postwar era.

title: House Was Untidy, But It Wasn't Vacant
description: Officials seeking to enforce a town cleanup ordinance recently broke into a couple's home while they were out of town and threw out or gave away their belongings because the officials thought the house was vacant.

title: Question Of the Week; What's Wrong With The Mets?
description: Davey Johnson. An American League-type manager mishandling great National League talent. ASHER B. ETKES New York

title: PRESSURES RISING FOR POLISH PARTY
description: Poland's Communist Party faces difficult decisions over what to do after its crushing setback in this month's national elections.

title: Federal Computers And Right to Know
description: The Government's shift to storing information in computers instead of on paper is causing a growing number of legal scholars to say the public faces new obstacles when seeking access to Federal documents.

title: THE WHOLE TOWN WAS MOLESTED
description: LEAD: ''DOC'' The Rape of the Town of Lovell. By Jack Olsen. 479 pp. New York: Atheneum. $19.95

title: DATA UPDATE
At Norfolk, A Showcase for Masters and Novices
description: THE Norfolk Chamber Music Festival is not only a long-established summer festival played amid the beautiful setting of the Ellen Battell Stoeckel Estate on Route 44, but it also a training center for outstanding young musicians. Officially, it is the Yale Summer School of Music, and a number of student recitals supplement the regular weekend recitals by faculty members and guest musicians.

title: Jennifer Pennoyer Weds Raymond Emerson 2d
description: Jennifer Frances Pennoyer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul G. Pennoyer Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I., was married there yesterday at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church to Raymond Emerson 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Emerson of Elizabeth City, N.C., and Naushon Island, Woods Hole, Mass. The Rev. William D. Dobbins Jr. officiated.

title: The National Finals, Las Vegas
description: After months of roping calves and breaking broncs at hundreds of smaller rodeos all over the country, the best and toughest riders and bulls of the rodeo circuit converge on Las Vegas in December for the National Finals Rodeo.

title: Low-Budget Films Use L.I. as a Set
description: LEAD: WHILE Michael Caine, Meryl Streep and Roseanne Barr are making major movies on Long Island, many low-budget films have also recently been shot on the Island. Industry analysts attribute the increase in low-budget movies to the 22-week writers' strike last year that halted some movies and television programs.

title: Social Events
description: Harlem Dance Celebrates

title: Miss Slaughter Becomes Bride
description: Leslie Brown Slaughter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. Slaughter of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to John Singleton Needham, the son of Mrs. Robert C. Ferris and Richard H. Needham, both of Chicago. The Rev. Michael A. Pearson officiated at St. Mark's Episcopal Church.

title: BASEBALL: Chasing Records, Game by Game; Maris's Mark Remains Elusive
description: When Kevin Mitchell hit his 23d home run for the San Francisco Giants nine days ago, he prompted a rush to everyone's baseball reference shelf. There, in the Elias record book, on page 382, instant researchers found that Mitchell was one game ahead of Roger Maris's 61-home run pace in 1961.

title: Poetic Innovation
description: To the Editor:

title: Hospitals Hurrying to Meet New Regulations on Residencies
description: Hospitals in New York State, hurrying to meet a July 1 deadline, are trying to put into practice new state regulations governing how many hours residents may work and how they are supervised.

title: Priscilla Bondy and Joel E. Dube Exchange Vows
description: At the Radisson Hotel in Burlington, Vt., Priscilla Bondy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene L. Bondy Jr. of Mamaroneck, N.Y., and Joel E.
