Dube, a son of Mrs. Simeon Dube and the late Mr. Dube of Madawaska, Me., were married yesterday by Judge Elizabeth Gretkowski, the Chitenden (Vt.) County Assistant Judge.

title: The Television Politicians Rise In Congress, Too
description: THE torch was passed on Capitol Hill last week not just to a new generation of Congressional leaders, but to a profoundly different sort of legislator, tempered by a new and highly personal style of politics and disciplined by television's demand for concise and biting messages.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Dog Day

title: Westchester a Target in Asia Society Drive
description: LEAD: THE Asia Society, pointing to the strong Westchester membership in the Manhattan-based cultural organization, is targeting county residents in its latest fund-raising effort.

title: Watch Steffi; Watch Wayne
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ames Colt Wed To Miss Emmons
description: Elizabeth Harley Emmons, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Beale Emmons 3d of South Salem, N.Y., was married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Lime Rock, Conn., to Ames Borden Colt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Beeber Colt of Little Compton, R.I. The Rev. William S. Holcomb performed the ceremony. Mrs. Colt graduated from the Darrow School and Skidmore College. Her father is a national sales manager at Fieldcrest Cannon in New York.

title: A Gracious Japanese Ritual to Prepare for Tea
description: For more than a year, a peculiar structure has taken shape in this Hudson River community a short drive south of from the George Washington Bridge. Built around a 10-ton lava rock from Japan and surrounded on three sides by water, the low building capped by a generous skylight would look more at home on a serene lake in the mountains than facing the towers that punctuate the Manhattan skyline.

title: A Look at the Men Who Would Be Deng
description: Sometime in the coming days or weeks, China is likely to present to the world a new face as its Communist Party leader, an individual who will be charged with rebuilding domestic and foreign support for the party following its military crackdown and internal purges.

title: A Father Remembered
description: The little girl, almost 5, handed out tissues to a roomful of tearful adults. She was happy to have so many relatives and neighbors gathered in her apartment on the edge of Harlem. But she couldn't understand why so many of them were crying. She heard the word ''funeral'' several times, and she knew that her father was missing. But it took a long time before she understood he wouldn't be back.

title: Towns Levy Fines for False Alarms
description: IF a Greenwich resident returns home late at night and trips his burglar alarm while trying to enter his house, it may cost him more than an embarrassing explanation to the police.

title: The Two Fathers I Have Known
description: BY the time I was 35, I had buried two fathers. One I feared. The other, I loved from a distance. The one I feared - the one whose genes I carry - was an alcoholic. I don't ever remember feeling close to him even when I was close to him. His life was a war, and whenever I was with him, I was involved in a skirmish.

title: Forgotten Soldiers: A Footnote
description: The article by Joseph G. Bilby, ''A Salute to Forgotten Soldiers'' (Opinion page, May 28), is yet another indication of how significant people never make it to the history books. While the role of women has also been slighted, it seems to me that blacks have been almost totally ignored.

title: NONFICTION
description: LOVE OR HONOR. By Joan Barthel. (Morrow, $17.95.) For devotees of cop tales and mob lore, few situations are as tantalizing as that of the undercover police officer, who struggles to keep from becoming what he is impersonating, ever edgy that his cover will be blown, unable to confide in family or friends. Chris Anastos, of the New York City police, lived that life for nearly five years. He was such a convincing ''wiseguy,'' or mob soldier, that he wound up having Sunday dinner every week at the home of a Long Island capo - and ended up in a love affair with the man's daughter. This was no simple story, and Mr. Anastos was no simple character. When he reluctantly accepted the undercover job, he was 33 years old, happily married to a professional singer and determined to earn his gold detective's shield through buy-and-bust arrests with the narcotics squad. By the time the assignment ended, he was physically ravaged by alcohol and cigarettes, unable to sleep without lights on, a stranger to his wife and incapable of informing on the mobster who regarded him as a future son-in-law. ''Love or Honor,'' by Joan Barthel, whose previous books include ''A Death in Canaan'' and ''A Death in California,'' is told entirely from Mr. Anastos' viewpoint, with extended segments of reconstructed dialogue. It is not clear whether any names have been changed. We never learn the last name of John, the capo who took on Mr. Anastos as his chauffeur, or of Marty, John's daughter, who never discovered her lover's true identity. Mr. Anastos emerges as a tarnished hero who wins his gold shield, but loses life as he knew it. Two lives, really.

title: There's a Hammering of Mallets As Artists Gather in the Studio
description: SEBASTINO MINEO envisioned a ''Left Bank'' atmosphere when he established the Art Life Studio in North White Plains five years ago. It would be a place where artists could come, as in old-time Paris, to ''develop their own theories and express their personalities,'' the 71-year-old painter and sculptor said.

title: WHO'S TO JUDGE?
description: A false accusation of parental sexual abuse can do as much damage to a family as sexual abuse itself. Therefore, an accusation of this type must be treated, in the absence of clear evidence to support it, with considerable skepticism. A parent in a custody battle cannot be allowed to undermine a court order merely by bringing unsubstantiated charges. That would lead to anarchy. Dr. Morgan should stay in jail. ROBERT J. YAES, M.D. Lexington, Ky.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; A Complex Permitting 'Aging in Place'
description: IN the Mystic area of Stonington, next door to the Hilton Hotel and across the street from the Marinelife Aquarium, a $60 million project called Maritime Park is under construction, offering varied living accommodations for people over 55.

title: 'The Life of Graham Greene: Volume One: 1904-1939'
description: Graham Greene's many masterly fictions have entertained and inspired readers the world over for half a century. (One can only speculate on the politics that have denied him a Nobel Prize in literature.) His personal story brings to mind a number of the stories he has written - a tireless ever-watchful wanderer, an ironist, a materialist, a rationalist, eager always for new experiences but deep down hoping against hope for the promised calm and rest that comes with the gift of faith.

title: Spielberg's Elixir Shows Signs Of Mature Magic
description: It is one of the anomalies of this liberated era, when virtually nothing is taboo on screen, that the best of our mass-market movies are now children's films, at least those children's film that, as a kind of bonus, can also be enjoyed by adults. ''Who Framed Roger Rabbit'' was last year's exemplar.

title: FICTION
description: CATAPULT: A Timetable of Rail, Sea, and Air Ways to Paradise. By Vladimir Paral. Translated by William Harkins. (Catbird Press, 44 North Sixth Avenue, Highland Park, N.J. 08904, $15.95.) Jacek Jost, a 33-year-old chemical engineer, husband and father, hates his dull but comfortable suburban existence. He feels suffocated by his work, his marriage, even his child, and wants to escape them all, yet he can't bring himself to do it. Then one day, as he is riding home from work, his commuter train suddenly jerks to a stop and Jost is hurled into the lap of a young woman, with whom he proceeds to have an affair. So begins this hilarious and tragic novel. Originally written in 1967, it is the first work by the acclaimed Czechoslovak writer Vladimir Paral to be published in English, in a skillful if at times too literal translation by William Harkins. Jost eventually finds seven lovers, each in a different town along his train route, and spends his days traveling from one to another. Each mistress offers an alternative life, and Jost might have any of them if only he could choose. But he can't. Instead, he's trapped by his neuroses and his chronic ambivalence. Unable to take any decisive action, he tries to force others to catapult him into change - by trying to get fired, for example, or to make his wife divorce him. But his efforts are always frustrated, and usually in comic fashion. Yet ultimately ''Catapult'' is a serious book. Mr. Paral masterfully switches from farce to drama and back again, so that in the end we feel Jost's dilemma even as we're laughing at him.

title: Sewage Plant: Unwelcome Neighbor
description: Although fairly reported, ''Nassau Studying Sludge as Filler'' (May 28) did not discuss, and only casually touched upon, the negative environmental and economic impact on the communities adjoining the Bay Park Sewage Treatment Plant.

title: African Conference Rejects An OPEC for the Ivory Trade
description: An African environment conference rejected a call today for an OPEC-type system to control supplies of ivory as an alternative to a global trading ban. Efforts for an ivory ban have won support from the United States, the European Community and Japan. The Soviet Union said it is considering support for a ban.

title: Berwick
description: To the Editor: Berwick-upon-Tweed (Letters on Travel, April 2) is in England, not Scotland. Though it is virtually on the border and has shifted back and forth between the two countries 13 times, it has been part of England (its northernmost town) since 1482. Berwick is indeed worth visiting, if only for the sight of those three long, magnificent, history-spanning bridges. JOAN H. ROTH ELI B. ROTH Southbury, Conn.

title: China Seeks a Party Leader
description: China is likely to present a new face as Communist Party leader, someone who will have to rebuild support for the party. Page 12.

title: Germany Is Basking in New Central Role
description: If the chant out in the streets during Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit was ''Gorby! Gorby!'' the word more often heard in well-appointed German offices was ''Fuhrungsrolle,'' the new ''leadership role'' that seemed to be settling on Bonn.

title: Cowboy Decor, in Boot, Spur and Horn
description: WHEN Roxanne Thurman and Judy Trattner opened Crybaby Ranch in Denver last year, the search for cowboy and Western furnishings and gewgaws for their store took Ms. Thurman back to her hometown of Littlefield in West Texas. To her dismay she could find none of the things that had decorated every rural Texas house in her childhood - no lamps made from cowboy boots, no chenille curtains with Western scenes, no spur ashtrays. Nor were there any thick desert-colored dinner plates rimmed in cattle brands, wagon wheel tables or boxy vinyl couches with embroidered steers.

title: Stephanie Cabot Becomes the Wife Of a Developer
description: The marriage of Stephanie Mariette Cabot, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Powell M. Cabot of Greenwich, Conn., to Marcus Lovell-Smith, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Lovell-Smith of Taunton, Somerset, England, took place yesterday at St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich. The Rev. Peter Dora performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. Beats Guatemala to Become No. 2
description: There are more glamorous places to play soccer, but perhaps none as important to the United States as this small southern New England town, one of the stops on the road to Italy next year. And although the Americans were reluctant to admit it, a defeat on home turf today probably would have cost them a trip to the World Cup, a trip that the United States has not made since 1950.

title: AIDS Experts Oppose Plan From Koch Commissioner
description: A group of AIDS experts told Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday that they opposed his Health Commissioner's call for more AIDS testing and mandatory tracing of people who had sex or shared needles with those infected.

title: Danielle G. Jerry To Marry in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Jerry Jr. of Albany and Speculator, N.Y., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Danielle Guerin Jerry and Robert Michael Platte, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George William Platte of Marne, Mich.

title: Vallauris
description: To the Editor: In her article on Vallauris (Travel, Feb. 22) Ruth Robinson has done a remarkable job sifting wheat from chaff. Nowhere in my broad experience of travel have I seen more junk per square inch offered to unwary tourists. One wonders what the French think of travelers - that they leave their taste at home?

title: Father's Day: Secrets of the Heart
description: LEAD: My late father was uncomfortable with Father's Day.

title: The High-Stakes Battle for Airline Reservations
description: One of the fiercest battles in the ceaseless competition among airlines is the fight to control the marketing of tickets through computer networks that allow travel agents to instantaneously make reservations.

title: The U.S. Starts to Deal Again on Arms Control
description: AFTER a review of national security questions, the United States has begun to re-engage the Soviet Union on a broad front of arms control issues.

title: HE CARED ABOUT GOOD CEMENT
description: ARCHITECTS OF FORTUNE Mies van der Rohe and the Third Reich. By Elaine S. Hochman. Illustrated. 382 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $22.50.

title: Reviews/Dance; The Turbulent Life of a French Poet
description: Peter Reed's ''Absent Moon,'' presented Wednesday night at the Kitchen, serves as a reminder that art and life are not the same. The poems - especially the hallucinatory prose-poems - of Arthur Rimbaud rank among the glories of 19th-century French literature.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Bangkok Hotels Agree to Hold Line on Rates

title: Drug Ad Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wizardry That Makes the Most of the Music
description: A composer may be the new Beethoven, but how is a listener to know it if a performer doesn't make sense of the music?

title: Jennifer A. Stone To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Stone Jr. of Middletown and Madison, Conn., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Jennifer Appleton Stone, and Jeffrey Weightman Potter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Winslow Potter of Woodbury, Conn.

title:
CRACKDOWN IN CHINA;
Did Deng, a Bridge Lover, Bid While Tanks Rolled?
description: LEAD: Last week, it was rumored that China's senior leader, Deng Xiaoping, was competing in a Beijing bridge tournament at the same time that his soldiers were violently suppressing the pro-democracy movement.

title: AIDS: THE YOUNGEST VICTIMS
description: THERE IS ONE QUESTION, says the social worker, that comes up with every mother.

title: Haggadah Withdrawn From Auction
description: A rare French medieval Haggadah manuscript said to have been stolen several years ago from the Jewish Historical Institute of Warsaw, was withdrawn Friday from the auction that Habsburg, Feldman is to hold tomorrow night in Geneva.

title: Charity Begins at H.U.D.?
description: Of all the people who may have raided the larder at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, probably none had a more interesting motive than Marilyn Louise Harrell. Ms. Harrell, who has admitted taking $5.5 million over a three-year period, was dubbed ''Robin HUD'' after she said she gave most of the money to charity - although that remains uncertain. ''I justified my actions inwardly only by reminding myself that I followed a higher law in an attempt to ease suffering,'' she said last week in an appearance before a House panel looking into the H.U.D. scandal. She said she was testifying against the advice of her lawyer and was seeking ''no leniency or immunity from prosecution.'' Nevertheless, one Congressman advised her, ''If anybody should take the Fifth Amendment, it's you, ma'am.''

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
The Intricacies Of Wisteria Control
description: LEAD: This is rather like going off to war or existing through the development of a recalcitrant teen-ager. The wisteria is a powerful, rampant and formidable opponent. It is a woody vine with the potential ability to overwhelm everything in its path. In nature, wisteria runs through tree tops and covers an enormous area.

title: Children Shooting Children: Move Is On for Gun Control
description: Five Florida children have been shot, two fatally, in accidents with their parents' guns in the last two weeks, setting off an emotional debate in this state, which has long opposed tightening of gun controls.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about ABC's ''Wonder Years'' in some copies of the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday incorrectly characterized the date on which the series had its premiere. The premiere followed the Super Bowl, not the Rose Bowl.

title:
GARDENING;
When Plants Poison Their Neighbors
description: LEAD: A SURE sign of trouble is a shrinking rhododendron. This seems to happen when rhododendrons are planted near walnut trees. The culprit is juglone, a substance produced by the walnut and released into the soil, and this phenomenon is called allelopathy.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate Gas Decontrol: Vote on a bill to remove price controls on natural gas. Approved 82 to 17, June 14. (The House passed a similar bill in April on a voice vote.) $ Connecticut Dodd (D) Y Lieberman (D) N New Jersey Bradley (D) N Lautenberg (D) N New York D'Amato (R) Y Moynihan (D) Y House 1. title: A HOMEGROWN VIEW
description: Decorators frequently talk about the ''bones'' of a room - the architectural framework around which they can create a suitable environment. Gardens have ''bones,'' too. Indeed, the walls, trees, borders and pergolas that outline a property are as important to a landscape as beautiful proportions are to an interior.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: WEARE, N.H.;
High Enders Welcomed
description: LEAD: A SUBDIVISION of homes priced well beyond the town's normal housing market has been started by a developer here and local officials see it as an example of what they would like the town to become.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE POWER GAME: How Washington Works, by Hedrick Smith. (Ballantine, $5.95.) Because of Congressional reforms, the advent of political action committees, the proliferation of lobbyists and the ever more pervasive forum provided by television, power in Washington has become fractured into hundreds of centers, each hard-pressed to garner enough influence to get things done. ''Most of this very long book is . . . an effort to explain how the new game is played,'' Alan Brinkley said here last year. ''It is knowledgeable and informative. And it is often highly entertaining, filled with enough inside information and spicy anecdotes to satisfy even the most jaded political junkie.'' BAD BEHAVIOR, by Mary Gaitskill. (Vintage, $7.95.) For the unhappy people in these matter-of-fact stories, there is nothing very remarkable about sadomasochism. The world, after all, is a painful place. Why should it be any different in bed? ''Remember the late stories of John O'Hara?'' our reviewer, George Garrett, said last year. ''How well he used the shock of sexual perversity as the central revelation? Here we go a step further. It is never revelation, just another quality in the cumulative discovery of character. Wise beyond her years, utterly unsentimental, Mary Gaitskill is at once ruthlessly objective and sympathetic.'' HAING NGOR: A Cambodian Odyssey, by Haing Ngor with Roger Warner. (Warner, $12.95.) The Cambodian doctor who played Dith Pran in the movie ''The Killing Fields'' and won an Academy Award tells how he himself suffered under the Khmer Rouge. Last year our reviewer, Rod Nordland, called this ''a book of punishing introspection. . . . This is a thoughtful, well-educated man, reduced to slavery and suffering, who never fails to bring his intelligence to bear on the events around him.'' SUCH GOOD FRIENDS, by Lois Gould. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $6.95.) As she waits loyally at her husband's deathbed, Julie Messinger discovers that his life was a marathon bout of promiscuity - and that he recorded the sordid details in a diary written in code. When Lois Gould's first novel was published in 1970, our reviewer, W. G. Rogers, called it ''witty, scintillating, peppery and fast-paced,'' though he wasn't sure readers under 18 should be admitted. Farrar, Straus & Giroux is also republishing four other Gould novels. In LA PRESIDENTA ($8.95), Rosa Andujar, a woman who seems a lot like Eva Peron, uses myth and magic to rule an imaginary Latin American land. ''Rosa Andujar is an extraordinary creation, fierce and gentle,'' Jerome Charyn said here in 1981. ''But the novel that surrounds her doesn't have Rosa's strengths.'' In A SEA-CHANGE ($6.95), a former model flees to a remote island after she is raped in her New York apartment and embarks on a strange new life. In 1976, our reviewer, Anne Tyler, called Ms. Gould's ''crisply written'' book ''a bizarre fantasy about one mild woman transformed by rage.'' FINAL ANALYSIS ($6.95), published in 1974, is about a journalist who has an affair with her former analyst, and it's not clear who is analyzing whom. One reviewer described the novel as ''a slick romance . . . which is occasionally quite funny.'' In NECESSARY OBJECTS ($7.95), four rich sisters, heiresses to a department store fortune, engage in sexual exploits and power plays worthy of the people on ''Dynasty.'' The sisters ''are horrible people, and their author depicts them here pitilessly and with an almost ferocious relish,'' Sara Blackburn said in The Book Review in 1972. LONGING FOR THE HARMONIES: Themes and Variations From Modern Physics, by Frank Wilczek and Betsy Devine. (Norton, $9.95.) With the mad confusion of subatomic particles and quasars, pulsars and black holes, the music of the spheres sometimes seems more like Stockhausen than Brahms; but beneath it all, physicists like to think, there is a subtle, enduring order. ''Mr. Wilczek and Ms. Devine describe the current research into their universe, and many of the researchers, with zest and humor,'' David Perlman said here last year. ''And if their descriptions at times demand a lay reader's closest attention and thought, the effort is immensely worthwhile.'' WHAT IS IT THEN BETWEEN US? by Ehud Havazelet. (Collier/Macmillan, $7.95.) When this first book of short stories about urban life was published last year, The Times's Michiko Kakutani said Ehud Havazelet is ''an agile ventriloquist, practiced at throwing his voice and making it emerge convincingly from a wide variety of characters. . . . He is also the owner of that rarer gift of sympathy, an unsentimental compassion for bruised and disordered lives.'' FLANAGAN'S VERSION: A Spectator's Guide to Science on the Eve of the 21st Century, by Dennis Flanagan. (Vintage, $8.95.) After spending 35 years as editor of Scientific American, Dennis Flanagan learned that science is the greatest spectator sport of all. Last year our reviewer, James Trefil, called this book ''a raconteur's ramble along the highways and byways of modern science. . . . Mr. Flanagan's descriptions occasionally rise to the level of poetry.'' THE SHIFTING POINT: 1946-1987, by Peter Brook. (Bessie/Perennial/Harper & Row, $9.95.) When this collection of essays was published in 1987, our reviewer, Francis King, said the director Peter Brook is the ''most original and creative theoretician'' of the theater. ''There is hardly a piece [ here ] that does not have something fascinating to say - not merely to those who look to the theater for their livelihood, but to those who go to it for enjoyment, instruction and, above all, for the 'interest' that, in his final essay, Mr. Brook interprets as taking in all those aspects of living that are directly related to essential questions of being and becoming.''

title: Slurs and Snickering Over, Greeks Are Set for a Vote That Might Surprise
description: By the laws of normal political logic, many Greeks say, Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou should be looking for a place to build his retirement home.

title:
THE TALK OF SAG HARBOR;
Sag Harbor Clings to Its Quaintness
description: LEAD: TWO hundred years ago, George Washington designated Sag Harbor as an official port of entry. This tiny village on the East End was later to become the center of a thriving whaling industry.

title: Molly T. Baldrige Marries Kerry Kring
description: Molly Trowbridge Baldrige, a daughter of Margaret Murray Baldrige of Woodbury, Conn., and Claunch, N.M., and the late Malcolm Baldrige, was married yesterday to Kerry Allan Kring, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Kring of Santa Maria, Calif. Judge Roxanne Bailin of the Boulder (Colo.) County Court officiated at the couple's home in Hygiene, Colo.

title: Mimi Ellis Weds C. M. Storey
description: Marie-Armide Longer Ellis, a daughter of Mrs. John Adams Blanchard of Needham, Mass., and Dr. F. Henry Ellis Jr. of Brookline, Mass., and Seal Harbor, Me., was married yesterday to Charles Mills Storey, the son of Mrs. Charles Moorfield Storey Jr. of Essex, Mass., and the late Dr. Storey. The Rev. W. Earl Mullins performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Dedham, Mass.

title: WHO'S TO JUDGE?
description: My heart goes out to little Hilary. I hope she is living a peaceful life somewhere, free from the intrusion of experts. She is the only one who really knows if she was sexually abused by her father. If she was, I expect she will spend the rest of her life trying to come to grips with that fact, as well as the fact that the details of her experience have been made public. However, she will have one thing going for her that most survivors of incest do not: she will know that her mother did everything possible to protect her. MELISSA GOODMAN Brooklyn

title: Personal Sampling
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; At Storm King, Sculpture Amid Green Galleries
description: There is no disputing which sculpture among the 130 at the Storm King Art Center is the favorite among children. Youngsters race up the hill to the right of the museum building and play king of the mountain on the nine granite boulders that constitute Isamu Noguchi's ''Momo Taro.''

title: One Run Is Enough For Mets
description: The Mets, who scored 15 runs in their last game, scored just one tonight. But, in its own way, it was enough because Bob Ojeda gave the best pitching performance of the season for the Mets and stopped the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: No Solos In TV Journalism
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. Seeks to Learn if Polluter Got Grant to Help Clean Toxic Wastes
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is seeking to determine whether a grant, intended to help a community polluted by toxic waste to participate in the cleanup process, went instead to a group that includes the polluter.

title: Bachelors on Parade, Lions on the Prowl And a Birthday Fete
description: Jerome Robbins's 70th birthday was celebrated with some high stepping at the New York City Ballet's spring gala June 8. Dinner and dancing were on the promenade of the New York State Theater. Monday was another festive night at Lincoln Center, at the branch of the New York Public Library, where ''Lions of the Performing Arts'' were honored. Ballet dancers and choreographers topped the list, which included actors, musicians and composers. Everyone, it seemed, took a turn on the floor.

title: STREETSCAPES: Kodak's Colorama; The End of the Line for Grand Central's Big Picture
description: IN any other place the Kodak Colorama sign in Grand Central Terminal would be a preservation issue. Since 1950 the huge transparency has refreshed and startled millions of urban travelers with its stupendous color views of whitewater rafting, Alpine idylls, farm scenes and family groups.

title: Harriet Morse Smith Becomes Bride Of Guy Richards Riegel, Stockbroker
description: Harriet Morse Smith, the daughter of Harriet Sturgis Walker of Beverly Farms, Mass., and Forrester Clark Smith of Tenants Harbor, Me., was married yesterday in Manchester, Mass., to Guy Richards Riegel, a son of Susan Richards Little of Laurel Hollow, L.I., and William Murchie Riegel of Memphis and Duxbury, Mass. The ceremony at the First Parish Congregational Church was performed by the Rev. John Hughes, the church's minister, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Alexander S. Daley, an Episcopal priest.

title: Language
description: To the Editor: The article on foreign language brought back memories of several trips with my young sons, Ray and Mike, during ski trips.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: TIBETAN SINGING BOWLS The Tibetan Singing Bowl Ensemble is neither Tibetan nor particularly vocal. The group of nine Manhattan-based musicians performs new American music on old instruments from Tibet, and it will do so at 8 P.M. Wednesday in the Armor Hall of Wave Hill. Marking the summer solstice, the longest day of the year, the concert will be lighted by candles after twilight.

title: Getting the Very Best Table
description: A NEW YORK magazine recently ran a feature on the heartbreak of not getting a good table at fancy restaurants like Lutece and ''21.''

title: Correction
description: An article on the Opinion page last Sunday about the safety of Long Island's water supply misidentified the author and his affiliation. He is Norman E. Murrell, not Mussell, of the H2M Group, a company that monitors the Island's drinking water.

title: Question Of the Week; What's Wrong With The Mets?
description: This year Met fans have been victimized by dull, lethargic, lackluster baseball since spring training. In comparison, the 1986 Mets had a never-say-die attitude that led them to numerous comeback victories. In 1989, it seems like no lead is safe for very long.

title: Rookie Shines as Yanks Top Texas
description: The moment that made the night came in the sixth inning, when Dallas Green, the Yankee manager, was ejected from the game in one swift motion by Umpire Dale Scott. Green stalked across the infield grass, kicked up a clump of mud when he reached the Yankee dugout, then threw his cap against the dugout wall.

title: Seeing Buffalo at Close Range
description: LEAD: A SHAGGY, burly buffalo, symbol of the American West, sauntered across the mountain road with only a glance at me, like a confident actor on the stage. He rolled in the dust to rub off his shabby winter fur and then kicked up his heels and twirled like a feisty pony.

title: Clare C. Franklin Weds Lieutenant
description: Clare Carruthers Franklin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin A. Franklin of Garrett Park, Md., was married yesterday to Second Lieut. Victor V. Duran U.S.A., the son of Victor Duran Acosima of Mexico City and Janice Duran of Potomac, Md. The Rev. Thomas B. Allen performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Bethlehem Chapel of the Washington Cathedral.

title: Videos With a Record Connection . . .
description: In the battle for shelf space in video outlets, bigger - big films from big companies - is better, so it's unusual to see some high ground seized by a smaller distributor with some decidedly rarefied titles. Early next month, Kultur Home Video, a purveyor of performing-arts cassettes, will release two videos of the Kirov Ballet of Leningrad, which will begin a United States tour (its first in 25 years) at the Metropolitan Opera on July 3. The Kirov tapes (highlights from several ballets at $29.95; ''Don Quixote'' at $39.95) will be at Tower and other video stores. They will also be upfront in Tower record stores.

title: Heather Ann Egan Is Married to Thomas Leeds
description: Heather Ann Egan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond R. Egan of Whitestone, Queens, and Thomas V. Leeds, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Leeds Jr. of Brookville and Southampton, L.I., were married yesterday by Msgr. Edmond J. Trench at Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary Roman Catholic Church in Southampton.

title: Tribes Gather for a Rodeo and a Powwow
description: LEAD: The Crow Fair is one-of-a-kind rodeo, an event that blends a traditional Plains Indians celebration and an all-Indian rodeo on the Crow Indian Reservation in southeastern Montana. The fair runs from Aug. 16 to 20.

title: Florida Mystery Is Fueled By Intrigues and 4 Deaths
description: With a briefcase full of papers, Jacob F. Horton, the senior vice president of the Gulf Power Company, took off for Atlanta in a corporate jet here in April to talk with corporate officials about possible theft, payoffs and cover-ups that are under investigation by a Federal grand jury.

title: Kathleen Lowden Wed
description: Kathleen Louise Lowden, an associate in the law firm of Davis & Gilbert, and Paul Evans Davison, a trial lawyer with the Legal Aid Society, both in Manhattan, were married yesterday at the Reformed Church in New Paltz, N.Y. The Rev. Howard Major officiated. The bride, who will keep her name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lowden of Fallbrook, Calif. She is a graduate of New York University. She and her husband, a graduate of Harvard University, received their law degrees from N.Y.U. Mr. Davison is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald L. Davison of Clintondale, N.Y.

title: Wrangling Over Where Rodeo Began
description: THE question seems simple enough: who put on America's first rodeo? But at least a century after the fact, the issue has been transformed into one of America's great bragging wars. No one may ever know for sure which dusty Western cattle town really had the first rodeo, but rodeo's centennial has had at least three different celebrations in the last few years, each with its own claim to frontier immortality.

title: A Family Savors Its 60-Year Tradition
description: LEAD: BRICCETTI'S Bedford Market first opened for business 60 years ago, the dream of its immigrant founder, Tito Briccetti. It turned out to be on the eve of the Great Depression. But the store developed a reputation for service and high-quality meats and survived, even in the leanest years.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: Wrought in Glass, Variations on a Presidential Theme
description: Eagles embellish the rims of footed glass compotes. They ornament the bodies of decanters. They decorate vases, tumblers, sugar bowls and water bottles. They stand poised above wind-whipped banners bearing the nation's motto, ''E Pluribus Unum.'' They grace the clear, frosted and tinted - red, green and blue - glass vessels, enriched with cutting, engraving and swirls of gilding.

title: Prospects; Doing Business in China
description: In the aftermath of the violent crackdown on the democracy movement in China, moderates appeared on television to reassure the nation that there would be no purges. The Government also said that China's economic reforms would continue. But the dramatic change in China has caused concern among American business leaders who have invested there. Four experts on Chinese-American business relations assess the situation. Gerald R. Pike Vice president and principal, Royal Silk Ltd.

title: Holmes Tuttle, 83, of Reagan's 'Kitchen Cabinet'
description: Holmes P. Tuttle, a California automobile dealer who was a longtime adviser to former President Ronald Reagan, died Friday at Cottage Hospital in Montecito, Calif. He was 83 years old and lived in Santa Barbara.

title: 1986 AMNESTY LAW IS SEEN AS FAILING TO SLOW ALIEN TIDE
description: The most sweeping effort to halt illegal immigration in American history, the 1986 overhaul of immigration law, may have cut the flow of illegal aliens less than expected and may have actually encouraged unlawful entry in several ways.

title: How to Get the Best Rate For Your Dollar Overseas
description: IT looks like it may be a summer of dollar volatility, which for travelers can mean exchange-rate anxiety.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE CHALK DOLL By Charlotte Pomerantz. Illustrated by Frane Lessac. 31 pp. New York: J. B. Lippincott. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8) TELL ME A STORY, MAMABy Angela Johnson. ILlustrated by David Soman. Unpaged. New York: Orchard Books/Franklin Watts. $13.95. (Ages 3 to 6)

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: ''Locals'' are stamps used to pay for mail services offered by unofficial carriers, usually in remote areas. Such services are often slighted by government postal authorities because they do not pay for themselves.

title: Moving to New League: Switch-Hitters and Switch-Pitchers
description: Whenever a player who has struggled in the National League goes to the American League and performs well, National League chauvinists, who have a superiority complex, immediately cite the experience as further evidence of their claim that their league is better. They behave similarly when a good American League player switches leagues and plays poorly.

title: Kngghts of the Range
description: THERE are many would-be inheritors of the knight-errant mantle. A lot of fictional private eyes think they are modern-day Lancelots. Some motorcycle cops, wearing their visored helmets and riding steel horses, believe they are latter-day knights. But perhaps the group with the best claim on the title are the cowboys, the knights of the range.

title: New Jersey's Legislators Peer Into a Half-Billion Budget Gap
description: The New Jersey Senate and Assembly are in sharp disagreement over how to close a budget gap estimated at between $500 million and $800 million in time for the budget year that starts July 1.

title: Five Myths About National Security
description: LEAD: In this time of transition, it is important to examine carefully the premises that underlie our policies. Unfortunately, several myths distort public debate on national security.

title: Minnesota Homesteading at End
description: Koochiching County, northern Minnesota, is withdrawing its offer of free land to homesteaders because of complaints from longtime residents of the areas involved and various legal and financial snags.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Tantalizing Idea in a Triple Bill
description: ALTHOUGH three two-character plays constitute ''American Shorts '89'' at the Passage Theater Company here through next Sunday, things do not get cracking until the aptly titled ''A Tantalizing'' by William Mastrosimone, Trenton's native playwright, takes the stage after the intermission.

title:
FOCUS: Baltimore's Affluent Homeowners Rebel at Tax Rate;
Rising Property Values Trouble Other Cities, Too
description: LEAD: A tax revolt bloomed here this spring, creating fear in city leaders accustomed to promoting the rebirth of the Inner Harbor and its connecting downtown areas.

title: Violence In a Man's World
description: WE WERE TALKING, my old classmate and I, about the case of Lisa Bianco. She, you may remember, was the battered Indiana woman who finally, after hundreds of attacks, succeeded in having her ex-husband put in prison, only to be murdered by him on a brief furlough.

title: 3 Accused of Planning Killing
description: Three Bronx men were charged with attempted murder here today and the Suffolk County police said they had been hired to kill Paul Amara, a Babylon resident, for $5,000. Felipe Cortez, 24 years old, of 720 Faile Street; Julio Roman, 17, of 1262 Lafayette Avenue and Miguel Roque, 18, of 624 Faile Street, all in the Hunts Point section, were charged with attempted murder, conspiracy and weapons possession and held in the Riverhead jail. The police said they found a .25-caliber pistol after stopping them when someone reported a suspicious car in the area.

title: What Will the People of China Do Next?; Insufficient Reaction
description: To the Editor:

title: Marian Salzman: Media Executive
description: In the spring of 1988, Marian Salzman was director of media relations at an investor-relations company in New York. Today she is president of Career Vision Inc., which provides services and products for the student market. ''Last year, I was probably the youngest 29-year-old in New York, and now I'm probably the oldest 30-year-old,'' she said.

title: Deprivation and Daffodils
description: To the Editor:

title: Peter Freed Wed To Janet Carlson
description: The marriage of Janet Reid Carlson, a daughter of Helen B. Garland of Gloucester, Mass., and Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Robert Stuart Carlson of New York, to Peter Alan Freed, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Shepard Freed of Providence, R.I., took place yesterday at her mother's home in Hastings-on-Hudson. The Rev. Mark Hollingsworth Jr., an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Alison R. Bryan, a Presbyterian minister and the bride's maternal grandfather, performed the ceremony.

title: Rounding Up an American Tradition
description: COME summer, cowboys and cowgirls hit the trail - the rodeo trail - and the fans are never far behind. Winter is the slow season -a finals competition here, a livestock show there - but in summertime in the West rodeos are as ubiquitous, and as well-loved, as barbecues and county fairs. Pro rodeo riders call the Fourth of July cowboy's Christmas, because, as David Brown of the Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association says, ''There are so many rodeos to go to they can make a good portion of their income that week.''

title: What Will the People of China Do Next?; Citizens Without Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; In Manhattan, Festive Bistro Fare
description: This is a listing of Manhattan restaurants that have been reviewed by Bryan Miller in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. Cafe Un Deux Trois

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: 21st-CENTURY MANAGEMENT;
Tomorrow's Company Won't Have Walls
description: LEAD: For many companies, the classic forms of corporate organization no longer work very well. This is evidenced by the way some of the best-known companies in the world have failed to keep pace with changes in the marketplace. It is also evidenced by the failure of many companies to develop a global perspective.

title: Jamie L. Odabash Becomes a Bride
description: At the Presbyterian Church in Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y., Jamie Lynn Odabash, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur R. Odabash of Demarest, N.J., was married yesterday to David Taggart McLain, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. McLain of Massillon, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. Edmund F. P. Jones officiated.

title: About Cars; Zipping Along on a Drive to the Future
description: When I was wearing short pants, one of the fun things was to keep track of the future in what used to be called the publick prints.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: FACING THE TANK. By Patrick Gale. (Dutton, $17.95.) Patrick Gale's fourth novel is a quietly farcical depiction of contemporary life in a small English cathedral town. Its central character is an American professor named Evan Kirby, who has come to Barrowcester (pronounced ''Brewster'') to research paradise legends for a follow-up to his successful book on hell.

title: Victoria Hill Is Wed To Dulany Howland
description: Victoria Vincent Hill, the daughter of Dorothy Vincent of Dallas and the late Frederick W. Vincent, was married yesterday in Dallas to Grafton Dulany Howland, the son of Mrs. Murdoch Howland of New York and the late McClure M. Howland. The Rev. Sherwood M. Strodel performed the ceremony at the Highland Park Presbyterian Church. Mrs. Howland graduated from Trinity University in San Antonio. Her previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months.

title: My Father, Unyielding Enigma
description: ''YOU don't know me,'' my 93-year-old father said abruptly on my last visit to his home. After my first startled denial, I admitted to myself the truth of what was obviously an accusation.

title: Not Much Light At the End Of This Tunnel
description: Nothing weakens a story more than the storyteller's effort to explain characters who should be explaining themselves. The writer's rule is: show the villain acting villainously or the wit being witty; don't hang descriptive tags around their necks and expect the reader to believe in their reality.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FOR DEAR OLD DAD

title: Q and A
description: Capital Gains Tax

title: When Hartford Was an Art Colony
description: THE visitor to downtown Hartford should be forgiven who suspects that the place has died and gone to Developers' Heaven. After all, it feels so like the city of the future that can be reached but never penetrated and where life itself seems to stop at 5 o'clock.

title: Bidding for Buyers in a Slow Market
description: STEVE JANOWIAK cut the price of his penthouse condominium in suburban Chicago twice over the two years he listed it with a broker but it still did not sell. Fred Uehlein's condominium development outside Worcester, Mass., had sold well until the New England market slumped following the stock market crash in October 1987, and he was left with a third of the units unsold.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I recently built an extension onto my house, the exterior of which is covered with tongue-and-groove cedar siding. For the last two years, the siding has been treated with wood preservative, which has darkened the cedar. How can I treat the new cedar to make it the same color as the old cedar?

title: Outdoors; Jersey Anglers Resisting Bluefish Limit
description: Intense opposition to a proposal to limit recreational anglers to 10 bluefish a day along the Atlantic coast has developed in New Jersey, said Axel Carlson, a member of the Mid-Atlantic Fishery Management Council.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Weare, N.H.;
High Enders Welcomed
description: LEAD: A SUBDIVISION of homes priced well beyond the town's normal housing market has been started by a developer here and local officials see it as an example of what they would like the town to become.

title: Cheyenne's Frontier Celebration
description: LEAD: The Cheyenne Rodeo calls itself ''the daddy of 'em all.'' It's an apt description. Cheyenne Frontier Days, as the entire celebration is known, last for 10 days, the longest rodeo and attendant revelry of any Western city. The spectacle includes chuck wagon races, bullfights (in which a clown must evade a bull for 90 seconds), a chili cook-off, traditional Indian dances, a Western art show and four two-hour parades that wind through downtown

title: OUTSIDERS WELCOME
description: CULTS Faith, Healing, and Coercion. By Marc Galanter. 230 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.95.

title: WHAT THEY'RE WEARING: BOWS
description: It's not that a bow is new as a decorative touch. But where they are putting them this season is riveting. Many of the most attractive women on the New York social scene are showing up at gala events in dresses featuring bows on the backside. These additions range in scale from minuscule to momentous, but in each case they add a certain je ne sais quoi to the costume. And nobody seems to worry a bit about what happens when they sit down. This back-bow mania is so prevalent that even the cool, beautiful model Diane DeWitt chose to have one attached to the back of her Hanae Mori wedding gown.

title: Ms. Kroloff Weds Brandeis Official
description: Sarah Esther Kroloff, the daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Charles A. Kroloff of Westfield, N.J., was married there last evening at Temple Emanu-El by her father, the senior rabbi, to Roger Alan Segal, a son of Dr. Ellen Graff of Los Angeles and Alvin D. Segal of Portland, Ore.

title: Susan Donovan Wed To Peter J. McNamara
description: Susan Marie Donovan, a daughter of Richard Arthur Donovan of Rumson, N.J., and the late Eileen Karthaus Donovan, was married yesterday to Peter James McNamara, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent W. McNamara of Centerton, N.J. The Rev. Walter J. Burghardt officiated at the Holy Cross Roman Catholic Church in Rumson.

title: Copeland vs. Tyson
description: According to one witness, the blow was really a little push, no more forceful than a hearty slap on the back. But that's not the way John Copeland says he felt it last year when he and Mike Tyson had a little set-to outside a bar in Hudson, N.Y.

title: Question Of the Week; What's Wrong With The Mets?
description: Davey Johnson's obsession with the long ball at the expense of all other aspects of the game, when coupled with his seeming disregard for good defensive play, is shameful.

title: Marcel Carne and the Nazis
description: To the Editor:

title: BEST SELLERS: June 18, 1989
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week Lis t Fiction 1 1 2 THE RUSSIA HOUSE, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $19.95.) Espionage changes its ways as glasnost begins to rust the Iron Curtain. 2 2 6 WHILE MY PRETTY ONE SLEEPS, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The murder of a gossip writer creates a storm in New York's high-fashion world. 3 3 8 THE NEGOTIATOR, by Frederick Forsyth. (Bantam, $19.95.) An American expatriate tries to thwart terrorists' attempts to prevent the signing of a disarmament pact. 4 9 3 TALKING GOD, by Tony Hillerman. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) Two New Mexican policemen pursue a mystery involving valuable Indian ceremonial masks. 5 8 3 CAPITAL CRIMES, by Lawrence Sanders. (Putnam, $19.95.) A self-anointed messiah disrupts political and social life in Washington. 6 4 11 THE JOY LUCK CLUB, by Amy Tan. (Putnam, $18.95.) The tensions and cultural bonds shared by Chinese-American women and their immigrant mothers. 7 5 7 THE TEMPLE OF MY FAMILIAR, by Alice Walker. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) The relations of the species, races and sexes through the past 5,000 centuries. 8 7 16 THE SATANIC VERSES, by Salman Rushdie. (Viking, $19.95.) Two emigres from Bombay find themselves enacting the roles of good and evil in contemporary London. 9 11 3 RED PHOENIX, by Larry Bond. (Warner, $19.95.) Three American servicemen and the roles they play in a second Korean war. 10 6 5 PLAYMATES, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $17.95.) The private eye Spenser on the trail of scandals in the world of college basketball. 11 12 13 A PRAYER FOR OWEN MEANY, by John Irving. (Morrow, $19.95.) A schoolboy who accidentally killed the mother of his best friend turns into a prophet with a message for our times. 12 10 6 STRANGER IN SAVANNAH, by Eugenia Price. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The vicissitudes of three families during the Civil War. 13 14 11 WE ARE STILL MARRIED, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $18.95.) Stories, poems and satirical pieces, mostly reflecting life in Minnesota during the Reagan era. 14 16 STAR, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The crossed paths of a man and a woman, both destined for stardom, one in Washington and the other in Hollywood. 15 13 2 GARDEN OF LIES, by Eileen Goudge. (Viking, $19.95.) Two women - one born to wealth, one to poverty - whose destinies would be forever linked by a mother's reckless act. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 6 A WOMAN NAMED JACKIE, by C. David Heymann. (Lyle Stuart, $21.95.) A biography of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. 2 2 33 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters. 3 15 2 IT'S ALWAYS SOMETHING, by Gilda Radner. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The late comedian's memoir describes her battle with ovarian cancer. 4 8 2 THE GOOD TIMES, by Russell Baker. (Morrow, $19.95.) The New York Times columnist recalls his experiences from Baltimore newsboy to Washington correspondent during the 50's and 60's. 5 3 4 SUMMER OF '49, by David Halberstam. (Morrow, $21.95.) The year the Boston Red Sox and the New York Yankees battled to the last game for the American League pennant. 6 4 8 LOVE AND MARRIAGE, by Bill Cosby. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Observations on the elations and frustrations of romantic relationships. 7 5 4 THE ANDY WARHOL DIARIES, edited by Pat Hackett. (Warner, $29.95.) Observations and opinions dictated by the artist and celebrity from 1976 to 1987. 8 6 61 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 9 9 6 THE NIGHT THE BEAR ATE GOOMBAW, by Patrick F. McManus. (Holt, $15.95.) Twenty-six semiautobiographical yarns by a devoted outdoorsman. 10 11 6 ABOUT FACE, by David H. Hackworth and Julie Sherman. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) A career Army officer recalls his experiences in the Korean and Vietnam wars and in the Berlin wall and Cuban missile crises. 11 10 10 CITIZENS, by Simon Schama. (Knopf, $29.95.) A history of the French Revolution. 12 12 17 INNUMERACY, by John Allen Paulos. (Hill & Wang, $16.95.) Americans' mathematical illiteracy and its consequences for our culture. 13 7 14 ''FUNNY, YOU DON'T LOOK LIKE A GRANDMOTHER,'' by Lois Wyse. (Crown, $12.95.) An advertising woman's reflections on her role as the grandparent of eight. 14 1 SKETCHES FROM A LIFE, by George F. Kennan. (Pantheon, $22.95.) Excerpts from the dairy of the verteran diplomat, written between 1927 and 1988. 15 2 YOGI: It Ain't Over . . ., by Yogi Berra with Tom Horton. (McGraw-Hill, $18.95.) The reminiscences and witticisms of the baseball catcher, manager and coach. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 167 WEBSTER'S NINTH NEW COLLEGIATE DICTIONARY. (Merriam-Webster, $16.95.) A standard reference work revised in 1983. 2 1 PEACE, LOVE AND HEALING, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) A physician's counsel about healing oneself. 3 2 8 GOING WITHIN, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $18.95.) A ''guide for inner transformation'' through meditation. 4 5 5 THE T-FACTOR DIET, by Martin Katahn. (Norton, $18.95.) A new regimen for weight loss. 5 * 3 21 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about how to make a personal fortune. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. And Bear in Mind (Editor's choices of other recent books of particular interest) HOLLYWOOD, by Charles Bukowski. (Black Sparrow, Cloth, $20; Paper, $11) The West Coast poet and hard drinker, screenwriter of ''Barfly,'' surveys the absurdities of the Hollywood scene, the wrangles of making a low-budget picture, in this deadpan novel.

title: Banker Married To Kate Rodgers
description: Katherine Witt Rodgers, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Rodgers Jr. of Brooklyn Heights and Quogue, L.I., was married yesterday in Quogue to Maxwell Baldwin Smith 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith 3d of New York and Atlantic Highlands, N.J. The Rev. John E. Madden, the archdeacon of Suffolk County, officiated at the Episcopal Church of the Atonement.

title: Fast Food and Mini-Marts Bite Into Grocers
description: In search of new ways to woo shoppers, the nation's 30,400 supermarkets have become a marketing testing ground.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: The fourth Epson Worldwide Bridge Contest, played nine days ago in 91 countries, did not quite match the 1988 effort. The number of participants was down from about 84,000 to about 80,000.

title: Alison B. Tracy Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ernest B. Tracy Jr. of Londonderry, Vt., and the Old Black Point section of Niantic, Conn., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Alison Bryan Tracy and Alexander Benson Nalle, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace D. Nalle of Philadelphia.

title: Question Of the Week; What's Wrong With The Mets?
description: The Mets lost their chance to be the dominant team of the 80's when they eliminated Kevin Mitchell and Ray Knight from their roster. The '89 Mets have all of the talent in the world but none of the spirit and inner strength characterized by these two players. That kind of drive is what enables a half-crippled outfielder to hit a home run at the 11th hour of a World Series game or a 17-year-old tennis player, seeded 15th, to win a Grand Slam tournament. The absence of such intangibles is what thrusts high-priced talent into a quagmire of mediocrity. MARIANA BERNUNZO Elmhurst, Queens

title: 2 Education Officials Removed
description: State Education Commissioner Thomas Sobol has removed New York State's two top vocational rehabilitation officials in an effort to raise their office's morale and improve performance.

title: Galling to Good-Hearted Folk
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE WESTCHESTER LIGHTHOUSE;
Helping the Visually Impaired Stay in the Mainstream
description: LEAD: ETHEL MAE GULLETTE recently arrived at the Low Vision Center at the Westchester Lighthouse with a suitcase full of eyeglasses.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: BALLROOM DANCING ''Dance on a Summer Afternoon,'' an opportunity to see and do ballroom dancing, will be presented next Sunday in Pennsauken to benefit ActionAIDS.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Conversions in Harlem; Buyers Struggle to Qualify for Mortgages
description: IF he could do it over again, said Robert Ezrapour, he would change the apartment mix to more larger units and fewer smaller ones. Instead, his conversion of two vacant rental buildings in the Hamilton Heights section of Harlem into 38 condominium apartments has 24 one-bedrooms. They have been a tough sell at the prices he needs, about $170 a square foot.

title: The Night Tony Got The Best Of Oscar
description: People, and perhaps their psychiatrists, are always talking about having mood swings. There they are, happy as squirrels romping across the greensward, and zap! gray skies are all they can see. Or vice versa. I don't seem to work this way. I tend to have mood lags, which are something like jet lags but take longer to shake.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Berry College; In Gratitude, Alumni Come Back to Work
description: Men and women in work clothes rake leaves, trim hedges, repair light fixtures and refinish giant oak doors. A few hundred yards away, the pounding of hammers echoes across the 28,000-acre campus as another crew begins to refurnish an upstairs room in a campus guest cottage. Downstairs, women are sewing draperies.

title: All French Divided Over How to Do the Fete
description: To stay or not to stay, that is the question Parisians are asking as they contemplate the siege of the capital next month when several million tourists, 30,000 police and soldiers, marching bands, Sri Lankan elephants, opera singers and almost 30 heads of state and government will celebrate the bicentennary of the French Revolution.

title:
GARDENING;
When Plants Poison Their Neighbors
description: LEAD: A SURE sign of trouble is a shrinking rhododendron. This seems to happen when rhododendrons are planted near walnut trees. The culprit is juglone, a substance produced by the walnut and released into the soil, and this phenomenon is called allelopathy.

title: Making History in Virginia - Maybe
description: NO state in this nation has ever elected a black governor. California almost did in 1982 when Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles lost a squeaker. And William Lucas, recently nominated to head the Justice Department's civil rights division, was trounced in the Michigan gubernatorial race three years ago.

title: All Together Now: 'Carry Me Back to Old Virginny . . . .'
description: To the Editor:

title: Dragons Are Off With Chants, Rice
description: The 14th annual Hong Kong International Dragon Boat Races began today and amid pageantry recalling the 2,000-year-old origin of this sport, and the United States team from Philadelphia qualified quietly and easily for the semifinals Sunday.

title: Keeping Crisp, as Well as Cool
description: In the summer, women are divided into two camps - those who affect the wrinkled look of linen, and those who do not. For the latter, there are clothes that can go from day to night wrinkle-free. Some can even be rolled into a ball, tucked into a suitcase and emerge hours later, with no need for an iron.

title: There's a Word For Yank Illness
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Scott Elias: Music Soundtrack Producer
description: What do Reebok, Levi, Perrier and MTV have in common? The music for their commercials was written by Elias Associates of New York. ''We don't write the jingles,'' said Scott Elias, the company's 37-year-old chairman. ''And we don't do sound effects. We do sound design.''

title: Off Their Backs
description: To the Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
Indoors or Outdoors in Roadside Yonkers
description: LEAD: AT best, the cooking at Peppercorns is amateurish, but many of the dishes are priced accordingly - particularly on the ''light'' or ''patio'' menu and on the daily specials. For example, a thick boneless slab of prime-rib special, poorly trimmed, overcooked but tender and low on meaty flavor, goes for $9, dryish salad and tough french fries included.

title: Inventing Philo Vance
description: To the Editor:

title: CRIME
description: Stocky, bald Peter McGarr came from the garden, bearing a copy of ''Ulysses'' on which a murder and its solution hinged. And what an absolute joy it is, in reading Bartholomew Gill's novel THE DEATH OF A JOYCE SCHOLAR (Morrow, $18.95), to watch the meditative chief superintendent of Dublin's murder squad (''the sempiternal Dub','' his wife calls him) discover his kinship with Leopold Bloom while hunting down the killer of a Joycean scholar who fancied himself a latter-day Stephen Dedalus.

title: Correction
description: A pennant illustration with a report in the Campus Life column on June 4, about students' means of soliciting money from parents, was printed in error. It should have named the University of Michigan, not Michigan State.

title: Drafting an Epilogue to Anne Frank's Diary
description: Most editions of the diary of Anne Frank end with her last entry of Aug. 1, 1944, about trying to keep her temper in the crowded hiding place. There is often a stark note: Anne Frank and her family were arrested by the Gestapo on Aug. 4, 1944; she died at Bergen-Belsen concentration camp in March 1945.

title: In Unusual Spotlight, Orioles Beat the A's
description: Phil Bradley drove in three runs with two doubles today as Baltimore beat Oakland, 4-2, in the first nationally televised game from Memorial Stadium in almost three years.

title: WHO'S TO JUDGE?
description: Two years ago, a young Long Island woman went to jail for her involvement in the homicide of her father. She said that he had sexually abused her for many years but that she feared no one would believe her if she accused him. The judge in the case sentenced her to jail for her ''crime'' because he believed she should have sought help, presumably from the legal system, instead of taking matters into her own hands.

title: U.A.W.'s Challenge From Within
description: To cooperate with management or to confront? The question promises to pervade the politics and policies of the triennial convention of the United Automobile Workers, which starts today in Anaheim, Calif.

title: Who Wants to Be Comptroller? People With Plans
description: CHANGES proposed in the New York City Charter may trim the powers of the city comptroller, but that prospect has not trimmed the office's appeal for politicians. The reason may have less to do with the nature of the job than with the comptroller's traditional role as candidate-in-waiting for mayor or other higher office.

title: Fellini Builds Reggiolo, the Town of His Dreams
description: On the southern fringes of Rome, a small Italian town recently came into being. It is too Italian to be real.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: 10-K Gridlock

title: The Calgary Stampede
description: LEAD: The smell of bacon and pancakes will waft over the streets of Calgary, Alberta, on July 7, the opening day of Canada's most famous rodeo, the Calgary Stampede, so named for the fact that when the first rodeo was held in 1912 people rushed to Calgary to see it.

title: CRACKDOWN IN CHINA: Reporter's Notebook; In Beijing, It's Difficult To Find Facts or Truth
description: Four blue balloons flew over the martyrs' monument in Tiananmen Square on Friday morning, apparently intended to promote a mood of celebration about the ''quelling of the counterrevolutionary disturbance'' that the propaganda machine has been proclaiming.

title: Wringing Profits From Clean Air
description: If President Bush has his way, the 1990's will see the sharpest jump in environmental spending since the 1970's. For the first time since then, there seems to be political will in the White House to fight pollution of the nation's air, water and land, and the President's plans have created euphoria at the companies that sell pollution-control goods and services.

title: HOME TO RUNAWAY INTELLECTUALS
description: THE TRIUMPH OF LIBERALISM Zurich in the Golden Age, 1830-1869. By Gordon A. Craig. Illustrated. 314 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $24.95.

title: Campaign Filings Find Need For New Sources of Funds
description: The first filings under New York City's campaign-finance law have revealed a new political landscape in which most candidates will have to devote considerable energy - and money - to finding new sources of funds rather than relying on large contributions from real-estate developers, lawyers, bankers and business people.

title: Getting Newark to Pose
description: IT has been a good year for Manuel Acevedo. First, there was the photography fellowship from the Career Development Program for Visual Artists, which is sponsored by the National Foundation for Advancement in the Arts. Then came the photographer's first solo exhibition - at ArtSpace, in Jersey City State College's Hepburn Hall, followed by his appearance in ''Latin Roots/American Visions,'' at the New Jersey Center for Visual Arts in Summit.

title: Flawed but Powerful, Like Its Subject
description: BIRD (1988, Warner Home Video, $89.95), Clint Eastwood's film about the life and times of the saxophonist Charlie Parker, may be long, messy and a bit drab-looking, but it is still one of the two or three most powerful jazz-oriented features ever produced.

title: Maria Mack Is Married
description: Maria Louise Mack, an associate editor at Bantam Doubleday Dell, and Peter Bragg D'Amario, an associate at Goldman, Sachs & Company, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York. The Rev. Mark Serna officiated. Mrs. D'Amario is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Mack of Birmingham, Mich. Mr. D'Amario is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony V. D'Amario of Westwood, Mass.

title: FOR SALE
description: THE FIRST RUMBLINGS of momentous change in the Adirondack Park were heard in 1985 when a New Jersey millionaire named Roger Jakubowski, who had made a fortune selling fast-food at the seashore, bought the Marjorie Merriweather Post estate north of Saranac Lake for less than a million dollars. A flamboyant fellow with a bottomless appetite for publicity, Jakubowski courted the press, telling reporters far and wide that Adirondack real estate was the last nickel bargain in America and that he intended to buy up the whole goshdarn park, all six million acres of it.

title: Therapist Is Wed To Miss McGrath
description: At the Heinz Memorial Chapel at the University of Pittsburgh, Kathleen Rae McGrath, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. McGrath Jr. of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Charles William Bonner 4th, a son of Teresa F. Di Caro of Oakland, N.J., and Mr. Bonner 3d of Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Drew Morgan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Clarkson; Copying Software Becomes as Easy As Buying a Soda
description: Clarkson University, which in 1983 became the first university in the nation to provide personal computers to all students, is now going a step further, giving them the chance to copy software easily and cheaply.

title: Spirits in St. Louis Are High - And Rightly So
description: In a major museum, there should be no dead ground, no rooms overdue for renovation and no flaky housekeeping. Order, reason, fine judgment and, wherever it is appropriate, a subliminal wit should prevail from attic to basement. We should go through the museum the way we go through a classic text that has been edited with exemplary scholarship.

title: Lindsay A. Berry Is Wed in Maine
description: At the Congregational Union Church of South Bristol, Me., Lindsay Anne Berry, a research assistant at Yale Women's Health Studies in New Haven, and Fabian Chen, a candidate for M.D. and Ph.D. degrees in human genetics at Yale University, were married yesterday by the Rev. Alan C. Mermann.

title: Reviews/Dance; Alvin Ailey Students Showcase Their Strengths
description: Looking correct but not constrained, and moving with pleasure yet without straining to be cute, 14 little girls stepped forward in simple, attractive patterns on Friday night in ''Sonata,'' a ballet by Celia Marino to recorded music by Mozart. The brief work suggested that the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center is giving its students fine training.

title: Betsy Fergusson Weds
description: Elizabeth Dodd Fergusson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Blake Fergusson of King of Prussia, Pa., and Ethan Platt, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Adams Platt of New York and Cornish, N.H., were married yesterday by the Rev. Edward Tyler at Trinity Episcopal Church in Cornish. The bride, who is known as Betsy, is a kindergarten teacher at the Park School in Brookline, Mass. Her father is a professor of geology at Villanova (Pa.) University. Mr. Platt is a partner in the contracting firm of Burleigh-Fergusson in Cambridge, Mass. His father is the principal in a New York architectural firm bearing his name.

title: Mothers Learn to Switch Roles
description: LEAD: ON Thursdays, 23-month-old Sheryl Hoffman's grandmother usually accompanies her to a play group designed for toddlers and their mothers at the Sid Jacobson-North Shore Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. in East Hills while Sheryl's mother, Wendy, works as a nutritionist.

title: Mays Should Be On the List
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Hot Tip
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance Theater of Harlem Keeps Its Eye on Change
description: Arthur Mitchell, director of the Dance Theater of Harlem, has long struggled for a single goal: To imbue young black ballet dancers with confidence in the artistry and quality of their dancing in a profession that historically relegated blacks to ethnic dance. The object, as he sees it, is to greatly increase the community of black classical dancers nationwide.

title: Thomas A. Pope, War Hero, 94
description: Thomas A. Pope, the last surviving Medal of Honor winner of World War I, died of congestive heart failure Wednesday at the Edward Hines Jr. Veterans Administration Hospital in this Chicago suburb. He was 94 years old.

title: Week's Scorecard: Raindrops 4, Mets 1
description: If Davey Johnson was feeling a bit like Joe Btfsplk last week, no wonder. Like the Al Capp character who went through life under a perpetual cloudburst, Johnson and his Mets just couldn't seem to elude the rain no matter where they tried to hide.

title: Rockefeller House Seeks Consent to Public Visits
description: REPRESENTATIVES of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, which owns Kykuit, the 80-year-old main house of the Rockefeller family estate, have asked North Tarrytown officials to allow public visits.

title: The Rising Allure of the Vineyards
description: For the past few years,the shareholders of Chalone Inc., the first and still the only publicly traded premium wine company, had little cause to rejoice, except for the sumptuous lunch and wine tasting that always followed the company's annual meeting.

title: VIDEO
description: In travels abroad, Americans often pick up videotapes of foreign movies not available in this country. On returning home, they discover that those foreign cassettes won't play on American VCR's.

title: Bush Retires a Kennedy Desk
description: President Bush has jettisoned the desk used since the days of President John F. Kennedy, the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said today. Mr. Fitzwater said Mr. Bush ordered his own desk, which he has used since May 2, 1985, installed in the Oval Office. The old desk has been returned to the White House storage bin.

title: A Pat on the Back for Some Modest Buildings
description: In May, a couple of weeks after the Oscars and a few weeks before the Tonys, the American Institute of Architects presented its annual Honor Awards, which it describes as ''the profession's highest recognition of design excellence for individual buildings by American architects.'' This year 14 buildings got the institute's official pat on the back, one less than last year and substantially fewer than the 20 in 1987.

title: Sylvia Schmokel Weds T. W. Trevor
description: Sylvia Hyde Schmokel, a daughter of Dr. Wolfe W. Schmokel of South Burlington, Vt., was married yesterday to Thomas Warren Trevor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. H. Trevor of New York and St. James, L.I., at Trinity Episcopal Church in Shelburne, Vt. The Rev. Alfred Stefanik and the Rev. J. Frederick Lehr, a Lutheran minister, officiated.

title:
BODY AND MIND;
Billows in the Heart
description: LEAD: SOME 14 YEARS AGO, I found myself in a high school gymnasium, listening to the rambunctious hearts of maybe 100 students who were trying out for soccer and track. I was to confirm, by a brief physical exam, that they were fit to play, and I was able to certify to the coach that the great majority of their hearts were normal.

title: SHE LEFT HER CHILD WITH THE HAT-CHECK GIRL
description: LEAD: TWICE TOLD TALES Stories. By Daniel Stern. 173 pp. Latham, N.Y.: Paris Review Editions/British American Publishing. $18.95.

title: Susan K. Wheeler Weds Architect
description: Susan Knight Wheeler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Wheeler of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Constantine Cacos, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Cacos of Somerville, Mass. Bishop Iakovos of the Greek Orthodox Diocese of Chicago performed the ceremony at St. George Greek Orthodox Church of Cape Cod in Centerville, Mass, assisted by the Rev. Spyros Mourikis.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Eye-Catching Wedding Finery
description: At most weddings, there is at least one simple rule: the bride wears white. That certainly was the color of choice for Caroline Rudd, above, when she married Nicolas Combemale at St. James' Episcopal Church in Manhattan this month. Her off-white, two-piece lace dress, a Pauline Trigere design, had a peplum bodice that gave it something close to the effect of a tailored suit. A cloudlike veil provided just the right touch of softness.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I'm under the desk. What a bloodbath.'' Lilliana Nealon, vice president for foreign exchange, Union Bank of Switzerland, on Thursday's currency market.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The 100 million or so television viewers who were watching last January when Tim Krumrie broke his leg in the Super Bowl should not be surprised that the Cincinnati Bengals' nose tackle will not be participating in next month's training-camp drills. The team said he would concentrate on classroom work and was not expected to join the club until sometime during the season. . . . Larry McElreavy, head coach at Columbia last season when the Lions broke a losing streak at 44 games, has been appointed an assistant football coach at the University of Toledo. McElreavy, whose Columbia team was 2-8 last year and 2-28 over three seasons, will coach tight ends and assist Dan Simrell, the head coach, with recruiting, said John McNamara, Toledo sports information director. . . . Jack Nicklaus, Al Geiberger, Hubert Green and Kathy Whitworth are to be inducted into the All-American Collegiate Golf Foundation's Hall of Fame at a dinner Tuesday in Manhattan.

title:
THE NATION;
Chavez Takes a Smaller Union Into Another Decade of Fights
description: LEAD: LAST August 3,000 people, most of them Hispanic farm workers and their families, gathered in the San Joaquin Valley town of Delano to demonstrate support for Cesar Chavez, who was then fasting to dramatize the boycott of table grapes called by the United Farm Workers of America. As Robert Kennedy had done in 1968, the Rev.

title: Hong Kong Fears China's Hard Line
description: China's repression of the democracy movement has abruptly weakened confidence in Hong Kong about its scheduled reversion to China in 1997, raising fears about the future and sparking a new political consciousness in this normally complacent territory.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I recently built an extension onto my house, the exterior of which is covered with tongue-and-groove cedar siding. For the last two years, the siding has been treated with wood preservative, which has darkened the cedar. How can I treat the new cedar to make it the same color as the old cedar?

title: Ann Arbuthnot Wed to William Huff
description: Ann Merrill Arbuthnot and William Clayton Huff were married yesterday at King's Chapel in Boston by the Rev. James L. Carter, a Presbyterian minister and a cousin of the bridegroom. The bride is a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Charles W. Arbuthnot of Bath and Georgetown, Me. Mr. Huff is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. C. Clayton Huff of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Longboat Key, Fla. Gay Walley was maid of honor. William Flynn served as best man. The bride, who will keep her name, is a vice president for account service at CGFM, a Boston advertising concern. She graduated from Swarthmore College. Her father retired as the director of the American Waldensian Aid Society in New York. Her mother, Eugenie H. Arbuthnot, is a former associate professor of interdisciplinary studies at Bloomfield (N.J.) College.

title:
WINE;
Standard Producers of the Napa Valley
description: LEAD: TWO recent visits to Napa Valley allowed sampling of a wide range of wines, including older vintages, bottles now on local shop shelves and newly released products now arriving at local retail outlets and restaurants. When quality, price and year-to-year consistency were taken into account, three standout producers emerged: the Robert Mondavi Winery, the Beaulieu Vineyard and the Grgich Hill

title: Trade Deficit Shrinks Again
description: The trade deficit shrank to $8.26 billion in April, the second monthly decrease in a row. The April figure was down 13 percent from the March level. Exports grew and imports declined, even though this year's surging dollar theoretically should be countering both trends . . . Consumer prices in May rose six-tenths of 1 percent, putting inflation so far this year at 6.7 percent . . . Retail sales were up only one-tenth of 1 percent in May . . .
