Housing starts fell 2.1 percent in May, to an annual rate of 1.31 million, the lowest rate since December 1982 . . . Business sales were up 1.7 percent in April, and inventories rose six-tenths of 1 percent . . . Factories operated at 83.8 percent of capacity in May, down from 84.1 percent in April. Industrial production in May was unchanged.

title: What Will the People of China Do Next?; The Disenchanted
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the new state taxes approved by the General Assembly misstated an action on the sales tax. The exemption for clothing costing less than $75 was not changed.

title: A Changed Court Revises Rules on Civil Rights
description: WITH a recent burst of discrimination rulings, the Supreme Court did something more than provide newly confining definitions to widely used civil rights laws. The Court all but guaranteed that civil rights would leap to the forefront of domestic politics.

title: Correction
description: Because of a producer's change of plan, a caption and a listing in the Arts and Leisure Guide today for ''What Have You Done for Me Lately?'' at RAPP Arts Center on Friday and Saturday gave an incorrect starting time. It begins at 8 P.M.

title: Nissequogue Facing Rare Election
description: LEAD: NISSEQUOGUE, a tiny village comfortably nestled on Suffolk County's North Shore, is embroiled in political unrest, as a faction threatens to overthrow the party that has governed since the community was incorporated in 1926.

title: Scrambled Revolutions
description: To the Editor:

title: Fear of Falling
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Watch; The Long Road to Argentina's Financial Disaster
description: The current inflation rate exceeds 400,000 percent annually. Factories are laying off their employees, and industrial production has virtually stopped.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: RED TEARS: War, Famine and Revolution in Ethiopia. By Dawit Wolde Giorgis. (Red Sea Press, $29.95.) Among the many books written so far about Ethiopia's 1974 revolution and the downfall of Haile Selassie's regime, none portray the internal dynamics as intimately as this personal account by Dawit Wolde Giorgis.

title: THE GLOOM AND THE GLORY
description: THE LIFE OF GRAHAM GREENE Volume One: 1904-1939. By Norman Sherry. Illustrated. 783 pp. New York: Viking. $29.95.

title: Serving Up the Poor As Exotic Fare For Voyeurs?
description: In Woody Allen's bleak comedy ''Stardust Memories'' the main character displays over the breakfast table in his stylish New York apartment a famous picture: Eddie Adams's photograph of a South Vietnamese police chief firing a gun at the head of a man suspected of being a Vietcong spy during the Tet offensive of 1968.

title: At the Table
description: To the Editor:

title: A Weary Buenos Aires Family Wonders How to Keep Afloat
description: With his 2-year-old son squirming on his lap, Guillermo Dietrich pondered how to keep his family afloat in Argentina's rising sea of inflation.

title: Four Are Killed in West Virginia Rampage
description: A man killed three people, including his sister and brother-in-law, and began firing at the police before he was shot to death, the authorities said today.

title: Sports of The Times; The Soccer Fan With Two Teams
description: There are many advantages to America being a nation of immigrants, but they do not always translate into a home-team advantage for the national soccer team. No matter where the United States team plays within its own borders, there will always be vocal and knowledgeable Americans with an undeniable bond to the Azzurri of Italy or La Seleccion of Mexico.

title: FOOD SAMPLING SOIREES DRAW CROWDS AND SPUR SALES
description: Sampling is being used by manufacturers with greater frequency these days to get products into the hands of shoppers and to stimulate the demand necessary to justify a spot on a grocer's shelf. Last year, ShopRite alone held 400 to 500 demonstrations a week at its 175 stores, up 50 percent from the previous year, according to the New Jersey chain.

title: U.S. Tries to Bar Crime Families From Carting
description: LEAD: FEDERAL prosecutors have begun their most sweeping effort ever to end what they term 30 years of organized-crime domination of the Long Island garbage-carting industry.

title: Reviews/Dance; A Work On AIDS By Lamhut
description: Phyllis Lamhut took on the subject of death in a 1980 dance called ''Passing,'' and since then she has dealt with death and the decay of civilization in pieces whose power, freshness and informing cultural references have made them urgently compelling and even exhilarating. Miss Lamhut's new ''Man,'' to be performed through June 25 at St. Mark's Church (Second Avenue at 10th Street), is the choreographer's response to AIDS. It has the grandeur of her recent pieces, but little of their power and none of the heroic anger expressed in her program notes.

title: COOL COMFORT
description: As temperatures climb in the summer, my enthusiasm for complicated cooking wanes. Although I still like substantial, robust-flavored foods, the slowly braised and roasted dishes that are nurturing in winter are too heavy and complicated in the heat. Fixed mealtimes also seem antithetical to summer, when outdoor activities have a greater tug. I stay away from anything that requires precise preparation and serving schedules, turning instead to dishes that allow most of the work to be done ahead of time and that can be served either chilled or at room temperature. Simple presentation and a fresh, vibrant taste are most important.

title: The Hearing Should Be Open To the Public
description: On June 26, A. Bartlett Giamatti, the commissioner of baseball, will hold a hearing regarding gambling allegations against Pete Rose. Then, probably sometime next month, the commissioner will issue his decision about the case. If he finds Rose guilty and bans him for a year or for life, he may face adverse reaction and litigation, while if he exonerates him, some will inevitably cry whitewash.

title: O'Neill's 'Moon' Revived in Hartford
description: FOR some works of art, the struggle for acknowledgement parallels the agony of creation. When critics and censors attacked the first production of Eugene O'Neill's ''Moon for the Misbegotten'' in 1947, it closed, after two months on the road, without coming to New York.

title: In Giant Media Takeover Battle, Role of Debt Is Starkly Revealed
description: The takeover frenzy engulfing Time Inc., Warner Communications Inc. and Paramount Communications Inc. is one of the most striking examples to date of the power of debt in corporate America's deal-making.

title: No Headline
description: IN the garden in back of Esther and Stuart Cox's house in Stratford are carrots, beets, peppers, tomatoes, lettuce and string beans. ''We avoid fats and the junk,'' Mrs. Cox said.

title: Study of Welfare Clients Says Trade Schools Fail
description: Few welfare recipients obtain jobs after taking government-financed training at private trade schools, New York City officials have found. They fear that new Federal welfare regulations intended to expand such job training may end up squandering tens of millions of tax dollars.

title:
MUSIC;
Waterloo Festival: Changes and Risks
description: LEAD: PUTTING forth a strong musical philosophy rather than programming simply to fill the house has made the last few years at the Waterloo Music Festival an uphill battle for the festival's founder and conductor, Gerard Schwarz, and its artistic director, Samuel Lipman. Both are optimistic as the Waterloo Festival and School of

title: Shared Moments in a Hectic Schedule
description: RECENTLY, I started my own writing business, and this has meant a dramatic change from my traditional routine of going to an office five days a week. Now I work from home most days, including weekends, and this inevitably has an effect on family life.

title: Article 061689 -- No Title
description: Illinois has offered $33 million to Sears, Roebuck & Company to keep its retail headquarters in the state it has called home for more than 100 years.

title: 'Welfare Reform Is So Essential'
description: LORRAINE M. ARONSON has been the state's welfare commissioner since Dec. 30, overseeing a budget of $1.3 billion and a staff of 1,600 people in the Income Maintenance Department. The department assists about 212,000 people receiving public assistance, including food stamps, welfare and Medicaid.

title: What Will the People of China Do Next?; A Country in Evolution
description: To the Editor:

title: Lyme Disease Clinic Opens To a Crowd
description: GOVERNMENT officials gathered at the Westchester County Medical Center last week to open what may be the nation's first Lyme disease walk-in clinic. They quickly learned why the diagnostic unit was needed. More than 50 people were waiting to be examined on the first day, even before the ribbon was cut.

title: The Magazine That Lost Its Way
description: Had he known that his most visible venture would be in such trouble, Arthur Lipper 3d would never have chosen to spend last Tuesday talking to an audience of entrepreneurs about business magazines.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Rome
description: Getting lost is a good way to discover Rome. Just take the wrong turn or simply follow your instincts through the city's labyrinth in the centro storico and the surprises soon follow. A piazza too small to appear on a map, a fountain more beautiful than famous, a cluster of nuns under colorful parasols, a shuttered palazzo decorated with the morning's washing, young boys playing soccer against a 10th-century wall and myriad other moments that prove Rome is more than a museum.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: MEMPHIS;
Mixed Project For a Rail Yard
description: LEAD: A MOSTLY UNUSED 32-acre railroad yard is being reclaimed with a $100 million mixed-use development called South Bluffs.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT: PETE ROSE AND THE PUBLIC'S RIGHT TO KNOW;
Players Retain Some Rights Of Privacy
description: LEAD: A monthly magazine stops to examine Pete Rose's relationship with his children; daily newspaper reports highlight his every move, and television cameras follow him from ball park to ball park.

title: FICTION
description: RED ARMY. By Ralph Peters. (Pocket Books, $18.95.) In his second novel, Ralph Peters, a United States Army intelligence officer, has concocted a might-yet-be tale of conventional war on the terrain where, according to the conventional wisdom, the Western allies would logically expect to meet the forces of the Eastern bloc - namely, the same German plains that have seen other invaders, from the Goths of the late Roman Empire to the Soviet troops of World War II. The tactics and strategy in ''Red Army'' are those of conventional armor and infantry, the weapons state-of-the-art for the near future. In other words, there's no high-tech gimmickry here. Instead, Mr. Peters attempts to paint a picture not of tanks and helicopters but of Russian fighting soldiers. Curiously, however, his officers, although well drawn, are more or less what one might expect. Among these are Chibisov, the general who feels ''compelled to struggle relentlessly against every last vestige of his Jewishness,'' and Malinsky, the commander of the Western front, a realist whose family has fought for Russia since Peter the Great. But if the generals are out of Tolstoy, the ordinary soldiers are out of Stephen Crane by Bill Mauldin. The war itself is bloody, and is fought against a Western alliance whose members (particularly the Germans) are uncommitted to a united defense. As with most wars, the ending of this one is inconclusive. Indeed, what comes out of this very readable novel is a feeling that while the wars change, the soldiers remain the same.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: LIKE many New Jersey residents, I'll be doing a bit of out-of-state travel this year. Hey, it's a big country. There's lots to see, lots to experience. I've done my share of summers in New Jersey - look forward to many more, in fact. But this is a pack-up and head-out year. New vistas, far horizons.

title: Elizabeth Haase Weds a Teacher
description: Elizabeth Katharine Haase, a magna cum laude graduate of Princeton University who has taught English for two years at Newark Academy, was married yesterday to Andrew Alfred Meyers, chairman of the English department at the Bergen School in Jersey City. The Rev. Robert Dorer of the Reformed Church in America and Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at the Union Church in Pocantico Hills, N.Y.

title: Out at Home
description: He has been stripped of an Olympic gold medal, banned from his sport, has testified that he lied to his fans and become an object of contempt for taking steroids before the 1988 Summer Games.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is increasingly obvious that most of the reasons for illegal immigration are in the countries people are leaving, and that unless those conditions change we may be able to reduce the flow somewhat, but no enforcement scheme will stop the tide.'' - Representative Bruce A. Morrison, Democrat of Connecticut. [ 24:4. ]

title: Accomodating New Riders, All Going the ''Wrong Way''
description: For decades, legions of Westchester residents have commuted by railroad each weekday to offices in New York City. While the train platforms are more crowded than ever in the morning with Manhattan-bound commuters, new trends have taken hold as well.

title: TRUTH STUTTERS
description: DEAD LANGUAGES By David Shields. 246 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: The Man With the Pictures
description: WHEN THE ACTRESS Lucille Ball died, a CBS reporter went to one of her longtime friends, the comedian George Burns, for his comment.

title: Review/Opera; Purcell's 'King Arthur' In St. Louis Production
description: It is no news by now that the Opera Theater of St. Louis counts as one of this country's most innovative companies. Really a festival rather than a season-long provider of operatic fare, it offers a month of performances during June. But those performances are generally of high quality, and usually include novelties both contemporary and revived.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: Every once in a while you come across a game that looks so classical and logical that you are tempted to believe you have seen it before.

title: Reversing the Reservoirs
description: If there's anything good to be said about day after day of June rain, it's that the reservoirs, those famous drought-stricken reservoirs, are within spitting distance of 101 percent capacity. If they get to that point, the overflow will go into spillways, then streams and eventually into the Hudson and Delaware Rivers. But what if it doesn't? What if reversing the reservoirs was up to New Yorkers? Could they do it? Of course they could!

title: Italy's Loreto Offers Vistas And a Legend
description: WHEN an Atlantic storm was tossing Columbus's ships during his second voyage to the Americas in 1493 his frightened men invoked Our Lady of Loreto for succor. As the storm raged a huge church was being built in Italy on a hill overlooking the Adriatic Sea. The church was named for a nearby laurel grove, lauretum in Latin.

title: A Sidewalk Debate That Refuses to Die
description: ARLINE LOMAZZO started a crusade to build a sidewalk from one end of Greenwich to the other soon after her 16-year-old son was killed by a motorist as he walked along the grassy shoulder of the Post Road in 1978.

title: Astronaut Dies in Plane Accident
description: S. David Griggs, a 49-year-old astronaut who flew on the space shuttle in 1985 and was training to pilot a mission of the Discovery in November, was killed today when his stunt plane slammed into a field, the authorities said.

title: Seoul Rethinks Its Overtures To the Communist North
description: THE political earthquake in China has sent tremors throughout Asia. In South Korea, officials are wondering about the future of their strategy of attempting to improve relations simultaneously with China, the Soviet Union and North Korea.

title: The King's Tall Order
description: IT IS LIKELY TO REPLACE Rick's Cafe Americain as the most renowned structure, fictional or otherwise, in Casablanca. Aside from those in the Islamic holy cities of Mecca and Medina in Saudi Arabia, the mosque under construction by order of the Moroccan king, Hassan II, will be among the world's most capacious -and its tallest. It will be known as the Great Mosque Hassan II.

title: 1,500 To Compete in Fairfield Race
description: LEAD: STEVE LOBDELL smiles when he recalls his first attempt to coordinate a road race, in Fairfield in 1981. ''I didn't know anything about race direction,'' Mr. Lobdell said. ''We ran a five-mile race and a half-marathon at the same time. And the five-mile race was a disaster. The lead car went the wrong way, and 30 runners went off the course.

title: Malinda M. Eichner Is Wed
description: Malinda Margaret Eichner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lambert J. Eichner of Westport, Conn., and Krister Frederick Johnson, a son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. William A. Johnson of Scarsdale, N.Y., were married yesterday by the bridegroom's father at Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn. The bride, a graduate of Connecticut College, and her husband, a graduate of Trinity College in Hartford, received master's degrees from the Harvard Divinity School. Mr. Johnson is a candidate for a Ph.D. in philosophy of religion at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: High School to Be Used for Child Care
description: LEAD: TINY chairs and tables, a neat stack of building blocks and freshly painted bright yellow lockers set apart one room in North Branford High School. The teen-agers have disappeared for the summer, but tomorrow a group of pre-schoolers will toddle in for the opening of a Family Resource Center, the first of three centers in the state that will use an existing school building to offer affordable child care and other services to families at all income levels.

title: WHY JULY 4 FALLS ON OCT. 8
description: DAVE BARRY SLEPT HERE A Sort of History of the United States. By Dave Barry. 178 pp. New York: Random House. $15.95.

title: Fulfilling a Dream at a Jazz Station
description: IN 1987, Anna Kosof was offered the rare opportunity to transform a dream into an institution. That is exactly what she has done as general manager of WBGO (88.3 FM), a National Public Radio station in Newark.

title: The Military Finds An Alternative to The Space Shuttle
description: LAST week's maiden flight of a giant new Air Force rocket marks the beginning of the end of the military's ties to the troubled space shuttle.

title: A MENANCE OR JUST A CRANK?
description: LYNDON LaROUCHE AND THE NEW AMERICAN FASCISM By Dennis King. Illustrated. 415 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: HYANNIS BOAT: And Other Stories. By W. D. Wetherell. (Little, Brown, $15.95.) People and places that time might otherwise forget are the subjects of W. D. Wetherell's second collection of short stories. ''The Mall: A History'' recalls a child's first encounter with the burgeoning ''throwaway'' culture of the 1950's; in ''Things to Come: Maine, 1951,'' a gas station owner's wife longs for an end to her isolation; and a Vietnamese cab driver in ''Hundred Year War'' seeks to absolve himself of his guilt for the accidental death of an American G.I.

title: Adjusting Sliding or Folding Doors
description: SLIDING doors are often a better choice than swinging doors for closets, cramped doorways or as patio entrances. But minor adjustment is frequently required to keep sliding doors operating smoothly.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis McEnroe and Connors in Final: John McEnroe, 30 years old, and Jimmy Connors, 36, breezed past semifinal opponents yesterday, setting up a clash between the veteran Americans for the Scottish grass court championships title in Edinburgh. McEnroe, the top-seeded player, scored a 6-4, 6-4 victory over his compatriot Aaron Krickstein despite being warned for abuse of an official. Connors overwhelmed the defending champion, Peter Lundgren of Sweden, 6-1, 6-1. In the women's final, top-seeded Mary Joe Fernandez of Miami defeated the defending champion, Gigi Fernandez of Puerto Rico, 6-2, 6-3. (AP) Lendl Advances: Ivan Lendl, who has not won a grass-court title since he was a junior player, moved into the final of the Queen's Club tournament in London yesterday by outlasting Paul Annacone of the United States in a three-set semifinal. Lendl, the world's top-ranked male player, broke Annacone's serve for the only time in the match in the penultimate game, then held his own serve for a 7-6, 4-6, 7-5 victory. Eighth-seeded Christo van Rensburg of South Africa overwhelmed the 14th-seeded American Derrick Rostagno, 6-4, 6-4, in the other semifinal.(AP) Navratilova vs. Garrison: Martina Navratilova overpowered Elna Reinach of South Africa yesterday to reach the final of a grass-court tournament in Edgbaston, England, against Zina Garrison. The top-seeded Navratilova used her serve-and-volley game to overwhelm Reinach, 6-2, 6-2. The second-seeded Garrison struggled in the opening set of her match against the defending champion, Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany, before settling down for a 7-6, 6-2 victory.(AP) Golf King Ties Ok: Betsy King shot her second straight three-under-par 69 to tie Ok Hee Ku, who shot a 70 yesterday, for the second-round lead at the Ladies Professional Golf Association's Lady Keystone Open in Hershey, Pa. The leaders were at six-under-par 138. Liselotte Neumann was one shot back, while Pat Bradley and Laura Davies were next at 140. Missie Berteotti, who shot a 66 Friday for the first-round lead, had a 76 and fell back to even par 142 heading into today's final round.(AP) 1-Stroke Lead for Charles: Bob Charles, the leading money-winner on the PGA Senior Tour, sank a 27-foot putt on the final hole to take a one-shot lead after the second round of the Northville Long Island Classic in Jericho. For the second successive day, golfers played 16 holes instead of 18 because the ninth and 14th holes of the par-72, 6,595-yard Meadow Brook Club were flooded. Charles shot a 59 and finished two rounds at 119. The first-round leader, Butch Baird, had a 62 and George Lanning shot a 61 to tie for second at 120.(AP) Horse Show Victory for Olisco and Dorman: Olisco, ridden by Michael Dorman of Jamison, Pa., won the Range Rover jump-off class yesterday at the Ox Ridge charity horse show in Darien, Conn. The event was the final prep for today's $40,000 Johnnie Walker Grand Prix. Olisco was timed in 25.043 seconds. Second was the former World Cup champion and Olympian Leslie Burr Lenehan of Westport, Conn., whose Regis was timed in 26.765 seconds. Kayak Racing Europeans Dominate: The United States was shut out yesterday in the wildwater phase on the first day of the whitewater world championships, with Yugoslavia, France and Italy taking top honors. Competing on the Savage River in Luke, Md., American canoe and kayak racers failed in their bid to break European domination of the sport. The championships are being held in the United States for the first time, and participants from 25 countries are competing in men's canoe, two-man canoe, men's kayak and women's kayak classes over this weekend and next, in two disciplines, wildwater and slalom. Yesterday's event was a 4.5-mile race down the Savage. Marco Previde Massara of Italy took the men's kayak event, and Sabine Kleinhenz of France won the women's kayak. Andrej Jelenc of Yugoslavia clinched the gold in the single canoe event. Srecko Masle and Andrej Grobisa of Yugoslavia won first place in the double-canoe competition. The highest American finish was a fourth in men's kayak by Jon Fishburn of Billings, Mont.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Puica Retiring
description: She won 33 gold medals in a 23-year running career.

title: Miss Danforth Becomes Bride Of D. A. Hurst
description: Elizabeth Wagley Danforth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Danforth of Fairfield, Conn., and Siasconset, Mass., was married yesterday to Douglas Andrew Hurst, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred L. Hurst of Milton, Mass. The Rev. Thomas Richard performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church in Nantucket, Mass.

title: Lorie Flater Is Wed
description: Lorie Ann Flater, an account executive with the New York public relations company of Keeble, Cavaco & Duka, and Neil Anthony Torpey, an associate at the New York law firm of Mudge Rose Guthrie Alexander & Ferdon, were married yesterday by the Rev. George Pennington, a Unitarian minister, at the New York Athletic Club in Pelhamdale, N.Y. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Howard Flater and the late Mr. Flater of Des Moines. Mr. Torpey is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward H. Torpey of Cherry Hill, N.J.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: ONCE the domain of private clubs and big-city concert halls, jazz is moving into the mainstream of suburban life as art centers, shopping malls and libraries across the state offer a steady series of jazz concerts the year round.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; A CORRECTION
description: An article on June 11 on assessments misstated the procedure by which property owners may present grievances before the Board of Assessment Review after the deadline for submission has passed. They have the right to file an application for consideration - not to consideration of the case itself - at any adjourned hearing of the board.

title: HOW TO SAVE $50 BILLION A YEAR
description: AFFORDING DEFENSE By Jacques S. Gansler. Charts. 417 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $24.95.

title: Correction
description: An article on May 7 about the prospects of the political opposition in Canada misstated the date by which the next general election must be held. As a reader has recently written to point out, the date is Nov. 21, 1993.

title: The Age For Forgetfulness
description: THERE'S an old song that begins, ''Did I remember to tell you I adore you,'' something, something, something. I cannot remember the rest. Personally, it's getting a little scary. I've read that a little forgetfulness can be expected in one's later years, but is 50 years old the time for oblivion?

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Wisconsin; Regents Approve A Disputed Ban On Discrimination
description: Settling a semester of debate over a possible intrusion on First Amendment rights, the governing body of the University of Wisconsin system has approved a proposal barring discrimination on its 12 campuses.

title: Karan's Look of Relaxed Elegance
description: ''These are clothes to wear north or south, partying or staying home,'' explained Donna Karan as she took visitors on a tour of her showroom last week. There, models were posing in styles from her first resort clothes for DKNY, her casual collection.

title: BISHOPS APPROVE PLAN ON DISPUTES
description: America's Roman Catholic bishops overwhelmingly approved today a long-stalled set of guidelines aimed at resolving doctrinal disputes between bishops and theologians.

title: Where Vienna Satisfies A Sweet Tooth
description: CH. DEMEL & SONS, the 203-year-old Imperial and Royal Court Confectioners, is flying its suggestive house flag outside its stuccoed headquarters on Vienna's Kohlmarkt. The colors: chocolate brown and the pink of the icing on the firm's rum-flavored punch torte. Scores of other dens of sweet-tooth debauchery within walking distance display Dobos Schnitten, a Hungarian composition of layered chocolate and hazelnut cream, side by side with an arsenal of diverse high-calorie bombs in their show windows. And the local classic, Sacher torte, can be sampled not only at Sacher's but in konditoreien and coffeehouses all over the city.

title: NONFICTION
description: HANK GREENBERG: The Story of My Life. By Hank Greenberg; Edited and with an Introduction by Ira Berkow. (Times Books, $19.95.) Had Henry Benjamin Greenberg lived to complete his autobiography, the story of his life in baseball would probably have been as flat as his big feet. Happily, his family sought the help of Ira Berkow, a New York Times sports columnist. The collaboration was unusual. Greenberg died at the age of 75 on Sept. 4, 1986. Mr. Berkow inherited 800 pages of rambling conversation that Greenberg had dictated, and edited those words into the heart of the book. Greenberg, who played for the Detroit Tigers from 1933 until 1946, with four years out for military service during World War II, relates the usual baseball lore. He tells stories of players' shenanigans, names the greats of the game and recalls his good and bad days at the plate. He was contentious during the annual contract talks and explains why. He was contemptuous of managers who coldly cut aging veterans, even Babe Ruth, from the roster. Latter-day players who outdistanced Greenberg in the record books have written similar stories. What was special about this player beyond his 6-foot 4-inch frame, dedication to the game and courtly manner? Greenberg is one of two Jewish players - Sandy Koufax is the other - to be named to the Baseball Hall of Fame. Greenberg does not deny his heritage, but he does not make much of it. It is Mr. Berkow who adds perspective and stature to Greenberg through interviews with sportswriters and the player's family, friends and colleagues. Greenberg was remembered by players and writers for his grace under the almost daily pressure of anti-Semitic vulgarities shouted by opposing teams and fans. He was regarded as the model by Jackie Robinson and other minority players who tried to concentrate on the game and ignore the viciousness of racial discrimination. Such a contribution is reason enough to celebrate Greenberg's life.

title: Officer's Wife Killed, Apparently in Dispute
description: The wife of a police officer was shot to death yesterday and her husband severely wounded in what appeared to be a domestic dispute behind a department store in Catskill, N.Y., the police reported.

title: Bond Insurer Cited for High Productivity
description: WITH profits of $418,000 for each of its 220 employees, a municipal-bond insurer based in White Plains tops the list of concerns rated for job productivity in a recent Forbes 500 survey of 778 companies.

title: Wasn't Speaker Foley Who Was Smeared
description: To the Editor:

title: Politicians Are Shortchanging SUNY Students
description: FOR the last several months the Governor, the Legislature and the SUNY-CUNY systems have been engaged in what has become an annual and nasty rite of spring: deciding how to pay for public higher education.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: WHILE MY PRETTY ONE SLEEPS. By Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Mary Higgins Clark's seventh novel is a real let-down, primarily because it lacks the tension and suspense of her previous best sellers. ''While My Pretty One Sleeps'' opens with the unidentified murderer driving through a blinding snowstorm to bury the body of his victim, a gossip writer named Ethel Lambston, in a state park.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I recently built an extension onto my house, the exterior of which is covered with tongue-and-groove cedar siding. For the last two years, the siding has been treated with wood preservative, which has darkened the cedar. How can I treat the new cedar to make it the same color as the old cedar?

title: ARTFUL SURVIVOR
description: In the late 1950's, one of my second-grade pupils in a small private school in Manhattan was Helen Frankenthaler's nephew Clifford. Through Clifford's mother, the class was invited to view a show of Frankenthaler's work at, as I recall, the Jewish Museum. The artist was not present.

title: A Renaissance City in Spain
description: LEAD: UBEDA is that rare city where the architectural integrity of the Renaissance remains palpable. ''You can see great works of art all over Spain,'' says Natalio Rivas, a town historian and owner of one of Ubeda's 16th-century palaces, ''but nowhere else can you find such a homogeneous assemblage of architectural style as we have here.

title: Sarah Gambling Weds L.I. Lawyer
description: Sarah Jane Gambling and Donald Martin McGayhey were married yesterday at the Shelter Island (L.I.) Presbyterian Church by the Rev. William R. Grimbol. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Gambling of New York and Shelter Island. Mr. McGayhey is a son of Mrs. William G. Dickerson of Shelter Island and the late Martin E. McGayhey.

title: Better-Paid Teachers Head Back to School
description: SOME teachers will be spending a part of their summer vacations in class, learning about teaching. The sessions will eventually be required of all the public school teachers in the state and are essentially the price they will have to pay for the salary raises they have been given in the last few years.

title: What Will the People of China Do Next?
description: To the Editor:

title: Improving Maternity Care for Poor
description: LEAD: A 16-MONTH-OLD state program aimed at cutting New Jersey's infant mortality rate is giving thousands of disadvantaged pregnant women comprehensive maternity care that health officials say is as good as or better than the care that wealthier mothers-to-be routinely receive. The program is also channeling more resources into the often beleaguered centers that serve poor women and their children.

title: Graduation Unceremonies
description: We went to graduation early to get good seats. Even so, we won't see the big moment until tomorrow. That's when the photos come back. A few of us saw the diploma change hands, in miniature, through our viewfinders. The rest of us missed it entirely. Our view was blocked by people crowding in front of the rostrum, standing on chairs, squinting through their own viewfinders at what used to be, and could be again, a ceremony.

title: Miss Unnameable (18-1) Wins
description: Miss Unnameable, the longest shot in the race at 18 to 1, led every step of the way over a soft and boggy grass course to win the $120,000 New York Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Unleashing the Dark Methods of the Cultural Revolution
description: THE scene could have come straight from the Cultural Revolution: 26 workers who had participated in the democracy movement were forced onto a stage before a packed meeting hall, so the masses could jeer at them. The workers' heads had been shaven, and some of them wore placards around their necks, giving their names and ''crimes.'' Their public humiliation was a prelude to the next punishment: reform through hard labor in a work camp.

title: As Applause Dies, Abdul-Jabbar Quietly Reflects
description: It was the first day of his retirement and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar was back in the Forum. Sitting amid the empty seats, his long legs stretched out into an aisle, he was serene in serene surroundings.

title: On the Record With a Witness To Sales Tricks
description: In their publicly professed view of audio retailing, most equipment manufacturers resemble those Chinese monkeys who see, hear and speak no evil. They don't want anyone to get mad at them.

title: Selecting a Bouquet for Profit
description: Investing in wine used to be a matter of pleasure first, profit second. But in the 1980's, as more buyers have entered the field, a group of wines has emerged that can be counted on for tremendous returns, according to William Sokolin, a New York wine merchant and author of Liquid Assets, a guide to investing in wine.

title: Catskills Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I recently built an extension onto my house, the exterior of which is covered with tongue-and-groove cedar siding. For the last two years, the siding has been treated with wood preservative, which has darkened the cedar. How can I treat the new cedar to make it the same color as the old cedar?

title:
THEATER;
A Rebellious 'Everyman' Struts Back on Stage
description: LEAD: On Dec. 10, 1896, A 23-year-old French playwright named Alfred Jarry reshaped contemporary drama - and caused a riot in the Paris theater - with the premiere of his ''Ubu Roi.'' Jarry's political travesty about the despotic, rotund Pere Ubu not only discarded the melodramatic theatrical conventions of its time, it also openly attacked the bourgeois audience, which Jarry considered stupid, childish and vulgar in its pursuit of wealth and power.

title: Sarah B. Polese, Consultant, Weds
description: Sarah Bradlee Polese, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James K. Polese of Beverly Farms, Mass., was married there yesterday to Joseph Vilsack Reineman Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Reineman of Tampa, Fla. The Rev. James H. Purdy performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church. Mrs. Reineman, a graduate of Lake Forest College, is the corporate travel consultant at Braxton Associates, management consultants in Boston. Her father is the chief financial officer at the North Shore Community Arts Foundation and the general manager of the North Shore Music Theater, both in Beverly, Mass.

title: A Highway of the Future Whose Time Has Passed
description: Burrowing through an island and floating across a lake, the stretch of Interstate highway that opened here this month was supposed to be the road of the future. But after 30 years of planning and construction, it is instead seen by some critics as nothing but a historical oddity.

title: The Lawn Jockey Rides Again
description: Bob Ostrander Jr. looked out over his dwarfs, reindeer, Jesuses and Fat Fannies and grew philosophical. ''You know,'' he said, ''you'd be amazed at how many pig people there are. For some it's pigs or nothing.''

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE MANAGERIAL MYSTIQUE: Restoring Leadership in Business. By Abraham Zaleznik. (Edward Burlingame/Harper & Row, $22.95.) Abraham Zaleznik isn't chary of biting the hand that feeds. In ''The Managerial Mystique,'' the author, a professor at the Harvard Business School, argues that the leadership void in American business is attributable to the rise of modern managers - ''spewed .

title: ; Devils Add Poddubny in One of 3 Trades
description: The Devils, who floundered last season after coming within a game of the Stanley Cup finals in 1988, made three trades today as the National Hockey League held its draft. New Jersey got Walt Poddubny in one deal and gave up Pat Verbeek in another.

title: Husband and Wife Take Hurdles Titles
description: Their devastating defeat in the Olympic Trials last year seemed a bit farther away today for David Patrick and Sandra Farmer-Patrick. They became the first husband-wife pair to win a national event in the same year in 29 years - both winning in the 400-meter hurdles - as the USA/Mobil track and field outdoor championships concluded here at Robertson Stadium.

title: Ann M. Paluch Wed To Robert J. Morrow
description: Ann Marie Paulch, an assistant general counsel at Chemical Bank, and Robert J. Morrow, an associate at the law firm of White & Case, both in New York, were married yesterday at St. Anthony of Padua Roman Catholic Church in Buffalo. The Rev. Secondo Casarotto officiated.

title: Aides and Critics Call Pierce A Loyal but Detached Chief
description: Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the only member of Ronald Reagan's Cabinet to stay in his job for the Administration's entire eight years, bristled at the nickname ''Silent Sam.'' But members of Congress and former aides say he was usually as detached in his approach to his department's inner workings as his taciturn public persona suggested.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
A 2d Apartment to Lure the Home Buyers
description: LEAD: AT a time when several developers are offering buyers new cars as an incentive to buy houses, and often not getting much response, Jerry Kramer and Michael Bellas, developers of a single-family-house project in Bohemia called the Regency, will be offering something they feel has more meaningful value.

title: In the Time Deal, the Public Is the Loser
description: Europe's Thirty Years' War in the 17th century was a clash of empires and religions: allies in one battle became enemies in another. White knights invited to help fend off invaders remained as tyrannical conquerors. In the end, the original purpose of the war was forgotten. Great monarchies were created and the real losers were the ordinary people of Central Europe.

title: THE EXECUTIVE COMPUTER
description: The adoption of standard, interchangeable parts revolutionized many manufacturing industries, from automobiles to personal computers. Now it's the turn of the multibillion-dollar personal computer software industry.

title: KING BHUMIBOL'S REIGN
description: In 1953, William J. (Wild Bill) Donovan was named Ambassador to Thailand by President Dwight D. Eisenhower (''King Bhumibol's Reign,'' by Barbara Crossette, May 21). Having directed the Office of Strategic Services, Donovan was an appropriate choice, because the O.S.S. had a powerful and successful operation in Thailand.

title: Jazz: A Free-for-All, But It Flourishes
description: WITH THE OPENING OF THE SUMMER jazz festival season, the annual chorus of lamentations begins. Jazz's big stars, the ones who can fill concert halls for the JVC Jazz Festival-New York (which starts Friday) and for similar festivals around the world, are becoming a gerontocracy with no obvious successors. As time passes and the obituaries mount up, a vacuum grows in what festivals define as the jazz mainstream: the recognized names - like Ella Fitzgerald, Miles Davis, Lionel Hampton, Sarah Vaughan or Joe Williams - who command large, loyal audiences. Meanwhile, New York's other summer jazz festivals - Classical Jazz at Lincoln Center, Jazz in July at the 92d Street Y and three Carnegie Hall Jazz Heritage Concerts - are largely archival. Hence, the laments and the extrapolation: jazz has no future, and its glories are all in the past.

title: George Lansbury, a Research Analyst, Weds Marianna Morgan in Vermont
description: Marianna Caroline Morgan and George Winthrop Lansbury were married yesterday at the Peru (Vt.) Congregational Church by the Rev. Alice O'Donovan of the United Church of Christ. The bride is the daughter of Matthew Morgan of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Mrs. John P. Ruppe Jr. of Brightwaters, L.I. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar G. Lansbury of New York.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: WALTER T. LAWTON;
What It Means to Be a Liberal Today
description: LEAD: IF last year's Presidential election is any indication, liberals are not in style these days. But the liberal philosophy is not dead, according to Walter T. Lawton, the leader of the Ethical Culture Society of Westchester.

title: When the Music Stops
description: I WATCHED my granddaughter play musical chairs at her birthday party. It was the same game I played half a century ago. There were ruffled dresses and little white suits then, but the faces and expressions were the same.

title: Computers Challenge Freedom of Information Act
description: With the Government's continuing shift to storing information in computers, the public faces new obstacles when seeking access to Federal documents, a growing number of legal scholars and lawyers say.

title: 6DIE IN CRASH OF MILITARY HELICOPTER ON CAPE CODE
description: All six men aboard a National Guard helicopter were killed when it crashed in dense fog on Cape Cod early today, narrowly missing several houses.

title: Reagan to Bush: Finish Start
description: Mikhail Gorbachev is ''taking risks for change.'' That is how Ronald Reagan put it in London. ''I believe,'' he added, ''we should take the risk that the Soviets are serious in their desire to reach genuine arms reductions with the West.'' His advice Tomorrow, American and Soviet negotiators will resume the strategic arms reduction talks in Geneva after a seven-month hiatus. Mr. Gorbachev has convinced much of the world that he has the fortitude to cut through the knotty issues that remain. George Bush has not, and reportedly, he has decided against offering acceptable compromises, at least for now. If so, that would brake valuable momentum toward a good agreement.

title: Glitter in the Wings at Carnegie
description: CONCERTS at Caramoor were once strictly a private affair, attended solely by personal guests of Walter and Lucie Rosen. But in 1945, after the death of their son in World War II, the Rosens bequeathed their 100-acre Katonah estate to the town and state ''to maintain a center for music and art.'' The next summer, three recitals in the Music Room launched what was to become one of the most prestigious festivals in the country.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Diapered Memory

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE INDIAN HARBOR YACHT CLUB IN GREENWICH;
In Sail of a Second Century of Seamanship and Camaraderie
description: LEAD: A BOOK called ''A Century of Sailing'' was recently published and is available only in Greenwich, and only at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. The book, published privately by the club, is, in fact, a history of the club, which this year is celebrating its 100th anniversary.

title: Correction
description: An article about ABC's ''Wonder Years'' in some copies of the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday incorrectly characterized the date on which the series had its premiere. The premiere followed the Super Bowl, not the Rose Bowl.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: Despite the seemingly endless rain in the part of the country where I'm cooling my heels, the peonies are in bloom. Since mine look so pretty in pink, my first thought was to take their picture.

title: Reid Norris Marries Charles Buckley
description: Barbara Reid Norris was married yesterday to Charles Boyle Buckley at Our Lady of the Chesapeake Roman Catholic Church in Pasadena, Md., by Anthony F. Warner, a deacon of the church, and the Rev. Columba Gilliss, an Episcopal priest. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. William H. Cowie Jr. of Baltimore and Robert Brewer Norris of Washington. Mr. Buckley is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard W. Buckley of Wilmington, Del.

title: Syria Frees Arafat Backers After 6-Year Detention
description: In a sign of improved relations with the Palestine Liberation Organization, Syria has released scores of followers of Yasir Arafat after six years' detention.

title: A PRUFROCK IN GLASGOW
description: LEAD: A DISAFFECTION By James Kelman. 337 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: America And China
description: When the Polish Government declared martial law in 1981, and then outlawed Solidarity, the United States reacted decisively. President Reagan, expressing outrage, imposed tough economic sanctions.

title: Quality of Life
description: To the Editor:

title: The Zantac Saga Includes the Cost
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Why You'll Never Have Fun in Russian
description: If Russians and Americans are really beginning to talk together, how do we sound to each other in translation? Even when all borders are open, language can still throw up surprising barriers. Translation as a form of glasnost was the subject of a recent conference at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. Aleksei Mikhalev, the translator of John Steinbeck's ''East of Eden'' and Muriel Spark's ''Prime of Miss Jean Brodie,'' described the difficulties of turning English into Russian. Richard Lourie, who published two suspense novels about Soviet-American relations and translated Andrei D. Sakharov's memoirs and Andrei Sinyavsky's novel ''Good Night,'' took on Russian to English. Here's part of what they said. Richard Lourie: In his brilliant and vastly entertaining biography of Gogol, Vladimir Nabokov devoted 12 pages (out of 155) to defining and musing upon a single ''pitiless'' Russian word, poshlost. An abstract noun, poshlost means moral tackiness and all its works, everything that is ''falsely important, falsely beautiful,'' everything that is mediocre and proud of it. Nabokov, the patron saint of the Russian-English continuum simply by virtue of his achievements in both languages, devoted nearly 10 percent of his book to a single word, but the translator encountering that word must render it with considerably more brevity.

title: Judith Riker Has Wedding
description: Judith Clifford Riker and Hugh Clifford Wiley, graduates of Bowdoin College, were married yesterday at Holy Trinity Church in Bailey's Bay, Bermuda, by the Rev. Michael Davis, an Anglican minister.

title: Some Caveats
description: To the Editor:

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Should Ben Johnson Be Allowed to Run Again?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Bowing Out
description: One reason it is so easy for so many to call Kareem Abdul-Jabbar the best ever is that he does not do it himself. Not that it is a matter of opinion. The numbers, the National Basketball Association records - 40 of them, from most points scored to most years played - speak for themselves. Before that he set records in high school in New York City and at the University of California at Los Angeles. Last week, in the last game of his 20-year professional career, the 42-year-old center scored only 7 of his more than 44,000 N.B.A. points, but nobody really cared. The Detroit Pistons took the championship from the Los Angeles Lakers, but Abdul-Jabbar took the bows for what the Laker general manager, Jerry West, called ''one of the most incredible athletic careers ever.''

title: INSIDE
description: Greek Leader's Uphill Battle After a nasty campaign, a corruption scandal and snickers about his romance with a woman half his age, Andreas Papandreou has not only run a hard campaign but is also given a chance to cling to office. Page 3. Anguish by Arabs in Israel The 800,000 Arab citizens of Israel are growing restive and occasionally violent as the Palestinian nationalism driving the Arab uprising in the occupied territories begins to energize them, as well. Page 18. The Winds of Change Washington is a town quick to declare the end of eras and the rise of new generations. But for the last three weeks, history has truly roared through the House of Representatives. Reporter's Notebook, page 23. AIDS Proposal Attacked Experts told Mayor Koch that they oppose mandatory tracing of AIDS patients' sex partners. Page 26.

title: Washington Seeks Promises From Salvador's Two Extremes
description: IN the space of less than an hour, Vice President Dan Quayle met last week with Roberto d'Aubuisson, the right-wing founder of El Salvador's ruling party, and with two leftist politicians linked to guerrillas trying to overthrow the Salvadoran Government.

title: Reviews/Dance; French Dancer in Debut With Ballet Theater
description: Guillaume Graffin, formerly a lead dancer with the Ballets de Monte Carlo, made an impressive debut with American Ballet Theater on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. He and the entire cast gave a glowing performance of George Balanchine's ''Stravinsky Violin Concerto.''

title: CONSUMER RATES
PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: June 18, 1989
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 GATES OF PARADISE, by V. C. Andrews. (Pocket, $5.50.) An orphaned young woman's quest for her lost half brother leads to sinister surprises. 2 3 TILL WE MEET AGAIN, by Judith Krantz. (Bantam, $5.95.) The exploits of a woman and her two daughters from pre-World War I Paris to present-day Los Angeles. 3 4 THE SILENCE OF THE LAMBS, by Thomas Harris. (St. Martin's, $5.95.) A small-town woman goes on a seven-year rampage of lying, cheating and killing. 11 * 27 THE HERO WITH A THOUSAND FACES, by Joseph Campbell. (Princeton University, $9.95.) The human race's struggle for identity, seen through many centuries of mythology. Weeks This On Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 13 YUKON HO! by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $6.95.) More ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 2 47 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) How to solve your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 3 8 WILDLIFE PRESERVES, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $5.95.) The 10th collection of ''Far Side'' cartoons. 4 2 BEYOND CODEPENDENCY, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $9.95.) How to resume a normal life after surviving a crisis. 5 23 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1989 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Charles Weinstock Weds Miss Singer
description: Martine Singer, a daughter of Nicole Silberkleit of New York and Martin Singer of Los Angeles, was married in New York yesterday to Charles Weinstock, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sander Weinstock of West Palm Beach, Fla. Judge Robert Sweet of Federal District Court in New York officiated at the Georgian Suite.

title: Cold Fusion, Superconductivity and Truly Incredible Ideas
description: SCIENTISTS, science writers and authors of science-fiction novels share an occupational hazard: in trying to predict the future they risk looking ridiculous in retrospect.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Using Development Credits to Save Farms
description: LEAD: EARLY this month, Gov. Thomas H. Kean signed a law to establish a pilot program in Burlington County to preserve agricultural land through the transfer of development rights and to insure that farmers retain the equity in their property.

title: LIFE STYLE: The Talk of the North Fork; Past Riverhead, Suburbia Looms Ever Closer
description: At the Hargrave Vineyard here, Abigail Bakker is packaging newly bottled wine. As on other weekdays on Long Island's North Fork, it's quiet. The grapes are swelling on the vines and the roads are all but empty. Now in her 20's, she remembers how it was when she moved here as a child.

title: Adjustments to Father's Day After the Divorce
description: ''WHAT should I get Dad for Father's Day?'' 16-year-old Josh asked his mother.

title: WHO'S TO JUDGE?
description: I respect and welcome second opinions of diagnoses. Others may see a case from a different view. Judge Herbert B. Dixon Jr. should stand back from this case to permit a second opinion. Dr. Morgan's confinement has lost its meaning, for, after 21 months, Judge Dixon can no longer coerce her through the threat of jail. MARIAN CHUNG, M.D. Wheaton, Md.

title: Tarra Mooney Is Wed
description: At the Manhattanville College Chapel in Purchase, N.Y., Tarra Dillon Mooney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David William Mooney of Purchase, was married yesterday to William Gorman Ferrone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard George Ferrone of Centre Island, L.I. Msgr. John J. Cunniffe officiated. The bride is an engraver at the John O. Mooney Company in Mount Vernon, N.Y., a steel and copper plate engraving concern founded by her great-grandfather and headed by her father. Her husband is a principal in Fido Dido, a cartoon syndication concern, and a seller for Index Stock International, a photography library service, both in Manhattan.

title: Braving the Heat and Sun, in High Style
description: The sun umbrella is making a modest comeback, along with sheltering - and flirty - accessories like wide-brimmed hats, fans and gloves, merchants in New York say.

title:
FOCUS: Baltimore;
Affluent Homeowners Rebel at Tax Rate
description: LEAD: A TAX revolt bloomed here this spring, creating fear in city leaders accustomed to promoting the rebirth of the Inner Harbor and its connecting downtown areas.

title: TALKING: Modulars; The Pluses Outweigh The Pitfalls
description: EVEN though modular homes are becoming increasingly commonplace, they can still generate the kind of apprehension that comes from unfamiliarity.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Kansas; In Farm Country, Lights, Cameras And Passing Fame
description: The arrow on the red stenciled sign on County Road 1055 pointed the way. ''Movie,'' it said. About 1,200 extras, including students from the University of Kansas in nearby Lawrence, gathered in the farmlands near this town last weekend to be a part of Hollywood.

title: Executives Recruit Children for Fresh Air Fund
description: Playful giggles mixed with horseplay as the children of the Adolph Ochs School in Manhattan honored the insurance company executives who had enlisted them for a summer of discovery.

title: Winner Loses
description: It seemed like a good idea at the time: bidding $800 for two confiscated tickets to a sold-out scheduled game between the Lakers and the Pistons in the National Basketball Association's championship series at the Palace in Auburn Hills, Mich.

title: POSTINGS: Showroom to Condos; 19 Montclair Duplexes
description: A one-time Chevrolet auto dealership in the heart of Montclair, N.J., has been transformed into 19 duplex condominium apartments through a development plan that has just been completed. Called Arbor Gate, the $3.3 million project involved gutting a building left empty for over a decade, while leaving in place the large curved oak roof trusses, which remain exposed. New sides were added to the curved, two-story structure, which then was divided into the 19 units.

title: Charles Mohr, a Times Reporter Who Covered War, Is Dead at 60
description: Charles Mohr, a prize-winning correspondent who covered the wars in Vietnam and the Middle East as well as political and military affairs for The New York Times for 25 years, died of heart failure at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md., Friday night on his 60th birthday.

title: Mitchell Hits 24th As Giants Beat Reds
description: Kevin Mitchell broke a brief dry spell with his 24th homer and a rookie, Dennis Cook, pitched a six-hitter and contributed a triple as San Francisco beat Cincinnati today, 8-1.

title: Lynne McGraw Becomes Bride Of R. L. Starkey
description: Lynne A. McGraw, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. McGraw of Bedminster, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Lester Starkey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester H. Starkey of Downey and Pomona, Calif. The Rev. Harry B. Whitley, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Roxbury Township Journal; Blast Serves to Remind Town of Its Ambivalence on Plant
description: WHEN the ground stopped shaking and the last shards of glass tinkled into silence after a recent explosion at a local gunpowder plant, many residents watched a ball of flame climb into the predawn sky, certain that, as several put it, ''it was Hercules going off again.''

title: The 300-Year-Long New York City Light Show
description: NEW YORKERS, perhaps overzealous in pursuing the Lord's strictures about letting there be light, have been engaged for nearly 300 years in blotting out the dark interval known as night. Ever since 1697, when the first public lighting ordinance was issued in the British colony requiring every seventh house to hang out a candle and a lantern pole on moonless nights, the goal has always been to shed more light on city streets, both to inhibit skulking crime and to offer esthetic inducements to the citizens for greater enjoyment of the thoroughfares during evening hours.

title: WHEN LEIBNER CALLS, THE NETWORKS LISTEN
description: LOOK, HOW DO WE GET THIS DONE QUICK AND clean, without a mess? I think that they're pleased with him, or he wouldn't be on that beat. He's ridden out that contract. How anyone could have signed a contract like that is nuts. Anyone who couldn't have gotten a contract closer to six figures is nuts. . . .

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Pennsylvania; Summer Interns Meet and Mingle With a Little Help
description: With its lure of politics, ''connections'' and Congressional internships, the nation's capital becomes a magnet each June for thousands of college students in search of the perfect summer job.

title: DATA BANK: June 18, 1989

GARDENING;
When Plants Poison Their Neighbors
description: LEAD: A SURE sign of trouble is a shrinking rhododendron. This seems to happen when rhododendrons are planted near walnut trees. The culprit is juglone, a substance produced by the walnut and released into the soil, and this phenomenon is called allelopathy.

title: Review/Theater; A Quebecois View of Love's Pursuit
description: As long as there is life, there is romance, as all the French know, and one point Gratien Gelinas seems to be making in ''The Passion of Narcisse Mondoux'' is that as masters of the rituals of the great Gallic religion of romance, the Quebecois surpass everyone.

title: At St. Paul's Church, the History is Family
description: LEAD: THE new administrator of St. Paul's National Historic Site, Margaret Brundage, looked out over the Mount Vernon church, completed in 1787, and said, ''Some day I'd like to be married here.''

title: Harvard Captures The Unofficial Title
description: The Harvard crew won another race today and this one was full of rewards. The Crimson varsity eight beat five of the best crews college rowing produced this season at the Cincinnati Invitational regatta and thus can claim the unofficial national championship for the third year in a row.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: BERNARD H. TENENBAUM;
Furthering the Entrepreneurial Spirit
description: LEAD: PROF. BERNARD H. TENENBAUM is clearly a man of diverse interests. One wall of his office in his Princeton home is lined with shelves filled with books on economics, art and travel; several original Ansel Adams prints hang on the opposite wall. In the basement are books on literature and literary criticism that are awaiting relocation to the office he occupies as director of the new George Rothman Institute for Entrepreneurial Studies at Fairleigh Dickinson University in

title: Yes in My Backyard
description: IF you refer to the Nimby syndrome on a cross-country flight, your seatmate is likely to accuse you of jargon. If you refer to Nimby on the Long Island Rail Road, everyone nods.

title: Are Commercials In the Classroom Cause for Alarm?
description: Nobody seems to be infatuated with the idea of introducing commercials into the nation's schools in exchange for a newscast. The Parent-Teacher Association, the National Principals Association, the National School Boards Association, the Superintendent of California schools and Action for Children's Television all oppose it.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
THEY TOOK MANHATTAN
description: LEAD: Ornette Colman was at the Five Spot and Dylan Thomas was at the White Horse Tavern. David Smith was in Brooklyn and Willem de Kooning was on the Lower East Side. NEW YORK: Culture Capital of the World, 1940-1965 (Rizzoli, $65) celebrates an era to which hindsight is beginning to lend a glamorous patina.

title: Richard Clarida And Polly Barry Wed in Westport
description: Polly Morgan Barry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Barry Jr. of Greens Farms, Conn., was married last evening to Richard Harris Clarida, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Clarida of Herrin, Ill. The Rev. Kieran Ahearn performed the ceremony at St. Luke Roman Catholic Church in Westport, Conn.

title: Graham Greene's Quiet American
description: To the Editor:

title: A PRAIRIE LOVE SONG
description: LEAD: GREAT PLAINS By Ian Frazier. Illustrated. 290 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Pelle the Conqueror 1988. HBO Video. 2 hours, 18 minutes. PG-13

title: WAITING IT OUT IN WARSAW
description: LEAD: MAD DREAMS, SAVING GRACES Poland: A Nation in Conspiracy. By Michael T. Kaufman. 270 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.

title: Why Not a College Admissions Lottery?
description: I JUST got another letter from my alma mater reminding me of my responsibilities. In the next few weeks someone will be calling to ask me to pledge $3,000 over the next three years. Are they serious? Don't they remember what I contributed last year, or did they just pull out the wrong file by mistake? Well, I don't have that kind of discretionary cash, but maybe an idea I've been mulling will get me off the hook.

title: Review/Piano; Pavlina Dokovska Recital
description: Pavlina Dokovska, a Rumanian pianist who has studied in France and New York, played Schumann and Chopin at Merkin Hall on Thursday night. Her solid skills and basic musicality might have held more interest - and, indeed, served music better -had the program been more imaginative. Miss Dokovska, on the other hand, chose almost everywhere to explore repertory long since mined to exhaustion - the Chopin B-flat-minor Sonata and G-minor Ballade in particular.

title: Sarah Greenhill, Consultant, Wed To J. M. Wildasin
description: Sarah Barnard Greenhill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Greenhill of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to James Mason Wildasin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Wildasin of Paris, at All Souls Episcopal Chapel in St. Huberts, N.Y., by the Rev. Alison Mary Cheek.

title: Question Of the Week; What's Wrong With The Mets?
description: The Mets' downhill slide began to gather momentum when Davey Johnson's MasterCard commercial hit the airwaves. His harebrained claim, ''Sometimes I wish I could use this card just to buy me a run,'' is insufferably ironic. Of course, if he can figure out how to breathe some life into this notion, instead of doing an endorsement next season, he can deliver a testimonial. VIRGINIA ANTONELLI New York

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Worcester, Mass.;
Landmarking Three-Deckers
description: LEAD: FROM 1880 to 1930, more than 6,000 three-story, three-family frame houses - known locally as three-deckers - were built here, providing affordable, spacious housing in a variety of styles ranging from Italianate to streamlined Colonial Revival.

title:
GARDENING;
When Plants Poison Their Neighbors
description: LEAD: A SURE sign of trouble is a shrinking rhododendron. This seems to happen when rhododendrons are planted near walnut trees. The culprit is juglone, a substance produced by the walnut and released into the soil, and this phenomenon is called allelopathy.

title: Mary C. Reynolds Marries a Builder
description: Mary Catherine Reynolds, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Adger Reynolds 3d of Sunnyvale, Calif., and Geoffrey Brunet, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Brunet of Mendham, N.J., were married yesterday at the United Methodist Church in Los Altos, Calif., by the Rev. John L. Dodson.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Second Avenue Festival, Second Avenue between 68th and 96th Streets will be closed today from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Federal Construction; U.S. Turning Projects Over to Private Developers
description: WITH pressure on Congress to reduce the Federal deficit, private developers are taking over the responsibility of building and financing new courthouses and Government office buildings.

title: 'Flowers in the Dirt': Love on the Rocks
description: Twenty years ago, as the Beatles were splintering behind the scenes, Alan Aldridge published ''The Beatles Illustrated Lyrics,'' a collection of fantasy drawings by a few dozen artists. The book's end-piece was a Michael Leonard sketch showing the Fabs in their 50's, with receding hairlines and looking paunchy and rich, but too eccentric to be mistaken for businessmen.

title: Sherri A. Lipton And John Grace, Executive, Wed
description: Sherri Alexandra Lipton and John Rovensky Grace were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York by the Rev. John Stubbs. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lester Lipton of Lakeville, Conn., and New York. Mr. Grace is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Morgan Grace of Palm Beach, Fla., and Newport, R.I.

title: Miss Baker Weds Shu-Ming Peng
description: Emily Laurence Baker and Shu-Ming Peng were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of St. John the Evangelist in Hingham, Mass., by the Revs. Robert Bruce Edson and Thomas G. Cleveland.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: There is a time just after the onset of maturity when one must balance the wildness of youth with the growing responsibilities of age. It's a strange time, a time to try new hairstyles and modes of dress, a time to choose friends and to find the combination of visual clues that tells others just who we are.

title: Top Honors
description: Britain may have had the Round Table, but the United States has the Oval Office, which now has its second knight. Queen Elizabeth II last week made Ronald Reagan an Honorary Knight Grand Cross of the Most Honorable Order of the Bath. In receiving the Order of Bath - conferred in recognition of, among other things, his Administration's aid during the war in the Falklands - the former President became the 58th American and second President, after Eisenhower, to be knighted. But unlike knighted Britons, the Americans are entitled to be addressed only as mister. ''I can't say how proud I am,'' said Mr. Reagan as he left Buckingham Palace carrying the star, the badge and the crimson sash of knighthood.

title: POSTINGS: Free Program in the Bronx; School for Supers
description: In an effort to upgrade the skills of building maintenance workers, as well as those seeking jobs in the real estate industry, a group of union and management leaders in the Bronx is starting a privately financed adult vocational school to train both building superintendents and people in entry-level positions. The school, which is under the aegis of groups that include the Bronx Realty Advisory Board and the Service Employees International Union Local 32-E, is to be called the New York Building Maintenance Institute and will be operated at a renovated building at 334 East 148th Street.

title: A BAGFURL OF ELECTRONICS - CARS AND SHELVES THAT TALK
description: With less time to shop and more money to spend, fewer shoppers are making lists and more are relying on their impulses. Shoppers make about 66 percent of their buying decisions in the store, up from 46.8 percent in 1977, according to the Point-of-Purchase Advertising Institute Inc., a trade group in Englewood, N.J.

title: William C. Keady, 76, U.S. Judge In Overhaul of Mississippi Prisons
description: LEAD: William C. Keady, a Federal district judge whose 1972 decision on prison conditions in Mississippi led to a sweeping overhaul of that state's correctional system, died of liver and kidney failure Friday at a hospital in Jackson. He was 76 years old.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Chester, Conn. $175,000 33 Spring Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 24-year-old contemporary; wraparound deck, views of pond, 0.5-acre; taxes $1,147. Deep River, Conn. $157,800 199 Union Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 4-year-old saltbox reproduction; loft area upstairs, old beams, 1.2 acres; taxes $1,394. Lyme, Conn. $500,000 62 Mount Archer Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 3-year-old contemporary; 2-story foyer, guest suite, 4.4 acres; taxes $1,897. Chappaqua, N.Y. $470,000 41 Hilltop Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; fireplace, study, 1 acre; taxes $7,931. Pound Ridge, N.Y. $387,500 Horseshoe Hill Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 35-year-old split-level; 2 fireplaces, family room, studio, screened porch, 2.05 acres; taxes $4,682. Waccabuc, N.Y. $450,000 Makepeace Hill 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 13-year-old contemporary; family room, eat-in kitchen, deck, 2-car garage, 2 acres; taxes $6,040. OTHER AREAS Avon, N.J. $315,000 46 Sylvania Avenue 7-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, century-old Victorian; eat-in-kitchen, h/w floors, 3-car garage; taxes $2,884. Bricktown, N.J. $115,000 51 Bridge Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 28-year-old colonial; fireplace, fenced yard, 1-car garage; taxes $1,318. Bayport, L.I. $158,000 273 Oakwood Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,900.

title: Mathematicians Meet Computerized Ideas
description: SUPPOSE a computer program could give artists their ideas for what to paint.

title: SOVIETS NOW ADMIT '57 NUCLEAR BLAST
description: The Soviet Government has acknowledged that an explosion at a nuclear weapons factory devastated a swath of land in the Urals in 1957 and led to the evacuation of thousands of residents.

title: Language
description: To the Editor: Thirty years ago a schoolmate and I burst upon Europe with four years' of impeccable French (and about a dozen words of German). But language was no problem; sign language, face language and sometimes the intervention of a passing bi- or tri-linguist was all we needed.

title: In Interview, Rushdie Bitterly Criticizes Iran
description: In his first interview since being forced into hiding by death threats, the British author Salman Rushdie has described the Islamic revolution in Iran as a force for evil that has eaten its own children.

title: Moscow's Afghan Mess, Part Two
description: FEW men have worked harder for an end to the war in Afghanistan in recent months than Yuli M. Vorontsov, the Soviet Ambassador to Kabul, who has shuttled among Pakistan, Iran, China and other points in a bid to create interest in the Soviet Union's plan for peace. So it was no surprise when Mr. Vorontsov ended a lengthy absence last week and flew to Kabul from Moscow, still less surprising that he drove almost immediately to the old Arg-i-Shahi Palace for talks with the Afghan Government leader, President Najibullah.

title: INSIDE
description: I. F. Stone Dies at 81 I. F. Stone, the muckraking pamphleteer who tirelessly crusaded for peace and civil liberties and against official evasion and wrongdoing, died at the age of 81. Page D13. Death Penalty: In Limbo Thirteen years after the Supreme Court restored it, capital punishment is bogged down in a costly legal and emotional morass. Page B10. A Media Battle and the Law As the Time-Warner-Paramount battle nears a legal showdown, the spotlight is shifting to the Delaware courts and the ruling that sealed Macmillan's fate. Market Place, page D1. Low Turnout in Poland Poles dealt the Communist Party a further rebuff in runoff elections for a new Parliament, largely ignoring appeals to vote. Page A3.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We found the most serious pollution I have ever seen over primary forest. There seemed to be no beginning or end to the pollution.'' - Dr. Meinrat Andreae of the Max Planck Institute describing atmospheric pollution over Africa. [ A2:4. ]

title: Hough's Knuckler Overpowers Yanks
description: Sometimes, the knuckleball will still dance and dart like a kite in the wind. Charlie Hough will reach back and throw one after another, all day long, and his arm will feel young and strong and resilient again. He will want to pitch forever.

title: 'Steroid Guru' to Testify
description: Testimony in the Canadian Government inquiry into the use of performance-enhancing drugs by athletes resumes today in Toronto, with Dr. Robert Kerr of San Gabriel, Calif., scheduled as the next witness.

title: At Sara Lee, It's All in the Names
description: The Sara Lee Corporation knows there is magic in a good name, and its own is something of a marvel: look once and you see cheesecake, but look again and you see shoe polish, coffee, combs and brushes, toothpaste, packaged meats, underwear, gloves and pantyhose.

title: Next Year, a Reprise for Numbers Players; British Correctness
description: To the Editor:

title: As Vote on Death Penalty Nears, Cuomo Advocates Life Sentences
description: With a vote on overriding his veto of the death penalty expected soon, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has mounted a vigorous campaign to pressure lawmakers to create a sentence of life without parole instead.

title: China's Peasants Get the Bad News
description: An American named Graham Peck who spent World War II in China wrote a book that he called ''Two Kinds of Time,'' putting forward the idea that China moves on another and slower kind of time than the Western world. For all the changes in recent years, the Tiananmen massacre has again illuminated the fact that clocks in the China countryside still run very slowly.

title: Action Urged To Retain Jobs In Finance
description: New York City, now the preeminent world financial center, could watch that position erode and lose tens of thousands of financial services jobs unless both business and government take action, says a report by a task force of the city's top securities companies, banks and life insurance companies.

title: Rae Koshetz, a Deputy Commissioner, Weds Andrew Melnick in Westchester
description: Rae Downes Koshetz, the deputy commissioner for trials of the New York City Police Department, and Andrew B. Melnick, the director of the bureau of city marshals of the New York City Department of Investigation, were married yesterday. Rabbi Gerald I. Weider officiated at the New Rochelle, N.Y., home of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald H. Spiro.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of June 18, 1989: MONDAY Bunker Hill Income Secs PHH Corp DiGiorgio Corp Rochester Tel Corp TUESDAY Brunswick Corp Hexcel Corp CPC Intl Inc House Fabrics Inc Federal Paper Brd Inc Park Electrochemical Corp Gibson C R Co Upjohn Co WEDNESDAY American Tel & Teleg Measurex Corp Carolina Pr & Lt Co National SVC Inds Columbia Gas Sys Inc Rochester Gas & Elec DCNY Corp SPX Corp Dow Jones & Co Stone & Webster Inc Hunt Mfg Co Wrigley Wm Jr Co Keystone Intl Inc THURSDAY American Med Intl Handy & Harman Boston Edison Co Knight Ridder Inc Campbell Soup Co Nalco Chem Co Commonwealth Energy TCBY Enterprises Inc Flightsafety Inl Inc Tektronix Inc General Signal Corp FRIDAY Central Hudson Gas & El Pacific Telesis Group Federal Signal Corp Snap-On Tools Corp

title: Report Cites Secrecy as a Cause of Problems at Nuclear Plants
description: Breakdowns of safety at the Government's nuclear weapon plants are rooted in a devotion to secrecy and in poor management, Congressional investigators said in a report today.

title: Letting Fun Come In First
description: THE annual L'eggs Mini-Marathon, a 10-kilometer race for women, will take place Saturday in Central Park. If you are one of the 9,000 runners scheduled to participate, realize it is not training volume as much as proper competitive attitude that will make the difference between success and disappointment.

title: Coal Strike Extends to 3 Mines in Kentucky
description: Miners at the Pittson Coal Group's only active mines in Kentucky walked out early today, joining a bitter strike by an estimated 20,000 coal miners in six states.

title: William Stephenson, 87; Market Specialist
description: William Stephenson, a specialist in market research who developed a widely used metholodogy for testing subjective reactions to advertising and other communications, died Wednesday at Boone Hospital Center in Columbia, Mo. A resident of Columbia, he was 87 years old and had suffered a stroke last month.

title: A Nuclear Cleanup's Staggering Cost
