description: An $838 million project to clean up chemical poisons and radioactive waste here is providing graphic evidence of the cost of restoring the environment at the nation's 17 nuclear weapons plants.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Davies Is Winner: Laura Davies made a 30-foot birdie putt on the final hole yesterday to win the L.P.G.A.'s Lady Keystone Open in Hershey, Pa., by one stroke over Pat Bradley at the West Course of the Hershey County Club. The putt gave Davies a five-under-par 67 and nine-under-par 207 total for 54 holes on the 6,348-yard, par-72 course. Bradley's 68 was the second-best score of the final round.

title: Pronouncing the Names
description: BIAN HANWU, Shanghai worker sentenced to death: byen hahn-woo

title: Keye/Donna's New Executive
description: Keye/Donna/Pearlstein, a Los Angeles-based agency with a strong creative reputation, has welcomed aboard an industry stalwart, Guy Day, a founder of Chiat/Day.

title: Parking That Yacht - for $2.25 Million
description: It is not easy for most people to find a home in Manhattan, but those who sail some of the world's largest private yachts will soon be able to find a berth.

title: Court Rejects MCI Bid Plea
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that the MCI Communications Corporation forfeited its opportunity to have a multibillion-dollar Federal telecommunications contract reopened.

title: Review/Pop; Songwriter With a Taste for the Dark Side
description: Janis Ian, more than any other songwriter of her generation, is drawn to dark psychological subjects that are not ordinarily broached in popular music. ''Society's Child,'' her first hit, in 1967, described an ill-fated interracial high-school romance. ''At Seventeen,'' seven years later, raked over an adolescence spent feeling ugly and unpopular. ''Uncle Wonderful,'' a major new song that Ms. Ian performed at the Bottom Line on Friday, deals with an even touchier subject, incest.

title: Few Poles Turn Out for Runoff Election
description: Voters in Poland dealt the Communist Party a further rebuff today in runoff elections for the new national Parliament, ignoring appeals for them to vote from both the Government and the Solidarity movement.

title: Honda Gets a Taste of Humility
description: By seeming never to make big mistakes, the Honda Motor Company became the envy of its bigger rivals through the 1980's. But in recent months, to the amazement of the auto industry here, Japan's most daring auto maker has been humbled - maybe briefly, maybe for longer.

title: Outdoors: Ill Winds and Compliant Chickcharneys
description: ONE of my early assignments for this newspaper, a bonefishing trip to Andros Island in the Bahamas, was an augury of what was in store for me in the years that followed.

title: Jockey and Colt Come Back to Belmont
description: El Senor beat Coeur de Lion by a neck in the featured $241,600 Bowling Green Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park, but the race was overshadowed by the returns of a popular jockey and a promising colt earlier in the day.

title: Elliot Sloane and Polly Leider Are Wed
description: Polly Leider, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Leider of San Francisco, and Elliot Sloane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Sloane of Forest Hills, Queens, were married yesterday at Greens at Fort Mason, a San Francisco restaurant. Rabbi Pinchus Geller officiated.

title: Mets Get Samuel for McDowell, Dykstra
description: The Mets today traded two of the blithe spirits and key players in their success of the last five years when they sent Roger McDowell and Lenny Dykstra to the Philadelphia Phillies for Juan Samuel, who will become the center fielder and leadoff hitter on a heavily revamped team.

title: Books of The Times; Everything but Sex (Lack of Time)
description: The Power of One By Bryce Courtenay 518 pages. Random House. $18.95.

title: Peru Is Trying to Shift Focus of Trade to Pacific
description: Overcoming centuries-old ties to Europe and the United States, Peru is taking halting steps to join the booming market on the Pacific Rim.

title: Washington Talk: Guest List; Glamour and Gaiety at 'La Maison Francaise'
description: ''Glitz and glamour'' are what party organizers are guaranteeing at ''La Maison Francaise,'' the French Embassy, Tuesday night. Fashion, politics and charity will be combined at a cocktail party and Karl Lagerfeld fashion show, and it all precedes a black-tie dinner to benefit Childhelp USA, a nonprofit charity combating child abuse.

title: People
description: * Paul Schulman has been named executive vice president and director of creative services at Backer Spielvogel Bates.

title: Claudia Rattazzi Weds Ron Papka
description: Claudia Rattazzi, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Mario C. Rattazzi of Port Washington, L.I., and Ron Papka, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Papka of South Paterson, N.J., were married yesterday at the deServersky Center, in Old Westbury, L.I. Rabbi Rolando Matalon officiated.

title: Children's Savior Recalls A Time of Last Goodbyes
description: The transports that took thousands of Jews to their deaths in concentration camps were a notorious part of the Holocaust, but there were also a few transports that saved lives, and Norbert Wollheim helped arrange many of them.

title: 17-Year-Old Chang Follows A Carefully Laid Game Plan
description: HIS victory on center court at Roland Garros in Paris was still fresh, but on this night last week, Michael Chang was playing Johan Kriek on a bandbox grass court where wide serves thud off the plywood protecting the temporary stands. Contented Dutch cows moo in the nearby meadows and gnats pester the players between points.

title: Devils Sought Sure Scorers in Trades
description: The lure of proven goal-scorers and dismay over their own decline in the 1988-89 season prompted the New Jersey Devils this weekend to trade away three of the team's mainstays in exchange for Walt Poddubny and Sylvain Turgeon, a pair of forwards distinguished by 40-goal seasons in their not-so-distant pasts.

title: Sprint at the Finish Wins for Oravetz
description: Greg Oravetz of the Coors Light/A.D.R. team outsprinted Michael Engleman of the Wheaties/ Schwinn team at the finish today to win the Core States United States Pro Cycling Championship. Alexi Grewal, also of the Coors team, placed third in the 156-mile race, which was run through the streets of Philadelphia.

title: An Archeological Hunt for 'Old' Video Games
description: They stand there as if they owned the place, row after row of bleeping, buzzing, wailing, boinging, whooping and gleeping machines generating a riot of computer-driven color: pyrotechnic yellows, blues, pinks and purples.

title: John Matuszak, 38, A Former Lineman For N.F.L. Raiders
description: John Matuszak, who played on two Super Bowl teams for the Oakland Raiders before turning to an acting career, died Saturday night after suffering heart failure. He was 38 years old.

title: Business and the Law; Bias Rulings Aid Japan's U.S. Units
description: The Business and the Law column on Monday about employment discrimination lawsuits against Japanese subsidiaries in the United States referred incorrectly to the vice chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. She is a woman, R. Gaull Silberman.

title: Downey Plans to Buy His Talk Show
description: In what appears to be a desperate bid to save his ailing show, Morton Downey Jr. said that he would begin negotiations today to purchase his confrontational talk show from the companies that produce and distribute it, in order to change it from a daily to a weekly program.

title: High Ozone and Acid-Rain Levels Found Over African Rain Forests
description: High levels of ozone and acid rain, pollution normally associated with industrialization, have been found for the first time over the virgin rain forests of Central Africa.

title: Corrections
description: A correction in this space on June 8, about a conservationist, Dr. David Western, misidentified the organization he directs. It is Wildlife Conservation International, not World Conservation International.

title: Next Year, a Reprise for Numbers Players
description: To the Editor:

title: Girl's Essay on Homelessness, From Experience, Wins Prize
description: Lashanda Daniels did not have to spend time in the library researching her prize-winning essay on the homeless. For five months the 13-year-old slept at a city shelter, sharing one room with her mother and four brothers.

title: PAPANDREOU LOSES MAJORITY CONTROL IN GREEK ELECTION
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou lost control of the Greek Parliament in national elections on Sunday, but his conservative challengers may not have won the majority needed to form a government.

title: Question Box
description: Temperamental Golfer Q. Tommy Bolt was reputed to have the worst temper in golf years ago, but he had some successes in the game, too. How good a player was he? A. Good enough to win the United States Open by four strokes over Gary Player in Tulsa, Okla., 31 years ago, and impressive enough to have won 14 other tournaments. Though he never led the annual money-winning standing in his years on the tour from 1950 to 1964, Bolt, now 71 years old, might have led in club-throwing as he drew warnings, reprimands, fines and even suspensions for his outbursts on the course. Still, he earned $320,792 and finished ahead of the field in such major events as the Los Angeles Open (1952 and 1955), the San Diego Open (1953 and 1955), the Tucson Open (1953 and 1955) and, of course, the United States Open (1958). In that tournament, which required 36 holes on the last day, Bolt led after each round with scores of 71, 71, 69, 72 for 283 at the Southern Hills Country Club. A Slugger, Briefly Q. When Davey Johnson, now the manager of the Mets, was a player, he hit 43 home runs in 1973 for Atlanta and earned a place in the record book with Rogers Hornsby for the most home runs by a second baseman in one season. What was Johnson's next-highest season total and what was his career total? A. If anyone had saluted Johnson's achievement that season with the expression ''more power to him,'' he could not have been more wrong. When it came to power, Johnson never had a season remotely close to that one during a 17-year career with the Baltimore Orioles, the Braves, the Philadelphia Phillies and the Chicago Cubs. His second-best home run total was 18 with the Orioles in 1971, and the season after he belted 43 homers he managed only 15 for the Braves. Over his career Johnson hit 136 homers, which means his 1973 total was nearly one-third his career total.

title: Campaign Matters; Anti-Bias Pledge: When the Cases Are Hard to Call
description: If a white candidate coined the campaign slogan ''strong enough to hold the line,'' some people might suggest that the subliminal message was racist.

title: Dance Award Used for Fellowships
description: An annual choreography fellowship has been established in memory of Doris Humphrey, Charles Weidman and Jose Limon by the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C. The fellowship will be financed by the 1989 Samuel H. Scripps American Dance Festival Award.

title: Foley Foresees Minimum Wage Agreement
description: Speaker Thomas S. Foley said today that he expected Congress and the White House to reach a compromise agreement to raise the minimum wage.

title: Jury Selection Begins Today In Princeton/Newport Case
description: Jury selection begins today in the first Federal racketeering case to result from the Government's three-year investigation of Wall Street fraud.

title: Computers to Aid Police In Crackdown on Drugs
description: The New York City Police Department plans to set up a new investigating unit and a computerized data base on 50,000 hard-core drug offenders to extend its crackdown on street-level dealers to more professional criminals in the higher echelons of narcotics distribution in the city.

title: Charles Mohr, a Times Reporter Who Covered War, Is Dead at 60
description: Charles Mohr, a prize-winning correspondent who covered the wars in Vietnam and the Middle East as well as political and military affairs for The New York Times for 25 years, died of heart failure at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md., Friday night on his 60th birthday.

title: Haagen-Dazs Move
description: The fallout from the recent upheaval at Doyle Graf Raj continued on Friday, with one of the agency's largest clients, Haagen-Dazs, announcing that it would remove its $5 million advertising account from the agency at the end of the month. Haagen-Dazs, an ice cream manufacturer based in Teaneck, N.J., said the changes and resignations at Doyle Graf had prompted the decision.

title: They Came Close
description: Yes, it took the Detroit Piston franchise 41 years to win its first National Basketball Association title. But it came within a few seconds of doing so 34 years ago.

title: A Move the Mob Would Like
description: For more than two decades, the Justice Department has waged an effective war on organized crime by assigning specialized strike forces of experienced investigators and prosecutors to regions of the country with high mob activity. Despite this success, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh is preparing to disband the 14 strike forces and merge them into local United States Attorneys' offices.

title: Hy Gardner, 80, Gossip Columnist And a Celebrity in His Own Right
description: Hy Gardner, a longtime Broadway columnist for The New York Herald Tribune and celebrity interviewer for radio and television, died of pneumonia Saturday night at North Shore Hospital in Miami. He was 80 years old and lived in Miami.

title: Thousands Rally in San Juan In Support of Independence
description: Thousands of chanting, flag-waving demonstrators marched for Puerto Rican independence Saturday during Congressional hearings on the island's political relationship with the United States.

title: A Week of Confusion for Bonds
description: After a week of confusing and highly emotional trading, prices of Treasury securities finished with moderate losses in what dealers described as one of the most volatile periods of the year.

title: Rookie Earns Save As Orioles Top A's
description: Mickey Weston pitched three innings of scoreless relief in his major league debut today and saved a 4-2 victory for the Baltimore Orioles over the Oakland Athletics.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-11

title: Consumers Lose if U.S. Presses 'Unfair Traders'
description: To the Editor:

title: Points With a Point
description: Last Friday night, 18 of the best female players in the country got the rare opportunity to display a brand of basketball they feel is worthy of another chance. They put on an all-star game at Columbia University to generate support for their struggling sport and to benefit New York's homeless.

title: Girl, 4, Is Critically Injured By a Falling Bottle of Beer
description: A 4-year-old girl was struck on the head and critically injured late Saturday by a beer bottle that had been tossed from a high-rise housing project, the police said.

title: Takeover Fight Worthy of Wall Street Envelops Small Daily
description: In a small-town Illinois version of a Wall Street takeover battle, the employee-owned Peoria Journal Star is trying to buy a neighboring daily that Thomson Newspapers Ltd., the huge Canada-based chain, thought it had locked up.

title: Crackdown in China; Pronouncing The Names
description: BO YANG, Taiwan writer: bwaw (rhymes with saw) yahng BO YIBO, party elder: bwaw ee-bwaw DENG XIAOPING, senior leader: dung sheeow-ping (sheeow rhymes with meow) FANG LIZHI, dissident: fahng lee-jur (jur rhymes with burr) LI SHUXIAN, dissident: lee shu-shyen QIAO SHI, Politburo member: cheeow sure (cheeow rhymes with meow)

title: Chinese Lose; U.S. Boat Sinks
description: The 14th annual Hong Kong international dragon boat races ended today with Indonesia dethroning the heavily favored Shun De team from China in the men's final. The False Creek Canoe Club of Vancouver, British Columbia, took the women's title from the similarly favored Chinese women's team.

title: 'It's a Cruel Game Sometimes'
description: IN the scorer's tent, Tom Kite turned and stared out under his white visor at the 18th green where he had hoped to be but where Curtis Strange soon would be presented with the United States Open trophy. Over nearly two decades, the sturdy little 39-year-old Texan has earned more than $4 million on the PGA Tour without winning a major championship. And with 14 holes remaining yesterday at Oak Hill, he had a three-stroke lead. But he collapsed with a 78, eight over par, finishing five strokes behind the first repeat champion since Ben Hogan in 1951. ''Too bad,'' an official told him. His face tight and grim, Kite nodded and walked down behind the scorer's tent, past where Strange was being interviewed on television and toward the golf cart that would take him to the media center's interview area. When some spectators noticed him, they called, ''Nice try'' and ''Nice tournament'' and he nodded. Then he looked over to where some friends were standing. But his wife wasn't with them. ''Have you seen Christy?'' he said. Without a word, they shook their heads. ''Meet us back at the house,'' he said. The golf cart was moving now. ''It's a cruel game sometimes,'' he said quietly. ''It's a cruel game.'' Without another word, he sat there as the golf cart weaved through more spectators who called, ''Nice try'' and ''Nice tournament.'' But he knew he hadn't really given it a good try. He knew that his tournament had turned into a disaster just when he thought he might win not only the Open but also, even more important, his first major title.

title: Worker Dies in Florist Mishap
description: A worker died today when he became tangled in a peat-mixing machine at a plant nursery here, the Suffolk County Police said. The worker, Hemryk Debecki, 33 years old, of Calverton, was working at Kurt Weiss Wholesale Florist Inc. mixing peat and water in a loading machine when he apparently lost his footing, said Officer Peter Kelly, a police spokesman. Mr. Debecki was pronounced dead at the scene.

title: Dana Friedman Weds a Lawyer
description: Dana Caryl Friedman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. K. Evan Friedman of New York and Lakeville, Conn., was married yesterday at the family home in Lakeville to Paul Robert Kiesel, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard L. Kiesel of Short Hills, N.J., by Rabbi Israel F. Dresner.

title: Fern B. Drillings Becomes a Bride
description: Fern Brenda Drillings, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Drillings of New York and Richard Henry Bregman, the son of Elaine Bregman of Spring Valley, N.Y., and the late Jack Bregman, were married yesterday at the Pierre in New York by Cantor Bruce Ruben.

title: Khomeini Upheld the Ideals and Values of Islam
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Places Priority on Cuts in Troops, Not Missiles
description: For the first time since the United States and the Soviet Union began talks on long-range nuclear weapons 20 years ago, the negotiations for an accord to limit strategic arms are not Washington's top arms-control priority.

title: 'Europhoria' And Sales Promotions
description: HERE'S a hypothetical case study from the 1992 textbook:

title: 2 to Be Named to F.C.C.
description: President Bush said on Friday that he would nominate a Washington lawyer, Sherrie P. Marshall, and the Illinois Commerce Commission chief, Andrew C. Barrett, to the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Unlikely Alliance Atop Bush's Staff
description: After nearly five months in office, the White House staff has assumed a shape that reflects President Bush's relaxed, unpredictable and almost secretive style, and an odd-couple alliance between John H. Sununu, the chief of staff, and Richard G. Darman, the budget director.

title: Environmental Journal Trying to Go It Alone
description: Magazines on the environment have often depended on sponsoring organizations like the Sierra Club and Greenpeace for their budgets. But one magazine is entering the territory as an independent.

title: Conspicuous Absences Revive a Debate
description: When a field of Olympians including Carl Lewis, Greg Foster, Jackie Joyner-Kersee, Andre Phillips, Evelyn Ashford and Butch Reynolds failed to compete last week here in the the USA/Mobil outdoor track and field championships, it assured that the United States would not be sending its most talented team to the World Cup in September in Barcelona, Spain.

title: Bigger Empire Is Aim Of Goldman Financial
description: David L. Goldman, starting from close to scratch, has built up a small industrial empire in the last three years and now is seeking to enlarge it with a $120 million offer to buy the Gleason Corporation, a leading maker of gear equipment.

title: Federal Funds for N.J. Transit
description: The Federal Government will give N.J. Transit $211 million over the next three years to pay for new and rehabilitated rail cars, track repairs and other capital improvements, an N.J. Transit spokeswoman, Rose Sheridan, said today.

title: The Franchise Retires
description: At times during the playoffs it was painful to watch him. Once quick, fluid and graceful in the low post, he was slow, occasionally clumsy and mechanical. His patented sky hook, once as good as money in the bank, now bounced hard off the rim.

title: Chief Seeking to Double Size of Applied Power
description: Richard G. Sim, chairman and chief executive of Applied Power Inc., is an executive intent on growth, and he went a way toward achieving it last week with his company's plan to acquire the Barry Wright Corporation for $145 million.

title: Crackdown in China; Which China Is for Real?
description: Over the last decade, the world had grown used to a China that seemed inexorably on the move toward the free market of ideas, as well as of commodities; a land of cordial, even convivial Communism.

title: Review/Opera; Making the Leap From Sea to Stars
description: There is much that is admirable about ''Under the Double Moon,'' Anthony Davis's new opera. The score received its first performance Thursday night by the Opera Theater of St. Louis at the Loretto-Hilton Center. This writer saw the Saturday evening performance, and repeats are scheduled for Wednesday and Friday.

title: Sports Logos Become Symbols of Big Profits
description: Only a few years ago, designer status most often took the form of the crossed G's of Gucci, or Ralph Lauren's signature polo horse. But a new kind of designer label is captivating millions of Americans: the Lone Star symbol of the Dallas Cowboys, or the Penn State Nittany Lion.

title: 'Trovatore' in the Park Starts the Season
description: By now a New York institution, the Metropolitan Opera's 23d annual season of free concert performances in the parks, sponsored by Chemical Bank, begins tonight with Verdi's ''Trovatore.''

title: Profits Over Politics; Economic Success of West Germany Underscored During Gorbachev Visit
description: The four-day visit by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union last week underscored a significant change in the relationship between politics and economics in West Germany. A good part of Mr. Gorbachev's time was spent with German bankers and business executives, whose foremost interest is profit, not politics.

title: Strange Takes 2d Straight Open Title
description: Curtis Strange executed one of the most efficient rounds of championship golf within memory today to become the first man to win a second consecutive United States Open title since Ben Hogan did it in 1951.

title: Washington Talk; Politics
description: First Ladies have many official duties. They also have an unofficial one: watching over the President's image.

title: Teacher Married To Miss Breinin
description: Constance Breinin, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Goodwin M. Breinin of New York and East Hampton, L.I., and Nigel Malcolm Paton, a son of Comdr. Malcolm B. Paton of Weybourne, Norfolk, England, were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York by Rabbi Martin Zion.

title: Mets Are Just Short Of Overtaking Phils
description: On an afternoon in which they lost some of their tradition and tone in one sweeping trade, the Mets also lost a ball game. And they ached over that, too, because they lost it to the Philadelphia Phillies when Von Hayes hit a ninth-inning home run off Randy Myers to defeat the Mets, 6-5, and end their winning streak at four.

title: Dr. Felise Milan Weds Physician
description: Dr. Felise Beth Milan, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard H. Milan of Port Washington, L.I., and Dr. Mark Joseph Polisar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard M. Polisar of Mountain Lakes, N.J., were married yesterday at the Community Synagogue in Sands Point, L.I. Rabbi A. Stanley Dreyfus and Cantor Jacob Yaron performed the ceremony.

title: Review/Ballet; A Bolshoi Troupe Excerpts 'Giselle'
description: The group currently touring the country under the rubric of Stars of the Bolshoi Ballet actually has a genuine star, Natalya Bessmertnova, to lead it and even a stellar dancer or two of the past for good measure.

title: Dawson, Cubs Defeat Expos
description: Andre Dawson again wrecked his former club, hitting a three-run homer today that sent the Chicago Cubs over the Montreal Expos, 5-4, in the battle for first in the National League East.

title: Managua to Require Americans To Get Visas to Enter Nicaragua
description: The Government has announced that beginning July 1, all United States citizens seeking to enter Nicaragua will be required to obtain visas. The decision ends a policy of allowing Americans virtually unrestricted access to the country.

title: Henderson Wants New Pact, Not Trade
description: Rickey Henderson yesterday dismissed the notion that he might approve a trade before the end of the season, but he continued to hold firm to his deadline for negotiating a new contract with the Yankees.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday Revised G.N.P. 1st. Qtr. Corporate Profits 1st. Qtr. Friday Personal Income May Durable Goods May

title: Union Leader Backs Cooperation With Industry
description: Owen Bieber, president of the United Automobile Workers, vowed today to continue cooperating with auto companies in making changes in working relationships but promised that the union will end such programs if they are ''abused'' by companies.

title: Caren Halbfinger Weds a Salesman
description: The marriage of Caren Riva Halbfinger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. William Halbfinger of Freeport, L.I., to Shlomo S. Besharim, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Besharim of Beer Sheva, Israel, took place last evening at the Dix Hills (L.I.) Jewish Center. Rabbis Jeremiah Wohlberg and Abraham Halbfinger, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Japan Pact On Phones Expected
description: The United States and Japan appear close to settling their long-running dispute over American access to the cellular telephone market here, officials from both countries have said. The United States had threatened to take retaliatory action within a month, All last week, the Posts and Telecommunications Ministry published proposals in the Japanese press to resolve the dispute, which has deeply divided the Japanese bureaucracy. The dispute arose because Motorola Inc. is permitted to use its car-telephone technology everywhere in Japan except the lucrative Tokyo-Nagoya corridor, which has the heaviest concentration of Japanese industry.

title: Nigeria's Economic Plan Falters
description: For nearly three years, to the acclaim of Western creditors and investors, Nigeria has committed itself to one of the most rigorous economic austerity programs in Africa. But the praise has grown fainter in recent weeks as a wave of unrest forced the military Government to begin a retreat from important aspects of the belt-tightening.

title: Corrections
description: A People listing in the Advertising column of Business Day on Friday misidentified the new position of Rolando Sainz de la Pena at Publicis-FCB. He was named chairman and chief executive of the Madrid office of Publicis-FCB.

title: Penalty and Championship for McEnroe
description: John McEnroe edged Jimmy Connors in two tie breakers today to win the Scottish Grass Court championship after nearly defaulting the match because of a tantrum that cost him a one-game penalty.

title: Bridge
description: The host country proved an upset winner of the Asia and Middle East Championships, which ended in Cairo six days ago. A final between Pakistan and India had been predicted, but these countries were both upset by the Egyptian players: Tarek Sadek, Walid El Ahamdi, Ashraf Sadek, Sherif Naguib, Samih Khalil and Samir Salib.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Experts Call For Rehabilitation And Tough Penalties for Rapists
description: Responding to increased public outrage over rape, law-enforcement officials and medical experts called for more effective rehabilitation programs and tougher penalties last week at a hearing of the New York State Senate Committee on Crime and Correction.

title: Marking the Limits Of a Workout
description: FOR MANY years, the small gymnasium where I work out has maintained a bank of three rowing machines with ergometers, exercise machines with which you mimic an oarsman on the water by pulling on a chain connected to a flywheel while sliding to and fro on a movable seat. People who pursue fitness regularly are vulnerable to becoming obsessed about it, and the machines encouraged this in me when I began to use them two years ago. The challenge was to see how many miles I could row during a 15-, 20- or 30-minute stint or, conversely, how quickly I could cover 10 miles or even 15.

title: ENVIRONMENTALISTS AND SOCIALISTS GAIN IN EUROPEAN VOTE
description: Socialists and environmentalists appeared to have made strong gains in all 12 countries of the European Community today, according to initial results of voting for seats in the European Parliament.

title: Matuszak Dead
description: John Matuszak, the former Raider defensive lineman, died yesterday at the age of 38. Obituary, page D13.

title: Andrea Borden and John D. Gillespie Are Married in a Connecticut Event
description: Andrea Varrell Borden and John Davies Gillespie were married yesterday at the Third Baptist Church in North Stonington, Conn., by the Rev. James Cowen and the Rev. Francis McMahon, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Judith Anderson Borden of Great Falls, Va., and Bradford P. Borden of North Stonington, Conn. Mr. Gillespie is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Gillespie 3d of Harrison, N.Y.

title: Summit Books Signs A Moscow Maverick
description: Summit Books has acquired the rights to a new book by Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian maverick Communist. Mr. Yeltsin made Soviet history recently when he was denied a seat in the Congress of People's Deputies, then given one when the Congress reversed itself, apparently in recognition of his popularity with the people.

title: Old Jingles Selling Anew
description: Advertising jingles may be on the decline, but Steven Gottlieb has found a way to capitalize on their nostalgic appeal. A 32-year-old New York record producer, Mr. Gottlieb recently released an album, ''TeeVee Toons: The Commercials,'' featuring 55 of the most famous advertising jingles.

title: 4,000 Protest in Hong Kong
description: Thousands of people gathered today to support the pro-democracy movement in China and watch the unveiling of a replica of the ''Goddess of Democracy,'' the statue torn down by troops in Beijing. About 4,000 people attended the ceremony in Victoria Park. It was the latest expression of this British colony's anger over the crackdown by the Chinese Government, which is to assume control of Hong Kong in 1997.

title: Mass Participation
description: It takes anywhere from $200,000 to $2 million a year to campaign in the 10-race American Hydroplane Series, which helps explain why the sport tends to be dominated by big corporations and why the boats tend to have names like Miss Budweiser, Mr. Pringle's, Jack Pot Foods and U.S. West.

title: Baker Builds Suspicion
description: Why is Secretary of State James Baker trying to undermine the political center in Israel?

title: New York Books
description: The New York Bound Bookshop -a bookstore specializing in new and old books, prints, photographs and maps about the city and state of New York - - has recently opened on the main floor of the Associated Press Building, 50 Rockefeller Plaza. The store, which operated at the South Street Seaport from 1977 to 1980 and on West 54th Street from 1980 to 1988, will be open Mondays through Fridays from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. and Saturdays from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Information: 245-8503.

title: Houston Journal; Freedoms Are Renewed In Recalling Deliverance
description: Al Edwards remembers the first parade 15 years ago this weekend. It was held - hidden, really - in a poor section of town. A dozen cars rode single file down the street, and then it was over.

title: Treasury to Auction Only Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues this week is confined to today's regular auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills.

title: End to Dirty Golf Balls
description: Swash International, a company based in Toronto, has come up with a portable golf ball washer that will also clean your club heads.

title: Strong Dollar May Cut Prices But It Lowers Profits as Well
description: From giant corporate headquarters to small businesses to Americans traveling abroad, the startling rise of the dollar over the last six weeks is beginning to be felt.

title: Nancy Arias Wed to L. Daniel Szor
description: At Temple Emanu-El in New York, Nancy Sue Arias and L. Daniel Szor were married yesterday by Rabbi David Posner.

title: Khomeini Upheld the Ideals and Values of Islam; A Medieval Vision
description: To the Editor:

title: Resignations Over Scandal In Brazil
description: In the latest repercussions of a widening stock scandal, the president of Brazil's central bank and the head of Rio's stock exchange have announced their resignations.

title: Dr. Leon Shein Marries Jill D. Adler
description: Jill Debra Adler and Dr. Leon Robert Shein were married yesterday at the Pierre. Rabbi David B. Kahane, an uncle of the bridegroom, officiated, assisted by Rabbis David L. Silverman and Ephraim Wolf and Cantor Eleazar Schulman.

title: G.M. Gets Australian Engine Technology
description: The General Motors Corporation said Friday that it had obtained a license to use the technology of an Australian company to build a compact two-stroke engine.

title: Explosion Injures 3 in Omaha
description: An explosion in a transformer vault Saturday knocked out electrical power downtown and in residential neighborhoods and interrupted telephone operator service to parts of Nebraska, South Dakota and Iowa. Three workers were critically burned. Jim Brader, a spokesman for US West Communications, a subsidiary of US West, said the workers were replacing a switching unit. Power was restored today.

title: Rebel Leaders Return To Namibia From Exile
description: Eight of the top political leaders of Namibia's guerrilla movement arrived in the Namibian capital today, some of them after decades of exile, and called for reconciliation after 23 years of war with South Africa.

title: Dangerous Dawdling on Debt
description: Negotiations to reduce the third world's foreign debt have stalled over the banks' unwillingness to take the losses. The banks are now much stronger than when the debt crisis erupted seven years ago. Still, they remain unwilling to ease pressure on the debtors. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady rightly warns that the losses involved in debt reduction are far less than those that lie ahead if debtor nations' economies continue to stagnate.

title: Train Derails, Causing Delays And One Injury
description: LEAD: Thousands of subway riders in Brooklyn and Manhattan were delayed and one woman was injured yesterday when one car of a southbound A train jumped a rail, slammed into a wall of support columns and split in half near the Columbus Circle station.

title: Labor Strife Turns a Restaurant Into a Combat Zone
description: With the strike at Tavern on the Green entering its eighth week, the dispute at the Central Park landmark has deepened into an angry urban battle involving a flamboyant restaurateur, a powerful union local with underworld ties and a Federal grand jury investigation.

title: More Help for More Victims
description: In New York as in other urban states, crime victims are an unfortunate growth industry. In 1966, only 196 presented claims to the state's fledgling Crime Victims Board. Last year, the number exceeded 25,000. Yet the board remains a relatively primitive governmental body. Governor Cuomo's proposal to strengthen it deserves support.

title: The Value of Network News From China
description: THE four national television news departments made expensive commitments to cover the upheaval in China in recent weeks, but the money spent is not being calculated as a loss.

title: Busy Conner Regains Local-Hero Status
description: DENNIS Conner was in the middle of eating a fried egg sandwich at Handy Lunch, his favorite breakfast spot here. It had been six years since Conner lost the America's Cup to Australia in this town. But last week, he was acting as if he owned the place. The pay phone behind his table started ringing. Conner, dressed for a day of racing on the maxi-boat Emeraude, jumped up to answer it. ''Handy Lunch,'' he said politely. The caller began rattling off an order, a lengthy request that Conner relayed verbatim to the chef behind the counter.

title: I. F. Stone, Iconoclast of Journalism, Is Dead at 81
description: I. F. Stone, the independent, radical pamphleteer of American journalism hailed by admirers for scholarship, wit and lucidity and denounced by critics for wrongheadedness and stubbornness, died of a heart attack yesterday in a Boston hospital. He was 81 years old and lived for many years in Washington.

title: Changes Urged in Adolescent Education
description: The Carnegie Corporation of New York yesterday called for basic changes in the way schools in the United States teach students in the turbulent years of early adolescence, when, despite a ''desperate sense of isolation,'' they are thrust into big schools and shuttled from class to class.

title: Arrests in Sudan Plot
description: Supporters of former President Gaafar al-Nimeiry were arrested today for plotting to overthrow the Government, the army announced. A statement did not say whether the unspecified number of soldiers and civilians taken into custody had tried to carry out their plan.

title: Rushdie Denies Interview Was Given Since the Threat
description: Salman Rushdie, still in hiding four months after Iranian leaders called for his killing, denied today that he had broken his silence in the furor over his novel ''The Satanic Verses'' by giving an interview to a British newspaper.

title: What's Wrong With Air Travel
description: Everybody knows that recent mergers have harmed airline travel. Passengers say so. A Government Accounting Office report released earlier this month says so. And Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner says as much, by divorcing himself from the Reagan Administration's permissive merger policy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The dollar's startling rise is beginning to be felt by giant corporations, small businesses and overseas travelers. The increase, if sustained, bodes ill for the trade deficit and the economy. For now, companies with large foreign operations expect lower profits, but Americans traveling abroad are getting more for their money. [ Page A1. ] Jury selection begins today in the racketeering case against five principals of Princeton/Newport and a former Drexel employee. The trial will be closely watched in legal circles both because of the use of the racketeering law and because some of the evidence may be introduced in a case against Michael R. Milken. [ D8. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT The U.S. and Japan appear close to settling a long dispute over cellular phone systems. Retaliation had been threatened unless U.S. companies are allowed more access to the Japanese market. [ D1. ] A Brazilian stock scandal has resulted in the resignations of the president of Brazil's central bank and the head of Rio de Janeiro's stock exchange. Share prices have also fallen sharply. [ D1. ] Peru is taking steps to join the boom on the Pacific Rim after noting Chile's success in attracting foreign investment. [ D10. ] A wave of unrest has forced Nigeria's military Government to retreat from aspects of its economic austerity program. [ D10. ] The Soviet leader's recent visit to West Germany underscored a significant change in the German relationship between politics and economics. News Analysis. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Honda has been humbled. The daring and highly successful auto maker's Japanese sales have fallen as its rivals, particularly Nissan, introduced a flood of new models. [ D1. ] Sara Lee's success in managing its many brand names has surprised many business people. Most large food companies have failed in their attempts to diversify. [ D1. ] G.M. will use the technology of an Australian company to build a compact two-stroke engine. The auto maker had acknowledged last month that it could not overcome pollution problems in its own attempts to develop the compact engine. [ D2. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS A drop in the use of advertising jingles disturbs some ad executives and composers. Reasons cited for the decline: shorter commercials and a reluctance to build brand identity over time. [ D1. ] The networks' news departments made costly commitments to China coverage, despite generally tighter budgets. So far, the expense seems to have paid off in higher viewership. [ D6. ] An employee-owned newspaper is trying to buy a neighboring daily in Illinois. The proposed deal raises the prospect of a chain of employee-owned newspapers with enough money to expand. [ D6. ] A new environmental magazine is trying to succeed without ties to any organization. Buzzworm is directed at the 20 million Americans who contribute to environmental causes. [ D7. ] Selling products to a unified Europe will require discounts, contests and trade incentives, in addition to advertising, a sales promotion executive says. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The Delaware courts may decide the fate of the Time-Warner-Paramount imbroglio, just as they forced the sale of Macmillan to Robert Maxwell. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D1. ] Japanese companies may reap the benefits of recent Supreme Court decisions on civil rights. Subsidiaries of Japanese companies have faced growing hostility from U.S. workers and have become targets of employment cases. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Last week's volatility unnerved many investors and traders in Treasury issues. Swings in the value of the dollar were partly responsible. Credit Markets. [ D5. ]

title: Fewer Ad Jingles Are Heard As Madison Ave. Shifts Beat
description: ''If you have nothing to say, sing it,'' David Ogilvy, the advertising genius, once declared.

title: Review/Dance; A Ballet Salute To the French Joie de Vivre
description: It is fitting that, in this year of the bicentennial of the French Revolution, American Ballet Theater is performing George Balanchine's ''Bourree Fantasque,'' a celebration of French joie de vivre. The ballet to orchestral pieces by Chabrier begins with a witty, chic ensemble. Next comes a romantic interlude. And the finale is a feast for the eyes.

title: Agency Group Promotes Self-Regulation on Ads
description: The Association of American Advertising Agencies has helped create a campaign to raise the profile of the advertising industry's regulatory procedures on Capitol Hill.

title: Kabul Journal; Even in War, Afghan Flair for Survival Survives
description: On a blindingly hot morning recently, a country dweller with 20,000 Afghanis, equivalent to about $70, solved the transportation problems that torment a country now entering its 11th year of war.

title: Simplistic and Unhelpful to Blame the S.A.T. for Women's Scores
description: To the Editor:

title: Crackdown in China; An Army's Agony
description: Administration officials say the Chinese Army put party loyalty and internal stability above all else when it fired on unarmed civilians around Tiananmen Square earlier this month. But specialists on the Chinese Army say that in doing so, it created problems for itself that will take a long time to solve.

title: Review/Television; 'Doctor': Medicine As Farce
description: ''Doctor, Doctor'' on CBS is to Marcus Welby what Max Headroom was to Ted Koppel. As a matter of fact, ''Doctor, Doctor,'' a sitcom having a trial run on Monday nights at 10:30, stars Matt Frewer, who portrayed Max from his early days of brilliant irreverence on cable to his eventual suffocation in ABC's commercial packaging. Mr. Frewer is now splendidly demonstrating that his own talent for inspired wackiness is not likely to suffer the same fate.

title: Crackdown in China; Foley Says U.S. Should Consider Further Sanctions Against China
description: Administration officials today dismissed China's allegations that Washington was interfering in Beijing's internal affairs by harboring two Chinese dissidents, and the Speaker of the House declared that Washington should consider further sanctions if the Chinese crackdown on the pro-democracy movement continues.

title: Washington Talk; New Cuban Diplomat: At Ease in a Hot Spot
description: At a reception at Cuba's small diplomatic mission here the other evening, an American said she was disappointed that the hors d'oeuvres gave no hint of Cuban cuisine.

title: For Jerseyans, a New Route to Escape High Living Costs
description: Come fall, a long-delayed piece of Interstate 78 crossing the Delaware River here is to open, tightening the bonds between exurban western New Jersey and rural Pennsylvania and creating a new migration route for disenchanted Jerseyans.

title: Fuel-Leak Rules May Hasten End Of Mom and Pop Service Stations
description: ''For Sale'' signs have begun to sprout at small gasoline stations across the country as owners find they cannot afford the cost of complying with new Government regulations aimed at protecting underground water from leaks from gasoline storage tanks.

title: Society's Conflict on Death Penalty Stalls Procession of the Condemned
description: Thirteen years after the United States Supreme Court restored the death penalty as the ultimate instrument of justice, the execution system has bogged down in a costly legal and emotional morass that has overloaded the courts, divided citizens and left more than 2,100 death row convicts in an agonizing and expensive legal limbo.

title: Dr. Julie Low Is Wed To Dr. Gilbert Block
description: Dr. Julie Low and Dr. Gilbert Block were married yesterday in Belmont, Mass., at the home of the bride's parents, Prof. Francis Low and Dr. Natalie Low. Rabbi Albert S. Axelrad officiated.

title: Cynthia Fissel Wed to Mark Glickman
description: At the New York Society for Ethical Culture, Cynthia Arnold Fissel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles L. Fissel of New York, was married yesterday to Mark Lewis Glickman, the son of Jack W. Glickman of Brooklyn, and the late Mary P. Glickman. Don Robert Johnson, the senior leader of the New York Society, officiated.

title: Spain Joining Money Plan
description: The Spanish Finance Minister, Carlos Solchaga, announced Friday night on state television that the peseta would be joining the European Monetary System on Monday.

title: Brazil Drops Inflation Plan
description: Conceding defeat to relentless inflation, the Brazilian Government has reinstated indexing of the economy and daily currency devaluations, officially ending a recovery plan begun in January.

title: Overfishing Is Depleting a Rich Fishing Area
description: In the waters off New England, one of the world's richest fisheries has been depleted of the cod, flounder and haddock that have long been the mainstays of the industry.

title: Miss Kaplan Wed to Paul I. Kandel
description: Emily Tess Kaplan, a daughter of George C. Kaplan and Barbara G. Kaplan, both of New York, was married yesterday to Paul Iser Kandel, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Eric Kandel of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Beth Davidson officiated at the Parker Meridien Hotel. Mrs. Kandel, a graduate of Bryn Mawr College, is a student at the Parsons School of Design. Her mother is an associate in the New York law firm of Stroock & Stroock & Lavan. Her father is an independent market researcher.

title: Israelis Are Banning 3 Islamic Groups
description: The Israeli authorities banned three Muslim fundamentalist groups tonight in an intensified crackdown on Palestinians associated with the 18-month-old uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Celebrating Summer in Music
description: ''What we're hoping the Fete de la Musique will be is a citywide party with music,'' Martin E. Segal said of the daylong celebration of the first day of summer that his New York International Festival of the Arts is presenting on Wednesday. ''We hope that in addition to the more than 200 events we're presenting, a lot of people will bring out their instruments and perform. Is that legal? We've ascertained that so long as you're not impeding traffic or panhandling, it's O.K.''

title: Home Aide Charged in Aged Man's Slaying
description: A home-care aide has been charged with fatally beating an 87-year-old stroke victim, William Brockmeyer, then setting a fire to cover the murder here, the police said today.

title: Geneva Arms Talks: U.S. Shifts Priorities
description: Talks on strategic nuclear weapons resume in Geneva today, but for the first time in 20 years they are no longer the top American arms control priority. Conventional arms talks are.

title: Dr. Weber Weds New York Lawyer
description: Dr. Pamela Ann Weber, an ophthalmic surgeon at the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary in Boston, and Michael Scott Levine, a senior trial associate at the New York law firm of Roemer & Featherstonhaugh, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz officiated. The bride, who will keep her name, is a daughter of the late Dr. and Mrs. Carl Weber of Buffalo. She graduated from McGill University and Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons. Her father was a dentist.

title: Market Place; In Time Inc. Battle, Eyes Are on the Courts
description: The Time-Warner-Paramount imbroglio has featured shifting rumors and wild swings in sentiment about who will win. Now, as the battle nears a legal showdown, the company name on the tongue of nearly every trader is Macmillan Inc.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PALESTINIAN RIGHTS - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM GOVERNING COUNCIL - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 'A' Party Chief Vs. 'the' Chief
description: A brief report from the official New China News Agency today added to the mystery of who the next Communist Party General Secretary will be.

title: Now Who Was Fickle In the MIG Incident?
description: To the Editor:

title: Adirondack Case Tests Eminent Domain
description: To get to Pine Lake, his property deep within the Adirondacks, Dr. Vincent J. Vaccaro has to use a four-wheel-drive vehicle over four miles of bumpy, muddy roads. He has to drive through a river, 20 feet wide, that swells when it rains.

title: Judith Alica Siegel Is Married
description: The marriage of Judith Alica Siegel, the daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Reuven Siegel of New York to Dr. Gilbert Jonathan Grant, the son of Dr. Abraham Grant of Smithfield, Mich., and the late Elaine J. Grant, took place yesterday at Temple Beth El in New Rochelle, N.Y. The bride's father performed the ceremony, assisted by Rabbi Paul Siegel, who is an uncle of the bride, and Rabbi Haskell Bernat.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Amalgamated Bank of New York, a commercial bank affiliated with the Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union, named Gabriel P. Caprio executive vice president.

title: Review/Music; Filipino Dances Set to Sounds Of Percussion
description: The music and dance of the Philippines came to Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday night by way of California. The Kulintang Arts, as this collection of nine musicians and dancers is known, formed in San Francisco four years ago. They dress in traditional costumes and play a variety of percussion instruments and plucked strings. Central to them is the kulintang itself - a melodic mallet-percussion device with eight bronze or brass gongs.

title: Review/Dance; City Ballet Interprets Beethoven and Mozart
description: The New York City Ballet displayed its prowess and versatility Sunday afternoon at the New York State Theater. Each of the four works it offered emphasized a different type of dancer or dance style.

title: Departing N.I.H. Chief Issues Warning on Politics
description: SINCE he became director of the National Institutes of Health in 1982, Dr. James B. Wyngaarden has deftly steered the agency through Washington politics.

title: Columnist Accused Unjustly Over Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; Henry James and His Country Coterie
description: A Ring of Conspirators Henry James and His Literary Circle 1895-1915 By Miranda Seymour 327 pages. Houghton Mifflin.$19.95.

title: Inflation in Venezuela
description: Inflation in Venezuela will rise by 65 percent to 70 percent this year, almost double last year's increase in the cost of living, the Planning Minister, Miguel Rodriguez, said today. The rate for 1989 so far, 52.7 percent, may slow down in the second half of the year as the Government's austerity program takes effect, Mr. Rodriguez added. Venezuela, which had one of Latin America's lowest inflation rates for many years, saw its cost of living rise by 35.5 percent last year after increasing 40.3 percent in 1987.

title: Elementary Publishing
description: THE Children's Writing and Publishing Center is an attractive and well-thought-out program, previously available for the Apple II series, that is now being offered for I.B.M. and compatible computers. It gives 8- to 14-year-olds a dollop of desktop publishing power for producing reports, letters, newsletters and the like, complete with line drawings, and for printing them out on a dot-matrix printer.

title: I.B.M. and Mac Bibles Entertain and Inform
description: ''THE Winn Rosch Hardware Bible,'' by Winn L. Rosch ($29.95, a Brady Book distributed by Simon & Schuster Reference Division) is our pick for best new microcomputer book of the season.

title: Datametrics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Net income and included gains from tax loss carryforwards of $244,500 for the quarter and $435,000 for the 6 months. The latest 6-month earnings were restated to reflect a first quarter correction of an error with respect to the company's tax provision.

title: Wacoal Corp reports earnings for
description: Year-to year results were not comparable because of a change in the company's fiscal year-end from Aug. 31 to March 31. The company in the 7 months ended March 31, 1988 had net income of $26,840,000, or 87 cents a share, on sales of $553,144,000. Fiscal 1989 dollar amounts represented translations of the Japanese yen at the exchange rate on March 31 of 132 yen equaled $1.00. Fiscal 1988 dollar amounts were translated at the exchange rate on March 31 of 125 yen equaled $1.00. Share earnings represented American Depositary Share (ADS).

title: Heck's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: Heck's is currently operating as a debtor-in-possession under Chapter 11 of the U.S. bankruptcy code. Certain adjustments have been made previously to quarters for reclassifications of store closing expenses and other items. The latest 13-week period included a charge of $8.2 million for store closing expenses, a $1 million LIFO charge, and $1.2 million related to the reserve for bankruptcy expenses and other writeoffs. The latest year loss included a $27.3 million provision for expenses resulting from the closing of 63 stores during 1988 and early 1989. The results also reflected a year- end LIFO charge of $1 million, an increase in the reserve for bankruptcy expenses of $400,000 and certain other writeoffs and adjustments totaling $1 million. The year-ago quarter only included 8 weeks. The company's fiscal year- end changed to February from January during its bankruptcy proceedings. The 1988 year ended Feb. 27 included only 39 weeks and included a $1,983,000 provision for reorganization expenses and a $5,318,000 provision for store closings. The company is listed on the Midwest Stock Exchange.

title: New York Eyes Games
description: Looking to snare the 2004 Olympics for New York, Mayor Edward I. Koch announced yesterday the formation of a sports foundation to spark the building of a stadium, attract another major sports team and involve school-age children in athletics.

title: Robots or Bones? Dinosaur Experts Disagree
description: SHOULD museums display dinosaurs as fossil skeletons or as replicas of living beasts, lunging, roaring and perhaps even sporting the bright courtship markings that some scientists believe they wore?

title: Sakharov in Appeal on China
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet human rights campaigner, urged world leaders today to press China to cancel death sentences imposed on pro-democracy demonstrators. Dr. Sakharov, on his second trip abroad since being freed from internal exile in 1986, sent telegrams to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet President, and Western leaders. ''Please do everything in your power to save from death the participants in the democratic movements in China,'' Dr. Sakharov said.

title: Soviet Cruise Vessel Hits Iceberg in Arctic
description: A Soviet passenger vessel with more than 900 people aboard hit an iceberg in the Norwegian Sea early today.

title: New Survey Raises Concerns About Recovery of Blue Whale
description: THE majestic blue whale, the biggest animal ever to live on earth, appears far closer to extinction than scientists have believed, new findings by the International Whaling Commission show.

title: MCorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After net from discontinued operations of $4 million and a $216 million gain on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After a $15 million gain from discontinued operations. d-After net from discontinued operations of $23 million. MCorp said its results for the latest fourth quarter included $359.5 million of charges related to the change in circumstances, including investment securities losses of $73.8 million. The quarter also included in these charges the writeoff of the investments in closed banks and other expenses. The gain from the disposal of discontinued operations in the latest year results from the sale of MCorp's 80 percent interest in MTech during the second quarter. MCorp also said that adversely affecting net income in 1988 were a loan loss provision of $621.4 million; the writeoff of its investment in 20 banking subsidiaries closed by banking regulators and other expenses related to this action; a reduction in net interest income; significantly higher costs associated with asset quality problems, particularly losses on assets acquired upon foreclosure, and the writedown of various investment securities to estimated market value.

title: Micron Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
Len Dykstra: Scruffy Little Folk Hero
description: rrDown the hall, a state of mourning is in effect. The resident Mets' fan is brooding beneath a series of photographs. Tom Lasorda has his Sinatra wall. This is the Lenny Wall.

title: 200 in Connecticut Flee a Chemical Lab Fire
description: A chemical laboratory that erupted in flames early today, forcing the evacuation of as many as 200 residents, appeared to have been firebombed, the state police said.

title: Columnist Accused Unjustly Over Israel; Historical Asymmetry
description: To the Editor:

title: Village Facing Suit on H.U.D. Deals
description: One of Island Park's few Hispanic residents has taken steps to sue the village, charging that he was rejected for a subsidized house because of discrimination.

title: Beijing Memo; As the Crackdown Continues, China Starts to Seem Just Like Old Times
description: Swept up in liberalization and a mood of relaxation until a few weeks ago, China suddenly seems more familiar to people who lived here or visited 10 or 20 years ago than to those who may have arrived recently.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * G. Kelly O'Dea, a senior vice president, has been named worldwide client service director of Ogilvy & Mather.

title: Ford to Buy Foreign Parts For Big Cars
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would buy some components now made in North America from foreign manufacturers in a move it said was necessary to insure that it could comply with Federal fuel economy rules through the 1990's.

title: Computer Associates and Cullinet Software Are Merging
description: Continuing an aggressive growth spree, Computer Associates International Inc., said yesterday that it had agreed to merge with Cullinet Software Inc. in a deal valued at approximately $320 million.

title: Review/Theater; 3 Site-Specific Plays in Central Park
description: Moving environmentally through the streets and buildings of Manhattan, En Garde Arts is an invigorating urban presence. With its current ''Plays in the Park'' trilogy, Anne Hamburger's nomadic troupe takes a venturesome stride forward. Mac Wellman's ''Bad Penny,'' the centerpiece of the company's current experiment in site-specific theater, encapsulates the lunacy of Central Park and the city that surrounds it.

title: Far Right's Advance Forces Reappraisal by Germans
description: A large surge of voters to the far right led an exodus of voters away from Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats in the West German elections to the European Parliament on Sunday. But when the dust settled the Christian Democrats were still barely on top and Mr. Kohl was apparently out of immediate jeopardy.

title: Peoples Jewellers Ltd reports earnings for
description: b-Included a tax credit of $3,400,000. The company changed its fiscal year-end to March 31 from Aug. 31. The company said net income from Canadian operations was $8,625,000, or 84 cents a share, for latest year, compared with $6,859,000, or 67 cents a share, for prior year. Equity earnings in Zale Corp. were $9,349,000, or 91 cents a share, for latest period, compared with a loss of $817,000 for prior year. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Genovese Drug Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
description: Share earnings figures reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in April.

title: Beauticontrol Cosmetics reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said share earnings data has been restated for a stock split paid in May.

title: 30,000-Acre Refuge Created for Endangered Florida Panther
description: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. today announced the creation of a national wildlife refuge in South Florida to help preserve the Florida panther.

title: Reviews/Music; Survey of Music for Guitar
description: Paul Stern, a guitarist with an uncommonly gentle touch, devoted most of his Sunday afternoon recital at Merkin Concert Hall to works firmly in the mainstream of his instrument's literature.

title: Effort to Sell CNN Center
description: Turner Broadcasting System has hired Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in a revived effort to sell CNN Center, an office-retail complex in downtown Atlanta that houses the company's headquarters as well as the studios of Cable News Network.

title: Herman Alofsin, Dentist, 91
description: Dr. Herman Alofsin, a dentist who practiced in Manhattan for 67 years, died of heart disease Saturday at White Plains Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: KEMP PUTS FOCUS ON URBAN CHANGE
description: Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, tried to shift public debate today from the recently uncovered scandals in the housing department to his proposals for a new and more conservative approach to the problems of inner city decay.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Quite a lot of rioters are yet to be apprehended, and we can in no way leave them unpunished and let them stage a comeback.'' - Prime Minister Li Peng, of China. [ A14:4. ]

title: Afghan Government Soldiers Capture American Journalist
description: Afghan Government troops have captured an American photojournalist who was traveling with rebels to cover the war, a spokesman for the United States Embassy in Islamabad said today.

title: Racal Electronics Plc reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary income of $472,700,000. c-After an extraordinary loss of $575,000. The share earnings figures are before extraordinary items. Results in U.S. dollars have been converted from British pounds at the balance sheet rate of 1 pound equaled U.S. $1.69.

title: Hilton Stock Rises On Speculation
description: Stock of the Hilton Hotel Corporation climbed sharply on continued speculation about the possible acquisition of the company. ''The rumors continue to persist that this company is about to be made an offer,'' said Marvin Roffman, an analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott. Hilton shares rose $5.50, to $102.75, in busy trading.

title: Time Falls By $5.625, To $156.875
description: Time Inc. stock fell $5.625, to $156.875, in heavy trading yesterday, but there was no ready consensus among Wall Street traders and analysts about whether Time would be able to complete its $14 billion takeover of Warner Communications Inc.

title: Baltimore Gas & Electric Co reports earnings for 12mo to May 31
Check Bounces, and Brazil Shakes
description: A single investor last week caused a crash in Latin America's largest capital market, and the tremors are still being felt, Today, the president of the nation's central bank resigned and six brokerage houses were at the point of collapse.

title: Rig Count Up in Week
description: The number of American rigs drilling for oil and gas, a leading barometer of the energy industry, rose by four, to 795, for the week ended Friday, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. By comparison, 905 rigs were exploring for oil and gas a year ago.

title: Rykoff-Sexton Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: Per share amounts in the year-ago periods are adjusted for a stock split effected in the form of a 25 percent dividend distributed Jan. 16, 1989.

title: Nominee's Critics May Fear Challenge to Civil Rights Orthodoxy
description: To the Editor:

title: Staples Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Collins Foods International Inc reports earnings for 12wks to April 30
description: The year-ago quarter and prior year included a gain of $1,229,000, or 5 cents a share, as a result of the sale of assets of Naugles Inc. for both the 12 weeks and 52 weeks. Prior year's revenue included revenue from Naugles, which was sold in the fourth quarter of the fiscal year ended April 30, 1988.

title: Rodime Plc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest periods included a restructuring expense of $11,966,000.

title: Chinese Premier Says More Arrests Are Expected
description: Prime Minister Li Peng warned today that many pro-democracy demonstrators had yet to be arrested, and he urged that they be punished ''without mercy.''

title: Accused Chief Of Crack Ring Goes on Trial
description: A chilling recital of murders and assaults unfolded in a Federal courtroom yesterday as the racketeering trial began for a 30-year-old man who the authorities say headed one of the largest and most violent crack-selling rings in Brooklyn.

title: Doctor Says He Supplied Steroids to Medalists
description: Dr. Robert Kerr, a sports medicine specialist well-known for his expertise in performance-enhancing drugs, told a Canadian Government commission today that he had provided anabolic steroids for about 20 athletes who won medals in the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles.

title: Imnet Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss The latest 6 months included pretax gain of $15,027,000 on the sale of the company's Florida cable television operation. Both latest periods included operations of the company's document image processing subsidiary, acquired on Dec. 16, 1988.

title: NWA's Buyer Builds On His Relationships
description: When Alfred Checchi arrived in New York to meet with the board of NWA Inc. on Sunday after a late-night flight from Los Angeles, he learned that his offer for the parent of Northwest Airlines was the highest. But just as important, he said he was told, ''we were the people who could deliver them a completed deal in the next 30 days.''

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Navratilova and Evert Advance: Martina Navratilova and Chris Evert, the two top-seeded players, had easy victories yesterday in the first round of the grass-court tournament in Eastbourne, England, and the third- and fourth-seeded players also won, but five seeded players were upset. The No. 1-seeded Navratilova overwhelmed Jo Durie of England, 6-1, 6-1. The second-seeded Evert, returning to tennis after a three-week break, had some patches of inconsistent play, but still overpowered Iwona Kuczynska of Poland, 6-2, 6-3. Third-seeded Zina Garrison of the United States eased into the second round when Janine Thompson of Australia retired with a rib injury after losing the first set, 6-2. Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, seeded fourth, defeated Amanda Grunfeld of England in straight sets. Fifth-seeded Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, a finalist at Eastbourne last year, lost, 7-6, 6-3, to a qualifier, Elizabeth Smylie of Australia, while sixth-seeded Lori McNeil of the United States lost to the American Betsy Nagelsen. Hana Mandlikova, seeded No. 9, and 10th-seeded Patty Fendick of the United States both lost to Frenchwomen. Mandlikova was edged, 7-6, 6-4, by Catherine Tanvier, while Fendick returned from a three-month injury break to be routed, 6-2, 6-1, by Isabelle Demongeot. The other seeded player to lose was 15th-seeded Anne Minter, who fell, 6-2, 4-6, 6-4, to her fellow Australian, Jenny Byrne.(AP) An Upset at Bristol: Third-seeded Omar Camporese of Italy was upset yesterday by an unseeded teen-ager, Nuno Marques of Portugal, 6-3, 6-2, in the first round of the grass-court tournament in Bristol, England. Christian Saceanu, the defending champion, was one of three West Germans to advance to the second round, along with fourth-seeded Eric Jelen and Michael Stich. Saceanu, 20, whose victory at Bristol last year was his first on the pro tour, cruised past Neil Borwick of Australia, 6-3, 7-5. Jelen had to win an 11-9 tie breaker in the first set before overcoming a British qualifier, James Turner, 7-6, 6-3. Stich defeated another British qualifier, Austen Brice, 6-3, 6-2. (AP) Pugh Rallies to Win: Jim Pugh of the United States rallied to defeat Goran Ivanisevic of Yugoslavia, 4-6, 6-3, 7-6, yesterday in the first round of the grass-court tournament in Wirral, England. He will face John McEnroe in the next round. McEnroe, seeded second, and Boris Becker, the top-seeded player, were given first-round byes.(AP) YACHT RACING A Ketch Rig Prevails: The 81-foot Fisher & Paykel New Zealand yesterday won the Rothmans Trans-Atlantic Cup, a trophy for the fastest yacht in a race from Newport, R.I., to Cork, Ireland. Fisher & Paykel's 3,000-mile trip took 11 days 14 hours. The New Zealand boat finished 400 miles ahead of its chief rival, the 81-foot sloop NCB Ireland of Cork. Both boats were using the trans-Atlantic race as a practice run for the Whitbread Round-the-World Race, which starts Sept. 2 in Southampton, England. Other Whitbread teams were watching the trans-Atlantic contest closely to see whether Fisher & Paykel's unorthodox ketch rig could compete successfully against NCB's sloop rig.

title: Pope Addresses Bankers
description: Pope John Paul II today urged United States bank executives to be compassionate in dealing with poor nations' debts, saying the problem threatens world peace. The Pope made the appeal while receiving members of the board of Chase Manhattan Bank at the Vatican. He said, ''Attitudes and decisions of leaders like yourselves do make a profound difference for good or ill in shaping the future of humanity.''

title: Talking Business with Barrett of Goodyear; The Importance Of Being Biggest
description: Tom H. Barrett earlier this year became chairman and chief executive of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. He recently talked about his company's future and the dramatic changes in the industry following the acquisition of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company by the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan, and General Tire by Continental A.G. of West Germany

title: Chinese Set for Arrival
description: After three months of visa verifications, four amateur boxers and one coach from the People's Republic of China will arrive in New York on Saturday to train at Gleason's Gym in Brooklyn in preparation for the 1990 Asian Games and the 1992 Olympics.

title: A Team Wins a Contest With Itself
description: FOUR years ago, the Boston Bruins hockey club hired Dr. Frederick Neff, a clinical psychologist, as a consultant to counsel its athletes with personal and performance problems. At first, he and the Bruins struggled to determine his role. Some players rebuffed him; some admitted they needed help.

title: Seeking Effective Strategy in the War on Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Sports Agents Get Prison Terms
description: Calling Norby Walters and Lloyd Bloom ''bad actors'' who must be held accountable for their misdeeds, a Federal judge today sentenced the sports agents to sizable prison terms.

description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which already holds a 17.1 percent stake in Sun Microsystems Inc., said it had been notified by Sun that it would be required to buy three million additional Sun common shares for a total of $75 million.

title: Murderer Is Executed in Nevada
description: A multiple killer and career criminal who asked to ''die with dignity'' was executed early today for killing a drifter.

description: A one-time gain from the sale of its mainframe computer subsidiary pushed the National Semiconductor Corporation's fourth-quarter results into the black, but at the operating level the company continued to lose money.

title: Circuit City Stores reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Rose, Citing Charges He Bet On Reds, Sues Commissioner
description: A lawsuit filed yesterday by Pete Rose against the commissioner of baseball reveals for the first time that the commissioner's investigation has uncovered allegations that Mr. Rose bet on games involving his own Cincinnati Reds. If the commissioner upheld the charge -which Mr. Rose has consistently denied, and denies again in the suit -the Reds' manager would be suspended from baseball for life.

title: Beleaguered Switzer Resigns at Oklahoma
description: Barry Switzer resigned as the head football coach of the University of Oklahoma today.

description: Mexico has extended an anti-inflation program, including a wage and price freeze, for eight months to give Mexican officials an edge in their current debt talks with foreign banks.

title: Forever Imelda
description: Short of Cleopatra, was there ever a woman more infinite in her variety than Imelda Marcos? Beauty contest winner, presidential spouse and world-class shopper, she is something else too. A chanteuse.

title: Soviets Report an Armed Rampage in Kazakhstan
description: Apparently distressed by economic hardships in their region, armed youths have gone on a deadly rampage in the Central Asian republic of Kazakhstan in the latest eruption of violence in the southern Soviet republics, Tass reported today.

title: Stellenbosch Journal; At Afrikaner Campus, Unsettling Ideas Take Root
description: On a balmy winter morning several hundred students lingered outside the administration building on a university campus waiting, with curiosity but no particular vehemence, for a verdict.

title: Supercomputer Link to Oracle
description: The Oracle Corporation, the leading producer of data base management software, said today that it would adapt its software to a new supercomputer introduced today by Ncube, a closely held company based in Beaverton, Ore. This is the first time Oracle has agreed to adapt its popular program, which runs on everthing from microcomputers to mainframes, to a supercomputer.

title: Savings Bill Vetoed in Texas
description: Gov. Bill Clements of Texas vetoed a bill Sunday night that could have increased the costs of Federal bailout programs for troubled Texas financial institutions.

3 Charged With Fraud on Military Engines
description: An indictment returned today contends that a military contractor substituted scrap metal in engine parts used in thousands of aircraft and tanks.

description: b-Net income and after a $299,000 loss from discontinued operations.

description: The Spanish peseta jumped in value yesterday and the Bank of Spain intervened heavily in the foreign exchange markets to brake its advance after the currency was accepted as part of the European Monetary System.

title: Fort Hamilton Claims P.S.A.L. Title
description: Fort Hamilton High School exploded for seven runs on seven hits in the sixth inning yesterday, then went on to win its first Public Schools Athletic League baseball championship by beating Lincoln, 10-3, at Yankee Stadium. Afterward, Jim Apicella, coach of the winning team, wanted to do something else memorable, so he cut up a $5 bill.

The company said during the third quarter of 1988, it changed its method of accounting for certain types of long-term fixed price contracts. The $3 million cumulative effect of the accounting change on years prior to fiscal 1988 is included in the quarter ended Feb. 29, 1988. Sales and income in the quarter ended May 31, 1988, and for the 6 months ended May 31, 1988, have been restated.

description: The independent counsel in the Iran-contra investigation recommended today that Oliver L. North serve a prison sentence for his crimes, saying the former White House aide had committed a ''serious breach of public trust.''

Congressional Anger Threatens Arts Endowment's Budget
description: Angered by works of art that they consider blasphemous or pornographic, many members of Congress are demanding greater accountability concerning grants made to artists and are threatening to slash the budget of the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Mets Looking for Punch From New Leadoff Man
description: Gary Carter sat in a chair yesterday in front of his stall in the Mets clubhouse talking about Juan Samuel, whom the Mets had acquired from the Philadelphia Phillies on Sunday, when he spotted the new arrival across the room examining a jersey with a bright orange No. 7 on the back.
