description: Mexico owes commercial banks over $50 billion but it has few dollars to give them. Debt-equity swaps seem to be an elegant alternative. The idea is to let Mexico give the banks something it does have: factories, land and other real assets.

title: U.S. FUND INSURING HOME MORTGAGES HIT BY BIG LOSSES
description: The main Federal Housing Administration fund, which insures $275 billion worth of American mortgages, is sustaining losses that could drain its reserves and add billions to the Federal budget deficit, according to Government investigators and private auditors.

title: Frances Denney Cos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sabena's Tie to British Airways and KLM
description: In what would be the largest cross-border alliance to date in the European airline industry, Sabena Airlines, the Belgian national carrier, said British Airways and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines would each buy a 20 percent stake in its airline operations.

title: Unfair Consequences Of Student Selection
description: To the Editor:

title: ANTI-SANDINISTAS WARY ON U.S. AID
description: Stung by word that the Bush Administration is considering efforts to influence the elections here, Nicaraguan opposition leaders have spoken out against such aid, calling suggestions that it is on the way a potentially fatal blow to their electoral hopes.

title: A Quail in Every Pot: An Old Delicacy Finds a New Public
description: LEAD: FOR centuries, quail were considered a great delicacy: a dish that only eminent chefs would cook and diners with an appreciative palate could enjoy. These small migratory birds, which are found in one variety or another throughout the world, were available until recently almost exclusively to hunters in the wild.

title: Reversed Priorities in the Battle Against AIDS; To Identify a Menace
description: To the Editor:

title: A Woman Blazes Trails At Tandoor
description: LEAD: IN a small restaurant in Queens, Kaneez Fatima, a 31-year-old Pakistani woman, stands over a tandoor, lowering giant skewers of meat into the flaming pit and slapping hand-stretched breads along the scorchingly hot inner walls. It is an extraordinary sight because in becoming a tandoori chef she has rocked an age-old

title: Former Ballet Executive To Lead Arts Company
description: Charles Dillingham has been appointed president and chief executive officer of Entertainment Corporation U.S.A., a new performing arts presentation and promotion company based in New York City.

title: The Pop Life
description: Back to the Future

title: Waterford Labor Pact
description: Waterford Glass Group P.L.C. said today that it had reached an agreement with its unions that would help restore its profitability and that it was changing its name to Waterford Wedgwood P.L.C. Detais of the labor accord were not released.

title: Mony Real Estate Investment reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,595,000 from investments for the quarter and year. c-After a gain of $195,000 on investments.

title: Too Many Chores? Help Is at the Doorstep
description: YOU arrived at the office late. Forgot to pick up your formal for tonight's company banquet. And failed again to have the car inspected, which means you might get a ticket on the way to the event. Perhaps you can run a few errands during lunch hour, but you planned a working lunch today. Maybe you can have your secretary do it, if only you had a secretary. Not to worry. The concierge in the lobby of your new office complex will arrange to do all of the above for you. Or you might have the concierge at your new condominium take care of it. And if you do not have a concierge, there is likely to be a business near your office or home ready to handle your personal affairs - for a price.

title: Bill to Protect Children From Guns Is Passed
description: The Florida Legislature today passed a bill making it illegal for gun owners to carelessly leave weapons around children.

title: Humana Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
State Of the Mart
description: ''Things have certainly changed, and perhaps for the better,'' Henry James thought. His face was in the hands of a chatty woman busy with powders and creams. He had never had his face improved with cosmetics in the old days.

title: Tavern on Green and Union Reach Tentative Pact
description: The union striking the Tavern on the Green reached a tentative settlement yesterday on a new contract, with raises of more than 20 percent in the first year of a five-year package and more than 5 percent a year after that.

title: Lewis, 3 Others Won't Run In Major European Meet
description: Carl Lewis and three of his Santa Monica Track Club teammates will not compete in a major European meet this weekend.

title: Beijing Memo; Is the Crackdown a Legacy of Traditional China or of 20th-Century Communism?
description: Musing bitterly over the recently televised spectacle of a woman who turned her own brother in to the police, a Chinese scholar reached into the treasury of ancient lore and came up with an old saying.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Soviet Troops Enforce Kazakh City Curfew
description: Troops are patrolling a central Asian city and a curfew is in force after weekend rioting in which at least three people were killed, the Government newspaper Izvestia reported today.

title: U.S. JUDGE FINDS DECEIT BY COMPANY
description: A Federal district judge in Minneapolis has found that officials at the FMC Corporation deliberately destroyed thousands of pages of evidence several years ago in response to a sex discrimination lawsuit and then lied to cover up the destruction.

title: Scrap New York City's Local School Boards
description: To the Editor:

title: Edwards, A G Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a charge of $9.9 million to settle litigation.

title: Hooker to Sell a Share In Most of Its U.S. Stores
description: The Hooker Corporation, the Australian developer whose properties include the Bonwit Teller and B. Altman stores, says it will sell a 50 percent stake in almost all its American stores and sell its three shopping centers in the United States.

title: Ferdinand Stone, 80, Tulane Law Professor
description: Ferdinand F. Stone, professor emeritus at Tulane University Law School and a leading authority on comparative law, died June 10 at Tulane Medical Center in New Orleans, where he lived. He was 80 years old.

title: Apparel America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said the fiscal 1989 quarter included a $910,000 tax benefit arising from the utilization of net operating loss carryforwards as well as an additional interest expense of approximately $309,000 principally relating to acquisition-related borrowings and certain non-recurring charges and expenditures relating to the company's recent acquisition of Primo Designs, Inc.

title: Duff & Phelps Ratings Change
description: Duff & Phelps Inc. announced today that its rating scale for corporate bonds and other long-term fixed-income securities would now match the scale used by Moody's Investor Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Ranger Job Appeals to Johnson; He Has No Offer
description: Bob Johnson, who had spent the morning working with youngsters on skating techniques and stickhandling drills, stepped off the ice in Vail, Colo., picked up the phone at his hockey camp Monday and deftly demonstrated he also possessed at least one skill of a potential National Hockey League general manager: He kept quiet about the future.

title: Review/Piano; Cliburn Returns, In Concert Pitch
description: Yes, to end the suspense, Van Cliburn can still play the piano. The lanky pianist's return to the concert stage on Monday evening after an 11-year absence to perform two concertos with the Philadelphia Orchestra left little doubt about that. The playing certainly lacked some of the heady exuberance and visceral excitement that characterized his music making at the time of his famous victory in the 1958 Tchaikovsky competition in Moscow. But why not? The Van Cliburn who stepped out on the stage at the Mann Music Center here was not that young contest warrior but a graying, 54-year-old statesman of the piano.

title: Reversed Priorities in the Battle Against AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Delinquencies On Loans Fall
description: Consumers fell behind on their loan payments less frequently in the first quarter than they did in the previous quarter, a trade group reported on Monday.

title: Crazy Eddie In Chapter 11
description: Crazy Eddie Inc., the flamboyant electronics retailer, filed for protection from its creditors today under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The company pledged to keep its stores open.

title: China Arrests Another Student Leader
description: The authorities today announced the arrest of one of China's most-wanted student leaders, along with another student who was accused of passing on ''rumors'' to an American reporter.

title: Review/Theater; Fourfold View of London's Shakespeare
description: The rage for Shakespeare among Hollywood movie stars is now a trans-Atlantic affair. Dustin Hoffman, a career-long stage actor but never before a Shakespearean, is dominating London theater-lobby chat, if not exactly London theater, with his Shylock in Peter Hall's staging of ''The Merchant of Venice'' at the Phoenix Theater in the West End. After ''Rain Man,'' the production has predictably sold out its three-month run, and, at the performance I attended, flash cameras augmented the lighting design. This prompted an usher to run down the aisle at the final curtain demanding one poor theatergoer's film and shrieking ''Ignorant people!'' at the fans who violated decorum.

title: U.S. Suspends High-Level Links To China as Crackdown Goes On
description: The White House announced today that it was suspending high-level meetings between United States officials and the Chinese Government. The move was taken to express American anger over the crackdown against pro-democracy demonstrators.

title: Charter Panel Urges Adding To Mayor's Planning Power
description: The New York City Charter Revision Commission decided yesterday to expand the size of a proposed new City Planning Commission in the hope of balancing citywide and local perspectives.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: ON a recent trip to New Orleans, I sampled a variety of seafood salads, many of them laced with peppers and chilies. It is common knowledge that people in the hottest parts of the world tend to cook the spiciest food, the theory being that hot inside somehow makes the sweltering outside seem less oppressive. There may be some truth to this, but I enjoy moderately spicy food any time of year.

title: Mets Lose Strawberry, Then Waste A 5-0 Lead
description: In one horrendous outing in Shea Stadium, the Mets took a 5-0 lead over the Montreal Expos in the first inning last night, lost it in the eighth, lost the game in the ninth and also lost Darryl Strawberry for a week or two with a broken toe.

title: Metropolitan Diary; By RON ALEXANDER
description: DEAR DIARY:

title:
Books of The Times;
Reflections on Poland, A 'Nation in Conspiracy'
description: LEAD: Mad Dreams, Saving Graces Poland: A Nation in Conspiracy By Michael T. Kaufman 270 pages. Random House. trc01 $19.95.

title: Review/Television; What to Do About the Cold War?
description: William F. Buckley Jr. is not likely to be in a very good mood these days. Sales of his last few books have been disappointing. Ronald Reagan is gone, leaving the reinvigorated Conservative movement to ponder the phenomenon of Lee Atwater. Former acolytes are beginning to talk openly about Mr. Buckley's becoming more cranky and less influential in Conservative circles. Mr. Buckley's polysyllabic locutions, his trademark, sound increasingly quaint.

title: Wire Service Joint Venture
description: ABC-TV, the PR Newswire and Indesys, a data broadcast company, announced the formation today of a joint-venture wire service to transmit news to entertainment and television editors and writers throughout the United States and Canada.

title: 2 in Britain Selling Animal-Care Unit
description: Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. and Wellcome Group P.L.C. said they had agreed to sell their jointly owned animal health business to the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation of Northbrook, Ill., for $206 million. International Minerals will also assume $34 million in debt owed by the division, Coopers Animal Health.

title: New Fashion School in India Draws From a Rich Heritage
description: TWENTY-FOUR sought-after graduates in India don't build rockets or computers, they design dresses. They are the first graduating class of a new fashion college set up here with the help of the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10 A top Iranian traveled to the Kremlin and was heartily welcomed by President Gorbachev, who made a pointed appeal to the speaker of the Iranian Parliament for closer relations. Page A1

title: Kitchen Bookshelf: Summer Reading And Eating
description: THE newest wave of books about food promises almost as much good summer reading as it does summertime cooking and eating. A case in point:

title: Knogo Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Unity Healthcare Holding Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Surgery for Burks
description: Ellis Burks. the Boston Red Sox center fielder, underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday to repair torn cartilage in his left shoulder.

title: 3 Freed Union Leaders Vow To Continue With Coal Strike
description: Three union leaders who were put in jail for encouraging strikers to block mine entrances were freed today after promising to obey a judge's restrictions, raising hopes for an end to a wildcat walkout by 27,000 miners in nine states.

title: Admar Group reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Mount Gay Rum Goes To Margeotes Fertitta
description: Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss has become the first beneficiary of Remy Martin et Compagnie S.A.'s acquisition of ''21'' Brands Inc. earlier this year. The agency yesterday gained the account of Mount Gay rum, part of the ''21'' package.

title: 14.2% CML Stake Acquired by Jacobs
description: A group led by Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis corporate raider, has acquired a 14.2 percent stake in CML Group Inc. and said it might seek control of the Acton, Mass., retail store concern. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Jacobs said his group had purchased the CML stock because it was undervalued.

title: Income Opportunity Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest first quarter loss included a loss of $117,000 due to the writedown of GNMAs to their market value, and increases in interest expense, property operations and depreciation.

title: China Wants Executives Back
description: Some foreign executives are trickling back to China after the military's crackdown, but many are wary of being used for propaganda. Page A9.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Gain
description: Treasury note and bond prices rebounded yesterday, largely because the Federal Reserve did not sell Government securities on behalf of the Bank of Japan and other central banks as it had in the five preceding sessions.

title: As the Labor Pool Dwindles, Doors Open for the Disabled
description: For millions of Americans with disabilities, the country's shrinking labor pool of qualified workers is opening up new job opportunities.

title: Utility Seeking Sale of Plant
description: The directors of the Sacramento Municipal Utility District have voted to try to sell the Rancho Seco nuclear reactor to another operator despite a referendum on June 6 in which voters indicated that they wanted it closed.

title: European Chip Move
description: The European Community today threw its weight behind a $4 billion research and development program intended to counter Japan's dominance in the computer chip industry. The European Community Research Commissioner, Filippo Pandolfi, said the community had decided to help finance the Jessi program begun last month by Siemens A.G. of West Germany, Philips N.V. of the Netherlands and the French-Italian electronics concern SGS-Thomson. Britain is also involved.

title: Momentum Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said Aerosol Systems Inc., acquired on Jan. 1, accounted for about $9.7 million of its sales.

title: National Services Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Ex-Fed Official Admits Disclosing Rate Data
description: Robert A. Rough, a former director of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, pleaded guilty today to disclosing confidential information on interest-rate policy to securities traders.

title: Bailey Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $244,000 for the quarter and $1,377,000 for the 9 months.

title: Job Approval Rating for Koch Declines to 1 in 3
description: One in three New Yorkers responding to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News poll said they approved of the way Mayor Edward I. Koch was doing his job, less than half the approval rating he enjoyed at the height of his popularity.

title: CHINESE EXECUTE 3 IN PUBLIC DISPLAY FOR PROTEST ROLE
description: The Chinese authorities staged a public execution today of three young men who were accused of taking part in a violent political protest in Shanghai.

title: George MacNichol, 90, Glassmaker Executive
description: George Pope MacNichol Jr., a former president of Libbey-Owens-Ford, the glass company, died of pneumonia Tuesday at his home in Perrysburg, Ohio. He was 90 years old.

title: F.B.I. Is Said to Get Slips Linking Rose To Betting on Reds
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has betting sheets with Pete Rose's fingerprints on them showing wagers in his handwriting on the Cincinnati Reds, a Federal law enforcement official said yesterday.

title: A Young 'Mr. June' Is at a Crossroad
description: In the major leagues, a baseball player is often measured by the kind of October he has. In high school, a player's ability is gauged by June. And it's hard to imagine any young player having a more exciting month than Jermaine Swinton of Fort Hamilton High School had.

title: Alexander's Inc reports earnings for 12wks to May 6
description: b-Net loss and after a credit of $1,741,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. The company said in the fourth quarter of the fiscal year ended July 30, 1988, the company adopted Financial Accounting Standards Statement No. 96, ''Accounting for Income Taxes.'' Net earnings for the first quarter of 1988 have been restated to include the cumulative effect of the change on prior years. The company noted that during this year's first half it completed the sales of leases and property for stores located in Milford, Conn., White Plains, N.Y. and Menlo Park, N.J., recording a pretax profit of $41,208,000.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: ALTHOUGH it appears so deceptively simple that we take it for granted, learning to go to sleep is often as much of a challenge to children as learning to walk.

title: CLOSE AT HOME
description: BECAUSE I was going to a waterfront festival and wanted to be - in Max Beerbohm's wonderful words - ''a courtesy to the beholder,'' I made a special effort one recent Saturday. My red sweatshirt was coordinated with my red-and-white espadrilles. Between them was a white skirt. By my lights, I looked very nice.

title: Review/Theater; Grim Doings Around a Bar Mitzvah
description: Donald Margulies's new play, ''The Loman Family Picnic'' at Manhattan Theater Club's Stage II, is a catalogue of cliches about middle-class Jewish family life. In it, the playwright is practicing on ground already well tilled by Woody Allen and Philip Roth, among many others. In that talented company, ''The Loman Family Picnic'' is an interloper.

title: European Meeting in Madrid To Discuss Monetary Union
description: LEAD: The creation of a European monetary union and adjusting the severe trade imbalances within the European Community will top the agenda at the community's summit meeting that begins on Monday in Madrid, the Bundesbank president, Karl Otto Pohl, said today.

title: Review/Dance; Works by Zvi Gotheiner
description: It is easy to see why Zvi Gotheiner is such an admired teacher of ballet in New York City, if his classes are anything like the four heroically surging, exalted dances he presented on Saturday night at the Dance Center at the 14th Street Y. Mr. Gotheiner used every bit of the rather large and empty stage space, in dance that soared and plunged and rushed ahead as if in some affirmation of life. The choreographer's intentions are not always clear in his new ''Room for Change,'' set to music by Harold Budd and by Maurice Jarre. But the group piece still grippingly suggests the place of the individual in a world characterized as much by violence as by love and by death as by life.

title: Mohr Memorial Service
description: A memorial service for Charles Mohr, a correspondent for The New York Times who died last Friday, will be held at 11 A.M. Saturday in the main lounge of the National Press Club, 5298 14th Street, N.W., Washington. Mr. Mohr, who died of a heart attack, was 60 years old.

title: Results Plus
description: HORSE RACING Fourstardave Wins at Belmont:Fourstardave, ridden by Jose Santos, came from just off the pace to take the lead entering the stretch and went on to a 2 3/4-length victory in the feature race yesterday at Belmont Park. Closing Bid, the favorite, was runner-up in a field of 10, a half-length ahead of War. The victory was the first in five starts this year for Fourstardave, who covered a mile on the Widener turf course in 1:35 2/5 to earn $28,200 for his owner, Richard Bomze. Fourstardave returned $11.20, $4.40 and $3.20 for $2 across the board. Closing Bid paid $3.40 and $2.80, and War was $6.20 to show.(AP)

title: Books of The Times; Japan's Kamikaze Pilots Tell Their Own Stories
description: Thunder Gods The Kamikaze Pilots Tell Their Story By Hatsuho Naito Translated by Mayumi Ichikawa. 215 pages. Illustrated. Kodansha International/Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: MGI Properties reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Stock Prices Fall Moderately; Dow Off 7.97
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday on slightly higher turnover.

title: Paper Wins in Privacy Case
description: The Supreme Court overturned a $100,000 damage award that a rape victim had won from a newspaper that published her name. Page B9.

title: HOUSE G.O.P. SEEKS INQUIRY ON MEMBER
description: Seeking to defuse a political problem, House Republicans took the unusual step of calling today for the House ethics committee to investigate one of their own: Representative Donald E. Lukens of Ohio.

title: Corrections
description: A Company News article by The Associated Press in Business Day on Tuesday misstated the percentage of stock involved in the Colgate-Palmolive Company's planned expansion of its employee ownership plan. Colgate's board authorized the repurchase of up to $410 million worth of shares - almost 12 percent of the stock at current prices. Colgate also said the $410 million might be used for purposes other than the purchase.

title: Washington Talk; 'Treaty' Within Pentagon Is Elusive
description: Reaching an agreement with Russian negotiators to cut the number of nuclear warheads in United States and Soviet arsenals is one thing. Settling disputes between the Navy and the Air Force over which weapons will be eliminated is another.

title: Review/Theater; Ayckbourn's England And Its Dark Laughter
description: In this Yorkshire seaside resort, where pensioners practice ballroom dancing at the Victorian Grand Hotel while teen-agers hang out at a shiny Pizza Hut, one can see the contradictions of England today. Pressing hard on the cozy English landscape that Americans still romanticize is the hard-edged environment of economic expansion, the Thatcher England of progress or soullessness, depending on one's point of view. There is nothing unique about Scarborough, and that's why it is a fitting home for Alan Ayckbourn. The most extraordinary career in contemporary English playwriting is built entirely of the stuff of ordinary lives.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: OUTDOOR decks require periodic care to preserve their appearance and strength. Easy-to-use products for cleaning and maintaining decks are available from hardware stores and home centers. To repair a damaged deck, more is required: carpentry skills, and sometimes ingenuity.

title: Fuller, H B reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Exchange Agrees to Review Time's Offer to Buy Warner
description: The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would review Time Inc.'s offer to acquire Warner Communications Inc.

title: Mississippi Anniversary Recalls Lessons in Blood
description: Under an unrelenting Mississippi sun, almost a thousand people gathered at a church parking lot today to remember one of the worst civil rights nightmares of the past and to ponder the vexing racial climate of the present.

title: 4 New Prisons Are Proposed For New York
description: New York will undertake a major prison expansion over the next two years under an agreement reached today by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and state legislative leaders.

title: Baker Denounces Executions of Chinese Protesters
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d joined a chorus of Western leaders today in denouncing China's execution of three men for their role in political demonstrations in Shanghai. But he said the Bush Administration was not planning any additional actions against Beijing ''at this time.''

title: Campaign Matters; Party Petitions: The Race Before the Race
description: ''Once the signatures are on them, they become gold,'' said Bill Lynch, the mayoral campaign manager for Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan. He was talking about the esoteric subject of designating petitions for candidates for mayor and other offices.

title: Market Place; Friendly Skies For Speculators
description: TAKEOVER fever has once again swept the airline industry. The contagion is the result of NWA Inc.'s decision to accept a bid by Wings Holdings, a group of investors led by Alfred Checchi, who will pay $121 a share. The $3.64 billion deal has set off a round of re-evaluations. If NWA is worth that amount, how much would Delta, United, USAir and other carriers bring?

title: Philadelphia Electric Financing
description: A $175 million financing by the Philadelphia Electric Company was sold through competitive bidding yesterday to an underwriting group head by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., an American Express unit.

title: James M. Flack, 75, Textile Executive, Dies
description: James Monroe Flack, a retired textile industry executive, died of a heart attack on Monday at a Moscow hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Tryon, N.C.

title: Fannie Mae Offer
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, is offering $400 million of real estate mortgage conduit securities through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Capital Funding. Backed by Fannie Mae 9 percent mortgage-backed securities, the financing offers investors yields ranging from a low of 9.15 percent to a high of 10.53 percent. Underwriters also said that the estimated average life for the multi-tranche deal began on the short end with an average 2.3 years and went out to 18.4 years.

title: Salvatore Bontempo, 79, a Leader In New Jersey Democratic Politics
description: Salvatore A. Bontempo, a former state chairman of the Democratic Party in New Jersey and a government official at the local, state and Federal levels, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Florham Park, N.J. He was 79 years old.

title: Leo Rosen, 82, Is Dead; A Lawyer for 50 Years
description: Leo Rosen, a retired lawyer, died yesterday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a stroke. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly COMMITTEE ON PALESTINIAN RIGHTS - 10 A.M. Economic and Social Council DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM GOVERNING COUNCIL - 10 A.M. and 3 and 7 P.M.

title: Hoyer of Maryland Picked to Head Democratic Caucus in the House
description: House Democrats completed their top leadership team today by electing Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland as caucus chairman.

title: Strange Stays on Top, but Not Alone
description: Curtis Strange is not exactly sure what winning two United States Opens in a row means to him. It hasn't sunk in yet.

title: Review/Music; Celebrating the Sounds of New York
description: There was music all over New York yesterday, from dawn to past dusk. Not just the music of the streets, the brassy honking of horns and the pedal-point of subways, but actual music made by musicians and, sometimes, nonmusicians.

title: Bargain Remedies For Our Educators
description: In the quest for educational excellence, money has needlessly become an obsession.

title: Survey by Fed Finds Growth Pace Is Slowing
description: Growth of the American economy continued to slacken in May and early June while the inflation rate remained fairly steady, a survey of business conditions by the Federal Reserve System showed today.

title: Layoffs at Scherer; 5 Units to Be Sold
description: The new owners of the R. P. Scherer Corporation have laid off 50 to 60 workers and put 5 subsidiaries up for sale so the company can concentrate on its basic capsule-making business, Scherer's president, Alex Erdeljan, said. Since its sale earlier this month to a New York investment group, Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc., Scherer has closed a 21-person Ann Arbor, Mich., research and development office and laid off 27 of the 37 workers at its Troy headquarters, Mr. Erdeljan said.

title: U.S. Growth In Economy
description: The gradual slowing of the American economy is a two-edged sword that will both help and hurt developing countries, a World Bank affiliate said today.

title: Baryshnikov Leaving Ballet Theater in '90
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov will leave his post as artistic director of American Ballet Theater in a year, with the intention of pursuing another career.

title: Bill Passed in Albany For Restroom Equality
description: New York never enacted an equal rights amendment, but women gained a small measure of equity today when the State Assembly gave final passage to a bill intended to reduce the time they spend waiting in line for the bathroom.

title: Pittway Accepts Modified Merger
description: The Pittway Corporation, a conglomerate with interests in burglar alarms, publishing and real estate, said it had accepted a modified merger with Standard Shares Inc., which owns a majority of its stock. Under the agreement, Pittway's public shareholders would receive three shares of a new Standard class A stock for each share of Pittway common in a nontaxable swap. Pittway would also become a wholly owned unit of Standard.

title: Methode Electronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
School Board Members Warned on Conflicts
description: New York City education officials yesterday began notifying 25 newly elected local board members that their board seats would be declared vacant if they did not resign their regular jobs in the school system or posts as political or party officeholders.

title: Calendar: Antiques Festival
description: In the Statue's Shadow, Train Terminal at Liberty State Park, at Exit 14B of the New Jersey Turnpike, Jersey City; 609-768-2773.

title: Seymour Birnbach, Professor, 68
description: Dr. Seymour Birnbach, a professor at New York University's School of Dentistry for nearly 30 years, died of chronic heart disease Tuesday at his home in Queens. He was 68 years old.

title: Personal Health
description: Along with whales and wildebeest, jungles and icebergs, museums and mountains, every foreign trip I have taken has produced its share of medical memories. Fortunately, all the ills were minor, or at least curable, and none forced a curtailment of my vacation. But that fact did not lessen my suffering - albeit temporary -from chigger bites, nausea, diarrhea, sunburn, bruises, backaches, sprains and prolonged abdominal pains.

title: Excerpts From High Court's Decision Barring Prosecution in Flag Protest
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court decision in Texas v. Johnson, holding that a person may not be prosecuted for burning the American flag as a peaceful political protest.

title: Perceptron Sells Stake to Germans
description: Perceptron Inc., a small privately held manufacturer of computer vision systems for use in automobile factories, sold 25 percent of its equity to the Wild Leitz Group of Wetzler, West Germany, for $7 million.

title: U.S. ADMIRAL SEES BETTER SOVIET TIES
description: The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said here today that he believed that the United States and the Soviet Union ''now have an environment where we can talk candidly.'' But he cautioned against expecting swift progress in solving thorny differences on arms control.

title: Corrections
description: A television review yesterday about ''Firing Line'' misidentified the editor of The New Republic. He is Michael Kinsley.

title: Tokyo Faults U.S. Sanctions For Chinese
description: As the United States and other Western countries impose sanctions and condemn China for its crackdown on the democracy movement, Japanese officials have begun sounding a note of caution that such steps could backfire and deepen Beijing's ''isolation'' from the rest of the world.

title: South Africans Reject Effort To Ban World Ivory Trade
description: In a move that is almost certain to limit the effectiveness of a likely worldwide ban on ivory intended to save the African elephant from extinction, South Africa has decided to oppose such a ban and continue trading in ivory.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Bodies of 2 Youths Found in Bags Near the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge
description: LEAD: The bodies of two Bronx teen-agers, who disappeared on their way to school 13 days ago, were discovered Tuesday night in two garbage bags near the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge, the police said yesterday.

title: For Any Chair, Fat or Skinny, A New Outfit
description: LEAD: Slipcovers are back. Not that these serviceable summer cover-ups ever disappeared completely, but the slipcovers now being draped go far beyond seasonal function.

title: OEA Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a gain of $304,100 from an accounting change.

title: A Clear Pronunciation and a Love for the Blues
description: Of all the musical lessons Joe Williams has absorbed in a singing career spanning more than 50 years, the experience he values most is his six-year stint with Count Basie and his orchestra.

title: Reuschel Wins No. 12 as Giants Beat Astros
description: Rick Reuschel scattered four hits in seven and one-third innings today for his major league-leading 12th victory and Will Clark belted a home run as the San Francisco Giants beat the Houston Astros, 2-0, to complete a three-game sweep.

title: Anger but Not Surprise Follows Regents Fiasco
description: Students at Midwood High School in Brooklyn were sorry the Regents chemistry examination was canceled. And they were angry that they had spent so many hours studying for a test they may never take.

title: Washington Talk; White House
description: They operate discreetly within the White House, slipping a memo to the chief of staff, lifting the phone to speak to the personnel director or the head of Congressional relations. They are not quite moles but operatives, a handful of conservatives seeking to keep the White House on the Right track.

title: Review/Theater; 'Arrivederci Papa,' Farce In Drag
description: Gemma, Philomena and Tootsie Mattarazza, who gather at the Casa de la Morte funeral parlor with their obese mother, Bella, may be the noisiest three sisters ever to have shouted across a New York stage. Convened for the funeral of their father, whose body lies in an open coffin, they preen and bicker and dish the dirt in a style that might best be described as camp fortissimo.

title: For New Bridges, a Venerable Material
description: LEAD: In another time, before the age of concrete and steel, wooden bridges were the backbone of New England transportation. Now they may become the structures of its future.

title: Club Owners Balk at Zoning Proposal
description: Night life in New York City might fundamentally change under new zoning rules proposed for music and dance clubs, but whether the result would be sleep for weary neighbors or death for a vital industry was sharply debated yesterday at the City Planning Commission.

title: 7 Makers Plan Chip Venture
description: Citing the critical need for domestic production of computer memory chips, seven American semiconductor and computer manufacturers have banded together to finance the establishment of U.S. Memories Inc.

title: Bulgaria Forces Turkish Exodus of Thousands
description: They trooped by the hundreds across the border today, this latest breed of displaced persons, pushing the remnants of their lives in carts and wheelbarrows.

title: As Nuclear Reactors Show Age, Owners Seek to Add Usable Life
description: The nation's nuclear reactors are getting old before their time, even as their owners say their lives can be extended.

title: Chrysler to Add Safety Features
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would install shoulder harnesses in the rear seats of all its domestic cars and expand its offering of anti-lock braking systems to 26 car and light-truck models.

title: A Bank in Long Island Taken Over by F.D.I.C.
description: The financial troubles of a mortgage-servicing company led yesterday to the insolvency of the Guardian Bank of Hempstead, L.I.

title: More Women in 30's Planning Children
description: The Census Bureau says that among married women in their early 30's, the proportion who expect to have children someday has soared from 33.5 to 54.4 percent since 1975.

title: Charter Panel Endorses Plans On Use of Land
description: The New York City Charter Revision Commission yesterday reviewed, and then rejected, a suggestion by one member that no church or other religious institution be declared a city landmark without the approval of its congregation.

title: Smaller Drop In Yields
description: Yields on money market mutual funds were down slightly for the week that ended yesterday, giving money managers some respite from a monthlong drop in interest rates.

title: Taurus Footwear Inc reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $8,329,000 and $322,000 for the latest and prior years, respectively. c-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Cimco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a gain of $344,000 from an accounting change. Prior periods' shares outstanding and share earnings figures reflected a 5-for-4 stock split effective May 2.

title: Gambling Hurts Sports More Than Drug Abuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayors Deplore Affirmative Action Setbacks
description: Ending a five-day annual meeting here, the nation's mayors adopted a resolution today deploring recent Supreme Court decisions they say weaken affirmative action.

title: House Panel, 18-17, Bars Rise In Jobless Compensation Tax
description: In the first major Congressional test of a tax increase since President Bush took office, the House Ways and Means Committee voted 18 to 17 today against raising the unemployment compensation tax to aid the young and elderly poor.

title: Arkansas Oversight: Sheepish Legislators Have to Repass Bills
description: Lawmakers met in an emergency special session today to repass hundreds of spending bills that had been ruled invalid because the Legislature violated a requirement in the state Constitution.

title: Fund to Award Grants To New American Plays
description: The Fund for New American Plays is to announce grants to seven plays today that are to open in five theaters in the 1989-90 season. Each of this year's grants, one of which underwrites a trilogy to be produced in repertory, includes an additional $10,000 stipend given directly to the playwright.

title: Judge in Liberal Party Case Approves an Open Primary
description: A Federal judge declared unconstitutional yesterday a New York State law that prohibits political parties from opening their primary elections to independent voters.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article yesterday about Black, Manafort, Stone & Kelly, a political consulting firm involved with Housing and Urban Development programs, misstated the political background of a partner, Peter G. Kelly. He was previously national finance chairman for the Democratic Party, not a Bush campaign strategist.

title: HARASSED VETERAN IS AWARDED $86,000
description: Brewery employees terrorized a jittery Vietnam veteran and ultimately drove him into extensive psychiatric treatment by making sudden, loud noises that caused him to throw himself to the floor, two state administrative law judges have ruled. They awarded the veteran $86,000 in worker's compensation.

title: Firm, Not Just Angry, Toward China
description: The news from China, more arrests and now executions, continues to chill the soul, and President Bush is right to tighten official pressure on the Beijing regime. Still, many Americans, liberals and conservatives, demand more dramatic steps like full trade and investment sanctions or the recall of Ambassador James Lilley. Their horror is justified but their choice of response confuses drama with strength. The President is proceeding in a tough and sensible way.

title: Paris Leader Speaks Little, Does Much
description: When Michel Rocard was named Prime Minister a year ago, the prevailing political wisdom was that he would not survive long. He was a foe of President Francois Mitterrand, who designated him after handsomely winning a second presidential term; the new Prime Minister did not enjoy a majority in Parliament, and fellow Socialists regarded him suspiciously as an apologist for capitalism.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Claire's Stores Inc., Miami, a retail chain, promoted Leslie D. Dunavant to senior vice president of its Claire's Boutiques Inc. division.

title: Royal International Optical Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $474,000, or 7 cents a share, due to a change in accounting principle (FASB 96).

title: Soviet Liner's Speed Questioned in Arctic Mishap uf1895>
description: The Soviet ocean liner that rammed into an Arctic ice floe, requiring a rescue operation to pick up nearly 1,000 people, was apparently cruising too fast for safe navigation in ice-littered waters, Norwegian rescue officials and maritime experts said today.

title: Q&A
description: New Siding, Old Siding Q. We plan to have vinyl siding installed on our home. I have noticed that in some cases the old wood siding is removed first, while in others the new siding is put on over the old siding. Is one method better than the other? A. A lot depends on the condition of the existing siding and on what is underneath the old siding. A reliable contractor should be able to give you the best advice.

title: Eastern Acts To Nullify Pilots' Pact
description: Eastern Airlines announced yesterday that it had asked the bankruptcy court to terminate the contract of its pilots' union and allow the airline to cut pilots' salaries and benefits temporarily as it begins to rebuild the carrier.

title: Atlantic City Mission Cares for the Losers
description: William Southrey had worked at the Atlantic City Rescue Mission for six years and was accustomed to lending a hand, so it was not unusual for him to pick up a hitchhiker, as he did one day 18 months or so ago. What was odd was that the hitchhiker turned out to be his old high school teacher and coach.

title: EAC Considers Unit Sale
description: The board of EAC Industries said today that it was considering the possibility of selling its hardware business. The company said the board intended to meet again soon to explore the possibility further. EAC is a diversified manufacturing concern serving the hardware industry and point-of-purchase advertising market.

title: Which Side Are You On: Baggy or Tailored?
description: ASK designers how a slipcover should fit, and the disagreements begin. Should they be loose and baggy, as the English fancy? Or crisp and tailored, as Americans prefer?

title: Troops Kill a Protester In a Rally in Rangoon
description: Troops fired on a demonstration by about 500 people in the Burmese capital today, killing one protester, the Rangoon radio said.

title: Budget Deficit Rose in May
description: The United States budget deficit rose to $25.47 billion in May, higher than the $22.58 billion deficit in May 1988, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Forest City Stake Of 15% Is Sought
description: A group led by Interstate Properties Inc., a New Jersey development concern, and two of its general partners filed for permission from Federal antitrust regulators to raise its stake in Forest City Enterprises Inc. to 15 percent. Forest City is a real estate developer and construction concern based in Cleveland.

title: Talking Deals; Survival Strategy At Cypress Fund
description: PAINE WEBBER'S complex of closed-end mutual funds is under siege, but yesterday, just when it began to appear that surrender was likely on all fronts, the company fought back.

title: Rumania Is Said to Violate 2 Employment Rights Pacts
description: The International Labor Organization accused Rumania today of violating two international conventions guaranteeing protection against discrimination in employment and the right of workers to freely form associations of their choice.

title: Heinz, H J Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 3
Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about news programs at network-owned television stations in New York City misattributed the concluding quotation, which said it was easy for local news coverage to slip into sensationalism. The comment was made by Mark

title: Greeks Open Coalition Talks
description: A conservative party and the Communist-dominated leftist alliance met today to discuss forming a coalition government excluding the Socialists of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou.

title: Telecheck Services Sale
description: The McDonnell Douglas Information Systems Company agreed this week to sell its Telecheck Services Inc. unit to the owner of its largest franchise, the Payment Services Company of Houston. Payment Services signed a letter of intent to buy Telecheck, which specializes in check-acceptance services for financial institutions. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. The deal is expected to close Sept. 1.

title: Ex-Pullman Head Returns, With an Interest in Buyouts
description: Thomas M. Begel, who built up the Pullman Company through acquisitions before selling it last fall, is back in business with a new investment company and an appetite for medium-sized industrial companies.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
The Monster Finally Got Switzer
description: LEAD: rrEverybody at the University of Oklahoma was so distraught at Barry Switzer's resignation on Monday that it took the school all of 24 hours to name a replacement, Gary Gibbs.

title: House Blocks Emergency Spending Measure
description: In a defeat for the newly installed Democratic leadership, the House sent an emergency spending bill back to a conference committee today for further talks with the Senate, backing away from a veto fight with President Bush.

title: A Chilean Securities Fund Files for Offering in U.S.
description: A closed-end fund representing the first vehicle for investing in Chilean securities to be offered publicly in the United States has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: KEY RATES
Review/Piano; An Individualistic Approach
description: There were moments of eccentricity, brilliance, clarity and messiness in Robert DeGaetano's performance on Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, but one thing the pianist could not be accused of is dullness.

title: Making the Chair Sit Well With the Environment
description: THROUGHOUT history, designers have used the chair to convey images like power (the throne) and movement (with wings and paw feet). Recently Paul Ludick, a New York artist, has been working with the chair as a means of expressing an environmental issue: the fragility of the atmosphere's ozone layer. In the process he produced 30, all of which can be seen in ''O Zone,'' an exhibition at the Bernice Steinbaum Gallery (132 Greene Street, near Houston Street) through July 15.

title: Yankees Send Henderson Back to Oakland
description: The Yankees, uncertain whether Rickey Henderson was worth a new three-year contract and desperately in need of pitching help, yesterday made the trade that seemed unlikely four days ago: they sent Henderson back home to the Oakland Athletics for two relievers and an outfielder.

title: Plan to Have F.D.I.C. Sell Saving Units
description: The Treasury and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation are working on a plan to give the F.D.I.C. control of the new agency that will liquidate and sell off hundreds of ailing savings institutions.

title: Thortec International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2.5 million for the quarter and $3 million for the 6 months and an extraordinary gain of $29.1 million for the both periods. c-Net loss and after losses of $400,000 for the quarter and $800,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations; the 6 months also included an extraordinary gain of $1.1 million.

title: QUESTIONS ON FILES AT A H.U.D. OFFICE
description: The Denver regional office of the Department of Housing and Urban Development has not been able to account for more than $7 million that the department should have been received from the sale of Government properties, an internal audit found.

title: Adding Up What Time Might Be Worth
description: Industry analysts have generally estimated that the market value of Time's assets is at least $200 a share.

title: Material Sciences Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Repligen Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Soviets Reopen Railroad Service to Iran
description: Moving quickly in his courting of closer ties with Iran, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today announced the restoration of railroad service across the border and the likely reopening of the Iranian natural-gas pipeline to the Soviet Union.

title: New Yorkers Are Pessimistic On City's Pressing Problems
description: As New York City prepares to select its next mayor, its residents are profoundly pessimistic about the city's future and are divided over the ability of any mayor to come to grips with the most pressing problems they face, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News poll.

title: Otis Bantum, 50, Dies; Rikers Island Warden
description: Otis Bantum, a jail warden in New York City, died of a heart attack Monday while on vacation in Vancouver, British Columbia. He was 50 years old and lived in Westbury, L.I.

title: Postal Service to Mark Riot by Homosexuals
description: The United States Postal Service has approved a special cancellation to commemorate an anti-police riot in Greenwich Village by patrons of a bar catering to homosexuals, the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation Inc. announced yesterday.

title: The Defense's Argument in the Princeton/Newport Case
description: Defense attorneys in the racketeering case against Princeton/Newport Partners L.P. conceded yesterday that some of the evidence might look bad at first only because the Government was presenting what one of them called ''a cropped picture.''

title: Correction
description: A drawing with the Home Improvement column last Thursday illustrated a taut-line hitch knot incorrectly. As stated in the column, the knot should be tied 6 to 12 inches from the post, not next to it, as the drawing indicated.

title: Walking the Tightrope of Celebrity Born in Tragedy
description: Last week, the New York City Police Department held its annual medal day ceremony, which honored 56 police officers, including five who were killed in the line of duty last year.

title: A Test for AIDS Infection in Newborns
description: A new test can identify babies who are born infected with the AIDS virus so they can be quickly treated in an effort to delay or stop fatal illnesses, researchers say.

title: Washington Talk: Exact Words; Of Wealth, Lending and Race
description: Representative Ronald V. Dellums, Democrat of California, speaking to the House on June 15 to urge passage of an amendment that would require banks and savings and loan institutions to disclose their patterns of lending to members of minority groups and the poor:

title: Brazil Shuts 5 Brokerages
description: The Government today closed five brokerages caught in the largest scandal in the history of the Brazilian stock market.

title: Victor Jacobson, Contractor, 90
description: Victor Jacobson, the former president of a New Jersey ceiling contracting company, died of a heart attack Tuesday at the Morton Plant Hospital in Clearwater, Fla.. He was 90 years old and lived in Clearwater.

title: Fed's Heller to Become A Top Visa Executive
description: H. Robert Heller, a member of the Federal Reserve Board since August 1986, will resign at the end of next month to become the executive vice president of Visa International, Mr. Heller said yesterday.

title: Fill It Up, Please, With Clean, Economical Ethanol; Bus Rule Backfires
description: To the Editor:

title: Stepping Into Void Of Antiques
description: JOHN LYLE, a New York antiques dealer, knows from experience just what is missing from the city marketplace. To fill the void, he and his partner Mark Umbach, an art dealer, have designed a 20-piece line of neo-Classical furniture and rugs for people who appreciate the past.

title: Fill It Up, Please, With Clean, Economical Ethanol
description: To the Editor:

title: New England Electric System reports earnings for 12mo to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Woodworking Teacher Bucks British Tradition
description: WITH equal ease, John Makepeace wears the three hats of furniture designer, teacher and businessman. He considers himself unusual in Britain where, he said, ''there has been a tendency in schools to direct people of lower academic ability toward practical subjects and high academic achievers away from them.''

title: Bridge
description: Four decades ago, the best players in the United States were concentrated in New York and Philadelphia. But they regularly faced a challenge from a Cleveland squad that usually included Alvin Landy, Arthur Goldsmith, Jeff Glick and Sol Mogal.

title: International Multifoods Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Last year's results included a pretax gain of $4,169,000 from the sale of the company's U.S. flour milling business and a pretax gain of $2,847,000 on Venezuelan investments and foreign currency obligations.

title: Teacher Seized on Drug Charges
description: A 44-year-old gym teacher who has worked the last 21 years in the New York City public school system was arrested yesterday in the parking lot of a Manhattan high school while apparently snorting cocaine, the police said.

title: Leafs' President Averts Possibility of Takeover
description: Harold Ballard, the president, managing director and governor of the Toronto Maple Leafs, said yesterday he had agreed to purchase shares held by his son Harold Jr. for $25 million to avoid the possibility of a takeover of the team and Maple Leaf Gardens.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Rivalry Over Razors Goes To Court
description: A COURT battle begins today between Gillette and Wilkinson Sword over whose razor provides the most comfortable shave.

title: New Jersey Steel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Willard G. Triest, 83; Led Building Company
description: Willard Gustav Triest, founder of the Triest Construction Company in New York City, died of heart failure Monday at his home in Annapolis, Md. He was 83 years old and also lived in Southampton, L.I.

title: Longwood Group Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fed Procedure Different Now
description: After learning in 1987 that one of its directors was accused of leaking news of discount-rate changes, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York changed its procedures to make it more difficult for similar abuses to recur.

title: James Baldwin the Focus Of a Tribute and Seminar
description: James Baldwin, a child evangelist at a Harlem storefront church who grew up to become perhaps America's most widely read black writer, will be the subject of a two-day program starting Friday evening.

title: Is Europe Turning Green?
description: Like tufts of grass in summertime, the Green parties of Western Europe have begun to flourish. It would be wrong to exaggerate their popular support. But given the factionalized politics of Europe, it would be equally wrong to underestimate their potential influence.

title: The Lure of Power
description: In the days since his death, I. F. Stone has been celebrated as the extraordinary scholar-journalist he was, the reporter who taught us to penetrate the squid-ink of official truth. But there is a point about him that still needs emphasis. It is a point of character, and it has a particular meaning for the American press today.

title: Penwest Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included income of $272,000 and $5,344,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a gain of $22,404,000 on the sale of discontinued operations for both periods. c-Included income of $505,000 and $1,334,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: INSIDE
description: A Soviet-Iranian Warming In a second day of negotiations with the visiting Speaker of the Iranian Parliament, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union announced an increase in trade ties between the two countries. Page A3. Pact on Prison Expansion New York will greatly expand its prison capacity over the next two years under an agreement reached by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and state legislative leaders. Page B1. Baryshnikov to Move On Mikhail Baryshnikov announced yesterday that he will leave his post as artistic director of American Ballet Theater next year. He plans to pursue other career opportunities, including acting. Page C17. Yankees Trade Henderson The Yankees traded Rickey Henderson, whose contract ends this year, to the Oakland Athletics for Eric Plunk and Greg Cadaret, pitchers, and Luis Polonia, an outfielder. Page B13.

title: Robert Knittel Is Dead; Editorial Chief Was 69
description: Robert Knittel, a former editorial director of William Collins, a London-based publishing company, died June 15 of complications following surgery at the Hospital of Charity in Locarno, Switzerland. He was 69 years old.

title: Review/Television; A Celebration of Music, on CBS
description: Music, straightforward, unadulterated music, used to be a television staple. From ''Your Hit Parade'' and ''The Bell Telephone Hour'' to Perry Como and even for a single summer Michael Jackson and his brothers, prime time wouldn't hesitate to pause for a song or two. Dolly Parton tried and failed to revive the variety format a couple of years ago. For the most part these days, music on the regular series is playing a supportive role. A ballad like ''When I Fall in Love'' can be heard only as a background mood setter for ''The Wonder Years.''

title: Steuben Show Celebrates a Glittering History
description: Artisanship and design have always been a major part in the development of Steuben glass. This is clear in an exhibition opening today at the company's shop, 1715 Fifth Avenue (at 56th Street), which is newly renovated.

title: International Barrier Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Measurex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 4
Oshap Technologies Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in U.S. currency.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''There were periods in our past when our border was turned into a blank wall. It is good that these times are apparently gone.'' - President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union. ''I have been staying in Moscow for only 24 hours, but I already feel almost at home.'' - Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, Speaker of the Iranian Parliament. [ A3:4. ]

title: Acquittal in Steroid Trial
description: Tom Gadd, the former South Carolina University defensive coordinator, was acquitted today of two misdemeanor charges stemming from the alleged use and distribution of steroids in the school's athletic department.

title: Method of Execution: A Stark Tradition
description: Execution by shooting through the base of the brain, the method presumably used in Shanghai yesterday in the execution of three Chinese, is a method traditionally favored for executions in the Soviet Union and other Communist countries.

title: Coal Miners' Strike Spreads, but Years Have Blunted the Weapon
description: The coal strike that began 10 weeks ago in this isolated corner of southwest Virginia and was touted as a make-or-break walkout for the United Mine Workers of America has now spread to nine other states.

title: Mason City Journal; Learn to Be a Fast Talker, or Fail
description: By day, 42-year-old Jim Kelley is a speech clinician from Chisago City, Minn. But in his dreams, Mr. Kelley is an auctioneer who sells lead crystal and quarterhorses at a thousand words a minute. ''It's something I've had in the back of my mind since I got a rabbit at auction as a kid,'' Mr. Kelley said.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Up 0.1% on the Big Board
description: A table in Business Day on Thursday showing the New York Stock Exchange's uncovered short sales, or ''short interest,'' for the four weeks ended June 15 included an incorrect amount for the Tech-Sym Corporation, provided by the company to the exchange, and misstated the total accordingly. The short interest in Tech-Sym for the period was 17,368 shares.

title: Political Tempest in a Rose Garden
description: GARDENING is one of the very few human pursuits in which moral questions almost never arise. The only two I can think of are stealing a plant or collecting one from the wild - and it is only in recent years that taking a wild plant has been widely accepted as wrong. Questions of politics, including political morality, do not ordinarily intrude themselves into discussions about plants or gardens.

title: Researchers Discover New Way Gene Defects Can Lead to Cancer
description: Scientists have found a previously unknown way in which gene defects can lead to cancer, a discovery that may eventually offer improved ways of detecting some forms of cancer in the earliest stages when treatment can be most effective.

title: Atari Is Blocked From Selling Game
description: A Federal judge here issued a preliminary injunction blocking Tengen Inc., a subsidiary of the Atari Corporation, from selling a version of its video game Tetris that can be used on the Nintendo game system. Tengen and Atari sued Nintendo in December under antitrust laws; Nintendo countersued for breach of contract and patent and trademark infringement. Federal District Judge Fern Smith issued the order at the request of Nintendo of America, based in Redmond, Wash., and the Nintendo Company, its Japanese parent.

title: HEALTH: Psychology; Study Finds Hypnosis Can Suppress Brain's Perception of Pain
description: Hypnosis can suppress the brain's perception of pain, a new study has found.

title: Tribute to Matuszak
description: Although it dropped football in 1975, the University of Tampa now plans to establish an athletic scholarship fund in memory of John Matuszak, the college's most famous player, who died Saturday in California at the age of 38. Matuszak, who played at Tampa in 1971 and 1972 and was the first selection in the 1973 National Football League draft, graduated with a degree in educational psychology.

title: Mandatory Insurance Is Backed by A.M.A.
description: The American Medical Association today endorsed a proposal to establish a Federal requirement that employers provide health insurance for workers.

title: Officer's Vest Deflects Bullets
description: A police officer survived a shooting in Queens yesterday when his bulletproof vest deflected three bullets fired at his chest, the police said. The officer, Paul Yurkiw, 34 years old, suffered only bruises in the incident.

title: India Keeps Border With Nepal Open
description: To the Editor:

title: A U.S. Soldier Pleads Guilty To Spying in West Germany
description: An American serviceman who once had been described as a model soldier pleaded guilty today to charges that he gave defense secrets to East Germany.

title: Stanley Wallace, 65, Professor of Medicine
description: Dr. Stanley L. Wallace, a specialist in studying and treating gout and a professor of medicine at the state's Health Science Center at Brooklyn, died of lymphoma Tuesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 65 years old.

title: Corrections
description: The Business and the Law column on Monday about employment discrimination lawsuits against Japanese subsidiaries in the United States referred incorrectly to the vice chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission. She is a woman, R. Gaull Silberman.

title: Writers, Meeting in Budapest, Warm to a Concept
description: Several dozen writers and poets from many nations, assembled in a hall where the Hungarian Parliament once met, have since Monday been sitting through sessions of parochial debates in which their colleagues, divided into national panels, discussed what seem to them the many pains and few joys of their work.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 In Angola, the first discussions are approaching between leaders of the Angolan Government and rebel forces involved in a 14-year civil war as part of an effort to promote a peaceful solution. Page A1

title: Money Manager Cuts Robins Stake
description: Michael H. Steinhardt, a New York money manager, has lowered his stake in the A. H. Robins Company to 2.74 percent from 5.6 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Steinhardt said he had sold the shares between June 1 and Tuesday at prices ranging from $26.50 to $30.50 a share. Robins's share price dropped 37.5 cents today, to $30, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: U.S. Target Of Criticism At GATT
description: The United States came under sharp and virtually unanimous criticism today at the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade for its threat to impose trade sanctions on Japan, Brazil and India.

title: Exhibits Are Off the Hook
description: Angered by an art exhibit here that invited viewers to step on the American flag to ''confront their feelings'' about patriotism and symbols, the United States Senate, Chicago City Council and both houses of the Illinois Legislature have passed measures barring the use of the flag in such an exhibit. But those acts appear to be nullified by yesterday's Supreme Court action in a 1984 Texas case.

title: Block, H&R Inc reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: The company said its 1988 figures have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Access Technology Inc. on Oct. 28, 1988.

title: Free Night at Whitney
description: A grant from the William H. Kearns Foundation has enabled the Whitney Museum of American Art to continue its policy of free admission on Tuesday evenings. Museum hours are 1 to 8 P.M. Tuesday, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Wednesday to Saturday, and noon to 6 P.M. Sunday. Information: 570-3676.

title: New Yorkers Try to Defend Students Hunted in China
description: As the struggles and torments of Chinese students in China became increasingly more vivid for New Yorkers over the last month, people in the city have begun exploring ways to defend the lives and views of those who are being hunted, arrested and imprisoned.

title: Task Force Challenges Regan As Single Trustee of Pension
description: New York's three public pension funds, which have more than $100 billion in assets, should be barred from investing in hostile corporate takeovers and other buyouts that could harm the state's economy, a task force appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Consolidated Stores Corp., Columbus, Ohio, a retailer of close-out merchandise, said it had been approached by Pic 'N' Save Corp., a Carson, Calif., retail chain, about a possible acquisition but had discontinued discussions.

title: 2 Taiwan Licenses Set By Sun Microsystems
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. said today that it had licensed two Taiwanese personal computer makers to produce low-cost desktop computers based on Sun's Sparc microprocessor.

title: Fokker Near Deal On Sale to Pan Am
description: Fokker N.V., the Dutch airplane maker that is gaining a strong foothold in the competitive North American jetliner market, is in the final stages of negotiating a contract with the Pan Am Corporation for the sale of 30 planes, a company spokesman said. The value of the deal, which is awaiting approval by Pan Am's board, was estimated at $679 million by industry sources here.

title: Richard L. Liebeskind, Retailer, 60
description: Richard L. Liebeskind, the founder and former president of Ann Taylor Inc., died of a heart attack Tuesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; First Amendment Protects Paper That Named Rape Victim, Justices Rule
description: The Supreme Court today overturned a $100,000 damage award that a rape victim won against a small Florida newspaper that published her name in violation of a state law.

title: Some Big Holders Plan Vote Against Time
description: Angered by Time Inc.'s offer to take over Warner Communications Inc., a number of Time's long-term shareholders plan to vote against the re-election of four Time directors at the annual meeting scheduled for June 30.

title: Back in the Ring
description: LEAD: When the movie ''Rocky'' was shown on Chinese television, millions of viewers tuned in to watch Sylvester Stallone, whose trademark ''yo,'' even in dubbed Mandarin, was still a working man's hero's simple ''yo.''

title: Electronic Mail Services Pact
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and the MCI Communications Corporation said today that they would cooperate to provide a commercial link between MCI's electronic mail service, MCI Mail, and the I.B.M. Information Network's Screenmail electronic mail service.

title: Cone and Myers Combine To Blank Expos on 5 Hits
description: The mystery of the lost mastery of David Cone wasn't exactly solved yesterday in Shea Stadium. But it was certainly clarified when Cone rebounded from four straight early knockouts and six weeks of not winning, and led the Mets to a 2-0 victory over the Montreal Expos with seven innings of five-hit, no-nonsense pitching.

title: Fighting Crime With Wind
description: The polls prove it, but New Yorkers don't need them to know that crime and drugs are, far and away, the issues of the mayoral campaign. That's plain from watching the candidates play ''Can You Top This?'' in ways that range from the silly to the unseemly.

title: Review/Ballet; Bustamante as Siegfried
description: Ricardo Bustamante took on a new role on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, when American Ballet Theater presented Mikhail Baryshnikov's new production of ''Swan Lake.'' The evening was not especially memorable for any new interpretation of Prince Siegfried. There was not a great deal of razzle-dazzle dancing, either, though this promising soloist did offer moments of superb technical achievement, one of them a beautifully finished series of pirouettes in his third-act variation. His performance was a highlight of the season.

title: Remembering an Artist and His Paris
description: IN the Paris of the 20's, 30's and 40's, the city of Diaghilev, Stravinsky, Picasso and Chanel, there was another talent, less well known but as influential: Christian (Bebe) Berard, an artist known for his haunting portraits as well as his exquisitely colored sets and costumes for the ballet, theater and film.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Lintas: London Makes Acquisition
description: Lintas: London and Still, Price, Court, Twivy, D'Souza concluded a courtship yesterday, agreeing to a merger that they say will create the 10th-largest agency in Britain. Lintas regarded Still Price, a four-year-old London shop, as such an attractive acquisition that it agreed to drop its custom of insisting on a majority stake in the agency.

title: Joseph A. Bevilacqua Dies at 70; Rhode Island Judge Linked to Mob
description: Joseph A. Bevilacqua, whose long friendships with people tied to organized crime tarnished and eventually ended his career as Rhode Island's foremost legislator and Chief Justice, died at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston today. He was 70 years old.

title: Another Squibb Official Joins Glaxo's U.S. Unit
description: The Squibb Corporation has provided another top executive to Glaxo Inc., a pharmaceutical rival. Dr. Charles A. Sanders, Squibb's vice chairman, has been named the chief executive of Glaxo's American subsidiary.

title: A MEETING TODAY OF ANGOLA ENEMIES EXPECTED IN ZAIRE
description: The stage has apparently been set here for the first face-to-face discussions between leaders of the Angolan Government and rebel forces involved in a 14-year civil war.

title: China Won't Ever Be the Same
description: LEAD: More than 50 years ago, my wife and I came to this wonderful country from China. For 40 of those years, we dreamed that one day it would be possible to work in our native land. More than anything we wanted to combine our love of the nation that had become our own with our desire to do something for the land of our birth and heritage.

title: Navratilova Advances; Infection Halts Evert
description: Martina Navratilova continued her preparation for Wimbledon today by moving into the quarterfinals of its main warm-up tournament, while Chris Evert was knocked out by an ear infection.

title: For Architect Of Child Care, Small Gains
description: BEFORE he sends his students at Yale University into the world to fight for better lives for the nation's children, Dr. Edward F. Zigler says, he outfits them with the verbal armor of an old warrior: ''I tell them, if you're not ready to lose and lose and lose, don't even start.''

title: Show House In a Relaxed Seaside Mood
description: THIRTY designers have breathed new life, sometimes startlingly so, into Kinkora, a summer cottage of the 30-room variety that had stood empty for 10 years in Westhampton Beach, L.I.

title: Mississippi Elects Black Judges
description: Two of six black candidates won judgeships in elections ordered by a Federal district judge who held that judicial districting in Mississippi discriminated against blacks.

title: Rinaldo Van Brunt, Army General, 87
description: Rinaldo Van Brunt, a retired Army major general, died of cardio-respiratory failure Sunday at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 87 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Monclova Journal; Steel Town Buckles Under $100 Billion Burden
description: Until just a few weeks ago, all the talk about Mexico's $100 billion foreign debt seemed remote and abstract to Victor Manuel Renteria, a 32-year-old laborer at Altos Hornos, the giant state-owned steel complex here. But no longer, now that he and 1,742 other workers have lost their jobs and 4,000 fellow employees have gone out on strike.

title: Enzo Biochem Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a $420,000 gain from extinguishment of debt. Year-ago 9 months was restated for an adjustment made in the fourth quarter of fiscal 1988 for an unrealized loss on the marketable equity securities of $168,000.

title: U.S. Charges Greek Bank Ran Scheme to Evade Tax
description: The Government yesterday accused a large Greek bank and 14 employees of running an extensive money-laundering scheme that allowed customers to send at least $700 million to Greece to evade American taxes.

title: Hartco Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Review/Dance; Dance, Like Life Itself, Emerging From Water
description: Modern dance at its most surprising and artistically exciting flourishes every summer at the American Dance Festival on the campus of Duke University. Certainly, it is hard to imagine a more unconventional dance event than the one presented by Eiko and Koma on Tuesday night at Reynolds Industries Theater. The two Japanese-born dancers performed their entire program in a pool of water, often with torrents of rain pouring down upon them.

title: J M Peters Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Hy & Zel's Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Creeping Royalism
description: When former President of the United States Ronald Reagan recently accepted an honorary knighthood from Queen Elizabeth II, most Americans took it in stride - after all, Dwight Eisenhower had done the same, and no kneeling was involved.

title: Fat Is Fat, So Don't Overdo the Olive Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Care Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Man Who Called His Trial Unjust Is Executed for Mississippi Killing
description: A black man who insisted he was unjustly convicted by an all-white jury was executed in the gas chamber early today for a five-day robbery spree in which three people were slain.

title: Itzhak Perlman to Open Mostly Mozart Festival
description: The 1989 Mostly Mozart festival is to open on July 11 at Avery Fisher Hall with Itzhak Perlman as guest soloist in violin concertos by Mozart and Bach, with Gerard Schwarz, the festival's music director, conducting.

title: Detroit Edison Mortgage Bonds
description: The Detroit Edison Company is offering $300 milion of 9 7/8 percent general and refunding mortgage bonds due 2019 at a price to yield 9.999 percent through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Yankee Pitching Is No Puzzle for White Sox
description: The Yankees began life without Rickey Henderson last night, although for all the controversy surrounding Henderson's departure, his teammates discovered that life without the outfielder may be as difficult as life with him.

title: Drug to Control Epilepsy Is Tied to Birth Defects
description: A medicine commonly used to control epilepsy appears to cause minor birth defects and retardation in the children of women who take it while pregnant, a study concludes.

title: Some Wrinkles at Journal, Age 100
