description: The Wall Street Journal began celebrating its centennial last night with an elaborate banquet for advertisers at the Rainbow Room. It begins its march toward a second century with a mixture of great strengths and considerable uncertainty, much like the world economy it covers.

title: Travelers Plan Set
description: The Travelers Corporation, a leading insurance company, said it had established an employee stock ownership plan that would buy $200 million of a new series of convertible preferred stock. The purchase will be financed by a loan guaranteed by Travelers. The proceeds will be used in Travelers' insurance operations. The stock was issued for $53.25 a share. The shares are convertible into common stock on a one-to-one basis. The company's common share price slipped 25 cents today, to $40.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Peter Evans Memorial
description: A memorial service for Peter Evans, an actor in theater, films and television, will be held at 5 P.M. Monday at Playwrights Horizons, 416 West 42d Street. Mr. Evans, who originated leading roles in plays by David Rabe, David Mamet and Arthur Miller, died of AIDS on May 20 at the age of 38.

title: Lee Calhoun, 56, a Star Hurdler
description: Lee Calhoun, who won two Olympic gold medals in the 110-meter hurdles, died today. He was 56 years old.

title: Standard Commercial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included losses of $2,609,000 and $3,926,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, respectively, and extraordinary credits of $280,000 and $373,000 for the same periods, respectively. c-Included extraordinary credits of $566,000 and $1,470,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Furniture That's Fit For a Czar
description: FOR several years, David Israel, president of Trouvailles, a furniture company in New York, has been working on a collection based on furniture at the Hermitage Museum in Leningrad, below. ''Antiques have risen way beyond the realm of the average person,'' he said of his motivation.

title: China's Newspapers, After Crackdown by Beijing, Revert to a Single Voice
description: China's newspapers today show little trace of the independence and pluralism that they displayed last month before the Government cracked down on pro-democracy demonstrators.

title: Singaporeans Buy RJR's Chun King
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. said it would sell its Chun King food division for $52 million to a group of investors from Singapore. The sale is part of RJR's continuing effort to reduce debt from its $24.5 billion buyout by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company.

title: Devtek Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Howard Responds
description: Responding to allegations made on Tuesday by Milt Ottey, a Canadian high-jumper, at the Canadian Government inquiry into drug use in amateur sports, Jimmy Howard told The Toronto Sun he tried anabolic steroids briefly in 1979, but gained too much weight and has not used them since.

title: Opening Antique Furniture's Locks
description: JOSEPH BIUNNO has been restoring antique furniture for 17 years. But year after year, he noticed that furniture required more than just refinishing. Because keys were often lost, armoires and desks were either permanently locked or permanently open. So Mr. Biunno taught himself to be a locksmith. He even makes house calls.

title: A Passport To History In Houses
description: WHILE most passports are meant for visiting foreign countries, a new kind has been designed to encourage New Yorkers to visit their own city. This little blue booklet was created by the Historic House Trust of New York, a nonprofit organization created to restore and maintain the 15 historic house museums in city parks.

title: Heilig-Meyers Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Mother Who Hid Girl Must Stay Behind Bars
description: A judge ruled Monday that a mother who has been in jail for 22 months in a custody dispute should remain incarcerated until she reveals her daughter's whereabouts or turns the child over to the city authorities.

title: Jalalabad Siege Over, Kabul Says, but U.S. Differs
description: The Afghan Government asserted today that it had broken the 15-week-old guerrilla siege of the strategic eastern city of Jalalabad. But Administration analysts immediately dismissed the claim as propaganda.

title: ISRAELIS WARNED ABOUT FRATRICIDE
description: Israeli politicians said in a stormy Parliament debate today that vigilante action by Jewish settlers could push the country to the brink of civil warfare.

title: Realty Loan Troubles Tarnish PNC's Image
description: Until last week it seemed as if the PNC Financial Corporation was invincible.

title: Harvard Picks Seattle Mayor To Head Institute of Politics
description: Mayor Charles Royer of Seattle has been named director of the Institute of Politics at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government, the school announced today.

title: Blue Jays Are Winning But Aren't Closing Gap
description: Steve Sax, Jesse Barfield, Andy Hawkins, Dave LaPoint, Jimmy Jones, Mel Hall, Lance McCullers, Steve Balboni, Tom Brookens, Luis Polonia, Eric Plunk, Greg Cadaret. It sure is easier to dismiss the manager than get a bunch of new players, and that's what the Toronto Blue Jays did.

title: STUDY SEES SHIFT IN PLANS FOR BIRTH
description: Married women in their early 30's are far more likely to plan to have children someday than they were in the mid-1970's, the Census Bureau reported today. The increase, to 54.4 percent in 1988 from 33.5 percent in 1975, could mean more stress on an already overburdened day care system.

title: Speeding the Way to New York Driver's License Renewals
description: To the Editor:

title: Buss Seeks Franchise
description: Jerry Buss, the owner of the Los Angeles Lakers and the former owner of the Los Angeles Kings, said he would like to establish another National Hockey League franchise in southern California. Buss, who also owns the Forum in Inglewood, Calif., the home of the Lakers and the Kings, said he recently sent a letter to N.H.L. officials informing them of his interest in owning a professional hockey team, preferably in San Diego or Orange County.

title: JUSTICES, 5-4, BACK PROTESTERS' RIGHT TO BURN THE FLAG
description: In a decision virtually certain to be a First Amendment landmark, the Supreme Court ruled today that no laws could prohibit political protesters from burning the American flag.

title: Interest Rates Take Upward Turn
description: Interest rates advanced yesterday as prices of Treasury securities retreated with the dollar.

title: Slaney Isn't Aiming to Be the Leader of the Pack
description: Anyone who doubts that the L'eggs Mini Marathon is a recreational run for the average woman rather than a serious race for the acclaimed elite is invited to keep an eye on Mary Slaney tomorrow morning as the 31-year-old legend makes her way around the 6.2-mile course at Central Park.

title: India Forces Down U.S. and German Pilots
description: Indian Air Force jet fighters forced down two civilian planes with American and West German pilots last week because they were near sensitive military installations, Indian and American officials said today.

title: Vote in House Sets Back Plan for Nuclear Weapons Plant in Idaho
description: The Energy Department's plan to build the first of a new generation of atomic weapons plants in Idaho sustained an important setback today when a House Armed Services subcommittee voted to cut money for its construction.

title: Review/Music; An Evening Of (and for) Organists
description: Anders Bondeman from Sweden played at the modest and unprepossessing Park Avenue Christian Church on Wednesday night. It was largely an evening by an organist for other organists, and there were certain virtues Mr. Bondeman had to share with his colleagues.

title: Payments Start At Bank on L.I.
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which on Wednesday assumed control of the failed Guardian Bank of Hempstead, L.I., said yesterday that it would begin paying insured depositors up to $100,000 from 2 to 7 P.M. today.

title: Rangaire Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included losses of $204,000 and $56,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included a loss of $5,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter; the 9 months included income of $239,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income

title: Police Investigating Death Of a Baby Girl in Foster Care
description: An 8-month-old girl in foster care died Tuesday evening, a week after a 1-year-old girl in the same foster home was hospitalized with breathing problems, the police said yesterday.

title: Oppenheimer Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
James Walter McGovern, Author, 65
description: James Walter McGovern, an author, died of heart failure on Wednesday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Vote Set on Minimum for Foreigners
description: The PGA Tour's 10-member policy board will vote Tuesday on a proposed rule that would cut the minimum number of American tournaments required of a foreign member of the tour from the current 15 a year to 12. The board voted, and defeated, the same proposal two years ago.

title: Women's Museum Fights for Its Life
description: This village halfway between Rochester and Syracuse is assured a place in history as the birthplace of the women's rights movement at an impassioned conference in 1848. But it is no longer assured a place as the home of the National Women's Hall of Fame.

title: Books of The Times; The Complications of Sex, Jealousy and Avarice
description: Love, Pain and the Whole Damn Thing By Doris Dorrie 178 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Wyeth's Helga, Alone and Floating
description: Andrew Wyeth's famous, if not notorious, ''Helga Pictures'' are making the last stop of their national tour at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, giving New Yorkers a chance to see what all the fuss was about. The media circus of August 1986, when Mr. Wyeth went public with the pictures - worked on in secret, even from his wife, over the preceding 15 years - has mostly died down.

title: Ruling Benefits Amgen Product
description: Amgen Inc. confirmed that the Health Care Financing Administration had said it would reimburse kidney dialysis patients' use of Epogen, the company's anti-anemia drug, retroactive to June 1. On that day, the Food and Drug Administration approved the use of Epogen.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Axel Johnson Inc. acquired 80 percent of ADS Services Inc., Huntsville, Ala., a developer of computerized waste water flow monitoring systems. The deal exceeded $10 million.

title: Reviews/Dance; Rugged Individualists, Together and Separately
description: Molissa Fenley and Doug Varone are among the rugged individualists of modern dance. Ms. Fenley is known for grueling works requiring enormous stamina. Mr. Varone, though blessed with an impressive technique of his own, is often choreographically introspective. Until this summer they had never performed together.

title: Dining Out Guide: Connecticut
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Connecticut Weekly section of The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Columbus Park Trattoria Very Good (Nov. 6, 1988), 205 Main Street, Stamford (203-967-9191) -This storefront restaurant has the ambiance and clientele of a comfortable neighborhood spot where the menu inspires memories of hearty Italian home cooking. Appetizers excel here, and one might consider ordering an appetizer and pasta rather than a full meal. Some choice starters are the bruschetta; fried calamari with fra diavolo sauce, and shiitake mushrooms grilled with garlic halves and served on arugula. Other exceptional dishes are orecchiette with broccoli and sun-dried tomatoes; scampi alla romana, and coniglio alla cacciatore. Appetizers are $3.50 to $7.50, pastas $9.95 to $12.95, entrees $12.95 to $17.95. Lunch: noon to 3 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 5 to 10 P.M. Monday to Thursday, until 11 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. Harry's Texas Barbecue And Arizona Grill Good (May 21, 1989), 934 Hope Street, Stamford (203-348-7427) - Old-fashioned Southern-style barbecue is the specialty of this house, where the hickory-fueled smoker turns out savory beef, chicken and pork. Stucco walls are painted in a Southwestern palette, and cactus plants and Western art posters evoke a pleasant if minimal sense of place. Barbecue is served in combination platters along with potato, corn bread and cole slaw. Recommended menu items include barbecued chicken wings; baked beans; potato skins; herbed chicken, and the sparerib platter. ''Lites'' are smaller portions of spareribs and chicken that could appeal to families with children. Entrees are $4.95 to $11.95. Open 11:30 A.M. to 9:30 P.M. Tuesday to Sunday. Closed Monday. Maison le Blanc Very Good (Aug. 14, 1988), Route 7, New Milford (203-354-9931) - One of the better new restaurants in the northwest corner of the state, Maison le Blanc incorporates cozy dining rooms in a white colonial house on the Housatonic. Lace curtains and flowered wallpaper decorate the rooms; the menu is country French. Escargots Madagascar (prepared with green peppercorns in a cream sauce, served in puff pastry) and seafood sausage with lobster sauce are acclaimed appetizers. On the entree side are sweetbreads braised with shallots; bourride Provencale, a terrine of fish with garlic, tomato and saffron; loin of lamb with a tarragon-meat glaze, and lobster Marie Antoinette, the lobster meat poached and placed back in the shell and served with a sauce of Pernod, an herb beurre blanc and julienne of vegetables. Entrees are $13.50 to $19.50. Open 5:30 to 8:30 P.M. Tuesday to Thursday, until 9:30 P.M. Friday and Saturday and 3 P.M. to 8 P.M. Sunday. Peppercorn Grill Very Good (Feb. 14, 1988), 357 Main Street, Hartford (203-547-1714) -Bring a healthy appetite to this colorful cafe where mesquite-grilled entrees compete for attention with pizzas, small plates and inventive pasta dishes. Neon sculpture and park-bench seating offer visual appeal. From the grill there is a a variety of fish or breast of free-range chicken. Pastas include scallop-and-lobster ravioli; linguine with clams, shrimp, calamari, tomato and chilies, and pasta with five cheeses and grilled vegetables. One of the individual pizzas is topped with eggplant, blue and mascarpone cheeses, and red pepper puree. Dinner prices: pizzas are $8.75 to $10.25, small plates, $7.50 to $12.50, entrees $14 to $19. Lunch: 11:30 A.M. to 2 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner: 5:30 to 9 P.M. Monday to Thursday, until 10 P.M. Friday and Saturday. Closed Sunday. Saigon City Very Good (March 26, 1989), 1180 Chapel Street, New Haven (203-865-5033) - New Haven, like many other college towns, supports many restaurants serving international cuisines. One of the newest is Saigon City. The moderately priced menu uses one to three stars to indicate mildly spicy, spicy and very spicy dishes. But even the no-star items are deftly seasoned. As starters, lime chicken, spring rolls or Vietnamese salad are recommended. One successful entree is called Saigon sound pancake, a plate-sized, browned pancake filled with shrimp, pork, chicken and vegetables. Other good choices are ginger squid sauteed with scallions, and lemon grass chicken. Prices are $3.95 to $5.75 at lunch, $8.25 to $13.95 at dinner. Lunch: 11:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M. Tuesday to Friday; dinner: 5:30 to 9:30 P.M. Tuesday to Thursday, until 10 P.M. Friday and Saturday, and 5 to 9 P.M. Sunday. Closed Monday.

title: Del Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
The City Sings, Dances and Acts Up In Alfresco Mode
description: AS New York City's indoor performing-arts season winds down, a remarkably extensive and diverse second season of outdoor concerts, plays, dance performances and even movies is starting throughout the metropolitan area.

title: INSIDE
description: Setback and New Manager For Atomic Bomb Complex A House subcommittee voted to cut funds for a new generation of plutonium plants, and the White House named a controversial regulator of nuclear power plants to supervise the troubled weapons industry. Page A9. American Abducted in Gaza A relief worker was kidnapped, and a note was said to demand that Israel free Palestinians. Page A4. Polish-German Talks As the 50th anniversary of blitzkrieg nears, Bonn and Warsaw are locked in talks on reconciliation. Page A4. Death Penalty Issue on Hold A vote on restoring the death penalty in New York was canceled because of a State Senator's illness. Page B1. Computer ID Screen A nationwide computer system to identify job applicants was urged as a way to curb illegal aliens. Page A7.

title: Vera Wang Wed To Arthur Becker
description: Vera Ellen Wang and Arthur Paul Becker were married yesterday at the Hotel Pierre in New York. The interfaith ceremony was performed by Rabbi Charles J. Davidson and the Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne, a Baptist minister. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cheng Ching Wang of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold H. Becker of Avon, Conn.

title: Dr. J. T. Culbertson, 85; Published Journal
description: Dr. James Thomas Culbertson, a former Columbia University professor who published a monthly medical journal, Current Therapeutic Research, died of colon cancer yesterday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J..

title: Pronouncing The Names
description: HAN XU, Ambassador to the United States: hahn shoo LI JINHUA, Foreign Ministry spokeswoman: lee jin-hwah REN WANDING, dissident: ren wahn-ding TIANANMEN Square in Beijing: tee-en ahn muhn ZHOU FENGSUO, student leader: joe fung-swaw

title: Comex Seen Filling Post
description: Arnold F. Staloff, the president of the Philadelphia Board of Trade, has been offered the job of president and chief executive of Commodities Exchange Inc., people familiar with the discussions said yesterday.

title: Virginia Utility Gets 8.91% Yield
description: The Virginia Electric and Power Company, a unit of Dominion Resources Inc., yesterday priced $100 million of first- and refunding-mortgage bonds due 1999 through competitive bidding.

title: Austin Journal; Murder Mystery Grips City: Just Who Would Kill a Tree?
description: This is a murder mystery.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-5

title: Two Rivals Raise Offers For Gateway
description: The battle for control of the Gateway Corporation, which owns Herman's Sporting Goods as well as Britain's third-largest supermarket chain, grew heated yesterday as rival bidders raised their offers and actively bought Gateway shares on London's stock exchange.

title: Economic Scene; The Markets As Forecasters
description: HOW well do financial markets forecast the economy? Although the stock market remains in the Government's index of leading indicators, doubts about its reliability have intensified since the stock market crash of 1987 was followed not by a recession, as most economists expected, but by continuing economic growth.

title:
About Real Estate;
Bensonhurst Condos Get Boat Slips
description: LEAD: A waterfront community under construction in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn is offering buyers a rare option in New York City: a boat slip along with a dwelling.

title: Sol Halpern, 69, Dies; An Accounting Partner
description: Sol Halpern, a partner in the Manhattan accounting firm of Irving Kaufman & Company who served for the last five years as president of the Brooklyn School for Special Children, died of colon cancer Tuesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 69 years old.

title: Massachusetts Debt Rating Is Under Review by S.& P.
description: The general obligation debt of the State of Massachusetts, currently rated double-A, has been placed under review for possible downgrading, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday.

title: Departing Dean Looks Back at Dream and Reality
description: Looking back over his eight years as dean of the Harvard Law School, James Vorenberg seems most proud of efforts to make law students more sensitive to the plight of the poor.

title: Riding a Current Of Anticipation
description: ''Spin, drop and slide,'' Ken Stone, a coach for the United States team, said today in reply to a question about how to handle one of the slalom gates at the world whitewater canoe and slalom championships.

title: Tokheim Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The implementation in the first quarter of 1988 of Financial Accounting Standards Board Statement No. 96, ''Accounting for income taxes,'' increased earnings by $2,390,000, or 37 cents a share, in the first quarter and 6-month periods. Last year's second quarter earnings were favorably impacted by about $320,000, or 5 cents a share, resulting from gains realized on the sale of fixed assets.

title: G.N.P. Rate In Early '89 Put at 4.4%
description: The nation's economy expanded at a 4.4 percent annual rate in the first three months of the year, slightly higher than previously estimated, but the overall growth masked a significant slowdown in business activity.

title: The Annex Built By George
description: rrUp on the message board the words ''Welcome to Yankee Stadium'' remained the same. Then, one by one yesterday, the photos introduced Luis Polonia, Eric Plunk and Greg Cadaret, the three players obtained in the trade with the Oakland Athletics for Rickey Henderson.

title: Dinkins Out Front
description: If taken at face value, a recent New York Times/WCBS-TV poll suggests that David Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President, will win the Democratic mayoral primary in September. As Mr. Dinkins himself no doubt would warn, don't be too sure.

title: Film Festival Leader
description: Marcio Moreira, the vice chairman of McCann-Erickson, was chosen Wednesday to be president of the 20-member jury at this week's International Advertising Film Festival in Cannes, France. Mr. Moreira is the third American selected for that post since 1985. Jerry Della Femina, chairman of Della Femina McNamee WCRS, headed the jury in 1987, and Keith Reinhard, chairman of DDB Needham, was president in 1985.

title: Corby Distilleries Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Henri Sauguet, French Composer On the Satie Model, Is Dead at 88
description: Henri Sauguet, a French composer who in the 1920's helped return French music to its natural state of graceful aphorism and wit, died on Thursday at his home in Paris. He was 88 years old.

title: Hospital Staffing Services Inc reports earnings for
National Computer Log Of Workers Is Proposed
description: The Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, Alan C. Nelson, today proposed a nationwide computer system to verify the identities of all job applicants in order to halt the widespread use of fraudulent documents by illegal aliens seeking jobs.

title: Theodore Spagna, 45; Made Science Films
description: Theodore Spagna, a photographer and film maker who specialized in scientific material, died Wednesday at Massachusetts General Hospital, Boston. He was 45 years old.

title: The Eye of Big Brother Is Busy Again in China
description: In recent weeks Chinese have learned just how effectively the Government can keep an eye on each one of them.

title: Market Place; When the Credit Lines Disappear
description: Arthur Goldberg, president of Integrated Resources, says he never saw it coming.

title: CREW OF BISMARCK MAY HAVE SUNK HER
description: A deep-sea inspection of the Nazi battleship Bismarck suggests she was scuttled rather than sunk, Robert D. Ballard, an underwater explorer, said today.

title: Coney Island Parade
description: Floats, marching bands, storytellers, musicians, stilt-dancers, puppeteers, members of the Philadelphia Mummers Fancy String Band and the Navy Color Guard are to be part of the annual Mermaid Parade, tomorrow on Surf Avenue in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn. Awards will be given for the best costumes, floats and musical groups. The event begins at 1 P.M. at West 12th Street and ends at the parachute jump at West 19th Street. The raindate is Sunday.

title: Art in the Anchorage Opens for the Season
description: Every summer since the 1983 centennial of the Brooklyn Bridge, the huge, vaultlike anchorage at the Brooklyn end has been transformed into an unlikely, somewhat otherworldly art gallery. Art in the Anchorage began its seventh season yesterday with an exhibition of 10 large-scale, site-specific installations that address the sound and light qualities of the cavernous brick space.

title: International Capital Equipent Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss The latest periods included pretax losses on equipment of $10,000 for the quarter and $45,000 for the 9 months. The year-ago periods included pretax gains on equipment of $188,000 for the quarter and $110,000 for the 9 months.

title: Review/Film; She's 40. He's 15. Hmmm.
description: By the time they're 40 years old, most people have learned not to blurt out their romantic fantasies to casual strangers; they know enough to reserve offbeat desires for someone bound by loyalty not to laugh out loud. But Jane Birkin and Agnes Varda, respectively the actress and director responsible for ''Kung Fu Master,'' blithely trot out the silly story of a glorious love affair between a 40-year-old woman and a 15-year-old boy. Though French films are often breezy and sophisticated about just this sort of sexual initiation, ''Kung Fu Master'' has all the naivete of a 12-year-old girl addicted to romance novels and all the charm of her smelly gym socks.

title: Chengdu Had Its Own Tiananmen Massacre; Where Are They Now?
description: To the Editor:

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''CANTERBURY TALES,'' a play by the Royal Buckingham Theater Company, directed by Alexandra Jones, based on Chaucer's stories, 8 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays, 2 P.M. Wednesdays and Saturdays, and 3 P.M. Sundays, at the Nat Horne Theater, 440 West 42d Street. Tickets: $8. Information: 279-4200. ''TRIPLE PLAY DAY,'' an afternoon of fun and fitness for the family, with demonstrations of volleyball, track and field, golf, gymnastics, badminton and other sports, from 1 to 4 P.M. tomorrow. At 2 P.M., New York Kids on Stage will perform sports-related skits and songs, at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue at 103d Street. Museum hours are Tuesdays through Saturdays 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and Sundays and legal holidays 1 to 5 P.M. Museum admission is free. Information: 534-1034. ''GOLDILOCKS AND HER FRIENDS,'' a musical comedy by Barbara Schaap, performed by children, tomorrow and Sunday 1 and 3:30 P.M., at the Fantasy Playhouse, 317 Merrick Road, Lynbrook, L.I. Tickets: $5; reservations required. Information: 516-599-1982. MYSTIC SEAPORT, a 17-acre outdoor maritime museum with historic ships, boats, exhibition buildings and two restaurants, in Mystic, Conn. Open daily from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: children under 5, free; 5 to 18, $6.25, and adults, $12.50. Information: (203) 572-0711. CHILDREN'S CLAY WORKSHOP, a program to teach children how to make clay objects and to show how marbles, buttons, pipes and bowls were once made out of clay, in conjunction with ''Dig In,'' an exhibition, Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Children's Center of the South Street Seaport Museum, 265 John Street, at the East River. Free, with museum admission of $2 for children, $5 for adults. Reservations recommended: 669-9489. ''CINDERELLA,'' a musical version by the Papageno Puppet Theater with Susan Delery Whedon, who is to sing during the performance accompanied by recorded music. Saturdays and Sundays, 1 P.M., at the West 72d Street Studio, 131 West 72d Street. For young children. Admission: $4. Reservations: 874-3297. ''THE CLEVER TURTLE,'' a story from Brazil told by Meg Lippert, and ''The Golden Watch,'' written and told by Peninnah Schram, Saturday at 11 A.M. at the Hans Christian Andersen statue in Central Park, 72d Street and Fifth Avenue. Free. ''PINOCCHIO,'' by the Puppetworks, Saturdays at noon and Sundays at 1 and 3 P.M., at 287 Third Avenue, at Carroll Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn. Children, $4; adults, $5. Reservations required: (718) 834-1828. BARTLETT ARBORETUM, a 63-acre garden, open daily from 8:30 A.M. to sunset, at 151 Brookdale Road, Stamford, Conn. Information: (203) 322-6971. THEODORE ROOSEVELT SANCTUARY, a preserve of 12 wooded acres, with trees and vines planted to attract birds, 134 Cove Road, Oyster Bay, L.I. Suggested admission: $1.50. Information: (516) 922-3200. BIBLICAL GARDEN, trees, plants and flowers grown in biblical times, at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, open daily from 7 A.M. to sunset, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street. Free. Information: 316-7540. CENTRAL PARK ZOO, open weekdays 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; weekends and holidays 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. and Tuesdays 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. until September. Admission: children under 3, free; children 3 to 12, 25 cents; the elderly, 50 cents; others, $1. Information: 861-6030. ''ALFRED THE DRAGON AND THE TRICKSTERS,'' a play about a shy dragon in Central Park and a funny zoo keeper, written by Miranda McDermott and performed by child actors of the New Media Repertory Company, 3 P.M. Saturdays at 512 East 80th Street. Tickets: children, $4.50; adults, $5. Reservations: 734-5195. RIVERSIDE CHURCH TOWER, a 392-foot-high structure at 490 Riverside Drive, at 120th Street, offering views of the Hudson River, New Jersey and Manhattan. An elevator to the 20th floor and one flight of stairs lead to the bell tower, where visitors may see the 74-bell carillon. Mondays through Fridays 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. and Sundays 12:30 to 4 P.M. For children older than 6 and adults. Admission: $1. Information: 222-5900.

title: New York Mayoral Poll: Ethnic Groups' Variables
description: The accompanying article on racial attitudes in New York City and yesterday's article on views of the mayoral election are based on a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll, in which whites comprised 55 percent of the sample, blacks were 25 percent, and those who called themselves Hispanic - some of whom also described themselves as black or white -amounted to 22 percent.

title: Review/Art; Sculptures at the Modern By Christopher Wilmarth
description: The retrospective of Christopher Wilmarth's sculptures and drawings at the Museum of Modern Art has fewer than 40 works, but only in terms of numbers can it be described as a modest exhibition. This may well be the most impressive sculpture show of the season, and it is certainly among the most moving.

title: Arizona Bank Expects a Loss
description: The Valley National Corporation said today that it would add $181 million to its reserves for loan losses and that it expected a $90 million loss in the second quarter as a result.

title: Bernard Gallagher, Newsletter Editor, 79
description: Bernard P. Gallagher, founder and editor in chief of The Gallagher Report, a weekly newsletter about the communications industry, died Wednesday at New York Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: For the Lawyer Who Has Everything
description: If a businessman who lost millions of dollars in civil lawsuits decided to poke fun at lawyers, he might invent a board game that was an outsider's parody of the legal system. The object would be to sue everyone and end up with all the money. Naturally, he'd call it Hornswoggle.

title: Transplant Reward Offer Raises Furor
description: In desperation, a family seeking a bone marrow donor for a 13-year-old California boy with leukemia offered to pay $5,000 to a donor whose marrow matched the boy's. But the offer was withdrawn after questions were raised about its legality.

title: New Hampshire Bidding $1 Million to Save Artifacts
description: Fearful that historic New Hampshire artifacts will be sold to out-of-state buyers, state legislators have appropriated $1 million to bid in an auction of the estate of Josiah Bartlett, this state's first Governor, who was also a signer of the Declaration of Independence.

title: Detroit Mayor to Support Son He Refused to Acknowledge
description: Mayor Coleman A. Young has agreed to pay $200 a week to support the 6-year-old son he refused to acknowledge until blood tests proved he was the father.

title: 2 Visions of the Future Compete in Long Island City
description: There are two visions for Long Island City, as starkly different from each other as the almost finished 50-story Citicorp building is from the low-slung warehouses, factories and brownstones it towers above.

title: New Pitcher, in Debut, Picks Up a Victory
description: The Yankees got a look at one of their two new pitchers yesterday, and although the picture wasn't dramatically different from what they have seen this season, there were promising moments. Ultimately, however, the Yankees called on their bats and not their bullpen to defeat Chicago, 10-7.

title: Outside Bid for Prime Intensifies MAI Battle
description: The protracted takeover battle between Prime Computer Inc. and MAI Basic Four Inc. heated up yesterday when Prime said it had received an acquisition offer from another party.

title: Commission Urges 400 New Cab Medallions
description: Citing a scarcity of licensed taxicab service beyond Manhattan, the Taxi and Limousine Commission proposed yesterday that 400 new yellow-cab medallions be issued on the condition that the drivers ''spend two days a week and 10 percent of their trips on other days'' in the other boroughs and upper Manhattan.

title: Eastern in Accord To Sell 3 Jetliners
description: Eastern Airlines said it had agreed to sell three 727 jetliners by the Boeing Company for $9 million to the Express One Corporation, a Dallas-based aircraft company. The sale, which must be approved by a Federal Bankruptcy Court in New York, is part of the plan by Eastern to shrink to about two-thirds its former size by selling $1.8 billion in assets. The reorganization plan must also be approved by the court and Eastern's unsecured creditors.

title: Accounts
description: * CVS Consumer Value Stores, to Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson, Boston, with a budget of $12 million.

title: Tidewater Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $6 million.

title: Somerset Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Polishing the City's Gems
description: ''While touring your fascinating city,'' an Englishwoman wrote The Times in 1985, ''we visited the Morris-Jumel Mansion in Harlem. To find such a historical gem was a delight. . . . What we found puzzling is that this house is being allowed to deteriorate. . . . These things cannot be replaced.''

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Man of the Clarinet Kenny Davern Quartet, Cafe Gianluca, 2124 Broadway, at 74th Street (877-9381). Although Kenny Davern has played saxophones of all sizes, from soprano to bass, during his career in big bands and traditional small groups (notably Soprano Summit with Bob Wilber), his heart belongs to the clarinet, and he has been faithful to it in recent years. He plays with the kind of concentrated involvement that possessed Pee Wee Russell, although despite occasional husky rasps and squawks, his sound and style are distinctly and fervently his own. He is making one of his infrequent appearances in New York tonight and tomorrow at Cafe Gianluca, leading a group that includes the pianist Marty Napoleon, another veteran of big bands (Charlie Barnet and Gene Krupa) and traditional small groups. The group plays from 10 P.M. until 2 A.M. tonight and tomorrow; there's a $10 minimum. Big-Band Update

title: Chinese Execute 24 More People, Including 7 From Beijing Protests
description: Twenty-four executions were reported in China today, bringing to 27 the number of people executed in two days.

title: Agreement on Sale By Hospital Corp.
description: The Hospital Corporation of America has agreed to sell 10 hospitals and seven nursing homes in Britain to BUPA Health Services Ltd. for $142 million. The concerns have reached an agreement in principle, but have no definitive accord, the Nashville-based Hospital Corporation said. The sale is to be completed within 45 days.

title: New Yorkers Pessimistic on Race Relations, Poll Shows
description: Black and white New Yorkers agree on many issues facing the city, including a generally pessimistic view of race relations, but they differ in their preferences for candidates in the upcoming mayoral election, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll.

title: Auctions
description: A Head From 1500 B.C.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We find no evidence that Congress intended to modify the nostrum to read, 'crime does not pay, except for attorney's fees.' '' - Justice Byron R. White. [ A1:3. ]

title: RJR Nabisco Names Chief of a Tobacco Unit
description: RJR Nabisco Inc. has named Dale F. Sisel, president and chief operating officer of its international tobacco unit, to the additional post of chief executive of the unit.

title: Fisher Business Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Court Limits Civil Rights Law
description: The Supreme Court narrowly ruled to further limit the scope of the Civil Rights Act of 1866. Page A8.

title: EFI Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WHITE HOUSE PICKS BOMB PLANTS CHIEF
description: The staff chief of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has been selected to take charge of the Energy Department's troubled bomb production plants, the White House announced Wednesday.

title: I.R.S. Nominee Links Revenue Gain to Tax-Law Change
description: The nominee to be the next Commissioner of Internal Revenue said today that the 1986 overhaul of the tax code had increased compliance by taxpayers and thereby contributed to an unexpected surge in Treasury collections recently.

title: Reviews/Dance; Birthday Party for the Harlem Troupe
description: Twenty years in a ballet company's life is, from a historical perspective, a very short time. Even the most prestigious troupes, like Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, which lasted exactly from 1909 to 1929, are lucky if they achieve the two-decade mark.

title: Vote to Back Death Penalty Is Canceled
description: A fervent debate over reinstating the death penalty in New York ended abruptly today when the State Senate canceled a vote on the issue that had been expected on Tuesday.

title: Reviews/Art; 8 From Eastern Europe, All Young and Unknown
description: ''Metaphysical Visions: Middle Europe,'' at Artists Space, is an admirable and difficult show. It brings together eight artists from four countries - Poland, Czechoslavakia, Hungary and Yugoslavia. All the artists are in their 30's; all are unknown in New York. The presentation is not helpful. There are no wall labels; there are not even titles. Sometimes it is hard to tell the artists apart.

title: Mux Lab Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a special gain of $59,000. c-After special gains of $2,110,000 for the quarter and $1,998,000 for the 9 months. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Cellular Phone Growth Starts Investor Rush
description: A table in Business Day on Friday about the rapid growth of the cellular telephone business misstated the estimates of customer potential for four companies. For BellSouth, the estimate was 28 million; Pacific Telesis, 30 million; Southwestern Bell, 27 million; U S West, 14 million.

title: Verdix Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sugar Quotas Of U.S. Cited As Violation
description: The 96-nation council of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade found today that American sugar import quotas violate world trade rules, and the United States said it would seek to bring its program into compliance.

title: Change Constant In Mets' Bullpen
description: When Roger McDowell and Lenny Dykstra return to Shea Stadium tonight in the uniform of the Philadelphia Phillies, they will be greeted by only half of their former teammates who won the World Series for the Mets less than three years ago. The other half, like McDowell and Dykstra, are gone.

title: Old Prejudices and Hostilities Stall Effort by Bonn and Warsaw to Reconcile
description: Bonn's hopes for a symbolic reconciliation with Warsaw, 50 years after German tanks swept into Poland and started World War II, have run up against tough bargaining over a key point: an exchange of West German economic aid for recognition by Poland of its German minority.

title: Congress, Angry at China, Moves to Impose Sanctions
description: Members of Congress introduced amendments today that could severely curtail exports of computers, weapons, satellites and financing to China.

title: Switzer to Be Paid
description: Barry Switzer, who resigned as head football coach at the University of Oklahoma this week, will continue to draw his regular $7,250 monthly salary until next June and will then earn $145,000 as part of a farewell settlement from the university. Until Feb. 1, Switzer will be on special assignment with Oklahoma but his duties have not been announced.

title: Too Soon to Dismiss Weighted Voting in City Charter Revision
description: To the Editor:

title: SmithKline Vote Set on Merger Plan
description: The shareholders of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation will meet on July 26 to vote on a proposed merger backed by shareholders of its proposed partner, the Beecham Group P.L.C. of Britain. SmithKline also said it had received permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission to distribute proxies on the question.

title: Gold Mine Fire Still Raging
description: A fire burned deep within the nation's biggest gold mine for a second day today as firefighters prepared to pump in sand and water. No injuries were reported, and the fire posed no danger to the mine itself, said a Homestake Mining Company spokesman, Scott Zieske.

title: Review/Film; 'Honey, I Shrunk The Kids'
description: ''Honey, I Shrunk the Kids,'' is as sweet, straightforward and funny as its title. The newest Disney film, like so many old ones, is a simple childrens' adventure about what happens when one of Dad's goofy experiments goes haywire. Suddenly, his own son and daughter and the neighbors' two boys become so minuscule that Dad sweeps them up in a dustpan and tosses them in the backyard, now a jungle where ominous ants lurk behind gigantic blades of grass.

title: Dollar Drops After Report Of Plan to Force It Lower
description: The value of the dollar dropped sharply yesterday, and traders said the action reflected a report that the United States, West Germany and Japan planned to force the dollar lower.

title: N.R.A. Ad on Beijing Causes a Stir
description: The dramatic photograph shows an anguished student surrounded by soldiers in Beijing. The accompanying message says, ''The students of Beijing did not have a Second Amendment right to defend themselves when the soldiers came'' and ''The right to own a firearm is a statement about freedom.''

title: Israel Is Planning to Devalue Shekel
description: Israel will devalue the shekel Friday by 4.4 percent against a group of currencies in the hopes of increasing exports and trimming imports, the Bank of Israel announced today.

title: 2 Airlines Won't Link Computers
description: A proposed partnership that would have combined the computerized ticket reservation systems of American Airlines and Delta Air Lines collapsed yesterday after the Justice Department said it would oppose the venture for antitrust reasons.

title: Hubbard Dyers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: 4-Year-Old Girl Hit by Falling Beer Bottle Dies
description: A 4-year-old girl who was struck in the head Saturday night by a beer bottle thrown or dropped from a 15-story Manhattan apartment building died yesterday at the Bellevue Hospital Center, having never regained consciousness.

title: Judge Gives Abortion Protesters a Painful Choice
description: A group of militant abortion protesters must go before a judge Friday to choose between renouncing criminal trespass as a form of protest and spending a year in jail.

title: Jazz New or Old, All Sounds Are In At the Annual Jam
description: THE JVC Jazz Festival, which starts tonight in halls all over town, has a history of going in and out of sync with jazz's new movements. This year it looks like it's in.

title: TV Weekend; Competitions With an Extra Element
description: As ''The Other Olympians'' opens, the skiing contests in Innsbruck, Austria, seem quite familiar, with competitors gracefully gliding down the slopes. Only when the camera moves in close do we discover that some of the skiers are balanced on only one leg or are missing an arm.

title: Woman Held for Filing False Rape Charge
description: A woman who said she was raped at gunpoint in Central Park shortly after she arrived by bus from North Carolina last month was arrested Wednesday on a charge of filing a false rape complaint, the police said yesterday, and all charges have been dropped against the man she identified as the rapist.

title: Josephine Riordan, Nurse, 100
description: Josephine O'Mahoney Riordan, a nurse with the British Expeditionary Forces in France during World War I, died Wednesday at the Powhatan Nursing Facility in Falls Church, Va. She was 100 years old and lived in Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Papandreou Taken to Hospital
description: Andreas Papandreou, the caretaker Prime Minister, was taken to a hospital tonight suffering from breathing problems, a Government spokesman said. He quoted doctors as saying the 70-year-old Mr. Papandreou, who had open-heart surgery last year, would be able to ''carry on with his duties normally.''

title: Police Kill Suspect in 4 Slayings
description: A man believed to have killed four members of his family was shot and killed by state police today after he opened fire during a six-hour standoff, the authorities said.

title: Ex-Packer Interviewed
description: Willie Davis, a defensive end for the Green Bay Packers from 1960 to 1969, said on Wednesday in Racine, Wis., that he had been interviewed by a committee seeking a National Football League commissioner. He also said he would like to be the man to succeed Pete Rozelle.

title: Moscow Dance Judges Withhold Grand Prize
description: The exquisite blend of anxiety and esthetics known as the Moscow International Ballet Competition ended Wednesday night with the judges deciding there was no standout dancer deserving of a grand prize.

title: Review/Film; Nicholson and Keaton Do Battle in 'Batman'
description: ''Batman'' begins with a lot of promise: the camera pans across dark, lowering clouds as we hear music so doomy you might think it to be Mahler, though it's really Prince in a cosmic mode. Gotham City swims slowly into focus. It's a production designer's coup de cinema, a nightmare version of megalopolis, an urban landscape without sun, seen through a smog of pollutants and despair. Everything seems foreshortened, squeezed, angry and rotten.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FRIDAY MAGIC OF JOSEPHINE BAKER

title: Airlines Ordered to Tighten Security Measures
description: The Federal Aviation Administration told United States airlines yesterday to inspect intensively all electronic devices taken aboard many flights originating overseas and urged international air travelers to leave such items at home whenever possible.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES The president of I.B.M. said the company has a surprising edge over Japan in the mass production of the next generation of memory chips. They are expected to be used in virtually all of tomorrow's electronic products. [ Page A1. ] Hanson offered to buy Consolidated Gold Fields, the world's second-largest producer of gold, for about $4.8 billion. One Gold Fields senior official indicated that the company would negotiate a higher price and would agree to be acquired by Hanson. [ D1. ] Delta and American abandoned their proposed partnership in a computerized reservation system after the Justice Department said it would oppose the venture on antitrust grounds. [ D1. ] Paramount accused Time of failing to keep its stockholders fully informed. [ D15. ] Holly Farms entered talks to accept a bid from Tyson and terminate its merger agreement with Conagra. [ D3. ] Mack Trucks said it expected to post a loss for the second quarter amid signs of weakness in the $9 billion U.S. market. [ D3. ] The battle between Prime Computer and MAI Basic Four intensified: Prime said it had received another offer. [ D4. ] The battle heated up for control of the owner of Herman's Sporting Goods. [ D4. ] The U.S. partners of Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young voted on a merger. Overseas partners will decide in the next few months on whether to participate in the merger. [ D6. ] Executives of the three major TV networks called for the repeal of restrictions on their investment in and profit from prime-time programs. Some lawmakers were skeptical. [ D15. ] Time and Newsweek refused to carry an N.R.A. ad that shows a Chinese student surrounded by troops. [ D15. ] INTERNATIONAL GATT found that American sugar import quotas violated world trade rules. The U.S. immediately said it would seek to bring its program into compliance. [ D1. ] THE ECONOMY The Navy violated Federal procurement rules by writing unfair specifications for a major computer contract that allowed only I.B.M. to bid, the G.A.O. said. [ D1. ] The 1986 overhaul of the tax code has increased compliance by taxpayers and brought a surge in Treasury collections, the nominee for Commissioner of Internal Revenue said. [ D2. ] The nation's economy expanded at a revised 4.4 percent annual rate in the first three months of the year. [ D2. ] The judge hearing the first criminal racketeering case brought since the Government began its crackdown on Wall Street crime said that he believed some defendants in the case had engaged in an illegal conspiracy. [ D3. ] MARKETS Blue-chip stocks forged higher and the Dow transportation rose to a record for the third day in a row. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 17.26 points, to 2,482.17. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose moderately. [ D12. ] The value of the dollar dropped sharply, and traders said the action reflected a report that the U.S., West Germany and Japan planned to force the dollar lower. [ D13. ] Reports of sugar purchases by Moscow created a frenzied rally in sugar futures. [ D13. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Integrated Resources' president says he never saw the company's crisis coming. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D1. ] How well do the markets forecast the economy? Doubts have grown. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] A group of advertising executives had lunch, and a good time, as their Chinese Gourmet Society gathered for its 15th anniversary. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D16. ]

title: KEY RATES
Potomac Electric Power Co reports earnings for 12mo to May 31
Republicans in Glass White Houses . . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Bar
description: The most commonly seen consumer items in law offices have brand names like Lexis or West. But the current shopping list at Cravath Swaine & Moore contains some more unusual trademarks: Fisher-Price, Play Skool, Child Craft and Crayola.

title: Holly in Talks To Call Off Deal
description: The Holly Farms Corporation said yesterday that it had entered negotiations to terminate its merger agreement with Conagra Inc., settle any claims and accept a bid from Tyson Foods Inc. A spokesman for Holly

title: Too Soon to Dismiss Weighted Voting in City Charter Revision; Voting Rights Act
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants
description: Out-of-town theatergoers who wander into midtown Manhattan at about 6 P.M. hoping to stumble upon a wonderful little restaurant with prompt, friendly service and delightful food (as well as available tables) have about the same chance of finding free parking in Times Square. Even the theater district's restaurant row - 46th Street between Eight and Ninth Avenues - has more than its share of gastronomic land mines to take the luster off a special evening.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Rise
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose moderately yesterday after being buffeted by rumors that provoked wild moves in the dollar, which lately has been the main influence on the fixed-income securities market.

title: Cognos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Washington Talk; The Capital
description: The Supreme Court is probably the least understood of the three branches of government - insulated from electoral pressures, from the probing eye of television and to a considerable degree from reporters' questions.

title: NBC Cable TV Work Shifted to Lord Einstein
description: ''It was a quick marriage and a speedy divorce,'' Arthur Selkowitz said about Penchina, Selkowitz's loss yesterday of the CNBC account to Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; New Limit Is Placed on Scope of 1866 Rights Law
description: A narrow Supreme Court majority further limited the scope of an important Reconstruction-era law today, ruling that the Civil Rights Act of 1866 cannot be used to bring damage suits against state or local governments for acts of racial discrimination.

title: PCA International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $315,000 and $47,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Plexus in Software Sale to Recognition
description: Recognition Equipment Inc., which makes products for data entry and processing, agreed to acquire the image-processing software technology of Plexus Computers Inc. Terms were not disclosed. The companies said the accord was waiting to be approved by a Federal Bankruptcy Court in Dallas. The approval is expected by the end of July. Plexus has been under bankruptcy protection since March.

title: Mexico Investigates Vote Fraud by Ruling Party
description: In the 60 years that it has governed Mexico, the Institutional Revolutionary Party has regularly been accused of rigging elections to guarantee its control. But in a remarkable case unfolding here, the Government and party are for the first time moving to prosecute and punish vote fraud apparently carried out by their own partisans.

title: Easing of House Arrest Denied
description: A Federal judge rejected a request Tuesday by the daughter of the former Brooklyn Democratic leader, Meade H. Esposito, to modify her house arrest so she could spend weekends at her summer home in Quogue, L.I. Mr. Esposito's daughter, Phyllis A. Zito, 62 years old, was sentenced to one year of house arrest after pleading guilty to tax fraud in March.

title: Policy on Drivers At Domino's Pizza
description: Domino's Pizza Inc., which has acknowledged 20 fatal accidents in the last year involving its drivers, has told its outlets to terminate or reassign drivers who are under 18 years old. A Domino's spokesman, Ron Hingst, said Federal law prohibited the company from hiring younger drivers, but in some cases people hired for other jobs have ended up delivering pizzas.

title: While Iran Warms Up to Moscow, It Reviles the U.S.
description: The Speaker of the Iranian Parliament hailed reconciliation with the Soviet Union today, while accusing the United States of still pursuing ''plots and conspiracies'' that prevent improved relations.

title: Plane Crash Kills 40 in Peru
description: A Peruvian Air Force transport plane with about 40 civilian passengers aboard crashed in the remote Andean highlands on Wednesday night and there were no survivors, an air force spokesman said. The twin-engined plane slammed into a mountain ridge near the town of Tarma in central Junin Province and broke in two, a Lima radio station reported. The civilians were aboard under a program in which the air force offers cheap transport for residents of outlying areas with little or no access by road.

title: Paul Doktor, a Violist And Teacher, 70, Dies
description: Paul Doktor, a violist and teacher, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, where he was having tests. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Charter Panel Backs Creating A Budget Office
description: The New York City Charter Revision Commission yesterday proposed a new, independent budget office that would serve to counterbalance the mayor's powerful Office of Management and Budget.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Shades of Bud Powell Shades of Bud Powell and Arcado, Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Bud Powell's piano style is omnipresent in modern jazz, but too few of his compositions are in general circulation. Shades of Bud Powell, a pianoless septet of young musicians (including tuba, trombone, French horn, bass and drums) led by Herb Robertson on trumpet, should remedy that, with arrangements that are equal to Powell's quirks. Sharing the double bill is Arcado, the improvising (and often introspective) string trio of Mark Feldman on violin, Hank Roberts on cello and Mark Dresser on bass. Shows Sunday at 8 and 11 P.M.; tickets are $10 in advance, $12 at the door. Go-Go on Bond Street

title: Nobility Homes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Arch Petroleum Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Our Towns; Toning Down The Bacchanals On a Boardwalk
description: Little shocks Ralph E. Sheets, mayor and former police chief of this long-faded resort town on the southern tip of New Jersey. He has seen toga parties turn into near-riots, bar-crashing 17-year-olds insist they're 32 and teen-agers sunburned because they've passed out on the beach. ''I mean so burned they needed treatment,'' he said.

title: Chengdu Had Its Own Tiananmen Massacre; Deng's Desire
description: To the Editor:

title: Touring a Heights
description: New York Walk-About will lead a tour of the Morningside Heights section of Manhattan on Sunday. The group will meet on the northwest corner of Amsterdam Avenue and 110th Street at 2 P.M. The fee is $7, and no reservations are necessary. Information: 582-2015 or (914) 834-5388.

title: Tapes Played At Princeton Case Trial
description: Admitting some tape recordings into evidence yesterday over defense lawyers' objections, the Federal district judge hearing the first criminal racketeering case in the crackdown on Wall Street crime said he believed that some of the defendants in the case had engaged in a conspiracy.

title: Correction
description: A brief article on the obituary page yesterday about a memorial service to be held Saturday for Charles Mohr, a correspondent for The New York Times, misstated the location of the National Press Club, where the service will be held. The club is at 529 14th Street, N.W., Washington.

title: TV Networks Press for End To Curbs U.S. Put on Them
description: The top executives of the three major television networks called today for the repeal of restrictions on their investment in and profit from prime-time programs. But some legislators questioned the merits of the appeal.

title: New Glory for Old Glory
description: Publicly burning an American flag is a despicable act that exhibits hatred for country and contempt for the sensibilities of Americans who revere their national symbol. No member of the Supreme Court thinks otherwise. But the justices disagree passionately over whether setting fire to the flag in a nonviolent political demonstration is constitutionally permissible.

title: Mallon Resources reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Comparable results were not available because the company, which is a combination of publicly-held Mallon Minerals and 19 limited partnerships, began operations in December 1988.

title: Review/Music; 150 Voices In Honor Of 2 Events
description: The 150-voice New York City Gay Men's Chorus opened a three-concert series at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening. The concerts celebrate Gay Pride Week and the 20th anniversary of the Stonewall Rebellion, in which the patrons of a gay bar in Greenwich Village resisted a police raid.

title: Gandhi's Domination of Broadcasting Brings Outcry in India
description: With a national election looming toward the end of the year, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and his Congress Party are rapidly assuming political domination of the Government-run television and radio networks that have a monopoly of broadcast news in India.

title: John Wiley & Sons Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said net income for the year reflected the sale of Milady Publishing Corp. and Park Row Publishing, on which it recorded an after- tax gain of $7.2 million. In addition, a series of unusual charges, totaling $8.3 million after tax, were taken to write off certain prior investments in composition and program development and certain other costs. Ongoing operations in fiscal 1989 were also impacted by increases in occupancy expense at Wilson Learning and at the company's headquarters in New York City. The decline in fourth-quarter revenue reflected the sale of Milady and Park Row.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly Meets at 10:30 A.M. COMMITTEE ON PALESTINIAN RIGHTS - 10 A.M. PARTIES TO INTERNATIONAL CONVENTION AGAINST APARTHEID IN SPORTS -3 P.M. Economic and Social Council Meets at 10:30 A.M. DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM GOVERNING COUNCIL - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: HERO Industries Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ex-H.U.D. Aide Tells of Role Played by Major Republicans
description: A onetime Federal housing official told Congress today how at the age of 26 he parlayed his contacts at the Department of Housing and Urban Development into a multimillion-dollar consulting firm that retained former Interior Secretary James G. Watt and two other prominent Republicans to lobby the department on behalf of housing projects.

title: Article 284089 -- No Title
description: James Watt, former Reagan Administration Interior Secretary, testified June 9 before a House panel. It was looking into charges that the Department of Housing and Urban Development, then headed by Samuel Pierce, allowed favoritism and influence-peddling to affect funding for rehabilitating moderate-income housing.

title: Results Plus
description: Furlong Leads in L.P.G.A.: Shirley Furlong, who has won only once in her five-year career, shot a five-under-par 66 yesterday to lead the first round of the L.P.G.A. McDonald's championship in Wilmington, Del. Furlong held a one-stroke lead over Nancy Ramsbottom and Missie Berteotti on the 6,366-yard par-71 Du Pont Country Club course. Ramsbottom and Berteotti have never won on the tour. Ramsbottom has missed six of the last seven cuts and is 133d on the money list with $5,765. Berteotti is 77th with $21,316. Her best 1989 finish was a tie for 16th. She failed to make the cut in 6 of 16 tournaments. Another stroke back were Cathy Gerring, Deborah McHaffey and Susan Sanders, each at 68.(AP) HORSE RACING Chenin Blanc Wins at Belmont: Chenin Blanc, the favorite, shadowed Nature's Gift, the pace setter, through six furlongs, took command after entering the stretch and raced to a three-length victory yesterday in the feature race at Belmont Park. Chenin Blanc, ridden by Chris Antley and carrying 109 pounds, won for the second time in three starts. Nature's Gift finished second in the field of six, nine lengths ahead of Reluctant Gambler. Chenin Blanc covered one mile on a fast track in 1:36 1/5 to earn $17,400 for his owner, Bertram R. Firestone. The horse returned $3.60, $2.60 and $2.20 for $2 across the board. Nature's Gift paid $5.20 and $3.40. Reluctant Gambler paid $3.20.(AP) CYCLING Belgian Wins 10th Stage: Johan Bruyneel of Belgium surged ahead with fewer than 20 miles to go to win the 10th leg of the Tour of Switzerland yesterday. With one day remaining in the race, Beat Breu of Switzerland is the overall leader. Bruyneel covered the 129 miles from Zermatt to Bruegg in 6 hours 52 minutes 36 seconds.(AP)

title: Brunswick to Sell Industrial Division
description: The Brunswick Corporation said it would sell its 1,300-employee industrial products division to concentrate on recreational, military and aerospace products. The division, which had sales of about $150 million last year, manufactures Vapor brand door-operating systems for buses and trains at plants in Niles, Ill., and Montreal, as well as Vapor air-conditioning systems in Montgomery, Ala.

title: Caving In at the Corcoran
description: ''My work is about seeing - seeing things like they haven't been seen before,'' the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe said several years ago. A Mapplethorpe portrait of a calla lily, then, is not simply exquisite. It is also curiously and remarkably erotic.

title: Fairs And Festivals
description: TOMORROW ARTS, CRAFTS AND ANTIQUES FESTIVAL, Broadway, from 72d to 76th Street. Crafts, food, antiques, entertainment; proceeds will benefit the Save the Beacon Theater Committee. Raindate, June 25. Information: 764-6330. SUNDAY FAMA FALL FESTIVAL, Fifth Avenue, from 44th to 59th Street, Park Slope section, Brooklyn; sponsored by the Fifth Avenue Merchants Association. Sunday, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Food, crafts, rides, entertainment. Rain or shine. Information: (718) 234-1657. JEWISH RENAISSANCE STREET FESTIVAL, Bay Parkway, from 78th to 84th Street, Bensonhurst section, Brooklyn; sponsored by the Bensonhurst Council of Jewish Organizations and the Jewish Community House of Bensonhurst. Sunday, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M. Food, crafts, entertainment. Information: (718) 331-6800.

title: Peter Evans Memorial
description: A memorial service for Peter Evans, an actor in theater, films and television, will be held at 5 P.M. Monday at Playwrights Horizons, 416 West 42d Street. Mr. Evans, who originated leading roles in plays by David Rabe, David Mamet and Arthur Miller, died of AIDS on May 20 at the age of 38.

title: Uphill Task: Recruiting a New York School Chief
description: As the New York City Board of Education and its search committee rush to find someone by the end of the year to run the nation's largest school system, they are facing the problems of recruiting someone from outside the city.

title: Frank G. Opton, 83, International Lawyer
description: Frank G. Opton, a lawyer who specialized in international business, died of cerebral thrombosis Tuesday at a retirement home in Hightstown, N.J. He was 83 years old. Mr. Opton, a graduate of the University of Cologne, practiced law in Germany before coming to the United States in the early 1930's. He was admitted to the New York Bar in 1939 and was a founding partner in the Manhattan firm of Opton Handler Gottlieb Feiler Landau & Hirsch.

title: Bush and Many in Congress Denounce Flag Ruling
description: President Bush said today that flag burning was ''dead wrong,'' and lawmakers lined up on Capitol Hill to denounce the Supreme Court ruling that such acts of protest were a protected form of free speech.

title: Gold Fields Gets Bid By Hanson
description: Hanson P.L.C., the British conglomerate, yesterday offered to buy Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C., the world's second-largest producer of gold, for about $4.8 billion.

title: Washington Talk: Districtspeak; The Fine Art of the Opening Statement
description: Here are samples of what have become known as Lantos-isms, from the opening statements of Representative Tom Lantos at hearings on mismanagement at the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The California Democrat is chairman of the House Government Affairs Subcommittee on Employment and Housing.

title: Quayle Urges More Aid To Cambodian Rebels
description: Vice President Dan Quayle urged Congress today to increase aid to the non-Communist guerrillas in Cambodia, saying the ''ghost of Vietnam'' must not be allowed to haunt American foreign policy.

title: Bush Calls for New Volunteer Effort
description: President Bush announced a proposal yesterday for a national volunteer effort to help the homeless, the poor, illiterates, drug abusers, AIDS victims and other Americans facing severe problems.

title: Tambrands Review
description: Tambrands Inc. announced Tuesday that it would consolidate all advertising for its domestic feminine protection division at one agency, and asked three of its shops - Ally & Gargano, Campbell-Mithun-Esty and McCann-Erickson - to participate in the review. The combined budget of the account will be $15 million.

title: Review/Comedy; Sid Caesar and Friends, In a Show From Shows
description: Before improvisational theater, Second City and New Vaudeville, there was Sid Caesar, a grandmaster of innovative comedy. Mr. Caesar, his fellow television performers and his writers (who included Woody Allen, Mel Brooks and Neil Simon) have defined American humor. For these reasons and others, it is heartening to see him on stage at the Village Gate in ''Sid Caesar and Company.''

title: Pearl Lang Dances
description: The dancer and choreographer Pearl Lang and her company are to give three performances this weekend at Florence Gould Hall, 55 East 59th Street. Miss Lang is to perform a new solo as part of her work ''Cantigas Ladino''; also on the program are several dances on biblical themes, ''Piece for Brass'' and four duets from ''Moonways and Dark Tides.'' Performances are at 8 tonight and tomorrow night, and at 3 P.M. on Sunday. Tickets are $12, or $8 for the elderly. Information: 355-6160.

title: Lesco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: People
description: * Ira C. Herbert, the president of Coca-Cola USA, has been elected chairman of the Advertising Council, succeeding Walter E. Mattson, president and chief operating officer of The New York Times Company.

title: Washington Talk; Party Committees Bend Under Off-Year Load
description: Ideally, members of the House would like their Congressional campaign committees to be heard and not seen.

title: Rules on Child Support Worked Out in Albany
description: For the first time, divorced parents in New York State would pay a fixed percentage of their income in child support under legislation agreed to today by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders.

title: I.B.M., in Surprise, Sees a Vital Edge Over Japan
description: The president of I.B.M. disclosed today that the company has a surprising edge over Japan in the mass production of a part vital to virtually all of tomorrow's electronic products.

title: Misplaced Testiness About Tests
description: Thomas Sobol, New York State's Education Commissioner, has a problem: Students have been stealing the statewide Regents exams. What does he do about it - insure security for the tests, which are taken by thousands of high school students? No. He denounces the press. What a poor example that sets for students who could obviously use a little ethical guidance.

title: Author Bows Out of 1990 Peruvian Race
description: Mario Vargas Llosa, the front-runner in the March 1990 elections and among Latin America's leading writers, announced Wednesday that he is bowing out of the presidential race, blaming political wrangling within the center-right coalition that has been backing him.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Apples for Film Makers

title: Caspen Oil reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago results were restated to reflect Bryson Oil and Gas Corp. as the predecessor company.

title: Challenging Giamatti: Rose Likely to Fail
description: As a brash, scrappy player, Pete Rose took on Ty Cobb and his supposedly insurmountable career record for hits and succeeded where all others had failed. As a confident but embattled manager, Rose is taking on a challenge no one has ever won. He is not given much chance of success because, legal experts say, judges are reluctant to interfere with procedures in private industry, such as the hearing into the Rose case that the commissioner of baseball, A. Bartlett Giamatti, has scheduled for Monday.

title: Western Health Gets Pacificare Bid
description: Pacificare Health Systems Inc. submitted a bid for the membership and doctor contracts of Western Health Plans Inc., an ailing health maintenance company based in San Diego. Western had invited Pacificare to bid. The companies said they would meet on Friday to discuss the offer, the terms of which were not made public.

title: Florence Walsh, 47, Child-Welfare Official
description: Florence Walsh, a field office director with the Child Welfare Administration of New York City's Human Resources Administration, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 47 years old. Mrs. Walsh joined the H.R.A. as a caseworker in the division of day care. In 1986 she was appointed deputy director of one of two Manhattan field offices of the Child Welfare Administration, and a year later she became its director. Last year the agency named her its outstanding woman of the year and cited her as ''a role model to women, a dedicated manager and a sensitive and caring human service worker.''

title: Review/Jazz; Contrasts Between Two Groups
description: At the Knitting Factory's double bill on Monday night, two band leaders, the drummer Marvin (Smitty) Smith and the trombonist Robin Eubanks, offered a series of brilliant moments - individual solos and arrangements - ending their status as promising young musicians. They are now mature. The excitement they generate is no longer just flavored with the excitement of discovery; it's laced with the excitement of genuine authority.

title: Riverbend International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a gain of $226,000, or 4 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: Navratilova Manages To Beat Fernandez
description: Martina Navratilova overcame Mary Joe Fernandez, 7-6, 6-1, today in the quarterfinals of the Pilkington Glass championship.

title: Nicholson and Keaton Do Battle in 'Batman'
description: "Batman" begins with a lot of promise: the camera pans across dark, lowering clouds as we hear music so doomy you might think it to be Mahler, though it's really Prince in a cosmic mode. Gotham City swims slowly into focus. It's a production designer's coup de cinema, a nightmare version of megalopolis, an urban landscape without sun, seen through a smog of pollutants and despair. Everything seems foreshortened, squeezed, angry and rotten.

title: Mayflower Co-operative Bank reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Showdowns of a Sort For the Older Crowd
description: A year ago, it was easy to predict who would be the nation's best older horses. All the star 3-year-olds of 1987 returned to the races last season, and Alysheba, Lost Code, Bet Twice and Cryptoclearance dominated the handicap division.

title: Blue-Chip Stocks Rise; Dow Up 17.26
description: Blue-chip stocks forged higher yesterday on the shoulders of a moderately higher bond market and another round of program buying. For the third day in a row, the Dow transportation rose to a record.

title: E.P.A. Adopts Stiffer Regulations To Protect Drinking Water Supply
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today adopted costly rules intended to eliminate harmful microbes from the nation's public drinking water, preventing some 90,000 cases of waterborne disease a year.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS SEIZURE OF ASSETS IN CRIMINAL CASES
description: The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 today that the Government can freeze the assets of many criminal defendants before trial without regard to whether the person will have enough money left to hire a defense lawyer.

title: Barrincorp Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $345,000 for the latest quarter and $83,000 for the year-earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Beacon Theater Street Fair, the northbound lanes of Broadway between 72d Street and 76th Street will be closed tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: Chrysler Financial Preferred Stock
description: The Chrysler Financial Corporation is offering 750 shares of money market preferred stock at $100,000 a share through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: High Plains reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from the writeoff of prepaid public offering expenses of $288,919. c-Net income and included tax credits of $264,300 and $664,200 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: An American Relief Worker Is Abducted in the Gaza Strip
description: An American relief worker was kidnapped Thursday in the occupied Gaza Strip, and the kidnappers apparently demanded Israel release Palestinian prisoners in exchange for his freedom, Arab reports said.

title: Nantucket Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $577,347.

title: A Sunny Day For Society Of Gourmets
description: IT so happens that when Ed McCabe wrote, ''It takes a tough man to make a tender chicken,'' he was drawing from his own experience as a culinary terrorist. A notorious scourge of copywriters, the co-founder of Scali, McCabe, Sloves has hectored chefs from coast to coast, a subject of no little concern on Wednesday as the Chinese Gourmet Society gathered for its 15th-anniversary luncheon. As Shepard Kurnit, the president of Kurnit Communications, said, ''When it comes to food, I've never seen Eddie happy.''

title: Chemical Spill Changes Bush's Flight Plans
description: A truck carrying two tanks of toxic chemicals overturned on a pier at Port Newark near Newark International Airport last night, causing the Secret Service to change President Bush's travel plans, officials said.

title: Senate Endorses Democratic Plan For Wider U.S. Day Care Service
description: After a week of heated debate over the Federal Government's role in child care, the Senate today strongly endorsed a Democratic plan to expand day care services, rejecting a Republican alternative that relied largely on tax credits to parents.

title: Warsaw Journal; How to Be Big Winner: Just Make No Promises
description: Zofia Kuratowska, a distinguished hematologist, adviser on medical affairs to the Roman Catholic Church, and organizer of the Solidarity health service, is in some ways a symbol of the union movement's prodigious success in Poland's national elections.

title: Evert Says She'll Play
description: Despite an ear infection that knocked her out of a Virginia Slims grass court tournament at Eastbourne, England, this week, Chris Evert said yesterday she would definitely play at Wimbledon next week.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Summer Closings

title: Mack Trucks Expects Loss for the 2d Quarter
description: Mack Trucks Inc. announced yesterday that it expected to post a loss for the second quarter, amid signs of weakness in the $9 billion United States market for heavy trucks.

title: Chengdu Had Its Own Tiananmen Massacre
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Cites Disparities in Care Given to Uninsured Patients
