description: Hospital patients who lacked health insurance were discharged earlier and underwent fewer procedures than insured patients, a new study concludes.

title: Pictures of Primus
description: The career of Pearl Primus - a dancer, a choreographer, an anthropologist and a leading authority on African dance - is the subject of more than 50 photographs at the Caribbean Cultural Center, 408 West 58th Street. The exhibition explores the dance techniques Dr. Primus created, as well as her research on the artistic expressions and belief systems of African and Latin American peoples. The show, which is part of the center's third annual tribute to African Diaspora Women, runs through Aug. 20. Hours are 6:30 to 8 P.M. today; 1 to 5 P.M. Saturdays, and 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays. Admission is free tonight; otherwise, $2, or $1 for students. Information: 307-7420.

title: High Court Upholds Noise Rule For the Central Park Bandshell
description: New York City's noise-control regulation for concerts at the Central Park bandshell was upheld today by the United States Supreme Court.

title: U.S. Nun Is Shot in Salvador
description: An assailant in a pickup truck shot an American nun in the head Wednesday night as she rode in another truck with two other nuns, a witness and Salvadoran officials said today.

title: Pistons' New Image
description: Fans can expect a kinder, more gentle band of Detroit Pistons next season, according to Joe Dumars, the unanimous choice for most valuable player for the Bad Boys as they swept the Los Angeles Lakers to win the National Basketball Association championship. Dumars, who averaged 27.3 points against the Lakers, was at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday to collect his prizes: a 1989 Jeep Cherokee and a trophy from Sport magazine.

title: Paramount Faults Time Over Stockholder Data
description: Stepping up its battle to thwart any merger between Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc., Paramount Communications Inc. accused Time yesterday of failing to keep its stockholders fully informed and resurrected old charges against Warner and Steven J. Ross, its chairman.

title: DIALOGUE: Art and the Taxpayer's Money  Corcoran: Courage or Cowardice?; Say No To Trash
description: In canceling the Robert Mapplethorpe exhibition last week, Washington's Corcoran Gallery did more than refuse to show a few raunchy photographs of what the press, unable to print them, primly called ''explicit homoerotic and violent images.'' Because the exhibition was supported in part by public funds from the Congressionally embattled National Endowment for the Arts, the Corcoran doubtless considered financial self-interest in arriving at its decision. One hopes those reponsible are aware that in saying no to Mapplethorpe, they were exercising the right to say no to an entire theory of art.

title: Investigator Tells of Evidence Linking Rose to Bets on Reds
description: The special investigator for the baseball commissioner testified today that he had extensive evidence that Pete Rose had bet on baseball and on his own team.

title: ANGOLANS AGREE TO A TRUCE UNDER NEIGHBORS' PRESSURE AFTER 14 YEARS OF CIVIL WAR
description: Leaders of the Angolan Government and rebel forces agreed here today to a cease-fire in their 14-year-old civil war.

title: Carpita Corp reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,917,000 and a charge of $796,000. c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $1,023,000, a tax credit of $1,829,000 and a charge of $3,243,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Figgie International Inc., Richmond, a diversified consumer- and industrial-products manufacturer, named Richard J. Subel president of its Figgie Leasing Corp. subsidiary

title: Maax Inc reports earnings for
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Bird Plans to Play In a Game for Charity
description: Larry Bird, the Boston Celtic star, said yesterday he expected to play 30 minutes Sunday in a charity game in his first competition against professional basketball players since undergoing foot surgery seven months ago.

title: Republicans in Glass White Houses . . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Score Board Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $10,000 and $83,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. All per share figures have been adjusted to reflect a 1-for-100 reverse stock split effective Feb. 21, 1989.

title: Qume Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Latest quarter results included a capital gain of $1,620,000 related to the private placement sale of common stock of the company's DTC Technology unit.

title: A Time Investor Sees Gains in Warner Deal
description: When Gordon Crawford's name was mentioned about a year ago to Martin S. Davis, chairman of Paramount Communications Inc., Mr. Davis said casually, ''Oh yes, he owns a piece of all of us.''

title: Blue Jays Top A's in 13th Inning
description: Fred McGriff hit a two-run homer in the 13th inning tonight and the Toronto Blue Jays beat Oakland, 4-2, making the Athletics winless in five extra-inning games this season.

title: Consolidated Gas Sells Debentures
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company yesterday sold $100 million of 10-year debentures through competitive bidding.

title: DIALOGUE: Art and the Taxpayer's Money  Cocoran: Courage or Cowardice?; Don't Punish the Arts
description: The decision of the Corcoran Gallery to cancel a retrospective of the works of photographer Robert Mapplethorpe has caused a firestorm. The action was not based on a curator's objection to the material, which might have been a tiny bit more defensible (one photo showed a black man urinating into a white man's mouth.) It was a pre-emptive maneuver, amid growing Government intervention in the arts, to protect the museum's $292,000 in Federal funding from Congressional retaliation.

title: 'Poison Pill' Plan Adopted by Disney
description: The Walt Disney Company said it had adopted a stockholder rights plan to prevent the company from being acquired in a hostile takeover. The company said in a statement, ''The stockholder rights plan represents a sound and reasonable means of safeguarding the interests of all stockholders, should an effort be made to acquire the company at a price not reflective of its fair value.''

title: Accounting Merger Passes Test
description: An important vote of the 2,105 United States partners of Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young that ended yesterday cleared the way for a merger of the two accounting firms.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 468 money market mutual funds increased by $4.01 billion, to $321.26 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 142 institutional funds increased by $1.79 billion, to $82.7 billion. The assets of the 231 general-purpose funds were up by $780.8 million, to $102.92 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.45 billion, to $135.64 billion, the institute said.

title: What Is Out There
description: Dozens of other outdoor performing-arts festivals in and around New York City have already begun. Here are some of them.

title: On Stage
description: A Bogosian Solo

title: Allan Meltzer Dead; Press Agent Was 77
description: Allan Meltzer, a press agent who began his career representing the stage productions of Orson Welles and John Houseman for the Federal Theater Project, died of heart disease on Saturday in Key Biscayne, Fla. He was 77 years old.

title: G.A.O. Says Navy Contract Unfairly Favored I.B.M.
description: The Navy violated Federal procurement rules by writing unfair specifications for a major computer contract that allowed only the International Business Machines Corporation to bid, an investigation by the General Accounting Office has found.

title: Manila Economic Aide Quits
description: President Corazon C. Aquino's outspoken economic planning minister resigned today, citing ''honest but irreconcilable differences'' on economic policy. The official, Solita C. Monsod, told Mrs. Aquino that she wanted the Government ''to speak with one voice'' during negotiations in Tokyo next month for a multilateral aid plan for the Philippines. Last week, she protested the transfer of foreign aid planning from her office to the newly created Philippine Aid Plan Committee.

title: Golden Valley Accounting Inquiry
description: Golden Valley Microwave Foods Inc. said it was cooperating with a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into the company's accounting practices. The S.E.C. investigation was reported today in USA Today, which said the inquiry involved the charge that Golden Valley had fabricated its revenues and that certain corporate officers had used company funds for their own use. A spokesman for the commission would neither confirm nor deny the existence of an investigation.

title: Bank Merger Is Proposed
description: The Republic New York Corporation proposed Thursday that the Manhattan Savings Bank merge with the Williamsburg Savings Bank, a Republic subsidiary.

title: Kidnapped U.S. Relief Aide Is Released in the Gaza Strip
description: An American who was kidnapped for 29 hours by a disgruntled Palestinian was freed today and said the kidnapper was trying to win attention for his efforts to build a playground in the Gaza Strip.

title: Tanker Strikes Reef Off Newport, Spilling Oil in Narragansett Bay
description: A tanker with a cargo of heating oil struck a reef near the entrance to Narragansett Bay off Newport, R.I., late yesterday afternoon, spreading 1 million gallons of No. 2 fuel oil over 50 square miles.

title: President Pressed on Rights Commitment in U.S.
description: The families of three civil rights workers murdered in Mississippi 25 years ago met President Bush today, but the session ended on a discordant note for some of the visitors, who said they had hoped for fresh commitments from the President on civil rights and social issues.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Keeping Bugs at Bay
description: Entomologists predict clouds of mosquitoes this summer, a result of heavy spring rains. Drain all stagnant water on roofs and in yards. Chiggers, flies and other insects will also be out looking for food. Here are ways to keep flying pests, particularly mosquitoes, from assaulting you. Repellents: Repellents containing DEET are most effective, but apply with care. Do not apply to hands or face or use in concentrations stronger than 50 percent; 15 percent is recommended. Clothing: Don't look like a flower. Many bugs are attracted to bright colors. Perspiration: Wash off perspiration. Sweat produces a scent that attracts bugs. Chlorine: Add a capful or two of chlorinated bleach to your bath water or take a swim in a chlorinated pool. The smell repels most insects. Sun oil: Oily sun screens make skin too slippery for insects to get a grip. Food and fragrance: Avoid alcohol and foods high in serotonin, like bananas and nuts. Mosquitoes are attracted to those scents. Avoid perfume, cologne and hair spray. (Sources: Dr. Roger Grothaus, Raid Center for Insect Control, Racine, Wis., Dr. Jeffrey D. Bernhart, New York City Department of Health)

title: Chladek Wins Silver; Penalties Costly for U.S.
description: In the slalom competition in which they were supposed to be so proficient, the United States canoeists and kayakers settled for a silver medal and a bronze today at the world whitewater championships here in the woods of western Maryland.

title: Morton Thiokol Operation Split
description: Morton Thiokol Inc. stockholders approved splitting the company's operations, returning the Thiokol name to its aerospace division and creating a new chemicals, air bags and salt business named Morton International Inc. Ballots representing 76 percent of the company's 47.6 million outstanding shares were cast in the election, with about 60 percent of outstanding shares favoring the split and 15.4 percent opposed.

title: Coping; With Safeguarding Valuables
description: When you're preparing for a vacation trip, it's a good time to think about your important papers and the kind of small but valuable possessions that virtually everyone has. What should you keep in a bank's safe-deposit box, what should you keep in a secure place at home and what should you take with you when you travel? Here are the basics: A safe-deposit box is the place for articles that are extremely difficult to replace. ''Also keep in your box all documentation of objects of value, so that if the objects are destroyed, damaged or stolen, you can prove possession and value,'' said Madeline I. Noveck, a certified financial planner in New York.

title: Review/Dance; The Urban Lower Depths, With a Staggering Junkie
description: The American Dance Festival is justly celebrated for its premieres. But it has also revived important works that can be considered classics of modern dance. With the aid of a grant from the Ford Foundation, it is presenting programs called ''The Black Tradition in American Modern Dance'' that feature reconstructions of productions by major black choreographers.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the poisoning of a notable tree in Texas misidentified the Mayor of Austin. He is Lee Cooke. Sally Shipman is Mayor Pro Tem.

title: No Tampering Found on Iran-Contra Papers
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee said today that it found no evidence of a deliberate or systematic effort by the Reagan Administration to withhold documents from the Congressional inquiry into the Iran-contra affair.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Prime Minister Michel Rocard of France misidentified another Socialist politician, Laurent Fabius. He is the President of the National Assembly, not the Senate.

title: Motorman Found Slain on Subway Platform
description: LEAD: An off-duty motorman who had been carrying $140 in cash was found shot to death on a Brooklyn subway platform only minutes after getting off a train at 5 A.M. yesterday, the police said.

title: Let the Punishment Fit the Devastating White-Collar Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Road Back to Yankees Looks Rocky for Guidry
description: Ron Guidry of the Yankees, who has declared that 1989 will be his last year as a professional pitcher, saw his Yankee future grow a little dimmer on Thursday when he lost for the third time in four decisions for the Columbus Clippers of the International League. Guidry hopes to perform well enough against Class AAA competition to merit one more call to the parent club, but his recent record has not been brilliant.

title: Helen Hershkoff, A Lawyer, Weds
description: Helen Hershkoff, the associate legal director of the American Civil Liberties Union in New York, and Stephen James Loffredo, an assistant professor at the law school of the City University of New York, were married yesterday in Rye Brook, N.Y., at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Loffredo. Judge Louise Gruner-Gans of New York City Civil Court officiated.

title: Lyrics by Wodehouse
description: Al Carmines and David Vaughan will perform songs with lyrics by P. G. Wodehouse on Wednesday at 9 and 11 P.M. at Jan Wallman's Restaurant Cabaret, 49 West 44th Street. Wodehouse, the comic novelist, wrote lyrics from 1904 into the late 1920's for shows with music by such composers as Jerome Kern, George Gershwin, Ivor Novello and Rudolf Friml. Dinner reservations: 764-8930. (Cover charge, $8; minimum, $8.)

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Save the Beacon Theater Street Fair, northbound lanes of Broadway from 72d to 76th Street will be closed today from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.

title: A Synthetic Bag Is Made For Bagpipes
description: IF W. L. Gore & Associates has its way, the Scottish bagpipe will never be the same. The manufacturer of Gore-tex, the ubiquitous waterproof material used in everything from ski jackets to slickers, has developed a synthetic bagpipe bag that it says will last years longer than traditional bags made from sheepskin, elk hide or cowhide.

title: Growth Lags In Spending And Incomes
description: Consumer spending and income grew a lackluster three-tenths of 1 percent in May, the slowest pace since the fall, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: New Security Planned for Regents Tests
description: Likening the theft of Regents examinations to insider trading on Wall Street and municipal corruption, the New York State Education Commissioner said yesterday that his department would overhaul its security for the tests before they are given again in January.

title: A Tireless Gubicza Shuts Out Yankees
description: In the ninth inning, when the Yankees were down to their last chance, Mark Gubicza was still throwing fastballs at 92 miles an hour. Steve Balboni saw four of them, one seemingly faster than the other, including the one that ended the game.

title: Dun & Bradstreet Agrees To Settle Suits on Charges
description: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to pay $18 million to settle Federal lawsuits by customers who said they had been unfairly overcharged for credit reports.

title: G.P. Craighead, 59, Executive-Search Aide
description: George P. Craighead, an executive-search specialist, died of cancer Wednesday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Darien, Conn.

title: Hunger, Yes, Surrender, No: Coping With Curfew in Gaza
description: The rabbits are plump and destined for the pot, and so, too, are the pigeons. Mohammed Awad, who keeps them in his yard, says that in their small way they represent a weapon against occupation.

title:
Your Money;
The New Allure Of Fixed Rates
description: LEAD: HOME buyers shopping for a loan this summer will find that for the first time in two years a fixed-rate mortgage is perhaps a more attractive option than an adjustable-rate mortgage. The reasons are a decline in long-term interest rates and tighter guidelines at the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie

title: Crude Oil Spills in Houston After Barge and Ship Collide
description: A cargo ship collided with a oil barge in the Houston ship channel last night, dumping about 4,000 barrels of crude oil into the water near Galveston Bay in what the Coast Guard called one of the more serious recent oil spills in the area.

title: Rally Opens Weekend For Homosexual Pride
description: More than 250,000 people are expected to participate in Lesbian and Gay Pride Weekend, say its organizers, beginning with a rally on the Great Lawn in Central Park today, continuing with a parade down Fifth Avenue tomorrow and culminating in a fireworks display tomorrow night.

title: New York Is Hit by Floods; State of Emergency Declared
description: A state of emergency was declared in several western New York communities as raging creek waters fed by torrential rains swamped bridges and inundated roadways, the authorities said today.

title: Review/Dance; Harlem Troupe Displays A Balanchine Presence
description: ''Allegro Brillante'' seems made for the Dance Theater of Harlem. The Tchaikovsky score and the choreography, by George Balanchine, are filled with sweetness. The ballet modestly combines virtuoso technique with dancing that sweeps romantically across the stage.

title: ANGOLA CEASE-FIRE A START, U.S. SAYS
description: American officials said today that the cease-fire announced by leaders of the Angolan Government and Angolan rebel forces was a first step toward a political settlement, but that there was no agreement on a future government.

title: Reservations Plan by AMR
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, will expand its computerized Sabre reservation system over the next 18 months to include hotel and car rental information, a company official said today.

title: Token Shortage Makes Mad Jerseyans Madder
description: Motorists who were merely annoyed at the 10-cent toll increase on the Garden State Parkway in April have since found reason to be downright irate: a shortage of discount tokens that has congested toll lanes.

title: Metro Datelines; Link Seen in Slayings In Greenwich Village
description: The bodies of two young men, both shot to death, were found about 500 feet apart early yesterday in Greenwich Village, and the police believe the shootings were related.

title: A Haven for Chinese
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Governor Is Out of Prison
description: Dan Walker, the former Governor of Illinois, was released from Federal prison in Minnesota Thursday after serving 17 months of a seven-year sentence for fraud, his lawyer, Thomas Foran, said. Federal District Judge Ann Williams ordered Mr. Walker's release Wednesday. The judge acted in response to a motion for a reduction of Mr. Walker's sentence because, the motion said, he is ''frail and chronically ill.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article yesterday about West German relations with Poland omitted a passage in some copies. The passage should have read: ''There has also been speculation, denied by the Government, that the rise of the right-wing Republicans and the appointment of a Bavarian conservative, Theo Waigel, as Finance Minister in April strengthened the hand of politicians opposed to making too large a financial commitment to Poland.''

title: Texaco Sets Debt Payoff
description: Texaco Inc. said today that it planned to retire almost $1 billion in debt securities before the scheduled maturity dates in a further effort to improve the company's financial footing.

title: Results Plus
description: GOLF Hendrickson Leads Seniors: Dick Hendrickson, who has not won in four years on the PGA Seniors tour, shot a six-under-par 66 yesterday to take the lead after the first round of the MONY Syracuse Senior Classic. Two strokes back after 18 holes at the Lafayette Country Club were Harold Henning, Mike Hill and Roland Stafford.(AP) King Ahead in L.P.G.A. Event: Betsy King, seeking her fourth victory of 1989, bogeyed the first two holes yesterday but went on to score eight birdies to take a one-stroke lead after 36 holes of the L.P.G.A. McDonald's Championship in Wilmington, Del. King, 33 years old, shot a second-round six-under-par 65 over the 6,366-yard Du Pont Country Club course for a two-round total of eight-under 134. One stroke back in the 72-hole tournament were Shirley Furlong and Pat Bradley.(AP) TRACK AND FIELD

title: Eastern Leases Out Three More Planes
description: Strikebound Eastern Airlines kept up the flurry of transactions under its rebuilding plan by delivering an L-1011 wide-body plane to Worldways of Canada and two Boeing 727-200's to Avianca of Colombia. The short-term lease deals were recently approved by the United States Bankruptcy Court in New York and will give Eastern $900,000 over four months from Worldways and $1.9 million from Avianca.

title: Vehicle Sales Dropped 9.8% In Mid-June
description: Sales of domestic cars and light trucks fell 9.8 percent in mid-June, leading analysts to predict huge discounts this summer and production cutbacks in the fall.

title: BEIJING'S LEADERS REPORTED TO MEET
description: China's top officials were believed to be meeting in secret today to resolve the nation's political crisis, but while there were many rumors in the capital there was no confirmation of an outcome.

title: Chilean Opposition Names A Candidate for President
description: A veteran centrist politician was effectively proclaimed the Chilean opposition's presidential candidate today after winning the backing of moderate leftist parties.

title: Senate Attempts to Reinstate Law on Desecration of Flags
description: The Senate tonight attached an amendment to the child care bill that was intended to rewrite Federal law and keep flag desecration illegal despite the Supreme Court's ruling this week that flag-burning could be protected as free speech.

title: Reviews/Music; A South African Lilt, by Its Inventors
description: For South Africans in the audience Wednesday night at S.O.B.'s, seeing Mahlathini and the Mahotella Queens with the Maghona Tsotle band must have been like being at a mid-1960's Motown revue - hearing a hallowed pop style played intact by the people who invented it. For Americans, it was the first chance to see musicians whose style - called mgqashiyo, ''the indestructible sound'' - has echoed around the world. The buoyant, three-chord vamps of mgqashiyo, with its stop-start syncopations and tickling, stuttering guitars, have proved irresistible to dancers and toe-tappers everywhere.

title: INSIDE
description: Bomber Budget Faulted

title: Public Safety Requires the Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times; Foreign Affairs, in the Lippmann Tradition
description: Barbarian Sentiments How the American Century Ends By William Pfaff 198 pages. Hill & Wang. $19.95. William Pfaff is a philosophical journalist who challenges the reader to think. His field is international affairs and he comes as close as any American columnist now writing to the tradition of the late Walter Lippmann in his ability to hinge events and trends together with historical underpinning. Unlike many newspaper columnists, he didn't develop out of the reporter ranks, one reason his commentary may have a more ruminative and lasting quality.

title: Release Mandela, Thatcher Urges Pretoria Party Chief
description: Despite consistent opposition from Mrs. Thatcher, the European Community has imposed economic sanctions on South Africa to force it to dismantle apartheid, and radical opponents of the South African Government have insisted on a full embargo.

title: Cuba Discloses A Drug Network Of Top Officials
description: Cuba has gone to great lengths in the last few days to acknowledge that some of President Fidel Castro's closest aides were involved in smuggling drugs to the United States.

title: William C. Beattie, 84, Con Edison Executive
description: William C. Beattie. a retired vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company, died of congestive heart failure Thursday at Winthrop Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 84 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Right to Death-Row Lawyer Curbed
description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that indigent inmates on death row do not have a constitutional right to a lawyer to assist them in a second round of state court appeals.

title: Wasserstein Group Raises Gateway Bid
description: A partnership led by the investment bank Wasserstein, Perella & Company raised its takeover bid slightly today in the battle for the Gateway Corporation P.L.C., Britain's third-biggest supermarket chain and owner of Herman's Sporting Goods.

title: Ms. Oliensis Wed To John Shoptaw
description: Ellen Sarah Oliensis, a doctoral candidate in comparative literature at Harvard University, and John Clark Shoptaw, an assistant professor of English at Princeton University, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Oliensis, in New York. Judge Judith S. Kaye of the State Court of Appeals officiated.

title: Computer Software Needs No Patents
description: To the Editor:

title: Dykstra Makes Noise But Mets Roll to Victory
description: Lenny Dykstra returned to Shea Stadium last night in the uniform of the Philadelphia Phillies, attacked his old teammates on the Mets with two walks, a triple and a stolen base and reported: ''Wally Backman called me after the trade and said: 'You're going to make a lot of money.' ''

title: A North Sea Oil Halt
description: In the latest blow to the reeling British oil industry, corroded pipework has forced the closing of two oil platforms in the North Sea, Chevron Petroleum Ltd. said this week. The shutdown earlier this month has cut production, already at a nine-year low, by 83,000 barrels a day. Oil analysts estimate British production in May was 1.54 million barrels a day, compared with an average in 1988 of about 2.2 million. A series of accidents has been responsible for most of the decline.

title: For the First Lady, Koch Lips Are Sealed
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch will not be kissing Barbara Bush anymore.

title: Navy Lifts Ban On Unisys Units
description: The Navy announced today that it had lifted its suspension of the Unisys Corporation, which was barred from Navy contracts after what investigators said was ''widespread misconduct'' in one division and suspicions of further misconduct at other divisions.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Morris S. Stone, Executive, 78
description: Morris S. Stone, vice chairman of the American Greetings Corporation, a greeting cards company, died of a stroke yesterday at University Hospital in Cleveland. He was 78 years old and lived in Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: Virgine Perissel, an English Teacher, Weds Christopher Simandl in France
description: Virgine Michele Perissel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andre Perissel of Montreuil and St. Briac-sur-Mer, France, was married yesterday to Christopher Jerome Simandl, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome J. Simandl of Rye, N.Y. The civil ceremony was performed in the Montreuil city hall by the bride's father, a former Mayor of Montreuil.

title: Beijing Memo; All Fire and Vengeance,The Dragons Are Loose
description: The dragons are everywhere in Beijing, and they are multiplying. Two of them twirl around the concrete pillars of the newly built International Hotel. Another pair, recently hatched, stretch over the entrance to the 16th-century Drum Tower.

title: What Middle Schools Can Teach
description: ''Adolescence, contrary to popular belief, is not a disease.'' That line, from a member of a Carnegie Corporation Task Force on Adolescent Development, drew laughs from 250 education and health experts gathered recently in Washington D.C. But the problems of youngsters aged 10 to 15 are unmistakably serious.

title: F.A.A. Finds Some Flaws In Eastern's Plane Repairs
description: An investigation at Eastern Airlines' maintenance bases in Atlanta and Miami found several instances in which pilots repeatedly had to report malfunctioning equipment before proper repairs were done, the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday.

title: JUSTICES UPHOLD BUSINESSES' RIGHT TO SELL PHONE SEX
description: The Supreme Court declared unanimously today that a Federal ban on commercial telephone messages that are ''indecent'' but not ''obscene'' violates the constitutional right to free speech.

title: Unilever to Buy 2 Schering Units
description: Unilever, the giant British-Dutch consumer products company, agreed to buy two color cosmetics units of the Schering-Plough Corporation for $120 million.

title: State Farm Faces a $100 Million Bias Suit
description: A $100 million discrimination suit was filed Thursday against the State Farm Insurance Company by seven Texas women. They charged that the company's hiring practices discriminated against women and members of minorities.

title: 'J'Accuse' For Pete Rose
description: Baseball's rules against gambling seem quaint in a country where government muscle has taken over the gambling rackets from the Mafia.

title: Judge Relents on Jail Terms For Anti-Abortion Protesters
description: A judge sentencing 48 anti-abortion protesters on trespassing charges today deferred jail time for many of them even though they did not promise to obey the law in the future.

title: William Gedney, Photographer, 56
description: William Gedney, a photographer and teacher of photography at Pratt Institute and Cooper Union, died of AIDS yesterday at his home on Staten Island. He was 56 years old. Mr. Gedney, a teacher since 1969, was the recipient of Guggenheim and Fulbright fellowships. An exhibition of his work, ''Eastern Kentucky and San Francisco,'' was staged in 1968 at the Museum of Modern Art. Mr. Gedney's pictures are in the collections of that museum and the George Eastman House in Rochester.

title: Dinkins Urges Help for Schools In Crisis Areas
description: David N. Dinkins, Manhattan Borough President and mayoral candidate, yesterday called for the creation of mobile teams of trouble-shooters that could be dispatched across New York City to assist schools in crisis.

title: Elizabeth Decker Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Elizabeth H. Decker, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Decker of Wilton, Conn., and Palm Desert, Calif., to Jean Marie Compagnon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michel Compagnon of Paris and Meaux, France, took place yesterday at the Church of St. Jean Baptiste in New York. The Rev. James Feeley, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Robert J. Kerdasha, Publisher, 72
description: Robert J. Kerdasha, a publisher and advertising executive, died of a heart attack June 17 at St. Mary's Medical Center in Evansville, Ind. He was 72 years old and lived in Evansville and Manhattan.

title: CRITICISM MOUNTS ON STEALTH COST
description: Under intense Congressional pressure to lift the lid of secrecy from the Stealth bomber program, the Pentagon today disclosed a detailed proposal seeking about $5 billion in each of the next two years and some $8 billion annually after that.

title: Review/Dance; 'La Sylphide' and Tcherkassky Return to Ballet Theater
description: ''La Sylphide,'' led by Julio Bocca and Marianna Tcherkassky, returned to American Ballet Theater's repertory Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House with all the delights that 19th-century Romantic ballet so naturally provides.

title: About New York; Helping Mothers With Problems Show Their Love
description: Baby breaks a vase, swallows a rock, scrapes a knee and cries and cries and cries. The life of a mother. Even for Ms. Perfect Mom, keeping up would be a big chore.

title: 2,000 Burmese Protest Attack on Opposition Chief
description: Two thousand young people rallied in the Burmese capital today after the military Government denounced an opposition leader, diplomats said.

title: Prenuptial tests for aids repealed
description: At the urging of health officials and AIDS specialists, the Illinois Legislature today repealed the only law in the country requiring prenuptial testing for the AIDS virus.

title: An Ethics Spotlight on Mr. Marino
description: New York City's corruption scandal excited public consciousness of the power of big campaign money in New York politics. Now, four years and two blue-ribbon commissions later, the State Legislature again seems ready to adjourn without enacting reform. Gov. Mario Cuomo and Ralph Marino, the Senate majority leader, could still break the deadlock. But time is running out.

title: Pronouncing the Names
description: BAO ZUNXIN, historian: bow (rhymes with now) dzwuhn-sheen

title: Putting Digital Sound In Movie Theaters
description: A marketing consultant and an audio engineer have patented a new approach to giving movie theaters digital sound. If the system is adopted by the film industry, the inventor said, theaters could provide the clarity of compact disk stereo systems without replacing their current projection equipment.

title: Metro Datelines; Entertainer Cleared In an Assault Case
description: A Manhattan jury yesterday found that the entertainer Joey Heatherton did not assault a clerk who had accused Ms. Heatherton of attacking her in 1985 in a Rockefeller Center passport office.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: Phyllis R. Flood Weds Ben Feder
description: The Radio City Suite at the Rainbow Room was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Phyllis Rich Flood and Ben Feder. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Robert E. Goldburg. The bride is the daughter of Jean Rich of Long Beach, L.I., and the late Abe Rich. Her husband is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. William L. Feder of New York.

title: New York Says It Will End Sea Dumping
description: New York City and Westchester County announced yesterday that they have tentatively agreed to phase out their dumping of sewage sludge in the Atlantic Ocean within three years.

title: Fine for Pets, Not Toddlers
description: Dry pet food can contain penicillin that makes it a hazard to children, particularly those at the toddler and crawling stage.

title: Blast Kills 2 in San Salvador
description: A bomb exploded outside a crowded market here today, killing 2 people and wounding 35. There was no claim of responsibility for the explosion, which occurred shortly before noon. Witnesses gave conflicting accounts, but some said they saw a man hurl a bomb from a rooftop. The attack came amid fears of an increase in violence after the inauguration on June 1 of President Alfredo Cristiani, a rightist.

title: Reviews/Music; Melancholy Mood vs. the Nonsentimental
description: Two different esthetics jostled a bit at the Knitting Factory on Wednesday night. Sound Theater, led by the young saxophonist Greg Osby, worked with traditional ideas about mood and technique, moving from long moments of melancholy to fury. Odd Job, a downtown supergroup made up of the singer Shelly Hirsch, the keyboardist David Weinstein, the saxophonist Ned Rothenberg and the drummer Samm Bennett, played a sentiment-free set laced with tunes from the 60's - ''Foxy Lady,'' ''White Rabbit'' and more. Irony ruled.

title: Stanford Agrees to Return Ancient Bones to Indians
description: In an exceptional agreement, Stanford University will return the skeletal remains of about 550 Ohlone Indians to their descendants in Northern California for reburial.

title: Judge Applies Alcohol Law To Casinos
description: A Federal judge in New Jersey has ruled that casinos can be held liable for the losses of drunken customers, and the Atlantic City casino industry is watching to see whether the decision will set off a deluge of lawsuits.

title: Paramount Lifts Offer For Time
description: Increasing its pressure on Time Inc., Paramount Communications Inc. yesterday raised its takeover offer to $200 a share, or $12 billion, in cash.

title: Court Curbs Death Row Rights
description: The Supreme Court ruled that indigent inmates on death row do not have a right to a lawyer to help them in a second round of appeals. Page 8.

title: Review/Music; A Much-Cut 'Fairy Queen,'Purcell's 'Semi-Opera'
description: The Central City Chorus's concert performance of ''The Fairy Queen'' on Thursday night at the Central Presbyterian Church was better perceived as an honorable conclusion to the church's musical season than as an important statement of Purcell's score.

title: Senate Passes Child Care Bill That Has Grants and Credits
description: The Senate today gave final approval to a modified Democratic child care bill that combines grants to states and modest tax credits to assist parents with expenses.

title: U.S. to Release Health Data On Nuclear Plant Workers
description: The Department of Energy has reversed its longstanding policy and agreed to make available to independent researchers the health records of 600,000 people who have worked at nuclear weapons plants since the early 1940's.

title: Navratilova-Reggi Matchup Set for Grass-Court Final
description: Martina Navratilova won her ninth match in nine days to reach the final of the women's grass-court tennis tournament here with a 6-3, 6-2 victory today over Ros Fairbank of South Africa.

title: New York H.U.D. Leaders Urged Housing Industry to Give to Causes
description: High-ranking officials in the Department of Housing and Urban Development's New York regional office repeatedly solicited the people they regulate - builders, housing managers, architects, lawyers, local housing authority directors - for donations to favorite charities, causes and the going-away parties of these H.U.D. officials.

title: Greeks Will Try Again To Form a Government
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou was invited today to try to form a government after a Conservative opponent whose party placed first in general elections Sunday failed to secure Communist support for a coalition of his own.

title: TV Marti Could Open Many Cuban Eyes
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Arrest for Guthrie
description: William Guthrie, the boxer who was barred from competing for a berth on the United States Olympic boxing team because he failed a drug test last summer, was arrested on Thursday in St. Louis on a cocaine charge one day after he won his second professional fight.

title: Patents Put on a CD
description: The United States Patent and Trademark Office has begun marketing a computerized data base of its patents on compact disk. The data base costs $300 a year, including software to search the files, and will be updated six times a year. It will include some information on every patent ever issued. Patent Office officials said the data base could run on an I.B.M. AT personal computer or a compatible, although the system must have several special features.

title: KEY RATES
Sakharov in Britain: Jab at Gorbachev
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, fresh from the kind of parliamentary confrontation in his own country that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher thrives on in hers, visited Mrs. Thatcher today with a message of skepticism about the West's ability to help President Mikhail S. Gorbachev change the Soviet Union.

title: Is Insurance a Shelter if a Tree Falls?
description: Slashing rain, hail and violent winds carried by spring storms have wreaked millions of dollars in damage from Texas to Washington, D.C., and left an expensive problem for thousands of homeowners. Much of the damage was done by huge trees that crushed cars, fell through roofs and, not least, destroyed expensive landscaping.

title: Kristine Murphy Weds
description: At the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, Kristine Ann Murphy, a daughter of William J. Murphy Jr. and June L. Murphy, both of Glen Ridge, N.J., was married yesterday to Ralph Lee Godwin Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Godwin of Wilmington, N.C. The Rev. Jerry Everly, a United Methodist minister, officiated. The bride, known professionally as Conor Murphy, is a model and actress. Mr. Godwin is a vice president of Jones Lang Wootton, a commercial real-estate firm in New York.

title: Firefighter Charged in Blaze
description: A volunteer firefighter and a friend firebombed the Carbolabs Inc. chemical plant in rural Bethany on Monday using gasoline while both were drunk, the police charged Thursday. The firefighter, Michael A. Legge, 19 years old, and his friend, Brian S. Golembowski, 22, both of Bethany, were arraigned in Superior Court here on arson charges.

title: On the Capture of a Hated French Collaborator
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear Battery Converts Reactor Waste Products
description: Paul Brown, a college dropout who is vice president of Peripheral Systems Inc., a six-year-old technology concern in Portland, Ore., has won patent approval for a nuclear battery.

title: Seabrook Tests Halted On Reactor Shutdown
description: Federal regulators today suspended low-power tests at the Seabrook nuclear power plant because of concerns about a reactor shutdown, a plant spokesman said. The regulators believe operators may have waited too long to shut down the reactor after discovering that a valve had malfunctioned.

title: Timothy Cardinal Manning, 79; Guided Los Angeles Archdiocese
description: Timothy Cardinal Manning, who brought social conscience and theological conservatism to the more than 2.5 million Roman Catholics he served for 15 years as Archbishop of Los Angeles, died of cancer today. He was 79 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Law page yesterday about the departing dean of the Harvard Law School misstated the size of a class there. Each of the three classes has about 540 students. The figures given for the graduating classes in 1981 and last year - 1,638 and 1,629 - were for the entire school.

title: Officers' Ouster By Metro-North Called Excessive
description: Three Metro-North police officers, dismissed from the force last year because of a 1983 videotape in which they were shown clowning in Grand Central Terminal, have been ordered reinstated by an independent arbitrator. The dismissals of three others were upheld in the decision Thursday.

title: New Signs of Economic Lag Touch Off Big Market Rallies
description: Reports from the Government and the nation's automobile makers provided new evidence today that the economy was slowing sharply, touching off big rallies in the financial markets on enhanced prospects for controlling inflation and reducing interest rates.

title: Winners of Humanities Prize Named
description: The National Endowment for the Humanities Tuesday announced the first five winners of the Charles Frankel Prize, honoring Americans for their efforts to educate the public about history, literature, philosophy and other branches of the humanities.

title: Fees for Documents Will Rise
description: Fees charged by town clerks in Connecticut for birth certificates, marriage licenses, burial permits, death certificates and other documents will increase under a law that takes effect July 1. The cost of birth, death and marriage certificates will rise to $5 from $3. Marriage licenses will cost $10 instead of $6. Burial permits will cost $3 instead of $2. Town governments keep the money raised by the fees.

title: Jazz Festival
description: Most of the JVC Jazz Festival concert at Avery Fisher Hall tomorrow will probably not be jazz, by any reasonable definition. But it is virtually guaranteed to be festive, since it presents three kinetic Afro-Caribbean dance bands - the Bhundu Boys from Zimbabwe, Tabou Combo from Haiti and Arrow from Montserrat -along with Malombo, a trio from South Africa whose music finds a comfortable, private territory between tribal tradition and the modern world.

title: The Signed Confession of Shoeless Joe
description: In the current movie ''Field of Dreams,'' Shoeless Joe Jackson and seven teammates of the Chicago White Sox - the historically besmirched Black Sox - who were banned from baseball for allegedly throwing the 1919 World Series to the Cincinnati Reds, are sentimentalized and glorified.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend yesterday about the Dance Theater of Harlem misidentified the performers. They were Judy Tyrus and Augustus Van Heerden, not Virginia Johnson and Eddie J. Shellman.

title: Hooker Receives Debt Moratorium
description: Forty-two Australian bankers have agreed to give the Hooker Corporation, the financially pressed developer and owner of American retail properties, a four-month moratorium on its $1.9 billion debt, Hooker said yesterday in Sydney. Hooker owns the Bonwit Teller, B. Altman, Sakowitz and Parisian stores in the United States. It said earlier this week that it would try to sell 50 percent stakes in each to reduce its debt.

title: Pioneer, Champion, Honoree
description: When the Public Schools Athletic League held its Pegasus Awards dinner two years ago to honor the top female senior athletes, one outstanding athlete, Shola Lynch, was noticeably absent. On Thursday night, her younger sister Nnenna was absent from this year's awards dinner. Unlike Shola, however, Nnenna had been invited and received the award for best cross-country runner.

title: Club Refuses to Comply
description: A long-simmering feud between The Athletics Congress and the Santa Monica Track Club has apparently escalated. The club president declared yesterday that his athletes ''will do our own thing'' rather than comply with any requests or programs of T.A.C., the national governing body for track and field.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5 China's leaders have met in secret to resolve the nation's political crisis, say Chinese in a position to know. But while there were many rumors, there was no confirmation of an outcome. Page 1 China's symbols have new meaning since the pro-democracy demonstrations. Many people have begun to look at symbols like the dragon as illustrations of backwardness and tools of repression, rather than of national glory. 4 Some of Fidel Castro's closest aides were involved in smuggling drugs to the United States, Cuba has disclosed after years of denials. 1 Surviving curfew in the Gaza Strip, which is frequently being imposed by Israel for long lengths of time, is a way of saying ''yes to hunger, no to surrender,'' one resident said. 1 An American who was kidnapped for 29 hours by a disgruntled Palestinian was freed and said the kidnapper was trying to win attention for his efforts to build a playground in the Gaza Strip. 5 The cease-fire by Angolan leaders and Angolan rebels is a first step toward a political settlement, American officials said. But they added that there was no agreement on the shape of a future government. 3 The release of Nelson Mandela would be an important step in solving Pretoria's political problems with Britain, Prime Minister Thatcher is said to have told the leader of South Africa's governing party. 3 At a Sakharov-Thatcher meeting in London, Mr. Sakharov delivered a message of skepticism about the West's ability to help President Gorbachev change the Soviet Union. 3 Two thousand Burmese rallied in the nation's capital after the military Government denounced an opposition leader, diplomats said. 5 National 6-8, 24, 46 A ban on commercial messages over the telephone that are ''indecent'' but not obscene was declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court. But the Court upheld the ban on obscene messages. 1 Death-row inmates are not entitled by constitutional right to a lawyer to assist them in a second round of state court appeals, the Supreme Court ruled. 8 The Senate moved to reinstate a law making flag desecration illegal, despite a Supreme Court ruling Wednesday that flag-burning could be protected as free speech. 8 Evidence of an economic slowdown was provided by the Government and auto makers, touching off big rallies in the financial markets on enhanced prospects for controlling inflation and reducing interest rates. 1 Leaders of the auto workers' union received approval from representatives of the rank and file to pursue cooperative programs on the plant floors of the Big Three auto companies. 31 Sales of domestic cars and light trucks fall 9.8 percent 31 A medium-sized oil tanker hit a reef near the entrance to Narragansett Bay near Newport, R.I., spreading a slick of 50 square miles in a few hours. 1 Stanford will return the remains of about 550 Ohlone Indians to their descendants in Northern California for reburial under an unprecedented agreement with Indian elders. 1 The Pentagon disclosed a proposal for the Stealth bomber program that seeks about $5 billion in each of the next two years and some $40 billion by 1993. 8 Illinois repealed an AIDS law, at the urging of health officials and AIDS specialists, that requires testing for the virus before marriage. 6 The Senate Intelligence Committee said it has found no evidence of a deliberate effort by the Reagan Administration to withhold documents from the Congressional inquiry into the Iran-contra affair. 46 Health records of nuclear workers dating back to the 1940's will be made available to independent researchers, the Department of Energy said in reversing a longstanding policy. 6 Seabrook tests halted because of concern on reactor shutdown 6 A Democratic child care bill that combines grants to states and modest tax credits to assist parents with day care won final Senate approval over Republican objections. 46 The families of civil rights workers murdered 25 years ago met President Bush, but the session ended on a discordant note for some of them, who said they had hoped for new commitments on social issues. 6 Increasing its pressure on Time Inc., Paramount Communications Inc. raised its takeover offer to $200 a share, or $12 billion, in cash. 31 Nevada executes man for murders of homosexuals 24 Regional 25-28 New York's Federal housing officials repeatedly solicited the people they regulate - builders, housing managers, architects, lawyers, local housing authority directors - for donations to charities, causes and parties. 1 A phasing out of sludge dumping in the Atlantic Ocean has been tentatively agreed upon by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency and New York City and Westchester County. 25 To safeguard Regents examinations, the New York State Education Commissioner said his department would overhaul its security for the tests before they are given in January. 25 High schools run their own graduation parties 25 Dinkins calls for trouble-shooters in failing schools 27 A portable stage for outdoor concerts by the New York Philharmonic and Metropolitan Opera is advancing toward final design, having won a $1.9 million commitment from the New York City Board of Estimate. 27 A neighborhood in lower Manhattan took its first step toward development with the approval of plans for a 38-story waterfront apartment building in the north end of Battery Park City 27 Casinos can be held liable for losses of drunken patrons, a Federal judge in New Jersey has ruled. The Atlantic City casino industry is watching to see whether the decision will set off a deluge of suits. 25 A shortage of discount tokens that has congested toll lanes on the Garden State Parkway is angering motorists already annoyed by a recent 10-cent increase. Resistance has evolved into guerrilla warfare. 26 Motorman found slain on subway platform 27 Officers' ouster by Metro-North called excessive 27

title: Goodbye-Not That You Care
description: LEAD: Sometime this month my colleague Bernard will retire after 32 years of teaching. The next year Arthur, concluding 35 years, will retire. The following year, after 31 years, I plan to retire, and probably my friend Herbie, who helps direct an alternative secondary school, will also retire. Bernard, Arthur and I teach English while Herbie teaches mathematics, but our counterparts can be found teaching every subject in hundrds of schools on every level throughout New York

title: Move by Virginia Coach
description: Terry Holland, who for the last 15 years has coached the University of Virginia men's basketball team, announced yesterday he would become the athletic director at Davidson, his alma mater, effective May 1. Holland will continue to coach the Cavaliers for the 1989-90 season and attempt to improve upon his 306-161 record, the best in Virginia history.

title: Harold Rhoden Is Dead; in Crash at 66
description: Harold Rhoden, a Los Angeles lawyer involved in several sensational lawsuits including the AIDS liability verdict against the estate of Rock Hudson, died Thursday when a light plane he was piloting crashed near Santa Clarita, Calif. He was 66 years old.

title: Donald Dayton, 74, Minneapolis Retailer
description: Donald Chadwick Dayton, a former executive of a Minneapolis department store, died of cancer Thursday at Abbott Northwestern Hospital in Minneapolis. He was 74 years old and lived in Wayzata, Minn.

title: Philharmonic and Met Await an Unusual Stage
description: A striking new portable stage for outdoor concerts by the New York Philharmonic and Metropolitan Opera is advancing toward final design, having won a $1.9 million commitment from the New York City Board of Estimate.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I hope that people who deal with the remains of Indians begin to interact with the descendants of those remains.'' - Rosemary Cambra, representative of the Ohlone tribe. [ 6:4. ]

title: Ruling Due Tomorrow On Hearing for Rose
description: Citing the volume of evidence, an Ohio judge said today that he would rule Sunday on Pete Rose's request for a temporary restraining order to block a hearing on allegations that he bet on baseball. The hearing before the baseball commissioner is scheduled for Monday.

title: Corrections
description: A Company News article by The Associated Press in Business Day yesterday referred incorrectly in some editions to the relationship between a store chain, Sam's Wholesale Club, and Wal-Mart Stores Inc. Sam's is a Wal-Mart division.

title: Retail Group Keeps Chief
description: The directors of the National Retail Merchants Association this week renewed the employment contract of James R. Williams, the association's president, for four years while also deciding to continue talks on a possible merger with the American Retail Federation.

title: Whitney Agrees to Buy Prime for $1.25 Billion
description: J. H. Whitney & Company, which calls itself the nation's oldest venture capital firm, said today that it had agreed to buy Prime Computer Inc. in a friendly merger valued at about $1.25 billion.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 29.

title: Cubs' Streak Ends With Loss to Expos
description: Dave Martinez hit two home runs in a game for the second time in his career, and Hubie Brooks added a two-run homer today as the Montreal Expos beat the Chicago Cubs, 5-1. The loss snapped the Cubs' winning streak at five games.

title: House Democrats Complete Selection of New Leadership
description: House Democrats completed their leadership reshuffling Thursday by electing Representative Vic Fazio of California to the position of vice-chairman of their caucus.

title: Talks Are Urged in Coal Strike
description: Gov. Gaston Caperton today invited the heads of the Pittston Company and the United Mine Workers to the Governor's Mansion to resume negotiations.

title: Dow Climbs by 49.70 On Rate-Drop Hopes
description: The stock market posted its best gain in six weeks yesterday as most major stock indexes moved to post-crash highs. Expectations of lower interest rates and of easing on credit by the Federal Reserve played an important role in the advance, which was dominated by large blue-chip stocks.

title: A Need for Speed on S&L's
description: When Phil Donahue devotes his TV show to a savings and loan rescue bill in Congress, the public must care. The cost of cleaning up this scandal grows steadily more monumental. The official estimate is $150 billion, and that could double.

title: A Vote for Auto Plant Cooperation
description: Representatives of the United Automobile Workers' rank and file have given the union president, Owen F. Bieber, and other top executives strong approval to pursue cooperative programs on the plant floors of the Big Three auto companies.

title: Yosef Yehudai, Jerusalem Police Chief, 42
description: Yosef Yehudai, the police chief of Jerusalem, died of a heart attack today, officials said. He was 42 years old.

title: Britain Under Pressure To Join Monetary Group
description: As Britain faces intense and growing pressure to join the European Monetary System, European leaders hope that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher will use next week's European summit meeting to announce that her nation intends to join the system soon.

title: Headlight Venture By G.E. and Ford
description: The General Electric Company and the Ford Motor Company have joined in a venture to develop arc discharge lamps for cars, like those in street and stadium lights. G.E. officials said headlights using the lamps would blaze with a whiter light, use less electricity and take more abuse than the halogen lights on most cars now. The companies did not say how much they would spend on the development program.

title: Tony Awards Show Loses Its Producers
description: Don Mischer and David Goldberg, the executive producer and producer of the Tony Awards television program for the last three years, have resigned. The announcement of the resignations was made yesterday by the League of American Theaters and Producers and the American Theater Wing, which present the awards and have begun a search for a new producer for the show, which is seen on CBS.

title: No Headline
description: It was a typical graduation for the seniors at Bridgewater-Raritan High School, from the cars they decorated with streamers and shaving cream to the caps and gowns in gold, the school color, that they threw on as they ran toward the gym.

title: Nevada Executes Man in Homosexual Killings
description: Sean Patrick Flanagan, who said he thought he was doing society a service by killing homosexuals, was executed by injection early Friday.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bausch & Lomb Inc., Rochester, an eyewear manufacturer, said it had reached an agreement with Levi Strauss & Co., San Francisco, the clothing manufacturer, to design a line of sunglasses bearing the Levi's name. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Sun, Fun, Sand, Sea - and, Again, Pollution
description: LEAD: Summer is here, and as temperatures rise crowds will again seek relief at New York and New Jersey shores. Will beachgoers find the same pollution that kept them out of the water in the summers of 1987 and 1988?

title: Soviet Star Free to Play
description: Aleksandr Volkov, a star forward on the Soviet national team, said today he had received permission to play in the National Basketball Association and was free to join any team.

title: Dr. Walter Hoover Sr., 91, of Lahey Clinic
description: Dr. Walter B. Hoover Sr., who headed the ear, nose and throat department at the Lahey Clinic in Boston for three decades, died June 17 at Universal Hospital in Plantation, Fla., after a long illness. He was 91 years old.

title: Chinese Hardliners Did the Right Thing
description: LEAD: In a New York Times article dated June 9, Deng Xiaoping was quoted as saying ''A very small number of people created turmoil, and this eventually developed into a counter-revolutionary rebellion. They are trying to overthrow the Communist Party, topple the socialist system and subvert the People's Republic of China so as to establish a capitalist republic.

title: Builder Wins Bid for Condos In Battery Park City Project
description: The first step toward development of a neighborhood in lower Manhattan was taken yesterday with the approval of plans for a 38-story waterfront apartment building in the mostly vacant north end of Battery Park City.

title: Pax Angola, Made in Africa
description: It's far too soon to break out the champagne for a durable peace in Angola. But after 14 years of war, a cease-fire is excellent news. Until three months ago, President Jose Eduardo dos Santos vowed he would never treat with Jonas Savimbi, leader of the Unita rebels. And yet there they were in Zaire, shaking hands at a gathering attended by leaders of 14 African states, building hopes for peace that no leader in shattered Angola can easily ignore, or disappoint.

title: Article 706689 -- No Title
description: Litton Industries disclosed today that it had paid $40 million to settle a dispute with Saudi Arabia's Ministry of Defense involving a contract to supply and install an air defense system.

title: Bridge
description: A situation that W. S. Gilbert would no doubt have described as ''a most ingenious paradox'' occurred during the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship: a major disaster proved to be highly profitable.

title: San Juan Journal; Is Nicaraguan Piggy Bank an Endangered Species?
description: For generations, Nicaraguans have guarded their savings in piggy banks handmade by the potters of this tiny town.

title: Metro Datelines; 83 Arrested in Raids At Massage Parlors
description: Eighty-three people, mostly Korean immigrant women, were arrested during raids on 10 massage parlors in New York City, but they were charged with breaking a state education law, the police said yesterday.

title: Fresh From Victory, Strange Shines Again
description: Curtis Strange would prefer it if pleasant memories of his United States Open victory at Oak Hill on Sunday didn't intrude on his concentration this week as he stands over putts or fairway shots at the Canadian Open.

title: Tyson Bid Is Accepted By Holly
description: After seven months of seesawing, litigious negotiations, Tyson Foods Inc. won its battle for the Holly Farms Corporation today, as Holly Farms' board accepted Tyson's offer of $70 a share, or $1.2 billion in cash.

title: N.Y.U. Dean Drops Out of Mayoral Primary
description: Herbert London, a New York University dean making his first run for political office, dropped out of the race for the Republican nomination for mayor of New York City yesterday.

title: Rates Tumble on Durables Report
description: Interest rates tumbled yesterday as prices of Treasury securities were marked up sharply on news that orders for durable goods dropped 4.2 percent in May. This further indication of a softening economy led many market participants to expect the Federal Reserve to start easing credit.

title: Losing Colors?
description: To the Editor:

title: TALKING: Board Slots; Picking The Right Candidates
description: RESIDENTS of condominiums, cooperatives and homeowner associations often talk about the need to select appropriate and able candidates for their boards of directors, but the skills and qualities board members need are often poorly understood.

title: A New Threat to Museums
description: To the Editor:

title: Libby Wadsworth Becomes a Bride
description: Elizabeth Jane Wadsworth and Paul William Hamilton Peppis, alumni of Williams College who are now graduate students at the University of Chicago, were married yesterday at the Plymouth Church of the Pilgrims in Brooklyn. The Rev. Frank A. Goodwin, a Baptist minister, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Richard L. Stanger, a Congregational minister, officiated.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: CROWN OKLAHOMA. By Jim Lehrer. (Putnam's, $18.95.) This book is a perfect example of why it's dangerous to advertise a novel as humorous. When, exactly, are we supposed to get to the funny parts? In ''Crown Oklahoma,'' Jim Lehrer, of television's ''MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour,'' has written the further adventures of One-Eyed Mack, a character he created in a previous novel called ''Kick the Can.'' In this installment, set in the early 1970's, Mack has grown up to become ''the first one-eyed lieutenant governor in Oklahoma history,'' a joke that is tossed out whenever the going gets slow, which is often. Mack, whose job description is not lengthy, is supposed to watch the television news so he can tell the governor if anything important happens. Sure enough, while Roger Mudd is substituting for the vacationing Walter Cronkite, there's a story about a new crime organization, based in ''a state known for its football.'' The group, dubbed the Okies, is apparently set to battle it out with the Mafia. Tracking both this mysterious organization and Archibald Tyler, the CBS correspondent who keeps making the story juicier, is now Mack's mission. Unfortunately he can't get much help from the governor, whose goal in life is to see that the state Capitol gets a dome. (The novel's title refers to this obsession.) The Okie crime organization scheme is meant to sound farfetched, and Mr. Lehrer uses it to get in his licks about responsibility, and the lack thereof, in television journalism. In doing so, ''Crown Oklahoma'' is good-hearted and inoffensive. Occasionally it's even funny.

title: Naming Rape Victim Is Still A Murky Issue for the Press
description: News organizations' widely observed practice of withholding the names of rape victims is one of modern journalism's few conspiracies of silence.

title: Homosexuals See 2 Decades Of Gains, but Fear Setbacks
description: Twenty years after a police raid on a gay bar in Greenwich Village unleashed the pent-up anger of the homosexual community and started the modern gay-rights movement, homosexual men and lesbians say that laws, court decisions and changing attitudes have helped them move closer to the mainstream of society.

title: Castro Is Anxious About His Military
description: BY the standards of the Cuban Army, Gen. Arnaldo Ochoa Sanchez was the model military man. A veteran of combat in Cuba, Ethiopia, Nicaragua and Angola, where until recently he was supreme commander of Cuban troops, he was decorated for his discipline, sacrifice and honesty. But now, in yet another indication of rising problems for Fidel Castro, General Ochoa is under arrest and scheduled to go on trial today before a special military tribunal.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Work Letters; Dealing With the Costs of Interior Construction
description: WHEN someone rents an apartment, it comes equipped with light fixtures, doors, electrical outlets, interior walls and finished floors. When a company rents office quarters, it gets raw space.

title:
GARDENING;
An Assortment of Tasks for the Summer
description: LEAD: THE arrival of summer brings with it a diversity of gardening tasks that are essential to attaining satisfactory results with the lawn and flower or vegetable gardens.

title: Canizales Retains Bantamweight Title
description: Orlando Canizales retained his International Boxing Federation bantamweight title today when he stopped Kelvin Seabrooks in 47 seconds in the 11th round of a scheduled 12-round bout at Harrah's Marina.

title: WHY MOW?
description: Michael Pollan has much to say about lawns, but he fails to mention Thorstein Veblen, whose social and economic theories included even lawns (''Why Mow?'' May 28). What governs our passion for a scrupulously maintained lawn, according to Veblen, is not the need for beautification, social conformity nor civic responsibility. The governing factor is the law of conspicuous waste. The more useless or futile an object is, the more it is valued. This he calls ''the canon of reputable futility.'' AUGUST FRANZA Moriches, L.I.

title: Keeping Hotels on Their Toes
description: THE Sheraton Stamford Hotel and Towers, on a Monday afternoon, breathed the quiet of a slowly filling hotel. A few people clustered at the front desk, a car or two slithered up outside. The gift shop was deserted, and only a couple of stragglers were dining in the lobby restaurants.

title: Joe Williams, at 70, In Songs of Many Moods
description: Joe Williams possesses a mixture of dignity and vocal command that in an earlier era and in another sphere of music once belonged to Paul Robeson. Mr. Williams, whose 70th birthday was celebrated at Carnegie Hall on Friday, has many sides to his musical personality. He is a blues singer, a band singer and a ballad interpreter. And his a cappella rendition of ''Let My People Go,'' which opened Friday's concert, revealed him to be a powerful, low-keyed interpreter of spirituals as well.

title:
MUSIC;
Symphony Expands Its Scope
description: LEAD: DURING the summer season, the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra has traditionally reached its largest audiences, sometimes playing for 10,000 people at a time. This summer, the orchestra's management is expanding its activities, with several new locations and adding one concert to its already well-established series at the Garden State Arts Center.

title: Time Warner Will Build, Not Extract, Value
description: To the Editor:

title: Historic Haven On an Ontario Isle
description: For the rebels in 1776, an American who sided with George III was reviled in a popular saying as ''a thing whose head is in England, and its body in America, and whose neck ought to be stretched.'' To avoid that fate many of His Majesty's loyal subjects fled to Canada, where they settled large parts of Ontario and the Maritime Provinces.

title: Buddy Bell Retires
description: BUDDY BELL, the Texas Rangers' infielder who made more than 2,500 hits and won six Gold Glove awards in an 18-year major league career, retired yesterday.

title: The Top Choice? Take Your Pick
description: Who will be the first player selected Tuesday night in the National Basketball Association draft? Your guess is as good as anyone's, including those of the general managers and scouts who have spent several months evaluating college talent.

title: HDTV Trap
description: To the Editor:

title: Illegal Irish Find Opportunity and Fear
description: LEAD: A SMALL group of men and women sat around a table in a dimly lighted Italian restaurant in northern Westchester, sipping beer and commiserating about life as illegal aliens. All had come from Ireland within the last few years and their accents were still laced with a brogue.

title: Ruth Omabegho: Jewelry Designer
description: Ruth Omabegho takes African artifacts and antiquities and combines them with natural and industrial discards to create jewelry sold at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, the Royal Academy of Art in London and Saks Fifth Avenue.

title: Labor Takes Heart In the Miners' Walkout
description: IN the 1940's, when John L. Lewis was president of the United Mine Workers, a strike by the militant 500,000-member union could bring the coal producers virtually to their knees. Today, the number of unionized mine workers is only about 65,000, and the power of the union has shrunk considerably as customers have turned to imported coal.

title: Historical Sites Face Aid Strictures
description: TWO historic-preservation organizations in the county have been counting on a total of $550,000 in restoration funds that the state awarded three years ago. But now there is fear that the price may be too high.

title: Movie Boom Is Not Welcome
description: Your report on Hartford's aspirations to attract more film makers to Connecticut is disturbing (''Boom in Movies Brings Profit to Towns and Fame to Neighbors,'' May 21). If Tricia Hood, the coordinator of the Connecticut Film Commission, plans to take issue with homeowners who won't bow to the whims of movie people or with local regulations barring power boats from a beautiful lake, she ought to have her head candled.

title: Restructuring Civil Rights, Restructuring Democracy; Good for Business
description: In Arthur A. Witkin's letter on June 25 discussing the Supreme Court decision on affirmative action in the job market, the last paragraph should have begun, ''The Court has now lighened this burden on the employer.''

title: Joel Morse Wed To Susan Miller
description: Susan Erica Miller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Miller of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Joel Harrison Morse, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Morse of Wilmot, N.H., were married last evening in the Pegasus Suite of the R.C.A. Building in New York. Rabbi David Posner officiated.

title: Soviets, at Rights Parley, Assail Rumanian Fence
description: In its first public criticism of an Eastern European ally at a four-week conference on human rights, the Soviet Union has condemned Rumania for building a barbed-wire fence along its border with Hungary.

title: Grandpa Lenin and the Sharp-Eyed Prudes
description: GROWING UP IN MOSCOW Memories of a Soviet Girlhood. By Cathy Young. Illustrated. 334 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $18.95.

title: Nets Get Bowie for Buck Williams
description: After months of speculation, the Nets have finally traded Buck Williams. And in the process, they have taken a major gamble.

title: Patriotism On the Bronx Front In the Korean War
description: ON June 25, 1950, the armed forces of communist North Korea, led by about 100 Russian-made tanks, crossed the 38th parallel in a massive surprise attack on South Korea.

title: Patricia Morrison Is Wed to Banker
description: Patricia Jane Morrison, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert J. Morrison of Harrisburg, Pa., and Abraham B. Mintz, the son of Rabbi and Mrs. Charles Mintz of Harrisburg, were married last evening at the home of the bride's parents. The bridegroom's father officiated.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 6 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the Group Theater gives an incorrect founding date for the Mirror Repertory Theater and misidentifies its founder. The group was started in 1983 by Sabra Jones with John Strasberg, Eva Le Gallienne and Geraldine Page.

title: Sophie Carpenter Wed in Washington
description: At the Washington Cathedral, Sophie Carre Carpenter, a daughter of Bowie Robertson Carpenter and Chapin Carpenter Jr., both of Washington, was married yesterday to Russell Frazier Speidel 2d, a son of Mrs. Edward Hake and Russell J. Speidel, both of Cincinnati. The Episcopal Bishop of Washington, John T. Walker, officiated.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE HUNGER FOR MORE: Searching for Values in an Age of Greed. By Laurence Shames. (Times Books, $18.95.) ''Among democratic nations, ambition is ardent and continual, but its aim is not habitually lofty; and life is generally spent in eagerly coveting small objects.'' Toqueville's observation was written more than 150 years ago, but it still applies today, Laurence Shames asserts in his suggestive study of contemporary American mores, ''The Hunger for More.'' Mr. Shames, the author of ''The Big Time: The Harvard Business School's Most Successful Class and How It Shaped America'' and a former columnist on ethics for Esquire, chronicles the social and economic forces that gave rise to the yuppies and the materialistic fast-track America of the 1980's. He begins by placing the current decade's fixation on glitz and money in the broader context of the United States' centuries-old romance with business success. But the love affair of the 1980's, Mr. Shames argues, is based on an assumption that no longer holds: that the economic boom would last forever. This new reality was brought home with a shock by the stock-market crash on Oct. 19, 1987, an event that Mr. Shames believes helped many to realize the emptiness of careerist values. The author is at his most persuasive when analyzing what he calls the ''war between life and lifestyle'' - the tendency to confuse style with substance, a fashionable surface with authentic feeling. His critique is on the mark, but unfortunately he tends to be overly abstract and facile. The single case history he uses to tie his book together, however - the Colliers, a dual-career couple on Manhattan's Upper West Side who realize that they must change their lives - makes concrete, compelling argument in itself.

title: Paying Now to Save Later on Mortgages
description: EVER since Brian J. Fifelski discovered last year that he could save thousands of dollars on his mortgage by adding a few dollars to each monthly payment, he has been ''telling everyone in sight'' about accelerated loan payoffs.

title: Bronislava Nijinska's Choreographic Gems Are Remounted
description: LEAD: IN 1923, THE BALLETS RUSSES impresario Sergei Diaghilev pleaded with Igor Stravinsky: ''Let her finish. Perhaps we'll be understood 50 years from now.'' He was speaking of the Russian choreographer Bronislava Nijinska and the creation of ''Les Noces'' (''The Wedding''), a ballet that many argue is one of this century's greatest dance masterpieces.

title: The Start of Gay Pride Weekend Is Marked With Demonstrations
description: LEAD: More than 1,500 people marched without a police permit from Greenwich Village to Central Park for a rally yesterday afternoon marking the 20th anniversary of a riot credited with beginning the modern gay-rights movement in New York City.

title: The Asian Fleets That Strip the Sea
description: IN southeast Alaska, where many villages are kept alive by the annual return of hordes of Pacific salmon, nearly 40 million were expected last year. But barely a fourth of that number went back there to spawn.

title: An Omission By Chang
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: What Makes a Violin Sing? Two Makers, Two Views
description: LEAD: SINCE the 16th century, when Andrea Amati founded the Cremona school of violin making in Italy, the violin's mystique has been nearly as compelling as its music.

title:
