WESTCHESTER Q&A;: GENE A. ROBBINS;
Teaching the Lessons of Little League
description: LEAD: IT started 50 years ago in Williamsport, Pa. Today, it involves about 2.5 million children in 33 countries. It is Little League Baseball, a program of regularly scheduled baseball games for children, mainly boys, ages 8 to 15.

title: At Mamaroneck 'Cafe,' it's Anyone For Chess
description: LEAD: CHESS, anyone?

title: Alphabet Soup OTB Style
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Stars Come Out for 'Twelfth Night'
description: ''This is very midsummer madness.'' - ''Twelfth Night,'' Act III, Scene 4

title: Culture Czar: Not a Good Idea
description: To The Editor:

title: Seafood, With Views of the Sound
description: A SUMMER-LONG question in Connecticut is not just where one can find good seafood, but where can one find it along the shore. The short answer to both questions is the Wharf. This simple, but attractive shore-side restuarant, ensconced in the Madison Beach Hotel in Madison, is as close to the shoreline as a building can be without being swept away. Located at the end of a road leading to the Madison beach, the two-story fram building is separated from the water by a mere sand dune or two.

title: Arafat Is Said to Be Ready for P.L.O.-Israeli Talks
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has told visitors at his headquarters in Tunis that he is ready to accept the latest United States proposal for negotiations between Palestinians and Israelis, according to diplomats and P.L.O. officials here.

title: Marx Set In on Rehearsals
description: LEAD: STORMY APPLAUSE Making Music in a Worker's State. By Rostislav Dubinsky. 292 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $22.95.

title: Baryshnikov's Exit
description: Striking a balance can be difficult even for Mikhail Baryshnikov. After a decade as artistic director of the American Ballet Theater and acting roles in films, on television and in a play, ''Metamorphosis,'' in which he is now appearing on Broadway, Mr. Baryshnikov said last week that he will be making a transformation himself, stepping down from the ballet company to pursue other options. The 41-year-old ballet star, who has had three knee operations, has rarely danced in recent seasons but will remain as head of the company through its 50th anniversary season, which runs through July 1990. At a meeting with the dancers, a participant reported that Mr. Baryshnikov ''was facing a lot of questions about his life and himself as a human being and that originally he had planned to 'die' in his current position.''

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
A 'Golden-Age' Zone Project for Seaford
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION is scheduled to begin next fall on a 71-unit condominium in Seaford, the first project approved under a ''golden-age'' zone classification designed to provide affordable housing for older residents of the Town of Hempstead.

title: A Band That Gave An Age of Excess A Good Name
description: THE FILLMORE EAST, A DILAPIdated old vaudeville theater on New York's Lower East Side, was host to more than its share of unforgettable rock-and-roll shows during its heyday in the late 60's and early 70's. The promoter, Bill Graham, usually herded soon-to-be-legendary bands on and off the stage with an almost military punctuality, but when the Allman Brothers Band was performing, even Mr. Graham stopped watching the clock. When the Allmans really felt like playing (and they usually did), he would often announce that he was locking the doors of the auditorium, and that anyone who had to leave should do so. Then the Allmans would play on through the night - and often into the morning.

title: Is Weetzie Bat a Good Role Model?
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE SURVIVOR. By Fritz J. Raddatz. Translated by Ralph Manheim. (Little, Brown, $15.95.) This dark, nightmarish novella - the first work of fiction by the editor of the German weekly Die Zeit - concerns a young German boy, his developing appetites and above all his fierce will to survive during the two terrible decades before, during and just after World War II.

title: Should Ben Johnson Be Allowed to Run Again?
description: We all make mistakes as we go through life. We all, too, need to be forgiven for our mistakes. The problem here rests in the fact that Mr. Johnson, once he had commenced taking steroids, continued playing by his own rules FOR YEARS. Then he tacitly lied to his followers, fans, family, by accepting the Olympic gold medal, and finally, with the opportunity at hand, still refused to be man enough, sportsman enough, to confess his faults. He continued in the error of his ways, thereby compounding the error.

title: Digging Out From the Savings Crisis
description: THANKS to the savings and loan crisis, the Government will soon have hundreds of billions of dollars of real estate on its hands. It will be a vast portfolio, including everything from ''see through'' office buildings - so named because tenants have never rented space - to vast residential tracts, shopping centers, raw land and, as it turns out, even a few brothels. And just how to dispose of these assets, and at the lowest cost to taxpayers, is now a critical issue confronting Washington policy makers.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: GLORY DAYS. By Rosie Scott. (Seal Press, Paper, $8.95.) ''I am always the first to admit that my life has been fairly sordid,'' says Glory Day, a hugely fat and boisterous character who is not normally given to such understatement. A woman of substance as well as girth, this big-hearted earth mother knocks us off our pins in Rosie Scott's ''Glory Days,'' a novel from New Zealand that's the latest addition to the International Women's Crime series recently inaugurated by Seal Press.

title: Writin' Is Fightin'
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The exterior of our 30-year-old house is covered with cedar shakes. They have never been stained or cleaned, and now are in shades ranging from dark brown to black. Painters have recommended everything from power washing, stain and paint to a clear preservative. What do you advise?

title: Susan Zilenziger Is Married in Rye
description: At the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church, Susan Rebecca Zilenziger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rodman Jay Zilenziger of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard Kevin Maier, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Maier of Harrison, N.Y. The Rev. Nancy R. Hutchison officiated, assisted by the Rev. Robert S. MacLennan.

title: Time for Second Thoughts
description: To the Editor:

title: A Legal Uproar Over Dimples and Grooves
description: ''Golf is a game about suffering and despair, interspersed with glimmers of hope,'' opined Frank Hannigan, a contributing editor of Golf Magazine and former president of the United States Golf Association. ''It can be alleviated by going into a store and buying something.''

title: In the Garden of Linnaeus
description: THE great gardens of the world - the Tivolis, Bellingraths and Sissinghursts - have flourished in latitudes blessed with a genial sun. Yet a mere 6 degrees below the Arctic Circle, where the thin winter sun visits for 6 hours out of 24, is the small and tidy plot of Karl von Linne, known to the botanical world as Carolus Linnaeus.

title: A Drama About Apartheid Brings Its Author Home
description: THE SOUTH AFRICAN PLAY-wright Athol Fugard says his latest appointment with himself was made when he came across a brief newspaper article about a black schoolteacher killed during racial unrest near the Indian Ocean city of Port Elizabeth.

title: Down to Trenches in City-by-a-Spill
description: When the first foul air from the oil spill off Brenton Reef began permeating Newport Friday night, Elizabeth de Ramel put the parakeet into the basement, thinking it would be safer there.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. DIANE SHRIER;
Seeking Answers to Acts of Violence
description: LEAD: DR. DIANE SHRIER has been diagnosing, treating and researching the psychiatric problems of children, adolescents and young adults for 20 years. She is a clinical professor of psychiatry and director of the division of child and adolescent psychiatry at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in

title: Cuban General on Trial Today for Drugs
description: The Cuban Government announced today that Gen. Arnaldo Ochoa Sanchez, an army officer accused of drug trafficking, will be put on trial on Sunday by a special military tribunal composed of 47 generals and admirals.

title: Man Meets Boat Meets Hurricane
description: SPARTINA By John Casey. 375 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: 61-Story Rental Tower Rising
description: A 61-STORY rental apartment tower is under construction as the latest project in Chicago's ambitious mixed-use Cityfront Center development.

title: NIXON LAUDS BUSH FOR CHINA POLICY
description: Richard M. Nixon has praised President Bush's ''measured response'' to the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing, urging the White House to stand firm against ''a strange coalition of China-bashers'' who want harsh American action.

title: Kerry McDermott Wed in Connecticut
description: At the First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, Conn., Kerry Murphy McDermott and William Matthew Holmes, associates at Marigold Enterprises, a financial advisory and management consulting firm in Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday by the Rev. Dean Ahlberg.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-17 Zhao Ziyang was dismissed from all his posts by the Chinese Communist Party, which named a new set of leaders who are likely to favor somewhat new directions in China's economic and political development. Page 1

title: Rose Linked Again To Bets
description: Two men named as witnesses in the Pete Rose investigation yesterday told of their knowledge of times that Rose bet on baseball games, including Cincinnati Reds games.

title: Elegant Chinese That Looks the Part
description: CHINESE food lovers feel strongly about their favorite restaurants. Ask any of them, and they will, without urging, recommend what is absolutely, positively Long Island's best Chinese restaurant. Great Neck's Chopsticks is often mentioned in such discussions. It's no wonder. Chopsticks certainly looks the part. Situated below ground, its entrance avoids any cavelike feeling by bringing nature indoors. A flagstone wall complete with tricking waterfall and a greenhouse array of plants greet diners.

title: The Future Has Arrived For Bioethics, and It's a Profession Now
description: ONCE a novel and somewhat suspect effort to examine the ethical problems arising from advances in biology and medicine, bioethics no longer carries a faint tinge of science fiction. It is now a well-established field with scholarly journals, endowed professorships and government commissions. Leading figures in bioethics have even begun to ask whether the field has become too well established.

title: WHY MOW?
description: I used to tell my students at the University of Akron, ''Some idiots play golf, other idiots mow grass!'' (I just finished mowing.) Possibly, one theory for mowing is that our Ohio pioneering ancestors cleaned around their cabins to have a better shot at marauders. EUGENE M. BENEDICT Peninsula, Ohio

title: For Pop, Comedy May Be The Sincerest Form of Flattery
description: TODAY'S POP MUSIC CUL-ture tends to take itself so seriously that almost any comic deflation of pop grandiosity and pretension is welcome. What does it mean to grow up in a society where Elvis imitators inspire reverence rather than laughter, Bruce Springsteen's lyrics are accepted as oracles and changes in Michael Jackson's and Madonna's wardrobes and hair styles are read as maps to our cultural psyche? Although the contemplation of such questions offers wonderful opportunities for satire, the response of most popular comedians to rock-and-roll idolatry has tended to be more respectful than cutting.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''He knew he had pulled a major blunder.'' - Gov. Edward D. DiPrete of Rhode Island, on captain of grounded tanker. [ 23A:2. ]

title: Soviet Union
description: To the Editor: My husband's and my experiences on three recent trips to various parts of the Soviet Union differ greatly from the complaints of Betty Tyler of Monroe, Conn. (Letters on Travel, April 2). On one trip to Leningrad, my husband and I purchased taxi chits one morning from a young woman stationed near the front entrance of Hotel Pribaltiskaya and were escorted by her to a waiting cab. She instructed the driver as to our destination, the Hermitage Art Museum, where we spent several hours, having the third floor (French Impressionist and post-Impressionist paintings) almost entirely to ourselves. Throughout the Soviet Union we have found attendants at cloak check rooms (a Soviet custom to avoid having heavy coats take up needed seat space at performances or restaurants) to be kind and helpful, especially to foreigners. One evening in Kiev's concert hall, following a piano concert by a superb recent participant in the Tschaikowsky competition, my husband and I, evidently the only foreigners attending the performance, lined up with the Ukrainians to get our coats. We were near the end of a long line when an attendant behind the cloak room counter began beckoning vigorously to us. People ahead of us turned around and explained that she wanted us to come up and be served first. We demurred and replied that we would wait our turn; but everyone insisted, saying, ''You are our guests.''

title: How H.U.D. Helped Many Make Money From Poverty
description: IN the late 1960's, when Watts, Detroit and Newark were exploding in riots, the Johnson Administration created the Department of Housing and Urban Development to provide poorly housed residents of decaying cities with a Cabinet-level advocate like that enjoyed by farmers, for example, through the Department of Agriculture.

title: Excerpt From Statement on Zhao's Dismissal
description: Following is an excerpt from the official statement today on the ouster of General Secretary Zhao Ziyang, as issued in translation by the Communist Party Standing Committee:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: JAMES BALDWIN: Artist on Fire. By W. J. Weatherby. (Fine, $19.95.) For nearly two decades, beginning in the 1950's, James Baldwin was one of America's leading writers. An accomplished novelist and relentless traveler, he was best known for works of essay-reportage - such as ''The Fire Next Time,'' first published in 1962 in The New Yorker - that explored black sensibilities in the civil rights movement, with a strong commitment to interracial harmony. W. J. Weatherby has written a moving account of Baldwin's life, especially the early years. Mr. Weatherby, a correspondent for The Manchester Guardian in New York, knew Baldwin for many years and interviewed him often, along with writers, activists, editors and others of his friends. The book suffers from excessive focus on the author-as-personality, with little analysis of Baldwin's writing. Footnotes are minimal; there is no bibliography. In his prime, James Baldwin was a magnificent writer; his later books proved a disappointment. By Mr. Weatherby's lights, that decline was the price of celebrity. At the end, Mr. Weatherby writes: ''A life was a journey, [ Baldwin ] was fond of saying, and you had to pay the price of the ticket. . . . What an incredible journey it had been.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: THE ENIGMATIC EYE. By Moacyr Scliar. Translated by Eloah F. Giacomelli. (Available Press/Ballantine Books, Paper, $5.95.) The terms ''fantastical'' and ''magical realism'' are loosely used today, and critics have applied both to the work of Moacyr Scliar. But if this delightful Brazilian fabulist can be assigned to the tradition immortalized by Gabriel Garcia Marquez, then so can Franz Kafka and Lewis Carroll.

title: Court vs. Family: Homeowners Lose
description: WORKING and middle-class people have long been stoical about the lack of consideration they receive from various levels of government.

title: Traffic Alert
description: The Lesbian and Gay Pride March today starts at 12:30 P.M. at Columbus Circle and heads east on 59th Street to Fifth Avenue, then south to Washington Square North and west through Greenwich Village, ending at Sheridan Square. It is expected to last at least three hours.

title: Koch Acts Like Himself, And Voters Are Tired of It
description: CRIME, crack, too few police officers, too many homeless people. In a city crowded with issues, many people believe the issue in this year's mayoral election is Mayor Edward I. Koch, as it has been, really, in most of his recent campaigns.

title: 'Guilty' Is on Jury Blackboard
description: Jurors considering murder charges against a United States marine say they can still reach a fair verdict after they entered the deliberation room Friday morning and found the word ''guilty'' scrawled on a blackboard. The word was accidentally left behind by a prosecutor on Thursday. Jurors will begin deliberations Monday in the case of Craig Toczko, 22 years old, who is charged with murder and conspiracy to commit murder in the shooting death of Mark Barnett, 29, in a New Britain shopping center on Dec. 27, 1987.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE SALONIKA BAY MURDER: Cold War Politics and the Polk Affair. By Edmund Keeley. (Princeton University, $24.95.) In May 1948, the CBS correspondent George Polk arrived in Salonika, Greece, and quickly made it known to journalists and diplomats around the city that he wanted to interview the leader of the Communist guerrillas encamped in the mountainous north.

title: Support Groups Aid Baldness Sufferers
description: LEAD: WHEN their hair starts falling out in patches, leaving round bald spots on their scalps, most men, women and children suffering from alopecia areata have never heard of their disorder.

title: The Mulvihill Perplexity
description: WHEN I WAS taught to write a business letter,'' wrote Jane Mulvihill of Sag Harbor, N.Y., ''the proper salutation, unless one knew the name of an individual to be addressed, was >Gentlemen. What do we do now? >Ladies and/or Gentlemen? . . . I need some advice.''

title: Corrections
description: A map in the Long Island Weekly last Sunday with a ''Talk of Sag Harbor'' article misplaced the Sag Harbor transfer station. It is on the east side of the Bridgehampton-Sag Harbor Turnpike, not the east side of Route 114.

title: Miss Kingsbury Is Wed on L.I.
description: The marriage of Heather Snow Kingsbury, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Kingsbury of Brooklyn and Point O' Woods, L.I., to William Newton West, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. West of Shaker Heights, Ohio, took place yesterday at the Church at Point O' Woods. The Rev. Dr. William A. McCartney, a Methodist minister, officiated. Mrs. West, a graduate of Yale University, was until recently a financial analyst with Kidder, Peabody & Company in New York. Her father is an executive vice president at Legg Mason Wood Walker, members of the New York Stock Exchange, and the chairman of Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn.

title: The Man Who Loved Ayn Rand
description: JUDGMENT DAY My Years With Ayn Rand. By Nathaniel Branden. Illustrated. 436 pp. Boston: A Marc Jaffe Book/ Houghton Mifflin Company. $21.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The exterior of our 30-year-old house is covered with cedar shakes. They have never been stained or cleaned, and now are in shades ranging from dark brown to black. Painters have recommended everything from power washing, stain and paint to a clear preservative. What do you advise?

title: Perilous Tribalism in the Balkans
description: Today and every day, some 2,000 refugees stream out of Bulgaria and across the Turkish border - 52,000 men, women, and children since last month. That's when the Bulgarian Government began expelling its own citizens of Turkish descent, whose forebears lived in Bulgaria for generations.

title: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical BARBER: CELLO CONCERTO; BRITTEN: CELLO SYMPHONY - Yo-Yo Ma, cello; Baltimore Symphony conducted by David Zinman. Mr. Ma's masterful playing, with exemplary orchestral support, makes this release of two important but seldom heard 20th-century works irresistible. (Paul Turok) CBS Masterworks MK 44900; CD and cassette. BARBER: ORCHESTRAL WORKS - St. Louis Symphony conducted by Leonard Slatkin. The ''School for Scandal'' Overture, the Adagio for Strings, Three Essays for Orchestra and ''Medea's Dance of Vengeance'' - established American classics in superbly disciplined yet fiery performances. (Andrew L. Pincus) EMI 49463; CD and cassette. BARBER, HARBISON, MENOTTI, STRAVINSKY: VOCAL WORKS - Dawn Upshaw, soprano; Orchestra of St. Luke's conducted by David Zinman. Barber's ''Knoxville: Summer of 1915'' and other works in performances that shine with the wizardry of technique and imagination. (Pincus) Nonesuch 79187. BARTOK: CONCERTO FOR ORCHESTRA; JANACEK: SINFONIETTA - Los Angeles Philharmonic conducted by Andre Previn. A probing, exciting, brilliantly played and recorded version of Bartok's popular orchestral showpiece. (Turok) Telarc CD-80174; CD only. HAVERGAL BRIAN: SYMPHONY NO. 3 - BBC Symphony Orchestra conducted by Lionel Friend. A monumentally conceived work, Mahlerian in scope, Elgarian in sound. A powerful performance superbly recorded. (Turok) Hyperion CDA66334; CD only. STEVE REICH: ''DIFFERENT TRAINS'' - Kronos Quartet. A work of astonishing originality that, with speech tape loops and music, contrasts the composer's American boyhood with the Holocaust, resulting in an experience of harrowing impact. (K. Robert Schwarz) Nonesuch 79176. WUORINEN: PIANO CONCERTO NO. 3 - Garrick Ohlsson, piano; San Francisco Symphony conducted by Herbert Blomstedt. A spectacular performance. The pianist tosses off irregular rhythms and note patterns with such panache that the momentum becomes irresistible. (Pincus) Nonesuch 79185-2; CD only. Pop/Jazz FRED ASTAIRE: ''THE FRED ASTAIRE STORY'' - Dating from December 1952, Mr. Astaire's two finest hours as a recording artist - one of his major accomplishments. (Will Friedwald) Polygram Verve 835 649-2; two CD's only. JACKSON BROWNE: ''WORLD IN MOTION'' - In Mr. Browne's most compel-ling album since ''The Pretender,'' his leftist rhetoric and romantic folk-rock finally blend in a high-minded vision of human possibility shaded by deep alarm. (Stephen Holden) Elektra 60830. DARLING BUDS: ''POP SAID . . .'' - In most of these songs from one of Britain's new guitar-charged, pop-centered girl groups, the singer lives for romance and awaits absent boyfriends' whims. As the guitars surge and the catchy choruses pile up, they supply unrepentant pop pleasure. (Jon Pareles) Columbia 45208. BILL FRISELL: ''BEFORE WE WERE BORN'' - While he has worked with jazz's structural experimenters, Bill Frisell's albums have been relatively conventional - until now; his best album so far. (Pareles) Elektra-Musician 60843. PAUL MCCARTNEY: ''FLOWERS IN THE DIRT'' - In his most appealing, well-crafted record since his 1973 ''Band on the Run,'' Mr. McCartney seems to have found a sense of direction only fleetingly evident in his recent work. (Allan Kozinn) Capitol 91653. BUSTER POINDEXTER: ''BUSTER GOES BERSERK'' - No rock-and-roller generates a more infectious sense of fun. On his second album the best cuts suggest scenes from a wild party where the host is the rambunctious, half-pickled singer, who has immersed himself in the persona of a funky soul man. The soul standards are uproarious turns full of personality. (Holden) RCA 9660. LOUDON WAINWRIGHT 3D: ''THERAPY'' - Over 20 years Mr. Wainwright has accumulated a body of brutally frank comic songs that has almost become a folk genre unto itself. Recently the humor has darkened, and beneath the smart-aleck tone one senses a profound bemusement. Much of the writing is first-rate, and the confessions cut more deeply than ever. (Holden) Silvertone 1203.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: University of California at Davis; School Struggles to Preserve Festival After Melee
description: With five people hospitalized and six others arrested after a melee at a recent festival celebrating black culture, administrators at the University of California at Davis are wrestling with the problem of how to save the popular event that has served as an image-maker in the school's efforts to attract more minority students.

title: The Bush Team Has Competing Ideas on Competing With Japan
description: THE Bush Administration is locked in a debate over how to strengthen American high-technology industries to meet the challenge from Japan.

title: Nancy Wilson to Open New Hampshire Festival
description: The newest addition to the calendar of summer performing-arts series in the northeastern United States is the Waterville Valley Bridge Jazz 'n' Clazz music festival, which begins its first season on Friday in Waterville Valley, N.H. It will run through Labor Day weekend.

title: Halt Arms to Beirut Christians, U.S. Urges Iraq
description: In an effort to stabilize a shaky cease-fire in Beirut, the United States has asked Iraq to stop supplying weapons to Christian forces in Lebanon, Arab diplomats say.

title: Natural Result Of 2 Bad Trades
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: When America Took a Big Step
description: AMERICA LEADS THE WORLD IN celebrating ephemeral events. The return of swallows to Capistrano and the emergence or nonemergence of a groundhog at Punxsutawney are faithfully documented each spring by press and television. The birthday of Elvis is occasion for dancing in the streets. Once a year, a grateful nation pauses to mark National Pickle Week. With so many significant dates to remember, it is hardly any wonder that a few may slip between the cracks.

title: Fort Dix Awaiting New Orders
description: LEAD: THIS 71-year-old Army post, where thousands of soldiers have learned to march, shoot, crawl and salute, is waiting for its new orders with the hope that current uncertainty will yield to long-term stability.

title: SLIPPER CHAIRS
description: The very idea of a slipper chair stirs the imagination. It conjures up a romantic setting of an 18th-century boudoir where a beautiful woman, wearing a skirt as layered and swagged as an elaborate curtain, sits on a small chair by the fire. Kneeling at her feet is her maid, helping her put on a pair of silk slippers. The chair is perhaps the least noticeable part of the scene, yet its compact design - the short legs, high back, armless body and soft upholstery - has made it a useful object that has endured for generations.

title: A Peek at the Undergarments and Fashions of the Victorian Era
description: LEAD: IN the prim and proper Victorian era, women wore lots of underpinnings, in contrast to today's more casual minimalism.

title: Should Ben Johnson Be Allowed to Run Again?
description: Athletes who abuse cocaine, an illegal substance on and off the field, are rehabilitated and welcomed back to their sports after their problems become known. But after abusing steroids, Ben Johnson may be banned from his sport for life. Sure, steroids give athletes an unfair advantage, but the fact that they're not illegal across the board can confuse seemingly naive athletes like Johnson. Especially when his own coach and a ''respected'' doctor eagerly promote his use of them. No coach gave Dwight Gooden the go-ahead on using cocaine, but he got a second chance. Why shouldn't Johnson get another chance, too? ED DECKER Purdys, N.Y.

title: Seaway Completes Its Plans On Handling of Major Spills
description: Saying that a quick response is the key to containing a major oil or chemical spill, the Saint Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation has written a new emergency plan for coping with accidents on the seaway between Montreal and Lake Ontario.

title: Perusing the Independent Booksellers
description: DESPITE steadily shrinking profit margins, there are still independent bookstores in the county where special orders, unusual titles and an ongoing literary dialogue are the rule rather than the exception.

title: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest: GOING UP! A Color Counting Book. Written and illustrated by Peter Sis. Greenwillow. $11.95. (Ages 3 to 6) A little girl named Mary, who is shown in sunny colors against a black-and-white background, gets on an elevator carrying flowers. As the elevator goes up, on each floor remarkable people, each in distinctive colors, join her. The whole crowd gets off on the 12th floor for a surprise birthday party for Mary's mother. THE PRESIDENT BUILDS A HOUSE. By Tom Shachtman. Photographs by Margaret Miller. Simon & Schuster. $14.95. (Ages 5 to 9) A well-organized photo essay shows how volunteers from the Habitat for Humanity organization, including former President Jimmy Carter and his wife, built 20 houses in Atlanta in one week during the summer of 1988. The short text gives the history of the group and its goals. SPLINTERS. A Book of Very Short Poems. Collected by Michael Harrison. Illustrated by Sue Heap. Oxford University. $10.95. (Ages 5 and up) The authors represented in this eclectic collection of very brief but topically diverse poems range from Ogden Nash to Osip Mandelstam.

title: A U.S. Soldier Who Defected Is Given 30 Years for Spying
description: A military court today sentenced an American soldier who disappeared into East Germany four months ago to 30 years in prison for espionage, a military spokesman said.

title: Social Security Chief Leaving
description: Dorcas R. Hardy is resigning as head of the Social Security Administration, a move that was expected. The Commissioner, whose three years as head of the Social Security agency were marked by disputed efforts to streamline it, told President Bush in a letter that her office made public Friday that she would step down July 31. The Administration's nominee to succeed her is expected to be Gwendolyn King, deputy assistant to the President.

title: Jericho Turnpike Project Questioned
description: A PLAN by the State Department of Transportation to widen Jericho Turnpike between Routes 106 and 107 and the Seaford-Oyster Bay Expressway has aroused varied concerns among residents and business owners in Jericho, Muttontown, Syosset and Woodbury, through which the section of the turnpike passes.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: HARVEST AND FROLIC

title: At Longwood Gallery, 20 ArtistsTraverse Culture and Literacy
description: THE current Longwood Arts Gallery production, an exhibition about literacy, could have used a spot more literacy itself. Its news release says, among other things, that ''the act of reading is either repressed or encouraged in subtle and not so subtle ways throughout our social fabric.''

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: AFTER 11 years, the Edison Papers project at Rutgers University has just produced ''The Papers of Thomas A. Edison: Volume I, The Making of an Inventor, February 1847-June 1873.'' It is the first of a projected series of 15 to 20 volumes to be drawn from three and a half million pages of Edison's records.

title: Yellowstone's New Drama
description: LESS than three miles inside the western boundary of Yellowstone National Park, just past the entrance station where the rangers now hand out brochures with the greeting ''Welcome to the New Yellowstone,'' the line of traffic winding into the park abruptly begins to slow. Up ahead, cars and campers are easing to the shoulder of the road.

title: Fillmore East
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: OTTO THE MAGNIFICENT: The Life of Otto Kahn. By John Kobler. (Scribners, $24.95.) Otto Kahn was a man of contradictions. He rivaled J. P. Morgan as a member of the robber baron set, yet he was called the only ''millionaire with a soul'' by the Communist editor of The New Masses. He was a Republican yet held some views that were considered socialist by many of his peers.

title: Their Best Years Were a Waste
description: LEAD: WHAT DID YOU DO IN THE WAR, DADDY? Growing Up German. By Sabine Reichel. 214 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $17.95.

title: The Fascination Of Horse Racing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; With the Omelets and Salads, Dazzling Decor
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Connecticut, Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester sections of The New York Times. Ratings at the end of each item - satisfactory, good, very good, excellent and extraordinary - are followed by the date of original publication. Carijon's Middleville Inn

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
A Combination Condo/Hotel
description: LEAD: FOR more than 16 years, the shell of an abandoned, unfinished, sawtoothed 33-story building was a blight on Rittenhouse Square, one of William Penn's five original city squares.

title: Hardware Hill
description: AS ANYONE WHO HAS TRIED TO keep up with the rapid evolution of computer technology is aware, the detritus of the information age is beginning to pile up. This is most literally true at the Katsu Ichikawa Company, a salvage operation devoted wholly to computers. It has more than 3,000 tons of discarded hardware resting on a half-acre site, 140 miles southwest of Tokyo, just outside of Toyota City. (The city, formerly known as Koromo, was renamed in 1959 for the Japanese automaking giant whose headquarters are there.) Mr. Ichikawa, above, began his business seven years ago, with his wife, and now employs 14 people. Through contracts with computer-leasing companies and affiliates of computer manufacturers, he buys used or out-of-date computer systems from companies in the process of upgrading. His company then picks up the old systems (deducting his removal charge from the price he pays), and resells chips and other parts to computer-maintenance companies, and old PC's and word processors to collectors. ''Avoiding serious damage to the useful parts, we can clean up a computer room quickly,'' Mr. Ichikawa told The Times's Tokyo bureau, often within three hours.

title: Driving Together
description: A NEW partnership announced at the Portland (Ore.) International Speedway yesterday has Bobby Rahal and Al Unser Jr. becoming teammates in 1990 and gives Rahal, a two-time CART-PPG Indy car champion, use of the Chevrolet V-8 engine for the first time.

title: A Display Full Of Surprises
description: THERE are surprises in the crafts at the Sheila Nussbaum Gallery here. A triangular back of one chair becomes a man's profile; the nose is there, a slight all-knowing smile and a round staring eye that might be inset or a knot in the wood.

title: More British Than Not
description: To the Editor:

title: DATA BANK: June 25, 1989
Handicap Favorites Prove Their Ranks
description: Cryptoclearance, Private Terms and Dancing Spree all justified their roles as betting favorites by scoring significant victories in different Grade II handicap races around the country yesterday.

title: WHY MOW?
description: Frederick Law Olmsted did not enshrine the lawn for Americans. The credit belongs to Andrew Jackson Downing, who preached the lawn gospel in his highly successful books. Probably the best example of his landscape work is the oval directly south of the White House. It was one of several small parks (collectively known as the President's Park) that he designed in the early 1850's.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Security Alert For Frankfurt

title: 'Longtime Companion' Takes an Unflinching Look at AIDS
description: LEAD: ANY FILM MAKER WILL tell you his project has special meaning for him. ''I really believe in this,'' he will declare in earnest.

title: For the Palestinians, Washington Is Losing Promise as a Peacemaker
description: IN recent weeks, the two continuing dialogues in the Middle East - one a dialogue of words between the United States and the Palestine Liberation Organization and the other a dialogue of deeds between Israeli Jews and Palestinian Arabs - have reached critical junctures. The question is which one is more likely to shape the future of the Palestinian-Israeli conflict.

title: FOCUS: From Strip Mine to Game Preserve in Southern Ohio; Zoo Consortium Using 9,000 Acres Donated by Utility
description: Eight zoos are turning 9,000 acres of reclaimed strip-mine land in Muskingum County in southeastern Ohio into a preserve for African animals.

title: Nancy Ann Toher Marries Thomas A. Hawkins
description: At the chapel of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Dominic in Oyster Bay, L.I., Nancy Ann Toher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Toher of Upper Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas Andrew Hawkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Hawkins 2d of Glen Cove, L.I. Msgr. James E. Collins performed the ceremony. The bride, a graduate of the Green Vale School and Friends Academy in Locust Valley, L.I., and Dickinson College, is a broker at Fulton Prebon USA Inc., a money-market brokerage in New York.

title: No Headline
description: LEAD: EDGAR TAFEL does not consider architecture art. From an architect trained by Frank Lloyd Wright, one who not only has lectured extensively about the legendary architect, but also is the author of ''Years With Frank Lloyd Wright: Apprentice to Genius,'' this view seems somewhat revolutionary. But Mr.

title: Jane Silverman To Wed in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leon Silverman of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jane Frances Silverman to Daniel Lawrence Hess, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Fritz Hess of Kirkville, N.Y. A March wedding is planned.

title: Late Abortion Laws Vary
description: Fewer than 1 percent of the 1.5 million abortions in the United States each year are performed in the last third of the pregnancy, the period when a fetus becomes able to live outside the womb. Because the Supreme Court has allowed states some latitude in protecting the fetus's interests in this ''third trimester,'' many states have adopted restrictive laws.

title: Altered Rest Stops To Offer Self-Serve Gas
description: LEAD: SELF-SERVICE gasoline will be available at all gas stations on Interstate 95 and on the Merritt and Wilbur Cross Parkways by the end of August, according to the State Department of Transportation. In addition, new 24-hour convenience stores will be open at Merritt and Wilbur Cross rest stops.

title: Q and A
description: Transfer Tax on a Co-op

title: Trouble in Texas
description: MORE than a third of the Dallas Cowboy cheerleaders have walked off the squad, saying the team's new owner, Jerry Jones, had threatened their wholesome image with a plan for skimpier costumes and relaxed rules that would let them fraternize with players and drink in uniform.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Deer Park $220,000 38 Byway Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 26-year-old high ranch; eat-in kitchen, pool, new roof and siding; taxes $4,000. Farmingdale $146,250 86 Intervale Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 39-year-old Cape Cod; finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. Levittown $158,000 73 Bloomingdale Road 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old ranch; den, family room, pool; taxes $3,400. North Patchogue $124,000 414 West Woodside Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, half acre; taxes $2,000. Selden $148,000 Clearview Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, new modular ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement; taxes not yet established. Wantagh $160,000 1036 White Birch Lane 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; finished basement, 2-car garage; taxes $4,000. OTHER AREAS Freehold, N.J. $142,000 32 Yard Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 28-year-old colonial; w/w carpeting, fireplace, sun room; taxes $1,412. Rye, N.Y. $405,000 11 Fieldstone Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 39-year-old ranch; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, porch, 2-car garage; taxes $5,666. New Milford, Conn. $135,000 39 Wellsville Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 7-year-old Cape Cod; expandable second floor, close to town; taxes $1,196.

title: Reviews/Dance; Four Offerings by Harlem Troupe
description: The second program in Dance Theater of Harlem's season, which ends next Sunday, is a decidedly mixed bill.

title: The Hard Case of the Flag: Apologies and Surprises
description: DISPLAYING some of the emotions that the Stars and Stripes inspires, the Supreme Court delivered its judgment: burning an American flag in a nonviolent political demonstration cannot be punished criminally because it is a form of expression protected by the First Amendment. Justices on both sides of the 5-to-4 ruling last week wrote fervent opinions on the defilement of the symbol of freedom.

title: For Rose, One Year Is Enough
description: THE day before the 1974 baseball season began, Pete Rose heard the tornado warning on the radio and looked out a window of his suburban Cincinnati home.

title: Lynda Sylvester: Product Designer
description: Lynda Sylvester is one of those people who float in and out of the ordinary workaday world every few years and remain unscathed. Right now, Ms. Sylvester, a product designer who specializes in custom china, lives in Sag Harbor, L.I., and is planning to open Sylvester & Simon, a home-furnishings shop, on the town's main street in a couple of weeks.

title: Jade in Many Hues Evokes China's Regal Past
description: CHINESE JADES HAVE been collected since antiquity more enthusiastically than any other Asian stone artifacts. As the broad sampling of examples assembled in ''Jade,'' an exhibition at Azuma Gallery, 50 Walker Street in the SoHo section of Manhattan, makes clear, the attraction of the precious material is multifaceted.

title: Michel Aflaq Dies in Paris at 79; Founder of Iraq's Baathist Party
description: Michel Aflaq, the founder and General Secretary of Iraq's governing Arab Baath Socialist Party, died in a hospital in Paris on Friday night, the Iraqi press agency reported. He was 79 years old, and had undergone heart surgery on June 10.

title: Youth on the Move in Tennis
description: EVERY tennis generation has produced child stars, resolute girls in pigtails, steely-eyed boys who have not yet begun shaving. In the open era, for instance, Chris Evert was 19 when she won Wimbledon and the United States Open; Tracy Austin was the youngest female winner of the Open at 17; Bjorn Borg and Mats Wilander were still teen-agers when they won the French Open for the first time, and John McEnroe was 18 when he reached the semifinals at Wimbledon in 1977.

title: God Was at Least Partly to Blame
description: NO RESTING PLACE By William Humphrey. 249 pp. New York: Seymour Lawrence/Delacorte Press. $18.95.

title: Mets Regain Winning Touch
description: Slowly, visibly, maybe even relentlessly, the Mets keep reviving an act that for two months seemed to be folding.

title: Young Guests Help Fill Up A Big Home
description: Three photographs of children sit atop the television set in the Haringa family living room, but only one is of a Haringa.

title: Vibrant Tiles From Portugal
description: LISBON'S ancient Moorish Alfama district is where hanging laundry billows across the narrow labyrinth of cobble serpentine alleys, archways and enchanting little squares. No visitor can help but be dazzled by the profusion of decorative wrought-iron balconies and panels of azulejos, the traditional hand-painted tiles of Portugal. Outside the capital tile-decorated facades are ubiquitous. But, beyond their decorative aspects, azulejos reflect the history of this once-powerful nation.

title: Made-for-Cable Movies: tempest in a Hot Tub
description: COUPLES HEATEDLY UNDRESS-ing each other, couples panting in hot tubs, couples sweatily entwined - we are, friends, in the aggressively liberated territory of pay TV's made-for-cable movies. And don't forget the foul language. Pay TV, like children everywhere, seems to equate being an adult with adolescent naughtiness.

title: Voodoo Politics
description: THE RAINY SEASON Haiti Since Duvalier. By Amy Wilentz. 427 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Ms. Lauterstein Weds a Lawyer
description: At the Union League Club in New York, Dorothy Weil Lauterstein, a news writer for ABC Radio in New York, was married yesterday to Eric Wood Doppstadt, an associate in the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian minister, officiated.

title: Nancy Hagoort,Lawyer, Marries
description: Nancy Lynn Hagoort and Robert Charles Treuhold were married yesterday at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York by the Rev. Gary P. Fertig.

title: COOL HEAD, HOT IMAGES
description: In placing Brian De Palma's new movie ''Casualties of War'' in the same genre as some of the director's prior works, Bruce Weber writes that many of De Palma's films ''have made an almost gleeful use of sex and violence for their natural evocation of tension and release'' (''Cool Head, Hot Images,'' May 21). I suggest that if Mr. Weber conducted an informal poll, he might discover that sex viewed as an act of ''tension and release'' is a notion derived from a predominantly male experience.

title: Agreement on Fishing Nets Is Reached by U.S. and Japan
description: The United States and Japan have reached an agreement on the use of drift nets by commercial fishing vessels, averting an embargo on Japanese fish imports.

title: In a New Film, Spike Lee Tries To Do the Thing
description: EVEN BEFORE ''DO THEJU Right Thing,'' opens on Friday, Spike Lee, its producer, director, writer and star, has already got what he expected most from the film: hot debate, heavy discussion and even denunciation from some who think he did the wrong thing.

title: Anne Drake L'Hommedieu Is Married
description: Anne Drake L'Hommedieu, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paige Bradley L'Hommedieu of Convent Station, N.J., was married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Williamstown, Mass., to Ian Crocker Sanderson, a son of Mrs. Herbert Hansen of Hillsboro, N.H., and James C. Sanderson of East Sandwich, Mass., and Palm City, Fla. The Rev. Thomas C. Sheffield, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Sanderson, who was until recently an English teacher at the Shipley School in Bryn Mawr, Pa., graduated from Williams College and received a master's degree in education from Harvard University. Her father retired as a national accounts representative in New York for Armstrong World Industries, the flooring and furnishings manufacturer.

title: Restructuring Civil Rights, Restructuring Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Caroline Burkhart Marries
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Wilmington, Del., Caroline Melinda Ashton Burkhart and Robert Greenwood Shaw, teachers at the Lawrenceville (N.J.) School, were married yesterday. The Revs. Richard H. Downes and Albert P. Neilson officiated. Mrs. Shaw is a daughter of Mrs. Paul E. Shipley of Wilmington and Dr. Charles B. Burkhart of Whitefish, Mont. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis A. Shaw of Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: The Rise of 'Civil Society'
description: The crises of reform in Communist states have brought forth the concept of ''civil society.'' The phrase is heard more and more frequently.

title: Hope and Fear at a Refugee Sanctuary
description: TWO years ago, a young Salvadoran woman in her mid-20's left five of her six children in El Salvador and, unable to get a visa, came to the United States illegally with her husband in the hopes of making more money.

title: Luxurious Towels To Sit on Or Put on
description: As you find yourself stumbling indecisively in the sand this summer, looking for the ideal spot, it is a good idea to avoid sitting near people with 80-pound radios and tiny beach towels. Such people simply do not know How to Be at the Beach. At the beach, the only thing loud should be your towel.

title: John Bunch at the Piano
description: Genial, quietly ebullient piano solos by John Bunch opened the JVC Jazz Festival on Friday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall. Mr. Bunch, who worked in the 1950's with big bands led by Benny Goodman and Woody Herman and who has also accompanied Tony Bennett, is an orchestral pianist on his own. He turns songs into richly harmonized two-handed counterpoint - bouncing stride chords under trickling right-hand lines, offbeats tossed back and forth, quietly stated melodies spinning off arpeggios above and below.

title: POSTINGS: Optimistic Outlook; The Cost of a Home Loan Continues to Fall
description: Prospective home buyers will be pleased to know that mortgage interest rates fell markedly - by more than a percentage point on fixed rate loans - this spring, and some economists believe rates will continue to decline for the rest of the year.

title: Visas
description: To the Editor: Though the answer to the question about getting a visa for Hungary (Q & A, May 14) was correct, it was not complete. Recently I obtained visas for my husband and myself by taking our completed application to the Hungarian Consulate General's office at 8 East 75th Street, New York, N.Y., waiting about 10 minutes and paying an additional fee of $5 per visa for immediate service (total of $20 each). Thus, we avoided the three-week wait, and our passports were available to be sent to the Czechoslovak Embassy in Washington.

title: Refugees, Twice Moved, Look to Future in Russia
description: Outside a small two-story brick house here, Zukha Germanove sat with her children, her sisters-in-law and their children and she laughed.

title: Subway Tactics For Bicyclists
description: IT'S not unusual for a tourist to see a city by bicycle or subway, but few people are familiar with the benefits of combining the two. If you know the rules and restrictions, the subway can become the bicyclist's best friend.

title: Ethnic Celebrations Open For 19th Year
description: LEAD: ABOUT 15 years ago, pleased with the growing popularity of its summer ethnic festivals, the county sought some special entertainment. When the musicians began to play, half of the audience threw up its palms in puzzlement; the other half pinched its nostrils.

title: Take Japan Seriously in Aerospace
description: THE aerospace industry plays a central role in Japan's strategic vision of its future. The Japanese are seeking technology leadership rather than cost advantage and will emerge as a dominant force in certain segments of the market much faster than is generally expected. American aerospace companies must avoid the ''it will never happen here'' attitude that contributed to the downfall of the steel, consumer electronics, automobile, shipbuilding and semiconductor industries. With aerospace providing an annual trade surplus to the United States of more than $17.8 billion, the stakes are high.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: North Carolina; A Tighter Code For Harassment By Sex or Race
description: The University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill has joined a growing number of colleges that have recently tightened their codes of student conduct governing sexual assault and sexual and racial harassment by students. Amendments to the campus code, which will take effect this week, have been designed to make victims more comfortable about reporting offenders to the Student Honor Court.

title: 4 Removed From Their Posts As a Result of Shifts in Power
description: In addition to those who gained new positions today, four people lost positions. Two were dropped from the Standing Committee of the Politburo, and two from the Secretariat, which handles day-to-day decision-making in the party. All are believed to favor more rapid political and economic liberalization. Zhao Ziyang

title: Polygamy Is Part of the Answer
description: MOON PASSAGE By Jane LeCompte. 187 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.

title: Children's Books
description: NO KIDDING By Bruce Brooks. 207 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Wall Street's Greed Is Fueled by Fear
description: DURING the 1980's, proven or alleged business crimes tended to be perpetrated by people who were already rich and whose hunger for more cannot be linked to any reasonable need. From the escapades of Ivan Boesky to the smirking and pseudo-shrewd misdeeds of the so-called yuppie crime ring, this decade has featured some of the more tawdry goings-on in American business history. But did Michael Milken, who stands accused of multiple infractions of the securities laws, need the relatively small proportion of his $500 million income that the Government claims was ill-gotten? And how about the others whose actions were beyond the bounds of social propriety?

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on April 2 misidentified a church in the Azores. A reader reported in April that it was the Convent and Chapel of Nossa Senhora de Esperanca; confirmation has just become available from the writer, who was out of touch.

title: Rhena Vaughns Weds Dr. H. R. Brown
description: The marriage of Rhena English Vaughns, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Wilford English of Brooklyn, to Dr. Howard R. Brown, a son of Muriel V. Brown of Arden Heights, S.I., and the late Isaac L. Brown, took place yesterday. The Rev. Robert Ross Johnson officiated at the St. Albans (Queens) Congregational Church.

title: Should Ben Johnson Be Allowed to Run Again?
description: Other track and field athletes, including Martti Vainio and Augie Wolf, have returned - without debate - to competition after serving two-year suspensions for positive steroid testing.

title: Bronx Baby Dies of Brain Injuries
description: A 7-month-old Bronx girl who the police say suffered brain injuries while in the care of her mother's boyfriend died on Friday, four days after suffering the injuries.

title: Malpractice Rates Ease, But Many Are Skeptical
description: With insurance rates expected to stabilize this year after more than a decade of increases, some analysts and government officials are cautiously declaring an end to New York's medical malpractice insurance crisis. But as the crisis ends, officials said, so do hopes of further legislative changes to the state's insurance system.

title: On the Departure Of Abdul-Jabbar
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Michele Grogan Weds Angus McL. Mairs Jr.
description: The marriage of Michele Ann Grogan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Grogan of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., to Angus McLeod Mairs Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mairs of St. Paul, took place yesterday at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Chester, Conn. The Rev. Thomas W. Ahern officiated.

title: She Minds the Child, He Minds the Dog
description: THE SECOND SHIFT Working Parents and the Revolution at Home. By Arlie Hochschild with Anne Machung. 309 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: Seeing Through The Crisis Makers
description: Philip Pilevsky complains that we have pushed a whole host of issues aside. He goes on to decry local communities' Not In My Backyard Syndrome. They don't want to hear about solutions to household garbage, jail overcrowding and medical waste, and become extremely susceptible to crisis makers who create a crisis where none exists. Mr. Pilevsky is mixed up. He should conclude precisely the opposite. Politicians have led us into deadlock because they perceive the public to deeply suspect that these crises are nothing more than issues manufactured to advance political careers, as he says Carol Berman did with the SST. Long Islanders also believe that these crises are simply a means by which the leftist agenda is foisted upon them.

title: Cathy Deane and Richard Krantz: Fashion Retailers
description: Cathy Deane and Richard Krantz met when they were both working for Macy's, she in the accessories field, he in junior sportswear and dresses. They decided that instead of climbing the corporate ladder, they would go into business for themselves.

title: In Hawaii, a Move to Deter Japanese Investors
description: The golf population should continue to surge. But to accommodate new golfers, 4,000 new courses would need to be opened by the year 2000 - or one every day starting now, according to the National Golf Foundation. Golf developers are not even close to meeting the demand.

title: The Bliss of the Insecure
description: ENCOUNTERS By Juan Garcia Ponce. Translated by Helen Lane. Introduction by Octavio Paz. 116 pp. Hygiene, Colo.: Eridanos Press. Cloth, $19. Paper, $10.

title: The Face and Fashions for the 90's
description: In an age when just about everything seems to be disposable, one shouldn't forget that time itself is, too. Not that anyone is likely to, what with the 1990's being one of the season's top topics. With the end of the 80's approaching, cocktail discussions are sprinkled with toasts to the 90's and there's curiosity about what to expect in the decade ahead.

title: A Boom, as Younger Golfers Flock to the Links
description: GOLF is taking off like a Jack Nicklaus tee shot. Last year, 23.4 million people played at least one round of golf, up from 15.1 million in 1980, according to the National Golf Foundation, a trade group.

title: PERSPECTIVES: The Arverne Solution; Courtyard Housing With Parking Below
description: IT cannot be said that New York City has looked to the West Coast, or out of town at all, for inspiration in the design of its low-rise housing. The names of such developments as Golden Gate Commons and South Beach Marine Village in San Francisco, Park Row in San Diego, the Vineyards at Almaden in San Jose and Turtle Creek in Dallas are probably unfamiliar here even in architectural circles.

title: Matthew Schutz, Antiques Dealer, 55
description: An obituary on Sunday about Matthew Schutz, a Manhattan antiques dealer, misstated the day of his death.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: The United States will lose its champion this fall when Michael Wilder drops the game to begin law school. The Princeton, N.J., grandmaster has pointed out the obvious: Chess is just too chancy a way to make a living.

title: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: Senate

title: New Gurus: Computers and Therapists
description: ''Golf is the most over-taught and least learned human endeavor in the whole spectrum of doctrinology,'' writes Jim Murray, a sports columnist, in Golf Magazine. ''If they taught sex the way they teach golf, the race would have died out years ago.''

title: Grasping an Idea, the Long Way and the Short
description: SOME ideas, no matter how ingenious and useful, never quite make it through our thick skulls. Not mine, anyway. Others go directly to the cerebrum with hardly any coaxing. It's all in the presentation.

title: Dam Break Kills 38 in China
description: A dam in central China burst early this week, sending tons of water down a mountainside and killing at least 38 people, a news report said today. The official China Daily said the disaster occurred on Tuesday on a mountain in Yang Quan, Shanxi Province.

title: Bentsen Rejoins Three Clubs He Had Quit For Campaign
description: Senator Lloyd Bentsen has rejoined three clubs he quit last summer after becoming the Democratic Party's nominee for Vice President, his spokesman said Friday, contending that the clubs have no membership restrictions.

title: That Rare Breed: Both a Revolutionary And a Man of Peace
description: ONE OF THE MOST REWARDING shows of the summer, and one that has an impact out of all proportion to its size, is ''The Intimate Eye of Edouard Vuillard'' at the Katonah Gallery in Katonah, N.Y. Well installed, well hung, well lit and prettily catalogued, it will give delight of a lasting and exhilarating sort to anyone who prizes the achievement of Bonnard, Vuillard, Maurice Denis, Felix Vallotton and their friends between 1890 and 1920.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: The cost of staging world championships has long been a heavy burden on host organizations. Some small countries, such as Jamaica in 1987, have risen to the challenge and performed magnificently. Others have reluctantly decided that a small body of players could not afford the inevitable big bills.

title: Aesthetic Goals At Exhibitions
description: Helen Harrison seemed to like the exhibition [ ''At Juried Show, Dominant Esthetic Is Abstract and Gestural,'' May 28 ] , because it had the esthetic cohesion of an invitational show. While there is much to be said for a show with a cohesive and dominant esthetic, the Huntington Township Art League's annual juried exhibition was publicized as an open juried show and should, therefore, have reflected many styles and media.

title: Philadelphia, Miss.: '64, '89
description: In June 1964, Andrew Goodman, a student at Queens College in New York City, went to Mississippi. There he joined with Michael Schwerner of Brooklyn and James Chaney, a state native. In the third week of June, these three young men - Mr. Schwerner was the oldest and he was only 24 -came to a crossroads: Mississippi's Philadelphia.

title: Canadian Wins L'eggs Race
description: Like the little engine that could -and a little engine that couldn't -Lynn Williams alternately chugged her way to the lead on the uphill stretches of the L'eggs Mini Marathon in Central Park yesterday and lost ground to Aurora Cunha of Portugal on the downhill runs. Then, the 10-kilometer course flattened out and Williams proved she was the woman who would.

title: Selling the Trump Shuttle
description: MARVIN SLOVES says he knows ''all about these guys,'' but his colleagues on Madison Avenue think he's got his work cut out for him.

title: A Mom's Plea to a Ballplayer
description: LEAD: Baseball is our little boy's passion and Gregg Jefferies, the rookie second-baseman for the Mets, is his first, and beloved, hero. A photograph plaque of Gregg Jefferies hangs in a position of honor, alone on the wall over his bed. On his seventh birthday, my son solemnly placed a Gregg Jefferies baseball card in the center of his birthday cake.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Armonk, N.Y. $945,000 5 Shippen Road 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, year-old contemporary; 2 fireplaces, family room, eat-in kitchen, den, deck, 1.5 acres; taxes as yet unassessed. Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. $500,000 71 Pine Road 6-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 79-year-old Mediterranean; 3 fireplaces, den, playroom, wine cellar, deck; taxes $7,520. Rye, N.Y. $405,000 11 Fieldstone Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 39-year-old ranch; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, porch, 2-car garage; taxes $5,666. New Milford, Conn. $135,000 39 Wellsville Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 7-year-old Cape Cod; expandable second floor, close to town; taxes $1,196. Kent, Conn. $130,000 Sumner Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 41-year-old cottage; screened porch, new refrigerator and stove, 1 acre; taxes $574. Litchfield, Conn. $190,000 Ethan Allen Drive 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 8-year-old Cape Cod; woodstove, 2-car garage, 125- by 200 foot lot; taxes $1,415. OTHER SALES Brick, N.J. $243,000 681 Rolling Hills Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old ranch; fireplace, deck, Florida room; taxes $3,600. Levittown, L.I. $158,000 73 Bloomingdale Road 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 40-year-old ranch; den, family room, pool; taxes $3,400. North Patchogue, L.I. $124,000 414 West Woodside Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, half acre; taxes $2,000.

title: 'Twas Method, Yet There Was Madness in It
description: An article on page 6 of the Arts and Leisure section today about the Group Theater gives an incorrect founding date for the Mirror Repertory Theater and misidentifies its founder. The group was started in 1983 by Sabra Jones with John Strasberg, Eva Le Gallienne and Geraldine Page.

title: The Meaning of Propaganda
description: To the Editor:

title: Doomed To Equality
description: SOMETIMES ANTHONY, my eldest son by three minutes, simply finds the presence of his twin brother, Paul, too much to bear. Abruptly, he'll grit his teeth and charge at his brother, and the two of them will fall, becoming a shrieking pile of 2-year-olds. Then, as Mr. Matter-of-Fact, Anthony will step up to me or my wife and point out that Paul is crying.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: 'CELEBRATE PERTH AMBOY'

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Quincy, Mass.;
Mining a Quarry For Mixed Uses
description: LEAD: A 175-ACRE former quarry at the junction of three of metropolitan Boston's busiest highways is being transformed into an office park.

title: Churches Reclaim Role in Social Services
description: LEAD: WHEN Phyllis Powell, a social worker in the Bridgeport office of the State Department of Children and Youth Services, needed to find furniture for two families that had none, she did not turn to the state. Instead, she asked the First Church Congregational in Fairfield, which quickly responded to her plea.

title: Now Showing: Snakes II
description: Restrictions on imports take many forms -tariffs, red tape and now, in South Korea, snakes.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The exterior of our 30-year-old house is covered with cedar shakes. They have never been stained or cleaned, and now are in shades ranging from dark brown to black. Painters have recommended everything from power washing, stain and paint to a clear preservative. What do you advise?

title: Dr. Rosenthal Marries Erik Eckholm
description: Dr Elisabeth Lindsey Rosenthal and Erik Peter Eckholm were married last evening at Bargemusic in Brooklyn by Justice Carmen B. Ciparick of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Glasgow
description: Just two years ago, Glaswegians still chuckled at the thought of visitors flocking to their city. No one laughs now. Last year Glasgow's huge international garden festival lured nearly four million visitors to this hilly Scottish metropolis on the banks of the River Clyde. And next year more than five million are expected for the blaze of festivities celebrating Glasgow's selection as European Culture Capital of 1990, an annual award previously bestowed by the European Community on more immediately obvious choices like Florence and Paris.

title: Henderson's Homer Helps A's Beat Jays
description: Dave Stewart pitched a four-hitter to become the first 12-game winner in the American League this season and Rickey Henderson hit his first home run since being traded back to Oakland, leading the Athletics past the Toronto Blue Jays today, 7-1.

title: The Education of Dan Quayle
description: DAN QUAYLE HAS BEEN BRUSHING UP ON HIS leaders. He has read William Manchester's biographies of Douglas MacArthur and Winston Churchill.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: JOY RIDE. By Barbara Howell. (Viking, $17.95.) ''Why are there so few real heroines anywhere to embolden us, perhaps cheer us up?'' laments Madeleine, the narrator of Barbara Howell's third novel. ''No wonder women are victims, not just of men, but of all those stories of weak, downtrodden women.

title: Nassau Needs A New Deal
description: WHILE it is true that the Nassau County District Attorney has not been able to find any indictable offenses as a result of his Mitchel Field investigation, unfortunately, it does in fact lead to one conclusion: the indictment of Nassau County government.

title: Joan Hirschhorn Becomes Bride of David Bright
description: Joan Morgenthau Hirschhorn, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Hirschhorn Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married last evening at her parents' home to David Evan Bright, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred S. Bright of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Amy Ehrlich officiated.

title: How to Handle Big-City Sneerers
description: Diedre M. Levine's resolution as to how to handle the sneering Manhattanite needs some (with deference) improvement.

title: Beware: Teen-Age Driver, Nervous Mother
description: THE State of Connecticut deems it not only appropriate but legal for children, at the age of 16, to learn how to drive. Yet, just as they are being given state's rights, they are at the height of irrationality.

title: Learning to Appreciate the Dandelions in Life
description: I GREW up in a small town where the elementary school was a 10-minute walk from my house and in a time, not so long ago, when children could come home for lunch and find their mothers waiting.

title: Economic Penalties Are Placed on China By Italy and Belgium
description: Italy and Belgium announced economic penalties against China on Friday, suggesting that sentiment exists in the European Community for broader, concerted action when the organization's 12 members meet next week in Madrid.

title: Ms. Reddington to Wed Jeffrey T. Herlyn in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry C. Reddington of Nutley, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Kristine Marie Reddington, to Jeffrey T. Herlyn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warner B. Herlyn of Mamaroneck, N.Y. A July wedding is planned.

title: Melissa C. Priest Wed to Architect
description: The marriage of Melissa Comingore Priest, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel B. Priest of Chevy Chase, Md., to Marc Tartaro, the son of Dr. Joan Emery of Westport, Conn., and John Tartaro of Plano, Tex., took place yesterday at the Mount Vernon Unitarian Church in Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Gary Gallun officiated.

title: TWO WATERWAYS FOULED BY SPILLS FROM OIL TANKERS
description: Tanker accidents near Philadephia and Newport, R.I., spread hundreds of thousands of gallons of oil into the Delaware River and Narragansett Bay yesterday.

title: I.B.M. Shows It Can Move Fast, Too
description: WHEN the Intel Corporation announced its new i486 microprocessor last spring, speculation immediately arose about when the Compaq Computer Corporation would ship the first computer based on that chip. Compaq had been the first major computer company to build a system around Intel's previous chip, the 386, and in doing so had leapfrogged the International Business Machines Corporation to become the perceived leader in personal computer technology. It took I.B.M. nearly a year to match Compaq's effort with the 386 chip.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LEAD: HORSE CRAZY. By Gary Indiana. (Grove, $16.95.) Gregory is young and beautiful. Gregory is a struggling artist who makes composite pictures using photographs from homoerotic magazines. Gregory is a former - and possibly current - heroin addict. Gregory never shows up on time. Gregory borrows money and never pays it back.

title: WHY MOW?
description: Something there is that doesn't love a lawn, and I know what it is: a mole. For almost 20 years, moles have been plowing my yard in hieroglyphs and run-on sentences. Now Michael Pollan has translated what they've been writing: ''Turn your lawn into a garden.''

title: MAKING COUNTRY MUSIC HOT AGAIN
description: WHEN THE CLEAN-CUT young man with dark brown eyes, brown hair swept off a high forehead and a prominent square jaw strides through the stage door of the Grand Ole Opry, barely a head turns. The musicians wandering the polished hallways recognize Randy Travis. He is, after all, perhaps the most sought-after young country singer in the world today. They notice, too, that by his side, wearing a Western suit and a cream-colored Stetson with a tiny diamond horseshoe pinned to the crown, walks Roy Rogers, King of the Cowboys.

title: At the Pollock House, Recalling the Birth of an Art Movement
description: ''JACKSON loved to play cards,'' says Ronald Stein, a nephew of the wife of Jackson Pollock, the famous Abstract Expressionist painter.

title: On the Road: Bags and Baggage
description: He roamed through bus terminals, rooming houses, rail yards and desert junctions, toting ''a few fundamental things'' in an old canvas bag. Sal Paradise, the youthful drifter of Jack Kerouac's classic novel ''On The Road,'' took plenty of time to see America, but no more luggage than today's weekend traveler. For him, the classic sport duffel, either a vertical ''north-south'' model that hangs cylinderlike from the shoulder or an ''east-west'' version with standard hand grips, works as well for vacations as it does for the gym. The kinds of bags men have long carried to work - briefcases, doctors' satchels, mail pouches - have been adapted for pure escape, too. At Orvis, the outdoor outfitting store, a tackle bag ($142.50) has room for a blazer as well as a two- or four-piece fly rod.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: LEAD: AMERICAN GENESIS: A Century of Invention and Technological Enthusiasm, 1870-1970. By Thomas P. Hughes. (Viking, $24.95.) Whether microwaving dinners, word-processing resumes or curling up with a videocassette recorder, we frequently overlook the social, economic and political contexts of the technology that shapes our lives.

title: Purse May Rise For Super Derby
description: The Super Derby purse will be doubled to $2 million if Sunday Silence and Easy Goer enter the Sept. 24 race, the Louisiana Downs owner, Edward J. DeBartolo, said Friday.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: The plot of A DENIABLE MAN by Sol Stein (McGraw-Hill, $18.95) can quickly be summarized. It is a standard triangle. A brilliant teacher of law becomes besotted with a very bright student and helps her become a fearsome trial lawyer. The woman's father is a general in the United States Army. He is killed in Rome by terrorists. A mysterious bodyguard is assigned to keep an eye on his daughter and her mother. They too are slated for execution. A romance develops between the young woman and the bodyguard.

title: Q and A
description: ndon to Egypt

title: What's a Mother to Do?
description: The Senate has just ratified a revolution. The revolution involves working mothers; the ratification involves what low-income mothers do with their children while at work. By passing the Act for Better Child Care Services, proposed by Democrat Christopher Dodd and Republican Orrin Hatch, the Senate acknowledges, as Senator Edward Kennedy says, that it ''cannot repeal the 20th century.''

title: Social Comment? Wrap It in Laughs
description: WHEN A SERVANT NAMED Juan puts on a luxurious silk dressing gown owned by his recently deceased employer, he instantly reveals the depth of his grief. ''The way I see it,'' Juan tells the servant next door, ''he spent three grand on a bathrobe, he deserved to die.'' Juan will turn out to be the most heroic figure in Paul Bartel's mordant satire ''Scenes From the Class Struggle in Beverly Hills,'' a film based on the clear and cynical assumption that the underclass is almost as greedy, callous and silly as the overclass. Nasty human nature is the great equalizer.

title:
ART;
Multiple Originals on Paper
description: LEAD: THE six artists grouped together in ''Impressions on Paper,'' the current exhibition at the Temperance Hall Gallery in Bellport, are among those whose prints and multiples are handled by Pace Editions. The work on view is thus a small selection of what might be seen on a visit to that New York City gallery.

title: Towns Check for Radon to Supplement State Test
description: THE director of the Westport-Weston Health District, Judith F. Nelson, decided that radon testing by the state of 100 houses in those towns was not enough. And one homeowner in the district can be thankful she decided to expand the program as a local effort.

title: In Beijing, a Month of Living Dangerously
description: Covering the recent tumultuous events in China has proved a logistical challenge for American television. Here are observations from several news correspondents sent to Beijing by the various networks. 'THE WALKIE-TALKIE BECAME MY LIFELINE'

title: Veterans of Abortion Battles Watch For Signal of Shift by Supreme Court
description: For the past 16 years since the 1973 Supreme Court ruling in Roe v. Wade turned abortion from a crime into a right, virtually every political and legal battle that could be fought on the abortion issue has been fought in Minnesota.

title: CHINA OUSTS ZHAO AND PICKS LEADERS TOUGH ON DISSENT
description: China's Communist Party dismissed General Secretary Zhao Ziyang from all his posts today and named a new set of leaders who are likely to favor somewhat new directions in the nation's economic and political development.

title: A Soldier of Quality
description: GENERAL MAXWELL TAYLOR The Sword and the Pen. By John M. Taylor. Foreword by Lewis F. Powell Jr. Illustrated. 457 pp. New York: Doubleday. $22.50.

title: Ideals Aside, Ethics Are Practical
description: ELABORATE ethical systems that include abstract concepts and specific codes are not helpful to practical managers. These days, even the word ethics can be confusing. Some say management ethics can be summed up in phrases like ''don't steal,'' while others argue that ethics are part of a larger social agenda for a business or company.

title: Nemerov Reappointed As U.S. Poet Laureate
description: Howard Nemerov has been appointed to a second term as poet laureate of the United States by the Librarian of Congress, James H. Billington.

title: Miss Burnette Weds Cloyd Laporte 3d
description: Suzanne Rae Burnette, the daughter of Mrs. Jerry F. McGehee of Kingwood, Tex., and the late Phillip L. Burnette, was married yesterday at the Valeur mansion in Rhinebeck, N.Y., to Cloyd Laporte 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Laporte Jr. of New York. Judge Richard Owen of the United States District Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Carolina Ryan, Art Consultant, Is Wed
description: Carolina Ryan, a daughter of John J. Ryan 3d of Geneva and Maria Luisa Lobo Montalvo of Lima, Peru, was married yesterday in Bornato, Italy, to Filippo Camperio Ciani, a son of Irma Orlando of Florence and the late Manfredo Camperio Ciani of Milan, Italy. Don Antonio Tommasoni performed the ceremony at the San Bartolomeo Apostolo Catholic Church.

title: A Bad Name
description: DAVID STERN makes it clear that Bad Boys is not a nickname he would have picked for his league's champions.

title: Spectators Need More Protection
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Review/Music; Syd Straw, an Iconoclastic Pop Star
description: Every few years a bohemian female singer emerges whose combination of talent and personal charisma allows her to become a pop star without playing by the rules. Syd Straw, who appeared at the Bottom Line on Wednesday, belongs to a tradition of willfully offbeat personalities like Patti Smith, Rickie Lee Jones and Cyndi Lauper. Although she has not yet had a hit, her just-released debut album, ''Surprise,'' is already creating a stir.

title: 3 Arms Dealers in New York Sentenced in Overseas Plot
description: Three New York arms dealers were sentenced to 10-year terms in Federal prison on Friday for plotting to ship military equipment illegally to the Soviet Union, Poland, Iraq and Argentina. Each defendant was assessed fines and forfeitures of more than $700,000.

title: The Chesapeake's Bounty
description: Just after the vernal equinox, the fields that were once covered with hundreds of Canada geese and swans begin to bud with the new summer crops. This is the signal that life in the Chesapeake Bay is about to change. The famous bay oysters are replaced with the beautiful swimmer, the blue crab. The floor of the Chesapeake comes alive with the scurry of blue crabs as the watermen begin preparing their work boats and traps for the summer's harvest.

title: A Seaside Town's Country Airs
