description: THERE are two Swedens. There is the Sweden that conjures visions of a meticulously organized but joyless society of blond-haired, blue-eyed conformists. Swedish design, for example, is often seen as elegant, intelligent, functional - yet soulless. And Swedish cities are often viewed as triumphs of social as well as civil engineering, but lacking the addictive taste of hustle, the tantalizing smell of opportunity, that New York, say, or Paris provide. Given this model of Sweden, it is easy to postulate boredom as the second leading cause of death, right behind taxes.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Stony Point
description: STEEPED in Revolutionary War history, Stony Point, on the northern tip of Rockland County, not only sponsors Memorial Day parades and Fourth of July fireworks displays launched from barges on the Hudson River, it but also celebrates Wayne Day, marking the July 16, 1779, Battle of Stony Point.

title: THE RETIRING KIND
description: How novel to find a person who is happily retired for the purpose of being retired, who is not, instead, ''busier than I have ever been in my life!'' (About Men: ''The Retiring Kind,'' by Austen A. Ettinger, May 28).

title: Fillmore East
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; Greek Chicken via a Church Bazaar
description: The best Greek food in this country, next to home cooking, can be found at church bazaars. That is where I found this recipe for chicken oreganato.

title: Burma Out, Myanmar In
description: Burma has a new official name: Myanmar.

title: Susan G. Scanlan Marries Banker
description: St. George's by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Susan Grace Scanlan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ward Scanlan of Fair Haven, N.J., to John Frampton Dittman, a son of Mrs. Marcus Walling Dittman of Lincoln, Neb., and the late Mr. Dittman. The Rev. George J. Willis Jr. officiated.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''If I had made money, I would be in Monte Carlo and have left my lawyers to sort it out.'' - Naji Robert Nahas, Brazilian speculator, defending himself over a $29 million bounced check.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Style Makers column on June 11 about Hamilton Hodge, a handbag designer, referred incorrectly to De Vecchi, an Italian leather goods company. It does not manufacture bags for Ralph Lauren or Bally.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Are the New Tennis Players Exciting?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: INSIDE
description: One State's Abortion War Ever since Roe v. Wade, virtually every battle that could be fought on the abortion issue has been fought in Minnesota. Now the opposing forces there are girding for what may be another landmark decision. Page 20. Soviet Refugees' Plight The Meskhetians, members of a Soviet minority driven by Stalin from their Georgian homeland, are refugees twice over now after fleeing nationalist rioting in their adopted homes in Central Asia. Page 16. Show Trial in Havana Stepping up its sudden and highly public crackdown on corruption within the Government, Cuba announced that a general accused of drug trafficking would be tried by 47 of his peers. Page 3. F.B.I. in Pakistan The F.B.I. is in Pakistan to investigate the plane crash that killed President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq. Page 13.

title: Uprooting the Weeds of Winter's Discontent
description: ''SUMMERTIME, and the living is easy,'' I hum, as I waltz barefoot from the kitchen into my backyard. Elusive spring, wedged between the extended chill of winter and the early flush of summer, has vanished without distinction. Therapeutic summer.

title: Margret Tingue Weds
description: Margret Stewart Tingue, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Tingue of Bedford Hills, N.Y., was married yesterday to Robert Adrian Shuford, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Wade H. Shuford of Atlanta. The Rev. Dr. William Foley officiated at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y. The bride, a teacher at the Trinity School in Atlanta, graduated from Vanderbilt University. Mr. Shuford, a graduate of the University of Georgia, is an insurance representative in Atlanta for the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

title: China's Economy: Pushed and Pulled Toward the Edge
description: AFTER a decade of spectacular growth induced by Deng Xiaoping's market-oriented changes, China's economy faces serious problems that could deepen popular discontent.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Soccer

title: F.B.I. Allowed to Investigate Crash That Killed Zia
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has for the first time sent agents to Pakistan to investigate the plane crash that killed the President of Pakistan and the American Ambassador there 10 months ago.

title: Reviews/Dance; Martine van Hamel in 'La Sylphide'
description: The sylphs of the Scottish highlands were once again magical and elusive on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House when American Ballet Theater presented ''La Sylphide,'' one of the great examples of balletic Romanticism. Martine van Hamel danced the title role, and Serge Lavoie, a guest artist from the National Ballet of Canada, gave his first performance as James in this production of August Bournonville's masterpiece of 1836. Both were competent, and both gave indications that they could be still better in the future.

title: Ms. Debrovner Weds Medical Student
description: At Tavern on the Green in New York last evening, Diane Hope Debrovner, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles H. Debrovner of New York and Lido Beach, L.I., was married to Charles Stanwood Carignan, a son of Elizabeth G. Pulver of Wells, Me., and Francis Carignan of Freeport, Me. Don Robert Johnson, the senior leader of the New York Society for Ethical Culture, officiated.

title: Kasey Kaufman Weds
description: Kasey Kaufman, a news anchor and correspondent at WBZ-TV, and Michael David Horwitz, a real-estate consultant for Leggat McCall Advisors, both in Boston, were married yesterday evening at Blantyre, an inn in Lenox, Mass., by Rabbi Herman Blumberg. The bride, who will keep her name, is a daughter of Toby Kaufman of Rancho Bernardo, Calif., and the late Allan Kaufman. She graduated from the University of California at Los Angeles. Mr. Horwitz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Erwin Horwitz of Chappaqua, N.Y. graduated summa cum laude from Tufts University, where he was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and where he also received a master's degree in international affairs.

title: Cardinal Forbids Mass by Black Priest
description: In one of the most serious racial disputes yet within the Roman Catholic Church in this country, James Cardinal Hickey, the Archbishop of Washington, has forbidden a black priest to celebrate Mass because the priest has charged the church with racism and announced plans to establish his own ''African- American'' congregation.

title: Sara Foote Wed To Bruce Cohen
description: The marriage of Sara Foote and Bruce Cohen took place yesterday at the Seneca Falls, N.Y., home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Paul Richard Foote. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cohen of Manalapan, N.J. Rabbi Alvin S. Roth and the Rev. Harold B. Sanderson Jr., a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: How I Ought vs. How I Do
description: LEAD: MORALITY AND IMAGINATION Paradoxes of Progress. By Yi-Fu Tuan. 209 pp. Madison: The University of Wisconsin Press. Cloth, $32.50. Paper, $11.95.

title: Ronni Mann Is Wed
description: Roanne Louise Mann, a partner at the New York law firm of Stein, Zauderer, Ellenhorn, Frischer & Sharp, and David Eli Brodsky, an assistant United States attorney for the southern district of New York, were married yesterday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Judge Jose Cabranes of Federal District Court in Connecticut officiated. The bride, who is known as Ronni, will keep her name. She is the daughter of Elias Mann and the late Gertrude Mann of New York and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Mr. Brodsky is the son of Jack Brodsky of Sea Cliff, L.I., and Vivian Brodsky of Elizabeth, N.J.

title: Nathan Zucker, 74, Film Producer, Dies
description: Nathan Zucker, an independent film producer, died Friday of kidney failure at Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 74 years old and lived in Cranbury, N.J.

title:
GARDENING;
An Assortment of Tasks for the Summer
description: LEAD: THE arrival of summer brings with it a diversity of gardening tasks that are essential to attaining satisfactory results with the lawn and flower or vegetable gardens.

title: Miss Hallowell Becomes Bride
description: Margaret Barnes Hallowell, a daughter of Meredith E. Hallowell of Harrington Park, N.J., and Peter S. Hallowell of Mahwah, N.J., was married yesterday to James Spencer Pasman 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Pasman Jr. of Pittsburgh and Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. Douglas Tompkins officiated at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Nantucket.

title: Eliot Nolen Wed To T. P. Bradley
description: Eliot Nolen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Nolen of New York, was married yesterday to Timothy Place Bradley, a son of Otis Treat Bradley of Quogue, L.I., and Patricia Place Smith of Litchfield, Conn., at the Great Island, Mass., home of the bride's maternal grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm G. Chace Jr. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: POSTINGS: Iberia on the Hudson; A Castle For Sale
description: The world's most famous monument to a wife is the Taj Mahal in Agra, India. But there is a fabulous building put up to please a wife only 50 miles north of Manhattan, in Garrison, N.Y., and it is being readied for sale at an asking price of $16.9 million.

title: Drug Companies Shouldn't Come First
description: Karen S. Dougherty ends her moving essay, ''The Muddle in Eating 'Right' '': ''It is ironic that miracle drugs are used to fight cancers that could be caused by the other 'miracle' drugs we eat and breathe.'' (Opinion page, May 14.) It is not only ironic, but also becoming apparent that such a connection is no accident. The companies that produce medical drugs and chemicals are a powerful lobby, strong enough to influence governmental bodies to ignore the threats these substances pose to our health and environment.

title: In Summer, The Swedes Think Bright
description: At an hour and change before midnight on Wednesday, there was still a line of people waiting to get into the Opera Cafe, wanting to sit at one of its outdoor tables, sip a drink and savor the day.

title: Pronounced Differences
description: A New Yorker cartoon some years back showed an exasperated woman upbraiding her husband in a wine shop. ''If you start talking to him about 'pooly-foossy,' I'll walk right out,'' she says.

title: FASHION: On the Street; To Take On An Artful Look, Use Your Head
description: Used to be, a diploma from the tonsorial academy was all one needed to practice barbering. Now, it seems, a couple of semesters at art school would not hurt. We are living in an age in which the term ''close back and sides'' has taken on a whole new meaning, and hair is more than just hair: it is a canvas, a hieroglyphic message center, a follicular billboard.

title:
tHE VIEW FROM: THE NESTLE KITCHEN;
Where New Recipes Get Top-Secret Testing and Tasting
description: LEAD: MUM'S the word when it comes to those creations as yet unnamed and untried in the kitchen at the Nestle Food headquarters here.

title: Suburban Steeplechase Isn't So Bad
description: Nancy Rupp paints a pretty bleak picture in her essay, ''Suburban Steeple-chase: The Commuter Derby'' (May 7). Describing a typical L.I.R.R. daily commute, she speaks of a horde of suited figures elbowing for space, and points out, ''Nobody smiles, nobody talks, nobody looks at anybody.''

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Boccherini, Dvorak: Cello Concertos; Bruch: Kol Nidrei Pablo Casals, cello; Czech Philharmonic conducted by George Szell (Dvorak), London Symphony conducted by Sir Landon Ronald. Pearl GEMM CD 9349; CD only. Except for technological advances in the recording process, these stunning performances, recorded over 50 years ago, have not been bettered. Although the Bruch and popular Boccherini (actually a 19th-century compilation from several of his works) offer vivid examples of the kind of energetic lyricism that characterized Casals' playing, the Dvorak performance remains in a class by itself. Casals' robust dynamism is so gripping that certain exaggerations frowned upon today seem just right for Dvorak's music in his hands, and Szell's accompaniment is fully integrated with the soloist. Mark Obert-Thorn's transfers are expert; one soon finds oneself listening to the performances rather than the antiquated sonics. -Paul Turok Beethoven: The String Trios Anne-Sophie Mutter, violin; Bruno Giuranna, viola; Mstislav Rostropovich, cello. Deutsche Grammophon 427 687-2; two CD's only. This seemingly unlikely combination of superstars with disparate temperaments, nationalities and constituencies may be just the thing to draw broader attention to these voluble, vibrant creations of a burgeoning master - the six-movement, serenadelike Op. 3, the five-movement Serenade, Op. 8, and the three four-movement works of Op. 9, all completed before Beethoven turned 28. Ms. Mutter, sometimes cool in approaching the classics, and Mr. Rostropovich, as often superheated, meet somewhere in the vicinity of Mr. Giuranna's enveloping warmth in compelling performances, not as consistently bottom-heavy as the indomitable cellist's presence might lead one to fear. -James R. Oestreich Walton: 'Facade,' 'Facade 2'; Stravinsky: 'Renard' Peggy Ashcroft, Jeremy Irons, narrators (Walton); Philip Langridge, tenor, Robert Lloyd, bass, others (Stravinsky); London Sinfonietta conducted by Riccardo Chailly. London 421 717-2; CD only. Walton's sassy setting of 29 Edith Sitwell poems for rhythmic narration with small instrumental ensemble here fully lives up to its subtitle, ''An Entertainment.'' Ms. Ashcroft and Mr. Irons not only supply superb diction, enhanced by digital clarity, but reveal a dimension of emotion lurking under Sitwell's strange wordplay not often felt in other performances. Mr. Chailly and the excellent instrumentalists prove unfailingly precise as well. ''Facade 2'' consists of eight interestingly sparse settings that Walton excluded from the published version. Mr. Chailly's ''Renard'' is an urbane affair, lacking the rough-and-tumble atmosphere others have (perhaps more aptly) brought to the work. -P. T. '1588': Music From the Time of the Spanish Armada The York Waits. Saydisc CD-SDL 373; CD only. The York Waits, a British Renaissance band, recorded this collection last year to mark the 400th anniversary of the defeat of the Spanish Armada. The battle serves as context and connective tissue (a few of the ballads describe it, or the men and ships that fought in it), but the Waits have wisely not made it the recording's sole focus. Included, too, are many more familiar tunes that were popular in Elizabethan England - most, domestic (John Johnson's ''Delight Pavan,'' the anonymous ''Robin Is to the Greenwood Gone'' and ''Watkins Ale''), with a sprinkling of dances imported from Italy and France. The works are arranged for shawms, sackbuts, lute, hurdy-gurdy, bagpipes and other gamy-sounding period instruments, all played spiritedly. -Allan Kozinn Weinberg: Symphony No. 6 (Op. 79); Shostakovich: From Jewish Folk Poetry (Op. 79) Lily Tuneh, soprano, Mira Zakai, alto, Neil Jenkins, tenor (Shostakovich); Neve-Shir Children's Choir (Weinberg); Jerusalem Symphony conducted by Yuri Ahronovitch. Stradivari Classics SCD 8005; CD only. These works have more than an opus number in common: Both reflect Jewish suffering and heroism. The Sixth Symphony of the Warsaw-born (1919) Moise Weinberg, who fled to the Soviet Union when Germany invaded Poland and became a leading musical figure in Moscow, is powerful and evocative. Three movements are settings for children's choir of poems about youth, death and hope. Shostakovich's score is arguably the most arresting of his Jewish-inspired works. These committed performances were recorded live at the Israel Festival in 1984 and 1985, respectively. What a difference a year made: The 1985 Jerusalem Symphony is a much better orchestra. Choir and soloists sing sensitively but with appalling diction, and no texts are provided. - Martin Bookspan POP/JAZZ Todd Rundgren: 'Nearly Human' Warner Bros. 25881; all three formats. ''Nearly Human'' finds the 41-year-old ex-boy-wonder of the recording studio still sorting through the hippie dreams of the late 60's and early 70's in songs that meditate on the gulf between everyday pain and cruelty and humanity's loftiest ideas of itself. Musically, this is Mr. Rundgren's most accessible album in years, still using the vocabulary of late-60's Philadelphia soul. To insure spontaneity, the album was recorded live in the studio after extensive rehearsals with a pop-soul band. Many of the cuts use at least five backup singers, whose elaborately arranged parts give the feel of a pop-jazz chorus. The recorded sound is oddly dry and trebly. -Stephen Holden Paul Desmond and Gerry Mulligan: 'Two of a Mind' Bluebird/RCA 9654-2-RB; all three formats. Like the poet Philip Larkin, the alto saxophonist Paul Desmond has honed his passion into a restrained lyricism. His orderly solos and vibratoless, liquid tones show a thorough knowledge of modern chord changes and time. But he often sounds like a New Orleans clarinetist who enjoys contrapuntal play rather than the dirty blues. In this collaboration with Gerry Mulligan, their third date together and their best, the saxophones chase each other without worry about a piano. The players' rapport throughout, especially in ''Out of Nowhere'' and ''Two of a Mind,'' and the fine solos - Mr. Mulligan in an elliptical ''Stardust,'' Mr. Desmond in his overdubbed specialty ''The Way You Look Tonight'' - offer evidence of a shared sensibility: a cooler, paler, slower Bird and Diz. -Richard B. Woodward Mavis Staples: 'Time Waits For No One' Paisley Park 25798; all three formats. The first solo album since 1976 by the Mississippi-born gospel singer was primarily produced by Prince, and its mixture of warm Southern soul-singing and gimmicky Minneapolis studio funk, though not always comfortable, is more harmonious than one might have expected. In the best cuts, like the lovelorn ''Come Home,'' which Prince wrote and produced in a style that deliberately echoes Willie Mitchell's 70's productions for Al Green, he extends himself knowledgeably into Ms. Staples' territory. In other cuts, like ''Interesting'' and ''Jaguar,'' her personality is all but smothered in Princely sound effects. -S. H. L. L. Cool J.: 'Walking With a Panther' Def Jam/Columbia 45172; all three formats. Fast, offbeat rhymes and a skill with polysyllables made L. L. Cool J. a rap phenomenon. Now the 21-year-old James Todd Smith, a k a L(adies) L(ove) Cool J(ames), has followed his second album, ''Bigger and Deffer,'' with more of the same on his self-produced ''Walking With a Panther.'' Over plain, midtempo funk, he glorifies himself and dismisses other rappers as imitators and other males as cuckolds and losers; elsewhere, he totes up his sexual conquests or speaks honeyed come-ons. One ballad, ''Two Different Worlds'' cleverly juxtaposes a cooing singer (Cydne Monet) and his own rap; of the boasts, ''Why Do You Think They Call It Dope?'' has the most motor-mouth virtuosity. But it's about time for Mr. Smith to look somewhere besides the mirror. -Jon Pareles Strata Institute: 'Cipher Syntax.' JMT/Polygram 834 425-4; all three formats. Despite a pretentious title (a note says it refers to a dialect of the M-Base language - ooh, cool), this group, featuring Steve Coleman and Greg Osby atop a brilliant rhythm section, means business when it starts to play. Neither nostalgic nor eclectic, it has created a dense, thrilling sound unlike anyone else's. Several songs could have used more cooking in the group's Brooklyn laboratory, but the album closes with a flourish of original music: the full-tilt ''Micro-move''; ''Humantic,'' a dark, sexy ballad with odd time changes; Mr. Osby's eerie ''Abacus''; and ''Ighnat,'' like a discourse on a James Brown riff. Even when trading fours, the players acknowledge tradition with a nod rather than a bowed head. -R. B. W.

title: Priest Begins Music Festival on Shore
description: THE Rev. Alphonse Stephenson, the former conductor and musical director of the Broadway hit ''A Chorus Line,'' says he wants to make this seaside resort known statewide for music and the arts through a new program called the Festival of the Atlantic.

title: Donna Williams Wed To J. Andrew Sanford
description: Donna Marie Williams, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth D. Williams of Manlius, N.Y., was married yesterday to J. Andrew Sanford, a son of Mrs. Laurence H. Sanford Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and the late Mr. Sanford. The Rev. William M. Hale officiated at St. Paul's Episcopal Cathedral in Syracuse.

description: INDEXES OF HOUSING COSTS N.Y.-Northeast N.J. area* % change from % change from May Apr.
