title: IF THE WALL CAME TUMBLING DOWN
description: WHAT MAGNIFICENT dream could President Ronald Reagan have had before his eyes in the spring of 1987 when he exclaimed, to polite applause from West Berliners, ''Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall!''? Or President Bush, when he followed his mentor by declaring in Mainz, West Germany, last month that ''the brutal wall . . . must come down''?

title: Should Ben Johnson Be Allowed to Run Again?
description: We should not condone Ben Johnson's use of steroids but rather use his return to track and field to promote drug-free athletics. If Ben Johnson is permitted to return to his competitive status, his drug-free return would promote a great campaign for drug-free athletics and act as a deterrent for those considering the use of performance-enhancing substances. DAVID G. DiMATTIA Yonkers, N.Y.

title: Spa Helps Cancer Victims Enhance Their Looks
description: LEAD: A BEAUTY spa in Stamford is helping women with cancer deal with hair loss and other physical side effects caused by chemotherapy.

title: Stephen Cardone Married To Julia Lawrence Colby
description: Julia Lawrence Colby, a daughter of Karen Colby of Bay Head, N.J., and F. Jordan Colby of Sandy Hook, Conn., and Stephen Frank Cardone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Cardone of Farmingdale, L.I., were married yesterday at the Presbyterian Church in Rye, N.Y., by the Rev. Dr. Richard Cromie.

title: Ms. Brennan Has Wedding
description: Beth Anne Brennan and Peter Robert Laitin were married yesterday at St. Joseph Roman Catholic Church in Demarest, N.J., by the Rev. Hilary Milton. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent F. Brennan of Demarest. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Laitin of Bethesda, Md.

title: Cities and Suburbs Join to Create Housing
description: LEAD: SIX communities in the Bridgeport area and 29 around Hartford have agreed to create up to 8,000 units of affordable housing. The agreements are the first attempt at regional cooperation on the housing problem between cities and suburban towns in the state.

title: Rachel Urquhart Is Married
description: Rachel Alexander Urquhart, the daughter of Sir Brian and Lady Urquhart of New York and Tyringham, Mass., was married yesterday to George Spyros Kalogerakis, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Michael G. Kalogerakis of New York and Wainscott, L.I. The Rev. Arnold F. Westwood, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Union Church in Tyringham.

title: Elizabeth Hansen Cohen, Art Adviser, Married to Stephen M. McPherson Jr.
description: The First Unitarian Church in Providence, R.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Elizabeth Hansen Cohen and Stephen Mather McPherson Jr. The Rev. Thomas E. Ahlburn officiated. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kip H. Cohen of Bristol, R.I., and Longboat Key, Fla. Mr. McPherson is the son of Mrs. Gregory A. Sharp of Northford, Conn., and Fishers Island, N.Y., and Mr. McPherson of New York.

title: Abstract Forms In a Pair of Shows
description: IN the Robeson Center Gallery at Rutgers, the menu is as usual: a group show in a large space, a solo in the small. Tony Moore, Winston Roeth and Robert Storr are the painters in the group, which is titled ''An Abstraction of Form''; James Bowness is the one featured in the solo, the latest in the New Jersey Artist Series.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: SALT LAKE CITY;
Desert Dream Resurrected
description: LEAD: WHEN Adnan Khashoggi, the Saudi Arabian businessman and arms dealer, came to the Utah market 15 years ago, he was warmly welcomed. But his dream of putting commercial developments in the desert faded amid suits by creditors.

title: Summer Theater Opens With Variety
description: SUMMER STOCK is not what it used to be, but at least it is still here. Gone are the star packages that once all but defined the straw-hat circuit. Now, the play, or the musical, is the thing, and there is more variety here than might be expected.

title: 'Write Till You Drop'
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Turnkey Program; Housing the Poor
description: The New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal has approved the first projects in a new housing program for low-income people - 500 apartments in 13 buildings at a cost of $40 million. The so-called Turnkey Program seeks proposals from developers who, after approval, borrow from private lenders, erect the buildings to state specifications, then sell them to the state, which in turn sells them to nonprofit community corporations, thus providing a revolving fund.

title: Alesia Ix MarriesHorace Klein 2d
description: Alesia Gilmore Ix and Horace Caldwell Klein 2d were married yesterday at St. Mary Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Mark A. Connolly, who was assisted by the Rev. Martin B. Hitchcock, pastor of the church, and the Rev. Mark R. Wood, an Episcopal priest.

title:
BODY AND MIND;
The Loss of Self
description: LEAD: IN ONE OF THE BETTER sections of Atlanta, a man in his early 60's again faces an anguished decision. His sister, 58 years old, has not been of normal mind for many months. Now, for the fifth or sixth time, she has smeared the walls of her home with feces. A neurologist has advised that she be admitted to high-quality nursing-home care, but the man is unable to bring himself to do that.

title: Sanding Floors: Prepare With Care
description: SANDING a wood floor before refinishing is not too difficult, but it is a dusty, noisy and time-consuming job.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: CONCORD, N.H.;
Transfer Tax Going Up 35%
description: LEAD: A 35 PERCENT rise in the state real estate transfer tax goes into effect next Saturday amid assertions by residential brokers that it may be ''the straw that breaks the camel's back'' for first-time home buyers.

title:
GARDENING;
An Assortment of Tasks for the Summer
description: LEAD: THE arrival of summer brings with it a diversity of gardening tasks that are essential to attaining satisfactory results with the lawn and flower or vegetable gardens.

title: Watch on the Roads: Quick Justice for Fast Cars
description: THE red Oldsmobile turned a curve on Route 8 at the north end of Bridgeport, and the driver saw the police car hidden in the brush. He braked so hard he nearly lost control of the car. But it is too late.

title: Dr. Ashley Is Wed To Dr. P. C. Sheils
description: Dr. Lucy Pope Ashley, who is to become a resident in pathology next month at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester, and Dr. Philip Charles Sheils, an ophthalmologist who plans to practice in Rochester, were married yesterday in Cooperstown, N.Y.

title: Whittingham Has 3 Chances
description: Charlie Whittingham, the trainer, has three chances at victory Sunday in the 50th running of the $500,000 Hollywood Gold Cup, the highlight of the summer season at Hollywood Park.

title:
DINING OUT;
Fine Fare, With Changes for the Better
description: LEAD: WHEN a highly rated restaurant changes hands, there is usually a certain amount of speculation about whether the changes under the new owner will be positive or negative. In the case of Le Delice in Whippany, which was made famous by its former owner, John Foy, most of the changes are positive. But the distinctive pink exterior of the old clapboard house that is Le Delice has remained the same, which at least makes it difficult to miss, perched as it is on the side of a main road leading from the

title: A Precarious Mission: Restitching a Torn China
description: In the brief televised image broadcast as he was elevated to the leadership of the Communist Party in China, Jiang Zemin looked a bit glum, his brow slightly furrowed. He may have been reflecting on a disquieting realization: the job he is assuming is a precarious one.

title: A Shoe Repairer Sees It All: Fear, Anxiety and Relief
description: ''YOU'VE got food addicts, you've got drug addicts, you've got shoe addicts - even if the shoe doesn't fit, they'll buy it.''

title: Nepal
description: To the Editor: I am the author of the book ''A Guide to Trekking in Nepal'' mentioned in Letters on Travel on April 9.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Concord, N.H.;
Transfer Tax Going Up 35%
description: LEAD: A 35 PERCENT rise in the state real estate transfer tax goes into effect next Saturday amid assertions by residential brokers that it may be ''the straw that breaks the camel's back'' for first-time home buyers.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: Since we can't expect the folks at camera sales counters to be any less hyperbolic than press releases, it's time I said a few words about what a ''point-and-shoot camera'' really is.

title: Courtroom Drama
description: It may have been the stuff movies are made of, but what about marriages? Aspiring actor meets ballerina during a summer stock season. The actor, William Hurt, becomes a star in ''The Big Chill.'' The dancer, Sandra Jennings, becomes the mother of their son. Last week, Mr. Hurt and Ms. Jennings were in a Manhattan courtroom arguing over their relationship. She could get half of his assets, said to be $7 million, if she can convince the judge that they had a common-law marriage. Mr. Hurt, who pays $65,000 a year in support for their son, now 6, said he had no intention of marriage. ''There are a lot of social issues involved here,'' said Ms. Jennings's lawyer.

title: In Hastings, Word Travels Fast on Village Youth Officer
description: IF a senior at Hastings High School received a new car as a graduation present last weekend, chances are Patrolman David M. Bloomer knew about it before Monday morning rolled around.

title: Katherine Veith Has a Wedding
description: Katherine Elizabeth Veith, a daughter of Mary Roth Veith of Pelham, N.Y., and Dr. Frank James Veith of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Harris Costantinos Vrachimis, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Costantinos C. Vrachimis of Nicosia, Cyprus. The Rev. Peter Kyriakos officiated at the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: FOCUS: Muskingum County, Ohio; From Strip Mine to African Game Preserve
description: EIGHT zoos are turning 9,000 acres of reclaimed strip-mine land in Muskingum County in southeastern Ohio into a preserve for African animals.

title: Mobile Missiles? A Waste
description: The public is being treated to a prime case of Washington self-contradiction. President Bush says he will consider dropping the ban on mobile missiles that the U.S. has proposed at the strategic arms talks if Congress agrees to fund two new mobile missiles.

title: Sweden's Tranquil Retreat
description: WALKING through Stockholm's Old Town one gray summer morning, I discovered a half-dozen Swedes standing transfixed and silent before a jeweler's locked and barred front door. Taped to the glass was a child's crayon drawing: seagulls and sun, bright sails on pale-green water, and a rose-laden island crowned by red-roofed towers. ''Rest till Gotland,'' read the careful printing below. ''We've gone to Gotland.''

title: Fireworks Law Sets Off Roadside Sales Frenzy
description: They come from all over the Northeast -clergymen, lawyers, brain surgeons and everyday people - and they pick excitedly through roadside tents and storefronts crammed with fireworks like Rebel Blaster, Crackling Delight and Flowers in Full Bloom.

title: Lauren Clark Wed to Michael Kenny>
description: The Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of two graduates of the College of the Holy Cross, Lauren Kennard Clark, a daughter of Richard McCourt Clark of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Diane P. Clark, and Michael Thomas Kenny, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen J. Kenny of North Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas Mulvanerty officiated.

title: Phoenix Prepares Its Second Season
description: ''PEOPLE said, 'You'll never do it.' Having done it, I then heard, 'That's it; you'll never do it again.' '' Such was the negativism that Bram Lewis recalls confronting as he established the new Phoenix Theater Company in Dobbs Ferry last summer. Now Mr. Lewis is trying to do it again.

title: Jill Bermingham Wed in Vermont
description: Jill Hinton Bermingham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eldredge Langstaff Bermingham of South Londonderry, Vt., was married yesterday at the Community Church in Landgrove, Vt., to Frank Robert Isenhart 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank R. Isenhart Jr. of Denver. The Rev. Roger Paine, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

title: West Hopeful of Soviet Response To Pakistan Plan for Afghanistan
description: Despite the Kremlin's silence about a Pakistani attempt to bring progress toward a political settlement to the Afghan war, Western diplomats say the Soviet circumspection may bode well in the long run.

title: Roaming the Shenandoah Valley
description: THE note taped to the door of the Inn at Narrow Passage told us that the proprietor and his wife had gone to do errands for an hour and that we were to make ourselves at home in Room 2.

title: Expert Witness
description: Testifying in Stockholm last week at the trial of the man accused of killing her husband, Lisbet Palme presented herself as an expert witness as well as an eyewitness. Mrs. Palme said she saw the defendant, Carl Gustav Christer Petterson, standing nearby as Prime Minister Olof Palme lay fatally wounded in the street on the night of Feb. 28, 1986. After Mrs. Palme said Mr. Petterson was still in view several minutes after her husband was shot, a defense lawyer asked if it was reasonable behavior for a murder suspect to linger in plain sight at the scene of the crime. Mrs. Palme, a child psychologist who repeatedly digressed to cite her professional training, replied: ''No it is not. But he is not a normal man.''

title:
Art;
Larger-Than-Life Folk Art
description: LEAD: ELECTRA HAVEMEYER WEBB (1888-1960), whose father was a sugar baron, was raised in the Gilded Age of one of the most important collections of American art. Yet, when she was 18 years old, she spent $15 on a wooden cigar store Indian she had spotted in Stamford. That first purchase was the beginning of a passion that led to the founding of the Shelburne Museum in Shelburne,

title: Sowell to Run
description: THE sprinter Dawn Sowell was the first woman to enter the July 22 New York Games at Columbia University the meet's executive director, Fred Lebow, said yesterday. She will join the six-time Olympic gold-medal winner Carl Lewis, who is the only man entered so far in the international track and field meet. Sowell set collegiate records of 10.78 seconds for the 100 meters and 22.04 for the 200. Her 100-meter clocking at this month's National Collegiate Athletic Association championships in Provo, Utah, was the third-fastest women's time ever in the event. Only Florence Griffith Joyner, the world-record holder, and Evelyn Ashford have run faster.

title: 114 Hudson St.
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of Jail, Ex-Legislator Turns to Art
description: About halfway between New Rochelle and Albany, a former State Senator, Joseph R. Pisani, lives in a log home here, painting scenes from the beautiful Catskill Mountains all around him.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Body as Bad Art

title: Debate on Aiding Gifted Disabled Pupils
description: TWO years have passed since school officials in Bloomfield sought to place a student with a learning disability and an intelligence quotient of more than 130 in a school geared to students with below-average intelligence, but the anguish of that time is still fresh for his parents.

title: A Time for Bargains in Co-op Insurance
description: IF you own a co-op or condominium unit, now is the time to re-examine your insurance policy. Thanks to a highly competitive insurance market, today you can buy broader coverage than ever before, often at no increase in cost. And if you are a board member buying for a co-op or condo association, you can get more coverage for much less than a year ago.

title: A Child's Tour of Duty
description: WHEN HEAVEN AND EARTH CHANGED PLACES A Vietnamese Woman's Journey From War to Peace. By Le Ly Hayslip with Jay Wurts. 368 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

title: In Jungle at Thai-Burmese Border, Last Stand for Student Protesters
description: Hailed as fighters for democracy last September when they fled the Burmese military crackdown to train with insurgents along the borders, the students who remain in this unforgiving jungle near the Thai border have too little to eat and not enough medicine to treat the endemic malaria. Worse yet, there is nowhere else to go. Events last August and September in Myanmar, formerly Burma, were similar to those in China: student-led demonstrations for democracy were crushed by soldiers shooting indiscriminately into crowds of unarmed civilians. Western diplomats say at least 3,000 Burmese died at the hands of the military.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
Pizza for Purists From Naples Ovens
description: LEAD: IN Naples, in a quiet side street off the bustling Corso Umberto I, a small, rather nondescript pizzeria marks the edge of the popular quarter called Forcella. Travelers, distracted by the brighter lights of other restaurants down the road, would hardly notice the pizzeria if they happened in this area by chance.

title: What Argentina Must Sacrifice to an Economy Gone Mad
description: THE newly elected president of Argentina faces the awesome task of restoring confidence to an economy in which prices are increasing at an annual rate of 400,000 percent.

title: WHY MOW?
description: It is indeed a futile struggle to contain nature. I spent three hours mowing and trimming last weekend, but after three days of midweek rain, my yard looked ready to go to seed. Yet, I managed to plod out to the barn and crank up the mower. As a hay field, my yard might look pretty, but the insects, woodchucks and snakes that would stake their claim would make my family's life miserable.

title: Washington's Hard Line on Trade
description: After less than two months on the job, S. Linn Williams, the Deputy United States Trade Representative and the person chiefly responsible for trade relations with Japan, has walked into a maelstrom.

title: Expos' Gross Throws Shutout and Sparks Rally
description: Kevin Gross pitched a three-hitter and drove in a run to spark a five-run fifth inning as the Montreal Expos beat the Chicago Cubs, 5-0, today.

title: A Halston Show Without Halston
description: The invitations were neatly printed on ecru cards embossed with the name Halston. Soon after 3 P.M. on Tuesday, the Halston made-to-order fall and winter collection was presented in the Halston salon on the 21st floor of Olympic Tower, 641 Fifth Avenue at 51st Street.

title: Elizabeth L. Kaplan Weds Todd Harmon
description: Elizabeth Lynn Kaplan and Todd Daniel Harmon were married last evening at the home of the bride's maternal grandmother, Ronne Wohl Wulwick, in Old Westbury, L.I., by Rabbi Saul I. Teplitz. The bride is a daughter of Stuart A. Kaplan of Huntington Station, L.I., and Mrs. Michael L. Greenberg of Lawrence, L.I. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall E. Harmon of Marblehead, Mass.

title: Should Ben Johnson Be Allowed to Run Again?
description: Of course, the final verdict isn't in on steroids yet. Perhaps they're just super vitamins. If he'd used cocaine or heroin, he'd go to drug rehab, write his autobiography, tout it on the talk-show circuit and be welcomed back. Runners wear sweatbands, not halos. Who among athletes is a paragon of perfect deportment? JOAN MARY MACEY Binghamton, N.Y.

title: Mary McFadden Is Married
description: Mary McFadden, the fashion designer, and Kohle Yohannan, a design associate in her company in New York, were married June 14 in Corona, Calif. The nondenominational ceremony was performed by the Rev. Valerie I. Ross of the Ministry of Salvation at the Main Street Gardens.

title: How the Old Yankees Did It
description: WHEN Rickey Henderson was sent back home to Oakland last week, much was made of how Willie Randolph, the former co-captain, had often been the only Yankee who could prod Rickey into playing harder.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Montana State; When 'Finals' Means Rodeo And U.S. Titles
description: Ty Murray has already won tens of thousands of dollars on the professional rodeo circuit this year. But last weekend, when the field house at Montana State University here was transformed from a 10,000-seat basketball arena into a red, white and blue rodeo arena, the loot couldn't compare with the shiny belt buckles that proclaimed Mr. Murray college rodeo's top all-around cowboy.

title: Celeste Penney Wed to Tyler Benson
description: The marriage of Celeste Penney, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John S. Penney Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., to Tyler Preston Benson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Benson of North Haven, Conn., took place yesterday at Christ Church in Short Hills. The Rev. David B. Earnest, the rector of the Episcopal church, and Msgr. Harrold A. Murray, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Benson, until recently the assistant operations manager at Kidder, Peabody & Company in Boston, is a graduate of Kenyon College. Her father, who is retired, was the director of real estate for the Warner-Lambert pharmaceutical company in Morris Plains, N.J. Her mother, Celeste S. Penney, is chairman of the New Jersey State Council on the Arts.

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: JOHN ADAMS KANAS;
A Banker Who Balances Development With Open Space
description: LEAD: CALLING him the man who saved Robins Island would be giving too much credit to John Adam Kanas, president of North Fork Bancorp.

title: ''There's Potential for Exploitation'
description: OFFICE romances are not always the forbidden trysts that novels and movies make them out to be, according to Lisa A. Mainiero, who has written a book on the subject after four years of research. Sometimes, she says, they are well-matched, healthy relationships. But bad or good, ''almost everybody knows or has been involved in an office romance, and they're dying to talk about them,'' she said. ''They are the ultimate gossip.''

title: Deadline Near on $500 Million New Jersey Gap
description: With a week to go before the new fiscal year, no one in the New Jersey Legislature or Gov. Thomas H. Kean's office knows exactly how a $500 million gap in the proposed $12.1 billion budget will be closed.

title: A 'Goldberg' by Any Other Instrument . . .
description: IF AN EARLY BACH BIOGRAPHER, Johann Forkel, is to be believed - and his tale has become an indestructible part of musical legend - Bach composed his ''Goldberg'' Variations on a theme of a young court harpsichordist, Johann Gottlieb Goldberg. Goldberg was often asked to tinkle his keyboard discreetly in an adjacent room to help overcome the insomnia of Count Hermann Carl von Kaiserling, the Russian ambassador to the Saxon court. Bach, appointed court composer in 1736, was asked for similar music to be used for the same purpose, and responded with a set of 30 variations on a theme of Goldberg's that appears at the beginning and the end.

title: Baseball Betting: How It's Done
description: While nationwide betting on professional baseball has declined over the last 20 years because of the increasing popularity of wagering on football and basketball, it continues to command an estimated 10 to 20 percent of the sports-betting market.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
For Glowing Colors All Summer Long
description: LEAD: Throughout the spring, most gardens are a riot of color. Nothing equals the vibrant hues of the spring-flowering shrubs. By the time the blooms have faded from the last rhododendron and azalea in mid- to late June, many gardeners must rely on annuals and perennials to produce color for the summer.

title: Israel
description: To the Editor: The article on visiting Israel was fair, yet might not convince one to go to Israel.

title: Israel
description: To the Editor: I am writing this in a cafe in Jerusalem after reading ''Assessing the Risks of Visiting Israel'' (Travel, May 7) and watching my kids sip lemonade. I shake my head in wonder. What a difference between what I see in Israel and what many in America believe.

title: Feverish and Futile
description: To the Editor:

title: David Johnson and Grace N. Kooper,Medical Student, Wed in Rhode Island
description: Grace Natalie Kooper, the daughter of Justice Sybil Hart Kooper of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, and David Dean Johnson, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Burton L. Johnson of Tacoma, Wash., were married in Providence, R.I., yesterday at Manning Chapel at Brown University. Justice Florence K. Murray of the Rhode Island Supreme Court officiated.

title: Taxpayers Beware
description: To the Editor:

title: Sinking Funds
description: The Pentagon's Inspector General says the Navy has sent $17 million worth of usable goods to the bottom of the sea on board two dozen surplus ships. Another 64 ships are headed for the deep with salvageable equipment, gear and materials - even some gold and silver - worth $40 million, he estimates.

title: Judith Margolis Becomes Bride
description: At the Bonnie Briar Country Club in Larchmont, N.Y., Judith M. Margolis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Margolis of McLean, Va., was married last evening to Robert S. Herbst, the son of Daniel L. Herbst of Larchmont and Pat Swartz of White Plains. Judge Edwin Margolis of the State Court of Claims, an uncle of the bride, and Rabbi Hershel Portnoy officiated.

title: W. S. Cowles Wed To Anne Cannon
description: Anne Boden Cannon, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Paul J. Cannon of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to William Stacey Cowles, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Cowles 3d of Spokane, Wash., at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York. The Rev. Stan Moseley and Dr. Jonathan A. Holloway, a deacon at St. John's Episcopal Cathedral in Spokane, officiated.

title: Calling Off The Fight for Angola
description: IN accepting a cease-fire last week after more than a decade of combat in southern Africa, Jonas Savimbi, the Angolan guerrilla leader, said, ''I was not born to make war at all cost.''

title: 31 Die in Brazil Road Cave-In
description: At least 31 people died today and 50 were seriously injured when a rural highway caved in and two crowded buses tumbled into a 100-foot hole, rescue officials said. The accident occurred near the town of Estancia, about 1,150 miles northeast of Rio de Janeiro.

title: Designed for Other Purposes
description: TESTAMENT The Bible and History. By John Romer. Illustrated. 367 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company.

title: 'Write Till You Drop'
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Cushing Wed in R.I.
description: Mary Ames Cushing, a daughter of Mrs. John P. Jennings of Mill Neck, L.I., and Howard G. Cushing Jr. of Newport, R.I., was married yesterday to James A. Tollefson, a son of Mrs. John J. Egan Jr. of Newport and the late Dr. George A. Tollefson. The Rev. John S. Rogers, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at St. George's School Chapel in Newport.

title: France's Revolution, Staged for a Multimedia Age
description: Louis XVI, learning the Bastille has been taken by the people:

title: Israel
description: To the Editor: I visited Israel in August 1988 with my wife, three children and my mother. Both Arabs and Israelis were courteous to us in Jerusalem, the West Bank and throughout Israel. We visited Bethlehem, Jericho, the Dead Sea, Old Jerusalem and the Golan Heights without a single problem. The Arabs I met treated us cordially. When my wife and mother were shopping in an Arab stall in Jerusalem and my children were playing card tricks, an Arab took the cards from them and started playing tricks with them.

title: After Death, A Grandmother Stays in Touch
description: I'M cooking dinner. It's April. The smell of earth is strong through the window. The sun sets and I am chilled by the coldness of the dark and the quiet in the house.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Slain After Finding Swastika
description: A 60-year-old Jewish man who found a swastika painted on the door of his room in a Brooklyn boarding house was stabbed to death yesterday after attacking the man he believed was responsible for the vandalism, the police said.

title: Scientists Differ on Spill, but They Contrast It With Alaska's
description: Government scientists sampling the oil-polluted water around Narragansett Bay this morning differed on how serious the spill from the World Prodigy was likely to be. But they were quick to draw distinctions between the spill here, of a refined oil product used for home heating and diesel fuel, and the Exxon Valdez spill of crude oil, which is much thicker, in Alaska three months ago.

title: Sorrel's Popularity Is on the Upswing
description: SORREL has had an uneven reputation in America. Its swings in popularity have probably been due to the fact that it is sour (it is also known as sour grass) and Americans like sweet things. But in France it has always been loved and now Americans are rediscovering its virtues. It is used with eggs, fish like shad, mackerel and salmon and as a sauce for veal, lamb or chicken. It has a tartness, a sharp lemony flavor and velvety texture that make it superb for sauces - and an excellent foil for rich or oily foods.

title: An English Recording Tradition Continues to Be Observed
description: BRITISH RECORD COMpanies, especially many of the smaller ones, take admirable pride in their native music; the pages of Gramophone magazine are always dotted with announcements of cycles of recordings of this or that British composer. In this tradition, one of the largest record companies, London (called Decca in Britain), has issued a clutch of midpriced compact disks, remastered from analog recordings, and bearing the series title the British Collection. The performances range from 1968 to 1980 and are beautifully recorded.

title: Why Design Can't Transform Cities
description: NEW YORK HAS ALWAYSJU been a city in which richness and poverty shared turf, but never so dramatically as now. The city's great monuments, from Grand Central Terminal to Grant's Tomb, house homeless people; so do the terraces of Central Park and the entryways of churches. It is so common to see vagrants on the sidewalk that few people pause any longer to notice them; they have become part of the landscape, like street lamps and park benches. When one adds to this the tragedy of the AIDS epidemic and the violence spawned by crack, it adds up to a situation in which human anguish is surely more visible on the streets of New York than ever before.

title: The D-RAM Consortium
description: On Wednesday, seven semiconductor and computer companies announced that they will finance the creation of a company to mass produce memory chips - the most commonly used chips. The company, U.S. Memories Inc., will make dynamic random access memory chips, or D-RAM's, using technology from International Business Machines, which only makes the chips for its own use. There are only three other big American manufacturers of D-RAM's competing in a Japanese-dominated market: Texas Instruments, Micron Technology and Motorola. U.S. Memories will be headed by Sanford L. Kane, a former I.B.M. executive. Four experts assess the new company. T. J. Rodgers President and chief executive, Cypress Semiconductor Corp.

title: Invisible 'Harvey': No Mirage
description: HOW would you respond if you were walking down the street and a six-foot-tall rabbit leaning against a lamppost wanted to start up a conversation?

title: POSTINGS: 8-Home Complex; Field & Stream
description: There was some heavy skirmishing in the Westchester Town of Yorktown during the Revolutionary War, and French troops under General Rochambeau were encamped there at one point to support the Colonials in case an assault on New York City became necessary. But General Washington, who slept in other nearby communities, never slept there. Some residents take a perverse pride in that nonevent, and in somewhat the same way, Robert Gross, developer of a home complex there, acknowledges that diligent research turns up no battles on his 40-acre site in Yorktown Heights.

title: Myanmar and the River of Time
description: American schoolchildren often show abysmal ignorance of geography. But even their elders may be hard pressed to name the capital of the Union of Myanmar. The answer, as of last week, is Yangon.

title: From Britain, Soul Across a Time Warp
description: American record companies have suddenly discovered black soul music from Great Britain. Although a handful of black British soul performers have emerged throughout the 80's, notably Five Star and Junior, recent months have brought a spate of releases.

title: Injuries Don't Faze Reds but Rose Case May Be Taking a Toll
description: AS a player, Pete Rose set so many major league and National League records he might hold the record for holding the most records. He is in jeopardy, however, of squandering a chance to set his first record as a manager.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Festival Finale

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
Russia's Fabulous Years
description: LEAD: Leonid Andreyev (1871-1919), Russia's pre-eminent Expressionist writer and playwright (''The Red Laugh,'' ''The Seven Who Were Hanged,'' ''He Who Gets Slapped'') enjoyed great popularity during his life, and again after Khrushchev. He worked during '' 'the fabulous years,' when Russia seemed on the verge of joining the community of European countries and becoming safely Westernized while retaining its Slavic identity.

title: William J. Catlett Jr., Rear Admiral, 80
description: Rear Adm. William Jackson Catlett Jr., retired, died of cancer Friday at Beaufort (S.C.) Naval Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Beaufort.

title: Parents in the Armed Forces Face a Shortage of Child Care
description: While the Pentagon has been claiming success in integrating women into the armed forces, families in the ranks have been facing a crisis in child care.

title: Corrections
description: A television review on Wednesday about ''Firing Line'' characterized the sales of the last few books by William F. Buckley Jr. incorrectly. His latest novel, ''Mongoose R.I.P.'' (Random House, 1988), was on the best-seller list of The New York Times eight weeks.

title: To Be Sons and Daughters of China's Elite Can Pay Well Indeed
description: To the Editor:

title: The Old-Fashioned Critic That Never Was
description: LEAD: THE PLEASURES OF READING In an Ideological Age. By Robert Alter. 250 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: South African Possibilities
description: The new Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, Herman J. Cohen, believes there is ''new thinking on both sides'' of the white-black deadlock in South Africa. He sees a chance for a process of real political change to begin, and he thinks the United States can effectively encourage it.

title: Diane Zambrano Is Wed
description: Diane Ruth Zambrano and Dr. Wei Hua Kuo were married yesterday at the chapel of St. Mary's College in Orchard Lake, Mich., by the Rev. Michael R. Dylag, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride, a daughter of Frances Zambrano of Sterling, Ill., and the late Alfred J. Zambrano, is an instructor at the Art of Dance School in Chester, N.J. The bridegroom, the son of Linda Lu of Green Brook, N.J., and Dr. Richard Kuo of San Jose, Calif., is a resident in psychiatry at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Piscataway.

title: Susanne B. Beck, Banker, Is Bride
description: Susanne Boulton Beck and George Willing Pepper were married yesterday in Kennebunkport, Me. The Rev. Laman H. Bruner Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Ann's Episcopal Church.

title: The Outdoor Concerts Are Getting Under Way
description: SEVERAL outdoor concerts get under way this week, including the Cultural Heritage Celebrations, a yearly gift from the county's Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation.

title: Laura E. Call Wed To R. C. Andolina
description: The marriage of Laura Ellen Call, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Call of Ithaca, N.Y., to Robert Charles Andolina, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony V. Andolina of Clifton Park, N.Y., took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Ithaca. The Revs. Daniel Little, a Presbyterian minister, and Richard Fragomeni, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: Professor Has a Passion For the Merritt Parkway
description: AFTER laboring in patches of poison ivy and the archives of the Connecticut Department of Transportation, Bruce Radde has essentially completed his book on what he calls ''the world's largest example of Art Deco design'' - the Merritt Parkway.

title: 'Amazing Grace': How English the Sound
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Progress, Is It?
description: IT'S not that I'm against progress. I was definitely exposed to it when I was growing up. My parents bought an electric toaster to replace the four-sided metal rack that toasted bread on the stovetop burner, and the iron I finally learned to use without inflicting damage on myself or my clothing was attached to an electric cord.

title: Nothing to Fear From a Czar
description: To the Editor:

title: The Face on the Back of the Book
description: LEAD: FOR Danielle Steel, the joy of finishing a novel is tempered by the knowledge that she'll have to get dressed up and made up, then submit yet again to the hours of posing necessary to produce the perfect book-jacket photograph.

title: Ex-Klansman Sentenced to Life in Murder
description: A state court judge sentenced a former Ku Klux Klansman Friday to life in prison for the 1981 beating and hanging death of a black teen-ager.

title: Review/Theater; Angst and Romance in 4 One-Acters
description: Humor is the dominant mood of four plays making up the Working Theater's ''Working One-Acts '89'' at the Henry Street Settlement Arts for Living Center - even though two of the four take slightly sinister turns. Modern urban anxiety is the theme of three; the fourth, a nice tonic at the end of the program, is about romantic shenanigans in the Cumberland Mountains long ago when life was simpler but by no means more innocent.

title: 2 Top Leaders Whose Status Is Unchanged
description: Senior leaders like Deng Xiaoping and Yang Shangkun are not members of the Standing Committee of the Politburo, but they sometimes attend meetings and their opinions usually prevail. Deng Xiaoping

title: Death Is Just the Beginning
description: UNNATURAL DEATH Confessions of a Medical Examiner. By Michael M. Baden with Judith Adler Hennessee. 209 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: Burroughs Steps Into Tour Spotlight
description: Every few weeks on the PGA Tour, a relatively unknown golfer bursts into the lead at a tournament. The ones who don't lose their cools on Sunday get that initial victory, the most difficult thing to achieve on tour. Some fall back and may wait a long time before getting another chance to win.

title: What Might Be Done To Cut Losses for New York's Hospitals
description: NEW YORK'S public and private hospitals, which last week reported combined operating losses of more than $1 billion, are clearly in crisis. The troubles are deepest in New York City, where homelessness, drug addiction, mental illness and AIDS strain institutions suffering from acute labor shortages. But hospitals across the state are also overcrowded, struggling with shortages of workers and an aging population that requires more care.

title: The Shabby Man in the Street
description: WE were on our way to Jody's dancing lesson, and we were late. A million errands were waiting to be done. At a stop sign, we noticed an old, bearded, shabbily dressed man. He staggered and stumbled as he walked.

title: WHY MOW?
description: For a truly natural lawn, Michael Pollan shoud turn in his mower and get himself a sheep. WALTER WATSON Stony Brook, L.I.

title: Corrections
description: An article last week about Venture magazine misstated Neil R. Goldhirsh's relationship to Inc. magazine. Mr. Goldhirsh joined Inc. in 1980, the year after it was established. He was not a founder. The article also referred incorrectly to the status of Venture's editor. He was dismissed last week, not the week before.

title: A Fifth Gold For Canoeist
description: JON LUGBILL tamed the river again yesterday. At the world whitewater championships, the 28-year-old environmental scientist from Bethesda, Md., won a record fifth gold medal with two powerful, controlled runs down a roaring river in the men's canoe slalom competition.

title: List Shows Link of U.S. Weapons To Banned Semiautomatic Imports
description: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady has told a House subcommittee that 17 makes of domestically produced semiautomatic assault weapons have the same characteristics as weapons subject to a temporary ban imposed earlier this year on imported semiautomatics.

title: Leslie F. MoffatBecomes Bride Of Gary R. Little
description: Leslie Frances Moffat, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Keith M. Moffat of New York and Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Gary Robert Little, the son of Mrs. Frank Little of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Little. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor.

title: The Image Polishers Go Global
description: MULTINATIONAL. Global. Pan-European. They are the buzzwords of the 1980's, words that have joined ''leading, largest, oldest and best'' on the list of adjectives that public relations executives labor mightily to get attached to their clients' names in the public's mind.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Pull out pea vines and plant beans in the row; plant another half-row of chard to prolong the harvest. Pick cherry tomatoes just before use in the salad for best flavor. Pinch off terminal growth of 'mums again to make them branch. Keep up with weeding. Keep up with blueberry, raspberry, cherry harvests. Propagation

title: Wimbledon: Noises In the Cathedral
description: WIMBLEDON, which begins tomorrow, is one of the many mirrors held up, not so much to nature as to the changing ways of society. What used to be a practically religious atmosphere has given way to a raucous cacophony of mingled high spirits and childishness. The money lenders are well and truly established in the temple. There is no way back. I say this with no particular regret. Sportsmen the world over have become professional, and demand remuneration to match their talents. Their active life is so short that their wishes command respect. There is no reason, in the world in which we live, why they should not take the money they can while their ephemeral powers last, and before they half-retire into fringe activities such as being club secretaries, sporting goods retailers, commentators, journalists and the like.

title: Restructuring Civil Rights, Restructuring Democracy; Locked Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Who Were Warmed By the City of Light
description: WE ALL KNOW ABOUT THE glory days of Parisian art between the wars and immediately after World War II when all roads seemed to lead to the City of Light and artists from throughout the world huddled together in cafes, pounded the streets and made art with a radiance that no other city could equal.

title: Covens and Chaos Groups
description: PERSUASIONS OF THE WITCH'S CRAFT Ritual Magic in Contemporary England. By T. M. Luhrmann. Illustrated. 382 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25.

title: How Peter Martins Is Personalizing The City Ballet
description: YOU DON'T NEED A WEATHER-vane to feel the fresh breeze blowing through the New York City Ballet. The troupe ends another outstandingly danced season at Lincoln Center tonight. And with ''Echo,'' a major premiere, Peter Martins has proclaimed his coming of age as a top-ranking choreographer.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Family Tradition GARY Baldinger loves the beach. He loves the beach so much - especially Tobay, the oceanfront beach owned by the Town of Oyster Bay - that he is in his ninth year of being a lifeguard there. What, you may ask, is so special about that? Well, Mr. Baldinger has another profession that takes a great deal of his time. He is a professional football player, a defensive lineman for the Atlanta Falcons. When he could be taking the summer off, relaxing before training camp starts in August, the Massapequa resident is busy rescuing people from the Atlantic surf. ''There's nowhere else I'd rather be on a summer weekend,'' he said. Being a lifeguard and playing professional football is a Baldinger family tradition. There are three Baldinger brothers; all are professional football players and all have been Tobay lifeguards during the off season.

title: Symposium to Address Arts Role in Education
description: LEAD: THE role of the arts in education will form the basis of a conference on July 6 at Livingston College of Rutgers University.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Voluntary Medicare Insurance to Be Considered
description: Bowing to complaints by elderly Americans, Senator Lloyd Bentsen opened the door today to allowing them to drop out of a new program aimed at insuring against the costs of prolonged major illness.

title: The Center Cannot Hold
description: TWO central problems retarding the healthy development of American society in the 1980's - the decline in education and the rise in drug abuse - sprung from the culture of the late 60's. Not coincidentally, it was also a time when the nuclear family lost its structure, and its component parts - children - lost their orbit. To paraphrase Yeats, the center no longer held.

title: Bonanza for Whale Watchers
description: WHALE watching cruises out of Gloucester, Mass., have been unusually rewarding this season with an average of 20 of the animals being sighted on each excursion.

title: Yankees Survive LaPoint's Tailspin
description: The way the night was moving along, it should have been as routine a victory as Dave LaPoint has ever earned. But nothing has come easily for the left-hander this season, and so a victory that belonged to the Yankees did not belong to LaPoint.

title: Remember to Pack Peanut Butter
description: AIR travel with children requires careful planning. You pack enough clothing to account for every spilled soda. Medication to cure everything from upset stomachs to unsightly rashes is tucked in the carry-on bag. Age-appropriate bribes from pacifiers to comic books are at hand.

title: Finding New Niches in the Travel Market
description: WHEN the United States Military Academy Class of 1949 held its 40th reunion last month, 400 officers and former officers and their wives celebrated the event not on land, but at sea.

title: Houston Ship Channel Collision Pours Crude Into Galveston Bay
description: The Coast Guard said today that as much as 6,000 barrels of oil had poured into Galveston Bay Friday night after a barge and a small freighter collided at the mouth of the Houston Ship Channel.

title: At Least 5,000 in Hong Kong March to Protest Crackdown
description: At least 5,000 people rallied and marched to the unofficial Chinese embassy today to deliver a petition protesting the crackdown on dissent in China.

title: 'Realism' In an Art Show
description: Rather than criticizing the work of the North Shore Watercolor Society or comparing it to the other work in the art show now at Gallery North in Setauket, perhaps it would have been more appropriate for Helen Harrison [ ''Mind's Eye as Creator,'' June 4 ] to question its being there in the first place.

title: River Not Yet Clean, but It's Fireproof
description: The good news about the Cuyahoga River, which became a symbol of urban pollution when it caught fire two decades ago, is that the river is no longer flammable.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: IT'S ALWAYS SOMETHING. By Gilda Radner. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Gilda Radner, who died of cancer May 20 at the age of 42, yearned to close her cathartic memoir with the words ''and she gets well.'' But she writes that the discovery a year ago of new sites from the ovarian cancer first diagnosed in 1986, on the heels of national publicity about her supposed cure, forced her instead to face cancer's treacherous realities for the first time. The spirited star of ''Saturday Night Live'' has laid out all the horrors of surgery and chemotherapy, but there are also lighter moments, like her 1984 marriage to the actor Gene Wilder; reminiscences from her childhood and career; and sappy stories about the dog who fulfilled her painfully thwarted maternal instinct. Radner, who knew herself well, has commented insightfully about how the performer's need for control conflicted with what a friend calls the ''delicious ambiguity'' of living with cancer. Though rich in friends, loved ones and paid helpers, she found the support group called the Wellness Community her most effective prop, and an outlet for her comedic talents. ''Cancer, I decided, needed a comedienne to come in there and lighten it up.'' There were joyful moments even during the period, after the recurrence, when she turned to alternative therapies, but her final pages are deeply somber, the sense of doom palpable. Though slow, meandering, detailed to a fault and sometimes marred by forced humor, ''It's Always Something'' is compelling as testimony from the cancer wars by a courageous and much-loved entertainer who liked herself enough to share her suffering in her own style.

title: Bottom Banana
description: Have you ever seen anyone actually step, slip and fall on a banana peel? A woman was hurrying down Broadway in the 90's Wednesday when other pedestrians saw her suddenly fall to her knees. Staring at the banana peel, she refused a hand from a passer-by, who understood her to mutter as she got up, ''Classic.''

title: Suffolk Challenged On Aid Cuts
description: LEAD: WHEN a homeless man asleep in a box was run over by a truck in the parking lot of a Bay Shore shopping center earlier this month, his death briefly called attention to the need to address the growing problem of homelessness on Long Island.

title: Israelis Seek 3 Palestinians Who Held American in Gaza
description: Israelis searched today for three Palestinians who abducted an American citizen and held him hostage for 29 hours in the Gaza Strip on Thursday and Friday.

title: An Urbane Technocrat: Jiang Zemin
description: Two months ago, as the democracy movement was beginning to grow, people were speculating that Jiang Zemin, the Communist Party leader in Shanghai, was so unpopular that he might be dismissed.

title: Hibari Misora, Japanese Singer, 52
description: Hibari Misora, known as ''the queen'' of Japanese singers, died of heart failure today after a long illness. She was 52 years old.

title: Chicago Theater Troupe in London Debut
description: The Steppenwolf Theater Company of Chicago received mostly warm reviews from London critics today about the European premiere of its stage adaptation of ''The Grapes of Wrath.''

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: Most miners going to the California gold fields in 1849 and 1850 took very little with them. Poor men, drawn by the allure of quick riches, they spent their money on picks, shovels, clothes and food. These items were in short supply in the gold fields and commanded a premium price.

title: Student Lawyers Are on Front Line Against AIDS Bias
description: When Laurel Fletcher's brother, Jack Townsend, died of AIDS a year and a half ago, she was in the middle of her first semester at Harvard Law School. Now Ms. Fletcher is one of a handful of Boston law students who provide free legal aid to clients battling many of the same legal issues her brother faced and fighting the same disease that killed him.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Brick $243,000 681 Rolling Hills Court 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old ranch; fireplace, deck, Florida room; taxes $3,600. Freehold $142,000 32 Yard Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 28-year-old colonial; w/w carpeting, fireplace, sun room; taxes $1,412. Marlboro $285,000 16 McCue Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old Cape Cod; new kitchen, full basement, h/w floors; taxes $4,431. Rahway $135,000 436 Hardwood Avenue 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 41-year-old split level; deck, family room, basement; taxes $2,739. Union $177,000 364 Tucker Avenue 6-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old Cape Cod; landscaped yard, w/w carpeting, deck; taxes $2,393. Westwood $201,000 26 Westervelt Place 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 36-year-old split level; patio, eat-in kitchen, new gas furnace; taxes $2,560. OTHER AREAS Rye, N.Y. $405,000 11 Fieldstone Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 39-year-old ranch; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, porch, 2-car garage; taxes $5,666. New Milford, Conn. $135,000 39 Wellsville Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 7-year-old Cape Cod; expandable second floor, close to town; taxes $1,196. North Patchogue, L.I. $124,000 414 West Woodside Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, half acre; taxes $2,000.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
The Manor Life Still Sells in Westchester
description: LEAD: DESPITE the uncertainties of the real estate market, developers in Westchester County are moving ahead with plans for estate living, offering finished homes, as well as building lots, with price tags rising above $1 million.

title: Is There Anything Worse Than a Man?
description: DANGER By D. Cymbalista. 209 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: Digital Speakers Make Their Debut
description: RIGHT IN THE MIDDLE of the Consumer Electronics Show, the great audio and video trade fair held early this month in Chicago, I found myself reminded of market day in the Slovak village where, long ago, I spent several childhood summers.

title: An Opera That Mixes the Comic and Serious
description: EAST WILL MEET WEST THISJU summer in Santa Fe, N.M., and with a timeliness that Judith Weir hadn't counted on. ''A Night at the Chinese Opera,'' the young Scottish composer's much-acclaimed new music drama, is among the productions planned this summer by the Santa Fe Opera. And its 13th-century story -''of someone,'' says Ms. Weir, ''who grows up in a country which suddenly falls under military dominance'' - has been thrown into dramatic relief by recent weeks' developments in the same country.

title:
MIDDLETOWN TOWNSHIP JOURNAL;
Neighbors Oppose Plan for Power Lines Along Railway
description: LEAD: BARBARA IANNUCCI was reading her local paper one night last March when a small item about the previous night's Township Committee meeting caught her eye. ''It was something about Middletown opposes rail route,'' she recalled. ''Most people skimmed over it. I read it because it was midnight and I needed to wind down.

title: ARGENTINA FACES NEW ARMY CRISIS
description: A new military crisis threatens Argentina as the nation moves toward the July 8 inauguration of President-elect Carlos Saul Menem.

title: Ad Executives Leave It All Behind
description: FROM a muddy hillside in Union, by seven burnings kilns, Matthew J. McNerney and Mark E. Greene earn their livelihood. They make charcoal, the kind that people use for backyard cookouts and industries use as filters.

title: Northwest Air Picks a Buyer
description: Northwest Airlines accepted a $3.64 billion offer from a group organized by Alfred Checchi, a 41-year-old Los Angeles businessman. The bidding group includes KLM Royal Dutch Airlines and the Elders beer company of Australia. Mr. Checchi said the Elders investment was passive but KLM would try to link its European routes and Northwest's service to Asia. The Checchi offer, which relies heavily on bank debt, is for $121 a share. Within the last year, NWA shares had traded as low as $42.

title: Kelly Good Wed To Peter McGee
description: Kelly Good and Peter B. McGee were married yesterday at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys performed the ceremony.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; Woodstock: A Colorful Past, a Lively Present
description: This village, nestled on the edge of the Catskills, is a place with a past, but it lives very much in the present. The rock festival that made its name famous around the world in August 1969 was actually held in Bethel, some 50 miles away, but no matter. Stores in Woodstock are selling as many T-shirts that say only ''Remember Woodstock: Three Days of Love, Peace and Music'' as those that point out that Bethel was where it was. The historic concert, held in heat, rain and mud, became a symbol of the 60's.

title: Whitman Lilley, a Medical Student,Marries John E. Reardon, a Scientist
description: Whitman Elisa Lilley and John Eric Reardon were married yesterday at St. Mary's by-the-Sea Church in Northeast Harbor, Me., by the Rev. Paul Gilbert, an Episcopal priest. The bride is a daughter of William Lilley 3d and Beverly Knight Sullivan, both of Washington. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. Thomas R. Reardon of Portland, Ore., and Janice Ellen Zavodsky of Vancouver, Wash.

title: Victors in the Struggle Among China's Leaders
description: The Standing Committee of the Politburo is the most powerful body in the Chinese Communist Party. It previously had five members, but now will have six. Its meetings will be presided over by Mr. Jiang. Li Peng

title: STREETSCAPES: 130 East 64th Street; The Mystery of Stone's Grille
description: The Streetscapes article on June 25 misidentified the second of three wives of the late Edward Durrell Stone. She is Maria Stone, who owns the town house at 130 East 64th Street and is the mother of Hicks Stone. Violet Campbell Stone is Edward Durrell Stone's widow.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. The exterior of our 30-year-old house is covered with cedar shakes. They have never been stained or cleaned, and now are in shades ranging from dark brown to black. Painters have recommended everything from power washing, stain and paint to a clear preservative. What do you advise?

title: Making Little Citizens
description: PRESCHOOL IN THREE CULTURES Japan, China and the United States. By Joseph J. Tobin, David Y. H. Wu and Dana H. Davidson. Illustrated. 238 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $26.95.

title: For Housing Foes In Yonkers, a Setback
description: THE continuing effort by four Yonkers Councilmen to challenge a court-ordered housing-desegregation plan suffered a major setback last week when Peter A. Chema, one of the four, broke ranks to delay action on a bid to challenge the plan's legitimacy.

title: All the World Stands Ready To Turn Away The Boat People
description: TEN years ago, the world's leading nations met in Geneva to open the doors of asylum for the flow of boat people from Vietnam. This month, a second meeting was held because these nations now think the exodus has gone on for too long, and they want to close the gates.

title: N.B.A. First: Warriors Sign Soviet Star
description: The Golden State Warriors today announced the signing of Sharunas Marchulionis, who will be the first Soviet player in National Basketball Association history.

title: At the Met, Honoring Those Who Help Out
description: The Candace awards for outstanding community service were presented to eight women Thursday at a party given by the National Coalition of 100 Black Women at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The awards were established to recognize serious black achievement.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending June 10 MANHATTAN Chelsea $475,000 332-334 West 19th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,700-sq.-ft. prewar co-op in a brownstone; dining area, recreation room, fireplace, hardwood floors; maintenance $899, 68% tax-deductible (Broker: Kingman Associates) Greenwich Village $1,470,000 77 Bedford Street 3-bedroom, 4-bath, single-family, 4-story semi-attached town house; dining room, 4 fireplaces, terrace, landmark district, 24- by 37-ft. lot; taxes $7,500 (Broker: William B. May) SoHo $274,000 66 Crosby Street 1,700-sq.-ft. prewar loft co-op; 1 bath, separate kitchen, columns, high-ceilings, hardwood floors; maintenance $903, 54% tax-deductible (Broker: Sinvin Realty) Sutton Place Area $435,000 400 East 56th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, balcony, rooftop pool; maintenance $1,042, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: B.J.
