Reid Tom Hammonds, Georgia Tech, 6-8 1/2 SMALL FORWARDS Sean Elliott, Arizona, 6-8 Glen Rice, Michigan, 6-7 Nick Anderson, Illinois, 6-6 Kenny Battle, Illinois, 6-6 1/2 Jeff Sanders, Georgia Southern, 6-8 BIG GUARDS George McCloud, Florida State, 6-5 1/2 Todd Lichti, Stanford, 6-5 1/2 Roy Marble, Iowa, 6-6 Lou Edwards, East Carolina, 6-4 Byron Irvin, Missouri, 6-5 1/2 POINT GUARDS Mookie Blaylock, Oklahoma, 6-1 B. J. Armstrong, Iowa, 6-2 Tim Hardaway, Texas El-Paso, 6-0 Pooh Richardson, U.C.L.A., 6-2 Sherman Douglas, Syracuse, 6-0

title: 5 Issues in This Week's Treasury Auctions
description: The Treasury's schedule of new issues this week includes today's regular auction of new three- and six-month bills, as well as the auction of a new one-year bill on Thursday and auctions of two-year notes tomorrow and four-year notes Wednesday.

title: Miss Sarnoff, Teacher, Weds
description: Susan Lynn Sarnoff, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur I. Sarnoff of New York and Charleston, S.C., was married yesterday to Jonathan David Bram, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard Bram of Andover, Mass., at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in New York. Rabbi James Prosnit and Cantor Ephraim Biran officiated.

title: Cuba Calls for Harsh Penalty For General in Drug Scandal
description: Defense Minister Raul Castro called today for ''exemplary punishment'' for Gen. Arnaldo Ochoa Sanchez, a hero of the Cuban revolution who is charged with drug trafficking and corruption.

title: American League; Ryan Flirts With Yet Another No-Hitter
description: Nolan Ryan came within four outs of his sixth no-hitter and surpassed 4,900 career strikeouts as the Texas Rangers beat the Cleveland Indians, 4-2, tonight.

title: Failure-Prone Marriages' Missing Ingredients
description: To the Editor:

title: Bonnie Hut Wed To F. A. Brimberg
description: At the Beach Point Club in Mamaroneck, N.Y., Bonnie Aileen Hut, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Aborn Hut of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to Frederick Andrew Brimberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Harry Brimberg of New York. Rabbi Robert Lennick officiated.

title: Harvests of Fish and Tourists Counted Around Narragansett Bay
description: One of the first casualties of the oil spill in Narragansett Bay was Edward W. Smith's dog, Snoopy, a 7-year-old brown mutt that took a walk around the shore of Hull Cove on Saturday and then made the mistake of licking her paws, which were covered in No. 2 fuel oil. Snoopy recovered after retching through the night and giving Mr. Smith a scare.

title: Among 'Country Folk,' Rumors and a Big Dose of Skepticism
description: Nearly 50 miles away from Beijing, in a small hamlet surrounded by tranquillity and grain fields that seem to roll on forever, a bright-eyed, chatty old woman clams up at the mention of the Government's television news.

title: Jeans Fade but Levi Strauss Glows
description: For much of this decade, Levi Strauss & Company's fortunes were fading like an old pair of blue jeans. The reason: jeans sales have been declining as the baby boom generation has aged.

title: For Angola Rebel, New Respectability
description: Rushing through the airport here last week, the Angolan rebel leader, Jonas Savimbi, found himself unexpectedly sharing a lounge with President Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique.

title: Critic's Notebook; Rock's Old Guard Dusts Off Its Music for Summer
description: What year is this anyway? For rock-and-rollers, the Summer of '89 is shaping up to be the Summer of Gray. Among the bands hitting the arena circuit are reunited versions of the Allman Brothers (at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night), the Doobie Brothers (at Jones Beach on July 20 to 21), Yes (on tour beginning July 29 under the name, for legal reasons, of Anderson, Bruford, Wakeman and Howe), the Rolling Stones (to be announced) and maybe even the Jefferson Airplane.

title: Tax Watch; Charitable Giving Also Aids Donors
description: MANY Americans who would like to respond to President Bush's appeal last week for greater private support of programs for social improvement may not realize that they can afford to do so, and help themselves as well. Experts in charitable giving say that donors can create a win-win solution by structuring assets to take advantage of tax regulations and perhaps improve their cash flow or estate plan.

title: Clinical Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The results for the latest quarter were negatively impacted by non- recurring and non-cash interest expense of $265,000 relating to the writeoff of original issue discount and finance charges incurred as result of the company's bridge financing completed in September and October of 1988 and repaid in February 1989. This amount represents the value of the company's common stock issued as compensation to bridge lenders.

title: Chess; By Robert Byrne
description: Deep Thought, the first computer program to defeat a strong human grandmaster, has now won the World Computer Championship, held in Edmonton, Alberta, from May 28 to 31. In a field of 24 machines from 9 countries, Deep Thought, programmed by a team headed by Feng-Hsiung Hsu, a doctoral candidate in computer science at Carnegie-Mellon University in Pittsburgh, won all five of its games in the Swiss-system competition.

title: Corrections
description: The crossword puzzle and answers were reproduced illegibly in some copies yesterday. Readers wishing corrected copies may write to Production Quality Control, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: G.O.P. Asks Cuts and Tax Rises To Close New Jersey Budget Gap
description: Assembly Republicans proposed a budget today that would pare $355 million from programs, increase taxes and siphon about $120 million from unemployment and state pension funds to close a $500 million budget shortfall.

title: QED Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss c-Net income Latest 9-month results included $575,000 non-cash writedown of oil and gas properties resulting from lower prices.

title: Concord Fabrics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: b-Net loss c-After a gain of $90,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: A Broad View of Racketeering
description: The Supreme Court refused to narrow the scope of the Federal racketeering law, which has become a weapon in private lawsuits. Page D1.

title: Navy Wins Submarine Award
description: Storm-tossed water forced the cancellation of the First International Submarine Races before the final event, but the United States Naval Academy entry won the overall performance award. Navy's teardrop-shaped submarine was awarded $5,000 Sunday in the competition for human-powered submarines for its speed, innovation and cost-effectiveness. The award was presented after a second day of bad weather forced the cancellation of a nine-submarine race around a one-kilometer course.

title: Litigation Floodgates: Don't Panic
description: Should this court be sticking its nose into the affairs of major league baseball? As we all know, courts are reluctant to interfere in matters of this sort because of the possibility that the floodgates of litigation will be opened. - Judge Norbert A. Nadel

title: Our Towns; Strangers, Yes, But the Faces Seemed Familiar
description: Yaacov Szklaniewicz was a carpenter. He was born in Kolno, Poland, in 1793 and died there in 1870. Little else is known about him, except that he had four children. And they had his 21 grandchildren. And they had his 96 great-grandchildren. And they had his 286 great-great-grandchildren. And they had his 483 great-great-great-grandchildren. And they had his 588 great-great-great-great-grandchildren. And they, so far, have had his 123 great-great-great-great-great-grandchildren. ''One was born a week ago,'' said Stanley Bloom, a retired physicist from Bridgewater, N.J., (and one of Mr. Szklaniewicz's great-great-grandchildren).

title: Data Show Wall St.'s Hard Times
description: Wall Street executives have been howling about hard times for many months and some fresh data show just how tough things have been.

title: For Night-Shift Workers, a Fix of Light
description: To the Editor:

title: Technodyne Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,997,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Wrapped Up in the Flag
description: In the wake of the Supreme Court's finding that the Constitution protects flag-burning, members of Congress are defiling Old Glory - by wrapping themselves in it. Cheap appeals to voters' emotions insult their intelligence.

title: HCC Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-After a loss of $213,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, tax credits of $210,000 and $550,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also included a charge of $146,000 on a settlement of a superfund claim. c-Net loss and after losses of $56,000 for the quarter and $95,000 for the year on settlement of superfund claims.

title: Topics of The Times; City Bridges Won't Wait
description: The 500-pound concrete slab that fell from a viaduct of Manhattan's F.D.R. Drive recently, killing a driver, was the latest reminder that too many of the city's bridges urgently need repairs.

title: Buyout Talk Clarified By Sea Containers
description: Sea Containers Ltd., a Bermuda-based shipping concern, sought today to clarify remarks about a possible leveraged buyout and recapitalization made last week by the company's founder and president, James B. Sherwood. The company said that the remarks had ''led to confusion'' and that there was ''no assurance'' that a buyout would take place.

title: Sears Plans Move to Site Near Chicago
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that it would move 6,000 employees to a Chicago suburb, ending a nationwide competition that included offers from Dallas; Miami; Charlotte and Raleigh, N.C., and dozens of other cities.

title: U.S. to Permit Use of Experimental Cancer Drug
description: FEDERAL agencies have agreed to permit widespread use of an experimental drug that has helped prevent recurrence of colon cancer in patients whose tumors have been surgically removed.

title: Addendum
description: * MLR Publishing Co. will introduce Family Business, a monthly magazine devoted to family-owned companies, in November.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air Midwest Inc., Wichita, Kan., said its board would review an unsolicited offer of $8 a share from Resort Air, St. Louis, a commuter airline.

title: Metro Cable Corp reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $6.9 million on the sale of cable systems.

title: A New British Sunday Paper
description: A new Sunday newspaper aimed at British readers in the 20-to-44 age group will begin publication in September, its chief executive said today.

title: Futures Pact For Treasuries
description: The New York Futures Exchange and the Financial Instrument Exchange said today that they would begin trading in United States Treasury bond futures beginning on Aug. 4, reviving a contract that was delisted several years ago. The Futures Exchange, the

title: Micro Bio-Medics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Philip Soskis, 78, Dies; Social-Work Executive
description: Philip Soskis, retired executive director of the New York Association for New Americans, died Sunday on a visit to Philadelphia. He was 78 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Underground Nuclear Blast Postponed for Second Time
description: A major underground nuclear weapon test was postponed Sunday for a second day because of erratic winds at the Nevada Test Site. The test was originally scheduled for Saturday morning. ''We had the same problem as Saturday, an erratic wind pattern,'' Jim Boyer, an Energy Department spokesman, said Sunday. He said the test would not be conducted before Tuesday.

title: Prism Entertainment Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $39,000 and $72,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Company News; Investors Financial Stake to Dominion
description: Dominion Capital Inc., a Richmond investment management firm, has acquired a 5.1 percent stake in the Investors Financial Corporation, a savings and loan association also based in Richmond.

title: Verify, And Then Trust
description: As U.S. and Soviet negotiators resume the strategic arms reduction talks in Geneva, the issue of verification has assumed enormous importance. Nowhere is this truer than in the Senate, which must approve a Start treaty. That treaty will be more complicated than the treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces, ratified in 1988, and will demand more stringent guarantees against potential Soviet violations.

title: Jazz Festival; The Autumnal Artistry Of Ella Fitzgerald
description: Like many other supreme musicians who have passed their physical peaks, Ella Fitzgerald at age 71 retains a remarkable artistic purity. Although it has been years since she could unleash the mighty barrages of vocal scat that are generously available on her recordings, at Carnegie Hall on Sunday, where she appeared as part of the JVC Jazz Festival with her trio and the guitarist Joe Pass, the basic elements of her style were intact. Her primary qualities are a celestial sweetness, an unflagging rhythmic acuity and a deep instinct for the melodic arc of a song.

title: A L Van Houtte Ltd reports earnings for Year to April 1
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Margaret A. Burt, Actuary, 98
description: Margaret A. Burt, a partner in Buck Associates of Manhattan, an actuarial firm, died of congestive heart failure Wednesday at her home in the Brooklyn Heights area. She was 98 years old.

title: Resignation Is Official For Chief of Immigration
description: The Justice Department has accepted the resignation of Alan C. Nelson as head of the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service, ending a peculiarly public and lengthy standoff between Mr. Nelson and his boss, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh.

title: Company News; Xicom Is Acquired
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation acquired the Xicom Technologies Corporation for an undisclosed amount. Based in Ottawa, Xicom develops and markets systems network architecture, which provides the connection between personal computers and mainframes. It has 25 employees. A National spokesman said Xicom produces the software that runs on National's Compatible Products Group's add-on circuit boards. The Xicom operations will become a unit of that group but will continue to be based in Ontario.

title: SPI Pharmaceuticals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Stocks Fall Broadly as Dow Retreats 20.49
description: Stocks fell broadly yesterday, retreating from a 49.70-point advance by the Dow Jones industrial average on Friday.

title: I.B.M.'s Advantage in New Chips
description: I.B.M.'s newly disclosed lead in the manufacturing of a high-capacity chip could give the computer giant a significant advantage over its domestic and international competitors at a time of transition to powerful systems that require large amounts of computer memory.

title: Trade of Sellers Gives Bulls 3 First-Round Picks
description: No matter how the Sacramento Kings use the first pick in tonight's National Basketball Association draft, a share of the spotlight will belong to the Chicago Bulls.

title: Review/Television; It's Koppel's Turn on China
description: One of the more peripheral consequences of events in China over the past several months has been to give the stars of network news an opportunity to demonstrate how adept they are in covering the big story. Dan Rather of CBS was the first anchor on the scene. Tom Brokaw of NBC was soon in Beijing, filing his reports while riding a bicycle.

title: Mixed View On Buyouts
description: Highly indebted companies will be more vulnerable in a recession, but the economy should otherwise be able to reap the benefits of leveraged buyouts without suffering the potential harmful effects, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, Manuel Johnson, said today.

title: Portland Journal; City That Had It All Leads in Crime
description: Residents here in the City of Roses like to say they have it all. They crow about their spotless parks, exemplary schools, award-winning water and strategic location - just an hour's drive from rugged ski slopes and pristine beaches.

title: Rockingham Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Malcolm Fooshee, 90, a Retired Lawyer
description: Malcolm Fooshee, a philanthropist and retired partner of the Manhattan law firm of Donovan Leisure Newton & Irvine, died of heart failure Friday while traveling from his Manhattan home to his country home in Pawling, N.Y. He was 90 years old.

title: Bait as Bully: A Crayfish Takes Over Fish Lakes
description: RUSTY crayfish, crustaceans introduced in the 1950's by fishermen who used them as bait for walleye and other large fish, have altered the ecosystem of lakes in northern Wisconsin, an ecologist at the University of Notre has found.

title: Palm Beach Utilities Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago revenue figures have been restated.

title: As First Boston Shifts, Defections Continue
description: Job-hopping has always been common on Wall Street, but the First Boston Corporation has suffered more than its share of departures in recent months. Those who have left include a senior executive in London, a core group of international merger specialists, the top energy team, and the heads of the equities, convertible securities, asset management and risk arbitrage departments.

title: Gtech Stock Inquiry Set
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission's New England enforcement chief said today that he asked for an investigation into whether insider trading in Gtech stock preceeded the lottery-equipment company's announcement that it was preparing for merger or buyout offers.

title: Sociology Is a Young Science, Still Carving Its Place; Dynamic, Productive
description: To the Editor:

title: Weigh-Tronix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Impenetrable Tumors Found to Block Even the Newest Cancer Agents
description: A BASIC misunderstanding of the structure of solid tumors has led researchers to design cancer drugs that are doomed to fail in many patients, a growing number of researchers say. The problem applies to the new, highly touted biological therapies like monoclonal antibodies, as well as to conventional cancer chemotherapy.

title: Rumania Is Said to Remove Fence Along Hungary Border
description: Rumania is pulling down a wire fence it recently built on its border with Hungary, the official Hungarian press agency reported today. The fence was criticized by the Soviet Union and Western nations at a rights conference last week.

title: Harry Breuer, 87, Dies; Percussionist for NBC
description: Harry Breuer, a percussionist and xylophonist in vaudeville and television who performed with Paul Whiteman and Benny Goodman, died of cancer Thursday at his home in Brightwaters, L.I. He was 87 years old.

title: Review/Ballet; A 'Giselle' Set in Louisiana
description: Judy Tyrus and Augustus van Heerden stepped into the leading roles of Dance Theater of Harlem's ''Giselle'' on Sunday afternoon.

title: AC&R Advertising Gets Armstrong Tire
description: AC&R Advertising, already the agency for the Pirelli Tire Corporation, has added the Armstrong Tire Company to its roster.

title: Hertz Account Under Review
description: Concerned about its market share and advertising strategy, the Hertz Corporation yesterday placed its $21.4 million account into review. The nation's largest rental car company invited four agencies, including the incumbent - Scali, McCabe, Sloves - to bid for its business.

title: U.S. Accord Is Called Near On Japan Car Phone Market
description: The United States and Japan were close tonight to resolving charges that Japan excludes foreign companies from its vast market for car telephones and private radio systems like those used by taxi companies, Bush Administration officials said.

title: Compumat Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and 6 months included a pretax charge of about $99,000 related to the proposed acquisition of the company. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Pop; The Uncluttered Hip-hop of De La Soul
description: De La Soul, the rap group that played at the Ritz on Saturday night, was, in many ways, the perfect group for the mostly college-age audience. The three musicians were witty, they avoided the sexism and self-aggrandizement that filters through much of hip-hop, and they looked solidly middle class, eschewing brand-name clothing and gold that other rap acts work with.

title: Cliff Resources reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said year-ago figures have been restated to give effect to the amalgamation of Cliff and Canaustra Gold Exploration Ltd., which was effective in January. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Head of Council of Churches Plans to Resign
description: The Rev. Arie R. Brouwer, the chief executive officer of the National Council of Churches, will announce his resignation today after four and half years in the post, staff members of the organization said.

title: Is Extremist or Opportunist Behind Bonn Rightist's Tempered Slogans?
description: Franz Schonhuber, the man most responsible for the heavy turbulence in West German politics this year, is not one to sidestep the limelight.

title: Broad Use Of RICO Is Upheld
description: The Supreme Court unanimously refused today to narrow the scope of the Federal racketeering statute, which has become a powerful weapon in private lawsuits in the 19 years since Congress enacted it as a prosecution tool against organized crime.

title: Clinic Help Needed for Sex-Abused Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Lester Knight, 81, Engineering Consultant
description: Lester B. Knight, founder of a consulting engineering firm, died Thursday at his home in Golf, Fla., after a long illness. He was 81 years old.

title: Bowie Passes Physical, Sealing Trade to Nets
description: Sam Bowie's first day in New Jersey as a member of the Nets went without a hitch.

title: A GERMAN CONCERN SOLD CHEMICALS TO IRAN, U.S. SAYS
description: A West German chemical company has arranged the sale to Iran of several hundred tons of chemicals used in making poison gas, American officials say.

title: New Clues Emerge in Mystery of Planetary Rings
description: WITH Voyager 2 closing in for a rendezvous with Neptune in late August, fascinated scientists are anticipating new insights into one of the solar system's most spectacular and puzzling phenomena: the multitude of rings around the giant outer planets.

title: American National Can Selects a New Chief
description: The American National Can Company, which is based in Chicago and owned by the Pechiney Group of France, announced yesterday that William N. Sick had resigned as chief executive and that Jean-Pierre Ergas had been named to the post.

title: JM Smucker Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Metro Datelines; 4 Towns Are Chosen As New Prison Sites
description: New medium-security prisons will be built in four upstate towns under a plan agreed to by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders.

title: Jazz Festival; Old-Time Be-bop Out Front Again
description: ''Be-bop Revisited,'' the title of tonight's concert at Avery Fisher Hall, is a bit of a misnomer. Be-bop, the complicated, richly textured jazz style developed by Charlie Parker, Dizzy Gillespie, Thelonious Monk, Charlie Christian and others in the 1940's, lost some of its popularity in the 1960's and 70's, under the double onslaught of the Free Jazz avant-garde and Fusion, which attempted the merger of pop and rock with jazz.

title: Hungarian Aide Sees Collective Rule
description: The president of the Hungarian Communist Party's newly created Presidium said today that his job was to be ''first among equals'' in a ''collective leadership'' that will ''guide and determine party policy.''

title: Company News; GAF Group Buys Pacific First Shares
description: A group led by the GAF Corporation and its chairman, Samuel J. Heyman, has acquired a 6 percent stake in the Pacific First Financial Corporation, the largest savings institution in the Northwest. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the GAF group said its members bought the Pacific First stock because ''the shares represent an attractive investment opportunity.''

title: Mystery at Milky Way's Center
description: SOMETHING has abruptly choked off the flow of gamma rays reaching the Earth from what is presumed to be a black hole near the center of the Milky Way galaxy, and astrophysicists are combing through a mountain of data in search of explanations.

title: Company News; Latshaw Invests In Paint Retailer
description: A group led by Latshaw Enterprises Inc., a mechanical controls manufacturer based in Wichita, Kan., and its chairman, John Latshaw, has acquired a 7.1 percent stake in the Standard Brands Paint Company.

title: Man in Car on L.I. Expressway Is Hit by a Bullet
description: In what the police termed an apparent ''random shooting'' on the Long Iscar passenger was wounded in the arm as the car traveled in a Manhattan-bound lane yesterday morning.

title: Books of The Times; An Older Woman Whose Love Rival Is Herself in a Novel
description: Second Fiddle By Mary Wesley 184 pages. Viking. $18.95.

title: FASHION: Patterns
description: Chilly Scenes of Summer

title: George Pidot, 82, Lawyer and L.I. Official
description: George B. Pidot, a lawyer and former village official on Long Island, died Saturday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Hobe Sound, Fla., and during the summer in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: The Judge on Pete Rose's Bench
description: Judge Norbert Nadel may go down in the annals of baseball as ''Two Week Nadel'' - the man who prolonged the agonizing gambling case against Cincinnati Reds manager Pete Rose. Sportswriters have impishly accused the Judge, who is up for re-election in Cincinnatti, of playing to the hometown crowd. Whatever his motives, the decision does little to promote orderly justice.

title: Flight International Group reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Acreage Up for 4 Crops
description: Vegetable processors have contracted for a sharply larger acreage this year to help make up for 1988's drought-shriveled production, an Agriculture Department report showed today. Over all, growers will have 1.41 million acres devoted to four important vegetable crops in this year, a 14 percent increase from last year and 15 percent more than in 1987. ''Planted acreage of snap beans is up 22 percent,'' the report said. ''Sweet corn is up 8 percent; green peas jumped 15 percent, while tomatoes increased 17 percent.''

title: Fireworks Shipments Seized by Government
description: In a crackdown at American ports the Customs Service and the Consumer Product Safety Commission have seized 400 shipments of fireworks this year because they violated Federal safety standards, the safety commission said.

title: Ross Cosmetics Distribution Centers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. Urges Japan to Assume Wider Global Responsibility
description: The United States said today that Japan should play a bigger political role on the world stage, commensurate with its economic power, and the Bush Administration proposed a new international body to foster economic cooperation in the Pacific Basin.

title: Chefs International reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss The company said share earnings for the latest quarter was less than 1 cent a share.

title: Review/Theater; Some West End Efforts to Repel The New American Invasion
description: If anyone wonders why the British invasion of Broadway dwindled to a single play last season (''Shirley Valentine''), the answer is to be found here. The most popular drama in the West End is an American import, ''M. Butterfly.'' Visitors to London can also see ''Steel Magnolias,'' ''Speed-the-Plow,'' ''Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune,'' ''Brigadoon'' ''To Kill a Mockingbird,'' Beth Henley's ''Debutante Ball,'' Steppenwolf's ''Grapes of Wrath'' and Lincoln Center's ''Anything Goes.'' Just departed are Jackie Mason, ''A Walk in the Woods'' and ''Forbidden Broadway.'' The Royal Shakespeare Company will soon open a new play by the American writer Richard Nelson and a revival of ''The Man Who Came to Dinner'' directed by Gene Saks.

title: Sociology Is a Young Science, Still Carving Its Place
description: To the Editor:

title: Q&A
description: Viruses

title: T Cell Sciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: John Patrick Walsh, Lawyer, 84
description: John Patrick Walsh, an insurance lawyer in Manhattan for almost 57 years, died Saturday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 84 years old and lived in Convent Station, N.J.

title: Herb Roberts In Homage to Bud Powell
description: Arcado, a string trio made up of Mark Feldman on violin, Hank Roberts on cello and Mark Dresser on bass, opened a double bill at the Knitting Factory on Sunday night with a composition that moved quickly from bass improvisation to written material to improvised swinging. Balancing ecstatic, swooping and riffing improvised moments against dry and angular composed sections, the group had done about all that could be done within its instrumentation by the time the piece was over.

title: Culp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Net income and included an after- tax gain of $927,000, or 21 cents a share, from the sale of a division. c-Included a one-time after-tax charge against earnings of $310,000 for both the quarter and year. Prior year sales included sales of $5,798,000 related to a division which was sold in fiscal 1988.

title: Venice-Mestre Union Backed
description: Venice has voted against breaking away from its mainland industrial neighbor, Mestre. In a referendum over the weekend, voters in Venice and Mestre voted 58 percent to 42 percent to stay together under a single city council, results showed today.

title: Brief Abduction of American Was Not a Hoax, Israel Says
description: An American relief worker kidnapped in the occupied Gaza Strip has been cleared of suspicion that he collaborated with his abductors, an Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman said.

title: In U.S.-China Ties, Cordiality Is No Longer on the Agenda
description: Two Chinese were hurriedly bicycling past the compound of the American Embassy the other day, rushing along as if it were a particularly dangerous neighborhood, when one leaned toward the other and then waved toward the embassy.

title: Company News; Kubota Will Buy 15% Stake in Rasna
description: Kubota Ltd., a Tokyo-based manufacturer, said it would invest $10 million to acquire a 15 percent equity share in the Rasna Corporation, a new company based in San Jose, Calif., that produces mechanical design and analysis software. Kubota will also establish a 50-50 joint venture with Rasna to market its software products in Japan.

title: A Second Man Dies In the Training Pool At Pensacola Base
description: A sailor has died in a training pool at the Pensacola Naval Air Station, the second such death in about a year, and an investigation has been ordered, Navy officials said.

title: Winnebago Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
description: The year-ago periods have been restated to conform with new accounting standards (consolidation of all majority owned subsidiaries) which are required to be adopted by the company in fiscal 1989.

title: A Large-Type Version Of the Screen Display
description: MANY people have trouble seeing text on a computer screen, especially on the tiny screens used on some laptop computers. The problem is acute for people with vision impairment.

title: Raul Castro Adds Sparks to Cuban Trial
description: An unexpected appearance by Raul Castro, Minister of the Armed Forces and brother of President Fidel Castro, has injected an even deeper sense of official importance in the trial of one of Cuba's most decorated military officers.

title: Stephen Hassenfeld Is Dead at 47; Led Toy Company to No. 1 Spot
description: Stephen David Hassenfeld, an executive who led Hasbro Inc. as it became one of the world's largest toy manufacturers, died Sunday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York City. He was 47 years old.

title: Santo Domingo Journal; From Guerrillas' Camp, A Hazy View of Peace
description: Sitting down to talk in a broad meadow beside a mountain river, Fabio Marino Vargas might pass for a young camper on a summer outing. But something is wrong in the details. On his neck, wrists and ankles, Mr. Marino bears the scars of a suicide attempt made during what he describes as prolonged torture in one of his many stays in Colombian prisons. An Israeli-made machine gun rests unobtrusively beside him. And on his breast pocket, an insignia identifies him as a top commander of the April 19 Movement, or M-19, Colombia's best-known and, at one time, most dangerous guerrilla army.

title: Hasbro's Stock Active Following Chief's Death
description: Hasbro Inc., the large toy company, was among the most-active stocks traded on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, following the death on Sunday of Stephen D. Hassenfeld, Hasbro's chairman and chief executive.

title: Why the Crackdown?; 2 Main Explanations Are That the Leaders Felt Threatened and Dreaded Instability
description: It was almost 200 years ago that the aging Qianlong Emperor told a British emissary named Lord MacCartney that his country would have to accept China's terms for foreign trade since Europeans would surely perish without China's tea and rhubarb.

title: 700 Refugees to Be Returned to Khmer Rouge
description: Thai officials and non-Communist Cambodians have agreed to return more than 700 Cambodians to Khmer Rouge control after they fled oppressive conditions and bombardment in Khmer Rouge camps, international aid officials and Western diplomats say.

title: Ex-First Boston Banker Will Join Wasserstein
description: Carol B. Einiger, who spent 15 years as an investment banker at the First Boston Corporation, will be joining Wasserstein, Perella & Company next week as a managing director.

title: Chimerine Quits at WEFA
description: Lawrence Chimerine, one of the nation's best-known economic forecasters, resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive of WEFA Inc., apparently in a dispute over management of the economic consulting firm.

title: Plastibec Ltd reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: MEDICAL SCIENCE: Delusion, Benign and Bizarre, Is Recognized as Common
description: DELUSIONS are more commonplace than most people assume, a growing number of researchers are concluding. These researchers say the delusions of those with psychiatric disorders are fundamentally no different from, say, a private belief that a color is unlucky or popular beliefs in the existence of flying saucers.

title: Development Team Is Picked for Trade Center in Harlem
description: A 10-year-old plan to build a huge international trade center in the heart of Harlem took a giant step forward yesterday as a development team was chosen.

title: Detroit Parishes Lose Appeal Of Cardinal's Order to Close
description: The Vatican has rejected the appeal of 15 parishes of an order by the Archdiocese of Detroit to close in July, Edmund Cardinal Szoka said today.

title: Evidence of 'Cold' Fusion Cautiously Cited
description: CAUTIONING that the finding may prove incorrect, scientists at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico said yesterday that they had found evidence of tritium, a fusion byproduct, during experiments on low-temperature nuclear fusion.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * W. R. Berkley Corp., Greenwich, Conn., an insurance holding company, appointed Robert S. Gorin senior vice president, general counsel and secretary.

title: 2 Tunisian Banks Merge
description: Two state-controlled Government banks - the Banque Nationale de Tunisie and the Banque Nationale de Developpement Agricole - have merged to form the Banque Nationale Agricole. The merger, which took effect on Saturday, was approved by the Cabinet this year to streamline credits to agriculture, previously handled by both banks. The new bank has a capital of $33.8 million.

title: Technology Research reports earnings for Year to March 31
Ford Curbs Production At 2 Plants
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it was canceling production at two plants in Atlanta and Chicago for a week next month because Ford and Lincoln-Mercury dealers were reluctant to order more 1989 model cars.

title: President Says Satisfacition Outweighs Job's Frustration
description: Others may have stooped under the weight of the Presidency, what Thomas Jefferson called the ''splendid misery'' of wrestling with the world's problems. But President Bush, in sardonic, humorous and reflective remarks underscoring how much his confidence has blossomed since the election, said today that the satisfactions of his first five months in office had far surpassed the frustrations.

title: Corections
description: A table in Business Day on Friday about the rapid growth of the cellular telephone business misstated the estimates of customer potential for four companies. For BellSouth, the estimate was 28 million; Pacific Telesis, 30 million; Southwestern Bell, 27 million; U S West, 14 million.

title: Radio Stands Up to Be (Better) Heard
description: Some 228 million Americans spend an average of three hours and 21 minutes each day listening to the radio, according to figures released by the Radio Advertising Bureau. But the radio dramatist Himan Brown, who created the 1930's mystery series ''The Inner Sanctum,'' says people are not listening the way they used to.

title: People
description: * Cheryl Greene has been promoted to senior vice president of Warwick Advertising.

title: Eastern Sides Hold Meeting
description: Strikebound Eastern Airlines and its pilots' union met today under court order, negotiating for the first time since Eastern sought permission last week to cancel the pilots' contract and impose concessions on wages and work rules.

title: KEY RATES
Reagan Back in Booth
description: For a few moments, Ronald Reagan will return to a former job on July 11 - describing baseball over the air. Mr. Reagan will do one inning of color commentary during NBC's telecast of the All-Star Game, the network said yesterday. The former President will join Vin Scully and Tom Seaver in the broadcast booth at Anaheim Stadium.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is insufficient evidence of a national consensus against executing mentally retarded people convicted of capital offenses for us to conclude that it is categorically prohibited by the Eighth Amendment.'' - Justice Sandra Day O'Connor [ A18:3. ]

title: Bridge; By Alan Truscott
description: The mysterious auction shown in the diagram produced what may well be the largest penalty ever conceded by experts on a major occasion. It happened in mid-May in the Cavendish Team event in Manhattan, and the proceedings were influenced by bidding screens: no player could hear any explanation given by his partner.

title: Quake Set Off by Volcano Shakes Hawaii, Spawning Tidal Wave
description: A powerful earthquake caused by the long eruption of Kilauea Volcano shook Hawaii Island on Sunday, generating a small tidal wave and destroying two houses, officials say. No serious injuries were reported.

title: Australian Loses TV Ruling
description: Alan Bond, the Australian businessman, lost a three-year battle today when the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal ruled that one of the companies he controls is unfit to run the country's largest television and radio network.

title: Company News; Northrop Starts Restructuring
description: The Northrop Corporation today announced the first steps in its restructuring, saying it has abolished the corporate staffs in charge of international marketing and technical programs review.

title: Expansion Set By a Ford Unit
description: The First Nationwide Financial Corporation, a unit of the Ford Motor Company, plans several acquisitions in the near future, particularly in California, its top market, the president of Ford Financial Services said today.

title: Wisconsin Toy Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about Matthew Schutz, a Manhattan antiques dealer, misstated the day of his death.

title: Horseplayers Will Feel Tax Pinch
description: New York's horseplayers will come away from the current session of the State Legislature with a major defeat and a small victory. A new tax burden will hack away at their bankrolls, but ongoing improvements at the tracks may make it more pleasant to lose, and some innovations may actually help them win.

title: Apartheid Foe Gets Passport And Is Expected to Meet Bush
description: Over the last 25 years, Albertina Sisulu, a bold articulator of black majority rule in South Africa, has been placed under house arrest, circumscribed by banning orders and, from time to time, jailed in solitary confinement.

title: Iran to Dredge 2 Ports
description: Two important Iranian ports that were badly damaged in the eight-year war with Iraq will soon be dredged, the Iranian news agency IRNA said on Sunday. The ports, Khorramshahr and Abadan, are on the Shatt al Arab waterway, whose sovereignty is disputed by the two countries. Some $75.3 million has been set aside for preliminary dredging and repairs to the ports, IRNA said. The reopening of the Shatt has been a stumbling block in United Nations-mediated peace talks that began after last August's cease-fire.

title: Account
description: * NFL Properties, the licensing unit of the National Football League, to CHC Advertising, Westport, Conn., with an undisclosed budget.

title: Excerpts From Interview With President on Foreign and Domestic Issues
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Bush today conducted by the New York Times: Evaluation on China

title: Compuflight Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Campaign by Portugal Thanks Its Tourists
description: Portugal will use an American aviation milestone to thank tourists for flocking faithfully to the country since 1939. Fifty years ago tomorrow, 22 passengers traveled to Lisbon aboard the Pan American World Airways Dixie Clipper - the first commercial flight between the United States and Europe.

title: Pickens's Battle With Koito
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman, said today that he would continue to press for a seat on the board of the Koito Manufacturing Company, of which he owns 20.2 percent, in a battle to open up Japan's financial system.

title: Bush Seeking Way to Circumvent Court's Decision on Flag Burning
description: President Bush has asked the Attorney General and the White House chief of staff to find ways to circumvent the recent Supreme Court ruling that extends First Amendment protection to political protesters who burn the American flag.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The chart of major financial indicators at the top of the Business Digest in Business Day yesterday misstated the value of the dollar on Monday and its change since Friday. In late trading in New York, the dollar rose 2.25 yen, to 141.10 yen.

title: Elcotel Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $214,000 and $2,451,000, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net loss and after a loss of $1,031,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $1,548,000. Prior quarter and year results are restated to reflect discontinuation of operator service and pay phone ownership/operation businesses.

title: Time Holders Sue to Block Meeting
description: Three large Time Inc. stockholders, Robert M. Bass L.P., the Cablevision Systems Corporation and Jerry Perenchio, filed suit yesterday in Delaware Chancery Court, seeking to block Time's annual shareholders meeting, which is scheduled for Friday.

title: Atlantic Express reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Davis Water & Waste Indusries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Dowd Served Both Sides in Court
description: It was closing in on midnight as A. Bartlett Giamatti sat alone in his Washington hotel room on Feb. 23. His official installation as commissioner of baseball was still more than a month away, but he had come to realize he could not wait a day longer to act as if he were already in charge of the game and its good name. Reports that Pete Rose was involved in gambling had continued to mount and his options about dealing with it continued to dwindle.

title: Oil Spills Leave Trail of Disturbing Questions
description: The three oil spills over the weekend, coming only 12 weeks after the Exxon Valdez spewed 11 million gallons of toxic crude oil off the Alaskan coast, have raised new concerns about the limits of cleanup technology, the weaknesses of existing emergency response plans and the loopholes in liability laws.

title: Ameron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
THE ENVIRONMENT: Despite Gains, Dealing With Big Oil Spills Is Still a Struggle
description: Until now, chance and the irresistible forces of nature have overwhelmed the comparatively puny efforts of humans in determining whether a major oil spill becomes an ecological disaster or spares the environment.

title: Home Resales Fell in May
description: Despite falling mortgage rates, sales of existing homes dropped 5.6 percent in May to their lowest level in 16 months, the National Association of Realtors reported today.

title: Fetisov Finally Signs to Play With Devils
description: After six years of frustrating on-again, off-again negotiations with the player widely considered the best defenseman in the world, the New Jersey Devils have finally signed Vyacheslav Fetisov of the Soviet national team, according to the Devils' majority owner.

title: Northwest Drug Co reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-After a special gain of $87,500. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Reporter Reprimanded In Capitol Gun Incident
description: A committee of journalists reprimanded the columnist Jack Anderson today for his role in bringing a gun into the Capitol for a television program on terrorism, but the panel did not revoke his press credentials.

title: Delaware Guard Joining In Tanker Spill Cleanup
description: One hundred and fifty Delaware National Guardsmen began helping in the cleanup of the Delaware River shoreline today and another 150 guards are to join them Tuesday.

title: American Medical Internaional Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included benefits from an adjustment to malpractice insurance provisions of $20.4 million for the quarter and $7.4 million for the 9 months, and $9 million in additions to legal settlement reserves and $12.8 million in asset writedowns, both for the quarter and 9 months; the 9 months also reflected pretax charges of $11 million representing lease buyout costs. c-After an extraordinary charge of $33,900,000 for repurchase of debt and a credit of $50,700,000. Year-ago quarter results included operations of 36 hospitals sold to Epic Healthcare on Sept. 30, 1988.

title: Health Development Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and after a special gain of $51,000.

title: Tons of Toys Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Pilot Says He Tried to Warn Tanker Headed for Reef
description: A harbor pilot, on his way to a rendezvous with a Greek oil tanker, tried to warn her that she was headed into dangerous waters. But the radio message came too late and he found himself watching helplessly from another boat as the tanker ran aground a mile from shore here.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on June 16 about a reunion of the Lehman family at the Metropolitan Museum of Art listed a family member erroneously among the guests. The member, Irving Lehman, former Chief Judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, died in 1945. His name should have appeared in a reference to notable Lehmans past and present.

title: Topics of The Times; Fish Gotta Sing
description: Sausalito, Calif., is being driven mad by the sound of fish - the mating call of the male toadfish, to be precise. It is a curious sound, reminiscent of an oboe with stuck stops. But it tickles the gills of the female toadfish.

title: Time Turns Paramount Bid Down
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Time Inc.'s rejection of a takeover offer from Paramount Communications Inc. attributed a statement incorrectly in some editions. It was Time's board, not Paramount's board, that said it was ''confident that belated efforts to characterize the Time-Warner transaction as a sale of Time will be judged properly in the courthouse.''

title: Prospect Park Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share net reflects a 10 percent stock dividend to be paid June 29.

title: Star Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Latest year included a $4,200,000 writedown of excess inventory.

title: Rowe Furniture reports earnings for Qtr to June 4
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 common stock split effective April 13.

title: Lendl Defeats Pereira In Wimbledon Opener
description: For Ivan Lendl, every match at Wimbledon is a marathon, and every campaign threatens to end tragically. Indeed, after arduously working his way to the semifinal or final on five occasions, he has unceremoniously been sent packing without a silver plate to enhance his Grand Slam collection.

title: William Erickson, 70, Ex-Chemical Executive
description: William G. Erickson, a former vice president of Air Chemical Corporation in Carlstadt, N.J., died of a heart attack June 18 at Northern Dutchess Community Hospital in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 70 years old and lived in Athens, N.Y.

title: Bird Begins Comeback
description: As first steps go, this one looked more like a leap for Larry Bird.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Universal Security Instruents reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Company News; Power-Plant Stake
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it would build and take a controlling stake in a $70 million project for a co-generating power plant in Boran, Calif. The company said the 55-megawatt plant will provide electricity to the Southern California Edison Company as well as backup power and steam to the United States Borax and Chemical Corporation. A Westinghouse spokeswoman said she could not disclose the size of the company's equity position but said it would be more than half.

title: HARVARD REACHES ACCORD WITH UNION
description: Harvard University and its one-year-old union of clerical and technical workers have reached a tentative agreement on their first contract, which would give the workers an average raise of 32 percent over three years.

title: Rose Incurred Debts of $400,000 In 3 Months, Betting Report Says
description: Pete Rose, the Cincinnati Reds manager who faces a lifetime suspension from baseball if he bet on his own team, once incurred a debt of $400,000 to a bookmaker in New York over a three-month period in 1987, according to the report on baseball's investigation of Mr. Rose.

title: MDS Health Group Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Stride Rite Corp reports earnings for Qtr to June 2
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $522,000 and $1,284,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and the 6 months also included a $1,723,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Faradyne Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Waters Instruments reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Indexing, Viewing and Linking Files
description: A HARD disk can easily get out of hand, so crammed with application programs and data in a labyrinth of directories and subdirectories and even sub-subdirectories that the most intrepid disk jockey can get hopelessly lost.

title: U.S. Trade Criticism Belittles Indian Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Cott Beverages Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: FASHION: By Design; To Shine Beneath the Stars
description: When a grassy lawn replaces the carpet and a starry moonlit sky the ceiling, the stage is set for fashion dramas. Dress-up bits that work wonderfully indoors have the opposite effect when exposed to nighttime nature.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about mergers among accounting firms misidentified A. A. Sommer Jr. He is a former commissioner of the Securities and Exchange Commission; he was not its chairman.

title: While Legislators Pack, Unresolved Bills Pile Up
description: As the New York State Legislature rushes to recess by the end of the week, negotiators are struggling to fashion a major revision of the state's welfare system that would prepare tens of thousands of welfare recipients for jobs.

title: 2 in Atlanta Are Said to Reap $1.6 Million in Housing Deals
description: Two private escrow agents in Atlanta conspired to divert or retain more than $1.6 million in proceeds from the sale of Government-owned houses, Federal investigators said today, calling it another example of lax management by Reagan Administration housing officials.

title: Aphids Versus Hybrids
description: Plants with a weak resistance to insects could be used in agriculture to control the evolution of harmful pests, rendering them less capable of causing crop damage, a new study suggests.

title: Who's Who in the Case
description: Pete Rose: Baseball's career leader in hits and the manager of the Cincinnati Reds who is under investigation for betting on his team. A. Bartlett Giamatti: The commissioner of baseball, whose office is conducting the Rose inquiry and who can suspend Rose for life if he determines he bet on his team. Judge Norbert A. Nadel: A Hamilton County (Ohio) Court of Common Pleas judge who granted a temporary restraining order Sunday that blocked the baseball commissioner from holding a hearing with Rose into the manager's betting activities, saying the commissioner has prejudged the case. John Dowd: A former Justice Department lawyer now in private practice in Washington who led the investigation of Rose for Giamatti. Ron Peters: A bookmaker and bar owner who told Dowd's investigators in April that Rose bet more than $1 million with him over a two-year period, including bets on Reds' games. Paul Janszen: A body-builder friend of Rose, who told Dowd he placed bets for Rose with Peters. Rose's attorneys say he said in the presence of a friend, Danita Marcum, ''that he was going to take Pete Rose down with him unless he was paid money.'' He gave the F.B.I. betting sheets, which included bets on Reds games, that he said he took from Rose's home. Tommy Gioiosa: A longtime friend of Rose who lived in the manager's home for several years as a teen-ager. He was a regular at Gold's Gym, a reputed center for drug traffickers and gamblers and allegedly ran bets for Rose. He is facing Federal charges of tax evasion and conspiracy. Mike Bertolini: A Brooklyn resident and business partner of Rose whom the Dowd report says handled bets for him with New York bookies. Val: A Staten Island bookmaker Janszen told investigators had taken bets from Rose through Bertolini. At one point he refused any further bets because Rose owed him $34,000. Steve Chevashore: Handled bets for Rose in Florida during spring training of 1987. The report says Janszen as the intermediary was never to use the word ''bet'' nor Rose's name. They did have an understanding, however, that the bets Janszen was placing for Rose would always be for $2,000.

title: Sunrise Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Art; In Washington, Cassatt's Japanese-Inspired Prints
description: Mary Cassatt was not the only artist to have been impressed by the exhibition of Japanese ukiyo-e prints at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris during the spring of 1890. Edgar Degas, James Tissot and Henri Fantin-Latour were a few of the others, and Berthe Morisot was inspired to make a color lithograph after seeing the exhibition at Cassatt's behest.

title: Boston Digital reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a loss of $146,000 from inventory cost adjustments. c-Net income and included a gain from inventory cost adjustments of $417,000 for the quarter and the year is after a provision for unrealized loss on marketable securities of $288,000.

title: Strong Demand For Oil Is Seen
description: OPEC's general secretary, Subroto, said today that the price of oil should be particularly strong in the fourth quarter because world demand is expected to rise from its current level to an estimated 52 million barrels a day.

title: Cubs Suffer Their 4th Straight Loss
description: Doug Drabek pitched a seven-hitter as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat Chicago, 2-1, tonight, sending the Cubs to their fourth consecutive loss.

title: For Brookens, Detroit Is Not an Away Game
description: It is never easy to move on. Tom Brookens had spent 10 seasons driving downtown, playing games at Tiger Stadium, saying goodbye to his teammates and returning to the suburbs. Then one day in spring training, he was traded.

title: Gooden and Mets Fall in Expos' 5-Run 4th
description: Davey Johnson said it, Dwight Gooden said it, everybody said it: Gooden's right shoulder, which has been getting stiff lately, was not troubling him. But then nobody had any explanation for what happened tonight in Olympic Stadium: The Mets' ace of aces was pounded for five runs in the fourth inning and made his earliest exit in nearly two years as the Montreal Expos whipped the Mets, 5-1, and replaced them in first place in the National League East.

title: WPP Group May Add To Its Balance Sheet
description: Martin Sorrell said yesterday that he might value Ogilvy & Mather as a brand on the WPP Group's balance sheet, adding several hundred million dollars to WPP's financial statement and offsetting somewhat the $864 million Mr. Sorrell paid for the Ogilvy Group in May.

title: Fundamental Fairness the Issue in New York's Commuter Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-8

title: Franco Closes Gap
description: Julio Franco of Texas, the American League's leading hitter, has narrowed the gap on the Yankees' Steve Sax in the race for the starting berth at second base at the All-Star Game.

title: Company News; A.&P. Sees Charge If Joint Offer Fails
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company said that if it fails in its joint bid for a British supermarket company, it expects to take a charge of $25 million. A.&P. said it had already incurred costs of about $25 million through its participation in the bid of more than $3 billion for the Gateway Corporation. It is making the bid along with Wasserstein, Perella & Company.

title: Potatoes and Mr. Hyde
description: For Americans who like to poke around in foreign policy, Britain offers a pleasant luxury: involved detachment.

title: Finance House Campaigns
description: LEAD: President Bush is expected to propose that political- action committee contributions to Congressional campaigns be banned or severely limited. He claims, plausibly, that eliminating PAC contributions would reduce special-interest groups' influence in the legislative process.

title:
Market Place;
Investor's Bet Is Against Horses
description: LEAD: IN horse racing, there is no such thing as a sure thing. The same uncertainty surrounds Hollywood Park, a venerable race track that may become a takeover target.

title: North American National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Study Finds 2d Thoughts Concerning Mastectomy
description: THE majority of women who had breasts removed after an early diagnosis of breast cancer would not make the same decision if they had a chance to choose again, a new study indicates.

title: Commissioner's Office Appeals Rose Decision
description: Arguing that the integrity of the game has been damaged and will continue to be, lawyers for A. Bartlett Giamatti, the baseball commissioner, yesterday asked an Ohio appellate court to suspend the temporary restraining order barring Giamatti from holding a hearing with Pete Rose regarding betting charges.

title: Anton Dermota, Tenor In Mozart, Dead at 79
description: Anton Dermota, a Yugoslav tenor known for his interpretation of Mozart roles, died of heart failure on Thursday. He was 79 years old and lived in Vienna.

title: Islanders Sign Arbour To Multiyear Contract
description: Al Arbour helped turn the Islanders from doormats to Stanley Cup champions in the early 1980's. Yesterday, he decided it's worth trying to do again. Arbour, who stepped down as the Islanders' coach three years ago only to return when the team collapsed early last season, agreed to a multiyear contract to remain behind the bench. General Manager Bill Torrey said Arbour would coach for ''at least two years and as many more as he may want.'' No financial terms were disclosed.

title: 'Batman' Sets Record And So Does Hollywood
description: ''Batman'' took in a record $43.6 million at the box office over the weekend, helping to give Hollywood its biggest weekend ever.

title: On China: Right Words, No Music
description: The news from China demonstrates again the soundness of President Bush's firm policy. But unless the President stops speaking so softly, he risks undermining his big stick.

title: Washington Talk; New Steps for the Military Budget Dance
description: For years, Congress has held an annual square dance over military spending, whirling from one section of the Pentagon budget to another and trading partners when necessary.

title: 'Africa and the Antilles,' a Mixed Bag
description: The Supreme Court majority that recently decided a sound system doesn't affect rock musicians' right to free expression might have reconsidered had the justices sat through ''Africa and the Antilles,'' Sunday's JVC Jazz Festival concert at Avery Fisher Hall. A miserable sound mix, perhaps worsened by the hall's poor acoustics for amplified music, turned a potential dance party into a debacle.

title: Reform Conference Debates Allowing Homosexuals to Become Rabbis
description: For the first time, the national organization of Reform rabbis debated yesterday whether to admit homosexuals into its rabbinic organization.

title: 20 Die in Blast on Chinese Train
description: A dynamite explosion on a train bound for Shanghai killed 20 people and seriously injured 11 more on Monday night, the official New China News Agency reported early today.

title: Careers; Companies Urged to Add To Training
description: IN the 1990's, American corporations must do much more training of their workers, said a strongly worded report from the American Society of Training and Development.

title: 3 Mobsters Found Guilty Of Plotting To Kill Gotti
description: A man reputed to be the most powerful member of the Genovese crime family in New Jersey was convicted with two associates today of plotting to kill John Gotti and his brother Gene in a struggle for control of organized crime in the metropolitan area.

title: Rig Count Rises Again
description: The number of rigs exploring for oil continued an upward climb last week, increasing by 15, to a total of 810, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. It was the fifth straight weekly gain in the nationwide count. A year ago, the count stood at 894.

title: FSI International reports earnings for Qtr to May 27
Angeion Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30

The company said its latest first quarter results were also adversely affected by losses incurred by its Canadian unit of $212,940.

title: Pennington's Stores Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Pressure From Gun Owners Dooms Assault Weapons Bill
description: Heavy lobbying by gun owners appears to have doomed legislation aimed at curbing assault weapons in New York, and has even prompted some early sponsors of the measure to withdraw their names from the bill.

title: Edberg Victorious In Opener at Wimbledon
description: True to form, the traditional clouds swirled in from the northern isles just in time to shadow the parched lawns of Wimbledon on opening day. Also in deference to tradition, the defending champion performed his first-round match with aplomb: Stefan Edberg of Sweden breezed past Chris Pridham of Canada, 6-3, 6-4, 6-1.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Increase by 3% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a 3 percent increase in short interest for the active over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended on June 15.

title: U.S. Sues Town Over Rights of Retarded
description: Most people agree that the mentally retarded are better off living in group homes than in institutions - unless, of course, the home happens to be near theirs.

title: Metro Datelines; Police Say 12 Youths Rob Times Sq. Riders
description: More than 12 teen-agers assaulted people in the Times Square subway station Sunday evening, robbing three of them, the transit police said.

title: FASHION: The Shorts and Longs of Resort Wear
description: The next step in fashion will be in the direction of golf clothes, Ralph Lauren maintains. Shorts represent the wave of the immediate future, says Louis Dell'Olio, whose new collection for Anne Klein II includes all kinds of shorts combined with serious tailored jackets, as well as more playful varieties shown with sweaters and T-shirts. Hubert de Givenchy reinforces the shorts movement with cool, crisp linen shorts and matching shirts. He is among many European designers to endorse the trend.

title: F.D.A. Gives Quick Approval To Two Drugs to Treat AIDS
description: In an action long sought by AIDS patients and their advocates, the Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved two new drugs to treat serious complications of AIDS infections.

title: Washington Talk; Congress
description: What is the biggest obstacle to a Federal pay increase and reform of Congressional ethics rules? Is it partisan bickering? How about sneaky lobbyists? Or maybe the hosts of talk radio shows?

title: Taurus Footwear Inc reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $8,329,000 and $322,000 for the latest and prior years, respectively. c-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Domco Industries Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: The company said the latest quarter was marked by a strike at the Farnham plant, which was settled after four weeks. It said direct and indirect costs of the strike are estimated at $1 million. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ceremony Heralds a $1 Billion Project in Brooklyn
description: After almost a decade of planning, city officials and business executives celebrated the official ground breaking yesterday of the first two major buildings in the $1 billion Metrotech office and academic complex in downtown Brooklyn.

title: Gasoline Prices Decline
description: Gasoline prices across the nation continued to drop in the last two weeks, the Lundberg survey of retailers has indicated. The survey of 12,000 gasoline stations concluded that average prices for all grades of gasoline and all types of service went down about a third of a penny, to 117.61 cents, in the two-week period that ended Friday, the survey's publisher, Trilby Lundberg, said on Sunday.

title: Cogeco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After special charges of $99,000 and $300,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Metro Datelines; Fallen Young Falcon Is Back in the Nest
description: A fledgling peregrine falcon was back in the nest on the high ledges of a hospital yesterday after spending Sunday in an animal shelter recovering from a fall down a smokestack.

title: Photo of Lisa Greene with Marvin Bunch, the firefighter who rescued her 14 years ago from a burning house in Brooklyn. He was the guest of honor yesterday at her high school graduation. (NYT/Dith Pran); Girl, 17, Tracks Down Man Who Saved Her in '75 Fire
description: Lisa Greene was 3 years old when she was rescued from the smoke and flames that engulfed her family's two-story home in Brooklyn 14 years ago. Since then, the events of that day, Jan. 19, 1975, have receded in her memory, but the need to know her anonymous rescuer grew stronger.

title: Crippled Soviet Nuclear Sub Will Be Towed Home
description: A Soviet nuclear-powered submarine armed with nuclear weapons headed home today after a burst pipeline crippled its reactor in the Norwegian Sea, Soviet officials said.

title: Wright Confirms Plan to Resign From House
description: Former House Speaker Jim Wright closed the door today on a return to Congress, saying he was gratified by the continued support of his friends back home but had decided he was right in announcing his retirement.

title: Metro Datelines; Man Killed and Girl And 2 Others Shot
description: One man was killed and three others, including a 9-year-old girl, were wounded last night during a shootout on a Bronx street corner, the police said.

title: Bioplasty reports earnings for Qtr to April 30

title: Governor Again Invites Coal Strike Leaders to Talk
description: Gov. Gaston Caperton of West Virginia today made a new, unconditional offer for talks aimed at ending a coal miners' strike that has spread to 10 states.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Consumer's World page on June 17 about Lyme disease misidentified the tick repellent that Michael Cohen of Camp Timberlane in Wisconsin plans to use. He has selected Cutter.

title: Canadian Shot-Putter Tells of Steroid Role
description: A former Canadian shot-put champion admitted today that he used anabolic steroids during 11 years he competed and that he had supplied the drugs to other Canadian track and field athletes.

title: Kean Proposes Transit Plan For Waterfront
description: A $2.5 billion plan to help develop the Hudson County waterfront by building a 14-mile loop of rail lines, roadways and bus routes was announced today by Gov. Thomas H. Kean.

title: CUNY Trustees Name 2 as College Presidents
description: The trustees of the City University of New York filled two important vacancies yesterday, naming new presidents for Fiorello H. La Guardia Community College in Queens and Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn.

title: Death and Mockery
description: What a mockery these latest Supreme Court decisions make of this nation's pretensions to be the leading proponent of human rights!

title: Tentative Accord Is Reached Between Con Ed and Union
description: Consolidated Edison reached a tentative agreement last night on a new contract with a union representing 14,000 employees, hours before a midnight strike deadline, officials said.

title: Wordstar International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 39 Reportedly Killed By Philippine Rebels
description: Communist rebels attacked villagers at a church in a remote village and killed at least 39 people, officials said today.

title: 4 Cases Found Of Rare Strain Of AIDS Virus
description: Researchers have discovered several blood samples in New York City infected with a second strain of the AIDS virus, which is widespread in western Africa but considered extremely rare in the United States.

title: Business and Health; General Hospitals Feeling Pressure
description: HOSPITAL executives and health-care analysts say the long-predicted shakeout in the $200 billion hospital industry is gathering momentum. Changes in the practice and financing of medicine are diverting patients from general hospitals to specialized centers for outpatient surgery, cancer therapy and diagnostic testing.

title: Stuart Hall Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
FDP Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income

title: Thatcher Balks at Plan For a Monetary Union
description: Amid signs of a deepening rift within the European Community, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told a 12-nation summit meeting here today that Britain would not accept a widely supported plan to move the region toward monetary union.

title: Waterhouse Investor Servces Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
description: b-Net loss

title: Mets' Hitter Honored
description: The Mets' Howard Johnson, who batted .478 and hit three home runs in the seven-day period ending Sunday, was named National League Player of the Week. Johnson had 11 hits in 23 times at bat, drove in seven runs, had two doubles and a slugging percentage of .957 as the Mets won five of six games.(AP)

title: Review/Theater; A Civil War Panorama In 'John Brown's Body'
description: Stephen Vincent Benet's ''John Brown's Body'' was written as a story in verse to be read aloud. For that and other reasons, it comes resonantly to life on stage, as is evident in Peter Hunt's current version at the Williamstown Theater Festival. As directed by Mr. Hunt and as performed by a fine three-person cast -Christopher Reeve, Robert Lansing and Laurie Kennedy - the adaptation is an enlightening and deeply felt drama about the Civil War, seen through the prism of the author's comprehensive historical perspective.

title: Mapplethorpe Photographs to Be Shown in Capital
description: The Washington Project for the Arts, an organization of artists, has reached an agreement with the Institute of Contemporary Art in Philadelphia to bring an exhibition of photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe to Washington.

title: Company News; Chinese Buying VW Equipment
description: Volkswagen A.G. said it would sell the tooling and production equipment from its closed New Stanton, Pa., plant to First Automobile Works of Changchun, China. A VW spokesman, Tom McDonald, declined to put a dollar value on the transaction. He said the equipment from the plant would be removed in about four months and would be shipped to China. The New Stanton plant closed last July. It had produced subcompact Rabbits and Golfs for the United States market as well as Jetta compacts, but shut after VW's American sales declined.

title: New Director Named For Craft Museum
description: Janet Kardon has been named director of the American Craft Museum in Manhattan.

title: COURT SAYS YOUNG AND THE RETARDED CAN BE EXECUTED
description: A sharply divided Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution permits states to execute murderers who are mentally retarded as well as those who were as young as 16 years old when they committed their crimes.

title: Excerpts From Report Submitted by Dowd to Commissioner Giamatti
description: Following are excerpts from the report submitted to the commissioner of baseball, A. Bartlett Giamatti, by his special counsel, John Dowd, regarding the investigation into allegations of gambling activity by Pete Rose. The commissioner's office made copies available yesterday after a county judge in Ohio put the report into the public record. I. Introduction

Page B1. Immigration Chief Is Out Ending a lengthy standoff, the Justice Department accepted the resignation of Alan Nelson, head of the immigration service. Page A10. Hudson County Transit Plan Governor Kean announced a $2.5 billion plan to help develop the Hudson County waterfront by building a loop of rail lines and roads. Page B1. Clues to Planets' Rings As Voyager 2 nears Neptune, scientists are anticipating new insights into the mysteries of planetary rings.

title: Martin Marietta Executive To Be Its Next President
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation said yesterday that A. Thomas Young, who heads the company's electronics and missiles group, would be its next president.

title: Experiments In Packaging At TV Guide
description: ''SYNERGY'' may be the communications industry's most over-used term and under-used concept - except by the media mogul Rupert Murdoch, who has made TV Guide his synergy central.

title: Company Faces U.S. Inquiry on Oil Thefts
description: A Kansas-based company faces a criminal investigation based on allegations that it stole oil from Indian-owned wells, a spokesman for a Senate committee says.

title: Realcap Holdings Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Medical Waste Is Piling Up, Generating New Concerns
description: AS beach patrols keep a wary eye out for improperly discarded hypodermic needles and blood vials this summer, environmentalists, hospitals, refuse handlers and Government regulators are grappling with a more serious public health problem: even properly handled medical waste is becoming harder to dispose of safely.

title: Note and Bond Prices Continue Up
description: Treasury note and bond prices continued to advance yesterday, after rising sharply and then retreating but closing above the levels on Friday.

title: A Correction
description: In Arthur A. Witkin's letter on June 25 discussing the Supreme Court decision on affirmative action in the job market, the last paragraph should have begun, ''The Court has now lighened this burden on the employer.''

title: Company News; BellSouth Creates Worker Stock Plan
description: The BellSouth Corporation, the Atlanta-based regional telephone operating company created in the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said its board had authorized a leveraged employee stock ownership plan. Beginning in January, the company said, its matching contributions to the management savings plan will be made to the new BellSouth stock plan. The plan will be financed with up to $550 million of common stock, which will be purchased in the open market beginning next month.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM GOVERNING COUNCIL - 10 A.M.

title: Hurt's Ex-Wife Testifies for Him In Marital Case
description: Mary Beth Hurt testified yesterday that she had urged her ex-husband, the actor William Hurt, to marry the former ballet dancer he was living with in 1982 but that he had refused.

title: INSIDE
description: Carla Hills Acknowledges Lobbying for H.U.D. Funds Mrs. Hills, now United States trade representative, acknowledged that years after she left office as Housing Secretary she was paid to lobby for funds under a department program now under scrutiny. Page A14. Monetary Moves in Europe The European Community agreed to take steps toward a monetary union after the British leader dropped her opposition to steps that might lead to a common currency. Page D1. Merrill Lynch to Move Jobs Merrill Lynch will move 2,600 jobs from New York City to Jersey City, prompting New York to reduce its dealings with the company. Page B1.
