Helmsman Takes the Fifth The helmsman of an oil tanker that ran aground near Newport, R.I., refused to testify at a Coast Guard inquiry into the accident. Page B6. Well-Preserved Treasure In what may be a major discovery, a Spanish galleon from the 1600's was found deep off Florida. Page A14.

title: Call It an Account Number
description: To The Living Section:

title: Housing Drive for Blacks Ordered in Boston
description: Ruling that public housing in Boston has been managed in a discriminatory way, a Federal judge here has ordered that the operators of Government-subsidized housing take aggressive steps to make homes and apartments more available to blacks in the city and its suburbs.

title: Modern Television Has a Variety of Fathers
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Music; Songs About Nightingales and Fleas
description: Jocelyn Wilkes is a specialist in the Gilbert and Sullivan battle-ax roles. Every town has one, but not many are as enjoyable as Ms. Wilkes, who has been heard locally in most of these formidable parts and who has sung Katisha over 300 times in 17 different productions of ''The Mikado.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Grenadier Associates, a consulting firm in Stamford, Conn., has acquired Southern Links, a golf magazine published in Hilton Head Island, S.C.

title: About New York; A Woid (Sorry!) About the Birds In Brooklyn
description: ''Dere's no guy livin' dat knows Brooklyn t'roo and t'roo, because it'd take a lifetime just to find his way aroun' duh town.''

title: Results Plus
description: GOLF Zahringer Wins the Ike: George Zahringer 3d rallied from a four-stroke deficit at the beginning of play yesterday to capture the Ike tournament -the Metropolitan Golf Association's stroke-play championship - by five strokes at the Stanwich Country Club in Greenwich, Conn. Zahringer recorded a four-over-par 76 on opening day Monday, but came back strong with a four-under 68 yesterday morning to tie the amateur competitive record for the 7,133-yard course. He followed that with a 74 yesterday afternoon for a three-round total of 218 and his fourth title in the five tournaments he has played this season. Westchester Final Today: Darrell Kestner, the assistant pro at Sunningdale Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y., and Jim O'Mara, the head pro at Rockrimmon Country Club in Stamford, Conn., will play for the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester PGA title today at Waccabuc (N.Y.) Country Club. In the semifinals yesterday, Kestner defeated Rick Meskell of Century Golf Club, and O'Mara defeated David Young of Waccabuc. TRACK AND FIELD Lewis, Kingdom Victorious: Carl Lewis posted his 59th consecutive long-jump victory, and the two-time Olympic champion Roger Kingdom returned to his winning ways in running the year's fastest 110-meter high hurdles yesterday. Those events highlighted the Athletissima meet in Lausanne, Switzerland, the third stop on the 1989 International Amateur Athletic Federation Grand Prix circuit.

title: Olympia & York In BCE Unit Bid
description: Olympia & York Developments Ltd. agreed to offer to buy the BCE Development Corporation from BCE Inc. for a total of about $557 million. Olympia & York, controlled by the Reichmann family of Canada, will offer $2.80 for each outstanding share. It will also offer 39 cents for each common share purchase warrant entitling holders to buy BCE Development common shares at $5.50 each, 7 cents for each common share purchase warrant entitling holders to buy BCE Development common shares at $7.06 each and $92 for each $100 in principal amount of 8 percent convertible subordinated debentures.

title: Krug International reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,897,000 for the latest year and $2,221,000 for 1988. The latest year's results reflected the company's decision to sell the four subsidiaries which comprise its industrial segment, including Dempster Systems Inc., Dempster Systems Ltd., Shelvoke Dempster Ltd. and Krug Power & Control Ltd.

title: The Pop Life
description: Like a Buffalo

title: May Stores Plans to Sell 2 Discounters
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the May Department Stores Company's plans to sell Caldor and Venture stores misidentified David C. Farrell. He is chairman and chief executive of May.

title: Reviews/Film; A Fantasy Suspense That Puts Adventure First
description: A film that shuttles between an English village in 1348 and a New Zealand city in 1988 had better be brilliant or it's likely to look very foolish. Vincent Ward, the director and co-writer of ''The Navigator,'' takes every artistic risk his bizarre premise allows. He assumes a 14th-century point of view, moves from black-and-white photography for the medieval scenes to color for the present, and weaves evocative visual imagery into a suspense tale. The result is a dark, thrilling fantasy that places Mr. Ward, a 32-year-old New Zealander, among the most innovative and authoritative young film makers.

title: Book Notes
description: Writing Over Running

title: Dalai Lama Says Beijing Can't Crush Hopes
description: The Dalai Lama, the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, says the arrests and executions set in motion by the Chinese Government will fail to wipe out aspirations for liberty and democracy.

title: Reviews/Music; A Rain-Shortened 'Lucia'
description: Dark clouds hung over the Great Lawn of Central Park at the start of the Metropolitan Opera's concert version of Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' on Monday evening. But the crowd, estimated by the Met to be more than 75,000, was not easily intimidated.

title: Market Place; Computer-Driven Shifts of Assets
description: DESPITE the sharp climb in stock prices this year, some money managers still see bargains in the market. Using computer-driven strategies, they have recently begun shifting into stocks. That is because the decline in bond yields and the rally in fixed-income markets are making stocks look relatively more attractive than they were a few months ago, the managers say.

title: Bernard Brownstein, Exporter of Metals, 78
description: Bernard Brownstein, a metal distributor and philanthropist, died of a heart attack Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Time Inc.'s rejection of a takeover offer from Paramount Communications Inc. attributed a statement incorrectly in some editions. It was Time's board, not Paramount's board, that said it was ''confident that belated efforts to characterize the Time-Warner transaction as a sale of Time will be judged properly in the courthouse.''

title: Sikes Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Bridge
description: A defender who is lucky enough to have five trumps can usually assume control of the play if he can make the declarer ruff. The key for the declarer is sometimes to refuse to ruff, but the answer on the diagramed deal was quite different.

title: Pete Rose Needs Help, Not 'Life'
description: During Derby Week last month, somebody in Kentucky described Pete Rose arriving at a track in the past year and being whisked to a private room.

title: Carter Hawley Hale May Close Office
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. will close or merge its New York-based marketing services division into another buying office in New York to cut costs, it was rumored in the apparel market yesterday. Bill Dombroski, the retailer's vice president for communications, said at its headquarters in Los Angeles that the company did not comment on such reports. He also would not comment on the reasons for a meeting scheduled for Friday at the division's offices on West 40th Street in Manhattan. Reports yesterday said that the 200 employees of the division would be told of the changes at the meeting.

title: Hong Kong's Future Is in Need of Renegotiation
description: To the Editor:

title: Guests at White House Dinner for Australian Prime Minister
description: The guest list for the state dinner at the White House for Prime Minister Bob Hawke of Australia. President Bush and his wife, Barbara Prime Minister Bob Hawke and his wife, Hazel Michael J. Cook, Ambassador to the United States, and his wife, Catriona Michael Codd, Secretary, Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet Richard Woolcott, Secretary, Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade David A. Hollway, Prime Minister's principal private secretary Geoff Walsh, senior adviser John Bowan, senior adviser, international relations Rod Sims, senior adviser, economics Dennis Richardson, first assistant secretary, international division, Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet Barrie Cassidy, press secretary to the Prime Minister Dr. Craig Emerson, adviser, economics Graham Freudenberg, consultant Representative Bill Archer, Republican of Texas, and his wife, Sharon Roone Arledge, president of ABC News, and Joanna Bistany Francis J. (Reds) Bagnell and his wife, JoAnne Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and his wife, Susan John P. Birkelund, chairman of Dillon, Read & Company, and his wife, Constance Nicholas F. Brady, Secretary of the Treasury, and his wife, Katherine Bishop Edmund Browning, Presiding Bishop of the Episcopal Church of North and South America, and his wife, Patricia Dean Burch, lawyer, and his wife, Patricia Jonathan Bush and his wife, Josephine John Butler and his wife, Penny Raymond Chambers, chairman of the Wesray Capital Corporation, and his wife, Patricia William Clark Jr., Acting Secretary of State for Near East and Asian Affairs, and his wife, Judith John Cochran, White House Correspondent, NBC News, and Barbara Cohen, Washington Bureau Chief, CBS News Stephen Dart and his wife, Iris Gov. Edward D. DiPrete of Rhode Island, and his wife, Patricia William H. Draper 3d, administrator, United Nations Development Program, and his wife, Phyllis W. S. Farish, business executive, and his wife, Sarah William H. G. Fitzgerald, business executive, and his wife, Annelise Richard Freeland and his wife, Deanna David Garvey, pianist Robert Georgine, president, building and construction trades, A.F.L.-C.I.O., and his wife, Rita William T. Graham, Commissioner of Banks, North Carolina Department of Commerce, and his wife, Kent Joel Grey, actor Gen. Robert T. Herres, Vice Chairman, Joint Chiefs of Staff, and his wife, Shirley Prof. Samuel Hynes, Woodrow Wilson Professor of Literature, Princeton University, and his wife, Elizabeth Kay C. James, Assistant Secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services, and Mrs. Charles James Representative Norman F. Lent, Republican of Long Island, and his wife, Barbara Morris-Lent Carl H. Lindner, chairman and chief executive officer, American Financial Corporation, and his son, Carl Lindner 3d Allen E. Murray, chairman, Mobil

title: Calm Prevails as Albany Puts Emphasis on Speed
description: It is, by all accounts, the last week of this year's legislative session, and the bills are coming up so fast that the Assembly clerk hardly has time to read the last section - ''this act shall take effect immediately'' - when the electronic voting machine buzzes to signal that the vote has already been completed.

title: Cambridge Approves Rules For Research With Animals
description: This city, where animal research is part of the academic bread and butter, has approved an ordinance protecting the welfare of vertebrates used in experiments.

title: New York Honors 7 For Arts Contributions
description: Six individuals and an organization active in the arts in New York City were given Mayoral Awards of Honor for Art and Culture yesterday at a ceremony at Gracie Mansion. These were the seven award winners: Petra Barreras, the executive director of El Museo del Barrio. Robert Giroux, the chairman of Farrar, Straus & Giroux. Andrew Heiskell, the chairman of the New York Public Library. Lenon Holder Hoyte, the executive director of Aunt Len's Doll and Toy Museum in Harlem. Jack and Lewis Rudin of the Rudin Management Company. The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allstate Insurance Co., Northbrook, Ill., promoted Wayne E. Hedien to chairman and chief executive of Allstate Insurance Group and Raymond H. Kiefer to president of Allstate Insurance Co.

title: Corning Inc reports earnings for 12wks to June 18
description: b-After a tax credit of $700,000. c-Included tax credits of $1 million and $1.3 million for the 12 weeks and 24 weeks, respectively, and the 24 weeks also included a charge of $83.9 million representing cumulative effect of an accounting change. Latest 24 weeks also included a net gain of $2.6 million, or 3 cents a share, from sale of 3.2 percent interest in Corning Asahi Video Products Co. Year-ago 12 weeks and 24 weeks both included one-time after-tax gains of $20.5 million, or 23 cents a share, primarily from sale of International Clinical Laboratories Inc.

title: Electronics, Missiles & Comunications Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $176,000. c-Net loss

title: Freezer Mysteries
description: To The Living Section:

title: Gamma Biologicals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a charge of $3,085,000 from the writeoff of assets and a plant closing for both the quarter and year.

title: Hewlett Plans Cuts
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said it would terminate about 20 percent of the 500 workers at the headquarters of Apollo Computer Inc., a maker of computer work stations that it acquired last month. Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, said no job changes would be made at Apollo's plants in Exeter, N.H., and in Scotland. Hewlett-Packard said that 150 employees at Apollo's headquarters in Chelmsford, Mass., were no longer needed, but that 50 would be transferred to other positions. Hewlett-Packard, a leading manufacturer of measurement and computing products, has 93,000 employees.

title: Canada's Liberals Ready to Wait for a Leader
description: An article on Wednesday about the Canadian Liberal Party's search for a leader misstated the date by which the next general election must be held. It is Nov. 21, 1993.

title: White House Gala A la Barbara Bush
description: At 6:15 P.M., the temperature was still 94 degrees. An hour later, as the guests began to arrive at the White House for the state dinner tonight in honor of Prime Minister Bob Hawke of Australia and his wife, Hazel, many of them looked relieved to be in air-conditioning.

title: Nance Out for Month
description: Larry Nance, a Cleveland Cavaliers forward, had surgery to repair a frayed tendon in his left ankle yesterday and will probably miss the first month of the season. Dr. John Bergfeld performed the surgery at the Cleveland Clinic, a team spokesman, Bob Price, said.

title: William J. Greer, 79, A Chemical Executive
description: William Jackson Greer, chief executive officer of Swiss-tex Inc., manufacturer of polyurethane foams, who earlier had founded the Texize Chemicals Company, died of bone cancer Monday at Greenville Memorial Hospital in South Carolina. He was 79 years old and lived in Greenville.

title: H & R Block Officer Shifts
description: Henry Bloch, 66 years old, a co-founder of the tax preparation company H&R Block Inc., will step aside as president Aug. 1, becoming chairman, the company announced Monday.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The National Archives, a Federal agency responsible for preserving historical documents and Government records, yesterday priced $301.7 million of trust certificates through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ONE of my favorite Fourth of July weekend meals is barbecued leg of lamb with herbs and garlic. It is always advisable to have your butcher butterfly the leg, which involves removing the center bone so the meat can be laid out flat on a grill and cooked more evenly.

title: Every Fourth of July, a Taste of 1776
description: EVERY year Dorothy Batchelder, whose father's family settled in Massachusetts in the 1600's and whose mother traces her family's arrival in this country to the Mayflower, eats poached salmon, peas and new potatoes and strawberry shortcake on the Fourth of July.

title: AIDS Drug Tested Secretly By Group Critical of F.D.A.
description: Contending that an official study is moving too slowly, a group of doctors and advocates for AIDS patients is conducting a clandestine study of a promising drug to treat the ailment.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Monday about a study of the Nicaraguan economy described one recommendation imprecisely in some copies. The study said it might be necessary to impose an emergency surcharge of 20 to 30 percent on sales, excise and corporate income taxes already being levied. The article also described the report incompletely. It was compiled at Nicaraguan request by Renato Aguilar, Stefan de Vylder and Teresa Hellgren of Sweden, Jose Antonio Ocampo of Colombia and Lance Taylor of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; a copy was made available to The New York Times.

title: AM Communications Inc reports earnings for Year to March 30
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $618,000 on restructuring liabilities- -largely debt forgiveness resulting from negotiations with major creditors. Year-ago revenue included $970,000 gain on sale of land and building.

title: Nofziger Wins Court Reversal Of Conviction
description: A Federal appeals court today overturned the ethics conviction of Lyn Nofziger, a close adviser to Ronald Reagan in the California governor's office and in the first year of the Reagan Presidency.

title: Murder and Mercy; New York Needs Life Without Parole
description: This year, Albany has performed its ritual dance over death with sad syncopation. As in other years, the New York Senate and Assembly passed a capital punishment bill; the Governor vetoed it; and supporters of the bill conducted a futile campaign to override. This year, victory seemed close until Senator James Donovan, a staunch supporter of the death penalty, developed doubts as cancer threatened his own life.

title: NASA Says Test Engine Fire May Delay Shuttle Mission
description: A fire that broke out in an engine in a test firing last Friday could delay the launching of the space shuttle Columbia this summer, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

title: Embarrassment in El Salvador
description: LEAD: Ask the average U.S. citizen to identify Roberto D'Aubuisson and you are likely to get an unknowing shrug. Ask the average Salvadoran and you will also fail to get an answer - but for a very different reason. Many there think of him as the most dangerous man in the country, a man who could have an archbishop murdered and get away with it.

title: Beijing Orders 2 More Americans to Leave China
description: In a sign of continuing diplomatic tensions, two Americans have been ordered to leave China, presumably because of their activities during the recent pro-democracy demonstrations, an American official here said today.

title: Wall Critical of Bailout Bill
description: The Bush Administration will be forced to double its initial spending on savings and loan association rescues if Congress restricts the financial power of the new savings industry bailout agency, M. Danny Wall, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said today.

title: Koreans Settle Shipyard Strike
description: Striking workers at South Korea's second-largest shipbuilder agreed by a slim majority to a pay package offered by the company and should return to work soon, company officials said today.

title: Lawrence Davis Barney, Pharmaceutical Executive, 83
description: Lawrence Davis Barney, former president of Hoffmann-La Roche Inc., died of cancer Sunday at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, N.J. He was 83 years old and lived in Montclair, N.J.

title: General Sciences Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Two Courter Aides Tied to H.U.D. Resign
description: Two political consultants to Representative James A. Courter, the Republican nominee for governor, resigned today as a result of their ties to a firm that has figured in the scandal involving accusations of influence peddling at the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Rockport, Wash.
description: LEAD: GENE KAHN, a 42-year-old self-confessed potato freak, grows 300 varieties of the humble tuber - something of a personal collection - on 110 acres of his 150-acre Cascadian Farm in the Skagit Valley north of Seattle.

title: Union Reports Mobil Pact
description: The Mobil Corporation and the Chemical Workers Industrial Union reached an agreement today on most elements of the oil company's withdrawal from South Africa, the union announced.

title: Deep in the Heart of Wine Country
description: EXPERIMENTATION is in the wind at Fall Creek Vineyards, a flourishing winery in the Texas hill country.

title: Tax Credits for Poor Workers Won't Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Coleslaw: How You Like It Depends On Where You Live
description: LEAD: COLESLAW is probably more often bought than homemade these days, yet it is everything ''home cooking'' should be - familiar, flavorful, nourishing and quickly and inexpensively prepared. It's easy to transport, easy to serve and eat, and it doesn't take up much room in the refrigerator.

title: KEY RATES
Juno Lighting reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a gain of $165,000 from an accounting change. The latest quarter and 6 months' sales figures included results of Indy Lighting Inc., which was acquired in November 1988.

title: Hamilton Digital Controls Inc reports earnings for Year to April 30
Expos Set Back Ailing Mets
description: The hard news swept over the Mets in waves tonight: They lengthened their already lengthy casualty list when they lost Barry Lyons for a month with a broken toe, they fielded a team of irregulars with first place at stake, they struggled for 4 hours 9 minutes in their longest game of the year and then they lost it to the Montreal Expos, 3-2, in 14 punishing innings.

title: HELMSMAN REFUSES TO GIVE TESTIMONY
description: The seaman who was at the helm Friday when an oil tanker ran aground near Newport refused to testify today at a Coast Guard inquiry into the accident.

title: Budigere Journal; Gandhi on the Stump: Give Power to the Villagers!
description: Rajiv Gandhi, the candidate who went to the voters in 1984 promising to whisk village India into the high-tech age, is a different man with a different theme in 1989.

title: Tunisia Growth Forecast
description: Tunisia slashed its 1989 growth forecast today because of a poor grain harvest and said it would have to modify an economic liberalization program intended to make the country more competitive.

title: On Oil Spills: Trust Turns Into Anger
description: When will America learn? The lessons of the Exxon Valdez calamity in March are shouted out all over again by the three new tanker spills:

title: Georgia Answers Kemp
description: Charles B. Knapp, president of the University of Georgia, said at a news conference in Athens, Ga., yesterday that a three-month investigation of grievances filed by Jan Kemp, an English instructor in Georgia's developmental studies program, had found that Kemp was subject to retaliation, but that most of her complaints had little merit. Kemp said that the report was flawed but added that she was gratified by the stand the report took against the retaliatory acts. (AP)

title: Warning to Creditor Banks
description: Banking regulators threatened today to raise reserve requirements for leading United States banks with loans to developing countries unless there is progress soon on Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady's plan for reducing third world debt.

title: Krug Sale Backed
description: The Krug International Corporation said its directors had authorized management to sell the four units that make up its industrial segment. Krug said its resources were insufficient to pay for the expected growth of all present operations. It said that William Blair & Company had been hired for advice on the sale of Dempster Systems Inc., Dempster Systems Ltd. and Shelvoke Dempster Ltd. Krug, based in Dayton, said it was negotiating the sale of Krug Power and Control Ltd., a British distributor of hydraulic equipment.

title: Real Estate; Vertical Mall Rises in Old Gimbels Store
description: IN the second attempt to create a successful indoor shopping center in the Herald Square area, a prime retail district in Manhattan, a team of developers is carving a sleek vertical mall out of the old Gimbels department store.

title: Francois Mergen, 64, Ex-Teacher
description: Dr. Francois Mergen, professor emeritus and former dean of Yale University's School of Forestry and Environmental Studies, died of liver failure Monday at Seven Rivers Community Hospital in Crystal Rivers, Fla. He was 64 years old and lived in Homosassa, Fla.

title: Europeans Adopt New Sanctions Against Chinese
description: Stepping up their pressure on China to stop executions and repression of political dissidents, European Community leaders announced a series of new reprisals today against Beijing, including a suspension of military cooperation and arms sales.

title: Burmese Attack Karen Rebels
description: Hundreds of Burmese troops backed by mortar and artillery fire today attacked Karen guerrilla positions near the Thai border, Karen rebel sources said. No casualties were reported. With about 8,000 armed fighters, the Karens are the largest of a dozen ethnic groups that have fought for more than four decades for greater autonomy from Myanmar, formerly Burma.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Atlanta
description: LEAD: BEVERLY WORRELL has discovered a way to combine down-home cooking with fast-food convenience: the Muffin de Soul. ''It is a neat, portable way to get home-cooked vegetables, the same way you could eat a hamburger,'' Mrs. Worrell said in the kitchen of Puffin Muffin, her shop in the Greenbriar Mall in southwest

title: Greenspan Leaves Hospital
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, was released from a hospital this morning after being treated overnight for heat exhaustion, a Fed spokesman said today.

title: PRESIDENT TO SEEK AMENDMENT TO BAR BURNING THE FLAG
description: Responding to two complex and emotional issues recently reopened by the Supreme Court, the Bush Administration said today that it planned no immediate legislation to revise the Court's rulings on civil rights but would push for a constitutional amendment against flag burning.

title: Cantel Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $4,424,000 for the quarter and $6,397,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses of $582,000 and $1,332,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively; the 9 months also included an extraordinary credit of $41,000.

title: 38 Families Settle Cases in '87 Plane Crash
description: The families of 38 of the 43 people killed when a dismissed airline employee brought down a jetliner in December 1987 settled their cases out of court today. The settlements came just before final arguments were to be heard in the liability trial against USAir and others in Los Angeles Superior Court. Damage cases brought by the families of two passengers, a flight attendant and the pilot remain.

title: Energy Chief Says Top Aides Lack Skills to Run U.S. Bomb Complex
description: Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said today that managers and supervisors in his department lacked technical skills needed to run the bomb production system and were presenting him with unreliable information on problems at the plants. Some, he said, lacked the discipline needed for safe operation of nuclear reactors.

title: Pupil Advisory Program Looks New in 17th Year
description: Right there in the principal's office, with four classmates watching, Matthew Kavanaugh, a sixth grader, balled up his sandwich wrapper and tossed it across the room at the wastebasket.It bounced off the side.

title: Animed Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $9,900 for the quarter and $785,100 for the 6 months. The company said the loss in the latest quarter included $820,600 in goodwill writeoffs and $477,000 in reserves set aside for the consolidation of the company's California labs.

title: Back Surgery for Kittle
description: Ron Kittle, who was among the American League leaders in home runs and runs batted in when he left the Chicago White Sox lineup June 19, will undergo back surgery next month, the team announced yesterday. Kittle, a designated hitter and first baseman, will apparently be lost for the remainder of the season.

title: Maggie on the Beach
description: Margaret Thatcher tried to do it again, digging in her heels, lecturing archly on her achievements, illuminating our European partners on the superior virtue of her ways. But it isn't working well anymore.

title: New Boats Are Giving Soviet Sailors the Jitters
description: Most sailors would be happy to have a new boat to sail. But a group of five sailors from the Soviet Union, invited here to compete in the Liberty Cup regatta in New York Harbor, are jittery about new boats.

title: GATT Weighs New Rules On Protection of Industries
description: Trade negotiators here are considering a compromise proposal aimed at ending the voluntary restraint agreements that many nations including the United States use to protect their industries against an unexpected surge in imports.

title: Echlin Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The latest quarter and 9 months included a gain equaled to about 3 cents a share on the sale of surplus assets. The year-ago periods included a gain of about 3 cents a share from non- operating earnings.

title: Review/Film; 'Taxing Woman's Return' in a Venal Tokyo
description: ''Money is a living thing, It grows with time. Money is my child, my future life. When I am one with money, I am immortal.''

title: Tigers and Trammell Spoil Sax's Big Night
description: The Yankees could have looked into the murky waters of last season and still seen the three games they played at Tiger Stadium in late June. They were Billy Martin's last as manager; they seemed to stand alone as three reasons why the season eventually tipped over.

title: The Thing Thing
description: A relaxed George Bush is learning to make fun of the press, and of himself. Talking on Monday with reporters from The New York Times, he referred to ''the Covenant House thing'' in discussing a New York shelter for homeless young people. ''Cancel the word 'thing,' '' he interjected, and in a mock-lofty tone corrected himself: ''the Covenant House visit.''

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Falls Church, Va.
description: LEAD: ACROSS the Potomac River from Washington, squeezed into a scruffy strip of neighborhood shops, is what may be the only Chinese restaurant in the nation with a bulletproof plate glass window.

title: Review/Film; Just One Joke After Another
description: Bran Ferren's ''Funny,'' the 81-minute documentary opening today at Film Forum 1, is the movie equivalent to a comedy record you listen to once and, if with friends, laugh at, even when it's not especially funny.

title: In Post-Shoreham Era, Lilco Seeks New Image
description: As the Long Island Lighting Company enters its post-Shoreham era, its chairman, Dr. William J. Catacosinos, is now trying to erase the bitter feelings many customers have toward Lilco.

title: Mark's Work Wearhouse Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-After a special gain of $450,000. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Holtzman Under Fire on Suspension
description: District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn has touched off a protest among her assistants by suspending a prosecutor for seeking low bail for a defendant who the authorities say killed a New York City police officer less than a month later.

title: Task Force Tries to Save Tree Poisoned in Texas
description: A task force of experts has been formed to devise a strategy for treating Austin's Treaty Oak, which was poisoned when someone poured a powerful herbicide around its base.

title: Steroids Accusation
description: Charges that East Germany gives its young athletes steroids and that all its top sports stars are required to use the drug were made yesterday in a mass-circulation West German newpaper, Bild, and its affiliate Sunday newspaper, Bild am Sonntag, They quoted a former East German world champion ski jumper, Hans-Georg Aschenbach, as saying that steroids are mandatory among top East German athletes, that he was told to take them during his athletic career and that they are required among such East German athletes as Katerina Witt, the Olympic figure skating champion; Renate Stecher, the sprinter, and Kristin Otto, the swimmer.

title: Traders in Time Inc. Battle Are Out on a Sizable Limb
description: Wall Street's professional traders are discovering that in the battle for Time Inc. the risk in risk arbitrage is staggering.

title: India and Pakistan in Talks on Kashmir
description: India and Pakistan are working for the withdrawal of their armies from a Himalayan glacier and the creation of a demilitarized zone in an area where they have clashed for five years, a senior Indian official said today.

title: British Wang Plant
description: The British Government said it would try to recover cash grants paid to Wang Laboratories Inc. to finance a factory in Scotland that is now scheduled to close, costing 240 jobs. Wang, a computer maker based in Lowell, Mass., said on Monday that it planned to close the plant. The plant, in Stirling, Scotland, was opened by Prince Charles in 1984, and the Government has provided money in hopes that it would create up to 780 jobs.

title: Canonie Environmental Servces Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
McEnroe Withstands An Endurance Test
description: On a day in which his match was delayed for nearly an hour by rain and his service game was delayed for the first two sets, John McEnroe managed to overcome his discomfort at Centre Court and win his opening match.

title: The New Think Tank on the Block
description: Does this city really need another think tank?

title: Disk-Drive Maker In Chapter 11
description: Domain Technology Inc., the troubled manufacturer of hard disk drives, had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The company, based in Milpitas, Calif., said it expected to continue operations while it searched for working capital. ''This is the latest step that has become necessary as a result of the company's efforts to restructure its operations and assets to be more commensurate with its reduced sales level,'' said David B. Pearce, Domain's chief executive.

title: Clarksdale Journal; An Institution on Mississippi Radio
description: ''I'm going to tell you this before I quit,'' said Early Wright, the Chaucer of the Mississippi Delta, clasping his hands together as if in prayer as he leaned toward the microphone at Radio WROX. ''If your toenails don't grow, you're wearing your shoes too small. Buy your shoes large enough, because your feet are so nice to your body.''

title: NMR of America reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $507,298. c-Net loss Revenue represents net revenue.

title: F.T.C. Approves Sun Divestitures
description: The Federal Trade Commission approved the Sun Company's proposed divestiture of light-petroleum product terminals and gasoline stations in Binghamton, N.Y., and Williamsport, Pa. The moves are required by an order settling charges that Sun's acquisition of the Atlantic Petroleum Corporation could lessen competition in distributing and marketing gasoline and other products in the areas.

title: Coors to Drop Criticized Ad
description: The Adolph Coors Company said today that it would drop a television commercial after a prominent Polish-American in New York called for a boycott of Coors beer, asserting the ad made fun of Polish music and heritage.

title: Critic's Notebook; Where Connoisseurs And Cowboys Play
description: They've gone home, all those piano players from goodness knows where. Most disappeared in a cloud of dust somewhere over Oklahoma, either on their way back east or else to the next piano competition. The foreign accents sound fainter and fainter, Van Cliburn is out making his comeback on the concert stage and his famous International Piano Competition has closed up shop for another four years.

title: Books of The Times; The Literary Country As Vivid as Reality
description: A Link With the River By Desmond Hogan 325 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.95.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the oil spill in the Delaware River misstated the ownership of the oil aboard a tanker that ran aground Saturday. None of the oil was owned by the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company.

title: Davis, Chief of Raiders, Makes Visit to Oakland
description: Al Davis, the managing partner of the Los Angeles Raiders, yesterday visited George Vukasin, the president of the Oakland Coliseum, the stadium in which the Raiders played for 22 years before moving to Los Angeles in 1982. They spoke about an offer from Vukasin to move the Raiders back to Oakland.

title: Women's Hall of Fame Expects to Stay Open
description: A $100,000 pledge from the Gannett Foundation and $30,000 in donations from nearly 1,000 people will enable the National Women's Hall of Fame to remain open, its board of directors said Monday night.

title: Cablec Chief Takes Same Title at Brintec
description: Harry C. Schell, who took a power cable company from $50 million in annual sales to $500 milllion in the last five years, has added another company to the fold.

title: Requirements Are Cut for Foreigners
description: The PGA Tour took its first step today toward reducing the number of tournaments foreign members are required to play.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Dorf & Stanton To Shandwick
description: Shandwick P.L.C. heightened its profile in New York yesterday by acquiring Dorf & Stanton Communications, the nation's eighth-largest independent public relations firm.

title: New Fields for the Supercomputer
description: Using a supercomputer to process a payroll or to make hotel reservations may sound a bit like using a sledgehammer to kill ants, but in fact these exotic machines are showing some real advantages for many business tasks.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There is a growing trend here to re-look at the entire abortion issue. The Supreme Court decision may well have serious implications for Europe.'' - Mark Laskin, a Planned Parenthood official in London. [ A9:1. ]

title: United Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $395,000 and $241,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively. Year-ago quarter results are restated to correct the amortization of product introduction costs previously reported.

title: People
description: * Sherry Carniglia has been named deputy general manager and Michael Goefft account director on the U S Sprint account at J. Walter Thompson/San Francisco.

title: Apogee Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 3
Economic Scene; A Plan to Ration Airport Runways
description: THE seats are cramped, the service is ragged and bargain fares all seem to require 45 days' advance purchase plus a change of planes in Memphis. Is airline deregulation, supernova in the free marketers' firmament, burning out?

title: Taiwan Ends Stock Inquiry
description: The Government of Taiwan suspended an investigation into illegal trading today, and some brokers said election politics was behind the move.

title:
BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
It Answers Phone, but Can It Type?
description: LEAD: rrA Los Angeles company is marketing an answering device for people working alone who want the prestige that comes with having a secretary but cannot afford one.

title: St. Louis Mayor Home After Alleged Threat
description: Mayor Vincent C. Schoemehl Jr. and his family returned home under increased police protection after fleeing their house for 48 hours because of threats that were alleged to have been made by the city's airport commissioner.

title: U.S. Reports a Thai Pledge on Cambodians
description: A State Department official said today that the United States had been assured by the Thai Government that Cambodian refugees would not be forced to return to camps run by the Communist Khmer Rouge guerrillas.

title: Fannie Mae Prices $2.1 Billion Issue
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, which sells debentures each month, yesterday priced a $2.1 billion issue at par through various securities dealers.

title: Sea Containers Sets Discussion Terms
description: Sea Containers Ltd., the Bermuda-based shipping company, specified the conditions under which it would enter into negotiations with Temple Holdings Ltd. about Temple's $50-a-share bid. In a letter included in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Sea Containers said it would begin the talks if Temple was ''prepared to offer realistic and competitive pricing'' and if it provided assurances from its financial advisers that the company would have the money for a sweetened bid.

title: Ketema Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: There was no comparison because the company began operations last December.

title: Jazz Festival; The Many Faces of Dr. John
description: From one rhythmic angle, Dr. John's grumbling left-hand chords and florid right-hand filigrees become gospel piano. Tilt them differently, and they're barrelhouse blues; let them roll a little, and they become rhythm-and-blues. In any form, it's pure New Orleans piano, and Mac (Dr. John) Rebennack turned his solo concert at 5 P.M. Monday at Weill Hall into a tour of New Orleans, from Mardi Gras songs to his own hit ''Such a Night'' to a radically revamped ''When the Saints Go Marching In.''

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Prices of Treasury securities continued to climb yesterday, with the biggest increases posted by issues with the longest and most volatile maturities. But the bond market had to overcome an unsettling rumor.

title: Scholar Exchanges Jolted by Tremors in Beijing
description: One casualty of the turmoil in China may be the scholarly and scientific collaboration that has enriched knowledge in the United States and China, opening up the geologic wonders of Tibet and the workings of the Chinese Communist Party for Americans while helping the Chinese fight off a potent crop disease.

title: Oliver Baldwin Dies; A Retired Banker, 57
description: Oliver Hazard Perry Baldwin, a retired banker and retired Air Force colonel, died yesterday at the Devon Manor Home in Pennsylvania after a long illness. He was 57 years old and had moved to the home from Villanova, Pa.

title: Trump Offers Unusual Plan To Use 'Underwater Zoning'
description: Plumbing the depths of the Hudson River, Donald J. Trump is proposing to extract extra development rights from some partially submerged waterfront property and, in essence, haul those rights ashore for use in the proposed Trump City project on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Strike at French Papers
description: France had no national newspapers today because of a 24-hour strike by printers protesting modernization plans that threaten to reduce the number of newspaper jobs. The Communist-dominated CGT trade union federation also blocked distribution in Paris of foreign dailies.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Oak Industries Owners Pick Interim President
description: LEAD: The investor group that gained control of Oak Industries Inc. after winning a proxy battle yesterday named an interim president, the first step in overhauling the company's management.

title: Graduation Ceremonies Unmarred by Cameras
description: To the Editor:

title: Lennar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Recognition Spurns Offer
description: Recognition Equipment Inc., which makes data- and document-processing systems, said today that its board had rejected the unsolicited tender offer made last week by the Prospect Group.

title: EAT WELL
description: IT'S a mine field out there. In one corner of the supermarket are the chocolate ice cream bars; in another the honey-dipped doughnuts. Even in places where you think you are safe, like the cereal aisle, there's granola, which is more like cookie crumbs than cereal. But by treading cautiously and choosing with steely-eyed determination, health-conscious shoppers can emerge unscathed.

title: Stocks Rebound; Dow Advances by 14.99
description: Stocks advanced broadly yesterday as portfolio managers resumed their buying as part of their usual ''window dressing'' at the end of the quarter.

title: Monitek Technologies Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Comparable year-ago quarter's results were not immediately available. The company said the fourth quarter loss was primarily due to an inventory writedown of approximately $170,000.

title: Money, Not Gestures, Would Help City Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Kings Take Ellison First in N.B.A. Draft; Clippers Pick Ferry
description: LEAD: Three years ago, when his Louisville team won the national collegiate championship, Pervis Ellison earned the rare distinction as a freshman of being named the most valuable player of basketball's Final Four. Last night, the 6-foot-9 1/2-inch Ellison became the first player selected in the National Basketball

title: Sports News Briefs; Palmer Surveys Familiar Scene
description: Arnold Palmer said today he hoped to end a private slump at the United States Senior Open, which begins Wednesday.

title: Bush Campaign-Finance Package To Be Tilted Toward the G.O.P.
description: The campaign finance package President Bush plans to announce Thursday is intended to help Republicans more than Democrats. He acknowledged as much today at a private meeting with advocates of changes in campaign finance law.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-13 The Soviet legislature won a face-off in the battle for control of the Government when it blocked the appointment of eight top officials approved by the Communist Party. Page A1

title: An Ex-Leader, a Mystery and the Eternal Nile
description: The exiled former President of the Sudan is not taking calls at his villa on the outskirts of Cairo these days. As an aide explained it, he has begun his campaign for a Sudanese comeback, having left for the airport, destination unknown.

title: SOVIET DEPUTIES, IN SHOW OF POWER, BLOCK 8 NOMINEES
description: The new Soviet legislature won its first major skirmish in the battle for control of the Government today when it blocked the appointment of eight top officials approved by the Communist Party.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Restoring A Lost Touch To Marketing
description: DON JOHNSTON has proved that you can, indeed, keep a good man down. The former chairman of the JWT Group, who has spent the two years since the company's acquisition by the WPP Group learning to fly, has returned to earth and taxied into a consulting partnership with Leonard S. Matthews, former president of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

title: TV Network Ratings Fall
description: With reruns dominating the ABC, CBS and NBC schedules last week, only 60 percent of the prime-time audience watched the broadcast networks, well below the season average of 67 percent. The rest of the viewers tuned in to cable, independent and public television stations.

title: Salvagers Find Hulk of Galleon South of Florida
description: In what archeologists say may be one of the most important discoveries ever of a Spanish galleon, a ship from the early 1600's has been found off southwest Florida in 1,500 feet of water, a depth where the temperature and pressure have apparently preserved much of the wooden vessel and her cargo.

title: Couple Killed on Wedding Day
description: A Michigan couple were buried side by side here Monday after being killed in a car crash on the way to their wedding. Donald Fournier, 25 years old, and Diane Dennis, 20, were killed Friday on their way from a Detroit suburb to northern Michigan, where both had been reared. Their car was struck head on by the driver of a pickup truck going the wrong way on Interstate 75 near Holly, Mich. The driver, Teresa Louise Patterson, 28, of Pontiac, Mich., was also killed.

title: Corrections
description: The chart of major financial indicators at the top of the Business Digest in Business Day yesterday misstated the value of the dollar on Monday and its change since Friday. In late trading in New York, the dollar rose 2.25 yen, to 141.10 yen.

title: Canton Looks Back, and Sees the Crackdown Gaining
description: At midnight, the strobe-lighted marble floor of the disco in the China Hotel was still jammed with young Chinese couples.

title: Navratilova, Graf Beat The Rain And Foes
description: A chilly burst of rain splattered down today on the grass at Wimbledon, delaying matches and sending spectators hustling toward the canopied zones of food and memorabilia. On the second day of this two-week jewel on the Grand Slam agenda, spectators were busy furling and unfurling umbrellas in harmony with the afternoon showers.

title: Witness Cites Anchor In Delaware Grounding
description: A tugboat captain who answered the distress call of the tanker that spilled thick fuel oil into the Delaware River said the ship ran aground when she inexplicably dropped anchor a mile and a half from port.

title: Of Loose Lenders And Bad Debtors
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Have All the Capital's Visitors Gone?
description: Is it the wet weather? The highly publicized drug wars? A lack of ''knockout'' exhibitions at the Smithsonian Institution?

title: Dr. Isaac Starr, 94, Heart Researcher, Dies
description: Dr. Isaac Starr, a pioneering researcher and teacher in the field of cardiovascular disease, died Thursday at the Cathedral Village retirement community in Roxborough, Pa. He was 94 years old.

title: Ex-H.U.D. Chief Linked To Housing Lobby Bid
description: Carla Hills, the United States trade representative and a former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, acknowledged today that she was paid by a developer to lobby H.U.D. for money under programs that are now the subject of a Congressional investigation.

title: Artists With a Paintbrush and a Whisk
description: WHEN it comes to food, Rolando Briseno's palate is considerably more sophisticated than his palette. He never eats roasted chickens, for example, but as an artist he paints them all the time.

title: California Brings Grape-Fraud Suits
description: IF you have ever felt foolish because you don't know one wine from another, relax. In a series of pending court cases in California, state officials say growers sold tons of cheap grapes suitable for jug wines to several large wineries, passing them off as expensive zinfandel and chardonnay grapes. ''Just looking at the grapes, it's hard to tell,'' a winery owner, Frank Indelicato, told The Los Angeles Times recently. ''You have to analyze the seeds.''

title: Israeli Relief Aid for Armenia
description: Israel's national airline made its first direct flight to the Soviet Union today as part of a humanitarian mission to bring 66 survivors of last December's Armenian earthquake to Israel for treatment. Transport Minister Moshe Katzav said the El Al flight to Yerevan was another sign of improving relations between Israel and the Soviet Union. Israel has sent military doctors to help those injured in the earthquake and in a rail accident in the Urals.

title: 2 Arab Inmates Dead in Gaza Prison Camp
description: The headline of a brief article yesterday about the deaths of two Palestinians in a prison camp located the camp incorrectly. It is in the Negev, not Gaza.

title: Cabletron Systems reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company became a public company on May 31. Prior to that date, the company was a subchapter S Corporation. Net income and net income per share, therefore, calculated pro forma on a basis comparable with other public companies.

title: C.D. Yields Down Again For Week
description: Yields offered for certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts were down again for the week ended yesterday. Among certificates with longer maturities, the yield spread is extremely narrow. The yield on a one-year C.D. is similar to what is available on a five-year certificate.

title: Captured U.S. Photographer Is Seen in the Afghan Capital
description: An American photographer captured on June 8 while traveling with the Afghan rebels appeared at a news conference today, the first time he was seen in public since his capture.

title: Landmark Restaurant Reopens in France
description: If there was ever a time when that food scribe's hackneyed phrase ''culinary temple'' had any journalistic verity, it was in describing La Pyramide, which was perhaps the pre-eminent French restaurant of this century and which aspires to be again. After 18 months of renovations, the restaurant reopened last week under new ownership.

title: Tokyo, Unsure of U.S., Talks Of Developing Its Own Arms
description: Stung by Congressional reluctance to share American weapons technology for a new advanced jet fighter, the Japanese military is quietly preparing to develop highly advanced weapons by itself in the expectation that American assistance will be greatly curtailed in coming years.

title: Guide on Mammograms Is Endorsed
description: A dozen health organizations endorsed guidelines for breast cancer screening today that call for women to have a mammogram every one to two years, beginning at the age of 40, to aid early detection of the disease.

title: The Capital
description: So far in the Bush Presidency, flashes of feeling have been rare. But on Monday, George Bush was extremely firm on a subject he feels he knows particularly well.

title: World-Wide Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income for the latest and year-ago quarters. Prior year figures are for the 7 months from inception to March 31, 1988.

title: Rose's Lawyers Strike at Report
description: Now that the Dowd report has become public and a torrid topic of conversation, what will happen with it next? If Pete Rose's lawyers can succeed in having the commissioner permanently barred from deciding if Rose bet on baseball games, their next task will be to shred the report, at least figuratively.

title: Review/Television; Stand-Up Comics Bolster Sitcoms
description: While life in these United States sometimes resembles a situation comedy, its cast of characters encompassing everybody from wisecracking teen-agers to muscle-bound wrestlers whose brawls are miraculously bloodless, the sitcom itself is coming full circle as it searches for new ideas and material. The basic form came out of stand-up comedy, beginning with the vaudeville stars who found employment in early radio. Jack Benny, Fred Allen, George Burns and Gracie Allen -they and many others brought their routines to broadcasting's enormous audiences. Gradually, brief comedy sketches were expanded to fill most of the 30-minute formats. Then, beginning in the late 1940's, came the move to television, and the situation comedy was born.

title: Abortion Fight Has New Front in Western Europe
description: In doctors' offices, church halls and political back rooms across Western Europe, a quiet shift is taking place on the issue of whether and when a woman has the right to end a pregnancy.

title: Rhode Islanders Find Pull of the Bay Is Strong
description: When word spread last Saturday that a grounded tanker was spilling oil onto the beaches of Narragansett Bay, the telephones of Save the Bay started ringing off the hook.

title: Canadian Drilling Slows
description: Drilling activity in western Canada has slowed, reflecting a lack of interest by the oil companies, the Canadian Association of Oilwell Drilling Contractors, an industry group, said today. The group said that 130 rigs were active in the week ended today, down from 145 in the previous week. In the period last year, 236 rigs were working, the group said.

title: Grand Jury Vote Expected Soon In Union Inquiry
description: After a three-year investigation, law-enforcement officials say evidence is being presented to a grand jury on possible extortion and labor racketeering in a case against the head of a Bronx construction union that authorities have labeled a front for organized crime.

title: Metro-North Seeking to Bar Officers' Return
description: Officials of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad will intercede with the Superintendent of the State Police to try to block an arbitrator's order that they reinstate three railway police officers, officials for the commuter line said yesterday.

title: Cuban General Fully Confesses And Declares, 'I Deserve to Die'
description: In a riveting, abject confession to charges of drug trafficking and corruption, one of Cuba's highest-ranking army officers was shown on state television tonight describing himself as a traitor to the Cuban revolution and saying that ''I deserve to die.''

title: Summagraphics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
JUDGE ORDERS END TO STRIKE ACTIONS
description: A Federal district judge ruled today that nearly 43,000 coal miners on wildcat strikes in nine states are violating United States labor law. He ordered the United Mine Workers unions to try to end the strikes, and he ordered union members not to engage in any strike-related activities.

title: Control Data Sets Pact With Convex
description: The Convex Computer Corporation and the Control Data Corporation said they had formed an agreement in which Control Data will sell and integrate Convex's C series supercomputers into selected areas, markets and accounts. The agreement follows Control Data's announcement that it would close its supercomputer-producing unit, ETA Systems Inc., after sustaining several years of losses.

title: Failure in Cola
description: At the supermarket to buy soft drinks for a party of 25, I faced acres of confusion.

title: Japanese Brace for A Melee
description: When T. Boone Pickens shows up at the annual meeting of the Koito Manufacturing Company on Thursday morning as its largest and most unwelcome shareholder, it may be a corporate showdown far rougher than anything seen in America.

title: Interpharm Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago figures reclassified to conform with current year presentation.

title: Sears, Roebuck Is Offering $250 Million in Certificates
description: Sears Receivables Financing Group Inc., a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company, is offering $250 million of Sears credit account trust 1989 B pass-through certificates with a final maturity date of July 15, 1993. The securities are being sold through an underwriting syndicate led by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Hong Kong's Future Is in Need of Renegotiation; Imperiled Chinese Elite
description: To the Editor:

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: LETTER from a movie fan friend:

title: Brazilian Investor Charged
description: Naji Nahas, the investor who caused a crisis in Brazil's stock exchanges when he failed to pay brokers, has been charged on two counts in connection with episodes that occurred in previous years, police said today.

title: Ideas Listed for Keeping Guns From Felons
description: The Justice Department has published a list of possible methods the Government could use to prevent criminals from obtaining firearms, including the distribution of a national identity card and the creation of special computer networks for checking criminal records.

title: U.S. SEEKS POLICY ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: The Bush Administration has begun consulting with Congress over what it hopes will become a new bipartisan policy toward South Africa.

title: Suit Against Time in Court Today
description: Chancellor William T. Allen of the Delaware Chancery Court will hear arguments today in a suit brought by three Time Inc. stockholders who are seeking to block Time's annual shareholders' meeting.

title: Suitors Seek Talks At Dunkin' Donuts
description: The two Canadian companies offering to buy Dunkin' Donuts Inc. for $43 a share said they might raise their offer if the doughnut-store chain would negotiate. Dunkin' Donuts, based in Randolph, Mass., has been given until Thursday to respond to the $305.3 million bid by the Unicorp Canada Corporation and Cara Operations Ltd.

title: Rumor of Soviet Purchase Lifts Grain Prices Sharply
description: Grain prices rose sharply today on speculation that the Soviet Union had bought up to one million tons of American wheat and 500,000 tons of corn.

title: UAL Shares Jump
description: The common stock of the UAL Corporation soared $6.75 a share today, to $146, on the New York Stock Exchange amid speculation that the parent of United Airlines Inc. might become a takeover target. The buying surge followed a report by the business writer Dan Dorfman in USA Today that a group headed by Robert M. Bass, the Fort Worth investor, had acquired 2.5 percent to 3 percent of UAL. A spokeswoman for Mr. Bass declined to comment and UAL said it would not comment on the activity.

title: Lorenzo Airline Battle Harder Than '83 Flight
description: At first glance, Frank Lorenzo, the chairman of the Texas Air Corporation, seems to be on comfortably familiar ground.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Query, Close to Home, Trips Up President
description: President Bush fielded questions on China, abortion and flag-burning with ease today but was hard-pressed to explain why his grandson, and not his granddaughters, is taken on the President's fishing trips.

title: Soviets to Let Arctic People Attend July Parley
description: In a new sign of its changing policy toward the Arctic regions of the world, the Soviet Union has agreed for the first time to allow representatives of an indigenous Arctic people to attend an international gathering in Greenland next month.

title: Monetary Links Seen In Europe
description: The 12 nations of the European Community agreed today to go ahead with the first steps toward monetary union after Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain backed off from blocking further moves that might lead to a common European currency.

title: Bush Lowers The Flag
description: LEAD: Reacting sharply to a recent Supreme Court decision, President Bush has proposed a constitutional amendment that would permit laws making it a crime to desecrate the American flag. He believes it is possible to create this exception to the First Amendment without damaging freedom of expression in general.

title: Review/Dance; Latin American Social Commentary
description: Dance, like any art form, is a reflection of the society in which it exists: this is a premise often overlooked or taken for granted. But it was an idea that certainly came to the fore on Monday night when the American Dance Festival here opened its first series devoted to Latin American modern dance.

title: Philip Morris Notes
description: A $500 million note issue from the Philip Morris Companies was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers. The 8 7/8 percent notes due in 1996 are priced at 99.787 to yield 8.916 percent, or about 77 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity. Noncallable through maturity, the issue is rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A by Standard & Poor's.

title: Avery International Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company said it received a $15 million payment under terms of a patent infringement lawsuit settlement with Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Co. during the latest quarter. However, it said various charges recorded during the quarter substantially offset this payment.

title: J. P. Sweisgood, 63, Alcoholism Unit Head
description: The Rev. John Peter Sweisgood, president of the Long Island Council on Alcoholism, died of heart failure Monday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 63 years old and lived in Plainview, L.I.

title: International Dairy Queen Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
Pirates Hit Early and Beat Cubs, 5-4
description: Andy Van Slyke and Bobby Bonilla hit consecutive run-scoring triples in a four-run first inning today as the Pittsburgh Pirates handed the Chicago Cubs their fifth successive loss, 5-4.

title: Wells Fargo and Nikko Set Advisory Venture
description: Wells Fargo & Company said today that it will spin off its investment management subsidiary, which is the largest single investor in the stock market, into a money management venture it will own jointly with the Nikko Securities Company of Japan.

title: BRIEFS
description: A Company Briefs listing in Business Day on Wednesday misstated terms of a deal between Jefferson Smurfit Group P.L.C. and the Container Corporation of America. Jefferson Smurfit is paying $58 million to the Container Corporation for its stake in a Colombian paper company, Carton de Colombia. Jefferson Smurfit did not buy a stake in the Container Corporation.

title: Corrections
description: An article in SportsMonday this week about inn-to-inn tours gave two telephone numbers incorrectly. The number for New England Hiking Holidays is (603) 356-9696 and for the Vermont Icelandic Horse Farm (802) 496-7141.

title: Appeals Court to Rule On Law to Help S.R.O.'s
description: New York State's highest court is to decide soon on the constitutionality of a New York City law that is intended to preserve tens of thousands of apartments in single-room-occupancy hotels.

title: Murder and Mercy; The Supreme Court's Cruel 'Consensus'
description: Determined to get on with the execution of murderers, the Supreme Court barely paused before deciding, by a pitifully close 5-to-4 majority, that 16 is not too young nor the bottom 2 percent of the population too feeble-minded to be eligible for the death penalty. That's not ''cruel and unusual'' punishment in violation of the Eighth Amendment, said the majority.

title: Beyond Rose Report, Troubling Testimony
description: Many assertions gathered by investigators looking into Pete Rose's gambling activity were not included in the official 225-page report submitted to the commissioner of baseball, A. Bartlett Giamatti, but are attached to the report in seven volumes of exhibits.

title: Price Decision Favors A.T.&T.
description: The Federal Communications Commission has denied a request to delay a new long-distance pricing plan scheduled to go into effect July 1 for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the agency said today.

title: Review/Concert; 2 Commissioned Works And a Bit of Tapping
description: The Naumburg Foundation's chamber music concert at Alice Tully Hall Monday evening was a happy occasion. The playing was good; more important, both newly commissioned works were interesting and effective; still more important, one - Stephen Jaffe's Double Sonata - had that special, undefinable quality that makes a listener eager to hear a piece again. It gives both a feeling of being fully intelligible on first hearing and an impression that subtleties and added delights might lie in wait to reveal themselves on further acquaintance.

title: The Jalapeno Bagel And Other Artifacts
description: LEAD: For Dr. Barbara Kirshen-blatt-Gimblett, a cultural anthropologist at New York University, food is life's essential topic. She teaches a course on food and society, and is doing research for a book on food in Jewish culture.

title: Food Notes
description: Wines Nationwide

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Merrill Lynch To Relocate 2,600 Jobs
description: Merrill Lynch & Company has decided to move 2,600 jobs from New York City to Jersey City, prompting New York to retaliate yesterday by removing the giant securities company as senior underwriter for municipal bond offerings.

title: Defector to Moscow Is Dead; Work for K.G.B. Is Lauded
description: The Soviet Union today announced the death of a United States Navy defector, who was described as having played a vital role as an intelligence agent for the K.G.B.

title: Northeast Utilities reports earnings for 12mo to May 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $7,360,000 and $13,863,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. Revenue is from continuing operations.

title: U.S.-Japan Phone Talks Resume
description: Japanese-American talks over opening Japan's thriving cellular telephone market to American companies resumed this afternoon after breaking down early this morning.

title: Bonn Acts in Iran Chemical-Sale Case
description: A diplomat at the Iranian Embassy in Bonn, suspected of being a central figure in Iran's efforts to stockpile chemicals used in poison-gas production, is no longer in West Germany, and Bonn has asked that he not return, West German officials said today.

title: Nets Steal Blaylock With 12th Pick
description: Daren (Mookie) Blaylock had more steals than any other collegiate player last season. And the Nets, who desperately needed a point guard, think they got a steal by selecting Blaylock with the 12th pick in tonight's National Basketball Associaton draft.

title: Lessons
description: Georgia, Oklahoma and other universities with big-time athletic programs are frequently accused of caring more about television revenues than the best interests of their student athletes. But the absence of big bucks and athletic scholarships is no guarantee that the Golden Rule will prevail. Take the case of Kenny Mennella. An 18-year-old senior at Iona Preparatory School in New Rochelle, N.Y., Kenny proved himself to be an above-average student, though no whiz, and a talented half-miler, good enough to run anchor on Iona's all-county two-mile relay team.

title: Barclays to Buy Mortgage Portfolio
description: A definitive agreement to buy a substantial portion of a mortgage servicing portfolio was reached yesterday between Fine Homes International L.P., which operates under the Merrill Lynch Realty name, and Barclays American/Mortgage, a unit of Barclays Bank P.L.C.

title: Charter Panel Approves Bar on Political Leaders in Elected Offices
description: The New York City Charter Revision Commission, completing its latest draft plan for a new municipal government, recommended yesterday that county political leaders and other holders of high political office be prohibited from running for elected city positions.

title: Barbecue Sauce As Individual As Each Creator
description: AS the United States gets ready to celebrate its 213th birthday, there is one substance that seems to have emerged as a symbol of the nation's treasured values of democracy, free expression and tolerance for individual difference. Barbecue sauce. Face it. What other commodity inspires such raw creativity, passionate debate and celebration of regional differences? What else is as at once so devoid of pretense, yet is capable of bowling over the most aristocratic gourmet?

title: Correction
description: A recipe for cucumber hot sauce with the Purposeful Cook column on June 14 included an incorrect instruction. In step 2, it is not necessary to reheat the sauce; it requires no cooking.

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE BACKS MIDGETMAN
description: The House Armed Services Committee voted today to continue development of the small, mobile intercontinental ballistic missile known as the Midgetman.

title: For Some Elite Students, the Debate's the Thing
description: For the highly articulate high school student, Georgetown's summer debate institute is both a boot camp and a paradise.

title: Penobscot Shoe Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
description: b-Net income

title: Matuszak's Death Caused By Accidental Overdose
description: John Matuszak, the former defensive lineman for the Oakland and Los Angeles Raiders, died 10 days ago as a result of an accidental overdose of a prescription drug, according to the findings of the Los Angeles County Coroner's Office.

title: Snatched Child Found Unharmed
description: A 16-month-old boy who was kidnapped yesterday from the lobby of the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst was found unharmed about 12 hours later, wandering a street in Queens, the police said.

title: Vasili Romanov, 81, Nephew of Last Czar
description: Vasili Romanov, the last prince born in Russia before the Bolshevik revolution, died Saturday at his home here. He was 81 years old.

title: Why Make AIDS Worse Than It Is?
description: The AIDS epidemic is far from over. But the toll of new cases, which has been rising for years, may at last be about to level off and then decline. Gloomier numbers released this week by the General Accounting Office mask the possibility that the epidemic's worst rages may be abating.

title: Dow Declines 21.63 in Moderate Trading
description: Stocks dropped broadly yesterday in moderate trading, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 21.63 points, to 2,504.74.

title: John Labatt of Canada Picks Chief Executive
description: One way to get ahead is to increase your company's national market share by five percentage points. That is what Sidney M. Oland did in Canada for Labatt beer, and yesterday John Labatt Ltd., the parent company, named him president and chief executive, effective Sept. 7.

title: Fare Increases Seen If Costs Are Not Cut
description: Faced with gloomy ridership figures, the New York City Transit Authority must cut costs now or face the prospect of raising fares to keep up with widening budget gaps, the State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, said yesterday.

title: Poll Shows New Yorkers Fault City Efforts for the Homeless
description: A majority of New Yorkers are dissatisfied with the city's efforts to help the homeless and say they are even willing to pay more taxes if the money is dedicated to improving their lot, according to a New York Times/WCBS-TV News Poll.

title: Tougher and Richer Tour de France
description: Steven Rooks has caught Tour de France fever and it hurts. Symptoms include a slight swelling of the head, a narrowing of vision and partial loss of a sense of identity.

title: The Onstage Life Of Daniel Gerroll
description: ''You spend two acts being mildly amusing, and in the third act you don't even have to get out of bed to get a laugh,'' Daniel Gerroll said. ''If you say your lines and you don't mess up, you'll be hailed as a genius. It's like the proverbial Swiss watch: you wind it up and it keeps ticking and ticking away.''

title: CCA Industries reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $132,175 for the quarter and $251,201 for the 6 months as a result of a net operating loss carryover. c-Net loss

title: Bell Suspended Again For Bumping Umpire
description: For the second time this season, George Bell of the Toronto Blue Jays has been suspended for bumping an umpire. The American League announced yesterday that Bell would receive a three-day suspension for bumping Tim Welke in a game at Oakland last Saturday won by the Athletics, 7-1.

title: House Panel Narrowly Rejects Cheney Arms Plan
description: The House Armed Services Committee narrowly rejected a proposal today to approve intact the budget submitted by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney to buy weapons in the fiscal year 1990.

title: Legislators May Let Grocery-Pricing Law Die
description: Legislators here were busy drawing up grocery lists today, not because they were headed to the supermarket but because they were in negotiations over the fate of New York State's item-pricing law.

title: Bonds Depressed by Profit Taking
description: An unexpected wave of profit taking swept the Treasury securities market early yesterday, with prices falling most sharply among the highly volatile and speculative long bond maturities.

title: Group I Software reports earnings for Year to March 31
Beijing Orders Its Ambassadors Home for a Meeting
description: China has summoned home its ambassadors for a meeting next week as the crackdown on dissent continues to evoke condemnations and sanctions abroad.

title: NEW STYLES END SLUMP IN WOMEN'S FASHIONS
description: A year ago, the market for women's clothes was slumping. Apparel makers had tried to force shoppers to buy short skirts, frilly blouses, dressy outfits impractical for career women - and, to top it off, were charging prices that many customers viewed as too high. Many women, it seemed, simply stopped buying clothes.

title: Close to Home
description: I DIDN'T smoke. Neither did any of the youngsters I went to high school with, except one, who was several years older and was my idea of a sophisticate. He took me to the junior prom and afterward kissed me, and I remember the strange, musty tobacco scent of his mouth. I didn't find it pleasant.

title: Talking Deals; The Time-Warner Freeze-Out Effect
description: EXECUTIVES at both Warner Communications Inc. and Time Inc. have stressed throughout the scuffling surrounding their proposed merger that neither company is for sale to a third party. Less attention has been paid to the extent to which they tried to insure that there would be no potential buyers.

title: Panel Supports Bill Restricting Horse Carriages
description: A City Council committee approved legislation yesterday that would largely ban horse-drawn carriages from midtown Manhattan.

title: Biomet Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The 1989 results included the contribution of Biomet's subsidiary, Electro-Biology Inc., for 12 months, while the 1988 results included the subsidiary's results for seven months.

title: Limiting Retirees, Town Says It Isn't 'Florida of the North'
description: Officials here love their older residents, but with about half of the township's population of 22,000 made up of retirees and the percentage rising, they have decided that there can be too much of a good thing.

title: Market Place; Nintendo Courts U.S. Investors
description: NINTENDO, which in the last three years has conquered the home video game market in the United States - it has more than an 80 percent share - is now testing the stock market. On June 7, the Japanese company issued American depository receipts, making it possible for American investors to hold its stock.

title: Laura Ashley Suit
description: Laura Ashley Holdings P.L.C. and its Penhaligon Ltd. unit said a settlement had been reached in their United States lawsuit against The Limited Inc. and its Victoria's Secret subsidiary. Laura Ashley said The Limited had infringed on the copyright for Penhaligon's packaging. It said the settlement, whose details were not disclosed, was reached after a day of trial in United States District Court in Manhattan.

title: Elizabeth Henry, Nutritionist, 86
description: Elizabeth Henry, a founder of the Meals on Wheels program in this country, died Sunday of pneumonia. She was 86 years old.

title: Pretoria Bank Chief Quits
