description: The head of South Africa's central bank, Gerhard P. C. de Kock, yesterday said he intended to resign at the end of October because of ill health. The Government said he would be replaced by Chris L. Stals, now special economic adviser to the Minister of Finance, Barend du Plessis.

title: Ex-Wife of Dead Spy Told Navy He Worked for Soviets, U.S. Says
description: Several years before Glenn Michael Souther was granted access to highly classified satellite intelligence, his estranged wife warned Navy investigators that her husband was a Soviet spy, Administration officials said today.

title: Mostly Ellington, in Jazz and Songs
description: It was only logical that a JVC Jazz Festival program called ''Jazz and the American Song'' at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening should be filled with the music of Duke Ellington. Not only was Ellington the most brilliant crossover between jazz and American song, both as performer and composer, but also the purpose of the concert, produced by Bobby Short, was to benefit the Duke Ellington Memorial Fund, which plans to erect a statue of Ellington at 110th Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: A Flashy Departure For I.B.M.
description: I.B.M. lifted the curtain yesterday on its second new advertising campaign, with television ads featuring flashy photography, special effects and a jingle that sounds like rap music.

title: Lafleur May Be Leaving
description: Guy Lafleur, who becomes a free agent on Saturday, may leave the Rangers and sign with the Quebec Nordiques, it was reported yesterday. Lafleur, a Hall of Fame member who came out of retirement to join the Rangers last season, was offered a two-year contract with the Rangers in May by the team's former general manager, Phil Esposito. But Esposito was dismissed May 24. ''If the new Ranger bosses don't offer us a deal by Saturday, Guy will become a free agent,'' Lafleur's agent,Georges Guilbault, told Le Journal de Montreal yesterday. (AP)

title: North Juror Admits She Gave False Answer in Questioning
description: A juror in the trial of Oliver L. North testified at a hearing today that she had given incorrect information about her background during jury selection because she had forgotten that her brother had been sent to prison for armed robbery.

title: House Acts to Free Woman Held in Child Custody Case
description: The House of Representatives moved today to free Dr. Elizabeth Morgan, who has spent 22 months in a Washington jail rather than obey a court order that she permit her former husband to spend time with their young daughter.

title: In Cincinnati, Rose Is Still a Hero
description: The matter of Pete Rose versus baseball is a thorny one for this city. Cincinnati has been a baseball town since the professional game began here in 1869, and it is behind the game all the way. But the problem here is fundamental: Is baseball really baseball, or is Pete Rose really baseball?

title: Currents; In Cooperstown, a New 'Ball Park'
description: LET'S play architecture!

title: Fonar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago quarter and 9 months included tax credits of $513,000 and $1,258,000, respectively.

title: S.E.C. Backs Rewards for Insider Data
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved new rules today that would allow the agency to begin paying rewards to people who provided information on insider trading cases.

title: Jazz Festival; With Three Generations Of Be-bop Musicians
description: Time has a way of making even the most renegade forms of art seem classic sooner or later. So it is with be-bop, the harmonically advanced style of jazz adopted by a musical elite in the 1940's in reaction to the cliches of swing.

title: Rich or Not, All Countries Can Do More for Refugees; Indochina Asylum
description: To the Editor:

title: Intervoice reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
A New Drug Inquiry
description: The International Ski Federation's medical and legal commissions will investigate published charges by Hans-Georg Aschenbach, a former East German ski-jumping champion, that his country's best athletes are made to take drugs, according to a published statement by Marc Hodler, the federation's president. The statement appeared in Blick, a Swiss newspaper. Hodler also said he had brought up the case with Juan Antonio Samarach, the president of the International Olympic Committee, who passed the matter on to the committee's medical commission.(AP)

title: Sluggish Connors Eliminated at Wimbledon
description: For Jimmy Connors, who has been trying to fend off the twilight from his career, darkness didn't descend early enough today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM GOVERNING COUNCIL - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Corrections
description: A map on June 20 with an article about a refuge for the Florida panther misidentified a national preserve near the site. It is the Big Cypress National Preserve.

title: Review/Theater; Plays About Shoplifting, Politics and Fitting In
description: The three plays in Series C of the Ensemble Studio Theater's Marathon '89 are diffuse, episodic works. Two of them have a degree of promise but would benefit from further development and, in particular, from an avoidance of the pitfall of predictability. Both deal with the potentially explosive rivalry between an older and a younger man.

title: Turnpike Bus Crash Hurts 37
description: Thirty-seven people were injured yesterday when an N.J. Transit bus rammed into a truck in the afternoon rush hour on the New Jersey Turnpike near Newark, the police said.

title: Funds Show Mixed Yields
description: Yields offered on money market mutual funds tracked by the IBC/ Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, as taxable funds remained unchanged and tax-exempt funds rose slightly.

title: China-Korea TV Deal
description: A Chinese television factory has signed an agreement with a South Korean company, the first time the Seoul Government has approved a direct investment by a company from a Communist nation, the Finance Ministry said Tuesday. The Hanzhou TV Factory will invest $2.8 million in a joint venture with the Orion Electric Company of South Korea and the Zhejiang Fuchen Company of Hong Kong. A ministry spokesman said the venture was expected to produce 580,000 tubes for color TV sets in 1989, 1.1 million of the 20-inch tubes in 1990 and 1.2 million in 1992.

title: Marriott Planning 5-Year Expansion
description: The Marriott Corporation said it would expand in the next five years with hotels, restaurants and retirement homes. ''With only a 4 percent share of the total U.S. lodging market, we have much more room to grow,'' David Chichester, a Marriott vice president, told financial analysts.

title: Woman, 20, Slain With Ax and Knife
description: A 20-year-old woman was found dead of wounds from an ax and a knife late yesterday in her Bronx apartment, the police said.

title: Milking Poor Children
description: Last year's Dairy Farmers' Bill of Rights has resurfaced. What's in a name? Try deception. The bill passed this week by the New York State Senate, sponsored by Senator John Kuhl, purports to protect the right of farmers to join cooperatives free from interference. In fact, the only right this bill protects is that of dairy farmers to drive up milk prices at the expense of poor children.

title: Bail for 2 Convicted In Mob Case Revoked
description: A Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday revoked the bail of Gene Gotti and John Carneglia pending their sentencing on July 7 on charges that they ran a multimillion-dollar heroin operation. Defense lawyers said the revocation means that it is virtually certain that the two men will be kept in custody during a planned appeal of their convictions.

title: American Diplomat In Grenada Is Slain In a Shooting Spree
description: A 33-year-old American diplomat was shot to death in Grenada today as he tried to subdue an apparently deranged senior police officer who had just killed the police commissioner and wounded two other high-ranking officers.

title: What Is America?
description: ''If there be any among us who would wish to dissolve this Union or to change its republican form, let them stand undisturbed as monuments of the safety with which error of opinion may be tolerated where reason is left free to combat it.'' - Jefferson, first Inaugural Address.

title: Ferry Fare No Bargain For Staten Islanders
description: To the Editor:

title: Rich or Not, All Countries Can Do More for Refugees; Costa Rica's Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: Elsa Adler Bass, Music Colony Leader, 94
description: Elsa Adler Bass, who with her first husband, Dr. Clarence Adler, operated a summer music colony at Lake Placid for almost 40 years, died Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 94 years old.

title: German Company Admits Role in Iran Chemical Sale
description: A West German trading company acknowledged today that it had arranged for Iran to buy a chemical used in poison-gas production from an Indian manufacturer. But the company said it had canceled the contract, and a Government official said the sale might not have violated West German export laws.

title: Almost an Asterisk
description: At the depth of their catching crisis Tuesday, with Gary Carter and Barry Lyons injured and only Mackey Sasser left, the Mets began thinking about the unthinkable: Joe McIlvaine, vice president of the club, asked the Expos' office to type up a contract for the Mets' bullpen catcher, Rob Dromerhauser, who has never caught in the big leagues.

title: Savings Unit Loses Ruling
description: A Federal court has upheld a decision prohibiting the Great Western Bank from leaving the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

title: Girl, 7, Swept Into a Storm Drain, Is Rescued After a Night of Terror
description: When rescue workers looked into the storm sewer where flood waters had swept 7-year-old Latricia Reese on Monday evening, they abandoned plans to search for her. It was too hopeless and too hazardous, they said.

title: The Environment
description: In most countries, the United States included, national wealth is measured by the value of goods produced and services rendered. Machines and buildings are counted as capital assets; as they age their value is deducted from national income.

title: Realtors' Political Arm Offers Lessons on Strength of PAC's
description: The National Association of Realtors wrote off Greg Laughlin as a probable loser when he ran for Congress in southeastern Texas last year, giving the maximum $10,000 to his opponent, Representative Mac Sweeney, a Republican.

title: Hanson Is Selling Restaurant Chain
description: The International Proteins Corporation agreed to buy the Ground Round restaurant chain from Hanson Industries, the United States arm of Hanson P.L.C., for about $53 million in cash and 2.85 million shares of newly issued International Proteins shares. The new shares will increase Hanson's ownership in the diversified food company to about 49.5 percent, from 9 percent. Hanson said the sale is part of a business combination under a strategic alliance.

title: President to Urge Pay Increase for Congress
description: President Bush will urge Congress on Thursday to give itself a raise and to phase out fees the lawmakers receive for speeches and public appearances, Administration officials said today.

title: Bulls Come Up Smiling After Draft
description: The day after a National Basketball Association draft, general managers, coaches and scouts usually pat themselves on the back and say nice things about the players they chose. It's always good for advance ticket sales. And so it was yesterday in many of the 27 franchise cities where general managers explained their selections and introduced the players to the local news media.

title: Canseco Back in Swing
description: Jose Canseco, trying to come back from shoulder and wrist problems that have kept him out all season, began a stay last night with Huntsville (Ala.) of the Southern League. He had an infield single in four times up during a 4-3 loss to Greenville.

title: Mack Arrested
description: Kevin Mack, running back for the Cleveland Browns, was arrested yesterday after the police found him in possession of 10 to 12 packages of a substance believed to be cocaine, authorities said. Commander Robert Bolton said Mack, 26 years old, was arrested without incident near East Tech High School, situated in a Cleveland neighborhood that has a reputation for drug trafficking.

title: Intermetrics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Home Improvement
description: HINGED doors that rub or bind often require only minor repairs. But it is important to diagnose problems correctly and to work carefully.

title: What's Next in Recruit Scandal? 15 Years in Court
description: The other day, prosecutors in Japan's big bribery scandal reported that in the last year they had questioned 3,800 witnesses, seized 9,000 pieces of evidence and searched 80 homes, offices and other places under suspicion.

title: Airlines Cut Scene From 'Rain Man'
description: crucial scene about aviation safety has been cut from the Oscar-winning film ''Rain Man'' in the version being shown by at least 15 major airlines.

title: Corrections
description: The headline of a brief article yesterday about the deaths of two Palestinians in a prison camp located the camp incorrectly. It is in the Negev, not Gaza.

title: >Old Homes Retain Allure For Group
description: NOW that so many of New York's neighborhoods with solid stocks of brownstones, like the Park Slope section of Brooklyn and the Upper West Side of Manhattan, have gone from down-and-out to up-and-definitely-in, it would seem that the mission of the 21-year-old Brownstone Revival Committee has been accomplished.

title: At Gold Giant, Issue Now Is Price
description: What a difference a month has made in the way Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. deals with takeover bids.

title: Currents; A Winning School
description: AMONG the recipients of last month's Bard Awards, given by the City Club of New York for excellence in urban design and architecture, was P.S. 234 in TriBeCa, designed by the architect Richard Dattner. The $13 million building at the corner of Greenwich and Chambers Streets resulted from a rare exercise in collaboration among an architect, a principal, parents, community members, two city agencies and children, who were occasionally invited to comment on the models.

title: If Rose Bet, He Avoided Gullickson
description: If Pete Rose did what the Dowd report says he did - bet voluminously on baseball games - two intriguing conclusions can be drawn from the records in the report that are said to list his wagers: He was a poor bettor when he wagered more than $2,500 on a game and he lost faith in Bill Gullickson three months before the Cincinnati Reds traded him to the Yankees.

title: Sanchez Is Finding Her Touch On the Grass
description: Until this year, Arantxa Sanchez Vicario regarded the lawns of Wimbledon as little more than a glorified pasture, a surface designed for grazing animals, not fiery Spanish tennis stars. Twice she had lost here in the opening round, and this month that indignity followed her to England despite her surprising defeat of Steffi Graf in the final of the French Open two weeks ago.

title: Ronald J. Watkins, Executive, 58
description: Ronald J. Watkins, a former vice president of human resources for Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, died of complications from a heart transplant Tuesday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 58 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: Central Pennsylvania Finanial Corp reports earnings for 12mo to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $341,000.

title: Palo Alto Journal; Where Bicycle Is King (And the Queen, Too)
description: In this car-crazy state, Ellen Fletcher's boast is at least eccentric and perhaps bizarre. She fills the gas tank of her battered 1963 Plymouth Valiant only twice a year and has to remind herself to take the car out of the garage once in a while for some exercise.

title: Supermarkets Plan to Boycott Table Grapes
description: LEAD: Some of New York City's largest supermarket chains said yesterday that they would limit and possibly end their sales of California table grapes because they are concerned about pesticides used by grape growers.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL Japan agreed to give foreign companies greater access to its mobile telephone market. The agreement, which is the most significant fruit yet of the tough trade law that Congress enacted last year, applies to all foreign companies that seek access to Japan's telecommunications market. The accord carries a symbolic importance in seeming to demonstrate an erosion of the Japanese practice of protecting a domestic industry from foreign competition until the industry is strong enough to withstand it. [ Page A1. ] ECONOMY The index of leading indicators fell 1.2 percent in May, the biggest decline in 18 months and the third in the last 4 months, the Commerce Department reported. The report did little to alter the widespread view that the six-and-a-half-year economic expansion will remain intact. [ D1. ] The Department of Veterans Affairs is suffering heavy losses from increasing defaults. And the way it handles those defaults is causing problems for another agency, the Government National Mortgage Association. [ A1. ] COMPANIES Banc One will acquire the operations of the 20 banks in Texas formerly controlled by Mcorp. The transaction is expected to require about $2 billion in aid from the F.D.I.C. [ D1. ] A Delaware chancellor declined to block the annual stockholders meeting of Time Inc., set for Friday. The ruling came in response to a suit by three major stockholders, who argued that Time's directors had not adequately kept them and other shareholders informed of its reasoning in rejecting Paramount's bid. [ D1. ] Consolidated Gold Fields has begun a campaign to convince shareholders it is worth more than Hanson's $4.8 billion offer. [ D1. ] More than 850,000 books from 65 small publishers are tied up in a Connecticut warehouse, under orders of a U.S. Bankruptcy Court. The publishers say that unless the order is lifted soon, it will drive many of them out of business. [ D2. ] T. Boone Pickens took on the management of Koito Manufacturing at the annual meeting early today, but the corporate showdown was a draw. [ D5. ] Sears will test selling I.B.M. computers in some stores and set up separate men's shops in others. [ D4. ] Chrysler said its Beijing Jeep plant has been operating at near capacity under the direction of Chinese managers. [ D4. ] Retailers and producers have agreed on a new strategy to fightmarket erosion and inventory glut. [ D12. ] MARKETS The S.E.C. adopted rules that would allow it to pay rewards to people who provide information on insider trading cases. [ D1. ] Stock prices dropped broadly in moderate trading, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 21.63 points, to 2,504.74. [ D8. ] Prices of highly volatile and speculative long bonds fell as a wave of profit taking swept the securities market. [ D17. ] Yields on money market mutual funds were mixed. [ D7. ] Coffee futures prices posted solid gains amid traders' hopes that a compromise could be reached to avert a collapse of the market's 26-year-old price-support machinery. [ D16. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Nintendo has conquered the home video game market in the U.S. and is now testing the stock market. Market Place. [ D8. ] A number of senior deal makers say Warner has spread investment banking assignments around to leading Wall Street firms, leaving the impression that the company was deliberately trying to create conflicts of interest. Talking Deals. [ D2. ] I.B.M.'s new television ads feature flashy photography, special effects and a jingle that sounds like rap music. Advertising. [ D19. ]

title: Books of The Times; From Solzhenitsyn, After 52 Years, a Monument
description: August 1914 The Red Wheel/Knot I By Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn Translated by H. T. Willetts. 854 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $50.

title: Candidate for Veto
description: About half of American children too young to go to school are cared for by their own mothers at home; those kids in the other half are cared for by a relative, a baby sitter, a child care center, or by nobody.

title: Rap Group Disbands Under Fire
description: Public Enemy, a Hempstead, L.I. rap group that has gained a growing popularity and performs a song in Spike Lee's new movie, ''Do the Right Thing,'' has disbanded in the wake of anti-Semitic statements given by Richard Griffin, who as the band's ''minister of information'' was known as Professor Griff.

title: Pettibone Corp reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $51,600,000 due to the forgiveness of debt upon the company's emergence from Chapter 11 in December 1988.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Washington Talk page on June 21 about the Department of Transportation omitted the status of six people who would lead agencies there. Five of the six have been formally or informally nominated by the White House. The sixth, Warren Leback, is being considered as a nominee for chairman of the Federal Maritime Administration.

title: Q&A
description: Painted Ceiling Beams

title: Giamatti Rebuffed Again On Hearing
description: For the second time in four days, an Ohio court yesterday blocked the baseball commissioner's effort to retain jurisdiction over the Pete Rose betting case.

title: RAILROAD WORKERS PRESSURE AMTRAK
description: Unions representing Amtrak employees will pass out leaflets and walk picket lines Friday, warning travelers that the railroad is ''courting a strike'' by demanding salary cuts and contract concessions.

title: In the Sudan, Enough Shame to Go Around
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Head of Lucky Sees New Career in Buyouts
description: After 17 years of running companies, most recently as the chairman and chief executive of Lucky Stores Inc., John M. Lillie says he is ready for a new career and a new way of living. So he is joining Sequoia Associates, a leveraged buyout firm based in Menlo Park, Calif., as a general partner, effective July 1.

title: KEY RATES
Rebel's Quest Is to Make Every Client An Architect
description: LEAD: BERKELEY, Califs., is a haven for renegade thinkers, and one of the most flamboyant is the architect Christopher Alexander. With his look of an English schoolboy and air of a philosopher, the 52-year-old Vienna-born design theorist has been a hero to students since the 1960's. Young people are drawn to Mr.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''California is the richest state in terms of human and capital resources, and yet for hundreds of thousands of children California is like living in the Third World.'' - Shirley M. Hufstedler, a lawyer here who was Secretary of Education under President Carter. [ A1:4. ]

title: Marion Oppenheimer, Education Director, 57
description: Marion Oppenheimer, director of public education of the New York City Sanitation Department, died of cancer on Friday at the New York University Medical Center. She was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Miniature's Summer In the City
description: The group Miniature - Tim Berne on saxophone, Hank Roberts on cello and Joey Baron on drums - opened the show at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night with an astounding set that moved from late-summer-afternoon idylls to dense cityscapes. Like a trio led by the saxophonist and composer John Zorn that closed the show -part of the JVC Jazz Festival -Miniature is a chamber group. Unlike most chamber groups it filled the hall with sound and seemed completely at ease in a large room.

title: Skewed Calculus of The Death Penalty
description: To the Editor:

title: P.L.O. to Use Posters to Get Its Message Across
description: In a novel move to improve its image in the United States, the Palestine Liberation Organization has hired an expert on graphic design to convey its message more effectively to the American people through political poster art.

title: Taking Creaks Out of Windsor Chairs
description: LEAD: Early American country chairs were often modeled after those of a settler's native land. None became as popular and survived in such numbers as the Windsor, inspired by a chair first made late in the 17th century in the English woodlands near the town of that name.

title: PORK BARREL BILL PASSED BY HOUSE
description: The House today approved an $18.5 billion energy and water development bill that includes money for nuclear waste cleanup, the start of construction on a giant atom smasher in Texas and hundreds of water projects scattered around the country.

title: Ann Fitzpatrick Becomes a Bride
description: Ann Fitzpatrick, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Fitzpatrick of Stockbridge, Mass., was married there yesterday at the First Congregational Church to Richard Allan Brown, the son of Jane M. Brown of Canandaigua, N.Y., and the late Kenneth E. Brown. The Rev. David M. Lockhart officiated.

title: View on Savings Deals
description: The Federal Government is not likely to cancel agreements reached in December to sell troubled savings institutions to private investors, John L. Douglas, general counsel of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said yesterday in a speech to the International Swap Dealers Association in New York. Although the deals have been criticized as providing too much Federal assistance to private investors who invested too little of their own money, Mr. Douglas said canceling the agreements would only increase the caseload facing the agency. But, he added, ''you might see some adjustments around the edges.''

title: Rising V.A. Mortgage Losses Spell Trouble at Other Agency
description: The Department of Veterans Affairs, whose mortgage guarantee program has helped 12 million veterans buy houses since 1944, is suffering heavy losses from increasing defaults. And the way it handles those defaults is causing problems for another agency, the Government National Mortgage Association, which is known as Ginnie Mae.

title: Communist Emerges as Key Player in Greek Crisis
description: In the 18 years during which the Communist guerrilla fighter was jailed, then banished to an island and condemned to death, he probably could not have predicted the phone calls from the presidential palace and from politicians of all stripes coming his way this week.

title: Seven Guilty In Racket Case At Mob Trial
description: Ending a 17-month racketeering trial, a Federal jury yesterday convicted seven men of being members or associates of a murderous crew of the Gambino crime family that operated out of a Brooklyn apartment.

title: James F. Sweeney, Ex-Steel Executive, 88
description: James F. Sweeney, a retired steel company executive, died Tuesday at his home in Titusville, Pa., after a long illness. He was 88 years old.

title: Enzyme Altered to Help Treat Heart Patients
description: Scientists have remodeled an important natural substance that dissolves blood clots to make it more durable in the human body and therefore presumably more effective in treating heart attacks and strokes.

title: Aid Given to Ineligible Housing Projects, Audit Shows
description: An internal audit of a Federal program intended to give financial assistance to private low-income housing projects has found that almost half the projects that received awards for 21 months failed to meet eligibility requirements.

title: Newsletters Can Chart the Route To a Rewarding Fishing Vacation
description: If you are planning a guided fishing trip, your best source of information on the quality of angling and services would be a friend who has been there ahead of you.

title: House Panel Votes an Overall Limit on Medicare Doctor Bills
description: Seeking to curb soaring health costs, the House Ways and Means Committee voted today to place an overall limit next year on what the Government will pay physicians who treat Medicare patients.

title: Dorothy S. Bullitt, 97, Broadcaster in Seattle
description: Dorothy Stimson Bullitt, a major figure in Pacific Northwest broadcasting and founder of the King Broadcasting Company died Tuesday. She was 97 years old.

title: Eagle Clothes Inc reports earnings for 13wks to April 29
description: b-Included a loss of $170,000 from reversal of tax loss carryforwards for the quarter and a gain of $1,654,000 from early extinguishment of debt for the 9 months. c-After tax benefits of $44,000 and $132,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Pickens Has A Showdown With Koito
description: T. Boone Pickens took on the management of the Koito Manufacturing Company today, but the corporate showdown was a draw.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: DR. JULES OLDER remembers when his twin daughters, then 12 years old, pulled back from his daily ritual of embracing them as they went off to school. They said, in unison, ''There's no law that says we have to kiss you goodbye every day.'' Dr. Older, an assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at the University of Vermont College of Medicine in Burlington, was taken aback.

title: The Rash of Tanker Spills Is Part Of a Pattern of Thousands a Year
description: The current rash of tanker spills is part of a pattern of accidents dumping millions of gallons of oil into United States waters each year, data presented by Coast Guard officials today showed.

title: Oil Tanker Captain Arrested On Pollution Law Violations
description: The captain of a Greek tanker that ran aground Friday and spilled 420,000 gallons of oil into the Narragansett Bay area was arrested today in Providence, R.I., and charged with violating Federal pollution laws.

title: Fingers Begin to Point as Yanks Lose Again
description: The latest loss kind of rumbled in the clubhouse for an hour or so after it had ended. Dallas Green leaned back in a chair, folded his arms and questioned his team's heart again. Don Mattingly fired salvos in another direction, claiming that constant trade rumors do little more than tell the players they aren't good enough to win.

title: Top Yield Is 6.60% On Maryland Issue
description: The State of Maryland is offering $80 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Hospital Workers Vote to Strike for One Day
description: Unionized employees of 49 private hospitals in the New York City area voted overwhelmingly yesterday to strike for one day, July 11, to express dissatisfaction over their wages, benefits and working conditions.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the May Department Stores Company's plans to sell Caldor and Venture stores misidentified David C. Farrell. He is chairman and chief executive of May.

title: U.N. Chief Says Fear Still Plagues Namibia
description: An atmosphere of ''fear and intimidation'' exists in northern Namibia, inhibiting the return of refugees and jeopardizing conditions for fair elections, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has declared.

title: 'Metamorphosis' Ending
description: ''Metamorphosis,'' an adaptation by Steven Berkoff of Franz Kakfa's short story, is to end its limited run after the evening performance on Saturday at the Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street. It was to have run until July 29. Directed by Mr. Berkoff and starring Mikhail Baryshnikov, the play will have run for 5 previews and 97 regular performances.

title: L.A. Gear Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Campaign Matters; Political Pruning May Cut Crowd In Rose Garden
description: The Rose Garden is getting crowded.

title: Israelis Slay an Arab Linked to Kidnapping
description: Israeli soldiers this evening shot and killed a Palestinian accused of kidnapping an American relief worker in the Gaza Strip last Thursday, the army said.

title: Farm Credit Agency Prices $2.6 Billion Bond Offering
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation yesterday priced a three-part consolidated bond issue totaling about $2.6 billion.

title: HEALTH: Pediatrics
description: Because of a production error, an article on the Health page on Thursday about nursing mothers' use of medications appeared in some copies with a passage misplaced. The affected passage should have read:

title: Small Publishers Struggling After Court Impounds Books
description: More than 850,000 books from 65 small publishers are tied up in a Connecticut warehouse, under orders of the Federal Bankruptcy Court in Bridgeport. The publishers say that unless the order is lifted soon, it will drive many of them out of business.

title: No Headline
description: A Federal grand jury is seeking to determine if a major drug-dealing organization paid the legal fees of two men convicted of killing a New York City police officer, lawyers and investigators said yesterday.

title: Currents; In the Disney-MGM Park, Dining A la Sitcom
description: NEO-FIFTIES restaurants have become as routine as sitcom reruns. But even Beaver Cleaver might love the Prime Time Cafe and Tune-In Lounge at the new Disney-MGM Studios theme park in Orlando, Fla.

title: HOUSING AUDITORS QUESTION PAYMENT TO G.O.P. OFFICIAL
description: The chairman of a group affiliated with the Republican National Committee received $50,000 for what Federal investigators described as ''questionable'' consulting work on behalf of the City of New Haven in its successful bid for a $10 million Federal housing grant.

title: 2 Officers Sentenced To Prison in Beating Of Man on 34th St.
description: Two police officers were sentenced yesterday to up to three years in prison for beating a man last year near Madison Square Garden.

title: Reports That Premier Might Quit Plunge Tokyo Into Renewed Crisis
description: The Japanese Government was thrown into a renewed political crisis today amid widespread reports that Prime Minister Sousuke Uno told his aides he was considering resigning because of his involvement with a former geisha and his loss of political backing within his party.

title: Amdahl Sees Income Drop
description: The Amdahl Corporation said today that its income in the second quarter may be 25 percent to 35 percent lower than the 48 cents a share it reported in the comparable period a year ago.

title: Sri Lanka and Tamil Rebels Agree to a Cease-Fire
description: The Government and the largest of Sri Lanka's Tamil rebel groups agreed to an immediate cease-fire in a six-year war in which 9,000 people are estimated to have been killed, the two sides said today.

title: Sears Will Test Sales Of I.B.M. Computers
description: In the latest changes in its format, Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that it would test selling I.B.M. computers in some stores and set up separate men's stores in others.

title: Critic's Notebook; Avant-Garde Films in a Struggle to Stay Avant
description: As he drives a vintage Thunderbird cross-country to California, where he will deliver it to a Japanese car collector, the narrator of Chip Lord's video ''Motorist'' keeps up a droll monologue on American consumer culture. He drives over the London Bridge, transported to Arizona. He passes through San Bernardino, which a gas station attendant proudly tells him is the birthplace of McDonald's, and enters Hollywood. Sounding like Sam Spade reincarnated as a post-modern guru, he snarls, ''This is where our memories get sold back to us, milked for the essential icon and dropped onto us like acid rain.''

title: A Fine Polish Can Make a Difference
description: ''THE English call it French polish, and the French call it English polish,'' said Eli Rios, a furniture restorer and polisher who is based in Manhattan. Call it what you will, the term French polish, which Mr. Rios thinks is a misnomer anyway, usually applies to furniture that has been finished with a rich, lustrous, high-gloss shine.

title: Ways Part for Y.&R. And Time Magazine
description: After a relationship of 50 years, Time Magazine and Young & Rubicam parted ways yesterday, prompting the prestigious publication to throw its trade advertising account into review. Although executives at both the magazine and the agency said the decision was mutual, advertising people who work with Time Inc. said the agency resigned, dissatisfied with the account's recent inactivity.

title: California Receives Grade of 'D' In Study of Children's Condition
description: In California, the most populous and by many gauges the richest state in the nation, half the children have not been fully immunized against disease, one of five has no health insurance, children are more than twice as likely to be jailed than children nationwide and are 50 percent more likely to be abused.

title: A. J. Ayer Dead in Britain at 78; Philosopher of Logical Positivism
description: Sir Alfred Jules Ayer, the British philosopher who did much to introduce the school of philosophy known as logical positivism to his English-speaking colleagues, died Tuesday at University College Hospital in London after long suffering from a respiratory ailment. He was 78 years old and lived in London.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Monday listing senators and House members who did not accept honorariums in 1988 was incomplete. It should also have included Senators John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, and Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida, and Representative Jan Myers, Republican of Kansas.

title: Versailles of 1989: Louis XVI Rates a Cheer
description: There is no better place than the royal capital of Louis XVI to grasp the ambivalence that pervades the ceremonies marking the 200th anniversary of the French Revolution.

title: Ruling in Winfield Case
description: A jury agreed yesterday in Houston that a woman's four-year relationship with Dave Winfield, the Yankees outfielder, constituted a common-law marriage, and she was granted the divorce she sought, Winfield's lawyer confirmed. Jurors in in the court of District Judge Allan Daggett deliberated for about 10 hours over two days before ruling in favor of the woman, Sandra Renfro, by a vote of 10-2. Renfro, 34 years old, filed suit against Winfield asking for a divorce, unspecified damages and court-ordered child support. Winfield's lawyer, Tom Alexander, said his client would appeal.(AP)

title: BRIEFS
description: * Applied Power Inc., Brookfield, Wis., a maker of hydraulic equipment, said it had received 7,03,528 shares of Barry Wright Corp., Newton Lower Falls, Mass., a manufacturer of filing systems and engineered products, in response to its tender offer. Applied Power now holds 92 percent of Barry Wright stock.

title: Addenda
description: * M/A/R/C Inc., a market research firm in Irving, Tex., will acquire two market research companies, Assessor Group and Custom Projects Group, from Information Resources Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: 'Twilight Zone' Economics
description: LEAD: After years of Keynesian economics and supply-side economics, Congress now appears to be practicing Twilight Zone economics.

title: Elliott Thorpe, 91, Army Attache Who Warned of Japanese Attack
description: Elliott R. Thorpe, a retired Army brigadier general who was chief of counterintelligence under Gen. Douglas MacArthur and delivered an unheeded warning about the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, died Tuesday at Sarasota Memorial Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived in Sarasota.

title: Lagos Journal; In Nigeria, to Rot in Jail Is a Hazard of the Innocent
description: A 26-year-old man with no criminal record is picked up by the police while driving near his home. He is not allowed to contact anyone, even his wife, whom he married the day before. He spends the next eight years in jail, without trial.

title: Dunkin' Donuts Rejects Takeover
description: The board of Dunkin' Donuts Inc. unanimously rejected the $43-a-share offer from two Canadian companies as inadequate. In a letter to shareholders, Dunkin' Donuts said that ''looking ahead, the company's prospects are excellent.''

title: Voters in Oregon Approve Move To Ban Export of Unmilled Logs
description: In what amounted to the first public referendum on the future of the Northwest's crucial timber industry, an overwhelming majority of Oregon's residents voted Tuesday to approve a measure to ban the export of unmilled logs from their state.

title: Circle K Chairman To Limit His Stake
description: The chairman of the Circle K Corporation said he had agreed to limit purchases to 10 percent of the convenience store operator's shares unless he received the company's consent to buy more. Earlier this month Circle K's chairman, Karl Eller, said he had hired financial advisers to help him formulate a buyout bid.

title: Air Transportation Holding Co reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said included in the latest year is $3,032,000 of costs associated with restructuring of the company's aircraft fleet, including $2,731,000 in provisions for loss on disposal of aircraft.

title: Players International Inc reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Compuserve Seeks Source
description: Compuserve, an electronic information service for personal computer users, is negotiating to buy The Source, a smaller competitor. Compuserve, owned by H&R

title: West Germans' Traffic With Terror
description: WANTED: A chemical plant for Libya . . . Nerve gas for Iran . . . Low-enriched uranium for South Africa . . . Heavy water for Argentina and India . . . Uranium and tritium processing plants for Pakistan . . . Missile know-how for Argentina, Brazil, Egypt, Iraq and Libya.

title: Economic Index Down 1.2%; Biggest Decline in 18 Months
description: The Government's chief economic forecasting gauge fell 1.2 percent in May, the biggest decline in 18 months and the third in the last 4 months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: American Business Computrs Corp reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: House Toughening China Curbs
description: Democrats and Republicans in the House of Representatives joined forces today to press a reluctant Bush Administration to accept tougher sanctions against China in response to Beijing's crackdown on the democracy movement.

title: Korean Rejects Demands for U.S. Troop Cut
description: Rejecting demands in Washington for a cutback in American forces, President Roh Tae Woo said today that United States troops here contributed to peace and stability in Asia at a minimal cost to American taxpayers.

title: Banc One Gets Units In Texas
description: The Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, one of the nation's most profitable banking companies in recent years, was selected by Federal regulators late today to acquire the operations of the 20 banks in Texas formerly controlled by Mcorp.

title: Rochester Community Savngs Bank reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: All amounts for fiscal 1988 have been restated to reflect the adoption of Statement No. 91 of the Financial Accounting Standards Board.

title: NCNB Loses an Edge In Bidding in Texas
description: An action last month to tighten Federal tax laws governing financial institutions might make it more difficult for the NCNB Corporation to strengthen its grip on the top rung of Texas banking by winning control of 20 banks formerly owned by Mcorp.

title: Death-Penalty Choice for Juries Urged
description: Under increasing pressure from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, the State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, today proposed the adoption of both the death penalty and the Governor's alternative of life without parole in murder cases.

title: Pete Rose Jr. Gets Time Off
description: With his father's troubles mounting, Pete Rose Jr. has been given permission to leave the Baltimore Orioles' Class A farm team at Erie, Pa., for a few days.

title: Former Officer Sues Ammirati
description: A former top executive at Ammirati & Puris filed a lawsuit yesterday against the advertising agency, charging that he was dismissed in March because of a speech impediment.

title: INSIDE
description: Economic Gauge Posts a Big Decline In yet another sign of a slowdown in economic growth, the Government's index of leading indicators declined 1.2 percent in May, the largest drop in 18 months. Page D1. Envoys Summoned Home China has recalled its ambassadors in what may be an effort to address reaction abroad, Western diplomats and Chinese officials said. Page A10. The Toll of Repeated Spills Millions of gallons of oil are spilled into American waters every year by accidents large and small, the Coast Guard told a House panel. Page A20. Shoreham Deal Approved Long Island Lighting Company stockholders approved a plan to abandon the Shoreham nuclear plant. Page B1. Giamatti Appeal Fails An Ohio court blocked the baseball commissioner's effort to keep authority in the Pete Rose case. Page B9.

title: IEH Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Currents; Crediting The Cause Of Design
description: USING credit cards afflicts many people, but especially those who are passionate about design because such people tend to be ardent shoppers. Now there is the Design Card, a special credit card for people who want to support the advancement of design.

title: Debating Canadian Health 'Model'
description: Executives at the Ford Motor Company are dismayed that the auto maker is spending the equivalent of $311 a vehicle for health care for its American employees, while in Canada, a half-hour drive from Ford's headquarters in Michigan, the cost is $49.80.

title: Power Over Guard Missions Belongs to U.S., Court Rules
description: Federal officials, not state Governors, have the final authority over the deployment of National Guard troops outside the United States, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: JAPAN TO GIVE U.S. INCREASED ACCESS IN KEY TRADE AREA
description: Facing a threat by the Bush Administration to impose heavy penalties on its exports to the United States, Japan agreed today to provide foreign companies greater access to its mobile telephone market.

title: When Rose Didn't Think He'd Age
description: As a batter, Pete Rose accumulated 200 or more hits in a season 10 times, which is just one of his 12 major league records. But, as so many athletes do, he thought he was immune to getting older. One night before batting practice several years ago, when his career was starting to wind down, he couldn't seem to explain why he was in a slump, why he had no chance to collect 200 hits that season.

title: Johnson Products Co reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After tax credits of $41,000 for the quarter and $630,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss

title: Reff Inc reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Quick & Reilly Group reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
description: Latest first quarter earnings reflected a 5 cent-a-share writeoff related to the recent acquisition of the specialist firm Conklin, Cahill & Co.

title: The Ruling on Rose: Out of Left Field
description: The Pete Rose case has attracted more grandstand attention to America's favorite pastime than the usual controversial call. Properly considered, the question is not whether the county judge should have issued a temporary restraining order to block a hearing on the Cincinnati Reds manager's alleged betting activities. Rather, it is whether the call should have been made by a judge at all.

title: Chrysler Stays Open in Beijing
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that its Beijing Jeep plant has been operating at near capacity under Chinese managers despite the departure of eight Western employees several weeks ago.

title: Langston Completes Expos' Sweep of Mets
description: The Mets got their first eyeball-to-eyeball look tonight at Mark Langston, the strikeout pitcher who got away, and they promptly rattled him for 12 hits in 8 innings. But that was all they did. Langston struck out 10 of them and pitched the Montreal Expos to a 4-3 victory that completed a three-game sweep over the Mets, their first wipeout in nearly a year, and that ended Bob Ojeda's recent three-game winning streak. And the Expos, the newest force in the pennant race, won their sixth straight game and moved two and a half games in front of the Mets in the National League's East.

title: Faradyne Electronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Corrected from Tuesday, June 27.

title: Review/Ballet; Solemn, Giddy, Dazzling: Nijinska
description: Dance Theater of Harlem honored a great 20th-century choreographer Wednesday night by presenting three works by Bronislava Nijinska at the City Center Theater (131 West 55th Street). The ballets, which were refreshing and often amazing to watch, surely challenged the dancers' techniques and expanded their stylistic range.

title: Review/Rock; The Who, Reunited, Performs 'Tommy'
description: Twenty years after it was written, the Who's rock opera ''Tommy'' still had its rock-and-roll kick when a reunited, reconstituted Who performed it on Tuesday at Radio City Music Hall. It was part of the band's 25th-anniversary tour, its first since a supposed farewell tour in 1982; the band will play a different program, though probably incorporating parts of ''Tommy,'' for four nights starting tonight at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: Rich or Not, All Countries Can Do More for Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Lilco Shareholders Vote to Abandon Shoreham Plant
description: Shareholders of the Long Island Lighting Company overwhelmingly gave final approval today to the utility's plan to abandon the $5.5 billion Shoreham nuclear power plant, which it spent 20 years preparing.

title: Bridge
description: One of the best performances in the Cavendish Club's Invitational Charity Pairs in Manhattan in May came from two young New York experts, Brian Glubok and Michael Radin. They were among the leaders throughout and finished third in a field that included many world champions.

title: Commodore Says Loss Is Possible
description: Shares of Commodore International Ltd. tumbled $3.75 today, to $14, on the New York Stock Exchange after the company said it might report a loss for its fourth fiscal quarter ending Friday. The 21.1 percent decline was the steepest of the day on the Big Board.

title: Crude Oil Is Spilled by Tanker
description: An Arco tanker berthed at Long Beach spilled about 1,500 gallons of crude oil Tuesday before a leak was halted, the Coast Guard said. The spill is still being investigated but may have been caused by a ruptured line on the tanker's upper deck, saidPetty Officer Elizabeth Neely of the Coast Guard. ''This is considered a minor spill,'' she said, adding that the oil company brought in two cleanup companies, which had contained the spill.

title: Colors and Patterns That Evoke Nature
description: Ray Rogers is a New Zealand ceramist now living in Australia whose pots look as if he found them in the outback. The pots also look somewhat American. This is because he uses a variant of raku, which he learned on a visit to California. Raku, used in regard to American pottery, refers to a technique; in Japan, where the term originated, it refers to a ware used largely for tea ceremony pieces.

title: Currents; At the Brooklyn Garden, A Growers' Gift Shop
description: URBAN gardeners in pursuit of red-leafed caladiums and other treasures need look no further than the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, which is to open its new garden gift shop on Saturday. The airy shop was designed by Eileen Ritter to resemble a greenhouse.

title: Wallace Traendly, 79, Publishing Executive
description: Wallace F. Traendly, a retired executive of McGraw-Hill Publishing Company and McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 79 years old and also lived in Essex Fells, N.J.

title: Sweet Disorder: Plants That Sow to Grow Again
description: LEAD: MUCH of the delight of a cottage garden is in its easygoing mixture of old-fashioned herbs and flowers. Instead of tightly tidy rows and rigid color schemes, a sweet disorder prevails.

title: Review/Jazz; Letting Loose on the Piano
description: Near the end of ''Good Bait,'' Geoff Keezer, an 18-year-old pianist who recently played New York as a member of the trumpeter Roy Hargrove's group, started setting harmonies against one another, spilling a skittering run between melody notes, taking the melody out of key, letting his ingenuity go wild. Though Mr. Keezer, who played with the bassist Walter Booker at Bradley's on Monday night, is an enormously talented musician - echos of all the great pianists of the 1950's run through his work, along with sounds of McCoy Tyner, Bill Evans and Herbie Hancock - it's this sense of play, where routine ideas and harmonies are bumped around a bit, all with a firm attention to swing, that marks him as a potentially important pianist.

title: A History of Asian Ceramics, All in One Place
description: IN the pottery and porcelain of most of the world, there are few developments that do not have some relation to Chinese ceramics. An exhibition that gives some sense of the evolution and highlights of Chinese ceramics, as well as a shorter history of Japanese ceramics, can be seen at the Asia Society in Manhattan through Sept. 3.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Bush Names Head of F.C.C.
description: President Bush today named Alfred C. Sikes, a Commerce Department official and a former broadcaster from Missouri, to become the next chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Delaware Oil Spill Laid to Early Move To Drop the Anchor
description: The pilot and the captain of a tanker that spilled more than 310,000 gallons of oil into the Delaware River last Saturday said today that an anchor had been dropped too soon, causing the vessel to swing around and run aground on the shoals.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Kestner Wins Again: Darrell Kestner, the assistant pro at the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, N.Y., captured the Westchester PGA championship yesterday for the second consecutive year, and Tim Stafford, the assistant pro at the Glen Head Country Club, took the Long Island PGA championship. The 36-year-old Kestner gained his second tournament victory of the season with an easy 5-and-4 victory over Jim O'Mara, the head pro at Rockrimmon Country Club in Stamford, Conn. The 31-year-old Stafford earned his first Long Island PGA title with a 2-and-1 triumph over Dave Gosiewski of the Noyac Golf and Country Club in Sag Harbor. Kestner earned $1,500 for his victory. Stafford earned $2,000 for his triumph in the Long Island event, sponsored by the Union Savings Bank and staged at the Garden City Golf Club. ROWING Harvard and Penn Triumph: Opening day at the 150th Henley Royal Regatta turned into an American celebration as Harvard and Penn won opening races in the Ladies Challenge Plate for heavyweight eights. Crews from Temple and Brown Universities and the Ivy Club of Princeton also advanced in competition for the plate yesterday. Columbia University was the first American crew to compete at Henley, but its lightweight four lost in the Brittania Challenge Cup. The King's Crown Rowing Association, a Columbia alumni boat, kept a measure of Light Blue hopes afloat by easily winning its heat in the Challenge Cup. HORSE SHOW Shafner Is Victor: The 28th Annual Lake Placid show opened with Debbie Shafner riding to victory over a 34-horse field in the power and speed competition yesterday. The third-place finisher, Charlie Jacobs, a 17-year-old from East Aurora, N.Y., took the lead by finishing fault-free in 40.165 seconds. He rode 19th over the seven-jump, 301-yard course designed by Frank Chapot, the United States Olympic show jumping coach. Two rides later, Anne Kursinski of Pasadena, Calif., took the lead by turning in a fault-free 36.685-second ride. Three rides later, Shafner, the 1988 Michelob show jumping champion, took the course without penalty in 34.953 seconds.(AP)

title: Court Declines to Block Time Inc. Meeting
description: A Delaware court today declined to block the annual stockholders meeting of Time Inc., which is scheduled for Friday.

title: Yonkers Refuses to Buy Land for Public Housing
description: The City Council, which last summer risked crippling fines as it fought a court order to build public housing, has balked at approving the $8.3 million needed to buy sites for the housing.

title: General Mills Inc reports earnings for Qtr to May 28
description: b-After a loss of $22,100,000 for the quarter and a gain of $169,000,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations, and the year also included a loss of $70,000,000 from an accounting change. c-After gains from discontinued operations of $1,200,000 and $900,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: No Headline
description: LENORA LIPSCHUTZ, the mother of Suzanne Lipschutz, has strong opinions about her New York daughter's weekend place in the Art Deco district of Miami Beach, not far from the North Miami Beach apartment that Mrs. Lipschutz, formerly of Brooklyn, has occupied for 18 years. ''Listen, it's her life,'' Mrs. Lipschutz said. ''It isn't for me. I live in a luxury apartment.''

title: Patent Is Expected By Archer-Daniels
description: The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company said it expects to receive a patent within a year for its process of making biodegradable plastic from corn starch. The company expects a patent hearing in six months to a year and the patent soon afterwards, Richard Burket, vice president of Archer-Daniels, said.

title: Events: 400 Exhibitors to Display Crafts
description: Artisans at Lincoln Center, Fordham University Plaza, 62d Street between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues; 212-677-4627.

title: Andrea Ciccarelli And Miss Earle Married in Rome
description: Amanda Wilmot Earle, a daughter of Eleanor Owens Earle of Naragansett, R.I., and Ralph Earle 2d of Washington, was married yesterday in Rome to Andrea Ciccarelli, a son of Dante Ciccarelli of Rome and the late Eneria Ruggieri Ciccarelli. The Rev. Giuseppe de Nicola, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Edward Todd, an Episcopal priest, at the Mausoleo di Santa Costanza.

title: A Piano-Fluegelhorn Duo
description: Oliver Jones, a pianist from Canada, shared his spot in the JVC Jazz Festival's daily series of solo piano recitals with the trumpeter and fluegelhornist Jimmy Owens on Tuesday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall.

title: Review/Theater; From Moscow, a Slice of Modern Life
description: Theater Chelovek is an Off Broadway-size Moscow theater that specializes in work that is both naturalistic and humanistic (chelovek means man in Russian). The company is currently on its first North American tour, beginning with a production of ''Cinzano'' at the Norstar Bank International Theater Festival at the State University at Stony Brook.

title: Viola Beats Stewart as Twins Sweep Series With the A's
description: Frank Viola allowed seven hits in the Twins' 2-1 victory over the Oakland Athletics, beating Dave Stewart in a battle between the two American League pitchers who have the most victories since 1987.

title: Allwaste IncO) reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $540,000 related to brokers' fees and acquisitions costs.

title: Helen of Troy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ambase Corp. of New York, a financial services concern, named Bruce W. Bean executive vice president.

title: Don't Leave Foster Children Living in Limbo
description: To the Editor:

title: Hofmann Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $42,000 for the quarter and $467,000 for the year, and losses of $50,000 and $1,777,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, on the disposal of foundry operations. c-Net loss Earnings in the latest fiscal quarter and year reflected a one-time charge of $256,000 related to the cost of patents determined to no longer have value.

title: Double Helix Films Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company began trading publicly in April.

title: Chief Is Named At Groupe Bull
description: Groupe Bull S.A., the Paris-based European information systems company, said yesterday that Francis Lorentz had been named its chairman and chief executive.

title: The East Hampton Intercontinental Airport Contest
description: With its peeling paint and buckling roof, the one-room airport here is a dilapidated affair, architecturally akin to the shacks selling fried clams on Montauk Highway nearby. But the terminal just hasn't seemed quite right, what with all those private planes buzzing in and Trump Air helicopters hovering overhead.

title: No Headline
description: Frederick M. Bush is no relation to his former boss, George Bush, but when it came to winning Federal housing grants, it did not hurt Fred Bush's consulting business if anyone thought otherwise.

title: 700 CAMBODIANS GIVEN A REPRIEVE
description: Responding to criticism by Western diplomats and international aid agencies, the Thai Government has postponed plans to return more than 700 Cambodians to Khmer Rouge control against their wishes, diplomats and relief officials said today.

title: New Charges At Northrop
description: A fraud case against the Northrop Corporation now includes charges that the defense contractor sold the Government about 200 improperly tested guidance systems for missiles and planes, rather than the 17 initially reported.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11 Japan granted American industry expanded access to its mobile telephone market, facing a Bush Administration threat of penalties against its exports to the U.S. Page A1

title: Israeli Aid for Armenia Signals Better Relations
description: An Israeli airlift that brought 61 Armenian earthquake victims to hospitals in Tel Aviv and Haifa on Tuesday is the latest step in a continued warming of relations with the Soviet Union.

title: Toxic Risk of Fish in Lake Michigan Is Assessed
description: The contamination of some Lake Michigan sport fish by toxic chemicals poses an increased risk of cancer among people who eat them, according to a report that will be released Thursday by the nation's largest conservation organization.

title: Review/Theater; Youths' Views of the Urban Jungle
description: The most refreshing thing about ''The Red Sneaks,'' Elizabeth Swados's contemporary musical adaptation of ''The Red Shoes,'' is the chance to hear youths rather than adults talk about the nightmarish pressures of urban life.

title: Albany Limits 'Junk Fax' Ads To 5 Pages and Night Hours
description: ''Junk fax,'' the electronic equivalent of junk mail, would be largely scrapped under a bill that received final approval in the New York State Legislature today.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: While intense attention has been focused recently on Lyme disease, the joint-stiffening infection spread by ticks, another tick-borne ailment has been overshadowed. That ailment, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, can be more serious and has begun to show up in urban areas.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Baer Marks & Upham said William M. Guttman, former vice president, general counsel and secretary of Time Inc., had joined the law firm.

title: Colgate Action On Animal Tests
description: The Colgate-Palmolive Company and Marrow-Tech Inc., a small research company based in Elmsford, N.Y., said they would collaborate on developing alternatives to using animals to test product safety.

title: HOUSE, BREAKING WITH BUSH, VOTES CHINA SANCTIONS
description: House Republicans broke with President Bush and joined Democrats in a vote of 418 to 0 today to impose new sanctions on China and condemn Beijing's suppression of human rights.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 2 Youngsters, No Frills: Off They Go
description: JUNE has been a heady month for Buckley/DeCerchio Advertising, opening with a gold pencil at the One Show and closing last week with a bronze lion at the International Advertising Film Festival in Cannes, and yes indeed, the phone has been ringing off the hook.

title: Marcos Has Special Surgery To Pinpoint Grave Infection
description: The former Philippine President, Ferdinand E. Marcos, battling for his life against multiple organ failure, underwent surgery today to determine the source of a life-threatening infection.

title: British Oil Licenses
description: Britain today awarded more than 100 licenses for oil drilling in the North Sea, saying that enthusiasm for the area insured that it would still be a big producer into the next century.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Open-Ended Tunes

title: Consultant Wed To Miss Pickman
description: Margaret Ann Pickman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Pickman of New York, was married last evening at her parents' home to Gary Mark Reiner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Reiner of New York and Manhasset Hills, L.I. Rabbi Stanley M. Davids performed the ceremony.

title: O.E.C.D. Sees a Slowdown In U.S., but No Recession
description: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today that economic growth in the United States would slow markedly in the second half of this year as well as in 1990, but the Paris-based group did not envision a recession.

title: Corrections
description: The caption of a picture from The Associated Press yesterday about the Serbian commemoration of the 600th anniversary of the Battle of Kosovo reversed the identifications of two portraits held aloft. Slobodan Milosevic, President of the Yugoslav republic of Serbia, was at the right, and Borislav Jovic, another Serbian official, at the left.

title: Review/Film; Wanted: A Husband
description: ''A Sinful Life,'' opening today at the Eighth Street Playhouse and the Eastside Cinema, is a dismal little movie that looks to be exactly what it is: a film version of a broadly eccentric farce that was apparently a long-running hit Off Off Off Broadway, in Los Angeles.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The guy could have killed two to three people in downtown Austin and just have gotten a local writeup. He could have blown up a building that nobody had heard of and not be in this much trouble. I bet he rues the day he decided to go at that tree.'' - Sgt. Gary L. Richards of the Austin police. [ A8:4. ]

title: Records Provide Fresh Details About Dinkins's Tax Lapses
description: An article in some copies yesterday about David N. Dinkins, the Manhattan Borough President and Democratic candidate for Mayor, misstated the amount of additional Federal tax he paid in February and March 1974. It was $1,381, not $1,238.

title: Head of Landstar Unit Appointed Parent's Chief
description: Jeffrey C. Crowe, who built one of the trucking companies of Landstar System Inc. almost from scratch into a business with $130 million in annual sales, has been named president and chief executive of Landstar.

title: 51% of Pupils Score Poorly In Reading
description: Using a new and tougher set of reading standards, the New York City Board of Education reported yesterday that slightly more than half of the city's public school students are unable to read at the level expected of their grade. Nonetheless, the reading scores showed a small improvement over last year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Arnold Wechter has been named chairman of Taylor-Gordon Aarons & Co.

title: Review/Film; Spike Lee Tackles Racism In 'Do the Right Thing'
description: In all of the earnest, solemn, humorless discussions about the social and political implications of Spike Lee's ''Do the Right Thing,'' an essential fact tends to be overlooked: it is one terrific movie.

title: Batman Busters
description: When ''Gangbusters'' started on the radio in 1936 with roaring cars and stuttering tommy-guns, it spawned an instant verbal cliche. The expression ''coming on like gangbusters'' has long outlived its source.

title: Tambrands Is Up On Buyback Move
description: The stock of Tambrands Inc. jumped $1 a share, to $60.50, in trading today on the New York Stock Exchange in response to the company's announcement on Wednesday that it would repurchase up to 1.125 million shares and that it might sell its diagnostics and cosmetics operations. Tambrands, which makes Tampax tampons and other personal-care products, said the buyback could equal up to 5 percent of its 22.4 million total shares outstanding.

title: Samuel Harris Cohen, Lawyer, 83
description: Samuel Harris Cohen, a retired labor lawyer from Manhattan, died Saturday in his sleep at the Bethesda Care Center in Laramie, Wyo. He was 83 years old and had moved to Laramie last year.

title: ISRAEL ARMY EXPELS EIGHT PALESTINIANS
description: The Israeli Army deported eight Palestinians to Lebanon today. But for the first time Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin told the deportees that they might be allowed to return, under certain circumstances.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article yesterday reported that the chairman of the National Black Republican Council had received $50,000 for helping the City of New Haven obtain a $10 million Federal housing grant under the Reagan Administration. Federal investigators later raised questions about the role played by the Republican leader, Fred Brown, and described the consulting fee as questionable.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 21 about Bruce Bailey, a slain tenant organizer in Manhattan, referred incorrectly to a case in which he was accused of having ordered an assault. It was adjourned in contemplation of dismissal, an arrangement under which charges are dismissed and the record is sealed after six months, provided the defendant is not rearrested during that time. Mr. Bailey was not convicted or sentenced to jail.

title: Dotson Reaches Terms
description: Richard Dotson, released by the Yankees last week, agreed to terms yesterday with the Chicago White Sox, the team that traded him to the Yankees after the 1987 season. The White Sox immediately scheduled the 30-year-old right-hander to pitch against Kansas City tomorrow night and take Bill Long's place in the rotation.(AP)

title: Kukla, Fran And Fletcher
description: LEAD: The death of Fran Allison at age 81 was a sad occasion, but it brought back numerous memories that were all pleasant. As the host of the television program ''Kukla, Fran & Ollie,'' Fran, along with puppeteer Burr Tillstrom and the Kuklapolitan Players, served as a surrogate babysitter for a lot of us in the early 1950's.

title: Gleason Spurns Bid By Goldman Group
description: The Gleason Corporation said its board had unanimously rejected a proposal by the Goldman Financial Group to acquire the company for $20 a share in cash. The board said it was not an appropriate time to sell the concern, which manufactures gear-making equipment, and added that the Goldman proposal, even if the uncertainties in it were removed, was inadequate.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on June 13 about theUniroyal Goodrich Tire Company misstated the timing of two plant closings. The merged company has not closed any plants; Goodrich shut two plants before merging with Uniroyal in 1986. The article also misstated the percentage of the company's revenue from sales to the General Motors Corporation. They account for 18 percent of Uniroyal Goodrich's revenue and 92 percent of its sales to auto makers, not 92 percent of its revenue. The article also misidentified the base of a union official. He is in Wisconsin, where Uniroyal Goodrich operations are unionized, not in Oklahoma.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * Henszey & Albert, a small New York agency, has been chosen to create a pro bono advertising campaign for the New York chapter of the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

title: Five-Day Fourth: A Wingding in the Rockets' Red Glare
description: Ever since the first Fourth, in July 1776, the day of Independence has been aiming at ever greater gloriousness. This year's extended Fourth, from today through Tuesday, gives every hyperbolic promise of living up to the tradition of freedom, fun and frolic that turns New York into the biggest small-town celebration in the nation.

title: Books of The Times; Growing Up Rootless in an Immigrant Family
description: The Floating World By Cynthia Kadohata 196 pages. Viking. $17.95.

title: A Bank That's Riding Technology to the Top
description: At a recent conference of bankers in Madrid, John B. McCoy, the chairman of the Banc One Corporation, mingled with leaders of the world's largest banks.

title: Review/Dance; Cheryl Yeager in Ballet Theater's 'Sylphide'
description: ''La Sylphide'' is often called a ballet about a mortal in love with a supernatural being. But as American Ballet Theater made clear on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, it could with equal accuracy be said to concern a supernatural being in love with a mortal.

title: ...Once Again, Steinbrenner Begins to Question His Manager
description: For almost three months, the Yankees have deftly avoided the turmoil that typically follows them through every winding summer. But sparks began flying Wednesday night, and they continued today when the team's owner, George Steinbrenner, said he questioned the game maneuvers of Manager Dallas Green.

title: Joris Ivens, 90, Dutch Documentary Film Maker
description: Joris Ivens, the Dutch creator of more than 50 documentary films, many of them about revolutionary struggle, died Wednesday at Laennec Hospital in Paris. He was 90 years old.

title: Frank Trapani, Trumpeter, 52
description: Frank Trapani, a longtime jazz trumpeter with the Dukes of Dixieland, died of a pulmonary embolism on Monday. He was 52 years old. Mr. Trapani played with the orchestras of Charlie Barnett, Les Elgard and Billy May and with performers including Pearl Bailey, Tony Bennett, Lou Rawls and Quincy Jones.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Alison on Dominick Street

title: Gulf Air Deal For Airbus Jets
description: Airbus Industrie said today that Gulf Air would buy 24 planes for Middle Eastern routes for at least $960 million. The deal includes 12 each of

title: Michael Alan Woods, A.I.D. Chief, Is Dead at 43
description: Michael Alan Woods, Administrator of the Agency for International Development, died of cancer yesterday at the Capitol Hill Hospital in Washington. He was 43 years old and lived in Washington.

title: 3 Western Governors Are Adamant on Waste
description: Three Western Governors at odds with Washington over disposal of nuclear waste in their states stood their ground today despite assurances from Energy Secretary James D. Watkins that the Government is serious about safety.

title: Got a Personal Problem? Maybe Legislature Can Help
description: When Catherine O'Brien and her husband, John, paid off the mortgage on their home in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn almost 20 years ago, they threw a party and burned their mortgage papers. The O'Briens, Irish immigrants, were proud to have made it in their new country.

title: Israel Is for Gamblers
description: Yitzhak Shamir, Prime Minister of Israel, is in his office, gambling.

title: Mets Sum Up Damages of Losing
description: By any reckoning, the Mets conceded, it was a total loss. In three days in Montreal, they lost three games, lost first place, lost Barry Lyons for a month, lost their momentum and even lost Howard Johnson's bat.

title: Lindsay Endorses Dinkins in Mayor Race
description: Breaking a tradition of pre-election silence, former Mayor John V. Lindsay yesterday endorsed David N. Dinkins for mayor, saying the Manhattan Borough President has ''the best chance of any person I can think of to unify New York.''

title: Review/Dance; New From Pearl Lang
description: Pearl Lang has had a long and distinguished career in dance, though she now performs infrequently in New York. She is probably best known for her years with the Martha Graham Dance Company, where she became the first dancer to whom Miss Graham entrusted her own solo roles. That Ms. Lang is still an exceptional performer was clear from ''Sephardic Romance,'' a new solo she choreographed and performed on Friday night at Florence Gould Hall, in a program of her dances that was dedicated to William Carter, a colleague who died last year.

title: 2 Qualifying Games Moved From El Salvador
description: El Salvador has been barred from playing its next two World Cup qualifying games at home, including the game scheduled for July 9 against the United States, soccer's world governing body announced yesterday.

title: A Long Weekend of Music, Fireworks and Frogs; HUDSON VALLEY
description: Music as well as fireworks will fill the air of the Hudson Valley this long Fourth of July weekend, along with street fairs, harness horse racing and the opening of an art show.

title: Mutual Fund Sales Climb
description: The Investment Company Institute said yesterday that sales of shares in stock, bond and income mutual funds rose by 4.4 percent in May, to $9.5 billion, from $9.1 billion in April. Sales a year ago totaled $7.1 billion. Assets of all mutual funds in

title: Loss of Jobs at Merrill Lynch Puts Pressure on New York
description: Merrill Lynch's decision to move 2,500 jobs from Manhattan to Jersey City underscores a pressing competitive issue for New York City: With new technology allowing companies to scatter groups of employees hundreds of miles from one another, can the other boroughs keep the jobs that will inevitably flee Manhattan's high costs?

title: Shultz Is Negotiating A Two-Book Contract
description: George P. Shultz, the former Secretary of State who served in three other Cabinet posts, is negotiating a two-book contract - a memoir covering his six years as Secretary of State under President Reagan and a book to be tied to a 12-part television series about diplomacy. He said he would write the books himself.

title: Fireproof Through the Night
description: The Supreme Court's decision that the Constitution protects flag-burning has evoked an extraordinary number of responses - no one of which is as peculiarly American as that of Skipp Porteous of Great Barrington, Mass.

title: More Cuts at Sears
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said it would eliminate 400 more management positions by mid-August in a realignment within its merchandising group. Previously, 425 management personnel had accepted a ''reorganization incentive'' to leave Sears as part of a restructuring at its Chicago headquarters that began in 1988, the retailer said. Sears said the new cuts and realignment would complete most of the reorganization.

title: Constitutional Change to Prohibit Flag Burning Introduced in House
description: A proposed constitutional amendment to outlaw flag burning was introduced in the House of Representatives today, and Republican leaders said it had the support of the White House.

title: Cuba Replaces Top Security Officer
description: In a strong aftershock from official charges that high military officers here were involved in drug trafficking, the Communist Party announced today that Cuba's Interior Minister, its highest security officer, had been replaced.
