title: Prices Paid To Farmers Drop by 2%
description: Prices farmers received for raw products dropped 2 percent from May to June but still averaged 5 percent more than a year earlier, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Scholastic Inc., an educational publisher, has acquired Instructor magazine from Edgell Communications Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Dining Out Guide: Late-Night Supper
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Amsterdam's Bar And Rotisserie * (March 3, 1989), 428 Amsterdam Avenue, at 80th Street (874-1377) -This popular Upper West Side establishment has a front room with bar, an open rotisserie section and an elevated back room with whitewashed brick walls, black tin ceiling and cafe tables. For a late-night supper, you might try Amsterdam's signature dish: roast chicken, which is usually moist with a nice blistered skin and is served with clean and crisp french fries. Light dishes for late at night would also include spaghettini with tomato, basil and mozzarella; sesame ginger noodles, and assorted crostini of roasted red peppers, chicken livers, and tomato, garlic and basil. Appetizers are $5.95 to $6.95, entrees $9.95 to $15.95. Open noon to 12:30 A.M. Sunday to Thursday, until 1 A.M. Friday and Saturday. Canal Bar * (Dec. 16, 1988), 511 Greenwich Street, at Spring Street (334-5150) -From outside, the restaurant has all the charm of a muffler repair shop. Inside, though, it is as hip as a 1957 Chevy convertible. This former diner has been converted into a stylishly tacky nightspot where restive downtowners display their latest vintage clothes and hair colors. There are three dining areas, all explosively noisy. For starters the late-supper menu offers fish chowder with corn, green salad with fresh herbs, red-pepper-and-mozzarella salad, melted chevre on toast, a leek-and-tomato tart and Nicoise pizza. Then there are such possibilities as a pasta of the day; croque-monsieur; grilled chicken, arugula-and-Parmesan sandwich, and the old standby, hamburger. For desserts there are hot apple tart with ice cream, and chocolate cake. Late-supper dishes are $4 to $9.50; Black Angus steak with french fries is $24. Dinner is 7 P.M. to 12:30 A.M. daily, late supper 12:30 to 2 A.M. Tuesday to Saturday. Maxim's ** (April 21, 1989), 680 Madison Avenue, at 61st Street (751-5111) - This clone of Paris's legendary nightspot has multi-level dining rooms that shine with burnished rosewood walls, vines of hammered brass, sylvan murals, stained glass and plush banquettes and tables. A late-night supper could begin with tuna carpaccio - a glistening sheet of fresh tuna garnished with asparagus spears, colorful salad greens, fresh herbs and caviar. This could be followed by braised red snapper over a slice of fennel. One of the bright and intense sorbets would make a light finale. Appetizers are $9 to $18, entrees $24 to $36. Dinner is 6 P.M. to midnight Tuesday to Thursday (music begins at 7 P.M., dancing at 9); 6 P.M. to 1 A.M. Friday and Saturday (music from 8 P.M., dancing from 10). Mezzogiorno ** (May 13, 1988), 195 Spring Street (334-2112) - At this buoyant North Italian restaurant, you encounter a long marble-topped bar at the entrance flanked by cafe tables along the white-paned windows; the playful back room has a long tan banquette on one wall and tables around a faux marble column. There are sprightly carpaccios, salads and vivid pastas, and from 10 P.M. until 1 A.M. the menu expands to include excellent brick-oven pizzas (behind the bar is a giant ceramic mask whose mouth is the opening for the pizza oven). The thin crusts are nicely charred, with toppings ranging from potato and sun-dried tomato to pancetta and onion, mixed vegetables and wild mushrooms. Appetizers are $9 to $12, carpaccios $10, pastas $11 and $14, pizzas $11 to $12. Lunch is noon to 3 P.M., dinner 6 P.M. to 1 A.M. Monday to Friday. Open noon to 1 A.M. Saturday and Sunday.

title: Vote Set for Thursday
description: N.F.L. owners will meet next Thursday in Chicago to elect a new commissioner, the league announced yesterday. The owners will be voting on a successor to Pete Rozelle, who announced his resignation on March 22 but has stayed on pending the election of his successor. Rozelle has been commissioner since 1960.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the Canadian Liberal Party's search for a leader misstated the date by which the next general election must be held. It is Nov. 21, 1993.

title: Suspect Is Held in Tree Poisoning in Texas
description: The Austin police arrested a 46-year-old farm equipment salesman and charged him with a felony in the poisoning of a 500-year-old tree in Austin. The police described the act as part of a ''ritual'' but did not elaborate.

title: Review/Rock; 10,000 Maniacs Take On The Troubles of the World
description: ''Trouble me, disturb me with all your cares and your worries,'' pleads Natalie Merchant, the lead singer and lyricist of the folk-rock group 10,000 Maniacs, which opened a two-night engagement at Radio City Music Hall on Wednesday.

title: Irish Fail to Form a Government, a First
description: For the first time, a newly elected Irish Parliament could not put together a government today, and it forced Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey to resign.

title: Constituents Unhappy About Lukens
description: In a move to gain some recognition, this city officially added an exclamation point to its name a few years ago. More than a few residents of Hamilton have been teased about that.

title: Now Bilzerian Is Facing the S.E.C.
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a lawsuit by the Securities and Exchange Commission against Paul A. Bilzerian referred incorrectly in some editions to a company in which he owned stock. It is Pay N Pak Stores Inc., not Pic 'N Pay Stores Inc.

title: Mack Is Charged
description: Kevin Mack, the running back who was the Browns' second-leading rusher last season, was charged with aggravated trafficking in cocaine yesterday. After Mack was released from Cleveland Municipal Court, he was hospitalized by the National Football League team for an evaluation, said Art Modell, the Browns' owner.

title: JIANG'S WARNING: 'NO FORGIVENESS'
description: The new head of the Chinese Communist Party has asserted that the leaders of the democracy movement should be ''severely punished'' and shown ''not an iota of forgiveness'' for their role in what he called a ''counterrevolutionary rebellion.''

title: Regents Fiasco Holds a Lesson About Learning
description: To the Editor:

title: On Trade, Bullying Isn't the Answer
description: Uncle Sam has forced Japan to cry uncle once again on trade. Tokyo agreed Wednesday to allow more imports of mobile telephones. This should help pierce Japan's protectionist shield against foreign competition. But Washington extracted that concession only by threatening heavy tariffs on Japanese products. With pressures for protection rising all over, it's crucial that world powers end their item-by-item battling, and press mutually for freer and fairer trade.

title: Margaret Walter Brown, Volunteer, 66
description: Margaret Walter Brown, an active community volunteer in Greenwich, Conn., where she lived, died of a heart attack June 22 at Greenwich Hospital. She was 66 years old. Mrs. Brown, a 1944 graduate of Vassar College, was a founding member of the Junior League of Greenwich and was associated with the Bruce Museum.

title: In Search of the Latest - Certainly Not the Last - Laugh in a Long Line of Jokes About the Profession
description: A man asked a lawyer his fee and was told it was $50 for three questions. ''Isn't that awfully steep?'' he asked. ''Yes,'' the lawyer replied. ''Now what is your final question?'' A newly deceased lawyer protested to St. Peter that, at the age of 52, he'd been too young to die. ''That's strange,'' St. Peter replied. ''According to your time sheets, you're 89 years old.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: ROWING Harvard Sets a Regatta Record: Racing in a downpour at the 150th Henley Royal Regatta in England yesterday, the Harvard lightweight varsity not only won its opening heat in the Thames Challenge Cup for eight-oared crews, but also set a course record.

title: King Takes Lead With a 67 in Canada
description: Betsy King kept on the roll that has made her the top player on the women's tour with a five-under-par 67 to take the first-round lead today at the du Maurier Classic, the richest event on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour.

title: About Real Estate; Edgewater Project Offers Hudson View
description: Grand Cove, a nine-acre complex of 51 town houses and 106 midrise apartments on the waterfront in Edgewater, N.J., has managed to keep selling even in a weak market. Twenty-three of its town houses and 85 apartments have been sold despite a surge of competitive construction in the area and a general lull in residential sales.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Burger King Stands by Pepsi
description: Pepsi-Cola dodged a bullet yesterday by holding on to its giant vendor account with the Burger King Corporation.

title: Vestron Cuts Jobs; Curbs Production
description: Vestron Inc., running out of cash after losing a $100 million credit line, said it had severely curtailed its film production and distribution business and laid off about 140 employees. ''This is a cash squeeze put on by Security Pacific National Bank revoking their loan,'' said Stephen Einhorn, the company's chief financial officer. The affected employees, mostly in the Vestron Pictures unit, were notified today of the layoffs, which take effect immediately.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 469 money market mutual funds decreased by $445.8 million, to $320.82 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The 143 institutional funds' assets decreased by $968.7 million, to $81.74 billion. The assets of the 231 general-purpose funds were up by $137.9 million, to $103.07 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds increased by $385 million, to $136.02 billion, the institute said.

title: F.C.C. Letter To Paramount
description: The Federal Communications Commission asked Paramount Communications Inc. yesterday to clarify what the agency called ''apparent inconsistencies'' in the request that the commission authorize a trustee to hold Time Inc.'s cable licenses pending transfer to Paramount.

title: Beijing Protesters Said to Flee To a Now-Uneasy Hong Kong
description: Several leaders of the pro-democracy movement in Beijing, who have been on the Government's most wanted list, have reportedly escaped to Hong Kong, raising further concern in this British colony about future relations with China.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Higher
description: Treasury note and bond prices closed moderately higher yesterday, after late selling cut some earlier gains in half. Dealers attributed much of the late selloff to the usual squaring of accounts before a long Fourth of July holiday weekend.

title: Calendar Tricks Won't Solve New York's Budget Woes
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS:Advertising; Aiming at Ad Taxes
description: A group of advertising and business executives took aim on Wednesday at legislative efforts to increase taxes on advertising. The group, the Leadership Council on Advertising Issues, said in a new report that such efforts threaten the freedoms guaranteed by the Constitution. The report says that if the taxes cause a 5 percent drop in advertising, the loss could jeopardize 31,500 jobs, forcing the closing of 438 broadcast and print outlets by 1993. Kennetih Roman, chairman of the Ogilvy Group and a co-chairman of the council, said such a loss ''would undermine the free speech and diversity of information about ideas, products and services that remian fundamental to economic and social progress.''

title: Eritreans Accept Peace Talks Without Political Conditions
description: Eritrean rebels engaged in a long-running war against the Ethiopian authorities said today that they were willing to talk ''without preconditions'' to the Government of Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam.

title: 19 Hits Give Jays 11-1 Defeat Of Orioles
description: Steve Cummings, making his first major league start, held the Orioles to one run and six hits in seven innings and the Toronto Blue Jays achieved a season-high 19 hits to defeat Baltimore, 11-1, tonight.

title: African Dictators, American Silence
description: ''In man's heart, if not in fact, the day of the dictator is over,'' George Bush declared in his Inaugural address. While the phrase has a nice ring, the reality is that millions of people are still being told by one man what is best for them, what they can print, whom they can listen to, what they can say. These days, Africa has the longest line-up of strong men - Angola, Zaire, Liberia, Malawi, Ghana, Somalia - and that just begins the list. Indeed, ''African democratic leader'' is an oxymoron.

title: For Once, Yankees Hold On And Win at Tiger Stadium . . .
description: The Yankees tonight finally shook away the torment that seemed to follow them through every inning of every game they played at Tiger Stadium. They won a game that waited to be lost, and as they dressed later, they conceded that there had been an eerie feeling here. But it is gone, at last. For now. One night earlier, Dave Righetti threw the pitch that Lou Whitaker hit into the bleachers to hand the Yankees another defeat. Tonight, Righetti threw a fastball past Gary Pettis to preserve a 7-6 victory that sent the Yanks home with a 3-3 record on their trip and allowed them to gain a game on the Orioles in the American League East. The Slide Ends

title: Fort Riley Journal; Army's Plan to Expand Draws Neighbors' Fire
description: This historic fort, long a protector of settlers, is locked in conflict with their descendants over 155 square miles or so of the Kansas Flint Hills that it helped tame to the fence and the plow.

title: New-Home Sales Rose 2.7% in May
description: Sales of new homes rose 2.7 percent in May as interest rates continued to fall, but analysts predicted that sales would remain slow because of the weakening economy.

title: Jazz and Dixieland
description: The Bronx Arts Ensemble, with Jill Vache, a vocalist, will play jazz and Dixieland music in a salute to George M. Cohan on Tuesday at 2 P.M. at Woodlawn Cemetary, Jerome Avenue at Bainbridge Avenue in the Bronx. Admission is free. Information: 920-0500.

title: Jazz Festival; Vaughan: a Diva; Jackson: Dour
description: Two performers who have been stars in the jazz firmament since the mid-1940's - Sarah Vaughan and Milt Jackson - shared a JVC Jazz Festival program at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening in very different fashion.

title: New From Eichelberger
description: ''Herd of Buffalo,'' a new play by Ethyl Eichelberger, is being presented at Performance Space 122 through July 16. The show is about a mad scientist and performance artist who is jealous of a rival performer starring at a Greenwich Village theater. The production also stars Jonathan Baker, Katie Dierlam, Gerard Little and Helen Shumaker. Shows are Thursdays through Sundays at 9:30 P.M.; tickets are $8. P.S. 122 is at 150 First Avenue, at Ninth Street. Information: 477-5288.

title: Market Place; Bondholder Woes In Time Inc. Battle
description: AS a result of the Time Inc. takeover battle, bondholders are again suffering the blows of what bond traders call ''event risk,'' almost eight months after they suffered heavy losses from the leveraged buyout of RJR Nabisco Inc.

title: Burmese Heroes, Faithless Friends
description: In 1959, when the Burmese people were last allowed to vote freely, their soon-to-be dictator Ne Win remarked: ''Let the country make its own choice. It will get the government it deserves.'' Shortly thereafter he deposed the country's choice, made himself dictator and ruled for three dismal decades, reducing a once-prosperous country to penury under a blundering military regime.

title: High Court Returns Dormitory Case
description: A divided United States Supreme Court indicated today that an effort by the State University of New York to bar all commercial activity in dormitories might violate students' constitutional right to free speech.

title: Economic Scene; Turbulent Days For Communism
description: WHAT are the economic implications of the turmoil in the Communist world? President Bush said this week that China remains a country of strategic importance to America but that a ''normalized relationship'' is impossible as long as the harsh crackdown on dissent continues. And Japan's decision to suspend aid to China dramatized the vulnerability of the Chinese economy to the shocks felt by both foreign government and business.

title: David Teichman, 90, of Arthur Murray Inc.
description: David A. Teichman, a former vice president of Arthur Murray Inc., died Monday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan and Truro, Mass.

title: Review/Film; 'Goodness Gracious!' Jerry Lee Lewis
description: As Jerry Lee Lewis, Dennis Quaid pops open his eyes, juts out his jaw and lets his wavy blond hair tumble over his forehead. He pounds on an upright piano while scooting it across the living room floor, chasing his young cousin Myra and her friends. ''Don't worry, little girls,'' he says, his voice holding the hint of a killer but mostly resembling the gulpy drawl of Disney's Goofy. ''It's only Jerry Lee!''

title: No Release for Radja
description: Dino Radja, a 6-foot-11-inch center for the Yugoslav national team who was selected by the Boston Celtics in the draft on Tuesday night, will not be performing in Boston Garden soon. His Yugoslav team, Jugoplastika of Belgrade, will not allow him to leave because he has a contract that does not expire until 1992.(AP)

title: Bonn Asserts Iran Chemical Sale Might Be Illegal
description: West German officials today reported ''strong indications'' that a Dusseldorf trading company violated West German export laws in arranging the sale to Iran of a chemical that can be used to produce poison gas.

title: Deng's June 9 Speech: 'We Faced a Rebellious Clique' and 'Dregs of Society'
description: On June 9, Deng Xiaoping, chairman of the Central Military Commission and China's foremost leader, delivered an address in Beijing to military commanders. The address, which was first reported in Chinese newspapers in Hong Kong and the United States, has emerged as a key document setting out the party line in the crackdown on the pro-democracy movement, and the Chinese authorities are urging citizens to study it. Here is a transcript of the speech, provided in translation this week by the New China News Agency.

title: A Jazz-Rock-Funk-Reggae-Etc. Band
description: Smart, knockabout jazz-rock and abstract, ruminative jazz shared a bipolar double bill - extroverted and introspective - at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night, part of the JVC Jazz Festival's Knitting Factory Goes Uptown series.

title: Dr. Arturo Morales Carrion, 75, Top Aide in Kennedy State Dept.
description: Dr. Arturo Morales Carrion, a Puerto Rican educator who was a high State Department official in the Kennedy Administration, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in San Juan, a spokesman for the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico said yesterday in Washington. He was 75 years old.

title: Corrections
description: A Company Briefs listing in Business Day on Wednesday misstated terms of a deal between Jefferson Smurfit Group P.L.C. and the Container Corporation of America. Jefferson Smurfit is paying $58 million to the Container Corporation for its stake in a Colombian paper company, Carton de Colombia. Jefferson Smurfit did not buy a stake in the Container Corporation.

title: Dow Drops 46.47 Points, To 2,458.27
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 46.47 points, to 2,458.27, the biggest drop in more than three months. Declines on the New York Stock Exchange led advances 1,325 to 273.

title: Becker Wins Easily But Some Are Unamused
description: The least of Boris Becker's troubles today was his second-round opponent, Richard Matuszewski of Newark, to whom he dealt a cavalier dismissal in straight sets, 6-3, 7-5, 6-4.

title: Canada Endorses Exxon Unit's Deal
description: The Exxon Corporation's Imperial Oil Ltd. unit said that Canada's Bureau of Competition Policy had approved its $3.24 billion purchase of Texaco Canada Inc. The bureau, which enforces antitrust laws, directed Imperial to sell a Texaco refinery in Nova Scotia and more than a tenth of the combined companies' 5,000 service stations across the country. The refinery produces 20,000 barrels a day.

title: Electrolux-Regina Merger Is Backed
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge has approved the Electrolux Corporation's $70 million bid for an ailing competitor, the Regina Company. United States Bankruptcy Judge William Tuohey agreed on Wednesday to allow the sale of all of the assets of the vacuum maker, based in Rahway, N.J., to CRC Acquisitions Inc., a unit of Electrolux, based in Marietta, Ga.

title: Salomon Forges Link With Big Italian Bank
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. and Italy's second-largest bank announced an agreement yesterday to cooperate in the American and Italian securities markets.

title: U.N.-Convened Cyprus Talks Fail to Produce Agreement
description: United Nations-sponsored talks between the leaders of the Greek and Turkish communities on Cyprus have failed to produce a draft agreement aimed at ending the division of the Mediterranean island, but the two sides agreed today to continue talking.

title: Weekend at Belmont To Be Long on Action
description: The long weekend at Belmont Park will seem almost like August at Saratoga, with a Grade I or II stakes race on every card from tomorrow through Tuesday.

title: Public Funds Need Not Support Private Tastes; Political Fig Leaves
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Is Urged to Bar Drilling
description: Lawmakers, businessmen and citizens urged a Presidential study group today to recommend banning proposed oil drilling off the rugged Northern California coast.

title: U.S. Defends Move to Expand Talks With P.L.O.
description: The State Department today defended a decision to elevate its dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization, saying the move was part of its overall effort to convince the P.L.O. to approve an Israeli election proposal.

title: Frank H. Wardlaw, Publisher, 75
description: Frank H. Wardlaw, who established scholarly publishing houses at the University of Texas, Texas A & M University and the University of South Carolina, died here Monday. He was 75 years old.

title: Germany Raises Rates; Most of Europe Follows
description: West Germany raised its key interest rates by half a percentage point today in an effort to lessen the inflationary pressures that hang over Western Europe. The move set off a coordinated round of rate increases by most Western European nations.

title: Roland Hanna With Classical Ornamentation
description: Gossamer impressionistic chords, spiky be-bop and broad-shouldered two-fisted stride piano are an unusual and potent combination in the music of Roland Hanna, who was part of the JVC Jazz Festival's piano series Wednesday afternoon at Weill Recital Hall. Mr. Hanna brings not just classical technique but a wealth of classical ornamentation and allusions to his playing.

title: Kansas City Southern Up
description: The common stock of Kansas City Southern Industries soared today after a Federal appeals court decision on Wednesday reversed a lower court ruling that had granted more than $800 million to South Dakota in a claim against the company.

title: A Long Weekend of Music, Fireworks and Frogs; CONNECTICUT
description: Fourth of July celebrations in Connecticut this year will include frog-jumping, Scottish games, a symphony performance and bicycle races, as well as traditional fireworks displays and Independence Day festivals.

title: Court Splits Over Tribal Control of Land
description: The Supreme Court ruled today in a splintered decision that the extent of tribal control over development within reservation boundaries should be defined by how much development had already occurred.

title: New Jersey Legislature Seeking Pact on Budget
description: Facing a deadline of midnight Friday for the adoption of a new budget, the leaders of New Jersey's Legislature groped today for a compromise $12 billion spending package that could address the state's growing fiscal woes and allow both Democrats and Republicans some ammunition for their political campaigns this fall.

title: G.E. and U. of Utah Join in 'Cold' Fusion Pact
description: The General Electric Company, a major builder of nuclear reactors, has agreed to do cooperative research with the University of Utah on low-temperature or ''cold'' nuclear fusion, both parties said yesterday.

title: READING SCORES: A NEW STANDARD
Reviews/Film; The Facts, Please, Just The Fcts
description: The Film Forum 2 opens a two-week retrospective today devoted to the work of the noted Belgian director Chantal Akerman with her 1981 film, ''Toute une Nuit.'' It is probably as good a choice as any for getting to know this most seductive of avant-garde film makers.

title: After Showdown in Japan, No Board Seats for Pickens
description: T. Boone Pickens took on the management of the Koito Manufacturing Company today, but the corporate showdown was a draw.

title: No Abortion Decision Yet
description: The Justices of the Supreme Court are apparently giving themselves one more weekend to decide two of the hardest cases of the term: the Missouri abortion case and one concerning the display of a Nativity scene in the government building of Allegheny County, Pa.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums 46TH ANNUAL CHILDREN'S ART EXHIBITION, by children in the New York metropolitan area and in Israel, with the theme ''We Want a Perfect World, Not a Wasteland,'' opens Sunday, Central Queens Y Fine Arts Gallery, 67-09 108th Street, Forest Hills, 8:45 A.M. to 6:45 P.M. Sundays; 9 A.M. to 9:45 P.M. Mondays through Thursdays, and 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Fridays. Admission: free. Information: (718) 268-5011. ''ALL-AMERICAN MUSIC,'' a 60-minute program with Bob and Eva Gabriel, 3 P.M. Sunday at the Richmondtown Restoration, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown, S.I. Admission: children under 6, free; children 6 and older, $2.50; adults, $4. Information: (718) 351-1617. ''ENVELOPE THE ANTELOPE,'' a story written and told by Laura Simms, 11 A.M. Saturday at the Hans Christian Andersen statue in Central Park, 72d Street and Fifth Avenue. Free. MYSTIC SEAPORT, a 17-acre outdoor maritime museum with historic ships, boats, exhibition buildings and two restaurants, in Mystic, Conn. Open 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily. Admission: children under 5, free; 5 to 18, $6.25, and adults, $12.50. Information: (203) 572-0711. ''CINDERELLA,'' a musical version by the Papageno Puppet Theater with Susan Delery Whedon, who is to sing during the performance accompanied by recorded music. 1 P.M. Saturdays and Sundays, at the West 72d Street Studio, 131 West 72d Street. For young children. Admission: $4. Reservations: 874-3297. ''PINOCCHIO,'' by the Puppetworks, noon Saturdays and 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at 287 Third Avenue, at Carroll Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn. Children, $4; adults, $5. Reservations required: (718) 834-1828. BARTLETT ARBORETUM, a 63-acre garden, 8:30 A.M. to sunset daily, at 151 Brookdale Road, Stamford, Conn. Information: (203) 322-6971.

title: Skirting a Time Inc. Barrier, Paramount Lines Up 7 Banks
description: Finding its way around a barrier erected by Time Inc., Paramount Communications Inc. said yesterday that seven leading international banks had agreed to put up $1 billion each to help finance its $12 billion takeover bid for Time.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Mead Corp. to Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners for Cycolor, a photocopying process, with a budget of $5 million.

title: Pop/Jazz; Music By Groups Large And Small
description: An article in Weekend yesterday about jazz groups gave an incorrect day for a performance by the George Gruntz Concert Jazz Band at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets. It is at 3 P.M. today, not tomorrow.

title: Former Doctor Sentenced in Fraud
description: A former doctor who bought blood cheaply from the poor and used it as the basis for stealing nearly $3.7 million from Medicaid has been sentenced to 5 to 10 years in prison, the special prosecutor for Medicaid fraud, Edward J. Kuriansky, announced yesterday.

title: U.S. Official Quits in Escort Service Inquiry
description: An aide to Labor Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole resigned today in the midst of a fraud investigation centering on what the authorities said they suspect is a homosexual prostitution ring.

title: Rangers Run Into Coaching Hurdles
description: It has been more than a month since Phil Esposito was dismissed as coach and general manager of the Rangers. Since then, Madison Square Garden officials have talked to a lot of people privately and to almost no one publicly. Meanwhile, life and developments in the National Hockey League go on.

title: Composite Issue From New Jersey
description: The New Jersey Economic Development Authority yesterday said that it had sold its largest tax-exempt composite bond issue ever, totaling $25.8 million.

title: Albany Pact on Prenatal Care Excludes Abortions
description: Breaking a three-year deadlock, lawmakers reached agreement today on legislation that would expand prenatal care for 70,000 poor women and their infants, but would exclude payments for abortions from the added coverage.

title: Salute to Harlem
description: The Salute to Harlem festival of free outdoor concerts on the West 125th Street embankment is to begin tomorrow at 7 P.M. Performers include Percy France, a saxophonist; Kenny and Warren, a comedy duo; James Roach and Georgia Brown, singers, and the Reggae New Generation. A second performance, featuring Nick Jones, an a cappella singer; John Brown, a blues singer; Mark Overton, a comedian, and Lonnie Younglood, a saxophonist, is to take place on Sunday at 7 P.M. The riverside performance series, which is sponsored by Revlon and the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, will continue for nine additional weekends. Food will be on sale, but concertgoers are encouraged to bring chairs or blankets. Information: 831-4206.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: The Terry Troupe

title: Gene Gotti Surrender Just Beats Deadline
description: Eight minutes before the court's deadline, Gene Gotti and John Carneglia, wearing nylon jogging suits and new Reeboks, surrendered to Federal marshals yesterday after a judge had revoked their bail and ordered them to jail pending sentencing on racketeering and drug charges.

title: Yanks Owe Guidry
description: Ron Guidry is struggling in the minor leagues in an effort to make it back to the Yankees, but yesterday he had a good day: he gained the first money award granted in baseball's two free-agent conspiracy cases. George Nicolau, the arbitrator in the second collusion case, ruled that the Yankees had to pay Guidry $91,758.24 because they, in effect, had docked him that amount when he didn't re-sign with them for the 1987 season until May 1.

title: KEY RATES
House Speaker Dismisses Report About Gray
description: House Speaker Thomas S. Foley today dismissed as inconsequential an article in The Washington Post reporting an unusual housing arrangement between Representative William H. Gray 3d and his church in Philadelphia.

title: Deng's Speech: A Transcript
description: A June 9 address by Deng Xiaoping, China's senior leader, has emerged as a key document on the party line in the Beijing crackdown. This week the Chinese press agency provided a transcript. Page A6.

title: A Banner For Rose Still Waves
description: A man named Proust who wrote in bed in a room with cork-lined walls once noted that ''there are a thousand selves in each of us.''

title: No Trial for Accused Murderer
description: A man accused of killing his wife and then commandeering an airplane and firing an assault rifle onto Boston streets from the air has been judged incompetent to stand trial for murder. Judge Charles E. Black of Brockton District Court made the ruling Wednesday after reviewing a psychiatrist's evaluation of Alfred Hunter.

title: Review/Art; 'Sculpture by Painters' at the Pace
description: More and more painters are involved with sculpture. Painters as different as Robert Kushner, Izhar Patkin and Bruce Gagnier have recently had sculpture shows in New York. ''Sculpture by Painters,'' an unusually intelligent summer exhibition at the Pace Gallery, includes the first sculptural efforts of the Pace artists George Condo and Malcolm Morley. Next season, the gallery will devote an entire exhibition to the sculpture of Julian Schnabel, another artist in the show, who is known primarily as a painter.

title: Mitzi E. Newhouse, Who Donated $1 Million for Theaters, Dies at 87
description: Mitzi E. Newhouse, who donated $1 million in 1973 to make possible the continued operation of the two theaters in the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, died yesterday at her home in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 87 years old.

title: Our Towns; Woodstock '89? Pleas, a Yawn, An Adamant No!
description: Georgina King yawns when her mom reminisces about Woodstock. ''She always talks about it,'' she said. ''You know, 'When I was young . . .' ''

title: New Computer Industry Group
description: Nine leading computer companies today announced the formation of an industry coalition to develop and communicate public policy recommendations to lawmakers.

title: N.B.A. Bans Washburn
description: The National Basketball Association banned Chris Washburn for life yesterday under the terms of the anti-drug agreement between the league and the players' union.

title: Sharpton Arrested to Face Charges of Stealing Funds
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton was arrested yesterday on charges of stealing at least $250,000 from an organization he set up almost 20 years ago with promises to help young people.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: 'New Chapter' on Apartheid Seen by Ruling Party Leader
description: The leader of South Africa's governing National Party, F. W. de Klerk, declared ''a new chapter'' in the nation's history today and wept before emphasizing that the white rulers will share limited power with the black majority.

title: Rene Wiegert, 59, Dies; A Show Music Director
description: Rene Wiegert, the original music director of ''Cats'' on Broadway, died of heart failure Monday at Arden Hill Hospital in Goshen, N.Y. He was 59 years old and lived in Hamptonburgh, N.Y.

title: Texas Law Restricts News Coverage
description: A two-week-old Texas law intended to prevent security alarm manufacturers from harassing recent burglary victims has opened a statewide debate over freedom of the press.

title: Edith M. Lerrigo, 78, Ex-Y.W.C.A. Director
description: Edith M. Lerrigo, who was national executive director of the Young Women's Christian Association of the United States before retiring in 1974, died of complications from Alzheimer's disease Saturday at the Health Services Center in Claremont, Calif. She was 78 years old. Ms. Lerrigo joined the Y.W.C.A. in 1937 and served as director of its college and university division, traveling to Mexico, Denmark, Australia and Ghana in the course of her work, before she was appointed to the executive director's post in 1960.

title: Efforts to Curb Advertising Expose Rift in the Bar
description: More than a decade after the United States Supreme Court allowed advertising by lawyers, there are growing efforts to restrict it.

title: Auctions
description: A Medieval Rarity

title: African Festival in Brooklyn Offers Art, Food and Song
description: The most populous borough, Brooklyn, which ends the summer with a million people of Caribbean descent cavorting on Eastern Parkway, celebrates the Fourth of July with thousands of African descendants buying and munching their way through the African Street Festival on the grounds of Boys and Girls High School.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7 Pro-democracy leaders in Beijing have reportedly escaped to Hong Kong, raising further concern in the British colony about its relations with China. Page A1

title: Cuomo Loses Effort to Pass Life Sentence
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's effort to pressure the Legislature to approve a penalty of life without parole for some murderers collapsed today when the Assembly Speaker said he would not bring the measure to a vote before the session ends, probably this weekend.

title: Sealed Air's Issue
description: The Sealed Air Corporation is offering $170 million of senior subordinated notes due in 1999 through the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation. The 12 5/8 percent notes are priced at 100 and are rated B-1 by Moody's Investors Service and B by Standard & Poor's.

title: A Breeze Against Sleaze
description: Only months ago, Democrats freely, and justifiably, denounced President Reagan for his unconcern about Government ethics and campaign finance. ''The sleaze factor,'' people called it as charges of impropriety, even crime, mounted against one senior official after another. Now President Bush proposes a welcome program to change the atmosphere, and now he leaves Democrats wailing that it will help Republicans.

title: Polish Leader's Re-election Faces Opposition in Communist Party
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, is facing a serious challenge within the Communist Party to his scheduled re-election as President next week, Poles and diplomats said today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM GOVERNING COUNCIL - 10 A.M., 3 and 6 P.M

title: 2 Suitors Pursue Prime Computer
description: J. H. Whitney & Company began a $1.25 billion tender offer for Prime Computer Inc., and MAI Basic Four Inc. extended its bid without changing its terms. MAI, based in Tustin, Calif., said on June 22 that it would raise its offer, valued at $1.1 billion, but no increase has been announced. An MAI spokeswoman said today she believed that an increase was forthcoming. Its bid was extended to July 6.

title: Reducing Gains Tax Is Unlikely
description: Faced with unwavering opposition from fellow Democrats, Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has decided that the capital-gains tax cannot be reduced, even temporarily.

title: A Menotti Opera
description: Gian Carlo Menotti's ''Saint of Bleecker Street'' will be performed by the Kurt P. Reimann Opera Studio of New York University at the University Theater, 35 West Fourth Street, tonight and tomorrow night at 8 o'clock. The production is directed by Patricia Heuermann and conducted by Robert Wallace. Tickets are $12. Information: 998-5278.

title: Dr. F. J. Hacker, 75, A Psychiatric Expert On Violence in Man
description: Dr. Frederick J. Hacker, a Vienna-born psychiatrist and psychoanalyst who was an expert on aggression and terrorism, died last Friday in Mainz, West Germany. He was 75 years old and lived in Los Angeles and Vienna.

title: 4 Mysterious Lines (About Fines)
description: As the Supreme Court's term comes to an end, a literary mystery remains unsolved. Is there a poet in the Supreme Court chambers of Justice Harry A. Blackmun? Could it even be Justice Blackmun himself? Or if not the Justice, who wrote the unattributed four lines of verse (some might say doggerel, but this is the Supreme Court) that appeared in an opinion on punitive damages Monday?

title: General Will Head City School Agency
description: Maj. Gen. Charles E. Williams, director of management in the office of the United States Army's chief of staff, was named yesterday to be the first president of the recently created New York City School Construction Authority, which is to oversee the rebuilding of city schools.

title: Review/Film; 'Karate Kid' Enters Round 3
description: It's no coincidence that John G. Avildsen, the director who gave the world the original ''Rocky,'' is also behind all three ''Karate Kid'' films. Daniel LaRusso, the boy who outsmarted the school bullies by becoming a karate champion in the hugely successful ''Karate Kid,'' was simply a high school Rocky, the underdog triumphant.

title: French Trade Deficit Up
description: France's trade deficit almost doubled in May, from April, the Government reported today, adding to concerns that an improvement since the beginning of the year was being reversed. The gap between imports and exports was 6.6 billion francs ($1 billion) in May, the French customs office said. Economists had been expecting at worst a deficit slightly lower than April's 3.7 billion francs ($555 million).

title: State Takes Over Some Council Powers in Yonkers
description: A New York State monitoring agency, faced with new defiance by the Yonkers City Council over a court-ordered desegregation plan, declared a fiscal crisis today and took over some of the Council's governing powers.

title: Chaim Sharon Is Wed To Diane S. Lederman
description: Diane Sarah Lederman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold H. Lederman of New York, was married last evening to Chaim Sharon, the son of Yamima Sharon of Tel Aviv and the late Simcha Sharon. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein and Cantor Avrum Davis officiated at the Park East Synagogue in New York.

title: Calendar Tricks Won't Solve New York's Budget Woes; 'Off Budget' in Albany
description: To the Editor:

title: Amateur Lives His Dream In Opener of Senior Open
description: Frank Boydston, a 53-year-old amateur from Phoenix who plays with a putter that's older than he is and a set of 20-year-old irons so worn you can't read the club numbers on the soles, was as surprised as everyone else today at the 10th United States Senior Open championship. After the first round, he found himself just one shot behind the leader, Al Geiberger.

title: O'Jays and Temptations Replace Charles
description: Though Ray Charles was delayed in St. Louis and didn't make the show, the O'Jays and the Temptations did their best to please what was left of the audience at Avery Fisher Hall as part of the JVC Jazz Festival on Wednesday night. And though they did their best, it was hard to avoid thinking that the music industry, the audience and the performers haven't come up with adequate way of recycling veterans of black show business. The two groups put on an embalmed show that emphasized old clothes, old routines and old material. Nostalgia was the reigning emotion. Which isn't to imply a lack of talent. Both groups have some of the best voices the gospel-to-pop connection has produced. The O'Jays, who are floating on their Top 10 hit ''Have You Had Your Love Today,'' have in Eddie Levert one of pop's great voices; he'd nail a new phrase with his falsetto, slipping up and up and up to imply emotion. And their blend, at its best, is seamless.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday PERFORMING IN THE PARK

title: Chairman at Thomson
description: Alain Gomez, the chairman of the state-owned electronics company Thomson S.A. and its Thomson-CSF unit, has been reappointed by the French Government to a three-year term, to expire in 1992.

title: KEMP IS CANCELING ANOTHER PROGRAM LINKED TO ABUSES
description: Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp announced today that he planned to end a Federal mortgage insurance program that was ''riddled with abuse'' and had been used to subsidize golf courses and other luxury projects.

title: Shrine Honors Mexican Stars
description: The setting may not be quite as pastoral as Cooperstown, but Mexico's Professional Baseball Hall of Fame shares a few things with its American counterpart, including some of the same honorees. The Salon de la Fama is first and foremost a shrine to baseball's glorious past here, and, like Cooperstown, it also happens to be celebrating its 50th anniversary this summer.

title: Restrictions Proposed on Dual Trading in Futures
description: Two members of the House of Representatives said today that they would introduce legislation to place sharp restrictions on dual trading in the futures markets, at least until the industry can develop computer systems to keep better track of trades.

title: Fairness Doctrine Would Improve Radio
description: To the Editor:

title: Holiday on Tuesday
description: Tuesday is the Fourth of July. Here are holiday schedules. NEW YORK Fireworks: East River, 9:15 P.M., between 23d and 42d Streets. Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Closed. Parking: Sunday rules in effect. Sanitation: No collections. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Subways and buses on Saturday schedule, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on holiday schedules. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Transportation: N.J. Transit trains and buses on Sunday schedules. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Transportation: New Haven Line on holiday schedule.

title: TV Weekend; A Documentary on Gance's Making of 'Napoleon'
description: Few events in the history of film have been more significant than the 1981 revival of Abel Gance's ''Napoleon,'' 54 years after it was first shown in Paris. Restored by Kevin Brownlow, a masterpiece was rediscovered and a film artist was rescued from decades of neglect. Gance died at the age of 92 in 1981, only weeks after his silent film opened at Radio City Music Hall, its new score by Carmine Coppola played by a full orchestra in the pit.

title: A Long Weekend of Music, Fireworks and Frogs; NEW JERSEY
description: From traditional parades and fireworks displays to concerts in historic villages and stately towns, Independence Day events in New Jersey assume the character of their surroundings, whether played out against sunlit ocean backdrops or in the shade of verdant woods.

title: On Stage
description: Sort of Open

title: College Student Loses $1.1 Million Jackpot
description: A college student has lost a bid to collect a $1.1 million casino jackpot that he hit while gambling illegally as a 19-year-old.

title: Review/Art; For the Unheralded, a Chance to Be Noticed
description: Sometimes the summer doldrums aren't as quiet as they're cracked up to be. Granted, the group shows that traditionally herald the closed doors and drawn shades of July and August are coming thick and fast. But many galleries are still mounting solo or dual exhibitions, and some are using this less pressured time to introduce new artists. This is especially true in SoHo, where a number of promising and occasionally impressive debuts are under way.

title: House Panel Urges One-Year Ban On Oil Drilling Off Much of U.S.
description: The House Appropriations Committee voted today to impose a one-year ban on oil drilling off much of the nation's coastline, including, for the first time, off part of Alaska's coast and previously unprotected stretches of the California coast.

title: Bush Urges Campaign Fund Curbs And Limits on Fees for Congress
description: After years of debate about the high cost of Congressional campaigns and the special interests that pay for them, President Bush weighed in today with campaign finance legislation that he said would free members of Congress from ''degrading'' financial influences.

title: Mexican Journalist Is Slain
description: A prominent journalist in Durango, a northern Mexican city, was killed today, the police said. The slain journalist, Elias Mario Medina Valenzuela, a former director of two Durango newspapers and until December 1987 press director of the state government, was shot in the head by three unknown assailants.

title: This Flag Thing
description: Memo to the Man:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Asarco Inc., a minerals company, said it had allocated $50 million to buy back its common stock and common stock purchase warrants.

title: House Panel Favors Restricting Arts Grants
description: The House Appropriations Committee approved a proposal by Representative Sidney R. Yates today to make the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities more accountable for all the work they support.

title: La Jarretadera Journal; The Nonstop Roadshow, Starring Carlos Salinas
description: Last year, as the Institutional Revolutionary Party's candidate for President, Carlos Salinas de Gortari campaigned briefly here and promised to return when he became President of Mexico. Now, standing on a platform under a broiling June sun, he was back to meet with local peasant leaders and hand out money for new Government programs here.

title: Military Buildup in Canada Falls Victim to Budget Cuts
description: An article on Friday about Canada's decision to scale back a military buildup gave an incorrect date in some copies for the installation of Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's Government. It was 1984. Because of an editing error, a passage in some copies also misstated the year the buildup was announced. It was 1987.

title: Spill Panel Considers Pilots' Timing
description: Local harbor pilots do not always board incoming vessels at the boundary line designated by state law, a boat operator testified today at a Coast Guard inquiry into the grounding of an oil tanker near Newport.

title: Public Funds Need Not Support Private Tastes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Party Line From 1 to 4
description: Deng Xiaoping's speech on June 9 referred to several principles to guide China's economic and political development, in sets of one, two, three and four.

title: Mcorp Deal Will Cost $2 Billion
description: The Government-assisted rescue of 20 failed banks in Texas formerly owned by Mcorp will cost about $2 billion, making it the nation's second-most-expensive bank rescue, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today.

title: Nominee Says His Testimony In H.U.D. Inquiry Was Faulty
description: A chief campaign fund-raiser for President Bush who is now the Ambassador-designate to Luxembourg acknowledged to Congress today that he had made several inaccurate or incomplete statements in earlier sworn testimony about his ties to senior housing officials.

title: U.S. Is Trying to Keep Shoreham Plant Alive
description: Proponents of nuclear power in Washington moved yesterday to block the dismantling of the Shoreham nuclear-power plant a day after Long Island Lighting Company stockholders approved a plan to abandon the $5.5 billion plant.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economy

title: Karl R. Bendetsen, 81, Executive And High-Ranking U.S. Official
description: Karl R. Bendetsen, who led a varied career as a lawyer, forest products company executive and high-ranking Federal official, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Washington. He was 81 years old. Mr. Bendetsen was the retired chief executive of the Champion International Corporation and a former Under Secretary of the Army. He was an Army colonel in World War II and directed the evacuation of 110,000 people of Japanese origin from areas on the West Coast. He also served as special assistant to the Secretary of State and more recently was chairman of President Ronald Reagan's panel for a space-based missile defense program, the Strategic Defense Initiative.

title: Soviets Shift on Limits On Conventional Forces
description: The Soviet bloc moved closer to the West's approach in the Vienna arms talks today by suggesting a new regional limit on conventional forces in central Europe, Western officials said.

title: Did Andy Warhol Overlook Me?
description: I'd been away from the city for a month, working on a book.

title: Garrison and Sabatini Struggle, Then Lose
description: Zina Garrison could find no explanation for the evaporation of her game as she found herself on court at Wimbledon missing the sort of shots that once came to her easily back on the playground in Houston.

title: Vice Chairman Named By Handy & Harman
description: Handy & Harman, the precious metals company, has created a post of vice chairman and named a former Beatrice Companies executive, Frank E. Grzelecki, to fill it.

title: INSIDE
description: No Abortion Decision Yet The Supreme Court postponed until Monday any word on its decision in the Missouri abortion case. Page A8. Tax Proposal Dies Representative Dan Rostenkowski has decided that the capital gains tax cannot be reduced. Page D1. Suspect in Tree Poisoning The Austin police have arrested and charged a suspect in the poisoning of the 500-year-old Treaty Oak. Page A8.

title: Juggling Money, Taste And Art on Capitol Hill
description: Representative Bob Carr, the Michigan Democrat who is chairman of the Congressional Arts Caucus, thinks it odd that the Bush Administration has requested an appropriation of $193 million for military bands but only $170 million for the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Joffrey Cancels China Trip
description: The Joffrey Ballet has withdrawn from performances in Beijing in mid-September. A spokeswoman for the company said the decision had been made on Tuesday ''because of the unrest.'' The company was invited in March by China's Ministry of Culture to represent the United States in the 1989 China ARts Festival, which is to take place throughout the country from Sept. 15 through Oct. 5. The Joffrey was to have opened the festival.

title: Heat Releases Pearl Washington
description: Three years ago, when Lew Schaffel was running the Nets' front office, New Jersey made Dwayne (Pearl) Washington of Syracuse its first-round draft choice. Promotions at home games centered on the guard from Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn, who played in 72 games as a Nets rookie. Last year, when the Miami Heat entered the National Basketball Association and Schaffel moved there, it wasn't long before Washington followed, selected by the Heat in the expansion draft.

title: Dollar Finishes Day Higher Despite Rate Rises Abroad
description: The dollar rose against the yen yesterday and rebounded strongly against European currencies after a coordinated jump in interest rates led by the West German central bank.

title: A Long Weekend of Music, Fireworks and Frogs; WESTCHESTER
description: What better way to begin a Fourth of July weekend than listening to John Philip Sousa's marches while picnicking on the spacious grounds of the Jay Gould mansion in Tarrytown, against the backdrop of the majestic Hudson River and a setting sun?

title: At the Movies
description: Working Together Leslie Dixon, who wrote the hilarious screenplay for ''Outrageous Fortune,'' is sleeping with the director of her latest project.

title: White House
description: They are the White House's political ''A list,'' a select group of Republicans who receive copies of major speeches, proposals and initiatives from John H. Sununu, the chief of staff, often with a note saying, ''Let me know what you think of this.''

title: Restaurants
description: The tapas phenomenon, for all its colorful and convivial appeal, has never caught on in a big way in the United States. The reasons are more cultural than culinary. For one, Americans do not dine as late as the Spanish, who start strolling into restaurants about 10 P.M., so Americans have no need for hearty appetizers early in the evening. Morever, tapas in Spain are devoured quickly and replenished, whereas in many American restaurants they languish too long on the bar.

title: Edith Begner, Novelist, 71
description: Edith Begner, a novelist whose work focused on the medical profession, died of lymphatic leukemia on Wednesday at Emerson Hospital in Concord, Mass. She was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Japan Says Phone Accord Cuts Tension
description: Japanese officials said today that the settlement of a festering dispute with the United States over access to Japan's mobile telephone market had defused a major source of trade tension and opened the way for a series of more complex negotiations starting next month.

title: Eastern Air Examiner Sets Goals
description: The examiner appointed by Federal Bankruptcy Court to help reorganize Eastern Airlines said today that he would make a strong effort over the weekend to resolve the 118-day-old strike that has crippled its operations.

title: Rose's Lawyer Would Consider a Deal With Giamatti
description: Talk of a deal in the Pete Rose case arose yesterday, but the likelihood of Rose and A. Bartlett Giamatti, the commissioner of baseball, reaching a settlement and ending the affair appeared small.

title: MOBUTU, ON VISIT, LAUDED AND CHIDED
description: President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire met with President Bush and members of Congress today and was confronted with expressions of concern about reports of human rights abuses in his Central African country.

title: Public Funds Need Not Support Private Tastes; Purse and Sword
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Funds Need Not Support Private Tastes; Voiceless Taxpayers
description: To the Editor:

title:
A Long Weekend of Music, Fireworks and Frogs;
LONG ISLAND
description: LEAD: Opera, jazz, rock-and-roll, pop and fireworks will fill the air over Long Island during the Independence Day weekend. Marching veterans and strutting mummers will also be part of the celebrations.
